description: A state trooper found beaten and dazed on the New Jersey Turnpike after apparently trying to make a narcotics arrest was reported in critical but stable condition yesterday at the Burlington County Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly.

title: Manager Confident On McDonnell Jet
description: Since becoming program manager for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's MD-11 aircraft project in December 1984, Robert C. Hornburg has spent most of his time nursing the tri-jet passenger liner through its protracted and difficult gestation. Now, like a relieved parent, Mr. Hornburg speaks enthusiastically about the future of the aircraft, production of which was authorized by the company's board last Monday.

title: OLES FOR PELE PROVE HE STILL CAN DAZZLE
description: In a fiesta of nostalgia Pele returned to the soccer field today for the first time since he retired a decade ago, reminding veterans and newcomers alike why he is known as the sport's greatest player ever.

title: Global Bull Market Had Vigorous Year
description: The performance of stock markets around the world startled many investment professionals in 1986, the second consecutive year of an extraordinary worldwide bull market.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Mandlikova Takes Final: Hana Mandlikova warmed up for the Australian Open with a convincing 6-2, 2-6, 6-4 victory yesterday over Pam Shriver in the rain-delayed final of the Jason Women's Tennis Classic in Brisbane, Australia. Mandlikova, a Czechoslovak who has applied for Australian citizenship, broke Shriver twice in the opening set and won it in 26 minutes. In the second set, however, Shriver changed tactics to offset the topspin shots of Mandlikova. Shriver charged to the net and swamped Mandlikova with volleys. But Mandlikova recovered and dominated the match as she broke Shriver in the fifth game of the deciding set. (AP) Masur Wins: Wally Masur of Australia held off Bill Scanlon in a second-set tiebreaker to win the championship of the South Australian Men's Open tennis tournament. Masur, a member of Australia's Davis Cup champions, got past Scanlon, 6-4, 7-6. Scanlon, from Dallas, did get one title yesterday, combining with Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia to beat two Australians, Peter Doohan and Laurie Warder, in the doubles, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Horse Racing Grecian Flight First at Aqueduct: Grecian Flight, a filly by Cormorant from the Green Ticket mare Green Greek, easily defeated five male rivals when she raced to a 6 3/4-length victory in the $67,500 Montauk Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. Carrying 118 pounds and ridden by Randy Romero, Grecian Flight shook off an early challenge by Embrace's Sybling to open a clear lead on the backstretch and went the rest of the way unthreatened to cover a mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 3/5 on the good track. Somekindafella was second, a nose ahead of Captain Len. The victory was the fourth in five career starts for Grecian Flight, who earned $40,500 for Henry C. B. Lindh. She returned $2.80 for $2 to win. Track and Field Clark Impressive in Victory: Joetta Clark, a University of Tennessee graduate student, scored an impressive victory in the women's open 600-yard run at the Reebok New Year's track and field meet at West Point, N.Y. Clark's time of 1 minute 18.70 seconds is the sixth fastest for 600 yards indoors. Patty Wiegand, a senior at Canastota (N.Y.) High School, won the mile in 5:00.42. In other high school competition, Sam Rice of Cardinal Hayes won the 200-meter dash in 22.68 seconds; Mark Lavery of Ballston Spa, N.Y., took the 800 meters in 1:56.94 and Sonya Henry of Freeport, L.I., won the long jump at 18 feet 9 1/4 inches and also the high jump at 5 feet 7 inches. N.H.L. Whalers 8, Leafs 3: Paul Lawless broke out of a scoring slump with two goals and four assists, setting a team record for most points in a game as the Whalers defeated the Maple Leafs yesterday in Hartford. Lawless, who had only one goal and six assists in his previous 17 games, scored his 11th and 12th goals of the season as Hartford snapped a two-game losing streak. (AP) Sabres 7, Nordiques 2: Adam Creighton had a goal and three assists and Jacques Cloutier made several superb saves as the Sabres won in Buffalo. The Sabres, 3-2-1 since Ted Sator took over as coach Dec. 22 from Craig Ramsay, got goals from Mike Ramsey, John Tucker, Mike Foligno, Doug Smith, Bob Logan, Creighton and Jeff Parker.(AP)

title: Now Still Another Rerun Of the Perils of Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: AT CARNEGIE HALL 'THE ART OF THE SPIRITUAL'
description: IT is a tribute to the rich, and largely untapped, quality of the spiritual repertory that a two-hour-plus, 35-song program could be assembled without trotting out such thrice-familiar material as ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot,'' ''Go Down, Moses,'' ''Nobody Knows The Trouble I've Seen'' or ''Deep River.'' A program called ''The Art of the Spiritual,'' presented at Carnegie Hall Saturday night, allowed the audience to hear some lesser-known songs, sung by four very different interpreters - the tenor Kenn Hicks, the sopranos Mattiwilda Dobbs and Lorice Stevens, and the bass-baritone William Warfield, accompanied by William Duncan Allen and Eugene Gash.

title: Debut for Russian Tenor
description: The Russian tenor Vyacheslav Polosov will make his Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday as Pinkerton in ''Madama Butterfly.'' Renata Scotto will sing the title role in the Puccini work, the baritone Lenus Carlson will sing Sharpless and the mezzo-soprano Ariel Bybee will portray the servant Suzuki. Thomas Fulton will conduct. The performance begins at 8 P.M. Information: 362-6000.

title: OPERA: 'DIE FLEDERMAUS'
description: VINSON COLE, a tenor with a pleasing and confident lyric voice, made his Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday evening. His arrival is good news, even though one had to extrapolate somewhat from the role of Alfred, the importunate singer in ''Die Fledermaus,'' to discern his qualities.

title: DITKA LAMENTS
description: The Washington Redskins took the air out of the football, but it was the Chicago Bears who took the fun out of the game and themselves out of a chance to repeat as Super Bowl champions, Coach Mike Ditka said.

title: STUDY FAULTS THE STATE FOR A RENT 'NIGHTMARE'
description: State housing authorities have failed to register an estimated 100,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City, leaving tenants in those apartments vulnerable to illegal rent increases and other unfair practices, a state legislative audit has found.

title: IT'S TAKING LONGER TO DIVORCE
description: For the past three years Jane, a 42-year-old Long Island scientist, and her husband, a real-estate broker, have been trying to get a divorce after 18 years of marriage.

title: The Black Factor
description: In all the Presidential elections since Harry S. Truman confounded the pollsters in 1948, the Democratic nominee has won a majority of the white vote only once, when President Johnson overwhelmed Senator Barry Goldwater in 1964. These nine contests produced only two other Democratic winners: John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter.

title: A Sound Compromise on U.N. Budgeting
description: Months of unpromising negotiations came to a surprise finish when the United Nations General Assembly adopted what may prove to be the most important self-reform in its 41-year history. The measure, a compromise solution in a battle over budget power that divided and may still bankrupt the world body, represents a good-faith offer to meet Congressional demands for a greater United States voice in budgetary decisions. Congress would be wise to accept it. Like any real compromise, it is a deal with something for both sides. For the developing countries, opposed to changes in United Nations decision-making that threaten their numerical advantage - such as Congress's call for contribution-weighted voting - the reform's virtue is that it keeps ultimate power in the hands of the General Assembly.

title: A LOOK AT THE TEAMS
description: Boston College Coach: Jim O'Brien 1985-86: 13-15 over all, 4-12 Big East Current Record: 7-3, 0-0 Outlook: The Eagles are in desperate need of scoring and muscle. In the games before conference play started, they finished seventh among Big East teams in rebound margin while finishing last in scoring with a 66.4 point-per-game average. The Eagles have held the opposition to 62.5 points per game, second lowest total among league teams. The problem facing O'Brien in his first season as coach is scoring. Connecticut Coach: Jim Calhoun 1985-86: 12-16, 3-13 Current Record: 5-6, 0-2 Outlook: Jim Calhoun is known for his ability to get the most out of his players, though this year could be like getting blood from a turnip. He favors an aggressive wide open running game, but the Huskies lack the personnel this season to do it. Cliff Robinson, a 6-8 sophomore forward, and Jeff King, a spindly 6-10 center, provide most of the offense. Robinson and Gary Besselink, a 6-9 senior forward look to be one of the better rebounding tandems in the conference. Georgetown Coach: John Thompson 1985-86: 24-8, 11-5 Current Record: 9-1, 0-1 Outlook: Despite having only one senior on the team, Georgetown is a prime contender for the conference title. Reggie Williams, a 6-7 senior forward-guard, could be the smoothest player in the nation at his position. He averaged 26 points per game in the Hoyas' first nine games. Georgetown's strength has been an extremely athletic and talented bench that can go seven to eight deep. Georgetown's substitutes scored a league leading 33.1 points per game during the nonconference games. The challenge facing Georgetown is getting increased point production from its big players. Pittsburgh Coach: Paul Evans 1985-86: 15-14, 6-10 Current Record: 9-2, 1-0 Outlook: Paul Evans has incorporated a patiently opportunistic style of play that utilizes the Panthers numerous offensive weapons. Three Panthers finished among the top 10 scorers in nonconference play. Some other ominous statistics for conference rivals are that the Panthers held opponents to 37 percent shooting accuracy and led all teams in rebounding. Providence Coach: Rick Pitino 1985-86: 17-14, 7-9 Current Record: 9-2, 0-1 Outlook: Don't be surprised if Providence replaces one of the Big Four -Villanova, Georgetown, Syracuse and St. John's - in the conference's upper echelon. Delray Brooks, a 6-3 sophomore guard, has joined Billy Donovan in the backcourt and already is averaging 18 points a game. Donovan loves the new 3-point field goal and has been throwing them up from everywhere. In fact, the Friars are scoring points by the bushels - 91.9 per game - but they're still giving up too many - 73.4 - for a championship quality team. St. John's Coach: Lou Carnesecca 1985-86: 31-51, 14-2 Current Record: 9-1, 1-1 Outlook: Big East coaches picked St. John's to finish fifth in the conference this season, and it looks as if they may have set him up for coach of the year honors. The key for St. John's will be outstanding play from Mark Jackson, Willie Glass and Shelton Jones, with timely help from four players off the bench. Seton Hall Coach: P.J. Carlesimo 1985-86: 14-18, 3-13 Current Record: 9-1, 1-1 Outlook: Seton Hall is the most improved team. The question is whether they can win in the Big East. Mark Bryant, a 6-9 junior center, and James Major, a 6-0 junior guard are two of the Big East's better scorers. Rebounding is a problem, however, and the Pirates have to get more from their bench. Syracuse Coach: Jim Boeheim 1985-86: 26-6, 14-2 Current Record: 12-0, 1-0 Outlook: This may be the most versatile and well-rounded team Boeheim has recently coached. Dwayne Washington is gone but Greg Monroe, Sherman Douglas and the freshman guard, Stevie Thompson, could be the conference's most efficient backcourt.

title: 3 SMALL FIRES AND OTHER OMINOUS SIGNS PRECEDED FATAL PUERTO RICAN BLAZE
description: For nearly two weeks before the hotel fire here New Year's Eve, there were ominous signs of trouble.

title: CANADA-SOVIET HOCKEY BRAWL
description: The world junior hockey championship tournament was ended today after the final game between Canada and the Soviet Union erupted into a brawl that lasted almost 20 minutes.

title: Israel and Reagan Deserve Better
description: To the Editor:

title: RAMON CASTROVIEJO, 82, DEVELOPER OF CORNEA TRANSPLANT PROCEDURES
description: Dr. Ramon Castroviejo, a Spanish-born pioneering eye-surgeon who worked and taught in New York for most of his career, died Thursday in a Madrid hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and had lived in the Spanish capital since his retirement in 1972.

title: NBC LOOKS AT REWARDS OF TEACHING
description: ''TO BE A TEACHER'' doesn't really criticize the educational system; it praises the teaching profession. Teachers may be underpaid, lacking in social prestige, and burdened with recalcitrant students, but their work, the program suggests, has its rewards. The NBC ''White Paper,'' on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, is refreshing.

title: IN WAKE OF RACIAL ATTACK, SECURITY IS TIGHTENED FOR 6 SCHOOLS
description: New York City school and police officials, responding to the Howard Beach racial attack, said they plan to give ''special attention'' to security at John Adams High School and several other Queens high schools as classes resume today after a 12-day Christmas vacation.

title: Hecho en Mexico
description: Does America's Government-sanctioned ''maquiladora'' program with Mexico keep American companies from moving operations to Asia? Or does it encourage American business to look for cheaper labor south of the border?

title: World Output Of Gold Climbs
description: World gold mining output in 1986 rose 4.5 percent from 1985, partly as a result of increased demand caused by international gold coin programs, the Gold Institute said Friday.

title: SWITCH TO DIRT FINE FOR LOTKA
description: Lotka, who would have carried 5 fewer pounds than Bonne Ile had the La Prevoyante Handicap at Calder today been run on the grass, had to concede her 5 pounds when the race was switched to the dirt, but still managed to win the race by 1 1/4 lengths.

title: Not Just Testing
description: Contributions to political parties always fall off dramatically just after an election, win or lose, so the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is trying to revive interest and also raise money by circulating ''the Official 1988 Democratic Presidential Poll'' to a test group of 100,000 party members.

title: CUOMO IS SAID TO PICK JUDGE FOR TOP COURT
description: Joseph W. Bellacosa, New York State's chief administrative judge and a longtime friend of Governor Cuomo, has been chosen by the Governor to fill a vacancy on the state's highest court, according to people familiar with the decision.

title: MORRIS TRIES TO OUTRUN FAME
description: Now he's gone and done it. Now the bright lights are really going to shine on Joe Morris. Now Brent and Irv are going to be close personal friends, and dozens of others will be right behind, and privacy will become a distant memory. Morris has only himself, and his linemen, to blame.

title: Let's Not Go Back to Eisenhower Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Cupgate
description: Television sports executives frequently express reservations about pro football's use of instant replay, on the ground that the networks ought to have no role in resolving the outcome of a given play or, for that matter, a given game. In an extreme kind of case last week, TV was drawn right into the heart of such a dispute, involving not football but the America's Cup defender trials off Fremantle, Australia.

title: PENTAGON'S BUDGET REQUEST LEANING TOWARD READINESS OF ITS FORCES
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed budget for the military makes a concession to the preferences of Congress by emphasizing improving the readiness of the forces rather than new weapons, according to confidential budget documents.

title: A NEW CONGRESS PREPARES TO FACE THE OLD ISSUES
description: The 100th Congress convenes Tuesday in an atmosphere that has changed dramatically since the 99th Congress adjourned barely three months ago.

title: Japan Trade Move Seen
description: Japan has decided to drop barriers to orange imports but to maintain quotas on beef after the United States-Japan agreement on those products expires in 1988, the newspaper The Asahi Shimbun reported today. Japan agreed to import 93,000 tons of oranges from the United States in fiscal year 1984 and increase imports by 11,000 tons a year, reaching 126,000 tons in fiscal 1987, the last year of the agreement. The Japanese fiscal year starts April 1.

title: 'Canes in Camouflage
description: There was a great deal of hype over the camouflage military uniforms being worn around Phoenix last week by the University of Miami's football players. In one respect, the attire was thoroughly fitting. Hadn't the Hurricanes themselves called on a popular if tiresome simile in heralding their Fiesta Bowl matchup with Penn State as a war? To those with vivid memories of the antiwar protests little more than a decade earlier, though, there was something decidedly ironic about the sight of a major campus's all-too-visible representatives parading around town in soldier's garb.

title: S.E.C. Lifts Blinder Ban
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that it would allow Blinder, Robinson & Company to continue operating while it appealed an S.E.C. suspension from the brokerage business.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER BATTLE GOES TO TRIAL
description: The difficult legal issue of custody of a child born to a surrogate mother is to be addressed in court here Monday.

title: West Points
description: A look at the list of college basketball's scoring leaders suggests that the military is permitting a little more individualism these days. On top is Navy's David Robinson, and right behind him is Army's Kevin Houston.

title: SUBWAY SCHEDULES COMING (AGAIN) TO A STATION NEAR YOU
description: It may not be as hard as making the trains run on time, but the Transit Authority has had its problems telling people at what times the trains would run.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LOOK AT THE PAST A tour of the Lower East Side that recalls its years as a Jewish immigrant community is being conducted by Lou Singer, a multi-faceted sightseeing guide. The half-day jaunt begins at 11:30 A.M. with lunch at Abe Leibwohl's Second Avenue Deli (156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street); the menu includes a beverage and kasha varnishkes, egg barley with mushrooms, health salad and pickles, and a platter of miniature corned beef, pastrami and chopped-liver sandwiches.

title: Insurance Lapse Shuts Camp For Homeless in Los Angeles
description: A holiday encampment for the city's homeless near City Hall was shut down Saturday because organizers were unable to renew an insurance policy for the tent city and its 200 residents.

title: China Coal Exports Up
description: China's coal exports in 1986 totaled a record 9.9 million metric tons worth $397 million, up from 7.8 million tons in 1985, and are scheduled to reach 16 million tons in 1987 and 30 million tons by 1990, the People's Daily said. It said the main buyer in 1986 was Japan, at about four million tons, with imports also going to the Philippines, Indonesia, France, Belgium, Denmark and Hong Kong.

title: NEW GENERAL MILLS IS 'LEAN AND MEAN'
description: Outside the corporate headquarters of General Mills Inc., the ducks paddle tranquilly in the oval pond. Inside, H. Brewster Atwater Jr. talks nervously about the quality of his company's management.

title: IRAN INVESTIGATOR EXPANDS HIS ROLE
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran arms case is expected to assume control soon of a Justice Department investigation in Miami of possibly illegal aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the case.

title: MUSIC: VANESS SINGS WITH AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: SOPRANOS who can sing them love the ''Four Last Songs'' of Richard Strauss, which is a fortunate circumstance in the event of a singer's indisposition. It is usually possible to find another soprano of high caliber to step in, as Carol Vaness did for the ailing Susan Dunn yesterday afternoon with the American Symphony Orchestra. Surprisingly, considering her long list of successes, Miss Vaness was making her Carnegie Hall debut. Surely she will be back many times.

title: ECONOMIC EXPANSION SEEN FOR '87
description: Almost in spite of itself, the United States economy will continue to expand in 1987, marking the fifth year of unbroken growth, according to forecasts by the Reagan Administration, the Federal Reserve Board and private economists.

title: Officer Is Suspended In Death of Black Man
description: At the end of a protest by 100 angry demonstrators at City Hall, the Mayor of Middletown today suspended with pay a white police officer who they said was involved in the death of a young black man in a confrontation at a movie theater.

title: F.B.I. Seizes 2 in Ring It Says Bilked Casinos
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported arresting two members of what it described as a Florida-based ring that defrauded casinos in Nevada and New Jersey of $2 million.

title: Jorge Bolet to Perform
description: The pianist Jorge Bolet will be the guest soloist with the Orchestra of St. Luke's in a performance of Liszt's Piano Concerto No. 1 in E flat and his ''Hungarian Fantasia for Piano and Orchestra,'' Thursday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra will also play Liszt's ''Hungarian March'' and Dvorak's Symphony No. 6 in D. Julius Rudel will conduct. Tickets, at $16, $13 and $11, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Advertising; Corporate Name Changes Set Mark
description: Largely because of increased merger and acquisition activity last year, corporate name changes reached a new high, according to Anspach Grossman Portugal, which describes itself as ''identity consultants.''

title: Voyager's Feat
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL SYRACUSE VS. PROVIDENCE, at Providence, R.I. (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7 P.M.) MICHIGAN VS. PURDUE, at West Lafayette, Ind. (TV - ESPN, 9:30 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. MINNESOTA NORTH STARS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BOAT SHOW: Javits Center, noon. HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.)

title: WHITE HOUSE STATEMENT
description: Following is the statement issued by the White House in the name of Col. John Hutton, the President's physician:

title: CABINET OFFICIAL DEFIES APARTHEID LAW
description: A mixed-race Cabinet minister led supporters today onto a whites-only beach in Port Elizabeth for a swim to protest apartheid.

title: UNHERALDED CAST OF PLAYERS HELP RESHAPE LEAGUE
description: IT seems like distant history now, but in fact only two seasons have passed since the Big East completed one of the most successful campaigns in National Collegiate Athletic Association history.

title: New York Court Should Set Up Corruption Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Heinzer Captures Cup Downhill
description: Franz Heinzer, racing on new snow and outracing fog that later forced a temporary halt in the competition, held off a strong Austrian challenge today to reassert Swiss domination of World Cup downhill events.

title: Advertising; CES Publishing Change
description: Last Thursday, CES Publishing, a subsidiary of International Thomson Business Press, changed its name to International Thomson Retail Press to reflect the fact that with the recent acquisition of its 12th title in the field it has become a major force.

title: I Think Reagan Is a First-Rate President
description: One of the top shows in Broadway history, South Pacific,'' had a top song, ''There Is Nothing Like a Dame,'' and the top lyric in that song went like this:

title: TERROR FILLED CASINO AS LUCK RAN OUT
description: Luck, evanescent elusive luck, is the touchstone of casino life. In two minutes of terror on New Year's Eve, luck ran out for a lot of the players inside the dimly lit casino of the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This was a malicious fire, it was arson.'' - Secretary of Justice Hector Rivera Cruz of Puerto Rico. [ A1:6. ]

title: 'SURREAL EYE' TRACES AVANT-GARDISM
description: CHRONICALLY short of production funds, public television has become skilled at the craft of packaging. The trick is to find materials already in the marketplace and then pull them together under a unifying title. The latest - and quite rewarding - ploy in this category is ''The Surreal Eye,'' produced for Channel 13 by Marion Swaybill and Andrea Traubner. The series, being presented on Mondays and Fridays through March 2, begins tonight at 10 with the 1978 documentary ''Europe After the Rain'' and the 1933 Jean Cocteau film ''Blood of a Poet.''

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS SAY 'IT WAS ARSON' IN SAN JUAN BLAZE
description: Federal and commonwealth investigators said today that the catastrophic New Year's Eve fire at San Juan's Dupont Plaza Hotel was caused by arson.

title: CRITICS VOTE 'BLUE VELVET' BEST '86 FILM
description: Members of the National Society of Film Critics yesterday voted David Lynch's ''Blue Velvet'' best film of 1986.

title: Market Place; Looking Past The Blue Chips
description: THE stock price of Subaru of America Inc. has been cut in half since reaching a record high of $39 a share in mid-1986. Stanley Lanzet of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. frankly describes this process as ''a horrible sell-off.'' But the analyst hastened to declare: ''We regard the price weakness as a buying opportunity.''

title: Washington Watch; Bank Failures Rose 20% in '86
description: THE final tallies are in at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on the number of banks failures in 1986. For the fifth year in a row, failures continued to break all post-Depression records.

title: VATICAN SAYS THE ENCOUNTERS WILL NOT AFFECT DIPLOMACY
description: The Vatican today described John Cardinal O'Connor's meetings with Israeli Government leaders as ''acts of courtesy'' and said the encounters would not have a direct effect on the Holy See's relations with Israel.

title: PREMIUMS IN PARKING AND DECOR
description: It may be the most lucrative, if unusual, investment in Boston: a parking space in the Brimmer Street Garage on Beacon Hill.

title: Lavi Proposal Criticized
description: Deputy Under Secretary of Defense Dov Zakheim arrived here today hoping to persuade Israel to ground its American-funded Lavi warplane project in favor of less-expensive aircraft. In an interview in Washington, he said he would suggest several alternatives to the Lavi, a single-engine fighter resembling an American F-16. Each Lavi costs from $15 million to $22 million. Israel manufactures F-16's, each of which would cost $14 million to $16 million to build.

title: A Museum Turns To Congress for Help
description: Filling the expansive old United States Custom House with the extensive collections of the American Indian Museum is a notion that has been floated, debated and even previously abandoned. It may yet survive. Both landlord and curator want the monumental landmark to become the museum's new home. But it will take an act of Congress. The president and director of the Museum of the American Indian-Heye Foundation, Dr. Roland W. Force, said: ''This is our only option to remain in New York. This will be a crucial year.'' It will be crucial because a bill will be introduced to convey the Custom House to the museum.

title: THEATER: PHILP BOSCO IN 'MAN FOR ALL SEASONS'
description: A FEW of the lines in ''A Man for All Seasons,'' Robert Bolt's acclaimed 1960 play now enjoying a faithful production at the Roundabout Theater, carry an odd spin these days. When the Man in question, Sir Thomas More, says, ''In silence is my safety under the law,'' one's thoughts stray from the great 16th-century public official to distinctly lesser officials of our own place and time.

title: THIRD CHANCE
description: When the Giants face the Washington Redskins next Sunday in the National Conference championship game, it will be their third meeting of the season.

title: GIBBS OF REDSKINS SPURNS PEP TALKS
description: Hours after the Washington Redskins disposed of the Chicago Bears, Coach Joe Gibbs said he was ''tossing and turning,'' thinking of a way to beat the Giants. Gibbs had good reason to be worried.

title: STRONG FOUNDATION AT ST. JOHN'S
description: WHEN Walter Berry decided last spring to skip his final year at St. John's, there was talk about the Redmen having to wear hard hats in practice this season as protection against a roof that was about to cave in.

title: TWO DEMOCRATS PRESS REAGAN ON TAX RISE IN CUTTING DEFICIT
description: Despite President Reagan's continued opposition, the incoming Democratic chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees today called upon the President to work with them on a deficit-reducing package that would include tax increases and spending cuts.

title: PURCHASERS REPORT SLOWDOWN
description: Industrial production and new orders declined in December, according to a report by the National Association of Purchasing Managers. In the report, released today, the nation's purchasing managers cited the continued sluggish growth pattern of the economy through the end of 1986.

title: Advertising; National Enquirer: 'America at Its Best!'
description: Meanwhile, the same agency, Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, is really proving its creative flair in a new campaign for the National Enquirer that will include network TV highlighting items from the current issue.

title: F.A.A. PRESSES INVESTIGATION OF LIGHTS SEEN OVER ALASKA
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has stepped up its investigation of wavering lights that a pilot of a Japan Air Lines cargo jet said followed his plane over Alaska for nearly an hour in November, an official said today.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Rightful Heir
description: LEAD: As basketball coach from 1929 to 1964, Leo Nicholson brought Central Washington University to regional, if not national, prominence. Nicholson won 505 games with the Wildcats, and in all of collegiate history the 500 plateau has been reached by only 45 coaches.

title: Topics: Scrabble and Babble; Word's Worth
description: The alignment of Earth, Sun and Moon that took place last week wreaked havoc with the weather. The extra gravitational pull kept tides high, increasing the danger of flooding and worrying millions. To Scrabble players, however, it has brought delight at the heavenly possibilities. For this kind of conjunction has a name: syzygy, pronounced SIZ-a-jee.

title: GALVESTON PONDERS CASINOS AS REMEDY FOR SLUMP
description: Old- timers all over Texas remember Galveston as the glossy sin city where Texans who were so inclined could find gambling, prostitutes and booze.

title: JEWISH GROUPS IN U.S. PRAISE O'CONNOR'S MEETING IN ISRAEL
description: Jewish groups in the United States yesterday praised John Cardinal O'Connor for meeting with President Chaim Herzog of Israel at the President's mansion.

title: Stock Market in Beijing
description: A stock and money market opened here Saturday, the first in the capital since 1949, and the third securities market in China, state television said. It said that the aim of the market was to improve the circulation of capital and that it would handle stock and bond trading and inter-bank business. Sales on Saturday totaled 1.02 billion yuan, the equivalent of $300 million, it said without giving details. Last year, a securities market opened in the northeast city of Shenyang and a stock market in Shanghai.

title: Citicorp, Dai-Ichi Seen Close to Alliance
description: While the report of an agreement between Citicorp and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Ltd. remained unconfirmed over the weekend, the heads of consumer banking for the big international banks in New York - and some top Japanese bankers based here - said they had been hearing that the two banks were close to forming a strategic alliance.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Holiday Corp. and its Holiday Inns subsidiary have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million principal amount of subordinated debentures due in 1999, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Philippines Talks Put Off
description: The Philippine Government and the 12-bank advisory committee representing its commercial creditors have called off indefinitely debt restructuring talks due to resume in New York Tuesday, after the banks failed to submit a counterproposal, a spokesman for the Philippine Central Bank said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Church's Fried Chicken, San Antonio, said Lewis B. Kilbourne had resigned as senior vice president of finance and chief financial officer ''to pursue an opportunity with another company.''

title: Stabilization Major Aim Of Cleveland-Cliffs Chief
description: M. Thomas Moore, who became chief executive of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. on New Year's Day, says the company has some big challenges ahead in its struggling iron ore and contract drilling businesses.

title: Advertising; Actmedia Account Goes To Lois Pitts Gershon
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, which over the years has been found attractive by a number of print and broadcast media clients, has now branched into out-of-home media.

title: HELEN TUBBS
description: Helen Tubbs, a cafe singer of the 1940's and 50's and the director of the Soldier's, Sailor's and Airmen's Club, a charitable organization, died on Dec. 23 at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 5, 1987
description: International

title: O'CONNER MEETS ISRAELI PRESIDENT IN COMPROMISE
description: John Cardinal O'Connor met President Chaim Herzog of Israel tonight after resolving a diplomatic impasse over the circumstances of such an encounter.

title: FUNERAL BELLS DISPLACING HOLIDAY PLANS ON ISLAND
description: This time of year, Puerto Ricans normally drop their work in preparation for the celebration of the visit of the Magi, Los Tres Reyes, to the Christ Child.

title: FLOODLIGHTS SHINE ON SCENE OF HORROR AT SITE OF COLLISION
description: Hundreds of rescue workers, most clad in yellow or silver slickers and hats, swarmed around the grisly crash late tonight frantically seeking to save people still trapped in the train more than eight hours after the wreck.

title: SHULTZ READY FOR TOUR OF 6 BLACK AFRICAN NATIONS
description: George P. Shultz will leave Tuesday on an eight-day swing through six African countries with close ties to the West. It is the first time the Reagan Administration has sent its Secretary of State to sub-Saharan Africa, where its policies toward South Africa have come under fire.

title: WEBSTER RETURNS FOR RANGERS
description: They have dramatically and suddenly become one of the most exciting teams to watch in hockey. They have new personality, new goal scorers, and at this point, the best goalkeeping tandem around. But the Rangers also have a peculiar situation confronting them.

title: Murdoch Foe Joins Bidding
description: One of Australia's biggest publishing companies joined a bidding contest late tonight for the properties of the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd.

title: FOR HOMELESS WITH AIDS, A NEW HOME
description: At the end of Christopher Street, Allen Hill has come to an unfamiliar new world carved from an all-too-familiar setting. Four floors above the abandoned dance hall where he met the lover he ultimately had to leave, Mr. Hill, 26 years old, has returned to the Hudson River shore to live as long as he can.

title: 'NO HOPE' FOR MORE SURVIVORS IN AFRICA CRASH
description: A French military officer said today that there was ''no hope'' for further survivors in a plane crash that killed 49 people and injured two passengers here Saturday.

title: PROVIDING HELP AND REFERRALS
description: Many research studies have shown that worker satisfaction and productivity are related to employees' ability to make adequate child-care arrangements. ''Worrying about your child's care certainly can increase anxiety,'' said Bill Webster, who is having a difficult time finding day care for his year-old son, Ryan.

title: The Operating Room
description: Edith Bolling Wilson, for a period in 1920, was in effect the chief executive of the United States. President Wilson was completely incapacitated; his wife, with an aide, clamped a lid of secrecy on his condition and ran the country from his bedside.

title: A NEW YEAR AND A NEW YOU
description: IT'S the first week of the new year, and short of dyeing your hair purple or wearing a sign, you want everyone to know that you are starting out as a new person. ''New Year's can be a second birthday,'' says Lynn R. Kahle, a social psychologist at the University of Oregon. ''People become acutely aware that time is marching on, and they see things about their march that they don't like and are determined to change.''

title: PHILDAEDPHIA HAILS MUMMERS, A BIT LATE
description: Three days late, Philadelphia's Mummers strutted up Broad Street today in their annual New Year's parade of comedy, fancy costumes and string band music.

title: Did Low Air Fares Die, Too?
description: People Express, airline to the backpack set, has now formally merged into the Texas Air Corporation, the world's largest private air carrier. By Feb. 1, People's brown and tan planes will be repainted in the red, white and gold of Texas Air's Continental subsidiary. No one's likely to miss People's late arrivals, overbooking or perpetually busy phones, but plenty of travelers will mourn fares low enough to drive Greyhound to sell its bus business.

title: DOCTORS REMOVE 4 'SMALL' POLYPS IN REAGAN'S COLON
description: Four small polyps that appeared to be noncancerous were removed from President Reagan's colon today in a medical checkup that showed no evidence of a recurrence of the colon cancer found in 1985, the White House physician said.

title: GIANTS ROLL OVER 49ERS AND ON TO N.F.C. FINAL
description: If it was a fight, the referee would have stopped it. The Giants, with a superb defensive performance and an offense almost as good, overwhelmed the San Francisco 49ers, 49-3, today and moved one victory away from Super Bowl XXI.

title: Israeli Receives a Transplant From Sister, a Soviet Emigre
description: An Israeli cancer victim received a long-awaited bone marrow transplant today, the Itim news agency reported. The donor, his sister, was allowed to leave the Soviet Union after waging a campaign for permission to emigrate so that she might save his life.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What's the most consecutive home runs hit by a team in one game?

title: ERASING THE SLUMS? THE 64-SQUARE-FOOT QUESTION
description: A white canvas apron around her, Zhi Xiuying plowed a metal spatula through the thick white flakes of cabbage in the iron wok, leaving small furrows.

title: Congress: The First and the 100th
description: The 100th Congress begins its session tomorrow, and is a very different body than the one that first met in 1789. The following is a comparison of the two congresses. Some figures, such as those on legisltaion, are for the 99th Congress. STAFF AND COSTS First Congress It cost $373,853 to run the first congress. The Senate staff consisted of a Secretary of Senate and two clerks, chaplain, doorkeeper and messenger. The House had a Clerk of House, two clerks, a chaplain, doorkeeper, assistant doorkeeper, and sergeant at arms. (Source: First Federal Congress Project at George Washington University; Congressional offices) 100th Congress It will cost $3.2 billion, for the two years ending Sept. 30, 1987, to operate the 100th Congress. There are 11,064 staff members for the House and approximately 7,200 for the Senate. (Sources: Congressional Quarterly; Congressional offices) THE BUSINESS OF CONGRESS First Congress 143 measures were introduced in the House, and 24 in the Senate. A total of 117 of bills were enacted. There was one standing committee each in the House and the Senate, although special commitees were formed to consider particular pieces of legislation. (Source: Congressional Record) 99th Congress 7,522 measures were introduced in the House and 4,080 in the Senate. A total of 664 bills were enacted. There were 31 standing committees in the House and 24 in the Senate. (Source: Congressional Record) PAY AND ALLOWANCES First Congress Pay was $6 a day for each day in session. Ther was a travel allowance of $6 for every 20 miles of the estimated distance by a normal route to the seat of Congress. (Source: Congressional offices) 100th Congress The salary for both senators and representatives is $77,400. In the House, expenses for the year ending Dec. 31, 1987 is $64,380,000 for staff and $176,853,600 for offices. The Senate will spend $104,030,000 for staff, and $6,100,000 for office expenses, in the same period. (Source: Congressional offices)

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday New-Car Sales Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Consumer Borrowing November Friday Unemployment December Producer Prices December

title: SEVERAL SHOCKS SET OFF AVALANCHE
description: ''Well,'' Bill Walsh said before a sigh. ''Life's full of experiences. If you're around long enough, they all happen to you at one time or another.''

title: FIGHTING FOR A LEAD POSITION
description: On the knuckles of Kevin J. Parry's meaty fists you can still see the faded scars of the street battles he fought as a boy growing up in a modest neighborhood here.

title: TOUGH TIME AHEAD FOR BOND
description: Alan Bond's three-year quest to defend the America's Cup hinges on the outcome of the next two days of the defender's trials.

title: SERVED FOR 20 YEARS AS STATE COURT JUDGE
description: John R. Starkey, who served for 20 years on the New York State Supreme Court, died Thursday. He was 82 years old and lived in Amityville, L.I.

title: SCORES INJURED
description: A northbound Amtrak train, carrying hundreds of passengers, collided with three Conrail engines near here early this afternoon, killing at least 12 passengers and injuring more than 175 others.

title: Rachelle Gershon Is Married to Marshall Epstein
description: Rachelle Tamar Gershon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hy Gershon of New York, and Marshall Harlan Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Epstein of Belle Harbor, Queens, were married yesterday. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: Bridge: The Cavendish Club's Loss May Be Goren Group's Gain
description: Two major bridge organizations underwent a change at the start of 1987, both involving Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., one of the most popular experts in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Washington Watch; Fed Vote on Banks' Capital
description: To combat the industry's persistent woes, regulators are turning to the belief that banks need higher levels of capital - a financial cushion made up of retained earnings and paid-in shareholder equity. And, after a year of consideration, the Federal Reserve Board has scheduled its final vote for this Thursday on a new way to measure whether a bank has sufficient levels of capital, a method based on the riskiness of a bank's loans and other asset holdings.

title: HIGH T.V.A. OFFICIAL PLANS TO RETURN
description: An official who left the Tennessee Valley Authority because of a possible conflict of interest has made plans to sign a new agreement with the Federal agency, a T.V.A. official says.

title: 'FATHERHOOD' AND 'IT' TOP SELLERS OF '86
description: ''Fatherhood,'' Bill Cosby's wry observations on family life, was far and away the best-selling hard-cover book in the United States in 1986, according to a survey by The New York Times. ''It'' by Stephen King, a tale of childhood horrors in a small Maine town, was the No. 1 selling book of hard-cover fiction in 1986.

title: Israelis Raid Two Sites In Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli helicopters attacked houses in two villages in southern Lebanon today, a military spokesman said.

title: ST. JOHN'S SUFFERS FIRST DEFEAT, 62-54 By William C. Rhoden
description: Coach Lou Carnesecca, asked recently about St. John's quick start this season, downplayed the Redmen's record, saying that success against nonconference opponents is usually misleading.

title: WALTON ACCENTS THE POSITIVE
description: The day after the Jets' season ended with a shattering playoff loss, Coach Joe Walton did not dwell on blown leads, blown passes, blown defenses.

title: DEVELOPERS ACQUIRE EMIGRANT BANK
description: The Emigrant Savings Bank, once one of New York City's most prominent housing lenders, has been sold to the real estate developers Seymour and Paul Milstein.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: A Federal jury has awarded $361,100 to a Brick Township man who charged that two Linden police officers had beaten him while arresting him.

title: RECALL IS SOUGHT ON SOME FORD VANS
description: The Government has intensified its investigation into reports of fuel tank fires on ambulances, but a consumer group said today the inquiry should be expanded to cover more than 320,000 vehicles in private use as well.

title: The Playoffs
description: First Round Sunday, Dec. 28 Jets 35, Chiefs 15 Redskins 19, Rams 7 Divisional Playoffs Saturday, Jan. 3 Browns 23, Jets 20 Redskins 27, Bears 13 Sunday, Jan. 4 Giants 49, 49ers 3 Broncos 22, Patriots 17 Conference Championships Sunday, Jan. 11 Broncos at Browns, 12:30 P.M. Redskins at Giants, 4 P.M. Super Bowl Sunday, Jan. 25 At Pasadena, Calif., 6 P.M.

title: ALABAMA NAMES CURRY AS COACH
description: Bill Curry was named football coach at Alabama today, and Steve Sloan, a former Crimson Tide quarterback, accepted the athletic director's job.

title: Treasury Sale Of $15.2 Billion
description: This week's Treasury financings are confined to today's $15.2 billion auction of new three- and six-month bills, which will raise $500 million in new cash after repaying maturing issues.

title: DROP IN NEW OFFERINGS IS EXPECTED THIS YEAR
description: Investors spent more money on initial public offerings than ever in 1986. But, for the most part, their dreams of striking it rich on hot new issues have so far gone unfulfilled. Because of that disappointment, a slowdown in new offerings is expected.

title: THE HOWARD BEACH CASE: PUZZLING PICTURE OF A RACIAL ATTACK
description: More than two weeks after a 23-year-old black man from Brooklyn was killed escaping from an attack by a group of whites in Howard Beach, Queens, the events of that night and its aftermath are still being sorted out in an atmosphere of profound distrust between the authorities, who say they did their job properly, and lawyers for the dead man's family, who have charged a cover-up.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 5, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 5, 1987: MONDAY Carolina Freight Central Vt Pub Service TUESDAY Borg-Warner Corp WEDNESDAY Amer Water Wks Houston Industries THURSDAY Adams Express WR Grace & Co Conrac Corp Luby's Cafeterias Ford Motor Co Petroleum & Resources General Dynamics Corp Rubbermaid Inc FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Sierra Pacific Resources Flowers Indus Snap-On Tools Learonal Inc SATURDAY Ohio Mattress Co

title: TV's Misguided Cold-War Games
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SAID TO WEIGH 'DIVIDED SPOUSE' EMIGRATION
description: The Government is reconsidering several previously rejected emigration requests from Soviet citizens married to Americans, two of the Americans said today.

title: Washington Watch; Efficiency of Appliances
description: What President Reagan stopped with a pocket veto on Nov. 1 will most likely return to his desk before too much of 1987 passes: a bill that mandates a national efficiency standard for home appliances such as refrigerators and dishwashers. Called the National Appliance Energy Conservation Act, the legislation passed the 99th Congress without dissent, but quietly died when the President failed to sign it while Congress was in recess.

title: Newest Giant Pass Weapon
description: THE next pass Raul Allegre catches will be his first, lifetime, but Tom Holmoe had no way of knowing that yesterday afternoon.

title: Topics: Scrabble and Babble; Dishonor Roll
description: A redundulating cheer for the Unicorn Hunters, who publish a New Year's Dishonor List of Words Banished From the Queen's English. This year's deserving targets include ''shower activity'' for rain; ''colorization'' of movies when all that's meant is coloring, and ''hands-on participatory experience.''

title: 4th-Quarter Profit for CSX
description: The CSX Corporation said Friday that it earned $132 million, or 86 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $440 million a year ago.

title: BEIJING POSTER ASKS A DENG REPLY
description: Illegal wall posters reappeared at Beijing University today urging the Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping, to respond to appeals for democracy and asking students to burn the Beijing Daily for inaccurate reporting.

title: DIVISIVE ISSUES AWAIT SESSION IN ALBANY
description: Just eight days after ending a stormy and only partly successful special session, the State Legislature will reconvene this week to begin the 1987 session, facing a politically divisive agenda that includes taxes, rent regulations and ethics rules for state officials.

title: MONTANA IS HOSPITALIZED FOR CONCUSSION
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback who was knocked unconscious in the 49ers' 49-3 loss to the Giants today, was kept overnight for observation at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

title: Dismissed Recruit a Suicide
description: A recruit who was dismissed from the police academy Friday, his graduation day, fatally shot himself in the head minutes later at the police training center, officials said. The recruit, Michael O'Neal, 25, of Denver, died about nine hours later at a hospital. Deputy City Manager Jim Mullen said Mr. O'Neal was dismissed because of statements he made last weekend while being questioned about carrying a concealed, unregistered weapon.

title: NEWCOMERS GET FIRST PUSH TO SLOPES
description: FOR anyone who has been thinking about learning to ski but hasn't gotten around to it, the next five weeks offer an unusual opportunity.

title: Painting Contracts Assailed in Report
description: Four companies have had a monopoly for at least 20 years on contracts to paint the Transit Authority's elevated subway structures, New York City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in a report released yesterday.

title: Big Brothers Award Dinner To Honor Four New Yorkers
description: Big Brothers of New York, the youth service organization, will hold its eighth annual fund-raising awards dinner on Jan. 20 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Howard Beach Started 200 Years Ago
description: Although Mayor Koch's intentions in visiting Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church a week ago were laudable, the anger with which he was met by its Howard Beach parishioners was totally understandable. The people there figure they're not very different from those in any other all-white neighborhood and thus should not be singled out for deviating from the national norm.

title: JOHN BARTLOW MARTIN, 71, AUTHOR AND ENVOY, DIES
description: John Bartlow Martin, the author, speechwriter and confidant of Democratic politicans who also served as Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, died Saturday of throat cancer at Highland Park Hospital in Highland Park, Ill. Mr. Martin, who had lived in the area for more than 40 years, was 71 years old.

title: AFTER 4 STRAIGHT, KNICKS STUMBLE
description: The Knicks did their best Saturday to dispel any hopes that might have been created by their recent run of success. They put on such a lackluster performance against the talented, young Hawks at the Omni in Atlanta that it moved Gerald Wilkins to say, ''It seemed like we went back to our old selves.''

title: Wright, the Listener
description: Like many Texans, Representative Jim Wright, the Speaker-designate of the Congress that opens tomorrow, does not hear a rich regional accent when he himself speaks but sometimes feels that lawmakers from other parts of the country talk funny. Particularly those from New York City, most of whose dozen Democratic members regularly address the House in distinctive metropolitan tones.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two sentences were fused and rendered unintelligible when a line of type was dropped in an article Friday by Arthur Schlesinger Jr., ''Why Not Question the Presidency?'' They should have read: ''It is evidence of the American people's determination to defend the Constitution and law. It is an admonition to future Presidents to respect their inaugural oath to execute the office faithfully and to preserve and protect the Constitution.''

title: INSIDE
description: Cuomo Picks a Judge Governor Cuomo has picked Joseph W. Bellacosa, a friend and the state's chief administrative judge, to fill a Court of Appeals vacancy. Page B1. Mystery of Howard Beach Sixteen days after the death of a black man in Queens, the night's events are still being sorted out amid confusion and contradiction. Page B1.

title: Holders of 4 Tickets To Share Lotto Purse
description: Four winning tickets in Saturday's Lotto 48 drawing were bought in Brooklyn, Queens, Erie and Madison Counties, state lottery officials said last evening, but only two winners had stepped forward to claim their $4.75 million prizes.

title: Lloyd Haynes, 52, a TV Actor And a Co-Star of 'Room 222'
description: Lloyd Haynes, an actor who was best known for his portrayal of the history teacher Pete Dixon in the Emmy Award-winning television series ''Room 222,'' died of lung cancer Wednesday in Coronado, Calif. He was 52 years old.

title: DANCE: THE MOMIX BLEND OF MOVEMENT AND HUMOR
description: MOMIX does what Pilobolus Dance Theater and Mummenschanz do better. Nonetheless, this zany spinoff group from Pilobolus got off to a rip-roaring start Saturday night as a packed house clamored for more at the 92d Street Y's Kaufmann Concert Hall on Lexington Avenue.

title: More Than Ever, the Arts Need Business
description: To the Editor:

title: AMTRAK OFFICIALS SAYS CRASH WON'T SLOW COMMUTERS HERE
description: Commuter train service in the New York metropolitan area should not be affected this morning by the Amtrak derailment near Baltimore yesterday, railroad officials said.

title: Advertising; Unit of Nynex Picks O'Reilly
description: The Nynex Development Company, which is about to take the first step toward the national introduction of its Phone-A-Friend service, has retained the French-owned, six-week-old O'Reilly O'Brien Clow/RSCG as its agency.

title: DAY CARE FINDS CORPORATE HELP
description: ''Lots of mothers now, they don't have their folks around to help them these days, as I did,'' said 53-year-old Lystra Williams in the living room of her Flatbush home. ''They're working, and they really need folks like me to help care for their kids.''

title: HOMELESS STIR DONORS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: The plight of the homeless, whose numbers seem to increase constantly in New York City, has inspired many contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: LIBYANS SAID TO BOMB CHAD IN AREA DEFENDED BY FRANCE
description: Libyan warplanes bombed targets today in southern Chad, a region that France has committed itself to defend, the French Defense Ministry said.

title: AQUINO IS WELCOMED ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: With well-organized fanfare, Corazon C. Aquino embarked this weekend on what amounts to a presidential campaign, one year after what had seemed an improbable bid for office against Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: JAPAN'S GROWING ROLE IN CHIPS WORRYING U.S.
description: America's semiconductor manufacturers, the linchpin of the nation's electronics industry, are rapidly falling behind their Japanese competitors, according to experts and Government documents assessing the situation.

title: One for All: A Sampling Of Reagans
description: Excerpt from ''Reagan's America'' by the Presidential scholar Garry Wills, newly published by Doubleday:

title: Advertising; Beyond 1986's Big Headlines
description: IT was a year that left the advertising community gasping, not particularly because of the economy - although it was depressing enough - but rather because of the almost constant explosion of big news stories.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAITH, SEX, MYSTERY: A Memoir. By Richard Gilman. 253 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95. IN the only weak section of this otherwise startling and original confession, Richard Gilman -drama critic and man of letters - lingers at the close, trailing off, hoping for some final revelation, some denouement.

title: It's Getting Harder to Cheat Children
description: No one knows how America's single mothers and their children are going to fare financially in the next decade. But one thing's already clear: Thanks to tighter child-support enforcement procedures, fewer parents will be able to run away from their responsibilities.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Ambulance In the Tunnel
description: LEAD: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Iran Threatens to Take U.S. To World Court Over Assets
description: Iran's Prime Minister said today that unless more than $500 million in Iranian assets held in the United States were returned within a ''definite period of time'' Teheran would take the case to the International Court of Justice.

title: Genex Chief Steps Down
description: The Genex Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Gaithersburg, Md., said yesterday that its president and chief executive, J. Leslie Glick, had resigned. The company said that it would name a successor at a later time and that its chairman, Robert F. Johnston, would assume the posts in the interim.

title: MAGELLAN PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $94,855 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the quarter also includes a nonrecurring credit of $581,000. c-Net loss and after extraordinary gains of $64,243 and $145,068 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A picture on Dec. 25 with a book review of ''Frank Norris: Novels and Essays'' was mislabeled by the publisher, the Library of America, and printed in error. It showed Herman Melville, not Norris.

title: GROSSMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $62,147,000 and $78,004,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectivlely, and extraordinary gains from a reorganization settlement of $226,072,000 for the quarter and $225,072,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $10,542,000 for the quarter and $45,274,000 for the 9 months, and losses from a reorganization settlement of $1,000,000 and $1,750,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CHADIANS DOWN A LIBYAN JET OVER OASIS
description: The Chadian Army announced today that it had shot down a Libyan MIG-23 fighter over the Saharan oasis town of Fada in northeastern Chad.

title: Bowl Victory For Academics
description: Viewed strictly as a football game, the All-American Bowl on New Year's Eve was nothing special. Florida State and Indiana went in with nine losses between them, and only 30,000 fans showed up in a drenching rain at Legion Field in Birmingham, Ala., to see the Seminoles prevail, 27-13.

title: Seagram's Mixer Job To Marquardt & Roche
description: Marquardt & Roche of Stamford, Conn., has been named the agency to handle the $2 million Premium Beverages account for Seagram's mixers. The Norwalk-based client is licensed by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons to franchise its mixers line to local bottlers across the country.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The procedure went very smoothly. There was nothing out of the ordinary.'' - Col. John Hutton,

title: PLAYWRIGHT, AUTHOR AND SCREENWRITER
description: Dwight Taylor, a playwright, screenwriter and author, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 84 years old and had lived at the hospital since 1981.

title: R.J. Reynolds Talks
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company is holding discussions with potential buyers for its smoking tobacco and little-cigar businesses, company officials said. ''These products now account for less than 1 percent of Reynolds Tobacco's total sales,'' said Gerald H. Long, the company's president and chief executive. The brands involved include Prince Albert, Carter Hall, Apple, Royal Comfort and Winchester little cigars.

title: If Not Us, Them
description: Cultural convergence: it's the proposition that, for all the Soviet-American hostility, the advance of technology and the complexity of modern civilization are steadily making the two nations more similar. The idea has superficial appeal, given the emergence in Moscow of Cardin fashions in the shops, news briefings in the Foreign Ministry and hard rock in the arenas. It's also evident, say what you will about evil empires and capitalist conspiracies, at the level of oratory.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,620,000, resulting from the discharge of a bank loan at a discount.

title: The Bol Watch
description: After 382 minutes of playing time this season, Manute Bol of the Washington Bullets has no assists.

title: Pinochet vs. the Hippocratic Oath
description: LEAD: As part of its clampdown on human rights activists, Gen. Augusto Pinochet's regime is persecuting Chilean doctors for complying with their Hippocratic Oath obligations. Only pressure from Washington can help combat this outrage.

title: Shevardnadze and Dobrynin Fly to Afghanistan for Talks
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union and Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet party secretary for foreign relations, flew to Afghanistan today for talks.

title: A BREAK WITH THE PAST: KOCH AND RACIAL ATTACK
description: Never before in his nine years in City Hall has Mayor Koch reacted to a racially motivated incident quite the way he reacted to the death of black man in Howard Beach, Queens, 17 days ago.

title: Advanced Steel Mill Planned by Nucor
description: The Nucor Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it was building a $200 million mill to produce flat-rolled products using a new thin-slab process. The company said it expected the new plant to be completed in early 1989.

title: Rockwell Seeks to Issue Stock to Deter Suitors
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest aerospace concern, said today that it would seek stockholder authorization to issue a new class of common stock to deter unwanted takeovers.

title: Fannie Mae Plans 10-Year Debt Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association plans to announce today the interest rate and price on $900 million of 10-year debentures.

title: Elway Expects to Start
description: Although he was limping around the Broncos' training center today on a sprained left ankle, John Elway was left off the Denver injury list for Sunday's playoff game against the Browns in Cleveland. Nevertheless Coach Dan Reeves said he would check Elway carefully when practice resumes tomorrow. ''I'll be out in full gear and take all the snaps, so I'll start, '' Elway said. . . . Tom Landry, the Dallas Cowboys' coach, and his son, Tom Jr., both underwent successful knee surgery yesterday in Dallas for old football injuries. Dr. Walter Knight, assisted by his father, Marvin, performed an arthroscopic surgery on the left knee of the coach for bone spurs caused when he played football for the Giants in the 1950's. He is expected to be released today. Landry's son, 36, had major surgery for a left knee injury suffered when he played at Duke. He is expected to be hospitalized for a week.

title: Chess: Solingen Tournament Won By a German Grandmaster
description: The West German grandmaster Robert Huebner, undeterred by a poor start, won the Solingen International Tournament in West Germany with a score of 8 1/2-2 1/2.

title: Stellar X-rays
description: Examination of X-ray data recorded in space by the Einstein Observatory, launched nearly a decade ago, has disclosed a two-star system in the galaxy M-82 whose X-ray emissions are 10 times more intense than those from any object with the Milky Way Galaxy to which the Earth and sun belong. They also exceed emissions from any other known system.

title: People
description: * Hedy Halpert has been named president of BMT Publications, a division of Tribune/Swab-Fox Companies.

title: ATMOSPHERE IS CALM IN QUEENS SCHOOLS AS CLASSES RESUME
description: All was quiet yesterday at John Adams High School in Queens, where classes resumed after a 12-day holiday break. Attendance was normal, no disturbances were reported, and the three students charged in the Howard Beach racial attack were absent.

title: Trade Doesn't Need Scapegoats
description: As Congress returns to work, the word on everyone's lips (after Iranscam) is ''trade.''

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 22
CONNECTICUT LEGISLATURE SET TO START PROSPEROUS SESSION
description: Connecticut's General Assembly will convene Wednesday for the inauguration of Gov. William A. O'Neill and the beginning of a five-month legislative session that will determine, among other things, how the state will share its current economic prosperity with the cities and towns.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1987
description: International

title: SOLARZ MEETS WITH PHILIPPINE COMMUNIST LEADERS
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz met with Communist officials Sunday for a ''very cordial, very lively'' discussion before ending a visit to the Philippines today, one of the officials said.

title: ARAFAT CRITICIZES JORDAN PLAN TO AID WEST BANK POPULACE
description: Yasir Arafat has denounced a Jordanian program for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories, declaring that the United States and Israel would use the plan to impose ''a de facto normalization of relations'' between Jordan and Israel.

title: Bosworth Won't Be Back
description: Brian Bosworth, the all-America Oklahoma linebacker, has played his last game for the Sooners, Coach Barry Switzer said today.

title: New York Milked for $135,000 a Day
description: Pressed to end state protection for New York City's price-gouging milk cartel, Governor Cuomo responds by dismissing the system's enforcer, Agriculture Commissioner Joseph Gerace. It remains to be seen whether that signifies a serious commitment to reform.

title: 'Smile' Closes
description: ''Smile,'' the musical comedy based on a screenplay by Jerry Belson, closed Saturday evening at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The play, written and directed by Howard Ashman, with music by Marvin Hamlisch, ran for 48 performances and 11 previews.

title: PROSECUTORS ON SEX ABUSE DISCLOSE WITNESS'S COMPLAINTS TO THE POLICE
description: The prosecution in the McMartin Preschool molestation case disclosed today that it recently discovered many police reports concerning the mental instability of a woman, now dead, whose complaints began the case.

title: 'THE VISA WAR' AND FREE SPEECH
description: IN a way, the McCarran-Walter Act is a sitting duck; outspoken critics outnumber outspoken supporters. McCarran-Walter allows the State Department to bar any foreigner deemed ''prejudical to the public interest'' from entering the United States. Critics say this stifles free speech; supporters say it protects the Republic. ''Do Not Enter: The Visa War Against Ideas'' takes the side of the critics without dismissing the supporters. The documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is a responsible piece of work.

title: Shift Weighed By Chapman
description: Chapman Energy Inc., an ailing energy company in Dallas, said today that it would investigate the possible sale, merger or restructuring of the company during the first quarter. The company, which has suffered mounting losses and had difficulty making debt payments, said that, if it was unable to bolster its credit structure, it could be forced to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Careers; More Need For Liberal Arts Seen
description: AT a time when the world is becoming more technically oriented, there appears to be growing support for a swing back to the liberal arts - an interesting paradox for job seekers.

title: DEBATE ON POLICIES IS RESTRICTED BY DECISIONS TO LIVE WITH DEFICIT
description: The issue driving the debate over the trillion-dollar budget President Reagan proposed today will be the enormous deficits that have set his economic policies apart from those of his predecessors.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S DOCTORS
description: The White House announced today that the following physicians participated in the President's medical procedures:

title: CARE AT HOME FOR AIDS PATIENTS
description: Massachusetts will spend $240,000 this year to allow AIDS victims to remain at home rather than in hospitals, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis announced today.

title: U.S. CHIP MAKERS PLAN CONSORTIUM
description: United States manufacturers of computer chips, battered by financial losses and competition from Japan, are laying the groundwork for an ambitious cooperative venture in a bid to regain the lead in microelectronics technology.

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $51,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Advertising; Optimistic Outlook For 1987
description: AMONG top agency leaders interviewed yesterday about prospects of the coming year there was a feeling not of desperation after a bad year at home but rather one of mild optimism.

title: STAGE: 'GREEK TRILOGY' RETURNS TO LA MAMA
description: AS primal theater, Andrei Serban's ''Fragments of a Greek Trilogy'' is a mesmerizing evocation of pity, terror, guilt and retribution. A dozen years after the trilogy (with music by Elizabeth Swados) was first performed in its entirety, it has returned to La Mama - with its urgency and originality intact. Though called fragments, these are three complete, unified works, free-form distillations of plays by Euripides and Sophocles.

title: COMPARING THE U.S. AND JAPAN
description: THE twin studies by the Japanese and American governments of each other's school systems that were made public Sunday are evidence of the extent to which educational quality has become a significant political issue throughout the industrialized world. They also show the radically different nature of the problem in varying cultures.

title: Reduce the Hotel Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: High-School Drama Teachers Await Their Call
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW SURGES 44.01, TO RECORD 1,971.32
description: So far, Wall Street loves 1987. The stock market had one of the best days in its history yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average soared to a record level that is within reach of the vaunted 2,000 mark.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. ATLANTA HAWKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. BUCKS, at Milwaukee, 8:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:30 P.M.) LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS VS. BULLETS, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) HOCKEY DEVILS VS. FLYERS, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. (Radio -WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) ISLANDERS VS. MINNESOTA NORTH STARS, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BOAT SHOW: Javits Center, noon. COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Iona at LaSalle (Radio -WRTN-FM 93.5, 7:25 P.M.) Monmouth at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M. (TV - Channel 25, 9 P.M.) Connecticut at Seton Hall, 7 P.M. (Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 6:30 P.M.) Kansas at Wichita State (TV -USA, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight)

title: Dale Mitchell Is Dead; Played for 11 Seasons
description: Dale Mitchell, the former outfielder who spent almost all of his major league career with the Cleveland Indians but is perhaps best remembered for making the final out in Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series, died today of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Rono Drinking Again
description: Henry Rono, the former distance runner who set four world records within 90 days in 1978, has left two alcoholic rehabilitation centers ''and has gone back to drinking, '' his agent said yesterday. Tracy Sundlun, the agent and president of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress, said that Rono voluntarily left a center in northwestern New Jersey a few days after being admitted in late November ''because it was too restricted'' and was thrown out of one in eastern Pennsylvania about three and a half weeks ago ''for disciplinary reasons.'' Rono now is living with a former running friend in Boston, Sundlun said. ''Henry was sinking very rapidly until the friend in Boston took him in,'' Sundlun said. ''Right now, he's just existing. He's in the process of treading water or sinking. He's real, real sick. There's no one who can help him stop drinking. He has to do it.'' Nine years ago, Rono, a native of Kenya, set world records in the 3,000 meters, 3,000-meter steeplechase, 5,000 meters and 10,000 meters. The two 3,000 marks still stand. Next week, Rono is scheduled to appear in court on criminal charges lodged by New Jersey police, who say he swindled four banks out of $1,300. Rono has pleaded not guilty.

title: BEI HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of about $5.8 million from the sale of a portion of BEI Holdings' Baypoint Development in Toms River, N.J., and the sale of property in Seabrook, N.J. c-After a one-time merger-related expenses and real estate valuation provisions totaling $13,130,000. There are no year-ago share earnings because the company went public in May 1986. The company said all periods reflect tax loss carryforwards.

title: Power Test in France
description: This week, French commentators say, will be decisive in determining if the Government can weather the current storm of labor protest or if it will face upheaval with serious economic consequences.

title: PHYSICISTS FASHION A BEAM OF IONS INTO A SCALPEL
description: A ''SCALPEL'' forged by particle physicists is being used to treat life-threatening brain tumors or other abnormalities that elude surgeons using conventional medical tools.

title: 10 Injured in Crash Of 5 Buses in Jersey
description: Five commuter buses were involved in a chain-reaction accident yesterday morning near the Lincoln Tunnel, leaving a bus driver seriously injured and nine passengers slightly hurt, officials said today.

title: Izvestia Invites a Californian To Defend Himself in a Suit
description: The Soviet Government daily Izvestia today invited Raphael Gregorian, a California businessman, to defend himself in a defamation suit it is bringing after he won a libel award in the United States. Izvestia said Mr. Gregorian had until Jan. 12 to submit evidence.

title: FUND MANAGERS EXPECT FURTHER GAIN FOR STOCKS
description: After two days of surging stock prices, Wall Street professionals said yesterday that they remained optimistic about yet-higher prices in 1987. But they repeatedly stressed the prospect of a trading environment marked by wide price swings.

title: Fiesta Bowl Sets Record for TV
description: Penn State's victory over Miami in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl Jan. 2 was watched in more American homes than any college football game in history, NBC Sports reported yesterday. The national championship game was watched in about 21.9 million homes, for a rating of 25.1. The previous record was 21.8 million homes for the 1980 Rose Bowl.

title: BANK SETTLES SUIT FOR $2.4 MILLION
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York, acting to settle a class-action lawsuit, has agreed to reimburse 1,800 customers for a total of $2.4 million in mortgage interest overcharges.

title: Sunday in the Parks With Bird Counters
description: AFTER 28 years of running the Audubon Society's annual Christmas bird count in southern Nassau County, Richard Sloss knows it's an emotional roller coaster. At 6 A.M. Sunday, he took his cassette recorder into the woods and played a tape of screech owl calls, but did not get a single owl to respond. ''Nothing,'' he said, ''just a duck.''

title: FREIGHT USE OF TRACK IS QUESTIONED
description: The death toll from the worst train wreck in Amtrak's 15-year history rose to 15 today as members of Congress, at the crash scene, urged a hard look at whether freight trains should operate on the Northeast Corridor's high-speed passenger rails.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PUBLIC BROADCASTING HEAD EYES DONORS
description: William Lee Hanley Jr., the new chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, wants to make educational radio and television programs such a good investment for American businesses that they will readily donate more money.

title: MORE MISSES THAN HITS IN '86
description: BEFORE erasing the files on 1986, here are some views of the biggest hits and biggest flops of the year, as offered by a variety of microcomputer analysts and presented by the weekly trade paper InfoWorld:

title: Vaccine For Colic Is Devised
description: COLIC is not only a human illness; it also afflicts horses.

title: JOINT VENTURES, RUSSIAN STYLE
description: A senior Soviet trade official today disclosed more details of the Soviet Union's plan to offer highly unusual operating independence and tax breaks as inducements to encourage American and other foreign companies to enter into joint business ventures with Soviet industries.

title: ATOM WEAPONS AND MISSILE DEFENSES ARE STRESSED
description: The Defense Department's 1988 budget proposal would spend heavily on nuclear weapons and missile defenses, cutting outlays for conventional warfare in seeking the smallest rise in military spending since President Reagan took office.

title: DEVILS CALL UP 3 FROM MINORS
description: After no victories in their last seven games, the Devils re-evaluated their position today and realized help was needed.

title: NEW FLEXIBILITY TOWARD CONGRESS SUPPLANTS A REAGAN CALL TO ARMS
description: President Reagan's 1988 budget, submitted today, falls far short of the manifesto for a ''third term'' that some of his close advisers once hoped and lobbied for.

title: Iraq Fixing Its Oil Prices
description: Iraq, joining a growing list of OPEC nations, said today that it was returning to a fixed-price system of crude oil pricing as of Jan. 1, an official of its state oil marketing organization said today.

title: WIDER POWER DUE IN VOTING ACT
