description: The Justice Department has approved a policy that would broaden its authority to enforce the Voting Rights Act, department officials said today.

title: Owens-Corning Stake Acquired
description: The Florida investor James T. Pearce Jr. has purchased 2.27 million shares, or 5.7 percent, of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Pearce said he had ''no desire or plan to control'' Owens-Corning.

title: BANKAMERICA BOARD REJECTS MERGER
description: Directors of the BankAmerica Corporation today unanimously rejected a merger proposal from the First Interstate Bancorp and vowed to fight for BankAmerica's independence.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
The Editorial Notebook; Super-Costly Supercarriers
description: In his new budget, the President asks Congress to give the Navy two new nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, costing $3.4 billion apiece, and that's just the down payment. With supporting planes and ships, a carrier battle group costs $18 billion. For each one on station the Navy likes to have two in refitting. What does that huge investment buy?

title: Buyer for Popsicle
description: Gold Bond Ice Cream Inc., a maker of ice cream novelties, said it had agreed to buy the American operations of Popsicle Industries from the Sara Lee Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Gold Bond, of Green Bay, Wis., is one of the nation's largest private-label producers of ice cream. Through licensing agreements, the closely held company markets novelties under the Eskimo Pie and Heath Bar labels. A Sara Lee spokesman said the company was still seeking a buyer for its Canadian-based Popsicle Industries operation. In the fiscal year 1986, Popsicle reported sales ofabout $70 million.

title: Please Read This Column!
description: The day the paper carried a story saying that I was moving out as Executive Editor and that I would write a column a carpenter was putting in some bookshelves for me and he asked what kind of a column. Well, about lots of things, I said, foreign affairs certainly, but also the country and city and people who were interesting including him and me and whatever was on my mind that conceivably would interest some other minds. Some traveling? Yes, I said, as a matter of fact, I think I will go to the Middle East right away. No, maybe Chile would be better now. He looked at me, grinned and we both said it: ''Pretty good job.''

title: PRETORIA REPORTS THREE DEAD IN VIOLENCE DURING WEEKEND
description: The wife of a black education official died in a hand grenade attack Sunday, becoming one of three people killed over the weekend, the Government said today.

title: Ziff Buys MacUser
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, a subsidiary of the Ziff Corporation, has acquired MacUser magazine, a publication for owners of Apple Computer's Macintosh. Peter Godfrey, chairman, and Felix Dennis, publisher, will continue to work at the magazine they founded. The acquisition brings Ziff-Davis's computer magazines to seven.

title: REFORM JUDAISM ASSAILED IN ISRAEL
description: Israel's Interior Minister, Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz, publicly criticized Reform Judaism today, saying it would lead Israel to ''assimilation and destruction.''

title: PARCELLS'S NEW 'MESSAGE'
description: When the Giants were preparing for the San Francisco 49ers last week, Bill Parcells walked into a meeting of his offensive linemen.

title: I.B.M. Said to Be Pillar of Venture
description: One measure of the precarious condition of the American semiconductor industry is that I.B.M., the nation's biggest computer company, is drumming up support for a chip-making consortium, according to industry sources.

title: Calling Minority Women
description: Considerable attention has been given in recent years to the relatively low number of women elected to public office. The same is true of members of ethnic minority groups, the black, the Hispanic and the Asian.

title: N.F.L. FREE AGENCY AT ISSUE
description: In its ''game plan'' for negotiating a new collective-bargaining agreement, the National Football League Players Association has proposed a ''management incentive plan'' that would reward the owners of teams who make the playoffs.

title: U.S. NAVY COPTER IS FIRED ON BY A SHIP IN THE PERSIAN GULF
description: A United States Navy helicopter was fired on today by a merchant ship in the southern Persian Gulf, the Pentagon said. The helicopter took evasive action and was not hit.

title: SPENDING: ATTACK AND COUNTERATTACK
description: Are we spending too much on education? The question was asked in the cover story of Forbes Magazine's year-end issue by Peter Brimelow, a senior editor and a former aide to Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah. Mr. Brimlow asked further: ''Why is it that people who complain about $600 toilet seats for the military don't become indignant when someone points out equally flagrant waste in the schools?''

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Leap to Record The Dow Jones industrial average continued to rally, soaring a record 44 points, to 1,971. That put it within reach of the 2,000 mark. Page D1. Chad Downs Libyan Plane The Chadian Army announced that it had shot down a Soviet-made Libyan jet over Fada, a Saharan oasis town in northeastern Chad. Page A3. 'Baby M' Trial Opens A New Jersey custody trial pitting a surrogate mother against the couple who hired her began with testimony from the baby's father. Page B1. Searching for Witnesses The inquiry into the Howard Beach racial attack is focusing on a search for witnesses, including eight people who placed calls to 911. Page B1.

title: Trying for the Sweep
description: When the Giants play the Washington Redskins Sunday at Giants Stadium for the National Conference championship, it will be their third game against the Redskins this season. The Giants won the two regular-season games. Only 12 times in pro football history has one team beaten another twice during the regular season and then faced that team in the playoffs. Of those 12 teams seeking a three-game sweep, six won and six lost in the playoffs. Winner Loser Playoff Result 1934 Bears Giants Bears lose N.F.L. title 1936 Packers Redskins Packers win N.F.L. title 1943 Giants Redskins Giants lose 1950 Giants Browns Giants lose 1950 Bears Rams Bears lose 1952 Lions Rams Lions win 1958 Giants Browns Giants win 1963 Chargers Patriots Chargers win A.F.L. title 1965 Packers Colts Packers win 1969 Raiders Chiefs Raiders lose A.F.L. title 1982 Dolphins Jets Dolphins win A.F.C. title 1983 Seahawks Raiders Seahawks lose

title: Floating Notes By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million of short-term floating-rate notes due July 9, 1987, at a price of par through various securities dealers. Interest on the notes, which

title: ANTI-PEDDLER DRIVE PLEASES FIFTH AVE. MERCHANTS
description: When it comes to merchandising, Donald J. Trump and Mody Dioum could not be much farther apart. But they agree on one thing: The holiday season was hard on Fifth Avenue street peddlers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How effective are cough syrups?

title: HOTEL FIRE TRACED TO BALLROOM AREA
description: Investigators have determined that the New Year's Eve fire in the Dupont Plaza Hotel started after an arsonist ignited furniture stored in plastic wrapping ''in the ballroom area,'' a high-ranking Federal investigator said today.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Boy Taken Hostage at Airport
description: A gunman described as ''excited and agitated'' held a boy hostage for eight hours today in the Delta Air Lines terminal at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, forcing the airline to halt its flights there, the authorities said.

title: Change in Drinking Age Only Postpones Fatalities
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY IS FAULTED ON A CONTRACT FOR AMBULANCES
description: New York City rejected the low bidder on an ambulance contract because the vehicles weighed too much, and then paid $1 million more to another bidder who also produced overweight vehicles, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $75,000 from the reversal of tax benefits. The year-ago revenue includes about $1,700,000 relating to the company's Scanterm credit card processing product line, which was sold in August 1985 at a net loss of $542,000.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Minor Fire in Reopened Hotel In Florida Termed Suspicious
description: A fire Sunday morning in an unoccupied room at the newly renovated Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables is of ''suspicious origin,'' Deputy Fire Chief Richard Gossett says.

title: Pooh's Pastime Noted In a Village on Thames
description: Winnie-the-Pooh fans converged in wind and rain Sunday, at a tiny village on the banks of the Thames River, for the International Pooh-Sticks Championship.

title: Whittingtons Sentenced
description: Bill and Don Whittington, race-car drivers and brothers who pleaded guilty last year to tax evasion, drug smuggling and money laundering charges, were sentenced to prison yesterday and ordered to turn over $7 million in property to the Federal Government. Bill Whittington, 37, who pleaded guilty in 1986 to income tax evasion and conspiracy to smuggle marijuana into the United States from Colombia, was sentenced to 15 years in prison by United States District Judge Jose A. Gonzalez in Fort Lauderdale. Gonzalez also ordered him to give the Government property, race cars, boats and planes worth a total of $7 million that the Government said he purchased with drug-smuggling profits. Don, 40, was sentenced to 18 months in prison. He had pleaded guilty to charges of money laundering.

title: O'CONNOR, ENDING VISIT TO ISRAEL, STRESSES PLIGHT OF THE PALESTINIANS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor ended a rocky nine-day visit to Jordan and Israel today with renewed expressions of concern about the poverty and statelessness of Palestinians in the Middle East.

title: Jazz Pianists to Open 'Crossroads' Concerts
description: A performance by the jazz pianists Marian McPartland and Muhal Richard Abrams open the third season of ''Music at the Crossroads: An American Sampler,'' on Jan. 20 at 6 P.M. The series is free, and runs through March 17 at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street.

title: A QUIET MAN IN HEARD FROM
description: Pro football's big stages are opening up now for Karl Mecklenburg with the biggest, the Super Bowl, possibly around the corner. And this athlete, largely unknown outside the enthusiastic family of Denver Bronco fans, is becoming excited.

title: FROM SNOWFLAKES TO OILFIELDS
description: If you take a snowflake and remove the symmetry, you get patterns of special interest to engineers trying to squeeze oil from depleted fields.

title: ANTI-CRIME UNIT URGED FOR NEW YORK BUILDERS
description: Corruption is so embedded in New York City's multibillion-dollar construction industry that a permanent investigative agency may be needed specifically to uproot it, a top state investigator said.

title: Winston Network Sold In a Leveraged Buyout
description: The Winston Network, the creation of Irwin Winston, announced yesterday that it had been acquired in a leveraged buyout by a number of employees headed by Craig P. Heard, executive vice president and general manager.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Politics, Egad!, in the Stacks
description: A major post is about to be filled by the Reagan Administration and, according to someone who has spoken to some of the candidates, each has been asked: ''Are you a Republican, what did you do for Republicans in the last election, and how much did you give to the party?''

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: American Realty Trust is 84 percent owned by the Southmark Corp.

title: 2 Fake Couriers Steal $150,000 at Park Cafe
description: Two men posing as couriers for an armored-car company stole $150,000 in cash and checks from Tavern on the Green in Central Park yesterday, an hour before the real couriers arrived to pick up the restaurant's weekend receipts, the police said.

title: BELLACOSA IS APPOINTED TO STATE COURT
description: In 1974, Mario M. Cuomo, who was about to become New York's Secretary of State, wrote a congratulatory note to Joseph W. Bellacosa, who was about to become Chief Clerk of the state's highest court. ''Did it occur to you that we may both be making a mistake?'' the new Secretary of State asked in his letter.

title: OFFICIALS SAY SOME VICTIMS OF BLAZE IN SAN JUAN MAY NEVER BE IDENTIFIED
description: Although health officials have completed the identification of nearly 80 percent of the victims of the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, the officials said today that some bodies might never be identified.

title: OFFICIALS SAY BUDGET CUTS WILL HURT REGION
description: Officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today described the Reagan Administration's budget proposal as ''unrealistic,'' ''vulgar,'' ''painful'' and ''intolerable.''

title: MORE RISK IN SURGERY OF PROSTATE
description: Although urologists say the risks incurred in prostatectomies remain small, recent studies involving thousands of patients show that those risks are higher than earlier research indicated.

title: A Training Program
description: To the Editor:

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,240,000 and $2,113,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: DEPARTMENTAL PRIORITIES: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE BUDGET
description: Following are highlights of the major programs in the budget President Reagan submitted to Congress today:

title: AFTER THE ROUT, PARCELLS WARY AGAIN
description: Bill Parcells is not a seer or a mind reader. He just seems to be a good judge of football talent.

title: SEIKALY'S 29 HELP SYRACUSE GO TO 13-0
description: Ron Seikaly scored a career-high 29 points and grabbed 10 rebounds tonight to lead undefeated Syracuse to an 89-85 Big East victory over Providence.

title: Ross to Georgia Tech
description: The ripples caused when Ray Perkins left Alabama to return to the professional ranks as coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are continuing. The latest to be affected is Bobby Ross, former University of Maryland coach, who was named football coach at Georgia Tech last night just hours after being released from his job as an assistant with the Buffalo Bills. ''I think every person reaches a certain time in his career where I think perhaps he's reached his ultimate goal,'' Ross said. ''It's just been a lifelong dream and something I'm glad has come about.'' The Tech job became available when Bill Curry resigned after seven years to take over for Perkins at Alabama. The 50-year-old Ross left Maryland after a 5-5-1 record last season and a 39-19-1 mark in four years to join Marv Levy at Buffalo.

title: SHULMAN, TAKING OFFICE, PROMISES NEW START
description: Claire Shulman, sworn in yesterday as Queens Borough President, promised to restore public confidence in the local government, a trust that was badly shaken during the municipal corruption scandal of the last year.

title: WANTED: INTERPRETERS FOR THE FRONTIERS OF SCIENCE
description: THE Tower of Babel so annoyed the Almighty, the Bible tells us, that the Lord forced its builders to converse in a babble of mutually unintelligible languages.

title: NO HINT OF FAULT IN AFRICA CRASH, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The Brazilian jetliner that crashed here Saturday, killing 49 people, was 19 years old but was believed to be in ''perfect condition,'' an airline official in Rio de Janeiro said today.

title: BOAT CRANE HITS TOWER BRIDGE
description: A tall crane on a barge struck Tower Bridge today, knocking part of its fairy-castle superstructure into the Thames and forcing the bridge to be closed indefinitely.

title: BONDS RISE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Bond prices rose yesterday, continuing a rally that began last Friday. But the gains, which amounted to half a point or more for most long-term government securities, were recorded on very light volume.

title: Who Are Judges to Argue for Evolution?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS DOUBT AMOUNT OF DEFICIT
description: Congressional Democrats said today that President Reagan's trillion-dollar 1988 budget underestimated the size of the deficit and the savings necessary to reach the deficit ceiling in the budget-balancing law.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES $31 MILLION CUT FOR ARTS
description: President Reagan proposed slashing Federal spending for the arts and humanities by more than $31 million today, but abandoned repeated, unsuccessful attempts to kill an agency that subsidizes museum operations nationwide.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Advanced Semiconductor Materials International N.V., Bilthoven, the Netherlands, said Franc R. J. deWeeger, president of ASM America Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, would leave the company to become chief executive of Krysalis Corp., Albuquerque, N.M., but would continue to serve as a director. John Krickl, director of strategic marketing, will replace him as president.

title: COONEY CHALLENGES SPINKS FIGHT BAN
description: Gerry Cooney is challenging the temporary injunction that Home Box Office has secured against his fight with Michael Spinks that has been scheduled for March 9.

title: Japanese Accused On Bidding
description: A Japanese construction industry practice that effectively shuts out American companies from Japanese public works projects may also be having anticompetitive effects in the United States, according to a Senator and a Commerce Department official.

title: QUESTIONS BEGIN AS JET SEASON ENDS
description: If anything punctuated the Jets' season, it was the lingering glimpse on Sunday of Lance Mehl leaning on his crutches, walking in the corridors of the Jets' training camp in Hempstead, L.I., while around him teammates said their last goodbyes and headed for their expensive sports cars.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's budget message to Congress today:

title: Thrift Unit Settles Suit
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had reached an out-of-court settlement with a California real estate developer who had charged that the thrift institution defrauded him through its complicated real estate loan practices.

title: 3 Are Killed in Rebel Attack On Peru Hydroelectric Site
description: Guerrillas killed an engineer and two of his assistants and blew up a tractor and a truck, the police said today. The killings were believed to be part of a rebel campaign to disrupt Government development projects.

title: Parade Today
description: The Three Kings Day Parade will begin at 10 A.M. today in front of El Museo del Barrio at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, moving east on 104th Street to Third Avenue, north on Third Avenue to 116th Street, west to Lexington Avenue, south to 106th Street, and west to Fifth Avenue. It will end on Fifth Avenue in front of the museum about 12:30 P.M.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''ONE year is just like the next,''

title: SURROGATE SEEMED 'PERFECT,' FATHER OF BABY M TESTIFIES
description: William Stern, the father of an infant girl born to a surrogate mother, testified today that he and his wife initially thought the surrogate, Mary Beth Whitehead, was the ''perfect person'' to bear the baby.

title: Crude Oil Prices Drop To Below $18 a Barrel
description: Crude oil prices slumped below $18 a barrel in light trading yesterday on world markets as the new OPEC production agreement entered its first full week.

title: Leukemia and Overeating
description: Researchers have found evidence suggesting that the incidence of leukemia in people exposed to radiation can be reduced by limiting their food intake. The evidence has come from experiments with mice at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in the Bronx. Previous studies there had shown that tumor growth can also be reduced by curtailing food consumption.

title: SOURCES OF REVENUE AND SAVINGS IN '88
description: President Reagan has asked Congress to raise $22.4 billion in new revenue by selling a variety of Federal assets and by imposing or increasing fees for some Government services. The proposals include these: User Fees Coast Guard. Fees would be imposed on direct services to individuals, such as licensing and inspection, but not those services meant to protect the general public. The Administration says this would raise $355 million in the fiscal year 1988.

title: Cetus Healthcare Offering Is Closed
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said it had closed a $62 million public offering of a limited partnership intended to finance the development and clinical testing of therapeutic products in Europe. The company said that 12,450 units of Cetus Healthcare Limited Partnership II had been sold for $5,000 each, but that additional units might be sold.

title: Two Units at G.M. Get New Chairman
description: John R. Edman was named yesterday as chairman of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Motors Insurance Corporation, units of the General Motors Corporation.

title: EXPLAINING THE EXPLANATIONS
description: GAUGING from the number of books sent me for possible review lately, personal computing has probably provided publishing with its greatest boost since the romance novel. The proliferation of volumes on personal computing began legitimately enough as an extension of the technology, which was supposed to render paper-based text obsolete.

title: Cabdriver Sentenced For Doctor's Slaying
description: A man who was convicted last month of killing the chief of surgery at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn was sentenced yesterday to prison terms totaling 28 1/2 years to life.

title: Creditors Set Redec Talks
description: International banks will meet in Bahrain at the end of this week in a bid to recover more than $330 million in loans to one of Saudi Arabia's most prominent private-sector companies.

title: PRISM ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Exxon Corporation's decision to give up ownership of its two subsidiaries in South Africa overstated their contribution to Exxon's revenues. It is two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Counterpoint
description: There were 2 minutes 52 seconds remaining in the first half of Wake Forest's Atlantic Coast Conference opener on Saturday when Tyrone Bogues, the Demon Deacons' 5-foot-3-inch guard, sank a long jump shot that added a new wrinkle to the controversy over college basketball's 3-point field goal.

title: BONN CASE TESTS ARMS EXPORT LAWS
description: The West German Government said today that it rejected a request last year by a West German aerospace company that it sell $1 billion worth of transport aircraft to Iran.

title: STUDENTS IN BEIJING BURN NEWSPAPERS
description: About 500 cheering, clapping students at Beijing University burned copies of the Beijing Daily today to protest what they called distorted reporting.

title: Market Place; Bullishness Up At Newsletters
description: THERE is nothing like the action of the stock market itself to condition the attitude of people who offer investment advice. As a prime example, the current bull market, which began in August 1982 and continued to propel the market to new records yesterday, has turned investment newsletters progressively more bullish.

title: NEW AGE OF THE NORSE GODDESS? TOO SOON TO SAY
description: In the poetry of Scandinavia's prehistory there was a woman, Volva, a great sibyl of whom it was said, ''The gods listen to her words.''

title: AMID THE RUFFLES, STILL A PLACE FOR TAILORED JACKETS
description: While the watchwords of fashion today are poufs and ruffles, tailored clothes have not disappeared from the scene. Not all the popular styles in spring collections are made with flounces and froufrou. The clean, spare jacket or blazer ranks high in the ordering at many companies.

title: Ashton-Tate Charges Theft
description: Ashton-Tate Inc., a computer software concern, said it had sued its former chief scientist and five others for reportedly stealing technology. The Superior Court suit contends that the six people took proprietary information from Ashton-Tate to use at their own companies.

title: GEORGE DANGERFIELD, HISTORIAN
description: George Dangerfield, the British-born American historian, died of leukemia on Dec. 27 at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: KEY RATES
CITY'S NEW TOP PLANNER: SYLVIA DEUTSCH
description: Sylvia Deutsch long ago established herself as someone to be reckoned with in city government. She wasted little time reinforcing the point yesterday when Mayor Koch selected her to be the new chairman of the City Planning Commission. Sitting next to the

title: WEILL RECITAL HALL OPENS AT CARNEGIE
description: The other, smaller shoe fell yesterday, and now Carnegie Hall - all of it - has been restored and reopened to the public. Yesterday saw the formal unveiling of the old Carnegie Recital Hall, now formally renamed the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes cumulative effect on prior years of changing method of accounting for direct selling and pre-operating expenses of $6,758,000. The latest quarter loss includes writeoffs and accounting changes and the latest 9-month loss also includes writeoffs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canadiens 2, Bruins 1: Ryan Walter banged in a late power-play goal from the corner of the net to give Montreal the victory last night in Boston. The Bruins outshot the Canadiens, 40-20. But they were frustrated by the acrobatic goaltending of Patrick Roy before Walter broke a tie just 21 seconds after the Bruins' Reed Larson was penalized for high-sticking at 16:16 of the third period. Bobby Smith set up the deciding goal by circling the Boston net and letting go a soft shot, which Bill Ranford, the Boston goalie, blocked. The rebound popped a couple of feet into the air and Walter whacked home his seventh goal of the season. The Canadiens took a 1-0 lead in the first period as Shayne Corson converted a passout from Mats Naslund for his 10th goal at 14:15. The Bruins tied the score at 1:50 of the third period when Greg Johnston fired a 15-footer into the net.(AP) Capitals 6, Blues 4: Pete Peeters, making his first start in goal after being recalled from the minors, led Washington. Peters was brought up from Washington's minor league team in Binghamton over the weekend. He shut out St. Louis over the last 34:11. The victory snapped a three-game St. Louis winning streak and was only the fourth triumph for Washington in the last 11 games.Washington's Mike Gartner broke a 4-4 tie when he fired a slapshot past the St. Louis goalie, Rick Wamsley, from point-blank range at 15:37 of the second period. Bob Gould then capped the scoring with an empty-net goal with seven seconds left.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 108, Clippers 102: Charles Barkley scored 38 points and pulled down 12 rebounds in Philadelphia last night as the 76ers handed the Los Angeles Clippers their 12th straight loss. Barkley scored 8 consecutive points in a 1:02 stretch of the fourth quarter, including two slam dunks and a 3-point shot, to give the 76ers a 100-88 advantage with 5:01 left. Michael Cage led the Clippers with 25 points.(AP) Pacers 144, Mavericks 135: Wayman Tisdale and Steve Stipanovich scored 27 points each to lead Indiana. The loss ended a four-game winning streak for Dallas, which also had won nine straight on its home court. The Mavericks' last home loss was 114-110 to the Los Angeles Lakers Dec. 5. Mark Aguirre had 28 points, Rolando Blackman 24 and James Donaldson 23 for Dallas. The Pacers, gaining their third straight victory, hit 65.3 percent percent from the field - the hottest shooting ever recorded against Dallas on its home court. Dallas last led at 99-97 with 2:44 remaining in the third quarter. Kyle Macy then hit a 3-point basket to put Indiana ahead for good. Indiana's 144 points were the most ever scored against Dallas in a regular-season game in Reunion Arena. (AP) Horse Racing Ms. Eloise Wins at Aqueduct: Ms. Eloise circled the field after a slow start to win going away in Aqueduct's allowance feature for fillies and mares 4-years-old and up. The Florida-bred 4-year-old daughter of Nasty and Bold went a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:44 3/5 to reach the wire 2 1/4 lengths ahead of Mine Tonight. Ms. Eloise, who carried high weight of 122 pounds, earned $27,000 for her owner-trainer, Margaret Grimm. The favorite, she returned $5.60 for $2 to win. Skiing Giant Slalom to Schneider: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the current leader of the World Cup overall standings, won her second giant slalom race of the season, in Sallbach, Austria. Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia finished second and Maria Walliser, also of Switzerland, was third. Schneider, 22 years old, clocked the fastest time in the first heat with 56.41 seconds. Her second run in 57.28 was enough to clinch the victory in 1 minute 53.69 seconds.(AP) America's Cup Racing Postponed: An America's Cup race committee canceled a critical match in the defender's trials at Fremantle, Australia, because of high winds. The weather prediction called for a 30-knot breeze, with gusts above 35 knots, and 6-foot seas. Scheduled to race were Alan Bond's Australia IV and Kevin Parry's Kookaburra II. Bond holds a tenuous position in the point standings. In order to qualify for the defense finals, he must win at least one of the two races left in the fourth round robin. Parry's team is racing two boats, Kookaburra II and III, both of which have a chance to move into the final. Racing is expected to resume today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1987
description: Markets

title: The Budget: No Plan, Just Poker
description: What is a Federal Budget: (A) a realistic blueprint from the President for spending and taxes; or (B) the beginning of a poker game with Congress over who gets the credit for spending and the blame for taxes?

title: A PARTISAN CLASH ERUPTS IN SENATE OVER IRAN INQUIRY
description: The first serious partisan dispute over the Iran-contra arms affair erupted in the Senate today, with Democrats pressing for a long, far-reaching investigation and Republicans arguing for a shorter, narrower inquiry.

title: TOASTS IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS
description: Sherlock Holmes is 100 years old and still gets many requests from real people to solve crimes. The stock reply is: ''Mr. Holmes thanks you for your letter. At the moment he is in retirement in Sussex, keeping bees.''

title: Investors Disclose Financing for Lear
description: An investment group taking over Lear Siegler Inc. has arranged conventional financing for the $2.19 billion deal, and said it does not plan to break up the conglomerate. The investors, led by the New York firm of Forstmann Little & Company, plans to operate Lear Siegler's businesses ''essentially as they are being conducted,'' according to documents filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nearly three weeks after they made the trade, the Yankees officially announced yesterday that they had sent Scott Nielsen, whose two shutouts led the team last season, and Mike Soper, a minor league infielder, to the Chicago White Sox for Pete Filson, the American Association pitcher of the year in 1986, and Randy Velarde, a minor league shortstop-outfielder. . . . LaMarr Hoyt, the San Diego Padre right-hander and a former Cy Young Award winner, surrendered to Federal prison officials at the minimum security facility at Eglin Air Force Base near Pensacola, Fla., yesterday to begin serving a 45-day sentence on a misdemeanor drug conviction.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,377,000.

title: Europe-U.S. Trade Talk Set
description: Top European Community and United States officials will meet toward the end of this month in a last-ditch attempt to avert a damaging trade war between the two sides, a spokesman for the community's commission said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO FINISHES Each year, members of the 34-year-old, 4,000-member American Society of Magazine Photographers judge the work of their fellows and award prizes for various achievements. The work of the prize winners go on exhibition today at Nikon House Gallery, 620 Fifth Avenue, at Rockefeller Center, giving the public an opportunity to see what working photographers think represents the best of their craft.

title: Standard Oil Write-Down
description: The Standard Oil Company, the ninth-largest American oil producer, said today that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $30 million after taxes to retire long-term debt. It also said it would report a loss for 1986 because of restructuring. Despite the charge, the

title: Sears Names Executive To Head Retailing Unit
description: In yet another move to rejuvenate its retail business, Sears, Roebuck & Company yesterday named Alfred Goldstein, president of the specialty retailing sector of the American Can Company, to the newly created position of president of Sears specialty retailing unit.

title: A REPRISAL BY ISRAELIS IS REPORTED
description: A roadside bomb killed four members of an Israeli-backed militia in southern Lebanon today, and police officials in Lebanon said Israeli helicopter gunships rocketed and strafed a Shiite Moslem stronghold in retaliation.

title: DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Official Resigns At Southland
description: Joe C. Thompson 3d, the youngest of the three brothers who head the Southland Corporation in Dallas, has resigned as senior executive vice president of the company in order to operate a local liquor store chain. Mr. Thompson, who is 45 years old, was in charge of Southland's Retail Stores Group.

title: M.H. Lamston Chain Is Sold
description: TriBeCa Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired M. H. Lamston Inc., the Manhattan-based chain of variety stores, from Carl Marks & Company for $25 million.

title: GENTLE METHOD PROVES BETTER FOR PREMATURE BABIES' LUNGS
description: A GENTLE hand has outperformed the traumatic technology commonly used to treat breathing problems of premature babies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Changes listing in Business Day on Thursday misstated James H. Levine's new title at the Corroon & Black Corporation. He is senior vice president of the brokerage services group, not of the entire company.

title: Montana Released
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback who was knocked unconscious in the 49ers' 49-3 loss to the Giants Sunday, returned to San Francisco yesterday after he was released from the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, where he had been kept overnight for observation.

title: Talking Business with Asklund of Data Resources; Growth Seen For Farm Belt
description: Despite the near-depression conditions that have plagued the nation's farm economy for the past three years, the states that are generally thought of as America's Farm Belt - North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri, Illinois and Indiana - have managed to keep their economies growing. Forecasters are looking for another year of growth in the farm states for 1987, even though they expect little improvement in farm conditions as such.

title: WRECK VICTIMS
description: Following is a partial list of the passengers and crew members killed in the Amtrak train derailment Sunday, as made public by the Baltimore County police.

title: Testimony Revised In Trooper Slaying
description: Thomas W. Manning testified yesterday that he ''came up with the wrong word'' a week ago when he testified that he had sought to retrieve ''my gun'' after killing State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco on Interstate 80 in Warren County five years ago.

title: REPORT OF U.S. APPROVAL IS FILED IN IRAN-ARMS CASE
description: Lawyers for an associate of the Saudi arms dealer Adnan M. Khashoggi asserted yesterday that their client became involved in selling arms to Iran only after being told by Mr. Khashoggi that the United States Government approved.

title: RAIL SIGNAL SYSTEM CALLED SAFE
description: The Amtrak signal-switching system that Federal railroad safety investigators have begun examining as a key element in the Amtrak-Conrail accident near Baltimore Sunday is considered by rail industry and Federal officials to be one of the best systems in the world.

title: Chief Named At Eagle Star
description: Michael Butt has been named chief executive of Eagle Star Holdings P.L.C., effective March 1, with a seat on the board of its parent company, B.A.T. Industries.

title: Raise the Driving Age
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fight Over Government Information
description: The National Security Archive officially opened its doors Friday. But even before that, the Archive, a research institute and collector of national security information, was locked into a sharp dispute with the Reagan Administration over questions concerning access to Government information.

title: MUSIC: THE JUILLIARD STRING QUARTET, AT WEILL HALL
description: CARNEGIE Recital Hall, as it was known until its reopening yesterday, has never been as glamorous as her big sister next door, but in a more modest way has contributed immensely to the musical life of this country. Perhaps no hall of comparable size anywhere has served so nobly as a spawning ground for young talent and, it must be said, as a graveyard for the hopes of the mediocre.

title: FIRST STEPS TAKEN IN EXPECTED SUITS OVER FATAL BLAZE AT DUPONT PLAZA
description: The opening rounds were fired today in what is expected to be a proliferation of lawsuits growing out of the fatal blaze at the Dupont Plaza here as lawyers for the victims and the hotel went to court.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Net assets were $94,044,000, or $14.74 a share, for the latest year, compared with $80,620,000, or $12.64 a share, for the year-ago period.

title: Times Mirror Planning For Sports Publication
description: The Times Mirror Company, which generally gets magazines by acquiring them, is planning to bring out a weekly trade magazine for the business of sports that will be its own creation. Called Sports Inc., it is scheduled to make its debut in May.

title: CONVICT WHO FLED IN '68 IS CAUGHT AS A FARE CHEAT AT PATH STATION
description: An armed robber who escaped from an Ohio prison 18 years ago is paying a heavy price for not paying a 75-cent fare at a PATH station in Manhattan last Nov. 5, Port Authority officials said yesterday.

title: Signature Gets New Identity
description: Signature, created 31 years ago as a magazine for Diners Club members, is getting a new identity next September from its new owner, Conde Nast Publications. It will become Fodor's Traveler.

title: REAGAN SENDS $1 TRILLION BUDGET TO CONGRESS, AND BATTLE IS JOINED
description: President Reagan submitted a trillion-dollar budget to Congress today, and the reaction it drew set the stage for what promises to be an unusually tense confrontation.

title: Long-Distance Runners
description: Joe Morris's 159 yards Sunday equaled the 14th-best rushing output in N.F.L. playoff history. Here are the 13 performances exceeding those of Morris and the player he tied, Elmer Angsman, whose big day helped the Chicago Cardinals beat Philadelphia in the league's championship game of 1947.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $236,000 for the 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $45,000. d-Net loss and after a $529,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: DEC. 11-20 CAR SALES UP 27.6%
description: Spurred by impending changes in the Federal tax law, sales of new domestically made cars increased 27.6 percent in the Dec. 11-20 selling period, the eight manufacturers reported today.

title: KISIO SCORES TWO
description: It had been an engrossing evening of hockey. The North Stars scored twice before the new Rangers, with their fresh appeal - more persistent, more creative, more interesting to watch - charged back with three goals. The North Stars tied it near the end, and expectations were set for an overtime just as heart-pounding. Madison Square Garden would throb. A strange, even ugly thing then happened - strange and ugly even for the Garden. Just as the extra session was to begin, players on the North Stars' bench and on the Rangers' side turned their heads. Several rows up in one corner of the arena, a fight broke out among fans, then another, and another. In the seats across the ice, another fight broke out, and two more started in other sections.

title: PARTIAL LIST OF FIRE VICTIMS
description: Here is a partial list of people killed in the Dec. 31 fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Testing Chemical Travel in Clouds
description: Scientists are scheduled to begin a series of experiments high over Australia Jan. 15 to test the theory that storm clouds act as funnels to carry chemicals from the troposphere, 7 to 10 miles above the earth's surface, to the stratosphere.

title: TEXAS HELD IN CONTEMPT OF COURT OVER PRISONS
description: A Federal district judge found the State of Texas in contempt of court today for failing to carry out reforms and improvements in its prisons that had been ordered by the court.

title: AUTO LUXURY OPTIONS
description: Digital clocks were the most popular luxury option on American-built cars last year, followed by adjustable steering columns and cruise control, a trade jouranl said today. Seventy-five percent of domestic-built cars were equipped with digital clocks in 1986, up 6 percent from the year before and compared with only 15 percent 10 years ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said.

title: Japan to Study Rice Subsidies
description: The Agriculture Minister has ordered a review of Japan's subsidies to rice farmers, but said the country's ban on commercial rice imports should be maintained, the newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun said today.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said comparative results are not available since it changed its fiscal year-end to Feb. 28 from March 31.

title: PAUL NEWMAN GIVES $40,000 TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: A $40,000 gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was received from the actor Paul Newman, his fourth annual contribution.

title: PRESIDENT IS WELL AFTER OPERATION TO EASE PROSTATE
description: President Reagan underwent what White House officials described as ''very routine'' surgery today to relieve obstruction from an enlarged prostate in an operation that lasted ''about an hour'' at Bethesda Naval Hospital.

title: POLICE SEEK NEW WITNESSES TO HOWARD BEACH ATTACK
description: The investigation of the Howard Beach racial attack has narrowed to a continuing search for witnesses other than the victims, including an effort to find 8 of the 24 people who placed calls to the police 911 emergency number, the police said yesterday.

title: To Aztecs, Cannibalism Was a Status Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Gephardt Gets Ready
description: Although he remains one of the darker horses in the herd of Democrats lining up for the Presidential nomination that is still a year and a half away, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri is gearing up for a fast start and an aggressive campaign.

title: Mortgage Note Offering Raised to $302 Million
description: First Boston Mortgage Securities Trust 9 is offering $302 million of floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation, acting as sole manager. Underwriters said that because of strong investor demand the size of the offering had been increased from $235 million.

title: New Emigrant Owners Are Tenacious Battlers
description: In the Manhattan real estate business, the Milstein brothers are known as tenacious battlers with scores of skirmishes and lawsuits under their belt. Now they are going into the savings bank business, with the purchase last week of the Emigrant Savings Bank.

title: WHEELING'S CHAIRMAN SELLS STAKE
description: Allen E. Paulson, chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, said yesterday that he had sold his 34.2 percent stake in the steel company, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: MARION GOUGH
description: Marion Gough, retired senior features and travel editor of House Beautiful magazine, died Sunday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENT APPROVES PAY INCREASES FOR TOP OFFICIALS IN GOVERNMENT
description: President Reagan today approved raises for top Federal employees in all three branches of Government to compensate for what he called the ''subtantial erosion'' of pay in recent years.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUER TO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had signed a 10-year, $92 million contract to engineer, install and maintain a telecommunicatins network linking 14 Navy facilities in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: 'MAH-JONGG 6' AND 6 OTHERS WIN JACKPOT
description: The Mah-Jongg Six of Brooklyn came forward yesterday. So did three other winners of a $19 million state lottery jackpot, including a group whose fifth member dropped out shortly before the ticket was purchased.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday on the Washington Talk page, comparing the Congress of today with the first Congress, misstated the number of standing committees in the 99th Congress. The House had 22 and the Senate 16. In addition, it reversed the figures for the number of days each Congress met. In the First Congress the House met 377 days and the Senate 366 days.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PANIC OF '89. By Paul Erdman. 304 pages. Doubleday. $17.95. THE ROPESPINNER CONSPIRACY. By Michael M. Thomas. 433 pages. Warner Books. $18.95.

title: Horror Stories on Taxis
description: In Washington as in New York, taxi drivers are a favorite target for criticism. But in the nation's capital, critics focus not so much on complaints that drivers take the long way around and thus kite the meter, but that they often have no idea where they are going in the first place, speak little or no English and do not have licenses.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
I.C.C. Order Endorsed
description: The Kansas City Southern Railway Company said it had asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to uphold its decision ordering the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to sell the Southern Pacific Railway. Santa Fe has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen its decision. Landon H. Rowland, Kansas City Southern's president, restated his company's willingness to buy the Southern Pacific. No formal offer has been made, however.

title: Officer and a 2d Man Critically Hurt in Fire
description: A 33-year-old police officer was critically injured, suffering burns over 40 percent of his body, while helping to alert residents in a burning five-story building at 222 East 21st Street last night, the police said.

title: GUINNESS CHIEF REPORTED TO FACE PRESSURE TO QUIT
description: The chairman of Guinness P.L.C., the big British brewer that is the target of a Government securities investigation, will face increasing pressure this week to resign, according to some of the company's large shareholders.

title: SNOWFLAKE'S RIDDLE YIELDS TO PROBING OF SCIENCE
description: SCIENCE has conquered the snowflake problem.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $22,906 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $257,515 for the year. c-After an extraordinary gain of $204,506 for the quarter and year.

title: CHALLENGER FAMILIES COPE WITH GRIEF, LEGAL ACTION AND ATTENTION
description: NEARLY a year after the shuttle disaster took the lives of the seven Challenger astronauts, their families are trying to cope with a world of complex finances, intense public attention, and grief still fresh and deep.

title: France Raises Rates in Bid to Aid Franc
description: France raised interest rates again today in an effort to stave off a devaluation of the franc.

title: TAX TABLES SUDDENLY TURN ON THE AUSTRALIAN TREASURER
description: Paul Keating, Australia's Treasurer, has used harsh words in Parliament to describe the opposition: ''sleazebag,'' ''harlot,'' ''gutless spiv'' and ''piece of criminal garbage.''

title: Margaret Laurence, Canadian Novelist
description: Margaret Laurence, a novelist whom The Toronto Star in 1974 called ''one of the titans of Canadian literature,'' died of cancer yesterday in Lakefield, Ontario, where she had lived for the last 25 years. She was 60 years old.

title: A U.S. FRIEND'S VIEW FROM FLORENCE
description: Guard boxes that look like telephone booths have sprouted in the olive groves around Giovanni Spadolini's hilltop villa. Men in gray fatigues lead big black dogs on patrol through a landscape that served as a backdrop in many hundreds of Renaissance paintings.

title: Reagan Sends $1 Trillion Budget to Congress, and Battle Is Joined
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  President Reagan submitted a trillion-dollar budget to Congress today, and the reaction it drew set the stage for what promises to be an unusually tense confrontation.

title: WARREN SCRIPPS BOOTH
description: Warren Scripps Booth, former president, publisher and chairman of The Detroit News, died Sunday after a brief illness. He was 92 years old.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 1
description: b-After idle plant costs of $1.4 million which includes a writedown of $1 million for both the 13 weeks and 52 weeks. c-Net income and after idle plant costs for the quarter and $400,000 for the year.

title: BY ADOLFO, A SOFT AND PRETTY SPRING
description: At a time when some fashion designers seem to be going haywire as they reach for never-before-seen effects, Adolfo has decided to avoid extremes and concentrate on pretty clothes. Nothing looks overblown or exaggerated. Shapes follow the body. Colors are soft and muted. In a calm way, Adolfo has put together one of the most successful shows of his career.

title: 10 Die in Brazil Bus Plunge
description: Nineteen people were killed and 28 others, many of them women and children, were injured when a truck crashed into a tree and plunged four yards over a precipice in the southern Brazilian state of Parana, the highway patrol said today.

title: BIG BEAR CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 29
HEART PUMP TO RECEIVE WIDER USE
description: Surgeons at Beth Israel Hospital here will soon begin implanting partial artificial hearts in heart attack victims as a temporary device to help them withstand shock.

title: JUDGE ORDERS WELFARE RISE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered the State of Massachusetts to increase welfare benefits nearly 30 percent, a move that could cost more than $400 million.

title: On Nixon and Watergate, Reagan and Iran
description: It has been a matter of special interest to me to note the comments of my old nemesis of 1972, President Richard M. Nixon, on the Reagan Administration's political crisis. Basing himself partly on his experience with the Watergate scandals, he has offered three basic observations.

title: NO RISE IN POSTAL RATE IS EXPECTED THIS YEAR
description: Postage rates will not rise this year, Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch said today, but he made no guarantees for 1988.

title: AIR FORCE IS CUTTING FIGHTER UNITS IN NUCLEAR SHIFT
description: The Air Force is cutting back units of fighter planes that would be employed in non-nuclear conflicts because nuclear weapons are consuming an ever-increasing share of its budget, Air Force officials said today.

title: U.S. RESEARCH ON NUCLEAR SAFETY TERMED DEFICIENT
description: The Government's program to improve the safety of commercial nuclear power reactors is seriously deficient and in ''dire need of reform,'' a study by the National Research Council charged today.

title: Athletics in Brooklyn Deserve a Multipurpose Sports Complex
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Motor Credit Marketing Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1997 at 99.50 to yield 7.948 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Redskins Look for New Ideas
description: Even though he won't throw a block Sunday, Joe Bugel is one of those whose responsibility is protecting the Washington Redskins' quarterback, Jay Schroeder, from the Giants' pass rushers, led by Lawrence Taylor and Leonard Marshall.

title: How'm I Doing? Terrific
description: Most red-blooded Americans would wheedle and scheme just to be in Giants Stadium on Sunday when those magnificent linebackers try to sack Jay Schroeder of the Redskins.

title: IN WASHINGTON, A DAY OF FRESH STARTS
description: With a champagne-and-orange-juice salute and a cluster of family and friends in his office, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, today celebrated the first day of his second term in the United States Senate.

title: KLM Denies Conflict Ended Bid
description: KLM, the Dutch airline that backed out of $975 million deal to buy the Hilton International hotel chain last month, issued a statement denying that internal conflict had scuttled the agreement. A decisive factor in the decision was the assessment of the long-term risks the deal could have entailed for KLM, the statement said.

title: Consolidated Selects Chief
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company, a big producer and distributor of natural gas, said yesterday that George A. Davidson Jr. would become chairman and chief executive in May.

title: Time Inc. Executives Shifted
description: WELL, at least Time Inc. won't have to change the monogram in the executive suite of Fortune magazine as James B. Hayes replaces retiring James B. Hoefer as publisher.

title: Woman Held in Plot To Kill Her Husband
description: A 31-year-old Katonah woman has been arrested and charged with hiring three men to kill her estranged husband.

title: REPORT SAYS U.S. LOST TRACK OF SULTAN'S CASH
description: The State Department, which solicited $10 million in nonlethal aid for the Nicaraguan rebels from the Sultan of Brunei, lost track of the money, according to a secret Senate report, and has no idea how it was spent.

title: Comex Chief Gets Chairman Job, Too
description: Alan J. Brody, who joined the Commodity Exchange Inc. in 1980 at the age of 28, will become its first full-time salaried chairman in mid-March.

title: STEIN URGES CITY HOSPITALS CHIEF TO BLOCK AMBULANCE PACT AWARD
description: City Council President Andrew J. Stein yesterday called on the head of the city's hospital system to block the award of a new city ambulance contract, after only one company - the city's major ambulance manufacturer - submitted a bid.

title: Inco's President to Add Chief Executive's Post
description: Donald J. Phillips says he has already seen the worst three years in the history of the nickel industry. In the view of Mr. Phillips, who was named yesterday as chief executive of Inco Ltd., the world's largest nickel producer, the prospects are brighter as long as the company pares operating expenses and expands its non-nickel activity.

title: P.&G. Links Issue To New Zealand
description: The recent stabilization of the Australian dollar and the New Zealand dollar in foreign-exchange trading has led to a flurry of Euromarket debt offerings denominated in those currencies.

title: Preparing Crown of Pork
description: A REGAL-LOOKING roast crown of pork makes a festive holiday dinner. The technique for preparing the crown is quite simple, especially if you have the butcher remove the backbone of the pork rack for you. Two racks, comprising seven to eight ribs each, make a crown that feeds at least 8 to 10 guests. The technique also works with rack of lamb. STEP 1 With a large chef knife, make three-quarter-inch-deep incisions between the individual pork chops, as illustrated, to loosen the rack. STEP 2 Stand both racks meat side down and end to end. STEP 3 Run a trussing needle through the thin layer of membrane between the last two ribs on one rack as shown. Loop the needle back through the same membrane on the last two ribs of the adjacent rack. Continue this looping pattern four or five times, starting at the top and working your way to the bottom, to attach the ribs.

title: U.S. DESCRIBES DATA THAT SPY PROVIDED ISRAEL
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former Navy analyst who became a spy for Israel, compromised more than 1,000 classified documents, most of them marked top secret, the Justice Department charged today.

title: A Tragedy's Long Shadow
description: Almost seven months have passed since Len Bias died of cocaine intoxication, but the case continues to shadow the lives of nearly everyone involved.

title: BODY FOUND IN KRISHNA CASE
description: A body believed to be that of a Hare Krishna devotee who disappeared three and a half years ago was found today in a muddy creekbed after a man who pleaded guilty in the slaying led the authorities to the spot.

title: JORDAN'S CHRISTIAN ARABS, A SMALL MINORITY, PLAY A MAJOR ROLE
description: When John Cardinal O'Connor of New York arrived here on his recent visit to the Middle East, an unusual clergyman was among the dignitaries greeting him at the airport.

title: U.S. SAYS A SECOND AMERICAN IS BEING HELD IN IRAN
description: Administration officials said today that Iran has been holding two American citizens on criminal charges and that both have been denied all diplomatic access in the months since their arrests.

title: Athletics in Brooklyn Deserve a Multipurpose Sports Complex; A White Elephant
description: To the Editor:

title: London Market Chief
description: Sir Nicholas Goodison was named chairman today of the expanded London Stock Exchange. Sir Nicholas, who is 52 years old, was first elected chairman in 1976. Stanislas Yassukovich, chairman of Merrill Lynch Europe and Middle East, and Graham Ross Russell, a partner at Lawrence Prust & Company, were elected deputy chairmen at the exchange's first formal council meeting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 7, 1987
description: Companies

title: INSIDE
description: Strikes Spread in France A strike movement spread from France's railroads to the state-run electrical power company and the Paris subway. Page A3. Amtrak Signals Tested Signals that should have warned a freight engineer before the crash with an Amtrak train worked in tests afterward, officials said. Page A14. Arrest in Airliner Shooting A hunter was arrested for shooting at and airliner and wounding a passenger as it approached Raleigh-Durham Airport, officials said. Page 20

title: U.S. FISHING PACT WITH PACIFIC ISLANDS PRAISED
description: Indonesia's Foreign Minister says Moscow's efforts to extend its influence into the South Pacific may have been set back by the Reagan Administration's decision to ease a conflict with island nations over fishing rights by negotiating a treaty on the issue.

title: CORPORATIONS RESHAPED BY COMPUTER
description: THE traditional organizational chart - the familiar pyramid-shaped, hierarchical diagram of interconnected boxes and lines emanating from the boss's office and branching down to the lowliest clerk - is being reshaped in today's climate of mergers, acquisitions and restructurings.

title: Patronage Wrinkle I
description: When an election shifts control of one house of Congress from one party to the other, leaders of the new majority assume full control of all committees, as the Democrats did in the Senate yesterday, electing chairmen and taking over a majority share of office space, budget and staff.

title: JWT Group Units Add
description: Integrated Resources, a financial services company with about $1 billion in capital, has named J. Walter Thompson Direct and Brouillard Communications, both subsidiaries of the JWT Group, to handle its advertising. The budget is about $6 million. The client ended its relationship with Chiat/Day, New York earlier this year when it dropped its corporate advertising program. Its direct response advertising remained with BBDO Direct. Now Integrated Resources will reinstitute a corporate ad campaign to be handled by Brouillard, while Thompson Direct will do the direct response advertising.

title: CBS Shows and News Lead in Ratings
description: CBS won first place in both the prime-time and evening news ratings for the first week of the new year, according to figures released today by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alpha Microsystems, Santa Ana, Calif., appointed Robert B. Hitchcock chairman, president and chief executive, replacing Richard A. Cortese, who had resigned.

title: Coghlan Ready to Run
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, the fastest indoor miler, said that reports of possible career-threatening injuries when he was bitten by a dog on both legs in Dublin 10 days ago were greatly exaggerated. ''The media scared a lot of people, more than the dog scared me,'' Coghlan said by telephone from his home in a suburb of Dublin. ''The incident was bad enough; I got bitten five times and had my left hand broken. But afterward, people were writing that my career was possibly over, that I wouldn't be able to run this indoor season, and by not running indoors, I would lose $75,000.'' The 34-year-old Coghlan is eagerly looking forward to the indoor season.

title: Bridge: A Toronto Couple Has Made Many Contributions to Game
description: Among the many married couples on the North American bridge scene few have had more distinguished careers than the Pauls of Toronto.

title: Now, Maximum Interest in the Minimum Wage
description: When Ronald Reagan took office six years ago, the minimum wage was $3.35 an hour - $134 for a 40-hour week. It hasn't changed. Now, after several years of efforts to raise the minimum wage, organized labor and worker advocacy groups are convinced that the time is ripe for a change. And they are quietly marshalling their supporters in Congress to make an early push for a big increase in the minimum wage, perhaps by as much as $1 or more an hour.

title: THEATER: 'BLOODY POETRY,' ON SHELLEY AND BYRON
description: ''IT will be history! The two poets meet on the beach!'' So says the very excitable Claire Clairmont (Jayne Atkinson) while anticipating the first encounter between Percy Bysshe Shelley (Thomas Gibson) and Lord Byron (Daniel Gerroll) in 1816. In ''Bloody Poetry,'' Howard Brenton's play at the Manhattan Theater Club, the poets soon meet at Lake Geneva, and the rest, of course, is bloody history. By the time Shelley drowns in Italy at age 29 six years later, he and Byron have left more than their share of abandoned children and lovers in their itinerant sexual menagerie's transcontinental wake.

title: DOW RISES 3.51 AS MOMENTUM SLOWS
description: Wall Street is now three-for-three in 1987 as stock prices rose again yesterday, but this time only by a moderate amount. Still, the move pushed the Dow Jones industrial average a bit closer to the 2,000 level.

title: FIRST 30 TENANTS ARE SET AT RETAIL CENTER IN JERSEY
description: As the steel framing for the peaked-roofed, village-style retail complex in Plainsboro Township, N.J., takes shape, the first 30 tenants have signed deals to take more than 25 percent of the retail space in Princeton Forrestal Village.

title: Paramount Films Lead at Box Office
description: Paramount held onto the top three positions at the box office for the first weekend of the new year, with ''The Golden Child'' remaining in first place for the fourth straight week.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer

title: PLEA BY BABY M'S MOTHER IS RECALLED
description: Dr. Elizabeth Stern, the wife of Baby M's father, recounted today a tearful and dramatic appeal by the child's surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, for a reunion with the infant four days after her birth.

title: Backing Draws S.&P. Triple-A
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation says it will give a triple-A rating to bonds insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, a new entity owned by four of the five members of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association.

title: CLUTCH BAG, SEWING KIT
description: 1.Leather Clutch Bag Here is a new look from Louis Vuitton - a clutch bag of solid-colored striated leather. It comes in black, red, green or royal blue. The clutch is part of Vuitton's EPI collection, which also includes wallets, card holders, key cases and coin purses. The clutch bag can be used alone or tucked inside a tote bag. It costs $260 at the Vuitton boutique, 41 East 57th Street. #2.Needles and Threads From Great Britain comes a sewing kit that is a household must. Its compact case contains the essentials and more - a dozen needles, scissors, 30 yards of wool-blend yarn, 27 yards of mending cotton, extra-fine nylon thread, buttons, hook-and-eye fasteners, assorted straight and safety pins, a tape measure. The kit, made in Hertfordshire, England, is covered with pretty cotton fabric. For $49.95 at Hammacher Schlemmer, 147 East 57th Street. #3.Table Companions This painted wooden rooster is a hand-carved napkin ring. It comes in a set of four, with a lamb, a pig and a goat for companions. The set, made in Indonesia, is part of a selection of colorful napkin rings shaped like animals and birds at Sarinah at the Indonesian Pavilion, 4 East 54th Street. A set of four costs $15.50. The Essential Boot Boots have become fashion essentials for everyone, including men. An ankle-length boot, made in Italy in black suede, is trimmed with three patent-leather snaps and a patent-leather boot pull. It is $130 at Avalanche, 152 Eighth Avenue, between 17th and 18th Streets.

title: Elton John Listed as Satisfactory After Throat Surgery
description: The singer Elton John was resting comfortably in satisfactory condition today after an hour of exploratory surgery on his throat that went ''very, very well,'' according to a statement by St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: FACING FILM BOYCOTT, SOUTH AFRICAN THEATERS PRESS FOR INTEGRATION
description: Boycotted by some American film makers, the biggest chain of movie houses in South Africa threatened today to close down theaters in a string of white-run towns unless local administrators agreed to desegregate them.

title: UNLEASHING SOVIET MINDS
description: LEAD: Little happens in the Soviet Union today that is not connected in some way with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's crusade to transform Soviet society - and that includes the release last month of Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belts
description: Starting out on the last lap of his long political journey, President Reagan was the reluctant recipient of two contradictory suggestions from some of his colleagues: (1) Rely on your brakes and not on your horn; and (2) Damn the tormentors, full speed ahead.

title: HELENKA A. PANTALEONI
description: Helenka Adamowska Pantaleoni, who served for more than 25 years as president of the United States Committee for Unicef, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, died of cardiac arrest Monday at New York Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Why the U.S. Should Sell Its Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND BOAT USES RADICAL SAIL
description: Alan Bond's Australia IV sailed to a dramatic victory in the America's Cup trials today, winning not only the day's race but a place in the four-of-seven-race series to choose a defender.

title: 3 to Leave Consortium
description: The Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, an electronics research and development consortium in Austin, Tex., said today that three of the consortium's 20 members were planning to leave at the end of the year.

title: IRISH CHEF, CALIFORNIA-STYLE
description: FOR years, much of the cooking in Ireland's restaurants has been of the ''Gravy, sir? One lump or two?'' school. The current 23 percent tax on all restaurant bills has not exactly helped, nor has the law against serving any liquor except wine; not even Irish whisky or beer is allowed.

title: Economic Scene; New, and Most Boring, Budget
description: FIRST off the mark in this year's competition for the prize of ''most boring story of the year'' is President Reagan's budget for the 1988 fiscal year.

title: On Drink
description: Sharp-eyed frequenters of Pennyslvania Avenue have noticed lately that the Cogswell Fountain is missing from the triangle at Seventh Street N.W. that it has occupied since 1882. This slender columned landmark, decorated with dolphins and topped with a heron, was a gift to the city from Dr. Henry D. Cogswell, a wealthy San Francisco dentist and promoter of temperance.

title: 'EVERYBODY SAY YEAH!' ON CINEMAX
description: LET me admit it at the outset:

title: SETON HALL DEFLATED BY CONNECTICUT
description: Three nights after beating nationally ranked Georgetown by 21 points and gaining a measure of respect in the Big East Conference, Seton Hall stumbled badly tonight, losing to the University of Connecticut, 77-68, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CONGRESS, SWORN IN, BEGINS ITS WORK
description: The 100th Congress convened today, mixing ceremony and substance with sometimes faltering efforts to infuse the new session with a bipartisan spirit.

title: RAIL SIGNALS WERE WORKING, CRASH INVESTIGATORS REPORT
description: The two signals that should have warned the engineer of a Conrail freight locomotive before its fatal crash with an Amtrak passenger train were tested immediately after the crash and found to be working, Amtrak officials said today.

title: CHINA EDITORIALS HINT PROTESTS HAVE REACHED LIMIT
description: A major editorial in the official paper of the Chinese Communist Party today attacked the spread of ''bourgeois liberalism,'' a formula that in the past has marked the beginning of sweeping campaigns in China against intellectual freedom and free expression.

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE, MINUS KOCH, RETAINS PRIVATE COUNSEL FOR APPEAL
description: Continuing a break with Mayor Koch, the seven other members of the Board of Estimate yesterday retained private counsel to appeal a Federal court ruling against the makeup of the board. But under conditions set by the city's chief lawyer, the outside lawyers will work without pay and will cooperate with lawyers in his office.

title: Market Place; Broader Rally: Hope Growing
description: FOR the first time in more than six months, portfolio managers and investment strategists see the possibility that a market rally that has been largely confined to the highly capitalized issues that make up the Dow Jones industrial average could become much more broadly based.

title: Steelers Drop a Rooney
description: In a major shake-up following consecutive losing seasons, the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday dropped their player personnel director, Art Rooney Jr., who is the son of the team's owner and the brother of Dan Rooney, the Steelers' president. The Steelers also announced that Coach Chuck Noll would become more involved in business operations and that Dick Haley would take over the scouting and player personnel duties previously handled by Art Rooney Jr. Dennis Thimons, the controller, will become treasurer and the No. 2 man in the front office. ''Our object is to establish direct lines of communication and better internal communications,'' Dan Rooney said. Art Rooney had been vice president for player personnel since 1971, the year before the Steelers made their first playoff appearance in 40 seasons.

title: CABARET: MICHAEL FEINSTEIN
description: WHEN, under the wing of Liza Minnelli, the singer-pianist Michael Feinstein made his New York debut at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel last year, he was immediately recognized as more than just another piano-bar smoothie. In the soul of the boyish musician who was Ira Gershwin's secretary during his declining years, America's pre-rock heritage of popular music took on an aura of brand-new freshness.

title: Majority Stake Bought In Firehouse Magazine
description: Dennis Smith, writer and fireman, reported yesterday that he had bought out his partner, J. Leonard Hultgren, and is now majority owner of Firehouse Communications, publisher of Firehouse and the newer Chief Fire Executive magazines.

title: A Work Force Of Immigrants
description: From the looks of the mostly female workers assembling and testing Tandy's new 1000 SX personal computer along a pair of 400-foot production lines, this plant could be situated in Malaysia or the Philippines, rather than five miles north of Tandy's headquarters here.

title: ON EAST 104TH ST., A CHILDREN'S EPIPHANY
description: Amid live camels and papier-mache kings, about 1,000 schoolchildren - transformed by costumes into angels, kings, shepherds and peasants - celebrated the Epiphany yesterday in a parade that wound through Spanish Harlem.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Ban on Apples Responding to a six-month-long campaign by Ralph Nader's Washington-based Center for the Study of Responsive Law, six supermarket chains and nine food manufacturers have announced that they will refuse to sell or process apples treated with daminozide, a potential carcinogen used to promote uniform ripening of the fruit. Uniroyal manufactures daminozide and markets it under the name Alar. The supermarkets are Safeway, A.&P., Giant, Kroger, Grand Union and Farmer Jack's. The manufacturers are Gerber, Heinz, Beech-Nut, Welch, Duffy-Mott, Seneca Foods, Vacu-Dry, Quaker Oats and Martinelli.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A NIGHT AT THE MOVIES. Or, You Must Remember This. By Robert Coover. 187 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95. OF all the post-modernist writers, Robert Coover is probably the funniest and most malicious, mixing up broad social and political satire with vaudeville turns, lewd pratfalls and clever word plays that make us rethink both the mechanics of the world and our relationship to it. The targets of his manic imagination are large -including religion (''The Origin of the Brunists''), baseball (''The Universal Baseball Association, J. Henry Waugh, Prop.''), the Presidency and anti-Communist fervor (''The Public Burning'') - and the methods he employs are often equally subversive of literary and philosophical conventions. In ''Pricksongs and Descants,'' he rewrote the stories of Joseph and Mary, Little Red Riding Hood, and Hansel and Gretel. In ''Gerald's Party,'' he refashioned the old-fashioned mystery story, turning its orderly narrative process into a mirror of mayhem and fear.

title: Article 967887 -- No Title
description: The Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan has given $5,000 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ''as our gift of love to the needy of our city.''

title: PUERTO RICO INQUIRY SAID TO FOCUS ON SEVERAL UNION HOTEL WORKERS
description: The investigation of the disastrous arson fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel is focusing on several hotel employees who are union members, a high-ranking Federal investigator said today.

title: AFGHAN GUERILLAS READY TO TALK WITH SOVIET DIRECTLY ON A PULLOUT
description: Afghan guerrillas, after rejecting the Afghan Government's cease-fire proposal, have countered with an offer to negotiate directly with Moscow for a truce and a withdrawal of Soviet troops, a guerrilla spokesman here said today.

title: Koch's Fading Links With County Chiefs
description: Mayor Koch, who has been at odds with Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, the Manhattan Democratic leader who ran for Mayor against him in 1985, has now cut off the Bronx Democratic organization and its new leader, Assemblyman George Friedman, from City Hall patronage and cooperation.

title: CASEY IS DESCRIBED AS TOO IMPAIRED TO STAY ON AT C.I.A.
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has not been able to speak clearly or control the right side of his body since his surgery for brain cancer last month, and a senior Administration official says he will be replaced after a ''decent interval.''

title: JAKARTA, CITING OIL PRICES, SETS AUSTERITY BUDGET
description: Indonesia, badly hurt by the sharp fall in oil prices over the last year, today announced the most stringent austerity budget the country has known since before the oil-boom years of the 1970's.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: HER name was Ann, and we met in the Port Authority Bus Terminal several Januarys ago. I was doing a story on homeless people. She said I was wasting my time talking to her; she was just passing through, although she'd been passing through for more than two weeks. To impress me with her bona fides, she rummaged through a tote bag and a manila envelope and finally unfolded a sheet of typing paper and brought out her photographs.

title: Less Booze, More Food
description: Among the sayings that have surfaced during the last 15 years - right up there with the wistful ''When I get my act together'' - is the boastful ''I'm going to take charge of my life.'' Judging by a report from the Department of Health and Human Services, millions of Americans have done just that.

title: BLACK COALITION URGES A BOYCOTT OF BUSINESSES
description: A coalition of black leaders from Brooklyn called yesterday for a one-day citywide boycott of non-black-owned businesses that they said they would model after a bus boycott led by the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. 31 years ago in Montgomery, Ala.

title: RULES OF TAKEOUT GAME
description: EVERY restaurant providing carryout or delivery service has its own set of rules, many of which will be broken not only for a good customer but also when business is slow. And even restaurants not offering such service will occasionally take care of their faithful customers.

title: 'END OF THE LINE,' ON COCAINE ADDICTION
description: ''END OF THE LINE'' is high- speed, glossy and graphic. It also burns with zeal. Sometimes the zeal is misplaced, and the WNBC-TV special on cocaine addiction gets trapped in its own sophistication. Almost always, however, it retrieves itself. The program, on Channel 4 at 9 tonight, is an imaginative and sometimes gripping work.

title: BISON RETURNS TO THE RANGE AND THE TABLE
description: LEAD: WHEN George Washington Nyhart arrived in Montana's Madison Valley in the 1860's, vast herds of bison roamed the plains, providing him and other settlers with an ample supply of fresh meat. Today, bison -or buffalo, as they are commonly, if incorrectly, called - supply George Nyhart's great-great-grandson Jerry, his wife,

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
