description: Maybe some burdens of leadership are common burdens, but surely not all. Consider the opposite examples of the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan.

title: When Will We Fly Smokeless Skies?
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO EMPHASIZES CURB ON SPENDING
description: Governor Cuomo, opening a legislative year in which he will decide whether to seek the Presidency, presented his agenda for 1987 today, calling for new programs in education, criminal justice and housing but stressing that, above all else, state spending had to be curbed.

title: CITY BALLET: 'DANCES,' 'LA SOURCE' AND 'SERENADE'
description: AN especially well-danced program served to reopen the New York City Ballet's regular repertory season Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. There is nothing like a monthlong run of ''The Nutcracker'' to get dancers' juices flowing again.

title: U.S. SAID TO ASK APPROVAL OF A MOVE TO INDICT BIAGGI
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have asked the Justice Department for approval to seek indictments against Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx and the former Brooklyn Democratic leader Meade H. Esposito on charges of bribery and obstruction of justice, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: TODAY'S NEIL SIMON TAKES ON EARLIER NEIL SIMON
description: AFTER the Jerome brothers of Neil Simon's ''Broadway Bound'' sell their first comedy sketch to CBS Radio, they are stunned to discover that one innocuous gag hits home harder than intended: a punch line about ''ladies' pajamas'' proves to be a subconscious indictment of their father's philandering. After taking another look at the first of Mr. Simon's three autobiographical plays about the Jeromes, ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' in its faithful film version, one might wonder if ''Broadway Bound'' itself wasn't a subconscious expiation of its author's past sins. The two Brighton Beach plays, set a decade apart and written only three years apart, share largely the same set of characters. Yet the new, more mature work repeatedly contradicts its predecessor in content and technique - almost as if ''Broadway Bound'' had been written to point up the sentimentalities and contrivances of what came before.

title: O'CONNOR REPORTS TO THE POPE
description: John Cardinal O'Connor had a private lunch with Pope John Paul II today after the New York Archbishop's churchman's visit to Jordan and Israel.

title: Representation Sought By Air Traffic Workers
description: A fledgling union is seeking recognition as bargaining agent for workers who have been without a union since President Reagan dismissed 11,400 air traffic controllers who went on strike in 1981.

title: WARNING ON ACCIDENT ON FILM SET DESCRIBED
description: A camera operator testified Tuesday that the director of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' responded to a warning about the impact that special effects explosions might have on the film's helicopter by saying ''we may lose'' the aircraft.

title: GARAGE-DOOR OPENERS
description: IF it weren't for labor-saving devices like stereo-record changers, electric toothbrushes and automatic transmissions, some people probably would not get up in the morning. Just try telling someone that they not only have to drive their car in 10-degree weather, but they also have to stand outside and close the garage door before they do it.

title: Activision Agrees To Settle Lawsuit
description: Activision Inc., a software producer in Mountain View, Calif., said it had agreed to settle a class action suit filed by a shareholder group for $4.75 million, of which at least $2.5 million will be in cash, with the balance in securities. The group had complained about purported misstatements and omissions in the registration statement and prospectus that were issued when the company went public in June 1983. Activision began to suffer losses soon afterward and its stock price plunged.

title: KNICKS IN REVERSE AS THOMAS STARS
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 7 -

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $492,300 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After tax credits of $12,700 for the quarter and $75,700 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months' results include $1,675,100 in income from the termination of a pension plan at the company's Quaker Fabric Corp. subsidiary. The 9 months also includes net of $119,200 from early compliance with new accounting standards for pensions. The year-ago third quarter and 9 months' results include $1,257,400 in life insurance proceeds as a result of the death of a former officer of the company.

title: Senate Panel's Report Omitted Bush Meeting
description: Details of a 1985 meeting between Vice President Bush and an Israeli Government adviser were provided to the Senate Intelligence Committee investigating the secret arms sales to Iran but not included in a report by the committee, a spokesman for the Vice President said today.

title: NEGLIGENCE IS CITED IN DEATH
description: The director of a school for severely autistic teen-agers and young adults was negligent in the death of a student who died while undergoing treatment, a judge said today.

title: Meet My Consort
description: To the Editor:

title: ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes unusual charges of $6,756,000 for both the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $6,059,000 and $9,477,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,410,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $2,065,000 for the year.

title: New Products Shown by Atari
description: The Atari Corporation, which has regained profitability largely because of the success of its 520 and 1040 ST personal computers, introduced a new ST today aimed at professional users. It also introduced a new low-priced laser printer.

title: Michigan Executive Takes Lilco Posts
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has named Russell C. Youngdahl president and chief operating officer, filling posts that have been vacant for several years.

title: EASY NIGHT FOR NETS
description: There was something almost too simple about the game. It had begun to look like a routine practice session by the second period, like an emphatic blowout by the third. There have not been many nights like this, not for the Nets. Not this season.

title: WHITE HOUSE PUTTING BLAME ON HIS AIDES
description: As the Iran-contra affair unfolds, the White House finds itself in the strange position of defending President Reagan with the argument that some of his most powerful aides were incompetent or deceitful.

title: U.S. AIDES CONFER ON A LATIN PEACE
description: Two senior United States officials met in Miami today with Costa Rica's Foreign Minister to discuss a new diplomatic initiative in Central America.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Rick Burleson, infielder, to one-year contract.

title: COLD ENOUGH EVEN FOR A MUSCOVITE
description: A solitary jogger moved through the brittle air, his beard encrusted with ice. A canopy of snow-draped trees overhead formed a crystal cathedral that sparkled in the sun.

title: CHINA REPORTS ATTACKS BY HANOI
description: Chinese frontier guards drove back several Vietnamese attacks across the border, destroying a company of Vietnamese soldiers today and ''wiping out'' another 200 enemy troops, Xinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.

title: ISRAELI IS LINKED TO WIFE OF A SPY
description: The Justice Department charged today that a prominent Israeli Air Force colonel attempted to assist Anne Henderson Pollard, the wife of a confessed American spy for Israel, after the couple's espionage activities was exposed.

title: FRENCH-ITT VENTURE PREDICTS PROFIT OF $260 MILLION FOR THE YEAR
description: The telecommunications company formed last month by France's state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite and the ITT Corporation forecast today that it will earn at least $260 million this year on expected sales of $13 billion.

title: Lord, Geller Discloses Influx of New Business
description: Now that he has regained his strength after the outpouring of jolliness over the holidays, Richard J. Lord, chairman of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, has found time to announce some new business that arrived just before Santa.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee Against Apartheid - 3 P.M.

title: EX-PRESIDENT OF LEBANON SURVIVES A CAR-BOMBING
description: Four people were killed and more than 30 were wounded today as former President Camille Chamoun survived an assassination attempt in East Beirut.

title: Yankees Spurn Gedman Overture
description: The Yankees, who three weeks ago passed up the chance to add Jack Morris to their pitching staff, yesterday rejected the opportunity to snatch Rich Gedman from the Boston Red Sox and make him their catcher. They also saw their chances of re-signing Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph dwindling as tonight's midnight signing deadline loomed.

title: Charges Dismissed In Friedman Scuffle
description: A judge yesterday dismissed assault charges against Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader; his wife, Jacqueline, and a New York photographer that resulted from a scuffle last November.

title: POLL GAUGES WHITE PROTESTANTS' VIEWS OF JEWS
description: White Protestants who hold conservative religious views do not consciously use their convictions to justify anti-Semitic views of Jews, according to the results of a poll commissioned by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith that was released yesterday.

title: FEDERAL JURY ON ARMS CASE TO BE EMPANELED IN WEEKS
description: A Federal grand jury will be empaneled before February to begin hearing testimony in the Iran-contra arms case, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the investigation.

title: THEATER: 'DOWN AN ALLEY FILLED WITH CATS' OPENS
description: WARWICK MOSS, an Australian playwright, is said to have changed the ending of ''Down an Alley Filled With Cats'' for each new production it has had since it won the award for best new play at the Canberra Festival in 1983. The ending of the current production at the Quaigh Theater is fitting and funny. But the ending of this farcical mystery might be changed every night, since you are never sure what has ended, anyway.

title: Israeli Printers on Strike
description: Printers on all of Israel's nine daily newspapers began a 48-hour strike today to press their demand for more pay, according to the union secretary general, Meir Goldstein. The strike, which will prevent the dailies from appearing Thursday or Friday, was called after publishers and printers failed to reach agreement on how much more printers should be paid as compensation for learning to operate new computerized print technologies.

title: The Catholic Church Is Also All Catholics
description: To the Editor:

title: About Mad Madge
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Browns Already Heroes
description: A hint of how Browns-mad Cleveland has become was indicated by a phone call to the team's owner this morning.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it is considering a new line of Jeeps for assembly at its Kenosha, Wis., plant if the state of Wisconsin will meet certain criteria.

title: KEY RATES
NEW AND POPULAR ORNAMENTAL GRASES
description: SOME of my gardening friends tell me it would be possible to have a garden with practically nothing in it but ornamental grasses. And certainly grasses are riding the crest of popularity these days. I admire these grasses, but my admiration does not trespass into fanaticism. There are too many other plants that I could not live without, like day lilies, old-fashioned roses, bee balm and sedums. I would not want to see these nudged aside. But I like the ornamental grasses I happen to grow. And since there are so many that I have not yet tried, I can see how they might get a larger share of my small plot, without a boring outcome.

title: MOTHER SAID TO CHANGE MIND AT BABY M'S BIRTH
description: The husband of the surrogate mother of Baby M, Richard Whitehead, testified today that his wife, Mary Beth, had planned to surrender the child to her natural father, William Stern, until moments after her birth.

title: Zruce Declines Offer
description: Earle Bruce, who said he was ''offered the moon'' to take over the football program at the University of Arizona, has decided to remain head coach at Ohio State University.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer Express 6, Sting 4: Fred Grgurev scored two goals and assisted on a third last night at Nassau Coliseum as New York held on to defeat Chicago for its first victory of the season after 13 defeats. Njego Pesa had a pair of goals for the Express, which led at halftime, 3-1. The triumph prevented New York from tying the Major Indoor Soccer League record of 14 consecutive defeats set by the Kansas City Comets in 1981-82.(AP) N.B.A. Lakers 147, Nuggets 109: Byron Scott scored 23 points and Earvin (Magic) Johnson had 20 points and 12 assists in leading Los Angeles. The victory was the eighth in a row for the Lakers, who have a 26-6 record, the best in the N.B.A. The loss was the fifth straight for the Nuggets. The Nuggets took a 31-21 lead, but the Lakers scored 12 of the final 16 points of the first quarter to trail by only 35-33. Los Angeles then went ahead for good with a 9-0 streak to start the second period. The Lakers went on to score 18 of the first 24 points of the quarter for a 51-41 advantage. It was 73-57 at halftime and the Nuggets got no closer than 16 points after that. Michael Cooper and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar added 17 and 14 points, respectively, for the Lakers.(AP) 76ers 109, Hawks 102: Cliff Robinson scored 31 points and Charles Barkley 25 last night as Philadelphia downed Atlanta, handing the Hawks only their second home-court defeat in 14 games this season. Robinson, Maurice Cheeks and David Wingate scored 4 points apiece in a 16-4 spurt that broke a 43-43 deadlock in the second quarter and gave Philadelphia the lead for good. Philadelphia clamped a lid on the Atlanta star, Dominique Wilkins, in the first half, holding him to only 2 points. Wilkins finished with 24 points.(AP) Celtics 119, Bucks 92: Kevin McHale scored 22 of his 28 points in the first half as Boston beat Milwaukee, gaining its sixth consecutive victory. With Larry Bird sidelined with a strained lower back, every Boston player scored while helping the Celtics improve their record to 22-9.(AP) N.H.L. Kings 6, Oilers 1: Luc Robitaille had a goal and assist to spark Los Angeles to a rout of Edmonton. The victory avenged an 8-1 loss to the Oilers in Los Angeles Saturday night and enabled the Kings, fourth in the Smythe Division, to even the season series at 2-2-2. Robitaille scored his 24th goal at 2:50 of the first period, banging the third rebound behind the goaltender, Andy Moog. Dave Taylor and Grant Ledyard scored before the first period ended, chasing Moog to the bench. Roland Melanson stopped 28 shots in the Los Angeles net.(AP) Golf O'Grady Ties for Lead: Mark Calcavecchia played his last seven holes in seven under par and tied Mac O'Grady for the first-round lead yesterday in the $500,000 Tournament of Champions golf tournament at Carlsbad, Calif. The two first-time players in this event that brings together only the winners of PGA Tour titles from the last 12 months, had a seven-under-par 65 each on the soggy La Costa Country Club course, drenched by two days of rain. ''I'm surprised to be able to score as well as I did,'' said O'Grady, who was fined and suspended last year by the commissioner, Deane Beman, for his criticism of the tour. Calcavecchia one-putted 12 times, including the last 7 holes. But he also three-putted twice, once from 4 feet, on the 11th hole. On the 12th, he started his big drive with a 20-foot putt for an eagle-3. Corey Pavin and Rick Fehr were tied at 68.(AP) America's Cup Australian Yachts Collide: The two top Australian 12-Meters sailed one last race yesterday at Fremantle before their meeting in a four-of-seven-race series beginning next Wednesday to decide which will defend the America's Cup. The two boats collided in the third leg of the race, leaving Kookaburra III with a small hole in her bow, and Australia IV, which won the race by 24 seconds. with a dented stern and a bent aerial. Iain Murray, skipper of Kookaburra III, said his crew had to bail the boat for the rest of the race to keep it from sinking. Both teams said they would be able to repair the boats overnight. Protests were lodged on each side, but the outcome of the race does not affect either boat's place in the finals. Horse Racing Actor's Colt Wins: Synastry, a 4-year-old colt owned by Albert Finney, the actor, won by a neck in the $45,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. With Chris Antley aboard, Synastry, a son of Seattle Slew and Municipal Bond, went a mile and sixteenth carrying 117 pounds on the fast track in 1:44 3/5. The colt held on gamely to hold off the late bid of Grand Rivulet. Synastry, the favorite, earned $27,000 with his fifth victory in 12 career starts and returned $4.80 for $2 to win.

title: Shoreham Plan Said To Violate Zoning
description: Continuing a challenge to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the Hempstead Town Board has voted to warn the Long Island Lighting Company that to use a building here as an emergency evacuation center would violate zoning laws.

title: O'NEILL ASKS TAX RELIEF AND AID TO POOR
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's State of the State Address to the General Assembly today:

title: MOSCOW HINTS AT AFGHANISTAN TROOP CUT
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze returned to Moscow from Kabul today amid indications that the Soviet Union would soon announce a withdrawal of some of its troops from Afghanistan.

title: Kay Practices With Broncos
description: Clarence Kay, a tight end sidelined the last four weeks while he underwent drug rehabilitation, rejoined the Denver Broncos today and could be activated for Sunday's American Conference championship game at Cleveland.

title: T.V.A. REINSTATING ADMIRAL AS MANAGER OF NUCLEAR PROGRAM
description: After more than two months of negotiations, the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that it had reinstated Adm. Stephen A. White as director of its nuclear reactor program and had rewritten his $355,000 a year contract.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of 12 cents a share from the adoption of an accounting rule.

title: THREATS FORCE SAN JUAN EVACUATIONS
description: A series of bomb threats today caused the evacuation of more than 200 people in and around San Juan, including at least nine who had survived the burning of the Dupont Plaza Hotel a week ago.

title: DETAILINGS: ALMOST THE REAL THING
description: LAST year, when Albert Pensis bought a weekend house in Water Mill, L.I., he liked its location near the ocean and its manageable size, but not its 1950's ranch style.

title: BUDGET DIRECTOR DEFENDS REAGAN'S PLAN
description: Dealing an early blow to chances for a compromise, the Federal budget director said today that President Reagan would not agree to a high-level meeting with Congress if it meant including tax increases in the negotiations.

title: JACKSON IS TRYING TO RETIRE IN STYLE
description: They call Tom Jackson the poet laureate of the Denver Broncos because he likes to talk so much. The volume is stronger than the content, and the poet is not above an exaggeration or two, a couple of winks, and one of the biggest smiles in the National Football League.

title: Undated Notes Post a Record Decline in Europe
description: The problems of a troubled $17 billion sector of the Eurobond market deepened today as prices dropped by record amounts on perpetual floating-rate notes.

title: 2 West Bank Schools Shut
description: The director of Aroudeh College in Nablus closed the school today for a week after a series of anti-Israeli disturbances, a military spokesman said. The Israeli Civil Administration, which runs the daily affairs of the West Bank, closed Al Najah University, also in Nablus, for a week beginning last Saturday.

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: The year-earlier results were restated to reflect FASB No. 87 relating to employer's accounting for pensions.

title: EXCERPTS FROM O'NEILL ADDRESS TO THE CONNECTICUT LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's State of the State Address to the General Assembly today:

title: 2 REPORTED KILLED IN RAID BY SRI LANKAN ARMY
description: Soldiers attacked the main Tamil city today and killed two people in the first military action since Tamil rebels announced they were taking civil control of the Jaffna Peninsula, witnesses said.

title: Creative Coupons for Poor Renters
description: The public housing program has been dead for years, but a substitute, rent vouchers, has appeared. The new Reagan Administration budget calls for giving vouchers to 103,000 families next year, twice as many as Congress approved for 1987. It's an appealing proposal. Housing vouchers are certificates payable to the owner of a building in which a poor tenant chooses to live. The size of the voucher payment is fixed, depending on the tenant's income and the Government's estimate of a fair rent.

title: AUSTRALIA'S BATTLE OF THE TITANS
description: With control of a sprawling newspaper, radio and television empire the prize, two of Australia's most powerful businessmen have become locked in a bitter battle that is likely to transform the country's publishing and broadcasting industries.

title: Many Bridge Fares Are to Rise Again
description: Motorists who use the major crossings of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority should prepare to pay more for the privilege. There will be a public hearing on Monday, but what would be the fifth toll increase since 1980 on the Triborough, Bronx-Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges and the Queens-Midtown and Brooklyn-Battery Tunnels is on the way.

title: Topics: Back to Work; Diet Month
description: January needs no official proclamation to qualify as diet month. December always qualifies as the opposite with its stuffed turkeys, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, frosted cookies shaped like reindeer and Santa Claus, hazelnut tarts, fudge balls, gourmet peanut brittle and the much-maligned fruitcakes.

title: NO UNITY IN UNIFICATION SERIES
description: Since it was formally announced nearly a year ago, Home Box Office's heavyweight unification series has had one after another of the sort of seriocomic vicissitudes that make boxing a delight to fans of chaos.

title: CONFLICT OVER SIGNAL IN TRAIN INQUIRY
description: The engineer of a Conrail freight locomotive that collided with an Amtrak passenger train Sunday testified today under oath that he received a signal that led him to proceed into the path of the speeding liner.

title: From Florida, A Senator of Note
description: As Governor of Florida, Bob Graham was on a trade mission to Brazil, flying from Brasilia to Rio de Janeiro, when the airplane suddenly began losing hydraulic pressure.

title: India Replies To Carbide
description: The Indian Government charged today that the Union Carbide Corporation was aware of a potential disaster before the gas leak disaster at Bhopal, but failed to design its plant there to safeguard against it.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT CURBS DONATIONS
description: The State Department announced today that it had sent a message to all posts barring them from accepting private donations for embassy entertainment costs.

title: Dark Days of Post-World War II Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor:

title: Kaiser Steel Settles With Shareholders
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that Bruce E. Hendry, a Minneapolis investor, would be elected chairman and chief executive of the company as part of a settlement between Kaiser's management and a dissident group of preferred shareholders.

title: CENTURY CLUB GROUPS OPPOSE ANTI-BIAS PACT
description: Despite an agreement with the city that paves the way for the admission of women to the Century Association, two groups at the all-male club are exploring ways for it to remain outside the jurisdiction of the local human-rights law.

title: Mario Hare, Gary Tortoise
description: I used to think that Mario Cuomo was the most likely person to get the 1988 Democratic nomination. Accordingly, I put in a few zaps in this space about his avoidance of foreign affairs issues, which, after all, are kind of central to a campaign for leader of the free world.

title: SOVIET, WITH DISOUNTS, GOES INTO SPACE BUSINESS
description: The Soviet Union has embarked on an international sales campaign to entice nations to send their satellites into space on Soviet rockets.

title: It'll Have to Be Off Broadway
description: With Mayor Koch steadfast in his refusal to authorize a ticker-tape parade in the event of a Super Bowl victory by those he has taken to calling the New Jersey Giants, Governor Kean is savoring the prospect of filling the publicity vacuum.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transposing of captions, two photographs in the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday were incorrectly identified.

title: Test Airplane Back Home
description: The two Voyager pilots, Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager, flew their experimental aircraft for what might be the last time Tueday when they returned to their home base. About 500 spectators cheered as the Voyager touched down at Mojave Airport, 20 miles north of Edwards Air Force Base, where their record-setting nine-day flight ended Dec. 23. Project officials hope that Voyager, the first aircraft to fly nonstop around the world on a single load of fuel, will become part of the aviation collection at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: CONCERT: BRASS QUINTET AT MERKIN
description: THE members of the Saturday Brass Quintet selected an unusually appealing program of works for the group's Tuesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall. Most of the music was unknown, with Bach's ''Little'' Fugue in G minor the only genuine warhorse. Yet there was nothing radical about the evening; the rare and contemporary works were played in a spirit of friendly inquest, rather than one of evangelical fury.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Sports Today
description: BOXING MICHAEL OLAJIDE VS. RICHARD BURTON, 12 rounds for the Continental Americas middleweight title, at Felt Forum, 1st bout at 7:30 (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: MONY Tournament of Champions, La Costa Country Club, Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Worthy Women
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Atheism and Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Surplus Up in Taiwan
description: Taiwan's trade surplus jumped 50 percent, to a record $15.62 billion, in 1986, the Taiwanese Government reported today. In the first nine months of 1986, its surplus with the United States alone topped $10 billion.

title: COMEDY: 4 ACTS IN 5 HOURS
description: UNTIL this month, the Ballroom, the midtown cabaret that regularly features musicians like Blossom Dearie, Larry Adler and Karen Akers, presented very little comedy. But that has changed with the introduction of four comedy acts that will appear at the club, at 253 West 28th Street, on a rotating basis through the end of this month. At a five-hour marathon on Tuesday, all four acts - Collins and Friedman, Steven Hayes, Leigh Clark, and Artificial Intelligence -performed complete shows. The high level of humor, most of it character comedy, turned a potentially exhausting evening into an exhilarating immersion in laughter.

title: Student Loan Debt Financing
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association is planning to sell in the United States debt market $100 million (New Zealand currency) of 16.85 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: NEW LEBANON ALLIES: CHRISTIANS AND THE P.L.O.
description: Lebanese politics has always been renowned for its upredictable shifting alliances, but the latest marriage of convenience in Beirut is perhaps the most startling of all: The Christian Phalangist militia in Lebanon has forged an alliance with Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: PRETORIA TERMS SCHOOL ROLLS 'ENCOURAGING' AFTER BOYCOTTS
description: The authorities said today that enrollment in the nation's segregated black schools was ''very encouraging'' at the start of a new academic year after months of boycotts.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Frank Gansz, coach of the Kansas City special teams, which carried the Chiefs into the playoffs for the first time in 15 years, resigned yesterday. Gansz, 48, said that he had accomplished all he could as a special-teams coach and that he wanted to become an offensive coordinator as a stepping stone to being considered for a head coaching job. . . . The Atlantic 10 Conference has suspended Bonzie Colson, a sophomore center for the University of Rhode Island, for two games for starting a fight in a game against Temple last Saturday in Kingston, R.I.

title: New York Ballet Contest Sets Entry Deadline
description: The New York International Ballet Competition has set Jan. 31 as the deadline for applications to take part in the event, which will be held at the City Center theater from June 8 to 29.

title: Money III
description: Somewhat belatedly, but just in time for Christmas, 51 of the 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in Iran recently received special pay bonuses voted by Congress. One hostage was not a Government employee and thus was not eligible.

title: Lawyer Seeks to Bar Statements by Youth
description: A lawyer for one of the white youths arrested in the Howard Beach, Queens, assault said yesterday that if his client was indicted, the attorney would seek to prevent the prosecution from using incriminating statements the youth reportedly made to a detective and a prosecutor.

title: Shultz Confirms Funds From Brunei Vanished
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz confirmed today that a large sum of money, reported to be $10 million, from the Sultan of Brunei had disappeared.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Gemcraft Inc., Houston, a home-building concern, announced that John C. Poss had joined the company in the new position of senior vice president of corporate development. It also appointed as directors Judy Neal Stubbs, active in civic affairs in Dallas, and Clarence C. Comer, president of Southdown Inc. M

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KENTUCKY STREAK HALTED BY ALABAMA
description: Derrick McKey scored 25 points and Jim Farmer 22 as Alabama snapped Kentucky's 24-game winning streak in Rupp Arena by beating the Wildcats, 69-55, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from replacement of a pension plan for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain from partial settlement of an insurance claim of $1.2 million, or 7 cents a share. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 28, 1986. The results of Flow Control operations have been included since its acquisition from ITT Corp. on Jan. 31, 1986.

title: FAMILY NEAR SCENE DESCRIBES ATTACK ON BLACKS IN QUEENS
description: A family living close to the scene of the Dec. 20 attack in Howard Beach, Queens, has provided the first independent description of a gang of white youths beating a black man.

title: Casey's Successor: Who Might Pass Muster?
description: Very quietly, inside and outside the White House, a debate has begun about filling one of the most sensitive jobs in Washington: Director of Central Intelligence.

title: U.S. SEEKS INQUIRY IN BREAK-IN AT POLITICAL GROUP
description: Justice Department officials say the department has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation for an inquiry into a burglary last November at the offices of a prominent political group here that opposes the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
PENTAGON SAYS GREEK VESSEL FIRED AT U.S. COPTER
description: The Navy has identified the ship from which a missile was fired at an American helicopter over the Persian Gulf on Monday as a Greek dry cargo vessel, Pentagon officials said today.

title: STUDY OF 1,835 WITH AIDS VIRUS ASSOCIATES TRAITS WITH GETTING ILL
description: A study of men infected with the AIDS virus has identified five traits associated with development of the fatal disorder.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 8, 1987
description: International

title: Door Open for Bosworth
description: Brian Bosworth's football career at the University of Oklahoma may not be finished after all.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $4 million pre-tax charge for a plant shutdown for the quarter and year. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $5.8 million from a pension settlement and an $8.2 million charge for reduction of tax benefit for unrecognized net operating losses. d-Net income e-Includes an investment tax credit of $8 million, a $6.9 million gain for capitalized interest, a $5.1 million gain for liquidation of inventory, and a $5 million pension settlement gain.

title: CUOMO TO APPOINT PANEL ON BIAS-RELATED VIOLENCE
description: Governor Cuomo, reacting to the beating of three black men in Howard Beach, declared today that he would establish a Task Force on Bias-Related Violence to suggest state actions ''to deter bias-directed violence and to address its causes and effects.''

title: Charity Payments Settle Suit
description: The payment of more than $7.6 million to 10 local charities has been completed by two defendants as part of the settlement of a Federal lawsuit in the 1981 skywalk disaster at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here.

title: 'Amerika' Far From Ready
description: Brandon Stoddard, head of ABC's entertainment division, said today that the network's mini-series ''Amerika'' was still being edited and was ''not remotely ready'' to be broadcast although it is scheduled to be televised in less than six weeks.

title: Chairman Is Appointed At Exco International
description: Richard Lacy, who at 39 years of age is the longest-serving employee of Exco International, has been named chairman of the London financial services company.

title: Reinhard A. Hohaus, Ex-Insurance Official
description: Reinhard A. Hohaus, a former insurance executive and an adviser to governmental bodies, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. SAYS N.S.C. WILL FACE CHANGES
description: The National Security Council will undergo major changes under Frank C. Carlucci, the new national security adviser, including a virtual prohibition against covert operations, a senior White House official said today.

title: Money II
description: American wage-earners who have received their first paychecks of the new year may have been pleasantly surprised to find less money withheld for Federal taxes. For most, the pleasure is probably premature. It simply means that the recipient has not yet filled out the complex new W-4 form - the first step in ''simplication'' of the tax structure - that will determine the number of exemptions the employer will use to determine the wage-earner's level of withholding. If the employee has not filled out the form, it is likely that Federal taxes were withheld on the basis of the old number of exemptions. It is equally likely that not enough was withheld. Exemptions under the new system are worth considerably more than under the old, so the amount of income on which withholding is calculated will be substantially less in the new tax code.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BANDITS. By Elmore Leonard. 345 pages. Arbor House. $17.95.

title: H.H. Robertson Stake Rises to 25%
description: A unit of the First City Financial Corporation, a company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, has raised its stake in the H. H. Robertson Company to about 25 percent, or 1.47 million common shares, from 20.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Belzbergs said they bought 302,700 shares of the Pittsburgh-based building products concern for $12 to $12.08 each.

title: Hats Off to These Guys
description: Mike Bossy of the Islanders has scored two goals in each of his last two games, narrowly missing opportunities to close in on the N.H.L.'s career hat-trick leader. Need you ask who that leader is?

title: A Letter From Iacocca
description: A sixth-grader in the Washington suburb of Silver Spring, Md., wrote a letter to Lee Iacocca not long ago in connection with a class project, and, like not a few others, asked the Chrysler chairman if he had any plans to run for President. Mr. Iacocca said no, as he has said repeatedly before, but he concluded with a deft politician's touch that partly explains why he is asked the question in the first place. ''Thanks for writing,'' he said. ''I wish I could type as well as you do. My secretary is going to type this letter for me.''

title: PIANO: ARTHUR GREENE IN RECITAL
description: DANIEL BARENBOIM was to have given the first piano recital in the remodeled Carnegie Hall, but owing to what was reported as a last-minute illness could not take unto himself that honor. The distinction fell instead, willy-nilly, to Arthur Greene, who last year won first prize in the University of Maryland International William Kapell Piano Competition.

title: IRAN SEEN EASING HOSTILITY TO U.S. IN SHIFT OF POLICY ON SUPERPOWERS
description: As they silence their critics of the secret arms deals with the Reagan Administration, Iranian leaders are portraying the United States less as the ''Great Satan'' than a defeated political giant that has finally come to recognize the durability of the Iranian revolution.

title: U.S. SPECIAL ENVOY MEETS WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Richard W. Murphy, met today with King Hussein of Jordan in the first leg of visits to American allies in the region.

title: VETERANS' GROUP ASSAILS U.S. ON FINANCING OF MEDICAL CARE
description: Federal spending on medical care for veterans may be inadequate now, even before President Reagan's proposed cutbacks in service, a report by a veterans' organization said today.

title: ASSESSOR FOR COUNTY DROPS FROM PRIMARY FOR CHICAGO MAYOR
description: Thomas C. Hynes, one of three major candidates running in Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary in February, formally withdrew from that race today.

title: For Jobs That Look Ahead, Not Back
description: The essential flaw in the Reagan Administration's new 1988 budget is that it's too little a budget and too much a bargaining position. To budget is to choose how to divide the pie; the ultimate choices will depend on give-and-take with Congress in the coming months. The Reagan budget nonetheless contains imaginative initiatives. Perhaps the most sensible and humane proposal would consolidate job-training programs for dislocated workers and triple funding to almost $1 billion. This is decent government. It's also smart.

title: REAGAN MAKING EXCELLENT RECOVERY, DOCTORS SAY
description: President Reagan received a clean bill of health today as he prepared to leave the hospital to return to the White House for further recuperation from prostate surgery.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DOW FLIRTS WITH 2,000, THEN DIPS
description: The Dow Jones industrial average zeroed in on the 2,000 mark yesterday, but the historic level proved elusive.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOME FOLKS As a New York City community, Greenwich Village began in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. By 1850 it was home to middle-class and well-to-do Americans. In 1875, with one resident out of three foreign-born, the Village was called the American Ward. Then, Irish, Afro-Americans and Italians moved in, in that order. After 1910 the Village became a refuge for the rebellious, followed by a group designated as ''Bohemian'' and including artists and writers. Recently, as real-estate costs have escalated, the Village has again become a home primarily for the well-to-do.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AMONG the many items that have come to attention in recent months, these should prove of interest to homeowners and do-it-yourselfers: Modular Tool System Anyone starting out in home repair and in need of three of the most widely used portable power tools might be interested in the new Three-In-One Modular Power Tool System from Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FINANCIAL LEGISLATION, PERHAPS
description: The call for financial reform and for new banking industry powers has echoed through the halls of Congress for the last four years. And every year, the predictions of major new legislation have gone unfulfilled.

title: RANGERS RALLY, BUT FALL SHORT
description: Everything in the Rangers' world had been on the rise. New players had been adding glitter. Everyone had been falling into roles. And, as if in celebration of a new day, the fans came out last night to make Madison Square Garden rock.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: QUIET REVELERS
description: Perhaps the eeriest scene in the aftermath of the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel here was played out hours after the fire was put out as midnight arrived to usher in the new year.

title: Talbott Heads Field for Squash
description: Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., has drawn the top-seeded position for the $15,000 Rolex Greenwich Open squash racquets championship, which opens today in Greenwich, Conn.

title: RACIAL DIVISIONS SEEN IN POLL ON HOWARD BEACH ATTACK
description: A third of New Yorkers say that many or almost all whites and blacks in the city dislike each other and that a racial attack such as the one last month in Howard Beach, Queens, could have occurred in their own neighborhoods, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Dec. 16 about the renovation of Carnegie Hall incorrectly identified the head of the company that did the work. He is John L. Tishman, chief executive officer of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $38,700,000 from the sale of real estate, net of certain debt refinancing transactions, for both the quarter and year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $14,600,000 for the quarter and $96,200,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago income from discontinued operations was from the Consumer Industrial Products Group, which was sold in September 1985.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday on the weekly television ratings gave an incorrect date for the last week in which ''The CBS Evening News'' led NBC's ''Nightly News.'' It was the week that ended Dec. 14.

title: STAGE: 'MUSICAL COMEDY MURDERS' AT CIRCLE REP
description: AS a backstage comedy-thriller with Hollywood overtones, ''The Musical Comedy Murders of 1940'' is a decided change of pace for the Circle Repertory Company, where the show opened last night. The new John Bishop play is a kind of crossbreeding of Charles Ludlam (''The Mystery of Irma Vep'') and Terrence McNally (''It's Only a Play''), seasoned with a soupcon of ''Noises Off.'' But in contrast to those comedies, it lacks both satiric specificity and biting wit. The show is also littered with excessively red herrings, but, bearing with the contrivances, it does provoke laughter, especially in the second act -and it offers elbow room for actors' antics.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 23, 1986. The latest third quarter and 9 months results include the operations of Converse Inc., from Sept. 8, 1986, and Highland House from Oct. 16, 1986.

title: MYSTERY IN THE OUTBACK: DID A DINGO KILL A BABY?
description: As Ranger Graham Lightbody finishes shepherding tourists around the exotic plant and animal life in the oven-hot red desert in the outback here, he is often confronted with as many questions about a notorious murder case as about the harsh environment.

title: FOR NOW, MANLEY SACKS HIS IMAGE
description: As he stood at the edge of the practice field yesterday, deflecting questions about the Redskins, the Giants and their showdown Sunday in the National Conference championship game, Dexter Manley looked up and saw Coach Joe Gibbs peering out of an office window. ''I feel I got spies on me,'' he said. Manley seemed at once disturbed and amused at the sight of Gibbs, perhaps mindful that the coach has had more than a few reasons over the years to keep an eye on him.

title: ASPIN LOSES POST ON MILITARY PANEL BUT MAY REGAIN IT
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives voted today to depose Representative Les Aspin as chairman of the Armed Services Committee. The vote was 130 to 124.

title: Dukakis Files Court Plea
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis asked the Massachusetts Supreme Court Tuesday to overturn a court order that would raise welfare benefits 30 percent and cost the state about $780 million a year. The state filed a brief asking Justice Francis P. O'Connor to stay the welfare order issued Monday by Judge Charles Grabau of Superior Court. Mr. Dukakis also asked for a prompt review of the order by the full court.

title: Accounts
description: * Adelphia Cable Communications, Coudersport, Pa., to Mullin Advertising, Prides Crossing, Mass.

title: ISLANDERS FRUSTRATE SIMPSON
description: The Islanders, who completed the first half of their season with a 5-3 victory over Minnesota Tuesday night - their first triumph in six games - know their weak points well. They are erratic, and coasting on a reputation they've managed not to tarnish, but certainly have not enhanced.

title: CALENDAR: QUILTING PLUS A BIT OF HISTORY
description: Annual Quilting Bee, the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-427-6000, extension 172.

title: Chase Manhattan
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday began offering $250 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due 1997 at a price of 99.90, to yield 7.89 percent,through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Noncallable for life, the 10-year notes yield 83-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: SYNTHESIZED DRUG EASES KIDNEY ILLS
description: A natural kidney hormone, made synthetically through biotechnology, has cured anemia and eliminated the need for blood transfusions in kidney dialysis patients, two medical reports say.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. PORTLAND TRAILBLAZERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) KNICKS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 8 P.M. (TV - Channel 9 and WTBS, 8 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: MONY Tournament of Champions, La Costa Country Club, Carlsbad, Calif. HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. RANGERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. WOR 710, 7:35 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BOAT SHOW: Javits Center, noon. BOXING: Tommy Ayers vs. Rigoberto Lopez, junior middleweights, 10 rounds; Lupe Aquino vs. Anthony Wiley, junior middleweights, 10 rounds, at Las Vegas (TV - ESPN, 9P.M.) FENCING: Michael Alaux Pan American team trials, at Manhattan College, 3 P.M. HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) SQUASH: Rolex Greenwich Open, at Field Club of Greenwich, 6 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.)

title: NATIONAL COMMUNITY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rod MacDonald
description: The songwriter Rod MacDonald will perform tonight and tomorrow night at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M., with Terri Radigan opening tonight and Megan McDonough tomorrow. There is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: CONTRA CASH LINKED TO NORTH
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North controlled cash and other money for Nicaraguan rebel expenses during two years of secretly overseeing an aid network for them, according to sources in the Administration and the rebels, who are also known as the contras.

title: Addendum
description: The names of the Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy offices in Atlanta, Chicago, Houston and Los Angeles have been changed to Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations.

title: MARS GRAPHIC SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The net income and share earnings for all periods are pro forma.

title: Rare Items on Display At Numismatic Society
description: Rare manuscripts, coins and other items documenting hundreds of years in the history of numismatics will be on view tomorrow through Feb. 21 at the American Numismatic Society, Broadway and 155th Street. The exhibition includes books and papers dating from the 16th century; among them are volumes by the 18th-century writer Joseph Hilarius Eckhel, who is considered by collectors to be the ''father of modern numismatics.''

title: JUDGE OVERTURNS A RULING LIMITING MILK SALES IN CITY
description: A Federal judge held today that a state decision barring a New Jersey dairy from expanding its sales in New York City was unconstitutional. The ruling could mean lower milk prices almost immediately and unravel a powerful group of milk distributors that has dominated the market for more than 50 years.

title: Mr. Reagan's Choice
description: The Reagan Administration's ''well-intentioned effort to find an opening to Iran,'' says Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota, ''met up with a scam and got taken to the cleaners. But . . . it is not a thing by which you topple a Government or tie up Congress for a year.''

title: A GIANT VICTORY: WINNING THE FANS
description: For years, the New York area had a love affair with the football Giants. The Giants seemingly could do no wrong, at least not until they moved to the Jersey Meadowlands in 1976. Then, when their losing ways continued, they seemingly could do no right. Now, as they are about to play a game that could put them into Super Bowl XXI, they seemingly can do no wrong again.

title: CHANGE CONSIDERED IN CONRAIL BRAKES
description: The Federal railroad administrator said today that he might ask that all train engines operating in the Northeast Corridor be equipped with automatic braking systems that could help avoid collisions such as the one that killed 15 people Sunday.

title: FEHR POSTS 67 FOR LEAD
description: Most good rounds of golf include at least one moment when a player salvages par from bogey country. But when a player gets birdies more than once from under the trees, he is going into four leaf clover territory.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $492,000. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary loss of $199,000 for the quarter. The company said sales figures for latest year are up 12 percent over prior-year results.

title: TREASURY CHIEF SAYS REAGAN WON'T AGREE TO INCREASING TAXES
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that President Reagan would not agree to increases in ''sin taxes'' on cigarettes or liquor or an oil import fee.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Vintage Jazz at the Vineyard, Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street (683-0696). The fourth year and seventh season of Vintage Jazz concerts is part of the Vineyard Theater's first Old Wave Festival, made up of one-time avant-garde music that is now rear guard - early music of the 18th century and traditional jazz from the early 20th century. The Vintage Jazz series opens tomorrow evening at 8 with the father-son team of Bucky and John Pizzarelli. Bucky Pizzarelli was a Swing Era guitarist with Vaughan Monroe's orchestra and has been a vitalizing co-leader of groups with the cornetist Ruby Braff and the guitarist George Barnes, as well as the leader of his own trios and duos and a versatile solo performer. John Pizzarelli has followed in his father's footsteps as a guitarist and is also a singer who is part of the forward-looking jazz contingent. The second concert in the series, which will continue through the next two weekends, will be given on Sunday afternoon at 3 by Jordan Sandke and his quartet. Mr. Sandke is in his eighth year as a trumpet player in the Widespread Jazz Orchestra, which draws on big-band jazz of the 1920's and 30's. His program with his group - Jaki Byard on piano, Mark Minkler on bass and Kenny Washington on drums - will include tributes to three landmark trumpet players, Louis Armstrong, Roy Eldridge and Fats Navarro. Tickets for each concert are $15 for a table, which includes a bottle of wine, or $10 for general admission.

title: TEEN-AGER CHARGED IN RACIAL ATTACK IS IMPRISONED IN ANOTHER CASE
description: A 17-year-old charged with being part of the gang of whites that assaulted three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison in a separate case.

title: FRANCE PLAYS DOWN LATEST LIBYAN AIR RAID IN SOUTHERN CHAD
description: France today played down the importance of a Libyan air attack in southern Chad on Wednesday, indicating that it was planning no immediate retaliation.

title: DYNAMICS TAKES A CESSNA WRITE-OFF
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's leading military contractors, said yesterday that it was writing off about $420 million of the $680 million it paid last year for the Cessna Aircraft Company.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE consignment of a late-15th-century work attributed to Botticelli in an Old Masters auction next week at Sotheby's has aroused international interest in the sale and spurred art historians and dealers to ask how much of the painting was actually executed by the Italian artist himself.

title: KNICKS HOPING TO CHANGE TRAVEL HABITS
description: Their hotel rooms are reasonably comfortable with their extra-long, king-sized beds. They fly first class. And the food on the road is often palatable.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Richard Davis-Sir Roland Hanna Quintet, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). The bassist Richard Davis lights a fire under his quintets. His jaunty countermelodies and springy riffs push soloists to take chances and keep the rhythm section jumping; there's a sense of daredevil camaraderie. With Sir Roland Hanna on piano, Cecil Bridgewater on trumpet, Ricky Ford on tenor saxophone and Frederick Waits on drums, Mr. Davis's current quintet promises harmonic sophistication, brawny delivery and fast reflexes. Tonight through Sunday at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Bird Droppings Cited In Closing of a Beach
description: Bacterial pollution that forced the closing of a beach here last summer was caused mainly by droppings from pigeons and starlings roosting on a nearby amusement pier, according to the county health officer.

title: Guarneri String Quartet
description: The Guarneri String Quartet will play works by Beethoven, Shostakovich and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8. The violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick will be the guest artists in a performance of the Sextet No. 2 in G by Brahms. Tickets are $15. Information: 570-3949.

title: TOLL BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago figures are pro forma; the company went public in July 1986.

title: Compromise Is Blessing for Fans
description: The National Football League, mindful of Sunday morning church services - and, in some cases, to conform with local laws - has made it a point not to start regular-season games before 1 P.M. in most cities (though TV requirements frequently cause a noon kickoff in the Central time zone). The N.F.L. thus avoids conflicts with the services, many of which start at 11 A.M.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CONSUL RESTAURANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary gains from early debt extinguishment of $6,452,000 and $6,497,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: HOUSE IGNORES REAGAN TO PASS CLEAN WATER BILL
description: The House of Representatives, ignoring a compromise urged by President Reagan, overwhelmingly passed a Clean Water Bill today that is identical to one he vetoed last year.

title: Too Soon to Grant Iran-Deal Immunity
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND QUEENS BOROUGH HALL, MANES MYSTERY LINGERS
description: What Donald R. Manes did in the seven hours before he was found after his first suicide attempt a year ago is still a mystery. But for many people in Queens, an even greater mystery continues to be Mr. Manes himself.

title: Kidder Unit Offers Mortgage Notes
description: Kidder Peabody Mortgage Assets Trust Three yesterday began offering $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations divided into five parts, one of which bears a floating interest rate. Rated triple-A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the obligations are backed by 9 and 9 1/2 percent Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participation certificates, a kind of mortgage pass-through security.

title: Economic Scene; Symbolism Vs. Reality
description: PETER F. DRUCKER, the Clarke Professor of Social Science at the Claremont Graduate School in California, contends that there has been a basic change in the world economy. The ''real'' economy of goods and services and the ''symbolic'' economy of money, credit and capital are no longer bound tightly to each other, he says, and ''are moving further and further apart.''

title: AIR FORCE SEEKS 3 SPACE TESTS OF NEW ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: The Air Force is asking Congress for permission to conduct three tests of its antisatellite weapon against targets in space beginning in October, Pentagon officials said today.

title: ICAHN ENDS HIS OFFER FOR USX
description: Carl C. Icahn yesterday called off his $8 billion offer to purchase the USX Corporation.

title: 53 FOR JORDAN
description: Michael Jordan scored a regular-season career-high 53 points to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 121-117 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight.

title: Market Place; How 3 Stocks Bounced Back
description: IF they were athletes, they might be given comeback-player-of-the-year awards. For just like a player who is injured, undergoes major surgery and then has a stellar season, the stocks of Colt Industries, the FMC Corporation and Owens-Corning Fiberglas have bounced back with a vengeance.

title: DDB Needham Gets GTE Spacenet Account
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, Washington, has won the GTE Spacenet account, which will add $2.5 million to $3 million in billings to the $50 million in GTE business already at the New York office.

title: STUDY OF EVIDENCE IN PUERTO RICO HOTEL FIRE COMPLETE, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Investigators have completed their examination of the physical evidence of the arson fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, Federal and commonwealth officials said today.

title: HELP FOR REMARRIED FATHERS
description: The problems of remarried fathers often require special attention, according to officials at the Stepfamily Foundation, a nonprofit research and counseling organization in New York.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
VETERANS AGENCY FINED FOR DESTROYING DATA
description: Ruling that the Veterans Administration had unlawfully and ''recklessly'' destroyed thousands of documents, a Federal judge today imposed about $115,000 in penalties against the V.A. The agency had been ordered to produce the documents in a lawsuit by veterans charging that they were exposed to radiation.

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND AND VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said income for the latest 6 months included receipt of a $250,000 insurance claim payment. Year-ago results are restated.

title: BOLCOM SETS BLAKE TO SEVERAL KINDS OF MUSIC
description: ''Could you ask the composer,'' came a voice from among the doublebasses, ''which of these lines he would like us to leave out?''

title: LOBBYING AND CONTRIBUTIONS BY CONSERATIVE FUND-RAISER EVOKE QUESTIONS
description: The Senate's decision this week to look into private fund-raising for the Nicagaguan rebels seems likely to lead the investigation to the doorstep of Carl R. Channell, a highly successful fund-raiser for conservative causes.

title: CRUDE OIL PRICES SPURT; OPEC MOVES ARE CITED
description: Prices of crude oil surged well above $18 a barrel yesterday on world markets, their highest levels since last Jan. 31.

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Acquisitions and Shifts At PSC Publications
description: PSC Publications, the limited partnership whose acquisition of Games magazine from Playboy Enterprises was announced New Year's Eve, also includes Needlecraft for Today and Needle Thread magazines, acquired from the Happy Hands Publishing Company of Fort Worth, according to Jerry Calabrese, Games publisher and one of the general partners.

title: LIMITED RUN FOR WILSON PLAY
description: The Circle Repertory Company production of ''Burn This!,'' a new play by Lanford Wilson, starring John Malkovich, will play only 21 performances when it opens next month because of a film commitment by Mr. Malkovich, the company said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Sony Corporation of America agreed to pay the Government $1.75 million to settle claims it provided inaccurate prices on audio and video broadcast equipment sold to the Government between 1980 and 1984, the Justice Department said. The department charged that Sony, based in Park Ridge, N.J., had failed to fully disclose the discounts it was offering other customers and did not pass on to Federal purchasers price cuts available to Sony's commercial customers.

title: Define a 'Good' Leader
description: Excerpts from ''The Moral Aspect of Leadership,'' the fifth in a series of papers prepared for the Leadership Studies Program in Washington, by John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, former chairman of the National Urban Coalition and former president of the Carnegie Corporation and the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching:

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KAPPA NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago results include financial data of the company's Polyphase Instruments Co. division for the eight- month period from Jan. 30, 1985, the date of acquisition.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
MOSCOW TRIES A NEW LULLABY: HEAVY METAL ROCK
description: A leading Soviet jazz-rock composer today extolled the virtues of heavy-metal rock music as a way for young working-class Russians to work out their resentment toward more affluent members of Soviet society.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 4 WORKS
description: THE New York City Ballet celebrated the pleasures of conviviality in three of the four works it offered Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FISCAL EXPERTS TO LOOK AT NBC NEWS OPERATION
description: On the third floor of NBC's headquarters on the Avenue of the Americas, just down the hall from where Tom Brokaw delivers his ''NBC Nightly News'' broadcast, a small team of analysts is preparing for a special new assignment. They are not journalists, but management consultants; their assignment is to help NBC News adjust to broadcasting's new fiscal age.

title: Sales of Corporate Bonds Soar
description: Interest rates for Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, as investor demand was focused on a large supply of new corporate debt issues.

title: CUOMO FAULTS ESPLANADE PLAN
description: After reaching a last-minute compromise, a state panel yesterday unanimously recommended that a six-lane roadway and adjoining esplanade be constructed along the Hudson River from the Battery at the lower tip of Manhattan to 59th Street.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAYS CONTRAS CAN FELL SANDINISTAS
description: The Reagan Administration's top official on Latin American affairs predicted today that if Congress keeps supplying military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Soviet-backed Sandinista Government ''will not survive.''

title: HUNTER AIMED AT JET'S PILOT, F.B.I. SAYS IN COURT PAPERS
description: An unemployed construction worker charged with shooting at a United Airlines jet here last week said he was aiming for the pilot, an informer said in court documents released Wednesday.

title: BENNETT OFFICIALLY BACKED FOR HOUSE MILITARY POST
description: Representative Charles E. Bennett of Florida, the second most senior Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee, today became the House Democratic leadership's official candidate to become chairman of the committee.

title: Sulfite to Be Listed on Labels
description: Meat and poultry processors will have to list sulfiting agents on labels when products contain confirmable levels of the chemicals, beginning on July 9, the Agriculture Department announced Wednesday.

title: BRONCOS SOLIDIFIED BY OFFENSIVE LINE
description: Keith Bishop, Bill Bryan and Paul Howard, left guard, center and right guard, respectively, have for years been the heart of the Denver Broncos' offensive line, one of the National Football League's best.

title: Mexico Oil Sales Falter
description: Mexico's oil sales fell nearly 60 percent in the first eight months of 1986 from a year earlier, the planning and budget department said Wednesday. Mexico received nearly $3.56 billion from oil sales in the period in 1986, compared with $8.71 billion the year before. And President Miguel de la Madrid said in a message to the nation that Mexico, despite its economic troubles, avoided ''what could have been a really chaotic situation.'' Still, he said, tumbling oil prices and foreign debt hurt production and employment.

title: COLECO SEES LOSSES IN QUARTER AND '86
description: Coleco Industries, the company behind the popular Cabbage Patch Kids, said yesterday that it expected ''very large'' yearly and fourth-quarter losses, citing a continuing decline in sales of the dolls.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A television review in some copies Tuesday of ''Do Not Enter: The Visa War Against Ideas'' omitted the name of a co-producer. The documentary was produced by Robert Richter and Catherine Warnow.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in September.

title: Bears Up for Grammy
description: The Chicago Bears, who cut a record before winning last year's Super Bowl, can set a record this year by becoming the first pro football team to win a Grammy award. The Bears' ''Shufflin' Crew'' - which features Jim McMahon, William Perry and Walter Payton, among others -has been nominated for best vocal recording by a rhythm and blues group. Their song, ''The Super Bowl Shuffle,'' was a rap record. Other nominees in the Bears' category include ''Kiss'' by Prince and the Revolution and ''Promise'' by Sade. The winners will be announced Feb. 24.

title: INSIDE
description: House Passes Water Bill With votes to spare to override any new veto, the House passed a Clean Water Bill identical to the one vetoed last year. Page A14. Ward Renews Attack The Police Commissioner renewed his criticism of Alton H. Maddox Jr., who says the police are covering up the Howard Beach attack. Page B5. Guidry and Yankees Part The midnight deadline passed for Ron guidry, the star pitcher, to sign as a free agent, effectively ending his 10-year Yankee carreer. Page A17. Pretoria Bars Reporters South Africa has ordered the bureau chief of The New York Times to leave the country and refused a visa to his designated successor. Page A3.

title: Couldn't 'Mona Lisa' Just Stay a Mystery?
description: To the Editor:

title: REDMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
CONCERT: ERICH LEINSDORF LEADS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: ERICH LEINSDORF is a perplexing conductor in many ways, but he knows how to put together uncommonly interesting programs. As a guest, he also has the rare ability on short notice to make a symphony orchestra sound like a symphony orchestra rather than a collection of talented instrumentalists. Mr. Leinsdorf's appearance at the head of the New York Philharmonic last evening testified so strongly to those good qualities that one was tempted, as often in the past, to overlook certain drawbacks in his performance.

title: Law Protects Privacy of Victim's Diary in Central Park Killing
description: To the Editor:

title: Beethoven Society
description: The Beethoven Society will present a chamber-music program featuring the pianist Lilian Kallir, the violinist Peter Oundjian and the cellist Leslie Parnas in familiar and unfamiliar works by Beethoven at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow afternoon at 3. Tickets are $15. Information: 362-1911.

title: U.S. SAYS SOUTH AFRICA REBELS ARE OBLIGATED TO COMMUNISTS
description: The State Department said in a confidential report delivered to Congress today that the African National Congress was deeply obligated to Moscow and the South African Communist Party for military assistance in waging guerrilla warfare against the Pretoria Government.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with a poll on race relations in New York City misidentified its sponsors. Also, in some copies it incorrectly reported results of a question about Mayor Koch's handling of the situation that began with an attack on three black men in Queens last month. The survey was a New York Times/WCBS-TV Poll; the correct results of the question about Mayor Koch appear today on page B2.

title: Dole Hits the Road
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has not yet announced his candidacy for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, but he is making what looks very much like a national campaign trip this weekend. Senator Larry Pressler of South Dakota, who just announced his support of Senator Dole, has invited him to tour his home state, which will hold its Presidential primary on Feb. 23 next year, a week after New Hampshire's primary and eight days after Iowa's caucuses. The two Republicans will arrive in Pierre Saturday to attend the inauguration of Gov. George S. Mickelson and will visit Rapid City and Sioux Falls on Sunday and Monday. Mr. Pressler plans to urge his constituents to back Senator Dole in the 1988 primary.

title: STRATEGIC PLANNING ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company went public Dec. 1.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: KITCHO is not a name that is bandied about often when gastronomic commandos huddle to swap intelligence reports on hot spots in the field. This 20-year-old midtown Japanese restaurant is about as chic as a Honda Civic, notable more for its longevity than its luster. Its formula for graceful aging is unglamorous and straightforward: a warm and efficient staff combined with dependably fresh and attractive Japanese food.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ex-U.S. Comptroller Rejoining Edgar, Dunn
description: Edgar, Dunn & Company, a management consulting firm based in San Francisco, has rehired C. Todd Conover, former Comptroller of the Currency, and will change its name back to Edgar, Dunn & Conover Inc.

title: Dining Out Guide; Hearty Fare
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AKBAR, #475 Park Avenue, near 57th

title: Choice Dates No Help as Hialeah Opens
description: The flamingos were on their infield island, the parrots were in their aviary, the horses were on the track. As usual, all that was missing from opening day of Hialeah Park were the horseplayers of seasons past.

title: THEATER: 'CRIME AND PUNISHMENT'
description: When Raskolnikov, the lapsed student turned ax murderer, is consumed by delirium in the director Yuri Lyubimov's adaptation of ''Crime and Punishment,'' he doesn't merely sulk or weep - he becomes almost literally unhinged. Raskolnikov (Randle Mell) stands against the blood-smeared white door of the scene of his crime and writhes in pain as if crucified. A slender vertical bar of light seems to pin him there, and just as the agony reaches breaking point, the door tears away from its frame and sends the still-squirming Raskolnikov hurtling with it across the blackened stage. Like a passenger on a grotesque amusement-park ride, Raskolnikov finds other terrors awaiting - eerie echoes, more swinging doors, anonymous phantoms of the psychic underground. But for him, there's no sunlight at the end of the tunnel, no exit from the nightmare of guilt.

title: THE THEATER: 'SWEET SUE,' WITH MOORE AND REDGRAVE
description: AS an articulate theatrical chronicler of WASP manners and mating habits, A. R. Gurney Jr. specializes in richly populated and furnished interior landscapes. The playwright is at his most artful when he invents an apparatus as premise - the dining room as an unchangeable environment for multi-generational maneuverings; a ''party critic'' who reviews a social gathering as emblematic of a way of life. However, in Mr. Gurney's new play, ''Sweet Sue,'' which opened last night at the Music Box Theater, the idea is simply an exercise in artifice.

title: MILLION-DOLLAR RESIDENCES IN A POLICE-HEADQUARTERS
description: Moving into a gymnasium where New York policemen once dribbled basketballs may not immediately appeal to apartment seekers who can afford more than $1 million for a cooperative - especially when the gym is in a building in Little Italy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cincinnati Reds have traded Eddie Milner, an outfielder, to the San Francisco Giants for Frank Williams, a relief pitcher, and two minor-league pitchers. Milner, 31 years old, hit .259 with a career-high 15 home runs and 47 runs batted in last season, but was unhappy about sharing center field with Eric Davis for the second consecutive season, and had sought a trade. . . . Tim Richmond, who led Nascar drivers in victories last year with seven, is expected to miss a good part of this year's early schedule, including the Daytona 500 on Feb. 15. Richmond, 31 years old, may need four months to regain his stamina after suffering from a life-threatening bout with pneumonia. . . . Pierre Larouche, who was benched Wednesday night because of a slump and after he flagrantly disregarded the coach's instructions during a practice Tuesday, will be back in the lineup at Madison Square Garden tonight for the game with the Islanders. . . . Buddy Alexander of Baton Rouge, coach of the men's golf team at Louisiana State and winner of the United States Amateur last year, has been ranked first among amateurs by Golf Digest magazine. Leslie Shannon of Hialeah, Fla., winner of four events last year, was ranked as the top woman amateur, and Bob Rawlings of Dallas the top senior.

title: Nielsen To Drop Diaries
description: THE A.C. Nielsen Company announced yesterday that it was dropping its long-used but questionable diary system of evaluating TV audience composition in favor of the recently developed ''people meter.''

title: OLD DOMINION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $283,000 for the quarter and $391,000 for the year.

title: Military Pressures In Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * John Slaven has joined Scali, McCabe, Sloves as senior vice president.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER CALLS FOR WIDENING OF 'ARMED ATTACKS'
description: Oliver Tambo, president of the African National Congress, called today on South African blacks to widen their struggle against apartheid beyond their townships to include attacks on strategic targets in white-controlled towns and cities.

title: BISHOP URGES EASED ZONING FOR L.I. HOMES
description: In a sweeping pastoral letter on affordable housing, the Bishop of Long Island's Roman Catholic Diocese today urged that two-family houses be permitted throughout Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lorimar Cuts TV Deal Price
description: In a move reflecting the weak conditions in the independent television market, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said today that it had cut the price it would pay for WPGH-TV in Pittsburgh to $21.25 million, from $35 million.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 5
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $26,000 for the quarter and $156,000 for the 6 months.

title: 3 YOUTHS SEIZED IN FATAL ATTACK ON FRENCHMAN
description: Three Brooklyn teen-agers were charged yesterday with the robbery and murder of a 71-year-old French tourist attacked while walking to Times Square to join the New Year's Eve celebration, the police said.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 377 money market mutual funds increased $2.8 billion, to $234.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $1.46 billion, to $65.43 billion. Assets of the 194 general purpose funds were down $1.04 billion, to $62.9 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds were up $2.38 billion, to $106.41 billion.

title: Composers Orchestra
description: Dennis Russell Davies will conduct the American Composers Orchestra in the New York premieres of works by Duke Ellington, William Bolcom, Francis Thorne and John Adams Sunday afternoon at 3 at Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $9 to $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
1924 'THIEF OF BAGDAD' ON CHANNEL 13'S SILENTS
description: OVER the last year, Exxon has been on a cost-cutting binge and, among other things, has begun pulling out of its longtime underwriting commitment to ''Great Performances'' on public television. As a result, that series is apparently looking for less expensive projects and acquisitions.
