A sample of what the future may hold can be found in ''The Silents,'' described as a new ''subseries'' and having its premiere on Channel 13 at 9 this evening (and rebroadcast on Sunday at 2 P.M. on the same channel). In effect, television is turning once again to old movies for programming help.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I GO to hear Michael everywhere he plays - here, in Washington, in London. To be a groupie at my age is pretty funny.'' So spoke Shana Alexander at Michael Feinstein's opening Tuesday in the Algonquin Hotel's Oak Room. Her feelings spring from having known the singer-pianist since he was a teen-ager, but her enthusiasm is not unique. An informal survey of cabarets around town turned up groupies of all ages who go to applaud their favorite performers wherever they appear.

title: NEBRASKA, IN NEW PAGE TO HISTORY, INSTALLS WOMAN
description: The nation's first woman to become a Republican governor, Kay A. Orr, was inaugurated today, bringing a surge of excitement to this wintry prairie town.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FRENCH FILM SERIES AT MODERN ART MUSEUM
description: The Museum of Modern Art is opening a film series today showcasing French movies made from 1955 to 1965 - the decade that marked the French cinema's great resurgence. The series features films by then-newcomers Jean-Luc Godard, Francois Truffaut and Alain Resnais, as well as by film makers who were already established, such as Henri-Georges Clouzot, Rene Clement adn Robert Bresson.

title: U.S. WANTS TO TURN INDIAN SCHOOLS OVER TO STATES OR TRIBES
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs said today that it wanted to turn over responsibility for Indian schools to state governments or tribes and to require Indian welfare recipients to work in return for the assistance they get from the Government.

title: KEY MODERN ART COLLECTION DONATED TO NATIONAL GALLERY
description: A major collection of postwar modern art belonging to Robert and Jane Meyerhoff of Phoenix, Md., will be given to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the museum announced yesterday.

title: Michel Camilo
description: The keyboardist Michel Camilo will lead his trio tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets are at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a three-drink minimum.

title: ONCOGENE SCIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: c-Net loss

title: AFRICAN STUDENTS IN BEIJING MARCH IN OUTRAGE AT A RACIAL SLUR
description: About 200 chanting African university students, reacting to a racial provocation, marched more than 12 miles across Beijing from their campuses to the capital's embassy district today to protest an apparently fraudulent letter slurring their behavior and manners.

title: THRIFT UNIT INDICTMENT
description: Allan H. Pearlstein, one of the principal shareholders of Old Court Savings and Loan Inc., was indicted today by a city grand jury on six counts of felony theft from the defunct thrift institution. The indictment accuses Mr. Pearlstein, 56 years old, of stealing $695,786 from Old Court and ''related entities'' from August 1983 through October 1984.

title: OUTDOORS
description: Although the casual angler in the Northeast puts his gear away before October is done, there are some dedicated fishermen who regard winter as simply another season, albeit often uncomfortable, in which to pursue their sport.

title: Diner's Journal
description: BEIGNETS, the deep-fried pastry fritters that are synonymous with the French Quarter of New Orleans, were not what I had in mind when I dropped into Patisserie Lanciani on Prince Street late one evening, still hungry after a woebegone dinner in a tragically chic SoHo restaurant. This pleasantly minimalist cafe and carryout, with gray walls and scattered Formica tables, offers a dazzling array of desserts and drinks, four pages' worth.

title: MAN WITH AIDS IS DENIED A WEDDING AT ST. PATRICK'S
description: The rector of Saint Patrick's Cathedral has refused to perform a religious marriage ceremony for a man dying of AIDS who wanted to renew the civil-marriage vows he made to his wife three years ago.

title: New President At WABC-TV
description: Walter C. Liss Jr. has been named president and general manager of WABC-TV in New York, the flagship station of Capital Cities/American Broadcasting Companies.

title: SHUTTLE'S DEBRIS IS STORED IN SILOS
description: Almost a year after the Challenger space shuttle disaster, workers at Cape Canaveral yesterday began storing the wreckage in two abandoned missile silo complexes that will be the permanent resting place for the remains of the worst accident in the nation's spacefaring history.

title: A SAMPLER OF DANCE WITH VERVE AND VISION
description: ONE of the pleasures of the annual Joyce Sampler program at the Joyce Theater is that it offers the chance to see a wide variety of choreographic styles in a relatively concentrated form. This weekend the program, which runs through Jan. 18, features Ze'eva Cohen and Dancers tonight and Sunday night, the Eleo Pomare Dance Company and Remy Charlip Dances tomorrow afternoon and evening, respectively, and Marta Renzi and the Project Company on Sunday afternoon. Each choreographer has a distinctive style. But, interestingly, the four choreographers make dances that refer fairly specifically to the world in which they live.

title: BEHIND WALL STREET'S SURGE
description: Most economic forecasters kicked off 1987 with a promise that it would be another year of decidedly unexciting economic growth. It has turned out to be a promise that the stock market, so far at least, seems to be irreverently ignoring.

title: FRICK AWAITS NEW DIRECTOR
description: There's a widespread belief that things never change at the Frick Collection. But they do, albeit slowly. In June, Charles Ryskamp, for 17 years director of the Morgan Library, will replace Everett Fahy as the Frick's director. Mr. Fahy, who has headed the Frick since 1973, will become chairman of the department of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: PHIL SEGHI
description: Phil Seghi, who hired Frank Robinson as baseball's first black manager with Cleveland in 1975 and signed Pete Rose for the Cincinnati Reds in 1960, died today in Thousand Oaks, Calif., after a long illness with cancer. He was 68 years old.

title: Target Publishing
description: Target Publishing Resources of New York will bring out a special newspaper supplement on May 17 called ''We the People . . .'' to mark the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution. In addition to carrying the entire text of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, as well as a calendar of bicentennial events of national importance, the supplement will carry advertising. A four-color page with no bleed charge is going for $49,500. The publication, to appear on the first day of National Tourism Week, will run in The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, with a total circulation of 2.5 million.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ART: 2 LOOKS AT CLEVE GRAY'S WORKS
description: CLEVE GRAY has had anything but a black and white career. As a student at Princeton, he studied Chinese art with the noted scholar George Rowley. In Paris after World War II, he studied painting with Andre Lhote and Jacques Villon, two painters passionate about structure whose work reflects the glory and decline of the School of Paris. In the United States in the 50's, when Abstract Expressionism seemed to have stolen the creative fire from Europe, Gray shifted from composition to gesture, and from figuration to abstraction. In the 1960's he was a contributing editor of Art in America. Between 1968 and 1971 he edited books on David Smith, Hans Richter and John Marin. He has traveled extensively in Asia, North Africa and Europe.

title: South Africa Tightens Curbs on Newspapers
description: The South African Police issued an order today under emergency regulations banning newspapers from publishing reports or advertisements that improve the image or defend the policies of banned organizations.

title: BROADWAY
description: MARTHA CLARKE followed her successful ''Garden of Earthly Delights'' with the even more successful ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' and now she's aiming for a triple play. ''The Hunger Artist,'' a new music-theater-dance piece she's conceived and is directing, will be presented by the Music-Theater Group beginning Feb. 3.

title: Wishful Thinking
description: Coach Buddy Ryan, whose Philadelphia Eagles don't select until ninth in the college draft, on why they nonetheless have a shot at quirky Brian Bosworth: ''Really, what I'm hoping is that enough people think there's something wrong with him that he's still there when we pick.''

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Mitsubishi Motor
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America will become the first Japanese company to sell South Korean cars in the United States when it begins importing 1,500 cars made by the Hyundai Motor Company in early spring. Mitsubishi Motor, a subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, will import and sell 30,000 Hyundai Excels annually under the name of Precis. The price will be about $5,000, according to a spokesman. He said sales of Mitsubishi-built cars in America would not be affected by the plan.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER TELLS OF DESIRE TO KEEP BABY
description: Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother of Baby M, said in tears today that she was powerless to overcome her desire to keep the child, even though she had planned to surrender the baby to her natural father until the moment of birth.

title: Where Are They Now?
description: An update on the starters who lost to the Chicago Bears, 14-10, in the N.F.L. title game of 1963, the last time the Giants played for a championship: *4*OFFENSE Pos. Ex-Player Age Current Vocation LE Del Shofner 52 Buys and sells feed ingredients in San Marino, Calif. LT Roosevelt Brown 54 Scouts for the Giants and lives in Teaneck, N.J. LG Darrell Dess 51 Works for the parks department in New Castle, Pa. C Greg Larson 47 Operates sporting goods company in Nisswa, Minn. RG Bookie Bolin 46 Land development salesman in Angleton, Tex. RT Jack Stroud 58 A New York stockbroker. RE Joe Walton 51 Head coach of the Jets. QB Y.A. Tittle 60 Insurance executive in Palo Alto, Calif. FL Frank Gifford 55 New York-based broadcaster for ABC Sports. HB Phil King -- Died in January 1973, at age 36, in gun accident. FB Joe Morrison 49 Head football coach at University of South Carolina. K-P Don Chandler 52 Real estate developer in Tulsa, Okla. *4*DEFENSE Pos. Ex-Player Age Current Vocation LE Jim Katcavage 52 Scouts for the Giants and lives in Maple Glen, Pa. LT Dick Modzelewski 55 Defensive coordinator for the Green Bay Packers. RT John LoVetere 50 Calling all cars: Nobody in the N.F.L. seems to know. RE Andy Robustelli 61 Operates a travel business in Stamford, Conn. LLB Jerry Hillebrand 46 Runs an insurance agency in Davenport, Iowa. MLB Sam Huff 52 Redskin broadcaster and hotel executive. RLB Tom Scott 55 Works in life insurance and lives in Wilton, Conn. LHB Erich Barnes 47 Works in public relations and lives in Yonkers. RHB Dick Lynch 50 Giant radio broadcaster and New York bond broker. S Dick Pesonen 48 Executive for a trucking company in Orlando, Fla. S Jimmy Patton -- Died in auto accident, at age 39, in December 1972.

title: BERNICE A. ARTHUR
description: Bernice A. Arthur, chief of staff of the Traffic Control Division of the Department of Transportation Bureau of Traffic Operations, died Sunday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx after a brief illness. She was 55 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $515,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss The company said the year-ago first quarter loss was after expenses involved in the transition to its new 16- BIT product line.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DEPOSED PANEL CHIEF ASSAILS SPEAKER OF ASSEMBLY
description: The former chairman of one of the State Legislature's most powerful committees has attacked the new Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, for ousting him from the post in an act of retaliation.

title: Givenchy to Rogers
description: Danskins bodywear and Pennaco hosiery are what Esmark Apparel is made of. Givenchy and Round the Clock brands make up Pennaco. Givenchy, previously handled in-house, is now going to Peter Rogers Associates with its $1 million budget.

title: REAGAN BACK AT WHITE HOUSE, SAYING 'I FEEL GREAT'
description: Beaming and waving, President Reagan left the hospital today facing a gradual resumption of White House duties that aides hope will not become overburdened by the Iran arms affair.

title: STRIKES FORCE CHIRAC TO DROP TRIP
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac called off a visit to Canada today as strikes left large areas of France without power and put new pressure on his conservative Government.

title: Investors Buy Control Of Entrepreneur Group
description: The majority ownership of Entrepreneur magazine, which frequently covers the franchising industry, has just been bought by three men in the business themselves. They are Barry Rupp, Peter Shea and Reinhold Pfahler, who run Stained Glass Overlay of Costa Mesa, Calif., a franchiser of 300 window-treatment product retailers.

title: NEEDIEST AID GIVEN TO HELP POOR IN CITY
description: Several contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases have said the city's great wealth makes the poverty in which many fund recipients live particularly outrageous.

title: GUIDRY PARTS WITH YANKESS, BUT RANDOLPH RE-SIGNS
description: Ron Guidry, the anchor of the Yankees' pitching staff for 10 years, failed to reach agreement on a new contract by last night's midnight signing deadline, effectively ending his glittering Yankee career in a negotiation that his agent called ''embarrassing and humiliating'' and that concluded with the two sides only $50,000 apart. However, Willie Randolph, the team's other co-captain, agreed to a two-year, $1.75 million contract minutes before the deadline.

title: GEOKINETICS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said of the latest year total loss, $1,220,579 was due to dissolution of the Seep Ridge joint venture with Gilbert Shale Oil Co.

title: THE REV. SAMUEL DAVIS
description: The Rev. Samuel Davis, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., from 1941 until 1978, died Wednesday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in retirement in East Hampton.

title: Y Chamber Symphony
description: Yan Pascal Tortelier will lead the Y Chamber Symphony in a program of works by Dukas, Saint-Saens, Faure and Gounod at the 92d Street Y tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3. Bella Davidovich will be the soloist in Saint-Saens's Piano Concerto No. 2. Tickets are $13 and $15. The 92d Street Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue; information: 995-1100.

title: RICHMOND SURGE DUMPS NAVY, 64-62
description: David Robinson, plagued by foul trouble, was held to 8 points tonight and Richmond scored the game's final 13 points to upset Navy, 64-62.

title: Sumitomo Unit Settles Suit
description: The Sumitomo Corporation of America settled a sex discrimination suit yesterday, agreeing to train and promote women for management and sales positions. But Sumitomo, a unit of a giant Japanese trading company, said the settlement preserved its ''right to give preference to Japanese nationals,'' usually men, in filling a few top jobs.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERANTIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' results include one month of the operations of the Ramis and UFO software products business purchased from Martin Marietta in late October.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary tax benefits of $271,000 for the quarter and $422,000 for the 6 months.

title: Subaru Follows Form To Promote New Model
description: Since late 1985 the words to live by for the creation of Subaru advertising, according to David L. Sippel, vice president of marketing, have been ''humanity with humor in a quality package.''

title: 9TH GRADER DIES DURING STRUGGLE TO KEEP JACKET
description: A ninth grader was killed Wednesday as he fought to prevent the theft of his leather jacket, and three juveniles have been charged with homicide, the police said today.

title: PRESSURE AGAINST FRANC PERSISTS AS MARK SOARS
description: The franc remained under strong downward pressure today, but both France and West Germany continued to resist the idea of realigning their currencies.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Greek Celebration
description: The World Music Institute (206-1050) will celebrate its second anniversary with Greek music, food and dancing in a party Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street. Admission is $15.

title: 'Battaglia di Legnano'
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York, under the direction of Eve Queler, will present a concert performance of Verdi's ''Battaglia di Legnano'' at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts tonight at 8. The cast will include Eva Baraian, Gregory Hopkins and Carlos Serrano. Tickets are $11 to $15. Lehman Center is on the campus of Lehman College on Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue in the northwest Bronx, a short walk from the Bedford Park subway stops of the IND D train and IRT No. 4. Information: 960-8833.

title: REPORTER TO BE TRIED FOR CONTEMPT FOR REFUSING TO TESTIFY IN MURDER
description: A Maine judge today charged a New Hampshire newspaper reporter with contempt of court for refusing to testify in a murder trial here.

title: WARD RENEWS ATTACK ON LAWYER IN BEATING CASE
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday renewed his criticism of a lawyer for one of three black men attacked by white teen-agers in a racial incident Dec. 20 in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: TURK MURPHY TO PERFORM AT CARNEGIE
description: TURK MURPHY, a founding father of the traditional jazz revival that exploded in the San Francisco area in the 1940's - and the only key figure of the movement who still leads a band playing the music of that revival -will bring his group to Carnegie Hall tomorrow night. This is not only Mr. Murphy's first New York engagement in more than a quarter of a century; it is also his Carnegie Hall debut.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS TIMES CORRESPONDENTS
description: The South African authorities have refused to reconsider an order to the Johannesburg bureau chief of The New York Times to leave the country before Sunday. They have also refused a visa to his designated successor.

title: COMEDY'S THE THING AT ONE-ACTS FESTIVAL
description: WHEN Manhattan Punch Line inaugurated its annual festival of one-act comedies two years ago, Steve Kaplan, the artistic director of what bills itself as New York's only comedy theater company, didn't foresee the overwhelming public response it would receive.

title: The Cardinal and Israel
description: John Cardinal O'Connor is not only a prince of the Church; he is a prince of a man. The extraordinary compromise he negotiated with Israel's leaders in Jerusalem this week is yet another example of what has impressed many of us about him.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that results are restated to reflect the acquisitions of Fidelity Trust Co. on Nov. 24 and Home Bank and Trust Co. on July 1, which have been accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: Fixed Mortgages Fall to 8-Year Low
description: Mortgage rates dropped again last month, reaching an eight-year low, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.

title: Democracy and Capitalism Collide; Denial, Not Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Drama for Lyubimov Premiere
description: Tonight's American premiere of the Russian director Yuri Lyubimov's adaptation of ''Crime and Punishment'' here was preceded by some political suspense.

title: VAST ARCS ENCIRCLE GALAXIES
description: Highly sensitive photography has shown the existence of vast luminous arcs encircling at least two distant galaxies. According to the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, which announced the finding, the arcs are the longest continuous features ever detected by optical telescope.

title: DOW TOPS 2,000 FOR THE FIRST TIME AS WALL ST. EXTENDS LATEST RALLY
description: Carried aloft by the stock market's stunning New Year rally, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,000 yesterday for the first time ever.

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the latest second quarter loss includes a $1,105,400 charge for restructuring, an additional tax assessment of $130,000 plus $80,000 interest from an I.R.S. audit for 1976 through 1980, and a $150,000 loss on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Combustion To Get Accuray
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., a diversified technology company, said today that it had won a bidding war and had agreed to acquire the Accuray Corporation for $45 a share, or $213 million. Accuray, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes computer-aided sensors and measuring devices for pulp and paper manufacturers. In December, Combustion's initial offer of $35 a share was topped by a $40-a-share bid from Hercules Inc., a specialty chemicals and aerospace company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IRON & SILK. By Mark Salzman. 211 pages. Random House. $16.95. IN 1982 Mark Salzman, fresh from studying Chinese at Yale, arrived in China for a two-year stint teaching English at a medical college in Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province. His first impressions were unpromising. Changsha turned out to be dirty and drab; the college campus was a mass of gray concrete ''mired in a swamp of loose bricks, cinderblocks and grey mud,'' and the heavy hand of officialdom seemed omnipresent.

title: Democrats Are Smiling
description: On one of the little-noted battlefields of the 1986 election, party leaders are only now completing the body count. To the Democrats' satisfaction and mild surprise, they appear to have scored a significant victory in state legislative races, one that bodes well for party prospects of retaining control of the House of Representatives into the 1990's.

title: AFTER A YEAR, EX-OFFICIALS UNDER PROSECUTION LEARN TO WAIT
description: For former city officials under prosecution in the municipal corruption scandal, life becomes a matter of waiting.

title: CONTRACTOR REORGANIZES A B-1B BOMBER PROJECT
description: The contractor responsible for building the flawed electronics system on the Air Force's B-1B strategic bomber announced a broad reorganization of the project's management yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer

title: Ad Revenues Up 10.2%
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau reported yesterday that ad revenues of the nation's daily newspapers were up 10.2 percent in October from the same month in 1985, to $2.5 billion, despite a drop in national advertising revenues. Within that, retail advertising rose 10.4 percent, to $1.34 billion, and classified climbed 16.4 percent, to $845 million. National was off 3.7 percent, to $328 million.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN VAN CLEEF TAX CASE
description: Van Cleef & Arpels Inc., the Fifth Avenue jeweler; its president, and its controller, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to falsifying business records to evade state and city sales taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 9, 1987
description: Markets

title: K.G.B. MAKES A RARE DISCLOSURE OF DISCIPLINING AIDES FOR ABUSES
description: In a rare admission that the K.G.B. abused its extensive powers, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda disclosed today that disciplinary action had been taken against several officials of the internal security agency.

title: DEVILS START SLOWLY, FINISH BIG FOR TIE
description: Someone forgot to put in an early wake-up call for the Devils again tonight as they spotted the opposition a three-goal lead in the first period. This time, however, the Devils roused themselves quickly enough to recover and earn a 4-4 tie against the Quebec Nordiques at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: FIRST GROUP OF THE CONTRAS COMPLETES FLORIDA TRAINING
description: The first group of Nicaraguan rebel commanders trained in Florida by the United States military has returned to Central America and training of a second group has already begun, according to rebel and American officials.

title: GEODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
SHULTZ, IN AFRICA, ASKS FREE MARKET
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on Africans today to continue their trend away from socialism and toward private enterprise as the most fruitful means of addressing their deep economic problems.

title: KOHL SEEKS TO CALM STORM OVER A SLAP AT THE EAST
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to calm a political storm touched off by his assertion that East Germany's Communist authorities hold political prisoners in ''concentration camps.''

title: No U.S.F.L. in '87
description: The United States Football League, which canceled its 1986 season, remains alive, although a lengthy court appeal will keep it dormant again in 1987, according to Commissioner Harry Usher. ''Given the time for appeal, we felt it unlikely there would be a season,'' Usher said yesterday. ''It will take about a six-month time frame to hear the appeal.'' Usher spoke following a three-hour meeting of U.S.F.L. owners in New York. The league will file an appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to overturn the award of $3 in its $1.62 billion antitrust suit against the N.F.L.

title: Handke Theater Piece
description: ''Self-Accusation,'' a theater piece by the Austrian playwright Peter Handke, will be presented for the next three weekends by the Women in Theater Network at the Women's Interart Annex, 552 West 53d Street. The work features three actresses in a presentation of dance and theater. The program is part of a director's workshop series sponsored by Women in Theater. Performances are at 7:30 P.M. Fridays and Saturdays and 5 P.M. on Sundays. Admission is $6. Reservations: 988-7187.

title: LEGACY OF THE SCANDALS: NEW RULES AND MORE CONFUSION AT CITY HALL
description: A year after the corruption scandals of 1986 began, it is clear that they have forced New York City's government to make changes - substantive and stylistic, dramatic and limited - in the way it runs itself.

title: MEMO SAID ISRAEL SUPPLIED CONTRAS
description: President Reagan was told by his advisers last September that American intelligence had detected Israeli arms shipments to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Congressional and Administration sources who have seen a White House memorandum on the subject.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said in the latest quarter it took a charge of $350,000, after taxes, for expenses involved in transferring production of many of its short-range wireless and infrared products from its Colorado plant to its Hong Kong manufacturing facility.

title: On the Phone
description: A new staff member of the House Select Committee on Intelligence was pleased to discover that the last three digits of his Capitol telephone extension were 007.

title: Without Rent Control, a Homeless Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: SCANDALS AND STRIFE ERODE KOCH'S STANDING, POLL FINDS
description: The yearlong corruption scandals and recent racial tensions have sharply eroded Mayor Koch's popularity among New Yorkers, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: What Became of Energy Independence?
description: LEAD: In 1986, the United States and much of the rest of the industrialized world forgot the energy lessons of the 1970's. With gasoline and home heating fuel prices at the lowest levels in 13 years, and with an Administration addicted to the wisdom of the marketplace, consumers and their Government have been lulled into complacency.

title: Philipp Brothers Receives Subpoena
description: Philipp Brothers Inc., the commodity trading subsidiary of Salomon Inc., said it had received a subpoena from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in connection with an investigation of off-exchange futures trading. Philipp Brothers said the investigation concerns trading activities at its London-based Cocoa Merchants operation from 1981 until the summer of 1984.

title: A Ray of Hope for Housing
description: New York City hopes to invest $240 million of a huge $4.2 billion housing expansion program in 5,200 new apartments in abandoned buildings. It's a sound idea that deserves support.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $2,496,000 for the quarter and $7,490,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,697,000 and a gain of $1,555,000 from a pension fund reversion. d-Includes branch sale gains of $9,502,000, or $6.2 million after taxes, an extraordinary tax credit of $8,809,000 and a gain of $4,012,000 from a pension fund reversion. There were no per share earnings reported for the latest year and year- ago periods it was not applicable prior to April 29, 1986 stock conversion.

title: ART: OLDENBURG'S WORKS AS PROPS FOR 'IL CORSO
description: CURRENTLY on view at three different locales in Manhattan are the primary objects, props and costumes of an extravagant and, it would seem, not always comprehensible performance staged in the open air at the Campo dell'Arsenale in Venice on Sept. 6, 1985. ''Il Corso del Coltello'' -or ''The Course of the Knife'' - was a collaboration between the Pop artist Claes Oldenburg; his wife, Coosje van Bruggen (an art historian who has worked with her husband on his public commissions since 1976), and the architect Frank O. Gehry.

title: Goodyear Begins Management Shifts
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday announced moves to consolidate its management, including the appointment of a corporate vice president for worldwide tire manufacturing.

title: SCHROEDER LEADS IN YARDS PER DOLLAR
description: They have a lot in common, the four quarterbacks who will lead their teams into the National Football League conference championship games Sunday. They all started every game this season, completed more than half their passes and threw for more than 3,400 yards. But one stands out from the others in several important areas:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Jazz 107, Lakers 101: Karl Malone scored 11 fourth-quarter points, and Thurl Bailey hit Utah's last three baskets as the Jazz ended the Lakers' eight-game winning streak last night. The Jazz took the lead for good at home when Kent Benson scored with 43 seconds left in the first half. John Stockton had a team-record 23 assists for Utah. The Lakers trailed by 99-94 with 2:55 remaining after three straight baskets from James Worthy, but the Jazz moved out of danger, 103-94, as Stockton fed Malone and Bailey for baskets. (AP) Cavaliers 103, Clippers 93: In Richifield Ohio, Ron Harper scored 24 points and John Bagley had 20 last night as Cleveland sent Los Angeles to its 14th straight defeat. The Clippers have lost 26 of their last 27 games and own the league's worst record at 4-29. The victory snapped athe Cavaliers' four-game losing streak. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Bruins 4: Ray Bourque scored his second goal of the game on a Boston power play with seven seconds remaining in regulation play capping a Bruins' comeback for the tie at home. The Bruins outshot Detroit, 18-4, in the third period and had an apparent tying goal disallowed before Bourque backhanded in his 11th goal on a rebound of Rick Middleton's shot after the Boston goalie, Bill Ranford, had been lifted for a sixth skater. (AP) America's Cup Australia IV Disqualified: A protest jury has disqualified Alan Bond's Australia IV from a race it won Wednesday against Kevin Parry's Kookaburra III in Freemantle, Australia. Even though the upset does not affect Australia IV's position in the final series to choose a defender, it does weaken the team's hold on that slot. If the syndicate should lose another protest - and there is a possibility that a previous protest hearing may be reopened - Australia IV could be knocked out of the finals and be replaced by Kookaburra II, Parry's other boat. Australia IV and Kookaburra III are scheduled to meet in a five-of-nine-race series beginning Jan. 14 for the right to defend the Cup. Parry's syndicate has asked the protest jury to reopen a case it decided in Australia IV's favor Wednesday. At issue was whether a new sail that Australia IV had introduced was rigged properly. Horse Racing Passing Thunder Wins by Length: Passing Thunder, who trailed early, rallied to circle the field and win going away in the $27,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Passing Thunder, a 5-year-old son of Valdez and Happy Summer, carried 117 pounds under Herb McCauley six furlongs in 1:12 on the fast track to reach the wire a length ahead of Haberdasher, the outsider in the field of six. Rolling By, the favorite, was another 1 3/4 lengths back. The winner returned $8.60 for $2. Boxing Olajide Wins Title: Michael (the Silk) Olajide of New York won the Continental Americas middleweight championship at the Felt Forum when he knocked out Richard Burton of the Bronx, at 1:38 of the fourth round in a scheduled 12-round bout. The rap against Olajide, who is ranked fifth by the World Boxing Association and seventh by the World Boxing Council, had been that he lacked the big punch. But he proved otherwise against Burton, knocking him down toward the end of the third round and putting him out for good in the fourth. Olajide, who weighed 157 pounds, is now 21-0 with 15 knockouts. Burton, who weighed 158, drops to 13-4 with 11 knockouts. Tennis Turnbull Gains Upset: Wendy Turnbull, one of the oldest players on the women's tour, upset Hana Mandlikova, the top-seeded player, by 6-3, 7-5 yesterday in the third round of the $150,000 New South Wales Open. The 34-year-old Turnbull, seeded 10th, stunned Mandlikova with accurate returns and some fluid groundstokes. Turnbull's victory over the 24-year-old Mandlikova was her second in succession over her doubles partner, the fourth-ranked player in the world, and earned her a quarterfinal berth against seventh-seeded Lori McNeil. (AP)

title: ISRAEL REPORTEDLY PERSUADED U.S. TO RESUME IRAN ARMS SHIPMENTS
description: A report by the Senate Intelligence Committee indicates that Israel played the central role in persuading the White House to resume arms shipments to Iran in January 1986 by assuring Washington that Teheran had promised to arrange the immediate release of American hostages in Lebanon, a senior White House aide said tonight.

title: BLACK MAN'S DEATH IN AN UPSTATE CITY IGNITED DEBATE ABOUT RACIAL CLIMATE
description: No one is sure exactly what happened at the movies that night. But at some point, Jimmy Lee Bruce Jr. and his friends became boisterous and were escorted out of the theater by two security guards.

title: U.S. Oil Data Revised Down
description: The drop in United States oil production during 1986 was about four times as sharp as the Government had previously reported, according to new statistics published today by the Energy Department.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As long as it keeps going, we're all happy. We don't have to cheer.'' - Rodney Berens, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company. [ D4:3. ]

title: BABY-FACED SOLDIER OF 'PLATOON': KEVIN DILLON
description: ONE of the most terrifying moments in the film ''Platoon'' belongs to the 21-year-old actor Kevin Dillon who plays Bunny, a swaggering, baby-faced young American soldier. When the platoon descends upon a Vietnamese village that may or may not be an enemy stronghold, the seething powder keg of a young man indulges his berserk lust for violence by savagely beating a peasant with his rifle butt. The savagery only kindles Bunny's appetite for a mass murder that is barely averted.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 9, 1987
description: International

title: FIVE TIED TO KLAN INDICTED ON ARMS CHARGES
description: A Federal indictment opened here today charges five members of white supremacist organizations with conspiracy to acquire stolen military weapons, explosives and equipment.

title: NEW SHOPS REVITALIZE A WEST SIDE BLOCK
description: Just a few steps away from such Upper West Side stalwarts as the Louis Lichtman bakery and Barney Greengrass, the sturgeon king, is the latest addition to the rapidly gentrifying neighborhood - a blocklong suite of shops at the base of the Packard, a newly built condominium building, and the adjacent refurbished rental building.

title: Providing a Friend For the Mentally Ill
description: TIMBER, a yellow Labrador retriever, jumped into the station wagon, but the other dog, Mindy has bad hips, and Mary Baker had to lift her onto the back seat. ''Come on Mindy,'' Ms. Baker said. ''Oh, you are so fat.''

title: British Airways to Offer 720.2 Million Shares
description: The British Government said today that it will offer 720.2 million British Airways P.L.C. shares to investors at a yet-to-be disclosed price when the company goes public in February. The sale is expected to raise $:1 billion, or about $1.47 billion.

title: G.M. Output Plan
description: An executive vice president of General Motors, Lloyd E. Reuss, said the company was gearing its plants to build enough vehicles in 1987 to account for 42 percent of the projected 10.5 million American car market. G.M. captured slightly more than 41 percent of the market in 1986.

title: I.B.M. TO SHUT INSTRUMENT UNIT
description: In its second consolidation move in two weeks, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would close down its I.B.M. Instruments Inc. subsidiary, ending the six-year-old venture to sell chemical analysis tools to laboratory scientists.

title: Giving Love, or Selling Life?
description: Who, short of Solomon, would choose to be in Harvey R. Sorkow's shoes these days? He is the New Jersey judge who must decide the legality of the contract by which Mary Beth Whitehead agreed to bear a child for William and Elizabeth Stern. Then Judge Sorkow must determine with whom the fruit of that contract, a little girl, should live - the biological mother and her husband, or the biological father (by artificial insemination) and his wife. And to help him make these difficult decisions, Judge Sorkow has about as much case law to call upon as Solomon did when he heard his famous custody suit. None. Elizabeth Stern, a 41-year-old pediatrician, is not, strictly speaking, infertile. Fearing, however, that pregnancy might aggravate her multiple sclerosis, she and her husband leased Mrs. Whitehead's reproductive potential for $10,000. Already the mother of two children by her husband, Mrs. Whitehead was, Mr. Stern said, ''too good to be true.''

title: Case of 7 Ex-Miami Officers Sent to Jury After Long Trial
description: After a trial of more than three months, the case of seven former members of the Miami Police Department accused of racketeering, possession of narcotics and of involvement in the drowning of three men went to the jury this afternoon.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: NEXT Friday, Steven Spielberg's controversial movie ''The Color Purple'' will reopen in 725 theaters nationwide, just three months after the 1985 film was taken out of release. The decision to have a new theatrical opening, with a large-scale national advertising campaign and new promotional material, is an unusual marketing strategy, since most films are released for video shortly after their first theatrical run.

title: 18th-Century Dances
description: The intricacies of the minuet, sarabande, gigue and other dances of the 18th century will be demonstrated Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street. Members of the New York Baroque Dance Company will lead participants through the paces in the second in a series of six performances devoted to historic entertainment; the ensemble will also perform a program called ''Two French Children.'' The next performance in the series, on Feb. 8, will feature a puppet show. Admission to each performance is $2. Information: 425-1778.

title: Mackovic Released
description: Coach John Mackovic, who led the Kansas City Chiefs to their first playoff appearance in 15 years this season, was dismissed yesterday after his fourth season with the team. ''The chemistry of an organization is an intangible that is crucial to its success,'' Lamar Hunt, the Chiefs' owner, said at a news conference. ''My evaluation is that our football team is lacking that ingredient. There is no perfect formula for becoming the best in pro football. We'd all like to think we have the right answers.'' Hunt said there would be no immediate decision on Mackovic's replacement. Mackovic, who was not at the news conference, has a year remaining on his contract, which will be honored. He had a 30-34 regular-season record with Kansas City. The Chiefs' offense, Mackovic's area of expertise, placed last in the league this season. The Chiefs were 10-6 before the Jets beat them in the wild-card playoff.

title: COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 23
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $228,000 and also $3,011,000 of pre-opening expenses related to new warehouse openings. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $17,000 and pre- opening expenses of $1,068,000.

title: A DARING U.S. STEP FOR HONDA
description: The announcement today that the Honda Motor Company would invest $450 million to manufacture engine and drive train components in Ohio is yet another daring step by a company that has often set the pace for Japanese auto makers in this country.

title: U.S. TO WAIT TO PROSECUTE RACIAL CASE
description: The Federal authorities will prosecute the three white youths arrested in the Howard Beach attack only if the state cannot go forward or otherwise cannot ''achieve substantial justice,'' a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Fraternity of Transients
description: It has come down to this: After a billion hours of watching films in the sunless bunkers, after a million hours scouting and shuffling, three teams may put their final Super Bowl hopes on the fickle feet of strangers.

title: FOR 3 FORMER CITY OFFICIALS, NEW JOBS FAR FROM SCANDAL
description: Since his abrupt departure last June as a top adviser to Mayor Koch, Victor E. Botnick says he has been enjoying himself ''doing some very interesting things in the private sector.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'LEGENDS' OF JAZZ Sixty photographs of great Afro-American and Latin jazz artists go on display today at the Caribbean Cultural Center. Framed to capture the mood, milieu and personality of each of the entertainers, these photographic portraits by Chuck Stewart feature such artists as Dinah Washington, Dizzy Gillespie, Machito, Tito Rodriguez, Miles Davis, Duke Ellington and John Coltrane. The exhibition, called ''Legends,'' runs through Jan. 31. The center, at 408 West 58th Street, is open today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. and tomorrow from 1 to 4 P.M. Admission is $2 ($1 for the elderly and students). Information: 307-7420. RAMEY AT CARNEGIE

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Sports Pages Tuesday omitted one year in which a professional football team beat another twice in the regular season and then met that same team in the playoffs. In 1964, the Buffalo Bills beat the San Diego Chargers twice during the season and then won the playoff game.

title: BROWNS ARE RUNNING AGAIN AS MACK DISCOVERS OLD FORM
description: Kevin Mack works himself into a harness so his left shoulder will not be jerked around, and he fits his Browns helmet gingerly over his head, gently adjusting the chin strap to his swollen jaw.

title: U.S. CONDUCTS BROAD AIDS STUDY IN BLOOD DRAWN FOR OTHER REASONS
description: In an effort to learn where and how fast the AIDS virus is spreading, Federal officials have begun screening anonymous blood samples drawn in hospitals for other purposes.

title: Boom-Booms as Bonbons
description: In the aftermath of World War I, there was a great campaign against the ''merchants of death'' who made fortunes selling arms and encouraging wars to use them up. Making money is now an important factor for governments in the world arms trade, but the politics of trying to win friends and influence people, not to speak of buying back hostages, has overtaken it.

title: Now, the Environment According to N. Dakota
description: As a college football player at the University of Minnesota, Quentin N. Burdick went relatively unnoticed. He was a blocking back, clearing the way for Bronko Nagurski, the great running back.

title: THE RACE IS ON AND ANYONE CAN WIN IT
description: Nearly everyone predicted a wide-open race in the Big East this season, but not many could have predicted how wide-open.

title: Browns Call an Audible
description: The Browns planned an end-run around their fans in Cleveland tonight.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FORMER ALLY CHALLENGES MAYOR IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Charging that Mayor W. Wilson Goode was guilty of ''ineptitude and mismanagement'' that crushed this city's renaissance under the ''rubble of unfulfilled programs and promises,'' a former District Attorney announced his candidacy today for the Democratic Mayoral nomination.

title: Democracy and Capitalism Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ART CONNOISSEUR'S GUIDE TO THE FRICK'S SERENE PLEASURES
description: IF - in the wake of the holidays - you need a getaway from the bustle and glitz of the city's big museums, there's a refreshing alternative.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $71,941.

title: Parade Poll
description: While New York's politicians debate whether there should be a ticker tape parade for the Giants should they win the Super Bowl, the city's public favors one, but just barely.

title: IN PHILIPPINES, MORE THAN JUST A 'PEACEFUL' KILLING
description: After the grenade exploded, it seemed that almost everybody could remember seeing the boy - barefoot, some said, wearing a hat, said others - loitering near one of the church doors eating a piece of bread.

title: C.B.O.E. Contract Date Kept
description: The directors of the Chicago Board Options Exchange voted today not to change the date of the popular Standard & Poor's 100 Stock Index Option contract. Many traders had urged such a move to help reduce the volatility of the markets on ''triple witching hours,'' the last hour of trading on the four Fridays a year when index futures contracts expire.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: The Brazilians Look Ready To Contend for World Titles
description: Historically, world events have been dominated by teams from Europe and North America. The only serious challenge to this trend has come from Brazil, which has a small group of highly talented players.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago fourth quarter and year figures are restated to reflect the results of two banks acquired in July 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page headline yesterday on a Washington dispatch reporting a vote to depose Representative Les Aspin as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee misstated the date for a second vote on the matter. It will be Jan. 23.

title: FORMER TIMES CORRESPONDENT
description: Thomas J. Hamilton, a New York Times correspondent for 35 years who was chief of the paper's United Nations bureau from 1946 to 1965, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn. He was 77 years old. Mr. Hamilton headed the Madrid bureau of The Times from 1939 to 1941, the Bonn bureau from 1965 to 1967 and the Geneva bureau from 1967 until his retirement in 1972.

title: HUNGARIAN ENSEMBLE
description: Traditional Hungarian music and dance will be presented by the Hungarian State Folk Ensemble, a group of more than 100 performers, Sunday night at 7 at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx. The troupe, led by Sandor Timar, is based in Budapest. Tickets are $13, $15 and $17.50 (half-price for students). Information: 960-8833.

title: 'Return of Sherlock Holmes,' 2-Hour Movie on CBS
description: Foul play will be committed tomorrow night at 9 on Channel 2, and there's no mystery about the perpetrators. ''The Return of Sherlock Holmes,'' a two-hour CBS movie, constitutes felonious assault on the memory of Arthur Conan Doyle's great detective, a particularly heinous crime in the week of Holmes's 100th birthday.

title: MORGAN'S FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
G.E. to Lay Off 1,400 at Factory
description: The General Electric Company will lay off about 1,400 of its 12,000 employees in Lynn this year, with about 1,000 of the layoffs coming as a result of increased competition and reduced demand for the jet fighter engines it makes, a spokesman, William Kennedy, said.

title: Peter Hall Replacement Is Reported in Britain
description: The board of directors of Britain's National Theater is expected to name Richard Eyre to succeed Sir Peter Hall as the company's artistic director in 1989, according to reports from the theater.

title: Portland General
description: The Portland General Electric Company said it had established a reserve to write down its investment in the Washington Public Power Supply System's Nuclear Project No. 3. The reserve will result in an after-tax earnings reduction of $1.64 a common share in 1986 for the Portland General Corporation, which has 46.1 million common shares outstanding. Earnings of $2 a share were previously estimated. The utility is trying to eliminate its exposure to unlicensed nuclear projects, Robert H. Short, Portland General's chairman and chief executive, said. Pacific General's share in the Washington Project No. 3 was $235 million before the write-down.

title: Otto M. Buerger Dies at 88; A Longtime L.I.R.R. Lawyer
description: Otto M. Buerger, who served as a lawyer for the Long Island Rail Road for 28 years until his retirement in 1963, died in his sleep Dec. 29 at his home in Sands Point, L.I. He was 88 years old.

title: FILM: A CZECH COMEDY, 'MY SWEET LITTLE VILLAGE'
description: THERE'S no irony in the title of ''My Sweet Little Village,''

title: Davis Nominated
description: Two men who have been keys to Raider football success and thorns to the hierarchy of the National Football League were among the 16 finalists named yesterday for possible induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio. The two are Al Davis, former commissioner of the American Football League and now the principal owner of the Los Angeles Raiders, and Gene Upshaw, the Raiders' former All-Pro offensive lineman who is now head of the players' union. The finalists, determined by the hall's 30-member board of selectors, will be considered for enshrinement when the selection committee meets Jan. 24. Davis, who engineered the Raiders' move from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982, has been in several legal battles with Commissioner Pete Rozelle over the move. He also appeared as a witness for the United States Football League in its antitrust suit against the N.F.L. last summer. One of Davis's former players, Fred Biletnikoff, who spent 14 seasons as a wide receiver with the Raiders, was also nominated. The others were Bob Brown, an offensive tackle; Larry Csonka and John Henry Johnson, running backs; Len Dawson and Bob Griese, quarterbacks; Joe Greene and Alan Page, defensive tackles; Jerry Kramer and Larry Little, guards; Jim Langer, a center; and Don Maynard and Tommy McDonald, wide receivers. Also named was the former Cleveland coach Blanton Collier.

title: The Test for Running the C.I.A.
description: The sad truth about Washington's chief collector of secrets is no longer a secret. There seems to be no chance that William Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, can recover sufficiently from a cancer operation to resume his duties. Already the capital buzzes with speculation about who should succeed him. But in order to get the right who, there has to be a lot more thinking about how to make the choice.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

title: SIMILAR STANDARDS FOR BANKS ARE SET BY U.S. AND BRITAIN
description: The United States and Britain announced a pioneering regulatory agreement today that will impose on British and American banks almost identical standards for the levels of capital they must maintain.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: 'MIAMI VICE' FREES ACTOR BY KILLING LIEUTENANT ZITO
description: By the time ''Miami Vice'' is over tonight, Detective Zito will be dead, murdered by a bunch of thugs in a gruesomely ironic way for a vice-squad cop to die.

title: CANONIE ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Awaiting the Ax Of 'Restructuring'
description: The World Bank calls it a ''restructuring,'' the first major one in 15 years. But to some of the organization's 6,500 employees, it is more like the sword of Damocles.

title: Man Shot in Sniper Attack
description: Shots fired tonight into a group home for the retarded wounded a 36-year-old employee, the 11th such shooting in northern Rhode Island or nearby areas in Massachusetts since Dec. 8, the authorities said. Two of the cases have been positively linked, and the police say they believe most if not all are related. The victim of tonight's shooting, Allen Gordon of Cranston, was described as being in fair condition at Fogarty Memorial Hospital with a back wound. A man shot in the first attack, which also occurred in North Smithfield, is recovering from a neck wound.

title: Movie Stunt Man Dies Trapped Under River
description: A stunt man was killed when he drove a car into the Hudson River during the filming of a movie here today and divers could not pull him out of the car, the police said.

title: REPUBLIC SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF WISCONIN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the 6 months. Republic went public in August.

title: In the Mail
description: Are Americans throwing away, unopened, letters that solicit donations or sell products? The Armed Forces Journal thinks so. The Washington publication, circulating a questionnaire to update its mailing list, printed on the envelope: ''Please, please, please open this envelope and reply. We are not asking for any money, we promise!''

title: Burger's Goal
description: Warren E. Burger, the retired Chief Justice of the United States, told a visitor the other day that he always keeps a copy of the Constitution in his pocket, another in the glove compartment of his car, yet another in his desk at home and another in his desk at work. As chairman of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, he is setting an example for the nation, which he proposes to paper with 50 million copies of the historic document, or very nearly one for every family.

title: HOUSE IRAN PANEL PICKS CHIEF COUNSEL AND DIRECTOR
description: The special House committee that will investigate the Iran-contra affair announced today the selection of its top staff and named a Washington lawyer with experience as a Congessional investigator and prosecutor as chief counsel.

title: 6 STORIES BY HAMMETT FOR SALE
description: A half-dozen unpublished stories by Dashiell Hammett, the author of ''The Maltese Falcon,'' are being offered to publishers by trustees of the estate of Lillian Hellman, the playwright and Mr. Hammett's longtime companion.

title: N.C.A.A. Opposes Playoff
description: Despite the attention and high television ratings generated by the Penn State-Miami Fiesta Bowl game on Jan. 2, the National Collegiate Athletic Association is not going to establish any form of Division I-A football playoff in the foreseeable future, according to university presidents and athletic officials.

title: Car Chased by Police Kills a Pedestrian, 59
description: A Brooklyn man was killed and his wife was critically injured last night when they were struck by a stolen car being chased by a police car, the authorities said.

title: BATTLE IS LOOMING ON ASBESTOS FUNDS
description: Congressional proponents of Federal financing for a program to remove asbestos from public schools say they will oppose the Reagan Administration's attempt to rescind a $50 million appropriation for the program.

title: EUROPEANS CURRENCIES MAY BE REALIGNED
description: Europe is likely to have a new set of currency values when markets reopen on Monday, monetary officials indicated today.

title: TEXTS OF ORDER BY REAGAN AND MEMO
description: Following are the texts of an intelligence finding authorizing clandestine operations by the United States Government signed by President Reagan on Jan. 17, 1986, and of an attached memorandum on the finding made public by the White House today:

title: DUKE NAMES COACH
description: Steve Spurrier, a Heisman Trophy winner while playing quarterback for the University of Florida in 1966, was named the head football coach at Duke University yesterday. He replaces another former quarterback, Steve Sloan, who resigned earlier this week to become athletic director at his alma mater, the University of Alabama. Spurrier, 41 years old, who played with the San Francisco 49ers from 1967 to 1975, was offensive coordinator for Duke under Coach Red Wilson from 1980 to 1982. ''It's a good feeling to be able to come back somewhere where you've worked before, you know the people here, where you have a lot of friends,'' Spurrier said. He was head coach of the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League, but since the league suspended operations he had been working with the Hall of Fame Bowl committee in Tampa. . . . The University of Wyoming athletic director, Paul Roach, a former assistant football coach for the Cowboys, was named the university's new football coach.

title: BABY BOOM GENERATION MAKES UP THIRD OF POPULATION, REPORT SAYS
description: The baby boom generation now makes up nearly one-third of the nation's population, a new study by the Census Bureau shows.

title: FOR GIANTS' FANS, EUPHORIA IS TEMPERED WITH DISBELIEF
description: The giddiness that Giants fans are feeling this week - the smiles they exchange that make words unnecessary - is still tinged with lingering disbelief. Is this for real or a dream? Yet fans talk confidently of spending Jan. 25 in Pasadena, Calif., where the Giants would make their first Super Bowl appearance. They think tomorrow's game against the Washington Redskins for the National Conference title is a mere formality, the third time this season the Redskins will be rebuffed.

title: SMITHSONIAN SETS A MINORITIES GOAL
description: The Smithsonian Institution today announced plans, including a greater diversification of exhibits, to attract more minorities to its collections and programs.

title: Quilting Bee
description: Amateur and professional quilters will gather tomorrow at noon for the annual quilting bee at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The film ''Quilting Women'' will also be shown. The fee is $2. Information: 427-6000, extension 172.

title: STATE WILL SHIFT INMATES WITH AIDS TO ST. CLARE'S
description: Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that the state would pull out of an agreement with New York City to build an AIDS treatment unit for state prisoners at Metropolitan Hospital. He said the state had chosen instead St. Clare's Hospital, where the cost would be less than half.

title: Lighter Ignites Oil Fumes
description: An oil company employee trying to determine the fuel level in an oil tanker truck lit a cigarette lighter, but he escaped serious injury in the resulting explosion, officials said Thursday. ''When he flipped the cigarette lighter, the vapors ignited and blew the end of the tanker out,'' a battalion chief said. The man with the lighter and another worker were released from a hospital after treatment.

title: CITY IS ACCUSED OF IGNORING PACT COVERING SHELTER
description: The Legal Aid Society charged yesterday that a city shelter for the homeless had violated a pledge made in court that it not admit pregnant women and young children because of the health threat posed by the presence of lead paint in the shelter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Pretoria Bans Meetings By Educational Group
description: The Government banned an unofficial education group today from holding meetings to discuss its alternative program for black schools.

title: SCREEN: HYBRID MONSTER HAUNTS 'THE KINDRED'
description: There are precisely two spirited scenes in ''The Kindred'' - Kim Hunter's entire role. She rises above this horror film's near-total banality as a dying scientist pleading with her son to end her secret experiment. He must destroy her notebooks, the ''Anthony journals,'' she warns John. When he asks, ''Who's Anthony?'' she practically rises out of her deathbed to cry, ''Your brother!'' and soon dies, without explaining.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Suits by Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments said today that it had reached agreements settling its patent infringement lawsuits against two Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, but that it would continue its court action against seven other foreign companies.

title: Anniversaries of Murder
description: This thought came into my head and has been working away at me:

title: Oklahoma Bank Sold by F.D.I.C.
description: The Security National Bank and Trust Company of Norman, Okla., has been closed and sold to two Arkansas bank holding companies by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Security National, which was closed Thursday afternoon by the Comptroller of the Currency, had total assets of about $200 million and deposits of $175 million.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about former New York City officials who have faced prosecution because of the corruption scandal described Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, incorrectly. Last month, after he was found guilty of corruption, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court suspended him from practicing law.

title: SUBSTANTIAL LOSS SEEN BY HUTTON
description: The E.F. Hutton Group said yesterday that it would report a ''substantial'' 1986 loss because of a $130 million reserve it has created to cover client losses on several types of securities and tax-shelter investments.

title: 7% FOR ALL 1986
description: The unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point last month, to 6.6 percent, the lowest level since March 1980, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 3 INQUIRES HALTED BY JUSTIC DEPT.
description: The Justice Department has suspended three grand jury investigations focusing on the private American supply network aiding rebel groups in Nicaragua, department officials said today.

title: ANSWER TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: US Sprint Joins In Contract Bid
description: US Sprint Communications said it had teamed up with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to join the bidding war for a $4.5 billion contract to re-equip the Government's telecommunications system, the world's largest private phone network. US Sprint, a joint venture of the GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., said it would act as the subcontractor in its bid for the 10-year Government contract. E.D.S., a computer services concern that is a unit of the General Motors Corporation, will act as the prime contractor.

title: Video Show: Focus on Yen
description: The stronger yen preoccupied the 100,000 manufacturers and retailers who gathered here this week for the electronics show.

title: TURNER DISCUSSING SALE OF POSSIBLY LARGE STAKE
description: Ted Turner, head of the financially troubled Turner Broadcasting System, may be negotiating to sell a significant piece of his 80 percent stake in the television and cable company, Wall Street analysts and sources close to Turner Broadcasting said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEAD: FISH STORY North Shore, as in ''North Shore Fish,'' the Israel Horovitz play, refers to the Atlantic seacoast communities just north of Boston. The most famous of these is Gloucester, the historic fishing port and artist colony. This play is about workers in a frozen-fish processing plant a few steps shy of going out of business.

title: WALL ST. A STRONG INFLUENCE ABROAD
description: Record highs on at least eight major stock exchanges have bolstered investors' spirits around the world since the New Year, although recent uncertainty on Western Europe's money markets has left some shareholders there crestfallen.

title: CHAIRMAN OF GUINNESS WITHDRAWS FROM POST
description: The chairman of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, announced tonight that he was stepping down until a British Government investigation of the brewing company was completed.

title: FIVE VETERAN ASTRONAUTS TO MAKE SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: Five astronauts who have performed ambitious and dangerous missions in space were named today to fly the first space shuttle into orbit once the current repair operations on the shuttle fleet are complete.

title: An Embassy Ball
description: Washington is home to 139 foreign embassies, from Afghanistan, Algeria and Antigua to Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe. But few people are aware there is also a Confederate Embassy here.

title: PHIL SEGHI
description: Phil Seghi, who hired Frank Robinson as baseball's first black manager with the Cleveland Indians in 1975 and signed Pete Rose for the Cincinnati Reds in 1960, died Thursday in Thousand Oaks, Calif., after a long illness with cancer. He was 68 years old. Mr. Seghi, who was the senior player-personnel adviser with the Indians, had served as vice president and general manager with the club after joining the organization in 1971. He also spent 12 years in the Cincinnati organization, and worked for the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Oakland A's.

title: MATCHING FUND FROM FAMILY PROVIDES $1,000 FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: A gift of $1,000 from a family in Katonah, N.Y., to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund resulted from a matching fund in which all members of the family participated. Sally and Robert Krefting explained in a note that the total spent by family members on Christmas gifts was matched by their contribution.

title: TECHNICALITY VOIDS CHARGES OF BIGAMY AGAINST A PHYSICIAN
description: A Manhattan doctor arrested on bigamy charges will probably not be prosecuted because of a legal technicality here and the unwillingness of prosecutors to pursue the case in Iowa, where he is said to have married his second wife in December.

title: SENATE REPORT ON IRAN ARMS SALES: ROLE OF ISRAEL IS HIGHLIGHTED
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee's report on Iran has raised new questions about the role played by Israel in persuading President Reagan to violate his own dual policies of never paying ransom to terrorists for the release of hostages and of not supplying arms to Iran.

title: Israelis Stage Air Raid On Targets in Lebanon
description: Israeli jets rocketed Palestinian targets near Sidon today, and shellfire from Christian militiamen shut down the Beirut airport again.

title: NAVY TO CUT ROBINSON'S TOUR TO 2 YEARS
description: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch senior center who has been exciting pro basketball scouts since he started scoring points for Navy but who was thought to be untouchable until 1992, yesterday moved three years closer to a possible pro career.

title: Owens-Illinois Stock Up Sharply
description: The stock of the Owens-Illinois Corporation rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday on Wall Street primarily because of rumors that a new bid, perhaps at $60 a share, might be forthcoming. The company received a takeover bid more than a month ago from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. At the end of the day, its stock was up $1.50 a share, to $55.25.

title: IN LONDON, THE 'DESIGN WARS'
description: In establishing retail beachheads on the Thames, a one-time public-relations man from Argentina, a Dane who was once an oilman and a former haircutter from Casablanca have skirmished with their predecessors and each other, embroiling London in what might be called ''designer wars.''

title: A NEW BLACK TOWNSHIP IS RESIGNED, NOT DEFIANT
description: The weekend begins early here, a hiatus in a segregated black township from a workweek in a segregated white town, and it is celebrated in a ritualistic kind of way.

title: DANCE: MARTA RENZI AND COMPANY
description: Dancegoers were taken to a party, to India and to a world of fantasy in the works that Marta Renzi and the Project Company presented Thursday night at the Joyce Theater. Unfortunately, one occasionally encountered fog during these journeys.

title: Garland Jeffreys
description: The songwriter Garland Jeffreys will appear tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: DANGERS CITED 18 MONTHS EARLIER
description: In an inspection 18 months ago, the Puerto Rico Fire Department found that the Dupont Plaza Hotel's fire alarm system was not working properly.

title: NOW, FOR CRIMSON TIDE, WINNINGS'S NOT ENOUGH
description: For more than half a century, in a tradition that brought the South national championships and a cause for pride in the barren decades when it had little to rejoice about, the University of Alabama has been one of the nation's great football powers, quickening the region's blood flow on Saturday afternoons.

title: WITNESS IN BABY M TRIAL TESTIFIES ON DISEASE'S EFFECTS IN PREGNANCY
description: A neurologist testified in the Baby M trial today that it was ''medically reasonable'' for Dr. Elizabeth Stern to avoid pregnancy because she suffered from a mild case of multiple sclerosis.

title: 3 CHARGED WITH SHIPPING OIL EQUIPMENT TO LIBYA
description: A businessman from Scotland and two oil industry executives from a New Orleans suburb have been arrested here on charges of shipping oilfield equipment to Libya, in violation of an embargo ordered last year by President Reagan.

title: Chief Steps Down at Crazy Eddie
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the retailer that advertises ''insane'' prices, said yesterday that its founder, Eddie Antar, had resigned as chief executive, for personal reasons. The company did not elaborate, but several analysts and other Wall Street sources said they understood that the 39-year-old executive was ill and had not been in the company's Edison, N.J., office since early December.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON AUTISTIC SCHOOL'S METHODS
description: A 16-month legal dispute over treatment at a school for severely autistic teen-agers and young adults has ended with a judge approving an agreement that allows the school to use physical punishment as treatment in some cases.

title: RUSSIANS UPSTAGE A PLAY
description: The nuances of the evening were not lost on Washingtonians Thursday as they gathered for the American premiere of the Russian director Yuri Lyubimov's production of ''Crime and Punishment'' at Arena Stage.

title: BIG JOHANNESBURG STORE IS DAMAGED IN BOMBING
description: A bomb ripped through parts of a leading department store in central Johannesburg today, causing a fire and extensive damage.

title: WILSON'S 'SALOME' WILL BE 'NORMAL'
description: Robert Wilson is best known for putting on theatrical events that are silent or seven hours long or entirely lacking a story line or even all of the above. Now he is trying very hard to stage an opera that can be considered ''normal.''

title: THE DANCE: 'PHOENIX,' ELEO PMARE PREMIERE
description: Things got off to a celebratory start when the Eleo Pomare Dance Company performed on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater as part of the Joyce Sampler festival. A proclamation from the office of David Dinkins, Borough President of Manhattan, declared it ''Eleo Pomare Day.'' As if to offer a primer on the art of Mr. Pomare, the proclamation spoke of the company's ''dynamic, vibrant performances,'' the work's ''raw energy and emotion'' and the choreographer's involvement with the use of dance to ''express the experiences of the oppressed.'' And the dance that followed, opening the program itself, bore all that out.

title: The Facts of Life of Teen Pregnancy
description: ''We were asked to look at information and the facts,'' said Dr. Daniel D. Federman of Harvard Medical school, who headed a National Research Council panel on teen-age pregnancy. The facts the group found are appalling - fully justifying an aggressive birth control campaign for youngsters.

title: Grammy Nominations Led by Steve Winwood
description: The singer Steve Winwood received five Grammy Award nominations Thursday to lead the rock category, while Peter Gabriel, Paul Simon and the jazz trumpeter Wynton Marsalis received four nominations each.

title: FILM: CHARLES BRONSON STARS IN 'ASSASSINATION'
description: In ''Assassination,'' which opened yesterday at the UA Twin and other theaters, Charles Bronson, who may outlast the Mount Rushmore sculptures, plays the chief of security for the nation's newest First Lady. ''What's she like?'' he asks on Inauguration Day. ''Let's just say,'' replies a friend, ''that you're going to miss the hell out of Nancy Reagan.''

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IN 1986 IN NEW YORK WAS AT 12-YEAR LOW
description: The unemployment rate in New York last year was the lowest in 12 years, and the New Jersey rate was the lowest in 16 years, according to Federal statistics released yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1987
description: International#3-6, 28 Oliver L. North may have planned many arms shipments to the Nicaraguan rebels through Portugal, according to Congressional sources who say the Senate Intelligence Committee has uncovered evidence. Page 1 White House documents show that considerations beyond the release of American hostages influenced the President's authorization of arms shipments to Iran. The documents were released to reinforce Mr. Reagan's claim that his approval was part of a broad-based policy.#1 News analysis: A Senate Iran report has raised questions about Israel's role in persuading Mr. Reagan to violate his own policies of never paying ransom to terrorists and of not supplying arms to Iran. #6 Three inquiries into aid to the contras have been shut down, the Justice Department said, and will not be resumed until they have been reviewed by the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair.#4 Jim Wright attacked Mr. Reagan, saying that the White House had ''breached'' its relations with Congress because of the Iran-contra affair. The new House Speaker said ''the law was violated.''#6 A new Nicaraguan constitution guarantees the right to hold meetings and lawful demonstrations and to publish uncensored news. But an existing state of emergency has the effect of suspending many of the new provisions. #4 A right-wing fund raiser gave cash to a senior Nicaraguan rebel official last year and to a contra rebel political office, contra officials say. Carl R. Channell worked closely with Oliver L. North. #5 Iran mounted a new offensive in the Persian Gulf war, and both sides reported heavy fighting near the southern Iraqi city of Basra. Each side's press agency reported heavy enemy casualties. #1 A bomb exploded in Johannesburg, ripping through parts of a department store and causing extensive damage. The store had been evacuated, and no injuries were reported. #4 A new segregated black township, Lethlabile, is one of South Africa's latest creations, a place to which people from another township have been consigned by an official design over which they have no control. 4 George Shultz praised Chad's forces and gave an optimistic assessment of its ability to combat Libyan troops in continuing battles in northern Chad. Mr. Shultz spoke as he flew from Cameroon to Kenya. #3 Fear of violence in France and a mood of crisis has resulted from crippling public sector strikes that continue on the railroads, the subway and bus systems and in the state-run power company. #3 New currency values for Europe are expected to be set this weekend, monetary officials indicated. A meeting to discuss realignment of the values is scheduled for Saturday, they said. #35 Intellectuals criticized in Beijing 28 National#7-8, 16, 50 The nation's unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a point last month to 6.6 percent, the lowest level since March 1980, the Labor Department said. Analysts said the figures were stronger than expected.#1 Jobless rate at 12-year low 50 A drug seems to halt an AIDS-related infection in six months of tests, a drug company said. Ribavirin is the first drug that has seemed to prevent AIDS from developing in patients with early signs of infection.#1 Five astronauts will fly the shuttle on its first flight once the current fleet repair operations are complete. The crew is the first to be comprised solely of astronauts who have previous experience in space. 7 Details of the San Juan hotel fire, pieced together through interviews with survivors and investigators, raise questions about the Dupont Plaza's response to danger, its safety equipment and procedures. 16 A football coach who stresses studies has been appointed by the University of Alabama, signaling changed priorities for the school and placing it in the forefront of a national movement to discipline college sports. 7 The merits of seat belts on Amtrak coaches and other commuter rail systems that use the Northeast Corridor will be considered by the Government's chief railroad safety officer, he said. #7 Oil drilling on a wildlife refuge is at issue, as debate over an Interior De partment proposal to allow oil drilling on the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge opened amid seemingly irreconcilable differences. 8 A ruling on treatment for the autistic students at a Boston school came when a judge approved an agreement under which he will decide case by case when the school may use punishment as a treatment. 50 $500 million in aid for the homeless has been proposed by leaders in the House of Representatives who say they hope to get the money by early spring.
