The package includes food, shelter and other aid. #31 Federal Customs officials charged three people from a New Orleans suburb with shipping oilfield equipment to Libya, in violation of an embargo ordered last February by President Reagan.#33 Smithsonian sets minorities goal 8 Washington Talk#8 Planning Holocaust Museum Regional#29-32 New York State will not appeal a Federal court ruling allowing a New Jersey dairy to sell its milk in all five boroughs of New York City, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday.#1 News analysis: Mario Cuomo has sent mixed signals over the last week about whether he will run for President. The Governor is under pressure from national Democratic figures to state his intentions. #1 More homeless people fill shelters in New York City than ever before. In the last week, as many as 10,108 people have used the city's shelter system, about 1,300 more than at the same time last year. #29 A housing plan may collapse almost a year after a group of New York City's leading developers proposed it. The developers had offered to build 3,000 apartments for middle-income New Yorkers at no profit.#29 A doctor testified in the Baby M trial that it was ''medically reasonable'' for Dr. Elizabeth Stern, the wife of the baby's father, to avoid pregnancy because she had a mild case of multiple sclerosis. #30 State to shift inmates with AIDS 6 Catherine St. shelter criticized 31 Schools get racism curriculum 31 Neediest Cases#32

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. SACRAMENTO KINGS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M; Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.). NETS VS. BULLS, at Chicago (Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:20 P.M.). COLLEGES: Iona at Army, 2 P.M. (Radio - WRTN 93.5, 1:55 P.M. and WFAS 1230, 2 P.M.); Loyola (Md.) at L.I.U., 2 P.M.; Temple at Rutgers, 2 P.M.; Cornell at Columbia, 2 P.M.; North Carolina at Duke (TV - Channel 2, 2 P.M.); Fordham at Fairfield, 3 P.M. (Radio - WFUV 90.7, 3 P.M.); Auburn at Mississippi State (TV - MSG, 3 P.M.); Georgetown at Pitt (TV - Channel 2, 4 P.M.); N.Y.U. at C.C.N.Y., 4 P.M.; Hunter at St. Francis, 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WNYE 91.5, 10:30 P.M.); Utica at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; Seton Hall at Syracuse, 7:30 P.M.(TV - MSG, 10 P.M., taped; Radio - WSOU 89.5 and WNYE 91.5, 7:30 P.M.); Boston College at St. John's, 8 P.M. (TV -Channel 9, 9 P.M., taped delay; Radio WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Georgia Tech at North Carolina State (TV -ESPN, 8 P.M.). FOOTBALL EAST-WEST SHRINE CLASSIC, at San Francisco (TV - Channel 11, 3P.M.). HULA BOWL, at Honolulu (TV -Channel 4, 4 P.M.). JAPAN BOWL, at Yokohoma (TV -ESPN, 10 P.M.). GOLF PGA TOUR: MONY Tournament of Champions, La Costa Country Club, Carlsbad, Calif. (TV - Channel 4, 1P.M.). HOCKEY DEVILS VS. VANCOUVER CANUCKS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1:35 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. and 10:30 P.M., taped; Radio - WMCA 570, 1:30 P.M.). ISLANDERS VS. TORONTO MAPLE LEAFS, at Nassau Coliseum, 7:05 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BOAT SHOW: Javits Center, noon. BOWLING: Seagram's Cooler U.S. Open, at Tacoma, Wash. (TV -Channel 7, 3 P.M.). FENCING: Michael Alaux Pan American team trials, at Manhattan College, foil and epee, 8 A.M. and 5P.M. HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) SQUASH: Rolex Greenwich Open quarterfinals, at Field Club of Greenwich, 11 A.M.; semifinals, 4P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: $60,000 Paumonok Hndicap, at Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6 and 10 P.M., taped)

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
PLAN TO BUILD BASIC HOUSING HITS COST SNAG
description: Almost a year after a group of the city's leading developers offered to build 3,000 apartments for middle-income New Yorkers at no profit, the plan faces collapse unless the city helps pay for it.

title: Mondale Campaign Is Fined For Election Law Violations
description: Walter F. Mondale's 1984 Presidential campaign has been ordered to pay $68,000 in fines for violating the election law's limits on spending and contributions, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: Murdoch Sweetens Australia Paper Bid
description: Rupert Murdoch made another surprise move today in the Australian media battle by substantially increasing his offer for the Melbourne-based Herald and Weekly Times Ltd. from $1.2 billion (United States), to $1.5 billion.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
INFORMATION PROCESSING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BATTLE OVER G.O.P.'S ANTENNA
description: A political battle has begun in the Senate over a television antenna on a Senate office building.

title: SNOW BLANKETS THE MIDWEST
description: Kerry Olson, left, and Ricky Barker trying out ski boards in St. Louis in a snowstorm. The storm left parts of the Middle West under up to nine inches of snow, forcing the closing of some schools and disrupting traffic. One traffic death was attributed to the storm. (AP)

title: U.S.-Soviet Student Exchange Began in '74
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Ringo Married to James Conlon
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Ringo, an opera singer, and James J. Conlon, a conductor, were married at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York yesterday. The Rev. Joseph F. Buckley performed the ceremony.

title: PATENTS
description: Compounds patented this week are designed to prevent clots when blood is exposed to plastics and other biochemicals. Prof. Andrew Lasslo, Prof. Marion Dugdale and two former staff members at the University of Tennessee in Memphis were granted patent No. 4,634,709.

title: Giants Are Wound Up As Preparations Wind Down
description: Before the Giants routed the San Francisco 49ers, 49-3, in the playoffs last Sunday, the Giants' intensity level was high. It is so high for this Sunday's championship game against the Washington Redskins that even a player on injured reserve is almost a nervous wreck.

title: RANGERS FALL A SAVE SHORT
description: Considering what Bob Froese had done all night, the way he had stopped so many shots in so many contorted positions, and only considering that, then maybe he should have been expected to stop one more.

title: MUSIC: DVORAK AND LISZT
description: Thursday night's concert by the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall was, if anything, a demonstration of Central European folk music's irresistible attractions for composers. Three of the pieces in this program conducted by Julius Rudel were by Liszt, the other by Dvorak; and in almost all this music the traditional songs and dances of Hungary and Czechoslovakia seemed both to use -and be used by - each of these men.

title: NEW FLORIDA GOVERNOR DENIES TAKING BRIBE AS TAMPA MAYOR
description: Two days after his inauguration, Gov. Bob Martinez took the witness stand in Federal District Court on Thursday and denied allegations that he took illegal campaign contributions and bribes when he was Mayor of Tampa.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISE SLOWS
description: Americans took on $4.02 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in November, the lowest monthly increase since August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Carrie Smith
description: The singer Carrie Smith will perform tonight and tomorrow night at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: CONTRAS SAY CASH CAME FROM ASSOCIATE OF NORTH
description: A conservative political fund-raiser who worked closely with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North gave cash to a senior Nicaraguan rebel official last year, gave money to a contra political office here and also gave money to several other pro-contra political activities in Washington, according to several contra officials and lobbyists for the rebels.

title: KRELITZ INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the 1985 comparable periods reflect the change in fiscal year-end from December to April.

title: Baldrige Leaves Hospital
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige was released today from a hospital here, where he had been treated for a lung ailment. Mr. Baldrige. 64 years old, was accompanied by his wife, Midge, and daughter, Megan Murray. Dr. Jonathan M. Samet said Mr. Baldrige suffered from an irritation of the lining of his lungs and heart, which had been complicated by pneumonia.

title: SHULTZ SEES CHAD GAINING AGAINST LIBYA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz gave an optimistic assessment today of the Chadian armed forces' ability to counter Libyan troops in their continuing battles in northern Chad.

title: PATENTS
description: THE seventh annual National Inventors Conference will be held at the Sheraton Crystal City Hotel in Arlington, Va., on Feb. 6. The sponsors are the Bureau of National Affairs Inc., and the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 13
Bearish Sentiment Seen Weighing on the Dollar
description: The wave of speculative trading that roiled the world's currency markets again yesterday capped a week that will be long remembered among market participants.

title: Age and Forgetfulness Do Not Go Together
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chernobyl-Type Accident Can't Happen Here
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SPAKER FAULTS REAGSN ON IRAN
description: In an unusually blunt attack on President Reagan, the new Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, said today that the White House had ''breached'' its relations with Congress because of the Iran-contra affair.

title: Books of The Times; A Tale of 2 Brothers
description: PALAIS-ROYAL. By Richard Sennett. 274 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. In this, his third novel, Richard Sennett proposes to tell the story of two brothers entirely through letters, diary entries and other found bits of writing. The time is the mid-19th century; the backdrop, Paris and London; the characters, Frederick and Charles Courtland, sons of a good English family - the first, a precocious and somewhat arrogant young architect; the second, a lapsed minister given to moody ruminations about faith and doubt and the state of his own soul.

title: KNICKS TOP 76'ERS ON ROAD
description: It had been so long since the Knicks last won a game at the Spectrum against the Philadelphia 76ers that the lone survivor of that team, Bill Cartwright, didn't remember it without prodding. He remembers the losses, however, almost all 17 of them - including two playoff losses - over more than five years.

title: SENIOR BOWL CHANGES
description: In light of the dismissal Thursday of Coach John Mackovic by the Kansas City Chiefs, officials of the Senior Bowl football game at Mobile, Ala., announced yesterday a change of coaching assignments for the game among graduating seniors to be played next Saturday. Mackovic had been scheduled to coach the North all-star team against a South squad coached by John Robinson of the Los Angeles Rams. But Robinson has now agreed to coach the North so that Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins could be in the charge of the South team. That squad includes 10 players from the University of Alabama, one being Shula's son, Mike, a quarterback.

title: KEY RATES
Black Leaders Meet Santucci Over Attack
description: An ad hoc committee of 25 black civic, religious and elected leaders met yesterday with the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci. Afterward, the group voiced confidence in the prosecutor's investigation into the racial attack in Howard Beach last Dec. 20.

title: DON SLEET
description: Don Sleet, a jazz musician who was Downbeat magazine's trumpeter of the year three times during the 1950's, died Dec. 31 of cancer. He was 48 years old.

title: 5 ARE KILLED IN CRASH OF A MARINE HELICOPTER
description: A Marine Corps helicopter practicing night landings crashed and burst into flames Thursday, killing all five crew members, officials said today.

title: WRITERS READ UP ON BEING PUBLISHED
description: Not long after a South Carolina schoolteacher sent his manuscript to a New York literary agent, the agent, Julian Bach, telephoned him to report that Houghton Mifflin had accepted the novel for $7,500.

title: 2 Major Limits On I.R.A.'s
description: A BIG negative in the new tax law is the two major restrictions put on the tax deductibility of contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: WALL STREET CONTINUES 1987's RALLY
description: Stock prices crept higher yesterday, giving Wall Street its sixth straight gain and permitting the Dow Jones industrial average to remain above the 2,000 level.

title: CUOMO DECIDES NOT TO CHALLENGE RULING ON MILK
description: New York State will not appeal a Federal court ruling allowing a New Jersey dairy to sell its milk in all five boroughs of New York City, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: THIS MAYOR IS A 'COACH'
description: Mayor Koch may have tried to disavow the Giants, calling them a foreign team because they play in New Jersey, but Mayor George Voinovich of Cleveland is riding the wave of popularity generated by the Browns.

title: 8 BASEBALL FREE AGENTS ARE PIONEERS
description: In the aftermath of the midnight madness in which talented free agents such as Ron Guidry, Tim Raines and Lance Parrish did not sign with their 1986 teams, people on both sides of baseball's combative labor front focused their attention yesterday on the effect the unprecedented departures could have on teams and players.

title: Good Governor, Clever Candidate
description: To judge by Governor Cuomo's annual report on New York, the state of the state is flourishing; the state of the candidate is not all it should be. Whether or not the report is intended to support a run for President, it shows him to be talented and successful but also, as the British say, too clever by half.

title: Pratt & Whitney Retirement Plan
description: Pratt & Whitney has announced that nearly 2,000 salaried workers in four states have agreed to early retirement or voluntary terminations under a program to cut payroll costs. The voluntary response means the East Hartford-based jet engine builder does not expect to lay off any workers to reach its goals, a spokesman, David Long, said. Mr. Long said precise figures on the cutback program were not yet available from Pratt & Whitney's seven plants in Connecticut, Florida, Georgia and Maine.

title: INTELLECTUALS BECOME TARGET OF CRITICISM BY BEIJING
description: The campaign of newspaper editorials criticizing the recent student protests for greater freedoms focused today on intellectuals and dissident members of the Communist Party.

title: PRODUCER PRICES FELL 2.5% in '86
description: A steep drop in oil prices caused the nation's producer prices to fall 2.5 percent last year, the best performance in 37 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: For Press Curbs
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTDATED TEXTBOOKS ARE CITED IN SURVEY
description: More than half of the state's elementary school students are using outdated science textbooks, according to a State Board of Education study of programs in Connecticut public schools.

title: TROUBLE SPOTS LISTED FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: The city's Department of Transportation said these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region this weekend:

title: DRUG SEEMS TO HALT AN INFECTION CAUSED BY THE AIDS VIRUS
description: In a six-month study, the drug ribavirin appeared to halt the progression of an early form of infection caused by the AIDS virus, a drug company announced today.

title: TEACHERS BRISTLE AT PLAN FOR COURSES ON RACISM
description: When one teacher suggested that ugly comments about recent racial incidents in Queens represented the feelings of a few ''punks,'' Surekha Rao, a teacher at the Charles E. Hughes High School for the Humanities in Chelsea, disagreed.

title: VALENTINE HONORED
description: Bobby Valentine, who in his second season as manager of the Texas Rangers, led them to a second-place finish, will receive the William A. (Bill) Shea Distinguished Little League Graduate Award at next Sunday's dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. Valentine, who played Little League baseball in Stamford, Conn., in 1961 and 1962, will be honored as the first former Little Leaguer to manage a major league team. . . . Mike Cubbage, a former infielder for the Mets, has been named manager of their top farm team, Tidewater of the Triple A International League.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1987
description: Markets

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,462,000 and $6,209,000 on the sale of securities for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain on the sale of securities of $1,455,000 and $3,684,000 for the quarter and nine months, respectively, and net income from discontinued operations of $884,000 and $1,909,000 for the quarter and nine months, respectively. The company said that the slight increase in the third-quarter net from operations compared with the year-ago net from continuing operations resulted from gains on the sale of several car-wash units, which exceeded a modest decrease in operating profits.

title: PIERRE M. GEORGE
description: Pierre M. George, senior officer of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JURY FINDS A MAN GUILTY OF RACIAL SLURS
description: An Essex County jury found a 21-year-old Maplewood man guilty yesterday of painting racial slurs in 1983 on the home of a black family that lived near his home.

title: ESTEP MOVES ON
description: Mike Estep, the tennis coach from Texas who since mid-1983 had guided Martina Navratilova to 10 Grand Slam singles titles, has parted company amicably with the world's No. 1 women's tennis player to move on to what he termed ''other challenges.'' ''Mike and I remain on very friendly terms,'' Navratilova said. She has reportedly hired Virginia Wade, a former Wimbledon champion, and Randy Crawford, a club player, as hitting partners to replace Estep.

title: BROWNS' BYNER IS READY
description: Earnest Byner and Kevin Mack, the tandem that rushed for more than 1,000 yards apiece for the Browns last season, will be reunited in Cleveland for tomorrow's American Football Conference championship game against the Denver Broncos. The Browns said Byner would be activated today after being sidelined since the seventh game of the season with torn ankle ligaments.

title: An Elusive Morris vs. a Cunning Jordan
description: As the free safety, he has the best view of the play. He sees everything, but with one possible exception when his team plays the Giants, and that's what worries Curtis Jordan of the Washington Redskins.

title: N.C.A.A. Cuts Recruiting
description: Recruiting seasons were reduced in football and basketball and players received permission to give one complimentary game pass to someone other than a relative or student as delegates ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.

title: Korean Police Used Prudence and Responsibility Against Rally
description: To the Editor:

title: MET OPERA: NEW FACES IN 'BUTTERFLY'
description: Renata Scotto, as stage director, actress and rather shaky singer, remained the centerpiece of Thursday evening's performance of ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Metropolitan Opera. But several others were new since the first performance this season.

title: SEARCH FOR CREW RESUMES
description: Coast Guard rescue teams resumed their search today after finding one of five crew members who were missing after their fishing boat capsized. The survivor, Allen Louzon, 30 years old, of Narragansett, was found in a life raft 30 miles south of Martha's Vineyard on Thursday. The 73-foot fishing boat, the Andrew & Allison, went down Wednesday night about 50 miles off Point Judith, officials said.

title: Coca-Cola Sales Set for Moscow
description: Soviet citizens will be able to buy Coca-Cola beginning this year under an agreement that will also increase the production of juice and other nonalcoholic drinks, according to the Government newspaper Izvestia . Izvestia said that Coca-Cola would probably be on sale in Moscow, Kiev and other selected Soviet cities by May.

title: 2 KEY DOCUMENTS ON IRAN POLICY ARE MADE PUBLIC BY WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House, seeking to bolster President Reagan's claim that he approved arms shipments to Iran as part of a broad-based policy, released documents today that showed other considerations beyond the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: POLICE TRANSFER INTELLIGENCE CHEIF
description: The head of the intelligence division of the New York City Police Department was transferred to another post yesterday, pending the outcome of an investigation into social contacts between the commander and a reputed organized-crime figure, the police said.

title: Correction
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday, about the Senate committee report on arms shipments to Iran, incorrectly attributed a comment about the report. A reporter for The Times spoke by telephone not with Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter but with his wife and understood her to be relaying a comment verbatim from the admiral.

title: PATENTS
description: A speech-controlled electronic watch was patented this week for a Swiss company. The user pronounces coded words that regulate starting, stopping, timing and an alarm. The vocabulary may contain 15 words. Patent No. 4,635,286, granted to N.C. Bui and two co-inventors, was assigned to Asulab S.A. of Bianne, Switzerland.

title: Cutting Bank Card Interest
description: IF consumer groups get what they are lobbying for this year in various states and in Washington, banks offering credit cards would be prohibited from charging interest rates as high as the 17 to 19 percent that most consumers now pay.

title: WILLIAMS SHOULDERS NETS' LATEST LOSS
description: Buck Williams allowed the weight of the game to fall heavily on his shoulders. He blamed himself when the night was done, assuming a large dose of responsibility because he was not in the game when the Nets needed his physical presence most.

title: NORTH IMPLICATED IN USING PORTUGAL IN CONTRA SUPPLY
description: Congressional investigators have found evidence that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North coordinated many arms shipments to the Nicaraguan rebels through Portugal, according to Congressional sources.

title: FOES CLASH ON U.S. PLAN TO DRILL FOR OIL IN ARCTIC
description: Debate over the Interior Department's proposal to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling opened here today amid seemingly irreconcilable differences between proponents and opponents of development.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax provisions of $11 million for losses on contracts and writedowns of certain assets, and a gain of 3 cents a share on the sale of securities for the quarter; and for the year includes pre-tax provisions of $13,400,000 for losses on contracts and writedowns of certain assets, and a gain of 24 cents a share on the sale of securities. c-Includes pre-tax provision os $6,900,000 and $14,300,000 for losses on contracts and writedowns of certain assets for the quarter and year, respectively, and for the year includes a gain of 14 cents a share on the sale of securities. Latest quarter and year results include a pre-tax foreign currency translation loss of $4.5 million, which was reclassified from a direct charge to stockholders' equity, and an $8.7 million tax benefit, both of which arose on the termination of subsidiary company arrangements in Europe in connection with the establishment of independent distributorships and branch operations there. The company said that the tax benefit results from losses recognized through the third quarter of the current year and prior years for financial reporting purposes but could not be accorded U.S. tax benefit at such time.

title: DOCTORS SPLIT ON PREGNANCY'S RISKS TO WOMEN WITH MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS
description: Testimony this week in the Baby M trial about the risks of pregnancy to a woman with multiple sclerosis has focused attention on a subject that for years has divided the medical community.

title: DEAD STUNT MAN IS REMEMBERED AS A TOP ARTIST
description: Victor Magnotta was the consummate movie stunt man. He drove cars off bridges, turned flips on horseback, rappelled down the sides of burning buildings and scrambled up 100-foot masts on tall ships. He was known as ''the Bear.''

title: For Soviet Emigres, Still a Curtain
description: Mikhail Gorbachev continues to make remarkable changes in the Soviet Union. Boris Pasternak's long-banned ''Doctor Zhivago'' will be published within the year. The K.G.B. has expelled one of its own top officials for harassing a reporter seeking to expose corruption. Yet in contrast to these positive changes inside the Soviet Union comes a seeming clampdown on emigration. Mr. Gorbachev probably can have it both ways in Moscow, but not in the West. If Westerners are to take his internal policy of glasnost seriously, he would do well to extend the openness to Soviet borders.

title: OFFICER SUSPENDED FOR TRAFFIC ACCIDENT
description: An off-duty police officer who was driving the wrong way on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive early yesterday was arrested and suspended from duty after her car struck two other cars and injured two people, one of them critically, the police said.

title: For Tasty Muffins, Smaller Is Better
description: Most of the Brobdingnagian-size muffins that a lot of New Yorkers are eating for breakfast these days give muffins a bad name. It is rare to find one of these giants that is moist. Size, in part, is responsible; beating a lot of air into muffins makes them stale more quickly.

title: A CRISIS MOOD GRIPS FRANCE, HIT BY STRIKES
description: A mood of disquiet and fears of violence gripped France today as a succession of public-sector strikes continued to cripple the national railroad, the Paris subway and bus systems and the state-run power company.

title: THOUSANDS REPORTEDLY KILLED
description: Iran mounted a new offensive in the Persian Gulf war early today, and both sides reported heavy fighting near the southern Iraqi city of Basra.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. These are under investigation. What are they and what are the circumstances? 2. John Cardinal O'Connor paid a call on President Chaim Herzog of Israel after an impasse over the site of their meeting was resolved. Where did the two meet and what was at issue? 3. ''At the moment he is in retirement in Sussex, keeping bees,'' is the standard reply sent to real people who still write a fictional character being feted on his centenary. Identify the character. 4. According to a New York Times/ WCBS-TV News poll, about (13/25/ 33/50/65) percent of New Yorkers say that many or almost all whites and blacks in the city dislike one another and that a racial attack such as the one last month in Howard Beach, Queens, could have occurred in their own neighborhoods. 5. According to recent reports by the Central Intelligence Agency and a Defense Department study group, the United States (laser/munitions/ semiconductor/surveillance) industry is in worse shape than had been recognized. 6. Despite contentions that it could do everything from treating arthritis to enhancing fertility, medical experts have shown that a food poses a significant health risk, and a Federal district court ordered it banned from interstate sale. What food is it? 7. In separate votes that involved ideology and personality, an incumbent prevailed on a Senate committee and an incumbent was deposed on a House of Representatives committee. Who are the legislators and what are the committees? 8. Saying it was ''absolutely untenable,'' the Landmarks Preservation Commission dealt a surprising setback to a four-year-old plan for one of New York City's parks. What park is it and what is the plan? 9. This man went for a swim. Why is that noteworthy? 10. ''We think time is our worst enemy, and the quicker we get it released the better off we will be,'' said a White House official. To what report was he referring and what happened? 11. An instrument that is sharper and more accurate than any surgeon's knife is being used to treat life-threatening brain tumors. What instrument is it? 12. A book of wry observations on family life was far and away the best-selling hard-cover book in the United States last year, according to a survey by The New York Times. Identify it. 13. For the first time since he retired a decade ago, an athlete returned to the playing field, reminding veterans and newcomers alike why he is known as the sport's greatest player ever. Who is he and what was the occasion? 14. The Government of (Denmark/ Finland/Norway/Sweden), the most feminized of democratic lands, is run by a Prime Minister who is a woman with the help of 7 other women in a Cabinet of 17 members. 15. President Reagan's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1988 would (increase/reduce/leave unchanged) funds for drug enforcement. 16. The Weill Recital Hall formally opened. Where is it and by what name was it previously known? 17. French warplanes bombed a Libyan-held airfield in the northern part of a foreign country to retaliate for Libyan air raids in the southern part, a region that France has committed itself to defend. Identify the country. 18. A Federal investigator into the fatal hotel fire in San Juan, P.R., said the inquiry was focusing on (hotel guests/hotel employees/gamblers in the hotel). 19. With their victory over the San Francisco 49ers, the Giants advanced to a championship game for the first time since (1963/1964/1965/1966).

title: SUFFOLK POLITICS: DEMOCRACY IN ACTION BUT CHAOS IN CONTROL
description: The recent organizational meeting of the Suffolk County Legislature had not received advance billing as an entertainment event. But a crowd of 250 people, many carrying brightly colored, often witty signs, clearly anticipated a show. They were not to be disappointed. The chaos last Friday began soon after the Pledge of Allegiance, when two legislators started shouting at each other across the room, arguing bitterly about proper procedures and professional courtesy. And soon, the organizational meeting became completely disorganized as a hasty call for a recess from the Republican leadership drew howls of protest from the crowd and cries of ''despicable'' and ''unlawful'' from many Democratic legislators.

title: Black Caucus and Jackson
description: Although they decline to commit themselves publicly, several prominent members of the Congressional Black Caucus met this week with the Rev. Jesse Jackson to discuss another Jackson run for the Presidency.

title: ROBERT YOUNG TAKES ON A NEW KIND OF TV ROLE
description: Robert Young, associated by most television viewers with the kindly, all-knowing father figures he portrayed on his long-running series, ''Father Knows Best'' and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.,'' is about to tackle a different kind of role. Sunday night, in a new NBC-TV movie called ''Mercy or Murder,'' Mr. Young portrays Roswell Gilbert, a Florida engineer who shot his wife - a victim of Alzheimer's disease -and was convicted of first-degree murder.

title: MERIDIAN NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago period results reflect two months of operations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf O'Grady Grabs Lead: Mac O'Grady stumbled a bit coming down the home holes yesterday but managed to hold on to a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 35th Tournament of Champions, at Carlsbad, Calif. The powerful hitter rescued a bogey 5 after two bunker shots on 18 to finish with two-under-par 70 for a 54-hole total of nine-under 207.

title: BILL TO HELP THE HOMELESS IS PROPOSED IN THE HOUSE
description: Leaders in the House of Representatives have proposed a $500 million emergency package of food, shelter and other aid for the homeless, and they say they hope to get the money by early spring.

title: Correction
description: A correction in this space yesterday in some copies, referring to a chart in Sports Pages last Tuesday, misidentified the league in which the Buffalo Bills and the San Diego Chargers played in 1964. They were members of the American Football League, which merged with the National Football League in 1970.

title: PROTECTIVE CUSTODY ORDERED FOR YOUTH
description: Jon L. Lester, one of three white youths charged in a racial attack on three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, will serve a one-to-three-year state prison term in another case in ''protective custody,'' the state Commissioner of Correctional Services ordered yesterday.

title: ORACLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
OUT OF ALL THE HORROR, SOMEHOW, A MUSEUM
description: Arthur Rosenblatt has just returned from a field trip to help him with the planning of Washington's newest museum. He shows off an album of color photographs he took on his trip, which was not a pleasant one.

title: Warning to Journalists
description: Reed Irvine, chairman of Accuracy in Media Inc., is seeking contributions for an advertising campaign to persuade journalists to ''take a more serious view of their responsibilities'' in reporting the Iran arms affair.

title: DR. LENA F. EDWARDS, WINNER OF U.S. MEDAL
description: Dr. Lena F. Edwards, who in 1964 received the Government's highest civilian honor, the Medal of Freedom, for her medical services to migrant laborers in Texas, died Dec. 3 at her home in Lakewood, N.J. She was 86 years old.

title: G.M. Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will place 350 workers on indefinite layoff at two Hydramatic division plants in southwestern Michigan effective Jan. 30. The layoffs were prompted by lower demand for cars using automatic transmissions produced at the plants in Three Rivers and Constantine, according to Allen Coleman, manager of the division's St. Joseph County operations. The two plants employ a total of 1,950 workers.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: 'Bookies' Will End, But No Whimpering

title: Bridge; Scheduler Kept Players Busy At the World Championships
description: The 1986 world championships in Miami Beach followed an interesting and innovative schedule, devised by Edgar Kaplan, the editor of The Bridge World. Since nobody likes to travel halfway round the world and spend most of the time in idleness, the plan was to keep everyone busy.

title: BOND RULING ON HOLD
description: The fate of Alan Bond's America's Cup syndicate remained tenuous in Fremantle, Australia, yesterday when a five-man jury adjourned, putting off for at least another day any action to resolve a dispute over a sail between Bond's Australia IV and Kevin Parry's Kookaburra team. At stake is the Bond syndicate's continued presence as an America's Cup defender.

title: BILL TYNES, ARTISTIC DIRECTOR OF NEW AMSTERDAM THEATER
description: Bill Tynes, the founder and the artistic director of the New Amsterdam Theater Company, died yesterday morning at his parents' home in Placentia, Calif., of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, his mother said. He was 30 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Diana Brooks Named President of Sotheby's
description: Diana D. Brooks was named president of Sotheby's Inc., the North American division of the international auction house, yesterday, replacing John L. Marion, who retains the title of chairman.

title: EPSILON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A NEW LICENSE PLATE?
description: LEAD: See that car ahead? It's one from home. How easy it is to recognize the nearly immutable orange and bluish-black colors of New York State's license plates.

title: Getting Two Bites at the Compensation Apple
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY SHELTERS REACH A PEAK IN POPULATION
description: With the coldest winter months still to come, more homeless men and women are already sleeping in New York City's shelters than ever before.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a very bullish employment report.'' - Jay N. Woodworth of the Bankers Trust Company. [ 50:1. ]

title: HUNT'S NEW FOCUS
description: Tomorrow is the day that justifies all the other days. Not necessarily because the New York Football Giants, still crazy after all these years, will be playing for a trip to a Super Bowl. Not so long ago, before this many inhabitants of the home team's dressing room became stronger, surer-handed and more self-assured, Giants of a sadder time wondered what it would be like, just once, if they had to spend Christmas week at work.

title: Hold the Horsehair
description: Hold your hand up if you're excited about the President's budget. Ah yes, there were bound to be a few out there. I was tempted to say that nobody cares about the budget anymore, but there are always a few who care, even about the budget.

title: The Breakup of Allied Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation is being forced into some drastic actions that it could have taken long before any acquirer hoisted its standard at the retailer's door.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Climb
description: Treasury bond prices closed sharply higher yesterday after laboring under the pressure earlier in the day of economic statistics that were bearish for the credit markets.

title: PATENTS
description: Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., received his 218th patent this week for a practice putting device that can be used indoors. Golf balls are knocked across a ramp and a level area containing a cup. Balls missing the cup land in a second pocket. The equipment, called Multi-Zone, can be used in competition by several players.

title: INSIDE
description: Currency Change Likely Europeans will discuss a series of new currency values this weekend.

title: 'IDEOLOGICAL GROUNDS' ARE A MYTH
description: Several individuals have complained to the media in recent months that the United States Government denied them visas on ''ideological grounds.'' This is untrue. Those denied visas may coincidentally espouse positions that are unpopular in the United States. But that is not the reason they are refused entry. Something else is going on.

title: Correction
description: Because of editing errors, a Bangkok dispatch on Jan. 3 about Prince Norodom Ranariddh, a Cambodian guerrilla leader who is Prince Norodom Sihanouk's son, incorrectly described his travels and the relative size of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Prince Ranariddh said he shuttled back and forth between the Cambodian border and Bangkok, not Beijing. And the Khmer People's National Liberation Front is not the smallest of the three groups in the Cambodian guerrilla coalition; the Sihanouk force is.

title: ERRANT MOOSE LOSES ANTLERS AND DESIRE
description: The desire that made a lovesick moose devote 76 days to wooing Jessica the cow apparently dropped off with his antlers, and he deserted the Hereford of his dreams the next morning.

title: CAR IS RAMMED BY DUMP TRUCK AT JAMAICA BAY
description: A man and a woman were seriously injured yesterday when a sand-laden dump truck struck and overturned their car on a causeway over Jamaica Bay in Queens. The police said up to three men in the truck fled on foot as another motorist halted and fired gunshots into the air.

title: OPPOSITION TESTS IT
description: The Sandinista Government put a new Constitution into effect today, and opposition groups moved to take advantage of its provisions by staging protest marches in two cities.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Irish Music
description: The flutists Jack Coen, from Galway, and Michael Preston, from Sligo, will play Irish music tonight at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Tickets are $5.

title: SEAT BELTS ON TRAINS WEIGHED AFTER DEADLY CRASH
description: The Federal Government's chief railroad safety officer said today that he would seek comments on whether seat belts should be installed on the passenger coaches of Amtrak and the five commuter rail systems that use the Northeast Corridor between Washington and Boston.

title: PORTRAIT OF A DISASTER: PANIC AMID FLAMES AT HOTEL
description: Alexander Leighton was walking his golden retriever on the wide, curving Condado Beach, a wild surf pounding at his feet, when a faint, acrid odor caught his attention.

title: Confusion Is Evident On a Presidential Bid
description: The Cuomo administration, under increasing pressure from national Democratic figures to signal whether the Governor will run for President, sent not one but half a dozen signals over the last week, most of them contradictory.

title: Letter: On Energy Efficiency; Need for Household Appliance Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: PURDUE TRANSFER
description: Purdue's new football coach, Fred Akers, announced yesterday that the Boilermakers' quarterback, Jeff George, would transfer to another school. ''To build the kind of program I want at Purdue, I want young men who love Purdue and want to be here. That is not the case with Jeff, so I wish him luck,'' Akers said, adding that he believed George would hold a news conference in Indianapolis today. The Indianapolis News reported that the schools George was considering included Auburn, Miami of Florida, Tennessee and U.C.L.A.

title: PATENTS
description: A yarn caddy that she calls a Happy Hooker has been invented by Christine A. Wilson of Ventura, Calif. She received patent No. 4,634,077 this week and has begun production.

title: MAN BITES FOOTBALL PLAYER
description: When the Giants take the field at home tomorrow in a football game that some people may have heard about, the fans will greet them with a mundane but heartfelt, ''Yeah, yeah.''

title: When Visa Officials Shut America's Gate
description: LEAD: When I read that an American journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, was jailed by the Russians for allegedly spying, I never imagined that I would live a similar nightmare on preposterous charges in the country of liberty, the United States.

title: Miss Grady Weds Thomas F. Skelly Jr.
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Kathleen Monica Grady, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Grady of Greenwich, was married to Thomas Francis Skelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Skelly of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Stephen J. DeLuca performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BRASS RUBBINGS Brass rubbing is an old craft that produces quickly and easily a respectable piece of art at minimal cost. It requires no artistic skill and is an enjoyable way to spend half an hour or so. Those who have never tried it may treat themselves to an introductory workshop under the watchful eyes of experts from the Brass Rubbing Center in London and its branch in Washington D.C., courtesy of the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport.

title: ENHANCED TV STANDARDS STILL ELUSIVE
description: At the outset of a new year, engineering executives entrusted with long-range planning invariably wax eloquent about things to come. In television, they usually tell us that everything is obsolete, that we ought to chuck the whole system and start from scratch.

title: EMELIN SCHEDULES THREE RECITALS
description: THE concert scene is beginning to emerge from its holiday hibernation, the Emelin Theater leading the way with three major recitals this week, and at least four major events vying for your attention next Sunday afternoon.

title: Putting a Career On Hold
description: What is this, female chauvinism? Aren't there any fathers who are interested in taking care of their children? It is good to hear that Procter & Gamble, at least, has paternity leave. I hope the idea catches on, and fast.

title: TECHNOLOGY/THEOLOGY IN UPDIKE
description: To the Editor: I was startled to read the description of John Updike's most recent novel, ''Roger's Version,'' in the first paragraph of the Rev. John P. Meier's fine article ''Jesus Among the Historians'' (Dec. 21). The young student pitted against Roger Lambert is not a divinity student but a computer programmer who has worked on computer research projects at the university where Lambert teaches, as the young man tells Lambert on page 18 of the novel. The fact that the young man's expertise lies in the area of computer technology and not in theology is an important feature of the novel. LAUREN A. HAHN Mundelein, Ill.

title: City Taxes
description: To the Editor: Your Dec. 14 article on Woodhaven, Queens [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Woodhaven'' ] says that houses there selling for $150,000 to $300,000 have taxes ranging from $600 and $1,200 a year, which means they are assessed at less than 5 percent of market value.

title: KNICKS PUT IT TOGETHER
description: It is no secret that the Knicks win games when their two most important frontcourt players, Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, play well enough to dominate their respective defenders. And when the two have failed, it has often been because the Knicks did not have a deep threat whose outside shot kept the opposing defense away from them.

title: BONDS ISSUED, STATE DRAWS CLOSER TO TRASH-TO-ENERGY SYSTEM
description: THE Connecticut Resource Recovery Authority has issued bonds for a $42 million waste-to-energy plant to be built in Wallingford. The action, taken in the final week of 1986, signaled the overcoming of another of many obstacles by the authority, which is seeking to erect six of the plants.

title: SPEED IS NEEDED ON TAX REFORM
description: THERE are very few problems confronting local government in New Jersey that cannot be traced directly to the state's onerous system of property taxation. And there should be no higher priority for the Governor and the Legislature than to find solutions for it.

title: Corporate Sponsors Climb Aboard
description: FOR a sport that attracts an upscale market, sailboat racing has attracted surprisingly little corporate support in the United States. That's all starting to change, however, thanks in part to the America's Cup and a recent decision to ease restrictions on advertising on racing boats.

title: ONE LESSON OF SAN JUAN BLAZE: IT COULD HAPPEN ANYWHERE
description: SPECIAL circumstances - a pile of new furniture, weak safety regulation and a poorly equipped, understrength fire department - helped bring the death toll to 96 in the fire New Year's Eve at the Dupont Plaza Hotel. But safety experts say these factors should not divert Americans from the real lesson to be drawn from the disaster:

title: 'SAVE THE ROLLS': RULES FOR THE FLORIDA VISIT
description: MY mother has become a ''snowbird.'' She flew to Florida before the first snowflake fell on Long Island, and she's not returning home until spring. I'm killing two birds with one stone this winter. I'll visit my mother and soak up some Florida sunshine at the same time.

title: ORIENTAL PORCELAINS IN EUROPEAN MOUNTS
description: Chinese and Japanese porcelains, mounted sparely and sumptuously in gilded and silvered metal mounts, were made to amuse aristocrats over more than six centuries. Today the charms of these extravagant decorations are enjoyed by enthusiasts from all levels of society, as could be seen on a recent morning in the mix of people filing through the exhibition ''Mounted Oriental Porcelains,'' at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street.

title: Judge's Decision Opens the Way To Cheaper Milk
description: A Federal judge ruled last week that Farmland Dairies of Wallington, N.J., which drove down milk prices on Staten Island when it was allowed to compete there, could sell its milk throughout New York City.

title: Ms. Cassata to Marry Dr. Robert Mazziotta
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Cassata of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Cassata, to Dr. Robert Mazziotta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mazziotta of White Plains.

title: MYERSON, AT GRAND JURY, INVOKED 5TH AMENDMENT
description: Bess Myerson, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, invoked the Fifth Amendment last month before a Federal grand jury investigating a contractor, but did not tell Mayor Koch or any member of his administration about it until a television station broadcast a news report Friday night, the Mayor said yesterday.

title: A New Era
description: To the Sports Editor: Regarding the New York Yacht Club's America's Cup campaign, I would like to note that although it is the first time since the inception of the America's Cup in the 19th century that the club has not been involved in the final series, it is also the first time the New York Yacht Club has had to compete to be involved in the final series. Yachting has changed dramatically since the 19th century. STEPHEN HICKS New York

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S 123 commercial banks reflected the state's economic growth and prosperity last year and expect 1987 to be ''just as good,'' according to a year-end report by Robert A. Rough, chairman of the New Jersey Bankers Association and president of the National Bank of Sussex County in Branchville.

title: It Has Declined, But Still Not Enough
description: WITH the United States trade deficit remaining stubbornly high, controversy has arisen about whether the dollar has fallen as far as the standard indexes say it has. Some analysts contend that the dollar has fallen hardly at all from its February 1985 peak, which explains the continuing large deficits. Others say the dollar has reversed nearly all of its previous rise, and predict a gradual decline in the deficits.

title: FRANCESCA HAD A SECRET
description: QUEEN OF HEARTS By Susan Richards Shreve. 354 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday in Portfolio of '86, the special Year in Review section, misstated the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. He was born on Jan. 15, 1929, and the birthday is observed as a national holiday on the third Monday of January.

title: HOBBLING REAGAN'S TRILLION-DOLLAR 'DRAGON'
description: THE zeal and fervor, the secrecy and surprise that used to surround President Reagan's budgets gave way last week to a note of fatalism as his seventh annual blueprint for Federal spending went to Congress.

title: THE 100TH CONGRESS IS FULL OF PARTISAN RISK
description: AT the outset of the 100th Congress last week, the leaders tried to strike a bipartisan chord. The new Democratic Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas, told the House of Representatives, ''We seek not confrontation but cooperation.'' At almost the same moment, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader in the Senate, was saying, ''It is necessary that we start off on a totally nonpartisan, bipartisan basis.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: HOMEOWNERS needing to borrow money to remedy a radon problem can now get a subsidized loan through the state's Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency.

title: THOMPSON, A 4TH TERM, LOOKING BEYOND ILLINOIS
description: Almost 34 years ago James Robert Thompson signed his high school yearbook, ''Jim Thompson, Pres. of U.S. 1984-1992.''

title: LAWMAKERS SEEK TO ADD U.S. JUDGE
description: THE Connecticut Congressional delegation is hoping that Democratic control of the 100th Congress will spur passage of legislation that would provide a seventh Federal judgeship in the state.

title: HOSPITALS REACT TO NEW HEALTH-CARE PLAN
description: FEWER hospitals in the county will treat acutely ill patients and more will offer drug rehabilitation and care for the elderly if a controversial plan for the future of the area's health-care system is put into effect.

title: Submarine Strategy
description: In his article ''A Silent Battle Surfaces'' (Dec. 7), Richard Halloran quotes a United States Navy admiral as saying that forward-attacks by American submarines on Soviet subs would reduce ''the attractiveness [ to the Russians ] of nuclear escalation by changing the nuclear balance in our favor.'' What neither the admiral nor Mr. Halloran pointed out, however, is of equal importance: such a change in ''nuclear balance'' may well make nuclear escalation more attractive to the American side. This danger increases as the Navy's confidence in its ability to attack and successfully destroy considerable numbers of Soviet nuclear submarines grows. Thus, it seems reasonable to conclude that the Navy's new submarine strategy is part of a larger American nuclear first-strike strategy. MARK D. HIGBEE New York City

title: A RUSH FOR BUSINESS DEGREES
description: A NEW doctoral-degree program in business at the University of Connecticut has attracted more than 30 applicants for each seat to be available this fall.

title: WHEN WILL IT END?
description: IN the tormented inner world of Giant fans, it is still the long, hot summer of 1969 and they are still singing ''Goodbye Allie.'' These poor souls still fall into a tortured sleep at night watching Mike Battle of the despised Jets hurdling the crouched, frozen bodies of Giant tacklers.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Housing the Elderly; Private Rentals In 18 Projects
description: WITH advances in health-care contributing to longer lives, the market for barrier-free and assisted-living housing for the elderly has steadily increased.

title: Submarine Strategy
description: Richard Halloran notes in his article that ''the battleship dominated naval operations in World War I.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ON THE AVENUE
description: LEAD: Do you live in Avenueland? If you're well-educated, successful at work and committed to good living, chances are you qualify. At least according to Judith Price, publisher of Avenue, a glossy magazine full of features on business, the arts, travel and trends. It also has luxurious fashion layouts and social and cultural calendars.

title: Wedding Planned By Suzanne King
description: Suzanne Deborah King and Jonathan Seth Scharfstein, fourth-year medical students at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married May 31, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. King of Los Angeles, have announced. Mr. Scharfstein is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Scharfstein of New York.

title: A TROVE OF BRIC-A-BRAC IN THE MARAIS
description: There is a little chunk of Paris that has been hollowed out and spruced up, reconstituted into a village and set down beside the Seine. On a bright weekday morning, it seems surrounded by the flowing of water: by the handsome 17th-century fountains and spouts of this corner of the Marais, where the odd wanderer may be washing a blanket, and by the streams that gush mysteriously from the gutters of Paris, courtesy of the municipal authorities.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: COMPETITION IS DEAD, LONG LIVE COMPETITION
description: THE BIGNESS COMPLEX Industry, Labor, and Government in the American Economy. By Walter Adams and James W. Brock. 426 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
BLACK ARTISTS, YES, BUT BLACK ART?
description: LEAD: WHEN the Great Neck Library mounted its first ''Contemporary Black Artists in America'' exhibition, in 1971, just the notion of ''black artists'' was unusual, especially in suburbia.

title: ORIGINS OF KAZAKHSTAN RIOTING ARE DESCRIBED
description: The Soviet press began reporting new details this week of the violent anti-Russian rioting last month in the republic of Kazakhstan, and it placed part of the blame on ethnic segregation in local universities.

title: TIGHTS TAKE THE STAGE
description: MEN in tights are becoming a more common sight these days in Manhattan, which means one of two things. Either there is a rash of ''Romeo and Juliet'' productions Off Broadway or we are once again on that precipice known as the cutting edge.

title: DEVILS SALVAGE A TIE (AGAIN)
description: After their second consecutive tie, this time 2-2 with the Vancouver Canucks today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Devils were without a victory in their last 10 games. But they viewed the streak from a practical perspective.

title: Headliners; Civilian Royalty
description: Apparently life at the Royal Marine commando training camp was not too tough for Prince Edward, just too - well, common. There was quite a stir in Britain last week when word leaked out that the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II was considering quitting the year-long commando course only four months after starting it.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FELLINI: A Life. By Hollis Alpert. (Atheneum, $21.95.) Hollis Alpert, the author of biographies of Richard Burton and the Barrymore family, has written a strangely somnolent account of the celebrated Italian film maker's life. Mr. Fellini has a compulsion - a joyous compulsion - to make movies. Disappointingly, though, Mr.

title: AFTER CHURCH: PORTRAITS OF A PROUD BLACK COMMUNITY
description: THE photographer stood in the midday summer sun. Her subjects posed in the shade, standing or sitting in the doorway of the First Baptist Church in Riverhead, before a blank, black paper screen that sometimes wafted and billowed in a breeze.

title: Cornelia Quarles Engaged to Wed Harry Wonham
description: The engagement of Cornelia Grant Quarles to Harry Brunie Wonham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Wonham of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Very Quarles 3d of Atlanta, parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Dawn L. Gordon To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Dawn Lisa Gordon to Ronald Charles Luks has been announced by her mother, Annette J. Gordon of New York. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Luks of North Royalton, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: FAMILY CARE LIFTS SAN JUAN FIRE VICTIMS
description: LEAD: WHEN Nicholas Perrotti, a victim of the Puerto Rico hotel fire, arrived at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven, he received two levels of care simultaneously. While doctors and nurses were preparing to put Mr. Perrotti in traction, members of his family fed him homemade soup.

title: Condos Top Northeast Ski-Area Boom
description: CONDOMINIUMS, which shot up alongside the birch and pine trees of Northeast ski resorts in the 1970's, seemed to push chalets and other single-family homes to the edge of extinction, as well as bruising motels a bit.

title: THE COLORS OF WALL STREET
description: LEAD: THE ROPESPINNER CONSPIRACY By Michael M. Thomas. 433 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

title: LEGISLATORS AWAIT KEY KEAN TALK
description: WHEN Governor Kean delivers his State of the State Message to the Legislature Tuesday, he will be firing the opening gun of what promises to be the most politically charged year in the Senate and Assembly in more than a decade.

title: Michelle A. Pagnucco To Wed Eric Bostrup
description: The engagement of Michelle Ann Pagnucco to Eric Bostrup has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Pagnucco of South Salem, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Bostrup of Purdys, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Pagnucco, a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., received a master's degree in nutrition last month from Case Western Reserve University. Her father is vice president and associate general counsel at PepsiCo Inc. in Purchase, N.Y. Her grandfather Louis A. Pagnucco of Sparta, N.J., is a retired judge of the New York State Family Court.

title: Putting a Career On Hold
description: Does no writer on the subject of careers versus motherhood have the temerity to tell a probable truth: that many corporate women quit ''to raise my children'' purely and simply because working is just too tough?

title: Giants Outrage
description: To the Sports Editor: In the aftermath of my euphoria over the Giants' most convincing victory of the year, I sat down in my favorite chair to read the Sunday sports section. I had scanned it before the game looking for any last-minute injury reports, but otherwise was too keyed up about the game to really sit down and read it.

title: CITING CHRONIC DEADLOCK, PANEL URGES ALTERING POLITICAL STRUCTURE
description: Amid the national celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution, a group of prominent political figures and analysts here has concluded that the political structure the framers set up impedes solutions to many of today's problems and needs to be changed.

title: Miss Richardson to Wed
description: The engagement of Deborah Brewster Richardson to Richard Hinrichs Beinecke has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas deQuartel Richardson of Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Beinecke is the son of Mary Ann Beinecke of Williamstown, Mass., and Herbert H. Hinrichs of Tenafly, N.J. He is the stepson of Walter Beinecke Jr. of Nantucket, Mass. Miss Richardson heads her own jewelry design concern in Cambridge, Mass. Her fiance is a senior planner at the Harvard Community Health Plan in Boston.

title: Debora Lee Freedman Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Debora Lee Freedman to Gregory Joseph Clower has been announced by Mrs. Henri Axel Schupf of Greenwich, Conn., and Walter Gary Freedman of Chicago, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Clower of Wilmette, Ill.

title: Mexico by Bus
description: To the Editor: The question in the Nov. 9 Q & A column regarding intercity bus travel in Mexico struck a chord.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HEY, AL By Arthur Yorinks. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: HOSPITAL FUND IS HELPED BY WEEKEND RESIDENTS
description: NEW MILFORD Hospital has $5.6 million for renovation work thanks to an unusual cross section of donors - residents of both Connecticut and New York State, and New Yorkers who spend only weekends in the New Milford area.

title: RACIST THREATS FAIL TO BREAK EFFORTS FOR A FREEDOM MARCH
description: When Charles A. Blackburn moved to this hilly, rustic North Georgia county five years ago from the San Franciso Bay area, he thought is was a perfect balance: a cabin on a lake in woodsy country just 30 miles north of metropolitan Atlanta. Mr.Blackburn is a white man, and he did not notice at first, so close to that city of racial harmony, that there were no black people in Forsyth County.

title: Hold the Replays
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to put in a vote for the abolition of the National Football League's replay rule. It was a joy to watch Penn State play Miami in the Fiesta Bowl without having to wait 4 minutes 10 seconds between plays. (a la Rams vs. Redskins). ROBERT NISSEN New York

title: O'Grady Wins Season Opener
description: Three months after ending a six-week suspension from the PGA Tour, Mac O'Grady achieved his biggest victory so far when he overcame putting tremors today to win the 35th annual MONY Tournament of Champions by one shot over Rick Fehr.

title: HOUSING SQUEEZE PRESSES CAPE TO FILL YEAR-ROUND JOBS
description: Among the more familiar sights on Cape Cod this winter are the ''Help Wanted'' signs in virtually all the large supermarkets, department stores, pharmacies and restaurant chains, from Sandwich to Orleans.

title: INFIGHTING HURTS TAMILS' CAUSE IN INDIA
description: In a major development in the Sri Lankan civil war, infighting among rival Tamil rebel groups has begun to anger India and damage the guerrillas' reputation in the eyes of sympathizers.

title: COMMITTEE SEEKS TO TURN IRVINGTON VILLA INTO BLACK MUSEUM
description: LEAD: VILLA LEWARO, a white neo-classical mansion on North Broadway in Irvington, was built for Sarah J. Walker, a laundrywoman who invented a hair straightener and became the country's first black female millionaire. (The mansion's name is made up of the first letters of her daughter's name.) Mrs. Walker died in 1919 at the age of 52.

title: Kathleen Joan Sterritt, An Editor, Is Engaged
description: Kathleen Joan Sterritt, the assistant editor of the Washington Home section of The Washington Post, and Mitchell Fanning Stanley, a special assistant to the Secretary of Commerce, are planning a June wedding. The announcement of their engagement was made by the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Wayman of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: WHEN FILM MAKERS INTERPRET BALLETS
description: Movies based on ballets are back in vogue. ''El Amor Brujo,'' a new film by Carlos Saura and Antonio Gades, is inspired by the ballet of the same name originally created in 1915. The choreography was by the Spanish dancer Pastora Imperio, set to a now-celebrated score by Manuel de Falla. ''Nutcracker, the Motion Picture,'' as conceived by Maurice Sendak and Kent Stowell and directed by Carroll Ballard, is a version of the even more famous 1890 Russian ballet to Tchaikovsky's score.

title: THE COLORS OF WALL STREET
description: THE PANIC OF '89 By Paul Erdman. 304 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: FRIGHTENED BY THE SILENCE
description: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS #1970-1985. By David Ignatow. 332 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $12.95.

title: Jazz
description: Whenever two or more jazz musicians get together to play the same instrument on the same stage, tradition dictates a ''battle,'' an evening of virtuosic muscle-flexing and crowd-pleasing. The ''Trumpet Summit'' at Fat Tuesday's this week looks more complementary than competetive, though, and that's a good sign.

title: Funerals
description: To the Editor: ''What's New in the Funeral Business'' (Dec. 14) made no reference to the country's 150 Memorial Societies. These are consumer-controlled, non-profit organizations that help their 250,000 members plan in advance the service and disposition of body they want. Some societies negotiate low prices with funeral homes; others simply collect prices for a set of simple funerals. You only pay the cost of the funeral when life's end finally comes.

title: EX-ACTRESS TENDS A MULLICA DRAWBRIDGE
description: LEAD: THE woman who operates the electric-powered drawbridge spanning the picturesque Mullica River here calls her work ''a labor of love.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BAYEUX TAPESTRY ''The Bayeux Tapestry as Unravelled by David Bernstein'' is not the chronicle of a horrendous act of vandalism, but an exhibition based on Mr. Bernstein's book ''The Mystery of the Bayeux Tapestry.'' It can be seen at the library of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers through Feb. 28.

title: N.F.C. CHAMPIONSHIP: GIANTS vs. REDSKINS; Tradition, Pride and Now Glory: Line
description: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

title: 'That Girl'
description: To the Editor: Regarding your Dec. 7 article on Brewster [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Brewster,'' ] : You failed to mention that those young professionals moving into the area probably first heard of Brewster while watching television when they were growing up in the mid-60's.

title: GAZEBO SITE
description: A gazebo, proponents say, would enhance the artistic and recreational life of Chappaqua. It would provide a place for concerts, lectures, exhibits and plays. It would be esthetically pleasing, would attract audiences to school concerts and would become a focal point for the community. No one has publicly disagreed; nevertheless, the gazebo has remained only an idea for the last six years, and following the latest rejection of a proposed site, it is likely to remain so longer.

title: Bank Ethics
description: To the Editor: Before Mr. Bennett continues to make broad-based accusations of ''scrappy marketing'' and misrepresentation by commercial banks (''Now, the Age of Fast Buck Banking,'' Dec. 14), let him attend a sales training session. The strong presence of integrity that he will encounter will far outweigh the wrongs some banks have done while entering the ''financial services revolution.''

title: How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
description: Whether the use of anabolic steroids should be allowed is controversial; to deny their popularity and desired effect is foolish. I am amazed at the continued lack of acknowledgement that anabolic steroids increase muscle size and strength. Maybe there is little evidence to prove this but how many scientific studies have been conducted?

title: Dining in Paris
description: To the Editor: It may be time to re-evaluate our stereotype of the Ugly American tourist in Europe. We travel to France often and enjoy the country, its culture and its cuisine. We find brasseries most enjoyable for good food at almost any hour, but the noise of the conversations is usually at near-shouting level. Even worse, the cigarette smoke is intense as most of the French seem addicted to tobacco. Recently, however, we had a lovely dinner at a small Parisian restaurant (recommended by The New York Times). The food was excellent. The conversation was cheerful and at a discreet level, and nobody smoked. All of the diners that evening were Americans. HENRY N. CLAMAN, M.D. Denver

title: REPUBLICANS PLAN MAJOR NASSAU SHIFTS
description: THE Nassau County Republican chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, is considering taking the powerful Hempstead presiding supervisor post for himself when Nassau officials make a major switch in jobs over four hours on Thursday.

title: REVVING UP THE AMERICAN FACTORY
description: WHEN T. J. Rodgers started the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation in 1983, he was bucking a strong tide. American manufacturers of all stripes were moving their production overseas and Japanese imports were grabbing an ever larger share of the domestic semiconductor market. But Mr. Rodgers was confident that a new, superfast computer chip that he was developing would enable Cypress to thrive - at home.

title: Verbatim; Reforms Needed
description: 'Even if you indict and convict every mobster involved in corruption, under current conditions, someone else will come along, recognize the potential and become the new predators.'

title: Pope Declares the Arms Race Fosters Rich-Poor Frictions
description: Pope John Paul II condemned the arms race today as a fundamental cause of friction between rich and poor countries, and he called on nations to cut their stockpiles of weapons to levels compatible with self-defense.

title: DEATH HALTS FAIRFIELD GAME
description: The basketball game between Fordham and Fairfield was suspended with 1 minute 42 seconds remaining today when the grandmother of one of the Fairfield players collapsed and died in the stands, officials said.

title: CLIP-ONS TO GIVE SHOES A LIFT
description: The Fairchild family, which founded Women's Wear Daily and W, has long been a force in American fashion. Now Jill Fairchild, the daughter of Women's Wear's publisher, John Fairchild, is stepping into the family business with a line of fanciful shoe accessories.

title: Leslie Safford Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Safford of Gardiner, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Anne Safford, to Claude Robert Spiro, a son of Robert Spiro and Elaine R. Spiro of Great Neck, L.I. Ms. Safford, an associate editor of the Journal of the Audio Engineering Society, graduated from the Emma Willard School and Vassar College. Her fiance is a music therapist at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn. He graduated from the Manhattan School of Music and received a master's degree in music therapy from New York University.

title: SPILL'S EFFECTS ON RHINE MAY BE LESS THAN FEARED
description: GENEVA, Jan. 10 -

title: NEW YORK THEATER: ISN'T IT ROMANTIC
description: There is a new phenonemnon in New York. Every night at 7:30 hordes of eager diners pour out of restaurants, from the intimate French bistros of Greenwich Village to the 874-seat ''Only Guacamole'' Yupeterias on the Upper West Side. Across Manhattan former ''foodies'' are forfeiting a final mousse, and leaving a souffle flat. But where is everybody going? To the theater, of course.

title: CITY VISITORS ADD TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Saying that their visit to New York had made them aware that ''the need for charity is not limited to our doorstep,'' Lilly and David Zohary of Israel have donated $100 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: THE TIMES APPOINTS A.O. SULZBERGER JR. ASSISTANT PUBLISHER
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. has been named to the newly created position of assistant publisher of The New York Times. The appointment, effective Jan. 19, was announced yesterday by his father, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of the newspaper and chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Times Company.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: DON'T CROWD ME; I'm distancing myself from the hottest cliche in Scandalville.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEAUTY OF DOGWOODS LASTS YEARLONG
description: LEAD: DID you ever wonder how the dogwoods got their name?It seems that the twigs of a

title: THE HAPPINESS OF CHRISTMAS IS MADE OF FRAGILE MOMENTS
description: WE HAVE dismantled the Christmas tree. And the little electric train, which had wound its way through the tiny village under the tree, no longer makes its scheduled stops. Also, I have put away the last of the red candles and plaid bows.

title: The Frustration Factor in Vacation-Club Bargains
description: Searching for the best deal in a cruise or tour can be a laborious and frustrating chore that may make you wonder, in the end, whether any money saved was worth the effort.

title: Chiefs Name Coach
description: FRANK GANSZ was named the Kansas City Chiefs' head coach last night. The 48-year-old Gansz succeeds John Mackovic, who was dismissed Thursday despite the Chiefs' 10-6 regular-season record in his fourth season and Kansas City's first playoff appearance in 15 years.

title: LET THE VICE PRESIDENT SERVE AS WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF
description: To the Editor:

title: A LANDMARK OF MISFEASANCE
description: Seven members of the New York City Landmarks Commission last week issued a gratuitous warning against any proposal that would obscure part of the rear of the New York Public Library on 42d Street. It was an act of arrogance against normal process that calls not just for criticism but also for corrective steps. The first step is for the city studiously to ignore the commission's abuse of power and bring forward the city's plan to renovate Bryant Park, behind the library.

title: GODS AND DUDS
description: DIVO Great Tenors, Baritones and Basses Discuss Their Roles. By Helena Matheopoulos. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

title: Long-Dormant New London Awakening
description: DURING the early part of the 19th century, the whaling port of New London was one of Connecticut's most prosperous and colorful communities. Its bustling harrbor created riches that led to the building of fine homes and majestic red brick commercial buildings and storehouses, many of which still stand.

title: T. C. Theobald And Gigi Mahon Exchange Vows
description: Gigi Mahon, a writer, and Thomas C. Theobald, a vice chairman of Citicorp and Citibank, one of its subsidiaries, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE ITALIAN INFLUENCE IN TRENTON
description: LEAD: THE Chambersburg section of Trenton has a lot in common with the Ironbound area of Newark. Both are oases of safety in cities that are sometimes inhospitable.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BUDDIES. By Ethan Mordden. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The importance of friendship among members of the New York homosexual community is the theme of these fictional pieces by Ethan Mordden, who takes part in and narrates them the same way Truman Capote played the colorful tour guide in his later essays.

title: THE YANKEE DEVILS!
description: THE ALLEY CAT By Yves Beauchemin. Translated by Sheila Fischman. 450 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: N.A.A.C.P. DEFENDS ACTIONS BY WARD
description: Leaders of the nation's oldest black civil-rights organization yesterday staunchly defended Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's handling of the attack on three blacks by a group of whites in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: ARE VOTERS ENTITLED TO REAGAN'S DIAGNOSIS?
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN is back at the White House, recuperating from his third major operation since his inauguration, his second in 18 months. A trans-urethral resection of Mr. Reagan's prostate went smoothly last week, and a checkup found no evidence of a recurrence of the colon cancer removed in July 1985. In 1981, he had chest surgery to remove a bullet from his lung.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEAUTY OF DOGWOODS LASTS YEARLONG
description: LEAD: DID you ever wonder how the dogwoods got their name?It seems that the twigs of a

title: Andrea Kim Feirstein Plans to Be Married
description: Andrea Kim Feirstein, an associate at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood, and Frank Loren Schiff, an associate at the law firm of White & Case, also in New York, plan a summer wedding. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. George Feirstein of Maplewood, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Ronald K. Schiff of Denver.

title: How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
description: I liken the recent steroid scare to the first warnings concerning cigarette smoking. In the early 1960's, the potential hazards of nicotine were made public. Most smokers continued to smoke and, in time, passed their dangerous habit to younger generations. Today, the initial warnings condemning the use of steroids are being similarly ignored. And, as in the cigarette example, the use of steroids is being passed to younger generations. Steroids are a big problem. STEVEN SISKIND New York

title: NO EASING OF EXIT VISA BATTLES FOR MANY IN SOVIET
description: In the last two weeks, Naum Meiman has made many visits to Soviet Government offices, spending hours in the bitter cold chasing evanescent assurances that the next piece of paper he obtains will secure the promised exit visa for his cancer-stricken wife.

title: Putting a Career On Hold
description: ''Why would successful, ambitious women choose to be simply mothers?'' There is nothing simple about the role of mother. It is the most complex, challenging and rewarding ''position'' I have ever held. It is a disgrace that more people don't understand this. KARLA STUEMPFLE MSALL Buffalo

title: Luisetti Recalled
description: To the Sports Editor: In his article marking the contribution to basketball by Stanford University's legendary player, Hank Luisetti (''He Fired the Shot That Started the Revolution,'' The New York Times, Dec. 30), Malcolm Moran focuses on Luisetti's role in the contest against Long Island University in the old 50th Street Madison Square Garden, just 50 years ago.

title: A NEW SETTING FOR L'AMBROISIE
description: Throughout his career, the Parisian chef and restaurateur Bernard Pacaud has lived by three common-sense rules: Keep the restaurant small, keep the menu simple, make sure the food is fresh. Those rules managed to win him two Michelin stars in a very short time, and so it only made sense that when he outgrew his nine-table restaurant, L'Ambroisie, on the Left Bank, the new one would follow the same principles. As it has.
