After a three-year search for better but not necessarily larger quarters, Mr. Pacaud and his wife, Daniele, opened their new Ambroisie in early December, transforming an old silversmith's shop under the romantic arcades of Place des Vosges on the Right Bank into a restaurant that is a gastronomic and decorative model of simplicity. While the old Ambroisie was a cool, contemporary study in gray, black and white, the new establishment glows with an antique, upper-class French charm.

title: MAINE JUDGE'S SENTENCING TACTICS LEAD TO DISPUTE
description: A popular Maine district judge is facing his second charge of misconduct in office in two years stemming from his policy of dealing severely with drunken drivers and juvenile offenders.

title: Leslie Church Dearing, Lawyer, Wed To James Fleming, Graduate Student
description: Leslie Church Dearing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Sears Dearing of Tallahassee, Fla., was married there yesterday to James McVickar Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Fleming Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. P. Frank Dearing, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: TENANT'S LAWSUIT COULD HELP UPGRADE HOUSING
description: FAIR-HOUSING advocates say that a case now before the courts could help provide a remedy for the problem of substandard housing on Long Island.

title: STATE IS ASKED TO STUDY HEALTH EFFECTS OF SHORE SWIMMING
description: LEAD: AN ORGANIZATION led by Shore-area doctors has asked the state to undertake a comprehensive study of the health risks that ocean pollution poses to swimmers.

title: POSTING: New Condo for Yorkville; A Midrise Rarity
description: Most of the condominiums to emerge in recent years in Yorkville, the upper stretch of the Upper East Side, have tended to be tall, with 35 stories not uncommon. But the Louisiana, a new condominium building at 300 East 90th Street, is only 10 stories high.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph on Dec. 21 of Phangnga Bay, Thailand, was incorrectly credited. It should have been credited to Adina Tovy/Stock Shop.

title: Rent Bills
description: To the Editor: Your use of the term ''rent bills'' in the Dec. 7 Q. & A. column is incorrect. Practically all standard form leases in use today in New York that rent is payable in a certain fashion.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
MAKERS OF BURGLAR ALARMS PROSPERING WITH CONSERVATIVE BUSINESS APPROACH
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FIRST DOWN AND A BILLION: The Funny Business of Pro Football. By Gene Klein and David Fisher (Morrow, $17.95.) If you have never heard of George Halas, Don Coryell or Dan Fouts then you can stiff-arm Gene Klein's breezy story of what it's like to own your own National Football League team. But if you start browsing in it, Mr. Klein's straight talk and first-rate wisecracking will mousetrap you into the world of big, big men and huge amounts of money. Mr. Klein was a Bronx boy who played some football at New York University: ''The best thing that could be said about my hands is that I had two of them.'' After he made his first millions selling used cars in California, he bought, for $10 million in 1966, the San Diego Chargers, a name derived not from lightning but from the fact that the first owner, Barron Hilton, was in credit cards. George Halas, the thrifty founder of the Chicago Bears, is described by one of his star players as a man who ''threw nickels around as if they were manhole covers.'' Mr. Klein, who is 6 feet 5 inches tall, recalls attacking the great passer Dan Fouts during a salary dispute. Don Coryell, the coach whose complicated plays made the Chargers winners, urged his teams to be killer dogs chasing the rabbit, killer bees stinging the foe. One player recalls, ''When we were going to be playing on a wet field, he wanted us to be killer ducks.'' On drugs: ''If the user was a star, or superstar, we learned to live with his problem.'' Of luck: ''If someone throws a candy wrapper on the ground in San Diego, a candy tree will sprout.'' The team was sold in 1984 for about $50 million.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
CAROLINA PUTS END TO DUKE STREAK
description: LEAD: Still dressed in his basketball uniform, Jeff Lebo sat by himself in the quickly emptying North Carolina locker room and quietly savored his team's 85-77 victory over Duke today. ''I think this is probably the biggest win we've had all year,'' Lebo, a sophomore guard, said of the Tar Heels, who ran their record to 13-1.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Divining the Dow

title: 8 BLACK GOLD MINERS SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA AND 53 HURT IN FIGHT
description: Eight black gold miners were killed overnight in fighting between workers at a mine, a company spokesman reported today. In an unrelated incident, the Government said a white policeman was killed in a grenade attack Friday night.

title: TOPIC
description: A NEW house was going to be built on our block, but before that could be started, the old one had to be removed. When the bulldozer arrived, I walked over to have a look. Who isn't intrigued with a mighty bulldozer in action?

title: KREMLIN FEELS STRAIN OF AFGHAN WAR
description: THE withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan is not far off, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced last week. ''This event,'' he predicted, ''is not behind the mountains.''

title: AN INCIDENT RECALLED BY DOG DISPUTE
description: Some years ago, our dog, who, too, was being walked on a leash, was attacked by dogs who were running loose. [ ''Family's Suit Raises Issue of What a Pet Dog Is Worth,'' Dec. 21. ] They belonged to my neighbor. Charlie received 19 stitches in his rectum, and spent the night sedated in the Emergency Hospital on Tarrytown Road. My neighbor did exactly what I would have done. She called the hospital, the vet's office, found out what the charges were and paid them without question.

title: RECITAL: SAMUEL RAMEY
description: THE chief distinctions of Samuel Ramey's singing, all discernible in the song recital he gave Friday night in a sold-out Carnegie Hall, arise from a vocal technique appreciably finer than that cultivated by his bass colleagues on the operatic scene. He sings with sonorous power, but stops short of the force that might jeopardize steadiness and control. He maintains a continuity of tone quality from loud notes to soft. And in breath control, legato and coloratura agility, he has set himself standards that only a few basses active since about 1920 could match.

title: POSTING: Westhampton Colony;
description: The yearnings of those who want to live by the water - both fresh and saline - may be quenched by a single-family house development planned for Westhampton, L.I. The 67-acre tract includes a nine-acre lake, and South Shore beaches are only a ''couple of minutes away by bicycle and a lot more minutes by car in summer traffic,'' according to Harvey K. Orens, president of Renaissance Capital Corporation, the developer.

title: DESIGNING AN ETHICAL FRAME FOR MOTHERHOOD BY CONTRACT
description: ''SURROGATE mother'' seemed a cruelly clinical euphemism last week as competing parents fought over a baby in a New Jersey courtroom. The legal drama was distinctly modern, but the agony of the actors could have been chanted by a Greek chorus.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE winner of last year's Indianapolis 500, Bobby Rahal, was named the winner of the Jerry Titus award as the outstanding driver of 1986 by the American Auto Racing Writers and Broadcasters Association. . . . Kamie Eldridge, a point guard who led the University of Texas to the women's collegiate basketball championship, was given the Broderick Award as the nation's outstanding female athlete. . . . Bernie Federko, who scored his 300th career goal last week and is the career leader for St. Louis with 885 points, will undergo surgery today to repair a dual fracture of a bone in his jaw and will be sidelined for four to six weeks. Federko, 30, suffered the injury Friday night in Edmonton when struck in the face by a teammate's stick. . . . Steve Grogan, the New England Patriots' backup quarterback, will undergo surgery for tendinitis in his right elbow, according to the team physician, who said shoulder surgery performed last week on Craig James, the team's top running back, had been a success and should make him more effective next season. . . . Kristi Terzian, who specializes in the slalom and giant slalom for the United States ski team, will be out for the season after undergoing knee surgery.

title: OLIVA IS FLOORED, BUT KEEPS CROWN
description: Unbeaten Patrizio Oliva of Italy retained his World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Mexico's Rodolfo Gonzales.

title: A BRITISH FARCE WITH A BROAD WINK
description: ''KEY FOR TWO,'' by John Chapman and Dave Freeman, being presented by the Arena Players, is a frothy, amoral sex farce designed for those who like their theatrical entertainment broad and uncomplicated.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
FLORIST FINDS THAT INTERNATIONAL EVENTS GREATLY AFFECT POTTED-PLANT BUSINESS
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: MUSIC: BOLCOM'S RENDERING OF BLAKE'S 'SONGS'
description: FOR nearly three years, there has been talk of William Bolcom's massive setting, for a Symphony-of-a-Thousand-sized ensemble, of William Blake's complete poetic collection, ''Songs of Innocence and of Experience.'' Finally, Friday night, New Yorkers got a chance to hear this 140-minute score live, courtesy of the Next Wave Festival, Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, who presented it at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House (the third and final performance is today at 2 P.M.

title: Bad Bosses
description: To the Editor: ''When the Boss Is Unbearable'' (Dec. 28) omits discussion of why a boss acts that way. If the employee can understand the boss's motives there is a wider choice available than quitting the job or saying, ''When you...I feel...''

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS LEAGUE
description: THE League-I.S.C.M. (a merciful abbreviation of the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music, U.S. Section Inc.) presented a characteristically diverse and engrossing program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night.

title: Jacqui Mitchell, a New Number One
description: Baseball fans are told within seconds when Pete Rose breaks a long-standing batting record, but in bridge everything is more leisurely. Unofficial calculations strongly indicate that the title of world's top-ranked woman player changed hands in September, but the World Bridge Federation does not appear to have noticed this, let alone revealed the fact to a waiting world or the players involved. The new number one is Jacqui Mitchell of Manhattan. Since the last figures of world master points were published two years ago she has finished second in the 1985 Venice Cup in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and won the 1986 World Women's Pair Championship with Judge Amalya Kearse in Miami Beach. She began the period 49 points out of the lead and had a net gain of 56 points.

title: WHAT RAIL TICKETS REALLY COST
description: Improvements in Metro-North's rail service have been widely acclaimed in recent years in the press, by public officials and even by commuter groups that are usually critical of railroad service. Typical is the article ''Metro-North Basks in Progress'' [ Nov. 9 ] . The article discusses how bad conditions on the railroad were only three yeas ago and how good the service is today. Mr. [ John S. ] Boritas of our Metro-North Rail Commuter Council is quoted: ''It's been a night-and-day change.'' In the entire article, the only hint of criticism is: ''As a result of the improved service . . . the increased ridership has created . . . a surge in demand for parking spaces at train stations.''

title: MUSEUM HOPPING IN ATHENS
description: Along with the Acropolis and a few other sites of antiquity, the museums of Athens are the principal attractions of a city that increasingly disappoints visitors by falling short of its renown. The museums compensate, by their variety and interest, for a capital that has suffered more than most from rapid urban growth and the effects of air pollution, noise and traffic.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ GUITARIST AT 'Y' Barney Kessel had played jazz guitar with celebrity musicians for more than 40 years and had recorded 50 albums before he appeared in New York City for the first time as a headliner on his own.

title: Miss Nadel, a Consultant, To Wed Armin W. Nauser
description: Edwin Nadel of Harrison, N.Y., and West Dover, Vt., has announced the engagement of his daughter Lauren Ann Nadel to Armin W. Nauser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Nauser of Zurich.

title: Boos or Cheers?
description: To the Sports Editor: Does booing a professional athlete help or hinder his performance?

title: PURSUIT OF CULTURE AT A YOUNG AGE
description: MY mother was born in a tough section of Chicago, near the Loop. To her, this was a nonpareil social blight. It had to be erased at all costs. My mother's solution took the form of a frantic, lifetime pursuit of culture as she understood it.

title: Trying to Preserve An Unusual View
description: Viewed from the west, the New York Public Library provides passers-by with a striking facade. Twenty-six bands of light marble alternate with dark, vertical windows, distinguishing the 75-year-old building from others in the Beaux-Arts style.

title: STORES WITH BASICS, PLUS PERSONAL TOUCH
description: THE Charles Department Store in Katonah, established in 1924, bills itself as ''the store that has everything'' - clothes and shoes for the entire family, appliances and cookware, vacuum cleaners and stationery, fabrics and televisions, picture frames and camping gear. Everything is stacked, hung and layered in an area measuring only 5,000 square feet, presided over by the Raneri brothers - Jim, 31 years old, and David, 32 -with the help of other family members.

title: Ms. Aarons, a Writer, Marries Michael Eisele
description: Gabelle Ada Aarons, a writer, and Michael Stewart Eisele, an artist, were married yesterday at Valeur, a historic mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y., by Town Justice Joseph J. Waters. The bride is the daughter of Barbaralee Ross Kantrowitz of Brooklyn Heights and Newport, R.I., and Jonas Aarons of South Orange, N.J., and Clinton, N.Y. Mr. Eisele is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Eisele of Deland, Fla.

title: IT'S A LONG, LONG WAY FROM JERUSALEM TO ROME
description: JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR'S visit to Jerusalem has left a bittersweet taste.

title:
THEATER;
AVANT-GARDE STAGE: FROM PRIMAL DREAMS TO SPLIT IMAGES
description: LEAD: What is most unique about the theater? What can happen there that can't happen at the movies, or in literature, or while standing before a painting or a work of sculpture? The answer - no matter who provides it - almost always has something to do with the fact that it's live, that it can put us in the presence of other living, breathing human beings.

title: High Technology
description: To the Editor: For over 35 years we have closely watched the short- and long-term effects of marketing American technology abroad, mainly through licensing (''The U.S. Giveaway,'' Dec. 7). More than any other nation we have generously offered our technology to outsiders. As a result, the entire world has been able to advance the automation of assembly line manufacturing, as well as the handling and processing of material.

title: JOHN ADAMS: MUSIC OF CONTRADICTIONS
description: LEAD: At first glance, the music of John Adams appears to consist of irreconcilably opposed elements. Long an admirer of Minimalism, Mr. Adams has absorbed and personalized a musical language that derives from the work of Steve Reich. Yet he has taken the Minimalist heritage and dispensed with its old austerity, employing its gestures within a highly expressive, almost Romantic context.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Baseball Players Asking for Too Much?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 11, 1987
WARHOL SEWS A SUBVERSIVE PATTERN IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: For many, Andy Warhol was the quintessential Pop artist of the 1960's. Certainly he became the most journalistically celebrated, since his Campbell soup cans and Brillo boxes readily lent themselves to spectacle and ridicule. If in the public mind a five-year-old could make a painting that looked like a Picasso, it didn't even take an infant to make a Warhol. Warhol's paintings looked like they had been done by a machine.

title: A Trucker Surrenders After a Queens Crash
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn truck driver who fled from an accident that left two people seriously injured in Queens Friday surrendered to the police yesterday. His lawyer said the suspect fled because a passer-by had fired gunshots he thought were aimed at him.

title: How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
description: Just how big a problem steroid use is among the professional athletes can only be determined through mutually agreed-upon testing procedures. But before a sweeping policy of testing is instituted, some important questions need to be answered: How reliable is the testing procedure? What would the consequences of steroid use be - suspension? And, of course, do athletes have the right to use steroids to enhance their professional capabilities and in turn their own livelihoods? KEVIN FREEMAN Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: THOSE LITTLE SURPRISES SNOW BRINGS
description: THE first snowfall of the season always takes me by surprise. Despite endless forecasts and warnings from the ubiquitous weather announcers on radio and the tube, and despite repeated admonitions from the spouse, there is never enough time - for me, at least - to do the things that should be done before it snows.

title: U.S. Peace Garden In Washington?
description: EVEN though Washington seems overrun with memorials and the Federal Government says it is running out of space for new ones, Representative George Miller, a California Democrat, said he had substantial support for his proposal: a national peace garden in the capital.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HART AND SOUL: Gary Hart's New Hampshire Odyssey . . . and Beyond. By Susan Berry Casey. (NHI Press, Box 825, Concord, N.H. 03301. Paper, $9.95.) These are the hard basics of running for President, particularly for an underdog like Senator Gary Hart in 1984: up before a cold New Hampshire dawn in a forlorn motel or a campaign worker's house to climb into a van driven by a campaign volunteer to accost hurrying factory workers at the plant gate or sleepy diners in a greasy spoon. Constantly scrambling for money and steeling yourself during shouting matches between campaign aides over whether Iowa or New Hampshire should get it. Doggedly persisting for nearly two years while reporters don't mention your candidacy or, if they do, brush you off as insignificant. Susan Berry Casey, co-director of Gary Hart's 1984 primary campaign in New Hampshire, has written a detailed - sometimes too detailed - chronicle of the New Hampshire primary. Her criticism of the press and television is harsh - and probably justified. They ignored and underestimated Mr. Hart all through 1983, overestimating at the same time Senator John Glenn's electoral muscle. Then a 16 percent Hart showing in Iowa became a victory of sorts that snowballed into the real New Hampshire victory a week later. Later, Hart the hero gave way to Hart the hack, whose age and name change were the subjects of reportorial investigations that helped sink the candidate. Despite it all, Ms. Casey is still hooked on Gary Hart and politics. She and her family have moved to Denver and the Hart command post for the next round of doughnuts at dawn in New Hampshire, Iowa and other 1988 primary and caucus states.

title: UNCERTAINTY SURROUNDS POWER AUTHORITY
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Power Authority, designed to take over the Long Island Lighting Company and keep the Shoreham nuclear power plant from going into operation, will become a reality this week.

title: Peru
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed Nicholas D. Kristof's views and coverage of Peru and Cuzco (Travel, Oct. 5), a country full of history and art. Unfortunately there is an underside to a trip to these areas; currently the country is living in fear and anxiety due to terrorism. As Mr. Kristof says, the Peruvian army is quite visible everywhere; military and security guards armed with machine guns are part of the landscape. You could think that such a display of force would intimidate common criminals, who, as mentioned in your coverage, are quite active in places visited by tourists. That is not the case; we were robbed twice, and we know we were not the only ones. Such occurrences made us feel afraid.

title: Immigrants
description: To the Editor: Barry R. Chiswick (''A Troubling Drop in Immigrant 'Quality', '' Forum, Dec. 21) claims that an immigration policy that favors ''productive applicants'' would ease the competition between America's native minorities and newly arrived unskilled immigrants for low-skilled jobs. Thus, he seeks to relegate America's minorities to a permanent underclass by assuming that they are the appropriate candidates for low-level jobs.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY SETS GOALS, AND EVEN MEETS SOME
description: Given the evident difficulties of running New York's subways, as well as the bureaucracy they spawned, it might not seem wise to put 473 goals for the year in writing, much less project them in foot-high letters onto a screen at the front of a crowded auditorium.

title: UPSCALE CHINESE IN GARDEN CITY
description: CHINESE food fanciers may have noticed a change in New York City's Chinatown, due to the influx of immigrants from Hong Kong. The restaurants opening in Chinatown reflect a new affluence and sophistication.

title: Portrait of a Power Broker Without the Power
description: As legislators streamed into town for the start of the 100th Congress, James Robert Jones, for almost 25 years one of this town's political power brokers, contemplated sleeping late and catching up on his reading. He was out of it, no longer a member of the House of Representatives.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
The Truth Is Not Simple
description: LEAD: I DON'T KNOW EXACTLY how long we lived together. (Which is one way we were different. She remembered the moment we met and precisely when we took our first apartment.) I think it was about 10 years, give or take a couple.

title: Pitfalls For the Unwary
description: THE advantages of buying into a condominium while it still is under construction are widely promoted and real, but the problems that may arise in an early purchase also should be considered.

title: WOLFE IN LOVE
description: ''I AM writing a book - a novel - trying, you see, to find a breach in the wall somewhere,''

title: Kosar and Elway Will Fill the Air
description: True to its passing heritage, the American Football Conference features a pair of dominating quarterbacks in Sunday's championship game.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BLOOD JUSTICE: The Lynching of Mack Charles Parker. By Howard Smead. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Whether Mack Parker, black, did indeed rape June Walters, white, outside the small Mississippi town of Lumberton in 1959 quickly became an academic point. A white mob decided Parker was guilty. Fearing he'd escape conviction because of a technicality - none of the county's blacks were qualified for jury duty, a condition that resulted in the reversal of a black man's conviction in a similar case - the mob elected to execute Parker.

title: CONCERT: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: THE Guarneri String Quartet is among the smoothest and most elegant of chamber ensembles, yet the group's Wednesday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was only sporadically successful.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NO PARKING RANDY GOTTLIEB, a senior at Great Neck North High School, may have the definitive answer to the school's lack of student parking space: The family chauffeur delivers him to and from school each day in a limousine.

title: 2 GARBAGE ISSUES AWAIT ACTION BY COUNTY IN 1987
description: COUNTY officials responsible for disposing of Westchester's garbage ended last year with a sigh of relief -feeling that they had resolved several potential crises - but acknowledged last week that this year loomed with two major questions unresolved.

title: V.A. Is Fined For Purging Files In Radiation Case
description: The Veterans Administration must pay an estimated $115,000 in penalties for trying to purge its files of potentially embarrassing documents, a Federal judge in San Francisco ruled last week. The agency had been ordered to supply the documents to a group representing 5,000 veterans who were exposed to radiation in Japan after World War II and in postwar tests of nuclear bombs.

title: BRAVING EPILEPSY'S STORM
description: I WITNESSED AN EPILEPTIC seizure for the first time in 1979, when I was 18. In the center of my college dining hall, a young man who worked in the kitchen had collapsed in a convulsion. Four students quickly piled on top of him. His arms and legs jerked violently and, in the process of trying to hold him down, the students seemed to be smothering him. The young man's face, twisted and red, made him appear to be in great pain and, somehow, inhuman. Yet I could see myself in his place - I had just found out that I had epilepsy.

title: Is a Long- or Short-Term Loan the Best Strategy?
description: THE new Federal tax law, which decreases the Government subsidy of mortgage-interest payments, raises some fundamental questions about borrowing strategies for home buyers and for owners thinking about refinancing to take advantage of current low rates.

title: 'Dagwood' of Movies, Arthur Lake, Is Dead
description: Arthur Lake, who portrayed the comic strip character Dagwood Bumstead and called for help with a high-pitched ''Blonnndie!'' in more than two dozen films, has died at the age of 81.

title:
DINING OUT;
NOT JUST ANOTHER CALIFORNIA FACE
description: LEAD: AT first glance, Seasons' menu looks like just another California clone - fresh this, fresh that, guacamole with everything.

title: A LONG HISTORY OF JOINING GROWS LONGER
description: My vegetable garden keeps acquiring interesting new foreign tenants. Last year I grew a luscious, ivory-hued Sicilin eggplant from seed my barber gave me. This year a French neighbor promised me an oversized shallot known by its shape as a ''cuisse de poulet'' -- a chicken thigh.

title: PERSISTENCE AIDS INJURED
description: LEAD: A PERSISTENT telephone operator, Marion Beaudette of New Haven, facilitated the airlift from Puerto Rico of seven injured survivors of the Dec. 31 fire in the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan.

title: NAKASONE STARTS TRIP TO FINLAND AND EAST BLOC
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left today for Finland and Eastern Europe, a weeklong journey that seems to be part diplomatic overture, part consolation prize.

title: THE BUSINESS CYCLE ROLLS OVER AND PLAYS DEAD
description: NOT so long ago, an awesome force known as the business cycle drove the economy along much as the moon drives the tides and the sun the seasons. It was almost always there, a perpetual motion machine that propelled the nation through booms and busts. Yet for more than a couple of years now, the cycle has been dormant, with the economy moving listlessly month after month.

title: Barbara Fowler To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Barbara Ann Fowler to Eric Lindsey Houston has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Fowler of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Mantoloking, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Warnock Houston of Urbana, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Impressive Performances Mark Recent Opera Disks
description: LEAD: Complete opera recordings are not reaching us in floodtide proportions any more. Whatever the reasons - and there are many - we can only applaud the results. Overproduction and senseless duplication have long plagued the industry. Less (in quantity) can be more (in quality), as three recent releases of major operas - by Purcell, Mozart, and Wagner - indicate.

title: UNCLOGGING A TOILET: PLUNGERS AND AUGERS
description: ALTHOUGH chemical drain cleaners often work well on clogged sinks, they seldom help a clogged toilet much.

title: A COLLAGIST'S MOSAIC OF GOD, LITERATURE AND HIS PEOPLE
description: Romare Bearden's intimate tapestries are about memory and forgetting, wisdom and laughter, silence and song. His human comedy is pieced together with the hard, racy, broken rhythms of New York City, where he has spent most of his life, and the communal rhythms of Mecklenburg County, N.C., where he spent the summers of his youth. Bearden has said that he wanted in his collages to ''bring the Afro-American experience into art and give it a universal dimension.'' In ''Romare Bearden: Origins and Progressions,'' a 40-year survey at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, it is clear that he has succeeded.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: YEARS AGO, A WRITER named Alexander King went on Jack Paar's late-night television show and zoomed to the top of the best-seller list. It was a terrible moment in the history of literature.

title: Stepping Up The Contra Battle
description: Amid assertions that they must act decisively and soon, thousands of United States-supported rebels have recently entered Nicaragua, and the Reagan Administration contended last week that the Sandinista Government might yet be overthrown.

title: Headliners; Base Motives
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former Navy intelligence analyst who admitted last summer that he had peddled his employer's property to Israel, is not a man of high motives, according to prosecutors. Mr. Pollard, who is to be sentenced next month on spying charges, contended that it was for love of Israel that he stole and sold American defense secrets. The Justice Department, in a sentencing memorandum filed in Washington last week, said Mr. Pollard had done it for the money. The authorities said Mr. Pollard received tens of thousands of dollars from the Israelis over 18 months and spent it on comforts and luxuries. He was ''literally addicted to the high life style,'' said the memo, which recommended that Mr. Pollard be sentenced to a ''substantial period of incarceration and a monetary fine.''

title: BEST SELLERS: January 11, 1987
description: Fiction 1 1 18 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 3 24 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 2 10 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 4 5 13 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A top New York model encounters three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 5 4 11 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $18.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 6 6 15 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 7 7 11 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 8 8 26 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 9 10 13 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $16.95.) The hero of the ''Foundation'' series searches for the lost planet Earth. 10 11 26 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 11 12 14 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.'' 12 13 19 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's life in 18th-century England and France. 13 14 10 PERFUME, by Patrick Suskind. (Knopf, $16.95.) An olfactory vampire kills people to steal their scents. 14 14 ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers. 15 9 7 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. Nonfiction 1 1 36 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 14 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) From Hoboken to superstardom: an unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 3 5 8 WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Putnam, $16.95.) A new collection of columns by the journalist and television personality. 4 3 16 McMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 5 4 10 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 6 6 34 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 7 7 15 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football by the television commentator and former Oakland Raiders coach. 8 9 44 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 9 11 11 ONE MORE TIME, by Carol Burnett. (Random House, $18.95.) The comedian's autobiography, beginning with her impoverished childhood in Hollywood. 10 8 6 THE CHRISTMAS DAY KITTEN, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) An illustrated true story. 11 13 2 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the coach Bob Knight and his Indiana University basketball team. 12 12 7 PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A biography of the wife of the 37th President written by her daughter. 13 10 2 ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Morrow, $18.95.) The author leaves his Tennessee farm to find adventure on the other side of the world. 14 12 THE STORY OF ENGLISH, by Robert McCrum, William Cran and Robert MacNeil. (Sifton/Viking, $24.95.) Companion volume to the PBS series about the world's most widely used language. 15* 15 14 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 11 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 2 2 48 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. 3 3 3 BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOK BOOK. (Meredith, $16.95.) The ninth edition; ring-bound. 4 5 4 BETTY CROCKER'S COOKBOOK. (Golden Press/Western Publishing, $19.95.) New, revised ring-bound edition. 5 4 11 BE HAPPY YOU ARE LOVED, by Robert H. Schuller. (Nelson, $15.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman.

title: MCFARLANE TOOK CAKE AND BIBLE TO TEHERAN, EX-C.I.A. MAN SAYS
description: A retired Central Intelligence Agency official has confirmed to the Senate Intelligence Committee that on the secret mission to Teheran last May, Robert C. McFarlane and his party carried a Bible with a handwritten verse from President Reagan for Iranian leaders.

title: CLARINET SOLOIST AT UNITY
description: LEAD: CHARLES NEIDICH, who will give a Unity Concerts recital at Montclair High School this afternoon, is one of relatively few clarinetists able to sustain a solo career.

title: TWO U.S. COLONELS LINKED TO EFFORTS TO SELL IRAN ARMS
description: Two United States Army colonels have been implicated in efforts to sell arms to Iran for private gain while they were on active duty in sensitive European assignments, one as early as 1983, according to military sources, arms dealers and confidential documents.

title: DANCE: OHAD NAHARIN AND COMPANY
description: Ohad Naharin's choreography is notable for its movement quality -especially for its smoothness within technical difficulty. But there is also an undercurrent of feeling that makes itself evident at all times.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MIDAIR, by Frank Conroy. (Penguin, $5.95.) This collection of stories by Frank Conroy is as spare as his autobiographical novel, ''Stop-Time,'' was expansive, William H. Pritchard said in these pages in 1985. Some of the tales, he said, are ''dreamlike happenings reminiscent of Franz Kafka or Nathanael West, with perhaps a twist of Philip Roth,'' while others are ''admirable precisely for their realistic textures, the way they provide us with confirmation of common experiences.'' THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT: And Other Clinical Tales, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) One man who could not recognize common objects at a glance, another who suddenly de-veloped an acute sense of smell and retarded brothers who could juggle huge prime numbers are among the subjects of these essays by the neurologist Oliver Sacks. The author ''sees the human condition like a philosopher-poet,'' John C. Marshall said in The

title: SMOKING BANS BEING EASED IN
description: IN NEW JERSEY, where the right of the nonsmoker to breathe clean air supersedes the right of the smoker to smoke, it is a punishable offense to light up at the wrong place and time.

title:
ART;
A BROAD SWEEP OF WORKS IN A GALLERY NOT MUCH BIGGER THAN A BROOM CLOSET
description: LEAD: ONCE past the initial jolt of the gallery's being not much larger than a good-sized broom closet, the visitor finds that the group show at Coup de Grace, a new gallery here, is a broad sweep of works.

title: Nancy Bregstein To Wed Physician
description: Nancy Jane Bregstein, a partner in the Washington law firm of Shea & Gardner, and Dr. Gary Victor Gordon of Philadelphia, a rheumatologist, plan to be married in March.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; New Protection For Tenants
description: A CONTROVERSIAL and far-reaching tenants'-rights ordinance has been added to the city's municipal code, strengthening the rights of some 1.5 million renters and alarming many landlords. It allows tenants to withhold rent if landlords fail to make ''necessary'' repairs that the tenants request, or to have the repairs made themselves and deduct the cost from their rent.

title: NOISE FROM MILITARY JETS IN WEST IS DRAWING FIRE
description: Military jet fighters and bombers on training missions are increasingly shattering the serenity of the American West, sowing anger and bitterness among rural residents who in the past had little quarrel with military activities.

title: And Then There Is Copper
description: The prices of gold and other precious metals have risen recently, but little of that luster has rubbed off on copper. The price of this important base metal has been between 60 and 70 cents a pound, and actually felll by 5 percent last year.

title: EXPOSURE PROBLEMS IN THE SNOW
description: LAST week's snowstorm in the Northeast got me out of the house and onto the cross-country ski trails for the first time this winter. North of the city, the snow was beautiful to behold, molding the landscape to a smooth pure white. For many, the urge to photograph at a time like this is too powerful to resist.

title: NO PIZZA CONNECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fact-Based Drama Gets Bogged Down in Fidelity
description: ''Mercy or Murder?'' is not a satisfying television movie, in part because the real-life killing and trial it dramatizes had no satisfying conclusion. Did justice triumph?

title: CHURCH DESIGN
description: PLANS are under way to rebuild the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, the Scarsdale landmark that was destroyed in a suspicious fire seven months ago.

title: No Headline
description: NEW LANDS, NEW MEN America and the Second Great Age of Discovery. By William H. Goetzmann. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: TENNESSE DEFEATS KENTUCKY BY 75-68
description: Tony White hit 32 points, including 8 in a row in a second-half run, as the Volunteers beat Kentucky, 75-68, today in a Southeastern Conference game. White scored 22 of his game-high points in the second half when the Vols opened a 16-point lead. Tennessee raised its record to 8-4 over all and 2-1 in the S.E.C. Kentucky fell to 7-4 and 1-3. Elvin Brown, who finished with 18, held Kentucky's star freshman, Rex Chapman, to 5 points, 12 below his average. Iowa 78, Minnesota 57

title: THE FIRST WEEK ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Select committees were established in both houses to investigate the sale of weapons to Iran and the diversion of money to the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras.

title: Low Profile
description: HE'S an assistant athletic director with an established interest in basketball and some of the best seats in the school arena, but Lefty Driesell hasn't used them to watch Maryland play this season.

title: K.G.B. Exposes Its Own Abuses
description: The Soviet press routinely exposes the misdeeds of Government functionaries and agencies. But rarely does it attack top officials, let alone suggest that the K.G.B. might abuse its enormous powers.

title: COMPULSIVE GAMBLERS: DIFFERENCE OF OPINION
description: DR. MARVIN STEINBERG was neither amused nor pleased when a checkout clerk at a supermarket in Hamden tried to sell him a $1 lottery ticket while giving him his change.

title: JEWISH GROUPS FAULT O'CONNOR ON MIDEAST TRIP
description: As John Cardinal O'Connor returned to New York yesterday after a trip to Israel and Jordan, virtually every major Jewish organization in the United States joined in issuing an unusually strong statement critical of several aspects of the nine-day visit.

title: PAULUS HOOK SEEKS A STAMP
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of this city's Paulus Hook section are up in arms to have a stamp issued commemorating the Revolutionary War raid against the British that took place at Fort ''Powles Hook'' on Aug. 19, 1779.

title: MOSCOW UPGRADES ARMS-TALKS TEAM
description: The Soviet Union has privately informed the United States that it is upgrading the level of its representation to the Geneva arms talks, according to Soviet and American officials.

title: THE DEMOCRATS' DILEMMA
description: Coming back to the leadership of both houses of the Congress for the first time in six years, the Democrats are confronted by both an opportunity and a danger. And how they handle this dilemma may very well determine whether they regain control of the White House in l988.

title: Miss Switzer Engaged To Brian D. Robbins
description: The engagement of Kimberly Belden Switzer to Brian Devin Robbins has been announced by the future bride's parents, Ruth Gray Switzer and H. Kirtland Switzer 2d, both of East Sandwich, Mass. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of New York City, Bedford, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Pretoria and Its Critics Maneuver For Advantage
description: The tactics of resistance to South African apartheid took many forms last week, while the Government of P. W. Botha pursued a strategy aimed at counteracting what it regards as adverse publicity in the United States.

title: COUNTY IN SEARCH OF THREE PRIZE-WINNING PLAYWRIGHTS
description: IF, indeed, ''everyone has a play in him somewhere,'' as County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke suggests, the Office of Cultural Affairs in White Plains may be deluged with manuscripts from aspiring dramatists before the end of the month.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: LUCHA. By Constance Urdang. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) Luz Filomena, the protagonist of this novella by the poet Constance Urdang, is fond of saying ''La vida es lucha'' (''Life is a struggle''). In fact, since childhood she herself has been called Lucha because, her sister Julia says, she was always ''a great one for struggling against the world.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
LEADERS OF CHYRON CORP., A MAKER OF ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT, ARE OPTIMISTIC DESPITE COMPANY'S RECENT GROWING PAINS
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: For the Constitution
description: The Commmission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, like sponsors of any celebration of consequence these days, is preparing to bestow its official blessing on a range of ''programs, projects, goods and services'' by permitting them to use its logo. Since the observance is to run through 1991, the anniversary of ratification of the Bill of Rights, you are likely to see a good deal of this emblem over the next five years:

title: Franco Zeffirelli's Dedication
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Steven M. L. Aronson's review of ''Zeffirelli: The Autobiography of Franco Zeffirelli'' (Dec. 14). I'm quite sure Mr. Aronson picked out all the highlights and saved me 358 pages of reading, as well as $19.95.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PLEASURE BOATING
description: THE America's Cup challenge has brought new excitement - and new revenue - to sailing, and focused the eyes of the boating world on Australia. But the overwhelming message of the New York National Boat Show that winds up today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is that America's weekend sailors are still motorboat-mad. While sailboats command a section, powerboats overwhemingly dominate the exhibit floor.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA INFORMATION CURVE
description: The White House is so eager to demonstrate that President Reagan didn't know about transferring Iranian arms money to the Nicaraguan rebels that it releases, and urges the Senate Intelligence Committee to release, humiliating evidence of its foreign policy ineptitude. To prove that he is no knave, Mr. Reagan seeks to prove he had no knowledge of remarkable conduct and, to a large extent, still has none.

title: NEW SPEAKER'S NEW GAVEL
description: When the new Speaker of the House, Jim Wright of Texas, gaveled the new Congress to order this week, he did it with an oversized gavel. It was, of course, a Texas product, and it was given to Mr. Wright by the Speaker of the Texas House, Gib Lewis. Both Speakers are from Fort Worth. Mr. Wright was given a leadership award last October, and the gavel was one of the tokens of the award.

title: Miss Roberts To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert Dee Roberts of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Roberts, to Peter Alan Rinfret, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre A. Rinfret of New York. The wedding is planned for March 21.

title: HELPING CHILDREN MEET THE CHALLENGE OF WRITING
description: WHEN I was in elementary school, I always did my homework at the kitchen table. As I worked, Mom ironed, and when I needed help Mom was there.

title: Page Stevens Plans to Wed
description: A May wedding is planned by Page Van Brunt Stevens, an account officer in the New York City real-estate division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and John Dixon Knox, a portfolio manager for Morgan Stanley Asset Management Inc. in New York.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: SOMETHING'S FISHY It might sound peculiar at first, throwing a ''Fish Birthday Party.'' But since the folks who run the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery and Aquarium are celebrating the recent arrival of 80,000 brook and brown trout, why not? So this afternoon at 2, everyone's invited to take a close look, via a projector that will show what they're like under a microscope, at the newcomers - known as sac-fry because they're still being fed by their birth sacs.

title: Search Begins for A New C.I.A. Chief
description: Since William J. Casey's surgery for removal of a cancerous brain tumor Dec. 18, the conviction has been growing that his eventful tenure as Director of Central Intelligence would end soon.

title: A CONFIDENT O'NEILL SETS NEW AGENDA
description: AS he began his second full term as Governor last week, William A. O'Neill, a 20-year veteran of Democratic state politics, was looking ahead with a new agenda.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Condominium Plans Fought in Montclair
description: LEAD: FACED with increasing development pressures, some Montclair residents have been organizing efforts to preserve the town's open space and its special residential character. It is an old community long recognized for its large estates and handsome one- and two-family homes on tree-lined streets, and for its population with differing economic and cultural backgrounds.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED AFTER THREAT IS MADE ABOARD PLANE
description: The police seized a Brooklyn man who had demanded to speak to the leader of a Black Muslim group today after passing a threatening note aboard a Continental Airlines plane that had flown from Newark to Washington, the authorities said.

title: COACH REGAINS HIS JOB
description: SPORTS fans in East Haven take their high-school hockey team very seriously. So much so that at East Haven High School, hockey outdraws basketball, the most popular winter sport at most other high schools.

title: Biotech's Stalled Revolution
description: Many people in the medical community are relieved to hear that the ''Biotech revolution'' has stalled (''Biotech's Stalled Revolution,'' by Keith Schneider, Nov. 16). The danger of inadvertently creating new pathogens against which we have no effective treatment and no innate immune defense far outweighs the touted benefits of this technology. The advocates of recombinant DNA technology claim that it is safe because they cannot see how a disaster would occur and because no disaster has happened yet. That amounts to saying that the technology is as safe as the Titanic, the Chernobyl nuclear reactor or the space shuttle. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Long Island City

title: Recent Sales
description: New Canaan, Conn. $695,000 116 Heather Drive 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 5-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, 2 acres; taxes $5,155. Ridgefield, Conn. $412,000 262 Peaceable Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old colonial, in-ground swimming pool, 3-room guest cottage, 3.9 acres; taxes $4,148. Westport, Conn. $399,000 2 Rebel Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod, gazebo, living room with French doors to sun room, 1 acre; taxes $3,011. Eastchester, N.Y. $380,000 7 Deerfield Avenue 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 85-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, family room, 136- by 100-foot lot; taxes $4,466. Larchmont, N.Y. $287,500 54 Stuyvesant Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 74-year-old stone/ stucco colonial; study, enclosed porch, beach rights; taxes $4,572. South Salem, N.Y. $370,000 Boutonville Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old frame contemporary; eat-in kitchen, balcony, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,025. OTHER AREAS Amityville, L.I. $410,000 333 Grand Central Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old waterfront colonial; family room, fireplace, central A/C, 2-car garage, in-ground pool; taxes $7,000. Islip, L.I. $110,000 474 Islip Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; basement, breezeway; taxes $2,600. Mahwah, N.J. $220,000 174 Grandview Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1-year-old condominium; fireplace in living room, den, loft, maintenance $126; taxes $3,000.

title: DATA BANK: January 11, 1987
FISH DELAY BRIDGE DEMOLITION
description: An unsafe bridge the city has wanted to tear down for three years will not be dismantled until 1,500 salmon and sturgeon make their spring trek up the Connecticut River, a state engineer said Thursday.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: WITH the release last year of the Macintosh Plus, it looks as if Apple is beginning to make real inroads on business computing. The current dominance of the I.B.M. standard has thrust into virtual oblivion the fact that brokers, insurance agents and financial analysts snapped up the original Apple II to computerize their work on their own individual machines. Big Blue's entry into the personal computer market relegated the Apple to the status of a toy in the eyes of the ''serious'' business user.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 11, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: OF THE 40,000 to 60,000 books published each year, many address a particular need (for example, how to raise a child successfully).

title: ISLANDERS WIN THIRD IN ROW
description: The Islanders scored three times in the first period and settled back in the next two, and that proved sufficient to eke out a 3-2 victory tonight against the Maple Leafs in the unelectric environs of Nassau Coliseum.

title: STOUFFER STARS IN SHRINE
description: Kelly Stouffer, the Colorado State quarterback, completed his first nine passes today, including two for touchdowns of 34 and 48 yards, to lead the West to a 24-21 victory in the 62d annual East-West Shrine Football Classic.

title: DUVALIERISM WITHOUT DUVAL
description: LEAD: Next month will mark the first anniversary of the ouster of Haiti's President-for-Life, Jean Claude Duvalier.

title: WRIGHT TO PRESS FOR HOMELESS AID
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, pledged today to rush through Congress a $500 million program to build shelters for the homeless and to seek money for food aid this winter.

title: Some Surprising Allies in Lebanon
description: In the surreal world of Lebanese politics, yesterday's blood-feuding enemies seem willing at times to suppress their memories and join forces. Over the years, both Christians and Moslems have zigzagged, sometimes allied and at other times contesting each other and such powerful outsiders as Syria, Israel and Yasir Arafat's Palestinians. Last week, Israeli officials said a surprising new alliance had been formed between Christian Phalangist militiamen and Mr. Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: BUCKING THE CLEAN WATER TIDE
description: Fifteen years after the Clean Water Act, many rivers and lakes are still disgracefully polluted with sewage and poisonous chemicals. Congress ardently desires to make America's waters swimmable and fishable once again. But President Reagan persists in opposing a bill to renew the Clean Water Act. The new House has just insisted on this legislation and the new Senate is about to do the same. If so, that will turn the dispute into a triumph for all, including the Administration, even though Mr. Reagan insists it's a defeat.

title: My Sesame Street Home Video: Getting Ready to Read
description: Featuring Jim Henson's Sesame Street Muppets and the Sesame Street Live cast. Produced by Random House Home Video in cooperation with Children's Television Workshop. 30 minutes. $19.95. If the average child discovers ''Sesame Street'' by the age of 2 and watches the program pretty loyally into first grade, it is only in the last months of faithful viewing that the brilliant segments about phonics and reading register as more than entertainment. This half-hour video of segments related to reading culled from the program's archives, and strung together by Big Bird, includes some properly treasured moments. The muppet Ferlengetti Donnizetti explains rhyme, as do Cookie Monster and Kermit the Frog. There are phonics and reading segments with changing three-letter words such as Man and Pan, and a lovely animation about a bus. Adults may find all this more amusing and inspired than children do until the magic moment when they really are ready to read.

title: SCARDLE OFFERS A HOUSE TO THE HOMELESS
description: A LITTLE white house with a picket fence may become the home of a now-homeless family if the village of Scarsdale, which owns it, and the county, which has hundreds of homeless families to shelter, can come to an agreement.

title: Making the Grade as a Consultant
description: WHEN Caroline Freeman Tunis was vice president of a large publishing house, she supervised the company's move to Virginia from Washington. About two years ago, tired of ''the rut of a day-to-day routine,'' she began assisting other corporations with relocations. Now her New York City consulting firm, Hire Intelligence Inc., has more business than it can handle. Still, the transition to consultant has been an eye opener: ''The most difficult part is to keep all the balls in the air without dropping any,'' she said.

title: A Poet's Subject
description: To the Editor: I would like to thank David Kirby, the reviewer of my book of poems, ''Dominion'' (Oct. 12), for his descriptive, nonjudgmental approach to my writing. I would also like to register a complaint, not so much against him as against the literary climate that makes it unremarkable to review a book of poetry without referring to its subject.

title: FUNDS FOR ROAD REPAIRS IMPERILED
description: WHILE vehicular bridges and roadways in New Jersey continue to deteriorate faster than they can be repaired, funds for repairs are in danger of drying up by June, according to the state's Department of Transportation.

title: SATIRE'S BARB JABS JAPAN'S TV NEWS
description: It is an arguable distinction, but ''Comic Magazine'' may be the only Japanese film ever conceived in a jail cell.

title: 'PLATOON' FINDS NEW LIFE IN THE OLD WAR MOVIE
description: ''I kept thinking about all the kids who got wiped out by 17 years of war movies before coming to Vietnam to get wiped out for good,'' Michael Herr remembers in ''Dispatches,'' his book of Vietnam memoirs published in 1977.

title: WRITER TURNS YOUNG DREAMS INTO FILMS
description: ''I LOVE films,'' said Gen LeRoy of Sag Harbor and the Upper West Side of Manhattan. ''I have always loved them. They were a very important part of my childhood, and I'm a terrific audience in case anyone wants to hire me.''

title: Deborah G. Ewen Wed To W. Ward Whipple
description: The New Preston Congregational Church in Connecticut was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Deborah Graham Ewen, a vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York, to W. Ward Whipple, a vice president and trust officer of the Scarsdale (N.Y.) National Bank and Trust Company. The Rev. John D. Elliott performed the ceremony.

title: AIR TRAVEL SETS SOME UNWANTED RECORDS
description: LURED by discount fares and long weekends, travelers flocked to the skies in record numbers over the holiday season. From the Friday before Christmas through the Sunday after New Year's Day, 21 million people, 8 percent more than last year, boarded flights in the United States. In New York, all three airports matched or surpassed previous records for passenger levels on the holiday weekends.

title: A LEAFY LOS ANGELES HIDEAWAY
description: Winding along Stone Canyon Road, pausing for a better look at baronial estates tucked behind overhanging sycamores and high iron gates, first-time guests at the Hotel Bel-Air might wonder if they have taken a wrong turn. What would a hotel be doing amid all the wealth and splendor of Bel-Air, the fabled wooded retreat for dozens of Hollywood stars?

title: AIR-FILLED MISS LIBERTY IS LOFTY AND ALOFT
description: MOTORISTS on Interstate 395 near Preston may have thought they had taken a wrong turn recently when they came over the crest of a hill and saw the Statue of Liberty.

title: SOUTH TOWARD HOME
description: LOUISIANA BLACK By Samuel Charters. 253 pp. New York: Marion Boyars/Kampmann. $18.95.

title: Putting a Career On Hold
description: Barbara Basler states that women who choose to leave the work force, even temporarily, to raise their children ''could undermine the standing of other women in their companies.''

title: HOW THE GIANTS LIFTED THEIR GAME
description: IN the far corner of the Giants' locker room, beyond the trainer's room, beyond the equipment room, beyond the washers and the dryers, is their big brightly lighted weight room. It is here that the Giants players, quite literally, have lifted themselves into today's National Conference championship game.

title: GROUP FIGHTS NASSAU ROAD
description: LEAD: A 40-YEAR-OLD highway project that would connect the isolated Five Towns peninsula with New York City and Kennedy International Airport may face yet another delay as a Lawrence citizens' group argues that part of the roadway is no longer needed.

title: CARLESIMO STARTS TO LOOKUP
description: PJ. Carlesimo had sort of curled up at one end of the gymnasium, his knees tucked tightly under his chin, his back resting stiffly against a padded wall, as he studied the workout that unfolded before him. In the past few days, there had been a victory of great importance and a defeat of great disappointment, and these were two things that Carlesimo could not fully dispatch from his mind as he watched his Seton Hall basketball team practice the other day. But there was little time to rejoice or lament. Another game was closing in.

title: NEW BONE BANK AIDS HIP SURGERY
description: WHEN Marvin Schaffer of Massapequa Park had a hip replacement in 1981, he said he thought it would end the ''exquisite pain'' he suffered when he walked.

title: SHEDDING TEARS AND PANTS
description: LAURENCE STERNE The Later Years. By Arthur H. Cash. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Methuen. $49.95.

title: TEXT OF O'NEILL'S STATE OF STATE ADDRESS
description: Following is Governor O'Neill's State of the State Address to the General Assembly on Wednesday, as transcribed by The Associated Press:

title: A French 'Riposte' In Chad's War
description: France and Libya crossed an important line in Chad last week. Libyan planes bombed two towns south of the 16th parallel, the so-called Red Line established by French forces as the southern boundary for Libyan incursions. In retaliation, French jets bombed an airstrip in Libyan-controlled territory.

title: Jamaica's Ackee and Callaloo
description: Most Jamaican hotels routinely include a few native dishes on their menus or offer a Jamaican buffet one night a week. The authentic tastes of Jamaica - aromatic vegetable stews, spicy meats and fish - are best sampled, however, on the oilcloth-covered tables in small roadside and beach stands.

title: PROTECTION SOUGHT FOR THREE RIVERS
description: THE first bit of business that Senator Bill Bradley and Representative William J. Hughes tended to on the opening day of the 100th Congress last week was to reintroduce legislation to protect three South Jersey rivers, a move that would thwart the state's efforts to place a toxic-waste dump in Maurice River Township.

title: RANCOR AND CONCERN
description: Good intention piled upon heightened concern last week as political, civic, religious, education and labor leaders denounced racism and condemned a white gang's attack on three black men in Howard Beach Dec. 20.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S pretty hard, maybe even impossible, not to hate them, but we've got to try. After all, it isn't their fault that they happen to have one of two gifts that are impossible to learn and that money can't buy. The gift is there or it isn't, that's all there is to it, and there's no point saying, ''Why not me?''.

title: THE IFAN-CONTRA UPROAR: A TRAVESTY
description: LEAD: The media uproar, the investigations and the public soul-searching occasioned by the Iran-contra affair are being touted as an indication of how well the American system works. I submit that they are a painful demonstration of how it sometimes does not work. Even if, at worst, an illegal act has been committed - still an open question - the disproportion between the alleged infraction and the response is a travesty of the

title: Q and A
description: Europe's Trains Question:I want to visit West Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland and Italy and would like to know about books and maps that give the best routes by rail and mention historic sites. - A. S. M., Valley Stream, N.Y. Answer:There is plenty of planning material available and there is no need for concern about the frequency of trains because services are so extensive. Many Americans discover that departure times are less important than they had imagined. There are, for example, 13 trains a day direct from Dusseldorf, West Germany, to Amsterdam and 5 from Munich to Vienna. In West Germany alone there are 20,000 passenger trains a day.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
INDUSTRIAL BUILDER STICKS WITH THE WORK HE'S FAMILIAR WITH
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: JAPANESE EDUCATION FADES AT THE FINISH
description: AMERICANS hoping to improve education have cast many an envious glance at the Japanese. In Japan, 95 percent of high school students graduate, compared to about 75 percent in the United States. In subjects like math, the best American high school students barely reach the level of the average Japanese. Unlike their American counterparts, Japanese employers know exactly what skills and knowledge to expect when they hire a high school or college graduate.

title: TO SOME CHINESE YOUTHS 'PRIVILEGE' IS NOT ENOUGH
description: FROM Kunming in the far southwest to Beijing in the north, tens of thousands of college students have marched through the streets of China's cities in the last month, demanding more democracy.

title: COAST GUARD BOARDINGS PROVOKE COAST FISHERMEN
description: Fishermen from Maine to Rhode Island are complaining that the Coast Guard's practice of routinely halting and boarding their vessels at sea is dangerous, costly and unnecessary.

title: THE SCULPTOR LOUISE NEVELSON'S LIFE IS TOLD IN A 3-DIMENSIONAL BIOGRAPHY
description: At a branch gallery of the Whitney Museum of American Art here, the story of the artist Louise Nevelson's life is being told in a diary of terra-cotta, bronze, Plexiglas and, especially, in throwaway scraps of black-painted wood.

title: AMONG THE THE HIGHLIGHTS, AN OSCAR NOMINATION
description: LEAD: KATHLEEN CROWLEY was a busy radio, television and screen actress for more than two decades, beginning in 1951.

title: POP: BUFFY SAINTE-MARIE
description: OF the many socially engaged singer-songwriters who emerged out of the folk music movement of the 1960's, few have offered a more clearly focused vision of injustice than Buffy Sainte-Marie, the longtime crusader for American Indian rights.

title: AGENCIES GET HELP FOR DATA
description: A PAIR of computer professionals began an unlikely charity two years ago -giving computers and computer instruction to nonprofit agencies around the state.

title: Koch-Cuomo Aid To the Homeless
description: IT began as a parody of the television program ''Miami Vice'' in the June 1986 issue of Penthouse magazine. The parody, titled ''New York Vice,'' displayed caricatures of Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo, packing guns and looking menacing.

title: Battling Imports
description: To the Editor: Jerry K. Pearlman, chairman of the Zenith Electronics Corporation (''Save the Lectures, Give Us Some Help,'' Forum, Dec. 14), says the problems of American business can be blamed on ''foreign producers (who) have flooded the American market with low-priced color TV sets.''

title: PAMELA J. BROWN TO MARRY EDITOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burt Brown of Edison, N.J., and Rock Hill, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their M. Crock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Crock of South Dartmouth, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for March.

title: ON NEED FOR HOUSING THAT IS AFFORDABLE
description: The article on the Dec. 28 Opinion Page by Joyce M. Lannert on zoning [ ''How Can Zoning Be Used to Create Housing Options?'' ] is of great interest, not only to me, but to all who are in need of affordable housing in our county.

title: AUDIO AWARDS UNCOVER GEMS
description: Proverbial truth is debatable.

title: Richmond
description: For many years the anti-paradisal view that Richmond was a dull, conservative, rundown red-brick industrial town induced many travelers to skip the city. Things have changed so much, however, that visitors now wish they could spend more time in the Capital of the Confederacy.

title: Making a Grim Case for Precious Metals
description: WHILE most eyes are again on Wall Street, as the Dow finally broke the magical 2,000 level, some experts argue that recent stirrings of life in precious metals prices may portend tougher times ahead for stocks and bonds.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEAUTY OF DOGWOODS LASTS YEARLONG
description: LEAD: DID you ever wonder how the dogwoods got their name?It seems that the twigs of a

title: HOW DAVID SALLE MIXES HIGH ART AND TRASH
description: DAVID SALLE'S LOFT IN THE TRIBECA area of Manhattan is divided into two: his work studio is downstairs; his living quarters, upstairs. His studio, where he spends most of his time, is sparse and industrial-looking, whereas one floor above, everything is bright and jazzy. His paintings are usually also in two distinct parts - left and right, top and bottom and, recently, outside and inside - with one of the panels set inside another. Salle's name is pronounced with two syllables, as in the name Sally. And when he talks, he can't help faulting his own argument; he says he always sees both sides.

title: Miss Ashley Engaged To Jeffrey I. D. Lewis
description: The engagement of Sharon Irene Ashley to Jeffrey I. D. Lewis has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Ashley of Hartsdale, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Lewis of Stamford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BULLION FROM SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: LEAD: Mexico's Libertad, a one-ounce silver bullion coin, is being produced in a new proof version dated 1986. It goes on sale tomorrow and plans are to issue proofs every year. The Libertad would be the first Mexican coin to be struck as an annual proof.

title: EVERYTHING A BASEBALL FAN COULD WANT -- AND THEN SOME
description: LEAD: A RESIDENT of this Essex County community has amassed what he believes to be the most extensive collection of baseball memorabilia in the world, bigger than even the one at the National Museum of Baseball in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: THE BIG BUSINESS OF SMALL BUSINESS
description: ON any given day, 2.5 million of the country's businesses are up for sale. And while much is heard about the large companies that come on the block, 98 percent of the businesses looking for buyers fall into the small- to medium-size category, those with yearly sales of less than $30 million. Yet, the number of business-brokerage offices equipped to serve this huge market are few; only 3,000 nationwide, compared with 150,000 real-estate brokerage offices - even though business sales account for $300 billion a year, $50 billion more than real-estate sales generate yearly.

title: Q and A
description: Releasing the Sponsor Question: When my apartment building was coverted into a cooperative, the sponsor promised in amendments to the plan to make some repairs, including patching some serious leaks in the parking garage. Recently, the board of directors gave the sponsor a general release from all claims concerning repairs in exchange for the sponsor's cooperation in renegotiating the building's mortgage at a lower interest rate. The sponsor's participation was needed because the offering plan prohibited the co-op from refinancing until 85 percent of the apartments had been sold, and this level has not been reached.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CLAY WALLS. By Kim Ronyoung. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) This earnest novel about Korean immigrants begins with a Los Angeles matron and her hired help bent over the rim of a toilet. The employer is pointing out a missed stain to the plucky Asian heroine, who calls her ungrateful benefactor sangnyun (''low woman'') and tells her where to put the job. From then on, the path is rocky for the Chun family, whose three-part story forms the core of this novel, one of the first about the plight of Korean Americans. The Chuns, married by arrangement, leave Korea in haste in 1919 to escape impending Japanese persecution. They settle among a large, politically active Korean community in Los Angeles, start a family, and fall into the business of selling produce, first with shiny apples on the street and later with an expanded wholesale setup. In political meetings they vent animosity for the Japanese overlords and arrange supply shipments for their fighting compatriots. Meanwhile, their second-generation children are turning into full-fledged Americans. Even more of a patriotic disappointment is their treatment by misunderstanding Americans. At father Chun's funeral, some of the mourning is over a grievous mistake on the Las Vegas death certificate; his race is listed as Chinese. And when the Government orders California's Japanese into internment camps for the duration of World War II, they include Koreans until someone goes to Washington to explain Korean history. These political-historical moments are the pearls in the novel, for the writing tends to get flat-footed and overexplanatory, and the tensions not peculiar to Koreans - such as adolescent sexual confusion - are treated routinely. Still, one is grateful for being invited into that closeted but lively world.

title: Alert Out on Pacemaker Wires
description: Two models of wires used in heart pacemakers have been malfunctioning at higher than normal rates, according to the manufacturer, which says the problem is not life-threatening to the hundreds of Americans with the devices.

title: Cryptoclearance, Mar Mar Impressive in Hialeah Races
description: Cryptoclearance and Mar Mar, 3-year-olds with bright futures, scored impressive victories in stakes races today at Hialeah Park while registering identical times of 1:09 4/5 for six furlongs.

title: DEATH WITH THE PROPER SHAMAN
description: THE BISHOP By David Helwig. 234 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: SCHOOL BOARDS ACT TO RAISE TEACHER PAY
description: SINCE September, school boards and teacher representatives throughout the state have been negotiating to raise teachers' salaries, with the vast majority of Connecticut's communities expected to follow suit by the spring.

title: TOPICS: Steps Forward; CURBED ADVANTAGE
description: New York drivers, like those almost everywhere, inch impatiently forward while waiting for a traffic light to change. But only in New York City do pedestrians seem afflicted with the same disease.

title: Dollars for Saving
description: WHEN he got the results of a survey of salaries in the National Hockey League, Alan Eagleson, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, thought he had stumbled on a financial anomaly. Goaltenders, he found, were the lowest-paid players on Canadian teams and the highest-paid on American teams.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOWCASE FOR DEALERS AND COLLECTORS
description: LEAD: DESPITE the possibility of snow-covered roads and absentee crowds this time of year, the annual Winter Antiques Show will take place at the National Guard Armory here. The three-day event gets under way Friday.

title: INSIDE
description: Rhine Pollution Report A group of independent Swiss experts has decided that the long-term effects of a chemical spill Nov. 1 may be less devastating than feared. Page 4. Jet Noise Angers the West Westerners are planning a ''national call-in'' to protest the noise from increasing flights by military jet fighters and bombers. Page 14. Upgrading Geneva Talks The Soviet Union is sending a higher-level official to lead its delegation at the Geneva arms talks, and has urged the United States to do so too. Page 7.

title: L. K. Firestone Weds Caroline Lynch
description: Caroline Hudson Lynch of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., a trustee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and the Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary in South Hamilton, Mass., was married yesterday to Leonard K. Firestone of Beverly Hills, Calif., the retired president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of California. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Biaggi Is Said to Face Indictment
description: As a force in Bronx politics for decades and a Democratic Congressman since 1969, 69-year-old Mario Biaggi has been a target of several Federal inquiries; last week prosecutors in Brooklyn were reported to have asked the Justice Department for permission to seek a joint indictment naming Mr. Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, the 80-year-old retired Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: IN TODAY'S OPERA WORLD STARS CAN CALL THE TUNE
description: The first thing to understand about bidding for the services of opera's superstars is that it's a singer's market. There are far, far more blank slots on opera house calendars waiting to be filled by a Domingo or a Freni than there are nights in Placido Domingo's or Mirella Freni's datebooks waiting to be filled by an opera engagement. Dozens of theaters around the world need to present at least a few of the top singers each season, and a few of the most prestigious houses are expected to deliver the whole list on a reasonably frequent basis.

title: Putting New Pep Into Sailboat Sales
description: EVERYONE agrees that sailboats don't sell as well as they once did. But ask about reasons or solutions, and the agreement ends. Some suggest the slump is temporary. Others say the industry needs drastic change.

title: OF BALKY DOORS AND REAGAN VISITS
description: FOR a long time, hundreds of automatic garage doors in San Bernardino, Calif., mysteriously failed to open. But only on certain days.

title: COLLEGES FEAR CUTS
description: THE members of Congress most actively involved in education are critical of President Reagan's proposed budget, but not worried; several said last week that Congress would not endorse the proposed cuts in student aid. Nonetheless, colleges and universities are mobilizing for a battle.

title: SEEKING THE PULSE OF THE ISLAND
