description: IT always makes me laugh to see a segment on a national news program in which the correspondent signs off, ''And this is so-and-so reporting from Long Island, New York.''

title: RECENT CASSETTES
description: The Streisand Specials: My Name Is Barbra and Color Me Barbra. CBS/Fox Video. 60 minutes. $29.95. Barbra Streisand's landmark CBS television specials in the mid-60's turned the star of the Broadway show ''Funny Girl'' into a household face as well as a household voice. Both shows, staged by Joe Layton, are unrelenting star vehicles in which the singer, then in her mid-20's, paraded front and center, without the support of famous guests. ''My Name Is Barbra,'' which aired in April 1965, was filmed in black and white and is the more memorable. In it, the star imagines herself as a kooky 5-year-old dashing about an oversized playground singing ''I'm Late.'' As a grown-up waif, she sweeps through a deserted Bergdorf-Goodman trying on outfits while singing ''Secondhand Rose.'' Though the star had plenty of brass even in 1965, her singing, higher and thinner then, is tinged with a vulnerability that has since vanished.

title: Pittsburgh Theater Closes
description: The last general-interest movie house in downtown Pittsburgh has closed. The owners of the Fulton Mini on Sixth Street said the theater was not profitable because of competition from theater complexes in suburban shopping malls.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 11, 1987
description: Fiction 1 7 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' resumes her prehistoric adventures. 2 6 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 3 11 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of a television production. 4 43 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 5 10 DARK ANGEL, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.50.) The saga of the haunted Casteel family continues among the Boston rich. 6 6 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. 7 1 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 8 20 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $4.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 9 6 STAR TREK IV: The Voyage Home, by Vonda N. McIntyre. (Pocket, $3.95.) Headed for a court-martial, the Enterprise crew faces a new threat. 10 * 3 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates an art gallery explosion. 11 46 THE CLAN OF THE CAVE BEAR, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) The tale of a woman at the dawn of the human race. 12 8 NIGHT OVER THE SOLOMONS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Six stories of World War II adventure in Brazil, Siberia and points between. 13 13 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 14 27 THE BACHMAN BOOKS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Four early novels originally published as the work of Richard Bachman. 15 1 LONDON MATCH, by Len Deighton. (Ballantine, $4.50.) Bernard Samson tracks down another traitor in a sequel to ''Berlin Game.''

title: Howard Beach Turns a Beam on Racial Tensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sydney Tritschler Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Sydney Guest Tritschler and Brian Hugh Sharples has been announced by her parents, Marigolden G. Tritschler of Shrewsbury, Mass., and Dr. Donald H. Tritschler of Worcester, Mass. Mr. Sharples is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Sharples of Braintree, Mass.

title: BULLS TOP NETS, 119-109
description: Michael Jordan scored 31 points and Charles Oakley added 21 tonight, leading the Chicago Bulls to a 119-109 victory over the Nets.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
TEST BORING COMPANY TAKES ON ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECTS
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: Alex B. Novikoff Dies; Professor and Biologist
description: Prof. Alex B. Novikoff, a cellular biologist and a professor of pathology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine for the last 28 years, died Friday at the college's hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A TEST OF COURAGE ON THE OPEN SEA
description: LEAD: ''SAIL back with you from Bermuda?'' I repeated. ''Yeah, I might like to do that.''

title: 'REAL MONASTIC LIFE' LIES TUCKED AWAY IN THE SUSSEX HILLS
description: WHEN the Order of St. Benedict was revived in 19th-century Europe, one of its new congregations, the Ottiliens, set up abbeys in Africa, Manchuria, South America ''and other places.''

title: Executive Who Lost His Job Leaps 18 Floors to His Death
description: A former vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, who had recently lost his job, killed himself Friday night by jumping out the window of his 18th-floor penthouse apartment on the Upper East Side, the police said yesterday.

title: NOT JUST FOOTBALL BOOMING IN JERSEY MEADOWS
description: After two decades of cleanup and land reclamation, the Meadowlands area of New Jersey is shedding its image as an environmental wasteland and emerging as one of the busiest centers of commercial development in the Northeast.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CELEBRATING BIRD: The Triumph of Charlie Parker. By Gary Giddins. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $15.95.) Charlie (Yardbird) Parker, coming out of Kansas City, Kan., in the Depression, struggled in Harlem to find a voice on saxophone. He hit his stride in the 1940's and liberated improvisational rhythms with brilliant innovations that have exerted a profound influence on jazz since World War II. His work was revered by musicians but largely ignored in the popular media. It was just one irony in a life too large for the times. Mr. Giddins, a Village Voice critic and author of two substantial books on jazz, has written an elegant, incisive essay on Parker, and has included a series of black-and-white photographs that capture Parker with poetic grace. Addicted to heroin in his teens, Parker led a tragic life, stalked by his habit, enveloped at different times by three women who loved him deeply; after a 1947 detoxification, he showed new enthusiasm for family life and might have cultivated domestic joys had the habit not kicked back. Still, writes Mr. Giddins, the addiction ''never entirely subverted his personality. He remained dignified, open, generous, curious, concerned.'' He died in 1955, at 34. This book does not pretend to be a definitive biography; however, it is as penetrating a character study of Bird as any yet written and that is no small accomplishment.

title: McDILL BOYD
description: McDill Boyd, a member of the Republican National Committee since 1965, died Friday of lung cancer. He was 79 years old.

title: Companies Doing More Themselves
description: IT costs corporations an average of $42,000 every time they transfer a valued employee. With such relocations reaching 500,000 each year, it is no wonder that businesses across the country are trying to save time and money - as well as to smooth the way for their employees - by getting more involved in the relocation process.

title: N.F.C. CHAMPIONSHIP: GIANTS vs. REDSKINS; Tradition, Pride and Now Glory: Secondary
description: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

title: Chinese Rugs
description: To the Editor: The day we read Fred Ferretti's article ''The Warp and Woof of a Tussle With Customs'' (Travel, Oct. 26) was most distressful in our home. We were leaving three weeks later for China with the hope of purchasing a handmade Chinese carpet. After reading the article, we thought seriously of going to Macy's sale of Chinese rugs and forgetting about this bit of memorabilia, but we decided to take a chance, and, on Nov. 25 we bought our carpet at the Friendship Store in Beijing. It cost $322, but we were told that the freight by ship would be $247 and would take three months. We hesitated, thinking not only about the cost but also about Mr. Ferretti's hassle. The clerk then suggested we send it by air for $129 (and we would have it in three to four weeks).

title: Miss Mazie Engaged To Robert M. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lowell I. Mazie of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Sue Mazie, to Robert Martin Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Cohen of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for April 5. Miss Mazie is director of residential services at the Boston Center for Residential Living. She is a graduate of Boston University, from which she also received a master's degree in education. Her father is president of Lowell Enterprises, a marketing consulting firm in Huntingdon Valley.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Hope Took Shape, and Finally Paid Off
description: LEAD: THE last time I wrote about a fanatic's perspective of the football Giants, the story was quite different. On that date, Sept. 6, 1981, the Giants, the National Football League's worst team of the 1970's, were a squad in which promises of glory were still being made and positive results were few and far between.

title: THE PRESIDENT - AND US
description: REAGAN'S AMERICA Innocents at Home. By Garry Wills. Illustrated. 472 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title: Looking for a Dock for the Day Sailor
description: THE industry, now beginning its summer retail season, always paints a rosy picture for consumers at the boat show. Based on current projections, the retailers manning the show booths are entitled to be enthusiastic. But there is one area that industry officials openly admit could be a major impediment to growth: lack of waterfront facilities.

title: London Sales
description: To the Editor: In Marilyn Bender's article about the post-Christmas sales in London's department stores (Travel, Nov. 30), she ended with some advice on the V.A.T. incurred in most purchases. Experience has taught me that the business of V.A.T. refunds can be frustrating, at best.

title: New Rules on 421a Tax Incentives
description: NEW YORK CITY is preparing to give tax breaks to developers of market-rate residential buildings in the core of Manhattan if they agree to generate affordable apartments elsewhere in the five boroughs.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An item in the Postings column Dec. 28 on Butler Plaza, a new condominium development at 44 Butler Place off Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, incorrectly identified the architect. It is Hirsch/ Danois Partnership, Architects & Planners.

title: IRAN SAYS TROOPS ADVANCE INTO IRAQ
description: Iran said today that its troops were advancing near the southern Iraqi city of Basra after having beaten back two counterattacks, and both sides reported continuing heavy fighting in the Persian Gulf war.

title: The Trend That Didn't Take
description: At the couture shows in Paris last fall and earlier this winter, a few designers unleashed a parade of flamboyant coiffed hairdos to go with their elaborately poufed evening dresses. The fashion pundits instantly predicted that women would be racing to salons for false hairpieces and layers of teasing - a fad that had faded with the 1960's.

title: JIRI MENZEL'S BITTERSWEET 'VILLAGE'
description: In 1968, Jiri Menzel's ''Closely Watched Trains'' - a compassionately funny tale of a railway crew in Nazi-occupied Bohemia - won the Academy Award for the best foreign-language film. The Czech director remembers that it was a turbulent time in America and that he received the Oscar two days after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. But it was an even more turbulent time in Czechoslovakia, and on Aug. 21 Soviet tanks quashed the flowering of politics and the arts that had come to be known as the Prague Spring.

title: HOW TO SURVIVE HEALTHFUL FOOD
description: I ORDERED an individual salmon sandwich on whole-wheat toast, no dressing, and orange spice herb tea. This was a lunch I carefully selected for its low calories and because of the calcium in the salmon, the fiber and wheat in the bread and the absense of tannic acid or caffeine in the tea. Next to me at the counter, a man ordered a super-deluxe cheeseburger, rare, with french fries and a chocolate malt.

title: Two Villages Lure Big-House Fanciers
description: WHEN Stewart Gordon was offered the position of vice president of academic affairs at Queens College about a year and a half ago, he held off making a decision until he could investigate the local housing market.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
'J. Edgar Hoover': Drama of Power and Personality
description: LEAD: ''In our society, information is power,'' the film maker Robert Collins says. ''And Hoover was a man who had more information about people - and for longer - than anyone in our history.''

title: Hebrew Department Established at N.Y.U.
description: New York University has created a department of Hebrew and Judaic Studies, the first of its kind in the school's history, with endowments totaling $4.2 million.

title: Immigrants
description: To the Editor: Mr. Chiswick's contention that the amnesty provisions of the Simpson-Rodino Immigration Reform Act will make ''illegal aliens ... more likely to become a permanent feature of the labor market ...'' simply ignores the fact that the group to which amnesty applies is already a permanent feature of the labor market. This is so because the amnesty provisions apply only to aliens who have been continuously in the U.S. since prior to Jan. 1, 1982, and, in addition, the grandfather clause of Simpson-Rodino makes employer sanctions inapplicable to any worker hired before Nov. 6, 1986.

title: COLUMBIA ANNOUNCES APPOINTMENT OF 65 TO THE PULITZER JURY
description: Columbia University announced yesterday the 65 newspaper editors, executives and others who will make up the jury to submit nominations for this year's Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title:
ART;
A WINTER SHOW THAT OFFERS A SCULPTURE GARDEN
description: LEAD: UNLIKE most East End art galleries, which close down during the winter, the Bologna/Landi Gallery in East Hampton remains active year round. In the off season, the gallery, situated in a converted railway depot on Route 114, offers a selection of works by many of the artists featured in the smaller group shows that dominate the summer calendar.

title: POSTING: Chieftans; Adapting A 96-Acre Estate
description: The Chieftans, the 96-acre estate in Greenwich, Conn., long owned by the Gimbel family, is going to become a single-family home development, while retaining some of its former identity. Plans call for the division of the 26-room manor house into two or three residences and the adaptation of several of the outbuildings into homes.

title: IMPROVEMENTS CITED ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: OFFICIALS and volunteers involved in preventing drunk driving are celebrating what they say is a major reduction of alcohol-related accidents on the county's roads, a change they credit to four years of intensified public education, better enforcement tactics and tougher penalties.

title: Headliners; Hidden Asset
description: Dashiell Hammett, who died a quarter-century ago owing the Government $100,000 in back taxes, apparently had something in the bank after all. Among the papers of Mr. Hammett, whose many detective novels include ''The Maltese Falcon'' and ''The Thin Man,'' curators at the University of Texas have found a half-dozen unpublished stories and many stories that never appeared in English. The unpublished works were discovered a year ago but offered to publishers only last week, after the Manhattan Surrogate Court defined the powers of the trustees of Lillian Hellman's estate. Miss Hellman, who died in 1984, was Mr. Hammett's longtime companion and had, with a friend, purchased the mystery writer's papers from the Government. Upon her death, the papers were deposited at the University of Texas.

title: For Competitiveness
description: Reacting to all the concern about trade deficits and sagging productivity, some business people and members of Congress have decided that the main thing America needs to do is hone its competitive instincts.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A POLICY THAT'S FAILED
description: When Adm. John Poindexter was asked why he had condoned an apparently illegal diversion of funds from the Iranian arms sale to the ''contras'' trying to overthrow the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua, President Reagan's former national security adviser is reported to have replied: ''I felt sorry for the contras.''

title: Jesse Helms Protests
description: It was interesting that R. W. Apple Jr.'s article ''Delivering the South'' (Nov. 30), offered glowing identifications of Democrats, liberals and blacks. But how was Jesse Helms identified? Oh, he is merely a ''former radio announcer.''

title: IS RESOURCE RECOVERY THE WAY TO GO?
description: IT'S NO secret that public officials at the local, county and state levels are grappling with the unenviable task of determining what to do with the more than 9 million tons of garbage collected in New Jersey each year. Having it picked up from the curb and taken away for what amounts to little more than long-term storage in a landfill is a luxury we can no longer afford economically or, more importantly, environmentally.

title: DARKNESS DESCENDS ON THE CITY OF LIGHTS
description: LIFE seemed gray and gloomily unpredictable in France last week. People waited hours for subway trains that never came. Patients in clinics that lacked emergency power had to do without X-rays. Stores were lighted by candles, and traffic lights went out, causing colossal tie-ups at major intersections. Factories that had no way to move goods to customers sent workers off on what is called ''technical unemployment'' - they receive unemployment pay and can expect to be rehired when the crisis ends.

title: NEW YORK JUICE INQUIRY IS CALLED LAX IN REPORT
description: The State Investigation Commission said last week that the New York State Agriculture Department had so badly mismanaged an investigation into adulteration of apple juice that it encouraged companies to sell fake apple juice throughout the state.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Rough and Tumble of Life

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Get Business on the Government's Side
description: NEARLY a year after the defeat of Ferdinand Marcos, the Philippine economy remains capital-starved and in trouble - per capita economic growth fell for the second straight year in 1986. Frightened by political instability, both American and Philippine executives continue to withhold new investment. Unfortunately, with the future of the Aquino Government hanging on the performance of the economy, this reluctance has itself become a major source of instability.

title: OIL DECLINE ADDING TO NIGERIA'S ILLS
description: WHEN the Secretary of State, George P. Shultz, spends a few hours here tomorrow on his eight-day African tour, he will be absorbing impressions of the continent's most populous country and one of its most fractious. Nigeria, shaken by seven military coups and a civil war in 26 years of independence, appears to be headed for new political stress. Oil wealth, the glue that held it together for a decade, has dwindled. Oil earnings fell from $26 billion in 1980 to only $5 billion last year.

title: LANGUAGE IS SMARTER THAN WE ARE
description: I THINK it is past time to put aside other business and to turn our energies to the remystification of virtually everything. I am as firmly persuaded as anyone that things can be explained, or usefully described, but I am convinced that our methods at this point are crude, and premature, and that they lead us to ignore such experience or intuition as cannot be accommodated by them. Bad assumptions are never better than no assumptions at all. And I am persuaded that among all the constellated forms of describable relationships in the world, there are mists in which we do not yet see configuration. These should neither be denied nor subsumed in other ways of perceiving.

title: Putting a Career On Hold
description: Barbara Basler's article ''Putting a Career on Hold'' (Dec. 7) causes me grave concern. The women she describes have ''made it to the top'' and yet choose not to juggle the demands of career, marriage and family, even with the supports that their salaries can provide. The attention paid to this minority of women serves to distract attention from the majority of women who have always juggled these demands. The overemphasis on women who work out of choice rather than necessity serves only to increase the demands on those who must work and whose contributions to family, community and profession are largely ignored. LINDA M. MAURO Philadelphia

title: Two States Of the States
description: Governors Cuomo and O'Neill moved into new terms last week and greeted new legislators, Governor O'Neill happily addressing the question of how to spend Connecticut's money and Governor Cuomo concentrating on how not to spend New York's.

title: MARINE WHO SERVED IN MOSCOW EMBASSY HELD IN SPY INQUIRY
description: A Marine guard who had access to classified documents in the United States Embassy in Moscow is being held on suspicion of espionage after confessing he gave secrets to a female K.G.B. agent, Defense Department sources said today.

title: MUSH! IT'S TIME FOR THE SLED DOG SEASON
description: JANUARY launches the sled dog racing season in this country, and in Bemidji, Minn., this weekend more than 2,000 dogs and 200 mushers, or drivers, are competing in the first leg of a three-part event known as Tuffy's Triple Trail.

title: Business Sense
description: To the Sports Editor: In response to Marvin Miller's charge that George Steinbrenner was part of an owner conspiracy not to sign Jack Morris as a free agent, Steinbrenner is quoted as saying: ''If Marvin Miller can run a business better than me, then he should be rich. And he's not.''

title: THE 1987 CONCERT SEASON MOVES INTO HIGH GEAR
description: WHETHER your preference is for solo recitals, chamber music or orchestral programs, you have quite a choice this afternoon.

title: WHITE ON WHITE ON WHITE
description: LEAD: THE ICE A Journey to Antarctica. By Stephen J. Pyne. Illustrated. 428 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. $37.50.

title: Maureen Howley to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Waide Howley of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maureen Louise Howley to Peter John Brigham, a son of Janet McCarthy Brigham and John H. Brigham, both of Niantic, Conn. Miss Howley and her fiance are students at Connecticut College. A June wedding is planned.

title: N.F.C. CHAMPIONSHIP: GIANTS vs. REDSKINS; Tradition, Pride and Now Glory: Coach
description: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

title: CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT COMPANY FINDS WORD-OF-MOUTH HELPS BUSINESS
description: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs. The subjects reported on included: William F. Kelly, president and owner of SAI Electronics in Melville, one of the largest electronics distributors in the country, used to tell friends he would be a millionaire by the time he was 35. In 1980, when he was 38, his salary was $764,000.

title: IS THE GOOD DEED A DYING SPECIES?
description: I'VE just come back from the supermarket and am trying to reassure myself that I am not a leper, nor (as yet) certifiably insane. The look on the face of the woman ahead of me in line is still lingering in my mind and insisting that I am one of the above, if not worse.

title: PROGRAM SET TO AID DISABLED ON HOUSING
description: LEAD: THE Yonkers Independent Living Center, a nonprofit agency whose staff of people with disabilities provides assistance to the disabled, has added a housing program to its services.

title: Steinbrenner Lie-Detector Test Had Few Friends
description: TEN years ago, George Steinbrenner introduced walkie-talkies to baseball. The Yankees' owner, an assistant college football coach in his earlier years, believed that someone sitting on the press level of a stadium could position the outfielders better than someone standing in the dugout. In more recent years, he has continued to borrow football techniques, making extensive use of films, as football coaches do.

title: Anne Mahoney Is the Bride Of James T. Tynion 3d
description: Anne Veronica Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Mahoney of Milwaukee, was married yesterday to James T. Tynion 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tynion Jr. of Brooklyn. The Rev. Owen W. Daley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

title: MEASURING AN OMINOUS CLOUD OVER THE PORT OF NEW YORK
description: LINED up hull-to-hull at New York's passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River are six of the newest and largest ocean-going vessels in the world, each bigger than the Titanic, with a hull four stories high and a deck the length of three football fields.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: FOOTBALL N.F.C. Championship Giants vs. Redskins At Giants Stadium, 4 P.M. Television Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130, WNBC 660, 4 P.M. A.F.C. Championship Browns vs. Denver Broncos At Cleveland, 12:30 P.M. Television Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 12:30 P.M. HOCKEY Rangers vs. Vancouver Canucks At Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Television MSG, 7 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. OTHER EVENTS Boat Show At Javits Center, noon College Basketball Hamilton Invitational St. Bonaventure at George Washington 4 P.M. Television MSG, 4 P.M. Skiing World Cup, Men's Television ESPN, 6 P.M. tape. Soccer Verona vs. Inter Television - Channel, 8:30 A.M. Squash Racquets Rolex Greenwich Open Championship At Greenwich, Conn., noon. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., taped.

title: Immigrants
description: To the Editor: I agree with Mr. Chiswick on the desirability of having an immigration policy that favors applicants for immigration who are most likely to be productive members of American society. However, I think Mr. Chiswick errs when he equates the educational level of the applicant with his probable productivity. I doubt that it can be established that a foreign worker's education level is likely to correlate with his productivity beyond a minimal level.

title: IN UPSTATE NEW YORK, A PANEL CREATES WAVES
description: When a political candidate in Monroe County believes his opponent has tried some dirty tricks, he can file a complaint with the county's Fair Campaign Practices Committee.

title: CHATHAM GETS MT. LAUREL AID
description: LEAD: JUST hours after more than half the municipalities in New Jersey failed to meet the midnight deadline for submitting their affordable-housing plans, the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency awarded a $536,000 check to Chatham Township to help build low- and moderate-income housing.

title: Battling Imports
description: To the Editor: Mr. Pearlman's article gave the exact picture of what is happening to the brush industry.

title: KENNEDY PLANS RENEWED PUSH FOR LIBERAL AGENDA
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today issued an unabashed liberal manifesto calling for new programs to assist the needy and criticizing ''ideologies such as laissez-faire and survival of the fittest.''

title: LETTER FROM CHINA - YOUNG WRITERS TEST THE LIMITS
description: THE Government crackdowns on the recent demonstrations in Shanghai, Beijing and other Chinese cities demanding greater democracy and freedom of expression are a striking example of the constantly shifting climate of intellectual freedom in China. Even in the more liberal ideological atmosphere of Deng Xiaoping's economic reforms, Chinese find it extremely dificult to gauge the boundaries on freedom of expression. Chinese writers, too, find it all but impossible to know whether they will be criticized tomorrow for what it seems safe to say or do today.

title: HOSPITAL FEES RAISED TO AID THE NEEDY
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY hospital patients began this week to pay a uniform 10.3 percent surcharge to cover the statewide cost of treating the uninsured poor. Until now, such assessments had varied widely among the state's 90 hospitals, depending on how much charity care each provided.

title: 'STEPPING OUT' TAKES SHAPE AS NOVICES TAP AWAY
description: Day after day, Tommy Tune had been trying to teach a tap-dancing routine to Don Amendolia, a chubby, balding actor who had never danced before. Day after day Mr. Amendolia clomped and clattered, sweating with exertion as he stumbled through segments of the routine.

title: MAYOR ASSESSES BOSTON: PROGRESS, AND PROBLEMS
description: Last year was the first in more than a decade that Boston closed the books on a fiscal year without a deficit, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn said in his State of the City address this week.

title: BOHEMIANS TURN 80
description: The Bohemians, which calls itself the New York musicians club, will celebrate its 80th anniversary this year.

title: More About 'Marilyn'
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Diana Trilling's review of ''Marilyn'' by Gloria Steinem (Dec. 21) and would like to add some relevant information of which Mrs. Trilling may not have been aware.

title: WEALTH OF A CITY SHOULD BE MEASURED IN PEOPLE
description: THE announcement four years ago that New Haven ranked among the nation's 10 poorest cities sent officals there scurrying for explanations and solutions. Millions had been invested to fight poverty in this, the model for the Great Society. The Mayor quickly formed a Poverty Commission.

title: Submarine Strategy
description: Richard Halloran's portrayal of the submarine-stalking games played by the United States and the Soviet Union sounds as if it's right off some admiral's drawing board. But his omission of any mention of the recent severe collision between an American nuclear submarine and a Russian counterpart does little to warn the public of the peacetime dangers of this ''cat and mouse'' technique. PETER HIRSCH New York City

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The battleground and the waters of the lake are crowded with thousands of Iranian bodies.'' - The Baghdad radio.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS FOUND SOFTER IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Although the economy of the New York-New Jersey region continued to grow last year - adding 135,000 jobs -a report released last week said that several suburban counties were beginning to show some signs of decreased economic strength.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THESE AMERICAN LANDS: Parks, Wilderness, and the Public Lands. By Dyan Zaslowsky and the Wilderness Society. (Holt, $22.95.) The voice of Robert Marshall echoes loud in ''These American Lands.'' Marshall was a founder of the Wilderness Society in 1935 and his memory and spirit likely still guide the organization. Thus it is not surprising that a book produced by the society is an unrelenting call for conservation and an almost unforgiving assessment of the way the Government has managed the more than 600 million acres of national parks, forest, resource lands, wildlife refuges, designated wildernesses, wild and scenic rivers and national trails. Moreover, it could be argued that the nation's parks and wilds need a passionate voice and stiff-necked advocate. But a polemic without a sense of perspective can quickly become shrill and lose the reader. Dyan Zaslowsky and the Wilderness Society, writing about the aggressive harvest of lumber in the 19th century and its effect on the nation's forests, say, ''We ripped at our forests in a frenzy of ignorance until, appalled by what we had accomplished, we fumbled toward a concept we chose to call 'Wise Use.' '' (It might have been enough to point out, as they did earlier, that in Michigan alone, by the end of the 19th century, enough white pine lumber had been cut to build 10 million six-room houses.) What is more, the book fails to convey the sense of history and beauty and wild longing that America's vistas often evoke. Still, this is a useful book and an important one. It catalogues the history and laws and major personalities associated with America's various public lands and the responsible Federal agencies, such as the National Park Service. At the end of each chapter, the authors suggest legislation or revisions in current laws and offer common-sense policies and guidelines.

title: LOCAL CHAPTER FORMS FOR PATIENTS WITH EPSTEIN-BARR VIRUS
description: LEAD: MARIA MENDEZ of White Plains used to repair washing machines for a living. Now she must work at home, repairing and adapting toys for the enjoyment of disabled children. On some days, just taking her morning shower will be as much as she can accomplish - until after she has a lengthy rest.

title: Pickens Takes Aim At Shamrock Again
description: T. Boone Pickens closed in on Diamond Shamrock, a property he has been coveting for years. His investment group, Lucky Partners, offered $15 a share, $300 million, for 18 percent of Shamrock's shares, which would give it 22.5 percent. And while William H. Bricker, Shamrock's chairman, is not likely to capitulate easily, Mr. Pickens could use his stake as a wedge to gain seats on the board. Mesa Partners, Mr. Pickens's chief takeover vehicle, previously offered $17 a share in stock for Shamrock, but Mr. Bricker resisted. Now, analysts say, he faces the unpleasant choice of finding another buyer for Shamrock, giving in to Mr. Pickens or dealing with unhappy board members and stockholders.

title: AN OLD QUARTER OF PARIS IS NEW AGAIN
description: The Kingdom of the Down and Out is how the Marais district of Paris was described some 30 years ago.

title: Room Service
description: Starring the Marx Brothers with Lucille Ball and Ann Miller. Directed by William Seiter and produced by Pandro S. Berman. 1938. RKO Home Video. 78 minutes. $29.95. Herewith rather claustrophobic Marx, obviously derived from a stage play, but still good, rowdy fun, with the brothers and a sporting cast mainly anchored inside a Broadway hotel suite, as members of a bill-swamped theater troupe shaping a new show. But the movie works because the daffy, spirited source did, with its fast clip and swarm of slapstick gags and characters, scroungy to wide-eyed.

title: IN THRALL TO A LETHAL MOTHER
description: ANYWHERE BUT HERE By Mona Simpson. 406 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: For Baseball Fans
description: It isn't easy to be a major league baseball fan in Washington. Since the Senators left town in 1971 to become the Texas Rangers, only an occasional unsanctioned contest, usually between creaking old-timers, has raised any diamond dust at R.F.K. Stadium. But now local fans of the New York Mets are excited because their World Champions have been booked into R.F.K. on April 5 for a preseason exhibition against the Phil-delphia Phillies. The Eddie Krane-pool Society, the local Mets fan club, is offering ''choice'' seats for the af-ternoon contest ''at cost'' for $20.50 each, a figure unlikely to touch off widespread clamor for the return of organized baseball to the capital.

title: MUSIC: ISSAC STERN AND FRIENDS AT WEILL HALL
description: THE aim on Friday night was to turn the stage of Weill Recital Hall into a musician's living room. And so it transpired - at least up to a point. Isaac Stern had eight of his friends over to play, but this was Hausmusik in name only. First, there was the fashionably dressed audience (continuing the Recital Hall's week-long reopening celebration); then there was the music-making itself, which was hard-edged and taut in a most professional manner.

title: BOSTON COMPUTERS: A USERS' DECADE
description: Jonathan Rotenberg, president of the Boston Computer Society, tells a story about the day he met Steven Jobs, co-founder of Apple Computer. They were riding in a cab in Boston when Mr. Jobs abruptly warned that the computer society would not survive another few years. Mr. Rotenberg asked why. ''Jobs said,'' Mr. Rotenberg recalled, '' 'We're making computers as easy to use as clothes dryers. And have you ever heard of a Maytag users group?' ''

title: AVANT-GARDE WORK TO BE STAGED
description: IF Michael Rush has his way, New Wave theater will not be new to New Haven for long.

title: Redskins Battling Destiny
description: No need to belabor the obvious: Everybody knows that the Giants had a great season, that they beat the Washington Redskins twice, that Joe Morris ran free the first time they played this season, that Lawrence Taylor ran wild the second time, that now they are playing for a third time, in the National Conference championship game.

title: How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
description: Although it's true that players' use of cocaine and other illegal drugs sets a bad example, it is the players' use of legally prescribed anabolic steroids for which the National Football League itself must bear primary responsibility.

title: FOR THE ATHLETES
description: The United States Postal Service will issue a commemorative stamp Jan. 29 to honor the Tenth Pan American Games. The sports competition will be held in 23 sites throughout Indiana from Aug. 7 to 25. The first day of issue ceremony will be held in Indianapolis, the site for many events.

title: FANCY CHICKENS HAVE MANY FANS
description: FRAMED, life-size portraits of chickens hang on the walls of E. Lea Marsh's home in Old Lyme. About 40 chickens scratch and squawk in their coops in his yard. And sometimes the birds get their feathers fluffed and their toenails trimmed in his laundry room.

title: OPERA: MOZARTS' 'MAGIC FLUTE,' TRANSMOGRIFIED
description: WEDNESDAY night's ''Magic Flute'' by the Opera at the Academy company seemed specifically intended to enrage pious Mozarteans and at the same time cause the iconoclastic heart to beat a little faster.

title: Anne Hay Gurin Plans To Wed Stephen J. Tall
description: Anne Hay Gurin and Stephen J. Tall plan to be married in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Gurin of Richlandtown, Pa., have announced. Mr. Tall is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony D. Tall of Cheshire, Conn.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEAUTY OF DOGWOODS LASTS YEARLONG
description: LEAD: DID you ever wonder how the dogwoods got their name?It seems that the twigs of a

title: AUSTRALIAN RIVALS PUT DIFFERENCES ASIDE
description: A conciliatory meeting this morning between Alan Bond and Kevin Parry has resolved a dispute over a yacht-racing technicality that could have thrown the America's Cup defense effort into a legal quagmire.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Millburn
description: LEAD: FROM its early days as a rough-and-tumble mill community, Millburn, nestled along the edge of the Passaic River deep in New Jersey's Watchung Hills, has been blessed by fortune.

title: 15 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 15 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: AMARILLO'S ANSWER TO STONEHENGE
description: Don't Mess With Texas'' read the signs at the state line. It was the nonwimpy approach to highway beautification, an antilittering campaign that didn't say please.

title: FRENCH MUSIC STIRRING AFTER A LONG NAP
description: In assembling the list of the best classical recordings released in 1986, I stumbled, all unawares, upon a trend. Critics love trends, just as bird-watchers delight in an especially exotic sighting; they make all that waiting and watching worthwhile.

title: COMFORT IN AGING WITH GRACE
description: The great days are gone - it is no matter; No lines come easy now upon my tongue. The world has been in crisis all my life What else could I do but hold on as it spun And say my little say and sing my song? My causes all were won - or they were lost; And now my friends depart and leave me lonely -And yet - to see the blossoms in the springtime To watch the sunset hover on the sea And know that the one I love is by my side Oh lucky was I - lucky I remain. - Robert D. Abrahams Philadelphia THIS poem is by my father, who is 80 years old. I have been rereading it and wondering at its upbeat tone. I remember when he was exactly half his age, and having his midlife crisis. Is this the same man who used to feel that the causes he had won, the poems he had written, the life he had led until then, were not enough?

title: C.I.A. SAID TO GUIDE CONTRAS' MILITARY DESPITE BAN ON AID
description: Central Intelligence Agency officers in Costa Rica were far more deeply involved than previously acknowledged in advising the Nicaraguan rebels on military and political strategy last year, according to rebel officers, Costa Rican officials and Congressional aides.

title: SCAPEGOAT COMMUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A MARKET WHERE CHEMICAL IS KING
description: * When one of Chemical Bank's British lending officers was reassigned to Manhattan's garment district not long ago, he began to study more than just the American rag trade. The heavily Jewish garment district is a place where speaking the language goes a long way, so the banker took up Yiddish.

title: MAINE LEGISLATURE IS URGED TO BAN TESTING BY EMPLOYERS FOR DRUG USE
description: A special panel has urged the State Legislature to prohibit companies from testing employees or job applicants for drug use.

title: An F.A.A. Reply
description: To the Editor: Neither William F. Bolger nor Jack A. Blum have properly defined the problems in aviation (''Breaking a Budgetary Logjam,'' Forum, Dec. 7). For example, Mr. Blum refers to the ''continuing erosion of the margin of safety.'' No one has ever defined what ''margin of safety'' is, let alone figured out how to measure it.

title: POST-COLONIAL OPPRESSORS
description: FUNU The Unfinished Saga of East Timor. By Jose Ramos-Horta. Preface by Noam Chomsky. 207 pp. Trenton, N.J.: The Red Sea Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: NASA MOVE TIED TO BUDGET THREAT
description: A new book says Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the space agency, put the Marshall Space Flight Center in charge of the shuttle's ill-fated rockets because Federal budget cutters were threatening to close the Alabama center, not because it had any special expertise in the creation of solid-fuel rockets.

title: Photography
description: Ten years ago, Virginia Zabriskie took a leap of faith and opened a Paris branch of her Zabriskie Gallery, which she devoted exclusively to photography. Situated in the shadow of the Centre George Pompidiou, the elegant and intimate Galerie Zabriskie has presented the work of American photographers such as Harry Callahan and Lee Friedlander to a European audience. The interchange has not all gone one way, however. Since the Paris gallery opened, the Zabriskie Gallery in New York has become a center for the best in 20th-century French photography, showing the likes of Brassai and Georges Hugnet, as well as such expatriates as William Klein and the late Man Ray.

title: HEARTY FARE AT A RUSTIC INN
description: IT has been several years since the Norwich Inn opened its doors, virtually new after being restored and renovated. At that time, the food served in the country-style dining room (with its antler chandelier, rose-patterned walls and wooden high-backed chairs) seemed very good indeed, with a promise of becoming even better.

title: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS FEAR I.R.S. PROPOSALS ON LOBBYING
description: Nonprofit organizations fear that new proposals by the Internal Revenue Service will curb lobbying they have done for years to help shape government policies about anything from health and welfare, education and family planning to the environment and the needs of the young or the aged.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
LUGWORM
description: LEAD: Arenicola cristata Size: To one foot long.

title: SHULTZ'S WAY
description: GEORGE PRATT SHULTZ RAISED HIS HAND in the hushed committee room, took an oath not to lie, and then upbraided the assembled members of Congress. ''This is the first time in my 10 years of service as a Cabinet officer that I have been asked to take an oath of office before Congress,'' he told them. ''If a public servant is not prepared to tell the truth, he has no business being a public servant, oath or no oath.'' The lesson given, he then proceeded to answer questions about the Government's secret arms sales to Iran and the skim to the Nicaraguan contras.

title: DUKAKIS SIGNS BILL TO EXPAND PRISON CAPACITY
description: Massachusetts, which after Hawaii has the worst inmate overcrowding problem in the country, has embarked on a program to construct two new state prisons, replace three county jails and renovate other aging facilities.

title: N.F.C. CHAMPIONSHIP: GIANTS vs. REDSKINS; Tradition, Pride and Now Glory: Linebakcers
description: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

title: PUGILISTS' PROGRESS
description: THE MANLY ART Bare-Knuckle Prize Fighting in America. By Elliott J. Gorn. Illustrated. 316 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, an article on page 21 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated theater information for ''Comic Magazine.'' It opens Friday at the Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Geanne Perlman Is Bride of Dr. K. P. Rosenberg
description: Geanne Perlman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Perlman of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married last night to Dr. Kenneth Paul Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rosenberg of Philadelphia. Rabbi Elliot Spar performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Childhood Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston; Warehouses Get a New Life
description: In a city where shiny new office buildings stretch vacant out to the flat edges of town, some turn-of-the-century downtown warehouses are putting a gleam in a local developer's eye.

title: INDIAN FARE ADDS SOME OF SPICE OF LIFE
description: FOR Christmas this year an enterprising friend gave me a large basket filled with Indian spices in small bags tied with ribbon. Of course, as soon as I smelled it, I craved Indian food. For the next two weeks, the house was filled with the warm, musky aroma of an Indian bazaar as I set about cooking my favorite dishes and tried some new ones.

title: Cheryl Ann Swaim Weds Peter Guillaume LaFleche
description: At the Plymouth Church in Framingham Center, Mass., yesterday Cheryl Ann Swaim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd B. Swaim of Framingham, Mass., was married to Peter Guillaume LaFleche, a son of Mary Catherine LaFleche of Riverside, Conn., and Ronald LaFleche of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Dr. Daniel Leavitt performed the Congregational ceremony.

South Salem, N.Y. $370,000 Boutonville Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old frame contemporary; eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,025.

title: REQUIRED RECYCLING IS GETTING CLOSER
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY will become the first state in the nation to mandate separating recyclable material from its trash stream when the Legislature completes action on a bill that already has been approved by both houses.

title: Florida Amusement Park, Pacific Mushroom Lore
description: It's Boardwalk And Baseball In Orlando Now

title: Giving Credit To Chamberlain
description: To the Sports Editor: In the annual review of the year in sports (The New York Times, Dec. 28), Dave Anderson noted that the Celtics' overall record of 82-18, an .820 percentage, was the best in National Basketball Association history. Actually, two championship teams led by Wilt Chamberlain - the 1971-72 Lakers, who were 81-16 (an .835 percentage), and the 1966-67 Philadelphia 76ers, who were 79-17 (an .823 percentage) - had better records according to winning percentage. Perhaps he meant to say the Celtics set a record for most overall victories.

title: THE NETWORKS ARE RE-MEASURING THE MINI-SERIES
description: Whether fighting for their honor, their lovers or their fabulous multinational companies, the heroes and heroines of mini-series are in unusual jeopardy this year: Viewers have become bored with their problems. Except for Linda Evans as an American woman facing the Australian outback in ''The Last Frontier,'' ratings for these special events have ranged from disastrous (''George Washington: The Forging of a Nation'') to mediocre (''A Year in the Life.'') The overall ratings for CBS and NBC plummeted in November because the three mini-series offered by them failed to lure an audience. ''Fresno'' and ''Monte Carlo,'' both on CBS, and NBC's ''Rage of Angels II'' all got worse ratings than any mini-series that was televised during the 1985-86 season. The networks were doubly hurt because November is one of the ''sweeps'' months when ratings determine new advertising rates.

title: Plan of Attack: Morris Is Focus
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants has said it over and over. The way to win football games is to run the ball when you have it and to stop the opponents from running it when they have it.

title: VIEWS OF NATURE ON EXHIBIT AT RIDGEFIELD'S EXPANDED ALDRICH
description: EVEN when the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield, was confined to one building, a handsome Colonial structure at 258 Main Street, its productions were not to be taken in at a glance. Now with its new wing, so cunningly grafted on by a Wilton architectural firm, Robert Faesy Associates, the exhibition space is almost twice what it was. The comfortable shoes that used to be merely an asset have become a necessity.

title: John Anthony Lacey Wed To Clementine Corbin Day
description: Clementine Corbin Day, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Corbin Day of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to John Anthony Lacey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hilton Lacey of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Herbert Draesel performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: U.S. PUPILS LAG IN MATH ABILITY, 3 STUDIES FIND
description: New evidence ranks the mathematical ability of American primary and high school students ''among the lowest of any industrialized country.''

title: '76 INCIDENT RECALLED
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAWARE TOWN PLANS RAFFLE
description: The Town Council will try to solve its budget problems with a raffle in which half the pot goes to the winner and half to Elsmere's general fund. Robert McWilliams, the town mansger, said he expected the first drawing to generate $200 to $400. The town, whose budget for 1987 is $925,000, just lost $125,000 through the elimination of the Federal revenue sharing program.

title: Patricia A. Leahy Engaged to Marry George Renner 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Leahy of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Leahy, to George Jonathan Renner 3d, a son of Mr. Renner Jr. of Bronxville and Cynthia Bjork of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: STATES ARE MAKING RECYCLING A MUST
description: RECYCLING, a fever of the 1970's that cooled when concern over shortages eased and markets for recycled materials were slow to develop, is on the rise again. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are in various stages of implementing plans to recycle at least 25 percent of their solid waste and incinerate much of the rest to produce energy.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: MATH IN PHILADELPHIA

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Maine Police Delete Expletives

title: Miss DiRe Plans To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Rosayn DiRe to Eric Austen Anderson has been announced by Mrs. John J. DiRe of Bronxville, N.Y., mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Eugene Anderson of Northport, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Cable TV
description: Some classics, including two imports and lesser-known bargains top the film week on cable. Two Vittorio de Sica imports cited by the New York Film Critics are on Bravo: the raffishly endearing ''Miracle in Milan'' (1951), with its marvelous, skybound fadeout - Tuesday at midnight.; and ''Umberto D'' (1952), a poignant study of an elderly pensioner, with superb performance by Carlo Battista in the central role - 11 P.M. on Wednesday.

title:
ISLAND ENTREPRENEURS: HOW THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' NOW;
REVENUES OF SAI TOOK SOME DIPS
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

title: FOUR IRANIAN STOWAWAYS JUMP FROM A SHIP INTO NEW YORK HARBOR
description: Four Iranians, stowaways on a freighter bound for Newark from Istanbul, were pulled from New York Harbor early yesterday morning after they jumped from the ship, the police said.

title: NOW LAWYERS ARE HOLLYWOOD SUPERSTARS
description: AT the top of the MCA black tower, in the office recently vacated by Frank Price, Thomas Philip Pollock is hunched over a pastrami sandwich and a Diet Coke. As the new overlord of Universal movies, Mr. Pollock is at the peak of the Hollywood hierarchy. But his appointment is more than just another executive move in an industry where people change jobs as often as movie stars change cars.

title: IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA, RITUALS OF ANOTHER AGE
description: One of the last purchases I made in Papua New Guinea was a man's pocketbook. Clutch-shaped, it was deftly fashioned from natural-colored, dried sago palm fibers and worked in a herringbone pattern. But what clinched the sale were the decorations. To avert the potential hazard posed by the two sharp wooden sticks framing the mouth of the purse, the weaver had swaddled them in bubble-gum wrappers. At one corner dangled a vivid orange heart, free-cut from a sheet of plastic, on a five-inch strip of electrical wiring. And in deference to my request for a shoulder strap, he tied on a length of imported straw twine of a kelly green that contrasted acutely with the muted tones of New Guinea's traditional vegetable dyes.

title: Children at the Art Museum
description: To the Editor: Our new book, ''Visiting the Art Museum,'' obviously made your reviewer, Grace Glueck (Dec. 21), very uncomfortable. It is a children's book after all, not an adult guide as she seems to assume. And it is just Ms. Glueck's didactic attitude toward the mix of children and art museums we are trying to dispel with this book. She certainly doesn't give children much credit; apparently, they are not to be consulted for their opinions about art.

title: Wright Still Calm at Corner
description: THERE he was, running easily around the practice field at the Denver Broncos' training site here, a tall, graceful athlete with a long stride.

title: Driver Sentenced
description: REJECTING a defense request for a delay in the proceedings, a judge in St. Augustine, Fla., sentenced John Lee Paul, the race car driver, to 20 years in prison for attempting to murder a witness in a Federal drug case. Paul also faces charges that he and his son, John Paul Jr., conspired to smuggle 200,000 pounds of cocaine into the United States between 1975 and 1983. The son was previously sentenced to five years in prison after pleading guilty to racketeering. Before their legal problems, the father and son had been a highly successful racing team, winning a record five consecutive races on the Camel GT circuit in 1981 and 1982.

title: May Wedding Set For Laura Myers
description: The engagement of Laura Susan Myers to Steven Hammond Poppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Poppe of West Islip, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. W. Earle Myers of Long Valley, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

title: DON'T WEEP FOR THE WILLOW
description: THE weeping willow at our house was a constant annoyance from spring until late fall, when family life turned reluctantly indoors. Reigning over the backyard, the willow spread its spindly leaves into the barbecue, over the picnic table and onto the wooden deck designed to angle around its swollen trunk. Even the lawn was strewn with its debris.

title: THE AIR WAR IN VIETNAM
description: OVER THE BEACH By Zalin Grant. 311 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I don't see a lot of hootin' and hollerin','' but ''it ought to bring new confidence into the market.'' - Anthony Woodruff, co-director of equity trading at Kidder, Peabody, on the Dow breaching 2,000.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: 30 to 50 Percent Off On Shoes and Boots D. Marshe Shoe Gallery in the Scarsdale Park Mall opened in November and has reduced fall and winter shoe and boot prices by 30 to 50 percent off suggested retail prices this month. Sizes are 5 1/2 to 10, with some styles in size 5. The store also has evening shoes, costume jewelry, scarves, hair and shoe ornaments from France and Italy, hosiery by Berkshire.

title: TOPICS: Steps Forward; DR. LIFE LIVES
description: In a poignant poem, ''The Nobel Prize,'' Boris Pasternak wrote in 1959 that he was treated like a bandit by Soviet authorities for ''the vile offense'' of winning the world's most coveted literary honor. He sought this solace: ''Nonetheless I still believe/ Though I feel my death is near / That the soul of men's goodwill / Will vanquish hate and fear.''

title: BALLET: 'KAMMERMUSIK NO.2'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S works contain the most difficult dancing in all ballet. A prime exemplar is the New York City Ballet's ''Kammermusik No. 2,'' set to Paul Hindemith's score of the same title and performed for the first time this season Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: SOVIET RETURNEES ANGER EMIGRES IN BROOKLYN
description: Along Brighton Beach Avenue, under the El and within sight and scent of the sea, there are Russian groceries and doctors' offices, Russian nightclubs and movies - so many staples of the old life that the neighborhood has come to be called Little Odessa.

title: Marion E. Martin Dies at 86; Began G.O.P. Women's Clubs
description: Marion E. Martin, founder of the National Federation of Republican Women's Clubs, died Thursday at her home here. She was 86 years old.

title: WATERBURY PROJECT LOOKS FOR A WAY TO PRESERVE ETHNIC MUSIC
description: MARY EURIST'S father was a tenor in a church in Moscow. Her mother was also a choir singer in Russia.

title: BLACK CRIME VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: IMPROVISERS ARE FINDING NEW MIXES
description: ''It's all in the mix - this is true of much 80's art,'' Bruce Sterling wrote recently in an essay intended to come to terms with trends and directions in the media culture of the present decade.

title: More Champions
description: To the Sports Editor: Although I enjoyed the champions listed in the 1986 sports review section, I noticed it failed to include the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's volleyball champions. If there was room to list the men's winners, I'm sure there was room for the women's team - which, by the way, was the University of the Pacific, in Stockton, Calif. JOANNE SKOOG Davidson, N.C.

title: TIME, AS SHAKESPEARE KNEW, IS RELATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Is at the Top of His Game After a Rocky Climb
description: CHIP BANKS, the colorful outside linebacker of the Browns, is sharing his excitement of being in the American Conference championship game.

title: REBEL BELLE, DOUBLE AGENT
description: CONSPIRACY OF KNAVES By Dee Brown. 392 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: Murder Conviction Is Gained Without Reporter's Evidence
description: Prosecutors won a murder conviction today without the evidence of a reporter who refused to testify about an interview he had with the defendant.

title: CLIMAX NEARS IN TRIAL OF 2 ACCUSED OF KILLING JERSEY TROOPER
description: The jury will hear summations beginning Monday in the two-month trial of two avowed revolutionaries charged with murdering a state trooper on Interstate 80 in December 1981.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
ONE FIERCE CARTOONIST
description: LEAD: Extended exposure to the art of Ralph Steadman is rather like inserting your eyeballs into an electric outlet. After a brief apprenticeship as a gag cartoonist, Mr. Steadman turned to tougher stuff with the opportunity provided in 1961 by the birth of the anarchic underground London magazine Private Eye.

title: A SACRIFICE, BUT NOT SOUND
description: Speculative sacrifices run a wide gamut from ''What kind of a stunt is that?'' through ''Well, he's a great tactician, maybe he can bamboozle his opponent,'' to ''Of course, it's so fantastically complicated that one cannot speak of a clear refutation.''

title: RAIL AGENCY PICKS UP PIECES AFTER AMTRAK'S WORST CRASH
description: A DECADE ago, the Federal Government embarked on an ambitious $2 billion program to rehabilitate passenger train service between Boston and Washington. Having created Amtrak five years earlier from the ruins of private passenger lines, the Government wanted to make service faster and safer while continuing to accommodate the freight and commuter lines that also used Northeast Corridor tracks.

title: Finding the Unusual in Singapore
description: Where do all those pinstriped Singapore yuppies go at the end of their air-conditioned days at the office? Rosalind Mowe knows. Some of them return to neighborhoods untouched by two decades of development: to the shop-houses of hundreds of Malay, Indian and Chinese craftsmen, to tearooms and to temples.

title: Miami Airport
description: To the Editor: It is virtually impossible to retain an objective and reasoned viewpoint when discussing the facilities at the Miami airport. Several months have passed since my latest trauma, but time has done little to lessen the impact.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: AGATITE. By Clay Reynolds. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) If your taste in novels runs to gory violence, misogynous sex and tortuous plots, then cuddle up by the fireplace with this one. Agatite, Tex., is a little town that time forgot, where the women are wanton, the men are troglodytes and the children are not above average.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SOMETIME before Easter, the 26-story spires of Newark's Sacred Heart Cathedral - a National Historic Landmark - will become visible at night from as far off as Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: The acrostic puzzle in The Times Magazine today includes a construction error. In the word to be guessed for clue T, letter 24 fits the literary quotation correctly, but must be replaced by ''R'' to fit the book title.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, an article in the Westchester Weekly today about Scarsdale's offer of a house to the homeless appears with a section omitted. A corrected version will be printed next Sunday.

title: DESERT ISLANDS, WITH CATERING
description: The trouble with the deserted island of many travelers' fantasies is that it is, well, deserted. Aside from inhabitants, it also lacks hammocks, restrooms and bars. Now, half a dozen cruise ships plying the Caribbean are doing something about that problem.

title: A Menagerie of Delights
description: WHEN ANTONY WORRALL-THOMPSON MADE up his mind in 1978 to learn the secrets of the great chefs, he went about it methodically and boldly. He purchased a Michelin guide and traveled through France to visit the 18 restaurants that had been awarded its coveted top rating of three stars. At the end of each meal, he would ask the chef for his autograph.

title: 'DAVID LEVINSKY' MATERIALIZES AGAIN
description: IN the various embodiments of his stage life over a decade, the fictitious character David Levinsky has materialized in such diverse settings as the auditorium of a synagogue on Manhattan's Upper East Side and a regional theater in New Jersey.

title: Binghams
description: To the Editor: I was saddened to read your story about the Binghams (''The Binghams, After the Fall,'' Dec. 21), not by their plight - for they are strangers to me - but by what has happened to one of my favorite newspapers, The Louisville Courier-Journal.

title: Julie Freundlich, a Graphic Designer, To Be Wed to J. F. Lang Jr., a Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Carol Schnall Goldberg of Los Angeles and Dr. Melvin Freundlich of Cedar Grove, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Julie Freundlich to Julius Francis Lang Jr., a son of Mr. Lang of Milton, Mass., and the late Ellin O'Malley Lang. A May wedding is planned.

title: MARK REVALUATION SOUGHT BY FRANCE
description: France demanded again today that West Germany bear the cost of ending the speculation crisis that erupted on international currency markets last week as the French franc declined and the West German mark soared in value.

title: STARTING AT THE SCENE, TEAM SEEKS CLUES TO CAUSE OF DEADLY TRAIN COLLISION
description: When the telephone rang at John Rehor's home near the Potomac River some 50 miles northwest of Washington last Sunday afternoon, the New York Giants were pulling away from the San Francisco 49ers on television. ''It had just started to become a rout,'' he remembered later.

title: Austrian Lederhosen to Weather the Alps
description: In Austria lederhosen are not so much a pair of trousers as a way of life. Worn summer and winter, casually and as Sunday best, these leather shorts or knickers are passed down from father to son, so that buying lederhosen is an investment that might cost anywhere from hundreds to thousands of dollars depending upon length (almost kneecap or knicker), embroidery (without or with, machine or hand) and whether the lederhosen is readymade or custom fit. The leather should be from Hirsch (stag) or Gams (chamois) as both are hardy animals, especially the elusive Gams, used to the rigors of winter and the aerobic exercise of leaping from crag to crag. Indeed, this Wildleder, as it is called, breathes and is soft as well as flexible, cool in summer and warm in winter.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: TAKING THE DOLLAR'S MEASURE;
The Dollar's 'Fall' May Be an Illusion
description: LEAD: THE expectation that a declining dollar will produce a significant drop in the United States balance of trade in the year ahead may be going sour. November's sharp and largely unexpected widening of the trade deficit, on top of a substantial upward revision for October, has renewed fears that the long-awaited improvement in our trade position may be postponed once again.

title: POSTING: Hudson Landmark; A Switch To Offices
description: ''This was the Bloomingdale's of the Hudson Valley,'' said Nachum Kalka, a New York developer, who recently bought the building that once housed the Luckey Platt department store in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: AUSTRALIANS SHIFT THEIR SIGHTS TO ASIA
description: This sprawling continent, which sometimes used to think of itself as a satellite of Britain, is increasingly shifting from a European heritage to a future linked with Asia.

title: ALGERIA, CONQUERED BY POSTCARD
description: THE COLONIAL HAREM By Malek Alloula. Translated by Myrna Godzich and Wlad Godzich. Introduction by Barbara Harlow. Illustrated. 135 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $29.50. Paper, $13.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LAY OF THE LAND. By Dean Crawford. (Viking, $16.95.) Jeremy and Leslie are wayward, late 1960's spirits, free from their spouses, eager to start anew, anxious yet happy to be living near one another - only there's something peculiar about their titillatingly close friendship. They are brother and sister. This first novel is narrated in a compelling voice by Jeremy, who recalls traversing the country in his van in 1974, when he was 24, following his 30-year-old sister in her Volkswagen bus. They drive from the East Coast to northern California, where they partly grew up and where they are resettling in the lush hills. Through flashbacks, Jeremy recounts their youth in California, Hawaii and eventually Connecticut; and he finely evokes the tumultous days of Richard Nixon, Vietnam, marijuana and women's liberation. Dean Crawford's writing can be abstract and careless, but an impassioned lyricism emerges when he's describing the California countryside: ''You know it's winter when the hills start turning green, spring when they look like Ireland, summer when they lighten to a shade of split pea on their way to becoming an inflammable blond again.'' The eerie beauty of California only abets the siblings' curse, their mutual attraction slowly engulfing them; the promise that something erotic and dangerous will happen keeps the pages turning. Mr. Crawford travels through vast emotional territory, but unfortunately is wary of journeying deeply into the incestuous miasma; too much is implied through innuendoes. However, the final chapters are rich with power and tension. The reader will feel chilled and unsettled - as if an Arctic wind blasted in.

title: REDMAN BEAT BOSTON COLLEGE TO END 2-GAME SLIDE
description: After consecutive laskluster efforts against Villanova and Georgetown, St. John's came alive and snapped its two-game losing streak last night. The Redmen survived a sensational shooting performance by Dana Barros and defeated Boston College, 62-58, at Alumni Hall.

title: OLD-FASHIONED AND MODERN
description: High Up Downtown Jan. 11 - There will be a buffet, dancing, an open bar and songs by Jean Carne at the annual New Year's reception of the Manhattan branch of the New York Urban League at Windows on the World. Festivities from 1 to 5 P.M. Tickets, $75, at the door. A Switch for the ABT Jan. 19 - Dancers and directors of the American Ballet Theater will be displaying some of their lesser known talents as they host and help prepare a fund-raising black-tie dinner at the QV Restaurant, 63d Street at Madison Avenue. Cocktails at 7:45 P.M. followed by culinary inspirations from Alessandra Ferri, Kevin McKenzie, Johan Renvall, Marianna Tcherkassky, Martine van Hamel, John Taras and others. Tickets, $250, from 212-477-3030, extension 245. Ballet School Benefit Jan. 21 - The annual winter benefit for the School of American Ballet at the New York State Theater will be a full evening starting with a 6:30 P.M. reception followed by an 8 P.M. performance of the New York City Ballet and ballet school students, and concluding with dinner. Tickets for reception and performance, $60, $85 and $125, and for the performance and dinner, $500 and $1,000, from 212-877-7635. Musical Competition Jan. 21 - There will be a note of suspense at a benefit for the American Symphony Orchestra as one of four young American conductors who have been selected from more than 100 competitors will be named the winner of the eighth annual Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition. The black-tie evening starts with 6 P.M. cocktails at Avery Fisher Hall. Each of the four finalists will then conduct the orchestra. At dinner afterward, the winner of the $5,000 first prize and an engagement at Carnegie Hall will be announced. Tickets, $300, from 212-581-1365. Party in Chinatown Jan. 22 - The Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund has been providing legal advice and advocacy for Asian-Americans for 12 years. To celebrate the Chinese Year of the Rabbit and to raise funds, the organization will hold a benefit complete with a dragon dance at the Silver Palace Restaurant, 52 Bowery, near Canal Street. The civil rights activist William M. Marutani, the photographer Dith Pran and the author Michi Weglyn are scheduled to be on hand as the festivities start at 5:30 P.M. with cocktails, followed by dinner at 7 P.M. Tickets, $45, from 212-966-5932. Supporting Israel Jan. 22 - The American Israel Public Affairs Committee lobbies the Government and supports pro-Israel candidates for Federal office. The politicians have been invited, as is the public, to a 7:30 P.M. cocktail party to find out more about the group at 4D, 605 West 55th Street. Tickets, $35 in advance from 212-557-2408, or $40 at the door. Fighting Persecution Jan. 22 - The International Rescue Committee is a leading American nonsectarian agency devoted to helping refugeess fleeing from religious, racial and political persecution. A noon luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Pierre will honor the Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, who will be introduced by the actress Liv Ullmann, a vice president of the committee. Tickets $150, from 212-751-5847. Old-World Gala Jan. 23 - Descendants of the Romanovs, the last ruling family of imperial Russia, will be out in force at the Plaza for Le Bal Blanc, the 37th annual celebration of the Russian New Year. The evening benefits the American-Russian Aid Association, which was founded in 1948 to aid Russian emigres in four homes on Long Island, but which has since been expanded to programs to aid the elderly of all nationalities. The evening starts with a reception in the Baroque Room at 8 P.M., followed by dinner, dancing, a fur and jewelry show and entertainment by the Balalaika Russe singers and sword dancers in the Grand Ballroom. Tickets, $175, or $110 for those 35 and under, from 212-787-0206 or 212-737-9010. Three-Party Benefit Jan. 23 - The Winter Antiques Show will fill the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street with the displays of 74 dealers from around the country selling a vast array of items ranging from small decorative pieces to massive furniture with prices from modest to tens of thousands of dollars. Three preview parties will benefit the East Side House Settlement, whose programs in the South Bronx for the past 75 years have included day care centers, teen-age after-school programs and clubs for the elderly. The first preview party will be a formal English tea at 4:30 P.M. in the Armory with tickets at $500. At 6 P.M. there will be a cocktail party with tickets at $250, and at 7:30 P.M. the final party will be held, with tickets at $150. All tickets from 212-665-5250. The show will be open to the public Jan. 24 to Feb. 1, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily and 1 to 6 P.M. Sunday. Admission $7.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LOST GET-BACK BOOGIE. By James Lee Burke. (Louisiana State University, $16.95.) James Lee Burke's fifth novel picks up a theme begun in his fine short story ''The Convict,'' about an experience that makes a man lose his boyhood innocence. The novel's title comes from the song the narrator, Iry Paret, a Korean War veteran and convict, wants to write to contain the memories of a prewar, preprison ''uncomplicated time.

title: POETRY-VIDEO AS TOOL KEEPS TRUANTS IN SCHOOL
description: LOUIS BARRIOS used to walk through the hallways of his high school in a fog. In class, his mind wandered out the window and onto the streets. A dark shadow hung over his head, but he just didn't know how to put his feelings into words.

title: PROGRESS MAY NOT, AFTER ALL, BE OUR MOST IMPORTANT PRODUCT
description: Communities confused or discontent in the present often strongly rediscover the moral and spiritual meaning of the traditional objects of their past. This has usually been associated with so-called ''traditional'' societies - certainly not industrial ones. Recently, however, the inexorable recognition that the technology of the industrial system is not a surefire solution to all life's problems has, in a strange paradox, begun to focus broad and appreciative attention on the old ''classical'' objects of the industrial way. An affectionate and imaginative display of this is the ''Machine Age'' show at the Brooklyn Museum, which chronicles a kind of rediscovery of the social and emotional meaning of things that people made. At the same time it issues this stark announcement about our remarkable forward-looking system: the progress of the heart demands we look back, too.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flyers 5, Bruins 4: A goal by Murray Craven at 13 minutes 5 seconds of the third period snapped a 4-4 tie and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 5-4 victory over the Bruins yesterday in Boston. Craven took a pass from Tim Kerr in a scramble in front of the Boston net and whirled round to beat the Bruins' goalie, Bill Ranford. (AP) North Stars 4, Whalers 3: In Bloomington, Minn., Kent Nilsson scored two power-play goals to help Minnesota to an early 4-0 lead. The triumph put Minnesota into a tie with Detroit for the Norris Division lead. Hartford fell out of a tie for first with Montreal in the Adams Division. (AP) Canadiens 5, Nordiques 2: In Montreal, Ryan Walter had two goals and two assists to pace Montreal. Walter made it 2-0 at 13:31 of the first period when he beat Clint Malarchuk, who faced 27 shots, with a wrist shot. (AP) N.B.A. Pistons 118, Celtics 101: Adrian Dantley scored 25 points and Isiah Thomas added 21 as the surging Pistons stopped Boston's seven-game winning streak. The Pistons have won eight straight at the Pontiac Silverdome and 12 of 14 over all. Boston was without Larry Bird and Danny Ainge, who have back injuries. (AP) Bullets 117, 76ers 111: Moses Malone scored a season-high 39 points and pulled down 17 rebounds in Landover, Md. Malone has turned in two outstanding performances against his former club. On Christmas night, he had 28 points and 21 rebounds in a Bullets victory in Philadelphia. (AP) Hawks 129, Cavaliers 104: In Atlanta, Dominique Wilkins scored 32 points and Atlanta had bursts of 22-8 and 12-2 to take control early. (AP) BOBSLEDDING Hiltebrand and Kiser Take Lead: Hans Hiltebrand and Andre Kiser of Switzerland took the lead yesterday after the first day of the World Two-man Bobsled Championships at St. Moritz. The Swiss No. 2 sled was timed in 2 minutes 16.02 seconds for the two heats. The last two heats will be held today. (AP) SPEED SKATING Ehrig-Schoene Wins at 1,500 Meters: Andrea Ehrig-Schoene of East Germany, the Olympic gold medalist at 3,000 meters, won the women's 1,500-meter race at a World Cup meet in Davos, Switzerland, yesterday. Bonnie Blair of the United States won the women's 500-meter event in 39.74 seconds. Viktor Shasherin of the Soviet Union captured the men's 3,000 meters in 4:05.05. (AP) TENNIS Shriver Overpowers Maleeva: Second-seeded Pam Shriver of the United States overpowered Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the final of the New South Wales Open championships in Sydney, Australia.
