Another American, Zina Garrison of Houston, will face Shriver in today's final. Garrison beat Wendy Turnbull of Australia, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Mecir and Schapers Advance: Top-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia and Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands advanced yesterday to the singles final of the Benson and Hedges Open in Auckland, New Zealand. Mecir beat Derrick Rostagno of the United States, 6-2, 6-1, and Schapers beat Limberger of Australia, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) MARATHON Scannel Holds Off Rodgers: Mike Scannel, running in his first major marathon, took the lead at the 23-mile mark and held off the veteran marathoner, Bill Rodgers, in the final 3.2 miles to win the first Phenix City (Ala.) Marathon yesterday. Scannel, a 24-year-old from Tempe, Ariz., finished in 2 hours 16 minutes 39 seconds. In the women's division, 44-year-old Harolene Walters, of El Toro, Calif., won in a time of 2:47.33. (AP) SKIING Zurbriggen First in Downhill: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won his third downhill race this season and took the lead in overall World Cup standing yesterday. It was the fifth downhill victory and the 15th World Cup triumph for Zurbriggen. Zurbriggen had a nearly perfect run on the Kandahar course at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, West Germany. (AP) HIGH SCHOOL TRACK Remigino Takes Dartmouth Mile: Mike Remigino, a senior at Northwest Catholic High School in West Hartford, Conn., who had made his reputation as a half-miler, moved up to the mile yesterday and won the event at the Dartmouth Relays in Hanover, N.H. The victory earned him an invitation to the boys' one-mile run at the Millrose Games Jan. 30. Remigino is the son of Lindy Remigino, gold medalist in the 100-meter dash in the 1952 Olympics.

title: Dance
description: The Joyce Sampler lives up to its name as it continues this week at the Joyce with an assortment of six modern dance companies that is about as varied as the New York dance scene. Mitchell Rose and Diane Epstein open the week on Tuesday with a program that includes some comic classics by the madcap Mr. Rose. David Parsons follows on Wednesday with his distinctive brand of high-energy dance and jabbing themes, in a program in which Mr. Parsons will be joined by Martine Van Hamel, Gary Chryst and Clark Tippet.

title: THE DANCE: ZE'EVA COHEN
description: ZE'EVA COHEN is a choreographer who can be depended on for literate, beautifully crafted dance that is appealingly performed. And a program by Ze'Eva Cohen and Dancers, presented on Friday at the Joyce Theater as part of the Joyce Sampler series, was no exception.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SKATING TO A DREAM
description: LEAD: JANUARY. Bleak and gray, without festivities. How nice, then, to picture something that might punctuate the dreary landscape, some speck of color and movement to brighten this drab stretch of winter. Skaters perhaps, whirling across the ice in gay costumes, to the sound of a waltz.

title: SOVIET TIE TO IRAQ SEEMS TO INCREASE
description: The Soviet Union has given signs in recent pronouncements of tilting further toward Iraq in the Iran-Iraq war, according to Western and Arab diplomats and experts on Iran.

title: MIDTOWN MEMORIES
description: Across the street from the town houses where Henry James and John Dos Passos once lived, on the edge of New York University in the heart of Greenwich Village, stands one of the city's most enduring landmarks and one of its most blatant drug bazaars - Washington Square Park.

title: Long Afternoon for Battered Schroeder
description: Here came the Redskins at game's end today, through the tunnel at Giants Stadium and into the corridor leading to their locker room. Without a word, with green and brown carpet burns staining their white uniforms, with helmets in hand. Here came Jeff Bostic and Dexter Manley and Steve Cox and Joe Jacoby and George Rogers and R. C. Thielmann. They came in solemnly and on their own two feet - all but Jay Schroeder, the quarterback.

title: A.M.C. MAY PRODUCE ANOTHER CHRYSLER LINE
description: The American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation are apparently close to a deal for A.M.C. to produce a second line of Chrysler cars at its assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis. But labor and financing difficulties may still block the project, officials of both companies have said.

title: Taiwan Gang Head Sentenced
description: A Federal judge imposed a 20-year prison sentence Saturday on a man convicted of playing a leading role in the racketeering activities of an international Taiwanese gang, the United Bamboo. The gang leader, Chen Chih-yi, 35 years old, of Houston, was convicted, along with 10 other men, in a trial last year in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Defense lawyers are expected to appeal the convictions.

title: CURRENCY ACCORD SET IN EUROPE
description: West Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium agreed today to increase the value of their currencies in an attempt to end the turbulence that engulfed international currency markets last week.

title: THEATER: 'STEPPING OUT,' STAGED BY TOMMY TUNE
description: TEN minutes before the end of ''Stepping Out,'' the new English play at the Golden, a group of Londoners from many humdrum walks of life suddenly meld into a high-stepping chorus line. For two acts we've followed these characters, the middle-class participants in a weekly adult dance class, as they've prepared for this golden moment at center stage in a charity pageant. Once the spectacle arrives, it doesn't disappoint. Tommy Tune, the director of ''Stepping Out,'' sweeps aside the play's gloomy basement set for glitzy backdrops, top hats, white gloves, canes and, with due respect to Michael Bennett, mirrors. The aging klutzes of the dance class are reborn - not as tap stars worthy of Mr. Tune's previous ''My One and Only,'' but as a team of proud amateurs sharing the exhilaration of reaching a once unattainable goal.

title: In Iran Affair, Follow The Smoking Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Colarossi's New Niche
description: Just the other day Benjamin Colarossi, 55 years old, left Young & Rubicam, where he was president of its Cato Johnson/Y&R sales promotion unit. Now, quick as a wink, he has turned up at McCann-Erickson, which is upgrading its sales promotion department into a full-fledged company called the McCann-Erickson Promotion Group. Mr. Colarossi will be its managing director.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND AHEAD OF PACE FOR LAST YEAR
description: Contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are running more than $200,000 ahead of those received at this time last year, a gain of 9 percent. As of Friday, 10,133 donors had given a total of $2,483,575.72. At the same point last year, 9,256 donors had given a total of $2,272,165.14. This year's goal is to exceed last year's record contributions of $2,702,695.23.

title: Let's Not Turn the Lights Out on Rural America
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealander Picked To Head Foreign Press
description: Roy Murphy, a correspondent for Television New Zealand, was elected last week to a third one-year term as president of the Foreign Press Association.

title: DIVORCE AT A YOUNG AGE: THE TROUBLED 20'S
description: ''My husband wasn't communicating with me in any way, mentally or physically, and when I told him, he said, 'You'd better leave,' '' recalled Louise Logan, a hairstylist in suburban Washington who was divorced at the age of 27. ''I was shocked. I thought if somebody cared about you, they'd do something. You realize there are more ingredients in a marriage than thinking you're in love.''

title: GUINESS NAMES REPLACEMENTS FOR SAUNDERS
description: Guinness P.L.C., the big brewer that is under investigation by the Government, named an acting chairman and executive committee today to replace Ernest Saunders, who stepped aside Friday night as chairman and chief executive at least until the inquiry is completed.

title: TRIAL OF OFFICER IN BUMPURS CASE STARTING WITH REQUEST FOR NO JURY
description: A police officer who fatally shot an elderly woman two years ago during an eviction will ask a judge, rather than a jury, to decide his guilt or innocence when his manslaughter trial begins today in the Bronx.

title: San Franciscan, 59, Is Guilty In Death of Employer on Ship
description: A San Francisco man was convicted Saturday of killing his wealthy employer on a cruise ship.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail SalesDecember Thursday Inventory-Sales RatioNovember Industrial ProductionDecember Friday Capacity UtilizationDecember

title: Fans Woof It Up for Browns
description: It started Saturday afternoon. The downtown streets seemed to be full of barking dogs, or ''dawgs'' as they are called here.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 12, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.

title: Saudis' Aid to Contras Called Reagan Request
description: President Reagan asked Saudi Arabia last year to contribute money to the Nicaraguan rebels, who then received $31 million because of his efforts, according to a Senate Intelligence Committee report, NBC News reported tonight.

title: Flurry of Tax-Change Bills
description: The monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 is just starting to take effect, yet members of the 100th Congress have wasted no time in proposing changes.

title: New Yacht Cup Rule
description: A new twist in the rules for the defense of the America's Cup has paved the way for the winner of the defense trials to substitute boats for the actual cup match.

title: BANKAMERICA ACTS TO DERAIL PURSUER
description: BankAmerica, which formally rejected First Interstate Bancorp's acquisition offer last Monday, has suddenly heightened its efforts to remain independent. BankAmerica is lobbying Government officials, enlisting its own employees and retirees in a public relations campaign and circulating documents critical of the proposed merger to get regulators to reject it.

title: OPERA: NEW 'BOHEME' CAST
description: THREE of the principal roles in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''La Boheme'' have changed hands in the past week, and these new faces were all present for Saturday night's performance. Hei-Kyung Hong, a Korean-born soprano who made her Met debut two years ago, sang Mimi. Peter Dvorsky, a tenor from Czechoslovakia, was Rudolfo. And Myra Merritt, the American soprano, became Musetta.

title: Gasoline Prices Jump
description: Retail gasoline prices jumped an average of 3 cents a gallon nationwide the last two weeks, a reflection of continuing volatility in the oil industry, the Lundberg Survey reported today. The average price was 87.9 cents a gallon.

title: ONE BLACK MAN IS BURNED TO DEATH AND ANOTHER WOUNDED IN SOWETO
description: A black man was burned to death in Soweto Saturday, the Government reported today, and a prominent black politician who refused to quit a community council was reportedly shot and seriously wounded.

title: REAGAN'S AGENDA BEING PARED DOWN FOR REST OF TERM
description: Hampered by political and physical ailments, President Reagan has pared down his agenda for his final two years in office, and will focus on protecting past gains rather than on promoting new programs, White House officials say.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 12, 1987: MONDAY Indiana Energy Inc Phillips Petroleum TUESDAY AAR Corp Teco Energy Inc Diversified Energies Unifirst Corp Proctor & Gamble WEDNESDAY Bally Mfg Southwestern Public Serv Bard (CR) Transco Energy Co Burlington Indus USLife Income Fund Pacificorp THURSDAY Bundy Corp Outboard Marine Cincinnati Gas & Electric RJR Nabisco Inc Energen Corp Texas Indus Nerco Inc FRIDAY Acme Elec Lomas & Nettleton Fin'l Communications Satellite

title: A TEACHER SHOPS FOR SCIENCE
description: Sixty-six students at William Alexander Junior High School in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn are spending two class periods a week in stores along Brooklyn's Fifth Avenue. They are learning the practical applications of science in beauty salons, plumbing stores, ice-cream parlors and other businesses.

title: SANDSTROM SCORES 4 AS RANGERS COAST
description: On the night he was hurt, before the regular season even began, George McPhee cried. His shoulder was separated completely, and he was told that he would not return until February, if then. So he turned the collars of his coat up and left the lockerroom.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President Named At Masco Industries
description: LEAD: Erwin H. Billig, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Masco Industries, has been elected president. He will retain the title of chief operating officer.

title: REDSKIN FANS LOYAL TO END
description: The mood at Mister Days Restaurant was gloomier than the overcast skies. The Washington Redskins were trailing the Giants by 17 points at halftime and in the opinion of some of the Capital's opinion makers, some of whom were now seated at the oak bar in the downtown restaurant, the prospect of a comeback seemed unlikely.

title: Advertising; Lorimar Seeking Poppe
description: LORIMAR-TELEPICTURES, the corporate parent of Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt and USAdvertising, is negotiating to buy Poppe Tyson, an advertising agency owned by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lorimar confirmed Friday.

title: Press South Korea On Labor Abuses
description: Behind the gloss of South Korea's economic boom are thousands of disgruntled employees -workers who increasingly decry their inability to form independent trade unions. One recent Sunday, thousands gathered outside Seoul to hear speeches, songs and watch plays about their struggle, which is being focused not only against the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan but also against the United States.

title: CONCERT: DAVIES LEAD AMERICAN COMPOSERS GROUP
description: YESTERDAY afternoon's concert by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall spoke several languages, all deriving from a common root. Tonality has been reasserting itself in music ever more strongly, and its magnetic pull on the ears of both composers and listeners was central to each of the four pieces heard here.

title: TEXACO, PENNZOIL REACH HIGH COURT
description: Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company will take their tangled, three-year-old legal dispute before the United States Supreme Court on Monday.

title: Stadium Reported To Fail Standards
description: More than 104,000 fans are expected to fill the Rose Bowl for the Super Bowl Jan. 25, but city officials concede the stadium does not meet current fire and building codes, a newspaper reported today.

title: Repeat That, Please
description: A newcomer to Washington dialed information in quest of an exercise class the other day and asked for the telephone number for Great Bodies.

title: How to Spend Those Education Dollars Better
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS WIN A SUPER BOWL DATE WITH BRONCOS
description: In the locker room about 30 minutes before kickoff today, Bill Parcells met, as he always does, with his kicker, Raul Allegre, and his punter, Sean Landeta, to discuss the weather conditions inside Giants Stadium.

title: 'IRAN: ADRIFT IN A SEA OF BLOOD' ON 13
description: WHO in Iran supports the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and war with Iraq?

title: A BITE ON THE WAY TO...
description: New Yorkers, to say nothing of visitors, have a lot to do: working, shopping, going to the movies, the gym, the hairdresser. All that racing around can bring on a big appetite, which is where sidewalk food vendors come in handy. With hardly a break in stride, men, women and children on the go can grab a chewy pretzel (sometimes even a warm one), a hot dog (sometimes even a hot one) or a piece of fruit (bananas, which don't drip on fur coats, are extremely popular). It may not be the greatest thing for the digestion, but eating on the run does leave more time for other things. Taxi! Taxi!

title: THE STAGE: 'FISH,' BY HOROVITZ
description: IN his new play, ''North Shore Fish,'' Israel Horovitz focuses on the workers in a frozen-fish processing plant that is about to go out of business. Although the portrayal of a way of life through shared work activity is a familiar dramatic device, Mr. Horovitz is artful in his delineation of a dying economy and in his small but sensitive group portrait of people allied by geography, their Roman Catholic upbringing and their limited aspirations.

title: 4TH LINE BOLSTERS ISLANDERS
description: Bob Bassen, who contributed a goal and assist in a 3-2 victory against Toronto Saturday night, sat back on the towel-strewn locker room bench at Nassau Coliseum and tried to remember the last time the Islanders had assembled a three-game winning streak. He could not. Actually, the team had enjoyed three straight victories, two of them courtesy of the Devils, in mid-December, but the five-game streak without a victory with which the club limped through the holiday season was more prominent in Bassen's mind.

title: Topics: Fashion Is Spinach; An Instinct for Junk
description: Children have an unerring instinct for nutritional food and reject it with contumely. So why do writers of medical texts insist that children will instinctively choose the right foods?

title: Toxic Tide Reappears Along Coast of Texas
description: Red tide has reappeared in the Gulf of Mexico, forcing an indefinite halt to shellfish harvesting along a part of the coast ravaged by an outbreak of the toxic bloom last year.

title: Accounts
description: * House Beautiful to Lotas Minard Patten McIver for trade advertising.

title: Wells, Rich, Green And Others Expand
description: A flurry of account assignments made Friday a busy day in adland.

title: Fran Alison Wallach Wed To Eric Richard Rosenfeld
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Fran Alison Wallach, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation, and Eric Richard Rosenfeld, a government securities trader at Salomon Brothers, both in New York, were married by Rabbi Theodore Steinberg.

title: COMPTROLLER GENERAL'S POWER UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the power of the Comptroller General of the United States to block the awarding of Government contracts while he investigates possible irregularities.

title: PREPARING FOR ILLNESS IN FAMILIES
description: BECAUSE the number of Americans who suffer from Alzheimer's disease, a degenerative condition of the brain that causes dementia, is expected to triple in the next half-century, families should begin planning how they might care for aged relatives who suffer from the disorder.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT REDSKINS BY 17-0, REACH SUPER BOWL WITH BRONCOS
description: A decade ago, the Giants were a losing football team: disorganized, disheartened and seemingly doomed. Today, they won their way into their first Super Bowl.

title: 4-Million Fraud Trial Begins in U.S. Court
description: The trial of a Manhattan gas station owner charged with cheating the state of $4 million in sales taxes begins today in Brooklyn.

title: Market Place; Wellcome's Bet On AIDS Drug
description: BETTING on the ''AIDS market'' promises to be an up-and-down affair - a point driven home last week to investors in Wellcome P.L.C., whose share price jumped almost 15 percent through Thursday and then fell back more than 7 percent on Friday. The Wellcome swings illustrate the speculative excitement generated by companies working on AIDS drugs.

title: TAYLOR RUNS INTO KRYPTONITE
description: In the six seasons he has spent at Giants Stadium, Lawrence Taylor never looked quite like this. On the day the Giants at last reached a Super Bowl, Taylor was forced to spend part of the time sitting on a bench in pain. As his defensive teammates completed an imposing run through the National Conference playoffs, Taylor was suddenly vincible.

title: Rev. William F. Lynch, Author of Nine Books
description: The Rev. William F. Lynch, the author of books on literature, media and theology, died Friday at Lennox Hill Hospital in New York City of complications from leukemia. He was 78 years old.

title: He Said It
description: Maybe it was one cliche too many heard during the recent round of holiday football telecasts that turned the mind back to the days when sports commentary had bite and the man with the memorable morsel was usually Arthur (Bugs) Baer. More likely it was a late-year communication from Baer's son-in-law, Nick Cavataro, a New York public relations man, pointing out that 1986 was the centennial of Baer's birth and recalling the master's more memorable sayings.

title: DAIRY FARMERS APPLAUD DECISION ON DISTRIBUTOR
description: To Herman Arbas and the many other small dairy farmers in Laurens, N.Y., decisions affecting milk prices and production are matters of simple economic survival. And when a Federal judge last week overturned a state regulation barring a New Jersey dairy from distributing milk throughout New York City, he and many others in the town, just north of Oneonta, applauded.

title: THE CROSSOVER APPEAL OF 'CROCODILE'
description: For the past few weeks tourists have been asking the doorman at the Plaza in New York whether Mick Dundee is registered at the hotel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 12, 1987
description: International

title: FUJITSU CHIP DEAL DRAWS MORE FLAK
description: From California's Silicon Valley to Capitol Hill, controversy is growing about the proposed sale of a pioneering computer chip maker to Japan's largest computer company, Fujitsu Ltd.

title: A MUSEUM OUTLASTING BAD TIMES
description: In tough times even cowboys get the blues. But events seem to be heading toward a happy ending at the National Cowboy Hall of Fame, scene of one of Oklahoma's longest-running soap operas.

title: Cowtown Controversy
description: About half the 1.7 million tickets for the Calgary Olympics next winter are still available, but that hasn't saved the Games' organizers from a blizzard of criticism leveled by frustrated Albertans, who, to be sure, have their reasons.

title: BRITAIN'S FOREIGN NEST EGG
description: Britain, a nation that just a decade ago went to the International Monetary Fund for a bail-out loan, has become the world's second-largest international creditor, trailing only Japan.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Hockey DEVILS VS. HARTFORD WHALERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) RANGERS VS. BRUINS, at Boston, 7:35 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 8:35 P.M., tape delay) OTHER EVENTS AMERICA'S CUP: Challenger's final, first race, at Bisbane, Australia. (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Georgetown at Villanova (TV -ESPN, 7 P.M.) L.S.U. at Oklahoma (TV - USA, 9 P.M.) Fordham at Iona (Radio - WRTN-FM 93.5, WFUV-FM 90.7, 8 P.M.) Brown at Seton Hall, (Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.)

title: Marion Hutton, 67, Vocalist With Glenn Miller Orchestra
description: Marion Hutton, a vocalist with the Glenn Miller Orchestra who for the last 20 years worked to help rehabilitate female alcoholics, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Kirkland, Wash. She was 67 years old.

title: Hutton Sets Securities Repurchase
description: About $70 million of the $130 million reserve fund that the E. F. Hutton Group plans to set up for the fourth quarter of 1986 will be used to repurchase certain tax-exempt securities it sold its customers in the early 1980's, according to Edward J. Lill, Hutton's chief financial officer.

title: MUSIC: GREGG SMITH SINGERS
description: THE Gregg Smith Singers opened their New York season at St. Paul's Church Saturday evening with a program of music written between 1778 and 1952, about two-thirds of it by living composers. The first group of songs came from the singers' tour repertory - well-tuned, well-blended renditions all.

title: Still Needed: Two More Milk Victories
description: A Federal judge has at long last given New York City consumers what Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature would not - the chance to buy milk at competitive prices. The question now is whether consumers must continue to depend on Federal courts and a single, discount-minded New Jersey dairy to tame the dairy cartel.

title: Bound for Philippines?
description: Nicholas Platt, a high-ranking State Department official, has become a leading candidate to be named the next United States Ambassador to the Philippines. Mr. Platt is a close adviser to Secretary of State George P. Shultz and holds two titles, Special Assistant to the Secretary and Executive Secretary of the Department. He formerly was the Ambassador to Zambia.

title: Ayer Is Challenging Army's Latest Move
description: Having learned that the Army refused to lift the suspension on its taking a Government contract, N. W. Ayer, long the Army's ad agency, went into Federal District Court in Washington on Friday. It requested a temporary restraining order to keep the Army from announcing the winner of the competition for its $100 million recruiting account this week.

title: AMBULANCES AND DELAYS STIR CONCERN
description: After six years of improved performances, city ambulances are taking longer to get to the scene of emergencies in New York City, according to figures provided by the city's Emergency Medical Services. The signficance of the increase is in dispute.

title: People
description: * Kenneth I. Roffe has been promoted to executive vice president and chief executive officer of Lowe Marschalk, Cleveland.

title:
Twice Wrong On AIDS;
Risks of Federal Screening
description: LEAD: The Federal Government is casting its net ever more widely in screening people to identify those who carry antibodies to the virus that causes AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome. These programs, though carried out in the name of public health, will have no impact on the spread of this devastating disease.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Dec. 25, about the sequence of events in the Iran-contra affair, misstated the date of the Rev.

title: CUOMO SON MUST ANSWER CHARGE
description: Andrew Cuomo, the son of Governor Cuomo, said yesterday that he has been asked to provide a written response to a conflict-of-interest charge filed this summer - but later withdrawn - by Abraham Hirschfeld, an unsuccessful candidate for lieutenant governor.

title: INSIDE
description: Drugs in Washington Sq. Despite thousands of arrests, Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village has become a growing center for the crack trade. Page B1. Currency Pact Reached Eight European finance ministers agreed to set new currency values to calm turbulent and costly market speculation. Page D1.

title: Ex-Im Tie to Tool Group
description: Machine tool companies, which recently won protection against imports from Japan, Taiwan, West Germany and Switzerland, are hoping to increase exports under a new program set up with the Export-Import Bank.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Bench Mark
description: LEAD: When he was growing up, Mark Scallion's favorite basketball player was John Havlicek. The curious thing is that he can't remember the early Havlicek, who earned acclaim as the sport's best sixth man. It's in that very role that Scallion, a 6-foot-2-inch guard, has developed into something of a milestone-achieving oddity at Mount St.

title: U.S. SETS A DATE FOR NUCLEAR TEST
description: The United States plans to conduct its first nuclear test of the year on Feb. 5, according to Government officials.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot at a McDonald's
description: An off-duty correction officer shot another man twice early yesterday after the two got into a fight in a fast-food restaurant in the Melrose section of the Bronx, the authorities said. The wounded man was arrested.

title: LOS ANGELES PRIMARY ON PASSOVER PITS JEWISH LEADERS AGAINT CITY
description: A coincidence in which a City Council primary election falls this year on April 14, the same day as the first day of Passover, has stirred a controversy here.

title: MORE COLLEGE FRESHMEN PLAN TO TEACH
description: Interest in teaching has increased among college freshmen for the fourth consecutive year but there has been a decline in students seeking careers in the computer field, according to a new study.

title: THERE'S ALWAYS A CHANCE WITH ELWAY
description: As they passed, John Elway coming off the field and Rich Karlis coming on, the quarterback said to the kicker, ''Just like practice,'' and smiled.

title: Corrections
description: The Bridge column on Wednesday referred erroneously to Maurice Paul, a Canadian expert. He died in Montreal last month at the age of 62.

title: ARMY IS SPEEDING UP DISCHARGES TO LIMIT COSTS IN BUDGET SQUEEZE
description: In an effort to save money, the Army has ordered the early discharge of most enlisted men and women who will end their service in this fiscal year, according to an Army spokesman.

title: PALESTINIANS UNDER ISRAEL: BITTER POLITICS
description: In December, on a quiet morning in this Christian Arab town north of Jerusalem, a 16-year-old Palestinian schoolboy walked up behind an Israeli soldier, pulled an ax out of his blue schoolbag, started shouting something about ''Palestine'' and began striking the soldier on the head.

title: Manuel's Return Is Complete
description: When Lionel Manuel, the Giants' elegant wide receiver, reached out to take in a crucial third-down pass from Phil Simms in the first quarter today, it was the first time he had caught a ball in a game since the third game of the season, against the Raiders in Los Angeles.

title: Big Corporate Bond Sales Expected
description: In the absence of new Treasury note and bond issues, securities dealers expect another week of substantial financing in the corporate bond market.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Garrison Wins Final: Zina Garrison pounded out a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Pam Shriver yesterday to win the $150,000 New South Wales Open women's tennis championship in Sydney, Australia. The sixth-seeded Garrison returned superbly to negate Shriver's big serve, punched her groundstrokes on both the forehand and backhand sides and volleyed excellently.(AP) Mecir Triumphs: Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, playing despite an injured hand, captured the New Zealand International Open with a 6-2, 6-3, 6-4 victory over Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands.(AP) Skiing McKinney Takes Slalom: Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., posted her ninth World Cup slalom victory, winning at Mellau, Austria. It was the first women's competition since a race at Courmayeur, Italy, early this season in which no Swiss skier was among the top three. In the overall World Cup standing, the first four places still belonged to Swiss skiers. The 24-year-old McKinney was fastest in the second heat and was timed in 1:48.79 seconds for her two runs over the course, which had 63 and 62 gates for the two runs. Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia was second in 1:49.23 and Margorzata Mogore of France third in 1:49.26.(AP) West German Moves Up: Markus Wasmeier of West Germany blazed through a snowstorm to win a men's Super-G ski race at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, West Germany, and move into second place in the overall World Cup standing. The cup leader, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, capped a productive weekend by following his victory in Saturday's downhill with a second-place finish in the Super-G. Wasmeier was timed in 1:23.44 on the windy, 1,860-meter long Kandahar course in scoring his second World Cup victory this season. Alberto Ghidoni of Italy, a late starter at No. 39, had a daring run on the difficult course and finished third in 1:24.18. Franck Piccard of France was fourth in 1:25.00. (AP) Bobsledding Swiss Duo Captures Title: Ralph Pichler and Celest Poltera of Switzerland won the world two-man bobsled championships in St. Moritz, Switzerland, to break a three-year East German hold on the title. The Swiss team turned in the fastest final run for a four-heat total of 4:33.09. Another Swiss sled, driven by Hans Hiltebrand and braked by Andre Kiser, tied for second with East Germany's 1984 Olympic gold medalists and triple world champions, Wolfgang Hoppe and Dietmar Schauerhammer. Their time was 4:33.45.(AP) Ski Jumping Ski Jumping to Norwegian: Vegard Opaas of Norway won a World Cup ski jumping event for his third victory of the season. Ernst Vettori of Austria continues to lead the overall cup standing, with 149 points, while Opaas is second, with 147. The meet was held on a 70-meter hill in the High Tatra Mountains of Czechoslovakia. Opaas had jumps of 91 and 86 meters for a winning total of 225.60 points. Second was Andreas Felder of Austria with jumps of 88 and 85.5 meters and 222.50 points. Ari-Pekka Nikkola of Finland was third with leaps of 87.5 and 85.5 meters for 220.20 points.(AP) Track and Field Belilgne Qualifies for Millrose: Atlaw Belilgne, who was born in Ethiopia and came to this country at age 23 to play soccer at St. Louis University, ran the one-mile distance indoors for the first time yesterday and qualified for the Millrose Games Masters Mile Invitation Jan. 30. Belilgne, a professor of mathematics at a branch of St. John's University on Staten Island, finished first in the Masters one-mile Millrose qualifying race at the Metropolitan Athletics Congress all-comers meet at Fordham University. His time was 4 minutes 38.4 seconds. Squash Racquets Talbott Rallies for Victory: Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., rallied from a two-game deficit yesterday to defeat Pepe Martinez of Mexico City, 9-15, 11-15, 15-6, 15-7, 15-10, in the final of the $15,000 Rolex Greenwich Squash Racquets Open at the Field Club of Greenwich, Conn. The 23-year-old Martinez, ranked 60th at the beginning of the season on the World Professional Squash Association computer, joined the professional tour in midseason after completing his engineering studies in Mexico City. Horse Racing Touchy Lady Wins at Hialeah: Touchy Lady, a Churchill Downs shipper dismissed at 13-to-1, took over turning for home and registered a three-length victory over Koluctoo's Power and Glorious Glory in the $31,780 Gold Stage Handicap at Hialeah Park. Ride Sally, the queen of Florida's sprinting fillies last year, checked sharply down the backstretch and never recovered, finishing ninth in a field of 10 as the 3-to-5 favorite. Touchy Lady, a 4-year-old daughter of Mr. Leader and the Prove Out mare Touch of Fame, paid $28.20 for $2 to win. She covered the five and a half furlongs in 1:04 1/5, a track record, under 112 pounds, including Keith Allen. Koluctoo's Power with 113 pounds, was up in the final stride to nose out Glorious Glory at 110 and Algenib at 112. Stakes Record for Bold Mate: Bold Mate established a stakes record racing to a 3 3/4-length victory in the $68,000 Busanda Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. Her clocking for a mile and 70 yards on the muddy inner track was 1:42 3/5. It bettered by a full second the previous standard posted by Lady Norcliffe in 1983. She paid $7.40 for $2 to win. N.B.A. Trail Blazers 103, Bucks 92: Kiki Vandeweghe scored 32 points and Clyde Drexler 23 as Portland defeated Milwaukee. A short jumper by Drexler gave the Blazers an 86-69 lead with 8:28 left in the game, but the Bucks came back to get within 11 with 5:45 remaining. Then another Drexler basket capped a run of 6 Portland points, rebuilding its advantage to 96-79.(AP)

title: It Takes More Than Love to Be a Good New York Foster Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: North Castle Changes Hands
description: The management of North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., has bought the agency back from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications because of conflict-of-interest problems perceived by prospective clients. F.C.B., the nation's ninth-largest advertising agency, acquired North Castle two years ago.

title: POINDEXTER AT THE SECURITY COUNCIL: A QUICK RISE AND A TROUBLED REIGN
description: Throughout his career in the Navy, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter was regarded as the consummate military aide, the man who carried out orders with alacrity and, at times, brilliance.

title: TRAWLERS IN SEATTLE FITTING OUT, READY TO FISH FOR THE RUSSIANS
description: Felix Garcia, master of the 98-foot trawler Endurance, stood in the center of the deck and talked of the prospects for the coming season when for the eighth year he will be captain of a ship that fishes American waters in the Bering Sea and sells the catch to foreign processing ships.

title: FENCING TAKING BIG STEPS
description: ''Fencing is a lifetime sport,'' the chief organizer of the tournament in lower Manhattan was saying above the din of the mayhem around him.

title:
Twice Wrong On AIDS;
The F.D.A. Frustrates Victims
description: LEAD: Although researchers recently announced the first promising treatment for AIDS, the experimental drug AZT, many AIDS patients who are eager to try AZT still can't get it.

title: KOCH DISCUSSES MYERSON'S ROLE AS CITY OFFICIAL
description: Mayor Koch convened his top legal advisers yesterday to discuss the future of Cultural Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson, who invoked the Fifth Amendment before a grand jury investigation into a city contractor.

title: Finding the Findings
description: ''. . . I determine it is essential to limit prior notice, and direct the Director of Central Intelligence to refrain from reporting this Finding to the Congress . . .'' - Document signed Jan. 17, 1986, by President Reagan.

title: GRIEF OVER BABY M
description: Long before the trauma of the Baby M case ensnared them, the principals were pulled together by a single, almost magnetic emotion - torment over birth of a child.

title: U.N. SOLDIER KILLEB BY ISRAELIS
description: An Irish soldier in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was killed Saturday by Israeli tank fire, the force's commander said today.

title: A Focus on the U.S. Economy
description: For the time being, the credit markets are focusing on forecasts of weak economic growth as a reason why the Federal Reserve and foreign central banks may move to reduce short-term interest rates in coming months.

title: BRAZIL COURT BANS MILK FROM EUROPE
description: A Brazilian federal court has banned the sales of powdered milk imported from Western Europe because it has been found to be contaminated with radioactive residue from the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union.

title: STOCK SURGE BUOYS INVESTORS
description: Wall Streeters with long memories had even more reason than most investors last week to cheer the new year's bullish burst that took the Dow Jones industrial average past 2,000 for the first time. Since 1950, early January gains have proved to be the forerunner of advances for the entire year in 20 out of 22 instances.

title: O'CONNOR IS UPSET BY CRITICS OF TRIP
description: Saying that he had gone to Israel ''in good faith,'' John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday expressed ''deep, deep disappointment'' with a statement issued by Jewish leaders in the United States that criticized several aspects of his Middle East trip.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: More S.E.C. Rumors
description: Rumors that John S. R. Shad will shortly leave the Securities and Exchange Commission for a post as Ambassador to the Netherlands have re-emerged since the first of the year, according to S.E.C. officials. But Mr. Shad continues to decline to comment on his future plans.

title: ISRAELIS DISMISS SUGGESTION THEY LED U.S. INTO IRAN DEALINGS
description: Senior Israeli officials said today that the latest disclosures suggesting that Israel had led the United States into the Iran arms affair were baseless. But the Israeli officials continued to refuse to spell out their country's role in the affair from beginning to end.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many players have been unanimous selections to baseball's Hall of Fame?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALL WE NEED OF HELL. By Harry Crews. 161 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: RUSH TO SUCCESS FOR DICKSON
description: WHEN Chris Dickson was 5 years old, he acquired a kinship with boats that has carried him all the way through to the America's Cup.

title: KNICKS ARE ON PATH TO MAKING PLAYOFF
description: The Knicks, a team that just three weeks ago seemed well on its way toward basketball oblivion with a record that left them 16 games below the .500 mark, are now actually in the race for the playoffs.

title: Albania Schedules Elections
description: Albania will hold parliamentary elections on Feb. 1, with Ramiz Alia, the Albanian leader, running in the constitutency of his predecessor, Enver Hoxha, the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug said today. The last Albanian parliamentary elections were in November 1982.

title: AT 80, HONDA'S FOUNDER IS STILL A FIERY MAVERICK
description: Age has not dulled Soichiro Honda, one of Japan's most successful inventors and entrepreneurs and the founder of the Honda Motor Company. Now 80 years old, he still denounces Government interference in business and still dreams of new technology.

title: CARDINAL WEIGHING WEDDING FOR MAN WITH AIDS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he was reviewing the decision of the rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral who refused to perform a Roman Catholic wedding in the church for a man who is dying with AIDS.

title: FRENCH STRIKES FADE, THOUGH UNIN PLEDGES TO PRESS RAIL WALKOUT
description: Most trains ran on schedule today and electrical service returned to normal as thousands of striking workers began returning to their jobs.

title: U.S. PANEL DIVIDED ON AIDING DISPLACED WORKERS
description: A Reagan Administration advisory council is deeply divided over how to address the growing problem of workers who lose their jobs because of imports or changes in the economy.

title: BROWNS LOSE, 23-20, ON OVERTIME KICK
description: Behind the acrobatic creativity of John Elway at quarterback, the Denver Broncos stunned this city and its Browns today, producing a sudden-death 23-20 overtime victory that propelled them into the Super Bowl as the American Conference champions.

title: THE CLAMOR FOR 'COMPETITIVENESS'
description: Remember ''industrial policy''?

title: IT'S ACT FIRST, FACE QUESTIONS LATER FOR SOME APPOINTEES
description: Recess appointees, chosen by the President while Congress is away, are strange creatures of the political process.

title: OFFICIALS IN NEW YORK REGION ASSESS U.S. BUDGET
description: As Congress began reviewing President Reagan's proposed budget this week, officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut analyzed its effect on the region and concluded it would be devastating.

title: Suriname Asks Dutch To Withdraw Envoy
description: Suriname asked the Netherlands on Saturday to withdraw its Ambassador, accusing him of interfering in the internal affairs of the former Dutch colony, the official Suriname News Agency reported.

title: Swiss Bank Secrecy Rules
description: Swiss banking authorities, embarrassed by their country's role as a center for laundering funds, said Friday that they had urged banks to tighten a loophole in their self-regulatory secrecy rules.

title: Forward and Back on College Aid
description: As college costs keep rising, so does reliance on loans - and so does fear that debt burdens will inhibit choices of college and career. The new Reagan Administration budget offers a creative plan to ease the loan burden, but then undercuts it by reducing scholarship grants.

title: Decorating at the Hill
description: Staff members of newly elected members of Congress are enjoying moving into their new quarters, and they are enjoying even more their housekeeping chores when it comes to throwing out the defeated previous occupants' flotsam and jetsam.

title: CONNER BRINGS SAVVY AND SPEED TO CHALLENGER FINAL
description: PERHAPS it is the maturity that comes with losing yachting's most valuable trophy and having the resiliency to try to win it back. But Dennis Conner has changed since his 1983 America's Cup campaign.

title: Distinctive Labels
description: For members of Congress, sponsoring bills with low numbers is a little like getting low-numbered license plates for their cars: Somehow or other, prestige has become involved. Having a low number doesn't make a bill any more likely to pass but makes it seem more distinctive and its shorthand designation easier to remember.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET PERFORMS 'BALLO DELLA REGINA'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Ballo della Regina'' received two festive performances by the New York City Ballet over the weekend at the New York State Theater.

title: Public Toilets
description: To the Editor:

title: Thompson to Push Jake's, a New Cola
description: A diet cola with the name Jake's certainly deserves a down-home kind of promotion, even though it was created by the city slickers at Pepsico Inc. And that's exactly what the new product will be getting, courtesy of J. Walter Thompson, when advertising begins in its Jacksonville, Fla., test market on Jan. 19.

title: BRONCOS GET BOMB THREAT
description: More than 15,000 Denver Bronco fans were forced to wait another hour at Stapleton International Airport to greet the new American Football Conference champions because of a bomb threat to the team's charter plane at Cleveland.

title: Why the Deficit Matters
description: President Reagan has railed against big deficits for five years now, but his 1988 budget offers fresh proof that he doesn't really care. His outrage about ''big spenders'' is little changed. His priorities remain the same: Spend more for defense, but raise no new revenues. And the results remain the same: a mendacious Federal budget and unacceptable deficits.

title: VOYAGE OVER, PILOTS HIT THE ROAD TO PAY FOR IT
description: When Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager touched down after guiding their experimental airplane Voyager on its nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel, they needed a shower, sleep and hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: FRUSTRATION, VOWS EMERGE AFTER LOSS
description: On Friday after a practice for today's American Football Conference championship game here, Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, dropped a friend off at Cleveland Stadium and then disappeared to park his car way around the back of the lakefront structure.

title: When West Is East
description: IN the gospel according to Rudyard Kipling, East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet. But then Rudyard Kipling was never in Giants Stadium when the wind was blowing. Yesterday the twain met. Yesterday east was west and west was east. And with a 17-0 victory over the Washington Redskins, the Giants rode that wind into Super Bowl XXI against the Denver Broncos.

title: BRAZILIAN LOAN REQUEST IS EXPECTED
description: Following a slump in its trade surplus and foreign exchange reserves, Brazil is now planning to seek between $2 billion and $3 billion in ''new money'' from its creditors, as part of upcoming negotiations to restructure foreign debt, according to officials in Brasilia.

title: ONE MAN'S POLITICAL VIEWS COLOR BRAZIL'S TV EYE
description: Every weekday evening at 7:55, at least 50 million Brazilians scattered across this huge land, including one neatly dressed 82-year-old man with a telephone by his side, watch the day's news as chosen, interpreted and broadcast by Globo TV, the country's largest television network.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI, SUTHERLAND
description: GALA performances of scenes stitched together from several operas have a long and honorable place in operatic history. They serve especially to celebrate great singers in the autumn of their careers. Dame Nellie Melba, for instance, bade her farewells in the 1920's in a program of acts from ''Romeo et Juliette,'' ''Boheme'' and ''Otello.'' Her great compatriot and successor, Dame Joan Sutherland, revisited three of her best roles in excerpts - the ghost story and love duet from ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' and the death scenes from ''Rigoletto'' and ''La Traviata'' -at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday.

title: COMMANDO LIFE LOSING APPEAL FOR PRINCE?
description: The fishbowl life of the Royal Family has come under new and heavy public ogling in recent weeks.

title: Bank Figure in Restitution
description: Antonio Gebauer, the former Morgan Guaranty Trust Company official who pleaded guilty to making millions of dollars in unauthorized withdrawals from Morgan accounts in Latin America, has repaid most of the accounts and is repaying the others, according to papers filed in court by his lawyer, Stanley S. Arkin.

title: AIDS STUDY IS ILLEGAL, CALIFORNIA UNIT SAYS
description: California health officials have refused to participate in a Federal study of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, saying it violates the state's confidentiality laws because it tests blood specimens without patients' written permission.

title: BLACKS, AFTER HOWARD BEACH, UNITE ON GOALS, SPLIT ON POLICY
description: Many black leaders agree that the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, has underscored the seriousness of New York City's racial problems and the need for strong actions to change the attitudes and conditions that prompt such attacks.

title: Outlook for Oil Use
description: The growth in oil consumption in the Western industrial countries is likely to slow slightly in the first three quarters of this year, the International Energy Agency said in its latest monthly oil market report scheduled to be released on Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How come society cannot cope with this problem?'' - Naomi Levine, an N.Y.U.

title: For Old Times Sq., Time Is Running Out
description: Times Square has always held its share of surprises. Now that it seems so close to becoming a memory, it has also won some surprising admirers.

title: SANTUCCI WILL NOT BALK AT A SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
description: Governor Cuomo and District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens will meet today to discuss the possibility of Mr. Cuomo naming a special state prosecutor to take over the Howard Beach racial assault case, which has been stymied by the refusal of a key witness to cooperate.

title: 2 RESCUED FROM EXPLOSION DEBRIS
description: A natural gas explosion destroyed a split-level home in Cranford, N.J., early Saturday night, but police officers arriving at the scene helped two elderly residents escape serious injury.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ GOT 'DOCTORED' DATA, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: American intelligence agencies provided Iran and Iraq with deliberately distorted or inaccurate intelligence data in recent years to further the Reagan Administration's goals in the region, intelligence sources said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 24 about the nonstop round-the-world flight of the aircraft Voyager included an incorrect report from the craft's designer about its insurance status. A Voyager organization spokesman says the plane did carry liability insurance, provided by the Home Insurance Company and others.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Butterick Co., a maker and distributor of Butterick and Vogue sewing patterns, named John E. Lehmann president.

title: Father Dies in Fire In Brooklyn Building
description: A Brooklyn man was killed yesterday when a fire swept through an apartment building, but his wife and 10-year-old son survived when the woman threw the child out of a third-floor window and then jumped after him, the police said.

title: AT LAST, FANS SHOW EUPHORIA
description: When it was over and the Giants had guaranteed themselves a spot in the Super Bowl, William F. Gloede wondered if he had been dreaming. It looked easy, too easy.

title: JAZZ: TURK MURPHY
description: AN enthusiastic and warmly sentimental audience filled Carnegie Hall and overflowed onto the stage Saturday evening to greet Turk Murphy, the 71-year-old trombonist who was a pillar of the traditional jazz revival in California almost 50 years ago, and who was here making his Carnegie Hall debut and his first appearance in New York in more than a quarter of a century.

title: AFRICAN PRESS GREETS SHULTZ WITH DOUBTS
description: Despite the congenial atmosphere that appears to have marked the official talks held by Secretary of State George P. Shultz with African leaders in the last few days, he has run into some critical questions and editorials from African journalists about Washington's policies on South Africa and the Middle East.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 12, 1987
description: International Report

title: At Last, Nehemiah Is Back on Track
description: IT has been almost 20 years since the little boy from Scotch Plains, N.J., gained one of those personal insights that can change a life. It happened, he recalled the other day, on Jackson Avenue, a side street near his home on Front Street, when he was about 8 years old. He and some other boys from the neighborhood challenged each other to a block race. They lined up and started together, but when they got to the corner the boy from Front Street was all alone and had learned something about himself he had never known before. It was the first time, Renaldo Nehemiah said, that he realized he was fast.

title: CANADIANS COMPLAIN REAGAN RENEGES ON ACID RAIN FUNDS
description: Less than a year after President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney signed an accord on a joint approach to the problem of acid rain, officials here have begun questioning whether the United States is serious about tackling an issue that has sensitive political overtones.

title: CHAD'S ANTI-LIBYA OFFENSIVE: SURPRISING SUCCESSES
description: Chadian forces, aided by sandstorms and superior morale, have scored unexpected successes against heavily armed Libyan troops in northern Chad in recent weeks and now control key locations, according to French and American military sources. In the fighting, which an

title: Forest for Klinghoffer Is Dedicated in Israel
description: Deputy Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani of Italy dedicated a forest in Israel today in memory of Leon Klinghoffer, the elderly American Jew killed in the 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship.

title: Verdict In Without Reporter
description: Prosecutors won a murder conviction Saturday without the evidence of a reporter who refused to testify about an interview he had with the defendant.

title: Giants Escape The Triangle
description: THE Giants could not reach the Super Bowl when they played in Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium in New York, and they could not reach the Super Bowl when they brown-bagged it to the Yale Bowl in Connecticut, but yesterday they finally reached the Super Bowl from their base in New Jersey.

title: 'NIGHT OF COURAGE,' FILM ON BIGOTRY
description: THIS evening's television movie on ABC, at 9 o'clock, is called ''Night of Courage.''

title: Washington Watch; Bank Failure Costs Rising
description: FAILURES of banks and thrift institutions this year and next will cost the Government a lot more than previously predicted - almost $10 billion more, according to numbers released in the President's budget last week.

title: G.M. Incentive Study Reported
description: The General Motors Corporation is studying a range of new buyer incentives to spur United States sales and is expected to announce them later this month, according to an industry trade paper. The publication, Automotive

title: Leigh Seong De Chen Wed
description: The marriage of Leigh Seong De Chen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tze Chin Chen of Seremban, Negri Sembilan, Malaysia, to Douglas Schnapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schnapp of New York, took place yesterday at the Town Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated. The bride, a graduate of Seton Hall University, is a tax accountant at Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company in New York. Mr. Schnapp, a graduate of New York University and the Brooklyn Law School, is a tax lawyer in New York and Florida.

title: DIPLOMACY TAKES HARD CHECK
description: Few things excite passion in Canadians as much as ice hockey, in particular ice hockey against the Russians.

title: U.S. IS SEEN LAGGING IN RAIL SAFETY
description: The high-speed rail systems of Japan and France have features that would have prevented the Amtrak train wreck in which 15 people died Jan. 4, railroad experts say.

title: Bridge: New York's Been Fortunate In Representatives to League
description: For more than 40 years, New York City and Long Island, which together form 1 of the 25 administrative districts of the American Contract Bridge League, have been very fortunate in their representatives.

title: A Saner Space Policy
description: Excerpts from ''Challenger: A Major Malfunction'' by one of the finalists in NASA's Journalist-in-Space competition, Malcolm McConnell, published Jan. 2 by Doubleday:

title: LAWYERS' STYLES DIFFER AT JERSEY TRIAL
description: For two months three lawyers with contrasting styles have maneuvered for the attention of jurors in the trial of two avowed revolutionaries accused of murdering a state trooper.

title: INDIANAPOLIS ROUSES FOR JOYS AND HEADACHES OF PAN AM GAMES
description: Kurt Vonnegut said that this city on the White River woke up once a year for the Indianapolis 500 race and then slept 364 days.

title: Layoffs at B.B.D.O.
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn reported Friday that it had let go about 50 people, or 5 percent of its New York staff. B.B.D.O. said it had to reduce overhead in the face of sluggish industry growth and to prepare for moving to 1285 Avenue of the Americas this spring from its long-time home at 383 Madison Avenue. The agency is part of BBDO Worldwide, one of three operating units in the Omnicom Group.

title: OUTDOORS: HUNTING, AND COOKING, SEA DUCKS
description: AS the seasons for the ducks that are more traditionally hunted draw to a close (in some Northeast states they are already over), a few enterprising waterfowlers turn to the sea ducks -scoters, eiders and old squaws - and of them the scoters, black, surf, and white-winged, are the most sought after.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Merrill Promotion For Expert on Deals
description: LEAD: Kenneth H. Miller, the man who helped Merrill Lynch move into the heady field of merchant banking, has been named vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Stephania Aulicino Is Married to James M. Condon
description: Stephania Aulicino, a daughter of Mrs. Armand D. Aulicino of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Aulicino, was married in Chicago yesterday to James Michael Condon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Condon of Stuart, Fla. The Rev. Douglas Cater, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Drake Hotel.

title: INgentina Standby Loan
description: Finance Secretary Mario Brodersohn said Friday that Argentina had reached agreement with the International Monetary Fund on a standby loan to help make payments on the nation's $50 billion foreign debt. Mr. Brodersohn told reporters the agreement would provide credits of more than .8 billion. Buenos Aires newspapers had said negotiators were seeking a standby loan of $1.2 billion, plus $350 million in drawing rights to compensate for lost exports.

title: TRIAL OPENS TODAY FOR 3 ACCUSED OF MURDERING DRUG RING INFORMER
description: Three Colombian nationals are to go on trial here Monday on first-degree murder charges in the machine-gun slaying of a key Government witness against the leaders of Colombia's largest cocaine smuggling operation, The three men are among four people charged in the murder of Adler B. Seal, a pilot smuggling marijuana and cocaine into the United States. Drug law-enforcement officials had expected Mr. Seal to testify against the leaders of Colombia's Medellin cartel, which reportedly controlled most of the Colombian cocaine trade.

title: Topics: Fashion Is Spinach; Maxi-coats Redux
description: One of this season's fashion hits, the longer, more fully proportioned coat, offers women enormous advantages. Hitting many wearers at the ankles, it keeps the legs warm. With more shoulder and hip room, it easily covers a dress-for-success suit or a fashionably bulky hand-knit sweater. And the wonderfully warm colors almost conquer the winter chill.

title: MUSIC: BEETHOVEN SOCIETY
description: SATURDAY'S Beethoven Society concert caught the composer in some of his serener moods. It was a program of chamber music - two duo sonatas and two trios, and most of the music emanates from one of the unhappier periods in Beethoven's life. Those who insist on relating life to art will have their troubles here. The composer's personal pain seems to have resulted in the Cello Sonata in A and the E flat Trio, both played at this concert, as well as the childlike high spirits and innocent raptures of the piano sonatas Opus 78 and Opus 79, which came not too long afterward.

title: Medical Costs and the Physician Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Workers Reach Pact
description: About 900 employees of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company can collect back pay and 130 laid-off workers can get their old jobs back under a $6 million settlement with the Communications Workers of America, according to the union.

title: HIRING ALIENS: THE NEW RISKS
description: Businesses across the country are struggling with the new immigration law's attempts to curb the hiring of illegal aliens, and perhaps nowhere is the concern more evident than in southern California, where several million illegal aliens are believed to be employed.

title: IRANIAN MISSILES FIRED AT BASRA AND BAGHDAD
description: Asserting that it had opened a ''second stage'' of its new offensive in the Persian Gulf war, Iran fired missiles today into the Iraqi cities of Baghdad and Basra.

title: TAKE IT EASY, DOCTORS ADVISE PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan has been ordered by his doctors to limit his physical activities for the next six weeks in line with the usual regimen for a man who has just been discharged from a hospital for a transurethral resection of the prostate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INTAR: THE CREATIVE PROCESS To produce a musical creation for the theater, says Graciela Daniele, it is necessary to collaborate. For the 20-year-old Intar Hispanic America Arts Center, Ms. Daniele is conducting a series of workshops emphasizing teamwork. In the workshops are playwrights, lyricists and composers who spend a week together thrashing out the details of the creative aspects of producing a musical. On hand also are professional actors, singers, dancers and technical crews. It is Intar's hope that these efforts will lead to the production of original music theater for the American stage.

title: Caroline Jones Is Bride of Peter Galison
description: Caroline Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jones of Princeton, N.J., was married last night to Peter Galison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Galison of New York. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the One Fifth Avenue restaurant in New York.

title: Gap on Organ Donations
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, has found an omission of just $7.4 million from President Reagan's trillion-dollar budget but one that the Senator says could end the hope of many people whose lives are endangered from the lack of quickly available body organs for transplants.

title: Murray Ohio Chief Quits
description: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, maker of mowers and bicycles, said yesterday that Richard W. Sappenfield had resigned as president, chief executive and a director in differences over the ''future strategic direction of the company.'' William M. Hannon, the chairman, whose grandfather founded the company, was appointed interim chief executive. Two directors, David K. Wilson and John N. Anderson, also resigned. Mr. Anderson is a former chief executive of the company, which is based in Brentwood, Tenn.

title: CARSON'S BAD TIMES LONG GONE
description: So now the guy's a big-shot columnist. His helmeted face rests on a prominent shelf in a bookstore near you. The face does not smile on the jacket cover, but it does most everywhere else these days. His voice is on the radio, telling you where your dial is tuned. Like the song says, the future's so bright, he's gotta wear shades.

title: School Bars Musical, Charging Sexual Bias
description: School officials have told high school students that they cannot stage the Broadway musical farce ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' because, the officials say, it is morally unacceptable and degrading to women.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $64,986,000 from the settlement of Chapter 11 obligations for both the quarter and year, and $780,000 from the termination of a pension plan for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,537,000 and $6,194,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the year-ago quarter and year losses from continuing operations include a writedown of $14 million on certain assets. The company said for the latest quarter and fiscal year, interest expense and discount amortization arising from securities in its reorganization amounted to $3,889,000.

title: CUOMO AND SANTUCCI CONFER ON RACIAL ATTACK
description: Governor Cuomo met with the Queens District Attorney here today to discuss turning the case of the Howard Beach racial assault over to a special prosecutor.

title: United Financial Officer
description: Frank R. Jarc, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Wilson Foods Corporation, will join United Airlines as senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective Feb. 2. Mr. Jarc, 44 years old, worked for Gould Inc. before joining Wilson, which is based in Oklahoma City.

title: NEW FINDINGS REVEAL ANCIENT ABUSE OF LANDS
description: RECENT discoveries in the southwestern United States, southern Greece and the South Pacific have persuaded a growing number of archeologists that primitive people were much more destructive to their habitat than had been generally believed.

title: GROWTH IN WESTERN STATES IS STALLED BY HARD TIMES
description: The buoyant, optimistic American West, whose economic growth has outpaced the nation over much of the past 20 years, has begun the new year facing a new set of realities: declining population growth, persistent problems in important industries and growing apprehension about the future.

title: 3 SEEKING TRADES BY DEADLINE
description: When Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' general manager, speaks of hoping to be able to complete a major deal before the league's Feb. 15 trading deadline, he has plenty of people sharing his sentiments. Among them are three Knicks, each of whom hopes by then not to be a member of the team.

title: KEAN, CRITICIZING WELFARE, PROPOSES WORK REQUIREMENT
description: Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message today, called the state's welfare system a failure. He said he wanted to start a program to require all able-bodied recipients to go to work to support themselves and their families.

title: COLLECTIVE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split which occurred July 17, 1986.

title: KOCH MEETS WITH CLERGY ON RACISM
description: More than 50 religious leaders met at City Hall yesterday to condemn the Howard Beach racial attack in the third such gathering that Mayor Koch has held to encourage groups to speak out against racism in New York City.

title: Joiner Retires
description: At the age of 39, Charlie Joiner, the San Diego wide receiver who holds the National Football League record for receptions and receiving yardage, has retired after an 18-year career in which he caught 750 passes for 12,146 yards. He also holds the record for most games played by a wide receiver, with 239.

title: THIOKOL DELAYS FULL-SCALE TEST OF SHUTTLE BOOSTER
description: Morton Thiokol has delayed until mid-March the first full-scale test-firing of its redesigned space shuttle booster, originally planned for the first week of February.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOST ENERGY FUNDS FOR MILITARY USES
description: The Energy Department's budget request would increase the share of agency funds that are spent on military programs while reducing funds for energy conservation and renewable energy programs, according to a Congressional study made public today.

title: Argentina Loan Accord
description: Juan Sourrouille, Argentina's Economy Minister announced today that the World Bank had granted Argentina a $2 billion loan.

title: CULTURAL ISOLATION
description: Momentum appears to be gathering for an attack on what many educators regard as Americans' ignorance about the world beyond their shores. Foreign failures and difficulties that have developed in recent years, from Vietnam to Iran, have led to calls for a general bolstering Americans' knowledge of unfamiliar languages and cultures.

title: KNOPF PRESIDENT WILL SUCCEED SHAWN AS NEW YORKER EDITOR
description: Robert A. Gottlieb, president and editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf, will succeed William Shawn as editor of The New Yorker, a magazine that for years has been a magnet for many of the country's leading writers.

title: 3 Banking Organizations Market 10-Year Notes
description: Three banking companies sold 10-year notes through Salomon Brothers yesterday, joining a large and growing list of corporate borrowers attracted to the debt market this year by a combination of strong investor demand and interest rates that are near their lowest levels in nine years.

title: Stars & Stripes Finds a Groove
description: If Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes is able to beat New Zealand today on the America's Cup race course in Fremantle, Australia, it may be due in part to a new ''secret weapon'' that Conner's syndicate revealed yesterday.

title: TEXACO-PENNZOIL HEARING STRESSES SIZE
description: David Boies, the lawyer representing Texaco Inc., had a difficult argument to make to the United States Supreme Court today.

title: Reagan Aids Woman Who Saved 100 Fliers
description: President Reagan today telephoned an 82-year-old Belgian woman who saved more than 100 Allied fliers in World War II to tell her she would be granted permanent residency in the United States after a five-year quest.

title: Secondary and Oil Issues Spur Rally
description: Wall Street's rally kept rolling along yesterday, but this time secondary stocks and oil issues, which have long been out of favor, provided the excitement that was lacking in the blue chips.

title: SOVIET TV ASKS FOR 'AMERIKA' SERIES
description: Officials of the Soviet State Committee for Television and Radio said today that they had begun discussions with ABC to buy broadcasting rights to the mini-series ''Amerika,'' and hoped to show it on Soviet television.

title: Japan Car Engines In Canada Venture
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company, Japan's sixth-largest auto maker, has agreed to provide a Canadian vehicle manufacturer with car engines and is considering forming a joint venture to build cars in Canada, according to Tomonaru Eguchi, the company's president. Mr. Eguchi said Daihatsu was working out final details on providing 850 cubic-centimeter engines to Bombardier Inc., a maker of snowmobiles and other special vehicles.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes income from the disposal of discontinued operations of $88,000 and $170,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: JARUZELSKI BEGINS OFFICIAL VISIT TO ROME
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today began his first official visit to the West since he imposed martial law in Poland five years ago.

title: GRAND JURY ASSAILS HOSPITAL IN '84 DEATH OF 18-YEAR-OLD
description: A Manhattan grand jury, in a report issued yesterday, determined that ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated mistakes made by unsupervised interns and junior residents at a New York hospital resulted in the death of a young woman there in 1984.

title: A World of Speed
description: When Renaldo Nehemiah left track in 1982 to play for the San Francisco 49ers, he held four world best times for indoor hurdle events and the 10 fastest indoor clockings for the 60-yard and 55-meter events. Now, after leaving pro football and petitioning successfully to return as an amateur hurdler, his times remain unmatched. He still holds five of the seven fastest 60-yard or 55-meter times:

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST RECALL CHILDHOOD DIFFICULTIES
description: Some donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recall their own difficult childhood experiences in contributing to the 75th annual appeal.

title: F.D.U. Regains Division I Status
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today restored Fairleigh Dickinson University to Division I status. The action clears the way for the school's teams to compete in championship competition this year, said Roy Danforth, the school's athletic director.

title: Allied Stores Chief Resigns From Post
description: Thomas M. Macioce, the 67-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Allied Stores Corporation, has resigned in the wake of the recent merger of Allied into the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian builder.

title: BACKERS OF ORGAN GIFTS CRITICIZE REAGAN CUTS
description: Organ donor advocates, including families who received help from the Reagans in seeking transplants for their critically ill children, have attacked a White House proposal to end Federal spending on donor programs.

title: KOHLBERG RAISES BID FOR OWENS
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company yesterday raised its acquisition offer for Owens-Illinois Inc. to $3.6 billion, only hours after the rejection of its previous bid.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Acme Electric Corp., Cuba, N.Y., said G. Wayne Hawk, president, had succeeded James W. McLaughlin as chief executive. Mr. McLaughlin will remain chairman of the board.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $100,000.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
'Silver Gun' Theory Attacked By Lawyer in Trooper Death
description: A defense lawyer in the trial of two men charged with killing State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco today attacked the state's contention that one of the men had a silver gun the day of the shooting.

title: Prince Edward Quits The Royal Marines
description: Prince Edward, Queen Elizabeth's youngest son and fifth in line to the British throne, quit the Royal Marines today, breaking a century-old tradition of princes serving tours of duty in the armed forces.

title: 3,000 Turbine Jobs To Be Cut by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company, responding to shrinking demand for steam turbines, said yesterday that it would lay off more than 3,000 workers at turbine and generator plants in Lynn, Mass., and Schenectady, N.Y., and consolidate operations.

title: Public Service Spot To Raise AIDS Funds
description: A new public service spot to raise funds for the fight on AIDS, created by a team at Cunningham & Walsh, is scheduled for tonight during an NBC-TV special entitled ''Men, Women, Sex and AIDS.''

title: MET-COIL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company went public in December 1985.

title: Insider Figure Is Sentenced to 30 Days in Jail
description: David S. Brown, a former lawyer and investment banker, was sentenced yesterday to 30 days in jail, 300 hours of community service and 3 years of probation for selling inside information about pending takeovers to Dennis B. Levine.

title: Will There Be a Highway Bill?
description: When Congress adjourned last fall without agreement on a bill for new highway and mass transit programs, it promised to address the issue first thing this year. It has made good on its word.

title: WILLIAM M. JUDD, 70, MANAGER OF MAJOR CLASSICAL MUSICIANS
description: William M. Judd, a manager of major classical musicians for more than 40 years, died of heart failure yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: 'HILL STREET BLUES' EPISODE BY MAMET
description: IT cannot be said often enough:

title: Bridge: Two Young German Players Surprised American Expert
description: Historically speaking, neither tennis nor bridge have been popular recreations in Germany. But the changing pattern in tennis, exemplified by Boris Becker and Steffi Graf, may soon be matched in bridge, judging from some evidence from the 1986 world championships in Miami Beach.

title: AN UNABASHEDLY PATRIOTIC STRAUSS GOES STUMPING
description: It is the refrain that touches off the stormiest applause. Hunkered behind the podium, Franz Josef Strauss calls upon his compatriots to come out of ''the shadows of the Third Reich'' and to be proud to be Germans again.

title: CAPT CRAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago loss includes a gain of about $210,937 from the sale of securities.

title: Lovelorn Moose May Return in Fall
description: Bullwinkle the moose may have left Jessica the cow in the cold last week, but animal behaviorists say he might return in the fall.

title: End of Low-Fare, Quick-Getaway Flights
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR FASHION, A GLITTERING NIGHT OF HONORS
description: It could be viewed as a comfortable family gathering, or as a glittering assembly of stars. Last night 450 people in evening clothes gathered at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a dignified fashion awards ceremony followed by a home-style meat loaf dinner. The atmosphere was both stylish and glamorous, the kind of mixture the fashion industry manages to pull off with panache.

title: Ex-Wheeling Head Sold Stake Far Below Value
description: Lloyd C. Lubensky is a friend of Allen E. Paulson, so good a friend that Mr. Lubensky paid only $100,000 for Mr. Paulson's 34.2 percent stake in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, it was disclosed yesterday. Analysts had estimated that, had Mr. Lubensky paid the market price for the stock, he would have paid $13.5 million.

title: The Vatican Shows a Schizophrenia About Jews; Holocaust Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: RJR Nabisco Move Possible
description: RJR Nabisco Inc., the tobacco and food products company, said yesterday it was considering moving its headquarters from Winston-Salem, N.C., where Richard Joshua Reynolds established his tobacco company in 1875. A company spokesman, Bill Ruffin, said RJR Nabisco ''does have studies under way with respect to the potential relocaton of its corporate headquarters.'' A decision is expected within 10 days, he said. The Mayor of Winston-

title: ABRAMS ADVISES STATE TO REPEAL MILK SALE CURBS
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams today proposed legislation to repeal most existing marketing restrictions on the sale of milk in New York State.

title: Mortgage-Backed Securities Offered
description: Securities dealers offered $700 million of collateralized mortgage obligations yesterday. Demand for the high-quality securities, which offer yields well above Treasury issues, remains strong from foreign and domestic investors.

title: Interest Rates Close Mixed
