description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday with little change in short-term rates, while note and bond yields rose modestly.

title: SAFETY RECORD OF U.S. AIRLINES SHOWS BIG GAIN
description: United States airlines enjoyed one of their safest years in 1986, a turnaround from a 1985 toll that was one of the highest on record, according to official figures made public yesterday.

title: OIL PRICES END ABOVE $19 A BARREL
description: Crude oil reached prices yesterday not seen since last winter on world markets, and oil-industry stocks soared in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Parcells's Fate Tied to Reeves
description: In the twists of history that often accompany a Super Bowl plot, the Giants have used three Denver Broncos draft choices to acquire two linebackers, Gary Reasons and Pepper Johnson, as well as Ottis Anderson, the running back. And indirectly, Bill Parcells is the Giants' coach because the Giants chose in 1979 not to hire Dan Reeves, now the Broncos coach.

title: NEW REPORT OF SAUDI MONEY FOR CONTRAS
description: Robert C. McFarlane told Congress that Saudi Arabia had contributed millions of dollars for the Nicaraguan rebels, increasing to at least $40 million the amount gathered for the rebels that now cannot be accounted for, sources familiar with the Congressional investigation said today.

title: U.S. HEALTH CARE FAULTED IN SENATE
description: Testifying before a Senate Committee today, Joseph A. Califano Jr. called health care in this country ''a pothole system because it damages our people and shatters their lives.''

title: WAITE RETURNS TO LEBANON
description: Terry Waite, envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, arrived in Beirut today and said he had spoken with one of his contacts within an hour of his arrival on a new bid to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

title: ONE OF HOLLYWOOD 10 REVISITS MOSCOW
description: Fifty-three years after his last visit and four decades since his association with Communism fractured his career as a screenwriter, Ring Lardner Jr. returned to Moscow last week.

title: FRENCH STRIKES: THE LINE BETWEEN PRESSURE AND PROVOCATION
description: When workers on the Paris subway and bus system decided to continue a long, intermittent strike here today, they announced beforehand to the public, almost as a matter of courtesy, that the trains and buses would not be running from noon until 4 P.M.

title: 9 Garbage Haulers Face Jail or Work
description: Nine Long Island garbage haulers who pleaded guilty to scheming to control Suffolk County collection routes were ordered today to choose between jail or community service.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foul Mood
description: After Derrick Chievous of Missouri hit 14 of 16 free throws to lead the Tigers to an 87-83 upset of Oklahoma on Saturday, Coach Billy Tubbs of the Sooners commented angrily: ''I've never seen a guy so protected. I don't know what his stats are, but I guess the officials must think he's an endangered species.''

title: Plasma And AIDS
description: SCIENTISTS have found that blood plasma of some persons infected with the AIDS virus has large quantities of antibodies that inactivate the virus in the testtube.

title: A.B.A. REPORT ON LIABILITY CASES
description: An American Bar Association commission studying personal injury claims is recommending that there be no limits on awards for pain and suffering, but says the courts should try to make sure the awards are not excessive.

title: The U.N. Today: January 13, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on the Status of Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REAGAN PLAN ON VERIFYING NUCLEAR TESTS FAULTED
description: Government intelligence officials say a far more comprehensive approach should be taken to verifying Soviet and American compliance with limits on nuclear testing than has been proposed by the Reagan Administration, according to newly obtained secret documents.

title: Head Start on Head Start
description: Nothing should count higher in a society than the care of its children, yet in the United States children have become a neglected constituency, comprising 40 percent of the poor. Head Start, one of the jewels of the Great Society, has proven that high-quality early childhood education for the disadvantaged produces youngsters much more likely to finish high school, hold a job and avoid welfare and crime. But for many disadvantaged children, even Head Start comes too late.

title: Kirk Trial Postponed
description: The trial of Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State University basketball coach, on tax evasion and obstruction of justice charges has been postponed indefinitely. Judge Odell Horton of United States District Court in Memphis scheduled a hearing for Thursday to discuss a new trial date. Kirk, discharged by the university in September, was scheduled to go to trial Jan. 26.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Net loss The compoany said it rescheduled its shareholders meeting to Feb. 6 to consider and vote on its proposed merger with Tender Loving Care Inc. and that it would continue to solicit proxies for approval of the merger.

title: Prostitute-Link Charge Against Grimes Voided
description: Prostitution-related charges against Timothy Grimes, a victim in the Howard Beach, Queens, racial attack, were dropped yesterday because of insufficient evidence, officials said.

title: KOCH PRESSES BOROUGH CHIEFS FOR THEIR SHELTER PROPOSALS
description: The Koch administration yesterday said that it would go forward with its plan for 20 new homeless shelters in the five boroughs, unless the borough presidents offered alternatives shortly.

title: Dravo President Resigns
description: The directors of the Dravo Corporation accepted the resignation today of Thomas F. Faught Jr. as president and chief executive. Robert Dickey 3d, Dravo's chief executive from 1965 until 1983, was elected chairman, president and chief executive.

title: HUBCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1, 1986, and a 3-percent stock dividend paid Jan. 2, 1987.

title: Czechoslovakia Has Struck Sour Notes on Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASTISED PRIEST IS SUSPENDED
description: The Rev. Charles Curran, who has been under fire from the Vatican for his views on sexual ethics, said today that he had been suspended from teaching at Catholic University of America but that he planned to show up for the start of the spring term anyway.

title: Immunity Is Claimed
description: ''Tysonitis'' is the fanciful tag that Don King, the boxing promoter, uses for the abruptly horizontal condition to which most opponents of Mike Tyson have been reduced. But at a news conference yesterday, Tyson's next opponent, James (Bonecrusher) Smith, claimed to be immune to ''Tysonitis.'' Smith is the World Boxing Association champion who is to meet Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, on March 7 in Las Vegas, Nev. ''I plan to win the fight,'' Smith said. ''Mike Tyson hasn't faced the caliber of guys I have.'' With a record of 19-5 (14 knockouts), Smith has victories over Mike Weaver, Frank Bruno and Tim Witherspoon. But Tyson, who has knocked out 26 opponents in his 28 straight victories, did not sound like a man who expected to be beaten. ''When I hit him,'' said Tyson, ''I'll hit him good.'' Meanwhile, there was word from Panama that Alberto Aleman, chairman of the World Boxing Association Championship Committee, was still insisting that Smith has to fight the W.B.A.'s No. 1 available contender within 120 days of his title victory over Witherspoon last Dec. 12. The No. 1 W.B.A. contender currently is Tyrell Biggs, but his managers have said they do not want to fight Smith at this time. Tony Tubbs was No. 1 before he pulled out of a fight against Witherspoon, claiming injury.

title: Market Place; Stock Frenzy Grips Mexico
description: INVESTORS have stood in line to buy shares, the stock market index has raced upward at a dizzying pace and a general investing frenzy has gripped Mexico as the nation's stock market enters what analysts here call a ''superboom.''

title: NEW GRAND JURY IN WALKER CASE TO INVESTIGATE SIZE OF SPYING RING
description: A new Federal grand jury in Virginia will investigate to determine whether John A. Walker Jr. hid hundreds of thousands of dollars in espionage payments and whether others who have not been charged were involved in his Soviet spy ring, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Curb Urged on Japanese Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company's president, Harold Poling, called on Japan today to curb car exports to the United States to less than 2 million annually, from the current 2.3 million.

title: A NEW CHIEF SPOKESMAN FOR THE PRESIDENT: MAX MARLIN FITZWATER
description: When Marlin Fitzwater entered the White House press briefing room today for the announcement that he would become President Reagan's new chief spokesman, reporters broke into spontaneous applause.

title: Test Shows Students Master Basic Skills
description: Students know the basic skills, but falter in applying higher-order skills such as interpreting written passages and performing mathematical functions with fractions, the state education commissioner said yesterday in releasing results of the Connecticut Mastery Test.

title: SHULTZ RAISES HEROIN ISSUE IN NIGERIA
description: Heroin trafficking, American wheat imports, South Africa and Libyan moves in Chad were discussed today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Nigerian leaders after Mr. Shultz flew in for a quick round of talks in Africa's most populous country.

title: U.S. TRIES TO EASE ISRAELI ANNOYANCE ON IRAN DISCLOSURE
description: The United States has assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the White House's disclosure last week of documents describing Israel's role in the decision to sell arms to Iran was not intended as a criticism of Israel's actions, a White House official said today.

title: Night Trading Under Study
description: The Chicago Board of Trade may begin trading at night on several contracts during the next few months to attract business from the Far East.

title: Brooklyn Academy to Honor Gershwins
description: Mayor Koch paid tribute yesterday to the Brooklyn Academy of Music -one of the country's oldest performing arts centers - on its 125th anniversary.

title: CANADA OPENS MARKETS' DOORS
description: One of Canada's leading investment companies recently summoned electronics experts to its offices in a high-rise tower overlooking Lake Ontario and ordered anti-bugging devices installed on its top executives' telephones.

title: Dominick Labino, 76, Artist And Inventor of Glass Works
description: Dominick Labino, an artist whose works made of glass are shown in more than 100 museums, universities and public and private collections, died Saturday in his home at Grand Rapids, Ohio. He was 76 years old.

title: Social Security Tax Rule Wins
description: A Federal court yesterday upheld the law requiring Social Security recipients to include their income from municipal bond interest when calculating the tax they may owe on Social Security benefits. The ruling was issued in Manhattan by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: DEVILS END VICTORY DROUGHT
description: The Devils and Pat Verbeek shook off a lot of frustration and disappointment tonight, the Devils by posting their first victory in 11 games and Verbeek, the team's leading goal scorer, by scoring his first goal in 13 games.

title: The Vatican Shows a Schizophrenia About Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVOLVING IDEAL OF BEAUTY
description: ''I keep hearing they look like spun candy,'' Terrence Brown, director of the Society of Illustrators, said at last week's opening of ''The American Beauty,'' an exhibition of commercial depictions of women at the society's Museum of American Illustration (128 East 63d Street).

title: New Shearson Research Chief
description: Jack L. Rivkin has been named director of equity research at Shearson Lehman Brothers, the investment firm said yesterday.

title: Dynamics Fighters
description: The Government of Greece signed a contract for the purchase of 40 F-16 fighter planes from the General Dynamics Corporation. The first four aircraft, each costing $940 million, will be delivered in January 1989.

title: PARCELLS RECALLS EARLY DOUBTS
description: Giants fans might say they knew all the time that their heroes would get to the Super Bowl. So it may shock them to learn that Coach Bill Parcells was not one of them, that for a time he did not think his team could get where it is.

title: DENVER FANS ARE A MILE HIGH
description: ''This is an unbelievable feeling,'' said Coach Dan Reeves, whose Denver Broncos beat the Cleveland Browns Sunday, earning the right to represent the American Football Conference against the Giants in the Super Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on Jan. 25.

title: HEART UNITS CLOSED AT 4 HOSPITALS
description: The Veterans Administration today identified four of its hospitals, including two in the New York City area, where heart surgery is being halted because of concerns over death rates and quality of care.

title: Chess: Grandmaster Is Champion After 2 Playoffs in Britain
description: A playoff of a playoff gave Jonathan Speelman the British championship.

title: CIGARETTE SUIT RULING STANDS
description: The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court's ruling that shields cigarette manufacturers from liability for injuries or death caused by smoking in suits based on allegedly inadequate health warnings or improper advertising.

title: INSIDE
description: Dollar Resumes Fall The dollar lost more than 1 percent of its value against the German mark in heavy trading that followed a European currency realignment. Page D1. New Reagan Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, Vice President Bush's press secretary, will succeed Larry Speakes as President Reagan's principal spokesman. Page A16.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 28
description: The company said the latest 9-month figures include an after-tax gain of $1.2 million, or 3 cents a share, taken in the first quarter, from the sale of a manufactured housing facility.

title: The Background; Verdi's Political Chameleon
description: In 1848, when Verdi began his 14th opera, ''La Battaglia di Legnano,'' Europe was in the throes of political upheaval. In Italy, citizens of Milan drove out the occupying Austrian troops after five days of street fighting, and republican revolutionaries in other cities were overthrowing aristocratic or foreign rulers. In this atmosphere, Verdi's nationalistic fever came to a boil. He turned for a subject to a 12th-century legend of Italian heroism: the defeat of the Emperor Barbarossa by the armies of the Lombard League. By the time of the opera's premiere in Rome on Jan. 27, 1849, Milan was back in the hands of the Austrians, but Rome was still republican territory, and the premiere succeeded so well that the third act had to be repeated.

title: CONTINENTAL IS BUYING PRESIDENTIAL AIR'S GATES
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was aquiring all the gates and airport facilities of Presidential Airways.

title: Philadelphia Candidate
description: John Egan, a Republican stockbroker who was beaten in 1983 by W. Wilson Goode in his first try for Mayor, said today that he would run for his party's nomination again. Mr. Egan is the first candidate in the Republican field, which is expected to include the former Democratic Mayor, Frank Rizzo, who last month changed his party registration, and City Councilman Thacher Longstreth.

title: Councilman Guilty Of Cocaine Charges
description: A Manville Borough Councilman faces up to 15 years in prison after he pleaded guilty yesterday to possessing and distributing cocaine, the Somerset County Prosecutor said.

title: RICHARD K. SYKES
description: Richard K. Sykes, president of Dresner-Sykes Associates Inc., political campaign consultants with offices in Manhattan and San Diego, drowned Jan. 6 while exploring a tidal pool on Molokai Island in Hawaii. He was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan and Molokai.

title: IRAQ CLAIMS GAINS AGAINST IRAN PUSH
description: Iraq asserted tonight that it had driven Iran back from much of the border region it had overrun in its new offensive near the key southern Iraqi city of Basra, while Iran said its troops had withstood three counterattacks in ''pitched battles.''

title: The Giants: Theirs and Ours
description: It felt good watching the Giants crunch the Washington Redskins, 17 to 0, in Sunday's National Football Conference championship. Shades of the glory days of two decades ago, of Charley Conerly in Phil Simms, of Sam Huff in Lawrence Taylor, of Alex Webster in Joe Morris. Real pros these Giants, then and now, their victories workmanlike, not flashy. The pleasure is all the greater after years of frustration and ineptitude.

title: New Apple IIe Is Introduced
description: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced an updated version of the Apple IIe personal computer that has as features an expanded keyboard with a built-in numeric keypad, improved training materials and the company's new platinum color scheme.

title: KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings net was adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split, effected in the form of a 200-percent stock dividend, paid Sept. 10, 1986.

title: Flying Tiger Line Plans to Expand
description: In a significant expansion, Flying Tiger Line Inc. said it would increase its jet fleet by more than 18 percent and put 23 percent more pilots on its payroll. The move comes less than a month after the financially troubled Flying Tiger, the nation's oldest and largest scheduled air-cargo concern, was granted significant wage and benefit concessions by its unions and imposed similar cuts on its executive and administrative staff.

title: Drugs and the Contras
description: A member of the Senate committee investigating the Iran-Nicaragua arms affair says the panel will decide soon whether to take up reports that some Nicaragua insurgents involved themselves in the cocaine trade to help finance their war against the Sandinista government.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1987
description: International

title: People
description: * Mark D. Goldstein promoted to president of the Washington office of Earle Palmer Brown Inc., Bethesda, Md.

title: NUTRITION WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss The 1986 periods reflect results of the acquisition of Health Foods Inc.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Don't Think It's Easy to Become a Teacher in New York State
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FATAL SHORE. By Robert Hughes. 688 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. IN 1770, Capt. James Cook claimed possession of the eastern coast of Australia, which he and his men had been the first Europeans to sight, in the name of George III. The actual process of colonization began some 18 years later, when a fleet of 11 British ships sailed into what was soon to be called Sydney Harbor. On board, along with the crews, were 736 convicts (188 of them women) and the marines who had been sent to guard them.

title: Some Record Figures
description: Wade Boggs and the Boston Red Sox turned in record-tying and record-breaking numbers yesterday in submitting their numbers for salary arbitration. Boggs, who has filed for arbitration for the third successive year, went in at $1.85 million, the Red Sox at $1.6 million. The Red Sox figure is the highest ever submitted by a club, eclipsing the $1.35 million they submitted for Boggs last year. The Red Sox won at their figure. Boggs, the three-time American League batting champion, lost last year at the same figure he submitted yesterday, $1.85 million, the highest salary ever sought by a player in arbitration. Boggs's player figure likely will be surpassed when Don Mattingly of the Yankees files for arbitration. Mattingly, who had a cordial but unproductive meeting with George Steinbrenner last Thursday, is expected to try for a salary of at least $2 million in arbitration. Chris Codiroli, the Oakland right-hander, was the only player who filed for arbitration yesterday.

title: REAGAN GIVES KAMPELMAN ADDED STATE DEPT. POST
description: President Reagan today appointed Max M. Kampelman, the chief American negotiator at the Geneva arms talks, to serve as counselor of the State Department.

title: MAURICE VILLENCY, DESIGNER OF MODERN FURNITURE
description: Maurice Villency, a pioneer in the design of contemporary furniture whose signature served as the logo for his chain of stores in the New York metropolitan region, died Sunday morning of heart failure at his home in Brookville, L.I. He was 85 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Century Communications Corp., New Canaan, Conn., acquired the New Canaan, Conn., acquired the cable television system serving West Los Angeles from the consortium formed to purchase all of the former Group W Cable Inc. cable television properties for about $55 million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. DALLAS MAVERICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. BOSTON CELTICS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 11 P.M. tape delay; Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) PHILADELPHIA 76ERS VS. INDIANA PACERS, at Indianapolis, 8:05 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. PITTSBURGH PENGUINS, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel 8 P.M. Radio -WOR 710 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS AMERICA'S CUP: Challenger's final, second race, at Fremantle, Australia. (TV -ESPN, 11 P.M.) COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Texas at Texas A & M (TV -USA, 8 P.M.) St. Francis at Bucknell (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 10:30 P.M.) Syracuse at Boston College (Radio -WNYE 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) Army at Manhattan (Radio - WFAS 1230, 7:30 P.M.) Marist at L.I.U. (TV - Channel 25, 9 P.M., tape delay) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight)

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON MILITARY CONTRACTORS' LIABILITY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a conflict among Federal appeals courts on the liability of military contractors to military personnel injured or killed by defects in the contractors' products or services.

title: EX-AIDE SAID TO ALTER MEMO ON REAGAN ROLE IN IRAN SALES
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former White House national security adviser, took part in a plan last November to put the best face on President Reagan's role in the Iran-contra arms case, a source close to Mr. McFarlane said today.

title: Diet-Brand Promotion Set at Coke
description: IT is common knowledge among marketers of diet food and drink products that the post-holiday-pigout period is their best time of the year. Oh, yes, there is profit to be made from guilt.

title: STUNG BY CRITICS, CARDINAL SEEKS APOLOGY
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, still smarting from a sharply critical statement that Jewish leaders issued shortly before he arrived in New York from a trip to the Middle East, said yesterday that he felt he deserved an apology.

title: On the Way to Losing The Middle Class
description: SUMMIT is an upper-middle-class suburb of 21,000 people, popular among New York City executives. People here tend to vote Republican - there has not been a Democrat elected to the City Council in 60 years.

title: OPERA: 'SALOME' IN MILAN, STAGED BY ROBERT WILSON
description: Robert Wilson is best known for the conception, direction and design of his own visionary spectacles, from ''Deafman Glance'' to ''Einstein on the Beach'' to ''The Civil Wars.'' But now he is venturing into the staging of the classics. He had already done Marc-Antoine Charpentier's Baroque opera ''Medee'' in Lyons, and, just last month, Gluck's ''Alceste'' in Stuttgart. But Sunday night, he essayed his first mainstream opera in one of the world's leading opera houses -Richard Strauss's ''Salome'' at Milan's Teatro alla Scala.

title: ON PLATO, CAVES AND SPELUNKING
description: AS a writer, I am interested in word processors. And as a curmudgeon of the old school, I have yet to find a word-processing package that truly suits me. According to certain members of my family, in fact, the reason I periodically aspire to add geese to our farm menagerie is solely to assure myself of a steady supply of quill pens. Although this is the type of hyperbole with which our teen-agers frequently confront me - I just happen to like fresh goose on St. Martin's Day - I cannot deny that my writing is done on narrow-lined yellow paper, the last upgrade in my production style having occurred some 20 years ago when I gave up leaky fountain pens for smeary ballpoints.

title: INSPIRED 'BUTTERFLIES ARE FREE'
description: Harold Eliot Krents, whose struggle to overcome blindness and become independent was the inspiration for the Broadway play ''Butterflies Are Free,'' died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Calvary Hospital Hospice in the Bronx. He was 42 years old and lived in Washington.

title: ARRESTS PLANNED IN HOTEL FIRE
description: Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon said today that the investigation into the fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel had reached ''the final stage'' and that one or more suspects would be arrested ''very, very soon.''

title: OPERA: 'LA BATTAGLIA'
description: ''LA BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO'' is one of several Verdi operas whose action, though set in remote times, sent patriotic juices surging through the veins of his countrymen in the 19th century, when Italy was a jumble of warring city-states. Although rarely revived, it is not an inconsequential work, a fact that could be glimpsed last night in the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

title: BEYOND THE SKIPPERS, TALENTED TEAMS BRING SMOOTH SAILING: IT'S NOT ALL GLAMOUR IN A WINNING EFFORT
description: On the way out to racing one day, the crews on Dennis Conner's first and second-string boats noticed a group of schoolgirls hailing from shore.

title: Quick Work
description: Computer and laser-beam technology can significantly speed the process of archeological field work, according to an anthropologist at the University of Pennsylvania. The anthropologist, Dr. Harold L. Dibble, an assistant professor of anthropology, has adapted the traditional surveyor's tool, a theodolite, with a laser-beam measuring device to locate artifacts. He has written a program to record and compile their locations.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: LORAL TO ACQUIRE GOODYEAR DIVISION
description: After several failed efforts to expand its military electronics business, the Loral Corporation has catapulted itself into one of the biggest companies in the field.

title: Judge Refuses Request By Ayer in Army Case
description: A Federal judge in Washington last evening refused to grant the N.W. Ayer agency a temporary restraining order to prevent the Army from announcing the winner of the competition for its $100 million account, from which it had suspended Ayer, the incumbent agency.

title: TOWN RESISTS BEARER OF BAD NEWS
description: This is the town of McCormick in the county of McCormick. It is a poor place, ingrown for decades, but it is the place that an editor, Ken Fortenberry, and his family decided to make their home.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share data do not reflect the 3-for-2 stock split declared in December and to be distributed Jan. 15, 1987. Shares outstanding reflect the March 3, 1986, conversion of Series A convertible preferred stock and the August 27, 1986, conversion of 9.50 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Business and the Law; Board Liability In Delaware
description: LAST June, the state of Delaware - home to most of the nation's largest companies - passed a law allowing corporations to limit, or even eliminate, their directors' financial liability for some kinds of mistakes. Under the Delaware law, shareholders can vote to eliminate the directors' liability, except in cases of disloyalty, bad faith or intentional misconduct.

title: GREYHOUND TO BUY G.M. UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its North American transit-bus manufacturing operations to the Greyhound Corporation for an undisclosed price.

title: SUMMIT BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: THERAPISTS SEEK CAUSES OF CHILD MOLESTING
description: WHILE courts and communities confront allegations of sexual abuse of children in schools and day care centers around the country, researchers and therapists are struggling to understand what causes child molestation and devise better treatment.

title: A Need for Sprinklers
description: To the Editor:

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Doctors' Fees, Doctored
description: One triumph of the Reagan Administration has been its firm, fair control of hospital costs for the $64 billion Medicare program. Now it wants to impose similar discipline on individual doctors. Yet the method Congress has put in place is neither firm nor fair. Just how complicated and confusing is known mainly to readers of physicians' newsletters. While the goal is worthy, all parties now need to get together on a sounder way to achieve it.

title: Fox Broadcasting Assigned to Chiat/Day
description: The Los Angeles office of Chiat/ Day has officially been assigned Rupert Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting Company, which is supposed to reach a $20 million billing level. Six agencies had competed for the account.

title: AIDS VICTIM TO BE ALLOWED TO WED AT ST. PATRICK'S
description: Maria and David Hefner, a couple married in a civil ceremony who had been denied a Roman Catholic wedding at St. Patrick's Cathedral because Mr. Hefner is dying of AIDS, will be able to exchange their vows at the Cathedral after all.

title: COUNCIL WITNESSES DEBATE TOUGHER ANTI-SMOKING REGULATIONS
description: Emphysema reduced Kathryn Kennedy's voice to a barely audible whisper, but it commanded the attention of the audience when she testified yesterday on proposals to limit smoking in New York City.

title: Ferment in Iowa
description: With the key Iowa Presidential caucuses a little over a year away, the Iowa Democrats are in the throes of choosing a new party chairman. The 30-member state central committee meets Saturday to pick a successor to A. Arthur Davis, who has announced he will not seek re-election.

title: MYERSON AND CITY AIDES MEET
description: The city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson, met for almost 2 1/2 hours yesterday with two of Mayor Koch's top advisers to discuss her having invoked the Fifth Amendment before a grand jury investigating a city contractor.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of investments of $4.2 million for the quarter; and for the year includes capital gains of $17.2 million and income of $16.5 million from Argonaut Group, and net before capital gains and Argonaut is $204.6 million, or $17.48 a share. c-Includes for the quarter a gain of $30.8 million on the sale of investments and income of $22.4 million from Argonaut Group, which was spun off at the end of the third quarter of 1986; and for the year includes capital gains of $173.7 million, income of $64.2 million from Argonaut and income of $81.7 million from a Litton Industries distribution, and net before capital gains, Argonaut and Litton Industries distribution is $226.8 million, or $19.36 a share.

title: TEST TRAIN STOPS IN ENOUGH TIME TO AVOID CRASH
description: Three speed tests conducted today indicated that a Conrail engineer could have been able to avoid a collision with an Amtrak train last week even if he never saw a disputed track signal.

title: CONFUSION ON ISRAELI ROLE
description: Recent disclosures of policy memorandums by the White House and the Senate Intelligence Committee seem to suggest that Israel somehow led the Reagan Administration into the Iran affair by repeatedly promising, on the basis of Iranian-Israeli contacts, that with one sale of arms to Teheran all the American hostages in Lebanon would be released.

title: Pakistani Police Wound 25 In Crowd Protesting Murders
description: The police wounded 25 people today when they opened fire on demonstrators protesting the murder of a man and his two daughters, witnesses said. Rioters burned down scores of houses and shops, and army troops were called out.

title: NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that fourth-quarter results reflect extraordinary expense items of $630,000 which are applicable to future periods as well as fiscal year 1986.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said results for the 1985 full-year include a gain of $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share on the sale of property.

title: EXCERPTS OF MESSAGE TO LEGISLATURE BY KEAN
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's annual State of the State Message to the Legislature, released today. The Governor will deliver a speech, based on his 95-page message, to the Senate and Assembly on Tuesday.

title: PRE-SUPER BOWL SCRIMMAGE: SO WHOSE GIANTS ARE THEY?
description: Consider, if you will, rooting for the Metropolitan Area Giants.

title: NEW ENTRIES IN THE LOW-COST ARENA
description: WHILE the rest of the world awaited more rumors about new computers from Apple and I.B.M., two home-computer makers were busy announcing new products last week at the winter Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Several people who tried to wedge their way into the crowded Atari and Commodore booths said that if crowd size was any indication, the home-computer market is primed for a resurgence in 1987.

title: CHRISTIE'S TRIAL OPENS IN A MANHATTAN COURT
description: A trial began today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in which Christie's, the auction house, is being sued for breach of contract in failing to sell eight Impressionist paintings that it had told a client could bring more than $10 million at auction.

title: New Hitch Added In Baseball Dispute
description: Baseball has an ongoing dispute in which players charge owners with conspiracy in dealing with free agents, and now the players and the clubs have developed a dispute within their dispute.

title: EXPECT SOFT SALES IN '87, EXPERTS TELL RETAILERS
description: Retail sales will be soft in the first half of this year and perhaps for the entire year, with no significant improvement until 1988, economists predicted yesterday at the opening convention sessions of the National Retail Merchants Association.

title: Designing the Forms Everyone Loves to Hate
description: Anyone who has struggled with the Internal Revenue Service's new four-page W-4 withholding form brought on by the recently enacted Tax Reform Act can only be fearing the worst about what it will be like next year to file a return under the new law.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer

title: Reagan's Drug Policy: a Bust
description: President Reagan's proposal to reduce drastically Federal anti-drug funding in fiscal 1988 and 1989 proves he never really believed in his own drug abuse policies.

title: CAREMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN IS SAID TO SEEK BILLS TO EASE TRADE GAP
description: President Reagan will soon ask Congress for changes in antitrust laws, restraints on imports of counterfeit goods and a $200 million war chest to help American companies sell goods abroad, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: BYRD HINTS AT EARNINGS CURB
description: The Senate majority leader said today that he might propose new restrictions on senators' outside earnings as part of a plan to allow a Congressional pay increase to take effect.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: PITY poor fashion models: despite the gobs of money they earn, they get precious little respect. But the disrespect is delicious in ''Dial M for Model,'' John Epperson's satirical musical dressed in 60's styles. It is on view at Pyramid (101 Avenue A), the downtown area's most consistently different nightclub.

title: YOUTH IN GOETZ SHOOTING IS DENIED STATE VICTIM AID
description: The state agency that administers New York's crime victims law has ruled that one of the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in 1984 is ineligible for state aid because ''it appears'' he was ''in the process of robbing'' Mr. Goetz when the shooting occurred.

title: Financial Director Quits Guinness Amid Inquiry
description: The management turmoil at Guinness P.L.C. continued yesterday with the resignation of the brewer's 36-year-old director of financial strategy and development, Olivier Roux.

title: Spermicide Shown to Kill AIDS Virus
description: Tests have shown that a widely used contraceptive substance is capable of killing the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a researcher at France's Pasteur Institute said today.

title: SORG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1987
description: Markets

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Davis Advances in Australia: California-born Scott Davis, who once ranked as high as 11th in the world, struggled for 3 hours 25 minutes yesterday before defeating Peter McNamara of Australia, 7-6, 6-4, 2-6, 3-6, 6-4, to advance to the second round of the Australian Open. Davis, now rated 39th on the A.T.P. computer, credited his Australian coach, Bob Brett, with giving him the fitness to rally against McNamara, who led, 3-0, in the final set at Kooyong.(AP) Horse Racing Spring Beauty Wins at Aqueduct: Spring Beauty stalked the front-running Nasherrico into the stretch, passed him there and went on to carry 117 pounds under E. T. Baird to a 4 1/4-length victory in Aqueduct's $40,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 4 years old and up. Nasherrico held on to finish second, two lengths ahead of Teriyaki Stake. Spring Beauty, a 4-year-old daughter of Full Pocket-Necessity earned $24,000 for Glencrest Farm with her third straight victory and her sixth in 16 career starts. She went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 and returned $4.40 for $2 to win as the favorite. N.B.A. Hawks 125, Clippers 115: In Atlanta, Dominique Wilkins celebrated his 27th birthday last night by scoring 53 points as the Hawks handed the Clippers their 16th straight defeat. Early in the third period, a layup by the Clippers' Michael Cage narrowed Atlanta's margin to 65-64, and the game remained close until the final quarter.(AP) Bullets 113, Kings 109: Moses Malone scored 41 points, including four free throws in the final 19 seconds, as the Bullets held off a Sacramento rally and defeated the Kings in Landover, Md. Malone made his first two free throws after the Kings had pulled to 109-107 on a 4-point streak, missing two free throws during that stretch. Malone also grabbed 20 rebounds.(AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 2, Maple Leafs 1: Sergio Momesso scored the winning goal early in the third period and the Montreal goaltender, Brian Hayward, stopped 30 shots as the Canadiens beat Toronto. Momesso, who had missed several scoring chances, was in full stride when a rebound of a Bobby Smith shot hit his chest and the puck rolled into the Toronto net for his seventh goal at 6:45. (AP) North Stars 4, Blues 4: Cliff Ronning, playing in only his fourth regular-season N.H.L. game, scored three goals within a 9:52 span of the second and third periods, sparking the St. Louis Blues to a tie with North Stars at home. The deadlock moved the North Stars into first place in the Norris Division.(AP)

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net income The company said the 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding for the prior year periods have been restated to reflect the 15-percent stock dividend paid in June of 1986. Corrected from Saturday, Jan. 10th, editions.

title: DOLE SEEKS TO ADD TO STRATEGY TEAM
description: Senator Bob Dole has asked the man who was dismissed as Ronald Reagan's strategist in 1980 to play a major role in his Presidential campaign, a move that has disturbed some conservatives.

title: Black Extremists and Howard Beach
description: The one good thing to come of the tragic beating in Howard Beach last month was the hope it raised of rejuvenating a multiracial civil rights movement in New York City. But that hope is already vanishing, ruined by black extremists determined to exploit racial polarization rather than join forces with decent whites committed to a racially integrated city.

title: Coke Unit Joins In TV Colorization
description: Coca-Cola Telecommunications Inc. said it had joined with a unit of Color Systems Technology Inc. to convert black and white filmed material into color. Herman Rush, chairman of the Coca-Cola unit, said the venture would focus mainly on colorizing some of unit's library of vintage television series, including ''Ivanhoe'' with Roger Moore, ''The Real McCoys'' and ''Wyatt Earp.''

title: Denver Fans Glued to TV
description: A remarkable 88 percent of Denver television viewers were watching their Broncos on Sunday, the ''overnight'' ratings disclosed yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q.When my grandfather was young his eyes were dark brown, but now that he's old, they are hazel. Is it possible for eye color to change with age? A.The color of the iris does not change with age, but the pupil, the apparently black hole at the center of the iris, may shrink with age causing the iris to appear lighter in color, according to Dr. Richard Thoft, chairman of the department of opthamology at the University of Pittsburgh. For example, Dr. Thoft said that bright blue eyes may slowly turn lighter as a person ages. Q.What causes plagues of locusts? A. Locusts, short-horned grasshoppers from the family Acrididae, have two phases: solitary and migratory. In the more normal solitary phase, the insects are sluggish and do not congregate much. Their color matches that of their surroundings. But in the migratory phase, locusts are much more gregarious, congregating in large, active groups. Their color changes to black and yellow. The locusts may eventually form large swarms of millions of insects and migrate to new areas where they can cause considerable damage. Although the reason locusts migrate is not clear, scientists believe that the availability of food and crowding are important factors.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said that the lower earnings were due primarily to loss of the investment tax credit, which resulted in a 4 cents a share charge for the quarter, compared with a credit of 2 cents in the year-ago first quarter.

title: DYSLEXIA'S CAUSE IS REPORTEDLY FOUND
description: MANY factors have been offered to explain the reading disorder dyslexia, among them impaired vision, head injuries, inner-ear disorders and even laziness.

title: DEBUT OF 'MORNING PROGRAM' ON CBS
description: HOW do you like your morning television? Who's for intimate and jolly? ''The Morning Program'' yearns to be loved; Mariette Hartley, Rolland Smith and the gang want to be members of the family. Maybe they will be in time, but yesterday they were self-conscious. It wasn't just that they were meeting us for the first time; they also seemed to be meeting one another. They worked too hard at having a swell time.

title: WEINBERGER GIVES STRATEGY OUTLINE ON MISSILE SHIELD
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today endorsed the deployment of an initial defense against nuclear missiles, provided that it served as a cornerstone for a nationwide shield.

title: OMAHA MAYOR BATTLING ON EVE OF A RECALL VOTE
description: Tall and ruddy-faced, looking nothing like a man who had fought for his life after a severe heart attack two years ago, Mayor Michael Boyle was up at dawn today and out on the streets by 7:30, shaking hands and slapping backs.

title: Ex-Chief of Macmillan Joins Simon & Schuster
description: Jeremiah Kaplan, who retired last month as chairman and chief executive of the Macmillan Publishing Company, has joined Simon & Schuster.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected August 1986.

title: Arms Control Ideas
description: Excerpts from remarks by Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser in the Carter Administration, prepared for delivery today before a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing:

title: The Vatican Shows a Schizophrenia About Jews; Palestinian Hostages
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No just society can deny the right of its citizens to the health care they need. We are the only industrial society that does.'' - Joseph A. Califano, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. [ B7:1. ]

title: A BUYOUT OF SCHWAB IS SEEN
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has tentatively agreed to sell its Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage unit to a group headed by the unit's chairman, Charles R. Schwab, industry sources said today.

title: BEYOND THE SKIPPERS, TALENTED TEAMS BRING SMOOTH SAILING: AMID THE PRIDE, SOME MISGIVINGS
description: The inky black tower that houses the Bank of New Zealand is Wellington's version of the World Trade Center. At Christmastime, a mammoth snowflake of tiny white lights twinkles into the night on all four sides.

title: GEORGETOWN HOLDS OFF VILLANOVA, 80-73
description: Reggie Williams scored 20 points tonight as Georgetown built a 21-point lead midway through the second half and survived a Villanova rally for an 80-73 Big East victory.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.N. REPORT LINKS DRUGS, ARMS TRAFFIC AND TERROR
description: Illegal drug production and trafficking are closely linked to the illegal arms trade and international terrorism, according to a United Nations report made public today.

title: NETWORKS SCORE BIG IN N.F.L. PLAYOFFS
description: From frigid Cleveland to the windy Meadowlands, from Bob Costas's hello on NBC at noon to Brent Musburger's goodbye on CBS at 7:30 P.M., Sunday was Football. It was also another one of those days when television sports deserves our attention and gratitude.

title: SCIENTISTS TRANSPLANT GRAIN GENES
description: SCIENTISTS have succeeded in using genetic engineering techniques to transplant foreign genes into cells of maize and have grown rice plants from modified single cells.

title: Hope From A Scholar
description: Fellow academics have called her ''a living legend,'' one of the founders and a key developer of African studies in the U.S. At her 80th birthday party last year, Dr. Gwendolen Carter said she was greatly relieved that ''no one suggested I should resign or give up anything. That would have annoyed me very much.''

title: After the Contras Are Gone
description: By all accounts, the contras and their sponsors in the State Department are trying desperately to make some headway in their war before the question of United States support for the insurgency comes up again in Congress. Nevertheless, it is not too soon to look ahead to the post-contra era that now seems in sight.

title: DANCE: FOLK PERFORMERS OF HUNGARY, IN BRONX
description: THE Hungarian State Folk Ensemble is not still another folk group. It is marvelous -crackling with dancing that snaps like a whip in a program framed successfully by a sophisticated context.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUTHERN EXPOSURE Glover is a town in the northeast corner of Vermont along Route 91, some 20 miles south of the Canadian border. Glover boasts a population of 846 and a Bread and Puppet Theater. In the late 1970's some students who took part in Bread and Puppet activities formed the only dance-theater company in the area, the Expanding Secret Company. Now the company, which has been performing in Vermont for six years, has brought 16 members to New York.

title: BRUINS DOMINATE RANGERS
description: It should be called the Boston Garden price, and if one is a hockey player on an opposition team, he should be prepared to pay it upon entrance. This comes as no surprise to the Rangers, for they have been here before and come away battered and injured. But they still seem unwilling to meet the harsh terms of winning here - checking and checking hard.

title: Careers; R.& D. In Service Economy
description: THE nation's shift toward a service economy has resulted in more studies and surveys on the trend's impact on employment.

title: MAN MAY THREATEN EAGLE'S WINTER HABITAT
description: UNDER a half moon rising in a winter sky, two bald eagles float on a current of air forced out of the North Cascades. While they look for salmon in a gravel bar of the icy Skagit River, tourists look at them.

title: Change of Tone
description: Denise Berry had become accustomed in November and December to receiving early morning telephone calls from her son, Walter, who was playing professional basketball as a rookie for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Giants' playoff victory over the Redskins and a related article on the first page of SportsMonday misreported the results of the coin flip before the game. The Redskins' captain called tails and the coin landed heads.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A dispatch yesterday from Baton Rouge, La., about the trial of three men accused of killing a Government witness against drug smugglers, misstated the date of the killing. It was Feb. 19, 1986.

title: DOLLAR FALLS 1% FURTHER VS. MARK
description: The dollar fell to a new six-year low against the West German mark in heavy trading on world currency markets yesterday, one day after European finance ministers acted to relieve tensions within the European Monetary System.

title: Coaches Reported Out
description: Coach Vladimir Vasiliev of the Soviet Union junior hockey team and his assistant, Valentin Gurayev, have been dismissed, according to a report in yesterday's issue of The Toronto Globe and Mail. The Soviet Union and Team Canada were disqualified from the world junior championships Jan. 4 after the two sides participated in a bench-clearing brawl that resulted in the match being called off. The disqualification cost Canada a chance at the gold medal. The Soviet team was in sixth place going into the game -its worst-ever showing at the tournament. The report out of Moscow said the decision was made by Soviet hockey authorities at a weekend meeting and would be announced later this week. The dismissal of Vasiliev and Gurayev was more the result of the team's poor showing at the tournament than the brawl, the report said.

title: REBECCA H. REYHER
description: Rebecca Hourwich Reyher, a veteran suffragist, author and lecturer, died of pnuemonia last Saturday at the home of her daughter, Faith Jackson, in St. Inigoes, Md. Mrs. Reyher was 89 years old.

title: ANGRY OUTBURST BY SPECTATORS DISRUPTS START OF BUMPURS TRIAL
description: The nonjury trial of a police officer who fatally shot an elderly woman during an eviction began yesterday in the Bronx, with spectators interrupting a defense lawyer's opening statements when he said the family of the woman shared responsibility for her death.

title: Drew Pleads Guilty
description: John Drew, a former Atlanta Hawks' forward who had been scheduled to go on trial yesterday on drug charges, instead pleaded guilty to selling and possessing cocaine. Under a negotiated plea, Drew was sentenced to six months in the Fulton County, Ga., jail. He already has served three months since his arrest Oct. 3. The 32-year-old Drew also was sentenced to five years probation.

title: A.M.C. to Rebuild Plant in Wisconsin
description: The American Motors Corporation announced plans to renovate its aging Kenosha auto plant and to begin manufacturing a new Jeep in 1989.

title: Dreaming In Pretoria
description: South Africa - it is like one of those dreams we all have. The kind where you see something bad about to happen, know exactly what will unfold, cry out in warning but know nobody is listening or will hear.

title: On the PAC Front
description: A year ago, the Federal Election Commission reported that the number of political action committees making special interest contributions to candidates had actually decreased, from 4,009 at the end of 1984 to 3,992, the first time this politically popular activity had ever experienced a decline.

title: CHINA OUSTS UNIVERSITY SCIENTIST WHO ADVOCATED BROADER RIGHTS
description: A Chinese scientist who became a hero among thousands of students who demonstrated for greater democracy over the last month was dismissed today as the Communist Party moved to reassert control over intellectuals with unacceptable views.

title: BRYANT PARK PROJECT APPROVED
description: An extensive renovation of Bryant Park was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Art Commission. Afterward, the head of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation said construction might begin as early as spring.

title: FELONY CHARGES FILED AGAINST GOODEN
description: The Hillsborough County state attorney today filed two third-degree felony charges against Dwight Gooden, the Mets' pitching star who was involved in a Dec. 13 scuffle with Tampa police that the prosecutor pledged would be dealt with in ''a very stern fashion.''

title: E.D.S. Acquisition
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said that it had acquired Societe Pour L'Informatique, a French computer services company, for an undisclosed amount. The purchase of the subsidiary of Pechiney added 600 employees to the 230 workers at E.D.S. International S.A., the French operating unit of the Dallas-based concern. E.D.S., founded by H. Ross Perot, is owned by the General Motors Corporation.

title: What to Take With the Fifth
description: No matter why Bess Myerson, Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, took the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury last month, she should have told her boss before he saw it on the evening news. The Mayor lacks the right to dismiss employees for invoking their privilege against self-incrimination, but he is entitled to know when they have done so. Ms. Myerson owes the Mayor and the public some explanation. Good taste and good judgment further require that she step aside from her official position while the investigations proceed.

title: SENATOR SAYS REAGAN MUST FACE 'MISTAKE' ON IRAN
description: The top Republican on the Senate intelligence committee asserted today that President Reagan could not ''escape responsibility'' for his Administration's ''mistake'' in selling arms to Iran and using the profits to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $3,572,000, or 10 cents a share, from accounting for leveraged leases brought about by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Share earnings for 1985 have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 common stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend distributed on Aug. 5, 1986.

title: Out of Their League
description: President Reagan's underground attempt to outwit the Middle East at its own game ought to remind us of Nelson Algren's famous rules for survival, the two most famous of which are (1) never eat at a place called Mom's and (2) never play poker with a man named Doc.

title: FARSIGHTED PROSECUTOR: CHARLES J. HYNES
description: Even before he was named to investigate the Dec. 20 Howard Beach racial attack, Charles J. Hynes was preparing for the job.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates were mixed at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. The average rate for $50 million of 91-day commercial paper was 5.812 percent, down from 5.915 percent last week and the lowest since Nov. 25, when the average was 5.801 percent. Citicorp also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 5.798 percent, up from 5.777 percent last week.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Baker Will Visit Riyadh
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will visit Saudi Arabia Feb. 3-4 for a meeting of the United States-Saudi Arabian Joint Commission on Economic Cooperation, the Treasury Department said today. Mr. Baker will meet in Riyadh with Mohammed ter, and other Saudi Government officials.

title: AT ISSUE IS HER USE OF 5TH AMENDMENT
description: Bess Myerson, New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, announced yesterday that she would step aside from her city post for up to 90 days, pending a special city investigation of issues stemming from a grand jury inquiry into a city contractor who is Ms. Myerson's friend.

title: RESORT FIRE IS TERMED ARSON
description: A smoky fire damaged a showroom today at a resort hotel beset by labor problems, and investigators said it was arson.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 1 about the closing of International Marketnet, a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company, incorrectly described the status of Trintex, a joint venture formed by I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company to develop a new videotex service. While CBS Inc. withdrew from the project last year, Trintex executives say that the service is on schedule and that they plan to offer it to consumers in 1988.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE popularity of various foods, it seems to me, sometimes rests on the lure of their names. Catfish, for example, one of the most American of fish, immediately calls forth delectable possibilities. Food experts heartily list and promote its delightful qualities. The name monkfish, on the other hand, does not readily entice, and it has only recently caught on at American restaurants and in homes.

title: LINEAR TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $592,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,089,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's an insane tragedy that 700,000 people get a diploma each year and can't read the damned diploma.'' - Secretary of Labor

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Investment securities gains totaled $3,702,000 for the latest fourth quarter, compared to $24,000 for the year-ago period, and investment securities gains for the latest year totaled $7,890,000, against $8,762,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: BITTER DAYS FOR JAPAN'S UNIONS
description: It was an unusual scene in a country famous for harmonious labor relations: hundreds of union members shouting at each other and finally throwing punches as they debated whether to go along with a Government plan to privatize the national railways.

title: HEAVY COMBAT IN GULF WAR: FIVE-DAY BATTLE STILL IN DOUBT
description: The five-day-old Iranian attack against the Iraqi defenses along the Shatt al Arab waterway south of the strategic city of Basra appears to be losing momentum in the face of fierce Iraqi artillery bombardments and air strikes.

title: JUDGE WEIGHS IMMUNITY FOR EX-PROSECUTOR IN CHILD SEX CASE
description: The first steps were taken today to grant immunity to a former prosecutor who threw the McMartin Preschool molestation case into turmoil when he asserted that the defendants were not guilty.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHETHER you resemble Charles Atlas or the prototypical 97-pound weakling at the beach, your body is a mass of voluntary muscles that enable you to move about, lift and carry, sit and stand and otherwise go through the motions of daily living. Every muscle has the ability to contract and relax, expand and shrink.

title: H. R. Wei Dead at 87; Physicist and Diplomat
description: Dr. H. R. Wei, an educator, author, nuclear physicist and former adviser to the Republic of China Mission to the United Nations, died Jan. 2 in Honolulu.

title: SONY'S VIDEO FORMAT BATTLE
description: THE Sony Corporation, which suffered a costly strategic defeat when its Beta format failed to become the standard in video cassette recorders, is in for another long, expensive and perhaps lonely fight over a video format. Once again, this time under the banner of 8-millimeter hand-held video cameras, Sony is challenging the dominant VHS technology being marketed by almost all of its rivals.

title: Alfred Y. Allee Is Dead at 81; Ex-Captain of Texas Rangers
description: Alfred Y. Allee, a former Texas Ranger who gained national attention fighting political bosses and breaking up farmworker strikes in south Texas, died of cancer Monday. He was 81 years old.

title: Turmoil and Immigrant Visas
description: State Department offices are passing the word these days about the high-level official in the Irish postal service who called the high-level official in the United States Postal Service begging to work out a deal.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago third quarter includes a pretax writedown of $2.5 million from the operations of its Sakowitz unit.

title: Enron Sees Charge
description: The Enron Corporation said that for the fourth quarter it expected to take a number of nonrecurring charges against earnings that would virtually offset a gain of $123 million from the sale of its petrochemical unit. The company said the charges included employee relocation and severance costs, building-lease obligations and write-downs in the value of assets. Enron had previously announced that it would charge off the $20 million premium paid in October to repurchase 7.6 million shares, or a 16.5 percent stake, in the company that were held by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs and the Leucadia National Corporation of New York. The gain had previously been estimated at only $90 million.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPEREL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company said that the apparel segment, represented by Cluett Peabody & Co., added $2.9 million to net income. Cluett Peabody added $193 million to sales and that its contribution to net income for the quarter came mainly from the shirt and hosiery group.

title: BankAmerica Step Reported
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has approached Japanese banks about investing in the troubled San Francisco banking company, the Japanese press reported today.

title: Ernest O. Melby, 95, An Education Dean At N.Y.U. 11 Years
description: Ernest O. Melby, a former dean at New York University and a former president of Montana State University, died Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he had lived for the last six years. He was 95 years old.

title: UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR SMALL UNITS
description: THE photocopying business is getting personal. Several companies have recently introduced hand-held devices that slip easily into a briefcase and can copy narrow strips of text.

title: GLOVES COME OFF AS SAILS GO UP
description: The recent run of shoreside friendliness between the two syndicates seeking the right to defend the America's Cup belies a more immediate concern: how to win on the water.

title: Israelis Raid Lebanon; 4th Attack in 10 Days
description: Israeli warplanes attacked Palestinian targets near the Syrian border today in the fourth raid on Lebanon in 10 days.

title: PILOT CHARGED IN SLAYING OF WIFE
description: A 49-year-old airline pilot was charged with murder today after the state police and forensic experts said they had found parts of his wife's body near a lake close to their home in suburban Newtown in northern Fairfield County.

title: KUWAIT CUTS KEY RATE
description: Kuwait cut one of its key interest rates by half a point today in a widely expected move to bring them more in line with rates in the United States. The central bank reduced its intervention rate in the domestic money market to 6.5 percent.

title: WHO ARE THE POWERS BEHIND OFF BROADWAY?
description: When Alan J. Schuster learned that Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' one of the most acclaimed plays of the fall season, had completed its limited run uptown without being picked up by a commercial producer, he put in an urgent call for the script.

title: Problem at Home
description: After playing all 26 games on the road during its first season of basketball a year ago, Wassuk College of Ely, Nev., opened with 16 more games away from home this season. Although it has no gym of its own, the team was scheduled Monday night to finally play before local fans in a game against Mesa College of Grand Junction, Colo.

title: Music Noted in Brief; TV's Bruce Willis In Singing Mode
description: An amateur singer sold out the Ritz Saturday night, opening an onslaught of hype. Bruce Willis, who plays the unregenerate male chauvinist-smoothie in the ''Moonlighting'' television show, is the latest celebrity to try rock singing; an album and a cable-television special are on the way. The concert was helped along considerably by guest appearances from Ben E. King, June Pointer and (as an organist) Billy Joel.

title: MEXICO'S LARGEST UNIVERSITY EMBROILED IN FEES CONTROVERSY
description: For the last week, an unusual series of discussions has been taking place at the National Autonomous University. Student leaders and university officials have been meeting in an effort to overcome an impasse over the university's plans to increase fees and strengthen academic standards.

title: Bridge: Play in Tri-State Regional Is Starting in Port Chester
description: For players in the New York metropolitan area, the 1987 tournament year begins today at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Flying Tiger's Counsel Is Unruffled by Turmoil
description: As general counsel of Flying Tiger Line Inc., Lawrence M. Nagin has had few chances recently to ruminate about the fortunes of the air cargo industry. Flying Tiger, the world's largest air cargo carrier, narrowly avoided liquidation a few weeks ago by negotiating substantial wage concessions from its pilots and announcing a major cost-cutting program.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PAST CARING. By Robert Goddard. 501 pages. St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. BULLETS, at Landover. Md., 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) COLLEGE: Brooklyn vs. St. John's, at Alumni Hall, Jamaica, Queens, 8P.M. (TV - MSG, 8 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Seton Hall vs. Pitt, at Byrne Meadlowlands Arena, 9 P.M. (TV - MSG, 10 P.M., tape delay. Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 8:30 P.M.); Iona vs. South Carolina, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena (Radio - WRTN-FM 93.5, 6:55 P.M.) Western Kentucky at Jacksonville (TV -ESPN, 7 P.M.); North Carolina at Virginia (TV - ESPN, 9 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, at Palm Desert, Calif.

title: Chip Index Posts Gain
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed its strongest rebound yet, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported increases in both orders and shipments, a trade group reported today.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
4,000 PAUSE TO MOURN POLICE HERO
description: Four thousand police officers and firefighters lined Fifth Avenue yesterday for four blocks for the funeral of Officer Francis J. La Sala, who died Saturday from injuries suffered while helping to rescue a dozen people from a burning building.

title: MARINE SPY SUSPECT REPORTED LURED BY A RUSSIAN WOMAN
description: A Marine Corps guard arrested last month as a suspected spy by the American authorities in Vienna was lured to work for Soviet intelligence by a Russian woman employed by the American Embassy in Moscow, a State Department official said today.

title: Airbus Joins Lease Venture
description: Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft-building consortium, said it had formed a leasing operation with Ireland's Guinness Peat Aviation and that the venture was ordering $2 billion worth of Airbus jetliners.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jean-Claude Killy, the skier who won three gold medals in Grenoble in pics were held in France, has agreed to become president of the organizing committee for the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville. . . . Herman Cohen, the 92-year-old former owner of Pimlico, has been named winner of the 1986 Eclipse Award of Merit in recognition of his 34 years as president of the Maryland Jockey Club. . . . Bob Probert, the 21-year-old forward for the Detroit Red Wings who was arrested after crashing his car in Windsor, Ontario, late last year, has pleaded guilty to impaired driving and has been fined $1,100, as well as having his driver's license suspended for a year. He is also required to continue treatment for alcoholism.

title: Arms and the Mail
description: Intervention by Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, has persuaded the Postal Service to cancel a plan to allow delivery of ammunition through the mail. Sweeping changes in the nation's gun control laws adopted by the last Congress allowed gun owners to order ammunition by mail, beginning last Nov. 15, for the first time since 1968. That was when Congress banned mail-order sales of guns and ammunition after the assassinations of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Despite Congressional legalization of ordering by mail, postal regulations continued to prohibit delivery of ammunition and other explosives by mail, limiting dealers to commercial parcel services. So, seeking a new area for competition, the Postal Service recently proposed a change in regulations that would have allowed delivery through the mail of up to 65 pounds of ammunition for small arms, rifles and shotguns.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
FINDING ON RADIOACTIVITY MAY UPSET PHYSICS LAW
description: Experiments conducted deep in a South Dakota gold mine have reportedly produced evidence for an extremely rare form of radioactive decay whose existence, if proved, would overthrow one of the basic laws of physics.

title: People
description: * Cyril Penn and Harvey Kipnis have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey.

title: Market Place; Beneficiaries Of Stock Surge
description: LARGE-CAPITALIZATION issues - drugs, papers and oils, among others - figure prominently on the expanding list of stocks scoring new 52-week highs on the New York Stock Exchange. But the market's broad advance also saw new highs set last week by components of the long-depressed oil-service industry, as well as by stocks in such ''niche'' sectors as check printers, funeral-related businesses and New Jersey home builders.

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE KEAN'S WARNING ABOUT STATE AID
description: A warning by Governor Kean in his State of the State Address that the cities must stop looking to the state budget for help drew loud and unanimous criticism today from the urban mayors.

title: The Right Minimum Wage: $0.00
description: The Federal minimum wage has been frozen at $3.35 an hour for six years. In some states, it now compares unfavorably even with welfare benefits available without working. It's no wonder then that Edward Kennedy, the new chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, is being pressed by organized labor to battle for an increase.

title: OWENS SETS STUDY OF HIGHER BID
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors would consider ''in the near future'' an improved $3.6 billion buyout offer received Monday from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: GRAND JURY SAID TO EXAMINE CONTRACTOR'S HOME EXPENSES
description: The Federal grand jury that called Bess Myerson to testify is hearing evidence on whether Carl A. Capasso, a wealthy contractor, improperly billed to his company the cost of improvements made to two personal residences, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Proposed Budget Bars College for Many
description: To the Editor:

title: VF Corp. Divides $200 Million Offer
description: The VF Corporation offered yesterday $200 million of medium-term notes equally divided between 7- and 10-year maturities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: THREE times last year my elder son told his friends that his mother does not work.

title: Syracuse Is Now 15-0
description: Greg Monroe of Syracuse scored 23 points, including three 3-pointers, to lead the unbeaten Orangemen to a 76-64 Big East basketball victory over Boston College tonight.

title: 2 TRAINS WERE SPEEDING BEFORE CRASH, BOARD SAYS
description: The Amtrak and Conrail trains involved in a fatal collision near Baltimore early this month were exceeding speed limits immediately before the collision, investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: U.S. CALLS EDUCATION OF POOR A PRIORITY
description: Accusing fellow conservatives of neglecting the needs of the poor, the United States Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett, announced yesterday that his department would make the ''education of the disadvantaged'' its major priority over the next two years.

title: LTV Pension Funds Seized
description: The Federal pension watchdog agency said today that it was taking control of three pension funds from the LTV Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel company, which is now in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAZZ GROUP REVIVES SPIKE JONES'S SPECIAL SOUNDS
description: THE revival of the musical mayhem perpetrated by Spike Jones and his City Slickers in the 1940's and 50's, now going on Tuesdays through Saturdays at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, took much more preparation than, say, putting a symphony orchestra together to play Beethoven's Fifth. Like Beethoven's effort, Mr. Jones's works have scores with instructive notations such as ''sputs,'' ''fweets'' and ''idiot babble.'' They require such instruments as tuned cowbells, razzer, klaxon and a variety of whistles - slide, cuckoo, bird, police, siren, train, steam boat and penny.

title: DIRECTOR OF MOSCOW THEATER
description: Anatoly V. Efros, the director of Moscow's Taganka Theater and a leading Soviet director for the last 20 years, died of a heart attack today, the official news agency Tass announced. He was 61 years old.

title: Energy Prices Retreat; Profit Taking Is Cited
description: Energy futures retreated yesterday after a five-day rally that had sent crude oil above $19 a barrel for the first time in 11 months.

title: WOODHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company said that while sales increases were reported by all of its divisions, a significant portion of the earning's improvement is attributable to its telecommunications subsidiary which was restructured during the latter part of the 1986 fiscal year.

title: DENG'S CRUSHING OF PROTEST IS DESCRIBED
description: One day after several thousand university students held a protest for democracy here Jan. 1, Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, ordered the suppression of any further demonstrations, Chinese sources said today.

title: TICKET ON THE 50-YARD LINE? IT'LL COST $1,500 IN PASADENA
description: For some Giants fans who have their hearts set on being in Pasadena for Super Bowl XXI on Jan. 25, money is apparently no object. The face value of a Super Bowl ticket is $75, but agencies that legally deal in buying and selling tickets on the open market say that prices may go as high as $1,500 for a prime seat.

title: Domtar-Imasco
description: The Justice Department said it would file a lawsuit challenging Domtar Inc.'s proposed acquisition of two Imasco Ltd. subsidiaries on the ground that it would lessen competition for gypsum board in Southwestern states. The department said Domtar's purchase of the units, the Genstar Gypsum Products Company and St. Georges Gypsum Mines Inc., in a deal valued at $241 million, would create antitrust violations.The companies have asked the Government to negotiate a settlement with them.

title: INSIDE
description: Peres Cites Warning on Iran Shimon Peres, Israel's Foreign Minister, said his country had warned that chances for success in the Iran arms deal were slim. Page A10. Liquor Rules Voided The United States Supreme Court struck down New York State rules on liquor pricing, saying they cause artificially high prices. Page B1. Myerson Steps Aside Bess Myerson, New York's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, took a leave of absence amid questions about her conduct before a grand jury. Page B1. Mayor in Midwest Is Ousted Voters in Omaha, Neb., voted to recall their Mayor in the middle of his second term after his conduct was called into question. Page A15.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES 8 MAFIA LEADERS TO PRISON TERMS
description: Prison sentences of 40 to 100 years were imposed yesterday on eight men convicted as top leaders and key associates of the ''commission'' that ruled the Mafia in the United States.

title: How Policy Is Unmade
description: There is still a serious question about how foreign policy will be decided here in the last two years of the Reagan Administration.

title: EGG CREAMS AND INSIGHTS READY AT THE MILL
description: IF you wanted eggs a la something, there are better places in town. But if you have just had your heart broken, you would go to the Mill Luncheonette.

title: Howard Beach and the Governor
description: Governor Cuomo, who has been taxed for his lack of visibility regarding the Howard Beach racial assault case, has now moved adroitly and decisively by appointing Charles Hynes as special prosecutor. Mr. Hynes, who is already serving as the state's special prosecutor for official misconduct, apparently has won the confidence of the victims of the attack - enough so for them to pledge the cooperation they had withheld from Queens District Attorney John Santucci.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Lincoln Center Society To Honor Alec Guinness
description: Sir Alec Guinness will be honored at this year's tribute of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, a benefit scheduled for April 27 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $16,311,000 and $33.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively resulting from penalties on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $545,000.

title: 54 Are Killed in in Ethiopia Crash
description: An Ethiopian Air Force plane carrying 54 passengers and crew members crashed today in the Eritrean provincial capital of Asmara, killing everyone on board, the official Ethiopian radio reported.

title: Transactions
