description: BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Reached agreement with Von Hayes, first baseman, on a three-year contract; signed Ron Roenicke, outfielder, and Ken Jackson, minor league shortstop, to one-year contracts.

title: Metropolitan Life
description: A county judge has reaffirmed his decision to allow the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York to assume life insurance policies issued by subsidiaries of the bankrupt Baldwin-United Corporation. The Sun Life Guaranty Company of Arkansas had asked Judge Perry Whitmore of the Pulaski County Circuit Court to reconsider his decision. Metropolitan Life will be allowed to assume about 100,000 policies worth about $2 billion.

title: Apology for Miami
description: Coach Jimmy Johnson of the University of Miami has apologized for his football team's behavior leading up to the Fiesta Bowl and promised to take steps to prevent such attention-grabbing incidents. The coach said he would request stricter off-field supervision of the players and implement a dress code. Johnson, just back from the Japan Bowl, said he had discussed the situation with Athletic Director Sam Jankovich and the university's president, Tad Foote, on Monday, and both had supported him. ''I offer no excuses,'' the coach said. ''Those incidents should not have occurred, and we certainly do not condone them.''

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for all periods reflect the acquisition of Third National Corp., which was completed Dec. 29, 1986, and accounted for as a pooling of interests. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1986.

title: 2 SEEN AS LIKELY TO FILL FEDERAL RESERVE SEATS
description: Leif H. Olsen, formerly the top economist at Citibank, and Edward W. Kelley, an investment adviser from Texas, seem likely to fill the two current vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board, Government and business sources said today.

title: Bethlehem Gain
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that as a result of improved operating results it would report a profit for the fourth quarter instead of the operating loss it had expected. Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, said a $130 million investment tax-credit refund would be recorded in 1987, instead of in the fourth quarter of last year. Bethlehem had initially announced that it expected to report a reduced loss for the fourth quarter. Then it said that because of the tax refunds it would report a profit for the quarter. Yesterday it said it would report net income without the refund. However, the company said it would still report a loss for the year. For the first nine months of 1986, the company reported a loss of $186.9 million on sales of $3.31 billion.

title: JARUZELSKI TALKS WITH POPE ON TIES
description: Pope John Paul II and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski discussed Poland's social problems as well as church-state relations at a long private meeting today, a Vatican communique said.

title: Other Forecasts In Tech Stocks
description: For the electronics industry, the California Technology Stock Letter suggests some areas investors should watch in 1987.

title: PREGNANCY TRANSFERS BY A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had banned all pregnant women from its semiconductor production lines, in response to a University of Massachusetts study that found a sharply higher incidence of miscarriages among workers who produce computer chips.

title: SOVIET AIDES EAGER ON GENEVA TALKS
description: Soviet officials indicated new interest today in reviving the arms control talks in Geneva, which have languished since the summit meeting in Iceland.

title: KOHL ASSURES PUBLIC OF NO SHIFT TO RIGHT IF HE WINS ELECTION
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to reassure the West German electorate that a victory for his center-right coalition in parliamentary elections this month would not mean a rightward shift in foreign policy.

title: BILL MOYERS ANNOUNCES HIS PUBLIC TV PROJECTS
description: Bill Moyers, who left CBS late last year contending that he had been ''spiritually unemployed,'' gave details today about his planned return to public television in the spring. Mr. Moyers said he had formed his own company to produce six public affairs projects during the next two years.

title: TO KNOW ITALIANS, KNEAD THEIR BREADS
description: WHEN you grow up in Brooklyn, you don't have to be Italian to know much about Italians. In fact, when you grow up in Brooklyn, you think you are Italian, or at least a reasonable facsimile, for a large part of your childhood.

title: NEW ICN DRUG PUTS CHIEF IN SPOTLIGHT
description: In the 26 years since Milan Panic founded ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., the company has gone from obscurity to the limelight and Mr. Panic has acquired a reputation as a good promoter. Some would say too good.

title: Curbside Network
description: To the Editor:

title: RULING HEARTENS BACKERS OF BILLS ON PARENTAL LEAVE
description: Some lawmakers and other advocates hope that a Supreme Court decision yesterday, upholding a California law that benefits pregnant workers, will improve the chances of other legislation on child care and pregnancy in the workplace.

title: Geoffrey Stone Named Dean Of U. of Chicago Law School
description: The University of Chicago Law School announced today that Geoffrey R. Stone, a 40-year-old professor of constitutional law, would become its ninth dean.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CIVILIAN DESCRIBES 'STRUGGLE' BEFORE SHOOTING OF BUMPURS
description: A city social worker yesterday described in court testimony the ''commotion'' and ''struggle'' that he heard between police officers and Eleanor Bumpurs before she was fatally shot by one of the officers during an eviction dispute two years ago.

title: SCREEN: 'TOUCH AND GO'
description: ''TOUCH AND GO'' is a dismally ineffective, would-be sentimental movie about a professional hockey star (Michael Keaton) who befriends a tough little street urchin (Ajay Naidu), after the urchin tries to mug him, then falls in love with the boy's unwed mom (Maria Conchita Alonso). The film, which opens today at the Coronet, was shot mostly in Chicago, where it's set and which also stands in for a brief sequence in Minneapolis.

title: The Reply Card Goes Electric
description: When the Telenet Communications Corporation started a big advertising push for its data communications network, it seemed silly to ask executives to clip out and send a coupon for more information about electronic messaging. So Telenet wisely opened its lines to allow respondents to send, via computer and modem, their ''electronic business reply cards.''

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 14, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Status of Women -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Arizona Selects Coach
description: After a search that lasted 11 days, the University of Arizona named Dick Tomey of Hawaii yesterday as its new football coach, giving him a four-year contract with a base salary of $85,000 a year. Tomey, 48 years old, succeeds Larry Smith, who took the head-coaching post at Southern California. Tomey was a finalist for the Arizona post for the 1977 season, but the job was given to Tony Mason, then coach at the University of Cincinnati.

title: Mellon Sees Lower Net
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said it expected to post lower year-end earnings next week, reflecting higher loan losses and the bank's decision to increase its reserves. Mellon said it expected net income for 1986 to be $183 million, or $6.20 a share, down 9 percent from 1985. Mellon Bank's stock fell $1.125, to $54.625.

title: PSYCHIATRIST FILES A LIBEL SUIT OVER FILM OF PLATH'S 'BELL JAR'
description: A Boston psychiatrist who says she is the basis for a character in Sylvia Plath's 1961 novel about suicide, ''The Bell Jar,'' has filed a suit contending defamation, invasion of privacy and intentional infliction of emotional damage, growing out of a 1979 movie version of the book.

title: ROBERT S. DANFORTH
description: Robert S. Danforth, former head of investment research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: It's All Downhill
description: The United States Senate is expected to be in recess on Friday (to give the members an extra-long holiday weekend marking the birth of Martin Luther King Jr.) but for a group of 16 senators, it will be business not quite as usual. They plan to convene a rump, or rather a slope, session in Park City, Utah.

title: 100 DIE IN EUROPE AS COLD CONTINUES
description: Europe is experiencing one of its worst cold spells on record, with icy Siberian blasts sweeping across the region in recent days causing more than 100 deaths, avalanches, transport chaos, food hoarding and power-failure warnings.

title: Blumenthal and Democrats
description: The Democratic Business Council, founded six years ago primarily as a fund-raising mechanism, is about to get a formidable new chairman, W. Michael Blumenthal, the former Secretary of the Treasury who is now chief executive officer of Unisys, the computer corporation formed by the merger of the Burroughs and Sperry Corporations.

title: 'LIONS OF AFRICAN NIGHT'
description: THERE are wildlife films and there are wildlife films; ''Lions of the African Night'' is one of the more distinguished examples of the genre. The ''National Geographic Special,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, and on Channels 21, 49 and 50 at 8 o'clock, beats with life.

title: Topics: Rejuvenated; Flower Beds
description: Envy the indoor gardeners blessed with green thumbs: Bougainvillea cascades from hanging pots in their sun-filled windows; their desks overflow with ivy. But for each of them, surely, there are a dozen whose thumbs remain dispiritingly brown. Their yuccas look leggy, and their African violets refuse to flower.

title: ELECTION UNLIKELY IN '87, NICARAGUA OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The Nicaraguan Vice President says local elections will probably not be held this year as previousy announced.

title: DR. MILTON WERBEL
description: Dr. Milton Werbel, president of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York in the mid-1950's, died of a heart attack Jan. 8 at Palm Beach Lakes Hospital, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Royal Palm Beach.

title: THE JAPANESE GREET '87, IN 31 APT SYLLABLES
description: In a ceremony as subdued as the whisper of snow that had fallen overnight, Emperor Hirohito presided today over Tokyo's lyrical welcome to the new year, the annual poetry party at the Imperial Palace.

title: TEST LIMIT TREATIES SENT TO SENATE
description: President Reagan asked the Senate today to approve two 1970's treaties that limit the size of underground nuclear explosions. But he said the unratified treaties would go into effect only if the Soviet Union agreed to additional verification measures.

title: AIRLINE FARE: THE ART OF MENU PLANNING
description: SWISSAIR, known in the airline industry for the quality of its in-flight food, faced a crucial culinary decision the other day: to sprinkle slivered almonds over its curried shrimp entree or to leave it plain.

title: BRONX SCHOOL EXCELS ACADEMICALLY, DESPITE THE ODDS
description: Public School 31, whose collegiated Gothic facade rises gracefully above the warehouses and gutted lots of the South Bronx, has been dubbed ''the castle on the Concourse'' by students and staff.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NOW IT CAN BE TOLD? Three prominent sports reporters who recorded the day-in, day-out successes and failures of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and who helped create the legends of Ebbets Field will talk about the good ol' days tonight, under the aegis of the Brooklyn Historical Society (718-624-0890). The program begins at 6 P.M. in the Packer Collegiate Institute auditorium, at 160 Joralemon Street, in downtown Brooklyn.

title: EATING IN KANSAS CITY: ULTIMATE UN-DIET
description: There are at least three Kansas Citys. There is the Kansas City of the ear, where Charlie Parker, Count Basie and Jay McShann blued the air over 12th Street and Vine. There is the Kansas City of the memory, a town bustling with cattle, cowboys and frontier wildness. And there is the Kansas City of the stomach: a metropolis devoted to lard, sugar, salt, beef and other dietary unspeakables. Funny thing is, nobody feels like a gustatory sinner.

title: COLLEGES ENCOURAGE STUDENT VOLUNTEERS
description: WHEN the Campus Compact, an organization of university presidents and chancellors, was established in November 1985 to stimulate student participation in voluntary community service, some of its founders wondered how much enthusiasm there would be for its message.

title: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. SEEKS BIGGER DROP FOR WEAK DOLLAR
description: The Reagan Administration let it be known today that it wants the dollar, now the weakest it has been since the start of the decade, to decline still further.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1987
description: International

title: FATHER OF BABY M THOUGHT MOTHER HAD BEEN SCREENED
description: William Stern believed that a Manhattan surrogate agency had psychologically screened Mary Beth Whitehead and approved her for surrogate motherhood before he signed an agreement that she bear a child for him, according to a statement introduced today at the Baby M trial.

title: U.A. Cable Stake
description: Telecommunications Inc. of Denver, the nation's largest cable system operator, has raised its stake in United Artists Communications Inc. to about 64 percent, or 26.6 million shares, from 55 percent. Telecommunications bought a controlling 51 percent stake in United Artists in July for $390 million. United Artists, based in San Francisco, operates a major cable television system and is not related to the movie producer, the United Artists Corporation.

title: Music Noted in Brief; New Repertory By Alexa Still, Flutist
description: Alexa Still is a young New Zealander who has had a busy professional life as a flutist in Auckland and now studies in the United States. She and several of her friends came to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night, playing a program of largely American music from our time.

title: BLACKMAN'S 41 SINK KNICKS
description: The Knicks tried three players on Rolando Blackman last night. They ran at him, bumped him and did what Bob Hill, the Knick coach, called ''everything but go illegal on him.''

title: CUOMO NAMES AGRICULTURE CHIEF
description: Dr. Donald G. Butcher, president of the State College of Agriculture and Technology at Morrisville, has been chosen by Governor Cuomo as the state's new Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, administration officials said today.

title: Beacon Theater Plan Said to Meet Rules
description: A planned conversion of the Beacon Theater into a nightclub would meet zoning rules now that its dance area has been reduced, the City Buildings Commissioner, Charles M. Smith Jr., said yesterday.

title: STAGE: 'TAKE ME ALONG' AT THE EQUITY LIBRARY
description: GOLDEN mists of Victorian innocence and small-town nostalgia waft through ''Take Me Along,'' the 1959 musical based on Eugene O'Neill's play ''Ah, Wilderness!'' Set on a Fourth of July near the turn of the century, the show is representative of the American mood toward the end of the Eisenhower era, as it evokes a sweetly fateful day in the life of the Millers, an idealized, all-American family from New England.

title: FARM PROSPECTS BETTER, BUT WORRIES INCREASE
description: For the first time in a long time, things are looking up a bit this year for the average American farmer.

title: Former Felon Elected Sheriff In a South Carolina County
description: A pardoned felon was elected sheriff of McCormick County today, defeating a former acting sheriff charged with trying to fix the election.

title: Robins Deadline
description: Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. has given the A. H. Robins Company three weeks to submit a reorganization plan, saying he has unhappy with what he called the lack of cooperation from lawyers involved in the 16-month-old bankruptcy proceeding. Judge Merhige said Monday that he had had ''less cooperation in this case than any other case in 20 years'' on the bench. The judge has already granted Robins two extensions of the deadline for filing the reorganization plan. He said he would not grant any extensions of Robins's Feb. 5 deadline for filing a plan. The large pharmaceutical concern filed for Chapter 11 protection in August 1985 in the face of mounting claims from women who said they had been injured by the company's Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth control device.

title: THE TRAGIC EXAMPLES
description: In the morning, it seemed business as usual in the National Basketball Association. The weekly newsletter from the league office arrived by mail and was complete with team statistics, and, as usual, it was casually perused.

title: Teamster Leader Has Tumor
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, underwent what was described as successful surgery today to remove a tumor on his lung, a spokesman for the 60-year-old union leader said. Mr. Presser underwent the surgery at the Cleveland Clinic after it was discovered in a routine checkup, according to his spokesman, John Climaco. He could not be reached for comment on whether the tumor was malignant, and a hospital spokesman said there was ''no report on that.''

title: RICHARD H. EVENSEN, AUTHORITY ON BRAILLE, AND WIFE ARE KILLED
description: Richard H. Evensen, an authority at the Library of Congress on transcribing material into Braille, and his wife Lorraine were killed Monday evening when they were struck by a car while crossing a busy street.

title: WINE TALK
description: THESE are hard times in the wine world. Not for many years has the future for wine been so uncertain. First of all, fewer Americans are drinking it. Understand, I'm talking about wine and not about the highly popular drinks made from it. The popularity of wine coolers is a remarkable phenomenon and a great boon to the companies that make them. So was the apple wine of the early 70's.

title: JOB RIGHTS BACKED IN PREGNANCY CASE
description: In a case of major importance to working women and employers, the United States Supreme Court ruled today that states may require employers to grant special job protection to employees who are physically unable to work because of pregnancy.

title: SPRINGFIELD, ILL., TERMED UNFAIR TO BLACK VOTERS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the form of government in Abraham Lincoln's hometown discriminates against blacks.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Lean Cream Soups
description: LEAD: IF you are on a diet, you may fail to appreciate the glorious alchemy that turns vegetables, water and milk or cream into a deep, delicious cream soup. After all, the adjectives for this type of soup are all wrong. They seem to circumscribe territory limited to those who are not weight-conscious: ''rich'' equals fatty as does ''creamy'' - precisely the attributes we value in a cream soup.

title: CBS PRESENTS 'MY DISSIDENT MOM'
description: ORIGINALLY scheduled for an afternoon broadcast last October as a CBS ''Schoolbreak Special,'' ''My Dissident Mom'' was suddenly pulled, prompting rumors that the little drama may have been too outspokenly ''liberal'' in its stance against nuclear weapons. But as it turns out, the program was merely being saved for prime time and a presumably larger audience. ''My Dissident Mom'' can now be seen this evening at 8 o'clock. If right-wing groups were upset by ABC's ''Day After,'' as was widely reported, they are likely to be apoplectic with rage over the more modest but more pointed ''My Dissident Mom.''

title: 9.75% Israeli Devaluation
description: Israel devalued its shekel today by 9.75 percent against the dollar and cut income taxes and food subsidies in an effort to salvage a popular economic program that has ended triple-digit inflation.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of 17 cents a share from the sale of real estate for both the quarter and year.

title: Guinness Picks Finance Officer
description: Guinness, the British brewing company, named James Bryant, an accountant and merchant banker, as its finance director today after the resignation of Olivier Roux.

title: TROOPS ARE CONFINED TO BARRACKS
description: Hundreds of paratroopers from the 82d Airborne Division remained locked in their barracks today while the military authorities investigated the apparent theft of two submachine guns, Fort Bragg officials say.

title: Drop in Bond Yields Sparks Refinancings
description: The decline in tax-exempt bond yields, with many medium- and high-quality issues now yielding less than 7 percent, is presenting many local governments with a chance to refinance, at a profit, bonds that they sold just a few years ago. Refunding bonds accounted for about 40 percent of last year's tax-exempt bond sales, according to Salomon Brothers data.

title: CHICAGO HOPEFUL MAY BE OUT
description: Bernard Epton, a Republican who was defeated for Mayor in 1983 by Harold Washington, is expected to be ruled off this February's primary ballot under a recommendation made today. He said Monday that he would never again seek elective office.

title: WEDTECH OFFICERS ARE REPLACED
description: The top officers of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is the subject of several state and Federal investigations, resigned yesterday and were replaced, as the company struggled to find new financing to resume operations.

title: South Korea Is Urged To Free 3 Journalists
description: Amnesty International and the Committee to Protect Journalists have issued appeals for the release of three South Korean journalists who were arrested last month for exposing a purported Government campaign to censor the press.

title: FRENCH WRITER SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: Gunmen today kidnapped a French reporter covering Terry Waite's mission to free American and other foreign hostages held in Lebanon. They pistol-whipped and shot at another French journalist, but he escaped.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Wrangler Closings To Lay Off 1,200
description: LEAD: The VF Corporation, the nation's largest publicly held apparel company, said yesterday that its Wrangler jeans division would close eight plants in Arizona and North Carolina and dismiss up to 1,200 employees.

title: LLOYD AND WIGGINS OF ROCKETS BANNED FOR DRUG USE
description: Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins of the Houston Rockets were banned from the National Basketball Rockets were banned from the National Basketball Association yesterday after having tested positive for cocaine.

title: OUT OF A PRISON, A BETTER DRINKING STRAW
description: WHEN inventors from around the world gathered last fall in California to select the best inventions of 1986, not all the contenders were there: some had scheduling conflicts and others could not afford the travel cost. One had to stay in prison.

title: Helping Volunteers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As one of New York City's major volunteer-placement agencies, we were delighted to read Thomas Morgan's ''Young Professionals: New Skills in Old Job of Volunteerism'' [ Dec. 3 ] .

title: SAN FRANCISCO AIDS PROJECT TRACING WOMEN
description: In an effort to curb the spread of AIDS, the Department of Public Health is tracking down and warning women who have had sexual relations with men later diagnosed as having AIDS.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary yesterday of Harold Eliot Krents, the lawyer whose life story inspired ''Butterflies Are Free,'' gave an incorrect date for the funeral. The service will be at 1 P.M. today, not tomorrow, at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street.

title: NETS FALL VICTIM TO BALANCED ATTACK
description: Larry Bird simply took his horrendous shooting night in stride, accepting the fact that he will occasionally endure these kinds of games in his career. It was over now. The Boston Celtics still won.

title: Piling On and the Cardinal
description: John Cardinal O'Connor is scarcely the first eminence to stumble over the loaded arguments in every visitor's path to the Middle East. The Cardinal was obviously innocent of the ambivalence in his church's diplomacy concerning Israel. But the criticism flung at him by Jewish organizations in New York is overwrought - especially since Israel invited the Cardinal at the urging of the very Jewish leaders now unhappy with an outcome that might have been predicted.

title: TROOPER-CASE DEFENDANT CALLED A LIAR
description: The defendant Thomas W. Manning lied when he testified about the slaying of a state trooper five years ago on Interstate 80, Deputy Attorney General Anthony G. Simonetti said today in summarizing the two-month murder trial.

title: UNDER SCRUTINY, SHE COPES WITH PRESSURE
description: On Monday night, seated before her television set, one of Bess Myerson's friends watched New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner sail out of a long and trying meeting with Koch administration officials and past a tangle of clamoring reporters.

title: NEW I.R.S. CAMPAIGN AIMED AT TAX EVADERS
description: Stepping up its war against tax evaders, the Internal Revenue Service today announced a new effort to crack down on one million Americans a year who do not file income tax returns.

title: STEIN SAYS CITY AMBULANCE RESPONSE IS TOO SLOW
description: A spot check of New York City's ambulance services found that despite improvements over the last few years, many people with life-threatening conditions are facing unnecessarily long waits for service, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
Effect of Dollar's Fall Widens
description: LEAD: The effects of the dollar's sharp decline became more pronounced in the credit markets yesterday, with interest rates falling on Treasury bills in the short-term sector but rising for notes and bonds in the long-term sector.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $6,678,347 for the latest quarter and $1,712,670 for the year-ago period.

title: Schlichter Seeks Post
description: Art Schlichter, the former Ohio State and Indianapolis Colt quarterback who was suspended for the 1983 National Football League season for gambling, is one of 36 applicants for the football coaching job at Wilmington High School in Ohio, according to a report in yesterday's Wilmington News-Journal. ''Chances are I won't play pro ball again,'' said the 26-year-old Schlichter. ''I would like to get back into the game, and coaching would help me do that.''

title: PERES ASSERTS ISRAEL WARNED OF 1-IN-4 ODDS IN IRAN DEAL
description: When Israel recommended to the United States in January 1986 that it engage in an arms-for-hostages deal with Iran, Israel cautioned the Reagan Administration that there was at best a 25 percent chance of success, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres was quoted as saying today.

title: SKETCHES OF THE PLAYERS
description: Mitchell Wiggins: The 6-foot-4-inch Wiggins was another in the long line of box-score names that few bothered to learn about until last season's playoffs. . . . After being used sparingly during the regular season, averaging 6.8 points a game, he had 24 points in first game of the Western Conference final against the Los Angeles Lakers. In Game 3 of the championship round against the Boston Celtics, he soared over his 7-foot-4 teammate, Ralph Sampson, and tipped in the basket that provided the Rockets with a 106-104 victory. . . . After two years at junior college and one season at Clemson, he averaged 23.2 points during his senior year at Florida State. . . . Was selected on the first round of the 1983 draft by the Indiana Pacers, but was traded the same day to the Chicago Bulls. . . . After averaging 12.4 points during his rookie season, he was traded to the Rockets. . . . Like Lewis Lloyd, he is an outstanding shooter. Averaged 11.1 points a game as a starter in 19 of 32 games. . . . Married to Marita Payne, a world-class sprinter, who finished fourth at 400 meters for Canada in the 1984 Olympics.

title: GRIMES FACES REDUCED CHARGE
description: Felony assault charges against Timothy Grimes, who is accused of stabbing his girlfriend in the back, were reduced yesterday to misdemeanor charges.

title: EVER FEWER WORKERS, BROCK SAYS, HAVE SKILLS FOR THE JOBS AVAILABLE
description: The Secretary of Labor told a Senate committee today that there was a ''dangerous trend'' in which American workers with insufficient skills were seeking jobs that demanded ever greater skills.

title: Advertising; New Drive By Ladies' Journal
description: ON the basis of focus group interviews of ad agency media planners and their supervisors in New York and Chicago, certain important people at The Ladies' Home Journal believe that though those respondents are bright to many ways of the modern world, they do not generally read women's service magazines nor the publications in which they advertise.

title: SCHULMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Feb. 17.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net income The company said the 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect the 15 percent stock dividend paid in June 1986. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA
description: THERE is always a need for short, brightly orchestrated pieces that can begin concerts and serve as wake-up calls for both musicians and audience. Since serious conductors are always looking for new works to fulfill their obligations to contemporary music, they frequently seek out scores such as Christopher Rouse's ''Phaethon,'' which opened last evening's Philadelphia Orchestra program at Carnegie Hall under Riccardo Muti's direction.

title: PRETORIA ARRESTS A FUGITIVE ANTI-APARTHEID LEADER
description: A top official of South Africa's largest anti-apartheid group has been seized after operating underground for about two years, members of the movement said today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Man With Explosives Seized at Milan Airport
description: A 26-year-old man arrested Monday at a Milan airport carrying about 24 pounds of plastic explosives is being investigated for possible links to Middle East terrorist groups, Italian officials said today.

title: Pay Raise Won't Make Better Legislators
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $32 million on offerings of class A depositary units of I.P.Timberlands Ltd., $41 million on the sale of the New York City headquarters building, and $11 million from a change in pension accounting for FASB '87. It is also includes a pre-tax charge of $31 million for a staff relocation reserve and plant closing costs, and a $20 million charge from an adjustment to income taxes in recognition of changes resulting from the Tax Reform Act. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $44 million for a change in pension accounting. d-Includes a pre-tax gain of $56 million on offerings of class A depositary units of I.P.Timberlands Ltd. and is after a pre-tax charge of $12 million for facility closings. e-Includes a $2 million restatement of net earnings for the cumulatitive effect (to Dec. 31, 1984) of a change in accounting for the cost of timber harvested and includes a pre-tax charge of $29 million for an early retirement program. The 1986 fourth quarter and year results include Hammermill Paper Company, acquired in November 1986, which accounts for 30 percent of sales.

title: Mayor Has Plan to Regulate Food Vendors in Midtown Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $178,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $49,000.

title: POLITICAL SATIRE IN 'SPITTING IMAGE'
description: PROBABLY the last thing Ronald Reagan needs these days is a volley of satirical darts aimed in his direction, but that's just what NBC has in store for him this evening at 9:30, courtesy of a gang of British puppets spawned by a TV production called ''Spitting Image.'' The show became a popular success in England by using its puppets' wicked caricatures to spoof and puncture everybody from the Royal Family and Margaret Thatcher to the latest batch of rock stars. The humor is not just naughty, it's scathing. Tonight's half-hour, made especially for the American market by the executive producers Jon Blair and David Frost, is in the form of a typical situation comedy. The title is ''The Ronnie and Nancy Show.''

title: Native Satraps
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE LANGUAGE BARRIER BECOMES A BARRICADE
description: For weeks, the signs posted outside banks and post offices in this southern port city have remained defaced, offering testimony to the intractability of India's oldest language dispute.

title: Honors for a Town Of 'Decent Folks'
description: TO hear them tell it, they were just doing what comes naturally.

title: Economic Scene; What Feeds A Bull Market
description: WHAT explains the disparity between the roaring bull stock market and the sluggish economy?

title: An Inattention to Detail Is Getting More Attention
description: Congressional leaders long concerned about what they consider President Reagan's inattention to detail say their concerns have been heightened in recent meetings with him at the White House.

title: STAFF MEMBERS, UPSET, MEET AT NEW YORKER
description: Staff members of The New Yorker held a 90-minute meeting yesterday afternoon to air their concerns and anger over the sudden announcement of a replacement for William Shawn as editor of the magazine.

title: Music Noted in Brief; The Mirecourt Trio In a New Piano Work
description: The highlight of the Mirecourt Trio's concert Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection was the world premiere of a Piano Trio by the Japanese composer Minoru Miki.

title: Ridding Leeks of Grit
description: DURING the winter months I always have a bunch of leeks in my refrigerator to add to soups and stews and to prepare as a side dish or appetizer. Cold poached leeks with vinaigrette, for example, are among the most popular appetizers in France. While leeks are versatile, healthful and delicious, they have one potential pitfall: sand. Clean them extremely well, or else your dish could be ruined by grit. The technique shown here should avert that. STEP 1

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary: Now is the time of the Champagne Decision - when festively wrapped bottles, sent as holiday greetings by classy acquaintances, are stored in cool but crowded closets, to be retrieved on worthy, cork-popping occasions.

title: What the Riots in Soviet Asia Were About
description: To the Editor:

title: HYNES IS SELECTED TO BE PROSECUTOR IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Governor Cuomo named a special prosecutor yesterday to take over the case of the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: COLOMBIA ENVOY, A DRUG FOE, IS SHOT IN BUDAPEST
description: A former Justice Minister who until recently headed Colombia's anti-drug campaign was shot and seriously wounded today in Budapest in an apparent extension of the country's drug war into Eastern Europe.

title: IRAN REPORTS BREAKING THROUGH IRAQI DEFENSIVE LINE EAST OF BASRA
description: Iran asserted tonight that its attacking forces had broken through Iraq's ''strongest defensive line east of Basra'' and pushed forward six miles.

title: Eaton Prices Debentures
description: The Eaton Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 98.648, to yield 8.626 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: CONCERT: VERDI'S 'BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO
description: ''LA BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO'' is one of several Verdi operas whose action, though set in remote times, sent patriotic juices surging through the veins of his countrymen in the 19th century, when Italy was a jumble of separate city-states. Although rarely revived, it is not an inconsequential work, a fact that could be glimpsed Monday night in the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $2,592,000 for the quarter and $3,758,000 for the 6 months. The company said sales to International Business Machines Corp. accounted for approximately 30 percent of the revenue for the latest three and six-month periods, compared with 28 percent and 38 percent for the year- ago periods, respectively. The company also said its latest quarter and six months were adversely affected by the resolution of the two suits brought by Berger-Lahr, a provision for pending patent litigation and the writeoff of assets as the company continues its plant modernization and automation.

title: Jewelry, Ancient and Modern
description: 1. Stylish and Sporty

title: The New 'Competiveness' Industry
description: No issue summons more bipartisan support, none elicits more unanimous conviction than American ''competitiveness.''

title: 'Kate Vaiden' Wins Book Critics Prize
description: ''Kate Vaiden'' (Atheneum), a novel by Reynolds Price, has won the National Book Critics Circle prize for the best work of fiction of 1986.

title: DEVIL RELIEF GOALIE SAVORING SUCCESS
description: Craig Billington, the 20-year-old goaltender for the Devils, has had plenty of success in a spot where three other goalies have failed this season, but he has not allowed the success to bother him.

title: EX-HEAD OF POLICE UNIT SAID TO GIVE CONFLICTING STATEMENTS
description: The former head of the Police Department's intelligence division gave investigators inconsistent accounts when they questioned him on two occasions about his contacts in 1983 with a reputed organized crime figure in Queens, police officials said yesterday.

title: LIQUOR RETAILERS EXPRESS ANGER AT COURT RUING
description: Liquor retailers in New York State generally expressed disappointment and anger over yesterday's Supreme Court ruling invalidating the state's pricing law for distilled spirits.

title: OMAHA VOTES TO OUST ITS MAYOR OVER HIS CONDUCT
description: Mayor Michael Boyle lost his bid to remain in office today as residents voted to remove him for alleged abuse of power.

title: Koch Wants Money To Fix Up Schools
description: In a preview of the preliminary city budget he will present Thursday, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday to set aside an extra $75 million for school maintenance from surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: CONNER DEFEATS DICKSON BY 1:20
description: Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes took an early lead and held on to defeat Chris Dickson's New Zealand by 1 minute 20 seconds today in the opening race of the four-of-seven-race America's Cup challenger's final series.

title: SUPREME COURT OVERTURNS NEW YORK'S MINIMUM LIQUOR PRICING
description: The Supreme Court today struck down New York State regulations on liquor pricing that it said allowed wholesalers to dictate artificially high retail prices.

title: LARGE DONATIONS FOR NEEDIEST ARE SENT BY COMPANY GROUPS
description: A gift of $375 from Consolidated Edison employees to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund marks the 16th year that the systems planning department of the utility has contributed to the fund.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $54,000.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Printouts; Investment Outlook In Biotechnology
description: Biotechnology stocks swing like a pendulum.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
NEW LIFE AWAITS BUILDING SAVED IN HEART OF NEWARK
description: For more than 15 years Gateway Plaza, the office complex in downtown Newark owned by the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America, has stood as a symbol of the revival of the city's business district.

title: 2D SUSPECT IS HELD
description: Law-enforcement officials today seized two men, one of whom was charged with setting the fatal fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel on New Year's Eve. The other was described as an accomplice.

title: Stadium Links For PGA Tour
description: Another of the new stadium courses will become part of the PGA Tour Wednesday when the long and tricky PGA West course serves as the host track for the $900,000 Bob Hope Chrysler Classic. This second event on the 1987 PGA Tour is a pro-amateur event played for five days over four courses.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Kosher Sausages

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Saudi Oil Plan Held Rejected
description: Four major United States oil companies have rejected a Saudi Arabian offer to sell fixed volumes of crude oil at prices set in line with the new official price system of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to a published report. The report was in the Middle

title: THE CASE FOR BAKING PASTRY SHELLS 'BLIND,' AT LOW HEAT
description: NANCY SILVERTON didn't realize that it was unusual to bake tart shells ''blind'' (unfilled) at a moderate-to-low oven temperature. But that is precisely what Ms. Silverton, a pastry chef and consultant in California, recommends in her new book, ''Desserts'' (Harper & Row, $22.50).

title: SUPER BOWL HYPE GETS EARLY KICKOFF
description: The serious business for the Giants will start Thursday. That is the day the players return from a three-day layoff and start meetings and practice for their Super Bowl game against the Denver Broncos on Jan. 25 in Pasadena, Calif.

title: I.B.M. Drop Holds Dow Gain to 3.52
description: Despite a poor performance by I.B.M., the Dow Jones industrial average advanced for the eighth straight time yesterday. But stock prices were mixed over all, ruining Wall Street's perfect record for 1987.

title: DOLLAR DROPS DESPITE JAPAN'S EFFORTS
description: The dollar sagged further on world currency markets yesterday despite a strong effort by the Bank of Japan to prop it up.

title: NAVAJO LEADER TAKES OFFICE, VOWING TO REBUILD RESERVATION
description: Facing severe economic problems and a dwindling flow of Federal aid, a long-time leader of the Navajo Indians took office once again here today, vowing to rebuild the nation's largest reservation with the help of private investors.

title: HISPANIC UNITS PROTEST ATTACK ON 2 IN QUEENS
description: Several Hispanic organizations asked officials yesterday to name a special prosecutor to investigate charges by two Hispanic teen-agers that they were beaten by a group of white men in Queens and later abused by officers whom they had summoned.

title: A Historical 'Memory' for Presidents
description: President Reagan has charged the commission headed by John Tower with answering this question: How can the White House be organized so that controversies like the one over the arms sale to Iran and its contra sideshow can be prevented? The commission can suggest reforms necessary to prevent repetition of foreign policy failures only by recognizing that the underlying problem that led Mr. Reagan astray has afflicted other Presidents. It is the absence of any historical memory in the White House.

title: Overachieving Infants
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Anna Quindlen's Life in the 30's column of Dec. 10 is one of the finest statements I have seen regarding the inordinate pressure we often place on very young children to ''achieve.''

title: Marginal Difference
description: One intriguing aspect of Super Bowl XXI is that it will match teams with the largest and smallest cumulative margins of victory in the history of conference semifinal and final playoffs games. The overall leaders: LARGEST MARGINS Team Scores Margin 1986 Giants 17-0 - 49-3 63 1978 Steelers 34-5 - 33-10 52 1977 Cowboys 23-6 - 37-7 47 1983 Redskins 24-21 - 51-7 47 1985 Bears 24-0 - 21-0 45 SMALLEST MARGINS Team Scores Margin 1986 Broncos 23-20 - 22-17 8 1980 Raiders 34-27 - 14-12 9 1972 Dolphins 21-17 - 20-14 10 1979 Rams 9-0 - 21-19 11 1970 Cowboys 17-10 - 5-0 12 1981 49ers 28-27 - 38-24 15 1969 Chiefs 17-7 - 13-6 17

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bus Drivers' Duty
description: The Transit Authority allows senior citizens to travel on city buses at half fare; they must show a Medicare card when challenged by a bus driver who believes they are too young for the subsidy.

title: Forum With Cardinal On His Mideast Trip
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced last night that John Cardinal O'Connor would hold an open meeting on Friday ''with interested parties'' to discuss his recent trip to the Middle East.

title: RIFT OVER HIGH-TECH EXPORTS
description: Creating a storm of protest, a National Academy of Sciences report has derided the Reagan Administration's efforts to restrict exports of high-technology goods.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $19,000, a loss from the disposal of the textile division amounting to $19,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,877,000 from the termination of two pension plans. c-Includes a loss of $3.7 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,877,000 from the termination of two pension plans.

title: Verdi's Political Chameleon
description: In 1848, when Verdi began his 14th opera, ''La Battaglia di Legnano,'' Europe was in the throes of political upheaval. In Italy, citizens of Milan drove out the occupying Austrian troops after five days of street fighting, and republican revolutionaries in other cities were overthrowing aristocratic or foreign rulers. In this atmosphere, Verdi's nationalistic fever came to a boil. He turned for a subject to a 12th-century legend of Italian heroism: the defeat of the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa by the armies of the Lombard League. By the time of the opera's premiere in Rome on Jan. 27, 1849, Milan was back in the hands of the Austrians, but Rome was still republican territory, and the premiere succeeded so well that the third act had to be repeated.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $99,000 for the quarter and a credit of $350,000 for the year. c-Net income and is after a credit of $500,000 for the quarter and year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1987
description: The Economy

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
EX-CHRISTIE'S CHIEF TESTIFIES AT TRIAL
description: The former president of Christie's, David Bathurst, testified yesterday in a State Supreme Court trial in Manhattan, giving an unusually detailed picture of the normally secret negotiations between an auction house and a seller of valuable works of art before a sale.

title: THE MAFIA: OTHER PENDING CASES
description: The Mafia is the target of a series of continuing legal battles.

title: BOSSY'S GOAL TIES SPIRITED PENGUINS
description: A large portion of the Islander repertory seems to be devoted to frenzied third-period comebacks that salvage, sometimes only partially, the damage done by desultory play in the early going.

title: Ueberroth to Testify at Conspiracy Case
description: As the Major League Baseball Players Association filed a grievance over the latest flap involving free agents, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said yesterday that he would testify at the hearing in the players' free-agent conspiracy case against the owners. The conspiracy hearing, which has been running sporadically since last June, is scheduled to resume Feb. 23.

title: The Rumsfeld Rumor
description: A new candidate has emerged in speculation around town concerning a possible successor to William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence. He is Donald H. Rumsfeld, the former Congressman, Secretary of Defense and corporate executive.

title: AUTODIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 13
description: b-Net income.

title: Ruland Returns
description: Jeff Ruland, the Philadelphia center, was taken off the injured-reserve list yesterday and will be available for the 76ers' game tonight against the Atlanta Hawks. But club officials say he will play as a reserve, between 12 and 18 minutes per game, with Tim McCormick remaining the starter. In addition, at the recommendation of Dr. Kenneth DeHaven, who performed arthroscopic surgery on Ruland's left knee Nov. 19, Ruland will not play consecutive games and will not practice hard the day after a game for nearly a month.

title: REAL COACH, PLEASE STAND UP
description: James Patrick came off the ice last week, exhausted, having fended off a two-on-one breakaway the smart way, to hugs and shouts from his coach.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $10,119,000 on the extinguishment of debt, and includes a one-time $60 million third quarter charge for restructuring costs for phase-out of facilities in Barbados and Puerto Rico and the company's exit from the bubble memory business. c-Includes a tax benefit of $4,494,000. d-Net income.

title: Japan Seeking U.S. Assurance
description: Japan will urge the United States next week to confirm an earlier agreement to stabilize currency exchange rates, the Japanese press reported today.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD BANKS ON DISCOUNT BROKERAGE
description: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for national banks to establish or acquire discount brokerage outlets anywhere in the country without regard to Federal geographical restrictions on bank branches.

title: JOHN DANIELSON
description: John Danielson, an administrator at hospitals and medical centers for more than 30 years, died Monday at the age of 62.

title: Energy Dept. Is Making Defense-Production Facilities Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Labor Leaders Meet With Jaruzelski
description: Italian labor leaders urged Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today to allow Polish workers greater freedom in organizing trade unions.

title: Canadian Tire Bid By CTC Blocked
description: Government regulators blocked a takeover bid worth $270 million, or about $198 million in United States currency, for the Canadian Tire Corporation, Canada's largest automotive and hardware retail chain, by a group of Canadian Tire store operators. A ruling by the Ontario and Quebec securities commissions stopped the store dealers, represented by CTC Dealer Holdings Ltd., from acquiring 49 percent of Canadian Tire's common shares at a price of $160.24, or about $117.76 American, each. The dealers already owned 17.4 percent of the company's common shares.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY DROPS CLASSES OF PRIEST CENSURED FOR SEX VIEWS
description: Officials at Catholic University announced today that they were canceling three courses scheduled to be taught this spring by the Rev. Charles E. Curran, a liberal theologian censured by the Vatican last year for his views on sexual issues.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Sal Butera, catcher; Lenny Harris and Chris Sabo, infielders; and Mike Smith, pitcher, to one-year contracts. Named Tom Runnells manager of Vermont of the Eastern League, Dave Keller manager of Billings of the Pioneer League, Jim Lett coach of Nashville of the American Association, Dave Miley coach of Vermont, Gary Denbo coach of Tampa of the Florida State League, Rich Bombard coach of Cedar Rapids of the Midwest League and Carl (Doc) Watson coach of Sarasota of the Gulf Coast League. COLLEGES

title: RANGERS AND DEVILS WINNERS
description: Tomas Sandstrom scored three goals tonight to lead the Rangers to an 8-5 victory over the Calgary Flames.

title: CONCERT: RECENT MUSIC AT MERKIN
description: THE emphasis was on the keyboard Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, when the Group for Contemporary Music presented a program of works by Igor Stravinsky, William Hibbard and Stefan Wolpe. Two pianos were on hand, and three pianists - Ursula Oppens, Alan Feinberg and Garrick Ohlsson. Benjamin Hudson was the token violinist.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net non-operating gain of $507,000, recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 1987.

title: FABRICS: STRUDY, HAND-PAINTED
description: MARK FEIGENBAUM, standing, and Raymond Wenzel offer hand-painted textiles they designed. These include sturdy cotton poplin and cotton blended with silk taffeta, said Mr. Wenzel of Marc-Raymond, their company. The fabrics are used for upholsteries, wall coverings and draperies, and can be washed by machine or dry-cleaned. Colors include muted earthy shades of green, terra cotta and beige. The colors can be custom-blend-ed. Patterns include plaids, checks and stripes. Behind the men, and on the left side of the table, is Dreamland, $107.25 a yard; Terra Nova, in Mr. Feigenbaum's hands, is $114, and Double-Check, at right on the table, is $125.25. Galaxy Supernova, right, is $125.25 a yard. Prices range from $67.50 to $125.25 a yard. Marc-Raymond is at 16 West 23d Street. The fabrics are sold through architects and designers.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Holly Sugar Bid Considered
description: Shamrock Holdings of California Inc., an investment firm controlled by the Roy E. Disney family, said that it was considering making an offer to acquire the Holly Sugar Corporation.

title: OFFICIAL KNEW OF INQUIRY
description: New York City's Commissioner of Investigation, Kenneth Conboy, said yesterday that he was aware last month that Bess Myerson had been called before a Federal grand jury in an investigation of the business activities of her regular companion, Carl A. Capasso. But he said that he could not tell Mayor Koch at the time because his office was participating in the investigation.

title: Boston Ballet Begins Renovation Campaign
description: The Boston Ballet has begun a campaign to raise $7.6 million to renovate and expand the turn-of-the-century building that houses its studios and offices.

title: 2 Missing Guns Found At Carolina Army Base
description: Two submachine guns missing since last week have been found and most of more than 500 soldiers at Fort Bragg who had been detained in their barracks during the search have gone back to their normal activities, officials said today.

title: Credit Card Issue By Republicbank
description: A unit of the Republicbank Corporation in Texas yesterday announced plans for a $200 million sale of notes backed by credit card receivables, which it said would be the first public offering of such securities.

title: TOM MORGAN
description: Tom Morgan, a former relief pitcher for the Yankees and one of the original members of the Los Angeles Angels in 1961, died today following complications from a stroke he suffered last week. He was 56 years old.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD RIGHT TO SUE BY PUBLIC HOUSING TENANTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that tenants in federally subsidized, low-income housing projects are entitled to a Federal court hearing on purported violations of their rights under Federal housing law.

title: OPERA: MOORE'S 'BALLAD OF BABY DOE'
description: DOUGLAS MOORE'S ''Ballad of Baby Doe,'' once hailed as a landmark American opera and fondly remembered by many from New York City Opera performances with Beverly Sills in the title role, has not joined the standard operatic repertory, but holds to a spot on its fringe. The Bronx Opera has revived it in a well-managed production heard Sunday afternoon at Lehman College in the company's home borough and bound for the Hunter College Playhouse in Manhattan this weekend. The production does little to overcome the work's weaknesses, but offers a good opportunity to sample its attractions.

title: UNION SAYS INQUIRY CLEARS IT OF BLAME ON PUERTO RICO FIRE
description: Union officials here said today that they had been vindicated by the results of the investigation into the fire that took 96 lives at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

title: For Top Executive, Big Career Change
description: Jane Evans, a leading woman corporate executive, is changing careers. She is joining Montgomery Securities, an investment firm in San Francisco, as a general partner, the firm announced yesterday.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures have been restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock split declared last October.

title: JAPAN'S ZODIAC: '66 WAS A VERY ODD YEAR
description: The Year of the Fire and Horse made its presence known in Japan today.

title: Reagan Recovery Is Hailed
description: President Reagan is ''doing beautifully and is having no problems in any respect'' in his recovery from prostate surgery, his doctor, Col. John Hutton of the Army, said today in a statement.

title: Glenn Odekirk Dead; Builder of Flying Boat
description: Glenn Odekirk, the designer and builder of Howard Hughes's giant flying boat, the Spruce Goose, which flew only once, died of cancer Monday at Nathan Adelson Hospice. He was 81 years old.

title: DECORATING THE STYLISH FLOOR: NEW OPTIONS
description: LEAD: UNLESS they happen to have been designed for Hadrian's villa or Monticello, floors have generally ranked fairly low on home decorating lists. But as imaginative treatments and new materials have appeared, floors are attracting the interest of designers and homeowners.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings and shares outstanding figures are fully diluted.

title: HOWARD BEACH: PATH TO NAMING A PROSECUTOR
description: State officials said today that Governor Cuomo had set three final conditions for appointing a special prosecutor in the Howard Beach case - that the Queens District Attorney publicly call for one, that witnesses who had previously refused to testify now agree to come forward and that the appointment have the public support of black leaders as an acceptable handling of the case.

title: Alexander Leitch Dies at 86; An Ex-Secretary of Princeton
description: Alexander Leitch, secretary of Princeton University for 32 years and a senior administrative officer for another decade, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Pennington, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: ART: 20TH-CENTURY WORKS IN ROYAL ACADEMY SHOW
description: With ''British Art in the 20th Century,'' which opens in London Jan. 15 and can be seen through April 5, the Royal Academy of Arts continues the provocative and controversial investigation of our century's art that was first mooted in ''The New Spirit in Painting'' in 1981 and carried a stage further in ''German Art in the 20th Century'' in 1985. A lively, radical, well-researched, not seldom dismissive and passionately presented anthology, it functions as a revisionist survey not only of British 20th-century art but also of the present role of the Royal Academy itself.

title: CBS INSTALLS TISCH AND PALEY IN POSTS
description: The board of CBS Inc. has cemented the triumph achieved by William S. Paley and Laurence A. Tisch in a board room coup last fall.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter earnings include an after-tax credit of 20 cents per share from a revaluation of its leveraged lease portfolio, as a result of the new tax law.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $3,016,635 net equity securities gains. c-Includes $706,971 net gain on the sale of real estate. Shares outstanding and share earnings have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend declared Dec. 30, 1986 and payable Jan. 15.

title: HEALTHCARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Oil Imports Rose 22% in '86
description: Oil imports last year rose to their highest level since 1980, an oil industry trade group said today, citing the drop in prices in the United States.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last May.

title: THE ART OF GLASS EXPOLORED AT SHOW
description: LEAD: GLASS AMERICA 1987, a new exhibition at the Heller Gallery in New York, provides a unusual look at emerging trends in American studio glass. The gallery director and co-owner, Douglas Heller, has assembled the works of 85 American glass artists from across the country - both famous names and relative newcomers -whose adventurous use of form and innovative design show the breadth and vitality of the movement.

title: Norton to Take Additional Charge
description: The Norton Company, a marketer of abrasives and products for the petroleum and mining industries, said its board had approved an additional $78.5 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings. In addition, Norton said about 300 employees, mostly in Worcester, Mass., would lose their jobs in a consolidation of its ceramics businesses.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SILVERCREST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results are reported on a pro-forma basis.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
NEW STORM DOORS
description: AN alternative to the functional, although not particularly decorative, aluminum storm door might be a storm door made of wood. The Old Wagon Factory in Clarksville, Va., manufactures ornamental storm doors in Douglas fir or poplar. The doors come in numerous designs, including Victorian, Chippendale and styles for the modern home. Custom-made doors are available as well.

title: HERS
description: AT the age of 27 I became the head foreign-exchange options trader at a major commercial bank in New York. I managed hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of options. I ran offices in New York and London. It was a powerful and demanding position.

title: Cars From Thailand
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd. is expected to import as many as 20,000 compact cars from the MMC Sittipol Company of Thailand, a spokesman for the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today.

title: 6,900 IN FARM FEDERATION GET UPBEAT MESSAGE
description: Dean Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, had an upbeat message for his group about American farming this week.

title: Donahue Will Decide
description: Terry Donahue, the head football coach at U.C.L.A., is expected to decide in the next few days whether he wants to take over as coach of the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Rodgers to Run Again
description: On April 26, the day of the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, Bill Rodgers and some other renowned distance runners will be competing in a considerably shorter race.

title: Holland Rejoins Yanks
description: Al Holland, who left the Yankees angrily when they released him last August, will rejoin the team in spring training, trying to pitch his way into an already-crowded left-handed side of the bullpen.

title: ST. JOHN'S OUTCLASSES BROOKLYN
description: Playing without two starters and continuing its search for an outside shooter, St. John's sprinted, then stalled and finally rumbled past Brooklyn College, 70-48, at Alumni Hall last night.

title: SHULTZ ENDS TOUR BY CHIDING LIBERIA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz finished his six-country African tour today with an unusually blunt warning upon his arrival in Liberia, declaring that the Government of President Samuel K. Doe ''must make changes in its economic policy.''

title: Bridge: Ross Spiro Has Twice Been An Elephant-Killer in Jersey
description: It seems very unlikely that a mouse has ever killed an elephant, but the equivalent in bridge terms does occur from time to time: the bottom-seeded team upsets the top seed in the first round.

title: A LIVELIER SOVIET TV KEEPS THE VIEWER'S IN MIND
description: Soviet television this week introduced sign language for the hearing impaired into its main, prime-time newscast, an unusual step in a country where special services for the handicapped are considered primitive by Western standards.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income. The 1986 figures include a writedown of $10.3 million on real estate properties.

title: Panel Releases Export Study
description: The National Academy of Sciences released a report today calling for less Government restriction of high-technology exports, saying that existing rules cost the United States billions of dollars in jobs and trade each year.

title: MANES'S WIDOW ENTERS A BRIBE-RESTITUTION PACT
description: The widow of former Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes has agreed to pay $301,000 to a city meals program for the elderly and the sick as restitution for bribes Mr. Manes is accused of soliciting, the Koch administration said yesterday.

title: RETAIL SALES SURGED BY 4.4%
description: Retail sales surged 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today. The gains were propelled by Christmas shoppers and by car buyers rushing to claim sales tax deductions for the last time.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a gain from a change in accounting principles of $2,051,000. c-Net loss

title: Brooklyn Union And Enron in Pact
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said it had signed a long-term agreement with the Enron Gas Marketing Inc. unit of the Enron Corporation of Houston for more than 230 billion cubic feet of natural gas, or about 25 percent of the company's gas supply. Craig G. Matthews, Brooklyn Union's chief financial officer, said the gas could serve up to 125,000 of its 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: WALL STREET RALLY GETS SECOND WIND
description: Wall Street's two-week-old rally got a second wind yesterday when technology issues led the entire market to another big gain.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR'S PASSION, A PERFUME
description: CAN Elizabeth Taylor's Passion compete with her friend Calvin Klein's Obsession?

title: WIND IS TAKEN OUT OF DICKSON'S SAILS
description: For the second day in a row, Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes led Chris Dickson's New Zealand almost all the way around the 24-mile America's Cup challengers' course, winning by 1 minute 36 seconds.

title: U.S. TO CONSULT WITH PAKISTANIS ON AFGHAN MOVES
description: The United States and Pakistan plan to consult early next week on a common approach toward the seeming Soviet effort to bring about a political settlement to the war in Afghanistan, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: MAYOR OF CHICAGO RETAINING A LEAD
description: Mayor Harold Washington continues to hold a substantial lead in his Democratic mayoral primary race with former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, according to a broadcast poll released tonight.

title: U.S. Judge to Name Receiver For Marcos New York Assets
description: A Federal judge decided yesterday to appoint a receiver to protect Manhattan real-estate assets in a complex lawsuit involving the Government of the Philippines and former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring charges of $323,000 related to shutdown expenses and writedowns resulting from operations terminated and sold during the year for the latest period, and similar charges of $1,236,000 in 1985.

title: South Carolina Inducts Republican Governor
description: Carroll Campbell was sworn in as Governor today, becoming South Carolina's second Republican Governor since Reconstruction. He immediately extended an olive branch to the Democratic-dominated Legislature.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for 13wk to Dec 27
description: b-After a gain from the sale of assets of $3,414,000.

title: The Palestinians Want Their Own Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bozell Quits Account, Sells Houston Office
description: In two other moves yesterday, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt quit about $20 million in McDonald's co-op advertising-association business, and sold its Houston office to a local shop.

title: DANCE: ROSE AND EPSTEIN PRESENT COMIC WORKS
description: IMAGINE a choreographer calling for seven volunteers from the audience to come onstage and be the instruments of a not-so-creative process. Imagine that each volunteer plugs in the headphones of a Walkman and then performs simple movements he or she is instructed to do by the tape. Imagine an audience doubling over with laughter as each ''dancer'' interacts with the others while gesturing as stipulated and some Herbie Hancock music is added. Presto, choreography hits the boards.

title: PENTAGON OFFICIAL, LIKED TO CONTRA AID, TO RETIRE
description: The Defense Department's senior official concerned with Central American affairs, Nestor D. Sanchez, will leave office on Jan. 31 amid reports from Administration and Congressional sources that investigators are questioning the nature of his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring gains of 11 cents per share from real estate sales.

title: HOMELESS REPORT ACCUSES PENTAGON
description: A program to make under-used military facilities available as shelters for the homeless has largely failed because of inaction on the part of the Defense Department, the National Coalition for the Homeless said yesterday.

title: Last Chance in Geneva
description: Either something very important will happen in the arms talks that resume today in Geneva or the talks will soon dissipate into the usual diplomatic minuet. The Russians want action; they have challenged the Administration by appointing an able and influential Deputy Foreign Minister to lead their negotiating team. But the greater challenge is for President Reagan. Time is starting to run out for him; this round of talks may well be his last chance to grasp the historic agreement that he has bargained so well toward.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It would be better if the President would say, 'The buck stops at my desk. If I didn't know I should have known.''' - Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah. [ A12:5. ]

title: 7 WILL BE NAMED TO ETHICS PANEL WITH WIDE POWERS TO INVESTIGATE
description: A bishop, a former newspaper editor and a retired judge are among those who Governor Cuomo will name to a commission with broad powers to investigate ethics in government. The appointments will be formally announced Thursday.

title: Yields Fall On Funds
description: Yields on money market mutual funds began returning to near normal levels for the week ended yesterday, after surging along with the higher Fed funds late in December and earlier this month. During the same week, yields offered by banks and thrift institutions for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were unchanged to slightly lower.

title: NICARAGUA'S COMMUNIST PARTY SHIFTS TO OPPOSITION
description: Nicaragua's small but vocal Communist Party, once allied with the Sandinista Government, has turned to outspoken opposition.

title: Former Felon Elected Sheriff In a South Carolina County
description: A pardoned felon was elected sheriff of McCormick County Tuesday, defeating a former acting sheriff charged with trying to fix the election.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a credit of $35,000 from the purchase of the ocmpany's debentures. The company said the latest quarter sales includes $1,100,000 and net includes $560,000 from favorable settlement of litigation regarding license of certain technology.

title: Is Israel Truly Off the Hook?
description: I found the news welcome indeed: at last, this week, after two months of leaks and open allegations about Israeli involvement in the Iran-contra scandal, the Reagan Administration informed Jerusalem ''that the United States has no intention either to blame Israel or to throw any responsibility onto Israel.'' Unfortunately, it is by no means clear that these assurances will end the scapegoating that began as soon as the first reports of the arms-for-hostages deal became public.

title: DIGITAL NET SOARS 98% IN QUARTER
description: Continuing its remarkable surge while the rest of the industry flounders, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that net income for its second fiscal quarter soared 98 percent, to $270 million.

title: Hialeah Loses Dates
description: ''Do we want to have to explain to the world that we allowed Hialeah to disappear?'' That was the question asked yesterday by Barry Richard, the attorney representing the race track.

title: Stadium Course Criticized by Pros
description: ''There is no way I can have fun on this course,'' said Ben Crenshaw.

title: MEXICO GETTING TOUGH IN WAR ON SMOG
description: The Government has announced a series of new policies on cars in Mexico City intended to reduce automobile-induced smog in one of the world's most polluted cities.

title: CLAYTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Maurice Golubov, 82, Dead; Prominent Abstract Painter
description: Maurice Golubov, an abstract painter, died Saturday at his home in Peekskill, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: PIANO: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY
description: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY is a pianist one would like to hear again, though preferably not in the renovated Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, where he played Tuesday evening. The room's acoustics - always glaring and now more so, especially from the balcony - conspired with the pianist's impressive but overemployed command of the instrument's extreme dynamic possibilities to approach the threshold of pain at some of the fortissimo climaxes. Still, the better side of his accomplishments lingered in the memory once the echoes had died down.

title: MANILA REPORTS ATTACKS BY MOSLEMS IN MINDANAO
description: Fourteen attacks were reported today on the southern island of Mindanao, apparently carried out by a Moslem rebel faction that has been excluded from peace talks between the Government and a larger rival.

title: 19TH-CENTURY GLASS, IN ALL ITS GLORY
description: Walking into the new exhibition of stained glass at the National Building Museum is a bit like walking into the middle of a rainbow.

title: INSIDE
description: Guinness Ousts Chairman The brewer dismissed its chairman in the midst of Britain's worst corporate scandal in years. Two directors were also asked to quit. Page D1. Tisch to Stay at CBS The broadcasting company decided to keep its leaders, Laurence A. Tisch and William S. Paley, on a permanent basis. Page D1.

title: GOTTI PROSECUTORS PALY TAPE, THEN REST CASE
description: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants after playing recordings of a secretly taped conversation in which the reputed underboss of the Gambino crime family berated a captain in the organization for ''disrespecting'' him.

title: Wang Presents Its New Series
description: Wang Laboratories introduced a series of high-end computers today and said that as part of a new strategy it was increasing its sales staff by 25 percent.

title: BENNETT ASSAILED ON EDUCATION CUTS
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett sparred with Republicans and Democrats today in testimony before two Senate committees as he defended his support for cutting the education budget.

title: Pan Am Union Chief Goes On the Offense
description: Margaret Brennan, the chairman of the Joint Labor Council of Pan American World Airways Inc., believes in being prepared.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' nets include an after-tax gain of $8,033,000 from the sale of a portion of the company's interest in Central-Hines. The per share earnings for all periods have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Nov. 18 and paid Jan. 6, 1987, and a special 8 percent stock dividend paid July 1986.

title: PANEL QUESTIONS SCHEDULE ON SHUTTLE CHANGES
description: The space agency will be unable to evaluate or incorporate any safety changes if it tries to meet the target date of Feb. 18, 1988, set for the resumption of space shuttle flights, according to the National Research Council, which has been directed to monitor the shuttle redesign.

title: BRONX EPISCOPAL CHURCH DONATES TO NEEDIEST
description: The Episcopal Church of the Atonement in the Bronx gave $56.62 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company said certain accounts in fiscal 1986 have been reclassified to conform with the fiscal 1987 presentation.

title: Fabled Gymnasium Moves to Brooklyn
description: There is a rough-and-tumble newcomer to the ancient Brooklyn waterfront at Fulton Ferry, whose own rough-and-tumble days began to decline as the Brooklyn Bridge rose, faded further when ferry service ended after almost 300 years and finally gave way to the silence of abandonment.

title: THE STAGE: ONE-ACTS AT PUNCH-LINE
description: IN David Ives's ''Words, Words, Words,'' three actors pretend to be caged monkeys taking part in a laboratory experiment. Mr. Ives suggests that if the monkeys keep typing long enough, sooner or later one of them will write ''Hamlet.'' One monkey (Helen Greenberg) finally begins to write ''Hamlet'' - at least she arrives at the word ''contumely'' - but the other two are so self-involved that they cannot tell the difference between gibberish and Shakespeare.

title: STRYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Learning to Live With the Iran Cloud
description: Before Christmas, some White House officials and Republican lawmakers were talking confidently about getting the Iran arms scandal ''behind us'' early in the new year. Now, the Reagan Administration and its supporters concede that there is no ''big bang'' solution that will bring the problem to a quick end, and that it will continue to cloud life in the capital indefinitely.

title: In the Blood
description: Two years ago, when she was 14, Samantha Toomey of Mission Viejo, Calif., ran 440 yards in 58 seconds, long-jumped 17 feet 5 3/4 inches and triple-jumped 36 feet 10 inches, all in one track meet.

title: AUTO SALES FELL SHARPLY IN FIRST 10 DAYS OF YEAR
description: Sales of cars and light trucks dropped sharply in the first 10 days of 1987, compared with the 1986 period, figures reported by the eight domestic manufacturers indicated today.

title: Whither Griscom?
description: With Marlin Fitzwater moving from Vice President Bush's office to become the chief White House spokesman, the Bush staff is searching for a new press secretary, and one of those featured in early speculation is Thomas C.
