Griscom, who recently completed two years as executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Before that, Mr. Griscom was press secretary to Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, when he was Republican majority leader; and he has had close relations in the past with Lee Atwater, one of the chief Bush strategists.

title: E-Z-EM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
WORLD CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WALTON RE-SIGNED
description: Joe Walton, who guided the Jets to a 10-6 record and a wild-card playoff berth last season, has signed a new contract to remain head coach. Terms were not disclosed. ''Joe and his staff have done an outstanding job overcoming adversity while guiding the Jets to the playoffs the last two years,'' said Jim Kensil, the team president, in a statement.

title: MEXICO TIE TO REPUBLIC WRITE-DOWN
description: The Republic National Bank of New York has become the first of Mexico's major American lenders to write down a significant portion of its Mexican public-sector debt, Wall Street sources say.

title: Jury Grants $138,000 In Self-Levitation Case
description: A jury has awarded nearly $138,000 to a former Transcendental Meditation insructor who charged the movement falsely promised he could learn to fly by using self-levitation techniques.

title: Clevite Sets Sale
description: Clevite Industries said it had entered into a definitive agreement to sell its engine parts division to J. P. Industries for $120 million in cash. The unit had sales of more than $150 million in 1986. The sale is subject to expiration of a waiting period because the Federal Trade Commission has made a second request for information about the deal. Clevite, a maker of transportation and industrial products, said it would lose money on the sale and would record that loss in its fourth quarter. J.P. Industries, which is based in Ann Arbor, Mich., makes plumbing products and transportation parts.

title: Canadian Debut
description: The Farm Credit Corporation of Canada made its debut in the American bond market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.375 to yield 7.59 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. With the backing of the Canadian Government, the notes are rated triple A. The issue is not callable before maturity.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary penalties on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances of $16,311,000 for the quarter and $33,663,000 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary gain of $545,000.

title: Greek Power Workers Strike
description: Greek electricity workers stayed away from their jobs today ahead of a 24-hour general strike that is expected to bring Greece to a standstill over demands for an end to a Government wage freeze. The 48-hour stoppage by 30,000 power workers resulted in blackouts in Athens and northern Greece.

title: PITT EDGES SETON HALL ON SMITH'S BASKET
description: Charles Smith, touted with the ability to develop into one of the nation's best big men, scored only 11 points tonight. But his last 2 represented the game-winning basket in Pitt's 87-85 Big East Conference victory over Seton Hall.

title: URBAN LEAGUE SAYS U.S. POLICIES HURT BLACKS
description: A report released today by the National Urban League asserts that black Americans have been made victims of Reagan Administration policies that are ''morally unjust,'' ''economically unfair'' and have widened the economic and social gap between the races.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADDITIONAL MUNICIPALS ARE COMING TO MARKET
description: The supply of new tax-exempt bonds, which has been very light so far this year, is increasing as interest rates have fallen to levels that encourage local governments and authorities to refinance bonds sold when rates were higher.

title: Boom Time Seen By Early 1989
description: To the Editor:

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
US TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 1.

title: Ski Chase Series Not Just for the Elite
description: The Great American Ski Chase is not a familiar event to most of the American sports public, but this winter it will attract between 12,000 and 14,000 participants.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax benefit of $130,000.

title: S.E.C. Rule Change
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to ease a restriction governing the underwriting of securities offerings by borkerage firms. The rule change would allow a firm to solicit brokered transactions except during a designated ''cooling-off period'' immediately before the offering is completed. That period is either two or nine days, depending on the liquidity of the offering, the S.E.C. staff said.

title: SPECIALTY RETAIL CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10-percent stock dividend paid Oct. 27, 1987, and share earnings results for the latest periods reflect a dilution from the initial offering and issuance of 712,000 common shares as well as the exercise of stock warrants.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus
description: Canada had a trade surplus of $811 million (Canadian) in November, compared with an upwardly revised $946 million surplus in October, the Government said today.

title: Our Persian Gulf Interests
description: In the first month after the Iran arms affair came to light, we saw a steady stream of commentary about the calamitous consequences for our interests abroad. Now, we are hearing from all quarters that an overture to Iran was long overdue. There is nothing wrong with attempting to open channels of communication with Teheran, but we need to keep a clear head about our interests in this part of the world before we rush into any kind of deal.

title: Market Place; Thrift Stock Opportunities
description: WHILE many savings and loan institutions have recently posted record earnings -mainly from taking in more interest than they pay out - in many instances stock prices have failed to reflect those gains.

title: KEY RATES
AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said net income for 1986 included an after-tax gain of $19 million, or $1.19 a share, from gains on sales of securities held in Merabank and Lear Siegler Inc. The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 3-for-2 stock distribution on April 11, 1986.

title: 2 Die in Crash of Air Force Jet
description: An Air Force passenger jet crashed and burst into flames shortly after takeoff today, killing two people and injuring a third, who was pulled from the wreckage before it exploded, officials said.

title: Crude Oil Prices Gain On Saudi-Soviet Move
description: Crude oil prices moved higher on world markets yesterday in the wake of a Saudi Arabian diplomatic initiative to the Soviet Union and growing support for oil prices in the $18-to-$20-a-barrel range among key oil-producing countries outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Bodies of Two More Women Found in Washington Suburb
description: Investigators searching a wooded area for clues to the death of a woman found over the weekend discovered the bodies of two other women Tuesday, bringing to five the number of women found dead in the same area of suburban Washington in the last month.

title: Game Plan for Party
description: Most of the Giants' season-ticket holders will be unable to obtain Super Bowl tickets. But all of them will soon be mailed an invitation to a celebration of the 1986 season that will be held on Jan. 27 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority is organizing the event, hoping to raise private funds to help pay for the post-Super Bowl party.

title: Dressing Pork for Success
description: SOME health experts consider pork a red meat rather than a white meat. The National Pork Producers Council, however, prefers to go along with the dictionary, which lumps pork right in the white meat category along with chicken and turkey, meats with a steeper growth curve.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPPORTERS SAY PRESIDENT OWES APOLOGY ON IRAN
description: Many of the Republican lawmakers investigating the Iran-contra affair, including some of President Reagan's strongest supporters in Congress, now say they believe the President should take full responsibility for his Administration's mistakes, apologize to the American public and appeal to the people to forgive him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 15, 1987
description: The Economy

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PARIS IMPORT Dixon Place had its origin a couple of years ago in Paris in the form of a dinner party for a few women friends. They listened as one read a short story, and such a good time was had that the experience was repeated weekly, with a variety of performing and visual artists participating. The place was an apartment belonging to the Dixon publishing family.

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said a special charge of $3.5 million, before taxes, or $1.9 million, after taxes, was recorded in the second quarter of fiscal 1986. The company decided to consolidate its Waukegan plant's keyboard design and manufacturing at its West German facility.

title: Last Copper Is Poured At a Polluting Smelter
description: Four workers today cast the last copper to be poured at the Phelps Dodge Corporation's aging smelter, which is being closed because pollution controls would be too costly.

title: BREAKING ROUTINE: VOICE OF THE SUBWAY
description: Habitues of the No. 1 line recognize Harry Nugent's voice, with its hint of raspiness and lilting, almost Anglicized intonation. The 26 stations along the conductor's route are not mere subway stops but opportunities to reflect on the diversions above ground and the efficiency with which his train will reach them.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $24.3 million. The company said the prior year loss includes a $46.7 million after-tax writedown of coal assets.

title: INSPIRATONAL IDEAS FROM EUROPE'S BEST
description: THERE are gardeners who are as rooted to their plot of ground as any plant they cultivate. Suggest a trip that involves two days from home and they will find it impossible: who would water the petunias? Some who wrap themselves in their private visions work wonders. Uncontaminated by outside influences, they create personal gardens of powerful charm, naive perhaps, but sometimes coherent and articulate as only single-mindedness can make them.

title: DRUG TRACE FOUND IN 2 CONRAIL WORKERS AFTER FATAL CRASH
description: The two men operating three Conrail locomotives that moved past a closed switch and were struck by a speeding Amtrak train used marijuana before the fatal accident, Federal railroad officials said today.

title: OFFICER WITH MISSING WIFE SUSPENDED AFTER THEFT ARREST
description: A New York City police officer whose estranged wife has been missing since August was suspended from duty without pay yesterday after he was charged with using a forged withdrawal slip to steal almost $18,000 from her bank account after she disappeared, the authorities said.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
That Sticky Salary Wicket
description: In theory, it looked easy, maybe even too easy. A blue-ribbon commission would propose pay increases for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior Federal employees. The President would review the proposals, perhaps modify them a bit and transmit them to Congress. Then, without any member of Congress needing to lift a finger, the raises would take effect automatically in 30 days unless both houses passed resolutions of disapproval.

title: JAZZ: OLIVER LAKE QUARTET
description: IN recent years, the alto saxophonist Oliver Lake has generally played either modern jazz with the World Saxophone Quartet or funk-reggae with his group, Jump Up. But through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, below 10th Street, he is leading a daring jazz quartet that includes the pianist Geri Allen and the drummer Pheeroan ak Laff (who play on Mr. Lake's new album, ''Gallery'') and the bassist Santi DeBriano.

title: Treasury Bonds Drop Again
description: Treasury bond prices declined yesterday for a third consecutive day, as developments in the domestic economy and foreign exchange markets reduced demand from investors and speculators.

title: LEARNING INTERIOR DESIGN
description: THE latest addition by the School of Visual Arts to its comprehensive art curriculum is a series of interior design workshops that will run through January. In the spring, related full-length courses will be offered.

title: A MINISTER, A PORTFOLIO AND JOKES
description: Wearing a mortarboard with a comic yellow tassel, Hans-Dietrich Genscher told a fictional anecdote about his appearance before the Bonn parliamentary committee that investigated payoffs by the giant Flick concern.

title: NOTORIETY OF THE QUEENS ATTACK BUILDS ON ANGER LEFT FROM EARLIER ASSAULTS
description: The Howard Beach assault, far from being an unusually grievous case, is disturbingly similar to other incidents of racial violence in New York City in recent years. Yet a combination of factors beyond the incident itself has elevated this case to a notoriety unlike that of any other.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Gains on sales of investment securities totaled $24.2 million for the latest quarter, compared to $32.5 million for the year-ago period, and for the latest year gains totaled $148.4 million, against $129 million for the previous year. Foreign exchange trading profits for the latest fourth quarter totaled $18.7 million, compared to $33.5 million for the year-ago period, and the profits for 1986 rose to $103.2 million from $101.5 million in 1985.

title: FLORIDA GOVERNOR LOBBYING TO OUST FEDERAL PROSECUTOR
description: Gov. Bob Martinez is lobbying the White House and Congress to replace a United States Attorney who accused the Governor of lying to a jury, the latest in a series of actions that have put the prosecutor at odds with key figures in Florida politics and business.

title: REMOVAL OF OMAHA MAYOR STIRS PRIDE AND SADNESS
description: ''If you want to know who runs things here,'' an Omaha native the other day, ''just look at the board of Ak-Sar-Ben.'' Ak-Sar-Ben, which is Nebraska spelled backward, is the name of the local horse-racing track, and the seats on its board of directors are usually filled with executives of the city's leading industries.

title: ABINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There were no per share earnings for the latest year and both year-ago periods because the bank converted to a stock form of ownership on June 18, 1986.

title: Alyson Pou to Perform
description: Alyson Pou, the performance artist, will present ''The Garden, the Fall, the Tea Party'' next Thursday through Jan. 24 at 8:30 P.M., at Franklin Furnace, 112 Franklin Street. The multimedia work has choreography by Tamar Rogoff, with text and visual imagery by Ms. Pou. Admission is $6. Information: 925-4671.

title: AS TRUCE BEGINS, AFGHAN CAPITAL SHOWS ITS VISITORS A RELAXED FACE
description: For a city surrounded by a war, this arid capital tucked amid the snow-covered Hindu Kush mountains seemed strangely placid today as Government forces prepared to begin a unilateral cease-fire.

title: Sinatra Recovering From a 2d Operation
description: Frank Sinatra was reading and resting easily today after an operation stemming from the removal last November of an abscess and a foot-long section of his intestines, hospital officials said.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
OPERETTA: A MODERN 'MIKADO'
description: THE most splendid of many eye-catching moments in the Stratford (Canada) Festival's modernized, thrillingly kinetic production of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado'' comes in the second act, when the title character makes his grand entrance.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Curbside Improvements; Parking Turnaround
description: Mentioning New York City's Parking Violations Bureau still evokes the extortion and bribery scandal. But under the new management brought in by Mayor Koch last January, the P.V.B. is emerging as an honest enforcement agency unusually responsive to the public's needs. For a laudable turnaround under trying circumstances, its director, Joseph Bruno, and his deputies deserve a shiny apple.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Schmidt, a relief pitcher, became a free agent when the Chicago White Sox did not tender him a contract. Yesterday, Schmidt reached agreement with the Baltimore Orioles on a one-year contract. . . . The State Supreme Court in Queens County dismissed a lawsuit brought against the New York Racing Association by Don MacBeth, a jockey. MacBeth filed suit after a spill at Aqueduct on April 5, 1986, in which MacBeth was injured.

title: PLATH CASE: A CLASH OF RIGHTS
description: The Bantam paperback edition of Sylvia Plath's 1961 novel ''The Bell Jar'' - about a young woman, her friends, their ambitions, emotional problems and suicide attempts -now in its 57th reprinting, is only 200 pages long.

title: MARKETING 'TOP GUN' CASSETTE
description: When ''Top Gun,'' the No. 1 box-office success of 1986, is released on video cassette March 11, it will be accompanied by a marketing campaign worth $8 million. This is as much or more than is usually spent to send a new movie into theaters, and millions of dollars more than has ever been spent to advertise a new video cassette.

title: Going Out on Top
description: Charlie Joiner, the San Diego Chargers wide receiver who announced his retirement Monday after 18 National Football League seasons, leaves as the career leader in both receptions and receiving yardage. But Steve Largent of Seattle, who gained 1,070 yards on 74 catches last year, could pass Joiner in both departments if he has a similarly successful season in 1987. The five career leaders in each category: RECEPTIONS Seasons Total Charlie Joiner 18 750r Steve Largent* 11 694 Charley Taylor 13 649 Don Maynard 15 633 Raymond Berry 13 631 RECEIVING YARDAGE Charlie Joiner 18 12,146 Don Maynard 15 11,834 Steve Largent* 11 11,129 Harold Jackson 16 10,372 Lance Alworth 11 10,266 *Active

title: CRAFTSMEN MELDING METAL AND CREATIVITY
description: AUGUST of winter air blows beneath the wooden garage door at James Garvey's blacksmith shop in TriBeCa, where his one-story blue building sits among the looming old warehouses of Franklin Street.

title: Talking Deals; Merger Games, Play-by-Play
description: CORPORATE takeovers have become a spectator sport. The business world follows these predatory dealings today with the same fascination shown professional football games, as the press provides play-by-play accounts and dazzling descriptions of tactics and personalities.

title: ZYTEC COMPUTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $203,000. c-Net loss

title: ROCKETS DISCUSS DRUG TEMPTATION
description: On Tuesday morning, the Houston Rockets were stunned by the news that two of their teammates - Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins - had been banned from the National Basketball Association after testing positive for cocaine.

title: Sales Up 3.8% At City Stores
description: December sales among several of New York's biggest stores rose by an average of 3.8 percent in the city and 5.8 percent in the metropolitan area from the period a year ago, a spot-check found.

title: 'REMEMBRANCE' HONORS MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.
description: IT is no disrespect to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to report that tonight's birthday tribute, ''In Remembrance of Martin,'' on Channel 49 at 8 o'clock and on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, is for most of its hour as exciting as you would expect excerpts from memorial services and commemorative meetings to be. The civil-rights leader's co-workers, relatives and admirers, including Coretta Scott King, Julian Bond, John Lewis and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, say all the expected things about how he fought for peace, justice, equality and good will.

title: Deborah and the Giants
description: On Sunday mornings in the fall and winter she was awakened by the bark of the quarterback.

title: 2 Towns Vie for Title Of Nation's 'Icebox'
description: Officials in this little mountain town want to wrest the title of ''icebox of the nation'' from International Falls, Minn., and they are ready to hold a contest to prove their claim.

title: Data Department
description: The American Library Association, concerned from the outset of the Reagan Administration about the President's vow to cut back on the ''blizzard of paper'' produced by the Government, has compiled a six-year chronology that it says shows steadily constricting access to Government information.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL DISPUTES ALLEGATIONS ON PATIENT'S DEATH
description: New York Hospital took issue yesterday with a grand jury report that said ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated mistakes by unsupervised interns and junior residents had resulted in the death of a young woman at the hospital in 1984.

title: CBS CHIEF HAS A SHARP KNIFE
description: From the day in September when he took over as acting president and chief executive of CBS Inc. Laurence A. Tisch made it clear that he thought the company was badly in need of cost-cutting and realignment.

title: Governor Kean's Real Welfare Reform
description: Who says welfare reform is passe? Governor Kean of New Jersey now declares it his top priority for 1987 and he outlines a plan that combines decency, common sense and intelligent research on welfare and poverty. Washington and the country will need to pay attention.

title: SOVIET STRESSING NEW ARMS TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they had learned that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, planned to give a major address Thursday, as arms negotiators from the two sides meet in Geneva.

title: Teen-Agers Seek Guidance From Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. UPSETS ALLIES BY LETTING DOLLAR EXTEND ITS DECLINE
description: The dollar tumbled again today, driven by continued signals from the White House that the Government would not support the currency.

title: MAURY STEIN
description: Maury Stein, a music store operator, big-band musician and brother of the songwriter Jule Styne, died of a heart attack Saturday. He was 76.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 15, 1987
description: International

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted to reflect two 3-for-2 stock splits, paid March 7 and Aug. 1, 1986.

title: STUDY ACCUSING RESEARCHERS OF INACCURACIES IS PUBLISHED
description: A British scientific journal is publishing a long-delayed study that accuses researchers at two American medical schools of writing inaccurate and misleading papers.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIFE ON SAN FRANCISCO'S CROOKED STREET
description: People who live in the expensive homes along crooked Lombard Street complain of congestion and vandalism that accompany the tourists, but they are divided over whether closing the block to traffic is the best answer.

title: GOVERNOR SUED BY L.I. UTILITY ON ATOM PLANT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company asserted in a Federal suit filed today that Governor Cuomo's efforts to block the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant violated the constitutional and civil rights of the company and its stockholders.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Rev. R.M.W. Coonradt, A Pastor
description: The Rev. R. Mark Wallace Coonradt, senior pastor of Rutgers Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side, died Tuesday at the age of 52 after a long illness.

title: GARDENS PAST AND PRESENT
description: English Gardens in Spring, Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; 212-757-0915.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings and shares outstanding do not reflect the 3-for-2 stock split declared Dec. 19.

title: National Car Rental Chooses Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day New York has been designated the agency for National Car Rental, which has been under new ownership since Jan. 1.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Curbside Improvements; 14th Street Sweep
description: A special program that allows property owners in business areas to tax themselves for block improvements is bearing impressive fruit in one Manhattan neighborhood. Twice a day, every day, a seven-person crew armed with brooms and sporting distinctive green and white uniforms sweeps litter from the sidewalks and gutters along the length of 14th Street and around newly refurbished Union Square Park.

title: ATHENS SAID TO AGREE TO PUT TRUMAN STATUE BACK
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was reported today to have agreed to restore a statue of Harry S. Truman, which was dynamited last March by leftist militants, to its original place on a central Athens square.

title: Court Removes Murdoch Bar
description: A court removed an injunction today that had blocked Rupert Murdoch's $1.47 billion bid to acquire the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., Australia's largest newspaper group.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY JEWELRY MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOCTOR DISPUTES PREGNANCY RISKS IN BABY M CASE
description: A neurologist testified today that Dr. Elizabeth Stern, the wife of Baby M's father, had an extremely mild case of multiple sclerosis and faced less than a 5 percent chance that the disease would worsen as a result of childbirth.

title: Morgan Notes
description: J. P. Morgan & Company is offering $200 million of 7 1/2 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.275 to yield 7.605 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Company. Noncallable for five years, the notes carry the highest triple-A ratings from Moody's and S.& P.

title: BLACK OFFICIALS PRAISE GOVERNOR ON HYNES POST
description: Several black elected officials, lawyers and others who have been vocal in their reactions to the Howard Beach racial attack spoke in support yesterday of Governor Cuomo's appointment of a special prosecutor in the case as a ''people's victory.''

title: TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,000. c-Net loss

title: ANTI-AIDS BIAS BY UNDERTAKERS RULED A HUMAN-RIGHTS BREACH
description: Funeral parlors that discriminate against AIDS victims are subject to the same human-rights laws that protect handicapped people, a judge in Manhattan has ruled in a decision that city officials said is the first of its kind.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PENETRATING finishes such as those achieved by old-time craftsmen with linseed-oil have a depth and luster quite unlike those of surface coatings such as varnish or lacquer. They help to accent the natural grain and color of many fine hardwoods, and the finish is much easier to touch up than lacquer or varnish. Also, since there is very little coating on the surface (it soaks into and becomes part of the wood), scratches are not a problem unless they are deep enough to go into the wood.

title: SENATE DELAYS VOTE ON CLEAN WATER ACT AT G.O.P.'S REQUEST
description: The Senate today postponed until next Wednesday a vote on a bill to renew the Clean Water Act in a move to accommodate Republicans who asked that action be delayed so that President Reagan would not have to veto the bill before his State of the Union Message on Jan. 27.

title: WHAT THE DOLLAR'S FALL MEANS
description: As it has all week, the dollar, the most widely used currency in international finance, came under severe attack again yesterday in foreign exchange markets around the world.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGE: Kansas at Oklahoma (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Wake Forest at North Caolina State (TV - ESPN, 9 P.M.) L.S.U. at Alabama (TV -USA, 8 P.M.) Manhattan at Fordham (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 7:30 P.M.) N.Y.U. at Widener (Radio -WNYU-FM 89.1, 7:30 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, at Palm Desert, Calif.

title: Stan Steiner Is Dead at 62; Author, Consultant, Teacher
description: Stan Steiner, a writer whose works dealt largely with American minority groups, particularly Indians and Mexican-Americans, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 62 years old.

title: RACIAL GANG FIGHT IN LOUISIANA
description: About 40 teen-age boys armed with knives, chains and clubs attacked each other in racial gang fighting Tuesday in Algiers, a racially integrated suburb of New Orleans, the authorities said. No injuries were reported

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SALICK HEALTH CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Harry Avirom, 72, Supervisor Of Demolition of Ebbets Field
description: Harry Avirom, the supervisor of the demolition of many New York City landmarks, including Ebbets Field, the old Belmont Park and the Polo Grounds, died of heart disease Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 72 years old and lived in Santa Monica.

title: 'DESIGNER' MODELS PERVADE ELECTRONICS
description: As homes have filled with audio and video equipment of all shapes and sizes, manufacturers are designing it to fit in more stylishly with its surroundings.

title: CHARLES B. FERRIS
description: Charles B. Ferris, an architect and engineer and a retired brigadier general in the Army Reserve, died Sunday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
IF THE PHONE WORKS, IT MUST BE THE IVORY COAST
description: Teodore Codo had a simple choice.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After net of $1.5 million for the quarter and a loss of $7.5 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $6.2 million and $5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and for the 6 months includes an extraordinary charge of $575,000 representing loss on early extinguishment of debt.

title: U.S. SEES SETBACK FOR CHINA'S PLANS OF MODERNIZATION
description: An attack by China's leader on a writer widely seen as the most influential intellectual figure to have emerged since the Cultural Revolution could undermine China's modernization program by frightening many intellectuals, State Department officials and other specialists said today.

title: CONTRA AID: LOOSE LAW?
description: Some Congressional Democrats and Republicans now acknowledge that the laws they drafted restricting aid to the Nicaraguan rebels last year were so loosely written that they offered the Reagan Administration many opportunities to test their legal limits and to find loopholes.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,277,000 for the quarter and income of $8,733,000 from discontinued operations for the year. The company said share earnings for the first 9 months of 1986 and all prior periods have been restated, reflecting the Oct. 7, 1986 recapitalization of the company, as if there had been an 8.3913-for-1 stock split. The latest periods included an interest before taxes charge of $41,437,000 for the quarter and $55,978,000 for the year, compared to $472,000 for the year-ago quarter and $5,607,000 for 1985.

title: West Point Cadet Earns His Star
description: In and around the Multi-Purpose Sports Facility at West Point, N.Y., the story has been circulated so many times that its time and place are occasionally forgotten or confused. On a basketball court at Fort Knox, Ky., in the summer of 1985, a group of enlisted men gathered for a pickup game. When they chose sides, they overlooked a cadet who had also wanted to play.

title: McReynolds Agent Asks Mets for Raise
description: Kevin McReynolds made his first appearance in New York yesterday as the newly anointed left fielder of the Mets, and his agent wasted no time disclosing that he and the Mets were ''several hundred thousand dollars apart'' in negotiations on a contract.

title: Summing It Up
description: The Hartford Whalers, who had lost four straight games before playing the Boston Bruins last night, may have been experiencing a midseason slump. But Coach Jack Evans, according to an Associated Press interview in which he described his team's plight, was still able to display metaphorical wizardry: ''As of late, our whole game has gone sour. You fill a hole one place and it crops back up in another place. Until recently, we'd been working well on all cylinders.''

title: Soviet Consulate in Montreal Seriously Damaged in a Fire
description: A blaze engulfed the Soviet consulate today, but diplomats kept firemen outside for 15 minutes while they grabbed documents and tried to put out the fire with extinguishers and buckets of snow, witnesses and fire officials said.

title: Caterpillar to Take $109 Million Charge
description: Caterpillar Inc. said today that it would report a pretax charge of $109 million against fourth-quarter earnings resulting from the proposed closing of three plants that would idle about 3,000 workers in Iowa, Oregon and Scotland.

title: U.S. Bridges for Costa Rica
description: A unit of 247 United States Army engineers will begin building seven bridges in Costa Rica this month, the Public Security Ministry said. A ministry statement on Tuesday said construction of two large bridges and five small ones in the southern Pacific coast region would allow year-round use of a highway that was often closed by floods.

title: CUOMO SUPPORTS BROAD REVISION OF LAW ON MILK
description: Governor Cuomo today endorsed a sweeping revision of New York's milk-licensing regulations, aimed at opening the state's milk markets to free competition for the first time in half a century.

title: AMNESTY, SENDING FEARFUL ALIENS FOR HELP, ONLY SOME OF IT USEFUL
description: When Ruben Montemayor, a lawyer in San Antonio, considers the nation's new immigration law, he does not see an open door to legal status for aliens eligible for amnesty. Instead, he sees what most of his clients do: a tantalizing quest full of great risks, demands and rewards.

title: Reagan's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: TEHRAN REPORTS OPENING 2D FRONT
description: Iran said today that it had opened a second front in its six-day-old offensive against Iraq, as fierce fighting continued near the southern Iraqi city of Basra and Iraqi bombers pounded Iranian cities.

title: Koch Urged to Reject Plan to Limit Traffic
description: Civic, business and labor leaders urged Mayor Koch yesterday to reject draft proposals by the city Department of Transportation to reduce traffic and adhere to Federal air-pollution standards.

title: 154 AT THE NEW YORKER PROTEST CHOICE OF EDITOR
description: In an unusual public protest, 154 writers, cartoonists and editors for The New Yorker - including the reclusive J. D. Salinger - asked Robert A. Gottlieb to withdraw his acceptance as editor of the magazine.

title: OPERA: KLEIBER CONDUCTS 'OTELLO' AT CONVENT GARDEN
description: This is the ''Otello'' centenary year; Verdi's masterpiece was first performed on Feb. 5, 1887, at La Scala in Milan. To honor that anniversary, the reclusive conductor Carlos Kleiber, who has made ''Otello'' one of his few specialties, is leading new productions of the opera this month at London's Royal Opera at Covent Garden and, starting on Feb. 5, at La Scala itself. Both productions offer the leading Otello of the present day, Placido Domingo.

title: PAN AM, AMERICAN SAID TO TALK
description: American Airlines is holding talks with Pan American World Airways to determine whether it wants to buy that carrier, which is ailing but still has valuable international routes, sources close to both companies said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: KAMIKAZE CREW
description: WEARING marching-band uniform jackets and baggy pants, the Kamikaze Ground Crew were dressed to match their music - mixing precision and drollery - on Monday at Dance Theater Workshop. The concert opened the workshop's fortnightly Bands on the Run music series.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Amounts have been restated to include American Bancorp Inc., acquired Dec. 31, 1985 and First Kentucky Bancshares Inc., acquired March 31, 1986. The acquisitions have been accounted for as poolings-of-interest.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gold Rises as Dollar Dives
description: As the dollar plunged yesterday to another six-year low against the West German mark in heavy and often hectic trading, gold prices climbed further.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Fly Me Again Scores With Stretch Drive: Fly Me Again rallied wide through the stretch to prevail in a driving finish yesterday in the $45,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Carrying 112 pounds, Fly Me Again went a mile and an eighth in 1:50 3/5 on the fast track under Chris Antley to reach the wire a neck ahead of Belocolus. Fly Me Again earned $27,000 for Viola Sommer and returned $7.20 for $2 to win. Tennis Lendl and Navratilova Advance: Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova, the top-seeded players, moved into the third round of the $1.65 million Australian Open championships, but three other seeded players were eliminated. Lendl, seeking his first Grand Slam victory on a grass court, breezed to a 6-4, 3-6, 6-1, 6-1 second-round victory over Danny Saltz. Navratilova, the defending women's champion, needed only 38 minutes to beat a fellow American, Jamie Golder, 6-0, 6-2. Boris Becker of West Germany, seeded second, squandered 4 match points in the fourth-set tiebreaker and was even at two sets each with Brod Dyke, an unseeded Australian, when their match was halted by darkness. Kelly Evernden, a New Zealander ranked 289th in the world, stunned Johan Kriek of the United States, a two-time winner of this tournament, 6-2, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) Track and Field Fastest Indoor Time: Truman High School's girls' distance-medley foursome posted the fastest indoor time in the country this season, winning the event in 12 minutes 41.6 seconds at Froz Fruit-Metropolitan Athletics Congress Relays at Manhattan College's Draddy Gym. Members of the Truman medley were Monique Stokes, Monifa Taylor, Camille Slappy and Moutique Jones. Over all, the Bronx school won four events and the team title with 27 points. In the boys' division, Bishop Loughlin's distance-medley team of Kenny Lewis, Jean Boulet, Jason Williams and Lance Smith finished first in a good time of 10:35.3. Uniondale of Long Island edged DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx, 17-16, for the boys' title. Soccer Sidekicks 5, Express 4: Marcio Leite scored three goals, including the game winner with 41 seconds remaining, to give Dallas the victory over New York last night at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. (AP) N.H.L. North Stars 3, Maple Leafs 2: Brian MacLellan scored at 7 minutes 20 seconds of the second period to break a 2-2 tie, and Don Beaupre stopped 38 shots to lead Minnesota last night at Toronto. Ron Wilson and Dino Ciccarelli also scored for Minnesota. Ciccarelli's goal was his 33d of the season and 16th on the power play. (AP) Jets 4, Penguins 3: At Pittsburgh, Steve Rooney scored his first goal with Winnipeg at 13:20 of the third period to provide a 4-1 lead, beating Gilles Meloche with a shot from the top of the left circle. (AP) Whalers 3, Bruins 1: John Anderson had a goal and two assists for Hartford, which ended a four-game losing streak. The loss, at Hartford, was the Bruins' fourth in five games.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 96, Hawks 93: Jeff Ruland returned to the 76ers' lineup after missing 34 games with an injured knee to score 19 points. He was injured in the second game of the season against Atlanta Nov. 2. Ruland played only 24 minutes, in line with his doctor's instructions to Coach Matty Guokas. Charles Barkley, who had 24 poitns for the 76ers, shot 10 of 11 from the field and had 20 rebounds, 4 assists and 3 blocked shots.(AP) Pistons 104, Cavaliers 87: At Pontiac, Mich., Adrian Dantley scored 26 points and Sidney Green added 22 to lead Detroit to its fifth consecutive victory.(AP) Celtics 117, Mavericks 108: At Boston, Larry Bird scored 14 of his 25 points in a decisive third period for the Celtics. Kevin McHale also had 25 points, and Danny Ainge had 24 in Boston's ninth victory in the last 10 games.(AP)

title: CABARET: TODD STOCKMAN
description: WHILE ventriloquism remains a popular art form associated in the public mind with children's entertainment, a handful of performers are nudging ventriloquism into territory where hand puppets and dummies become adult alter egos.

title: Last Year's Scandal
description: Scandalmongers keen to follow every jot and tittle of the illegal diversion of arms profits have all but forgotten the first blot on the Reagan escutcheon - the abuse of access by the former White House aide Michael Deaver.

description: The year-ago share earnings figures were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last July.

title: GUINNESS OUSTS HEAD IN SCANDAL
description: Guinness P.L.C. dismissed its chairman and demanded the resignation of two directors tonight amid indications that the British Government is widening its investigation of the big brewing company.

title: US Sprint Rate Cut
description: The US Sprint Communications Company, responding to lower long-distance telephone rates recently announced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that it too would lower its rates. The Sprint reductions on long-distance services would be 9 percent for residential consumers, 13 percent for businesses, effective Feb. 1. ''We plan to continue to be competitive by offering our customers lower rates than A.T.&T.,'' a company spokesman said.

title: S.E.C Ban on Insider
description: Robert Salsbury, a former arbitrage analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has been barred from the securities industry for three years in the settlement of Securities and Exchange Commission charges arising out of his participation in an insider-trading ring.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $2.24 million for the latest quarter and $617,000 for the year-ago period. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in December. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SWAN LAKE'
description: THE current setting for ''Swan Lake,'' which was performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, has suggested to balletgoers everything from strip mines to glistening caverns.

title: URBAN HOMICIDE RATES IN U.S. UP SHARPLY IN 1986
description: Homicides in some of the nation's largest cities rose sharply last year as officials grappled with an increase in shootings among teen-agers and the seemingly intractable spread of cocaine and its derivative, crack.

description: Scores of entertainers ranging from Jim Dale to Bernadette Peters to Milton Berle to the Radio City Music Hall Rockettes plan to converge at Lincoln Center for a gala $500,000 fund-raising benefit, Nathan Leventhal, the center's president, announced yesterday.

title: Reputed Mafioso Shot At a Club in Brooklyn
description: Several gunmen wearing ski masks rushed into a Brooklyn social club late last night and shot and critically wounded Salvatore Scarpa, a reputed member of the Colombo crime family, the police said.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about immigration visas incorrectly listed the three Soviet republics eligible for such visas. The three are Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania; Liechtenstein is a sovereign European nation outside the Soviet bloc.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and after a write-off of goodwill of $13,664,000 for the year.

Tenneco Offers 9 3/8% Debentures
description: Tenneco Inc. yesterday offered $350 million of 9 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The size of the sale was increased from $250 million. The debentures are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: CHINA EXPELS A TOP SHANGHAI WRITER FROM PARTY
description: A nationwide crackdown on dissident intellectuals continued today with an official announcement that a prominent Shanghai writer had been expelled from the Communist Party.

title: Giants Notebook; Taylor Steals Show at Garden
description: Giants mania continues in the metropolitan area. Lawrence Taylor received an ovation unlike any other at Madison Square Garden. Phil McConkey was chosen as the fall guy for a benefit roast expected to attract more than 1,500 people.

description: CBS Magazines yesterday agreed to sell George A. Hirsch's creation, The Runner magazine, to Rodale Press, where it will be merged into the older Runner's World, with Mr. Hirsch becoming publisher.

title: HUNTER IN HALL WITH WILLIAMS
description: Billy Williams of the Chicago Cubs, who fell four votes short last year even though he hit 426 home runs in the big leagues, was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame last night along with Jim (Catfish) Hunter, one of the best money pitchers of his time for the Oakland A's and the Yankees.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RULING SPURS EFFORT TO LET VETERANS HIRE LAWYERS
description: A Federal judge's finding that officials of the Veterans Administration unlawfully destroyed thousands of documents is likely to revive a drive in Congress to alter a century-old system that limits veterans in pressing appeals, veterans' and Congressional spokesmen say.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE $1 LEAGUE: The Rise and Fall of the USFL. By Jim Byrne. 352 pages. Prentice Hall. $17.95. FIRST DOWN AND A BILLION: The Funny Business of Pro Football. By Gene Klein and David Fisher. Illustrated. 300 pages. Morrow. $17.95. JIM BYRNE'S ''$1 League'' begins at the pro football stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands that is home of the Super Bowl-bound New York Giants. But it is not a story of winning that Mr. Byrne relates. The opening scene is the last game ever played by the United States Football League, which has managed in its career so far to spread misery everywhere and lose nearly $200 million.

title: CONTRACTOR IS INDICTED OVER TAXES
description: Carl A. Capasso, a major contractor for New York City, was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he evaded $774,600 in corporate and personal taxes by manipulating his company's records of expenses on city projects.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHEMICAL UP 4.9%; CONTINENTAL GAINS
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, reporting its second consecutive quarter of disappointing results, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose just 4.9 percent, to $102.4 million, from $97.6 million.

title: PORTRAIT OF ELDERLY: STILL INDEPENDENT DESPITE LIMITATIONS
description: MOST Americans age 65 and older do not have private pensions and rely on Social Security, according to a study conducted by Louis Harris & Associates for the Commonwealth Fund's Commission on Elderly People Living Alone. Although their incomes are limited, most of the elderly do not receive money from their children; in fact, they are four times more likely to give regular financial assistance to their children than they are to receive it.

title: 2 WHITES ARE ATTACK VICTIMS
description: A 17-year-old white Brooklyn youth and a 24-year-old white Staten Island man were assaulted by black and Hispanic youths in two separate incidents, which the police described yesterday as racially motivated.

title: MERGERS SPUR NEW STRATEGIES IN RETAIL INDUSTRY
description: The recent wave of mergers and divestitures in the retail industry is forcing many merchants to re-examine their strategies, both to take advantage of business and personnel opportunities and to defend themselves in a tough new arena.

title: King's 'Dream' Is Kept at a Distance
description: During the national holiday Monday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., we will no doubt hear a number of high-toned official pronouncements that his legacy lives on. But the tributes to Dr. King, whose chief goal at the time of his death was to end poverty, are painfully ironic when viewed alongside the harsh facts about the growing numbers of poor and powerless in this country.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes significant and unusual transactions, including the sale of Kissell Co., a mortgage banking concern, which increased net income $3.5 million, or 7 cents per share. c-Includes gains from significant and unusual transactions which increased the net by $14.8 million, or 30 cents per share.

title: Q & A
description: Q.I used rubbing alcohol to remove a gummy adhesive (left when a price tag was removed) from a marble table top. Unfortunately, the alcohol also left a dull-looking spot. How can I restore the finish? A.Chances are that the marble was originally protected with a coat of wax or some type of sealer. The alcohol probably removed this coating along with the adhesive residue. I suggest you contact the manufacturer or dealer to see if you can find out what kind of wax or sealer was used. If you cannot get this information, try applying a thin coat of white paste wax and then buff vigorously. Or you can try one of the sealers sold by marble dealers for just this purpose. Q.We may buy a house with yellow aluminum siding. Although we have been told that aluminum siding cannot be painted, we may decide to attempt it. If we do, how long will the paint last? A.Aluminum siding can be painted. Several paint companies make latex paints designed for use on old, weathered aluminum siding. Other companies specify on their paint labels that their latex house paints can be used on this type of siding. Most do not require a special primer, but check the instructions on the label and follow these closely -especially on the preparation required before applying the paint.

title: HINCKLEY HAD 12-HOUR HOSPITAL PASS, AGENTS SAY
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Reagan and three others in 1981, left the grounds of the mental hospital where he is confined on a 12-hour pass for a reunion with his family last month, the Secret Service said today.

title: Reagan's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Heimlich is Dead at 99
description: Philip Heimlich, a retired social worker who founded a program to assist troubled youths, died Dec. 30 in Cincinnati, where he had lived for 12 years. He was 99 years old.

title: FALSE BIDS WERE CALLED, CHRISTIE'S JURY IS TOLD
description: In an auction of eight Impressionist paintings at Christie's in May 1981, six of the pictures received no bids at all from potential buyers, although the auctioneer called several apparent bids for each of the pictures from the podium.

title: NETS DO NOT FEEL AT HOME ON ROAD
description: In the brightest moments of a generally dreary season, the Nets always seemed to point to their defense, the one facet of their game that had become dependable. But even that failed them tonight, and now they are staring at another forgettable losing streak.

title: Runners Go To Head of Class
description: At first glance, it should not appear especially surprising that the team from the new Paul Robeson High School in Brooklyn has qualified for the Public School Athletic League Mile Relay at the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 30. Robeson's predecessor, after all, had a long and glittering athletic tradition.

title: STAGE: 'DAVID LEVINSKY,' AN IMMIGRANT'S STORY
description: IN ''The Rise of David Levinsky,'' Isaiah Sheffer and Bobby Paul's musical about the Jewish immigrant experience in turn-of-the-century America, Larry Kert bites deeply into a title character who is practically identical to his much smaller role in the recent, ill-fated Broadway show ''Rags.'' But where ''Rags'' failed to make coherent drama out of the story of Eastern European Jews flocking to New York's Lower East Side, ''The Rise of David Levinsky,'' adapted from a novel by Abraham Cahan, presents a sober, historically detailed version of a familiar saga.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $62,000 and $584,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net losses and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $886,000 for both periods and a gain on insurance recovery of $137,000 and $456,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Figures include the results of Graniteville Co. under the equity method in 1986 and on a consolidated basis in 1985.

title: Burmese Sentenced to Hang
description: A 63-year-old woman has been sentenced to hang for trafficking in heroin, the official News Agency of Burma said today. It said the woman, Daw Kyi, was arrested in Mandalay in June 1985 with 7.7 pounds of heroin. Executions for drug offenses are rare in Burma and the woman can appeal against the sentence to a higher court.

title: Resident Status Is Granted To Woman Who Aided Fliers
description: A woman who helped downed Allied fliers escape from Nazi-occupied Belgium in World War II was granted permanent resident status in the United States today and President Reagan urged Congress to make her an American citizen.

description: The Department of Agriculture is seriously considering and expected to act favorably on a proposal from a health-oriented consumer group that it change the name of one classification of beef from Good to Select.

title: The White House Mystique
description: It is next to impossible, given what we know, to conjecture intelligently whether or not President Reagan could have remained ignorant while White House staff members took certain liberties regarding arms to Iran and siphoning the proceeds for the benefit of the contras. But it seems to me that the President could very well have been kept in the dark by staff members who believed they were doing the right thing. For we should not overlook the unpleasant fact that the White House does strange things to people.

title: Carol Perrenot Longone, 94; The Founder of Operalogues
description: Carol Perrenot Longone, the developer of operalogues, a combination of opera and narrative, died of pneumonia Jan. 4 at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 94 years old and had lived in Manhattan since 1924.

description: Iain Murray and his Kookaburra III team survived a dramatic gear failure today within a half-mile of the finish in the America's Cup defense finals and beat Australia IV by 1 minute 34 seconds.

Back From Bulgaria
description: Melvyn Levitsky, now the United States Ambassador to Bulgaria, is returning to Washington to become executive secretary to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He will succeed Nicholas Platt, who is becoming Ambassador to the Philippines. Both men are former deputies of Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, Mr. Platt when Mr. Abrams was Assistant Secretary for International Organization Affairs, Mr. Levitsky when he was Assistant Secretary for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs.

description: Tonight at 8, the Thunderbird American Indians open the aptly named Festival for Raw Space, a monthlong happening to inaugurate the Theater for the New City's new, not-altogether-finished home in the East Village.

description: Preston County Commissioners, who had been trying for more than a week to break a tie and elect a president, today unanimously chose one on the 482d ballot.

description: The Soviet Union said today that reports that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, planned to give a speech today on arms control issues were wrong.

description: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 11.3 percent of the work force in December, from 11.4 percent in the previous month, according to preliminary estimates released by the British Department of Employment.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell by $673.2 million, to $234.09 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $420.9 million, to $65.01 billion. Assets of the 193 general purpose funds dropped $703.8 million, to $62.2 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $451.5 million, to $106.88 billion.

title: Decision in Jockey Case
description: In what it says is the final word on the apprentice jockey weight allowance matter that arose last month, the New York Racing Association has redistributed purse money of approximately $76,000. Seventeen horses were involved. The action was taken after stewards' rulings had disqualified horses that had finished fourth or better in the 53 races in question from Nov. 15 to Dec. 17 last year. The horses had been ridden by four apprentices with a two-pound weight allowance to which they were not entitled because the clerk of scales, Charles Sullivan, had misapplied the rule that reduces their weight allowance from 7 to 5 pounds after each had ridden his 35th career winner. Sullivan was fined $500 by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. The riders will suffer no penalty and bettors are not affected by the rulings.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MAYOR'S LETTER ON PRELIMINARY BUDGET PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's letter to the Board of Estimate, the City Council and the Financial Control Board that accompanied his plan for the next four fiscal years.

title: Trump Condominium Account Lost by Beber
description: Beber Siberstein & Partners of Miami, which lost the Helmsley Hotel business because it also took on the Trump Plaza, now abuilding in Palm Beach, Fla., has now also lost that Trump condominium.

title: SYNBIOTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that latest quarter revenue includes $33,750 from one- time Prutech licensing fees, compared with similar fees of $225,000 in the year-ago third quarter.

BEAN STAYS HOT ON CHILLY DAY
description: Andy Bean asked his wife to ship warm clothes to him two weeks from now, when the AT&T Pro-Am is to be played at the Pebble Beach, Calif., site that usually is cold. Bean never thought he would need the cold-weather gear until then because he anticipated no need for woolens at the two PGA Tour events in southern California and one in Phoenix before Pebble Beach.

title: CUOMO PLEDGES $5 MILLION BUDGET IN ANNOUNCING CORRUPTION PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday promised a budget of $5 million and ''all the resources they need'' to a newly formed state commission to investigate corruption, and ordered the panel to follow ''every lead, no matter where it takes them.''

title: BROADWAY
description: ALMOST anyone would be grateful to have his life saved but, depending on who does the saving, the gratefulness can wear pretty thin. Take, for instance, if the savior is an absolute nerd and if this nerd turns the saved life into a complete shambles.

title: TESTS IN REDESIGN OF SHUTTLE ROCKETS DISCLOSE UNEXPECTED PROBLEMS
description: The National Research Council said today that preliminary tests on improvements for the space shuttle's booster rockets had disclosed unexpected problems that would complicate efforts to repair the shuttle for relaunching in February 1988.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As recent unfortunate events have demonstrated, we cannot be complacent about racism and bigotry.'' - President Reagan. [ A12:5. ]

title: DOUGLAS SIRK, MADE 'MAGNIFICENT OBSESSION'
description: Douglas Sirk, the director whose Hollywood melodramas included ''Magnificent Obsession'' and ''Written on the Wind,'' died Wednesday in Lugano at age 86.

title: BUTLER, JOHN O CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Comings and Goings
description: Mel Bridgman, the captain of the Devils, has a fracture in his left foot rather than a bruise, which was the original diagnosis. Bridgman was injured Monday night during the victory over the Hartford Whalers, but he finished the game. He missed Wednesday night's victory in Chicago. . . . In a plea-bargaining agreement, Michael Dokes, a former World Boxing Association champion, pleaded guilty in Las Vegas, Nev., to possession of a controlled substance, cocaine. Dokes, who was arrested last Oct. 6, will be sentenced Feb. 26 and faces a maximum of six years in prison and a $5,000 fine.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT ARRESTED BY BONN
description: The West German authorities have arrested a Lebanese whom they believe to be one of two men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines plane to Beirut in June 1985. After the hijacking, 39 Americans were held hostage for 17 days.

title: PONCE FEDERAL BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DETROIT ABUZZ ABOUT IACCOCA DIVORCE PLANS
description: A group of automotive executives and companions were having dinner before the Detroit Auto Show last week and the conversation ran to the usual topics: sales, new models and potential bonuses. Then the group was joined by an official of a California-based car company who immediately blurted out: ''I don't care about any of that. I want to know what the inside story is: Are Peggy and Lee getting back together?''

title: CONVICTED CRIME CHIEF CHARGED IN BID RIGGING
description: A convicted Mafia boss and several associates were charged yesterday with rigging bids on more than $30 million worth of concrete work for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

description: For some, giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund took precedence over giving Christmas presents to family members and friends.

title: FILM: RICHARD PRYOR IN 'CRITICAL CONDITION'
description: RICHARD PRYOR impersonates a doctor in ''Critical Condition,'' a frantic mess of a movie that tries to offer a microcosmic view of modern medicine. It takes place in a New York City hospital during a power failure, and has a screenplay by John and Denis Hamill, whose last big idea was about the graffiti-writing Robin Hood of ''Turk 182!''

title: OFFICIALS WARN OF GAPS IN INSURANCE FOR AGED
description: Federal and state officials are increasingly showing concern about the grave financial risks facing millions of elderly Americans who wrongly believe they are covered by insurance for long-term health care.

title: TREASURY BONDS RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Treasury bond prices rose slightly yesterday, following the lead of the foreign exchange market, where the dollar improved against major foreign currencies.

title: C.B.A. Suspensions
description: The Mississippi Coast Jets of the Continental Basketball Association have dropped from their roster Billy Goodwin and Bobby Parks after they refused drug testing ordered by the league, The Sun Herald in Biloxi, Miss., reported yesterday. According to the Jets' owner, Ted Stepien of Cleveland, the players informed Coach Keith Fowler yesterday morning that they would not submit to urinalysis set for later in the day in Denver, where league offices are situated. ''After Keith told me that, I said I have to support the position of the commissioner. He has suspended them and they have to leave the team,'' Stepien told the newspaper. Goodwin, who played for St. John's University, and Parks, formerly with Memphis State, are the team's leading scorers. They were suspended by the league last weekend after their arrests in Pensacola, Fla., on charges of cocaine and marijuana possession. They face a Jan. 29 court date in Pensacola on second- and third-degree felony charges. Parks refused to comment when contacted, and Goodwin was unavailable for comment.

title: REAGAN BILL ASKS FLEXIBILITY IN FUNDS FOR BILINGUAL EDUCATION
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed legislation that would give local school districts flexibility in using Federal funds for remedial language programs for children with limited proficiency in English.

title: Farmer Knows the Market
description: At age 40 he's now in the Hall of Fame, but Jim (Catfish) Hunter is younger than two of the pitchers in the Yankees' rotation, Joe Niekro and Tommy John. And when he put on a Yankee cap yesterday for the cameras in the Sheraton Centre, he had the trim look of somebody who could still pitch. With his grayish mustache, he remains the elegant farmer from Hertford, N.C., with a 224-166 record who taught baseball the value of signing free agents, a lesson the club owners have forgotten.

title: The Prophecy
description: With a tough schedule ahead and half his roster made up of freshmen, Hal Smith, basketball coach at Malone College in Canton, Ohio, chose ''No Easy Road'' as the team slogan this season. On the Pioneers' first road trip, one of their two vans broke down.

title: SKATING AND SKIING DURING SEAPORT FESTIVAL
description: Lovers of sea and ice might enjoy a trip the the South Street Seaport this weekend for the beginning of a two-week Winter Festival. A temporary ice-skating rink has been set up at Pier 17 for a series of daily shows, beginning today at 5:30 P.M. Bleachers have been set up to accommodate 150 viewers and there is plenty of standing room for the 20-minute shows, which are free; there will also be shows at 6:15 and 7 P.M. today and at 2:30, 3:15 and 4 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Museums

title: Bridge: Deal in World Championship Inspired an Unusual Message
description: There are many ways in which a player can instruct his partner to select one of two specific suits. The selection is normally made on the basis of length, and if the length is equal the choice may be trivial.

title: Insurer Shows Off New Spots
description: THE Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee, which almost by accident discovered the thrill of big-time advertising during the 1972 Olympics, is cutting its 1987 budget back a million dollars so it can make its splash during next year's Olympics that much bigger.

title: F.C.C. SEEKS NEW OWNERSHIP RULES
description: In an effort to bolster struggling AM radio stations, the Federal Communications Commission today proposed a loosening of its ownership rules.

title: 'TELEVISION MAKERS' EXAMINES DIRECTORS AT WORK
description: TELEVISION, we all know, is impossible. Most of the programming we see in prime time is produced on an entertainment assembly line, not unlike the kind that used to churn out movies several decades ago. Budgets are limited, schedules are ridiculously tight, and artistic considerations are not quite as crucial as getting the thing done and moving on quickly to the next project. Yet despite everything, there are periodic flashes of quality and originality. Defying the odds, some talents survive and flourish.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Oliver Lake Quartet, Carlos 1, 452 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets (982-3260). Phrases as dry yet slippery as a rattlesnake come slithering out of Oliver Lake's alto saxophone. But so do gospel-ish celebrations, wry ironies and melodies of love. His quartet, which just made what may well be Mr. Lake's finest album, has the kind of empathy that can't be bought or rehearsed, but certainly can be honed in live performance. So there'll be a lot more going on here than a saxophonist soloing with rhythm accompaniment. The Oliver Lake Quartet plays around 9 and 11 P.M. through Sunday, with a 12:30 A.M. show added tonight and tomorrow. The cover charge is $10, and there is a $7.50 minimum.

title: SPOTLIGHT CONTINUES TO GLOW FOR TYSON
description: Ever since he knocked out Trevor Berbick on Nov. 22 for the World Boxing Council title, Mike Tyson has been in demand.

title: ENIGMATIC HARD-LINER: NAJIB
description: So mysterious is Afghanistan's leader that there is not even agreement about the rendering of his name.

title: CHINESE ACROBATS
description: A display of skill and folk arts will be presented by the Chinese Golden Dragon Acrobats and Magicians of Taipei tonight at 7:30 at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard, in Flushing. The 23-member troupe, directed by Danny Chang, will perform music, dance and acrobatics in elaborate costumes decorated with centuries-old designs. Admission is $9, $11 and $12. Information: (718) 793-8080.

title: TEST FLIGHT OF NAVY'S MISSILE CALLED A SUCCESS
description: A Trident 2 missile designed to be used by submarines was lofted from a launching pad here today on a maiden test flight of the Navy's newest and most powerful rocket. It was a success, the Navy said.

FILM: 'BEDROOM WINDOW,' A THRILLER
description: ONE rainy night after leaving an office party early, Terry Lambert (Steve Guttenberg), a young, cheerfully on-the-loose Baltimore bachelor, returns to his apartment. There, by pre-arrangement, he meets his boss's sexy young wife, Sylvia (Isabelle Huppert), who's also managed to slip away from the festivities. Both having had too much to drink, they proceed to consummate what, for some time, has been a vague yen.

title: Quaker Oats Plans Charge in Closing
description: The Quaker Oats Company said that it would close its pet foods plant in Rockford, Ill., leading to a $20.9 million after-tax charge against earnings. Quaker said the closing was part of its plan to reduce overcapacity resulting from its recent acquisition of Gaines pet food. The Rockford plant, which employs 324 workers, is the oldest of its five pet food units and is unable to produce dry dog food, an area Quaker has chosen as a target for growth. A company spokesman said the plant would be shut by June 30.

title: RESEARCHED CANER VIRUSES
description: Dr. Charlotte Friend, a medical microbiologist who made major contributions to the understanding of cancer during a career that spanned almost four decades, died Tuesday after a long illness. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The per share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid yesterday.

title: VOLUME IS RECORD AS STOCKS EXTEND STREAK TO 10 DAYS
description: Wall Street erupted with another explosive rally yesterday that sent trading volume to a record. The advance made the stock market's winning streak the longest - and most productive - in 14 years.

title: Calamitous Clip
description: ''This was like winning the World Series,'' said Cedric Maxwell of the Los Angeles Clippers. ''It was like being in Pasadena for the Super Bowl.'' What had happened? Why, the Clippers had actually won a game Wednesday night, by 18 points over Denver. Even at that, their 5-31 record (.139) left them on a pace for the worst N.B.A. season in 14 years and the third-worst in the league's history. Here are the clubs that have made the most dismal showing for a full season. W L Pct. 1972-73 76ers 9 73 .110 1947-48 Steamrollers 6 42 .125 1982-83 Rockets 14 68 .171 1952-53 Warriors 12 57 .174 1949-50 Nuggets 11 51 .177 1967-68 Rockets 15 67 .183 1970-71 Cavaliers 15 67 .183 1980-81 Mavericks 15 67 .183 1981-82 Cavaliers 15 67 .183 1968-69 Suns 16 66 .195 1979-80 Pistons 16 66 .195

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sphere, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sphere started out in 1982 as a quartet with two longtime associates of the pianist-composer Thelonious Sphere Monk - the saxophonist Charlie Rouse and the drummer Ben Riley - and two compatible outsiders, the pianist Kenny Barron and the bassist Buster Williams. At first, they lent their considerable talents to Monk's stubbornly brilliant compositions, playing them at the tricky midtempos Monk prescribed and keeping the original quirks and hollows intact while testing their own ensemble powers. Now, after four years as a working group, their sets juxtapose Monk classics with pieces by ensemble members; the music joins Monk's steely intelligence and Sphere's own suave lyricism. The group plays tonight through Sunday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: Epton Is Off Chicago Ballot
description: The Chicago Board of Election Commissioners has ordered the name of Bernard Epton removed from the Feb. 24 Republican mayoral primary ballot. The board said Wednesday that Mr. Epton, who ran for Mayor in 1983, had fallen short of the required number of signatures on his nominating ballots.

title: DANCE: DAVID PARSONS AND FRIENDS AT THE JOYCE
description: DAVID PARSONS, a dreamboat of a dancer in Paul Taylor's company - he has speed, fluency, wit, looks, charm - has taken to choreography in recent years. Wednesday night's program at the Joyce Theater, as part of the ''Joyce Sampler'' series, offered the first major overview of the works he has created since 1982.

title: ROGER KELLWAY'S MANY FACETS
description: ROGER KELLAWAY, the pianist, composer and conductor, has been described by the lyricist Gene Lees as bearing ''the curse of unclassifiability.'' He is a jazz pianist whose repertory ranges from Dixieland through be-bop to avant-garde. He is a classical composer who wrote a ballet score for George Balanchine and the New York City Ballet in 1971 and has just received a commission from the New York Philharmonic Society for a tuba concerto to be performed in 1988. He has written film and television scores, including one of the most familiar of all television themes, the closing music of the 1970's series ''All in the Family,'' for which he played honky-tonk piano. He has led, composed for and recorded with a so-called cello quartet that included only one cello - played by the celebrated musician Edgar Lustgarten.

title: REAGAN, ON TV, URGES STUDENTS TO HONOR THE MEMORY OF DR. KING
description: In his first public event since last month, President Reagan urged a television audience of high school students today to honor the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by being ''totally intolerant of racism anywhere around you.''

First Union said results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of First Railroad and Banking Co. on a pooling of interests basis.

description: Benny's Good Men, former members of the Benny Goodman band, will perform Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040). The group will include Peter Appleyard on vebraphone, Warren Vache Jr. on cornet and fluegelhorn, John Bunch on piano, Bucky Pizzarelli on guitar, and others. Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly; the ''Heavenly Jazz'' series of concerts benefits the Day School.

Fermenta is under investigation by the police, the Swedish bank inspection board and the stock exchange itself over its business practices.
