title: ART: EXHIBITION MARKS DUCHAMP'S CENTENARY
description: THERE never was a more implausible centenarian than Marcel Duchamp. Even in his 80's, he carried his age lightly, imperceptibly. Erect, steady and precise in all his movements, debonair in his bearing, he measured his every word, yet let it slip all but noiselessly. When present, he seemed to displace no air and demand no attention. From time to time a silent cachinnation and a look of benignity not exempt from mischief were his distinguishing marks. And when people went on and on about how astonishing it was that he had given up making art and seemed not to miss it, he let them finish, ruminating the while, quite possibly, on the enormous environmental work -''Etant Donnes,'' now in the Philadelphia Museum - that he had been elaborating in secret for almost 20 years.

title: ROSS, A J LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Navratilova Advances: Martina Navratilova, the defending champion, breezed to a 6-2, 6-1 triumph over Camille Benjamin today to move into the fourth round of the Australian Open. Hana Mandlikova seeded second, defeated Anne Smith, and Pam Shriver, seeded third, beat Elna Reinach.(AP) Horse Racing The Rogers Four Wins at Aqueduct: The Rogers Four, the longest price in the field of five, closed fast on the rail to outfinish the favorite, Rexson's Bishop, in Aqueduct's $40,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up yesterday. With 116 pounds, The Rogers Four went six furlongs in 1:10 2/5 on the fast track to give the jockey, Chris Antley, his fourth winner of the day. The Rogers Four paid $32.40 for $2 to win. Track and Field Records Set in Japan: Ben Johnson of Canada, and two athletes from the Soviet Union, Sergei Bubka and Oleg Protsenko, set world indoor records yesterday at the Yomiuri International indoor track and field meet in Osaka, Japan. Johnson broke his own indoor record in the 60-meter dash with a time of 6.44 seconds. Bubka broke his own indoor world record of 19 feet 6 1/4 inches in the pole vault by clearing 19 feet 6 1/2 inches. The meet's third world indoor record was produced when Protsenko triple-jumped 57 feet 11 3/4 inches, bettering the mark of 57 feet 6 1/2 inches held by Maris Bruziks. All the marks are now considered world records following a ruling by the International Amateur Athletic Federation that it would recognize world records, rather than world bests, in certain events including the dashes, the pole-vault and the triple jump.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 130, Bucks 91: Dominique Wilkins scored 32 points, and Glenn Rivers hit a 76-foot shot at the halftime buzzer last night for the Hawks in Atlanta. Wilkins broke a 4-4 tie with a 3-point field goal that put the Hawks ahead for good with 9 minutes 53 seconds left in the first quarter. (AP) Pacers 113, Bullets 105: Chuck Person scored 12 of his 29 points in the second quarter, reaching double figures for the 14th consecutive game, to help Indiana, playing at home. The Pacers snapped their three-game losing streak and the Bullets' four-game winning streak. The victory gave Indiana an 18-18 record, marking the first time since 1981 that the team has been at .500 this late in the season.(AP) Rockets 107, Bulls 96: Chicago, playing at home, lost despite Michael Jordan's 43 points. Akeem Olajuwon scored 8 of his 20 points in the final four and a half minutes and, Robert Reid had 26 as Houston won its fourth straight and ended the Bulls' four-game winning streak. (AP) N.H.L. Flyers 6, Canadiens 3: At Philadelphia, Rick Tocchet scored the game-winner for the Flyers, breaking a 3-3 tie at 7:59 of the third period.(AP) Oilers 4, Nordiques 1: Mike Krushelynski's rebound goal snapped a 1-1 tie early in the third period at Quebec. Wayne Gretzky added a goal and an assist as Edmonton won its fourth in a row.(AP) Bruins 6, Whalers 4: Reed Larson, a defenseman, scored the 200th and 201st goals of his career for Boston, playing at home. Larson, acquired from Detroit last spring, broke a 1-1 tie with his ninth goal of the season, a 45-foot slap shot on a power play at 17:42 of the first period. He gave Boston a two-goal advantage with another hard slap shot on a power play early in the second period.(AP) Maple Leafs 3, Red Wings 1: At Detroit, Allan Bester turned aside 37 shots and Vincent Damphousse scored two goals as Toronto broke a four-game losing streak. (AP)

title: CALIFORNIA TURNS TO DEVELOPER FEES
description: Facing expanding enrollment and hampered by tax limits created by a taxpayer revolt in the 1970's, many California school districts are rushing to take advantage of a new state law that encourages them to charge fees to building developers to help pay for new schools.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in the latest period. The results for 1986 include Fidelity National Bank of Baton Rouge from July 1 and Southwest National Bank of Lafayette from Sept. 1. The company said year-ago results do not include these two banks. Guaranty Bank & Trust of Alexandria is included from Aug. 1, 1985.

title: U.S. TRIAL STARTS FOR EX-OFFICIAL OF QUEENS PARTY
description: The Federal trial of Richard L. Rubin, an influential Queens Democratic figure, opened yesterday with the prosecution portraying him as a man who used his influence to defraud New York State of more than $49,000 to pay the salaries of two private secretaries in his own law firm.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Courts and Quarts
description: It has been a splendid few days for New York's imbibers, whether their weakness be alcohol or cholesterol. State regulations restricting competition in the sale first of milk and now of liquor have been wiped off the books, setting the stage for a 10 to 20 percent plunge in retail prices. The only regrettable aspect is that the state's consumers had to turn for relief to the Federal courts; their elected representatives sided with the dairy and liquor lobbies.

title: The Limits of Apology
description: Should Ronald Reagan apologize to the nation for the blundering acts of omission or commission that led to the arms-to-Iran scandal former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance has termed ''severely damaging to our national interest''?

title: Gorbachev Invites a Hart
description: Gary Hart, the former Democratic Senator from Colorado now preparing for a 1988 Presidential campaign, received an unexpected dividend on his recent trip to the Soviet Union. At a six-hour meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader invited Mr. Hart's daughter, Andrea, to visit the Soviet Union for three months.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LICENSE MOVE NEARS FOR AIDS DRUG
description: Amid impassioned debate over what access a patient with a fatal disease should have to experimental drugs, the Food and Drug Administration is nearing a decision on whether to license the only drug shown to prolong life in a group of AIDS victims.

title: A New Look at New York Ethics
description: Governor Cuomo's recent decision to appoint a new panel on ethics in government was welcome news. Yesterday's announcement of his choices for the group make it sound even better.

title: SELVAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Panel to Review Pay Of Top City Officials
description: Richard R. Shinn, executive vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will head a new commission that will recommend pay levels for top New York City officials, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: FIRST FIDELITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPUTED MOB FIGURE FATALLY SHOT IN BROOKLYN CLUB
description: A reputed organized-crime figure was killed in a Brooklyn social club late Wednesday by one of five armed men who forced several patrons to lie on the floor while they robbed them of money and jewelry, the police said yesterday.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months includes a tax credit of $85,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Dance
description: Eight New York Times critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead just to make sure everything is on schedule.

title: ART: 'OIL SKETCHES FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS'
description: ''OIL SKETCHES FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS: 1816-1863'' offers a fresh perspective on academic art. It is the first exhibition to bring together oil sketches that won prizes in the French Academy. It is the first exhibition that demonstrates the academic importance of the sketch, which throughout modernism has been identified with freedom, instinct and the avant-garde. The show is one more indication how complex the relationship between the French Academy and the avant-garde actually was.

title: Gooden, Mattingly File for Arbitration
description: Don Mattingly and Dwight Gooden, who last year negotiated their 1986 salaries after filing for salary arbitration, took the same first step yesterday, joining 95 other players in asking for arbitration on the final day of the filing period. That brought the arbitration total this winter to 104 players.

title: JUDGE SEES NO BIAS IN SITES OF SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the city had not discriminated against minority communities in its placement of shelters for the homeless.

title: SCIENTISTS VOICE DOUBTS SOVIET BREACHED TREATY
description: Experts from the United States nuclear laboratories today questioned Administration charges that the Soviet Union has probably exceeded the limits of an unratified 1974 treaty that limits the size of underground nuclear tests.

title: Vainisi Steps Down
description: Almost one year after Chicago captured the Super Bowl for the first time and less than two weeks after the Bears were eliminated in the playoffs, Jerry Vainisi has stepped down as general manager of the team. Michael McCaskey, the Bears' president and chief executive officer, said yesterday that it was a mutual decision. ''We have been 32-4 in our last two years and obviously it's hard to break up a winning combination, but Vainisi's departure was in the best interests of the Bears,'' McCaskey said. ''We want to see where we stand with the idea of gaining another Super Bowl victory.'' McCaskey gave ''strong philosophical differences'' as the reason for Vainisi's leaving, adding that Vainisi would remain with the club for a while as a consultant. Vainisi's contract runs until mid-1988, and McCaskey said no agreement had been reached on how it would be paid off. Vainisi, in a written statement, said he was confident the Bears would fulfill the contract and that he would ''continue to serve the Bears to the best of my ability until this matter is resolved.'' Coach Mike Ditka said he regretted the move because ''Jerry Vainisi is a class person.''

title: The Parachuting Dollar
description: The dollar's sharp recent drop is not bad news, not as long as it doesn't drop too far or too fast. The decline can mean a certain amount of good news for the United States. Some reduction in the dollar's value may well reduce the dangerous trade deficit and relieve the pressure already evident for protectionist legislation in Congress.

title: HITK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After realized gains on business development investments and other securities of $5,583,988 for the quarter and $9,109,936 for the 9 months. c-After realized gains on business development investments and other securities of $648,401 for the quarter and $891,283 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect a 1-for-4 reverse stock split paid Dec. 2.

title: U.S. MEDIATOR IS OPTIMISTIC ON L.I.R.R. CONTRACT TALKS
description: A Federal mediator said yesterday that there had been ''some useful discussions'' in the effort to avert a Long Island Rail Road strike threatened for Saturday.

title: Regan Seems to Have Survived the Hue and Cry
description: When President Reagan appeared today at his first official event since his prostate surgery, addressing a group of high school students by television from the Oval Office, Donald T. Regan was right there by his side.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THERE was a party the other evening that was not as joyous as it might have been. It was planned by Margaret Whiting and Jean Bach to toast Larry Carr, a singer and piano player as well as record producer and writer on music and films, on the occasion of his new record. Mr. Carr died a few days before the occasion, but the evening went on as scheduled as his jazz musician pals made it a musical salute to their friend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 16, 1987
description: International

title: LEASE/PURCHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures for the year-ago quarter are not applicable because the company was in the development stage prior to the acquisition of Velstar on Aug. 1, 1986. The company said its latest year results are not comparable to those of the prior year for reason given above. Also, Lease/Purchase went public in August 1985.

title: Volkswagen Plans New U.S. Import
description: Volkswagen U.S., a unit of Volkswagen A.G. of West Germany, said it planned to begin selling low-cost compact cars made in Brazil in the United States market. The new car, called the Fox, carries a price tag of $5,690 for a two-door model and $6,490 for the four-door Fox-GL, with a wagon due in the spring, company executives said. Volkswagen expects the new cars to compete with Asian-produced cars.

title: MEDITRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There are no comparable year-ago results because the company went public in October 1985. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 31.

title: CENSURED PRIEST DROPS TEACHING PLANS FOR SPRING
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran, a liberal theologian who was censured by the Vatican last year for his views on sexual issues, announced today that he was abandoning his efforts to teach this spring at Catholic University of America. He emphasized, however, that he would continue to fight for an eventual return to the classroom.

title: Destination: the Black Hills
description: South Dakota has rescheduled its 1988 Presidential primaries, moving them up from June to just after the well-publicized Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary of February. This seems certain to increase the number of politicians and their followers visiting the state that winter and to make Mount Rushmore and its sculpted profiles of Presidents Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt even more familiar as a backdrop for candidate pictures.

title: BARRY'S JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $104,000 for both the quarter and 9 months from termination of defined benefit pension plan of a subsidiary. The company said the latest quarter and 9 months sales include $5,588,000 and $12,594,000, respectively, from the recently acquired Howard H. Sweet & Son Inc.

title: Economic Power Makes Political Power
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS & LOAN OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $235,000 from redemption of subordinated notes.

title: WITH AIRLINE'S END, FARE RISES BEGIN
description: New Yorkers and others who now fly People Express will, in some cases, pay more than twice as much for tickets after the carrier is absorbed by Continental Airlines on Feb. 1.

title: PROTEST AT NEW YORKER IS CRITICIZED
description: New York literary figures are stunned by the unusual public protest by 154 members of The New Yorker asking Robert A. Gottlieb to withdraw his acceptance as editor of the magazine. Some writers and editors are decidedly unsympathetic toward the protesters, and while most would not speak for attribution, some were willing to speak on the record.

title: In China, Tradition and Change Are Old Foes; Since Mao's Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Deng Versus Deng in China
description: Suddenly, China is torn by political crisis. Leading liberal intellectuals have been denounced and purged. Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party General Secretary, is rumored to be on the way out. And China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is said to have called, in a chilling secret document, literally for the blood of the defiant students who two weeks ago staged their own long march through the streets of Beijing.

title: EA ENGINEERING, SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company went public in October 1986.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DREW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $344,000. The company said results do not reflect the operations of White Metal Rolling & Stamping Corp. acquired Dec. 29.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALTEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of oil and gas properties of $1,094,000 and $1,040,000 for the latest year and year- earlier period, respectively, and a provision for bad debts of $132,000 for the latest year and $208,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
4G DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December. The company said results include the effects of several major transactions taken in the third quarter of 1986, including loan chargeoffs, asset writedowns, discounts and a $336.2 million loss on disposition of a subsidary.

title: Two Trumpeters
description: Two trumpeters, Jon Faddis and Tom Harrell, will lead their quintets tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Mr. Faddis's group includes Greg Osby on saxophones, James Williams on piano, Phil Bowler on bass and Ralph Peterson Jr. on drums; Mr. Harrell's quintet will include Michael DeSibio on saxophone, Jim McNeely on piano, Rau Drummond on bass and Keith Copeland on drums. Double bills begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: Juilliard Quartet
description: The Juilliard Quartet will continue its 40th-anniversary subscription series at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow afternoon at 3 with a program of works by Mendelssohn, Brahms and Dvorak. Tickets are $15. Information: 874-6770.

title: Bentsen Urges A Simpler W-4
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee urged the Internal Revenue Service today to come up with a simpler W-4 form for Americans to use in computing how much tax should be withheld from their paychecks.

title: MANHATAN CO-OP PLAN ANGERS TENANTS
description: An oversized doormat in front of the revolving door at 24 Fifth Avenue still reads ''Fifth Avenue Hotel'' despite the building's ever-changing identity. In the last decade it went from a residential hotel to a rental in what proved a rocky transition. And today the 17-story brick building at the corner of Ninth Street is on the verge of becoming a cooperative.

title: INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains from tax credits of $170,000 for the quarter and $542,000 for the year.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AUCTIONS of corporate art collections, although still few in number, are becoming increasingly important in the 1980's, as values of art and antiques soar and companies expand their investments in both. Corporate holdings are sold for the same reasons that any art collection is dispersed - deaths, partnership changes, financial distress.

title: PRETORIA RESCINDS ORDER EXPELLING LOS ANGELES TIMES CORRESPONDENT
description: South Africa, which has expelled five foreign correspondents since June, granted a reprieve today to a reporter for The Los Angeles Times who had been ordered out of the country.

title: LUFTHANSA TO BUY AIRBUS A340
description: Lufthansa German Airlines said today that it would buy 15 A340 jets from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, and take an option on another 15 planes. The deal is considered a breakthrough for the jet, which will compete with a new McDonnell Douglas wide-bodied airliner.

title: TAX EXEMPTION FOR APARTMENTS CALLED IMPROPER
description: City officials extended an $800,000-a-year tax exemption for a building partly owned by Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader. without getting the required Board of Estimate approval, the Koch admistration acknowledged yesterday.

title: Time Inc. to Take $63 Million Charge
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it would take a $63 million pretax charge against earnings for the fourth quarter, resulting from the costs of staff reductions.

title: NEW LILFE IN HIGH-TECH STOCKS
description: As technology stocks continued to lead the Wall Street rally today, many analysts said the bull market for these issues would continue at least through the first quarter - and possibly for much of the year.

title: DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary loss of $39,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $443,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: COLUMBIA FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Columbia said its year-earlier second quarter net was reduced by 19 cents per share by a loan prepayment penalty incurred when refinancing Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings.

title: McCoy Tyner Trio
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: In Support Of Bill Curry
description: One measure of the alumni fury that has resulted from Alabama's hiring Bill Curry as football coach is that the Crimson Tide's sports information director felt compelled to issue a press release the other day defending the appointment and dealing the critics a history lesson.

title: Modern Music
description: Lukas Foss will lead members of the Brooklyn Philharmonic in the first ''Meet the Moderns'' program of the year tonight at 8 at Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street in the East Village. The program will include works by Kenneth Altman, John Downey, Leo Kraft, Ivan Tcherepnin, Robert Stern and Richard Trythall. Admission is $7. Information: (718) 636-4120.

title: Love Those Revolutions
description: A Washingtonian attending a performance of the Broadway-bound ''Les Miserables'' the other evening at the Kennedy Center discovered the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, in an adjoining box with three aides. In the course of the musical, French peasants and work-ers storm the barricades with red flags in an 1830's uprising, and the Russian theatergoers responded enthusiastically, standing to applaud during the curtain calls. The American then introduced himself to Mr. Dubinin and asked him how he had liked the revolutionary scenes. ''Excellent,'' replied the Soviet Ambassador, ''an excellent performance.''

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit from an accounting adjustment of $2,887,000. The latest quarter results reflect the acquisition of Cheshire National Bank and Farmers & Traders National and Savings Bank on Dec. 31, accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: UNION FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: IT'S a little less than three months until Academy Award time, but already behind-the-scenes dramas are being enacted that are of interest to film makers and film lovers.

title: PUERTO RICO ACTS TO BOLSTER FIRE LAWS
description: Hoping to counter possible damage to the tourist industry from the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, the government of Puerto Rico has acted quickly to try to dispel fears that it could happen again.

title: Accounts
description: * Morton Frozen Foods division of Conagra Frozen Foods Co. to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS BANK FA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $4,031,000 from a reduction of federal income tax attributable to prior years' operating loss carryforwards and an extraordinary charge of $407,000 from early extinguishment of debt. All figures adjusted to reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 15, 1986.

title: Capital Mayor's Ex-Aide Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former deputy mayor of the District of Columbia on charges of extortion, tax evasion, false financial disclosure and defrauding the city government.

title: TIMES EDITORS NAMED TO SENIOR NEWS POSTS
description: Promotions at senior levels of The New York Times's news department were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, executive editor. They will take effect in the coming weeks.

title: DETECTIVE'S SUICIDE REFLECTS PRESSURE ON SUFFOLK POLICE
description: No one is quite sure why Detective Lieut. John Gaggin, a top official of the Suffolk County Police Department who was said to have an unblemished record, killed himself.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: LEAD: Friday LARTIGUE IN THE 20's The elegance and style of France between the wars may seem remote from the frenzy of 1987 New York. But these days it is as near as the Museum of Modern Art, where the photographs of Jacques-Henri Lartigue are on display in a new exhibition, ''Lartigue: Panoramas of the 20's.

title: NEW ARMS SESSION BEGINS IN GENEVA
description: The chief Soviet and American arms negotiators began a new round of talks in Geneva today. They held an unexpected two-hour luncheon that appeared to underscore recent Soviet efforts to project a new face at the 22-month-old negotiations.

title: Panel Gets Contra Issue
description: To focus on some politically sensitive issues before Congress, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is about to create a Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Communications, headed by Senator Edward Zorinsky, Democrat of Nebraska.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports Today
description: AMERICA'S CUP Challenger's and defender's trials, at Fremantle, Australia (TV -ESPN, 11 P.M.) BASKETBALL HOUSTON ROCKETS VS. PISTONS, at Pontiac, Mich., 8 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, at Palm Desert, Calif.

title: Inspectorate Bid Refused
description: The Network Security Corporation, a supplier of protective services and equipment, said its directors had rejected a $95.9 million takeover offer from Inspectorate Holdings U.S.A. Last Friday,

title: BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Envoy Says Pretoria Barred Visit to Priest
description: An American diplomat says he was unable to persuade South African officials to allow him to see a missionary imprisoned for nearly a month in a black territory.

title: Joint Venture Set On Barter TV Time
description: An agreement to establish a joint venture to sell barter TV time has been signed on the Coast by Coca-Cola Telecommunications and Gulf and Western Entertainment, both creators and syndicators of programming.

title: Bobby Watson Trio
description: The alto saxophonist Bobby Watson is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight, with a $5 cover for the first two sets, no cover for the late set, and a $5 minimum.

title: Help for Pretoria's Neighbors
description: The ad in Gaborone's Gazette says ''Now you can jet to Jo'burg in 40 mins.'' South African Airways adds that via Johannesburg it can provide connections with ''non-stop S.A.A. flights to London and direct flights to New York and various destinations in Europe.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN HITLER'S GERMANY: Daily Life in the Third Reich. By Bernt Engelmann. Translated from the German by

title: LSB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $111,000 from the sale of the company's insurance subsidiary.

title: Brookehill Filing On Holly Sugar
description: The New York brokerage Brookehill Partners Inc. became the third concern to express an interest in seeking control of the Holly Sugar Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Brookehill said that it was considering a higher offer than that by the company's management.

title: Contract for John Lucas
description: John Lucas, a veteran guard who tested positive for drugs last year for the second time in two seasons, has reached an oral agreement to sign with the Milwaukee Bucks. Bill King, a spokesman for the Bucks, said that the contract for the remainder of this season must still be put in writing and signed before Lucas can practice with the team under National Basketball Association regulations, but that should take place by the middle of next week. Three Milwaukee guards, Sidney Moncrief, Paul Pressey and Scott Skiles, have been bothered by injuries this season. Lucas, who is 33 years old, was put on waivers last season by the Houston Rockets, and has been undergoing rehabilitation for the last 10 months at Houston International Hospital. ''I want to play basketball again because I think I have something to give to the game,'' Lucas said. ''I have developed a program that I think will keep me drug free, regardless of my environment. I want to prove to the world that I have something that works.'' Lucas is getting another chance to play in the N.B.A. because he volunteered for drug rehabilitation. . . . Allen Leavell, the guard signed by the Rockets when they released Lucas last season, has signed a 10-day contract with the team. Leavell fills one of the vacancies left when two guards, Mitchell Wiggins and Lewis Lloyd, were banned for at least two years after tests showed they had used cocaine. Leavell was waived by the Rockets last November when a foot injury cost him a spot on the team.

title: KOCH PROPOSES RAISING BUDGET TO $22.5 BILLION
description: Mayor Koch proposed a $22.5 billion preliminary budget yesterday that offered several improvements in New York City services and no major cutbacks.

title: Matt Hazeltine, 53, Is Dead; Former Linebacker for 49ers
description: Matt Hazeltine, one of three former San Francisco 49ers players stricken with Lou Gehrig's disease in the last two years, died from the disease Wednesday. He was 53 years old.

title: OPERA: THE METROPOLITAN'S FIRST 'TANNHAUSER' OF THE SEASON
description: THE trouble with coming upon real quality at the opera is that it makes you impatient with anything less. That happened last night at the season's first ''Tannhauser'' when Jessye Norman suddenly illuminated the Metropolitan stage with her second-act ''Dich, teure Halle'' and went on to create as vocally electrifying and dramatically moving an Elisabeth as that stage has known in years. Though different in almost every way from the Elisabeth of Leonie Rysanek, long the reigning soprano in this Wagnerian role, Miss Norman's Elisabeth was on the same high level, up there where the air is thin and few singers survive.

title: NEW VOTING RIGHTS RULES BRING PRAISE AND PROTEST
description: Members of civil rights groups are generally praising new Justice Department regulations that would strengthen enforcement of the Voting Rights Act. But some civil rights groups said the rules could continue to create problems in enforcing voting rights.

title: WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect 2-for- 1 stock split in November.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year sales include about $2.9 billion and $5.7 billion, respectively, from RCA operations since June 1.

title: QUARREL PRECEDED BLAZE AT HOTEL
description: The union member charged with setting the fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel had a quarrel with hotel security officers shortly before the blaze was set, a union official said today.

title: RJR Nabisco Plans to Move
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved plans to move its headquarters from Winston-Salem, N.C., to Atlanta in September. The company, formerly R. J. Reynolds Industries, began as a tobacco company in Winston-Salem in 1875 and grew to be a major conglomerate, changing its name after it acquired Nabisco Brands Inc. in 1985 for $4.9 billion.

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR MEETS WITH LAWYERS FOR ATTACK VICTIMS
description: The special prosecutor in the Howard Beach attack discussed the case for more than an hour yesterday with two lawyers representing the black victims, one of the lawyers said.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LE REGENCE, the opulent French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, wasted no time picking up the pieces after losing its chef, Daniel Boulud, and two sous chefs, to Le Cirque last fall. Managers of the hotel, which has a sister establishment in Paris, recruited the flying Rostang family - Jo, the chef-owner of the two-star (Michelin) La Bonne Auberge on the French Riviera; Philippe, his son and co-chef, and Michel, another son whose own two-star establishment in Paris bears his name - to oversee the new regime. Under the arrangement, one or more of the Rostangs spends a week to 10 days a month in New York working with the resident chef, Jean Michel Bergougnoux.

title: THE COSTS OF THE FALLING DOLLAR
description: The recent sharp drop in the dollar has heightened fears that a surge in consumer prices on imports may finally be at hand.

title: ARMS DEALERS LINKED TO U.S. POLICY SHIFT
description: For more than a year before the Reagan Administration began to consider selling arms to Iran, many of the arms dealers who eventually helped carry out the change in policy had been planning among themselves to sell American arms to the Teheran Government, according to American and Iranian sources and documents.

title: FRIEDMAN AND 2 OTHERS INDICTED OVER NATIONAL GUARD CONTRACT
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and two other men have been indicted on bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with seeking a contract to sell hand-held computers to the New York National Guard, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: HUMAN TESTS SOON PREDICTED IN QUEST OF AIDS VACCINE
description: Testing on humans for some vaccine for AIDS could take place as early as the end of this year or the beginning of 1988, the coordinator of AIDS research at the National Institutes of Health told a Senate panel today.

title: Another Questionnaire In Army Agency Search
description: All hope that the Army would announce the agency winner of its $100 million recruiting account disappeared yesterday as word got around that the finalists had received still another questionnaire that had to be back in the Army's hands in Washington by 1:30 P.M. next Tuesday.

title: HOME SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN-DURHAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted to stock from mutual form last June.

title: Bias-Violence Panel To Begin Programs
description: The new State Task-Force on Bias-Related Violence will soon begin working on programs in education, law enforcement and housing, the State Human Rights Commissioner, Douglas H. White, said yesterday.

title: OTHER TALKS ON PAN AM REPORTED
description: Another potential buyer expressed interest in Pan American World Airways before American Airlines began exploratory talks with the ailing carrier, an industry source said yesterday.

title: OPENING SALVOS ARE FIRED ON N.B.A.'S CONTRACT
description: Making a trade in the National Basketball Association may be more difficult than in most other sports. It requires a conference call between the trading teams and the league office, and after an agreement has been reached a computer determines whether either team would exceed its salary cap by making the trade.

title: SNOWSTORM DRIVES BRONCOS INDOORS
description: A howling snowstorm blanketed this city today, but inside a pressurized bubble the Broncos staged their first practice for their Jan. 25 game with the Giants in Super Bowl XXI.

title: E.P.A. FINDS LAKES OF WEST ARE FREE OF ACID RAIN
description: A survey made public today by the Environmental Protection Agency found that no lakes in mountainous areas of the Western United States were currently polluted by acid rain but that a large number were potentially susceptible.

title: THE QUEEN OF THE DISCOTHEQUE DEEJAYS
description: A wedding party full of gray-haired parents is not where one would expect to find New York's queen of discotheque deejays. As the star and music director of the Palladium's Mike Todd Room, Anita Sarko normally fiddles while late-night New York burns.

title: THE REBEL SOLDIER WHO'S NEVER WITHOUT A CAUSE
description: At his wedding two decades ago, Victor Corpus exchanged bullets with his bride instead of rings, pledging that if either betrayed the Communist revolution, the other would exact vengeance.

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest fourth quarter it charged earnings with a $15.7 million loan loss provision, which was higher than the $11.5 million charged in the third quarter of 1986.

title: Inventories Fell 0.2% in November
description: Business inventories, which had shot up in October, edged down two-tenths of 1 percent in November, while total business sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Morgan Income Rose By 9.3% in 4th Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company turned in another quarter of above-average results, reporting yesterday that fourth-quarter net income rose 9.3 percent.

title: SHULTZ IS UNDER FIRE FOR ASSERTING LIBRIA HAS MADE GAINS ON RIGHTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who returned from a six-nation tour of Africa late Wednesday, has become embroiled in criticism over his assertion that Liberia has made progress in human rights.

title: SONGS OF WOMEN
description: The soprano Lucille Field will present a program entitled ''Songs: With Women in Mind'' at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67 Street, Sunday night at 8. The program will include music by Nancy Van de Vate, Josephine Lang, Robert Starer, Miriam Gideon, Patsy Rogers and others. Admission is $8; students and the elderly, $5. Information: 362-8719.

title: Spectra-Physics Filing by Reliance
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, which is controlled by the New York investor Saul P. Steinberg, said that it might seek control of Spectra-Physics Inc., the world's largest commercial laser manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reliance said that it ''cannot continue to be merely passive investors'' in Spectra-Physics because of a proposal to change the company's incorporation from California to Delaware.

title: Former Judge Named To Inquiry of Myerson
description: Mayor Koch yesterday appointed Harold R. Tyler Jr., a former Federal judge, as the special investigator examining the activities of Bess Myerson, who has stepped aside as the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: Brokerage Suspended
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended Butcher & Singer Inc., a Philadelphia brokerage, and two of its employees in connection with illegal transactions in securities in 1977. The action upholds an administrative law judge's decision.

title: RAY BOLGER, SCARECROW IN 'OZ,' DIES
description: Ray Bolger, the loose-limbed song-and-dance man who became known to millions as the Scarecrow in ''The Wizard of Oz,'' died yesterday of cancer in Los Angeles. He had his 83d birthday last Saturday and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Economic Scene; Currency Rift: Fog Thickens
description: THE conflict raging among the United States, West Germany and Japan over the values of their currencies has been compared to a game of chicken, in which the players with the least nerve lose. If nobody chickens out, the result would be a general smash-up, with ruinous consequences for all - and for the world economic and monetary system.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

description: LEAD: Harvey A. Weinberg, vice chairman of the Hartmarx Corporation, yesterday was elected chief executive officer of the Chicago-based apparel manufacturer and retailer.

title: FILM: 'DEFENSE OF REALM'
description: ''DEFENSE OF THE REALM,'' which opens today at the Cinema 1, is an English melodrama about an ambitious young Fleet Street reporter, a cynical older Fleet Street reporter who drinks too much, the bombing of an embassy in Ankara, Turkey, a prominent Labor Party official who frequents the same London call girl as a diplomat from a Communist country, and a couple of young men who are trying to escape from prison.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KANGAROOS STIR A DEBATE
description: Is it a careful program of wildlife management, as the Australian Government says, or ''one of the most barbaric commercial wildlife massacres in the world,'' as Marian Newman of the International Wildlife Coalition asserts? In dollar terms, the stakes are relatively small, but the emotional stakes are high. The issue is the killing of millions of one of the world's most endearing animals, kangaroos, and the use of their skins in sports shoes and other products.

title: THE BUDGET IS AGAIN HOSTAGE TO POLITICS
description: The sad thing about American politics today is that even if the new Democratic Congress liked President Reagan's fiscal 1988 budget, they would have to throw it out. Having wrested Congressional power from the Republicans last November, the Democrats must demonstrate their independence of Mr. Reagan or risk being derided as second-rate players in the political game. Moreover, they must clear the decks for the 1988 Presidential election, and that means trying to whittle Mr. Reagan down to size to diminish the aura of his accomplishments.

title: AUTOMATIC BRAKING DEVICES URGED FOR TRAINS USING NORTHEAST RAILS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board formally recommended today that all trains operating on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor tracks, between Washington and Boston, be equipped with devices that automatically halt trains when engineers do not heed track signals.

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

description: Fighting continued along two fronts in the Persian Gulf war today, with both Iran and Iraq asserting that they were inflicting heavy losses on the other.

title: K Mart Debentures
description: The K Mart Corporation is offering $300 million of 8 3/8 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97.125 to yield 8.644 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Nonrefundable for 10 years, the debentures yield 1.05 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016 and are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P. A sinking fund beginning in 1998 will retire 5 percent of the issue annually, but the payment may be increased by 200 percent at the company's option.

MEESE BACKS ADMINISTRATION OVER CUTS IN DRUG CAMPAIGN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d denied today that the Reagan Administration was scaling back its campaign against drug abuse. He charged that critics who protested cuts in some Federal drug law-enforcement programs were ''more interested in politics than progress.''

title: OKLAHOMA BEATS KANSAS BY 76-74
description: Tim McCalister's jump shot with nine seconds remaining broke a tie and Ricky Grace blocked a last-second shot as Oklahoma defeated Kansas, 76-74, tonight in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: 6 KILLED IN MOSLEM ATTACKS IN PHILIPPINES
description: Violence continued today on the southern island of Mindanao as Moslem rebels killed 6 people and wounded nearly 40 in a series of attacks, according to military reports.

title: SAM WAGSTAFF, 65, A CURATOR AND PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTOR
description: Sam Wagstaff, a former museum curator who became a leading collector of photography, died of pneumonia Wednesday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 65 years old.

title: OIL-GEAR EXPORT CURBS TO SOVIET TO BE LIFTED
description: The Reagan Administration, over objections by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, has decided to remove most controls on exports of oil and gas equipment and technology to the Soviet Union.

title: SLUGGISH ISLANDERS DEFEATED
description: Mike Bossy had predicted that the Islanders would have to do better than be merely mediocre if they wanted to be victorious, and tonight their inefficiency cost them a game.

description: A twin-engine commuter airliner and a small private plane collided over a residential area south of Salt Lake City yesterday and officials said that 10 people had been killed.

title: SCREEN: A TV SPINOFF, 'WANTED DEAD OR ALIVE'
description: ''WANTED: DEAD OR ALIVE'' was a 1958 television series starring Steve McQueen. It has now, in the process of becoming a feature film, lost its colon, and that's not the half of it. Even to those of us who have become more or less used to the cultural cannibalism that passes for inventiveness these days, the film ''Wanted Dead or Alive,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, will seem outstandingly unnecessary. It's not that the television show was sacrosanct; all it really had to recommend it was Mr. McQueen. It's just that producers wanting to make another latter-day urban ''Rambo'' should at least be expected to come up with something of their own.

title: Put Toilets in OTB's
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman, 21, Arrested As 'Push-In' Robber
description: A 21-year-old woman was arrested last night and charged in a series of robberies of elderly women in Forest Hills, Queens, the police said.

title: In Jersey, a Dairy Savors Star Status
description: SUDDENLY, grocers all over New York City and Long Island want the prestige of carrying Farmland Dairies milk on their supermarket shelves.

title: Mighty Mites
description: Its most illustrious alumnus is Carl Yastrzemski, but baseball is no longer the big sport at Bridgehampton (L.I.) High. It's basketball, which is, in fact, the school's only sport these days. ''We've tried to get them to play baseball, but they won't do it,'' says John Niles, Bridgehampton's basketball coach. ''But throw a basketball out on the court, and you can't keep them away.''

title: Little Program Trading As Stock Indexes Soar
description: As expected, stock index futures soared yesterday, along with their underlying market averages. What was not expected was that the index futures would follow the stock market and not lead it, as has usually been the case.

title: Soviet Cancer Patient Given Visa to Get Treatment in U.S.
description: The wife of a well-known Soviet dissident said today that she had been granted an exit visa and would leave the Soviet Union on Sunday to receive cancer treatment in the United States.

title: Welcomed Demotion
description: A former major league catcher, Barry Foote, who managed the Yankees' Class AAA team in Columbus, Ohio, last year before being replaced by Bucky Dent for this season, has had enough of that level. Yesterday, he was named the first manager of the Myrtle Beach Blue Jays, a Toronto affiliate in South Carolina that is on the Class A level - and Foote prefers the demotion. ''Managing in AAA is probably the worst job for a manager,'' the 34-year-old Foote said. ''The players on the team complain because they think they should be in the major leagues, and those who were once in the major leagues and were sent down to AAA for one reason or another, complain because they feel they should be in the major leagues.'' . . . Tucker Ashford, a former major league infielder who managed the Mets' Class A team in Columbia, S.C., to a championship last season, has been promoted to the Class AA affiliate in Jackson, Miss. He succeeds Mike Cubbage, who moved up a notch in the Mets' system and will manage at Tidewater this season.

title: T.W.A. Elects New President
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that D. Joseph Corr, its vice chairman, had been elected president. He will retain the title of chief operating officer.

title: CAROLINE GRUSS, 76, PHILANTHROPIST WHO SUPPORTED JEWISH EDUCATION
description: Caroline Gruss, who with her husband donated millions of dollars to educational institutions in this country and in Israel, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 76. Mrs. Gruss was born in Poland, where she received a law degree and studied classical languages at the University of Lvov. She and her husband, Joseph S. Gruss, an investment banker, came to the United States as refugees in 1939. Other family members stayed behind and became victims of the Nazis.

title: Martha Graham Gets Danish Arts Award
description: Martha Graham has been awarded Denmark's gold medal ''Ingenio et Arti'' for distinction in the arts and sciences. The American modern-dance pioneer has taken her company to Denmark several times in recent years. Only one other non-Danish artist, the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, has received the irregularly presented medal.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Combustion Engineering Inc., Stamford, Conn., named W. Mack Torrence to the newly created position of president and John A. Cunningham as executive vice president of its Resource Recovery Systems division.

title: ART: 47 FIGURAL PAINTINGS OF DAVID PARK ON VIEW
description: UNTIL a full-scale museum retrospective is organized, the work of David Park, who died of cancer in 1960 at the age of 49, may be doomed to perennial rediscovery. The current exhibition of his paintings at Salander-O'Reilly (22 East 80th Street) is the third this gallery has mounted in almost as many years; it is the best yet and should win Park even more admirers. Park, born and reared in Boston, never finished high school and had only one year of formal art education, at Otis Institute in Los Angeles. He was largely a self-taught painter who lived most of his adult life in San Francisco, teaching first at the San Francisco Art Institute and then at Berkeley.

title: CONGRESS AMENABLE TO FURTHER DROP
description: As the value of the dollar stabilized today, leading members of Congress said they would welcome a further decline to help shrink the nation's trade deficit - if it came in an orderly way.

Lloyd Jacobs, 48, has been named executive vice president. Charles C. McKinney, 55, who gave up the president's title, remains chairman and chief executive.

title: AMERICAN NURSERY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Dining Out Guide; Pre-theater
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE 43 RESTAURANT AND WINE BAR, #147 West 43d Street (869-4200) -*(Dec. 21, 1984) Just a few doors east of Times Square is this comfortable and bright restaurant that has one of the more extensive wine-by-the-glass menus in town and a table d'hote dinner that is just right for pre-theater dining. The menu changes every two weeks, and you might start with tortellini in Roquefort and basil sauce; wild mushroom and bacon crepe, and tuna and fusilli salad. Entree choices included sliced breast of chicken with butter, wine and lemon sauce; sauteed medallions of venison with pears, and a steamed winter vegetable platter with mustard soy sauce. If you'd prefer something light, hamburgers and cold salads are always available. Prix-fixe dinner $19.95; with wine $29.95; entrees $8.75 to $16.75. Fridays, noon to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. CAROLINA, #355 West 46th Street (245-0058) - *(Feb. 14, 1986) An arching skylight, gray banquettes and wraparound glass walls make this restaurant one of the more accommodating on 46th Street's Restaurant Row. The menu is narrowly focused and the best appetizer choices are chili, corn chowder and hot-smoked pork sausage with roasted red peppers. Main-course selections include crab cakes that are slightly peppery and generous with crab meat; moist and flavorful hot smoked brisket of beef, and a special of Texas tenderloin, which is marinated strips of grilled steak covered with sweet onions. Dinner entrees $15 to $23.

title: PARTIAL ANTIMISSILE DEPLOYMENT WEIGHED
description: The Reagan Administration is considering deployment of defenses against missiles, with some units installed in space, in the early 1990's, experts said today. They estimated the cost at roughly $100 billion.

title: 2 OFFICERS WITH MISSING WIVES TRAINED AT SAME STATION HOUSE
description: Two New York City police officers whose wives disappeared under mysterious circumstances worked in the same station house on the Upper West Side for more than a year while they were trainees in the late 60's, police officials said yesterday.

title: Article 380287 -- No Title
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would offer its ultra-luxurious Allante convertible sports coupe for $54,700, the highest price ever put on a G. M. car offered the public. The car is not expected to be a big money maker for G. M., but is considered essential to upgrade the image and prestige of its Cadillac division in the luxury car market increasingly dominated by European makes. It will go on sale in six markets in early February. Cadillac announced at a news conference that it expected to sell at least 4,000 Allantes in the 1987 model year.

title: ROBERT S. DRISCOLL
description: Robert Swanton Driscoll, former managing partner of Lord, Abbett & Company, an investment management firm, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SIX-YEAR-OLD Shun Lee, formerly called Shun Lee West, could be likened to a midwinter sun - at times it breaks through and shines brilliantly, cheering all who fall under its glow; then again it can be weak and dispiriting, an experience to tolerate rather than celebrate.

title: Books of The Times; 15 Years of Confidence
description: AMERICAN HIGH: The Years of Confidence 1945-1960. By William L. O'Neill. 321 pages. Illustrated. Free Press. $19.95. Postwar America was a rich hunting ground for social critics. Everywhere they turned, there was something to shoot down. They took particular aim at conformity, peppering such weak sisters as the Organization Man and the Other-directed Type. They told us that our cars were too big, our roads too disruptive, our homes an offense against good taste and our suburbs were dull, dull, dull. President Truman was assailed by the right for being soft on Communism and by the left for being unkind to the Soviet Union. Educated people made fun of President Eisenhower's locutions. And, of course, there was Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

title: 2 Israeli Helicopters Strafe Post of Lebanese Guerrillas
description: Two Israeli helicopter gunships strafed Lebanese guerrillas today who had just overrun a position of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army, the police said.

title: SPEEDUP URGED IN AIR SAFETY EFFORTS
description: The midair collision Thursday near Salt Lake City brought new pressure yesterday for a speedup in persistently delayed programs to install new equipment and impose new rules designed to prevent such accidents.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE DUTCHMAN

title: Foster Beats Nehemiah
description: Greg Foster gave Renaldo Nehemiah a rude welcome back to track tonight, beating his longtime rival with the fastest 60-meter hurdles ever run indoors.

title: Up the Mountain, Then and Now
description: Ah, but skiing has changed. There's a whole generation of skiers now who've never ridden a Poma lift (straddle the round metal plate that pulls you up on your skis) or a T-bar (different shape, same effect). Who've never buckled more than two buckles per boot. Who've never chosen their skis by matching the tips to the midpoint of their forearm held high. Who've never had to take their mittens off in the flesh-searing cold to fasten a safety strap.

title: Edberg Advances in Australia
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeking his second straight Australian Open men's singles title, moved into the fourth round of the $1.65 million tennis tournament today by defeating John Frawley of Australia, 6-4, 6-3, 6-1.

title: Iran, Iraq and America
description: The fierce upsurge of fighting in the six-year-old war between Iran and Iraq has caught American policy in disarray. The practical and principled position of neutrality, discouraging arms sales to either side, has been wrecked by news of the White House's covert policy, trading arms for hostages with Iran and supplying intelligence to both sides.

Dutch Dance Theater To Perform at the Met
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater, which has not danced in New York since 1982, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House on June 22 for a week of performances. The company, under the direction of Jiri Kylian, will present two programs of works by Mr. Kylian. The repertory includes six New York premieres by him, among them ''Heart's Labyrinth,'' ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' ''L'Histoire du Soldat,'' ''Six Dances,'' ''Silent Cries,'' which is a solo staging of ''L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune,'' and ''Stamping Ground.'' ''Les Noces'' completes the repertory.

title: PANEL BACKS LICENSING OF AIDS DRUG
description: In a highly unusual step, a panel of expert medical advisers to the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that a promising drug against AIDS be licensed for sale despite what the scientists described as major gaps in knowledge about its effectiveness and safety.

title: NBC TO BUY MIAMI TV OUTLET
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a seventh television station, WTVJ-TV in Miami, for $270 million in cash from the Wometco Broadcasting Company.

title: INSIDE
description: Longest Steel Strike Ends After 170 days, USX Corp. and the United Steelworkers reached a tentative agreement to end the industry's longest work stoppage. Page 8. Sale of AIDS Drug Favored An advisory panel recommended that the Government license for sale a promising but not fully explored drug against AIDS. Page 32. Japan Surplus a Record Japan said its trade surplus with the United States soared last year, to $51.5 billion, 30 percent greater than in 1985. Page 33. Milk Prices Drop Milk prices dropped between 18 and 71 cents a gallon in New York City supermarkets after a New Jersey dairy began selling citywide. Page 29.

title: What's in a Sack?
description: Ricky the Third Avenue barber -or hair stylist, or landscaper, depending on the particular head of hair she is presented with -is from the Netherlands. She was asked whether she was going to watch the Super Bowl. ''I don't like football,'' she said. ''What is it? All these big guys bending over a ball and then they fight about it.'' That's one view. Here's another: ''There's a sack, and then there's a sack. It depends on how you hit 'em. A sack is when you run up behind a quarterback when they're not watching and you get a chance to put your helmet in his back and he blows and snorts and the ball goes fluttering away and he's laid out on the ground and the coach comes out and asks the quarterback if he's all right. That's a sack.''

title: A SHERLOCKIAN BREAKFAST MARKS HOLMES'S 100th
description: Mrs. Hudson was hostess at a breakfast the other morning in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Only an ill-read civilian who doesn't know what's Watson in the world of detective fiction would not instantly recognize the name of the housekeeper for the brilliant loner who lived on Baker Street, at No. 221B, in London.

title: MARTIN ERDMANN, AN EX-JUDGE
description: Martin Erdmann, a former Manhattan Criminal Court judge and former trial lawyer with the Legal Aid Society, died of heart failure Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He lived in Manhattan and was 72 years old.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its earnings for the first three quarters of 1986 have been restated for a change in accounting for pension expense to comply with new accounting rules.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JANUARY 17, 1987
description: International

title: N.F.L. Said to Fine Hill for Hit on Rice
description: Sources indicated yesterday that the National Football League had fined but not suspended Kenny Hill of the Giants for a late hit on Jerry Rice of the San Francisco 49ers during the Giants' 49-3 playoff victory Jan. 4.

title: New York's Poor Children: A Tinderbox
description: Unless New York City dedicates itself to making 1987 the year for a concerted effort to improve the lives of the children of poverty, we will contribute to the creation of a social tinderbox.

title: WEBSTER REJOINING RANGERS
description: The coach who has sometimes coached and the general manager who has sometimes coached will return to their normal places. The coach will return to the bench, the general manager will return to his office, and the Rangers say that the confusion is ended.

title: OPERA: SEASON'S FIRST 'TANNHAUSER'
description: The trouble with coming upon real quality at the opera is that it makes you impatient with anything less. That happened Thursday night at the season's first ''Tannhauser'' when Jessye Norman suddenly illuminated the Metropolitan stage with her second-act ''Dich, teure Halle'' and went on to create as vocally electrifying and dramatically moving an Elisabeth as that stage has known in years. Though different in almost every way from the Elisabeth of Leonie Rysanek, long the reigning soprano in this Wagnerian role, Miss Norman's Elisabeth was on the same high level, up there where the air is thin and few singers survive.

title: OUTPUT UP STRONG 0.5% LAST MONTH
description: The nation's industrial production rose a solid five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third consecutive monthly improvement, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: GRETZKY LEFT OUT
description: Wayne Gretzky, the record-breaking center of the Edmonton Oilers, was snubbed by fans in selecting the National Hockey League all-star team, which was announced yesterday. Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, currently sidelined with a knee injury, topped the balloting for starting center with 247,222 votes. Gretzky, the league's perennial scoring champion, received 212,246 votes. ''My record through the years and my two Stanley Cups speak for themselves and if some people don't like what I do on the ice, there is nothing I can do about it,'' Gretzky said. Lemieux, who is expected to be fit for the game next month, will be joined on the starting team by Mike Bossy, the Islanders' right wing, Michel Goulet, the left wing from the Quebec Nordiques, and two defensemen, Paul Coffey of the Oilers and Mark Howe of the Philadelphia Flyers. The Quebec goalie, Clint Malarchuk, was the top vote-getter at that position, beating Patrick Roy of Montreal, 116,137 to 102,781.

title: ADAMS'S PAIN IS WORSE NOW
description: George Adams is going to the Super Bowl.

description: A memorial service will be held at 10 A.M. Monday in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan for the Rev. Mother Ruth, founder and headmistress of St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's Episcopal day school. The Reverend Mother, who died Dec. 22 after a brief illness, was 89 years old.

LENGTHY HELMSLEY INQUIRY IS SEEN

title: FRENCH LOOK TO PRIVATE HELP FOR POOR
description: At noon today there were several hundred people - among them unemployed artisans wrapped in solid leather jackets and scarves, homeless men with tattoos and five days of stubble, women with children in tow -crowded into the line at what is euphemistically called the Restaurant of the Heart here in this bleak, semi-industrial suburb just south of Paris.

DISSIDENTS' SENTENCES ARE SAID TO BE UNDER REVIEW BY SOVIET UNION
description: The Soviet Union's chief spokesman on human rights issues said today that the Government had begun an intensive review of the sentences of prisoners convicted of ''anti-Soviet activities,'' a category that includes many imprisoned political and religious dissidents.

title: SMALL PLANE IS A FOCUS OF INQUIRY INTO COLLISION
description: A small private plane apparently flew into the flight path of a larger commuter aircraft before the two collided over this Salt Lake City suburb Thursday, killing all 10 people aboard, a Federal safety official said tonight.

title: ROCKETS GET MAXWELL
description: The Houston Rockets, attempting to fill the void created by the ban earlier this week of Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins, acquired Cedric Maxwell from the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday for a first-round 1987 draft pick and a third-round choice in 1988. The Rockets had re-signed an eight-year-veteran guard, Allen Leavell, earlier this week. Lloyd and Wiggins, both guards, were banned after they tested positive for drug use. The 31-year-old Maxwell, a veteran forward, was in his second season with the lowly Clippers. The 6-foot-8-inch Maxwell spent eight years with the Boston Celtics after playing college ball at North Carolina-Charlotte.

description: The United States was reported today to be close to establishing diplomatic relations with Mongolia, a Soviet ally on the Soviet-Chinese border.

title: HOLIDAY MONDAY
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - Regular collections. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Connecticut, closed; in New York and New Jersey banks have the option of closing. Financial markets - Open. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North and N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. Schools - Most schools closed in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Libraries - Closed

title:
PATENTS;
FINGERPRINTS COMPARED BY CREDIT CARD CODE

Clark of Holden, Mass. Mr. Clark was granted patent 4,636,622 for the system.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies yesterday about an anti-apartheid protest at Citibank headquarters in Manhattan gave an incorrect account of Coretta Scott King's involvement. Mrs. King was in Atlanta on Thursday, and was not among the 21 people seized on trespassing charges. A spokesman for the protest group in New York had read statements attributed to Mrs. King.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 133, Cavaliers 128: In Boston, Kevin McHale scored 38 points and Larry Bird added 35 last night as the Celtics edged Cleveland in overtime, extending the Cavaliers' losing streak in Boston Garden to 21 games. The Celtics, who trailed by as many as 13 points in the second period, outscored Cleveland, 11-6, in overtime. Boston made nine of nine free throws to win for the 10th time in its 11 games. Cleveland pulled into a 122-122 tie on a jump shot by Ron Harper from the side as regulation play ended. The Cavaliers, who have not won in the Garden since Oct. 13, 1978, suffered their fourth loss in a row and eighth in the last nine games. Harper finished with 30 points, Brad Daugherty had 26 and John Williams and John Bagley 24 each. (AP) Rockets 112, Pistons 106: Akeem Olajuwon scored 33 points and the Houston Rockets survived a late threat to extend their longest winning streak of the season to five games in a victory over the Pistons playing at home. The Pistons lost for only the fifth time in their last 25 games, despite outscoring the Rockets, 33-20, in the fourth quarter. It was Detroit's first loss at home in 10 starts. Olajuwon was supported by Robert Reid's 21 points and a career-high 19 by the reserve guard, Steve Harris. Vinnie Johnson and Joe Dumars shared the Detroit scoring lead with 18 points, while Bill Laimbeer and Adrian Dantley had 16 each. The Rockets led, 97-76, with 9:31 left in the game before the Pistons shaved 18 points off the lead. John Salley scored 9 points in a 15-point run over 4 minutes 1 seconds that brought Detroit within 4 at 97-93. Detroit cut the Houston lead to 101-98 at the 3:18 mark, when Salley's free throw followed a 3-point basket by Dumars, but the Pistons drew no closer. (AP) SKIING Figini Leads Swiss Victory: Michela Figini held off a strong challenge from her Swiss teammates and a surprisingly strong West German team yesterday in winning her second World Cup downhill race this season. Swiss and West German racers dominated the event at Pfronten, West Germany, taking the first seven places. Figini, 20 years old, mastered the 2,260-meter Breitenberg course in 1 minute 20.12 seconds, giving the powerful Swiss team its 12th triumph in 17 World Cup races this season. Regine Moesenlechner of West Germany placed second in 1:20.21. Maria Walliser of Switzerland was third in 1:20.62 and regained the lead in the overall World Cup standing with 197 points, 14 more than Vreni Schneider, a teammate. The top American finisher, Pam Fletcher, was 11th in 1:21.57. (AP) HORSE RACING Decisive Victory: Proud Debonair took the lead entering the stretch and drew away to a five-length victory in the $40,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Jean-Luc Samyn rode the 5-year-old son of Lyphard and Proud Delta over the mile and an eighth in 1:48 4/5 on the fast track to record his fifth victory in 12 career starts. Tinchen's Prince, who led most of the way, was the runner-up, seven lengths ahead of Spark of Love, the favorite. Proud Debonair returned $9.40 for $2 to win. SQUASH RACQUETS Talbott Advances: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., defeated Bill Doyle, also of Barrington, 18-17, 15-11, 15-12, yesterday as play opened in the $10,000 Marsh & McLennan Apawamis Invitation Squash Racquets Championship at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y. Steve Bowditch of West Germany, the second-seeded player, defeated John Leonard of New York, 15-13, 16-18, 15-12, 15-13. The tournament, begun 45 years ago as an amateur event, is one of the oldest continuous squash events in the country. The final will take place tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. COLLEGE BASKETBALL Dartmouth 74, Harvard 69: In Cambridge, Mass., Len Bazelak led a first-half rally, scored 11 of his 17 points in the second half and contributed a 3-pointer that put Dartmouth ahead for good with less than three minutes remaining as the Big Green whipped Harvard in an Ivy League game. Dartmouth is 8-4 over all and 1-2 in the Ivy League. Harvard is 7-7 and 2-1. (AP) Cornell 93, Yale 87: Sam Jacobs scored 15 of his 23 points in the final 10 minutes to lead Cornell (5-6, 1-1) to an Ivy victory over Yale (7-5, 1-1) in New Haven. Jacobs scored 8 points in the last two minutes. (AP)

Ricky Horton of St. Louis and Bill Krueger of Oakland reached agreement with their teams Thursday not long after filing for arbitration (Horton for $410,000, Krueger for $175,000). Then yesterday four more players who had filed settled with their clubs - Ed Lynch with the Chicago Cubs, Steve Crawford with Boston, Bill Schroeder with Milwaukee and Donnie Hill with the Chicago White Sox.

Citibank Pact On Manila
description: Citibank N.A., which was purportedly blocking a Philippines debt rescheduling, has agreed to terms outlined by other foreign banks, banking sources said today.

PATENTS;
Spurring Ingenuity In Children
description: LEAD: A NATIONWIDE program designed to stimulate inventiveness in American school-age children will start on Feb. 5 with a three-day conference here for 600 teachers. Sponsored by the United States Patent Model Foundation, the program, ''Invent America!,'' is expected to involve 85,000 elementary schools throughout the country.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income
