New State Dept. Computers: 'Awesome'
description: With economics becoming increasingly important in international affairs, the State Department is trying to compile as much data as possible on topics like overseas trade, foreign manufacturing trends and currency exchange rates.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Still Coaching Hockey at 76
description: He is 76 years old, the namesake of the local football field, creator of championship hockey teams and by his admission not such a nice man once he gets behind the bench. ''Just ask my wife,'' he said the other day. ''In hockey, you have to yell, but I'm against all the rough stuff. I think hockey's gotten too rough, and I come from the days when team managers went around the locker room collecting everybody's false teeth before each game.''

title: Floods in Argentina Kill 7
description: Torrential rains in a remote region along the border with Paraguay have left at least seven people dead, including six children, the police said today. Another 4,000 people have been evacuated to a hospital in this northern Argentine town.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. SEEKS PROSECUTOR IN NOFZIGER CASE
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had asked for a special prosecutor to investigate Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, and his efforts to lobby the White House on behalf of a California rice company.

title: U.S. MINERALS EXPLORATIONS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $1,000 loss from discontinued oil and gas operations for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes an $8,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $117,000 estimated loss on the disposal of oil and gas operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,000 and $13,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Official Language
description: On the heels of the landslide vote in California that established English as the state's ''official language,'' a Washington-based group, calling itself English First, says it will put adoption of a constitional amendment to do the same thing for the entire nation at the top of its agenda this year.

title: ERICH LEINSDORF CONDUCTS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The pieces that began and ended Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall shared not only a common tradition but an unusual informality. Thus the Mozart Symphony in A (No. 29) and Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' seem to burst in on the listener unannounced. There are no preparations, no introductions; they simply appear with a startling abruptness. Another shared quality - they endure as two of the most endearing symphonies in the Classical repertory.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AFTER THE COURT BATTLE, A WAR OVER LIQUOR PRICES
description: At 3 P.M. Wednesday, the day after the United States Supreme Court declared illegal a New York State law setting a minimum markup on liquor prices, Steve Hollister posted in his East Side window new low costs for about 20 items.

title: UNIBANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $787,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $2,597,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $534,000 from reversal of a tax benefit for the quarter.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 14
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a stock dividend issued in January 1987.

title: State Urges Citadel Changes
description: A state commission today recommended several changes to improve race relations at the Citadel, where a racial hazing incident occurred in October.

title: New De Larosiere Post
description: Jacques de Larosiere, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, took over today as the governor of the French central bank. Bankers noted that Mr. de Larosiere was taking over responsibility at the central bank at a particularly difficult moment for the franc. Last week's realignment of European Monetary System currency values is already being tested by the weakening dollar and skeptical currency markets.

title: IRAN CLAIMS GAINS ON KEY ISLAND
description: Iran asserted today that it had captured most of a strategic island southeast of Basra in the Shatt al Arab, the waterway at the head of the Persian Gulf.

title: ON SALE: 12 TITANIC-SIZE SHIPS
description: The United States Lines has a problem: How to quickly get rid of 12 of the world's largest container ships -six of them dominating the Hudson River waterfront on Manhattan's West Side.

title: GRUMMAN TO END 1,500 JOBS ON L.I.
description: Long Island's largest employer, the Grumman Corporation, said today that it planned to eliminate about 1,500 jobs in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. It is the first time in more than decade that Grumman has cut its Long Island work force.

title: Wardair in Pact With Airbus
description: Wardair International, the Canadian airline, said that it had agreed to buy 12 wide-body A310 aircraft from the European Airbus consortium in a deal valued at $780 million. The agreement was made public Thursday night in connection with the twoday Canadian visit of the French Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard Raimond.

title: What Health-Maintenance Groups Do Well
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the fiscal 1986 results have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1986.

title: Caterpillar Unit Sit-In
description: About 370 Caterpillar Inc. workers spent a third day in a factory that the American farm equipment manufacturer says it plans to close this year, with a loss of 1,220 jobs.

title: AFGHAN CAPITAL UNEASY AS SOVIET UNITS GATHER
description: Soviet forces staged a major show of force in Kabul today, and Western diplomats said it suggested concern about possible guerrilla attacks or factional fighting among Afghan political groups.

title: TOLLNER JOINS BILLS
description: Ted Tollner, the former head coach at Southern California whose recent losses to Donahue's U.C.L.A teams were a factor in his dismissal Dec. 8, was named yesterday as receivers coach for the Buffalo Bills. The Bills' chief offensive weapon is the passing of Jim Kelly. The Bills also hired Ted Marchiboda, the head coach of the Baltimore Colts from 1975 to 1979, and named him the quarterback coach and passing-game coordinator. Also named to the staff of Coach Marv Levy was Bruce DeHaven, a former assistant with three United States Football League teams, who will work with special teams. Tollner, 46 years old, had a 26-20 record in four seasons at U.S.C. and Marchiboda, 55, a 41-36-0 record with Baltimore before being replaced in 1980.

title: COLGATE SLIDE ENDS
description: Within five games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association record for most consecutive losses by a Division I team, the Red Raiders of Colgate ended a 32-game losing streak Thursday night with a 76-64 victory over Manhattanville, a Division III opponent, at Hamilton, N.Y. A home crowd of 350 danced on the court after Colgate won for the first time in 14 games this season under the new coach, Joe Baker, and stopped worrying about tying or breaking the record of 37 straight losses set by The Citadel in 1954 and 1955. For a team so unaccustomed to winning, there was apprehension till the end. ''Somebody said a long time ago the game's not over until the fat lady sings, and I never heard her tonight,'' said Baker, whose team's string of 48 straight losses in the E.C.A.C. North Atlantic Conference remains intact.

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GUINNESS TELLS OF WRONGDOING
description: Guinness P.L.C., the embattled British brewer, admitted today that its management used illicit deals and made unexplained payments in a multibillion-dollar corporate takeover last year.

title: HOW TO STAY INFORMED IN CASE OF RAIL STRIKE
description: With the possibility that unions of the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike early today, officials provided the following telephone numbers for information about train service and bus and car-pool arrangements: L.I.R.R. BUSES AND SUBWAYS Metropolitan Suburban Bus System (Nassau County), (516) 222-1000. Suffolk County Bus System, (516) 360-5700. New York City Transit Authority, (718) 330-1234. EXPRESS BUS/PARK AND RIDE Nassau County Planning Department, (516) 294-7094. Suffolk County Transportation Department, (516) 360-5700. Queens Borough President's Office, (718) 520-3447. description: b-Includes a $33,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Reagan Supporters Unite
description: After some initial disarray and hesitancy, President Reagan's grass-roots supporters appear to have formed a united front. A coalition, America at Risk, organized last month, has now coalesced with the active support of three of the Administration's point men.

title: BONN MAY BALK AT EXTRADITING TERROR SUSPECT
description: The West German Government said today that a Lebanese believed to be a pro-Iranian terrorist could be extradited to the United States only if a commitment was given that he would not be subject to the death penalty.

title: STAGE: THE ICE CAPADES WHIRLS INTO THE GARDEN
description: There was an air of deceptive thaw outside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday evening as temperatures -by January standards - soared. Inside, however, it was a season of the brave and the beautiful and the extraordinarily well balanced - in this year's incarnation of the Ice Capades.

title: BLACK DEBATE THE INFLUENCES OF TOBACCO INDUSTRY
description: The huge billboards cannot be missed, appearing in just about every black neighborhood in big cities across the country: beautiful black models, always enjoying themselves, smoking cigarettes and urging blacks to follow suit.

title: MILK PRICES PLUNGE IN NEW YORK CITY IN A BURST OF COMPETITION
description: Milk prices dropped between 18 and 71 cents a gallon in New York City supermarkets this week in the face of new competition from a New Jersey dairy.

title: ATLANTIC FINANCIAL FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $4,852,000.

title: Topics: Sense and Spectacle; Wow at BAM
description: Everything about Robert Wilson's ''the CIVIL warS: Act V - The Rome Section'' seemed calculated to turn away baffled audiences during its recent run. Characters in this avant-garde work include Lincoln (hobbling on enormous stilts), a Snow Owl, Hercules, Robert E. Lee (seen turning in the porthole of a spaceship) and a troupe of Hopi Indians and Italian Redshirts. And there's Garibaldi, singing ''Rome or Death!'' or some such from a balcony, in the insistently repetitious score by Philip Glass.

title: FIRST JERSEY SETTLEMENT
description: First Jersey Securities has agreed to pay $10 million to settle a class action suit charging that the brokerage firm defrauded customers by charging excessive markups in a number of stocks.

title: PARENTS ENCOURAGE CHILDREN TO DONATE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Some parents hope donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will help teach their children the importance of charity.

title: Takeover Rejected By Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said today that it had rejected a revised takeover offer from an investor group headed by Resource Holdings Ltd.

title: EQUITABLE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' per share earnings were adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Would it have been reasonable for me, for example, without any Presidential approval, in the obvious opposition of the Secretary of Defense, to tell Israel: 'Go ahead and deliver arms, and then you can come to the Pentagon and buy arms from a Secretary of Defense who is fundamentally opposed to it?' Clearly not.'' - Robert C. McFarlane. [ 6:5. ]

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about the arrest of a New York City police officer charged with stealing money from the bank account of his estranged wife misstated part of the accusation. The officer, Robert Fioretti, is charged with having used a forged withdrawal slip - not a deposit slip - to steal $18,000 from her bank account.

title: HEALTH CHIEF WARNS AIDS WILL ALTER CITY
description: New York City's Health Commissioner, Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, warned yesterday that the projected rise in AIDS cases ''will change everything about the city, its demography, the political and economic life of the city.''

title: PARK ADVOCATES RISE TO DEFEND THE TREES
description: TREE rustlers have stolen four large unwieldy ones from Inwood Hill Park, and New York's tree lovers - sometimes mad, always passionate - are clamoring for the thieves to be brought to justice and torn limb from limb.

title: DEVILS, UP BY 2 LOSE TO JETS
description: The Devils scored three power-play goals against the league's top penalty-killing team, but their game failed them in other ways tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Soviet Leader at Arms Talks Plans Absences From Geneva
description: The new head of the Soviet arms control delegation, Yuli M. Vorontsov, has told American officials that he does not plan to be in Geneva for the entire round of negotiations, which began this week, Administration officials said today.

title: TENTATIVE PACT IS REACHED IN LONG USX STEEL DISPUTE
description: Negotiators for the USX Corporation and the Unitd Steelworkers of America reached a tentative settlement early today that would, if approved by the union's members, end the longest work stoppage in the United States steel industry.

title: Foley's-Sanger Merger Planned
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said that it was merging its two Texas store divisions, Foley's in Houston and Sanger Harris in Dallas, into one 37-store operation. The combined division, which will have sales of about $1.1 billion and be Federated's largest division, will be based in Houston and all stores will bear the Foley's name.

description: Marla Hanson, the model disfigured in a razor attack, yesterday sued the man who has been convicted of arranging the assault.

description: YOU are standing in the cereal aisle at the grocery store, trying to decide whether your wife would rather eat Fruit Pebbles or Fruit Loops for breakfast. Cost is not the issue, nor is nutrition, and she has expressed interest in both. You are stumped.

title: Why So Pale And Wan?
description: The city of Washington is very interesting. The people in the city of Washington are very interesting, too. One of the most interesting things about the people of Washington, if you do not happen to live here, is how modest and delicate they seem.

Matt Hazeltine, 53, Is Dead; Former Linebacker for 49ers
description: Matt Hazeltine, one of three former San Francisco 49er players stricken with Lou Gehrig's disease in the last two years, died from the disease Wednesday. He was 53 years old.

title: DONAHUE TO STAY PUT
description: Despite reports that he would take the job, Coach Terry Donahue of U.C.L.A. has decided not to become head coach of the Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League, spurning an offer reported at $2.5 million over five years. Taylor Smith, the Falcons' executive vice president, announced that Donahue had ''decided it was in his best interest to remain at U.C.L.A. where he was well established.'' The 42-year-old college coach, who has an 88-34-7 record in 11 seasons with the Bruins, has won five straight bowl games, including three in the Rose Bowl, and has defeated Southern California, U.C.L.A.'s crosstown rival, in four of their last five meetings. He is the second well-known coach to reject an offer from Atlanta, which dismissed Dan Henning on Dec. 22 after a fourth straight losing season. Dick Vermeil, the former coach of the Philadelphia Eagles who is now a pro football television analyst, turned down the Falcons last month and recommended Donahue. . . . Unable to agree on a new contract, Wake Forest's Al Groh resigned yesterday as the Demon Deacons' head coach.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15. o

title: CREDITORS PUTTING PRESSURE ON SAUDI
description: The Saudi business executive Adnan M. Khashoggi is facing increasing pressure from creditors trying to recover unpaid debts of many millions of dollars, according to records and associates.

title: New Zealand Trims U.S. Rival's Sails
description: A startling spinnaker foul-up on Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes today allowed Chris Dickson and his New Zealand team to come from behind and win their first race in the challenger finals for the America's Cup.

title:
PATENTS;
TALKING BOOK KEEPS UP WITH TURNING OF PAGES
description: LEAD: A talking book with a detector that notes page-turning and regulates the sound accordingly has been invented by two Massachusetts men. Paul E. Brefka and Klaus R. Pichler assigned patent 4,636,881 to James T. Shaw of Sagaponack, L.I. Mr. Shaw plans to arrange for a manufacturer.

title: M'FARLANE ADMITS U.S. INTELLIGENCE ON IRAN WAS POOR
description: The Reagan Administration official who initiated the arms shipments to Iran acknowledged today that the United States had virtually no independent intelligence to support its policy.

title: DOW RISES 5.90 MORE TO 2,076.63
description: The Dow Jones industrial average managed to rise for the 11th straight time yesterday, despite waves of profit taking and an apparent reluctance by many investors to accumulate stocks at current high prices.

title: ALREADY, 'MISERABLES' IS A BOX-OFFICE MARVEL
description: Five weeks before its first performance, ''Les Miserables'' has shattered two Broadway box-office records.

title: AT 8 A.M.., OR 7, THE HAIRDRESSER'S THERE
description: There may still be women who get up late, go to lunch and spend the afternoon at the hairdresser. But Eileen Ford, Heidi Freund and Rosalie Stern are not among them. They are members of a growing constituency of busy women (and men, too) who schedule their hair appointments before 9 A.M. - sometimes before 8 -to get a fast start on the day.

title: ARTHUR DREXLER, 61, AUTHORITY ON ARCHITECTURE
description: Arthur Drexler, for 35 years the highly influential curator and director of the Department of Architecture and Design at the Museum of Modern Art, died of pancreatic cancer in New York yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: UNIFORM CHANGES BUT TROUBLES CONTINUE
description: Beneath the slightly ironic smile, Mark Haynes leaves the impression that, on second thought, he'd rather be back with the Giants.

title: EDWARD D. KUEKES
description: Edward D. Kuekes, whose editorial cartoon on the irony of young men going to war before being old enough to vote won him a Pulitzer Prize in 1953, died Tuesday in a retirement home in Oklahoma City. He was 85 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 17, 1987
description: Markets

title: 2 LEADERS FOLLOWED PARALLEL CAREERS WITH CONTRASTING STYLES
description: Though they have markedly different political styles and personal backgrounds, Zhao Ziyang and the man he replaced yesterday, Hu Yaobang, both owe their rise through the Chinese hierarchy to the same factor: the sponsorship of the country's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping.

title: SCHLICHTER ARRESTED IN BETTING INQUIRY
description: Art Schlichter, a former all-America quarterback at Ohio State whose National Football League career was interrupted by a 1983 suspension because of gambling, was one of seven men arrested here today in an investigation of a multimillion-dollar college and professional sports betting operation. Warrants were issued for six other suspects.

title: VAST JAPAN TRADE GAIN WITH U.S.
description: Japan reported a vast increase in its trade surplus with the United States yesterday, underlining the magnitude of America's trade problems with Japan.

title: LEADER OF PARTY IN CHINA IS OUSTED FOR HIS 'MISTAKES'
description: Hu Yaobang, the chief of the world's largest Communist Party, was forced to resign today after being accused of major ''mistakes'' during his tenure. His dismissal followed recent demonstrations for freer expression and democracy in China.

title: TEXAS PRISONS STOP ACCEPTING INMATES UNDER FEDERAL ORDER
description: The beleaguered Texas prison system today was forced to temporarily stop admitting new prisoners after its population crept above levels mandated by a Federal court order.

title: YOUR MONEY OWNING REALTY IN SMALL UNITS
description: INVESTORS have a new way of getting capital gains, income or both in the real estate field, thanks to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

description: The taxable value of property in New York City has been set tentatively at $60.7 billion, an increase of $5.3 billion that is the largest annual rise in the city's history, municipal officials said yesterday.

title: Loan Rate Cut
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it would lower the maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages to 8.5 percent, the lowest level in almost nine years.

title: IN MANHATTAN, AMPUTATED BUILDINGS
description: LEAD: After a Barnard student was killed in 1979 by a piece of masonry that fell from an apartment building on Broadway, the city enacted a law mandating that building facades be maintained ''in a safe condition.'' Known as Local Law 10, the statute was passed with the laudable intention of preventing further fatalities.

DOUBLEDAY PRESIDENT NAMED
description: Nancy Evans, editor in chief of the Book-of-the-Month Club, has been named president and publisher of Doubleday. Previously the book columnist for Glamour magazine, Ms. Evans is also an author and is the co-host of ''First Edition,'' the book club's review and interview program on public television.

title: ECUADOR TROOPS KIDNAP PRESIDENT AND TRADE HIM FOR FAILED GENERAL
description: A group of armed military men seized President Leon Febres Cordero today and released him 12 hours later in exchange for an Air Force general who had been arrested in a mutiny 10 months ago.

description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Heublein Inc. wine and spirits subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British brewing, hotel and leisure concern, for $1.2 billion.

Did He Drop Protege Or Was He Forced?
description: The abrupt ouster of Hu Yaobang, China's Communist Party chief, raises the question whether the move was engineered by Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, or was forced on Mr. Deng by increasingly powerful hard-liners in the party.

title: LANGER FIRST IN PALM SPRINGS
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany didn't quite bring the new PGA West course to its knees. That may never happen.

title: European Joblessness
description: Unemployment in the 12-nation European Community rose by 130,000 in November, pushing the total number of registered jobless to 16.2 million, the community said.

title: MOCK SECURITY HIJACKING ALARMS INDIANS, INCLUDING SOME OFFICIALS
description: Indian security forces staged a mock hijacking of a commercial plane by supposed Sikh extremists today in an operation so realistic that for hours several officials said they believed a real hijacking was under way.

title: TWO GIANT PANDAS TO VISIT THE BRONX ZOO
description: Two giant pandas will be sent to New York City by China for a three-month stay at the Bronx Zoo, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

BLACK MUSLIM CHARGES IN SLAYING OF ISLAMIC SCHOLAR AND HIS WIFE
description: A man identified as a Black Muslim was arraigned here today in the fatal stabbing of an internationally known Islamic scholar and his wife, but the authorities said they did not know what motivated the slayings.

title: NETWORKS AND N.F.L. ARE DRAWING THE BATTLE LINES
description: For many years, the three major television networks and the National Football League have formed a partnership that has handsomely benefited everyone involved. ABC, CBS and NBC paid top price for exclusive rights to the games, filling the coffers of team owners, helping to fund increased player salaries, and, most years, earning millions of dollars in profits for themselves.

title: STRANDED BY POLITICS AND WAR: NICARAGUA'S LOVED, NEGLECTED POET
description: ONE can hardly imagine how remote the newborn republic of Nicaragua must have been from the world's cosmopolitan centers during the last century. It was perceived, not quite correctly, as a tropical backwater, steamy, inert and destitute of learning and culture. Yet from a wretched Nicaraguan village, by some amazing mystery, emerged Ruben Dario, the vagabond poet who was to influence Latin American and Spanish literature forever and dazzle Europe as no provincial ever had. ''That such a thing could happen makes you believe either in God or Darwin,'' said Carlos Martinez Rivas, a prominent Nicaraguan poet who, inescapably, has spent much of his life immersed in Dario's legacy.

title: CAGE CENTER: YOUTHS FIGHT FOR A FUTURE
description: WHILE a tall, clean-cut boy of 17 galloped around the ring throwing punches in too-rapid succession for his balance, a rugged 16-year-old hit a heavy bag that hung across the room.

title: The Historical Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKES ARE GETTING FEWER BUT LONGER
description: WHIPSAWED by automation, increasingly anti-union managements and a large pool of unemployed people willing to break a strike, many union members are finding that ''givebacks'' - cuts in wages and benefits - have become a fact of life. One result appears to be fewer but longer strikes. While the rank and file often regarded concessions as onerous from the start, labor leaders strove mightily to put the best face on them, calling them temporary measures to strengthen companies and, above all, protect jobs.

title: All in One's Stride
description: To walk with a spring in one's stride is no longer a mere phrase. Scientists at Leeds in England have measured the springiness in the arch of the human foot. Running, in their analysis, is a matter not of sweat and endurance but of storing and expending energy between strides - ''like a rubber ball bouncing along.''

title: IRE AROUND THE NEW YORKER
description: Writers and editors at the The New Yorker may have become so accustomed to their literary freedom that they confused it with democracy. description: Dollar Diplomacy

title: UNLIKELY GAME JOINS ROSTER OF WINTER SPORTS
description: LIGHT snow fell on the D. Fairchild Wheeler municipal golf course in Fairfield, atop the four inches from a previous storm. It looked like no day for a round of golf. Not even for a diehard.

title: OF NEW ISSUES, CONTINUING SERIES AND FIRST DAY COVERS
description: A new set was issued Jan. 5 by Palau, one of the United Nations Trust Territories administered by the United States. The block of four depicts butterflies from the south Pacific island nation and enhances a popular topical specialty: butterflies-on-stamps. As with the butterflies themselves, the stamps are collected because of their beautiful colors and great variety.

title: WHAT DRACULA WAS REALLY UP TO
description: LEAD: FORBIDDEN PARTNERS The Incest Taboo in Modern Culture. By James B. Twitchell. Illustrated. 311 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $24.95.

title: WHERE HISTORY'S SWEEP CONQUERS THE VISITOR
description: LEAD: Julius Caesar once had so quick and successful a trip to what is now Turkey that he celebrated with a terse alliteration: Veni, vidi, vici - I came, I saw, I conquered. Having disposed of Pharnaces II, the son of King Mithridates, who had backed his enemy, Pompey the Great, in the Roman Civil War, Julius returned to face sharper foes in Rome itself.

title: Salvador State of Siege to Expire
description: A state of siege that had been in effect almost continuously since 1980 has expired after members of the conservative minority in the National Assembly, who are on strike, refused to act on a bill to renew the restrictions.

title: Cold Wave in Russia Alarms Soviet Chiefs
description: Soviet leaders have expressed alarm at the possible harm to the economy by the exceptionally harsh weather that has gripped the Soviet Union since the start of the year.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: THE FOLK OF THE AIR (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95) by Peter S. Beagle, a fantasy novel set in contemporary California, mixes science and the supernatural so seamlessly that the bedazzled reader soon ceases to care which is which. Certainly none of the characters in this book stay up nights worrying about such distinctions.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S VINTAGE WHINES
description: BACKSTORY Interviews With Screenwriters of Hollywood's Golden Age. Edited by Pat McGilligan. Illustrated. 382 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $27.50.

title: Elizabeth Nay, Fund-Raiser in Capital, Marries Robert H. Schwengel, Student
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday Elizabeth Denby Nay, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Riley Nay of Tenafly, was married to Robert Harrison Schwengel, a son of Franklin D. Schwengel of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Lynn Kenworthy Schwengel. The Rev. Harry E. Chase performed the ceremony.

title: Master Of the Sentimental Sell
description: During the 1984 Presidential campaign, I suddenly noted that, from the preambles, I couldn't differentiate between commercials extolling the virtues of the President and those promoting raisin bread (''Master of the Sentimental Sell,'' by Art Kleiner, Dec. 14). Distressed, I monitored other facets of my cognitive processes and was comforted to find no other evidence of deterioration.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed tomorrow in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - Regular collections. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Connecticut, closed; banks in New York and New Jersey have the option of closing. Financial markets - Open. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road Metro-North and N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. Schools - Most schools closed in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Libraries - Closed.

title: EPIC BATTLES IN THE WAR BETWEEN IRAN AND IRAQ
description: Iran and Iraq agree that their battles of the last 10 days have been epic, even by the grisly standards of their seven-year war. But in what has become a ritual, both countries claimed victory last week and issued grandiose assertions.

title: WHILE MR. WHOEVER-HE-IS SLEEPS
description: JOYCE'S BOOK OF THE DARK Finnegans Wake. By John Bishop. Illustrated. 479 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $25.

title: THE SUMMIT FOR COLLECTORS
description: THE END OF JANUARY may be when some people flee the city to escape winter doldrums, but for the serious collector New York is the only place to be. The annual Winter Antiques Show, which opens to the public Saturday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street and runs through Feb. 1, has traditionally been a catalyst for antiques events in New York - a time when galleries dress up their windows with knock-em-dead pieces and auction houses conduct some of the most important Americana sales of the year.

title: COLLEGES PRODDED TO PROVE WORTH
description: American colleges and universities, which have operated for more than three centuries on the premise that the fruits of higher education are self-evident, are facing mounting pressure to prove that their students are being educated.

title: BETTING WITH THE ODDS
description: The card-playing enthusiasm of the British aristocracy has added more than one word to the English language. In the 18th century the third Earl of Sandwich, a diplomat and politician of some notoriety nicknamed Jeremy Twitcher, was unwilling to take time out from his game to eat. He asked the waiter to bring him some meat between two slices of bread and millions now use his name daily.

title: GAMBITLESS VERVE
description: It is unusual for a game to be seriously considered for a brilliancy prize if it does not feature sacrifice of material. One may surmise that, if a player ingeniously maneuvers to obtain a clearly better position and presses the attack relentlessly and with great style, the judges still feel he is not venturing anything and hence is not making the supreme prize effort.

title: ASTRONAUT WAS TOLD O RINGS WERE 'PROBLEM'
description: An executive of Morton Thiokol Inc. has said in sworn testimony that the space agency's chief astronaut asked about booster rocket seals in late 1985, and he replied, ''It appears to be a problem.''

title: BRONCOS ARE PART OF DENVER LANDSCAPE
description: IT is the confluence of the Rocky Mountain myths: here, in one glorious weekend, there is the convocation of cowboys, Indians and Broncos.

title: How to Stay Informed In Case of Rail Strike
description: With the possibility that unions of the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike today, officials provided these telephone numbers for information about transportation arrangements: L.I.R.R. L.I.R.R. strike hot line: (718) 468-8600 or (516) 422-4040, taped message. L.I.R.R. 24-hour Travel Information Center: New York City, (718) 454-LIRR; Nassau, (516) 794-LIRR; western Suffolk, (516) 234-LIRR; eastern Suffolk (516) 758-LIRR. BUSES AND SUBWAYS Metropolitan Suburban Bus System (Nassau County), (516) 222-1000. Suffolk County Bus System, (516) 360-5700. New York City Transit Authority, (718) 330-1234. EXPRESS BUS/PARK AND RIDE Nassau County Planning Department, (516) 294-7094. Suffolk County Transportation Department, (516) 360-5700. Queens Borough President's Office, (718) 520-3447. CAR POOLS AND TAXIS Island Rides, (516) 423-2277, Nassau County Taxi Owners, (516) 225-1235. Suffolk County Taxi Owners, (516) 744-2002.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING: TROOPER'S CRUSADE
description: TROOPER JIM BARNES is persuaded he had to tell teen-agers about the results of drunken driving he had seen. As he carried a microphone while pacing in front of the stage in the auditorium of the Francis T. Maloney High School in Meriden this month, the 31-year-old trooper recalled an accident in Montville four and a half years ago.

title: Dance
description: French dance is enjoying a renaissance. And the venerable Paris Opera Ballet is not the only important French choreographic center today. The enterprising Lyon Opera Ballet opens Tuesday at the City Center with Maguy Marin's ''Cinderella,'' which promises to be like no other version of the fairy tale. All the action takes place in a dollhouse and a jitterbugging Cinderella rides off to the ball in a pink convertible. Another French company, the Paris-based Ballet de France, established in 1985, will also offer an unusual treatment of a familiar story. Gray Veredon's ''Romeo et Juliette,'' to be danced by the troupe Saturday night at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, retells Shakespeare's classic tragedy - but to Berlioz, rather than to the Prokofiev score most choreographers employ. (For an interview with Francoise Adret, artistic director of the Lyon Opera Ballet, see the Dance page of the Arts and Leisure section.) Among the American choreographers who are influential in France is Kansas-born Karole Armitage, whose works often combine classicism with punk. A ballet-trained dancer who was formerly a member of both the Geneva Ballet in Switzerland and Merce Cunningham's modern-dance company, Ms. Armitage has organized a new group, the Armitage Ballet, which opens Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. Guest artists will be Stephanie Saland and Robert La Fosse of the New York City Ballet, and Robert Blankshine, formerly of the Joffrey Ballet.

title: A TROUPE THAT REVELS IN MIME AS SATIRE
description: The Adaptors, whose ''movement theater'' piece ''Autobahn'' has just enjoyed a resounding critical success, are not billed as mimes. Nonetheless, the troupe's founders, Tony Brown and Kari Margolis, both studied in Paris with the master of classical mime, Etienne Decroux, and they performed with the Montreal mime group Omnibus.

title: Don Redlich Dancers In 'Pierrot Lunaire'
description: The Don Redlich Dance Company will present a new version of ''Pierrot Lunaire'' in performances Feb. 5 through 7 at 8 P.M. at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: In his new budget, President Reagan has proposed raising Congressional salaries to $89,500 a year, from $77,500. The increase will take effect automatically next month unless both houses of Congress vote to block it.

title: Porters' Contract Triggers Commercial Rent Rises
description: A NEW labor contract covering janitors and porters in 1,200 commercial buildings in New York City has triggered monthly rent increases for most tenants of nearly $3 a square foot.

title: Miss Schwalb to Marry Joel Hollander
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Schwalb of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Robin Schwalb, to Joel Daniel Hollander, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton B. Hollander, also of Stamford.

title: Woodbridge
description: AS lower Fairfield County becomes more and more urban, the quiet, rustic charm and spacious lots of bucolic communities like Woodbridge become more desirable and less remote to many home buyers.

title: COMPANY'S VOLUNTEERS COUNSEL SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: IN Norwalk, Gwendolyn Gaither has found a new friend in Christine Kantzas, an 8-year-old student at the Fox Run Elementary School. Ms. Gaither, an employee of the human resources department at Occidental Chemical Corporation, which has its headquarters near the school, is one of 50 employees who have volunteered to spend time with youngsters at Fox Run.

title: CAVALIERS BEAT KNICKS, 116-110
description: The last time the Knicks lost to the youthful Cleveland Cavaliers, the coach emerged from the locker-room looking drawn and drained, and he spoke in terms of ''I'' and not ''we'' in an effort to divorce himself from his team. Two days later, Hubie Brown was dismissed.

title: PREGNANCY LEAVE FOR WOMEN, AND MEN
description: For women serious about both career and family, life can quickly become a difficult balancing act. A new Supreme Court decision promises to make the balancing a bit easier. It allows states to guarantee job-protected leave to pregnant workers.

title: Fuming
description: To the Editor: Shouldn't we fault the Federal Government for speaking with a forked tongue where tobacco consumption is concerned? On the one hand, the Surgeon General cautions against use of the weed; on the other, Washington continues its generous subsidies to tobacco growers. THOMAS G. MORGANSEN Jackson Heights, N.Y., Jan. 5

title: The Intimate Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: BY ANY NAME What's in a name? Apparently, everything. So in the pursuit of accuracy, the Nassau County Puppet Theater has become the Nassau County Children's Playhouse; and all because, on occasion, live actors have spelled their wooden colleagues. With its new name, and with a flesh-and-blood person in the title of ''Little Red Riding Hood,'' the Playhouse today moves to Bay Park in East Rockaway.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Given the burgeoning throng of Presidential aspirants, it is increasingly difficult to find a novel way to make one's availability known - short, of course, of some gaucherie like, ''Well, for my part, I'd like to be President of the United States.''

title:
CABLE NOTES;
DISCOVERY CHANNEL FAVORS NATURE FARE
description: LEAD: Since its inception in June 1985, The Discovery Channel has been television's sole showcase exclusively devoted to nonfiction fare, providing a continuous array of programs grouped under the rubrics ''Nature,'' ''Science and Technology,'' ''People and Places,'' ''Adventure'' and ''History.''

title: READERS WRITE ABOUT PROBLEMS THAT PLAGUE THEIR HOMES
description: TO catch up on the backlog of mail, this week's column is again devoted to readers' questions about common home-repair and maintenance problems.

title: CONNER'S CREW SAILS TO 3-1 LEAD
description: The boat with a racing record so exemplary that she has acquired the nickname Kiwi Magic sailed in the America's Cup challenge finals today as if someone had cut a hole in her bag of tricks.

title: 2 ESCAPE FROM A U.S. CENTER
description: Two inmates, lowering themselves down bedsheets from a fourth-floor recreation area, escaped yesterday from an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in lower Manhattan, immigration officials said.

title: Fishing on Thin Ice
description: As the trout and salmon season on inland lakes begins today, officials are warning anglers to beware of thin ice. ''Most of the lakes that are usually frozen and safe by now aren't,'' said John Hall of the Fish and Wildlife Department. ''There are dangerous conditions near the mouth of rivers, near points of land, bridges, and over reefs.'' Lakes and ponds designated for fishing include Lake Willoughby in Westmore, Lake Dunmore in Salisbury, Caspian Lake in Greensboro and Lake Seymour in Morgan.

(Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 3 2 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: ''Through Alaska On Your Own'' by Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton (Travel, Dec. 21) reminded me of a favorite part of my own independent trip through the Canadian Rockies and Alaska last summer. We took a local train from Anchorage to Denali National Park and saw a rich variety of people and scenes: professional couples heading for their weekend cabins, retired railroad workers debarking at their front doors, a horde of people netting king salmon in a stream, a load-carrying huskie and its owner, mail tossed out the window at specific locations and an anxious-looking man from California, holding a fishing pole, who hoped his son hadn't forgotten to meet him. We were allowed to roam through the train.

title: BEYOND REAL ESTATE AND RIGATONI: Henry A. Lambert; Stirring Up the Next Course
description: CAN Henry A. Lambert do for stews and pot pies what he did for pasta?

title: FOR THE RECORD
description: To the Editor: We were most interested to read Bernard Holland's recent account of the music-publishing industry and pleased by the attention he devoted to the new management of G. Schirmer [ ''For Music Publishing, Technology Means Hard Times,'' Dec. 7 ] . Still, there were a number of inaccuracies in the account that we wish to point out.

title: Eileen Conley to Wed C. E. B. Schlee in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Conley of Madison, N.J., of the engagement of his daughter M. Eileen Conley to Clive Edward Benedict Schlee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robin A. Schlee of Woodbridge, Suffolk, England. A June wedding is planned.

title: OPERA: 'ATYS', BY LULLY, IN PARIS
description: Jean-Baptiste Lully was the great operatic composer of the high French Baroque, the man who defined French opera in the age of Louis XIV. His works are rarely heard today, but that omission may be ending now that the French early-music movement has grown so confident and accomplished. Friday night at the Salle Favart, the Paris Opera presented Lully's ''Atys'' for the first time since 1760, when Lully's works were swept aside in the enthusiasm for the new music of Rameau and then Gluck. Sic transit operatic gloria.

title: NEW SHIITE TERROR FEARED IN EUROPE
description: The two Lebanese men arrested this week carrying explosives through the Milan and Frankfurt airports may have been part of a new terrorist offensive planned by radical Lebanese Shiites, according to senior American and Italian officials.

title: HE ALMOST MADE GARBO LAUGH
description: SEE YOU AT THE MOVIES The Autobiography of Melvyn Douglas. By Melvyn Douglas and Tom Arthur. Illustrated. 258 pp. Lanham, Md.: University Press of America. Cloth, $24.50. Paper, $9.75.

title: Learning On the Job
description: As a new high-school teacher in New York City, I do what I can to awaken, in each successive brood, love of the principles Mr. Rosenthal articulated in his article. I am going to use his essay to teach my students about the opportunities that I believe are available to them, just as they were available to him. BETSY FOGELMAN New York City

title: A NEW 'DRACULA' TO SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: FORTUNATELY, all of the wolfsbane in the world will not keep ''Dracula'' from appearing and reappearing in theaters everywhere. At the moment, this denizen of the dark side, this precursor to Darth Vader and the forces of evil past and present, is ensconced at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: 'STATE OF THE STATE' MESSAGE OPENS DOOR TO DEBATE
description: GOVERNOR KEAN delivered what he called an ''opportunity agenda'' to the Legislature last week, and one of the opportunities will be for heightened debate over his program in the coming months.

title: 'HUMAN ISSUES' IN WRECK INQUIRY
description: As officials said the investigation of Amtrak's worst accident was focusing on ''human performance issues,'' the National Transportation Safety Board recommended the wider use of technology that takes over if a human lapses.

title: COLD WEATHER TESTS RESOLVE OF BRITISH ISLES
description: The celebrated British stiff upper lip has been tested for the last week by the European cold spell and found quivering.

title: Finding Tax Shelter in a Second Home
description: FOR the thousands of individuals who own second homes, 1987 will mark a key turning point for tax benefits. People who rent out their vacation houses must decide whether to begin using the home as a second residence, so they can deduct the mortgage interest, or whether to continue renting so they can claim a loss on the business venture.

title: New York Revises Tenant Succession
description: THE New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which was expected to issue new rules for governing the city's 950,000 rent-stabilized apartments, instead has issued yet another set of proposed regulations. This document, the third proposal published by the agency in 15 months, contains hundreds of minor changes - including new provisions affecting a tenant's right to pass an apartment to family members. Neither tenant nor landlord representatives are happy with the latest proposals for revisions.

title: ECUADOR LEADER TELLS OF BEATINGS BY COMMANDOS WHO SEIZED HIM
description: The President of Ecuador said today that he was punched, kicked and repeatedly told he was going to be killed during the 12 hours he was held captive Friday.

title: THE BARBARISM OF THE STEEL-JAW TRAP
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature recently voted for a bill to ban the use of steel-jaw traps to capture animals. I was amazed to read that this is the first ban of these in this state, as I would have thought that these barbaric and cruel traps would have been banned long ago, particularly in the suburbs where the population is increasing and the habitat of small wild animals is rapidly dwindling.

title: 'BABY BOOMER' STIGMA STILL STICKS AT 40
description: LAST year was a long, strenuous year. Like 3.5 million other Americans, I turned 40 -several times.

title: Berkeley
description: To the Editor: You are to be commended for your recent article ''What's Doing in Berkeley'' in which most of the highlights of that delightful city were discussed.

title: CITY FAULTS STATE OFFER TO HELP PLACE BABIES
description: State officials say they have offered to help New York City find foster homes for the growing number of healthy babies in hospitals who are awaiting placement, but the city says the state's proposals are inadequate.

title: For Immigrants, a Rough Road
description: FOR years, the prevailing wisdom on how immigrants fare in the labor market has been based on the notion that assimilation is a key, even determining, factor. Drawing mainly on 1970 Census data, studies concluded that while earnings of new immigrants were lower than those of comparably situated native workers, earnings of immigrants who had been here for more than a decade exceeded those of native workers of the same age, education and so on. The assumption was that as immigrants gained language and work skills, their earnings grew.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE RED PRESIDENT. By Martin Gross. (Doubleday, $17.95.) What if a Communist were elected President of the United States? Not just a social democrat, but a fire-breathing Marxist-Leninist with plans to bring America into Moscow's orbit? The ''red'' of Martin Gross's title is Senator Jed Hankins of Virginia -wealthy, young, handsome and angling for the Democratic Presidential nomination on a platform of ''More Peace, More Prosperity.

title: Seeking Truth in Baseball
description: THIS was going to be a joyous midwinter review of the videotapes of the Mets' World Series victory, a last chance to revel in the glories of baseball before Super Bowl mania hits us like a ton of Twinkies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CASE OF THE FRAGMENTED WOMAN. By Cleo Jones. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mary Sable, the heroine of Cleo Jones's third novel, is a Marin County housewife and aspiring writer; she takes care of a husband who neither appreciates nor understands her, and three children, who treat her as little more than a maid. Dutifully, she tends to waxy buildup, and spends most of her day preparing meals, watching soap operas, meeting with her women's networking group and fretting over her unproductive life. It seems the only thing capable of rousing her from this ennui is a good murder to solve. The murder in question is that of a conniving local soap star, Hermoine Leanders. As a woman fooling around with half the male population within commuting distance of San Francisco, is it any wonder that one day Hermoine's head winds up in a prize box on a television game show? A roundup of the usual suspects includes not only cast and crew, but also Mary's best friend, Jill, whose husband has succumbed to Hermoine's charms. Mary is elected by her women's group to do some behind-the-scenes sleuthing and exonerate Jill. Ms. Jones is a deft writer and the novel, which is as much a satire of life in the slow lane as it is a mystery tale, is highlighted by some delightfully macabre touches, like a human foot served up on a tray as an hors d'oeuvre. The plot, however, is rather thin and Mary does little real detecting, so hardcore mystery buffs will likely be disappointed. And all the characters, save Mary, are boobs. As a result, the novel, much the same as Mary's life, is unfulfilling.

title: JEWISH GROUP ACCEPTS NEW EXPORTS TO SOVIET
description: An American advocacy group on Soviet Jewry has told the Government that it will not contest the decision on Thursday to allow exports of gas and oil technology to the Soviet Union.

title: A May 17 Wedding for Joanna Dember
description: William and Cynthia Dember of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanna Dember to Charles William Engelke, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Charles Edward Engelke of Jericho, L.I. The wedding is planned for May 17.

title: Jazz
description: Since Gerry Mulligan, the baritone and soprano saxophonist who is also an arranger, organized his 13-piece Concert Jazz Band in 1960, it has been an on-again, off-again part of his career. The original Concert Jazz Band was active until 1967 when Mr. Mulligan gave it up because, he said, ''it got to be taken for granted, like an old shoe.'' In 1973 he formed a flexible band - a quintet that could be expanded to 17 pieces - but is soon boiled down to a sextet.

title: A TALE OF THE HOUSE THAT SACK BUILT
description: When Israel Sack, a Lithuanian immigrant, began selling New England highboys and Philadelphia chairs to Bostonians at the turn of the century, the experience of collecting American antiques was akin to high adventure. That, in any case, is the way Harold Sack and Max Wilk describe it in ''American Treasure Hunt,'' published recently by Little, Brown and Company ($24.95).

title: BEARS' PRESIDENT EXPECTS DITKA TO STAY
description: The president of the Chicago Bears today denied reports that the Atlanta Falcons, who are still searching for a coach, had asked permission to talk to Mike Ditka, who has one year remaining on his contract with the Bears.

title: THE REGION
description: A sense of deja vu accompanied the unfolding of New York City's corruption scandals last week, but the news was all new. Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, was indicted on fresh charges in connection with Citisource, the computer company that figured prominently in his conviction on racketeering charges in November; Richard L. Rubin, a former secretary to the Queens Democratic organization, went on trial accused of putting two secretaries in his law firm on State Assembly payrolls, and Governor Cuomo named a Commission on Government Integrity to investigate corruption.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: STREAM OF HISTORY ''One of the most significant shifts in social studies has been toward an emphasis on local history,'' according to Roger Panetta, one of three speakers in a series of illustrated lectures about the Hudson River and its expanding place in American history. No longer a simple tale of Hendrick Hudson and his discovery of a great body of water, the river has been redefined as the location of some of America's outstanding architecture, as the inspiration for the country's first indigenous school of painting and as a benchmark of waterfront land use from residential to industrial and, lately, returning to residential.

title: Miss Sanclementi Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sanclementi of Wayne, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Sanclementi, to Richard Alan Balter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Balter of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Miss Sancelementi is vice president of corporate services at Murphy Realty-Better Homes and Gardens in Ramsey, N.J.

title: POSTINGS: New Try in Tarrytown; A Rent Reduction
description: The Christiania office building in Tarrytown, N.Y., was dedicated in 1984 by Crown Prince Harald and Crown Princess Sonja of Norway, but even that royal cachet was not enough to make it profitable. Now Morris Bailey of Morris Bailey Enterprises in Manhattan's financial district is taking a crack. He purchased the six-story, 210,000-square-foot building at the end of last year for $35 million from Christiania, a Norwegian insurance company. The company never was able to lease space in the building to any tenants other than itself and Ultramar, a diversified oil and energy business.

title: REDMEN DOMINATE U CONN
description: St. John's may not be back in the same groove that allowed it to win its first nine games this season. But after two straight losses and a couple of mediocre victories, the Redmen have apparently moved into a higher gear.

title: PACE EXPANSION
description: Pace University is expanding - again. On the Pleasantville campus, construction of a $3 million science building is now complete, and work on the second of three planned town-house residence halls is well under way. Next month, the 80-year-old university will hold a ribbon-cutting ceremony to celebrate the opening of its latest project, the $12 million Evelyn and Joseph I. Lubin Graduate Center in White Plains.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE other night an executive, dining at a moderately sized restaurant, paid his check with a credit card and added a rather generous tip. When the young waitress returned his card she said, ''Thank you very much, Charles.'' The two had never met - she had seen his name on the credit card.

title: FROM NEW YORK'S POOR AREAS TO PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: Regina Winters, 17 years old, grew up in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the daughter of a single woman on welfare. She now lives next door to a ''crack house.''

title: UNDER THE THUMB OF MEN
description: LOVE MUST NOT BE FORGOTTEN By Zhang Jie. 207 pp. San Francisco: China Books & Periodicals. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Miss Tiernan Wed in Jersey
description: Katharine Balfour Tiernan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Thomas Tiernan of Essex Fells, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter Michael Rooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Rooney of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: GERMANY EXPECTED TO CARRY ON WITH KOHL
description: UNLESS all of West Germany's opinion polls have made a huge miscalculation, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition will be re-elected next week.

title: TALE OF MYSTICISM ENDS UP MYSTIFYING
description: We can all rejoice, presumably, that Shirley MacLaine went to Peru and found inner peace. Unfortunately, however, ABC-TV has given her five hours of prime time to tell us all about it - in minute detail. For those of us who remain skeptical, at best, about reincarnation, extraterrestrials, out-of-body trippers and trance channelers, ''Out on a Limb'' may well prove to be this year's most excruciating television experience.

title: Master Of the Sentimental Sell
description: Thanks to Hal Riney for his Norman Rockwell approach to advertising. In a world as harsh and complex as ours is, his sentimental approach is refreshing! MANDY VICTOR Fairfield, Conn.

title: SECONDARY IMAGES IN VAN GOGH'S LANDSCAPES
description: To the Editor: While Michael Brenson is haunted by the faces in van Gogh's landscapes [ Jan. 4 ] , I am haunted by many of his statements: First of all, by his contention that ''van Gogh has never been identified with reason.'' I do not know (nor do I care) with what Mr. Brenson identifies van Gogh, but let him show us, in the three volumes of the painter's collected letters, a single unsound passage or argument. I find the Dutchman much more levelheaded than your critic's approach to his paintings, which I consider irrational.

title: Cable TV
description: There's good home viewing in some of the week's newer film fare, like Bravo's ''Bring On the Night'' (1985), a rock feature with Sting and his new group, done with originality and skill - Sunday at 8 P.M. and 2 A.M.; and the station's ''Camila'' (1984), a passionate, beautifully played and fact-based costume drama about the love of an aristocrat and a priest in Argentina - Monday at 8 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. Police-drama buffs should catch ''The Glitter Dome'' (1984) -Friday at 10 P.M. on HBO. This is one of the better versions of those flint-hard crime novels by Joseph Wambaugh - made for TV - about the seamy side of Hollywood. It has well-turned characterizations, including the lead partner detectives, along with nimble pacing and unforced dialogue, and an able cast headed by James Garner, John Lithgow and Margot Kidder.

title: IN TRUCE, FILIPINO REBELS PRESS A POLITICAL WAR
description: Striding through rice fields, Ka Christine, nine months pregnant, sang to herself with more enthusiasm than melody: ''Wave the red flag, advance the revolution.''

title: 2 Israelis Are Stabbed In Jerusalem's Market
description: Two Israeli men were stabbed today in the Old City market area, and the police said they suspected Arab guerrillas were responsible.

title: Karen Dowicz Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Zenon Dowicz of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Sea Girt, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Maryla Dowicz to Bruce Charles Haas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Haas of Packanack Lake, N.J.

title: SHELTERED BAHAMA ISLES
description: Competition for the accolade of the most idyllic outpost in the Caribbean is stiff, but for tranquil shallow waters, Liliputian villages with an 18th-century flavor and sun-drenched beaches, the Abacos are arguably the best.

title: ENHANCING BLACK SKIN
description: WITH BLACK MODELS among the stars of the fashion industry, and with the proliferation of skin-care and makeup lines for black consumers, the 1960's slogan ''black is beautiful'' is finally reaching commercial fulfillment. As Susan L. Taylor, the editor in chief of Essence magazine, explains: ''Black skin is such an incredible canvas. White against black skin is startling. The primary colors against black skin delight the eye. But what's exquisite about the black race is that it has every representation of humankind, from pale alabaster skin to cafe au lait to ebony.''

title: Toting Up Americans' Scores in Math
description: SOUNDING disappointed but not surprised, educators met in Washington last week to confront the news that in mathematics American pupils score dismally, compared to those in other industrialized countries. The symposium was sponsored by the National Research Council's Mathematical Sciences Education Board, which had issued three comparative studies pointing to serious shortcomings in American elementary and secondary schools. What mathematics educators might do about them was addressed by two panels. Excerpts from remarks by several participants follow. BEYOND COMPUTATION

title: Recent Sales
description: Ossining, N.Y. $230,000 14 Bracket Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; paneled den, deck, central A/C, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,822. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $495,000 Knapp Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; study, Jacuzzi, lake rights, abuts nature preserve, 2.2 acres; taxes not yet assessed. Rye, N.Y. $335,000 18 Harding Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, beach rights, walk to station; taxes $5,630. Darien, Conn. $640,000 64 Greenleaf Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; screened porch, den, 1 acre; taxes $4,377. Ridgefield, Conn. $335,000 198 Ramapoo Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, circa 1730 saltbox; detached studio, stone wall around 1.3 acres; taxes $2,702. Wilton, Conn. $685,000 224 Nod Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1810 colonial; moldings, swimming pool, 2 acres; taxes $4,117. OTHER AREAS Hempstead, L.I. $99,990 9 Thomas Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; finished basement, dining area, 1-car garage, aluminum siding; taxes $2,000. Hampton, N.J. $177,000 13 Conford Circle 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; patio, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,675. Livingston, N.J. $575,000 27 Mayhew Drive 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, large eat-in kitchen, deck, 3-car garage; taxes $6,334.

title: 30,000 Hail Penn State
description: This small college town was decked in blue and white today as a crowd estimated at 30,000 by the State Police honored Penn State's national championship football team at a parade through the campus and downtown. Penn State (12-0) defeated Miami, 14-10, in the Fiesta Bowl Jan. 2 for the title.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: It's not true that Congress and the White House have inadvertently cornered the market on political humor in Washington. The Capitol Steps, a troupe of Congressional staff members that specializes in musical satire, has been in such demand that it has been compelled to advertise for a full-time scheduler and public rela-tions agent. The ad in the current Roll Call, a weekly Hill tabloid, suggests that applicants should have ''the political savvy to correctly answer more questions than the typical Maryland Senate candidate,'' a reference to a particularly embarrassing 1986 campaign debate.

title: CAREFULL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: 20 Percent Discount Just the Beginning A Woman's Place opened in September in Kisco Plaza East in Mount Kisco - that is on East Main Street between Loehmann's and Benetton -and specializes in sizes 14 to 52, always at discounts of 10 to 20 percent off suggested retail prices. The semiannual clearance sale this month reduces prices an additional 30 to 50 percent on fall and winter merchandise.

title: Learning On the Job
description: Cheers to A. M. Rosenthal. Nobody has ever made a better case for how much a free press means to a free people. And he did it in prose as spare and lean as a good police reporter's account of a murder. If eternal vigilance really is the price of liberty, then America has been lucky these last 40 years to have had a bowman like old Four Eyes on the battlements. JANET O'DANIEL CICCHETTI Upper Nyack, N.Y.

title: Gail Weisen Married
description: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., last night Gail Robin Weisen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weisen of Merrick, L.I., was married to Louis Alan Gossert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gossert of Palm Harbor, Fla. Rabbi Robert Benjamin officiated. Mrs. Gossert, a certified public accountant for Ernst & Whinney in New York, graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo. Her husband, who graduated from SUNY at Albany, is an advertising account executive for The New York Post.

title: SHAW'S PLAYS GO ON TALKING TO MODERN AUDIENCES
description: George Bernard Shaw's contemporaries would have been astonished to know that his plays were still being performed around the world toward the end of the 20th century (''You Never Can Tell'' is now winding up a revival in New York). A playwright was the last thing they considered him to be. If theater reviewers agreed on nothing else, they were certain that he could not write for the stage. ''The trouble of course,'' explained Ibsen's translator, William Archer, ''is that he is not at all a good dramatist.'' And the venerable critic of The Times of London, A. B. Walkley, agreed: ''An admirable speaker - and a detestable dramatist,'' he decided. Not that G.B.S. wasn't capable, they all agreed, of some excellent fooling in a formless way - if only he had taken to comic opera there was no telling what he might have achieved.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES THAT COLOR THE WINTER LANDSCAPE
description: LEAD: ONE has but to travel through the countryside of the Northeast to discover the full potential that exists for winter color in the landscape. To be certain, the colors are for the most part muted when compared with those of spring, summer and fall, however, the subtle differences from species to species provide a panoramic contrast across the fields, meadows and mountainsides.

title: Massachusetts Town Ends a Siren Splurge
description: This town in western Massachusetts has been paying for years for electrical service to run an air-raid siren no one can find, town officials say.

title: Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
description: I am an archeologist who has worked for the last 10 years on protecting archeological sites. I have come to the conclusion that the only way we will have any sites left is by educating the public about the importance of these sites and about their desecration by looters.

title: STEEL PIER TO GROW AFTER RAZING OF RIVAL STEEPLECHASE PIER
description: LEAD: THE Steeplechase Pier, for nearly 90 years an amusement delight for millions of visitors, is to be demolished so its former archrival a half-block away - the Steel Pier - can become even larger and grander.

title: RURAL AREAS BECOME DEBRIS SITES IN WAKE OF DUMP CLOSING
description: SINCE the closing of the Croton landfill last summer many towns have discontinued or limited pickup of bulk trash. Commercial carters, the alternative to municipal pickup, refuse to remove a lone discarded sofa or refrigerator, while the larger loads that they agree to remove are likely to cost homeowners more than four times as much as a year ago. Fees for disposing of construction debris have also risen by as much.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: LEAD: The Indomitable Teddy Roosevelt Produced and directed by Harrison Engle. Prism. 94 minutes. $79.95.

title: PREVENTIVE DETENTION: A CONCEPT GOES ON TRIAL
description: IN one of the more important criminal law disputes of the decade, the Supreme Court will hear arguments Wednesday on the constitutionality of the ''preventive detention'' of allegedly dangerous but unconvicted criminal defendants. The issue is at the center of the great divide between civil libertarians and advocates of tougher law enforcement.

title: YACHT RACE AT LIBRARY
description: LEAD: FAR away off Australia's coast on the Indian Ocean, gladiators of the yacht racing world are battling for a famous work of silver, the America's Cup. Since the Americans lost the cup to the Australians in 1983, the first time the cup had left American hands since 1851, there has been worldwide interest in the event.

title: MT. VERNON TOXIC CLEANUP: A NEIGHBORHOOD DISRUPTED
description: FEDERAL environmental experts clearing a warehouse containing potentially explosive chemicals at the southern edge of this city indicated last week that their worst fears might not be realized and that they could probably thank the owners, now serving 13-year prison terms, for the progress.

title: SEOUL TO INVESTIGATE MAN'S DEATH IN POLICE CUSTODY
description: The South Korean Government has announced that it will investigate the treatment of a college student who died when he was being questioned by the police last week. Relatives and others say the student may have been tortured, and the United States Government has expressed concern about the matter.

title: Fuming
description: To the Editor: While the gathering of evidence regarding the effects of passive smoking on the non-smoker may eventually put an end to this controversy, there is already a Federal law that should be used to eliminate smoking in public places - the one insuring equal access to public places for handicapped people.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Large-Office Market Tightens in Nassau
description: LEAD: COMMERCIAL tenants on the Island are still enjoying rent concessions and other inducements to lease office space. But brokers and developers say the market, especially in Nassau County, has begun to shift in the landlord's favor.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CANCELLATIONS AND DELAYS HEAD COMPLAINTS ON AIRLINES
description: When you travel by air, you have to be prepared for problems. Files of the Federal

title: QUESTIONS ON NEW DUNNE POST
description: THE appointment recently of State Senator John R. Dunne, a Garden City Republican, as deputy majority leader of the State Senate is a step forward in his career. But the significance of his new post for Long Island was less than clear.

title: SLOWING DOWN, SLIGHTLY, AT 94
description: SOMEONE looking for a man in his 95th year could not be faulted for taking the search to a hospital. And in the case of Jack Horwitz, the search would bear fruit when it reached the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.

title: Give Foreign Borrowers a Break
description: IF 1982 marked the emergence of the international debt crisis, 1987 could the year the notion of debt relief becomes respectable. Developing countries in Latin America and Africa, whose outstanding debt totals an estimated $973 billion, have been rumbling about relief for at least two years. Stringent adjustment programs, they say, which buy them payment extensions from creditors, also sap their economies and threaten their political stability.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THAT NEW PET! By Alane Ferguson. Illustrated by Catherine Stock. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $11.75. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: I think it's only natural that in a free enterprise system some ''market correction'' develops. It was the owners who were responsible for the explosion of player salaries in the 1970's; they have now realized the risky economics of continued bidding wars and longterm contracts. There is no premeditated ''collusion'' here - it's just that they're all thinking and acting the same way.

title: Dr. Goldberg Wed To Fellow Dentist
description: Dr. Gari Ellen Goldberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Goldberg of Brooklyn, and Dr. Charles Henry Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Bloom of Edison, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Original Intent
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DOLLAR'S SLIDE RAISES U.S. HOPES
description: Japan's central bank bought billions of American dollars last week, and officials in Bonn hinted at a tax cut to stimulate the West German economy. Both countries were also said to be considering lowering interest rates as they scrambled to slow the precipitous drop in the value of the dollar, which closed Friday at 153.10 yen in Tokyo and 1.8465 marks in Frankfurt.

title: Nemerov First Winner Of Taylor Poetry Prize
description: Howard Nemerov, the author of some 30 books of poetry and fiction, has been chosen as the first winner of the Aiken Taylor Award for Modern American Poetry. The $10,000 prize, administered by the Sewanee Review and its publisher, the University of the South in Sewanee, Tenn., is awarded for the work of a substantial and distinguished career. The award was established through a bequest by Dr. K. P. A. Taylor, a poet and a younger brother of Conrad Aiken.

title: A TASTE OF ISTANBUL
description: LEAD: ''You can get one of the great fish dinners in the world here,'' a friend said as our boat pulled up alongside the Korfez restaurant along the Bosporus strait. Somehow that seemed unlikely. How good could the food be in a sprawling city on the edge of the third world with its smoggy streets clogged with 1950 De

title: COOPERMAN TENURE MARKED BY UNUSUAL RATE OF SUCCESS
description: SOON after Saul Cooperman became the state's Commissioner of Education in 1982, he attended a meeting with some nationally prominent educators and began to talk about his ideas for change, especially his plan to overhaul the state's system of teacher certification.

title: AUDI AGREES TO A RECORD RECALL
description: Confronted last summer with complaints that some Audi 5000's with automatic transmissions lurched forward or backward when shifted into gear, the manufacturer blamed drivers for stepping on the gas instead of the brake.

title: PIANIST ON STAGE TO TALK
description: FREDERICK MOYER, a concert pianist, is proud that he can talk about music to just about anyone.

title: JAZZ: SPHERE, AT VANGUARD
description: IN the four years since the quartet Sphere made its debut with a repertory that emphasized the compositions of Thelonious Monk, it has not only become less dependent on Monk in its programming but has moved away from its earlier use of Monk's performances of his compositions as a guide.

title: Foundation Dug for Long-Delayed Queens Project
description: AFTER seven years of delays, backhoes are finally scratching a foundation into the frozen ground at Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens, Queens. But Sidney Esikoff, the developer, still is not certain exactly what he can build there.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Basketball Celtics vs. Houston Rockets At Boston, noon Television Channel 2, noon COLLEGE North Carolina St. at North Carolina Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. L.S.U. at Kentucky Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. Louisville at Purdue Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Syracuse at Michigan Television Channel 2, 2:30 P.M. Radio WNYE FM 91.5, 2 P.M. Temple at St. Joseph's Television MSG, 4 P.M. Golf Bob Hope Chrysler Classic At Palm Desert, Calif. Television Channel 4, 4:30 P.M). Hockey Devils vs. Washington Capitals At Byrne Meadowlands Arena 7:35 P.M. Radio WMCA AM 570, 7:30 P.M. Flyers vs. Islanders At Philadelphia, 7:05 P.M. Television Sportschannel, 7 P.M. Radio WOR AM 710, 7 P.M. Other Events America's Cup Challenger's and defender's trials at Fremantle, Australia Television ESPN, 11 P.M.) Harness Racing At Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Soccer Express vs. Tacoma Stars At Nassau Coliseum, 5:05 P.M. Radio WBAU FM 90.3, 5:05 P.M. Squash Racquets Marsh and McLennan Apawamis Invitation At Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y. Semifinals 10 A.M., final, 3:30 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., taped.

title: Fighting Imports
description: To the Editor: I can't help but think that I have met the enemy - and he is Jerry K. Pearlman of Zenith Electronics Corporation (''Save the Lectures, Give Us Some Help,'' Forum, Dec. 14). Why shouldn't I be allowed to trade peacefully with any other citizen of the world? Why shouldn't I be allowed to buy a color TV from Korean, Japanese or Chinese manufacturers?

title: CARLUCCI AND THE N.S.C.
description: LIKE ANYTHING ELSE,'' SAYS Frank Carlucci, ''it can be abused.'' ''It'' is covert action, and Carlucci, who took office two weeks ago as President Reagan's fifth assistant for national security, knows what he is talking about. His immediate predecessor, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, resigned last

title: More Bosses
description: To the Editor: ''When the Boss Is Unbearable'' (Dec. 28) offers a variety of ''solu tions'' for dealing with ''weak, willful and devious'' bosses. All of these so-called solutions, be they ''keeping your distance,'' ''apple polishing'' or ''grinning and bearing,'' have one fatal flaw. All are based on the assumption that an individual worker can and must continue to deal on an individual basis with a monstrous boss. The one sensible, obvious solution was overlooked - stop sweating and bowing and kowtowing. Join a union! MARSHALL F. DUBIN Brooklyn, N.Y., Dec. 29

title: DANCE: POOH KAYE AND COMPANY
description: THERE are a great many enjoyable elements in the program Pooh Kaye and her Eccentric Motions company presented on Thursday at the Joyce Theater, as part of the Joyce Sampler series. Ms. Kaye, one of the wilder and wackier young leading experimentalists, has merged her antic humor and anarchically organic brand of movement into a distinctive style in the decade she has been choreographing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHEN PEOPLE PUBLISH: Essays on Writers and Writing. By Frederick Busch. (University of Iowa, $19.95.) A novelist and short story writer who teaches at Colgate, Frederick Busch hastens to assure his readers that this collection isn't intended as ''formal instruction, but as talk about writers and books among admirers of grown-up writing.'' Even so, it's tempting to urge that some of his more personal essays be required reading not only for aspiring writers but for all those who pull their editorial strings. They include wry hints of his doubts about teaching, looks at the nature and structure of fiction, reminiscences of his long apprenticeship as a writer (when the worst tortures were rejection letters that called him ''promising'' and every waking moment seemed like ''grist for the mill'') and particularly his thoughts about the tragicomic vagaries of the book publishing business. Mr. Busch is also wonderfully scathing in a critique of a one-month sampling of the fiction writers published in 16 popular magazines, in which he detects ''the new anti-Freudian psycho-piddle'' aimed at a market of contemporary Dagwoods and Blondies.
