Other essays ramble in and around the work of some of his favorite writers, using the thematic connections between, say, Hemingway and John Hawkes or Norman Mailer and Melville, the ''fiction-about-fiction'' of Conan Doyle, the idiosyncratic magic of Leslie Epstein's ''Steinway Quintet'' and the ''language of starvation'' in Dickens and Kafka to explore the posture of the writer toward the reading public (and vice versa) and what various writers' work has to say about telling stories. But provocative, intelligent, and gracefully phrased as these more formal essays are, they're still not quite as appealing as those that deal with the one writer who remains closest to Mr. Busch's heart - and he, of course, is Frederick Busch himself.

title: A REGULATION TACKLES YOUNG FOOTBALL PLAYER
description: LEAD: AT 14 years of age, Philip Yagoda of Lawrence is a 6-foot, 200-pound aspiring running back without a football team.

title: Indian Land Claims Rejected
description: Land claims by descendants of the Sioux Indians have been rejected by a Federal appeals court in a case lawyers said might affect similar claims to about 1.5 million acres nationwide.

title: DISSIDENTS IN ECUADOR AIR FORCE SIEZE PRESIDENT
description: Last year, Ecuador locked up Gen. Frank Vargas Pazzos, an Air Force commander, after he staged two revolts within a week. The authorities turned aside General Vargas's insistence that he was merely protesting against corruption in the armed forces. Later the national congress voted to grant the officer amnesty, and he became something of a folk hero. But President Leon Febres Cordero, evidently viewing the revolt as an affront, denounced General Vargas as a traitor and vetoed the amnesty measure.

title: President Reagan Seems Trapped in a Tangled, Paradoxical Web
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN appears to be trapped in a web of paradox over the secret sale of arms to Iran, vulnerable if he knew more about the deal than he has acknowledged and vulnerable if he knew less about it than his critics insist any President should have known.

title: Bucks Sign Lucas
description: JOHN LUCAS, twice waived from the N.B.A. for cocaine use, returned to basketball yesterday when he signed to play the remainder of the season with the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: SEYMOUR PHILLIPS, 83, LED CLOTHING COMPANY
description: Seymour J. Phillips, chairman of the board of Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation and vice president of Beth Israel Medical Center, died of a heart attack Friday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

title: 'BRIGHTON BEACH' AT THE PAPER MILL
description: YEARS from now - maybe next year, even - audiences who go in for marathons may get the chance to see the Neil Simon autobiographical trilogy ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' ''Biloxi Blues'' and ''Broadway Bound'' in one ''Nicholas Nickelby''-like day's journey into real enlightenment.

title: Murdoch Wins an Autralian Dust-Up
description: Rupert Murdoch came out on top of the battle of the media titans in Australia. In a deal struck with his rival, Robert Holmes a Court, Mr. Murdoch cleared the way to take control of the Herald and Weekly, Australia's largest media group. In turn, Mr. Holmes a Court, who agreed to withdraw his $1.4 billion bid, is to purchase the group's two Perth newspapers and its Melbourne television stations, which many analysts said were what he really wanted. Mr. Murdoch thus regains much of the media empire built by his father, Sir Keith Murdoch.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WARNING BELL. By Lynne Reid Banks. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Lynne Reid Banks's second novel opens in post-World War II Edinburgh, where 18-year-old Maggie Robertson desperately wants to be an actress - a fate unthinkable to her strict Presbyterian father. Yet she manages to attend drama school in London where she meets Tanya, a flamboyant actress, but remains torn between wanting to be Margaret, the dutiful, puritanical daughter, and Maggie, the renegade artiste.

title: POUNDING ON THE OLD HOUSE
description: NOW that 'tis no longer the season to go bankrupt, we are back to the old grind around here, also known as really doing something with this old house. We've been at it for 28 years. Old houses aren't really-done-something-with in a day, a week, a year, unless you've got a lot of money, and then you'd buy a new one anyway.

title: The Cult Of Ceausescu
description: In his article ''The Cult of Ceausescu'' (Nov. 30), David Binder is mistaken when he writes, ''. . . it appears that Ceausescu has not allowed torture or killing to be part of his style of governance.'' Amnesty International consistently receives reports of prison mistreatment and police beatings in Rumania.

title: NAMING BABY FOR HISTORY'S SAKE
description: Linda Liefland's essay on ''Finding a Surname for Baby'' [ Dec. 28 ] reminded me of my childhood in Hungary where many of us came from mixed marriages, the mothers being Catholic and the fathers Protestant. For most of us the egalitarian division fell so that the girls went to the Catholic church and the boys to the Protestant church, which made us believe that the niceties, colors and elaborate decorations in our church were meant for women while the men went to more down-to-earth and masculine houses of worship.

title: THE ROOF OF THE WORLD BY BUS, CAR AND FOOT
description: Benares, India's ancient holy city astride the Ganges, houses the only temple built by Mohandas K. Gandhi. It has neither Sivas nor Gneshes, only a huge relief model of India. Gandhi included Tibet in his vision of a unified India. Mao Zedong disagreed.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FINN WINS THE SALTUS AWARD
description: LEAD: The American Numismatic Society has named a prominent Finnish medalist, Kauko Rasanen, as this year's winner of its coveted Saltus Award. Mr. Rasanen received his award for lifetime achievement in medalic sculpture and is the second non-American to win the award in its 67 year history.

title: JAILING OF CRIME FIGURE CALLED TELLING BLOW TO MAFIA IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Capping a drive that some officials predict will shatter the influence of the most powerful organized crime syndicate here, a Federal magistrate ruled Thursday that a reputed Mafia leader, Nicodemo Scarfo, was a public danger and ordered him held without bail pending trial on charges that he had planned an extortion scheme with a City Councilman.

title: Langer Holds One-Shot Lead
description: Bernhard Langer returned to a conventional golf course today but turned in a rather unconventional round to barely hold on to his lead through four rounds of the 28th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: THE SUPERPOWERS' ROLE
description: Did the United States deliberately distort the intelligence reports it delivered to Iran and Iraq in an effort to prolong their war? According to intelligence sources in Washington, American officials, among other things, gave Teheran information that exaggerated the number of Soviet troops on its border and altered satellite photographs that were shared with Iraq.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES THAT COLOR THE WINTER LANDSCAPE
description: LEAD: ONE has but to travel through the countryside of the Northeast to discover the full potential that exists for winter color in the landscape. To be certain, the colors are for the most part muted when compared with those of spring, summer and fall, however, the subtle differences from species to species provide a panoramic contrast across the fields, meadows and mountainsides.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: P-K4 ON THE HIGH SEAS, GLASS IN EUROPE
description: Chess Cruise Setting Sail For Bermuda

title: BRADLEY OUTPACES ITS PLAN FOR GROWTH
description: IN 1982, when the state announced plans for a $100 million upgrading of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, it was expected that the improvements would carry the airport through the late 1990's.

title: Yale Beats Columbia
description: Yale converted 15 of 16 foul shots in the final two minutes to earn a 76-66 Ivy League victory over Columbia tonight.

title: MURDOCH HOLDINGS ISSUE IN AUSTRALIA
description: The overnight transformation of Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper holdings into a national chain with two-thirds of the country's circulation has raised concerns here about the concentration of so many newspapers in the control of one individual.

title: CONSTANT CALENDAR UNFAIR TO SABBATHS
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
HAND-COLORED PHOTOS: NOSTALGIA AND INVENTION
description: LEAD: IN the days before color print film became widely available, people who wanted a more naturalistic effect in photography took their black and white pictures to be professionally hand colored. Most family albums boast at least a few of these souvenirs of bygone days, their soft, understated tones muted by the subsurface grays of the monochromatic print.

title: VERMONT TOWN STRUGGLES TO REBOUND
description: In Windsor, where the Green Mountains fall away to meet the Connecticut River and the local diner still has a roast beef special for $2.75, economic bad news, like snow, has become part of the landscape.

title: DEFINITELY NOT FOR CLARK KENT
description: THEY stand like sentinels at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 60th Street - a trio of sleek, smoothly curved black towers with only white back-lighted symbols of a telephone receiver hinting at their purpose.

title: Of Military Garbage and Military Glory
description: Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman underscores his place as the No. 2 officer in the Army by telling friends, ''I'm Avis, not Hertz.'' Adm. James B. Busey 4th stays so far from the limelight that two middle-ranking Navy staff officers say they don't know what he does and a third couldn't recall his name right away.

title: LIVING BY THE BOOK IN RETIREMENT
description: YOU CAN always tell a new resident of an adult condominium community from the other gray-haired types because one shoulder is always lower than the other. This comes from carrying the prospectus around from condo meeting to condo meeting. What is this prospectus? It is the thick, telephone directory-size book of rules and regulations for living in a condominium, the thing that all condo real-estate ads clearly state you can't buy one of their homes or apartments without.

title: Lendl and Becker Gain in Melbourne
description: Ivan Lendl conquered a court surface he didn't care for and Boris Becker defeated his best friend today as the two top-seeded men advanced to the fourth round of the $1.65 million Australian Open tennis championships.

title: PANEL TRIES PERSUASION IN OPEN MEETINGS CASES
description: LEAD: AFTER the director of a Shelton center for the elderly complained that the local Senior Citizens Commission conducted meetings without giving notice required by law, a lawyer for the State Freedom of Information Commission went to Shelton and conducted a workshop explaining state open meetings laws.

title: WHEN VIBRATO IS ON SHAKY GROUND
description: That was a fascinating story in this newspaper the other day about the retarded child who, without musical training, could sit down at a piano, reproduce a melody and immediately improvise four-part harmony to it. Such ''idiots savant,'' as the French call these mysteriously gifted persons, turn up in music now and then, to the astonishment of us all. However, if there is a case in the psychological annals of an idiot-savant writer, I have missed it. Such a biological sport would be able to sit down at a word processor and say what he had to say so clearly and unequivocally that the literary world would fall dumb in amazement. Instead, we know of plenty of writers who are either idiots or savants, but none who came into the world full-blown, with idiocy and savvy in perfect equilibrium.

title: GIANT DEFENSE LOOKS FOR WAYS TO STOP BIG PLAYS BY ELWAY
description: THE key player in Super Bowl XXI may be John Elway, the Denver Broncos' exciting young quarterback.

title: Hillary Holland and Russell Fogarty, Vice Presidents of Christie's, Are Wed
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Hillary Ann Holland and Russell Fogarty, both vice presidents of Christie's, the fine-arts auctioneer, were married by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley.

title: A NOVELIST AS POLITICIAN
description: Quick now, who was the last bona fide Presidential candidate - one with a chance to win - to have written a novel? Did any President do so, before or after the White House?

title: MOUNTAINEER'S LIFE REFLECTED IN PHOTOS
description: MOUNTAIN LIGHT,'' Galen Rowell's latest book, is a splendid blend of autobiography, personal philosophy and superb color photographs of high, wild places.

title: FOR THE RECORD
description: To the Editor: In his interesting article on the troubles facing the music publishing industry, Bernard Holland writes that the time is long gone when the market for printed music was ''voracious'' and reminds us of the success of the old Etude magazine as a sharp contrast to today's sad situation. However, he omits mentioning the phenomenon of Keyboard Classics magazine, with 50,000 subscribers, and its pop-music sister publication, Sheet Music magazine, with 250,000 subscribers. Like Etude, both contain music, but they reach more people than the editors of that magazine ever dreamed possible. As a regular columnist for Keyboard Classics, I'm happy to report that the piano-playing, music-loving public is alive and still quite hungry. RUTH LAREDO New York City

title: DARED BY THE BUTLER'S DAUGHTER
description: FAMILY LAUNDRY By Dorie Friend. 300 pp. New York: A Peter Weed Book/ Beaufort Books. $17.95.

title: FIRKUSNY IN REPRISE WITH CZECH ORCHESTRA
description: RUDOLF FIRKUSNY'S first concerto performance was given with the Czech Philharmonic, in 1922, and one of the first major works he inaugurated was the Second Piano Concerto of Bohuslav Martinu, in 1935. That performance was with the same orchestra that will accompany him in Carnegie Hall tomorrow when he gives his latest New York performance of the rarely heard work.

title: GOOD SEX AT HOME IN ANCIENT ROME
description: THE CARE OF THE SELF Volume Three of The History of Sexuality. By Michel Foucault. Translated by Robert Hurley. 279 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: WHEN SALT MUST BE RESTRICTED, THERE ARE TASTY ALTERNATIVES
description: SOME seasonings are roughly interchangeable. Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley. Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne. But no seasoning does exactly the same job of bringing up flavor as salt. When a diet requires salt to be restricted it becomes a challenge for the cook.

title: EAGLES GAIN HOME NEAR THE SHEPAUG
description: LEAD: THE American bald eagle is closer to being assured a permanent winter haven on the Housatonic River. A 93-year-old Southbury woman recently donated 50 acres of land in Newtown near an area where eagles hunt in the winter to the Nature Conservancy.

title: PLANTS TO GROW FROM TROPICAL PITS AND TUBERS
description: LEAD: A decade ago, the rage was to raise avocado trees from the pits of store-bought fruit. The immense popularity of these plants defied the fact that they often performed poorly, became ungainly or refused to branch. Now that avocadomania has subsided, it might be time to experiment with the seeds and pits of tropical fruits and vegetables.

title: CO-OP HUNTING IN THE OUTER BOROUGHS
description: WHEN Bill Dillard was not on the road, singing and acting in musicals or playing his trumpet with Louis Armstrong, he lived in rental apartments in Harlem. Last year, at the age of 75, he and his wife, Celestine, became impatient with waiting lists for new rental projects and began looking for a better home outside Manhattan. They couldn't find a rental they liked.

title: JAZZ: GEORGE SHEARING
description: THE delicate pianism of George Shearing, who combines one of the most feathery touches in jazz with an English-parlor gentility, has an almost sleight-of-hand quality in club performance. Especially when Mr. Shearing calmly wings his way through a series of interlocking blues progressions, the music almost seems to emanate from a magical source separate from the pianist's fingers.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Beans for the Critic Just as some Americans try to go through Europe on $5 a day, a character in Bernard Malamud's ''Last Mohican'' rations his perceptions in Rome. This is one of many stories in ''The Art of the Tale'' (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking), edited by Daniel Halpern.

title: Lynn Sturtevant Wed To Andrew von Salis
description: Lynn Ruth Sturtevant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Sturtevant of Chatham, N.J., and Andrew Mead von Salis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gaudenz von Salis of Samedan, Switzerland, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends in Brooklyn Heights.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Jan. 4 with an article about Kariba, Zimbabwe, misidentified a herd of animals in a field. The animals were African buffaloes, which are also known as Cape buffaloes.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CHANGING HOMES -- WITHOUT MOVING
description: LEAD: NINE years ago, my husband, son and I moved into a house with a private front entrance and a grass-and-trees backyard.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
PILGRIMAGE TO GIANTS STADIUM
description: LEAD: THE Giantmobile - nickname courtesy of driver - pulled out of the parking lot at Bob Hyland's Sports Page restaurant and bar and headed toward the parkway that leads to East Rutherford, N.J., and Giants Stadium. On the van's windows were stickers that read ''Giants fan on board'' and '' 'Skins fan in trunk''; inside were five whooping young men covered from head to toe in the Giants's colors of red, white and blue.

title: DAIRY THAT WON THE EAST BEGAN IN '17
description: LEAD: ''HELLO, Bubbie, what do you think?'' asked Marc Goldman, president of Farmland Dairies Inc. ''We won! How do you feel?'' The telephone amplifier on Mr. Goldman's desk at the company's multimillion-dollar processing plant here came to life. The voice on the other end was that of his 92-year-old grandmother,

title: Fuming
description: To the Editor: After reading ''Nobody Is Safe If a Smoker Is Around,'' by Charles Lemaistre, and ''A Propaganda War Against Cigarettes,'' by Scott Edward Stapf (Forum, Jan. 4), I fear that the debate over ''passive'' smoking has become too clinical - it loses sight of the problem in a muddle of facts and studies.

title: Julie Ann Cantor To Marry Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Cantor of Rye, N.Y., have announced that their daughter Julie Ann Cantor and Andrew Charles Peskoe are to be married Feb. 21. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd F. Peskoe of Colts Neck, N.J., and New York.

title: Jury to Convene for 5th Day In Jersey Trooper Killing Trial
description: The jury will begin a fifth day of deliberations Sunday morning in the trial of two avowed revolutionaries charged with murdering a New Jersey state trooper on Interstate 80 in 1981.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was shouting, 'Kill me, kill me.' What else could I do? I was President of the country.'' - President Leon Febres Cordero of Ecuador. [ 1:2. ]

title: Felice Zinn Is Wed
description: The marriage of Felice D. Zinn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Zinn of Livingston, N.J., and David H. Raff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Raff of Livingston and Rancho La Costa, Calif., took place last evening. Rabbis Barry H. Greene and Stanley Asekoff and Cantor Norman Summers officiated at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. Mrs. Raff graduated from Ithaca College. Her husband is an American University graduate.

title: C.I.A. RECALLS COSTA RICA AIDE
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has recalled its station chief in Costa Rica after allegations that he gave military and logistical advice to the Nicaraguan rebels, Government officials said today.

title: OFF-ISLAND TRASH FEES RISING
description: LEAD: TENS of thousands of Long Island residents and businesses are facing dramatic increases in the fees they pay for shipping garbage off the Island, local officials say.

title: OFFICIAL BELIEVES SMALL PLANE FLEW INTO FLIGHT PATH
description: A small private plane apparently flew into the path of a larger commuter aircraft before the two collided over this Salt Lake City suburb Thursday, killing all 10 people aboard the planes, a Federal safety official said Friday night.

title: MAFIA BOSSES ARE SENTENCED TO CENTURIES
description: Seven of the eight men convicted in November of operating or helping operate a New York-based Mafia ''commission'' were sentenced last week to jail terms of 100 years; the eighth received 40 years. Included among the seven were three men convicted as bosses of major crime families: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, 75 years old, of the Genovese family; Anthony (Tony Ducks) Corallo, 73, of the Lucchese family, and Carmine (Junior) Persico, 53, of the Colombo group. Judge Richard Owen recommended that all be denied parole, for which they would otherwise be eligible under Federal law after 10 years.

title: Guess Who's Grinning
description: LAST year I wrote for this page about how I hated the Chicago Bears, and had hated them since I was a kid growing up in Wisconsin hard by the shores of Lake Michigan some 60 miles north of Chicago. Being then a youngster with visions of becoming another Don Hutson, I took every Bear victory over my Green Bay Packers very personally. And since that happened all too often, my psyche was as battered as the Packers.

title: SETON UPSETS HOYAS
description: With six seconds remaining, a surprised Mark Bryant made a pair of free throws today that enabled Seton Hall to upset Georgetown, 66-65, in a Big East game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was Seton Hall's second defeat of Georgetown this season, the only losses the Hoyas have in 14 games.

title:
ART;
A MINIMALIST'S LOOK AT NATURE OPENS NEW PEEKSKILL GALLERY
description: LEAD: THE scale of the work on exhibit at the Forecast Gallery, a recently opened gallery in Peekskill, is new for Westchester. You might call the work corporate-collection size. Anita Balter, who owns and directs the gallery, has her eye on the many corporate headquarters sprouting in areas outside New

title: WHITE OPPOSITION PARTY REJECTS TUTU BOYCOTT IDEA
description: Colin Eglin, the leader of the Progressive Federal Party, the official white opposition, rejected a suggestion Friday by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu that the party withdraw from Parliament.

title: A PASSION FOR WHEELS, WINGS AND ENGINES
description: The photographs of Jacques-Henri Lartigue, who died last summer at the age of 92, are art photography's best-known version of primitivism. Most were taken in the early years of this century, when Lartigue was a boy, and they have the freshness and spontaneity of an eye unjaundiced by the conventions of the photography of the day. Instead of duplicating the style of Pictorialism, with its studied Whistlerian veils, they have improvisational compositions and a beguiling, transparent charm. They may look like common snapshots, but their sophisticated sense of form transcends the genre.

title: Taming the Economic Policy Monster
description: By ALICE M. RIVLIN;

title: In Big League Sailing, Pressure Is Intense
description: MENTAL pressure could have at least as much to do with winning the America's Cup as secret keels, new sails or subtle differences in hull design. It is a matter of who breaks first. Of the four skippers who reached the finals of the challenger and defender selection series, only one - Dennis Conner of Stars and Stripes, has steered in a cup match before.

title: GARDENERS DON'T WITHER WITH WINTER
description: WINTER, when the ground is rock-hard, the meadows covered with snow and the branches on trees turned to icicles, is not the gardener's favorite time of year. The scenery seems especially bleak in January, yet at the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford there are plenty of visitors strolling along the paths. Still other gardening fans opt to visit commercial greenhouses or stay snug in classrooms, listening to lectures on gardening and dreaming about spring.

title: BELAGA HEADED FOR HARVARD
description: LEAD: A FELLOWSHIP at Harvard University will help Julie D. Belaga, the unsuccessful 1986 Republican gubernatorial candidate, decide ''what I want to go into, what I want to do,'' she said.

title: Penn Central Envisions Towers in the Air
description: A PROPOSAL to build three towers containing 278 luxury condominiums and an 11-story office building lined up over the railroad tracks in White Plains was made to the White Plains Common Council early this month by the Penn Central Corporation.

title: A MUSTY MYTH
description: THE ONLY THING HARDER than getting people to accept a good idea is getting them to abandon a bad one. A relevant example: the almost universal reverence for old wines.

title: Proposal Rejected
description: WHEN the International Olympic Committee decided to allow professional athletes to compete in the Olympics, there were those who thought the move would virtually guarantee a hockey gold medal for Canada at the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary. After all, they figured, with the likes of Wayne Gretzky and other Canadian-born National Hockey League stars suiting up for Team Canada, it would be a formidable opponent.

title: TALKS CONTINUE IN BID TO AVERT L.I.R.R. STRIKE
description: Negotiations continued yesterday in an effort to avert a Long Island Rail Road strike threatened for this morning.

title: VATICAN MUST DEAL EVEN FOR SMALL GAINS IN THE EAST
description: IN a front-page photograph last week, L'Osservatore Romano showed Pope John Paul II standing soberly beside the equally unsmiling Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. The Vatican newspaper added only a 40-word caption stating that the Polish leader had been received in a private audience Tuesday.

title: AIDS INFECTION FOUND IN TRANSFUSION PATIENT
description: After weeks spent searching through records in more than 100 hospitals in the New York metropolitan region, medical investigators have identified a patient who has been infected with the AIDS virus through a blood transfusion.

title: HU'S OUSTER RAISES TROUBLESOME QUESTIONS
description: CHINA'S sweeping economic reforms of the last few years had raised hopes that political liberalization would follow. For some Chinese, the hopes were personified by Hu Yaobang, the General Secretary of the Communist Party, who was expected to succeed Deng Xiaoping.

title: LEFTISTS IN MEXICO SEEKING A MERGER
description: Mexico's political left, traditionally divided, is trying to unite into a single party that could present a greater challenge to the governing party.

title: BOTH USX AND STEEL UNIONS SEE GAINS IN LABOR PACT
description: A tentative agreement to settle the steel industry's longest work stoppage was reached early today, and officials of the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America said it would achieve the objectives of both sides.

title: SIGNS OF VIOLENCE ARISE IN MEAT PLANT'S LOCKOUT
description: Hardly anyone here was surprised the other day when two puppies were found killed, one bludgeoned, one poisoned. It was widely believed that the motivation was a grudge against the town's biggest employer, Iowa Beef.

title: ALTERING TRADITION
description: SOME OF THE MOST AD-vanced men's clothing to reach the stores this spring is, in a sense, the most traditional. Even the most novel designs are loosely modeled on the conventional English gentleman's suit.

title: OYSTER PLAN HITS 300-YEAR-OLD SNAG
description: LEAD: ONE of the treats for a visitor to Southampton used to be a big plate full of fresh local oysters on the half shell. That was before the state ordered Mecox Bay, the town's major source of the shellfish, closed to oystering in 1978 because of contamination.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: RHYTHM-A-NING: Jazz Tradition and Innovation in the '80's, by Gary Giddins. (Oxford University, $7.95.) ''Rhythm-a-ning,'' named for a Thelonious Monk composition, is Gary Giddins's second essay collection and ''one of a handful of essential books on jazz published this decade,'' Francis Davis said in The Book Review in 1985.

title: PHILIPPINES PUTS TROOPS ON ALERT AGAINST A MUTINY
description: The armed forces were placed on alert and roadblocks were set up outside Malacanang Palace on Saturday after reports circulated that armed groups were planning a new move to destabilize the Government.

title: Small-College Back Scores 4 for South
description: Christian Okoye, a Little all-American from Azusa Pacific College, a member of the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics, set a Senior Bowl record with four touchdowns today as the South edged the North, 42-38. Three of Okoye's scores came on 1-yard runs, and he had a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minute 6 seconds to play. Okoye finished with 47 yards on 13 carries.

title: CHILD SUPPORT: AN ANXIETY MILL FOR MOTHERS, FATHERS AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: SECONDARY IMAGES IN VAN GOGH'S LANDSCAPES
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS END HOME DRILLS
description: The Giants held their final practice at home today before their Super Bowl game Jan. 25 against the Denver Broncos in Pasadena, Calif.

title: A VISIT FROM THE 'MINISTER OF GLOOM'   LCBy BILL MAJESKI; Bill Majeski lives in Norwalk.
description: MARRIED couples have many joyous firsts among their mementos to look back upon with fondness as they travel through life together. The first kiss, first argument, first child, first home, etc., are events that are rife with vivid memories. But there are others that somehow become memorable although the occurrences in themselves are not usually associated with unforgettable times.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HELLAS: A Portrait of Greece. By Nicholas Gage. (Villard, $17.95.) Nicholas Gage is the author of ''Eleni,'' a best-selling account of his quest to track down the man responsible for killing his mother during the Greek civil war. Her sacrifice enabled the 9-year-old Nicholas to escape from the Communists and reach America; he became a journalist, for some years based in Athens for this newspaper.

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: Rand McNally's Videotrip Guide to San Francisco Hosted by Jill St. John. Lightning Video. 1986. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: In a Hot Market, the Bargains Evaporate
description: WITH the stock market flying on afterburners, analysts are hard-pressed to find stocks that look undervalued by such traditional measures as price-earnings ratio and book value. Indeed, among many analysts surveyed, few could come up with a classic value play. John Johnson, of Johnson, Valliant & Broadfoot, noted that the entire ''emerging growth'' sector - generally smaller companies with fast earnings gains -looked undervalued from one perspective: the average price-earnings ratio about matches the overall market's; in 1983, smaller growth companies commanded twice the market's P/E ratio.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE wetlands compromise announced in December managed to hold together in January, and the State Assembly approved for the first time a bill to restrict development on 200,000 acres of environmentally sensitive land.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 18, 1987
NEW SAVINGS BANK
description: By April, a new savings institution, the Prime Savings Bank, hopes to open its doors for business at 875 Mamaroneck Avenue in Mamaroneck. It is the first savings bank to be state-chartered in 21 years - although three Federally chartered savings banks have opened in the state in the last three years. The head of the new bank, Felix Ginorio Jr., retired chairman of the Union Chelsea National Bank in Manhattan and a banking consultant, said the bank's incorporators expected to have the $10 million in necessary capital raised by the end of February.

title: ZABALETA, AT 80, STILL MASTER OF THE HARP
description: ''But you see, the harp is not so difficult,'' Nicanor Zabaleta, one of the few musicians who can make that statement truthfully, said with a gentle grin. ''I'll make you a drawing - I always do this for composers, for all the composers who are frightened of the harp. I tell them to imagine that they are are playing a piano only on the white keys - the pedals will fill in the missing black keys. And then you must play without using the small finger on each hand. And because of the placement of the hands, one opposite the other, the composer must write for two left hands. But after that it is very simple.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ECONOMIC CIRCLES
description: THE American Economic Association did not choose New Orleans for its annual convention to spur the ailing local conomy, but the 6,000 economists and perhaps 2,000 spouses who descended on the city certainly did not hurt.

title: RUSH OF BILLS FILED ON ISSUES BIG AND SMALL
description: NEVER mind what to do about increasing state aid to the cities, improving the professional training of the state's schoolteachers or continuing the death penalty.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A JOB CRUNCH JOLTS JAPAN
description: HIDEAKI NARA, 38 years old and out of work, sat in the unemployment office of this northern industrial city and stared at a card describing a job at a textile factory. The job would require him to move away from Muroran, where Mr. Nara lives with and supports his parents, and it would pay him less than he received as a welder with the steel company Nippon Seiko.

title: Can RICO Help?
description: To the Editor: Prof. Robert Blakey asserts that if Congress had passed the reform of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) proposed last session, financier Ivan Boesky would no longer have been subject to a treble-damage RICO civil action (''The Public's Secret Weapon vs. Boesky,'' Forum, Dec. 7). Professor Blakey implies that Bronx political leader Stanley Friedman also would have secured immunity from RICO liability.

title: SEA MUSEUM SEEKING FUNDS
description: IN the 19th century, an inspector would sit up on the roof of the Customs House in New London and peer through his spyglass at the busy harbor ''to make sure nobody got away without paying customs,'' said the president of the New London Maritime Society, Lucille Showalter.

title: City as Landlord
description: To the Editor: Your article headed ''New York Plays Reluctant Landlord'' on Dec. 14 misses one very important point: Many of these buildings coming under city control were previously rent-controlled or -stabilized. The consequent severe restrictions on rent increases caused the buildings to be unprofitable, and therefore neglected, and finally abandoned by their owners. The city takes over when the situation is beyond hope.

title: CLARKE WORK
description: FOR ALMOST FOUR MONTHS, Martha Clarke has been obsessed with Franz Kafka, working on a new theater piece based on his art and life. The process of creating the show has been painstaking, intuitive, highly collaborative and fragmentary. This continued to be true as the first Off Broadway preview on Feb. 3 approached.

title: Miss Wiener Engaged To David Freeman Jr.
description: The engagement of Patricia Anne Wiener to David F. Freeman Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Freeman of Chapel Hill, N.C., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Howard E. Wiener of Hewlett Neck, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Everybody and his brother went out and bought a car to take the sales tax deduction.'' - Michael K. Evans, analyst, on the December surge in retail sales.

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: Good News Starring Peter Lawford, June Allyson. Screenplay by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. Directed by Charles Walters. 1947. MGM Home Video. 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Art
description: At a moment of considerable interest in the possibilities of abstraction, the Luise Ross Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, has brought together four little known artists whose work defines, each in its own way, an edge between abstraction and figuration. The diptychs of Cynthia Gallagher and the vertical slabs of George Hildrew are paintings with precise figurative and sculptural associations. The allusive reliefs of Elisa d'Arrigo and constructions of Peter Kagle breathe psychological tension.

title: CHILD SUPPORT: AN ANXIETY MILL FOR MOTHERS, FATHERS AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: CRASHES RISE ON CROWDED INTERSTATES
description: THE number of traffic accidents on Connecticut's three major Interstate highways increased substantially in 1986, according to figures provided last week by the state police. In particular, the figures showed a large increase in the number of fatal accidents involving trucks.

title: Deborah Ironson Engaged to Wed
description: Judge and Mrs. Burton J. Ironson of Springfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Ironson, to Jordan Irving Katz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Katz of New York and Remsenburg, N.Y. The wedding is planned for March. Miss Ironson, a vice president of the North American department at Chemical Bank in New York, graduated cum laude from Princeton University and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. Her father is a judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey.

title: THE NIGHT ROMMEL SAID 'MAZEL TOV'
description: NIGHT OF THE FOX By Jack Higgins. 316 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster, $17.95

title: 50 People Die as Boat Sinks Near Central Philippine Isle
description: A boat carrying participants in a Roman Catholic festival sank near an island in the central Philippines on Friday, killing at least 50 people, the authorities said today.

title: KING AND GANDHI: APOSTLES OF NONVIOLENT RESISTANCE TO EVIL
description: IN 1956, when Martin Luther King Jr. wished to inspire his followers to continue their boycott of the segregated buses of Montgomery, Ala., he would refer to Gandhi's principles of nonviolent resistance and to Gandhi's successful use of the method of noncooperation with an evil system. Because Dr. King adopted several of these principles and applied this method, he came to be regarded by some as ''The American Gandhi.'' The numerous similarities between them, both in thought and method, have provided an ample basis for this designation.

title: AT HOME AND ON THE BARRICADES
description: YOUR NATIVE LAND, YOUR LIFE By Adrienne Rich. 113 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: SPEAKERS SERIES HONORS THE CONSTITUTION'S 200TH
description: LEAD: NOTABLE speakers in the field of constitutional rights will participate in a lecture series at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers underwritten by the school's Donald C. Samuel Fund for Economics and Politics. The series, in honor of the Constitution's 200th birthday this year, was organized by Gerald Horne, a member of the Sarah

title: DIJON'S CASSIS ENJOYS ANOTHER VOGUE
description: Dijon, which is renowned for its mustard, is also the source for cassis, without which the popular aperitif Kir would be an ordinary glass of wine. Indeed, the drink has given the black currant juice a certain repute not only in France but also in the United States, where wine has become a popular substitute for hard liquor as a cocktail. Yet, in its hometown, cassis is ubiquitous. Windows of pastry shops are filled with jams, candies and cakes with a decidedly purple cast; local recipes feature boneless chicken breasts in cassis sauce or royally hued poached pears topped with sharply contrasting vanilla ice cream.

title: DRINKING LAW: MASSACHUSETTS DEBATE
description: A tougher drunken driving law, approved by the State Legislature last year just in time for Christmas and New Year's Eve, has set off a heated debate here about civil liberties and public safety.

title: Crash Survivor Settles Suit
description: The only survivor of the Galaxy Airlines crash that killed 70 people in Nevada on Jan. 21, 1985, has settled his lawsuit against the airline, his attorney says. George Lamson Jr., whose father died of injuries suffered in the crash, reached agreement on Wednesday with lawyers for the Florida-based airline for an undisclosed sum, said attorney, Charles Hvass Jr. Mr. Lamson, 19 years old, was thrown from the fuselage when the plane hit the ground.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MORGAN BEQUEST ON VIEW Five years ago, the Wadsworth Atheneum began assessing its bequest of European decorative arts, made decades ago by J. Pierpont Morgan Jr., son of the railroad and steel leader, who collected them.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CRANS-MONTANA
description: The Crans-Montana plateau in Switzerland was once scorned by local peasants as fit for little more than cow grazing; 60 years ago it was a destination for tuberculosis patients seeking crisp, dry air. Since then, skiers and golfers seeking the same weather conditions for winter and summer sports have come to predominate the 5,000-foot-high resort community.

title: Young Teaches Winning Course
description: WHEN Nick Schloeder got out of the service in the mid-1950's, he returned home to Baltimore to begin a teaching career and - he hoped - to find a job coaching football. Luckily for him, a classmate of his at Bucknell some years before was the head coach at a nearby Catholic high school, and he offered Schloeder a job as assistant. Schloeder was thrilled.

title: Why We Need the Fifth
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnival
description: To the Editor: I appreciate your informative section and enjoy it each week. I especially liked ''Looking Ahead to Carnival'' (Travel, Dec. 28). But why have you neglected Nice, France? You included Venice, Italy; Basel, Switzerland, and Cologne, Germany, but Nice, which is noted for a splashy, wonderful Carnival, doesn't get a tip of the hat, a mention of any kind.

title: Sheila Harrington Bride of Lieut. Paul J. Sweeney
description: Sheila Harrington, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Harrington of the Bronx and High Falls, N.Y., and Lieut. Paul J. Sweeney, U.S.M.C.R., were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Sweeney Jr. of Garden City, L.I., and Monroe, N.Y. The Rev. Sabas Kilian performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx.

title: CRIME
description: Two cult writers of mystery fiction have published new books featuring series characters -and both live up to their reputation. Joseph Hansen's latest book is THE LITTLE DOG LAUGHED (Holt, $15.95), and Tony Hillerman's is SKINWALKERS (Harper & Row, $15.95). They are cult figures because they write well, have staked out an area of their own and have attracted a discriminating and faithful audience.

title: DISPUTE ON SUFFOLK LEAGAL FUND
description: THE Citizens Legal Defense Fund, approved by the Suffolk County Legislature last year, continues to be controversial even as leaders attempt to set up the nonprofit agency that would contract with the county.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DANGER & THE ENEMY. By Jos Vandeloo. Translated by Dirk H. and Dirk P. van Nouhuys. (Sachem Press, P.O. Box 9, Old Chatham, N.Y. 12136, $14.95.) These two short Flemish novels deal with formidable subjects. ''The Enemy'' is a taut, briskly paced narration by a 15-year-old Belgian boy, recalling his days in a ''hiding pit'' during a shelling attack by German soldiers in World War II.

title: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: THE DOW IN PERSPECTIVE  TRACING THE UPS AND DOWNS OF THE 20th CENTURY THROUGH THE EYES OF WALL STREET; Most Experts Are Saying the Surge Will Continue
description: It may be fun to look back at the Dow's history, but that's no way to make money.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CAMBODIAN WITNESS: The Autobiography of Someth May. (Random House, $17.95.) On April 17, 1975, the old Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh fell to the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas. These new rulers literally took the capital's citizens prisoner, first evacuating them under the pretext of an imminent American bombing raid.

title: HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM CUTS SERVICES
description: ONE month after county legislators slashed its budget request almost in half, the Hudson River Museum has announced plans to shorten hours, close the Andrus Planetarium and abandon new science programs.

title: 'SWEET CHARITY' STAGED IN EAST WINDSOR
description: EAST WINDSOR is more than 100 miles from Broadway, which is why ''Sweet Charity,'' still running in New York, has been allowed to be presented at the Coachlight Dinner Theater.

title: WELFARE PLAN OFFERS RECIPIENTS SELF-HELP
description: LEAD: DURING his State of the State Message before the Legislature last Tuesday, Governor Kean held up an application for welfare and asked:

title: CLARINET: GERVASE DE PEYER
description: WEDNESDAY night's curious collection of clarinet pieces at Merkin Concert Hall had a common denominator - their personal associations with the featured performer, Gervase de Peyer. Mr. de Peyer arranged the sonatas by Handel and Schubert and has given the premieres of all the other items on this program except one.

title: LANDLORDS ATTACK HOBOKEN LAW ON PRESERVING APARTMENTS
description: A law to preserve apartments for middle-income tenants here is drawing the ire of landlords.

title: LEGALLY BLAMELESS, BUT ACCIDENT-PRONE
description: THE bare facts are, I got in the car and just as I was passing my next-door neighbor's driveway, wham, slam! she backed up, bang into the side of my car. What a way to meet. I had not seen Kathie since she went off to college. Shaken up as I was, I could not help noticing what a pretty woman she had turned out to be. And I told her so.

title: Miss McCabe to Wed Robert D. Kirschner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ellen McCabe to Robert D. Kirschner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Kirschner of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for May 2.

title: About Men; The Comfort of Pals
description: RECENTLY, WHILE I WAS CON-valescing from an operation, Bert and Buddy, two old friends whom I rarely see because they live far away, visited me. I couldn't use the stairs, so my wife brought them up to my study and left us alone. For hours, we talked nonstop, pouring ourselves out for one another, drinking one another in, joyously celebrating the sacrament of friendship.

title: SPA FOR HEART PATIENTS PLANNED IN WEST HAVEN
description: A $200 million health complex designed to help people with heart problems change their style of life is scheduled to break ground this spring in West Haven. But it is already being criticized as unnecessary and costly.

title: WHEN MR. REAGAN CHOOSES DOCTORS
description: Do as I say, not as I do. That would seem to be President Reagan's maxim on Medicare for the elderly.

title: Miss Perkins To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall Perkins of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Gamble Perkins, to Mark Kilbourne Jeffrey Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Davis Robinson 3d of Gambier, Ohio. The wedding is planned for June 27.

title: FOR AIR TRAVEL, 1986 WAS SAFE, BUT JUST BARELY
description: The numbers for 1986 suggest that the nation's airlines are flying closer than ever to disaster, but by some combination of wit and luck are emerging with an improving safety record.

title: Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
description: Derek Goodwin placed far too much emphasis on specific monetary gains and not enough emphasis on the immoral and criminal behavior surrounding such excavations.

title: ALASKA
description: To the Editor: What an accurate description of the ferry ride to Alaska! My husband and I did the seven-day Inside Passage trip on the Matanuska this past September. And we, too, had only 200 people aboard and found the food and accommodations just fine. But it was the scenery that made the voyage memorable. As Mrs. Hamilton states, the major shipboard occupation was sitting mesmerized by the changing scenery. May we add to the enjoyment of future travelers by suggesting that they bring binoculars to view the scenery? We found we were in the minority not using binoculars to take full advantage of the birds, the bears and the whales. ETHEL FISHMAN SY FISHMAN Brooklyn

title: Old Giants Rate The New
description: WHEN the Giants were winning six Eastern Division titles in eight seasons, from 1956 through 1963, their Hall of Fame defensive end, Andy Robustelli, was known as the Pope in the locker room. To his teammates, the Pope was infallible. When the Pope spoke, they agreed. They still do. When the Pope invited several Giants alumni to a dinner for the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at ''21'' the other night, they agreed. And now, in groups of two and three, they were discussing the Giants who will oppose the Denver Broncos next Sunday in Super Bowl XXI.

title: Diane Levitt, a Teacher, Marries David Chodosh
description: Diane Levitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Levitt of Huntington, L.I., was married last night to David Chodosh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chodosh of Carmel, Calif. Rabbis Joy Levitt and Lee Friedlander, the bride's sister and brother-in-law, performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge Restaurant at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: HARRY DARBY
description: Harry Darby, a Republican political figure in Kansas, died yesterday at the Bethany Medical Center in Kansas City, Kan. He was 91 years old.

title: THE MET MAKES ITS MOVE INTO THE 20TH CENTURY
description: The opening of the Metropolitan Museum's expansive new Lila Acheson Wallace wing for 20th-century art is not only a major event in the history of this august institution, but in the history of New York as a center for that art. With the $26-million Wallace addition - housing an international survey of painting and sculpture from 1900 to now - the Met has established, in essence, a separate museum that becomes the fourth big one in Manhattan devoted solely to the present century. What's more, it provides a grand-scale arena where not only modern but very current art will be seen in a direct continuum with the art of the past - the entire encyclopedia of objects, ranging over 5,000 years and most of the world's civilizations, that constitute the Met's collections.

title: IRAN AFFAIR RAISES DEMOCRATS' HOPES AND CAUTION ON '88
description: The controversy over arms sales to Iran has substantially altered the campaign for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, politicians say, by increasing the value of the nomination and thus slowing the race down as potential candidates and political professionals reassess their hopes and interests.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Retracing a Flight Of Mythology

title: The Historical Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: MAILBOX BASHING: MYSTERIOUS CRIME
description: MY wife nudged me awake. ''I heard the doorbell ring,'' she said.

title: The Cult Of Ceausescu
description: David Binder's article shows only the darker side of the President of Rumania. Mr. Binder reports that he had to submit his questions ahead of time when he requested an interview with Mr. Ceausescu. Is it not the same when you request an interview with a United States President? And what about protocol? Is there none in Washington?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 18, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: OFFICIALS CITE 27 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 27 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Susan Ribet Engaged To Scott Howard Kaye
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Ribet of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Joy Ribet, to Scott Howard Kaye, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Kaye of Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: GREEKS' PLANS FOR OLYMPIAD ARE IMPERILED
description: The event is nearly a decade away, but the Greek Government may already have lost what it considers a historic right: the ''Golden Olympiad'' of 1996.

title: 'CALMER WATERS' FOR NEW YORK CITY'S FINANCES
description: Just two months ago, it seemed that New York City would have to start sailing closer to the wind. Mayor Koch projected a $623 million deficit for the fiscal year beginning July 1 and warned that services might have to be cut.

title: OLD MARKER RETURNING TO COUNTY
description: DORIS E. AUSER and Richard M. Lederer Jr. were heartsick; the engineer in charge of the project was sorry, but nobody else seemed to care. ''You just drive along and you are oblivious to these things,'' Janet Connolly, secretary to Supervisor Nancy R. Elliott of Yorktown, said last week when she learned what had happened.

title: THE LYON BALLET BRINGS INNOVATIVE CHOREOGRAPHY TO CLASSIC WORKS
description: The Lyon Opera Ballet comes from France, the cradle of the classical ballet. Its name brings to mind the Paris Opera Ballet, which just this summer offered a season of glittery French stars and spectacle at the Metropolitan Opera House. And so, the ballet classics - a ''Swan Lake'' here or a ''Giselle'' there -might be expected from the Lyon troupe, which opens at City Center on Tuesday for a two-week engagement that marks the company's American debut.

title: Deborah Phillips To Wed April 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Phillips of Weston, Mass., and Center Harbor, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Phillips to John Lee Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Robertson of Houston. The wedding is planned for April 11. The future bride was until recently the director of international rights for CBS Educational and Professional Publishing in New York. She attended Wellesley College and graduated summa cum laude from Wesleyan University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her father is the chairman and chief executive officer of the Raytheon Company in Lexington, Mass.

title: 128 Are Arrested in Protest Of Trident Missile Launching
description: More than 100 protesters, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician, were arrested today when they scrambled over a fence at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station as thousands of demonstrators protested the test launching Thursday of a Trident 2 missile.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK TO FOMENT GREEN REVOLUTION IN AFRICA
description: AGAINST the bleak landscape of African agriculture, a hundred scientists from 44 countries are working on the technologies they hope will someday lead to the long-sought Green Revolution.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: The Republican Party is expected to decide in the coming week to hold its 1988 Presidential nominating convention in New Orleans. The choice signals the importance of the South as a battleground in the next contest for the White House; only rarely has the Republican Party ventured below the Mason-Dixon line for its quadrennial celebration.

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: Ducks Unlimited's VideoGuide to Waterfowl and Game Birds Written, directed and narrated by Michael A. Godfrey. MasterVision. 75 minutes. $74.95.

title: REVIVE SALT II, GET FRANKENSTEIN
description: If Dr. Frankenstein were around today, he could offer a very useful reminder to some Democratic members of Congress: it's mighty dangerous trying to breathe new life into a dead body.

title: RACIAL BIAS INCIDENTS RISING IN CITY, POLICE SAY
description: Confirmed incidents of racial bias in New York City, after dropping sharply in most of 1986, have jumped more than 150 percent in the month since the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, according to police officials who investigate crimes of bias.

title: MY TROUBLES WITH THE TAXMAN
description: LEAD: THREE QUICK POINTS TO set the mood:

title: U.S. OFFICIAL URGES A RIVERFRONT DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: In a major policy shift, the region's chief Federal environmental official has proposed that a comprehensive plan for development on New York City's riverfronts be devised to avoid ''environmental gridlock.''

title: Betsy Stephens Engaged to Wed James Hebb 4th
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wade Carroll Stephens of Lawrenceville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Wade Stephens to James Stephen Hebb 4th, a son of Mrs. John Steven Slorp of Memphis and Mr. Hebb 3d of Alexandria, Va. The wedding is planned for June 20. Miss Stephens, who is known as Betsy, is the director of student activities, a history teacher and an admissions associate at the Madeira School. She graduated from the Princeton Day School and Mount Holyoke College. Her father is the director of studies at the Lawrenceville School. Her mother, Jean Stephens, is president of the Princeton (N.J.) branch and a director of the English-Speaking Union.

title: M. L. Grass, a Chain-Store Executive, Engaged to Jody Harrison, a Designer
description: The engagement of Jody Leigh Harrison to Martin Lehrman Grass has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Harrison of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Grass is a son of Alexander Grass and Lois Lehrman Grass, both of Harrisburg, Pa. The wedding is planned for May 17.

title: WESTBURY HUNTS NEW SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: LEAD: IN 1979, after a decade of racial unrest and growing neglect of its school system by a divided community, the Westbury Board of Education began a search for a new superintendent.

title: FEELING ISOLATED ON THE ISLAND
description: Wendy Turgeon's ''Won't Anybody Here Talk to Me?'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 14), painfully refers to the isolation many of us can feel here on Long Island. Often, those who express these feelings blame their situation on the fact that they are ''employed women'' lacking time to develop relationships or homemakers claiming underexposure for their lack of contacts. Walls of silence have emerged where friendships could have begun. Suspicious responses to gestures of interest have become commonplace.

title: Freshman attitudes
description: American college freshmen are more interested in financial success according to a new survey by the University of California at Los Angeles and the American Council on Education, and less interested than their predecessors in helping others. The study, based on responses from 204,491 students who entered college last fall, also reported less support for the preservation of the environment and a significant drop in support for the legalization of marijuana.

title: IRAQIS ASSERT THEY BOMBED KHOMEINI'S HOME
description: Iraq asserted today that it had bombed Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's home in Teheran, and Iran said its troops were continuing to make gains in heavy fighting near the main southern Iraqi city of Basra.

title: AN AUTHORITARIAN BY POPULAR CONSENT
description: LEAD: PERON AND THE ENIGMAS OF ARGENTINA By Robert D. Crassweller. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: THE MUSE, POSTMODERN AND HOMELESS
description: If you're a writer and if you're by nature Sublime and Magisterial,

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Mauston, Wisc.;
Blowing Up A Building
description: LEAD: WHEN Xanadome Structures Ltd., a small manufacturer of prefabricated homes, builds its new factory this spring, it will use a giant balloon to literally blow it up.

title: FRENCH HOSTAGE SEIZED
description: Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy, returned to Beirut last week seeking the release of more hostages. But his visit was the occasion for another kidnapping. Gunmen seized Roger Auque, a French free-lance reporter and photographer, not long after he finished photographing Mr. Waite on the seafront in Moslem West Beirut. Mr. Waite, a representative of the Archbishop of Canterbury, has been involved in successful negotiations to free a number of American and other hostages in Lebanon. Eighteen foreigners, including five Americans, are still being held.

title:
MUSIC;
SYMPHONY BEGINNING NEW CHAMBER SERIES
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will open a new Chamber Orchestra series with concerts Friday at 8:30 P.M. in Princeton, Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in New Brunswick and next Sunday at 3 P.M. in Lakewood.

title: THE WORLD'S WORST CRITICS
description: SELF-CRITICISM is an art not many are qualified to practice. Despite our best efforts it is probable that, apart from the most immediate, pragmatic, technical revisions, the writer's effort to detach himself from his work is quixotic: knowing too much is a way of knowing too little; or, conversely, how can we expect to know more about ourselves than we know about anything else? In the human eye no light energy can stimulate the retina at the exit of the optic tract: all human beings carry blind spots with them in their vision. Everywhere we look there are points of invisibility, it might be said, which can't be seen even as absence. We are all in the position of King Lear, who, holding absolute authority over his kingdom, ''but slenderly knew himself.''

title: MONKEY TROUBLE AT FLORIDA RESORT
description: WHAT was described as the nation's only free-roaming colony of monkeys came under state condemnation at Silver Springs, a junglelike tourist attraction in Florida.

title: BEYOND THE COURT FIGHT: DEEP LOVE FOR BABY M
description: To the world, the infant known as Baby M is the central figure in a landmark custody fight.

title: WATERBASHING TOO UNDIGNIFIED
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RELUCTANTLY, JAPAN IS CONTEMPLATING THE PILL
description: MORE than two decades after the birth control pill launched a sexual revolution in the United States, the Japanese Government is close to officially condoning its use. Instead of praise, however, the move has met with criticism from feminists and wariness from the public, which is not expected to switch en masse to oral contraception.

title: GREATS OF CLASSIC JAZZ IGNITE A REISSUE
description: When Orrin Keepnews and Bill Grauer Jr. compiled ''The Riverside History of Classic Jazz'' in 1956, the overview of jazz was much different than it is from the perspective of 30 years later, and the availability of jazz records for reissue was much more restricted. To encounter this five-disk set today, newly reissued (Riverside B-005) in an exact reproduction of the original boxed album, including the artwork and a warm, colorful, introductory essay by Charles Edward Smith, a pioneer jazz enthusiast and historian (in that order of preference), is both an encounter with a jazz Rip Van Winkle and a view of the dinosaur age of jazz recording.

title: DR. WALLACE M. ALSTON
description: The Rev. Dr. Wallace McPherson Alston, president emeritus of Agnes Scott College in Decatur, Ga., died Wedesday at his home in Lithonia, Ga. He was 80 year old.

title: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC UNDER VARIOUS BATONS
description: For both general and specific reasons, the New York Philharmonic records far less often than it used to. Still, on two labels with three conductors recorded in three locations, the orchestra has been represented on four new releases in recent months.

title: Miss Fager Plans To Wed D. N. Fish
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Fager of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Geraldine Maria Fager to Daniel Nelson Fish, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Bartlett Fish of Watertown, N.Y.

title: No Airplanes Necessary
description: EVERY Giant football fan has a vivid recollection of the Philadelphia Eagle game on Nov. 19, 1978, which football history refers to as The Fumble game. That disaster, and the resulting loss, did not cost the Giants a division title, a playoff game, or even a winning season. Yet, it set into motion a chain of events that can best be described as total fan outrage.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
STUDYING DEATH ON CENTER STAGE
description: LEAD: ''WOULD I really lose control of my emotions in front of a patient?''

title: SCARSDALE OFFERS HOMELESS A HOUSE
description: Because of a production error in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly, the following story appeared with a section omitted. A LITTLE white house with a picket fence may become the home of a now-homeless family if the village of Scarsdale, which owns it, and the county, which has hundreds of homeless families to shelter, can come to an agreement.

title: ISLANDERS LEARN WHY FLYERS ARE NO.1
description: Beaten again, and by Philadelphia, the team they need to learn how to subdue in order to be contenders for the Patrick Division title, the Islanders showered and dressed slowly, ruminatively. That they were in no hurry to board the bus waiting outside had much to do with its destination: Philadelphia, where this home-and-home series will conclude Sunday night.

title: Quake Jolts Northern Japan
description: A strong earthquake jolted the Pacific coast of northern Japan today, but the police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake, which struck at about 7 P.M., registered a preliminary 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale.

title: AFGHAN GUERILLAS VOW TO STEP UP THEIR WAR
description: Cheered on by tens of thousands of people shouting ''Death to the Russians!'' Afghan guerrilla leaders at a rally here today vowed to step up their war against the Afghan authorities in Kabul and said they would try to form their own government in exile.

title: CALIFORNIA FACES A SPENDING FIGHT
description: George Deukmejian, a Republican, has begun his second term in office as he began the first one: fighting over money with Democratic legislators and the state's influential public schools lobby.

title: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: THE DOW IN PERSPECTIVE  TRACING THE UPS AND DOWNS OF THE 20th CENTURY THROUGH THE EYES OF WALL STREET; Where the Dow Was When
description: 1900 The Dow: +6.8% for year to 70.71 Mass production of the automobile begins at the Olds Motor Company's factory near Lansing, Mich. Real G.N.P. Growth: +7.4% Average Unemployment: 5.0% 1916 The Dow: -4.2% to 95.00 Albert Einstein revolutionizes physics by publishing his General Theory of Relativity as World War I rages across Europe. Real Growth: +7.6% Unemployment: 5.1% 1919 The Dow: +30.4% to 107.23 The 18th amendment, Prohibition, is passed, outlawing the manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating beverages. The United States is dry until repeal in 1933. Real Growth: -7.3% Unemployment: 1.4% 1929 The Dow: -17.2% to 248.48 The Crash signals the start of the Great Depression. Real growth will not match 1929's level for a decade; joblessness will soar and stay in double digits until World War II. Real Growth: +6.3% Unemployment: 3.2% 1939 The Dow: -21.5% to 150.24 Social Security is expanded to provide benefits not only to working Americans, but also to their survivors and dependents; Germany invades Poland touching off World War II. Real Growth: +7.9% Unemployment: 17.2% #1945 The Dow: +26.6% to 192.91 The United States drops two atomic bombs on Japan forcing a surrender that ends World War II. Real Growth: -1.9% Unemployment: 1.9% 1951 The Dow: +14.1% to 269.23 Remington Rand installs the first commercially available electronic computer, called Univac. Real Growth: +10.3% Unemployment: 3.3% #1957 The Dow: -12.8% to 435.69 The United States is left stunned at the starting gate when the Soviet Union starts the space race by launching Sputnik in October. Real Growth: +1.7% Unemployment: 4.3% #1964 The Dow: +14.6% to 874.13 President Johnson pushes the Tonkin Gulf resolution through Congress, beginning the big United States build-up in Vietnam. Real Growth: +5.3% Unemployment: 5.2% #1969 The Dow: -15.1% to 800.36 Two United States astronauts are the first men to walk on the moon. Real Growth: +2.4% Unemployment: 3.5% #1973 The Dow: -16.6% to 850.86 OPEC's embargo raises oil prices fourfold, and most of the nation watches televised Congressional hearings on Watergate. Real Growth: +5.2% tr,fnlUnemployment: 4.9% #1982 The Dow: +19.6% to 1,046.54 The Bell system is dismantled, and the Government drops its antitrust suit against I.B.M. Fed chairman Paul Volcker acts to lower interest rates, igniting the stock market rally that is still under way. Real Growth: -2.5% Unemployment: 9.7%

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Penguins 2: Third-period goals by Steve Kasper, Tom McCarthy and Nevin Markwart led the Bruins at home yesterday. They trailed by 2-1 entering the third period. (AP) Capitals 6, Whalers 1: At Hartford, Kevin Hatcher and Dave Christian each scored twice as the Capitals scored five goals on their first 12 shots against Mike Liut. Hartford has lost eight of its last 10 games. (AP) Canadiens 4, Sabres 2: At Montreal, Brian Skrudland scored one goal and set up another, and Bobby Smith and Larry Robinson each had two assists to lead the Canadiens. Brian Hayward turned aside 26 shots for the Canadiens. (AP) Oilers 7, Maple Leafs 4:The line of Esa Tikkanen, Wayne Gretzky and Jari Kurri accumulated 13 points, including two goals each by Tikkanen and Kurri, to lead the Oilers to their fifth consecutive victory. Gretzky, who scored on an empty net with 1:17 left, Randy Gregg and Steve Smith also scored for the Oilers. Kurri and Gretzky each had three assists and Tikkanen two. (AP) N.B.A. Pacers 119, Mavericks 115: In the second overtime at Indianapolis, Herb Williams scored 6 of his 14 points for the Pacers. He also had a game-high 14 rebounds. John Long, who finished with a game-high 29 points, put the Pacers ahead to stay, 113-111, on a 19-footer with 1:25 to go in the second overtime. (AP) HORSE RACING From 10th to First: Storm on the Loose, ridden by Jorge Velasquez, rallied from 10th place to run down Lyphard Line in the final yards and win the $70,175 Royal Palm Handicap by half a length at Hialeah Park. The winner, a Canadian-bred 4-year-old son of Lyphard, paid $19.20 for $2 after covering the mile and a sixteenth on the grass in 1:41 4/5. He carried 116 pounds, 3 more than the runner-up. Infantry, the 9-5 favorite, finished 12th after making his first start in nearly 15 months. Squan Song Scores: Squan Song scored her third consecutive stakes victory when she rallied to win the $93,900 Affectionately Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Clemanna's Rose, the longest shot in the field of 11, took the early lead and held well to be runner-up, three-quarters of a length behind Squan Song and 2 3/4 lengths ahead of Ms. Eloise. The 6-year-old daughter of Exceller and Foreign Missile earned $56,340 for her owner, Robert Brennan, and returned $5. SKIING West German Wins Downhill: Markus Wasmeier of West Germany won a World Cup downhill race for the first time yesterday, mastering the 4.1-kilometer Lauberhorn course in 2 minutes 29.62 seconds at Wengen, Switzerland. The 23-year-old slalom specialist finished 1.09 seconds ahead of Karl Alpiger of Switzerland on the longest run in cup competition. Franz Heinzer of Switzerland, skiing with an injured left knee, finished third in 2:31.17. Pirmin Zurbriggen, the Swiss ace who leads in both the overall and downhill standings, finished ninth in 2:31.55. The top finisher from the American team was Michael Brown of Vail, Colo., who was 12th in 2:31.96 on the course with a drop of 1,028 meters. (AP) French Skier Wins: Catherine Quittet of France posted her first World Cup victory as she won a women's supergiant slalom at Pfronten. Maria Walliser of Switzerland, the leader of the women's overall World Cup standings, struggled to a ninth-place finish, her worst showing of the season. Quittet clocked 1 minute 17.40 seconds through the difficult Breitenberg course, which dropped 430 meters through 37 gates. (AP) BOBSLED Hiltebrand Leads: Hans Hiltebrand of Switzerland, in a promising bid for the first four-man bobsled title in his 17-year racing career, held a slight lead after yesterday's opening heats of the world championships at St. Moritz, Switzerland. Hiltebrand, who will be 42 on Sunday and is the oldest athlete on the circuit, turned in the two fastest heats at the controls of the Switzerland II sled. His sled's total time was 2 minutes 10.84 seconds for the two trips down the 1,585-meter, 16-curve chute featuring a drop of 130 meters. In second place, 86-hundredths of a second behind, was the East Germany I sled, driven by Wolfgang Hoppe, the double gold medalist at the 1984 Olympics. (AP) SQUASH RACQUETS Two Upsets: Alberto Nunez of Mexico City rallied from a two-game deficit yesterday to upset second-seeded Steve Bowditch of West Germany in the Marsh & McLennan Apawamis Invitational Squash Tournament in Rye, N.Y. The scores were 10-15, 17-18, 18-16, 15-11, 15-6. In another second-round upset, unranked Gary Waite of Toronto surprised fifth-seeded David Boyum of New York, 17-16, 15-12, 15-4, but seeded players advanced to the quarterfinals. Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., ranked first, defeated Larry Hilbert of New York, 15-11, 9-15, 15-10, 15-8; Mario Sanchez of Mexico City beat Kenton Jernigan of Newport, R.I., 15-12, 15-9, 15-12, and John Nimick of Philadelphia beat Hugh Labossier of New York, 9-15, 15-8, 15-12, 15-7. SPEED SKATING Thometz the Winner: Nick Thometz of the United States sprinted past Uwe May of East Germany to win the men's 500-meter World Cup speed-skating race yesterday at Davos, Switzerland. Thometz was timed in 37.12 seconds, one-hundredth of a second in front of May. (AP)

title:
THEATER;
SCREEN STARS ENLIVEN THE PARIS STAGE THIS SEASON
description: LEAD: Theatrical impresarios, like fashionable ladies, are always complaining that they have nothing to put on. They should visit Paris and take a look. Here everything is being put on: Greek tragedy, German tragedy, Shakespeare, native comedy - both classic and modern, musical frolics and importations from Broadway and Off

title: CARNIVAL
description: To the Editor: To get wet feet in Venice, it is not necessary to visit during the Carnival period. My wife and I arrived in the Queen of the Adriatic on the heels of a huge low-pressure area that had bounced our plane around en route from Milan in September 1968. That evening we went from the Hotel Metropole to Piazza San Marco to hear the municipal band, which was playing selections from ''Norma'' and ''Tannhauser.''

title: D.E.P. SEEKS CURBS ON PERMIT HEARINGS
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is considering a regulatory change that would deny environmental groups the right to request an administrative law hearing on permits they oppose.

title: CONCERT: MUSICKE CONSORT
description: THE Consort of Musicke's Wednesday night concert at Weill Recital Hall, devoted to English and Italian music of the 17th century, provided an ample impression of the group and its charms even to this listener who was pushed into an early departure by the flu.

title: POWER COST IS DOWN BUT STILL AN ISSUE
description: LEAD: WITH electric rates in Westchester's Con Edison region down in 1986 for the second consecutive year, the push for cheaper power has lost some of its urgency, county officials say. Nonetheless, they add, it is an issue that they expect to re-emerge.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A FOOT IN EACH WORLD:

title:
ANTIQUES;
50'S AMERICAN GLASS ART AT WHEATON VILLAGE
description: LEAD: THE inquiring intellect and entrepreneurial talent of Dr. T. C. Wheaton, a physician and pharmacist who went on to establish a successful glass-making company here in 1888, continue in spirit at Wheaton Village.

title: JERSEY CITY MARCH SET FOR HOMES AND JOBS
description: LEAD: A MARCH and motorcade to support jobs for minorities and low-income housing at the Newport construction site here is expected to start at 1 P.M. tomorrow, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: HERO AND GOAT
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Judge Delays Elections In Voting Rights Case
description: A Federal district judge issued an injunction Friday to prevent the city from holding any elections and gave officials 60 days to propose a new form of goverment that does not violate the voting rights of blacks.

title: D.E.P. PLANNING TO INVOLVE THE PUBLIC
description: LEAD: THE storm that forced the state's Department of Environmental Protection to abandon a plan to dispose of radium-contaminated soil in Vernon Township last year is now bringing changes within the department.

title: WHERE THE MIDDLE AGES LIVE
description: What does one call a city that has nearly 80 recorded names, 7 of them coined by Goethe's Mephistopheles as he was flying toward it on his magic cloak with Dr. Faust?

title: OLIVER NORTH'S STRANGE RECRUITS
description: LEAD: AS SOMEONE WHO HAS SPENT A good deal of his life as an investigative writer, I like to think that there's not much left to surprise me.

title: DOES MOSCOW MEAN IT THIS TIME?
description: TEN years ago this month, the Bendix Corporation and the Soviet Union announced that they had started down the aisle together toward a mixed economic marriage.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: CALIFORNIA HERE WE COME;
Coming Together
description: LEAD: THERE are three significant factors that contributed to the sucess of the 1986 Giants, and they will utlimately lead them to the Super Bowl championship. First and foremost, it seems to be a team of tremendous character. In many respects, only four or five players were what you might consider household names at the beginning of the season.

title: AMBASSADOR SHOT BY COCAINE RING
description: As Justice Minister of Colombia, Enrique Parejo Gonzalez received so many death threats from cocaine traffickers that he was named Ambassador to Hungary and rushed out of the country in August. But last week, the barons of Colombia's multibillion-dollar drug racket claimed vengeance. In what the State Department deplored as a ''narco-terrorist'' attack, Mr. Parejo was shot as he left his home in Budapest.

title: IMPASSE IN QUEENS ATTACK CASE ENDS
description: Lawyers for the two surviving victims of the Dec. 20 racial assault in Howard Beach declared a ''people's victory'' last week after Governor Cuomo assigned a special prosecutor to take over the case.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES THAT COLOR THE WINTER LANDSCAPE
description: LEAD: ONE has but to travel through the countryside of the Northeast to discover the full potential that exists for winter color in the landscape. To be certain, the colors are for the most part muted when compared with those of spring, summer and fall, however, the subtle differences from species to species provide a panoramic contrast across the fields, meadows and mountainsides.

title: Q and A
description: New 2d-Home Tax Rules Question: I own vacation property on the Jersey Shore that has two homes, one I use for myself and the other a rental. For tax purposes, I proportioned the buildings on a 30-70 percent basis. On the rental, which is much larger, I take deductions for repairs, interest, taxes, insurance and depreciation. The life of the depreciation for the property is 15 years. Under the new tax law, will I be permitted to deduct the full depreciation for this home or is this type of property subject to change? . . . E. B., Fort Lee,N.J. Answer: Neil O'Keefe, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, says the new tax law does not affect the depreciation schedule for your rental property since it applies only to residential rental properties placed into service after Dec. 31, 1986. For these, depreciation is recovered over a period of 27.5 years.
