Bed and Breakfast Question: I own a five-family brownstone in New York and I would like to rent one very small unit as a bed-and-breakfast. What are the regulations that govern such establishments and what permits would I need? . . . K. D., Manhattan Answer: Assuming that your building is in a residential zone, you would not be able to rent any of the individual dwelling units on a daily basis like a transient bed-and-board establishment, according to Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the City's Department of Buildings.

title: HOW TO JUSTIFY A U.S.-GROWN FORM OF APARTHEID
description: To the Editor:

title: New Talent Bolsters 15-0 Syracuse
description: IT is 9 o'clock at night and Jim Boeheim, the basketball coach at Syracuse University, is relaxing in the recreation room of his split-level house.

title: EUROPE'S INNOVATIVE RADIO ORCHESTRAS
description: When the BBC Symphony Orchestra made its first tour in 1936, it took along Schoenberg's Orchestral Variations, Op. 31, and played it in the composer's native city of Vienna. The work caused total mystification for an audience used to Mozart and Schubert, and when the conductor, Adrian Boult, was introduced to the Austrian President after the performance, the President asked, ''Who is this Schoenberg anyway?''

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: Harlem Harmonies Volume I - Dorothy Dandridge, Erskine Hawkins, others. 35 minutes. Volume II - Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Nat King Cole, Billie Holiday, others. 34 minutes. Jazz Classics. Distributed by Audiofidelity Enterprises, Inc. $19.95.

title:
ART;
WORKS BY NEVELSON IN STAMFORD
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH she is one of the most substantial artists in America, Louise Nevelson deals with themes that are highly delicate and evanescent. These themes include the dawn, brides and the tide. Even her almost omnipresent use of black is primarily for the evocation of shadows. Nevelson is a distinct combination of staunchness and mystery.

title: Slim Pickings Elsewhere
description: Outside the financial stocks, definitions of ''undervalued'' must be stretched for many names to surface. One money manager scanned his entire list for a cheap stock before coming back with a verbal shrug, ''None.'' The rare companies with low P/E multiples or large discounts from book value generally have problems that discourage analysts from recommending them. But here are a few offerings that managers cite as undervalued -at least compared with the rest of the market:

title: SIX SLAYINGS STIR ANXIETY IN CAPITAL
description: The discoveries of the bodies of six young black women has set off a police search crossing state lines and has aroused anxiety among the capital area's blacks.

title: NO LONGER THE SALAD DAYS
description: A YEAR and a half ago, East of Athens, in Port Jefferson, was a gem of a restaurant. There was wonderful, authentic Greek country food, an appealing dining room and a staff full of pride. Little touches like a complimentary appetizer and a small portion of fresh fruit between courses were symbols of the restaurant's care, quality and effort. Those symbols remain like a remnant of better days.

title: WHAT HE FOUND, WHAT HE LOST
description: FAITH, SEX, MYSTERY A Memoir. By Richard Gilman. 253 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'ANNE FRANK' IN TEANECK ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' produced by the professional American Stage Company of Teaneck, opened this weekend at the Becton Theater on the Teaneck campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: A CHILI WINTER
description: ON A RECENT EXPEDITION in Sonoma County, Calif., my hunting partner, Bob Cooley of California's Hacienda Winery, and I netted a wild boar.

title: CARDIAC SURGERRY: NEW CURBS ARE SOUGHT
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY should adopt tough, new volume standards for open-heart surgery and other cardiac procedures, and the state's Department of Health should have the authority to close services that do not measure up, according to a far-reaching report released here last week.

title: WHITE PROTESTORS DISRUPT 'WALK FOR BROTHERHOOD' IN GEORGIA TOWN
description: A civil rights march was halted here today when a crowd of whites, including members of the Ku Klux Klan, confronted about 50 marchers near this rural, all-white community in northern Georgia.

title: Ms. Cowles Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Cowles of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Ann Cowles, to Mark D. Resnick, the son of Paula Menard of Cranston, R.I. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Cowles, who is known as Jackie, and her fiance graduated from the University of Rhode Island. She is an associate wildlife biologist for T.R.C. Environmental Consultants in Hartford, where he is a sales representative for Beatrice/Hunt-Wesson Foods Inc.

title: JUDGE DELAYS CALIFORNIA MURDER TRIAL
description: The judge in a murder trial, angered that the police seized documents in the home of the chief defendant while jury selection was under way, has put off the trial to determine if the case involving members of the Billionaire Boys Club has been tainted.

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: I am in the minority who believe that baseball players are not asking too much. First of all, for most of the game's history, ballplayers were virtual slaves of the owners. Secondly, ballplayers are entertainers just as actors are. Yet there is no outcry when stars receive millions of dollars for cameo roles in films, even though those fees help push up the cost of our ticket prices. Finally, no one put a gun to the owners' heads when they began shoving big bucks into the faces of free agents. The pendulum will eventually swing back of its own momentum. Meanwhile, let the players get what they can. JIM WEIGERT New York

title: Roya Meghnot Fiancee Of Keith A. Schuman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Parviz Meghnot of Ann Arbor, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Roya Lesa Meghnot to Keith Andrew Schuman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Schuman of Ardsley, N.Y.

title: PLAYING THE BLUES, CHICAGO-STYLE
description: LEAD: For five decades, Chicagoans - mostly blacks, but including some white blues buffs - have gone to dance or listen at the city's legendary blues clubs. The two dozen or so surviving clubs (down from twice that number in the 1950's) can be traced to Southern blacks who migrated to Chicago since the end of the Depression.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Now, It's Weehawken's Turn to Bustle
description: LEAD: NEARLY every inch of land is spoken for in Weehawken, a tiny old Hudson County community whose streets are crammed with two-family homes and bulky brick factories.

title: Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
description: The American Indian had no word for art and believed that a beautifully made object was ''a prayer made visible.'' Avarice, ignorance and indifference are allowing the destruction of our most profound cultural heritage. J. REZENDES New York City

title: Fuming
description: To the Editor: When the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that the slightest involuntary exposure to tobacco smoke is worse than anything else, except breathing asbestos, are they playing a political game?

title: IN ANIMATION FOR CHILDREN, THE OLD DAYS WERE BETTER
description: They come from two different worlds: she is a se rene thoroughbred, he's a street-smart scoundrel with radical ideas. They meet through friends and fall in love, and he does what he can to show her the world. ''Aw, come on, kid, start building some memories,'' he urges. But she wants a stable and conventional life, while he wants freedom to roam. He scorns her fondness for ''life on a leash.''

title: WORKERS ARRESTED IN HOTEL ARSON
description: A maintenance worker has admitted setting the fatal fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, apparently because he was angry at the management, Federal and Puerto Rican officials said last week. Hector Escudero Aponte, who had worked at the San Juan hotel for 10 years, was charged with arson and with separate counts of murder for each of the 96 people who died in the New Year's Eve blaze.

title: SUZANA AMARAL: HER 'HOUR' HAS COME
description: Suzana Amaral was married at age 20, and in the next 10 years had eight children. At 37, she entered the University of Sao Paulo film school, and went on to get a master's degree in film at New York University. She is now 54, and her first full-length theatrical feature, ''The Hour of the Star'' - a film about the troubled life of a young woman in Sao Paulo that the Brazilian director shot in four weeks for $150,000 - opens Wednesday at Film Forum 1, after having won awards at the Berlin, Brasilia, Havana and International Woman's Film Festivals and having been selected as Brazil's official entry for the best foreign-language film Academy Award.

title: BABY M, ETHICS AND THE LAW
description: The emotional courtroom battle for custody of Baby M has cast a sharp and disquieting light on the tangle of ethical and legal uncertainties surrounding the growing practice of surrogate motherhood.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WOLF TICKETS. By Edward Hower. (Viking, $17.95.) Edward Hower's thoughtful novel about a girls' reform school in upstate New York confronts the ironies of the juvenile justice system while drawing compassionate, lively portraits of the teen-agers under its control. The story is about Steven Fox, a soul-searching counselor whose experimental group therapy program encourages freedom and self-discipline;

title: Escape Route as Design Element
description: IT did not take the New Year's Eve inferno at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan to focus Alfred Menziuso's attention on the subject of designing safe means of escape from burning high-rise buildings.

title: STATE LOOKS TO CONGRESS AGAIN FOR HIGHWAY AID
description: CONNECTICUT transportation officials are eagerly awaiting enactment of a highway bill that would enable the state to begin and continue major projects. The projects have been delayed because of a Congressional deadlock.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Jan. 4 on Guiding Eyes for the Blind included incorrect information about how new guide dogs are provided. The organization, which retains ownership of the dogs, requests a voluntary tuition fee of $150 for the 26-day training course given to blind people who receive the dogs.

title: Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
description: As a former Bureau of Land Management ranger, I witnessed firsthand the archeological-site destruction in southern Utah and Colorado documented by Derek Goodwin in ''Raiders of the Sacred Sites'' (Dec. 7). Artifact collectors are professional and elusive; despite back-country patrols and aircraft surveillance, most of my time was spent reburying the remains of Native Americans scattered across the surface of prehistoric sites. One bulldozed site I visited had a stack of five sun-bleached human skulls. Some of the bones I discovered had been gnawed to pieces by wild animals.

title: Status Report
description: 'Black Americans enter 1987 besieged by the resurgence of raw racism, persistent economic depression and the continued erosion of past gains.' - John E. Jacob, president of the National Urban League, releasing a report on ''The State of Black America.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SPORTS SPECTATORS. By Allen Guttmann. (Columbia University, $24.95.) In the introduction to ''Sports Spectators,'' Allen Guttmann, a professor of American studies at Amherst College, gives his working definition of a sports fan - an ''emotionally committed 'consumer' of sports events.'' Unfortunately, ''Sports Spectators'' lacks emotion. It is not a book for the sports fan seeking a quick, absorbing peek into a large part of the society to which he belongs. Mr. Guttmann's work is an often ponderous look at the history of those sitting in the grandstand from ancient Greece and Rome up to the present day's soccer and baseball fields. When the author moves from his historical narrative to his analysis of the sociological, economic and psychological elements of sports spectatorship, he meanders. In his care to include as many theoretical approaches to the subject as possible, he seems to submerge any thesis of his own. It is interesting to read that ancient Romans preferred their gladiators to be citizens rather than slaves - and if they were knights or senators, so much the better - because plebeian spectators were probably thrilled to see the high and mighty exposed to risks and hazards comparable to their own. ''We are what we watch,'' says Mr. Guttmann.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CHINESE PUPPETS AT YALE

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: The debate is always are players asking for too much? I would like to know how much income the owners derive from the team. I know how much each player and the managers of the Steinbrenner Yankees and the Wilpon/Doubleday Mets earn, but how much money did George and Fred make in 1986 on their respective teams? Are they making too much? Should they lower ticket prices? Should they pay more in stadium rental to the city? These questions are valid and should be asked whent we discuss player salaries. ISAAC SASSON Queens

title: FLAWLESS FRENCH IN GREENWICH
description: GUY SAVOY, the restaurant named after the chef who opened it several years ago in Greenwich, has undergone a name and ownership change and the results are an all-round improvement - in food, in decor and in the welcome accorded guests.

title: THE OTHER PARIS ACCORDS
description: THE PALACE FILE By Nguyen Tien Hung and Jerrold L. Schecter. Illustrated. 542 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: Next Week; Who Will Win the Super Bowl, And Why?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: SUFFERING AN EXCESS OF GOOD INTENTIONS
description: Not long after Mrs. Rivlin gave the speech from which the accompanying article is excerpted, President Reagan sent his proposed Federal budget for the fiscal year 1988, touching off the annual scramble that consumes much of official Washington's time and energy. In an interview this week, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office discussed the current budget and the prospects for reform.

title: THE SEASON OF AMBIVALENCE
description: IT'S back again - the season of my discontent, and of my content. The season I hate, the season I love. Winter.

title: FEDERAL POLICY TERMED THREAT TO YELLOWSTONE
description: Development in the seven national forests surrounding Yellowstone National Park is fragmenting and eroding the natural systems that support the park, the Wilderness Society charged in a report released today.

title: INQUIRY INTO N.S.C. UNCOVERING LITTLE ABOUT IRAN DEALS
description: Less than two weeks before its report is due, the White House panel examining the National Security Council's role in the Iran-contra affair has uncovered almost no new information. It faces the prospect of making recommendations about the council's future that may already be outdated.

title: MR. SHAWN
description: William Shawn, the editor of The New Yorker, is a legendary fussbudget. ''Questioning a comma,'' the critic Brendan Gill wrote of him, ''he will shake his head and say in his soft voice that he realizes perfectly well what a lot of time and thought have gone into the comma and that in the ordinary course of events he would be the first to say that the comma was precisely the form of punctuation that he would have been most happy to encounter at that very place in the sentence, but isn't there the possibility - oh, only the remotest one, to be sure, and yet perhaps worth considering for a moment in the light of the care already bestowed on the construction - that the sentence could be made to read infinitesimally more clearly if, say, instead of a comma a semicolon were to be inserted at just that point? And the author, touched by Shawn's sympathy, aghast with admiration for the skill of his circumlocutions, and determined at all costs to prevent Shawn from suffering the humiliation of having his proposed semicolon rejected, throws up his hands and exclaims, 'Much clearer your way!' ''

title: GUERILLA PLEDGES DRIVE ON SOUTH AFRICAN WHITES
description: South Africa's white settlements near the northern border will be the targets for increased guerrilla attacks by the African National Congress, according to Joe Modise, the guerrilla commander.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Columbus, Ohio; Recycling A Courthouse
description: THIS city's original United States Courthouse and Post Office, a Romanesque and Gothic Revival structure on the National Register of Historic Places, has undergone a $10 million renovation in time for its centennial this year. But it might never have reached its 100th birthday had it not been for an unusual partnership between a prominent local law firm and municipal officials.

title: Carol Weil to Marry Prof. David Medine
description: Dr. and Mrs. Max Harry Weil of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Juliet Weil to David Medine, the son of Ruth Medine of New York and the late Dr. Myer Medine. The wedding is planned for July.

title: SURPLUS SCHOOLS: THE DEBATE CONTINUES
description: To anyone unfamiliar with the ongoing controversy over the disposition of two surplus schools in District 14 (Hewlett-Woodmere), Dr. Bert Nelson's letter to the editor (Dec. 28) in response to an article by Saul Schindler, ''Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 7), would appear to be a model of clarity. However, appearances are often deceiving; with Dr. Nelson, too often.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: A Lot of Smoke In Rhode Island

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: Not if there's somebody willing to pay them. MIKE SEGHINI New York

title: PAN AM'S DISAPPEARING ACT
description: IN his private conference room on the 46th floor of the Pan Am building, C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of Pan American World Airways, reacts calmly when asked if his strategy is to declare the troubled airline bankrupt.

title:
ART;
PHOTOS OF MULTIPLE MEANINGS
description: LEAD: THERE are photography enthusiasts and professional colleagues of the late photographer Max Waldman who become immediately animated at the mention of his name. To these admirers his works are extraordinary achievements as dynamic human images that rely totally on studio devices. He had an insightful eye, and created with great flair and style.

title: Exemption From Rent Regulations
description: To the Editor: A question was raised in your Q. & A. column on Nov. 16 about creating exempt status on rent-regulated apartments. The answer stated: ''The only way to rid a building of its rent-regulated status is through a gut-rehabilitation includingnew ceilings, floors, walls, etc.''

title: SUPER DREAM
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A BRITISH MUSEUM'S CHOICE: ACQUISITIONS OVER 13 YEARS
description: In the National Gallery in London there can be seen through Feb. 15 an exhibition that marks the retirement of Sir Michael Levey, who was director of the National Gallery from 1973 though 1986 and had spent his entire working life on its staff. Though restricted to 38 paintings, ''Director's Choice: Selected Acquisitions 1973-1986'' cuts a swath that runs in time from 1325 (three panels by the Sienese painter Ugolino di Nerio) to 1904 (a portrait by Gustav Klimt) and 1908 (a portrait by Henri Matisse).

title: 'PAPER'S THIRD DIMENSION' IN PARAMUS
description: ''PAPER'S THIRD DIMENSION,'' an exhibition currently at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science here, has brought to northern New Jersey the works of six innovators in applications of paper.

title: STRUCTURES WITH BUILT-IN SHUDDERS
description: The brooding grandeur of Giovanni Battista Piranesi's thousands of architectural prints and drawings of ancient Roman buildings and ruins have made them immensely popular, and the prison scenes in the series of large prints called ''Carceri'' have inspired artists and writers for 200 years. Piranesi, who was his own etcher, engraver and printer, made hundreds of changes not only in different editions of the prints but in individual prints in the same issue. In PIRANESI: EARLY ARCHITECTURAL FANTASIES. A Catalogue Raisonne of the Etchings (University of Chicago, $65) Andrew Robison, curator of prints and drawings at the National Gallery of Art, gives a superbly intelligent account of Piranesi's early works, ''Prima Parte di Architetture e Prospettive,''

title: CASTING LIGHT ON THE USE OF FLASH
description: FOR some photographers, night football games are enormously funny. Not that the game itself is all that amusing; it's the sight of thousands of fans in the stadium firing off thousands of electronic flash units. Too bad for the fans that such bursts of light are ineffectual.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
MOTHER VS. DAUGHTER: COMBATANTS IN SHOPPING WAR
description: LEAD: WHOEVER invented the word angst was probably watching me shop for clothes with my daughter. It is a scene that is duplicated in dozens of department stores by hundreds of mother-daughter pairs in thousands of dressing room cubicles from Merrick to Montauk - a fact that gives me absolutely no comfort whatsoever.

title: UNSINKABLE SOUTH AFRICA
description: It's not hard to figure why South Africa's white rulers are excluding foreign journalists, like reporters for The Times, and stifling what was once the freest press in Africa. President P. W. Botha wants fewer television pictures and better newspaper headlines. He wants his National Party to overwhelm all opponents in the election looming this spring. He wants to keep the good news flowing, like champagne at the captain's table on an unsinkable Titanic.

title: POSTINGS: Ulster Project; 500 Town Houses in 5 Years
description: A developer from Forest Hills, Queens, who is making his first foray into Ulster County is planning a $50 million town-house development on the west bank of the Hudson River, across from Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT HELD IN FRANKFURT
description: Middle Eastern terrorists were on the move again last week, but two Lebanese men, one a hijacking suspect, were arrested at European airports.

title: COLOMBIA'S PRESS UNITED TO FIGHT DRUGS
description: Colombia's newspapers and radio and television stations, reacting in concert to a surge of drug-related violence, are warning that this country is in danger of falling under the ''total domination'' of narcotics traffickers.

title: Dr. Deborah Ruiz To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Ruiz of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Deborah Geraldine Ruiz, to Anthony Blenk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Blenk of New York. A May wedding is planned. Dr. Ruiz, an ophthalmologist in New York, graduated from Barnard College and the Albany Medical College of Union University. She completed a residency in ophthalmology at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York. Her father is managing director of the Latin American division of the Mag-Tran Financial Corporation in Westport, Conn.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THERE is a world that runs parallel to our own. I offer it to you as an alternative - to discover and explore, to probe with your senses and, in time, to grow familiar with. The world is called night. Except for two remote places on the globe (and even at these, it is seasonal), night commands a measure of each 24-hour period.

title: ADDICTS TOLD OF AIDS PREVENTION
description: LEAD: COUNSELING and testing for intravenous drug abusers, who last year registered the greatest number of new cases of AIDS in the state, will soon be increased at several locations.

title: POSTINGS: 316 for Garden City; New Condos on Old Site
description: The remaining undeveloped segment of one of Garden City's most venerable sites will soon be home to one of Long Island's newest condominium projects. Construction will start this spring on the Wyndham at Garden City, a $125 million, 316-unit condominium complete with pond, gazebo and health club. The development will cover the 12.5 acres that form part of the historic 21-acre site of the 100-year-old, Georgian-style Garden City Hotel, which was razed in 1974 and replaced with a new hotel in 1983.

title: 'LOOSE ENDS' IN WALKER SPY CASE
description: The Federal Government is not finished with John A. Walker Jr. and his spy ring, law-enforcement officials said last week. A new grand jury is investigating what happened to a million dollars in espionage payments and whether the ring involved people other than the four Navy men already convicted.

title: FROM LOVE OF JAPAN, A SHOP IS BORN
description: LEAD: TO satisfy her longing to live in two countries, Carole Nedvin built a Japanese antique shop onto her Stamford home. There she sells the dolls, chests and clay figurines she grew to love when she accompanied her husband, an I.B.M. executive, on two four-year stints in Japan.

title: VICTORIES SHORE UP CHADIANS
description: The unexpected success of Chadian military attacks against Libyan forces in northern Chad this month has raised hopes within the Chadian Government that the Libyans can soon be driven from Chad. The Chadian Information Minister, Mounne Togoi Hamid, asserted on Wednesday that the Chadian Army of President Hissen Habre held the initiative in the current fighting, and said: ''Now is the most propitious moment to beat Libya. If we don't fight now, we may never win.''

title: SHULTZ VISITS AFRICA WITH GIFTS AND EXHORTATIONS
description: GIVING foreign aid is the process of doing good for somebody else in pursuit of your own self-interest. That seemed to be the governing proposition of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's 14,889-mile trip, concluded last week, to six countries in Africa. As he arrived at one airport or presidential palace after another, often to the accompaniment of drums and dancers brought out in his honor, Mr. Shultz stressed again and again Washington's desire for ''partnership'' in helping the Africans help themselves.

title: TWO CITIES GET FUNDS TO CUT SCHOOL DROPOUT RATE
description: THE state's two largest cities, with help from the Ford Foundation, have begun programs to reduce the dropout rate among their Hispanic students.

title: The Historical Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO ORCHESTRAS REACH MIDPOINT OF THE SEASON
description: THE pace of the concert season quickens somewhat next weekend, with two of the county's fine orchestras leading the way.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: IN NEW YORK I USED to stay in no-power hotels. It was awful. Nobody interviewed me for press or television.

title: Some Sympathy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WERE THESE PEOPLE PROPERTY?
description: MUTINY ON THE AMISTAD The Saga of a Slave Revolt and Its Impact on American Abolition, Law, and Diplomacy. By Howard Jones. Illustrated. 271 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: Nancy Tarbell to Wed Fellow Boston Doctor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stone Tarbell of Binghamton, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Nancy Jane Tarbell, to Dr. Jay Steven Loeffler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John G. Loeffler of Carlisle, Pa.

title: A WORLD OF FANTASY IN MUSEUM SHOW ON DISNEY
description: WITHIN the walls of a turreted castle on a hilltop in Rye Brook, N.Y., an exhibition of more than 150 drawings, watercolors and painted celluloids from Walt Disney films and comic strips depicts a crucial chapter in the history of cartooning.

title: LET NATURE TAKE CARE OF SWANS
description: I take issue with the methods proposed to control swans reported in the article on swan control [ ''Controls on Swans Proposed,'' Jan. 4 ] . I get the feeling that Nobel Proctor, albeit a professor of ornithology, truly hates swans. I 've read other articles in which he maligns swans.

title: KING ACTIVITIES AIM TO DEPICT RELEVANCE OF HIS VISION TODAY
description: With the racial violence last month in Queens still on their minds, organizers of religious and cultural activities over the weekend commemorating the birth of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. emphasized that the civil rights leader's vision is as relevant today as it was during his lifetime.

title: AN OLD FAVORITE IS BACK IN TOWN
description: ACCESSORIES of alligator and crocodile skin have long been chic. But since laws were passed to protect those reptiles, such adornments have not been as visible as they were a couple of decades ago, when they added a special touch to many a smart woman's attire. Now, however, handbags and belts made from the skins are back and despite their price tag - bags start at around $800 and can run into the thousands - customers have been lin ing up to buy them. Unfortunately, more than half of such skins come from protected animals. An alternative is an older bag, like the one above, which was made in the 50's. As for buying a new one, the World Wildlife Fund recommends asking for accessories made from American alligators, now abundant and legally hunted in the Southeast. Black is the favorite color, but brown has its advocates and so do more exotic shades.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: A JURY award of more than $400,000 in damages to two police sergeants who had been demoted in Allentown, Pa., raised a pertinent question last June: Who will pay?

title: MEMORY IS HER WORK
description: BREAKING BREAD By Joyce Reiser Kornblatt. 206 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: Learning On the Job
description: Having worked as a newspaper reporter, wire-service foreign correspondent, magazine editor and publisher for more than 50 years, I found myself in complete agreement with A. M. Rosenthal's articulate defense of the First Amendment (''Learning on the Job,'' Dec. 14). It would be a better world if the freedom to write and the freedom to think were universal.

title: Master Of the Sentimental Sell
description: We need to take a long hard look at the people who concoct ''warm-hearted, gentle, spirited and emotion-laden commercials'' selling junk food, junk beer, junk wine and junk presidents, and, thereby, take a desperately needed look at ourselves and our very foolish buying habits. GEORGE WINSHIP Montclair, N.J.

title: A FLOWER MAN TAKES ROOT ON L.I.
description: LEAD: ''FOR the love of flowers'' is the motto of J. Barry Ferguson, an Oyster Bay flower designer whose displays are popular attractions at many events on Long Island and in New York City.

title: TRYING TO SHIELD INJURED AMERICAN INDUSTRIES
description: WHILE preaching free trade, the Reagan Administration has made protectionist concessions to a number of powerful domestic industries, from steel and lumber to semiconductors. But its piecemeal approach, aimed at slaking demand for trade restraints, might instead have increased it.

title: Fine Is Reported
description: MARK GASTINEAU, the Jets' defensive end, has reportedly been fined for a flagrant hit on Bernie Kosar, the Cleveland Browns' quarterback, in the American Conference divisional playoffs two weeks ago.

title: CONSTANT CALENDAR UNFAIR TO SABBATHS
description: To the Editor:

title: RECALLING THE DAYS OF 'WE SHALL OVERCOME'
description: Chapters of American history most regretted by Americans have sometimes been those for which people in the rest of the world have most admired the United States. Watergate comes to mind. What many in the international community remember most about Watergate is not the criminality of a President but the effective working of the civil machinery that removed him from office - the way in which the will of the people truly prevailed.

title: POSTINGS: Coming Attraction; Builders' Show
description: For nine days, starting next Saturday, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center will the scene of what is being confidently billed as the first annual Greater New York Home and Apartment Show. The show, sponsored by the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, the trade association of the real-estate industry, will run through Sunday, Feb. 1.

title: MILK REGULATIONS ARE A HOT POTATO
description: JUDGING by the grateful praise it elicited from consumer groups and local politicians, a Federal court ruling 10 days ago allowing more competition in New York City's milk markets verged on divine deliverance.

title: HERE'S TO 200 YEARS OF MINORITY PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: BLAZING A NEW TRAIL IN WILDS OF NASSAU
description: A SECOND greenbelt trail across Long Island has been mapped and blazed for 22 miles from Massapequa to Cold Spring Harbor. It passes through parks and preserves and rights of way acquired for a railroad and road that were never built, offering an intimate look at not only the Island's nature but also its historic roots.

title: Wendy E. Reiner To Wed Surgeon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules Reiner of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Ellen Reiner to Dr. Ross G. Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Stone of Pottsville, Pa., and Boynton Beach, Fla. A March wedding is planned.

title: RING AROUND THE KREMLIN
description: Forty years after he paid dearly for his faith in Communism, Ring Lardner Jr. concedes some disappointment but no regrets. Mr. Lardner, whose promising career as a screenwriter was aborted in 1947 when he was blacklisted after refusing to answer questions from the House Un-American Activities Committee, reflected on his long association with Communism while visiting Moscow as a tourist last week. ''I still think some form of socialism is a more rational way to organize society,'' he said. ''But I recognize it hasn't worked anywhere yet.''

title: Karin Morgenstern to Marry Scientist
description: Karin Dewing Morgenstern and Michael Louis Papp plan to be married in May. The future bride is the daughter of Dorothy Morgenstern Thomas of Princeton, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., who has announced their engagement, and the late Prof. Oskar Morgenstern. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Papp of Wrentham, Mass.

title: 'GOOD NEWS' AND A BULLY PULPIT
description: Touche Ross Video Tax Guide 1987 MasterVision. 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Corrections
description: Because of the operator's change of plans, an item last Sunday in the Travel Advisory column carried outdated information on the opening of Boardwalk and Baseball, an entertainment and sports complex in Florida. The opening has been postponed to April 4.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
NASSAU'S WATER NEEDS PROTECTION
description: LEAD: GOVERNMENT officials who met in Albany in mid-November said they expect to get $60 million for the Long Island region from the recently approved state environmental bond issue. But most of this may go to purchase thousands of acres of pine barrens in Suffolk County to protect that county's underground drinking water supply.

title: Weinberger Aide to Retire
description: Vice Adm. Donald S. Jones, the top military aide to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, will retire March 1 after more than 35 years of active service, the Defense Department said Friday. Admiral Jones, 58 years old, a native of Madison, Wis., has been Mr. Weinberger's military assistant since last spring. A replacement for Admiral Jones was not announced, but an official who requested anonymity said Mr. Weinberger would by select Maj. Gen. Gordon E. Fornell of the Air Force.

title: Maura Liptack Is Bride of Christopher McMahon
description: Maura Theresa Liptack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Liptack of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Joseph McMahon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Jordan McMahon of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Patrick Walsh and the Rev. James Beattie performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: AWARDS CITE INNOVATIONS IN AMPLIFIERS AND TUNERS
description: The audio industry spawns new equipment with the regularity of a brood hen hatching her chicks. Each new flock clamors for attention, and with so many products similar in concept and performance, it is often difficult to spot the standouts. In the competitive whirl, the Grands Prix awarded annually by Audio Video International, a widely known trade journal, are helpful in pinpointing items of unusual merit.

title: Betsy B. Phillips To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Betsy Bowman Phillips to Edward Safford Mandel has been announced by Melvin Burdette Phillips of Liberty, Ky., father of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Frank Mandel of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Historical Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAIR A DAY IN PORTUGAL
description: If you happen to be in Portugal on the first Sunday of the month, any month, stormy or sunny, the thing to do is to visit the country fair at Vila Nogueira de Azeitao, 21 miles south of Lisbon.

title: REAGAN PRESSES FOR ARMS REQUEST
description: President Reagan said today that the United States approached the current round of the arms talks with a ''sense of anticipation'' and asked Congress to support the Administration's military spending request.

title: NEW YORK'S HIGH COURT IS A COUMO PRODUCTION
description: New York State's Court of Appeals -now entirely the handiwork of Governor Cuomo - has begun to take a leading national role in the protection of individual liberties, according to legal observers.

title: SOONERS STOP NO.1 NEVADA-LAS VEGAS
description: Darryl Kennedy's basket with 12 seconds remaining carried Oklahoma to an 89-88 victory over top-ranked and previously unbeaten Nevada-Las Vegas today.

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: I can only say that a man by the name of Rich Gedman, the catcher of the Boston Red Sox for the last six seasons, recently turned down a three-year contract that would have guaranteed him $2.65 million. Is that asking for too much? I'd say that's not only asking for too much, I'd say that's something only an extremely greedy individual would do. JOHN COLE Paxton, Maine

title: WHEN STUDENTS ALSO HOLD JOBS
description: THOSE who track the efforts of the United States Department of Education to stem the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' characterizing American education may know that, under the department's aegis, a new report (completed by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching) has just been released. The foundation finds the undergraduate college a very troubled institution.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.;
M.I.T. Teams With a Builder
description: LEAD: HOPING to spur local redevelopment and capitalize on the scores of science-related businesses it and other local universities have spawned, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has embarked on a $250 million project involving development of a 2.5-million-square-foot mixed-use complex on 27 acres next to its campus.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: IT BEGAN IN A NEW YORK minute after a piece about geographical derogations, the use of place names as modifiers to sneer at a trait or an occupation. My colleague Russell Baker passed along a cryptic message - ''Larchmont lockjaw'' - which I took to mean the pronunciation affected by yuppies. I then passed it along to the Philadelphia lawyers who read this column as the speech affected by ''upper-class lowerclassmen returning to suburbia.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
OLD SAWS AND THE NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: LEAD: NEW technology is causing parent-child adages to become obsolete. For centuries, mankind has relied upon the wisdom of ancient philosophers. It used to be true that sons learned at their fathers' knees, children were seen and not heard and as the twig was bent so grew the tree.

title: EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ON HOLOCAUST URGED
description: THE Westchester Holocaust Memorial Committee is planning a $1 million ''living memorial'' to victims of Nazi atrocities, and county agreement is expected this month, members of the group said last week.

title: CLUES CLARIFYING SHIFTS IN BEIJING REMAIN ELUSIVE
description: China offered no further clues today to the forced resignation of Hu Yaobang as the Communist Party leader and the naming of Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang as his acting successor.

title: BEQUEST FOR THE HUNGRY
description: Marlene Manes, whose husband, Donald, left a rather large estate for a public employee, has agreed to share her inheritance with the city's elderly and sick, municipal officials announced last week. Mr. Manes, the Queens Borough President who committed suicide last year after being implicated in the municipal corruption scandal, left an estate of slightly more than $1 million, as much as $300,000 of which, investigators charged, came from bribes. In a deal under which the city pledged not to sue to recover the money, Mrs. Manes agreed to donate $301,000 to Citymeals on Wheels, which delivers free hot meals on weekends to about 7,000 aged or infirm New Yorkers. Lawyers for Mrs. Manes said the agreement should not ''be viewed as any indication that she acquiesces in the truth of the charges'' against her husband.

title: STATE U. SEEKS RISE IN CHIEF'S PAY
description: The trustees of the State University of New York say they will suspend their search for a new chancellor unless the Legislature gives them the power to raise executive salaries.

title: NEW MEXICANS SEEKING HEALTH THROUGH THINNESS
description: New Mexicans are trying to shed as much as 200,000 pounds by the end of March as part of the nation's first statewide campaign to reduce heart disease through health education.

title: Jonathan R. Eiseman Weds Miss Seigerman
description: The marriage of Robin Judith Seigerman, a third-year law student at New York University, and Jonathan Richard Eiseman, a lawyer in the real estate department of the New York law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, took place last evening at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. Rabbi Isaac Swift officiated.

title: MUSIC: FOSS AND 'MODERNS'
description: LUKAS FOSS, that indefatigable champion of contemporary and American music, brought his customary zeal and a widely diversified program to Cooper Union Friday night as part of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's ''Meet the Moderns'' chamber series.

title: THE STATE OF THE UNION
description: On the 27th of January, 1987, President Reagan will deliver his seventh annual State of the Union address to the 100th Congress of the United States at the beginning of the 200th anniversary of the Federal Constitution.

title: POOR SUBSTITUTIONS BLAMED IN NETS' LOSS
description: The game seemed to turn during one forgettable stretch in the second period. In the aftermath, Coach Dave Wohl would blame himself for a series of ill-advised substitutions, but it was clearly just another example of what ails the Nets these days: When a lead dissolves, they are simply unable to grab it back.

title: Master Of the Sentimental Sell
description: Thirty years in the advertising business, telling my friends, neighbors and students that good advertising should never lie, and Hal Riney - one of the best in the business - blows it for everybody by freely admitting that he is an emotional and verbal liar and manipulator.

title: LIFE'S BEST THINGS ARE PRICELESS
description: ONCE upon a time, when I still believed that mothers had the duty and power to grant wishes, I promised my last child, then an 11-year-old girl who dreamed of owning a horse, that if we ever moved away I would buy her one. It was an easy promise, one I thought I would never have to keep. Friends who passed down to her their own daughters' castoff velvet riding caps, hoof-pickers, horsefly spray and crops assured me that Kate, too, would automatically trot out of the horsey stage when she was 13 or so. Besides, I could not imagine moving from the city where we had lived forever.

title: Cold Disrupts European Sports
description: Record cold weather has disrupted sports schedules in Europe, with soccer, the national sport in Britain, severely hit. Scores of English and Scottish League matches were postponed today because of the sub-zero temperatures.

title: ISADORA'S SCARF AND OTHER SECRETS
description: SPHINX By D. M. Thomas. 248 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title:
FOCUS: Rights-of-Way;
New Uses For Old Rail Lines
description: LEAD: THE nation's once-mighty rail-transportation network is making a comeback, but there is no return to trains. Rather, abandoned rail corridors are becoming recreation trails.

title:
DINING OUT;
LISTINGS ON THE PASTA DIRECTORY
description: LEAD: WHEN Mimmo and Toni Vassallo opened Regina, a stylishly casual cafe-restaurant in Montvale seven months ago, it seemed like a breath of fresh air. Word of Northern Italian cooking by a chef from Milan and a pasta directory listing no fewer than 99 preparations drew us to the attractive dining room tucked at the end of a shopping strip in northern Bergen

title: LOGRANDE FORGES TIE TO SHOREHAM FOES
description: LEAD: WHEN Acting Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande named a former Federal official last week to coordinate county efforts to block the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, he forged a bond with the County Legislature that brought Suffolk opposition to the nuclear plant to a new peak.

title: Diane Schwebel, Perry Freedman, Lawyers, Marry
description: Diane Schwebel, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Perry Dean Freedman, a lawyer in private practice in New York, were married yesterday at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony.

title: Turning Your PC Into a Crystal Ball
description: THE busiest booth in the convention exhibit hall was the one where Ruth Polak was handing out invitations to the first annual meeting of FAUG.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section accompanying an article about a playwriting contest incorrectly identified two of the judges, Ruis Woertendyke and Norman Kline, whose names were transposed.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: MOST OF U.S. WILL HONOR DR. KING, BUT SOME STILL DISPUTE THE HOLIDAY
description: One year after the civil rights struggles by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were officially recognized by the Federal Government with a holiday in his honor, some of the controversy that surrounded efforts to win that recognition continues.

title: PRESERVING AMERICA'S PAST
description: Scarcely a major city in the United States has not been touched, or even transformed, by preservation. From coast to coast, the impulse to save old buildings - from the gabled house on Main Street, to the Beaux-Arts railroad terminal - has helped to preserve the past, and provide an anchor for our collective memory. Americans' increasing fascination with their history is resuscitating dying cities and renewing interest and pride among residents and visitors. Perhaps most significant has been the notion of adaptive re-use: the adaptation of older buildings to uses other than those for which they were originally intended. The key to the success of this revitalization is a recognition of those buildings or streets that are, or once were, special - whether for architectural, historical or cultural reasons. In 1968, the old Ghirardelli Chocolate factory buildings in San Francisco were reborn as a vital, inviting complex of shops, restaurants, spacious courtyards and interiors, while still retaining the character and integrity of the original architecture.

title: Leigh F. Watkins To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Leigh Foster Watkins to Brent Michael Taylor has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Frank M. Watkins of Royal Oak, Md., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith I. A. Taylor of Wellington and Otaki, New Zealand. A June wedding is planned.

title: ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
description: Yes, baseball players are paid too much money. These players should put some money away so they don't have to be so greedy.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: SORTING OUT THE TRADE PROBLEM;
Business Holds Its Own as America Slips
description: LEAD: FOR most of the last 35 years or so, the United States share in world export markets for manufactured products has been falling, and imports have taken larger and larger shares of United States markets. As the decline in the trade balance accelerated, so too did the debate about its causes. But most analyses miss an important distinction between the export performance of American companies - including all their worldwide operations - and that of the operations within the geographical boundaries of the United States.

title: Venetian Lace
description: To the Editor: I read with much interest Anne Marshall Zwack's article ''Splendor of a Fading Art'' (Travel, Dec. 14). The descriptions of Jesurum's museum and shop brought back wonderful memories. In October 1980 while on vacation in Italy, I visited Jesurum with a specific task in mind. My oldest daughter was to be married the following August and was going to wear my wedding gown, which was then 30 years old. Since I had borrowed a wedding veil and no longer had it, I was determined to find a beautiful piece of lace for my daughter to wear.

title: STUDENTS FOR NUCLEAR FREEZE GIVE CAMPAIGN NEW TWIST
description: LEAD: THE 30-second videotaped commercial opens with two young barefoot women carrying a sign that says ''Make love, not war.'' Playing in the background is ''Mellow Yellow,'' a hit song of the late 1960's.

title: INTEGRITY? YOU CAN GET IT RETAIL
description: RATING AMERICA'S CORPORATE CONSCIENCE A Provocative Guide to the Companies Behind the Products You Buy Every Day. By Steven D. Lydenberg, Alice Tepper Marlin, Sean O'Brien Strub and the Council on Economic Priorities. 499 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: YOUNG MAN WITH A FLUEGELHORN
description: THE GREAT FAKE BOOK By Vance Bourjaily. 305 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: Poison Pills
description: To the Editor: Peter Clafman and Richard Schlefer do not trust incumbent management of corporate bureaucracies to serve shareholder interest in wealth maximization; Martin Lipton distrusts institutional investors and deal makers to serve the long-term interests of the corporation as a socioeconomic institution (''The Fuss Over Poison Pills,'' Forum, Dec. 14).

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE FOURTH ANGEL. By Robin Hunter. (Arbor House, $16.95.) If governments won't retaliate against terrorists, thinks Simon Quarry, then he swears he will. Quarry is a well-off, well-connected British publisher, whose wife and children are killed when terrorists set fire to an El Al jetliner on the tarmac at Athens airport.

title: BANFF'S RICH VEIN OF NATIVE CRAFTS
description: Banff, the resort in the Canadian Rockies long acclaimed for its natural beauty, has over the last decade or so emerged as a center for native arts and crafts. Shops emphasizing Canadiana, from Eskimo carvings to bronze sculptures, from paintings to jewelry incorporating native stones, have been profilerating along Banff Avenue, in the arcades off it and in the cavernous regions of the Banff Springs Hotel, which alone boasts more than 30 boutiques.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CABINS AND KINGS

title: 151 NEW YORKERS GET SCIENCE HONOR
description: The Westinghouse Science Talent Search last week announced the names of its 300 national semifinalists, and more than a third were from New York City.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hampton $177,000 13 Conford Circle 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; patio, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,675. Lawrenceville $197,000 38 Morton Court 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old condominium town house; central A/C, dining room, 2-car attached garage, maintenance $205; taxes $3,600. title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A.&P.; ARCHIVES
description: LEAD: BUSINESS students and anyone with an interest in the history of a major American corporation can now leaf through the A.&P.; Business Archives in the Learning Resource Center at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. The archives, a collection of business records, newspaper and magazine articles and letters, were amassed by the Hartford Family

title: COURTS WORKING ON CIVIL BACKLOG
description: LEAD: A STATE SUPREME COURT experiment in Bergen County to speed the handling of civil suits is yielding promising results and could be in operation statewide next year, according to court officials.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
COMMON MERGANSER
description: LEAD: Mergus merganser Size: To 27 inches.

title: Honors and Merit
description: Sentiment counts for little when the Federal budget ax is swinging but power is still power. That's quite evident in two scholarly footnotes to President Reagan's plan for fiscal 1988.

title: COMMEMORATIONS SET FOR KING BIRTHDAY
description: ALTHOUGH the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born on Jan. 15 - he would have been 58 years old last Thursday - the Federal holiday is tomorrow and celebrations have been planned throughout the country, including New Jersey.

title: LONDON POLICE PLAN TO USE EVEN FEWER GUNS
description: The London police, who have traditionally disdained the widespread use of firearms to combat criminals, have announced that they will further reduce the number of officers authorized to use guns.

title: IN KANSAS CITY, TO BE NUDE IS LEWD
description: Controversy, a columnist here warned the other day, is threatening to ''rend the fabric'' of Kansas City civility and ''divide the citizenry.''

title: PARTIES TO HELP OTHERS
description: Continuing a Cause Jan. 26 - Sports will be the theme at the seventh annual Thurman Munson Award Dinner - an event to aid the mentally retarded - at the Grand Hyatt Hotel starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Before his death in a plane crash in 1979, the Yankee catcher had been active in promoting programs for the retarded. Sports figures, including Arthur Ashe, Henry Brown, Lou Piniella and Gary Carter, are expected to attend the benefit to continue his work for the New York City chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children. Tickets, $275, from 212-254-8203, extension 242. Sweet 16 for Pilobolus Jan. 27 - It started almost as a lark 16 years ago when two former Dartmouth College students, Moses Pendleton and Jonathan Wolken, formed a dance company called Pilobolus, which has since earned a solid niche as one of the nation's more evocative modern-dance companies. The 11-member Connecticut-based troupe will be performing 16 works, including five premieres, in its season at the Joyce Theater on Eighth Avenue, near 19th Street, through Feb. 22. The 7:30 opening-night performance of ''Carmina Burana, Side Two,'' will be followed by a dinner-dance benefit at Twenty-Twenty, 20 West 20th Street. Tickets, $75 for the performance alone and $175 for the performance and dinner-dance, from 203-868-0538. Benefit for a Theater Jan. 29 - It was 1969 and the five performers, who were internationally known musicians in their 20's, were not yet the stars they eventually became. In a one-hour film, Itzhak Perlman, Pinchas Zukerman, Daniel Barenboim, Zubin Mehta (double bass) and Jacqueline du Pre, whose career was cut short by multiple sclerosis two years after the film was made, are shown rehearsing and performing Shubert's ''Trout'' quintet. It will be shown at a benefit for Symphony Space, a nonprofit community-sponsored center for performing arts on Broadway, at 95th Street. After wine and hors d'oeuvres at 7:30 P.M., Isaac Stern will introduce the movie. Viennese desserts will be served afterward. Tickets, $100, from 212-864-1414. Welcoming a New Year Jan. 29 - To celebrate the Chinese New Year (4685), the Year of the Rabbit, and to support the activities of the China Institute Women's Association, a banquet will be held at the Peking Duck restaurant, 100 Park Avenue, at 40th Street. The Institute operates a school of Chinese studies in language, history, art and current affairs. It provides orientation and hospitality for Chinese students and scholars attending American schools. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. followed by dinner and entertainment of Chinese dance and traditional and modern songs. Tickets, $60, from 212-744-8181. Waldorf Opera Ball Jan. 30 - The 32d annual Viennese Opera Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria will benefit the Margit Bokor-Norman Scott Memorial Fund for Cancer Research at Columbia University. The fund was named after two opera singers who died of cancer. Research supported by the fund has resulted in major advances in the past year, including the identification of genes involved in causing cancer, according to researchers at Columbia. The white-tie ball gets under way with 8 P.M. cocktails followed by performances by New York City Opera singers. The evening continues with dinner, dancing and performances by Metropolitan Opera singers. Tickets, $175 or $325 per couple, from 212-819-0158. In Boston Jan. 30 - The annual Consuls' Ball to benefit CARE will be held at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston starting with 7:30 P.M. cocktails. Dinner and dancing follow. Tickets for the black-tie event, $100, from Ann Sargent at 617-267-5300. Granting Wishes Feb. 1 - Whether it's a new bicycle or a visit with Michael Jackson, a horse or a family vacation in Hawaii, a stint as a disk jockey or an appearance on a television show, the Starlight Foundation seeks to grant the wishes of chronically and terminally ill youngsters. A black-tie benefit for the four-year-old charity, which has granted about 1,000 such wishes, starts with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. at the Grand Hyatt hotel. Dinner and an auction of vacations will follow. Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d will be honored and Marvin Hamlisch, Robert Klein and Maureen McGovern are scheduled to entertain. Tickets, $250, from 212-221-0148.

title: KEAN AIMS FOR WELFARE REFORM THAT WORKS
description: IF the Legislature goes along, as expected, New Jersey may soon be the first state in the nation to require every able-bodied welfare recipient, including mothers of young children, to work or attend school. Governor Kean, announcing the new direction for the state's $1 billion welfare system last week in his State of the State message, called it ''a bold and reasonable plan.''

title: THE SCHOOLTEACHER AND THE SINGING COWBOY
description: KEEPING WARM By Mary Gardner. 262 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: ISLAND LIVING, ENGLISH STYLE
description: Barbados, the easternmost island of the Caribbean, combines the beauty of a rocky Atlantic shore on the east and sandy Caribbean beaches on the west. Between lie miles and miles of sugar plantations with winding roads running like narrow corridors through fields of towering sugar cane. Though Barbados only gained independence from Britain in 1966, the lower house of its Parliament, the House of Assembly, has been active since 1639. The political entities of the island are its 11 parishes, each with an exquisite old Anglican church. For along with political stability and an excellent educational system, Barbadians possess an important architectural heritage as old as its Parliament and politics.

title: BESS MYERSON STEPS ASIDE
description: Her former campaign manager, David Garth, described Bess Myerson as a fighter, ''not the sort of person who pulls the bedspread over her head.'' But last week the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner quietly began a leave of absence pending an inquiry into issues stemming from a Federal grand jury investigation of a contractor who has been her regular companion for several years.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES THAT COLOR THE WINTER LANDSCAPE
description: LEAD: ONE has but to travel through the countryside of the Northeast to discover the full potential that exists for winter color in the landscape. To be certain, the colors are for the most part muted when compared with those of spring, summer and fall, however, the subtle differences from species to species provide a panoramic contrast across the fields, meadows and mountainsides.

title: Does Reagan Have Time To Strike a Soviet Deal?
description: WITH arms control getting attention in Congress and Geneva last week and a Russian-orchestrated cease-fire attempt under way in Afghanistan, Reagan Administration officials were calculating that they may have only about nine months left to achieve significant agreements with the Soviet Union. After that, veteran officials say, the politics of the 1988 Presidential campaign are likely to take over.

title: Foster Elated
description: GREG FOSTER was jubilant, with good reason. It was one of the rare times in Foster's track career that he had beaten Renaldo Nehemiah in the hurdles. He was so happy, Foster said afterward, that he didn't notice when Nehemiah tried to congratulate him after Foster's world-indoor record clocking of 7.36 seconds in the 60-meter hurdles Friday night at the Sunkist Invitational meet in Los Angeles.

title: SOVIET REPORTS ECONOMIC UPTURN
description: The year-end Soviet economic report, made public today, showed a positive trend, but said serious deficiencies remained.

title: TALKING: Insurance; Covering Mortgage Payments
description: WHEN a borrower takes out a mortgage loan, the lender customarily offers insurance to cover payment of the outstanding balance in the event of the borrower's death or disability.

title: HAYES SAYS PHILS ARE SET TO CHALLENGE
description: IF the Philadelphia Phillies want a precedent, they need look back only three years. The Kansas City Royals finished the 1983 season in second place, 20 games behind the Chicago White Sox, then won the American League West championship the following season.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE JUROR AND THE GENERAL. By M. Patricia Roth. (Morrow, $17.95.) When Gen. William Westmoreland dropped his libel suit against CBS, he pretty well ruined M. Patricia Roth's book. ''The Juror and the General'' is Mrs. Roth's account of what it was like to be on the jury in that trial, in which General Westmoreland claimed that he had been libeled by allegations, made in the 1982 documentary ''The Uncounted Enemy,'' that the United States military command in Vietnam had altered estimates of the enemy's troop strength for political reasons.

title: Shopping Malls
description: To the Editor: Shopping malls are of interest to sociologists for reasons other than esthetics and traffic patterns. ''Why Everyone Goes to the Mall'' (Dec. 21) refers to malls as the new town squares and as rigidly programmed selling machines, without ever pondering the implications of this conjunction.

title: CONDERT: KRONOS QUARTET AT WEILL HALL
description: THE Kronos Quartet, which seems poised to unseat a lot of assumptions about what can be expected of audience response, played a program of contemporary music to an enthusiastic standing-room-only crowd Friday night at Weill Recital Hall.

title: FENWICK IS GIVEN AWARD
description: LEAD: MILLICENT FENWICK, the 76-year-old former Congresswoman from Bernardsville and United States envoy to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome, has received the state's first Governor's Gold Medal Award.

title: LOVINGLY, A WOMAN DONATES HER BONUS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: A gift of $1,000 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases from Martha V. Smith of East Williston, L.I., came with a note saying ''I hope my Christmas bonus will be shared by those who need it most,'' and it was signed ''Love.''

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS LIQUOR PRICE LAW
description: In striking down a New York law last week, the United States Supreme Court may have made liquor less expensive in the state, but some in the industry said small retailers would pay a heavy price as a result.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Hamlin, Officer of a Bank
description: Announcement has been made by Helene M. Hamlin of Haddonfield, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter Dianne Marie Hamlin to William Kent Haydock Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Kent Haydock of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: DANCE: KATHRYN POSIN
description: THE Joyce Theater gave a performance Friday night, but the choreographer of honor seemed conspicuously absent. The program by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company, the closing group in the Joyce Sampler Series, proceeded from one trivial or poorly thought-out dance to another, performed with an understandable lack of conviction. What has happened to the Kathryn Posin we came to know in the 1970's, whose work was full of energetic life if not of particularly well-realized ideas?

title: TAKING IT LYING DOWN
description: THE WAR AGAINST THE PRESS Politics, Pressure and Intimidation in the 80's. By Peter Stoler. 226 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95.

title: A BUSINESS GROWS TO FIT OTHER WORKERS
description: THE big trick for most small businesses is knowing when to change direction, something Robert O'Brien, president of the Workingman's Closet in New Rochelle, is familiar with. Starting with an industrial laundry and uniform rental company as a nucleus, Mr. O'Brien added the Workingman's Closet, a direct factory sales division, six years ago. Now, with 25,000 individual items in stock, Mr. O'Brien says the Workingman's Closet has the largest inventory of new and reclaimed work clothes in Westchester.

title: A Very Stylish Processor of Words
description: THE software selection available for word processing is probably greater than that for any other form of computing. There are packages like Words & Figures, limited in text-handling capabilities but specifically fashioned for spreadsheet users.

title: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: THE DOW IN PERSPECTIVE  TRACING THE UPS AND DOWNS OF THE 20th CENTURY THROUGH THE EYES OF WALL STREET; Despite Quirks, the Dow Stands for the Market
description: PERHAPS no animal is possessed of a shorter memory than the bull who lives on Wall Street. So it seems useful amid the euphoria over the breaching of the 2,000 barrier on the Dow - and the buying spree of last week - to step back and put a historical perspective on the index's recent climb.

Mineola $122,000 101 Clinton Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old co-op dining room, eat-in kitchen, walk to station; monthly maintenance $600. Wilton, Conn. $685,000 224 Nod Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1810 colonial; moldings, swimming pool, 2 acres; taxes $4,117.

title: The Historical Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATION ON SCHOOL SALES IS FOUGHT
description: LEAD: A proposal to build housing for the elderly at the site of the recently closed Brookside Junior High School in North Merrick is at the center of a growing dispute in the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District.

title: Q&A
description: Multiple Visas Question:I am planning a lengthy trip to 10 or 12 Asian countries. Is there a company that will obtain all necessary visas for me? What will it cost, how much time is needed and how precisely must one predict the dates for visiting a country? - R. B., Wickliffe, Ohio Answer:Several companies in New York - where most countries have consulates - specialize in obtaining visas, and there are similar services in Washington, on the West Coast and some other cities. Much of their work is done for business travelers and they also obtain visas for travel agents acting for clients.

title: A May Wedding For Gigi Simeone
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Simeone of Somerset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Angela Simeone, to Ben Yagoda, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Yagoda of New Rochelle, N.Y. A May 17 wedding is planned.

title: COURT UPHOLDS JOB PROTECTION FOR PREGNANT WOMEN
description: California law requires employers to grant as much as four months of unpaid leave to women when childbearing makes them physically unable to work.

title:
DANCE;
BLIND STUDENTS FIND A WORLD OF DANCE
description: LEAD: WHEN Michael Todd gets ready to do a tour en l'air, he thinks about turning from 6 o'clock to 12. His dance lexicon includes demi and grand plies, lunges, quarter- and half-turns and pointing and flexing his feet.

title: ENCOURAGING 'DREAMERS' WITH GRANTS
description: ON May 16, Dr. Carolyn Falk will place a top over the billiard table in her basement recreation room in Middlebury, converting it into an appropriate setting for the annual meeting of the Falk Foundation of Excellence. The foundation, which Dr. Falk started ''to encourage dreamers,'' she said, has given monetary awards to artists, schoolchildren and even a skier, and this year's applicants promise to be no less exciting, she said.

title: AMID LEAN TIMES, A CLINIC SURVIVES TO SERVE THE POOR
description: Born in the plenty of the Great Society and come of age in the stringent days of the Reagan Administration, a Bronx family-care clinic yesterday celebrated its 20th anniversary.

title: RAVE REVIEWS AS JOHNSON REVISES HIS MAGIC SHOW
description: Wild and crazy. Earvin Johnson liked the sound of the words. They still fit. They still made him laugh aloud when he said them, because even now - in the eighth winter of his wondrous professional career - he remains an unpredictable sort, an artist with a touch of magic. The thought was appropriate.

title: FASTER THAN SOUND SWIFTEST AT HIALEAH
description: Faster Than Sound, making his first start since August, began his 3-year-old campaign with a flourish by holding off Cryptoclearance in the final yards to win the $59,000 Bahamas Stakes today at Hialeah Park.

title: Ellis Larkins on Piano With Pop Standards
description: Although Ellis Larkins first played piano in New York in 1942 when he was 19 years old, and has been here off and on ever since, he is currently making both a debut and a comeback of sorts.

title: Holiday Today
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed today in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules:

title: LIBERALS PEEK OUT AND SEE SPRING
description: At Road Runner speed, Senator Gordon J. Humphrey raced into the hearing of the Labor and Human Resources Committee and skidded into his seat.

title: CONCERT: BBC SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: READING about the BBC Symphony's adventurous repertory yesterday and then perusing its program at Avery Fisher Hall the same afternoon, one could not avoid a certain sense of missed opportunities. An ensemble superbly equipped to let us know what is going on in new British orchestral music - music our own orchestras cannot be expected to prepare or present on a comparable scale - came to Lincoln Center with a brief, bright Walton overture (''Portsmouth Point,'' composed in 1925), a Shostakovich symphony (No. 11) that is well known even if it's not played every other week, and the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto.

title: Bally Signs Deal to Buy Golden Nugget Casino
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Golden Nugget Casino/Hotel in Atlantic City from Golden Nugget Inc. in a deal valued at $439 million.

title: Adele Aron Schwarz Wed To Dr. Bertram Greenspun
description: Adele Aron Schwarz, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Aron of Philadelphia, and Dr. Bertram Greenspun, son of Mollie Greenspun of Cherry Hill, N.J., and the late Frank Greenspun, were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Haddon Heights, N.J. Rabbi Albert Lewis performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Mordechai Fuchs.

title: UNION RIVALRIES COMPLICATING TALKS
description: Negotiating labor contracts is never easy for agencies on which the public depends, but in the case of 11 unions that were unable to reach agreement with the Long Island Rail Road this weekend, interunion rivalries and a contentious history complicate the task.

title: Atom Plant Is Unable to Say What Happened to Uranium
description: Officials at the idled Browns Ferry nuclear power plant have been unable to account for 27 milligrams of uranium in a recent inventory, the second such loss since October, according to a plant spokesman.

title: DISTURBANCE ERUPTS AT DETENTION CENTER AFTER 2 INMATES FLEE
description: The police, firefighters and immigration officials quelled what one official called ''a small disturbance'' yesterday involving Cuban inmates at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in lower Manhattan, where two prisoners had escaped a day earlier.

title: Advertising; Bonnier Group Buys All of Cook's Magazine
description: Cook's magazine, which has catered to the epicurean market since 1979, has been acquired - lock, stock and barrel - by Sweden's Bonnier Magazine Group, which has sometimes been content with half a loaf.

title: INSIDE
description: Extradition for Lebanese The Justice Department said it would not seek the death penalty for a Lebanese hijacking suspect, clearing the way for his extradition. Page A5. Nicaraguan Cardinal Beaten The Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua was beaten, verbally abused and robbed over the weekend in Miami, relatives said. Page A3. Dollar Tumbles in Tokyo Continuing its tumultuous slide, the dollar fell through a key psychological barrier - trading under 150 yen in Tokyo. Page D1.

title: ARTHUR MILLER'S 'ALL MY SONS,' ON 13
description: PUBLIC television's ''American Playhouse'' begins its sixth season tonight, on WNET at 9, with a good, solid revival of Arthur Miller's ''All My Sons.'' In its original 1947 production, which ran for just under a year, the play was staged by Elia Kazan and starred Ed Begley and Arthur Kennedy as the father and son. This TV production has been directed by Jack O'Brien, artistic director of San Diego's Old Globe Theater since 1981, and the cast is headed by James Whitmore and Aidan Quinn.

title: Stronger Radio Station Set Up by the Contras
description: A new clandestine radio station operated by Nicaraguan rebels can be picked up by AM radios here and elsewhere in Nicaragua.

title: MUSICIANS IN BALLET ORCHESTRA MAKE A DONATION TO NEEDIEST
description: Among the contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are musicians of the New York City Ballet Orchestra at the State Theater in Lincoln Center, who gave $430.

title: FLYERS SURPRISED BY ISLANDERS, 3-1
description: The Islanders had talked about taking the giant step from being an also-ran to a contender, and they knew they needed to dominate the Flyers in order to achieve that.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: Although Governor Cuomo will get some money for his recently-appointed state Commission on Ethics in Government, it may not be the $5 million he has requested, according to a state official.

title: GIANTS ARE FIRST TO ENTER SPOTLIGHT
description: Super Bowl week began at 3:09 P.M. today, Pacific time, when the Giants walked off the chartered plane that brought them to Long Beach Airport from Newark.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 19, 1987: MONDAY Central & South West PS Group Inc Eastern Utilities Assoc Republic Gypsum Jorgensen (Earle M) TUESDAY Honeywell Inc Scott Paper Jostens Inc Security Pacific Corp Loews Corp Southern Ind G & E Parker Drilling WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Hillenbrand Indus Barnett Banks of Fl Mexico Fund Clorox Co NCR Corp Columbia Gas System Norstar Bancorp Dow Jones & Co Republic New York Corp Dun & Bradstreet St Joseph Lt & Pwr GenCorp Inc Zero Corp THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Mead Corp Comdisco Inc Morgan Stanley Group Empire District Elec Pfizer Inc First Wisconsin Corp Potlatch Corp Handy & Harman Potomac Elec Hexcel Corp Smucker Co Iowa-Ill G & E Triangle Indus Lee Enterprises FRIDAY Archer-Daniels-Midland Harland Co Central Louisiana Elec Monsanto Co Florida Steel SATURDAY AVEMCO Corp Wackenhut Corp SUNDAY Williams Co

title: Mexico Gives OPEC a Symbolic Lift
description: Mexico will support the effort of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce world crude oil surpluses and force oil prices higher by cutting its own oil exports. The cuts seem to be largely symbolic, however, since the Government cannot afford serious reductions in foreign earnings.

title: EISENHOWER'S PERSONNEL CHIEF
description: Philip Young, the chairman of the Civil Service Commission in the first Eisenhower Administration and a former dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, died of a heart attack Thursday at Arlington Hospital in Virginia.

title: NO JIM BROWN AROUND HERE
description: THE T-shirts are already in place at the airport souvenir shops, blue and red for the Giants, orange for the Broncos.

title: We Must Pay the Price for Space Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Cole Married To Carol Ann Hartley
description: The marriage of Carol Ann Hartley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Hartley of Fredonia, N.Y., to Thomas Patrick Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Desmond Cole of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Strathmore Hall Arts Center in Rockville, Md. The Rev. Caroline S. Pyle, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising; Commercials' Cost Cut
description: The in-house television commercial production facility established last April by the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, has cut the average cost of commercials by 10 percent or $13,400, according to the agency. The unit is called Starlight Productions.

title: JOHN J. GUERIN, 56, CHIEF OF OPERATIONS FOR TIMES AD SALES
description: John J. Guerin, the director of advertising sales operations for The New York Times, died Saturday after he suffered a heart attack while playing tennis in Freeport, L.I. He was 56 years old and lived in Bellmore, L.I.

title: NEW TALKS TODAY; RIDERS ARE BRACED
description: Nassau and Suffolk commuters today put together car pools, made hotel reservations and imposed on friends and relatives with apartments in Manhattan as they mapped strategies for getting to work with the nation's busiest commuter railroad paralyzed by a strike.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Let's say the Yankees and Red Sox are playing in an inning with none out, a Boston player perched on each base and Wade Boggs at bat. On a 3-2 pitch, all three runners begin advancing, confident that Boggs will make contact and most likely hit the ball on the ground. Instead, Boggs laces a low liner past the pitcher's mound that strikes the umpire standing behind the mound and ricochets off his left shoe to Willie Randolph, the second baseman, who catches the ball before it hits the ground. If Randolph tags the runner going from first to second, then speeds over to second and touches the base before that runner gets back, is it an unassisted triple play?

title: SERMONS CELEBRATE DR. KING
description: The words, the deeds and the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were remembered yesterday in religious services throughout New York City and the region.

title: ALCOHOL AND DRUG ABUSE SEEN AS A KEY ISSUE IN RAILROAD SAFETY
description: Alcohol or drugs have figured in many of the major railroad accidents in recent years, government and industry officials say.

title: Keep an Eye on the Parole Board
