description: New York's highest court rules, correctly, that the state Board of Parole cannot be sued for damages by the victims of crimes committed by parolees. Last year an appellate court in Manhattan, apparently distressed by the board's refusal to explain its release decisions, held board members civilly liable if the victim could show a failure to follow state law and regulations.

title: TYING WAY TO FAME
description: IF the years have picked his dreams of glory bare, the ageing angler can gain some sustenance from the knowledge that with a lot of luck, savvy and dexterity he could achieve a small measure of immortality by creating a fishing fly that is so effective it will be treasured by his kind 100 years hence.

title: BankAmerica Meeting Shift
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said Friday that its board would meet Wednesday and Thursday, rather than on Feb. 1-2 as regularly scheduled. Analysts said they expected the bank to disclose the terms of a proposed stock offering at that time.

title: In the Giant's Grip
description: The peasant and commercial farmers of Zimbabwe, both highly successful in recent years, have piled up a big stock of white maize, a milled corn much in demand internationally. But for export it would now have to go by rail to Durban, the South African port 1,300 miles from here - and that would take $50 of the sale price of $80 a ton.

title: Many at Heublein Surprised by Sale
description: There were rumors last week around the headquarters of Heublein Inc. in Farmington, Conn., that something was afoot, but the announcement that RJR Nabisco was selling Heublein to Grand Metropolitan surprised many employees.

title: PAVIN IS WINNER IN HOPE TOURNEY
description: Corey Pavin rolled in an 18-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to win the 28th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by a shot over Bernhard Langer and end a grueling, five-hour-plus duel between these two close friends.

title: Washington Watch; A Banking Bill Rush
description: The rush has already begun in Congress to pass major banking bills. Lobbyists say they cannot remember when the chairmen of the two banking committees, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, have worked so feverishly to pass early legislation.

title: NEW TALKS TODAY; BUS RUNS PLANNED
description: Workers walked off their jobs early yesterday at the Long Island Rail Road, shutting down the nation's busiest commuter line.

title: AND NOW...CIRCUS MAXIMUS
description: BETWEEN phone calls last week, George Young was munching on a turkey sandwich in his Giants Stadium office when Bill Parcells appeared in the doorway.

title: U.S. WILL NOT SEEK DEATH IN HIJACKING
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not seek the death penalty for a Lebanese accused of hijacking an American jet in 1985.

title: DANCE: HISTORICAL REVUE
description: ''TIME marches on,'' the saying goes. But on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, the years danced by as Dance Through Time, a San Francisco company directed by Carol Teten, presented ''Dancing the 20th Century,'' an anthology of popular dances that have flourished in our century.

title: Reagan's Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MANSON IN HIS OWN WORDS. As Told to Nuel Emmons. Illustrated. 232 pages. Grove Press. $16.95.

title: CONCERT: THE CZECH PHILHARMONIC
description: PATRIOTISM in music can either inspire or debilitate, as Central and Eastern European history so eloquently demonstrates. Indeed, it has taken personalities of exceptional strength to break free of the reverence normally shown the traditional tunes and dances of these countries and make them interesting to outsiders. Less individual composers over the last century or two have created a body of music, particularly opera, that is mutually celebrated by those of a common heritage but that remains practically unknown to the foreigner.

title: WOBBLIES, AND SHOP, SLIP AWAY
description: Socialists the world over are mourning the death of a bookstore at the University of Michigan and the passing of an era when students sat-in as often as they went to class.

title: Magic and Muscle
description: Political analysts are forever looking for some secret factor that election winners have but losers do not. For 1986, they might examine membership in the Capitol Hill Squash and Nautilus Club. Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Representatives Les Aspin of Wisconsin, Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, Sander M. Levin of Michigan and Tom Tauke of Iowa - all members of the club -were candidates last fall, and all six won. No club member was defeated.

title: From Tackles to Tacks
description: A number of football players have seen their season come to an end in recent weeks, not just on the turbulent fields of the Meadowlands and Cleveland but also on the roiling waters off Australia. With only Stars & Stripes remaining among the United States' challengers, the eliminated America's Cup teams include several that had taken to adding crewmen with football experience, and for good reason.

title: Markets Open Today
description: Financial markets are open today, but all Government offices will be closed in observance of the holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Banks in New York and New Jersey have the option of remaining open, while all Connecticut banks will be closed.

title: U.N. NEGOTIATING FOR CHANGES IN ABC'S 'AMERIKA'
description: The United Nations has retained Theodore C. Sorensen, who served as special counsel to President John F. Kennedy, to negotiate with ABC for changes in its controversial new mini-series ''Amerika,'' United Nations officials disclosed today.

title: Washington Watch; High Salaries At Loan Banks
description: AMID the debate over excessive spending on business travel, meetings and entertainment by thrift industry regulators, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed figures last week indicating that the presidents of its regional home loan banks received salaries that were at least 40 percent above those received by the presidents of the much larger Federal Reserve Banks.

title: NEW LOW FOR DOLLAR IN TOKYO
description: Pushed downward in fast-paced speculative trading, the dollar breached a psychological barrier of 150 yen in early trading here today.

title: More Protests Are Promised
description: Five anti-apartheid groups said Friday that protests and shareholder actions would continue against most American companies that have ended their direct investment in South Africa. The groups said that the divestment plans announced by a number of large companies have done nothing to stop the flow of their products to South Africa.

title: STATE PLAN TO URGE CHANGES IN RENT-STABILIZATION LAW
description: A major housing study to be released this week by the Cuomo administration will advocate elimination of leases for rent-stabilized apartments, according to officials familiar with the document.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. BOSTON CELTICS, at Madison Square Garden, 1 P.M. (TV - MSG, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 12:50 P.M.) NETS VS. LOS ANGELES LAKERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 1 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 12:50 P.M.) ATLANTA HAWKS VS. PISTONS, at Pontiac, Mich., 8 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) ST. JOHN'S VS. PITTSBURGH, at Pittburgh, 7 P.M. (TV -ESPN, 7 P.M.) IOWA VS. PURDUE, at West Lafayette, Ind., 9 P.M. (TV -ESPN, 9 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. KINGS, at Inglewood, Calif., 10:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 10:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 10:20 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS AMERICA'S CUP: Challenger's final, if necessary, at Fremantle, Australia (TV -ESPN, 11 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 1 A.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.)

title: International Flavor To Highlights in Jazz
description: ''Jazz Is My Passport,'' presented by Highlights in Jazz, brought a multinational lineup of musicians to the Loeb Student Center at New York University on Thursday. Judging by the jam session-concert, American dominance of jazz is not in any danger.

title: NEW ORLEANS VOTES AGAINST A TAX RISE
description: Despite pervasive fears about crime here, New Orleans voters overwhelmingly defeated a proposed tax increase to finance more police and fire protection.

title: To Geneva, With Firmness
description: As we begin the seventh round of the nuclear and space talks in Geneva this month, we look with satisfaction on one conspicuous fact: this past year, the United States succeeded, for the first time in history, in drawing the Soviet Union into serious negotiations on proposals for deep reductions in offensive nuclear arms. The agenda in arms control is now, irreversibly, deep offensive weapons reductions. To remain effective in our negotiations with the Soviets, it is essential that we hold staunchly to the principles that have guided our efforts over the past six years.

title: KNICKS TAKE BACKWARD STEPS
description: The image was clear, the intention evident. Saturday night, amid the quiet aftermath of one of the Knicks' more discouraging defeats under their new coach, Gerald Henderson didn't talk basketball, but bricklaying.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLEThree in Guinness Case Had Nestle Connection
description: The two directors of Guinness P.L.C. who were asked to resign Wednesday in the widening investigation of the big British brewing company are a Washington lawyer and a powerful Swiss businessman who is chairman of Bank Leu and former chief executive of Nestle S.A.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS MAY PURSUE EFFORT IN WHITE COUNTY
description: Civil rights leaders meeting here today said they would pursue ''the gamut of legal activity'' in a desegregation campaign aimed at all-white Forsyth County, where violence broke out Saturday at a march for brotherhood.

title: Corrections
description: The Business and the Law column in Business Day on Tuesday, about the liability of corporate directors, referred incorrectly to a Delaware law.

title: CELTICS TOO TOUGH FOR ROCKETS AGAIN
description: The Houston Rockets played the Celtics today for the first time since they were beaten by Boston in their bid for the National Basketball Association title last June. They found that little had changed. Larry Bird, the most valuable player of the championship series, was there to score 32 points. The front line of Kevin McHale, Robert Parish and Bird was equally effective piling up points and dominating the boards, and the backcourt of Danny Ainge and Dennis Johnson played helping defense that virtually shut down Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon.

title: DANCE: 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ELLEN FISHER, Isabelle Marteau and Diane Martel, the choreographers represented on the program that Dance Chance offered Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, cleverly combined movement with scenic effects and contemporary music to achieve a true mixing of media. However, they were less persuasive in their presentation of ideas.

title: Soviet Dissident's Wife Leaves for Care in U.S.
description: Inna Kitrosskaya Meiman, the wife of the Soviet dissident Naum Meiman, left the Soviet Union today, three years after she first sought an exit visa to seek treatment for a malignant tumor on her neck.

title: A SUPER WAVE FROM 63,277
description: A sea of orange-and-blue-bedecked fans -63,277 of them - sent the Broncos off to the Super Bowl with a highly charged pep rally today.

title: Crime, Race, Prejudice, Fear
description: In the aftermath of the Howard Beach incident, we must restate certain truths about the evil of racism, the need for racial tolerance and the importance of the fight against discrimination. But we will not advance racial understanding unless we also attempt to come to grips with the fear of crime in general and white fear of black crime in particular.

title: An Awful Mystery
description: The death last week of Matt Hazeltine, the former all-pro linebacker, has focused attention on what researchers say could be either an important clue in a longtime medical puzzle, or merely a tantalizing statistical anomaly.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Housing Starts December Consumer Prices December Thursday Gross National Product 4th quarter Friday Personal Income December Consumer Spending December

title: GERMANS STAY IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: In West Germany, Government investigators are trying to determine if submarine blueprints were sold illegally to South Africa. BASF, the chemical giant, is under pressure to stop selling computers to Pretoria that some say are used for police work. Lufthansa is being criticized for providing service to destinations that other airlines, in withdrawing from South Africa, have abandoned.

title: Getting There: Travel During the Long Island Rail Road Strike
description: Bus Service Fares on regularly scheduled Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority buses service to and from Nassau: One-way fare to or from Jamaica and Flushing, $1.15. One-way fare to or from Far Rockaway, $1. Exact fare is required. One-dollar bills, coins, Transit Authority tokens accepted. 24-hour bus service will be provided on routes N4, N6, N20/21 Additional buses will be added to other routes to Queens. Rush-hour bus service from Nassau to Queens subways includes: N4 - Freeport Terminal to 168th Place and 88th Avenue, Jamaica (via Merrick Road) every 8 minutes. Connect with E or F subway at 169th Street, Jamaica. N6 - Hempstead Terminal to Jamaica (via Hempstead Turnpike) every 5 minutes. Connect with E or F subway at 169th Street or 179th Street, Jamaica. N20 - Hicksville L.I.R.R. Station to Flushing (via Northern Boulevard) every 30 minutes. Connect with No. 7 subway at Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, Flushing. N21 - Glen Cove City Hall to Flushing (via Northern Boulevard) every 30 minutes. (Routes N20 and N21 merge to provide more frequent service from Roslyn.) Connect with No. 7 subway at Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, Flushing. N22 - Hicksville Mid-Island Shopping Plaza to Jamaica (via Hillside Avenue) every 20 to 30 minutes. Connect with E or F subway at 169th Street or 179th Street, Jamaica. N22A - (Mornings) Carle Place (West) to Jamaica and (evenings) - Jamaica to Roosevelt Field (via Hillside Avenue). N22 and N22A merge to provide more frequent service from Williston Park to Jamaica (via Hillside Avenue) every 6 minutes. Connect with E or F subway at 169th Street, Jamaica. N24 - (Mornings) Mineola (west) to Jamaica and (evenings) Jamaica to Roosevelt Field (via Jericho Turnpike) every 15 minutes. Connect with E or F subway at 169th Street or 179th Street, Jamaica. N31/32 - Hempstead Terminal to Far Rockaway (via Broadway and Central Avenue) every 20 minutes. 10 minutes from Lynbrook. Connect with A subway at Beach 21st St. and Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway. N33 - Long Beach Terminal to Far Rockaway (via Beach Boulevard, West Park Street and Mott Avenue) every 30 minutes. Connect with A subway at Beach 21st Street and Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway. N70/71/72 - Hempstead Turnpike buses from the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale to the Hempstead Terminal. Transfers should be obtained for switch to N6 Jamaica-bound buses at Hempstead. (Buses stop outside Coliseum grounds along Hempstead Turnpike. Through fare to Jamaica with transfer is $1.15). Nassau Express Bus Service Continuous bus service to midtown Manhattan and the Jamaica subway station will operate, beginning Jan. 20. To Midtown Manhattan, 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas and Third and Lexington Avenues: A.M. Service: Leave Roosevelt Raceway Parking Lot (off Zeckendorf Boulevard), between 5:30 and 9:30. P.M. Service: Leave 42d St. between 5th Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, near Bryant Park, and between Second and Third Avenues between 3:30 and 8. To Roosevelt Raceway Parking Lot. Fares: $8 one-way, $15 roundtrip (Tickets will be issued at point of departure). Express service to Jamaica 169th Street for E and F subway: A.M. Service: Leave Seaford Railroad Station, Sunrise and Washington Avenues, Seaford Merrick Railroad Station, Sunrise and Merrick Avenues, Merrick, between 5:30 and 9:30. To IND subway station, 169th Street, Jamaica P.M. Service: Leave Hillside Avenue and 169th Street, Jamaica. To Merrick, Bellmore, Wantagh and Seaford railroad stations, between 3:30 and 8. Fares: $5 each way. Suffolk Express Bus Service To IND subway line in Queens. Buses will depart from Suffolk between 5 A.M. and 7 A.M. from the northeast parking field, at the South Shore Mall, Bay Shore, and the Amityville, Copiague, Lindenhurst, Babylon, Sayville, Patchogue, Ronkonkoma, Huntington, Northport, and Smithtown Long Island Rail Road stations. With the exception of buses from Babylon, all buses will go to the 179th Street IND station in Jamaica for connections with the E or F trains. Babylon buses will go to the Van Wyck Boulevard subway stop for E and F trains. Return buses will leave the IND stations between 4 P.M. and 7 P.M. Fares will approximate regular L.I.R.R. Suffolk to New York City rates. Car Pool Sites Nassau Christopher Morley Park, Roslyn (Searingtown Road, north of Long Island Expressway exit 36). Cantiague Park, Hicksville (West John Street, west of Broadway). Hempstead Lake State Park, Hempstead (south of Southern State Parkway at exit 18). Jones Beach State Park, Jones Beach (Field 4, enter from Ocean Parkway). Green Acres Shopping Center, Valley Stream (south side of Sunrise Highway near Queens/ Nassau line). Nassau County Office Complex, Plainview (Old Country Road entrance, midway between Long Island Expressway exits 46 and 48). Times Square Store, Elmont (south portion of lot fronting on Hempstead Turnpike, approximately 1 1/2 miles east of Nassau/ Queens line).* New York State Department of Transportation Park & Ride Lot, Hicksville (east side of Route 106/ 107, just north of Sears Department Store).* Eisenhower Park, East Meadow (Lot 1, fronting on Hempstead Turnpike east of Meadowbrook Parkway).** Nassau County Coliseum, East Meadow (area 4 adjacent to Hempstead Turnpike entrance).**

title: Dr. Chaplan Is Wed to David J. Nathan
description: At Congregation Shearith Israel in New York yesterday Dr. Rebecca L. Chaplan, a daughter of Charmian Reading of New York and Dr. Abraham Chaplan of Los Angeles, was married to David J. Nathan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar J. Nathan 3d of New York. Rabbi Marc D. Angel performed the ceremony.

title: THE TWO SIDES OF BILL PARCELLS
description: IT has nothing to do with his generous waistline, but Bill Parcells seems to be two people. One is the highly successful football coach who will take his Giants into Super Bowl XXI against the Denver Broncos Sunday in Pasadena, Calif. The other is the little boy who grew up five minutes from where Giants Stadium would be built, dreamed of coaching the Giants, realized that dream and sometimes flexes his muscles to assure himself the dream is actually reality.

title: Trumpet Ensemble In Italian Program
description: Weill Recital Hall, the newly refurbished chamber auditorium on the third floor of Carnegie Hall, has bright, blaring acoustics that are immediate to a near-painful degree. For this reason, one was grateful that the New York Trumpet Ensemble, which presented a concert entitled ''The Italian Influence'' at Weill Thursday night, was outside the hall when it played the two rousing fanfares by Monteverdi and Girolamo Fantini that began and ended the first half of the program. The effect was not only brilliant but it spared our hearing as well.

title: MANY ORCHESTRAS IN FINANCIAL STRAITS
description: More of America's symphony orchestras are in trouble than at any time since the Depression - afflicted with strikes and lockouts, struggling to raise money and in some cases canceling seasons and even declaring bankruptcy.

title: Pilot Discusses Risk of Stunt In Movie Manslaughter Trial
description: A stunt pilot with 26 years of experience in Hollywood has testified that he would not have performed under the circumstances that led to the crash of a helicopter on the set of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNION MAN Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the slain civil-rights leader, were particularly close. Dr. King spoke at union-sponsored events and union members participated in demonstrations he led.

title: High Costs, Low Prices Seen Ahead for USX
description: To relight its furnaces, the USX Corporation, which has reached a tentative contract settlement with the United Steelworkers of America to end a six-month work stoppage, will sustain a large cash drain, industry analysts predicted yesterday.

title: ROSALIND LaROCHE
description: Rosalind LaRoche, founder and director of Earth House, a residential treatment center for mental disorders in East Millstone, N.J., died last Monday at the Robert Wood-Johnson Memorial Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J., after a long illness. She was 47 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: THE STAGE: 'PANACHE!'
description: ''PANACHE!'' brings to mind those good old stomach-challenging Jewish meals, before the health-food craze spoiled everything. It's drenched in schmaltz, but there's enough good humor bubbling up like seltzer to stave off indigestion. Ron Mark's new fantasy-farce, which is having its premiere at the American Jewish Theater of the 92d Street Y, tells of the breaking-out of Shmulke Coldwater, the 68-year-old proprietor of a Chicago shoe store who lost his chance to star as Cyrano de Bergerac when he was 19 and settled into crusty bachelorhood.

title: We Must Pay the Price for Space Leadership; On to Mars
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Joy Aufzien Weds P.S. Levine
description: Leslie Joy Aufzien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Aufzien of Tamarac, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Steven Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levine of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and Tamarac. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J.

title: SEOUL ADMITS DISSIDENT DIED OF BRUTALITY AT POLICE HANDS
description: The national police director said today that police brutality caused the death of a dissident student last week, and he announced the arrest of two officers and apologized.

title: AMERICANS LONGING FOR HOME
description: During the decade that Australians went to Newport, R.I., to seek the America's Cup, the crews had the same complaint time and again.

title: Wanted: Developer For New Skyscraper
description: Nothing has been swift about the completion of an appointment at the Grand Central Station Post Office. In three years, the Postal Service has narrowed the field to three from nine real-estate developers in a contest for a 99-year-lease at the Lexington Avenue site.

title: Police in Punjab Raid Sikh Temple Complex
description: Paramilitary police forces in the Punjab entered the Sikh religion's holiest shrine today and arrested several people suspected of terrorist activities, according to news reports here.

title: What the Founders Did About Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILD SEX ABUSE CHARGED IN MORE DIVORCES
description: Growing numbers of fathers involved in divorce disputes are being wrongly accused of sexually molesting their children, according to family law experts and mental health professionals who specialize in evaluating reports of child sexual abuse.

title: CHINA VOWS CURB ON FREE DISCUSSION
description: After the replacement of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader, China's intellectuals were warned today that the recent atmosphere of freer expression and discussion would be sharply curtailed.

title: 2D SEATTLE BISHOP TAKING A MORE VISIBLE ROLE
description: Nearly a year after the Vatican sent Auxiliary Bishop Donald Wuerl to Seattle with a mission to bring more orthodox teachings to Roman Catholics here, he has begun to assert his moral authority.

title: Regulators Reviewing Air Mergers
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, has asked her staff to examine how the wave of mergers that have taken place in the airline industry has affected the consumer, and whether the merged carriers have done what they had promised in their proposals.

title: AQUINO, IN AREA OF A REVOLT, BRIEFLY MEETS REBEL OFFICIAL
description: Under heavy military protection, President Corazon C. Aquino flew briefly today to this city, which for the last week has been the center of the heaviest Moslem fighting in years.

title: The Iran-Contra Affair: A Cast of Characters
description: Charles Allen: The C.I.A.'s national intelligence officer for counterterrorism, he received intercepted conversations from Iran and was one of the first to sound the alarm about problems in the covert action. Richard L. Armitage: Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, he was aware of the arms shipments. William J. Casey: The Director of Central Intelligence, he was recently operated on for a brain tumor. Investigators want to know if he or the C.I.A. illegally aided the contras. George Cave: A retired C.I.A. agent who speaks Persian, he was called out of retirement in March 1986 by the C.I.A. to work on the arms sales. He accompanied Robert C. McFarlane to Teheran in May 1986. Duane Clarridge: Chief of the C.I.A.'s European division, he helped Colonel North arrange for a flight by a European airline connected to the C.I.A. that carried arms to Iran in November 1985. Robert Gates: The Deputy Director for Intelligence, the agency's senior analyst, in the first months of the Iran initiative, he replaced John McMahon as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence in 1986 and is now acting director in Mr. Casey's absence. Clair George: The C.I.A.'s Deputy Director for Operations, he had overall responsibility for the clandestine help provided by the agency to the National Security Council. Manucher Ghorbanifar: The key Iranian middleman, he was distrusted by the C.I.A. He was developed as a contact by the Israelis and later by the National Security Council. When he was cut out of the arms operation in August 1986 he threatened to expose the secret dealings. Albert Hakim: An Iranian-born arms dealer and businessman who is now an American, he is a business partner of Mr. Secord. Adnan M. Khashoggi: A Saudi arms dealer who introduced Mr. Ghorbanifar to the Israelis, he remained as the deal's financier. He claims to have raised millions for the transactions from investors. Michael Ledeen: A part-time consultant to the National Security Council, he first broached the Administration's hope for better relations with Iran in 1985 meetings with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. He told the committee he was cut out of the dealings in December 1985. Robert C. McFarlane: National security adviser until Dec. 4, 1985, he continued to assist the Administration through December 1985 and went to Teheran in May 1986 at Mr. Reagan's request. John McMahon: C.I.A. Deputy Director until he resigned in February 1986, he objected to the November 1985 arms shipment and demanded the agency get Presidential authorization for any future activities. Yaacov Nimrodi: A former Israeli official in Iran and now an arms dealer, he helped bring together the participants and ease the first shipments. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North: The dismissed National Security Council aide, he is said to have been the central figure in arranging the Iran arms sales and diverting profits to the contras. Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter: Mr. McFarlane's successor as national security adviser, he resigned last November after it was disclosed that he knew about the diversion to the contras of millions in profits on the arms sales. Maj. Gen. Colin L. Powell: When direct arms shipments began in 1986, he was Mr. Weinberger's senior military assistant. President Reagan: Among the issues central to the investigation, according to Congressional staff members, is whether the President knew and approved of the diversion of Iran arms funds to the contras. Donald T. Regan: President Reagan's chief of staff, he has survived calls for his resignation after the initial disclosures about the activities of National Security Council staff members. Richard V. Secord: A retired Air Force major general and an associate of Colonel North's, he was an American intermediary who arranged logistics, worked on negotiations and helped develop a second channel for the Iran shipments. He is also believed to have been involved in running a private supply network for the contras. Al Schwimmer: An Israeli businessman, he was involved in the early months of the arms shipments through Israel. George P. Shultz: The Secretary of State, he disapproved of the covert operation. He has said he was not informed about key aspects of the sales. William H. Taft 4th: Deputy Secretary of Defense, he was one of several senior defense officials said to be aware of the arms shipments early on. Caspar W. Weinberger: The Secretary of Defense, he repeatedly objected to the arms sales. But he ordered his subordinates to make the weapons available.

title: Manager of the Waldorf To Run Caesars Palace
description: Caesars World Inc. has announced that W. Dan Reichartz will become president and chief operating officer of Caesars Palace of Las Vegas, the flagship hotel and casino of the Los Angeles-based gaming and resort company.

title: Steve Krieckhaus
description: Steve Krieckhaus will return to Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, for performances at 8 P.M. on Feb. 9 and 10. The Philadelphia-based choreographer and performer is to present ''Missouri Driver's License,'' a popular solo seen in the workshop's ''Out-of-Towners'' series last summer. Tickets are $8; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: 924-0077.

title: 16 Stolen Snakes Are Back at Zoo
description: Sixteen snakes stolen from the Bronx Zoo were back home and apparently healthy yesterday after the police traced them to the apartment of a snake fancier, the authorities said.

title: BAN ON CIGARETTE ADS TO BE URGED IN CONGRESS
description: Backed by a declaration by the Surgeon General that cigarettes harm nonsmokers and a 1986 Supreme Court decision suggesting that the Government could prohibit cigarette advertising, advocates of such a ban are planning a major push for it in Congress this year.

title: Meredith L. Frieze Marries Gary Fenton, an Executive
description: Meredith Lynn Frieze, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Frieze of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday to Gary H. Fenton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Fenton of Beachwood, Ohio. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: New Principals In Met 'Rigoletto'
description: Interest in Friday evening's ''Rigoletto'' at the Metropolitan Opera centered on two new principals in the cast - Gwendolyn Bradley singing the role of Gilda and Denes Gulyas as the Duke of Mantua.

title: SEVERE STORM DISRUPTS THE SOUTHWEST
description: Much of the Southwest is digging out today from a snowstorm that closed highways, shut airports and caused the Governor of New Mexico to declare four counties disaster areas.

title: U.S. CONGRESSMAN WARNS KENYA AGAINST A TREND OF RIGHTS ABUSE
description: An American Congressman said today that a growing trend of human rights abuses by the Government of Kenya could ultimately lead to instability and damage the country's strong relations with the United States.

title: DEVILS LOSE BY 6-1; ALONE IN LAST PLACE
description: It was a battle to avoid last place at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, and the Devils fell to the bottom of the Patrick Division for the first time this season after their 6-1 loss to the Washington Capitals.

title: Advertising; Muir Cornelius Moore Wins Helicopter Job
description: Muir Cornelius Moore has become the ad agency for the LHX Light Helicopter, now under development by the Boeing Sikorsky LHX Team, a joint venture of Boeing Vertol and Sikorsky Aircraft. The helicopter is expected to be fully operational by 1990, and in the meantime the agency will be promoting it in publications reaching the military industry.

title: LENDL ADVANCES IN AUSTRALIAN OPEN
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia survived a nerve-racking battle today with an unseeded American, Dan Goldie, before advancing to the quarterfinals of the $1.65 million Australian Open tennis championships at Kooyong.

title: COACH BEHIND THE COACH
description: THE Coach remembers that Bill Parcells was a strapping teen-ager, about 6 feet 1 inch and 180 pounds, the best athlete in River Dell High School in Oradell, N.J., in the mid-1950's. Parcells played quarterback and linebacker on the football team, was a baseball catcher with some potential, and a basketball forward who liked to bully his way to the basket.

title: Albany Strikes Health Blow Against the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Bartley Leaves Posts At D'Arcy Masius
description: Eugene F. Bartley Jr., 41, executive vice president and group account director, has resigned from the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles ''in order to pursue other interests.''

title: Market Place; Some Bears Stick to Guns
description: JANUARY'S sizzling rally in stocks has dispatched most market bears into hibernation - for a while, at least. ''Money managers who were sitting with cash late last year now are jumping in to buy,'' said Theodore Halligan, an institutional salesman for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood. ''They figure they can't afford to miss an up market like this one.''

title: Advertising; Retail Chain Chooses Kornhauser & Calene
description: Gentlemen's Wear-House, operator of a 29-unit retail chain, has assigned its $2 million account to Kornhauser & Calene. The previous agency was MJA Advertising Associates.

title: Bridge: Tri-State Swiss Team Titles Won by a New York Couple
description: An unusual double was achieved last Thursday at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y. While Allan Stauber of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., was winning the Men's Swiss Teams event, his wife, Marcia Warner Stauber, was capturing the Women's Swiss Teams title.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Friday, about a surge in technology stocks, misidentified two companies. The correct names are Pansophic Systems Inc. and the Maxtor Corporation.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 3 BALANCHINE WORKS
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE avoided giving overtly descriptive titles to the works he choreographed for the New York City Ballet, preferring that dancegoers decide for themselves what his ballets were about. One of his most matter-of-fact titles is ''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze,' '' the ballet to Schumann piano music which, with Jerry Zimmerman as pianist, was performed for the first time this season Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: N. CAROLINA WINS 13TH IN ROW, 96-78
description: There's a familiar look in Chapel Hill these days, as an exhausted North Carolina State Wolfpack discovered this afternoon. Early season adjustments done, North Carolina is again emerging as a power, as its overwhelming 96-78 victory attests.

title: The Answer to 'Iranamok'
description: The search for a recognizable headline word for the arms-to-Iran-profits-to-the-contras story continues to command the attention of Washington publications and writers. When The New Republic, after a contest, officially adopted ''Iranamok,'' it became inevitable that a conservative journal like the National Review would have to produce a catchword of its own, and the cover of its current issue offers ''Irandeal.''

title: MAJOR FOLK ART COLLECTION ACQUIRED BY SMITHSONIAN
description: A key collection of American folk art with an estimated value of several million dollars has been acquired by the National Museum of American Art, a branch of the Smithsonian Institution, museum officials announced today.

title: CUOMO AND HOWARD BEACH: RECALLING POLITICAL ROOTS
description: For a time last week, the clock seemed turned back 15 years: Mario M. Cuomo, Queens lawyer, was once again mediating a racial dispute centered in his home borough but of interest nationwide.

title: WEDTECH: RISE AND FALL OF A WELL-CONNECTED BRONX COMPANY
description: In 1970, a Hispanic tool-and-die maker and a Rumanian refugee joined forces and began to transform a small machine shop in the South Bronx into a $100 million-a-year military contractor listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SOARING YEN STIRS CONCERN
description: The latest rise of the yen against the dollar has heightened concerns here about the effect that the shift in currencies is having on the domestic economy.

title: Salomon Seeks to Expand Japan Subsidiary
description: Salomon Brothers has applied to the Japanese Government to increase tenfold, to nearly $350 million, the capital of its Japanese subsidiary, the company said Friday.

title: BONN UNEASY ON EXPORTS
description: A week before a national election that it seems assured of winning, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government is growing deeply anxious about the implications of a rapidly sinking dollar and a rising mark for West Germany's export-based economy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 19, 1987
description: International Report

title: Advertising; 'Celebrity' Campus Magazine
description: IT might be that Michael Weiss, 25-year-old entrepreneur, has struck upon a winning idea for a campus publication: Make national campus ''celebrities'' out of certain students.

title: Washington Watch; Economic Council's Report
description: It's no surprise that the 1987 Council of Economic Advisers' Economic Report of the President will find much to celebrate in the Reagan economy, according to those who have perused its galleys. To be published Jan. 29, the report will celebrate the fall of inflation and interest rates.

title: MUSIC: COLLEGIATE CHORALE
description: THE Collegiate Chorale and its young conductor, Robert Bass, performed Brahms's ''German'' Requiem at Carnegie Hall Saturday night the way it should always be performed - unadorned, without intermission or other works, a somber, unified hour of musical meditation.

title: We Must Pay the Price for Space Leadership; Who's in the Lead?
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG WORRIES OVER SMALL GCA
description: In a world as unforgiving of mistakes as the microelectronics industry, most people would simply shrug it off if a high-tech equipment maker as small as the GCA Corporation ceased to exist in the midst of the computer slump.

title: Japanese Pullback Is Feared
description: The sharp decline in the dollar early last week sent a shiver through the bond markets, where securities dealers and the Treasury have come to rely on the purchases of foreign investors.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing A First for Gaspoz: Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland won his first World Cup slalom yesterday with a skillful performance on the steep Lauberhorn course in Wengen, Switzerland. The 24-year-old Swiss was timed for the two heats in 1 minute 36.86 seconds. Dietmar Koehlbichler of Austria finished second in 1:37.40, giving an unexpected lift to the Austrian team, which has been lackluster this season. Five Austrians finished among the top 15 in their best showing so far. Yugoslavia's Bojan Krijaz was third in 1:37.44. Gazpoz went from fifth to third in the overall World Cup standing with 125 points, behind a countryman, Pirmin Zurbriggen, with 203, and Markus Wasmeier of West Germany, with 157.(AP) Walliser Triumphs in Women's Race: Switzerland's Maria Walliser easily won a women's World Cup giant slalom race in Bischofswiesen, West Germany, with two fast runs as Swiss skiers captured the top four places. Walliser had a combined time of 2:19.24. Vreni Schneider was runner-up in 2:21.40, followed by Brigitte Oertli in 2:21.44 and Zoe Haas in 2:21.50. Walliser leads the overall World Cup standing with 229 points. Schneider is second with 201 points.(AP) Bobsledding Swiss Take Four-Man Title: Hans Hiltebrand completed a Swiss sweep of the gold medals in the 1987 world bobsled championships by capturing the four-man title yesterday on his 42d birthday in St. Moritz, Switzerland. Last week, Ralph Pichler won the two-man championships. Although Hiltebrand had steering problems on the second day, the margin was large enough to enable him to hold off a strong challenge by Wolfgang Hoppe, the East German double Olympic champion of 1984. The total winning time was 4:22.65, with the runner-up sled clocked in 4:22.91. Matt Roy of Saranac Lake, N.Y., piloted USA I to ninth place in 4:25.72, leading the non-European entries. (AP) N.B.A. Lakers 115, Bullets 101: Magic Johnson, hitting only 5 of 16 field-goal attempts in the first three quarters, scored 11 of his 26 points in the first six minutes of the final period to lead Los Angeles yesterday. Washington, playing at home in Landover, Md., had made up a 14-point deficit in the third quarter while Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was on the bench in foul trouble. Abdul-Jabbar finished with 15 points and James Worthy had 20 for the Lakers. Jeff Malone scored 27 and Moses Malone 21 for the Bullets.(AP) Bucks 100, Hawks 91: In Milwaukee, John Lucas, playing in his first game for the Bucks, scored a 3-point basket to snap a tie as they came from behind to defeat Atlanta. Lucas's basket gave Milwaukee a 92-89 lead with 1:50 left, and Jack Sikma, who finished with 18 points, increased the Bucks' margin to 95-91 with 39 seconds left. Ricky Pierce led Milwaukee with 20 points. Mike McGee led the Hawks with 24 points. Dominique Wilkins, who missed part of the game with a knee injury, finished with 18. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres 6, Oilers 5: In Buffalo, Scott Arniel's second goal of the game, in overtime, led Buffalo to the victory last night. Arniel's 35-foot slapshot beat Andy Moog high to the glove side at 1:49 of overtime to hand the Oilers their first road loss in nine games. (AP) Red Wings 1, Penguins 0: Dave Barr scored midway through the third period and Glen Hanlon made 36 saves to give Detroit the victory in Pittsburgh. Barr broke the scoreless tie at 9:55 of the third period on Detroit's 26th shot. Steve Yzerman fed a backhand pass from the right wing and Barr, at the top of the slot, fired a 30-foot shot past Gilles Meloche on the stick side.(AP) Running Frostbite Race in Central Park: Frank Sharkey of Salisbury, Md., won the Frostbite 10-mile run in 52 minutes 23 seconds yesterday in Central Park. Sharkey, an Irishman now running for the Warren Street Athletic Club, defeated a field of 953 men and women who ran in snowy, chilly weather. Sharkey finished 380 yards ahead of Tom Phillips, who led the Central Park Track Club to the team title with 83 points. Phillips finished in 53:37. Atlaw Beligne of the Millrose Athletic Association was third in 54:00, followed by Martin Carle of Stony Point, N.Y., in 54.36 and Jim Kempton of Nanuet, N.Y., in 54:51. Cindy Gerard-Klein of the Atalanta Track Club shattered the women's meet record with a time of 57:09. The previous record of 58:06 was set by Cindy Wuss of the Atoms Track Club in 1985. (AP) Horse Racing Easy Victory at Aqueduct: Indistinctly, one of the outsiders in the field of 13, led from wire-to-wire under E. T. Baird to score a 5 3/4-length victory in the $75,000 Broadway Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old daughter of Vaguely Noble-Bold Rondo maintained a clear lead throughout, widening her advantage in the late stages. Wendy Walker outfinished She Skates, the favorite, for second. Indistinctly earned $45,000 for Flying Zee Stables after covering one mile and 70 yards on the sloppy strip in 1:43 2/5. She returned $53.40 for $2 to win. M.I.S.L. Stars 6, Express 5: Cico's goal at 2 minutes 18 seconds of overtime gave the Tacoma Stars a 6-5 triumph over the New York Express last night at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. The victory was the sixth in six overtime contests for the Stars, leaders of the Western Division. It also was Tacoma's 10th victory in 10 one-goal games. Preki led the Stars, who were tied at 2-2 at halftime, with three goals. Mark Liveric and Chris Whyte each had a pair of goals for the Express, who lost their fourth in a row. Liveric sent the game into overtime with his second goal at 14:02 of the final period.(AP)

title: AFGHAN ASSERTS SOVIET TROOPS WILL STAY UNTIL THE WAR ENDS
description: The Afghan leader today denounced as a ''crime against the people'' an Islamic guerrilla rejection of his cease-fire bid, and he said Soviet troops would stay in Afghanistan until the civil war was over.

title: TO BE OR NOT TO BE A PROTEST CANDIDATE
description: Will Patrick J. Buchanan run for President? President Reagan's director of communications drums his fingers on his White House desk in an agitated beat as he ponders the answer.

title: UNDER FOWLER, F.C.C. TREATED TV AS COMMERCE
description: Television, Mark S. Fowler once observed, is really nothing more than ''a toaster with pictures.''

title: STEEL UNION LOCALS BACK USX PACT
description: The presidents of locals of the United Steelworkers union ratified contract concessions tonight with the USX Corporation that will mean wage cuts for its members and the loss of more than 1,300 jobs.

title: Open the Borden Avenue Shelter
description: Opponents of a proposed city shelter for homeless single men on Borden Avenue in Long Island City offer many reasons for rejection by the Board of Estimate next week. Though some might sound good, none carry enough weight to counter the city's basic point: The Borden Avenue site is the best available to meet the need now.

title: New York Tax Windfall Understated by Cuomo
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE A MOTH IS A TREASURE
description: An estimated 942,000 new items became part of the Smithsonian Institution's collections in 1986, some for public display, most put away for study purposes.

title: DROP-INS: VISITORS OR INVADERS?
description: KAREN MARCING, a Chicago purchasing agent, planned to spend a recent evening working on an oil painting, but she never had a chance to pursue her hobby because an old friend stopped by.

title: OFFICIALS PROTEST PORTRAYAL OF ISRAELIS IN 'POPOLO'
description: The selection last month of ''Avanti Popolo'' as Israel's entry in the foreign films category of the Academy Awards has set off a furor among some politicans and members of the Israeli Parliament.

title: TOP CONSERVATIVES CELEBRATE DOCUMENTARY OF THEMSELVES
description: The occasion was the premiere of ''The Conservatives,'' a documentary to air Tuesday night on the Public Broadcasting System.

title: S.E.C. IS SAID TO WIDEN ITS WALL STREET INQUIRY
description: In its continuing investigation of the takeover business on Wall Street, the Securities and Exchange Commission has uncovered evidence suggesting that Ivan F. Boesky worked with several brokerage firms to systematically evade securities laws and profit from corporate takeovers, according to lawyers and other sources with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: Patterson and Ware On Guitar and Flute
description: Saturday's evening of guitar and flute music at Merkin Concert Hall was one of those events that smile, glassy-eyed, out from the stage and invite us to ''have a nice day.'' Richard Patterson and Bettine Clemen Ware were the performers, and together they offered nice little pieces of music interspersed with nice little jokes and repartee. Both the new pieces and the arrangements of old ones seem to have had any incipient originality, substance or adventure baked away by the California sun. R. Towner's ''Icarus'' offered tape-delay echos; John Geist's ''Iron Maiden'' for guitar and string quartet used dissonant chordal blocks as movie-style melodrama, while Mr. Patterson's three guitar pieces burbled in the best tradition of elevator music. Both instruments, moreover, were amplified - incomprehensible in this small hall but serving (and appropriately I'm afraid) to encase these proceedings in plastic.

title: Helping Poor Nations Helps America
description: Too little and six years late, the Reagan Administration has finally come to appreciate the importance of the International Development Association. An affiliate of the World Bank, this agency aids the poorest of the poor, nations whose per capita income is less than $790. The Administration stopped its growth in 1981. Now, with substantial aid from Japan, Washington is working to restore the institution's previous lending capacity. That's among the best ways to help poor nations grow, which helps America recover debts and expand trade.

title: Marci Kraft Married To a Fellow Lawyer
description: Marcijane Kraft, a daughter of Shirley Parmet of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and Morry Kraft of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Naar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Naar of Cranbury, N.J. Rabbi David Glicksman performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Pavon, in Cranbury.

title: Subdued Financing Activity Is Seen
description: The Treasury securities market will be closed today, and analysts expect that activity in the corporate, tax-exempt and financial futures markets will be subdued until a full complement of traders and investors returns tommorow.

title: Adelia Williams a Bride
description: Adelia Valmira Williams and Jeffrey Floyd Lubitz were married yesterday at the Port Washington, L.I., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. George L. Williams. Mayor Thomas Pellegrino of Port Washington North officiated. The bride, who received bachelor's and master's degrees from Queens College, is a doctoral candidate in French at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. Mr. Lubitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Lubitz of Manhasset Hills, L.I., owns Sweet Impressions, a designer and manufacturer of T-shirts in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: How to Overcome
description: What would Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. think, if he were alive for the nation's observance of his 58th birthday, about Howard Beach? It would be presumptuous to say - but it might also be instructive to speculate.

title: MANAGUA CARDINAL BEATEN IN MIAMI
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua was tied up, beaten, verbally abused and robbed here over the weekend, relatives and friends said today.

title: Dog of the Decade
description: Everybody at the Hollywood Greyhound Park outside Miami is watching the clock nowadays, at least on the nights when P's Rambling runs. In his last five starts, the 27-month-old, 68-pound, brindle-colored dog has posted the five fastest times for three-eighths of a mile in track history, a feat made all the more astonishing by Hollywood's stature as the leading greyhound oval in Florida, the No. 1 greyhound state.

title: AUSTRALIA'S 'LUCK' STARTS RUNNING OUT
description: Once this was known as ''the lucky country,'' and Australians were confident their vast nation would prosper on its abundance of gold, oil, coal and other resources. But a parade of economic difficulties, including a foreign debt that is rapidly becoming one of the world's largest, has eroded that carefree optimism.

title: Buchanan's Win Wish
description: Far be it from me to put the kibosh on Pat Buchanan's possible run for the Presidency, but it's better that the secret come out now: conservative True Believers should know that he is a member of the Judson Welliver Society.

title: A YEAR OF MISTAKES AND WARNINGS IGNORED IN IRAN DEAL, REPORT SAYS
description: For more than a year, the Reagan Administration repeatedly ignored internal warnings that its arms sales to Iran were based on faulty intelligence, dependent upon unreliable middlemen and likely to fall far short of White House goals, according to a staff report prepared for the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Notification requirements were intended not only to insure the propriety of covert operations, but also to insure their effectiveness. In this particular case, notification could have prevented what proved to be a costly setback for U.S. foreign policy.'' - Staff report prepared for the Senate Intelligence Committee. [ A1:2. ]

title: TEXT OF SUMMARY OF SENATE REPORT ON THE IRAN-CONTRA INQUIRY
description: Following is the text of Part Two of the final draft of the Senate Intelligence Committee report on the Iran-contra arms investigation, which was obtained by The New York Times. Part One of the report, essectially a chronology of the affair, was made public earlier by NBC News.

title: COLLEGES ACCUSED OF BIAS TO STEM ASIANS' GAINS
description: Asian-American leaders say their young people are encountering increasing discrimination when they apply to the nation's most selective universities.

title: CHINESE IN U.S. DRAFT PROTEST OF OUSTER
description: In an act of protest that seems certain to arouse anger among Chinese leaders in Beijing, representatives of Chinese students and professors in the United States have drafted a statement condemning the dismissal of Hu Yaobang as Secretary General of the Communist Party and suggesting that they might refuse to return to China if hard-line policies prevail.

title: PROSECUTION AN ISSUE IN ABUSE CASE
description: The McMartin pre-school case has come a long way since seven teachers and administrators at the school in nearby Manhattan Beach were accused nearly three years ago of sexually molesting hundreds of children.

title: ARTS GRANTS AWARDED
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced today that it would award $189,875 in Federal grants to designers and artists collaborating on six model projects to develop public spaces.

title: All-Male Club Votes On Allowing Women
description: Members of the University Club, bitterly divided over whether to admit women to New York City's largest male club, have voted on a resolution that would allow female members if a city antidiscrimination law is upheld in the courts.

title: REEVES GUIDED BY BASIC VALUES
description: IT happened a long time ago back on a Georgia farm somewhere between Americus and Andersonville. Dan Reeves, who will turn 43 years old today, remembers he was 5 years old, and had been very sick.

title: Out of the Red
description: The American Enterprise Institute, an active and influential research organization in the capital for many years, has emerged rapidly from the shadow of financial peril, with program and staff trimmed somewhat but basic conservative goals and philosophy intact, according to its new president, Christopher C. DeMuth.

title: 3 RETAILERS TO PASS ON TAX SAVINGS BY PRICE CUTS
description: Some of the nation's best-known retailers say they are going to cut prices to pass along their savings under the new tax law.

title: William Latham, 83; Guided Niagara Project
description: William H. Latham, an engineer who worked closely with Robert Moses and presided over the construction of the Niagara Project hydroelectric works, died Thursday at Mount Saint Mary's Hospital in Lewiston, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Lewiston.

title: SYNDICATION WOES TRIP MCA
description: The decision late last week by MCA Inc. to take a $50 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings underscores the problems faced by the once-booming television syndication industry, according to analysts and other industry experts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 19, 1987
description: International

title: WHAT BECOMES A LEGEND MOST?
description: That fun couple of rodentdom - we're speaking here, of course, about Mickey and Minnie Mouse - are nothing if not enduring. Besides their notable career in films, the pair have appeared in countless children's books and on the face of watches that are often worn by grown-up children. Mr. Mouse also serves as guest host at huge amusement parks in California and Florida and for several years, about a generation ago, had his own club on television (he was the leader of the band that's made for you and me). Nowadays, the Mouses - they prefer it to the Mice - can be found on everything from ski parkas, sweaters and fake-fur coats to bracelets and men's evening shoes. Donald Duck is seething with jealousy. But who knows, he might be next.

title: GALVESTON AGAIN REJECTS CASINOS
description: In the second referendum in three years, Galveston voters Saturday turned down a proposal to re-establish the casinos that once flourished in this struggling seaport. Despite torrential rains, the turnout was higher than expected, with 59 percent of the voters rejecting a proposed beachfront casino district.

title: Accommodating History
description: Historical Significance You May Have Missed Until Now. The Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution has approved, among a number of celebratory programs, ''a major multimedia campaign to inform and educate the public on the Constitution and the role inns and taverns played during the four months of the Federal convention.'' The sponsor, not surprisingly, is the American Hotel and Motel Association.

title: MICHIGAN UPSETS SYRACUSE BY 91-88
description: The centerpiece of a poster in the Michigan dressing room today was a big orange ''15-0'' - Syracuse's record entering its game with the Wolverines. But the Orangemen were upset today, 91-88, and after the game, someone had covered up the ''0'' with the number ''1.''

title: ENGLAND'S GREEN AND PLEASANT LAND, SPLIT IN TWO?
description: In the days of Empire, Bolton's smokestacks were towering red-brick symbols of the prosperity earned by spinning textiles for the world. There were about 200 textile mills and enough jobs and money for everyone. The spinning jenny was invented here; William Hesketh Lever cut his first bar of soap here.

title: IRAQ SAYS THE ATTACK FAILED
description: Iran asserted today that its troops had advanced ''deep inside enemy lines'' in heavy fighting, to within 400 yards of an oil refinery just south of the major southern Iraqi city of Basra.

title: ABOUT CARS: 2 WINNERS FOR CHEVROLET
description: BACK when automobiles were new and still thought a bit fangled, a French race driver appended his name to a touring car and the first Chevrolet was born. That was 1912, and the first Chevy was a ponderous roadster with a huge engine and a price to match.

title: HOW TO GET PARENTS OFF TO WORK CALMLY
description: How can working parents avert the kind of crisis that can transform an ordinary morning into an obstacle course? Here, from the pages of a new newsletter, are a few suggestions:

title: GUILTY VERDICT AND MISTRIAL IN JERSEY TROOPER DEATH
description: Thomas W. Manning, an avowed revolutionary, was convicted today of murder while in the commission of felonies the shooting of State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco in 1981.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Belgium is issuing $300 million of 8 percent Eurobonds due in 1997 at 101 1/2 to yield 7.78 percent, through County Bank Ltd.

title: IRAQ ASCRIBES A KEY DEFEAT IN '86 TO MISINFORMATION FROM THE U.S.
description: A leading Iraqi official has asserted that misleading intelligence information provided by the United States led last year to a major Iraqi defeat in the war with Iran.

title: U.S.-Canada Talks Set
description: Vice President Bush and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will go to Canada this week to confer on trade and other economic matters, the White House has announced.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 19, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Drafting Committee for Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. And 3 P.M.

title: Security Forces Design a Defense
description: At Super Bowl XX last January in New Orleans, a rumor circulated that several foreign terrorists had been spotted in the area and intended to disrupt activities leading to the National Football League's championship game.

title: On Bearing Arms
description: What's in store for the gun lobby in the new Congress?

title: ECUADOR GENERAL REPORTED IN HIDING
description: With the political climate in Ecuador still tense, the rebellious air force general whose freedom was gained when commandos took the country's President hostage has gone into hiding.

title: PLAN OFFERED FOR VAST ATOM SMASHER
description: President Reagan will decide this month whether the United States should build a $6 billion atom smasher about 50 miles in circumference and he may express support for the project in his State of the Union Message, Administration officials said.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'SQUARE ONE' TO TEACH MATH TO VIDEO-LITERATE
description: Graduates of ''Sesame Street'' will soon have a television show all their own. On Monday, the Children's Television Workshop, which introduced Big Bird and Kermit to preschoolers 18 years ago, will unveil its newest project, ''Square One,'' aimed at 8- to 12-year-olds. The show will be broadcast on most local public television stations on weekday afternoons.

title:
WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING;
Transporting Reagan
description: LEAD: Although President Reagan's recent prostate operation was by all available information a complete success, one of its lingering effects is on Presidential mobility.

title: An Inner City Asks For a Supermarket
description: THE people of central Newark have a dream: a big, modern supermarket for their neighborhood.

title: Sailor With an Obsession: Dennis Conner
description: ''This is a great day for Stars & Stripes and a great day for America,'' Dennis Conner said today with tears in his eyes after he had won the right to challenge Australia for the America's Cup he lost in 1983.

title: JUDGE SUGGESTS RACISM IS MOTIVATING INQUIRY
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami, who is facing possible impeachment charges, has filed a report in Congress suggesting that his critics on the bench were motivated by racism.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company's stock is traded on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December. The year-ago figures restated to reflect acquisition of American National Holding Co. in July 1986, on a pooling of interests basis.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ROCKY MOUNTAIN CHOCOLATE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss on the sale of assets of $146,534 due to the closing and writedown of assets on the company's Houston store. c-Net income

title: Mets Name Minors Managers
description: Butch Hobson, a former third baseman with the Yankees, and John Tamargo have been named minor league managers for the Mets. Hobson was named manager at Columbia of the South Atlantic League. Tamargo, who played for the St. Louis Cardinals and Montreal Expos, was named manager of Lynchburg of the Carolina League.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGE: Seton Hall vs. Boston College, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 9 P.M. (TV -MSG, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:55 P.M., WSOU-FM 89.5, 8:30 P.M.) Virginia Tech at Louisville (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Clemson at Georgia Tech (TV -ESPN, 9 P.M.) Missouri at Kansas (TV - USA, 8 P.M.) Fordham at Columbia (Radio -WKCR-FM 89.9, WFUV-FM, 90.7, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY DEVILS VS. CAPITALS, at Landover, Md., 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) ISLANDERS VS. CALGARY FLAMES, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight)

title: Sikh Radicals Blamed For 6 Deaths in Punjab
description: Sikh extremists killed six people today, including a leader of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, according to the police.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Who's Who at Bargaining Table
description: Bruce C. McIver President, Long Island Rail Road Born in Great Falls, Mont. . . . 46 years old . . . married, father of five children, appointed president of the railroad in 1985 . . . was chief labor negotiator for the City of New York from 1979 to 1983 . . . held the same post with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 1983 to 1985 . . . . described as hard-edged bargainer by union leaders during 1980 negotiations that averted a strike by the police, firefighters, corrections officers and sanitation workers . . . served three years in the Marine Corps . . . earned a degree in sociology from Columbia University in 1973. Edward Yule Jr. General chairman, United Transportation Union Native of Flushing, Queens . . . 50 years old . . . married, three children . . . plays golf . . . joined L.I.R.R. as a ticket agent in 1955 . . . elected chairman of the U.T.U., the largest union, in 1978 . . . is a commuter and has called commuters ''the most courageous people in the world'' . . . led a seven-day strike in December 1979 . . . opposed efforts by the M.T.A. in 1980 to reincorporate the L.I.R.R. so that its workers would be covered by the Taylor Law . . . has previously won pay parity with engineers for his members. John A. Caggiano Business manager, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Chief bargainer for the coalition of unions . . . 44 years old . . . grew up in Long Island City, Queens . . . married, two children . . . has worked 20 years on the railroad as a lineman-cable splicer . . . business manager of the union since 1982 . . . involved in contract talks in 1979 and 1983 . . . has two certificates in labor relations from the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University . . . graduated from Long Island City High School. Joseph A. Cassidy Jr. General chairman, International Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers 44 . . . grew up in Richmond Hill, Queens . . . married, three children . . . graduated from St. John's University with a degree in English . . . represents the fourth generation in his family to work on the railroad and the third generation of engineers . . . his father, Joseph Sr., was director of training for engineers and conductors on the line . . . has been with the railroad 16 years . . . has been involved in negotiations for six contracts . . . spokesman for all of the union locals in the eastern United States . . . in the Marines, served on a support vessel during the Bay of Pigs invasion. Walter C. Wallace Member, National Mediation Board Born in Manhattan . . . 62 years old . . . married, one daughter . . . joined the mediation board in 1982, after private law practice in Washington . . . .chief of staff to Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell in the Eisenhower Administration . . . general counsel to the Presidential Railroad Commission during the same period . . . in the 60's, worked with Ronald Reagan and George Bush on Republican study groups . . . a World War II Army veteran, served in combat in Italy and was awarded the Bronze Star . . . graduated magna cum laude from St. John's University . . . received law degree from Cornell.

title: TOWER FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $12,000. c-Net loss and includes loss of $629,000 from discontinued operations. The net loss and loss from discontinued operations includes a $594,000, net of taxes, writedown. The company went public in June 1986.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $315,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a tax benefit of $1,965,000, or 32 cents a share.

title: New President Joins Goldmark Industries
description: Peter A. Derow, 46, a former Newsweek and CBS Publishing executive, has joined Goldmark Industries as president.

title: The Taking of Ecuador's President
description: These have not been democracy's finest days in Ecuador. Last Friday air force commandos seized President Leon Febres Cordero at gunpoint, holding him until he secured the release of an air force general imprisoned for attempted coup-making. Now the newly released President is threatened with impeachment for infractions against the Constitution and the national honor. Old-fashioned machismo reigns supreme all around. Another new democracy is shown to be just one step ahead of traditional military meddling.

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $88,700 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 9 months.

title: TEXAS PRISONS RESUME ACCEPTANCE OF INMATES
description: The Texas prison system began accepting new convicts today after weekend paroles cut the prisoner population below a mandated ceiling designed to avoid overcrowding.

title: PRETORIA FOES REACH OUT TO THE WEST
description: At a conference of the African-American Institute here last week attended by several score politicians and buiness officials from Africa and the United States, probably the most sought-after participant was a man with a close cropped beard, an easy smile and a metal-stemmed pipe.

title: INTERIOR DEPARTMENT WEIGHS BID TO PRESS A MINERALS PROGRAM
description: The Interior Department is considering a new policy statement that would explicitly make one of its key agencies an advocate for minerals development.

title: 3d Ferry Line Joins Jersey and New York
description: A third ferry line between New Jersey and Manhattan began yesterday. The ferryboat Spirit made her inaugural run from the Ross Dock at the Palisades Interstate Park here, just north of the George Washington Bridge, to Pier 11, near the South Street Seaport, according to the director of Tradebase International Inc., Eugene Wahl.

title: Hewlett Co-founder Retiring From Post
description: William R. Hewlett, who founded the Hewlett-Packard Company with David Packard in 1939, will retire as vice chairman effective Feb. 24, the company said yesterday. Mr. Hewlett, 73 years old, is best known for his innovative engineering and people-oriented style of management.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: EX-IM BANK TO SPUR LENDING
description: The Export-Import Bank, preparing for a surge of exports from the cheaper dollar, will announce lower fees, simplified paperwork and broader loan guarantees Tuesday under revamped programs for exporters.

title: ELIA KAZAN IS HONORED AT FILM MUSEUM DINNER
description: Dustin Hoffman said he doubted whether he, Robert De Niro or Al Pacino - all of whom were sitting at the same dinner table - would ever have become actors if it hadn't been for Elia Kazan.

title: Talking Businesswith Rep. Schroeder of Colorado; 'Family Rights' For Employees
description: Last week the United States Supreme Court ruled that states could require employers to grant job protection to workers disabled by pregnancy. It was a ruling of major importance and has been hailed by women and labor groups as a big step toward protecting ''family rights.''

title: An Angola Angle to the Scandal?
description: LEAD: As the special prosecutor Lawrence Walsh and the select House and Senate committees investigate the Iran-contra arms affair, they should be careful not to overlook a possible Africa connection in the scandal.

title: RECITAL: MARIELLA DEVIA
description: MARIELLA DEVIA'S musical life in New York has been more or less operatic up until now. The Italian soprano has been appearing regularly at the Metropolitan Opera since 1979, and we know her, too, for her concert performances with Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hispanic Rights Group Names Ex-Gov. Anaya
description: Toney Anaya, the former Governor of New Mexico, today was appointed president and general counsel of of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, but his appointment was immediately challenged.

title: CABARET: RETTADEL TUPPER
description: RETTADEL TUPPER, a veteran pop singer and dancer who once worked with Ray Eberle's band, returned to public performance after 25 years at a Greenwich Village club. This past weekend, she concluded a two-weekend engagement at a supper club, Ristorante Eleonora, where she was accompanied by a piano-bass duo.

title: DANCE: FROM CITY BALLET, BALANCHINE'S 'EPISODES'
description: THE New York City Ballet offered George Balanchine's ''Episodes'' for the first time this season Sunday night at the New York State Theater. ''Episodes'' is just what its name implies: a series of choreographic sketches to brief orchestral pieces by the 20th-century composer Anton von Webern. Yet, though none of the ballet's scenes last long, all are rich in implication.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Gains on sale of investment securities totaled $4,797,000 for the latest quarter and $134,649,000 for the latest year, compared with $10,476,000 and $92,511,000 for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively.

title: White Man Attacked By Brooklyn Blacks
description: A white man who was walking on a street in Brooklyn with two black women was beaten late Sunday by a group of young black men who said, ''You don't belong here,'' the police said yesterday. They called the attack racially motivated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1987
description: International

title: 8 PHILANTHROPIES ARE WINNERS OF FORD FOUNDATTION GRANTS
description: With a $500,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, a community foundation in Florida says, it hopes to forge a coalition among the ethnic populations in the Miami area.

title: Finding Flaws in Concrete
description: An inexpensive and nondestructive method for detecting flaws in concrete has been developed by researchers at the Commerce Department's National Bureau of Standards. The technique may ultimately find wide application in construction and bridge repair. Currently, defects are found by drilling a core sample or using X-ray techniques, which are expensive and cumbersome.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $902,000 and includes a gain of about $776,000 from the sale of three branches. c-After a tax credit of $262,000.

title: BSD MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Lugar Lesson and the Aspin Appeal
description: Politicians tell much about themselves by whom they choose to lead them. In the Senate, Republicans have rejected Jesse Helms, a rock of the right, and retained Richard Lugar, an experienced moderate, as their senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee. But in the House Les Aspin has been deposed, at least for the moment, as chairman of the Armed Services Committee because some Democrats judged him too devious, too hawkish or too contemptuous of seniority.

title: Home Shopping In Acquisition Talks
description: Responding to market rumors that touched off a sharp rise in the price of its stock, Home Shopping Network Inc., the television retailer, disclosed yesterday on the advice of its lawyers that it was discussing two possible acquisitions.

title: TOP STRATEGISTS HEDGING BETS
description: These are times that try even the most firmly anchored stock market strategies. An air of unreality pervades the giddy rises of the last two weeks, leaving professional strategists delighted, but flinching at the thought that just at the moment they throw caution to the wind the market could dive.

title: IRANIAN WARSHIPS NOW USING MISSILES FOR NIGHT ATTACKS
description: Iranian warships in the Persian Gulf are using Italian-made Sea Killer missiles against oil tankers in night attacks for the first time, according to United States intelligence officials.

title: GEORGE SELKIRK
description: George Selkirk, the man who replaced Babe Ruth in the New York Yankees' outfield in 1934, died here this morning after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: IRAN IS SAID TO BE SOLIDIFYING FOOTHOLD GAINED INSIDE IRAQ
description: Iranian troops appear to be solidifying their foothold near the Iraqi city of Basra, gaining new patches of territory with Iraqi forces unable to dislodge them, according to United States officials.

title: Turkey Focuses on Its Image
description: Turkey is concerned about its image in the United States. It is worried that too many Americans tend to see it only as aggressive, with a chip on its shoulder, instead of as a country with a great cultural legacy, modern diversity and a geographical location that is of increasing strategic importance to the West.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $208,000 for the quarter and $436,000 for the 6 months, and also a loss of $1,739,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $388,000 from discontinued operations and including a pre-tax charge of $400,000. d-Net income and after a loss of $419,000 from discontinued operations and including a pretax profit of $4,183,000 on the sale of Plasma Center assets. The year-ago figures include a $1.1 million pretax non-recurring charge for the closing of certain facilities.

title: CUOMO BUDGET IS EXPECTED TO CALL FOR 2 NEW PRISONS
description: Governor Cuomo will propose building two new state prisons, to accommodate a total of 1,400 inmates, in the budget plan he will present Tuesday, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M.'S NEXT MOVE
description: IT will be the best of computers; it will be the worst of computers. It will have a powerful new chip; it will have a feeble old chip. It will wipe out the clone makers; it will merely inconvenience them. It will be announced this month; it will be announced this spring.

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $300,000, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of the company's computer graphics division. c-Net loss and after a loss of $80,000 in the computer graphics division.

title: IMMUCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $86,025 for the quarter and $188,214 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After a tax credit of $3,300.

title: INDIA HOPES TO SPEED VERDICT ON BHOPAL
description: The Indian Government, bolstered by a recent decision by the nation's highest court on a chemical leak in New Delhi, has adopted a novel legal strategy that lawyers say could force an early verdict against the Union Carbide Corporation in the lawsuit over the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paul Kalmanovitz, 81; Owned Pabst Brewing
description: Paul Kalmanovitz, owner of the Pabst Brewing Company and several other breweries and a prominent figure in the beer industry for more than 40 years, died at his home here Saturday after a long illness. day. He was 81 years old.

title: Classes at S.I. School Canceled After Fire
description: A fire set by vandals at a Staten Island high school has forced the cancellation of classes today, the city's Board of Education reported yesterday.
