title: EAGLE BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company became public in March 1986.

title: INLAND VACUUM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DR. KOOP WARNS OF SPREAD OF AIDS
description: Nearly 100 million people worldwide could die from AIDS by the end of the century if a cure or vaccine is not found, Dr. Everett C. Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, said today.

title: Goodyear's Shares Top Tender Offer
description: Shareholders of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company tendered more than 85.2 million shares under the company's offer to buy back up to 40 million common shares at $50 each, Goodyear said. The tender offer expired at midnight Friday, and because the number of shares tendered exceeded the buyback offer, some shares will not be accepted. Goodyear said it would determine a prorating factor for returning those shares. Goodyear's stock closed today at $44 a share, up $1, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $152,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $294,000 for the quarter and $450,000 for the 9 months.

title: FCS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
HAMMOND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company revised its estimates used to calculate deferred loan sale premiums for loans originating in the current fiscal year, resulting in increased net income of $292,000, or 13 cents a share, in the latest quarter.

title: U.S. MIGHT SEEK CONSECUTIVE TERMS IN HIJACKING
description: A senior Justice Department official said today that the department might seek consecutive prison sentences for a Lebanese man accused of hijacking an American jetliner in 1985 and killing an American passenger.

title: LONG WAIT ENDS FOR BILL ARD'S FATHER
description: From this week forward, no one will be able to laugh at the sense of timing of Bill Ard Sr., a Giant fan and the president of a real-estate appraisal firm in northern New Jersey. His loyalty has taken the form of a season ticket since 1964, when the last of the reserved bleacher seats at Yankee Stadium were sold on a season basis.

title: MUSIC: BOLCOM AND MORRIS
description: IN their recorded anthologies of American popular song, the husband-wife team of William Bolcom and Joan Morris have winningly presented vernacular music as light classical concert music distinguished from its European counterpart by the absorption of Afro-American influences.

title: MAKING MATHEMATICS FUN AGAIN
description: THE scene: a grocery store.

title: Toyota, Nissan See Export Fall
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's largest car makers, said today that their exports fell in 1986 because of the Japanese yen's rise against the United States dollar, which made Japanese cars more expensive abroad.

title: Spencer Charged With Murder
description: Brian Spencer, who played for the Islanders in the 1970's, was arrested in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday and charged with murder and kidnapping in the death of a man five years ago. Spencer, 37 years old, was charged with the murder of Michael James Dalfo, who was found on a roadway on Feb. 4, 1982. The victim had been shot through the head, according to the police in West Palm Beach.

title: Trial's Site Ordered Changed In Killing of a Drug Witness
description: A state district judge ordered the trial of three Colombian nationals accused of killing a key government drug prosecution witness moved to another city after a futile week of jury selection.

title: Selling Amtrak Northeast Line Is Still a Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST MICHIGAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results include the acquisition of FMB State Savings Bank, completed Dec. 29, 1986, on a pooling of interest basis.

title: NEW CENTURY ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax benefit of $56,000. c-Net income and includes tax benefits of $177,000 for the quarter and $513,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter results were adversely affected by a $1,055,000 writedown of film costs.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings for 1985 are determined since the bank's conversion on Feb. 21, 1985.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Airborne Pollutants
description: Twice as much airborne pollution is deposited above 3,000 feet in the Appalachian Mountains as in lowland areas, two Yale University geochemists have found. Dr. William C. Graustein, an associate research scientist, and Dr. Karl K. Turekian, chairman of geology and geophysics, also found that 40 percent to 60 percent of the pollutants came from the lowest layer of the atmosphere and were, therefore, more likely to be deposited within 50 miles to 100 miles of where they originated.

title: HOME FEDERAL BANK OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $202,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months.

title: Chief Resigns At Activision
description: James H. Levy has resigned from his positions as chairman, president and chief executive of Activision Inc., a maker of software for video game machines and home computers, the company said today.

title: Bridge: Knockout Final at Regional Reverses Last Year's Result
description: The final of the Tri-State Regional Knockout Team Championship played Saturday in Port Chester, N.Y., proved to be a rematch of the 1986 event, but with a different result.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax benefit of $289,000.

title: WALLACE'S SUCCESSOR USHERS IN CONSERVATIVE ERA
description: Of all those elected to major state offices in Alabama last fall, only the new Governor, Guy Hunt, is a Republican. But as he and the rest of the new administration were sworn in today, ending the long era of the populist coalition brought together under Gov. George C. Wallace, the theme of the day was so pro-business they all sounded Republican.

title: Railroad's Net Declines 36.8%
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said today that its earnings fell 36.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1986 from a year earlier, and for all of last year the railroad holding company had a loss of $860.5 million. For the three months ended

title: CONTRA ARMS CREWS SAID TO SMUGGLE DRUGS
description: Federal drug investigators uncovered evidence last fall that the American flight crews covertly ferrying arms to the Nicaraguan rebels were smuggling cocaine and other drugs on their return trips to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: ALLWASTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company recently went public Dec. 5.

title: DR. MAX J. ROUTTENBERG
description: Dr. Max J. Routtenberg, former rabbi of Temple B'nai Sholom of Rockville Centre, L.I., died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Working Oil Rigs Drop
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped this week to 886, down 30 from last week, officials of the Hughes Tool Company said today. Last week's rig count of 916 was down 46 from the previous week. ''This is a period of seasonal decline,'' Ike Kerridge, keeper of the rig count, said. ''I think we'll see a decline for another six weeks or so.'' Last year at this time, the count totaled 1,773, Hughes officials said.

title: VOLCANIC SCENARIO
description: LAST August a flood of water mixed with toxic gases overflowed Lake Nyos in the Cameroon and swept into the valleys below, leaving more than 1,700 people dead and destroying crops. British scientists who have examined the lake have now come up with a probable scenario of how volcanic gases caused the disaster.

title: Advertising; Publisher Set at Time Magazine
description: REGINALD BRACK JR., the new chief of the Time Inc. magazine operation, announced further changes in the operation yesterday. The most important shifts are the naming of Richard B. Thomas to the new position of top advertising sales executive in the group and Robert L. Miller to replace him as publisher of Time magazine, the company's flagship publication.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,428,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $450,000 for the quarter and $1,465,000 for the 9 months.

title: No. 1 Iowa Beats Purdue
description: Kevin Gamble scored 19 points, including the go-ahead basket with 3 minutes 58 seconds left tonight, and undefeated Iowa held off Purdue, 70-67, in Big Ten basketball. Iowa, 17-0 and named No. 1 in

title: VACATIONS TO GO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $16,000. c-Net loss

title: 1,000 CHINESE IN U.S. ENDORSE A PROTEST
description: As many as a thousand Chinese nationals studying in American colleges and universities have now endorsed an open letter to the leadership in Beijing voicing concern over the removal of Hu Yaobang as the Communist Party leader and the disciplining of Chinese intellectuals.

title: SHOE CITY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings are fully diluted. The company said effective July 1, it adopted the FASB new pension accounting requirements and this change increased both the latest third and fourth quarters' results by about 4 cents a share and 8 cents a shares, respectively.

title: SALOMON EXPECTS DROP IN 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Salomon Inc., one of the nation's major investment banking houses, said yesterday that it expected its fourth-quarter earnings to fall about 40 percent, to $80 million, from $132 million in the comparable period in 1985.

title: BRYN MAWR TRUST CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The bank, on Jan. 2, was reorganized with the formation of a bank holding company, Bryn Mawr Bank Corp., having Bryn Mawr Trust as its wholly owned subsidiary. Each share of Bryn Mawr Trust stock was converted into three shares of the holding company's stock. Per share earnings have been retroactively restated to reflect the stock conversion.

title: KINGS AND RANGERS BATTLE TO A 2-2 TIE
description: After four days off, with their coach back with them to stay, the Rangers returned to playing hockey tonight. They were at times impressive, but they were matched by the Los Angeles Kings and the clubs finished in a 2-2 tie.

title: FOR CONNOISSEURS: A FLOOR OF ENGLISH COLLECTIBLES
description: Known for years as one of the city's best places to ferret out English antiques, Kentshire Galleries has unveiled the Collector's Gallery, a 3,000-square-foot space on the third floor of the loft building at 37 East 12th Street that the company has occupied for 10 years.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $6.2 million, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $14.9 million for the year. c-Includes a credit of $900,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $5.6 million and a gain of $20.1 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the year.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $497,000 for the quarter and $592,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and includes gains from discontinued operations of $462,000 for the quarter and $788,000 for the 6 months, and gains on disposal of $461,000 and $1,157,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $16,770 and $61,064 for the latest year and year- ago period, respectively, and the year-ago period also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,577. The company reported no revenue for the prior fiscal year.

title: JOHN VAN ANTWERP FINE
description: John Van Antwerp Fine, Ewing Professor Emeritus of Greek Languages and Literature at Princeton University, died Saturday at a nursing home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: BHA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOTIVATIONS OF SURROGATE MOTHERS
description: WOMEN who choose to become surrogate mothers have motivations ranging from selflessness to egocentricity, from guilt to joy, according to the handful of researchers who have studied them.

title: Stonewalling by Any Other Name
description: Debate over the Iran-contra affair has turned down a blind alley: Should President Reagan apologize or not? Almost daily, some responsible legislator or another calls for the President to acknowledge his errors, as if a little contrition would cleanse the deeds and put the matter to rest. It won't. Only facts and hard truths will, and these are still not readily forthcoming from the White House. By incompetence or design, the Administration seems to have perfected a new kind of resistance, stonewalling in motion.

title:
WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING;
Health and Kennedy
description: LEAD: Although a devoted cigar-smoker, Senator Edward M. Kennedy tries to heed staff advice to restrain himself when he is before the television cameras, not least because health advocates feel it does not present a good role model.

title: BROODING IDOLS EVOKE AN ANCIENT NICARAGUA
description: A collection of massive stone idols carved by Indians as long as 1,000 years ago has quietly gone on display in this stately colonial town.

title: K-Car Package Set by Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation has an America version of its K-cars waiting in case the American Motors Corporation does not reach an agreement with labor that would let it build Chrysler's Omni and Horizon models, the Automotive News has reported. Members of the United Automobile Workers at A.M.C.'s Kenosha, Wis., plant on Saturday refused to reopen their contract to negotiate changes that A.M.C. says it needs to get the Chrysler contract to build the Omni and Horizon.

title: What an Extravagance!
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVANCED PROFESSIONAL SALES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $181,000. The company said the year-ago first quarter results reflect the operations of Tin Box Co. of America and its affiliate only, treated for accounting purposes as the acquiring company. description: For three Giants in particular, this is a time of reflection, when past disappointments are reclassified as learning experiences and a trip to the Super Bowl is the testimonial dinner most players never receive. Harry Carson, Brad Benson and George Martin have spent a total of 32 years wearing blue and white, more often than not leaving the field at twilight on a Sunday afternoon, on the short end of the final score.

title: Harrah Retires as Player
description: Toby Harrah, a three-time American League all-star, announced his retirement as a player yesterday and said he would manage the Texas Rangers' rookie league farm club. The 38-year-old Harrah, who played the last two years with the Rangers, will manage the Gulf Coast Rangers, a Gulf Coast League team that will play at Port Charlotte, Fla.

title: SPAIN TELEPHONE STOCK
description: Telefonica, Spain's telephone company, plans to place its shares on the New York Stock Exchange next June. A company spokesman, Alberto Martinez, said there would be 45 million shares valued at about $300 million and representing 5 percent of the company's capital. Foreign ownership in Telefonica is limited to 25 percent. The Government owns 31.5 percent and private investors the rest.

title: Bucks Sign Webster
description: The Milwaukee Bucks yesterday signed the veteran 7-foot-1-inch center, Marvin Webster, to a 10-day contract. The 34-year-old Webster had been playing with Pensacola in the Continental Basketball Association, where he was averaging 11 points a game. If Milwaukee decides to sign Webster to a standard National Basketball Association contract for the rest of the season, it would have to reach an agreement with the Knicks, Webster's last N.B.A. team, a spokesman for the Bucks said.

title: Minor Earthquake Reported In Area of San Francisco Bay
description: A minor earthquake struck the southern San Francisco Bay area today, but it caused no damage or injury, officials said.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Prelate Is Asked by Nicaragua
description: The Nicaraguan Embassy here said today that Ambassador Carlos Tunnerman would ask the United States to investigate the assault in Miami on Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: RACIAL VIOLENCE A FOCUS AS DR. KING IS HONORED
description: Marches in a frigid rain, solemn memorial services in houses of worship, cultural programs and speeches against racial violence yesterday culminated the observance in the New York metropolitan region of the holiday that marks the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A common thread running through most of the observances was the attack last month on three black men by white youths in Howard Beach, Queens. One of the blacks, Michael Griffith, was killed when a car struck him as he fled his pursuers.

title: HAZY MAZE OF BUTTONS
description: HYPERTEXT, billed by its enthusiasts as the ultimate in word processing, is one of those ''Now you see it, now you don't'' concepts so common at the technological perimeters of our culture. Ted Nelson, who coined the word, envisioned it as the computerization of everything ever written and to be written. But even he can't seem to come up with a clear definition of hypertext, usually relying instead on a 5,000-word celebration of its wonders.

The manufacturer of papers, newsprint and other wood products attributed the earnings gain to improved business conditions and internal cost-cutting.

description: Everybody, a nice round of applause for John Cardinal O'Connor and the Israeli leaders. Between them they managed recently to destroy two old stereotypes about people and that of course is always healthy.

title: WHERE SUPER BOWL SEEMS TO BE TAKEN IN STRIDE
description: A steady trickle of excited visitors has made a pilgrimage to the empty Rose Bowl in recent days, just for a glimpse of the still-quiet field where, on Sunday, the Giants and Broncos will battle in Super Bowl XXI. Few of the visitors have been Pasadenans.

title: Surrogate Motherhood: A Bad Idea
description: LEAD: The struggle being played out in a New Jersey courtroom over the fate of Baby M., born of a surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, is uniquely melodramatic. The husbands of other such mothers, so far as we know, have not had to flee out the back door to another state to keep the police from taking a child contractually promised to another couple, in this case William and Elizabeth

title: 'CONSERVATIVES' STUDIES HISTORY OF A MOVEMENT
description: HOW did conservatives come to loom so large on the political landscape? By persevering, ''The Conservatives'' says; out of obscurity and a certain amount of scorn, conservatives came to inherit, if not the earth, at least a large piece of the Republican Party. The knowledgeable documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, traces the history of a movement.

description: The Mellon Bank Corporation yesterday reported a 65.3 percent drop in fourth-quarter net income, to $15.6 million, from $45 million in the corresponding 1985 quarter. On a per-share basis, net income fell to 42 cents, from $1.57.

title: USX-LED PRICE CUT EXPECTED
description: In the wake of a tentative agreement between the United Steelworkers and the USX Corporation, industry analysts are widely predicting that steel prices will decline by up to 5 percent once the nation's largest steelmaker resumes production in its idled plants.

description: Ajai Singh Mehta, the publishing director of Pan Books Ltd. in London, has been named president and editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf. Mr. Mehta, widely known as Sonny, will succeed Robert A. Gottlieb, who next month will become the editor of The New Yorker magazine.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday about air safety proposals after a collision near Salt Lake City referred incorrectly to a plane involved in a 1984 collision near San Luis Obispo, Calif. The private plane that collided with a Wings West commuter airliner in that accident was a single-engine piston-powered Rockwell Commander, not a jet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 7 about Myrtle Allen, co-owner of Ballymaloe House in Ireland, misstated the tax rate for Irish restaurant bills. It is 10 percent.

description: Commuters who normally ride the Long Island Rail Road to work drove, flew, sailed and bused to Manhattan today and generally found the going not quite as tough as they had expected.

title: JAPAN MINISTER RUSHING TO U.S. ON DOLLAR'S FALL
description: At the end of a day when the dollar plunged again, the Treasury Department said tonight that Japan's Finance Minister would fly to Washington to meet with Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday.

title: Broadway Gets 'Coastal Disturbances'
description: The Circle in the Square Theater announced yesterday that it will present the Second Stage production of ''Coastal Disturbances,'' beginning Feb. 14.

title: SHV Cuts Pretoria Tie
description: SHV, a Dutch-based multinational company plagued by anti-apartheid arson attacks in the Netherlands, announced today that it would halt business operations in South Africa. SHV, which owns a 40 percent interest in five Makro department stores in South Africa and has a coal trading office in Johannesburg, is the first major Dutch company to pull out of South Africa.

title: Cocoa Rules Discussed
description: Cocoa-trading nations decided unanimously today to bring into force on Tuesday a new agreement to stabilize prices, said Kelvin Scott, spokesman for the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. Delegates said the accord, negotiated last July to defend minimum and maximum prices for cocoa, would not operate immediately, as rules for intervention in the market had not yet been settled.

description: H.F. Holdings Inc., a San Francisco company headed by Preston Martin, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it had been chosen by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to negotiate to acquire two failed California thrift institutions.

title: Hot-Dogs and Robbery
description: A 37-year-old man was charged with holding up a savings and loan institution using a package of hot-dogs as a ruse. The police said the suspect, Murshin A. Rahman, told a bank teller at a branch of the Broadview Savings and Loan Saturday that his briefcase contained a bomb. The teller gave him about $2,400.

title:
WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING;
Toward a Better Budget?
description: LEAD: A year-old group called the League of Concerned Citizens says individual Americans can produce a better budget than the White House and Congress, and it is putting together a nationwide network to do just that.

title: G.O.P. TO PRESS CUOMO ON TAX CUTS
description: New York State Republicans plan to push for larger tax cuts this year than Governor Cuomo has proposed, partly to keep him occupied with state matters as he is making critical decisions on a possible Presidential candidacy.

title: Bonn to Sell VEBA Stake
description: The West German Government, confident of support for its economic policies just a week before a general election, announced today that it would sell off its 25.6 percent stake in the giant industrial group VEBA in March. The state hopes to receive about 3 billion marks, or $1.7 billion, from the sale to the public of its holding in VEBA, an energy and chemicals company. The sale would be one of the largest ever on the West German capital market.

title: RODMAN & RENSHAW CAPITAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Greg Foster's time for the 60-meter high hurdles in the Sunkist Invitational, at first announced as a world indoor record, will not be submitted for recognition because of a false start.

title: VERSATILITY IN A WRAP HANDMADE IN KENYA
description: ''I don't want to tell Americans how to wear these things - I want them to tell me.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPANISH CIVIL WAR The problem of keeping history alive has been tackled in fiction, film, art and personal recollection, but rarely do these approaches match the vividness of recall that is found in photography. A visit to the new exhibition at the International Center for Photography's Midtown premises, in International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street (536-6443), serves as evidence.

title: 14-3 and Talking
description: Although he has one of the better basketball squads in the Southwest or the West, Coach Jim Killingsworth of Texas Christian University is taking nothing for granted concerning a place in the 64-team N.C.A.A. tournament. Last year T.C.U. finished 22-9 but was snubbed by the selection committee and had to settle for the National Invitation Tournament. This year Killingsworth is calling attention to his cause. When his Horned Frogs, now 14-3, beat Oklahoma last month, he said, ''I wonder if the N.C.A.A. computer heard about this one.''

title: Olivetti in Venture
description: The Italian computer giant Olivetti S.A. and Japan's Canon Group have announced a joint venture to produce laser printers and copying machines. The companies said the venture, Olivetti-Canon Italy, is aimed at conquering the copier market in Europe.

title: STATE BANKS IN BID FOR POWERS
description: The New York State Banking Department is being asked to decide whether to permit subsidiaries of state-chartered banks to underwrite securities.

title: SNIPER TERRORIZES AREA OF NORTHEN RHODE ISLAND
description: When night falls here, people draw their curtains tight, forgo their after-dinner walks and let frightened children sleep in their parents' beds.

description: When the man with the square jaw and blue blazer sauntered into the city garage shortly after 7 A.M. today, the plow operators and the truckers all knew who he was. A lot of them had met him before and many had even voted for him once.

title: POSSIBLE JAPANESE STRATEGIES

description: Sweden's Catarina Lindqvist upset third-seeded Pam Shriver to advance to the women's semifinals of the $1.65 million Australian Open tennis championships today.

title: HAWAII'S IMPOSING VOLCANOES: STILL POWERFUL BUT LESS DEADLY
description: ''Landslides were numerous and precipices fell thundering into the sea. The earth rent in a thousand places; fissures opened from one inch to six, eight and ten as unexpected breadth. The streets and fields of Hilo cracked, and seams opened all around us, where we had supposed that volcanic forces had long ago left their final traces.''

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in April 1986, and year-ago results are not available. The company said the losses were anticipated and resulted, in part, from expenses associated with its initial public offering and development costs related to its new diaper products; the decrease in sales resulted primarily from discontinuance of the company's franchise program and changes in its phototherapy sales.

title: SPAIN RELUCTANTLY GIVES PICASSO WORKS TO FRANCE
description: Sixty-one paintings and sculptures from the private collection of Pablo Picasso - many of them works that show the often overlooked Spanishness of the artist -are being returned to France after Spain decided it could not keep them.

description: The jury that convicted one defendant in the 1981 slaying of a New Jersey state trooper deadlocked at 7 to 5 in favor of acquitting the other defendant, Richard C. Williams, according to one of the jurors.

description: A bartender at the Dupont Plaza Hotel committed suicide Saturday, three days before he was to be questioned about the New Year's Eve fire at the hotel that killed 96 people. However, he was not listed as a suspect, an official said today.

title: Knight Meets With Orioles
description: Ray Knight and his agent, George Kalafatis, met with Hank Peters, general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, for about two hours yesterday. The Orioles need a third baseman and offered Knight a one-year contract for about $425,000. Knight, who rejected the Mets' $800,000 offer last month, asked for two years, and they discussed the possibility of a second year that would be triggered by the number of games Knight started.

title: Dance Magazine Names Five Award Winners

title: EXCERPTS FROM REGULATIONS TO CARRY OUT NEW LAW ON ALIENS
description: Following are excerpts from Part 274A and Section 245A.1 of regulations drafted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to carry out the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. Part 274A deals with aliens' eligibility for legal employment. Section 245A.1 concerns the establishment of legal residency by aliens who have been in the United States since Jan. 1, 1982. 274A.2 (a) Aliens authorized employment incident to status. The following classes of aliens are authorized to be employed in the United States as a condition of their admission or subsequent change of status to one of the indicated classes, and specific authorization need not be requested: (1) For an alien admitted or subsequently changed to one of the followng classifications, employment authorization is not restricted as to the specific employer or workplace while in this status: (i) A lawful permanent resident alien; (ii) An alien admitted to the United States as a conditional permanent resident pursuant to Sections 245A or 210 of the Act; (iii) An alien admitted to the United States for temporary residence; (iv) An alien admitted to the United States as a refugee for the period of time in that status; (v) An alien paroled into the United States as a refugee for the period of time in that status; (vi) An alien granted asylum under section 208 of the Act for the period of time in that status; (vii) An alien admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant fiance or fiancee for the period of admission to the United States . . . ; (viii) An alien granted withholding of deportation; (ix) An alien who is a member of a nationality group granted extended voluntary departure. (2) For an alien admitted or subsequently changed to one of the following classifications, employment authorization is restricted and limited as to the specific employer or workplace: (i) A foreign government official (A-1), or (A-2). An alien in this status may only be employed for the foreign government agency. (ii) An employee of a foreign government official (A-3). An alien in this status may only be employed for the foreign government official. (iii) A nonimmigrant visitor for business (B-1). An alien in this status may only be employed for the foreign employer. (iv) A nonimmigrant crewman (D-1). An alien in this status may only be employed on the vessel or aircraft of arrival, or on a vessel or aircraft of the same line. (v) A nonimmigrant treaty trader or investor (E-1), or (E-2). (vi) A nonimmigrant (F-1) student. An alien in this status may only be employed, without permission of the Service, for part-time on-campus employment. (vii) A representative of an international organization (G-1), (G-2), (G-3), or (G-4). An alien in this status may only be employed by the foreign government or the international organization. (viii) A personal servant of an employee or representative of an international organization (G-5). An alien in this status may only be employed by the employee or representative of the international organization. (ix) A temporary worker or trainee (H-1), (H-2) or (H-3). An alien in this status may only be employed by the petitioner and for period during which the petition is valid. (x) A temporary agricultural worker (H-2A). An alien in this status may only be employed by the petitioner and for the period of time during which the petition is valid. (xi) An information media representative (I). An alien in this status may only be employed for the foreign news agency or bureau. (xii) An exchange visitor (J-1). An alien in this status may only be employed within the specific program and time period for this admitted. (xiii) An intra-company transferee (L-1). An alien in this status may only be employed by the petitioner and for the period during which petition is valid. (b) Aliens who must apply for work authorization. Any alien within a class of aliens described in this section may apply for work authorization to the district director in whose district the alien resides: (1) Any alien maintaining a lawful nonimmigrant status in one of the following classes may be granted permission to be employed: (i) Alien spouse or unmarried dependent son or daughter of a foreign government official . . . or the dependent of an employee of a foreign government official. . . . ... (ii) A nonimmigrant (F-1) student as provided in Sec. 214.2(f) of this chapter. (Off-campus employment is prohibited during the first year of study in the United States.) ... (iii) Alien spouse or an unmarried dependent son or daughter of an officer or employee of an international organization (G-4) as provided in Sec. 214.2(g) of this chapter. (iv) Alien spouse or minor child of an exchange visitor (J-2) as provided in Sec. 214.2(j) of this chapter. (v) A nonimmigrant (M-1) student may only be authorized employment for practical training as provided in Sec. 214.2(m) of this chapter. (Practical training may only be authorized after completion of the student's course of study.) ... (2) Any alien who has filed a nonfrivolous application for asylum pursuant to Part 208 of this chapter may be granted permission to be employed. (3) Any alien who has properly filed an application for adjustment of status to permanent resident alien may be granted permission to be employed. (4) Any alien paroled into the United States temporarily for emergent reasons or for reasons deemed strictly in the public interest: Provided, the alien establishes an economic need to work. (5) Any alien who has applied to an immigration judge under Sec. 242.17 of this chapter for suspension of deportation pursuant to section 244(a) of the Act may be granted permission to be employed: Provided, the alien establishes an economic need to work. ... 274.3 (b) Individual's Application for Employment. Form I-9 must be prepared by individuals entering employment, and by individuals recruited for a fee or referred for a fee prior to recruitment or referral for employment in the United States. (1) An individual must provide biographical information on the Form I-9 and attest under penalty of perjury that he/she is: (i) a citizen or national of the United States; or (ii) an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence or an alien who is authorized under the Immigration and Nationality Act or by the Attorney General to work in the United States. (2) An individual must provide documents identified in subsection (c) to the employer, recruiter or referrer for the purpose of establishing his/her identity and employment authorization. ... (c) Acceptable Documents. The individual may present either a document which establishes both employment authorization and identity as defined in Sec. 274A(b)(1)(B) of the Act, or an original document which establishes employment authorization as defined in 274A(b)(1)(C) and a separate original document which establishes identity. . . . (1) The following are acceptable documents to establish both identity and employment authorization: (A) United States passport. (B) Certificate of Citizenship, issued by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. (C) U.S. Citizen Identification Card, issued by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. (D) Certificate of Naturalization. (E) An unexpired foreign passport which: (a) contains an unexpired stamp therein which reads, ''processed for I-551. . .'' or (b) has attached thereto a Form I-94 in the same name (with identical biographic information) on which is an employment authorization stamp so long as the period of endorsement has not yet expired and the proposed employment is not in conflict with any restrictions or limitations identified on the Form I-94. (F) An Alien Registration Card, provided that it contains a photograph of the bearer. (G) An unexpired Work Permit, issued by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. (2) The following are acceptable documents to establish employment authorization: (A) Social Security account number card . . . (other than such a card which specifies on the face that the issuance of the card does not authorize employment in the United States). (B) A certificate of birth in any state. . . . (C) Report of U.S. Citizen Birth Abroad. . . . (D) Form I-94 with employment authorization stamp. (3) The following are acceptable documents for the purpose of establishing identity of the individual: (A) An original driver's license issued by any state which (i) bears a photograph of the individual, or (ii) contains personal identifying information which, at a minimum, includes his/her full name, date of birth, height, weight, color of eyes, and residence address. (B) An original identity document issued by any state for the purpose of identification which either (i) bears a photograph of the individual, or (ii) contains personal identifying information which at a minimum includes his/her full name, date of birth, height, weight, color of eyes, and residence address. (C) In the case of individuals residing in a state which does not provide for issuance of an identification document (other than a driver's license). the following: (i) Notice of discharge from the U.S. Armed Forces. (ii) Document evidencing active duty or reserve status in the U.S. Armed Forces. (d) Examination of documents and attestation of employer, recruiter or referrer.

title: SERIOUS COMMUTER TIE-UPS FEARED
description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and 11 unions met yesterday for the first time since the line was struck, but any optimism about an early end to the walkout soon faded.

title: SHELLING BY IRANIANS CAUSING MANY TO FLEE BASRA
description: The relentless Iranian shelling of the southern Iraqi port city of Basra has led to the exodus of much of its population of one million, the first time that so many of its people are said to have fled, according to American officials, military analysts and diplomats closely following the war.

title: BRITISH TO SUPPLY NATO SATELLITES
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. and Marconi have won a $136 million contract to supply two military communications satellites to NATO, The Financial Times has reported. The first of the satellites, known as the NATO-4 series, is to be launched in 1990 aboard the United States space shuttle, the paper said. The designs, which are based on Britain's Skynet-4 military communications satellites, have not been tested in orbit.

description: A number of Las Vegas sports books yesterday were quoting a Super Bowl spread as high as 10 points, giving the Giants equal stature with last year's Chicago Bears, at least in the minds of the wagering public. title: DOLLAR'S PLUNGE UNCHECKED
description: The dollar was battered again yesterday in foreign-exchange markets, closing well below Friday's levels in spite of new signs that West Germany and Japan might be about to cut their interest rates.

title: Snyder's of Hanover Picks Martin Agency
description: Snyder's of Hanover, a snack food company based in Hanover, Pa., has named the Martin Agency of Richmond to handle its account. The agency has already begun work on a regional print campaign.

title: BARYSHNIKOV IS INVITED BY BOLSHOI TO DANCE AGAIN IN SOVIET UNION
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, the Russian ballet star whose defection in 1974 stunned the dance world, has been invited to return to the Soviet Union to dance as a guest at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet said here yesterday.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Ordeal of Maputo
description: A senior Mozambican official answered the general question about his country's direction with a wry smile. ''What you in the West used to say about us was never quite right, and what you're saying now isn't quite right either,'' he said.

title: IMMIGRATION RULES TO ASK NEW PROOF FROM JOB SEEKERS
description: Employers across the country will have to verify the citizenship status of all new employees, Americans and aliens, within 24 hours after they are hired, under rules drawn up by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Faust Got I-A, Huggins Got Zip
description: Largely overlooked amid the national publicity given Akron University's hiring of Gerry Faust to head the football program last year was the damaging effect that it might have on the Zips' successful basketball program. The chickens are now coming home to roost, and the school's administration has one unmistakably dismayed coach on its hands.

title: Ciba-Geigy Plans Venture in China
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G., Switzerland's biggest chemical and pharmaceuticals company, said it plans to begin production in China in 1989 with a large local manufacturer, the Beijing General Pharmaceuticals Corporation. The initial capital investment for the venture will be the equivalent of $12 million at current exchange rates, according to a Ciba-Geigy statement.

title: JOHNSON'S 42 POINTS OVERWHELM NETS
description: When the afternoon was over, Magic Johnson talked mostly about the third period, about how he had simply decided that the game would be won or lost at that point, that he might have to place the burden of the offense on his own shoulders.

title: Pravda Editor Faults Visa Delay
description: Viktor G. Afanasyev, the editor of Pravda, today criticized delays on applications for emigration, saying that they created negative publicity abroad.

description: The Ford Motor Company will top the industry leader, the General Motors Corporation, in profits in 1986 and in the next two years, analysts interviewed by an industry trade journal predicted.

LED F.B.I. OFFICE IN NEW YORK
description: John F. Malone, head of the regional F.B.I. office in New York from 1962 to 1975, died of a stroke last Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Carbondale, Pa. He was 76 years old and had lived in Carbondale since his retirement in 1975.

description: COLLECTORS will remember the original Vienna Octet, an ensemble that made several splendid disks for London in the 1950's. A younger group assumed the name in 1973, and the new Vienna Octet's recital on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall offered eloquent proof that the tradition lives on.

description: Prof. Pedro Cuatrecasas, an American biochemist, and Prof. Meir Wilchek of the Weizmann Institute in Israel have been awarded the Wolf Prize for medicine, the prize foundation announced today.

title: SEARCH FOR ANTIMATTER IS SHOWING RESULTS
description: HALF a century after the discovery of the baffling, rare stuff known as antimatter, scientists are beginning to collect it in minuscule amounts, creating a wave of excitement around the world as they explore its nature and applications and redouble their efforts to find it in the heavens.

description: After meeting yesterday for nearly three hours with John Cardinal O'Connor, Jewish leaders changed their critical assessment of his visit to the Middle East and said the trip represented ''a helpful contribution toward greater understanding'' between Catholics and Jews.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: Q. Will an alcoholic drink keep you warm in cold weather? A.Alcohol dilates the blood vessels, which causes a brief sensation of warmth as the blood rushes to the skin, according to Dr. Roger Maickel, professor of pharmocology at Purdue University. This effect causes many people to flush when they drink. After the initial warmth, however, the body starts to lose heat through the dilated vessels. The body's normal response to cold is to constrict the blood vessels to retain heat, Dr. Maickel said. Thus, in cold weather, alcohol has an adverse effect. Q. Why do raccoons wash their food? A. Scientists do not know why raccoons dip their food in water before eating it, according to Dr. Sidney Anderson, curator of mammalogy at the American Museum of Natural History. Dr. Anderson, who has observed this behavior in the wild, said that the raccoon is probably not washing its food but rather ''manually handling'' it with its forepaws. The effort is not to clean the food since the water may be dirtier than the food, he said. Raccoons who find themselves away from water rub their food in the dust or just in their paws before eating, he added. However, most raccoons feed near the water, and those in captivity have been known to dip their food in their water bowl.

Three years later, he began publishing a photocopied fashion magazine, Key, which led to his becoming a fashion stylist and a feisty fashion columnist, taking swipes at Seventh Avenue in New York Talk. When that tabloid suspended publication recently, Mr. S. formed his own ''image'' company, Form.

title: RECITAL: LUCILLE FIELD, SINGER
description: THE soprano Lucille Field chose a program of unusual interest for her Saturday evening recital at Merkin Concert Hall. Entitled ''Songs: With Women in Mind,'' the program contained not only repertory classics such as Beethoven's ''Adelaide,'' Schubert's ''Lied der Mignon'' and Richard Strauss's ''Cacilie'' but also several songs by Josephine Lang, a German composer of the 19th century who studied with Felix Mendelssohn, and recent works by Nancy Van de Vate, Robert Starer, Miriam Gideon and Patsy Rogers.

title: Running Scared
description: Felix Alejandro Flores, a 30-year-old gym teacher and marathoner making his first trip outside his native Peru, arrived on a flight to Miami in the early morning 10 days ago. He fully expected to have plenty of time to find lodging and rest up before competing in the Orange Bowl Marathon the following day. Problem was, the race wasn't the following day. As Flores discovered while browsing through a newspaper at the airport coffee shop, it was that day -in fact, at that very hour.

title: A's to Sign Blue
description: Vida Blue, who broke into the major leagues with the A's in 1969, is returning to Oakland. The signing of the 37-year-old pitcher, who became a free agent after going 10-10 with the San Francisco Giants last season, will be formally announced today, a spokesman for the A's said. Another former A's star, Reggie Jackson, has also rejoined the team for next season.

title: Australian Trade Gap
description: Australia's trade deficit in December was the narrowest in eight months, the Government reported today.

title: CLEMENTS RETURNS AS TEXAS GOVERNOR
description: Bill Clements was once again sworn in today as Governor of Texas, facing what many believe will be the most painful era in the state's 150-year history.

title: P.& G. Offering Has 8 1/4% Yield
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is offering $200 million of 8 1/8 percent sinking-fund debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 98.625 to yield 8 1/4 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WINE TALK
description: MANFRED ROMMEL, the Mayor of Stuttgart, tells the story of a wine-loving student named Hegel, who became a philosopher of some repute. Hegel once turned up so drunk in the university town of Tubingen that his comrades hid him from his teachers. A prefect supposedly warned him, ''Hegel, you'll drink away that little bit of sense you've got left.''

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last April and another 2-for-1 stock split to be paid in February.

Model Assesses Routes Of Hazardous Shipments
description: More than 1.5 billion tons of hazardous materials are transported along the country's roads, rail lines and waterways each year, and both the tonnage and the number of truck accidents involving dangerous cargo are on the rise. In the growing debate over what routes these materials should follow through populated areas, industry often thinks in terms of economics while the public thinks in terms of safety.

title: BEN ALCOCK
description: Ben Alcock, retired executive vice president and director of creative services of Grey Advertising Inc., died Jan. 14 at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.

title: ELECTION EVE TALK WITH KOHL: SURE OF VICTORY AND ALL SMILES
description: Snugly ensconced in one chair, Helmut Kohl reached out with a long arm and dragged an empty one to him in a kind of half-embrace. ''I have been underestimated for decades,'' the West German Chancellor said with a big smile. ''I've done very well that way.''

The machine, which makes 62 copies a minute, uses a microprocessor as powerful as five personal computers. The 1065 sells for $23,095 and will be available by May.

title: CongressWASHINGTON TALK: CONGRESS; You're in the House; Now What to Do?
description: You can go for high visibility or low visibility, high risk or low, says the spiral-bound handbook of tips and advice for new members of the House of Representatives.

description: A senior Central Intelligence Agency official helped Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North begin the network to supply weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels three years ago, even as Congress moved to prohibit military assistance to them, according to a former senior rebel official and other sources.

title: Reruns of Reagan Speeches
description: The White House announced today that people who missed President Reagan's weekly Saturday radio speeches could call a recording of it later in the day, for a fee. Elizabeth Board, director of the White House television and radio office, announced plans for an experimental program in which the Presidential address will be available on a call-in basis from 12:30 P.M. to midnight, Eastern standard time.

title: UNSOLVED SLAYING OF A REPORTER IS FOCUS AS PHOENIX TRIAL OPENS
description: More than 10 years after Don Bolles, a Phoenix newspaper reporter, was killed by a bomb, a new courtroom drama began in the long-running case today, reminding this city that Mr. Bolles's murder is still unsolved.

title: SETON HALL SUFFERS 79-75 UPSET
description: Dana Barros scored 19 of his game-high 30 points in the second half to lead Boston College to a 79-75 come-from-behind victory over Seton Hall tonight in a Big East Conference game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Paying for Subways With Sky
description: If the Board of Estimate approves tomorrow, the immense Coliseum redevelopment project will be cleared to rise 700 feet above Columbus Circle and the public will be $455 million richer. That's what the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will get for the land. The public may also be poorer in a way that is harder to measure but more lasting in its effect. This project, at the southwest corner of Central Park, could overwhelm the skyline.

description: A Federal district judge today rejected a request by the American Medical Association and other groups for a restraining order to delay new rules forcing doctors to decide whether to participate in Medicare.

title: Comings and Goings

Henry, 6 feet 7 inches, was originally selected by Houston in the fourth round of the 1986 draft out of the University of California at Santa Barbara. He was waived by the Rockets Dec. 12 and had received two 10-day contracts from the Celtics this month. . . . Chris Washburn, the Golden State Warriors' 6-foot-11-inch rookie, will miss several games because of a kidney problem. Although he was a first-round draft pick, Washburn has averaged only 10 minutes of playing time.

description: New York City's Schools Chancellor will send a team of investigators today to look into what he called ''serious educational and administrative problems'' in an upper Manhattan school district that has been plagued by poor student performance and overcrowding.

description: Despite growing signs of interest by the Soviet Union in getting its troops out of Afghanistan, American officials and foreign diplomats said today that an early withdrawal seems unlikely unless the Afghan insurgents moderate their opposition to forming a coalition government acceptable to Moscow.

description: A dispatch on Jan. 7 from Tallahassee, Fla., about the induction of a new Governor misstated the party affiliation of the Florida Senate President.

description: President Chun Doo Hwan, acting to defuse a political crisis, dismissed his Interior Minister and his National Police Chief today after the Government's admission that the police had tortured a student to death.

title: Stuffing a Flank Steak
description: FLANK STEAK, also known as London broil, comes from the tail end of the loin. It is a relatively economical and lean cut of beef that lends itself exceptionally well to stuffing and braising. To save time, ask the butcher to trim all the fat from the flank steak. Follow the technique below for stuffing and trussing the steak and then brown it well on both sides in a high-sided pan. I usually make a stuffing with sausage, bread crumbs, onions and fresh herbs - about a pound of stuffing for a steak between one and three-quarter and two pounds. The stuffed steak can be braised slowly with tomatoes, onions, carrots and herbs. Served with potatoes and a salad, it makes a restorative cold-weather meal. STEP 1: With a long boning knife, make an incision into the periphery of the steak to form a pocket while leaving a 1-inch rim. STEP 2: Spoon the stuffing into the cavity and pack it evenly. STEP 3: Use kitchen twine to tie the steak securely in four or five spots. Season the outside well with salt and pepper. It is ready for braising.

title: The Wow! in the Dow
description: The dollar is plummeting, the trade accounts are a mess and every day the national debt grows by a half-billion dollars. But sobering news from Washington and Tokyo seems to have little impact on investors' enthusiasm. The Great January Rally has lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average by 11 percent, increasing the value of all traded stocks by an astounding $270 billion.

title: Bridge: Two Chinese Teams to Play For World Titles in Jamaica
description: When the 1987 world team championships begin in Jamaica in October, two Chinese teams will take part, representing their geographical zone. By winning the Far East Championship in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, last month, six players from Taiwan qualified to play in the Bermuda Bowl, in which they will be known, for political reasons, as Chinese Taipei.

title: THE SCREEN: 'THE HOUR OF THE STAR,' FROM BRAZIL
description: THE heroine of ''The Hour of the Star'' is a doomed innocent, a young woman so naive and unworldly that she is first seen wiping her nose on the collar of her blouse. She works as a typist in Rio de Janeiro, living in one cramped room with several roommates. Yet she is so lonely that she likes riding the subway, just for the sake of companionship. Part of what she enjoys on these train rides is the chance to stand next to men, with whom she otherwise has little contact. As a holdover from her sheltered girlhood, she still dresses and undresses under the bedcovers.

Night trading is seen by many members of the exchange as one way to attract business from the Far East.

title: A CRIME RISE SPURS BRAZIL LYNCH MOBS
description: During the wake for a taxi driver killed in late December in the western town of Amambai, word reached mourners that a murder suspect had been found. A few hours later, his bullet-riddled and mutilated body was dumped beside an outlying road. He was the victim of a lynch mob.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Zurbriggen Takes Giant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen rebounded from a disappointing weekend to win a World Cup giant slalom race yesterday in Adelboden, Switzerland, to widen his lead in the overall standing. The 23-year-old Zurbriggen posted his 24th World Cup victory in seven seasons on the circuit with a two-run total of 2 minutes 33.82 seconds. Second was Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland, who missed his fourth victory of the season by 61-hundredths of a second. Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden was third. Zurbriggen's victory increased his World Cup total to 221 points, adding 9 more points to his lead over Markus Wasmaier. Wasmaier, a West German, is second in the overall standing with 166.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Nordiques 3: Charlie Simmer scored two power-play goals as the Bruins won their third straight game at Quebec this season. Simmer got his 16th goal at 7:46 of the first period. His second of the game, at 11:08 of the middle period, made it 3-1. Thomas Gradin's eighth goal, a short-handed score at 14:10, gave the Bruins a 4-1 lead. Keith Crowder and Rick Middleton had Boston's other goals against Clint Malacrchuk, who faced only 17 shots.(AP) North Stars 5, Sabres 0: Don Beaupre stopped 27 shots for Minnesota's first shutout since last March and Dino Ciccarelli scored twice, leading Minnesota to victory. Beaupre, who earlier this season was in such a slump that he was put in the position to refuse the team's request that he go to the minors, recorded his third straight victory. He has allowed only four goals in those three games and has helped Minnesota take a 3-point lead over idle Detroit in the Norris Division. Beaupre, who has three career shutouts, was in net for Minnesota's last whitewash, a 4-0 victory over Edmonton last March 11. Ciccarelli scored the only goal Beaupre would need just 1:21 into the contest when he tipped a pass from Neal Broten past the Buffalo goaltender, Tom Barrasso. The North Stars made it 2-0 after one period when Broten faked a shot to draw Barrasso's attention and then passed to Kent Nilsson, who wristed a power-play goal into the open net. After Brian MacLellan's power-play goal made it 3-0, Ciccarelli took a goalmouth feed from Keith Acton and scored to tie Philadelphia's Tim Kerr for the league lead with 17 power-play goals. Ciccarelli has 35 goals and 63 points, both good for third in the league. (AP) N.B.A. Bulls 103, Bucks 90: Michael Jordan scored 14 of his 31 points in the final quarter and a reserve forward, Gene Banks, scored 8 critical points in the same period for Chicago. With the Bulls holding an 86-82 lead with 3:35 left, Banks scored on an offensive rebound and added a free throw for a 7-point Chicago advantage. Banks finished with a season-high 18 points. Jordan, who received several stitches inside his mouth after being hit by an elbow in the first quarter, then added two free throws and a field goal to put the game out of reach after Terry Cummings made two free throws for Milwaukee. Cummings had 27 points for the Bucks and Ricky Pierce added 17. In the final quarter, the Bulls did not score from the field for almost four minutes. Then Banks made a layup and a short jumper, Jordan had a reverse layup and John Paxson hit a layup to give Chicago an 81-74 edge with 6:49 remaining. (AP)

title: REPUBLIC BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The fourth quarter net includes a provision for loan losses of $53.5 million, which was in excess of net loan chargeoffs.

title: ART: UNEXPECTED JUXTAPOSITIONS IN THE MET'S NEW WING
description: ONE of the better-kept secrets around New York this last nine years has been the content of the forthcoming 20th-century wing at the Metropolitan Museum. To what extent would it rival, duplicate or usefully supplement the great quantities of 20th-century art already on view in New York's museums? Was it primarily a vanity operation, or had it something all its own to offer? Everyone was asking these questions, and nobody was telling. The answers were classified information, and we just had to go home and wait to see.

title: JUSTICES BAR A LAW LIMITING APPEALS MADE DOOR TO DOOR
description: The Supreme Court today struck down an Illinois city's ordinance barring all door-to-door soliciting before 9 A.M., after 5 P.M. and on Sundays and holidays, ruling it was a violation of the right to free speech.

title: A Latin Alliance Behind Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Merchants National said that seven bank acquisitions which were consummated during the fourth quarter of 1986 were accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: G.O.P. PANEL PICKS NEW ORLEANS AS THE SITE FOR 1988 CONVENTION
description: A Republican committee today recommended New Orleans, a city renowned for its jazz, Cajun cooking and wilting summer heat, as the site of the party's 1988 national convention.

title: BARGAINS IN BULK SHOPPING
description: THE New York area can be a bargain hunter's paradise for any cook. Everything from pounds of fresh, plump shrimp and exotic mushrooms to plastic pouches of turmeric and liters of extra-virgin olive oil can be found at a fraction of the prices typically charged in most retail shops and supermarkets.

title: Democratic Fits and Starts on Nuclear Testing
description: Early this month it looked as if the Democratic leaders in Congress had decided to make a big push on the issue of nuclear testing.

title: Murdoch Bid Is Topped
description: Rupert Murdoch's $1.5 billion bid for Australia's largest news group came under renewed pressure today as a rival company, John Fairfax Ltd., offered $1.63 billion for the Herald and Weekly Times. There was no immediate response from the Melbourne-based Herald, which had accepted Mr. Murdoch's offer of $9.75 a share, provided no other bidders came forth. Fairfax said it was seeking court action to prevent the transfer of Herald shares to Murdoch's News Corporation, which had previously won the support of the Queensland Press, the largest Herald shareholder. Last week, Mr. Murdoch overcame fierce competition from Australia's richest man, Robert Holmes a Court, with a compromise deal.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 26
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for the 5-percent stock dividend payable in March 1987.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $80.4 million and including a special pretax charge of $449.4 million related to the company's Illinois Central Gulf Railroad operations and its Pneumo Abex Corp. unit. c-Net income after a gain from discontinued operations of $4.7 million. The company said it accrued $6 million in investment tax credits through the first nine months of 1986, which were reversed in the fourth quarter by a charge against income, as a result of the new tax laws. The latest year results include several companies acquired in 1986, including Primo Foods Ltd., Ogden Food Products Co. and three Pepsi- Cola franchises.

title: For the Reagan Doctrine
description: American foreign policy has always been mindful of a special national purpose - that all mankind should be free - while nevertheless adapting to the circumstances and possibilities of American power at each stage of our history. In this, the Reagan Doctrine of support for anti-Communist insurgents in Nicaragua, Angola, Afghanistan and elsewhere is a modest and natural development of historic American foreign policy - a discreet combination of principle and interest.

title: AMTRAK CHAIRMAN ATTRIBUTES CRASH TO CONDUCT OF CONRAIL CREW
description: The chief executive of Amtrak today attributed the fatal collision of a passenger train and three Conrail freight engines to ''the outrageous conduct of the Conrail crew'' and cited several violations of operating procedures.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Invited Bill Scherrer, Carl Willis, Jeff Montgomery, Mike Konderla and Derek Bothelo, pitchers, to spring training.

title: LABOR DEPT. AIDE QUITS IN PROTEST OF U.S. STANCE ON MINORITY HIRING
description: The Government official responsible for requiring Federal contractors to hire minority workers has resigned in protest, saying some Reagan Administration officials are paying only ''lip service'' to enforcing anti-discrimination laws.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $10.9 million pre-tax gain from the final settlement for losses related to a 1982 fire for the quarter and $20.8 million in pre-tax gains from the settlement of losses related the fire and sales of bank premises for the year. c-Includes a $38.5 million in pre-tax gains from asset sales.

KIDNAPPING OF WEST GERMAN LINKED TO ARREST
description: A West German business executive kidnapped in Beirut last weekend was evidently seized in an effort to prevent the extradition to the United States of a Lebanese suspected of being a pro-Iran terrorist.

title: Esposito Wants Jury Disbanded in Inquiry
description: Meade H. Esposito, the retired Brooklyn Democratic leader, has asked that the grand jury investigating him be disbanded and a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate what his lawyer described as ''unlawful disclosures of grand jury materials'' by Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: MARK B. MITIN
description: Mark B. Mitin, a Marxist philosopher and member of the Academy of Sciences since 1939, has died, the Tass press agency announced today. He was 85 years old. He was a member of the Central Committee from 1939 to 1961, and a member of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature, from 1950 to 1962. He won a Stalin Prize in 1943.

title: NEW ALLOYS TRIED AT LOW TEMPERATURE
description: TWO recent discoveries in the esoteric field of superconductivity - a phenomenon in which materials lose their resistance to electricity at very low temperatures - could eventually save the electrical industry billions of dollars and result in a variety of new electronic intruments and computer elements, according to scientists and power industry experts.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago results include a plan implemented to provide for future asbestos litigation costs.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES RAISING SPENDING BY 7% IN BUDGET
description: Hailing a ''continued resurgence'' in New York's economy, Governor Cuomo today proposed a $40.9 billion budget that would increase state spending by 7 percent while putting into effect the final phase of a three-year tax cut.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST. LOUIS, MO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prices Rise Again, Modestly
description: Treasury bond prices rose modestly for the third consecutive day, but without the ebullience of the stock market.

title: SAYS PUBLICITY HINDERS HIS WORK
description: A high-ranking commander in the New York City Police Department whose social contacts with a reputed organized-crime figure in 1983 have been under investigation applied for retirement yesterday, police officials said.

title: ROCK GROUP ACCEDES TO ARAB PROTEST
description: A rock song called ''Killing an Arab'' by a British group, the Cure, has resulted in a nationwide campaign to control the implications of its title. Although the song itself does not have a racist message, the Cure announced yesterday that it had agreed, after protests from the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, to place explanatory stickers on albums, to add a message in the credits of its concert film and to discourage American radio stations from playing the song.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY KOCH TO COUNCIL ON STATE OF THE CITY
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's State of the City Address to the City Council and the Board of Estimate as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: In Defense of Cognac
description: Evan G. Galbraith, the outspoken former United States Ambassador to France, is speaking out in defense of French Cognac.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CONCERN WARNS IT WILL DISMISS ALL WHO SMOKE
description: The USG Acoustical Products Company has told its employees at plants in eight states that they must stop smoking or lose their jobs. The company said today that the smoking ban applied to both work and home and that it would conduct lung tests to make sure the employees had stopped.

title: Dolphins Make Moves
description: The Miami Dolphins, who were ranked next-to-last in the National Football League in team defense for most of the season, yesterday hired Tom Olivadotti, an assistant coach with the Browns, to be their new defensive coach. Chuck Studley, who had been the defensive coordinator for the last three seasons, was reassigned to coach the linebackers, working primarily on the defense against the run. In another move, Coach Don Shula said that Bob Matheson, linebacker coach for the last four years, resigned after learning he would not get the top defensive coaching job.

title: CONCERT: 3 PREMIERES BY SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: SPECULUM MUSICAE, the ensemble of 20th-century specialists that began its 16th season on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, is one of the most active proponents of the idea that there is room in our culture for defiantly recondite musical craftsmanship. Such groups - and there are quite a number of them - serve first to keep many composers of modest talent from sinking into total obscurity. But, perhaps as importantly, the musicians' unending struggles to master these complicated new scores tend to raise the level of performing skills throughout their profession.

title: I TOO AM ISRAELI, ONE ARAB DECLARES (IN HEBREW)
description: An Israeli Arab has written a novel in the Hebrew language, and it has set the Israeli literary world on its ear.

title: Newsweek, McDonald's In Date at White House
description: Gerard Smith, publisher of Newsweek, and Edward H. Rensi, president of McDonald's U.S.A., are scheduled to be at the White House today to present to the First Couple a copy of a special issue of the newsweekly entitled ''Newsweek on the Drug Crisis'' that is intended to educate the high school students of the nation.

title: THE SUPER BOWL INITIATION
description: In a sunny sky a softer blue than that of the Giants' jerseys, sea gulls floated in the wind that swayed the palm trees. But with the temperatures plunging into the 60's, thin-blooded southern Californians considered this to be a ''cold'' morning. They had to wear sweaters, some even windbreakers. Hardly what the nearby Pasadena Chamber of Commerce had in mind for a warm-weather Super Bowl XXI site.

title: NEW YORKERS EXCEL IN CONTEST
description: Fifteen high school students from New York State, including five each from the Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, were among the 40 national finalists named yesterday in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: DELICATE DISHES FLOURISH WHERE POT ROAST IS KING
description: THE pan, Peter Gaylor has concluded, is mightier than the sword. At least cooking keeps him better fed than fencing, the sport that led a decade ago to his discovery of fine French cuisine.

FIRST ALBANY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Fighting Over a Suspect?
description: Security planning is already intense for Mohammed Ali Hamadei, the Lebanese man who is expected to be extradited shortly to the United States for trial on charges of hijacking an American jetliner in 1985 and killing an American passenger. And some Administration officials are predicting a struggle between the United States Marshals Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation over which agency oversees Mr. Hamadei's custody during legal proceedings.

title: Creative Seminar Sets Heavyweight Debates
description: Seven of the most important creative people in the advertising business will discuss three of the most important questions facing them at a Creative Seminar for Senior Management sponsored by the New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies on Feb. 11 at the Helmsley Hotel of New York, on East 42d Street.

title: STRATUS COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
MECKLENBURG HAS HIS EYES ON MORRIS
description: Karl Mecklenburg's active mind is on Joe Morris this week, conjuring ways to bedevil the little speedster.

title: Concerns on Immigration Law
description: Business executives and immigration lawyers expressed concern yesterday about the ability of small companies to comply with the new immigration law and proposed rules for its enforcement.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHANGES AT FEDDERS AS SPINOFF NEARS
description: The Fedders Corporation, a leading maker of room air-conditioners, announced yesterday that it had named Richard D. Tyler Jr. president and chief operating officer.

title: SUIT BASED ON PORTRAYAL IN 'BELL JAR' FILM BEGINS
description: Literature, lesbianism, psychiatry, film making, television and video cassettes were all touched upon in United States District Court today as a $6 million libel suit opened here. It is rooted in a movie and television film based on ''The Bell Jar,'' Sylvia Plath's 1961 novel. The 55-year-old plaintiff in the suit is Dr. Jane V. Anderson, a psychiatrist and assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School. Dr. Anderson contends she was defamed and her privacy invaded because a character in the film, television and video-cassette versions of ''The Bell Jar'' was recognizably based upon herself. There are lesbian scenes in the film version involving the character Joan Gilling, the character that Dr. Anderson says is based on herself.

title: Parrish, Phils to Talk
description: The Philadelphia Phillies will confer Friday with a representative of Lance Parrish to determine if the club is interested in signing the free-agent catcher. The Phillies have indicated an interest in signing Parrish if they are assured the back condition that ended his 1986 season on July 26 is not a chronic injury. Larry Shenk, a Phillies spokesman, said that Parrish's agent sent medical reports to the Phillies yesterday. Parrish, who hit .257 with 22 home runs and 62 runs batted in last season, has ended negotiations with the Tigers and declared that he will not play for Detroit again. At any rate, Parrish, under the rules of free agency, cannot sign with the Tigers until May 1 if he should change his mind. He rejected a $1.2 million Detroit offer and is reportedly seeking $1.8 million.

title: Embarrassed Indian Resigns
description: Foreign Secretary A. P. Venkateswaran resigned abruptly today after being publicly embarrassed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, official sources reported. Mr. Venkateswaran, 56 years old, former Ambassador to China and the top bureaucrat in the Foreign Affairs Ministry, was at a news conference when Mr. Gandhi told reporters, ''Soon you will be talking to a new foreign secretary.'' Mr. Gandhi increasingly has been criticized in India's press for a reportedly high-handed manner and for what were viewed as autocratic and unseemly commands to officials.

title: Blood Samples Tested For Form of Leukemia
description: The American Red Cross said today that it had collected samples from thousands of blood donors around the country to test for a rare form of leukemia that could be spread through transfusions in the same way AIDS is sometimes transmitted.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNOR'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO THE LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature:

title: Teacher Cites Pressure
description: A high school English teacher in Jackson, Tenn., said yesterday she quit her job after being pressured into changing a failing grade she had given a star member of the school's undefeated basketball team. The teacher, Ann McGhee, said she changed an F to a D-minus at the direction of the Campbell County High School principal, Clifford C. Douglas.

title: U.S. MONITORS' POST IN SOVIET TEST AREA IS DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: A seismic measuring station installed by American scientists as part of a project to monitor Soviet nuclear testing has been destroyed by fire, a member of the American team said today.

title: DOW UP 13TH TIME, CLOSING AT 2,104.47
description: The Dow Jones industrial average set records yesterday - but just barely. After an up-and-down day, the popular yardstick of 30 blue-chip stocks finished with a small gain for a 13th consecutive advance, its longest string ever.

title: FIRSTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'KEEP YOU FOREVER,' ON MISSING IN VIETNAM
description: ''WE CAN KEEP YOU FOREVER'' is maddening; it bumps and slithers in and around factual material, falls back on flashy technique and weakens its own best case. At the same time, it makes a provocative, even compelling, argument that American prisoners are still held in Vietnam and Laos. The 90-minute documentary, on Channel 9 at 9 o'clock tonight, examines an emotional issue.

description: SPHINX. By D. M. Thomas. 248 pages. Viking. $17.95. THE jacket of D. M. Thomas's

title: EVERYTHING BIGGER, EVEN TV REPLAYS
description: At the end of the National Football League's first season with the experimental use of videotape to confirm or overturn some calls by officials, there will be one change in the replay booth for Super Bowl XXI.

description: America's beef industry is blanketing the nation with a $29 million advertising campaign intended to reverse a trend away from red meat among cholesterol-conscious consumers.

title: Jersey Mayor Warns Of 200 City Layoffs
description: Mayor Sharpe James warned yesterday that unless the state provided additional money for city operations he would be forced to layoff about 200 city employees, including police officers and firefighters, and raise property taxes almost 33 percent.

description: For a few hours today, it seemed that a significant breakthrough had been achieved in the 11-month investigation of the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary after- tax charge of $33,485,000 for the quarter and year. Manufacturers said it recognized an after-tax gain of $29.3 million in the latest quarter from the sale of three properties in New York City. Results for the latest year include an after-tax gain of $117 million on the sale of the company's mortgage banking subsidiary during the second quarter. It said the latest fourth quarter includes an income tax benefit of $68.8 million, compared with an expense of $54.9 million in the year-ago period.
