description: The company said on Dec. 30, it acquired Delta Graphics Inc., which was accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis. Results for Delta Graphics will be consolidated with Bolt Beranek in the current third quarter. Prior periods have not been restated for the acquisition, because Delta Graphics results were not material to Bolt Beranek's previously reported earnings. Results for the latest second quarter include $230,000 associated with the acquisition, which reduced net income for that period by about 2 cents a share.

description: Alan Bond spent nearly a decade and millions of his own dollars trying to win the America's Cup for Australia before finally succeeding in 1983. Now he has lost his chance to defend it.

ELECTION IS DUE
description: The coalition that has governed Ireland for four years collapsed today, and Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald immediately announced that there would be a national election Feb. 17.

description: Marlene Manes, the widow of the former Queens Borough President, resigned yesterday as director of clinical services for Holliswood Hospital, the hospital administrator said last night.

title: U.S. BID TO HALT DOLLAR'S DECLINE CALLED POSSIBLE
description: A senior Administration official today raised the possibility that the United States would try to arrest the monthlong decline of the dollar if it goes on much further.

title: Benedictine Vocations Sought in Secular Press
description: The Benedictine monks at the Newark Abbey, suffering from a shortage of vocations as are most religious communities, did something yesterday that the others rarely do. They spent some big dollars for major ''help wanted'' ads in the secular press.

title: Technology Stocks: An Investment Strategy
description: Historically, technology stocks have outperformed rising markets, notes Marc G. Schulman, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. But unlike the big technology stock rally of 1983-84, which was dominated by small companies that had innovative new products, he says, this time the best performers will be larger-capitalization stocks, and among those, the winners will be the ones that offer ways to integrate existing hardware.

title: AQUINO APPEALS FOR PATIENCE
description: President Corazon C. Aquino appealed to Filipinos today to ''please be patient'' and promised them a better standard of living in the year to come.

title: A SON OF SILICON VALLEY BACK FROM CAPITOL HILL
description: After trying unsuccessfully to unseat Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, former Representative Edwin V. W. Zschau is returning to System Industries, which he founded in 1968. He will be chairman of the company, based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: Golden Speech Cites Growth in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, said yesterday in his State of the Borough address that ''a decade of ambitious planning'' for economic revival was making Brooklyn ''a major economic force.''

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year results include the impact of a change in pension cost accounting required by FASB 87 that added $7.1 million, or 11 cents a share, to earnings.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available due to the national holiday honoring Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1987
description: The Economy

title: TRAFFIC IS HEAVY IN STRIKE'S 3D DAY
description: With negotiations proceeding slowly, thousands of commuters struggled through slushy, traffic-swollen roads yesterday on the third day of the Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: DARING RESCUE IN FRIGID RIVER SAVES 8-YEAR-OLD
description: A former New Haven police officer and a New York City firefighter were credited yesterday with a daring rescue in which they pulled an 8-year-old boy from a submerged van that was being dragged into the frigid currents of a Connecticut river.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is a curious fact of life that some of the foods most coveted by gastronomes are looked upon with disdain by many home cooks. These include most of the so-called variety meats, a euphemism if ever there was one for the innards of animals. These include brains, sweetbreads, kidneys and, sometimes, liver. In England, these parts are referred to as offal, a name with a decidedly unappetizing sound.

title: INTERLEAF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: F.B.I. INTO GEORGIA RACE INCIDENT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will investigate assaults last week on civil rights demonstrators in Forsyth County, Ga., the Justice Department announced today.

title: Trump Blocks Deal by Bally
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, succeeded today in temporarily blocking the sale of the Golden Nugget Hotel/Casino to the Bally Manufacturing Company, a deal that Mr. Trump's lawyer said was designed to prevent Mr. Trump from taking over Bally.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on Saturday showing the Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party Politburo misidentified one of the five members. Chen Yun is a member; Li Peng is not.

description: Six months after law-enforcement officials began seizing cars to stop out-of-towners from buying drugs, anti-drug strategists say they have inflicted a blow but not a defeat on the commuting crack trade in New York City.

description: Stefan Edberg, the defending champion, and top-seeded Ivan Lendl powered their way today into the men's semifinals of the $1.65 million Australian Open tennis championships.

title: FIRST COLONIAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $90,000 for the quarter and year.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $900,000 out-of-court settlement regarding alleged sewerage permit violations and alleged groundwater contamination.

title: ONE OF THOUSANDS IN CHAPTER 11 LINE
description: One day last fall, with liabilities of $2.1 million and assets of $1.7 million, Virginia and Doyle Lay filed for Chapter 11 protection in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Dallas. The Lays, whose real estate operations near here had been sliding toward foreclosure, were not alone.

title: Parting Shot
description: Howard Sharpe of Bicknell, Ind., who will retire at age 71 after the season with more victories than any other coach in the history of Indiana high school basketball: ''Of course, if I get incapacitated and can't see anymore, I can always be a referee.''

title: Dr. Otto Steinbrocker; Led Arthritis Research
description: Dr. Otto Steinbrocker, a pioneer in rheumatoid arthritis research, died of cancer Jan. 11 at his home in Delray, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: IRWIN MAGNETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $386,000 for the quarter and $585,000 for the 6 months.

description: The results are affected by the acquisition of Centran Corp. in September 1985, by two divestitures in the last half of 1985 and one divestiture in the 1986 fourth quarter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the reaction of Chinese students in the United States to political developments in their homeland misidentified a New York Chinese newspaper to which the students delivered a letter. It was The Centre Daily News.

title: All Welcome, For a Change
description: A basketball game between rival high schools can stir the teen-age blood, so much so, in fact, that it has periodically led to brawls between opposing groups of fans at P.S.A.L. games in recent years. Principals at a number of schools - roughly a dozen in Brooklyn alone - have been fighting back this season with a controversial tactic: barring game attendance by visiting teams' fans and cheerleaders.

title: Topics: In the Wind; No-Show Ethics
description: A Federal trial in Brooklyn casts an embarrassing spotlight on payroll padding, Albany style. Richard Rubin, a longtime Queens Democratic Party official and formerly chief patronage dispenser for Donald Manes, is charged with using his political clout to have state legislators put his law office secretaries on their payroll.

title: 5 DIE IN MIDWEST PLANE COLLISION

ECUADOR'S CRISIS MOUNTS AS CRITICS OF PRESIDENT PRESS FOR HIS OUSTER
description: Four days after the President of Ecuador was briefly kidnapped by air force commandos, the National Congress went into special session today with opposition leaders seeking his resignation.

title: TWO MORE QUIT IN GUINNESS SCANDAL
description: The chief executive of Britain's top investment bank, Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., and the concern's head of corporate finance resigned today in the wake of the stock-trading scandal surrounding Guinness P.L.C.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: BARNEY GREENGRASS was known as the ''Sturgeon King'' when the store opened in 1908. He was still the Sturgeon King when the store moved to its present site on Amsterdam Avenue, between 86th and 87th Streets. His son, Moe, and his grandson Gary preside over the store nowadays and it is they who followed in Barney's footsteps and share the title of Sturgeon King. Everybody knows that.

title: TOUGHEST SUPER BOWL TICKET MAY BE ONE FOR AIRLINE SEAT
description: If you have a ticket to Sunday's Super Bowl game, congratulations. If you do not have an airline ticket to southern California, though, your luck may be running out.

title: Real Estate; Shopping Mall Set In Yonkers
description: BERNARD J. ROSENSHEIN, a major developer of shopping centers, will do anything to slip some stores into a spot near an already established hub of retail activity, including - as he puts it with a characteristic touch of hyperbole -''move a mountain.''

title: Sacramento Teachers Strike
description: Teachers went on strike today after a 20-hour bargaining session failed to produce a new contract. Despite the strike by 2,300 teachers, the district hoped to keep schools open for the 44,000 students with the help of 700 substitute teachers who would be paid $140 a day. Normal pay for substitutes is $52 to $89 a day.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lemieux to Return
description: Mario Lemieux, the leading vote-getter in the National Hockey League All-Star balloting, will return to the Pittsburgh Penguins' lineup tonight after being sidelined for a month. Lemieux twisted his right knee in a Dec. 20 game against the Philadelphia Flyers. ''He'll be a big lift,'' said Eddie Johnston, the Penguins' general manager. ''Maybe some guys will come to life and put the puck in the net.'' The Penguins, who have a road game tonight against the Los Angeles Kings, have lost three in a row and are without a victory in their last five games. They have been 2-7-4 during Lemieux's absence and lost five games by a goal in that time.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $20 million charge to cover writeoffs and shutdown costs in connection with the closing of a manufacturing facility. The company said the accounting changes in 1986 increased fourth quarter net by $1.3 million, or 1 cent a share, and $9.3 million, or 7 cents a share, for the year.

title: Competitiveness - Not Just a Buzzword
description: Competitiveness is emerging as this year's fashionable political buzzword. President Reagan is expected to make it a central theme of his State of the Union Message. Given the Administration's difficulties, there will be a great temptation to advance a program that provides the ''answer'' to our trade problem, defuses protectionist pressures and distracts attention from other political issues. But a few legislative and administrative measures cannot make us competitive.

title: HOMOSEXUAL PARENTS WINNING SOME CUSTODY CASES
description: The 36-year-old man, a homosexual who had just been awarded custody of his 13-year-old son, recalled his opening testimony before a State Supreme Court justice here: ''Yes, I'm a homosexual. Now let's get on with the case.''

title: KENT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company completed its initial public offering on June 11, 1986.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a cumulative adjustment of $3,670,000, 14 cents a share, due to an adjustment in the effective tax rates. Share earnings reflect the 5-for-3 stock split approved by the shareholders on April 15, 1986, effective April 25, 1986.

title: THERAPEUTIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Howard Beach Gets A Visit From Mayor
description: Mayor Koch met last night with 50 leaders of Howard Beach, Queens, to discuss their concerns about being labeled a racist community.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of assets of $25,740,000.

title: STAGE: SECOND ROUND OF ONE-ACT COMEDIES
description: FAMILY ghosts emerge from the woodwork in Laurence Klavan's ''If Walls Could Talk,'' the most entertaining of the four plays in the second round of the Manhattan Punch Line's festival of one-act comedies. There are extraneous moments, but in contrast to the other plays, Mr. Klavan's work at least has a storyline and a destination.

title: Bond to Increase Media Holdings
description: The Bond Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the broadcasting interests of Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd. for the equivalent of $665 million. The proposed acquisition -which involves 25 television, radio and other broadcast-related companies - would make Bond the biggest TV station operator in Australia, with access to nearly 60 percent of the nation's viewing public.

title: HOPES RECEDING FOR A QUICK END IN RAIL WALKOUT
description: The president of the Long Island Rail Road last night offered the line's striking employees lump-sum payments -about $5,000 a person - if they would accept binding arbitration to settle their labor dispute and go back to work.

title: PENN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TAI CHI EXERCISES: FAD UNSETTLES INDONESIA
description: China has stirred a debate in Indonesia, but not because of leadership changes in Beijing. The problem is the Chinese exercises known as tai chi.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split payable yesterday to shareholders of record Dec. 31.

title: ARCHITECTURE: BLAND WITHOUT, A MARVEL WITHIN
description: THE galleries of the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are the best museum spaces in New York for the display of 20th-century art. This is not to say that they represent an architectural triumph: as a building, the Wallace wing is dull and not a little clunky. But what is banal on the outside is both inventive and serene within, and it manages the difficult trick of accommodating the needs of art without capitulating into complete neutrality.

title: Rutgers Strike Enters 2d Day; Some Classes Are Called Off
description: Styrofoam replaced china in some dining halls, sidewalks went unshoveled and phones went unanswered as a strike by 2,800 clerical and service workers at Rutgers University entered its second day today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Downhill Racers

title: FEES FOR ALIENS SEEKING AMNESTY COULD REACH $250, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A Reagan Administration official said today that illegal aliens would probably have to pay application fees of $150 to $250 if they wanted to obtain legal status under a landmark immigration law.

title: Expecting the Worst And Sharing the Trip
description: AFTER rising at 5 A.M. in the suburbs and driving more than two hours on icy streets and traffic-clogged roads, Bill Hogan alighted from his car in Manhattan yesterday and said, ''This was a breeze, an enjoyable trip.''

title: LOWELL INSTITUTION FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted to a stock form of ownership in May 1986.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: I WATCHED ''Gone With the Wind'' on television recently. It's my favorite movie. It's hokey, it's predictable, the color's lurid, I throw balled-up tissues at Olivia de Havilland when she's on screen. I love it. Each time I see it I notice something new.

title: Topics: In the Wind; Underdog Under Sail
description: Four years ago, Dennis Conner was the goat after he blew a commanding lead and allowed an Australian boat to capture the America's Cup. It was the first time in 132 years that a foreigner had taken the cup away from the U.S. On Monday Mr. Conner earned the chance to bring the cup back when his new boat, Stars & Stripes, defeated a yacht from New Zealand in a best-of-seven series.

title: PAY-FONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics: In the Wind; Continental Drift
description: Campaigning for the Presidency seven years ago, Ronald Reagan called for a ''North American Compact'' to bind the United States, Canada and Mexico. Nothing came of the idea, but acid rain brings it back to mind.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXERCISE WITH A FRIEND LIKE CURLY ARM CURL
description: EXERCISE machines that talk? Count repetitions for you, urge you to push harder, tell you when to rest and even urge you on with little quips like ''no pain no gain.'' Right. A personal exercise coach can help when motivation falters, but the expense could easily cripple one's budget. Enter Powercise, a group of exercise machines with built-in personal fitness coaches. Well, sort of.

title: FUTURE SHOCKS: A NEW AUTO SUSPENSION SYSTEM
description: THE Lotus Esprit sports car screams around a tight corner at 105 miles an hour. While most cars would list sharply to one side as the driver struggled desperately to hold the road, the Lotus takes the turn effortlessly, almost as if it were cruising down a straight, flat country lane.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after tax gain of $2.3 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of Dorsey Corp. common shares. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter included investment tax credit of $1 million, or 4 cents a share. The company said the investment tax credit repeal reduced the latest fourth quarter net by about $1.7 million, or 8 cents a share.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: The year-ago quarter ended Dec. 28. Sales represent net sales.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS VOW TO DEFEAT MISSILE SHIELD PLAN
description: Two key Democratic Senators said today that they were confident of defeating any Reagan Administration proposals to speed the installation of defenses against ballistic missiles when the military budget is debated this year.

title: CADNETIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $476,000 and $850,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Choice in the House
description: Paradoxical as it may seem, Democrats in the House of Representatives - which last year voted to force a nuclear test ban and continued observance of SALT II - may be about to elect an Armed Services Committee chairman with the following record:

title: BUCHANAN YIELDS TO KEMP IN RACE
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the outspoken director of White House communications, bowed to pressure from supporters of Representative Jack F. Kemp today and announced that he would not run for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,940,000 on the sale of a building for the quarter and year.

title: Super Helmets
description: The Gipper may have played with a leather hat, but when the Giants butt heads with the Broncos Sunday in Super Bowl XXI their craniums will be protected with polycarbonate plastic shells lined with foam padding and honeycombed with hollow channels that can be inflated with air for a skull-hugging custom fit, or with antifreeze to absorb shocks and distribute the impact.

title: Talk of the Ivies
description: Who is the most versatile basketball player in the Ivy League? Here's a vote for Guido Casparis, Columbia's center, a freshman from Switzerland who is fluent in English, Italian, German and French, and is now studying Russian. His most difficult language? ''American slang,'' he says. ''Like, if you 'dog it,' you don't play hard enough, but a 'hot dog' is a show-off. I'm picking it up slowly. After four years, I want to be able to speak New York-ese.''

title: BUDGET SEEKS TO RAISE SCHOOL AID $405 MILLION
description: Governor Cuomo proposed today a $405 million increase in state aid to public schools in the next academic year, with half going to economically disadvantaged communities.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
All About Niches
description: Following are excerpts from ''Setting Course: A Congressional Management Guide,'' from Chapter Three, ''Niches in the System'':

title: SUPER BOWL'S SIDELINE: SPORT OF EATING
description: THE question of what to serve for a Super Bowl party takes different forms. In Pasadena this Sunday, both the Giants and the Broncos will be hoping to serve the other their helmets on a platter, but that's another matter.

title: HUDSON FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company acquired Corbett Enterprises on Sept. 27, 1986.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF THE CAROLIAS F A reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share data has been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 split last March.

title: MT BAKER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split payable Feb. 2.

title: BTR Drops Bid For Pilkington
description: BTR P.L.C., the industrial conglomerate, has announced that it had dropped its contested bid for Pilkington Brothers P.L.C. Pilkington, one of the world's leading makers of glass, took over the large glass operations of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company of Toledo, Ohio, the primary American supplier of automobile windows, last April.

title: BALLARD MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EL NINO REUTRNS, BUT DISASTER IS NOT FORSEEN
description: El Nino, the momentous shift in the winds and waters of the tropical Pacific, has returned, but it appears unlikely to bring the widespread climatic disaster it did four years ago, the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $8.1 million by provisions of the tax reform act of 1986; the tax law changes reduced the company's investment tax credit by $9.8 million while adding $1.7 million of reinstated research and development tax credits.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,654,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: EX-OFFICER DESCRIBES KEY MOMENT AT SCENE OF THE BUMPURS SHOOTING
description: A retired police officer testified yesterday that Eleanor Bumpurs made repeated stabbing motions at him after a fellow officer fired the first of two shotgun blasts during a 1984 police eviction attempt in her Bronx apartment.

title: A Funny Little Jugf
description: 1. Syrup With a Smile

title: Owens to Sell Ladish Division
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has agreed to sell its Ladish Company subsidiary, which produces high-technology forgings for aerospace and industrial applications, for $236 million to a new company formed by an investor group led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, an investment banking firm specializing in leveraged buyouts.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results for 1986 include a settlement gain of $50.5 million relating to the company's pension plan. The 1985 net included a gain of $55.7 million on the sale of the tower portion of the Interfirst One Building. Results for the fourth quarter of 1986 include net securities gains of $3.8 million, compared with net securities gains of $5.2 million in the year-ago period. For the full year of 1986, net securities gains totaled $18.8 million, compared with $9.8 million in 1985.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Strikes are just something else you have to live with.'' - Jim Stillwaggon, a Long Island commuter. [ B1:1. ]

title: Thermal Underwear: A New Development
description: The law of thermal underwear -weight equals warmth - no longer holds true at J. E. Morgan Knitting Mills Inc., a Hometown, Pa., concern that makes almost half of the nation's long johns. Its Arctex fabric reportedly traps more body heat and weighs less than other popular thermal garments, according to tests done at the International Fabricare Institute in Maryland, a trade group for dry cleaners and launderers.

title: British Unit Backs New Agency
description: TWO Scali, McCabe, Sloves executives, backed financially by a publicly held British concern, have established Lowe Tucker Metcalf, an agency that already has its first client. British, of course.

title: BAVARO STRONG, SILENT AND ONE OF A KIND
description: As the Giants finished posing for a team picture today, hundreds of reporters swarmed onto the field of LeBard Stadium at Orange Coast College to talk to them in the first en masse news conference of Super Bowl week.

title: UNRUSHED BACKUPS PLAYING QUIET ROLES
description: There was no rush of reporters descending on them today, just as there is usually no pass-rush to contend with on Sunday afternoons. Jeff Rutledge and Gary Kubiak were free to roam the practice field at Orange Coast College, enjoying the view, wondering what it would be like to be the focus of attention during the week of the Super Bowl. It is what every quarterback aspires to, but for now, Rutledge and Kubiak will settle for a front-row seat to the biggest game in town.

title: Henry J. Kaufman Gets Automobile Association
description: The American Automobile Association in Washington has consolidated its advertising at Henry J. Kaufman & Associates, also in Washington.

title: VISTA CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are full diluted. The company went public in December 1986 through an initial public offering of common stock.

title: We Still Need the Minimum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Claim Maxwell
description: The Rangers claimed Brad Maxwell, a defenseman, on waivers from the Vancouver Canucks yesterday. Maxwell, 29 years old, played in 30 games this season, scoring 1 goal and adding 8 assists. The 6-foot-2-inch 195-pounder started his National Hockey League career with Minnesota in 1977, and also has played for Quebec and Toronto.

title: APPLE BRANDY: HARD CIDER TRANSFIGURED
description: AS president of the oldest American company producing aged apple brandy, Larrie Laird of Laird & Company in Scobeyville, N.J., must take the long view of apples. His fruit must withstand the rigors of fermentation, distillation and seven and a half years of aging. When the essence of those apples is poured into a snifter in the 1990's, it must prove itself worthy of being savored like Cognac or like apple brandy's French counterpart, the Calvados produced in Normandy.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 results have been restated for a pooling-of-interests to include the 1986 merger with Commonwealth Trust Bancorp Inc. The results of Central Bancorp Inc. and Wainwright Financial Corp. are included for 1986. The results of Kasco Financial Corp. are included subsequent to its November 1986 merger with Huntington.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST WANT OTHERS TO FOLLOW MODEL
description: Many contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the wish that others will follow their example.

title: FABRICLAND WHOLESALERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENDANGERED SPECIES: BIRD'S NEST SOUP
description: Nothing that a Chinese host can put on a table has more cachet than a bowl of viscous bird's nest soup. For centuries, it has been a delicacy throughout the Chinese world, a dish famed for its ability to keep people young and healthy.

title: 'STAR WARS' TIMETABLE: WHAT EFFECT AT GENEVA TALKS?
description: Pentagon suggestions that the United States consider deploying elements of an anti-missile defense system in the early 1990's are spurring a new debate within the Administration over what position to take in the Geneva arms-control talks.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MONEY-SAVING MENUS A LA BONNE FEMME
description: THE French housewife, with her inborn sense of balance and proportion, her acquired instinct for the careful composition of robust stews and little sauces, her insistence on the finest quality at the cheapest price and her ability to make much of very little, is a paragon of culinary virtue. As such she may already have become a creature of history, if indeed she ever existed at all.

title: Kenya Denies as 'Scandalous' Charges by a U.S. Legislator
description: Kenya's Foreign Minister described as ''scandalous and unfounded'' today criticism by a United States Congressman of this nation's human rights policies.

title: Economic Scene; Preventing A Money Crisis
description: EXCITEMENT in the stock market and the foreign-exchange market is reaching a fever pitch. Professional money managers are getting worried as the stock market seems to soar farther and farther away from the reality of a sluggish economy. But the pressure for performance keeps institutional investors buying stocks, anyway. And some stockbrokers have begun to warn their customers to lay back.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in June 1985.

title: SCIENTIST AND SOVIET EMIGRE
description: Dr. Benjamin G. Levich, an internationally prominent physical chemist who won a six-year effort to emigrate from the Soviet Union, died of cardiac arrest Monday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: NEW PENNSYLVANIA GOVERNOR SEEKS AN ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP
description: The Pennsylvania that Gov. Robert P. Casey today swore to lead for the next four years is really two states in one, some of his fellow citizens point out.

title: DEVILS COME UP SHORT AGAIN
description: The Devils got caught short on defense tonight several times, the most costly breakdown coming on a 3-on-1 attack early in the second period.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GRAND JURY IS PRESENTED RACIAL ATTACK EVIDENCE
description: A Queens grand jury began receiving evidence yesterday in the Howard Beach assault, sources familiar with the case said.

title: CBS PLANS A SNAPPY PRELUDE
description: CBS is not having a two-hour Super Bowl pre-game show on Sunday. Instead, it will fill the two hours before the game with a show called ''The Super Bowl Today.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday on the New York State tax reduction to take effect this year incorrectly described state income tax rates. Currently, 9.5 percent is the maximum rate on earned income; 13.5 percent is the maximum rate on unearned income. The maximum rates are to be reduced to 9 percent and 13 percent, respectively.

title: Ex-Belgian Premier Is Guilty
description: The Brussels appeals court today ruled that former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants, given a three-year suspended jail sentence in June 1986 for tax fraud and using forged documents, was also guilty of forgery.

title: Cleaning Indoor Air
description: THE National Academy of Sciences estimated in November that 2,400 people die each year of lung cancer caused by breathing smoke from other people's cigarettes. The United States Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, in his December report on the health risks to nonsmokers from cigarettes said, ''Involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer, in healthy nonsmokers.''

title: AMR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter reflects a $38.9 million one-time charge resulting from retroactive provisions of the Tax Reform Act related to investment tax credits. Offsetting the charge was an $8 million gain reflecting tax benefits from the sale-leaseback of Aircraft. The company said the year net reflects a pre-tax gain of $60.3 million from sale of subsidiaries.

title: MARINE CORP (WIS)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter results include a pre-tax gain of $4.4 million from the sale of the company's former investment in Illinois Marine Bancorp.

title: Signature Magazine Plans to Cut Rate Base
description: Signature magazine, which was to go to a circulation rate base of 925,000, from 840,000, with its March issue under its old owner, the Citicorp Diners Club, is instead being cut back to 750,000 with the February issue under its new owner, Conde Nast Publications. That was announced yesterday by Ron Galotti, Signature publisher.

title: IRAN SAYS IT TOOK TOWN NEAR BASRA
description: Iran said today that it had captured an Iraqi town east of Basra, suggesting incremental progress in its grueling advance against the heavily defended city near the Persian Gulf.

title: Family Affair
description: Ben Hinson, a high-scoring forward for the basketball team at Baptist College in Charleston, S.C., is considered the best player in the Division I Big South Conference. It wasn't until he was a teen-ager, though, that he could beat his sister in a game of one-on-one.

title: IN NEW YORK, TRADERS START TO SELL DOLLARS
description: Several New York foreign-exchange dealers began selling dollars last night on the Tokyo market, indicating disappointment with the meeting between Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa.

title: COLLIER: A BRONCOS SURVIVOR
description: Gone are opposing quarterbacks like Joe Namath, Len Dawson, John Hadl and Terry Bradshaw. But Joe Collier, whose job was to stop them, remains.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONNECTICUT CHIEF JUSTICE URGES 9 NEW JUDGESHIPS 881>
description: Connecticut's Chief Justice proposed today the creation of nine new judgeships to help meet what she called ''the destabilizing effect'' of recent legislation that has increased the judiciary's workload.

title: HOME OWNERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in April 1986.

title: NEWARK GETTING 650 TOWN HOUSES IN AREA ONCE TORN BY RIOT
description: Mayor Sharpe James signed a contract today for the construction of 650 moderately priced town houses, the largest addition to the city's housing stock in decades.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter earnings were reduced by $12.6 million due to the reversal of investment tax credits recorded in previous quarters and amounts foregone in the fourth quarter. The one-time adjustments due to the new tax law reduced fourth-quarter earnings by 27 cents a share.

title: Xerox Retirements
description: The Xerox Corporation said that about 1,000 of about 4,000 eligible salaried employees had elected to retire early, and most will leave the company by the end of the month. The company said its savings would be substantial, but it declined to project its reduction in expenses this year. Xerox said the retirees, who are at least 50 years old, with 10 years of service at the company, work at locations around the United States, but the largest group is at its Rochester office. Xerox employs about 60,000 in the United States.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LAST TENANT SPURNS OFFER OF 'BLANK CHECK' TO LEAVE
description: Rafael Villa Vicencio was approached some time ago, he said, and offered ''a blank check'' to move out of his room at the St. Clair Hotel at 69 West 38th Street. ''They told me to pick the amount,'' he said yesterday. ''I didn't accept it. I asked them to fix the room I had.''

title: MILLIONS OF ZAMBIANS HIT BY ECONOMIC HARDSHIPS
description: The realities of economic misery are increasingly menacing this dusty town, which is in a tug-of-war against poverty.

title: Protect Abortion Rights
description: LEAD: The 14th anniversary of the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade, which legalized abortion, finds us with a continuing paradox. In private, abortion has become an essential and integral component of women's health care and the care of families. Publicly, we remain deeply divided, and further legal protections, including perhaps a constitutional amendment, are needed to preserve a woman's right to obtain a safe abortion.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After reductions of 33 cents a share for the loss of investment tax credit under the new tax law and 16 cents a share to relocate the Paper Group's headquarters to Bosie for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a negative impact of 55 cents a share associated with a strike at Boise Cascade's pulp and paper mill in Rumford, Maine. c-Includes gains of 58 cents a share from the sale of assets and charges of 15 cents a share for severance and other employee cost-reduction program.

title: City Water Agency Sets 7.017% Top Bond Yield
description: The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority is offering $387.3 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.017 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $3,123,000 for the quarter and $8,690,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $2,659,000 for the year. The bank converted to stock form in July 1985. The latest quarter includes a $494,000 payment to the F.D.I.C. under terms of an agreement to acquire the Central Savings Bank. The payment for the full year amounted to $1,266,000.

title: KRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1,900,000 for the quarter and $23,100,000 for the year. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $15,900,000 for the quarter and $58,100,000 for the year.

title: U.S. Trade Retaliation
description: President Reagan imposed retaliatory duties of 200 percent today on European imports, in an action that United States officials say will probably cause Americans to pay more for gin, brandy, cheese and some white wine. Mr. Reagan's order puts into effect, on Jan. 30, measures that the White House announced Dec. 30.

title: The Beira Corridor
description: From this border city a road, rail and pipeline run to the Mozambican port of Beira, 190 miles away. They are Zimbabwe's shortest connections to the outside world, and a way for other landlocked countries of the region to reduce South Africa's economic grip. But they are fragile links now, threatened by war and decay in Mozambique.

title: Advertising; A Mobile Pizza Hut Campaign
description: AS a method of communicating what it considers its myriad strongpoints synergistically and within a single advertising campaign, Pizza Hut, the largest chain in the fastest-growing facet of the restaurant business, has borrowed a concept from Charles Kuralt of CBS-TV and has taken to the road.

title: Mcorp's Net Drops 68.3%
description: Mcorp, the largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that its earnings for the fourth quarter declined by 68.3 percent, to $9 million, or 14 cents a share. Its earnings for the fourth quarter of 1985 were $28.4 million, or 62 cents a share.

title: Many New Yorkers Live Under Noisy Skies
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS' LOSING STREAK IS ENDED
description: The losing finally ended tonight. The Nets, whose season has been one losing streak after another, surged and held off the Phoenix Suns, 120-114, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. And then, predictably, the players spoke in positive terms.

title: 1800's MILLS CONVERTED INTO MODERN HOUSING
description: LEAD: IN 1923, 16-year-old Camille Descheneaux used to bicycle to work at the sporting goods plant in Chicopee, Mass.

title: CANADIANS SCOLD BUSH OVER TRADE AND ACID RAIN
description: Canadian officials, in an unusually fractious mood, met today with Vice President Bush today and demanded that the Reagan Administration make greater efforts to fulfill commitments on trade, acid rain and other issues.

title: Authors, Artists, Amateurs and Women
description: Several years ago, members of the 139-year-old Century Association in New York City conducted a correspondence so felicitously phrased that it would have done credit to the young Henry James. On one side were those who would admit women. ''It is our belief,'' they said, ''that the fundamental pleasures of the Century as a gathering place for cultivated people will not change if we acknowledge an important fact, that the worlds of 'authors, artists and amateurs' include women as well as men.''

title: ANCIENT AND MODERN POMPEII DO BATTLE OVER NEW HIGHWAY
description: Mount Vesuvius did such a good job of burying Pompeii in A.D. 79 that only now has anyone thought of doing it again.

title: Spencer Arraignment
description: Brian Spencer, the 37-year-old former Islander who was named the team's most popular player by its booster club in 1973, will be arraigned Friday morning in Palm Beach (Fla.) Municipal Court on charges of first-degree murder and kidnapping. Spencer has denied any connection with the death of Michael J. Dalfo. The charges stem from the Feb. 4, 1982 murder of Dalfo, 29 years old, son of a prominent North Palm Beach real-estate man. The police found Dalfo unconscious with two gunshot wounds to his head in a shallow pool of water off a service road near his home in suburban West Palm Beach. He died at Palm Beach Gardens Hospital. According to police reports received by Lynn Baldwin, the State's Attorney, Spencer shot Dalfo after an altercation between Dalfo and a friend of Spencer who was employed by an escort service.

title: PROS OPPOSE PLAYING PGA WEST COURSE
description: More than 100 golfers are expected to petition Deane Beman, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, within the next week to insist that the PGA West course not be used again.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SMALL hand-held electric grinders - rotary power tools that look something like a dentist's drill - have long been popular with hobbyists and craftsmen who carve or build models. However, these versatile little tools are also handy for small maintenance and repair jobs around the house. Sometimes they make it possible to complete a job that would otherwise be almost impossible.

title: COLLECTING CARPENTERS' OLD PLANES
description: LEAD: No matter what a woodworking plane's purpose was - producing a flat surface, carving molding or performing some task for a trade long since superseded by mechanization - the old planes can be fascinating. For collectors, they are fairly easy to acquire: The sources of supply, whatever the shape, size or condition, are plentiful.

title: ROCK HALL OF FAME ADDS MEMBERS
description: Rock-and-rollers put on black tie and tails last night for the second annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame ceremonies at the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom.

title: Wood Loses Appeal
description: A judge in United States Appellate Court has ruled against Leon Wood, the Nets' guard, in a case that tested the legality of the National Basketball Association's college draft and its salary cap provisions. Judge Ralph Winter, on behalf of a unanimous three-judge panel, held that the draft and salary cap were governed by labor law rather than antitrust law, and since they were subject to collective bargaining with the union, the draft and the cap were not subject to challenge by an individual player. Judge Robert L. Carter of the United States District Court in New York first rejected Wood's contention last February. Wood objected to the cap, which puts a ceiling on each team's total player salaries, and the draft, which assigns the rights to a player to only one team, ''because they assigned him to work for a particular employer at a diminished wage.'' But the appeals court said ''the choice of the employer is governed by the rules of the hiring hall, not the preference of the individual workers.'' Wood, who was drafted by the Philadelphia 76ers, filed his suit in September 1984. Eventually, he signed a four-year contract for more than $1 million, including a signing bonus, with the 76ers. He was traded to the Washington Bullets, who then sent him to the Nets.

title: Book Critics' Awards

The event, open to the public, is to begin with a 5:30 P.M. reception in the Greenberg Lounge in Vanderbilt Hall. The presentation ceremony, for the winners in fiction, nonfiction, biography, poetry, criticism and book reviewing, is to be at 7 P.M. in Tishman Auditorium in Vanderbilt Hall. Tickets, $20 each, can be bought at the door.

Remarkable seven-figure prices were paid for an American table and a wing chair, a German jeweled box, a British silver epergne, a French drop-front secretary and a Chinese porcelain dish. All but the 14th-century Ming dish were 18th-century works.

title: Q & A
description: Q.About a year ago, motor oil spilled on the porch planking (pressure-treated 2-by-4's) and apparently soaked into the wood because the oil is seeping through the penetrating stain. How can I remove the oil and restain the planking? A.This will not be easy after such a length of time and it has been made worse by the stain that was applied. I assume that most of the surface oil has been washed off or worn off, but if there is any on the surface, use grease solvent (such as paint thinner or dry-cleaning fluid) and a lot of rags to wash off the grease. Then mix a paste of powdered portland cement and liquid grease solvent and spread this in a thick layer over the oily area. Slowly pour on additional solvent to wet it more, then immediately cover with sheet plastic to keep it from drying rapidly. Allow to sit for about 24 hours, then sweep off. Repeat if necessary. Q. On the advice of a paint store salesman, I recently used a high-gloss oil paint on part of the wood on the exterior of my beach house. But now a builder has told me the glossy surface will be almost impossible to paint over. Is he right? A.House paints vary from a matt finish to a fairly high gloss. Trim paints have a high, enamel-like gloss, but they should not be used on siding or shingles (too brittle).

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Jazz 112, Pistons 108: Karl Malone had 23 points and John Stockton sank two free throws with nine seconds left as Utah held back a late Detroit surge. Detroit trailed, 109-99, with 2:50 left, but Isiah Thomas and Joe Dumars sparked a 9-1 Piston rally that closed the gap to 110-108 with 11 seconds left. Thomas, who finished with 30 points, scored after a steal, Dumars added a 3-point shot and Thomas scored on two more drives. After Stockton's two free throws, Thomas missed a 3-point shot and the Jazz held on, snapping their four-game losing streak.(AP) Lakers 112, Hawks 109: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 8 of his 26 points in the final 6 minutes 41 seconds as Los Angeles, helped by two late offensive rebounds, won in Atlanta. It was the fifth victory in a row for the Lakers, who have the league's best record at 31-8. Abdul-Jabbar scored 5 points in an 11-1 spurt that gave the Lakers the lead for good, turning a 96-94 deficit into a 105-97 lead with 4:39 to play. The Hawks, dropping their third game in a row, then got 8 points in succession, 6 by Kevin Willis, to cut the lead to 2 points, but Atlanta never could regain the lead.(AP) Celtics 130, Pacers 100: Larry Bird scored 26 points, Kevin McHale 24 and Robert Parish 22 in leading the the Celtics at Boston. Bird, who scored 72 points in 70 minutes of action in two previous victories over Indiana in Boston Garden, put on another dazzling show as he hit three 3-point shots. With Bird and Parish scoring 12 points each, the Celtics shot 72 percent from the field in taking a 41-26 first-period lead. Boston managed only 19 points in the second period, but still led by 60-48 at the half. The Celtics gained their 18th victory in 19 starts at the Garden this season.(AP) N.H.L. Whalers 3, Canadiens 1: Ron Francis, Sylvain Turgeon and Kevin Dineen scored goals to support strong goaltending by Mike Liut as Hartford moved a point from first place in the Adams Division. Liut made 25 saves as Hartford won its second game in three nights over first-place Montreal.(AP) Maple Leafs 4, Blues 2: Steve Thomas scored two goals and led Toronto over St. Louis. Thomas and Jeff Jackson scored for Toronto in the first period and Doug Wickenheiser of the Blues scored the only goal of the second period. Thomas's second goal and 20th of the season came at 12:11 of the third period. He picked up a loose puck at the St. Louis blue line, shed a body check by Gino Cavallini, took one more stride as he approached a defenseman, Rob Ramage, and slapped a drive past the goaltender, Greg Millen. Doug Gilmour of the Blues narrowed the gap to 3-2 with 4:36 remaining, intercepting Thomas at the Toronto blue line and putting a wrist shot between the legs of the goalie, Allan Bester, on a breakaway. Seven St. Louis regulars missed the game because of injuries.(AP) Flyers 5, Blackhawks 5: Troy Murray scored his second goal of the game with 63 seconds left in the third period lifting Chicago into the tie. The Blackhawks had pulled the goaltender, Murray Bannerman, for an extra attacker, and Murray put a 5-foot shot past the Flyers' goalie, Ron Hextall, for his 17th goal of the season. (AP) Horse Racing Front-Running Winner: Shine Diulus took the lead at the start and maintained a clear margin throughout to score a 3 1/4-length victory in the $29,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Christopher R. and Bonnie Image sped six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 on the sloppy track to register his first victory of the year in three starts. Faraway Island was second, with Hey Now Harry next and Maelstrom, the favorite, fourth in the field of eight. Shine Diulus returned $6 for $2 to win as the second choice.

title: Whimsies Made of Found Lumber
description: STEPHEN WHITTLESEY'S furniture is made from salvaged wood, which for this artist possesses a personality, smell or patina that new wood does not. His pieces are whimsical and expensive. ''Mummy's Cupboard,'' $3,200, second from left, is of lumber from the floor of an 18th-century whaling supply building in Woods Hole, Mass., that still had a briny odor. ''People are so terrified of the subject of death that I decided to make this piece, which actually fits my body, to erase that feeling of fear,'' said Mr. Whittlesey, far left. The removable shelves are painted peach and the doors are cream with green trim. It is 81 inches high. The free-standing, four-sided ''Giraffe,'' right, was made from a piece of wood that ''looked like a shoulder from a giraffe,'' he said. It is $3,600 and is 72 inches high. The shape of the ''Lily Pond'' hutch, left, reminded the artist of a frog. It stands 76 inches high and is $2,850. The most straightforward piece, ''Sound and Fury,'' second from right, is a storage unit for audio-visual equipment. The doors are natural wood, the sides are pale yellow and the shelves dark blue. It is 81 inches tall, and is $3,250. Mr. Whittlesey's furniture is being shown at the Gallery at Workbench , 470 Park Avenue South, near 32d Street, from Jan. 22 through Feb. 15.

title: JOHNSTOWN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures are not comparable since the company converted to stock from mutual form on Oct. 29.

title: PARCELLS KEEPS INTENSITY FLOWING IN DRILL
description: The Giants practiced for two hours today at the Los Angeles Rams' complex.

title: PRESSURE IN BONN FOR A RATE CUT
description: The West German central bank's highest decision-making body meets Thursday under strong pressure to cut the nation's key lending rate.

title: KEY SENATOR DOUBTS ARMS-HOSTAGE DEAL WAS REAGAN'S GOAL
description: Senator David Boren, the new Democratic chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said here today that he believed President Reagan did not intend to trade arms to Iran for hostages.

title: CASEY SAID TO HAVE HAD PROSTATE CANCER FOR YEAR
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, was under treatment for cancer of the prostate for nearly a year before his brain tumor was discovered last month, an Administration official said tonight.

title: New Venture Offers Catalogues for Sale
description: The Catalog Retail Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., of which Jay Walker, formerly of Folio, is chairman, will begin its new business of selling catalogues in retail outlets on Feb. 1. Mr. Walker says there is a demand. Catalogues priced from $1 to $3 will be displayed in freestanding racks. The first 1,000 racks will be in outlets of Waldenbooks and Eastern Newsstands, which operates in office buildings in three markets. The next move will be into the B. Dalton bookstore chain, and Mr. Walker envisions 5,000 outlets by the end of the year. Catalogue issuers already signed up, he said, include Bloomingdale's, Mark Cross, Horchow, Eddie Bauer and The Sharper Image.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $25,121,000 from the sale of First Gibraltar Mortgage Corp. Results for 1986 include provisions for loan losses of $34,125,000, losses on real estate operations of $33,147,000 and extraordinary after-tax charges of $7,270,000 related to early extinguishment of subordinated debt.

title: Boston Jury Selected to Try Ex-College Chief in Sex Case
description: A jury was empaneled today for the trial of the former president of Westfield State College, who was indicted in June on charges that he sexually assaulted two undergraduates.

title: To Pretoria, Blank Spaces Are Subversive
description: To the Editor:

title: Box-Bound Brian
description: Brian Curran, the Islander defenseman, is collecting penalty minutes at a rate of 434 for the year, a total that would make him more heavily penalized in a single season than all but one other player in N.H.L. history. Here are the 10 instances to date of greatest familiarity with the penalty box.

title: Dooley to Wake Forest
description: Bill Dooley, who left Virginia Tech on Jan. 1 after a contractual disagreement, was named head football coach at Wake Forest yesterday. Dooley, 52 years old, replaced Al Groh, who resigned last week after Wake Forest refused to renew his contract. For Dooley, it will be his second tenure in the Atlantic Coast Conference. He served at North Carolina, where he won conference titles in 1971, 1972 and 1977. In January 1978, Dooley accepted the dual position of head football coach and athletic director at Virginia Tech. His 63 victories at the Blacksburg, Va., school made him the top coach in the school's history.

title: METS GIVE BACKMAN A $2 MILLION PACT
description: Wally Backman, one of seven Mets to file for salary arbitration, became the first to settle his case, reaching agreement last night on a three-year contract for about $2 million.

title: 'EYES ON THE PRIZE, ON RIGHTS
description: By The film ''Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years'' was reviewed by Walter Goodman in The New York Times on Nov. 19, 1986. Here are excerpts from that review. The film will be broadcast in six one-hour segments over six weeks starting tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: CITYFED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a charge of $54.9 million resulting from a continuing high rate of mortgage loan prepayments and this charge takes into consideration prepayments which are anticipated to occur in the future. The company said the latest year includes total asset writedowns of $84.5 million, of which $43.9 million was for current mortgage loan prepayment experienced and $40.6 million for future prepayments. Shares earnings for all periods are fully diluted.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: MY first job out of graduate school was as an assistant loan officer at a commercial bank. Not realizing at the time that a lending area is the place where they store bodies before declaring them legally dead, I was excited and nervous about the job. But I had a problem. Nothing to wear. ''What'll I do?

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Guinness Disclosure
description: A British financier, Gerald Ronson, has admitted buying Guinness P.L.C. stock at the request of the company's former chairman to lift the company's stock price during a takeover battle.

title: PRESIDENT IS URGED TO PROTECT MARCH
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on President Reagan today to assure the safety of participants in a civil rights march planned Saturday in Forsyth County, Ga.

title: MUSIC: ROYAL PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA
description: DVORAK'S concerto not excepted, there is no work in the cello literature that allows such latitude and variety in interpretation as ''Don Quixote,'' which Lynn Harrell performed last evening with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Although Strauss cast this remarkable piece in the shape of an introduction, theme with 10 variations and finale, the most memorable readings of it treat it as a series of whimsical and pathos-laden adventures in which the formal workings-out are less prominent than a sense of tragicomic drama and shameless theatricality.

title: AMTRAK CRASH SPURS CALL FOR RANDOM DRUG TESTS
description: Spurred by the recent collision of Amtrak and Conrail trains, Congressional and Reagan Administration officials today called for Federal rules mandating random testing of transportation workers to detect drug and alcohol abuse.

title: On Paying the Brass
description: While members of Congress, Federal judges and senior civilians in the Government stand to get sizable pay increases in early February unless Congress votes them down, most of the nation's military leaders will gain only modestly.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Deal at the Manhattan Club Produces a Strange Ending
description: Once in a long while, perhaps once a year, there is a really unusual ending. A strong candidate for the ''weirdest ending of 1986'' title arose from the deal shown in the diagram. It was played, just before the end of the year, at the Manhattan Club, at 27 West 72d Street.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KHASHOGGI'S SUITE IS ATTACHED
description: An Olympic Tower suite in Manhattan belonging to the Saudi investor Adnan M. Khashoggi has been attached by a judge in a dispute over money Mr. Khashoggi owes a British company.

title: MAN BEHIND MEN BEHIND CAMERAS
description: The scene is Super Bowl XXI. The Broncos and the Giants are lined up opposite each other as the Giants' quarterback prepares to take the snap from center.

title: Red Wings Beat Islanders, 8-5
description: Newly acquired Brent Ashton scored twice and had two assists during Detroit's six-goal second period tonight to help the Red Wings to an 8-5 victory over the Islanders.

title: 'Whipping Boy' Wins Newbery Book Award
description: The John Newbery Medal for the outstanding children's book of the year was awarded Monday to ''The Whipping Boy'' by Sid Fleischman (Greenwillow Books). The Randolph Caldecott Medal, honoring the year's most distinguished American picture-book for children, was awarded to Richard Egielski, illustrator of ''Hey, Al'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), written by Arthur Yorinks.

title: DANCE: KAROLE ARMITAGE
description: THE Armitage Ballet, the new company directed by Karole Armitage that opened Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater (Eighth Avenue and 19th Street), is just what its name implies: a ballet company. Ms. Armitage initially attracted attention as a performer with Merce Cunningham's modern-dance company and as a choreographer for her own modern-dance group. Nevertheless, she has studied ballet and was once a member of the Geneva Ballet of Switzerland.

title: CUOMO'S PROPOSED BUDGET DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Less than 24 hours after Governor Cuomo proposed a $40.9 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1, the plan was widely assailed today by Democrats and Republicans alike, who demanded greater tax cuts.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in March 1986 and no year-ago figures are available.

title: SCIENTIST RETURNING TO LABORATORY WHERE IDEA INSPIRED 'STAR WARS'
description: The scientist whose idea for an X-ray laser inspired President Reagan's plan for a space-based defense against missiles is returning to the nuclear weapons research center he left in October because of objections to military work.

title: U.S. News to Accept Condom Advertisement
description: Right on the heels of KRON-TV, San Francisco, becoming the first major-market TV station to agree to accept condom advertising, U.S. News & World Report announced yesterday that it would do the same, ''in accordance with the magazine's existing standards as to truthfulness and appropriate presentation of the subject matter.'' It is the first news magazine to adopt that policy.

title: George Goes to Miami
description: Jeff George, former quarterback at Purdue, said yesterday that he will switch to Miami as a transfer student. George said earlier this month that he had decided to leave Purdue, where he is completing his freshman year. He will be eligible to play three years with the Hurricanes, starting with the 1988 season. At a news conference in Indianapolis, George said he had no animosity toward Purdue and thanked George King, the athletic director, for giving him the release that will allow him to transfer. ''I came to Purdue as you all know because of Coach Burtnett's passing philosophy and the fact I wanted to stay in Indiana,'' George said, referring to Leon Burtnett. ''Things didn't work out as we hoped this year.'' George first expressed concern about staying with the Boilermakers after Fred Akers was hired on Dec. 10 to replace Burtnett, who finished 3-8. George said that the passing philosophy of Jimmy Johnson, the Miami coach, was a major reason he decided to join the Hurricanes.

title: CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Only Those Served by Public Housing Like It
description: To the Editor:

title: People Express Head to Shift
description: Donald C. Burr, a founder and president of People Express Inc., will become an executive vice president of the Texas Air Corporation on Feb. 1. People Express has been acquired by Texas Air and will be merged into its Continental Airlines on that date. Mr. Burr will also be chairman of Continental's executive committee.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,168,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $739,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Chili Days Are Here Again
description: If there are those who doubt that a sense of renaissance is running through the Democratic Party, let them note that Robert S. Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman, has once again scheduled his annual chili fest for the press, for Feb. 17.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from operations of the properties distributed of $213,000 for the quarter and $2,061,000 for the year.

title: The Right Message
description: Arizona was notable by its absence from the ranks of states celebrating Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday this year. The new Governor, Evan Mecham, in his first official act canceled the state holiday that former Gov. Bruce Babbitt decreed last year. Now, in a simple but eloquent protest, Democratic National Chairman Paul Kirk has moved a party council meeting that was scheduled for next month in Tucson.

title: Charting China's Change
description: A Chinese pundit, examining the political turmoil in the United States, could advance a ''Dozen-Year White House Foul-up Cycle.''

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect a pooling of interests.

title: SUPREME COURT HEARS ARGUMENTS ON ISSUE OF PREVENTIVE DETENTION
description: Solicitor General Charles Fried urged the Supreme Court today to uphold use of a 1984 Federal law to jail a ''lethally dangerous'' Mafia leader and a co-defendant before trial in order to prevent them from carrying on crime that he said included ''murder and mayhem.''

title: CONCERT: THE CZECH PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Czech Philharmonic's second New York performance, under the direction of Vaclav Neumann at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, was one of the most exciting concerts this listener has attended in some time.

title: PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Firm Increases Van Heusen Stake
description: An investment firm controlled by trusts of the wealthy Texan Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf has raised its stake in the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation to 19 percent, or 1.1 million shares, from 13.79 percent.

title: BIG CHARGE PUTS UNISYS IN THE RED
description: The Unisys Corporation lost $188.5 million in the fourth quarter because of a huge one-time charge to cover the costs of its creation through the merger of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, the computer maker said today.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $530 million on the sale of the company's E.J. Brach confectionary business on Dec. 31, and $495 million in special charges, which resulted in an increase in net income of $15 million for the latest quarter and year.

title: DOW POSTS FIRST LOSS THE YEAR
description: The streak that has had Wall Street grinning since Jan. 2 is over.

title: A Fight to Finish - And Beyond
description: Full-scale brawls, rare enough in college basketball, are unheard of in the women's version of the sport, which makes the one that broke out between Missouri and Oklahoma at Columbia, Mo., last Saturday night one for the record books. The melee, which involved both coaches and half a dozen or so players from each team, erupted moments after the final buzzer of a 74-72 Missouri victory, and before it was over one Sooner player had a broken finger, one Tiger player had a broken nose, and both teams had enough bumps and bruises to last them a season.

title: Don't Call Him Rambo
description: It turns out that he played five games this season with a fractured jaw. Two other games on a cracked big right toe. And when Mark Bavaro speaks, he sounds as if Sylvester Stallone were his voice coach. But as imposing as the Giants' all-pro tight end is at 6 feet 4 inches and 245 pounds, he doesn't like to be called Rambo. ''Why not?'' somebody asked. ''Because Rambo exploited the Vietnam veteran,'' he said, ''I have a lot of respect for the people in my family who were in Vietnam.'' ''Who in your family?'' ''My uncle, Donald Bavaro, and my cousin, Bobby Rossi.'' ''Were they Army officers?'' ''No,'' he said. ''Just regular old soldiers.''

title: Yields Are Down a Bit
description: Yields on money market accounts, certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds fell a bit in the week ended yesterday.

title: LOFTON TRIAL ORDERED
description: James Lofton of the Green Bay Packers was ordered by a judge to stand trial on a charge of sexual assault after hearing testimony from a woman who said Lofton had attacked her. Lofton pleaded not guilty, and Judge Alexander Grant of Brown County Circuit Court set trial for May 18. Lofton said he was confident that he would be exonerated. ''Hopefully, it will be over quickly so I can move on to the next football season,'' he said. Lofton missed the final game of the season after Forrest Gregg, the Packers' coach, suspended him on Dec. 18, the day Lofton was arrested.

title: THEODORE STREIBERT, FIRST DIRECTOR OF U.S.I.A.
description: Theodore C. Streibert, first director of the United States Information Agency and a longtime broadcasting executive, died Sunday at his home in Laurel Hollow, Syosset, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: STARTING OUT ON THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: Questioners, dozens and dozens of questioners, milled about the football field at Orange Coast College as the Denver Broncos stood in the sunshine in their white uniforms. The anxiety of a football game seemed a long way away. Opinions were solicited on issues such as the size of a point spread and impressions of corporate America's sporting festival. If there was any doubt that the circus had come to town, the cheerleaders from the host school, in their white uniforms with OCC on the front, punctuated the occasion by cheering conversations.

title: Rescued Motorist Dies in Hospital
description: A Long Island man who was saved from drowning Monday when his van slid off Interstate 95 and into a Connecticut river, died last night of heart failure at Yale-New Haven Hospital where he had been under intensive care since the accident, officials said.

title: The Subversive Federal Debt
description: Wall Street knows it. Main Street knows it. Congress knows it. But the Reagan White House continues to pretend it isn't so.

title: GOODEN PREPARES FOR CASE
description: Dwight Gooden, the Mets' star pitcher who faces two Florida felony charges carrying penalties of up to 10 years in prison, was preparing for arraignment in a Tampa courtroom tomorrow morning amid indications that he would be able to avoid a jail term by pleading no contest to the charges and accepting a year's probation.

title: Text of Joint Currency Statement
description: Following is the text of a joint United States-Japan statement on an agreement by the two nations to monitor their currency exchange rates, as released tonight by the Treasury Department:

title: GROVE HALL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in August.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 31.

title: DREXEL STUNS NAVY; ROBINSON SCORES 44
description: Casper Cooper scored 23 points tonight to lead Drexel past 18th-ranked Navy, 83-80, at the Palestra. David Robinson led the Midshipmen with 44 points and 14 rebounds.

title: State Bar to Jobless Pay After Pregnancy Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that states are not required to pay unemployment benefits to women whose employers refuse to reinstate them after absences for pregnancy or childbirth.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHULTZ DISCLOSES SECRET IRAN TALKS UNTIL LAST MONTH
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said in a closed Congressional hearing today that as late as December, the United States was still using a secret channel involving C.I.A. officials to meet with Iranians despite the furor after the disclosure a month earlier of arms sales to Iran, committee members said.

title: MCCLAIN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADAMS-RUSSELL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: The company said the operating results for the quarter include RHG Electronics, acquired in January 1986, but do not include SDI Inc. and Reaction Instruments Inc., acquired at the end of December 1986.

title: Reading Scores of New York Secondary and Junior High Schools
description: Following are the scores released by the New York City Board of Education on the reading test given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1986.

title: THE DANCE: 'CINDERELLA' FROM LYONS
description: THE astonishingly original and magical production of ''Cinderella'' that the French choreographer Maguy Marin has created for the Lyons Opera Ballet can already be called a major event in the entire season. It is something different, unlike anything we now see in New York.

title: BANGKOK HOUSES PUT ON EUROPEAN AIRS
description: A ROMAN extravanganza, a cosy corner of Bavaria, the whitewashed stucco of Iberia: they could all be part of a Floridian fantasy or the makings of a southern California developer's brochure. But these aren't. They are the most sought-after homes of Bangkok's newly rich.

title: New Maryland Leader Sounds an Old Theme
description: William D. Schaefer, the former Mayor of Baltimore, was sworn in today as Maryland's new Governor, sounding his familiar theme of putting people first and ''doing it now.''

title: THEORY ON CALCIUM AND BONE LOSS IS DISPUTED
description: Consuming extra calcium appears to have little effect on aging bones, even though it is often recommended as a way to protect older women from fractures, a new study indicates.

title: Surgeons Strike in Italy
description: Thousands of Italian surgeons refused today to operate except in urgent cases, in the latest of a series of nationwide medical strikes. The two-day strike by the surgeons was a protest against rates of pay in public hospitals.

title: Figure in Winans Case Indicted on 55 Counts
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted David W. C. Clark, a lawyer who formerly worked in New York, on 55 felony counts in an extension of the insider trading case centering on R. Foster Winans, the former reporter for The Wall Street Journal.

title: UNITED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: United Savings is based in Vienna, Va.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The biggest trading partner of the United States is not West Germany or Japan, it's right here, by a long shot. And the Government of Canada, and Canadians, don't want to be on anybody's back burner, or taken for granted at any time.'' - Prime Minister

title: Vouchers No Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results include a $22 million increase in the provision for loan losses for the year 1986, which included a $7.9 million increase in the fourth quarter. Results for the latest periods also include a charge of $15.3 million for the preliminary settlement of litigation primarily related to an oil and gs loan. The same periods include an increase in expenses of $4.2 million incurred in the reorganization with Midlantic Banks Inc. Of the $4.2 million, $3.6 million was charged against fourth quarter earnings.

title: F.D.I.C. CHIEF SEES BANK FAILURE RISE
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned today of a ''sizable'' increase in the number of bank failures in 1987 over last year's record levels.

title: KEYCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax litigation charge of $2.8 million. c-Includes a pension settlement gain of $4.7 million. d-Includes a charge of $3.6 million from a company-wide review of assets and operations. e-Net loss

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Newspaper Group Calls Off Meeing in Arizona as Protest
description: An organization representing 134 black-owned weekly and daily newspapers canceled a convention here today, saying it wanted to send a message to Gov. Evan Mecham, who rescinded a state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. On Tuesday, Paul G. Kirk Jr., the chairman of the Democratic Party, announced that a meeting of the party's finance council had been moved from Tucson to California to protest the cancellation of the King holiday.

title: PRESS VS. PALACE: AQUINO WIELDS A SWORD
description: The word ''media,'' a spokesman for President Corazon C. Aquino said in the early days of her Government, is the plural for ''mediocre.''

title: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a series of extraordinary costs totalling about $1.8 million and which include a provision for closing down the company's unprofitable Tandy Brass division, costs related to its annual stockholders meeting, and the hiring of investment banking counsel to evaluate an unsolicited corporate takeover proposal. Year-ago sales and earnings were restated to reflect an acquisition.

title: LILLIANA W. TERUZZI
description: Lilliana W. Teruzzi, a former opera singer and donor of the $2,500 Teruzzi Award for aspiring singers in the mid-1960's, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: Perfect Blend
description: One year after the State Department of Education lifted rules forbidding girls to play contact sports against boys, Lynn Auth, a senior at Edgemont High in Scarsdale, has nailed down a spot as a right wing on the school's hockey team. And though her status as the only girl in the Westchester-Rockland Interscholastic Ice Hockey League may seem extraordinary to others, she's fully comfortable with it. ''I love skating and team sports,'' says Auth, ''so hockey was the perfect blend.''

title: NOTE AND BOND RATES UP A BIT
description: Interest rates on Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants awaited the outcome of a meeting between Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Unionist Denied Parole
description: A former president of the teamsters' union, Roy Lee Williams, has been denied a request to be paroled from a Federal prison hospital in Missouri, where he is serving a 10-year term for conspiring to bribe a United States Senator, the Justice Department said today. The Parole Commission made the decision Tuesday. Mr. Williams and four other men were convicted of conspiring to bribe Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada, in 1979 when he was a Senator.

title: KNICKS SURGE, THEN COLLAPSE
description: If the Knicks expect to harbor hopes of qualifying for the playoffs much longer, they cannot afford to endure too many more nights like this. Just one game after one of their most meaningful victories of the season, against the defending champions, the Boston Celtics, the Knicks tumbled back to mediocrity.

title: Arthur Stanton, 69, Chairman Of Distributor of Volkswagen
