description: Arthur Stanton, chairman of World-Wide Volkswagen of Orangeburg in Rockland County, N.Y., died of heart failure Tuesday in Maui, Hawaii. Mr. Stanton was attending a business meeting in Maui. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST OAK BROOK BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE APPROVES HIGHWAY AND MASS TRANSIT BILL
description: The House of Representatives today voted 401 to 20 to authorize highway and mass transit projects that could cost up to $91.6 billion over the next five years. The bill retains the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.

title: Japanese Reaction: Uncertainty, Disappointment
description: Government officials, economists and traders said today they were unsure of how to interpret a United States-Japan statement on exchange rates.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $406,000, reflecting a gain of $16.1 million on the sale of securities in connection with the acquisition of Sanders Assoc. and non-recurring costs of $17.8 million previously deferred in connection with an ongoing foreign production program. The net charge also reflects a $2.3 million gain on the sale of a plastic packaging subsidiary and a $1 million writedown of a minority interest investment.

title: U.N. CHIEF PESSIMISTIC AFTER LATIN PEACE TRIP
description: A tour of Central America by the foreign ministers of eight countries and the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States has failed to break new ground in the effort to reduce hostilities in the region, according to some diplomats involved.

title: UNISYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special charges of $280 million that cover costs for restructuring and repositioning of the company; Unisys was created by the merger of Burroughs Corp. and Sperry Corp. last year. The charges included $201 million for the closing and consolidation of manufacturing and administrative operations, reduction of employment levels and divestiture of operations; the charges also included $79 million reflecting provisions for discontinuance of non-strategic programs and excess assets, investment and other asset valuation adjustments, and other charges. c-Net income

title: Norwest Markets Issue of 7 7/8% Notes
description: The Norwest Corporation is selling $100 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1997 at par. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets heads the underwriters.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Arms Control Out of Control
description: After six years and two summit meetings, the Reagan Administration's arms control policy remains in near-total disarray. The State and Defense Departments remain consistently at war. The weak National Security Council staff still fails to enforce order. And now even the most elemental coordination between decisions on strategic weapons and negotiating positions approaches breakdown.

title: TIP LEADS TO THE ARREST OF RADICAL SOUGHT IN 1970 OREGON CASE
description: A leader of the Weather Underground who had spent 17 years in hiding and was once listed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as ''the most-wanted fugitive terrorist'' was arrested Monday in Eugene, Ore.

title: 3D DRUG MIXUP SINCE 1981 BY PARAMEDICS IS REPORTED
description: For the third time in the last six years, a city ambulance crew has mistakenly switched identically shaped drug bottles and injected a potentially fatal dose of a powerful heart medication to a patient, the city's Emergency Medical Services said yesterday.

title: Steel Output Off in 1986
description: Crude steel production in the non-Communist world fell 4.3 percent last year, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today, to 416.9 million tons from 1985's 435.5 million. The decline was led by the United States, where output fell 8 percent, to 72.9 million tons, from 79.2 million.

title: CITIZENS FIRST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Platoon' Meets Rambo
description: A father inclined to worry about his son finds reason to be grateful for the ultra-realistic Vietnam war movie ''Platoon.''

title: AMR Income Slides 73%
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines Inc., reported a 73 percent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter. With traffic up and revenues flat, the airline was apparently the victim of the fare wars that shook the industry.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 17
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $190,000. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $35,000 and a gain of $150,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Talking Deals; Little Gain Seen for USX
description: The USX Corporation has long been viewed by labor as the ''big bully'' of steelmakers and had, at one time, set the bargaining standards for the industry. But the tentative settlement reached last weekend to end a six-month work stoppage - the longest in the industry's history -resulted in a complex pact that many say gave the United Steelworkers union some important victories.

title: METROBANC, FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRUST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include gains on the sale of investments of $8,902,000 for the latest quarter and $5,303,000 in the year-ago period.

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represent gross earnings.

title: WITH TAYLOR ON FIELD, STRATEGY CHANGES
description: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants is arguably the best linebacker ever to have played football. There is a common perception that he has changed the nature of defenses. Actually, he has changed the nature of offenses.

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $16.8 million from the sale of surplus land and $6.5 million from the adoption of FASBS No. 87. c-Net loss after an after-tax charge of $230 million for the company's restructuring program and including a gain of $24,954,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DANCING: WHO WORE WHAT WHEN
description: THIS has been quite a season for exhibitions tracing the history of social dancing.

title: 12 SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS SLAIN IN HOME
description: Assailants burst into a home in a black township near Durban today and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing 12 people, the police said. Seven of the victims were children.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FT. MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,920,000.

title: Most Violence Victims Said to Know Attackers
description: In the last few years, fewer than half, or 46 percent, of reported violent crimes were committed by complete strangers, according to a report from a Justice Department agency.

title: WIESEL WARNS OF PERILS IN DISUNITY AMONG JEWS
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, warned yesterday that internal disunity was ''the most serious danger facing the Jewish people,'' more ominous than the threats from anti-Semitism or assimilation.

title: RECITAL: ERIC RUSKE, HORN
description: ERIC RUSKE is a horn player of fluency and grace, and his Tuesday evening recital at the 92d Street Y was eminently satisfying.

title: BRAZIL GETS FLEXIBLE DEBT AID
description: The United States and other major industrial countries have agreed to let Brazil, the developing world's largest debtor, postpone repayment of more than $4 billion it owes them. They have also agreed on unusually flexible terms in an apparent softening of their approach to the problem of international debt.

title: V.A. ORDERED TO PAY PENALTIES
description: New sanctions were ordered against the Veterans Administration today for failing to provide documents sought by veterans who are trying to overturn a 123-year-old law that limits legal fees for challenging the agency's decisions to $10.

title: An Anti-Meese Campaign
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is in the midst of a petition campaign urging President Reagan to remove Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d from office. It reports an enthusiastic response to its mailings but concedes the campaign is unlikely to actually bring about Mr. Meese's ouster.

title: DE-ICING WITH SALT CAN HARM TREES
description: AFTER a major snowstorm, many New Yorkers de-ice their walkways with rock salt. But according to the New York City Street Tree Consortium, they may not be aware of the severe damage this can do to neighborhood street trees.

title: DOLE TESTS IOWA POLITCAL WATERS, PREPARING '88 STATE ORGANIZATION
description: Shortly before departing from Des Moines Tuesday night after a speech to hundreds of enthusiastic Iowa homebuilders, Senator Bob Dole was asked when he would start setting up a Presidential campaign organization in this pivotal state.

title: ECOLAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest second quarter results reflect the elimination of investment tax credits, offset in part by non-recurring gains on the sale of certain operations. The net effect was a reduction in after-tax earnings of 3 cents a share.

title: WALT DISNEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBC PRESENTS 'THE TORTELLIS,' A 'CHEERS' SPINOFF
description: FAMILIES, extended or nuclear, are big on television these days. Comes now ''The Tortellis.'' He's unscrupulous; she's dumb; everyone lives in Las Vegas, Nev. The new NBC series, a spinoff from ''Cheers,'' begins tonight at 9:30. It's not great, but here and there it has moments.

title: Without the L.I.R.R., Long Islanders Look for Alternative Routes...
description: For Marlena Rubin, the Long Island Rail Road strike could hardly have come at a worse time.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter and year results are restated to reflect the acquisitions of Franklin Bancorp on Jan. 24, 1986 and of Commercial Bancshares Inc. on Dec. 1, 1986. Both acquisitions were accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis. The 1985 per share earnings has also been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 24, 1986.

title: ROLE FOR HELMS DISMAYS U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Officials in the foreign policy apparatus reacted with dismay today to the election of Jesse Helms, the combative conservative from North Carolina, as ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of 29 cents a share from the sale of assets and 16 cents a share from new accounting standards. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $73 million, or $1.29 a share, from the sale of Master Builders.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes land sales of $265,747 and $1,031,807 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes land sales of $3,398,848 and $4,899,770 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Without the L.I.R.R., Long Islanders Look for Alternative Routes... To Traverse a Strange Land Called Queens
description: You couldn't quite call it an invasion of Queens. It was more of an incursion.

title: CASA BLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,220,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months.

title: Accounts
description: * Lotus Development Corporation, Cambridge, Mass., a microcomputer software company, to Leonard Monahan Saabye, Providence, R.I.

title: 6 OF CITY's TOP 10 SCHOOLS IN READING TESTS ARE ON S.I.
description: Of the 10 elementary schools that scored highest in the citywide reading test administered last spring, six are on Staten Island -including the top-ranking school, Public School 5 in Huguenot.

title: Murdoch Seen Leading in Bid
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation still appears to have the upper hand in the takeover battle with John Fairfax Ltd. for the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., analysts here said today. They noted that Herald and

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The net increases for the current periods are primarily due to a $3,927,300 gain on the sale of the Alexandria cable system to one of the company's limited partnerships in November.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL CERAMICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been restated to reflect the March 1986 and November 1986 3-for-2 stock splits.

title: N.C.A.A. Accepts Tulane Reforms
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association says it will accept Tulane University's termination of its men's basketball program and other corrective actions for rule violations that were revealed during an investigation of point-shaving.

title: COLUMN ONE: Capitol Report; Freshmen Learn The Ropes in House
description: Getting on the committee of his choice came down to simple mathematics for Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, a freshman Democrat from the 1st District of New York, in Suffolk County.

title: DEFENSE IN 'BELL JAR' TRIAL MAKES OPENING POINTS
description: In writing a novel or a screenplay, an author has great latitude in using and disguising autobiographical and biographical material, defense attorneys argued today in Federal District Court here in the libel trial that centers on a film of the late Sylvia Plath's novel, ''The Bell Jar.''

title: From Brazil to Koch: Please Cancel a Visit
description: Another international incident avoided. Or maybe just postponed.

title: RACIAL VIOLENCE FOCUS OF BLACKS IN DAY OF PROTEST
description: In moves protesting the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, last month, 3,000 marchers chanted noisily through Manhattan and small groups gathered to discuss racial violence. But black shoppers, for the most part, ignored calls for a boycott of white-owned businesses.

title: CONSTELLATION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split that became effective Sept. 30.

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a one-time non-cash charge of $364,981,000 from the purchase of the assets of its first two R&D partnerships. c-Net income. Per share earnings reflect the pending Jan. 28 2-for-1 stock split.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year nets include a charge of $683,000 from repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: DREAMS OF CITIZENSHIP RIDE ON DELUGE OF MAIL
description: Just seconds before midnight, the countdown began Tuesday: ''Nine, eight, seven, six, five, four three, two, one.''

title: CABARET: SONGS BY MARC SHAIMAN
description: AS an Off Broadway composer (''Livin' Dolls,'' ''Dementos'') and as an arranger-accompanist for Bette Midler and other performers, Marc Shaiman has established himself in recent years as a formidable talent who, had he arrived a decade ago, would almost certainly have been Broadway bound.

title: ECUADOR STARTING ABDUCTION INQUIRY
description: The Government disregarded a promise made by President Leon Febres Cordero while he was in captivity last week and announced Wednesday that it was beginning a criminal investigation into the kidnapping of the President by rebel air force commmandos.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Van Lines Inc., Chicago, appointed Peter Mazzetti president.

title: No Headline
description: Karsten Mahlmann does not fit the stereotypical image of a commodities broker, in spite of his nickname, ''Cash.'' In fact, Mr. Mahlmann, a soft-spoken and reserved German immigrant, more resembles a corporate chief executive than some of the more boisterous denizens of Chicago's exchanges.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL BANCORP (WISC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLAN TO STUDY CONTENT ON PBS SAID TO FACE REJECTION
description: The board of directors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is not expected to authorize a proposed ''content analysis'' of public-broadcasting programs at its next meeting tomorrow, according to corporation sources.

title: MADNESS IS THE NORM AT GIANTS' HOTEL
description: These days the lobby of the Westin South Coast Plaza, where the Giants are staying while preparing for the Super Bowl, is a forest of fans, players, cameras, notebooks and questions.

title: TWO SIDES REST IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL AFTER 15 MONTHS OF EVIDENCE
description: Both sides rested yesterday in the Federal ''pizza connection'' case - a 15-month-old trial that has involved hundreds of witnesses and taped conversations, 37,000 pages of transcripts and thousands of documents and other exhibits.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $104,000. The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February 1986, and a 4-for-3 stock split in April 1986.

title: Koch Sends Champagne
description: Mayor Koch may have refused to give the Giants a ticker-tape parade at city expense, but he does have an offering for them - champagne.

title: JAZZ: NEW YORK STRING TRIO
description: THE String Trio of New York opened Sweet Basil's festival of new jazz, ''Music Is an Open Sky,'' with finely etched pieces that touched on classical and folk music. Two-thirds of the trio - the bassist John Lindberg and the guitarist John Emery - have been together for 10 years; the violinist Charles Burnham recently replaced Billy Bang in the group.

title: NEW YORK AREA COSTS UP 2.6% IN '86
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose 2.6 percent in 1986, the smallest annual increase since 1967, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: AFGHAN VISIT SHOWS DAMAGE OF A CONTINUING WAR
description: The wind-swept graves that punctuate the barren hills outside this provincial capital, as well as the helicopters roaring overhead and the tanks that share the dusty highway with camels and oxen, belie the Government's contention that this area has been pacified.

title: Koch Warns of Halt On Chinatown Plan
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that a long-delayed housing project in Chinatown for the elderly, promised by the city in 1982 during negotiations over siting a 500-bed jail in the area -might not be built unless a dispute could be resolved over the community group supervising the project.

title: Chrysler Extension
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would extend indefinitely the cut-rate financing program that had been scheduled to end today. The program offers financing as low as 3.9 percent for 24-month loans, or cash allowances of as much as $1,000. The program applies to 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt E, DL and Premier models; Plymouth Reliants, and Dodge Aries, pickup trucks and Ramcharge sport utility vehicles.

title: Moscow Opening
description: For the Soviet Union to invite a defector to return as an honored guest once was unthinkable. A 1985 film, ''White Nights,'' was based on the opposite premise - that any defector unlucky enough to crash land in Soviet territory would be abducted by the K.G.B. The star of that film was Mikhail Baryshnikov, the dancer who in real life defected in 1974. Now the director of the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow has just invited him to return for a guest performance.

title: NAVRATILOVA TO FACE MANDIKOVA IN FINAL
description: Martina Navratilova, the defending champion, and Hana Mandlikova advanced today to the women's singles final in the Australian Open championships at Kooyong.

title: FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert CMO Trust F is offering $200 million of collateralized mortgage obligations backed by 10 percent Federal National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates.

title: CAPITOL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MACHEL CRASH INQUIRY STARTS
description: An inquiry into the plane crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique opened hearings Tuesday and was told that Soviet crew members reported moments before the accident that they could not find the airport in Mozambique's capital.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGE: Cincinnati at Louisville (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M.) North Carolina at Wake Forest (TV - ESPN, 9P.M.) Auburn at Alabama (TV -USA, 8 P.M.) Yale at Army (Radio - WFAS 1239, 7:30 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Phoenix Open, Tournament Players Club, Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are based on the average number of common equivalent shares outstanding adjusted for the 2-for-1 common stock split effective March 28, 1986.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL CHAMBER TAKES IN HOMELESS
description: Thomas Ricardo Castro has been homeless almost all the four months of his life. Tuesday night he, his mother and 50 others slept in the safety and warmth of the cathedral-arched chambers of the City Council.

title: FOR WAR MEMORIAL, A BIT OF ESTHETIC DEMOCRACY
description: Thousands of Muscovites, unaccustomed to being asked their opinion about a public works project, thronged the city's Central Exhibition Hall last week to quarrel over proposed designs for what is to be the Soviet Union's grandest war memorial, a 330-acre Moscow park celebrating the victory over fascism.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from the restructuring of operations of $28.1 million, or 97 cents a share, in the quarter and $6.8 million, or 23 cents a share, for the year. In the latest quarter and year the company had preferred dividend requirements of $12.7 million. Also, a change in accounting for pensions increased net income by $6.3 million for the quarter and $21.3 million for the year. c-After charges from the restructuring of operations of $18.8 million in the quarter and $12.8 milion in the year.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $255,000 and $424,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $461,000 for the quarter and $648,000 for the 6 months, and a gain from disposal of discontinued business of $68,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Weight Watchers Unit Chooses Butner Agency
description: Lawrence Butner Advertising, specialists in the use of broadcast and cable advertising for direct marketing, has just been tapped by Weight Watchers magazine to handle its first such pitch for subscribers.

title: Borden Avenue Men's Shelter Plan Is Unwise
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Reagan's involvement with the Iran arms affair incorrectly located the two men shown. Senator Dave Durenberger was at the left and David M. Abshire at the right.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
REAGAN TO SPEAK TO INVESTIGATORS
description: President Reagan will submit to questioning Monday by his special commission that is examining the National Security Council in light of the Iran-contra affair, the White House announced today.

title: HOME & CITY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2,040,000. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,864,000 for the quarter and $2,561,000 for the year. The company went public on Feb. 13, 1986.

title: Atlantic Institute Appoints Andrew J. Pierre as Director
description: Dr. Andrew J. Pierre, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, has been appointed director general of the Atlantic Institute for International Affairs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page B8 in some copies yesterday with an article about Mayor Koch's State of the City Address misidentified the man at the left. He was Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, not Peter F. Vallone, the City Council majority leader.

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring charges totalling $28.9 million related to an early retirement program and the withdrawal of three products due to tampering.

title: REAGAN COMPROMISE IS REJECTED
description: The Senate, emphatically rejecting President Reagan's compromise proposal for amending the Clean Water Act, today overwhelmingly passed a bill identical with the one he vetoed last November.

title: Zenith Expansion
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said it would add 600 jobs at its plant in Melrose Park, Ill., a suburb, to build tubes used as computer monitors. Production of the new tubes, which Zenith says are the first with a perfectly flat front, is scheduled to begin in the second quarter. Zenith said $700,000 of job training aid from government agencies would help in the expansion.

title: Volvo's Profit Declines
description: A.B. Volvo, the Swedish car maker, today reported a small drop in 1986 sales and earnings, blaming the effects of a weakening dollar on the United States market. Volvo's pretax earnings fell to $1.15 billion from 1985's $1.16 billion.

title: RANGERS ACQUIRE DUGUAY AGAIN
description: There had been a lull. Twenty-four hours went by and the Rangers did not make a transaction. Then the quiet period ended as it always does during Phil Esposito's ''why not'' regime.

title: Plant Catalogues' Sweet Seduction
description: LIKE many other gardeners, I imagine, I feel sorry for the postman at this time of year.

title: Rockland Center Plans 40th-Year Programs
description: The Rockland Center for the Arts is celebrating its 40th anniversary, and tomorrow at 8 P.M., the center will present the first of a number of special events that will be held throughout the year - a lecture by the writer Toni Morrison. Miss Morrison is a prize-winning novelist, playwright and Albert Schweitzer Professor at the State University of New York at Albany. She will speak on ''Memory and Creation.'' A reception will follow the event.

title: CASEY PROSTATE CANCER CONFIRMED
description: Hospital officials confirmed today that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, who is hospitalized for treatment of brain cancer, has also suffered recently from prostate cancer.

title: Help From New Zealand
description: The New Zealand syndicate that lost to Dennis Conner in the challenger's final, will help the Australian effort to defend the America's Cup.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CASES SURPASS RECORD SET IN 1986
description: Contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded the record of $2,702.695.23 received in the previous appeal. That amount was reached in late February last year. As of yesterday, gifts to the 75th appeal totaled $2,717,840.96.

title: Long-Term Treasuries Lower
description: Renewed weakness in the dollar sent Treasury note and bond prices lower yesterday, even though data on fourth-quarter G.N.P. was weaker than forecast and heightened expectations of anemic growth in the first quarter.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (IND)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and prior year per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1986 and a 5 percent stock dividend that will be paid Jan. 23.

title: 'Super' TV Slot - For $40,000!
description: You are going to find it hard to believe, but you can still get a one-minute commercial time slot during a Super Bowl telecast for only $40,000.

title: Faculty Calls Foul on Knight
description: Bob Knight has a temper, and as one who sets high standards for his Indiana University players (and even higher standards for referees), he has frequent occasions to lose it. That, coupled with a coaching style that might best be described as leadership through intimidation, has helped him mold winning basketball teams. It has also made him a bit of a pariah to some faculty members.

title: Largest of 'Sunflowers' By van Gogh to Be Sold
description: Vincent van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' - the largest of seven painted by the artist in 1888 and 1889 at Arles, France - will be auctioned by Christie's in London on March 30, Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York, announced yesterday.

title: CROSSLAND SAVINGS FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $17,303,000 for the quarter and $57,752,000 for the year. c-Includes gains of $11,776,000 for the quarter and $34,385,000 for the year from early extinguishment of debt. The per share earnings for both year-ago periods are for the period Oct. 30, 1985 (initial issue of equity securities) to Dec. 31, 1985.

title: MORALITY URGED IN SEX EDUCATION
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett called on school boards today to insist that sex education courses teach children not to engage in sexual intercourse.

title: HARRIS BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AUCTIONS
description: ''WHY is this desk a Philadelphia piece and not a New York piece?''

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago 9 months figures include a charge of 21 cents a share for the closing of the Oakland plant.

title: Alcoa, Inland Have Profits
description: Two large and beleaguered companies in basic industries - Inland Steel and Alcoa - yesterday reported fourth-quarter profits after having had losses in the 1985 period.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NETWORK STAKE SOLD BY TURNER
description: In a move that keeps Ted Turner in control of the Turner Broadcasting System, the company said yesterday that it had received $550 million in financing from cable operators and Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Boxing Notebook; TORRES WANTS AN ARBITRATOR FOR CONFLICTS
description: When Don King promoted the Tim Witherspoon-James (Bonecrusher) Smith heavyweight title fight last month in which his son, Carl, had managerial interests in both fighters, the words ''conflict of interest'' were beaten like a drum.

title: YEAR-OLD SEX CASE IN BRITAIN STIRS CONCERN OVER U.S. TIES
description: A sex-offense case involving a British child and the husband of an American diplomat formerly based in London came to light this week and immediately attracted national attention.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ONCE AGAIN, TOKYO'S IN TROUBLE OVER FINGERPRINTING OF ALIENS
description: Japan has put together a new set of regulations to fingerprint and keep track of the foreigners in its midst.

title: Fourth Quintuplet Dies
description: Four tiny quintuplets died in their parents' arms so ''they knew that they were loved,'' their father said today as the last premature baby clung to life. ''We were not able to spend much time with most of our children, but there were special moments,'' the father, James Hawkins of Hendersonville, said soon after the fourth infant died of respiratory failure. Three of the babies died Wednesday.

title: CITY EXAMINES DEATHS OF 2 INFANTS IN FOSTER HOMES
description: The New York City Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it was investigating the deaths of two babies who died shortly after they were placed in separate foster homes by a Roman Catholic organization in Brooklyn.

title: Environmental Groups Urge Ban on Pesticide
description: A coalition of environmental groups released a study Wednesday demonstrating that a widely used pesticide caused cancer in animals and asked that the pesticide be removed from the market.

title: Stalemate In Angola
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Venancio de Moura felt the urge to address the men having lunch in the mess hall. He introduced Representative Mickey Leland, a Democrat from Houston. He said he wanted to explain why ''Americans should be welcomed as friends although Angola has no diplomatic relations with the U.S. and Washington is helping the armed bandits.'' That was a reference to Jonas Savimbi's South African-supported Unita rebels.

title: AN ANTIQUES FAIR FILLED WITH BIRDS, BEASTS AND BIPEDS AT THE ARMORY
description: BIRDS, beasts and bipeds abound at the 1987 Winter Antiques Show, the nation's most prestigious antiques extravaganza, opening today in previews and tomorrow to the public for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: USX Raises Prices
description: The USX Corporation's steel unit announced increases in the published prices of steel products effective May 5. USX said the increases, which averaged 3 to 5 percent, would be $15 a ton on hot-rolled steel, $20 a ton on cold-rolled products and $30 a ton on coated steel products. The company said it did not plan to discount its steel products to recapture the market share it lost during a six-month labor shutdown.

title: Essence Bans Ads Of Revlon
description: ESSENCE COMMUNICATIONS, publishers of Essence, a magazine for black women, has announced that it will ban further advertising by Revlon from its pages because of a remark attributed to its president, Irving J. Bottner, last October. A Revlon spokesman said that Mr. Bottner had immediately apologized for the remark, saying that it was taken out of context.

title: OFFICIAL CALLS IN PRESS AND KILLS HIMSELF
description: R. Budd Dwyer, the Pennsylvania State Treasurer, whose conviction for bribery last month jolted the state's Republican Party, shot and killed himself today at a news conference in his office in Harrisburg, the state capital.

title: INTERLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,835,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,521,000 for the quarter and $598,000 for the year.

title: ART: DAVID SALLE'S WORKS SHOWN AT THE WHITNEY
description: THE exhibition of David Salle's work that has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art (945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street) and will be on view there through March 29, is a sobering, exhilarating event, full of handsome, intelligently made paintings that mirror contemporary life in ways we cannot help but find poignant, jarring and sometimes offensive. In addition, they do this to great decorative effect.

title: 3Com Acquisition
description: The 3Com Corporation, a manufacturer of computer network systems based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had acquired Centram Systems West, a software company based in Berkeley, Calif., that has developed TOPS, the first network software product for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computer.

title: NEW YORKERS ENDURE A DAY WHOSE BYWORD WAS 'IMPOSSIBLE'
description: Even Donald J. Trump couldn't fix the Wollman Rink yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of reading scores for New York City's elementary and junior high schools in some copies yesterday omitted explanations for results marked with asterisks. Students with a limited proficiency in English who have been in the school system less than a year were excused from the test, and their scores were automatically put below grade level. A single asterisk indicated a school in which 10 percent or more of the students fell into this category. Two asterisks next to an elementary school indicated a school that runs only from kindergarten through second grade, and only second graders were tested. Two asterisks next to a junior high school indicated a school that includes a special program for children left back a grade.

title: GEORGIA COUNTY BRACING FOR TROUBLE
description: Two members of the Southern White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, wearing starched and pressed combat fatigues, sat in a restuarant Wednesday night in Cumming, Ga., and, as snow began to swirl outside, considered the likelihood of trouble when thousands of people gather this Saturday for a ''march against fear and intimidation'' in Forsyth County.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS (MADISON) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GUINNESS GETS OFFER BY ARGYLL
description: Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer, announced today that it had received a merger offer from the Argyll Group P.L.C. -the same company Guinness beat out last year in a takeover battle for the Distillers Company. Guinness said it had turned down the offer.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3.5 million for a staff reduction program. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the sale of a business and the effects of a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1986.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter sales results includes revenue from the Carver Tripp Wood Stain and the Emil Villa Restaurant businesses which have since been sold.

title: ART: JOSEPH CORNELL'S BOXED EPHEMERA COLLAGES
description: LIKE a tropical fish exposed to the air, a Joseph Cornell exhibition reviewed loses its luster as well as its life. Art - or the ritual of its appreciation - is not the element of these boxed ephemera, perhaps because they themselves don't behave like art. Most come in clusters for, as John Bernard Myers has pointed out, ''continuity and repetition were necessary to the unfolding of the basic theme, to the vision,'' yet each remains a little magnetic field on its own.

title: U.S., Europe Seek Accord
description: The United States and the European Community, meeting at the offices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have narrowed differences over a negotiating format in a new round of world trade liberalization talks and are expected to meet Wednesday's deadline for concluding procedural discussions, United States officials said today.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Some Feet
description: When Darrick Heath thinks he has a kick coming, he takes it. Heath, a 6-foot-5-inch forward for C. W. Post and a black belt in karate, was so incensed by a call in a recent game at Gannon University of Pennsylvania that, having carefully placed the ball on the court, he hurled himself into the air and unleashed a kick that missed the side of the backboard by less than an inch. The referees declined to call a foul, perhaps out of sheer astonishment, but Heath's teammates weren't surprised. Several times in practice, he has put his foot to the backboard, whose underside hangs 9 feet 6 inches from the floor.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: IMPERIAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $5 million. c-After charges of $65 million from retirement of a debenture and $90 million from costs associated with staff reduction and reorganization. d-After special charges of $50 million due to the deregulation of crude oil pricing.

title: COUNCIL PASSES BILL ON S.R.O. HOTEL CONVERSIONS
description: Owners of single-room-occupancy hotels would be allowed to convert or demolish rooms for a fee of $45,000 per unit under a bill approved last night by the City Council.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The company said the reversal of investment tax credits for the latest half of fiscal 1986 and the first quarter amounted to $830,000, or 2 cents a share was reflected in the latest second quarter results. The company said in the year-ago second quarter, earnings benefited from a $500,000 investment tax credit, resulting in a 4 cents a share swing in quarterly earnings. The company said the year-ago results are restated to give effect to the adoption of new pension standards in the fourth quarter of last year retroactive to the beginning of the year. This increased last year's previously published first quarter net income and share earnings by $800,000, or 2 cents a share and increased its second quarter net income and share earnings by $700,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Looking to Bonn for Bravery
description: Terrorists are pressing West Germany not to extradite Mohammed Ali Hamadei, a Lebanese accused of participating in the 1985 T.W.A. hijacking and the killing of an American passenger. Release him, the terrorists insist, backing up their demands by kidnapping two German businessmen.

title: REAGAN STATEMENTS ON IRAN DEAL: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF DECEMBER
description: A review of President Reagan's public statements on Iran last November and December shows that they were fundamentally inconsistent with events occurring at about the same time.

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of about $12 million from the sale of E.A.B.'s former administrative building in Roosevelt Field, Long Island.

title: Gulf Canada Plan
description: The Gulf Canada Corporation, a Canadian holding company, announced its restructuring into three companies in a move that is expected to strip debt from its oil and gas business and increase its shareholder value. Gulf Canada proposed to spin off its oil and gas division into a publicly traded company that will resume oil exploration off Canada's Arctic coast.

title: F.B.I. Traces Sniper Bullets In New England to One Gun
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined that the same .22-caliber weapon was used in sniping attacks in rural Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

title: LAW REVIEW ARTICLE BY MEESE ASSAILS RULE ON WARNINGS TO SUSPECTS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has prepared a long law review article attacking the Supreme Court's landmark decision requiring the police to inform criminal suspects of their legal rights, the Justice Department said today.

title: The Dole Team
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas may not have all the machinery of his 1988 Republican Presidential campaign in place yet, but he is certainly coordinating smoothly with his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation. On Wednesday, Mr. Dole had been scheduled to join a group of Republican lawmakers introducing bills to require random drug testing of railroad and airline operating personnel. But when Mrs. Dole decided to steal a small march on Congress by announcing the same day a proposal to achieve some of that goal by administrative order, her husband decided not to appear at the lawmakers' competitive news conference. One ''Dole Denounces Drugs'' headline appeared to be sufficient unto the day.

title: Subtract 43 Minutes From Times Sq. and Add 14
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTHORITIES INVESTIGATING REPORTS OF L.I. AND QUEENS RACIAL ATTACKS
description: In unrelated incidents carrying overtones of last month's Howard Beach racial attack, the police reported yesterday an assault on blacks by white youths in Deer Park, L.I., and an attack on white teen-agers by young blacks in Jamaica, Queens.

title: A.T.&T. Spending
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to spend about $2.5 billion in 1987 to expand its digital long-distance telephone network. Industry analysts said the announced expansion was a direct response to the aggressive marketing tactics of US Sprint. A.T.&T. has 11,000 miles of fiber optic lines in service and plans to build another 24,000 miles by 1989, when the company would offer digital service to 350 cities.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $168.9 million, to $234.43 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $25.0 million, to $64.99 billion. Assets of the 195 general purpose funds were up $142.0 million, to $62.52 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $51.9 million, to $106.93 billion.

title: Invitations to Moscow
description: Several hundred Americans from fields as diverse as politics, scholarship, business, foreign affairs, science and entertainment have been invited to participate in a group of international conferences in Moscow Feb. 14-16, traveling at Soviet expense. Those invited range from Robert S. McNamara and John Kenneth Galbraith to John Denver.

title: FLOOR PRICE PROPOSED
description: A plan to provide greater energy security -first proposed by the Ford Administration in the mid-1970's - was revived before a Congressional committee today by James R. Schlesinger, who served as Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration.

title: BANKAMERICA REPORTS PROFIT, ON SPECIAL GAINS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, ending a nightmare of a year on a slightly bright note, returned to profitability in the fourth quarter of 1986, though only because of special gains.

title: Market Place; Stock Analysts Raising Sights
description: SOME technical analysts - those professionals who study investor sentiment and the internal workings of the stock market - believe that equity prices, despite yesterday's explosive action, are headed still higher.

title: Church's Son Pleads Guilty
description: Chase Church, a son of Senator Frank Church of Idaho, now dead, has pleaded guilty to growing hallucinogenic ''magic mushrooms.'' Mr. Church, 29 years old, of Bethesda, Md., was arrested at his family's home in June. The police said the mushrooms contained the illegal substance psilocybin. Mr. Church pleaded guilty Tuesday in Chester County to one count of manufacturing a controlled substance.

title: MCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: American Nouvelle
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AN AMERICAN PLACE, #969 Lexington

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. SEATTLE SUPERSONICS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20P.M.) KNICKS VS. ROCKETS, at Houston, 8 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Phoenix Open, Tournament Players Club, Scottsdale, Ariz. (TV - ESPN, 4 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. OILERS, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9:20P.M.) TENNIS AUSTRALIAN OPEN, women's final, at Melbourne. (TV - ESPN, 9P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.)

title: TROOPS IN MANILA KILL 12 IN CROWD AT LEFTIST RALLY
description: In the first such incident since President Corazon C. Aquino came to power 11 months ago, troops fired into a large crowd of demonstrators Thursday and hospitals reported 12 dead and at least 94 wounded.

title: The Journalists Debate
description: The Washington journalism title for high-volume combativeness will be on the line next month when the 14th annual Conservative Political Action Conference presents a debate on ''The Media vs. the President'' between Sam Donaldson, White House correspondent of ABC News, and Robert Novak, co-author with Rowland Evans of the newspaper column Inside Report. Mark Shields, also a political columnist, will moderate the Feb. 21 session.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra, Vineyard Theater, 309 East 28th Street (683-0696). On Sunday afternoon, the New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra makes one of its rare excursions away from Michael's Pub, where it has been playing on Monday nights for 14 years. This is the band with which Woody Allen plays clarinet at the Pub. When Mr. Allen is able to join them, which is most Monday nights, the band reflects his musical tastes by leaning strongly toward traditional New Orleans-style jazz. But on those occasions when he is not present, such as Sunday afternoon at the Vineyard Theater, the style turns toward Chicago jazz of the 20's. Led by John Bucher on cornet, the band includes Dick Dreiwitz on trombone, Barbara Dreiwitz on tuba, Dick Miller on piano, Eddy Davis on banjo, Chuck Spies on drums, and a clarinetist to be named. For the 5 P.M. performance, tickets are $15 for a table with a bottle of wine included or $10 for general admission.

title: SCHEDULE OF 'FOCUS!' CONCERTS
description: ''Focus! Music in the Melting Pot: Immigration and Interaction,'' a series of concerts with dance and musical theater, opens tonight and closes next Friday at Alice Tully Hall. Other performances will be at the Juilliard Theater. All peformances are at 8 P.M. For information on obtaining tickets, which are free: 874-7515 or 874-0465. Here is a schedule of the concerts and their programs:

title: Taming Traffic Flow With Sensor System
description: JOE CONTEGNI sat behind his computer in the traffic control center, staring at the 25-foot-wide map of Long Island highways. ''I don't know,'' he muttered.

title: SOVIET CUTS OIL EXPORTS, SAYING IT BACKS OPEC
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had agreed to cut its oil exports to help OPEC increase world oil prices.

title: Murdoch Offer Under Scrutiny
description: The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal said it would examine whether Rupert Murdoch's $1.5 billion takeover offer for the Herald and Weekly Times news group breaches Australian regulations prohibiting foreigners from owning more than 15 percent of a radio or television station. The tribunal said the inquiry would start Feb. 2.

title: 4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. UP A SLUGGISH 1.7%
description: The nation's economy grew at an anemic 1.7 percent rate in the final three months of 1986, the Commerce Department reported today, a weaker showing than the Reagan Administration and private economists had expected.

title: STARK BEAUTY AMID DISRUPTIONS
description: The first major snowstorm of the winter roared up the Eastern Seaboard and across the New York metropolitan area yesterday, virtually halting transportation, commerce, education and government services and disrupting the lives of millions of people.

title: RECITAL: CAROL WILSON
description: CAROL WILSON, a soprano on the faculty of Vassar College, made her New York debut Tuesday in Weill Recital Hall. She is, as her program of Nin, Mussorgsky, Poulenc, Schubert, Ives and Richard Wilson demonstrated, a thoughtful singer of discriminating curiosity, but she could develop further in the direction of effective vocal communication of the songs to which she is drawn.

title: Hokkaido Records a Tremor
description: An earthquake registering 5.3 on the Richter scale shook Nemuro on the island of Hokkaido today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The Central Meteorological Agency said the center was in the sea about 35 miles off the Nemuro peninsula.

title: A BIG-BAND WEEKEND IN TWO BOROUGHS
description: BIG bands - a term for jazz-related orchestras of 10 to 25 musicians - were popular once, as popular as today's heavy-metal rock and heavily amplified folk-rock. But the public grew tired of hearing shouting trumpets, thundering drummers and fast, flashy unison passages for saxophones. Which is a shame, because many swing-band fans of the 30's and 40's rarely got to hear what a creative big band is really capable of.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,716,000, consisting of a penalty paid to the Federal Home Loan Bank for early repayment of borrowings, net of $1,088,000 of income tax credit. c-Net loss.

title: IT'S TIME TO GO TO MARS
description: LEAD: There was a time when America's space program was the proudest in the world. As the National Aeronautics and Space Administration landed men on the moon and launched robot emissaries to every known planet except Pluto, people all over the world - even those with grave reservations about other aspects of

title: UConn Search Begins
description: Under mounting criticism of its educational support program for athletes and widespread calls for departmental change, the University of Connecticut announced yesterday that it is launching a nationwide search to replace Athletic Director John L. Toner. Toner, a past president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, will relinquish his responsibilities as athletic director effective June 30 but continue to oversee the completion of a new campus sports complex. ''I feel there have been some strong things that have happened in our program and obviously some problems exsist that have to be corrected,'' Toner said. ''I have confidence that the university will endure and solve those problems.'' Toner said it was his decision to give up the responsibilities he has held for 17 years. A report submitted in May by a special task force on athletics criticized nearly every aspect of Connecticut's athletic department, from the way it handled its budget to cheerleaders' performances. Toner joined the university as football coach in 1966 and became athletic director in 1969.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $6 million for the quarter and $8.8 million for the year. The year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $7.6 million for the quarter and $30,937,000 for the year.

title: WHITHER CHINA? WATCH TICKER TAPE
description: This bustling British territory, which will become a part of China in just a decade, has been nervously eyeing the turmoil across its border in the last few weeks.

title: THE SCREEN: BRUCE BERESFORD'S 'FRINGE DWELLERS'
description: WITH ''The Fringe Dwellers,'' Bruce Beresford, whose American films have been a mixed bag ranging from ''Tender Mercies'' to ''King David,'' returns to his native Australia to make a small, graceful, low-keyed drama about the lives of contemporary aborigines.

title: INSIDE
description: Landmark-Panel Vacancy An outspoken member of New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission, Anthony M. Tung, will not be reappointed. Page B1. Contractor Pleads Guilty Carl A. Capasso pleaded guilty to tax evasion charges but denied that his friend Bess Myerson helped him obtain city contracts. Page B1. Inquiry on Abortion Ads The New York Attorney General's office is preparing to sue three centers its says deceptively portray themselves as abortion clinics. Page B1. G.N.P. Grows 1.7 Percent The economy increased at an anemic rate in the fourth quarter. For all of last year, growth slowed to 2.5 percent after inflation. Page D1.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a non-recurring tax credit of $3 million, or 11 cents a share and losses of $2.9 million, or 10 cents a share resulting from the company's equity in an unconsolidated affiliate.

title: STORM'S SWIFTNESS A FACTOR
description: The winter storm that pounded the Eastern Seaboard yesterday was the kind that can sometimes be more destructive than hurricanes, in terms of damage caused by high seas and coastal erosion.

title: FILM: TECHINE'S 'SCENE OF THE CRIME'
description: ''Scene of the Crime'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 27, 1986. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street. ANDRE TECHINE'S elegant thriller ''Scene of the Crime'' is alive with danger and sexual possibility, in a manner reminiscent of Claude Chabrol. Though its setting is rural, it is never bucolic, not for a moment. The film begins as a young boy takes a bicycle ride, and no sooner has he stopped to pick a flower - a sprig of oleander, which is poisonous - than he is accosted by a stranger. The man has no money, and he orders the boy to get him some and return with it by nightfall. The boy is too frightened not to do as he is told.

title: Players Gearing Up For Contract Talks
description: Leaders of the National Football League players union said today that they would do everything possible to avoid another strike but that intransigence by the owners could force them into one.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Administration is taking and will take criticism of why its foreign policy went wrong.

title: U.S. RETICENCE ON DOLLAR SEEN AS PART OF PLAN
description: By withholding any promises to help his Japanese counterpart cope with the falling dollar, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has demonstrated his evolving strategy to force America's most powerful allies to run their economies his way, analysts said today.

title: RJR Nabisco Debentures
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. is offering $500 million of 8 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 3/8 to yield 8.62 percent through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: 2 ISLANDERS HURT IN CAR CRASH
description: According to their coach, Murphy's Law is paying the Islanders an extended visit.

title: Baker Seeks Simpler W-4
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d called the new four-page W-4 form for calculating wage withholding taxes ''too complicated'' and said he had ordered the Internal Revenue Service to see if it could be simplified.

title: IN STORM, WARMING TRENDS
description: Some were smiling, some were grim, as they struggled through the snowstorm. Hats were an asset, umbrellas a handicap, as the snow blew in at every angle.

title: Chase to Close 21 Branches
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would close 21 of its 230 branches in the New York metropolitan area.

title: STAGE: 'TASTER'S CHOICE'
description: IN Christopher Blake's ''Taster's Choice,'' James Jenner plays a food critic who has completely lost his sense of taste and smell. Naturally one would think that he would retire from his profession - in other words, that he would be the equivalent of a drama critic who had become deaf and blind.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BONN CUTS BASIC RATE HALF-POINT
description: West Germany's Bundesbank approved today a package of monetary measures including a half-point cut in its basic interest rate, to 3 percent.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST UNITED BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Is Still Excluding People for Their Beliefs; Abuses in the Lara Case
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE MESSAGE IS MIXED FOR REGION'S MARCHANTS
description: While phones rang and reservations poured in at Direct Line Commuter ferry during yesterday's snowstorm, at Pennsylvania Station only four customers were in Pete Smith's Hall of Fame cocktail lounge across from Long Island Rail Road Tracks 13-17.

title: G.M. Announces Improved Warranty
description: In an apparent effort to increase its sales and improve its image for workmanship, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would extend the warranty on major mechanical components from three years and 36,000 miles to six years and 60,000 miles on all of its 1987 cars built in North America.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: The year-ago figures are restated to include Gold Mills Inc., acquired in Oct. 1986 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Czechs' Rights Movement: 10 Years of Struggle
description: Charter 77 - the Czechoslovak human rights movement - is 10 years old this month. It has endured longer than any other human rights movement in Eastern Europe. This fact seems all the more remarkable, given the nature of the Czechoslovak regime. Any hope for change in Czechoslovakia resides with the charter movement rather than in outside influences coming from either the East or the West.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes foreign currency exchange losses of $16,689,314 for the quarter and $19,824,125 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary loss of $9,945,353. c-Net loss and includes foreign currency gains of $10,527,597 and $13,915,124 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 23, 1987
description: International

title: NEW TALKS ON AFGHANISTAN ARE REPORTEDLY SCHEDULED
description: Pakistan and the Soviet Union will step up their discussions on ways to reach a negotiated settlement of the eight-year-old war in neighboring Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said today.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: WEINBERGER WARNS OF GAINS IN SOVIET SPACE TECHNOLOGY
description: Making his most specific and spirited arguments yet for an early deployment of a space-based defense against nuclear missiles, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that ''we must seize this opportunity'' because the chance to stay ahead of Soviet technology ''will not remain with us forever.''

title: 334 Watch Devils Win
description: Doug Sulliman scored three goals tonight to help the Devils post a 7-4 comeback victory in a game delayed almost two hours by the heavy snowstorm that hit the area.

title: GIANTS ARE 'COMFORTABLE'
description: The Giants are favored over the Denver Broncos by 9 or 9 1/2 points in Super Bowl XXI Sunday.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in net earnings for the latest quarter to a pre-tax loss of $22 million incurred by its Comdisco Equities Inc. risk arbitrage subsidiary.

title: MAGUY MARIN'S DOLL'S-EYE VIEW OF 'CINDERELLA'
description: IN the dance boom that has burst over France in the 1980's, there is one choreographer who stands apart. Most would say that Maguy Marin does so because of her fiercely original talent, especially in the theatrical approach she takes toward modern dance.

title: Glemp Is Invited to Moscow; He Cites Too Busy a Calendar
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, said today that he had been invited to attend a peace symposium in Moscow next month, but had declined because of a crowded calendar.

title: Ah, New Mexico
description: Ordinarily, pride in the home state flourishes almost uncontrolled in Congress. Preposterous bets are made on the floor involving interstate sporting contests like the Superbowl. Senators nearly come to blows over the relative virtues of their states' farm products or industrial prowesses. Which is why the pending resolution on New Mexico's 75th anniversary as a state is so unusual. Sponsored by Representative Manuel Lujan Jr., it carries humility to the extreme. New Mexico, it con-cedes, is ''often referred to as either a part of a foreign nation or a separate nation altogether.'' Tourists inquire ''if passports are needed to enter New Mexico, if New Mexico's drinking water is safe and if New Mexico's currency exchange rate is favorable to the American dollar.'' To compensate for all these slights, Congress, under the resolution, would recognize 1987 as ''New Mexico's Diamond Jubilee Year'' and ask President Reagan for a proclamation saluting the anniversary and ''reaffirming New Mexico's status as the 47th state of the Union.''

title: NASA'S TIES TO ROCKET COMPANY RAISE CONCERN AT SENATE HEARING
description: Key Senators complained today that the space agency appeared locked into its close relationship with Morton Thiokol Inc. and had failed to use other industrial expertise to redesign the flawed Thiokol rocket joints that caused the space shuttle disaster.

title: CYPRUS MINERALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago periods' results include an after-tax charge of $532,500,000 from the writedown of assets.

title: LANDMARKS COMMISSION MEMBER LOSING POST
description: Anthony M. Tung, an outspoken member of New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission for more than seven years, will not be reappointed because he submitted an opinion piece to The New York Times, the panel's chairman said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a march in Manhattan to protest racial violence misidentified the police commander who estimated the crowd. He is Assistant Chief Arthur J. McNevin, commander of the Manhattan South patrol borough.

title: BUREAUCRACY JUST ANOTHER MACHINE STALLED IN SNOW AT NATION'S CAPITAL
description: A snowstorm today did what six years of the Reagan Administration's deregulation efforts had failed to accomplish. It got the Government off the nation's back - at least the part that works in the capital.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS HAS GAIN
description: Two of the nation's leading financial services concerns, the American Express Company and the Morgan Stanley Group, yesterday announced higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: SARA LEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 1. Net-income figures for 1985 are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: SUPERVISORS UNION REACHES AGREEMENT WITH L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road reached agreement yesterday with another union, the supervisors, as a swirling snowstorm made the fifth day of the strike the roughest yet for commuters.

title: Bridge; Doubling Three No-Trump May Lead to Difficult Choice
description: Players who double three no-trump usually have a lead-directing motive. They want partner to lead his own suit, the doubler's suit or dummy's suit, in that order of preference.

title: Beyond Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Jakarta Gymnastics By Any Other Name
description: President Suharto of Indonesia has put an end to the controversy over the use of Chinese fitness techniques by ordering that the exercises be given Indonesian names, The Jakarta Post reported today.

title: A WORLD IN MANY MEDIA: IT'S 'THE BIG PICTURE'
description: ''When I moved to New York in 1977, it was my first trip outside of Japan, and I didn't speak any English,'' the choreographer Yoshiko Chuma recalled the other day. ''It was a tremendous shock to come to here. I felt I was in the middle of a nonstop performance.''

title: AUDIT FINDS 7% DROP IN ANTI-SEMITIC VIOLENCE
description: Acts of anti-Semitic vandalism against Jews and Jewish property in the United States declined 7 percent last year, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday in its eighth annual audit of such incidents around the country.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''EVERYONE'S Rolodex is here.'' That's how an official of the Metropolitan Museum of Art described the crush of invited guests at the opening of the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for 20th-century art. Nearly 3,000 people, including artists, dealers, collectors, donors and business leaders, turned out for a look at the new galleries and cocktails and dcici a afterwa. .

title: RESIDENCY LAW ON TOP OFFICIALS SIGNED BY KEAN
description: Governor Kean signed a bill today requiring members of his Cabinet and of the state Judiciary and Legislature to maintain their principal residence in New Jersey.

title: FILM: 'SWEET COUNTRY'
description: THE suffering of destitute, undernourished, ignorant and despairing peons amounts to nothing when compared to the ghastly emotional distress suffered by those liberal members of the haute bourgeoisie who care deeply about mankind.

title: Septien Indicted
description: The Dallas Cowboys' kicker, Rafael Septien, was indicted on charges of aggravated sexual assault, accused of molesting a 10-year-old girl, according to the Denton County (Tex.) District Attorney, Jerry Cobb. If convicted, Septien could be sentenced to up to life imprisonment and fined $2,000, Cobb said. The police from The Colony, a suburb in Denton County where Septien lives, brought the case to the District Attorney's office last week. Cobb said he declined to issue an arrest warrant until a grand jury heard the case. ''We now have investigated the case and feel confident about it,'' he said. State District Judge John Narsutis set bond at $50,000.

title: SENATE PANEL ON IRAN NAMES NEW YORK LAWYER AS COUNSEL
description: A New York City criminal lawyer who has represented many prominent public figures and directed several government inquiries was named today to be chief counsel of the special Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: FLAGLER BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MORRIS GETS AHEAD BY SLOWING DOWN
description: At first glance, it would seem that Joe Morris of the Giants - whom general manager George Young calls ''our home-run runner'' - contradicts the accepted verity that patience is a virtue.

title: JUILLIARD'S FREE MUSICAL MELTING POT
description: A piano concerto that shows the gentle, melodious side of Arnold Schoenberg, and an orchestral piece that shows the angular, 12-tone side of Aaron Copland, will share a program tonight at Alice Tully Hall with two other 20th-century works.

title: Happy Returns
description: Three years ago, Ladell Anderson, basketball coach at Brigham Young University, watched helplessly as a debilitating total of seven of his best players left school on missions of the Mormon Church. Anderson kept the program going for two years with junior-college transfers, and this season, patience is paying rewards. Five of the departed seven have returned and, together with the juco players, have given B.Y.U. its deepest team ever. After a sluggish start, the Cougars have won 11 of their last 13 games and established themselves as favorites in the Western Athletic Conference.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FELINE PULCHRITUDE Cat lovers will probably want to know that beginning today 1,000 prize-winning cats from around the world will be on display at the International Cat Show at Madison Square Garden. Featuring the rarest of pedigrees to the most common housecats, the show offers fans of the feline the opportunity to watch cats strut their stuff. The show will also offer lectures on cats, a supermarket of cat merchandise and an artist who can immortalize a favorite cat on canvas. The show, which is being held in the Garden's Exposition Rotunda and the Felt Forum, will end on Sunday afternoon with the ''Best of the Best'' judging in the Felt Forum. Today's session is from 3 to 10 P.M., tomorrow's is 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. and Sunday's, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. General admission tickets are $8 today and $10 tomorrow and Sunday. Reserved seats for Sunday's ''Best of the Best'' - which will be held from 3 to 6 P.M. - are available for $12 and $15. Information: 564-4400. TWO BY ORPHEUS

title: MAJOR POWER STRUGGLE IS REPORTED AMONG NICARAGUA REBEL LEADERS
description: A power struggle is again splitting the Nicaraguan guerrilla movement, threatening its leadership at a time when it is trying to stage an offensive, according to American and rebel officials.

title: PREGNANCY CENTERS: ANTI-ABORTION ROLE CHALLENGED
description: The advertisement in the Yellow Pages asked if she was ''thinking of an abortion,'' which the schoolteacher was. So she visited the AAA Pregnancy Problem center in Brooklyn, where a counselor advocated child birth and chastity, with pamphlets and pictures to buttress the appeal.

title: 51.60 SURGE PUTS DOW AT 2,145.67
description: Just a day after suffering its first setback of 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average soared yesterday by 51.60 points, its biggest one-day point rise ever, to a record 2,145.67.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chevron Corp., San Francisco, and Texaco Inc. said P.T. Caltex Pacific Indonesia, a jointly owned affiliate, had discovered oil at two sites on the Indonesian island of Sumatra. The output is expected to total 1,800 barrels a day.

title: A Job for Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO NOMINATES 5 TO PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION
description: In a move to shape energy policy in the state for the coming decade, Governor Cuomo today announced five nominations to the seven-member Public Service Commission. The nominations quickly met with resistance from the State Senate, which must confirm them.

title: OUSTED JUDGE IS DENIED PAROLE
description: Harry E. Claiborne, the Federal district judge impeached and removed from office last year, has lost his final bid for parole, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

title: Dollar Falls Once Again
description: The dollar, pummeled in early trading yesterday by the inconclusive Baker-Miyazawa talks, fell further in New York, mainly against the West German mark. Trading was busy.

title: MANY PORTS IN THE STORM, BUT MOST OF THEM ARE ALREADY FILLED
description: For those who never made it home last night, refuge from the storm could be found in a hotel, on a couch, or on an office desk.

title: PROBLEM ARISES IN DRUG TESTS IN TRAIN WRECK
description: Federal investigators may be unable to determine precisely when a Conrail crew member involved in a fatal train collision this month last used the marijuana detected in his blood and urine, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Du Pont Enters Venture in India
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has agreed to a $100 million joint venture with the Thapar industrial conglomerate to manufacture and market industrial nylon yarn and fabric in India. It is the largest American-Indian business deal in the private sector since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi assumed power in 1984.

title: Judge Rules For Panhandle
description: An administrative law judge of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission yesterday absolved the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the Houston-based pipeline company, of discriminatory procedures in transporting natural gas to industrial and utility customers in the Middle West.

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $27,479,000, or $1.95 a share from a contract default award.

title: SINGAPORE SOLICITED ON CONTRAS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the State Department had asked Singapore to provide communications equipment to the Nicaraguan rebels in 1985, at a time when it was uncertain whether such aid could be provided under humanitarian assistance approved by Congress.

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $11,160,000, or 43 cents a share, form the sale of properties.

title: Economic Scene; A Minimalist Masterpiece
description: THE joint American-Japanese statement Wednesday night on the discussions of economic, trade and financial issues between Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa was a masterpiece of minimalist economics.

title: FORT WAYNE NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Surgery for Sutter
description: Bruce Sutter, the Atlanta Braves relief pitcher, plans to undergo a third operation on his shoulder in an attempt to save his career. The surgery will be performed, possibly within the next week, at the University of Colorado Health Center, according to Bobby Cox, the Braves' general manager. Cox said that the right-hander would not pitch for the team in 1987, but might return the following season. Sutter's problem, which originally sidelined him toward the end of the 1985 season, is an entrapment of nerves in the right shoulder. His doctors say that, because of the nerves' failure to regenerate fully, there has been atrophy of muscle in the shoulder. Sutter, 34 years old, was first operated on in December 1985. He returned to the mound last year, but saw no action after May 27. The second operation was performed last August, and doctors then also uncovered an incomplete tear of the right rotator cuff.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insurance Broker Case Is Settled
description: Two former executives of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, settled Federal charges that they had falsified company records to hide millions of dollars in bond trading losses. Marsh & McLennan also signed a consent decree and agreed to establish new accounting and control procedures.

title: Bingham Painting Sells For Reported $6 Million
description: George Caleb Bingham's painting ''The Jolly Flatboatmen'' has been sold privately from the Pell Family Trust to Richard Manoogian, a Detroit art collector, according to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, where the work has been on loan since 1953. The museum did not disclose the price, but according to the New York art dealer Alexander Acevedo, Mr. Manoogian paid $6 million for the painting.

title: US WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $52 million, or 27 cents a share, from costs associated with restructuring of some operations. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split in May 1986.

title: U.S. AND FRENCH EXPERTS DIFFER ON CAMEROON GAS ERUPTION
description: Scientists who have investigated the death of 1,800 people in Cameroon in August generally agree that they were killed by carbon dioxide erupting from Lake Nios. They differ, however, on the cause of the eruption.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the previously announced net gain of $280 million for the quarter and year from the sale of the company's propane distribution and petroleum pipe line businesses. The latest periods' nets also reflect previously announced net charges of $227.4 million for the quarter and $233.1 million for the year for asset writedowns and costs associated with restructuring certain of the company's operations. The net effect of the credits less the charges increased earnings for the latest quarter by $1.33 a share and $1.17 a share for the year. The latest year net also includes a gain of $26.4 million, or 66 cents a share, from certain pension plans terminations, and other income of $7.8 million, or 19 cents a share. In addition, results for 1986 include sales of $478 million and net income of $55.3 million from businesses sold principally during the 1986 fourth quarter. The 1985 net income includes other income of about $25.3 million, or 63 cents a share. Results for 1985 also includes sales of $112.5 million and net of $2.9 million from businesses sold during the 1985 third quarter. Penn Central said its tax loss carryforward at the end of 1986 was estimated to be about $1.3 billion.

title: KARLIN: BAREFOOT SOLDIER
description: You can hear it now, the first time the Denver kicking team goes on the field in the Super Bowl on Sunday.

title: AST RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today: Jan. 23, 1987
