description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Drafting Committee for Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. And 3 P.M.

title: BONN OPPOSITION FACING KEY FIGHT IN OWN PARTY
description: His voice reduced by laryngitis to a rasping croak - ''a mixture of Willy Brandt and Louis Armstrong,'' he says - Johannes Rau goes bravely through the motions of pretending that he expects to be become Chancellor after the national election on Sunday.

title: Racing Notebook; Cordero Sticking to a Selective Schedule
description: Angel Cordero rode a big gray horse into the paddock for a minor race here one day last week and, as always, his fans yelled out some encouragement. ''Hi-ho, Silver!'' one called out. ''Oh yeah, that's me,'' Cordero replied, half to himself. ''The Puerto Rican Lone Ranger - in living color.''

title: CHIEFS AT CHINA SCIENCE ACADEMY OUSTED ABRUPTLY
description: The campaign of repression against liberal ideas among intellectuals touched the highest reaches of the official scientific establishment today with the abrupt dismissal of the president and vice president of the Academy of Sciences.

title: O'Connor's Mideast Visit a Harbinger of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate; Slim, High Building in Manhattan
description: IT comes as no surprise to people familiar with the difficulty of assembling sites for development in Manhattan that many new buildings are slim and high. The merger of zoning lots makes it possible to continue residential development in locations with high land values without demolishing all the buildings on the site, which would dispossess all tenants.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,630,000 for the quarter and $5,716,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,686,000 for the quarter and $3,580,000 for the year.

title: President to Resign At American Can
description: Frank J. Connor, president of the American Can Company, announced yesterday that he would leave March 1 to pursue other business interests.

title: U.S. Is Still Excluding People for Their Beliefs; Strange Exception
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S always great to hear something positive, especially in a season that hasn't been studded with hits. The something positive in this case is a new theater, a dream come true for a 26-year-old theater buff who believes that Broadway became what it was because of young innovators and young blood.

title: AIR WAR HEATS UP, BUT TEHERAN STILL BUSTLES
description: The aerial war between Iran and Iraq appeared to step up today, as Iran said it had suffered more than 800 civilian casualties in Iraqi air raids on 10 cities.

title: Lloyd's Backs Shift in Power
description: Lloyd's of London, the world's largest insurance underwriting exchange, immediately accepted a Government panel's recommendation today that it shift the power on its ruling council from the market's leaders to independent directors and investors. However, the restructuring might take two years to complete, Lloyd's chairman, Peter Miller, said at a news conference.

title: BRONCOS NOT FAZED
description: Under the palm trees of the peach-colored resort, Coach Dan Reeves and his laconic style are suited perfectly to the role of underdog.

title: SCREEN: 'PACKAGE TOUR'
description: THEY might be at a college reunion, standing by the old brick buildings and walking through the wrought-iron gate, talking about the past. But the gate is infamous, with its sign that reads ''Arbeit Macht Frei.'' And the place is Auschwitz, where many of these elderly Hungarian visitors were once imprisoned. They are now returning politely as tourists, paying heed to the No Smoking sign as they walk through the crematorium. ''Package Tour,'' a simple and very affecting documentary by Gyula Gazdag, is a record of the memories and emotions that this pilgrimage arouses.

title: All Eyes on Wright and His Brows
description: In a top-secret meeting with Jim Wright the other day, several Democratic strategists gazed at the new Speaker of the House of Representatives and wondered how his bushy eyebrows would play on television.

title: STAGE IS SET FOR A GIANT GALA
description: A light snow was already falling on Giants Stadium, but workers seemed intent on completing the 7-foot-high stage that was slowly rising at the east end. It was the initial step of a grand plan to honor the Giants next Tuesday after they return home from Super Bowl XXI, and officials at the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority are bracing for an overflow turnout.

title: 3 Kuwait Oilfield Fires Precede Islamic Session
description: As the foreign ministers of the Islamic Conference Organization met to prepare for a meeting of their nations' leaders, a shadowy group in Beirut took responsibility today for setting fire Monday night to three of Kuwait's oilfields.

title: ARGENTO COMIC OPERA
description: ''Christopher Sly,'' a comic opera by Dominick Argento, will be presented by the Center for Comtemporary Opera for the next two weekends at the Harry DeJur Playhouse at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street. The work, which opens the fourth season of the opera company, is based on the introduction to Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew.'' Richard Marshall, director of the center, will also direct the production; the cast features Shawn Roy, Robert Trentham and Kathryn Fields. Performances are tomorrow and next Friday and Jan. 31 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $8, $12, and $15. Information: 279-400.

title: The Governor's Thermometer
description: Governor Cuomo's 1987-88 New York budget proposal includes a plan that could interest governors all over the country. He would install a large painted thermometer on the state Capitol lawn. It would register the level of surplus funds to be returned to taxpayers when revenues exceed state spending. Legislative leaders of both parties, eager for tax reductions, scoff at the idea. Yet the issue it forces - accountability - deserves to be confronted directly and fairly.

title: Storm Shuts Some Markets
description: Most commodities exchanges in New York closed early yesterday because of the snowstorm in the New York area. The New York Mercantile

title: BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last month.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page picture caption on Wednesday about the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art omitted the identities of artists for two works shown. The sculpture at right foreground was Eduardo Chillida's ''Silent Music II,'' and the work at left was Martin Puryear's ''Tango.'' The caption also mentioned an artist in error; David Smith's work was not pictured.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Commercial Credit Co., Baltimore, named Daniel S. D'Agostino president and chief executive of its Delaware subsidiary, First National Bank of Wilmington, and Edwin E. Sherin senior vice president of the parent company.

title: SPEECH LINKED TO STATE OF PRESIDENCY
description: As top Republican Party officials met here in an unusally low-key session that reflected the party's recent setbacks, President Reagan was preparing a State of the Union Message that one adviser said today could be a ''seminal event'' in Mr. Reagan's struggle to regain his political footing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Pavin Takes Early Lead: Corey Pavin, who won the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic last Sunday by a shot over Bernhard Langer, continued playing well yesterday in the opening round of the Phoenix Open, shooting a six-under-par 65 on the new Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale to finish two shots off the lead. Mark O'Meara came in with an eagle 3 on the 15th hole to finish at eight-under 63 on the 7,000-yard, par-71 course and take the lead. Brad Faxon was second with a 64. The start of the tournament was delayed an hour and a half yesterday morning because a heavy frost made the greens unplayable until the sun rose high enough to thaw out the putting surfaces. As a result, 45 of the 144 players were unable to finish before dark, when play was suspended. Those players will complete their first round before the second starts. Horse Racing Tracks Closed: Yesterday's racing programs at Aqueduct, the Meadowlands and Roosevelt Raceway were canceled because of the inclement weather. The tracks were expected to resume regular programs today. N.H.L. Bruins 7, Canadiens 3: In Boston, Tom McCarthy scored his 21st and 22d goals last night and the Bruins skated to their fourth consecutive victory with Bill Ranford, a rookie, in goal. The Canadiens, weary from tough losses to Hartford on Monday and Wednesday nights and a half-hour hike through a driving snowstorm when their bus got caught in downtown Boston traffic earlier in the day, battled the Bruins to a 2-2 standoff for one-and-a-half periods. With their first home victory in four games with Montreal this season, the Bruins handed the Canadiens their third loss in four nights. Boston moved within a point of idle Hartford and within 2 of first-place Montreal in the Adams Division. Boston's Cam Neely broke the 2-2 tie at 10:48 of the second period when he took a pass from Rick Middleton and outmuscled Montreal's Petr Svoboda to score his 16th goal of the season with a short off-balance back-hand shot. McCarthy's second goal of the game made it, 4-2, at 18:10, taking a passout from Keith Crowder and beating the Montreal goalie, Brian Hayward, with a short flip to the stick side. Boston outshot Montreal, 14-8, in the second period, then nailed down the victory on third-period goals by Nevin Markwart, Middleton and Dwight Foster before Claude Lemieux scored for the Canadiens in the final minute. The start of the game was delayed for 24 minutes because many of the Bruins were late in arriving from their homes because of the storm.(AP) N.B.A. Lakers 118, Pacers 108: Magic Johnson scored 29 points, grabbed 10 rebounds and handed out 11 assists to help the Los Angeles Lakers to a victory over the Pacers in Indianapolis. The Pacers, who trailed, 63-52, at halftime, stayed close in the third quarter as Vern Fleming and Steve Stipanovich scored 10 points each. In the fourth quarter with the Lakers ahead by 95-91, Johnson scored 4 straight points and Los Angeles was never threatened. The Lakers, who improved to 32-8, jumped out to a 36-26 lead after one quarter as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 10 of his 20 points. Johnson had 12 points in the first half and James Worthy added 13. Worthy finished with 22. The Lakers were 30 of 35 from the foul line, including 11 of 12 by Johnson. Stipanovich led the Pacers with 25 points. John Long added 17 and Fleming had 15. (AP

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer

title: Envoy in Paraguay Dispute
description: President Alfredo Stoessner's Colorado Party today demanded that the United States Ambassador, Clyde Taylor, leave the country for meddling in the country's internal affairs. Last Friday, Mr. Taylor said Washington had urged Paraguay to reinstate an independent radio station and a banned newspaper.

title: U S West's Net Is Flat for Year
description: U S West Inc., which provides local telephone service to the Pacific Northwest, Rocky Mountain and Great Plains states, said yesterday that its earnings were flat in 1986 because of a $52 million restructuring charge it took in the fourth quarter. The after-tax charge is the result of the company's decision to market its information and communications services solely within its servicing area. U S West had sought a national presence, but found the effort too costly.

title: EX-STUDENT TELLS OF MOLESTATIONS BY PRESIDENT OF WESTFIELD COLLEGE
description: A graduate of Westfield State College testified in Suffolk Superior Court today that the president of the college molested him twice in 1984, his junior year.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ECUADOREAN BARS REQUEST TO RESIGN
description: President Leon Fabres Cordero today rejected a formal request by Congress for his resignation.

title: ASPIN RETAINS JOB AS UNIT CHAIRMAN OF ARMED SERVICES
description: Representative Les Aspin, repudiated by his colleagues two weeks ago, today staged a dramatic comeback to win re-election as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest third quarter it took a net provision of $90,000,000 for restructuring of operations.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT LINKED TO IRAN TALKS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency operative who met with Iranian negotiators last month, angering Secretary of State George P. Schultz, was George W. Cave, the former C.I.A. agent who has figured in most of the secret dealings between the United States and Iran, according to Congressional and other sources.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9.5 million for the quarter and $15.5 million for the year. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $22.8 million for the quarter and $31 million for the year. The lastest year figures also include a gain of $64 million from the reduction in the costs of goods sold, as a result of liquidations of LIFO inventory quantities, carried at lower costs prevailing in prior years.

title: WEBSTER'S RELAPSE CAUSES CONCERN
description: Coach Tom Webster of the Rangers, while on the team's commercial flight today to Edmonton from Vancouver, British Columbia, today, suffered a relapse of the inner-ear infection that has troubled him since soon after he was hired in November. There is now the possibility that he will not be permitted to fly again this season and will therefore not be able to serve as coach.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash gain of $2,790,000 from effects of changes in yen exchange rates on certain long- term obligations payable in yen for the latest quarter; for the latest year, yen exchange rates resulted in a loss of $27,491,000 compared with a similar loss of $14,111,000 for the prior year. c-Net losses and include a loss from discontinued operations of $15,500,000 for both periods.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ANYONE who remembers the movies made during and after World War II, or who has seen them on late-night television, knows that Hollywood war films emphasized the justice and dignity of the American cause and the evil and duplicity of the enemy.

title: WHITE HOUSE OFFICIALS SHOW IRRITATION WITH SHULTZ
description: White House officials expressed irritation today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, saying he was trying to shirk responsibility for the Iran arms deal.

title: TV SPORTS;
description: No matter what the Giants and the Broncos do on Sunday, CBS is looking like a winner. The network plans to make lots of money, at least for the day, and maybe a little history.

title: FIRST MIDWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $140,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the year.

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,300,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of $30,100,000, or 42 cents a share, and income from discontinued operations of $43,200,000 or 60 cents a share. c-Includes a gain of $160,000 and $20,166,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and income from discontinued operations of $2,751,000 and $34,918,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: International Music
description: The World Music Institute (206-1050) will present two concerts in its ''Music Around the Mediterranean'' series this weekend at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street (691-9510). Tomorrow at 8 P.M., there will be a concert of Lebanese music and dance featuring the oud (lute) players Mansour Ajami and Simon Shaheen and the nay (reed flute) player Jihad Racy. On Sunday at 3 P.M., the oud player John Berberian will lead his five-member group in a concert of Armenian music. Admission to each concert is $8.

title: What Not to Learn From Japanese Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a pooling-of-interests acquisition.

title: Bombs Away
description: Manute Bol, the Washington Bullets' 7-foot-7-inch man mountain, had the audacity to try a 3-point shot the other night. The miss left him 0 for 2 from beyond the arc on his career, and looking up, for a change, at these active leaders in N.B.A. career 3-point accuracy (minimum of 50 shots made).

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3 million, or 3 cents a share, from a change in accounting for pensions and a pretax gain of $33 million from sales and redemption of debt, preferred stock and warrants of a formerly-owned commodity chemicals subsidiary sold in 1984. c-Includes a gain of $10 million, or 10 cents a share, from settlement of a suit. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $30 million.

title: 'Lost Empire' Series, Based on Priestly Book
description: THE seven-part ''Lost Empires,'' the new ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation getting under way on Channel 13 Sunday at 9 P.M., does not lend itself to tidy summary blurbs. Produced by June Howson for Granada Television, the gorgeously mounted mini-series is not nearly as successful as it so insistently intends. The source material, a 1965 book by J. B. Priestley - the program's host, Alistair Cooke, calls it ''a sort of memoir'' - resists smooth dramatization. There is not one but several plots, all wrapped around the coming of age of a young man who, unfortunately, is not quite as fascinating as he assumes. Yet, ''Lost Empires'' is filled with wonderful characters and bravura turns, enough surely to satisfy those with a keen eye for memorable details.

title: Hagler Gets a Scare
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, left for his Palm Springs, Calif., training camp hours after surviving a scare on the Southeast Expressway near Boston. Hagler's car skidded on an icy patch about 2 A.M. Wednesday and banged into a concrete barrier, but the boxer was not hurt. Hagler was heading toward his home in Hanover, Mass., after visiting friends in Boston when the accident occurred, The Boston Herald said. Hagler was heading to Palm Springs, Calif., to train for his Apr. 6 title defense against Sugar Ray Leonard in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: CATERPILLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring pre-tax charges of $109 million and $112 million for the quarter and year, respectively from plant closings and consolidations. c-Net income d-Includes non-recurring pre-tax charges from plant closings and consolidations of $26 million for the quarter and $25 million for the year.

title: HADASSAH CELEBRATES 75 YEARS OF HELPING
description: Seventy-five years ago, Henrietta Szold, the first woman to enroll in the Jewish Theological Seminary, decided to transform her small New York study circle into a national organization dedicated to promoting Zionist ideals among American Jewish women and providing basic health care in Palestine. She called her association Hadassah, the Hebrew for Esther, a queen in Persia who saved the Jews from a massacre.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about earnings at big banking companies omitted a major qualification involving results for the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEXT: A SHOP-AT-HOME LOAN
description: Picture this. Right after viewers of the Home Shopping Network television show have snatched up an allotment of zirconium rings, and before a shipment of ceramic figurines from Capodimonte, Italy, is put up for sale, the announcer offers, of all things, a cheap car loan.

title: Failing Promise of Junior College
description: Community colleges were supposed to be the cutting edge of the democratizing reforms that swept higher education in the 1960's. These two-year institutions were to be gateways to higher learning, affordable and accessible to all. Over the years they often became academic dead ends, especially for the minority members who rely on them most heavily. Early results from a Ford Foundation project now suggest that their promise can still be redeemed.

title: BURT HAS HIS MEMORIES OF GOOD TIMES AND BAD
description: The essence of Jim Burt has been captured in two distinct portraits during these playoffs. He was the little boy in a football uniform skipping merrily across the field to the locker room after the Giants defeated the Redskins for the National Conference championship Jan. 11, having climbed into the stands earlier to share the victory with his wife and some fans.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PURDUE SURVIVES IN OVERTIME
description: Purdue's Kip Jones made the winning free throw with less than one second to play in overtime tonight and Doug Altenberger of Illinois missed a technical foul shot after that as Purdue won, 87-86, in a Big Ten game.

title: RALLY AGAINST ABORTION HEARS PLEDGE OF SUPPORT BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan pledged his continued support to thousands of people rallying here today to protest abortion, saying he would work with them to overturn the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion and to ''end this national tragedy.''

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter results include an after-tax gain of $236 million from the sale of Banca d'America e d'Italia. The company said results also include severance costs of $46 million that were incurred for actual staff reductions during the quarter and planned staff reductions in 1987, and a $38 million charge for losses arising from excess office space subleased in the fourth quarter of 1986 and anticipated to be subleased in 1987.

title: IOWA TOPS INDIANA FOR 18TH IN A ROW
description: Top-ranked Iowa, facing third-ranked Indiana for the first time this year, put on an awesome display of rebounding and pressure defense this evening and routed the Hoosiers, 101-88, before 15,570 near delirious fans at Carver Hawkeye Arena.

title: FOR ANTIQUES SHOW, IDEAS, IDEAS, IDEAS
description: For the last three days the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street has been a sea of movers, painters and electricians. Louis XV commodes and 19th-century armchairs, crates of porcelains and bundles of quilts have sailed from one end of the vast drill hall to another. Indeed, the days before the opening of the Winter Antiques Show are spent magically transforming blank space into a labyrinth of creative showcases. While the entire setup takes little time, dealers put months of preparation into planning their spaces and many enlist the help of designers.

title: CAPASSO, IN SURPRISE MOVE, PLEADS GUILTY IN TAX CASE 821:86,813>
description: Carl A. Capasso, a contractor who has done major work for New York City, pleaded guilty to tax-evasion charges in a surprise move yesterday at his arraignment.

title: NAVRATILOVA GAINS FINAL IN AUSTRALIA
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova breezed to victory and second-seeded Hana Mandlikova had a one-set lapse as they won semifinal matches today and advanced to the final in the Australian Open.

title: Helen Lewis, 73, Dies; Psychoanalysis Expert
description: Dr. Helen B. Lewis, a psychoanalyst and professor emeritus of psychology at Yale University, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 73 years old and also had a home in Croydon, N.H.

title: WORK STOPPAGE IN EL SALVADOR SHUTS DOWN COUNTRY FOR DAY
description: A one-day work stoppage led by businessmen and tacitly supported by leftist rebels appeared to have virtually shut down El Salvador today.

title: Soviet Says It Is Terminating Jamming of BBC Broadcasts
description: Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, announced today that Russian-language broadcasts of the British Broadcasting Corporation would no longer be jammed.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF the Japanese have an equivalent for the voguish American-style open grill restaurant, it is the yakitori bar, where meat and seafood are barbecued and served with various sauces. One such grill opened two weeks ago, called Haru, at 165 West 72d Street. This sleek new spot, with mirrored walls, black banquettes, track lighting and shocking pink tables, offers a full range of sushi, sashimi and other Japanese standards in addition to the grilled foods. Beef negimayaki, the scallion stalks wrapped in sheets of beef, was exceptionally good at lunch this week - the bite-size rolls were served sizzling hot under a semisweet glaze ($4.50 for an appetizer portion). Grilled chicken ($3.50) and eggplant with ginger ($3.50) were nicely done, too.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK(WALLINGORD)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in July 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 23, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Infinity in a Flake
description: Walk out into the newly fallen snow and, without feeling a crunch under your foot, you will be crushing thousands on thousands of nature's most marvelously varied creations. The snowflake is the product of nothing but water, dust and changing air. Yet from this prosaic mix come structures of intricate design and patterned beauty.

title: ART: ROTHENBERG HORSES AT THE GAGOSIAN GALLERY
description: IT is more than a decade now since Susan Rothenberg's horses began appearing in galleries and museums. They were peculiar creatures. They looked like horses, but they were invariably flat, featureless and tailless, and they stood and rocked in dense, nondescript spaces. There was nothing romantic about them, but they were not anti-romantic either, and here and there they nodded in the direction of their illustrious ancestors. The nerve and conviction of these paintings became signposts for a generation.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A's Seek Gedman
description: After meeting with Rich Gedman, the free-agent catcher, Sandy Alderson, the general manager of the Oakland A's, said the team's chances of signing him were 50-50. Gedman, who batted .258 for the Boston Red Sox last season and .295 the previous season, was in Oakland on Tuesday and Wednesday with his agent, Jack Sands. ''We've talked about a lot of things, some financial and some not,'' Alderson said. ''Fifty-fifty is as good an evaluation as I can give. I can say now that is a fact, not an assumption.'' The A's are very interested in Gedman, he said, and added, ''The interest is reciprocal.''

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Les Skah Shah, Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Haitian rock lilts unlike anything else in the Caribbean, cruising along at medium tempos with a rhythm that, sooner or later, insinuates itself into every listener's hips. The Haitian compas direct beat is related to the Dominican Republic's merengue (from the other half of the island), but where the merengue has grown more and more uproarious, the compas direct has grown suaver. Les Skah Shah are one of the leading bands in Haiti and in Brooklyn's Haitian community; their tunes feature an intoxicating interplay of horns, guitars, percussion and salsa-influenced harmony vocals. Sets tonight at 11 P.M. and 1 and 2:30 A.M.; admission is $10 with dinner, $15 without, and there is a two-drink minimum at tables.

title: Illinois Pulls Funds From First Chicago
description: The Treasurer of Illinois withdrew almost $220 million in state deposits from the First National Bank of Chicago to protest its 19.8 percent credit-card interest rate. ''Illinois taxpayers will not help fund their gouging of consumers any longer,'' Jerome Cosentino said, making good on a campaign promise 10 days after he took office.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHARADE. By John Mortimer. 188 pages.

title: H.R.A. CHIEF ORDERS REVIEW
description: The city Human Resources Administrator, William J. Grinker, has ordered a major re-evaluation of how his agency delivers services to families and children.

title: Testaverde Flexible
description: Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy winner, indicated yesterday that he would prefer to play for Tampa Bay, but said he'll be happy ''wherever I go'' in the National Football League. Bob Woolf, the Boston attorney chosen by Testaverde to represent him in contract negotiations, said that wherever the 1986 All-American goes, he won't come cheap. Woolf, who has represented more than 2,000 athletes, including two former Heisman Trophy winners, Jim Plunkett and Doug Flutie, in the last 25 years, hedged on what the asking price would be for Testaverde's services, but put him in the million-dollar class with such other quarterbacks as Don Marino of the Dolphins, John Elway of the Broncos and two other former Miami quarterbacks, Jim Kelly of the Bills and Bernie Kosar of the Browns.

title: MCI Cuts Rates For Long Distance
description: MCI Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of long-distance service, is cutting its rates by an average of 10 percent, following a similar reduction last month by the industry leader, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. MCI's cuts, totaling $250 million, will take effect over the next two months. MCI said some rates would be reduced by more than 25 percent and daytime business rates would decline an average of 13.5 percent.

title: California Federal Gets A President and Chief
description: William L. Callender has been elected president and chief executive of California Federal Savings and Loan Association, the nation's fourth-largest thrift institution.

title: Let's Warm Up Relations With Eastern Europe
description: A very strong case can now be made for reinvigorating United States relations with Eastern Europe. The region is at a critical juncture, and the Administration has made a timely appointment in giving a high-level State Department official - Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead - special responsibility for its policy there.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: QUO VADIS, once the dolled-up doyenne of the East Side gentry, has tossed off her ankle-length gown and donned a bathing suit and white-rimmed sunglasses, California cool, in hopes of winning favor with the fickle new generation of diners. The classic Italian cuisine that nurtured her habitues in the 1960's is a faint memory, replaced by such modern juxtapositions as ''sushi of wild rice and crisp vegetables'' and ''Dover sole spaghetti served with shrimp Bolognese.''

title: Get Smarter About Drunken Driving
description: In New York and 41 other states, the 21-year-old drinking age law pays handsome dividends in accidents avoided and lives saved. But new evidence suggests that another popular tactic in the war on drunken drivers is based on false and naive assumptions. It's time to challenge these assumptions and change the programs.

title: For a Smoking Ban in New York City
description: LEAD: Ten years ago, a few weeks after my 38th birthday, I was on vacation in California with my husband. On the way out on the plane, I happened to pick up a special issue of Harper's magazine devoted almost entirely to the subject of cancer. For some reason, I read every article in that magazine, mesmerized by the appalling statistics.

title: GREECE IS OPEN TO TALKS ON BASES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said in Parliament today that Greece would negotiate with the United States for the continuation of American military bases only on what he called ''a zero basis.''

title: JAPAN TO SCRAP FORMULA FOR LIMITING ARMS BUDGET
description: Japanese Government and ruling party leaders agreed today to scrap a long-held policy that had linked the military budget to a specific percentage of the country's gross national product.

title: A Visit to Sakharov
description: Delayed for a day by the snowfall that blanketed the Northeast, Alexei Semyonov, the son of Yelena G. Bonner, left the United States for the Soviet Union yesterday for a visit with his mother and his stepfather, Andrei D. Sakharov, who was recently allowed to return to Moscow from exile in Gorky.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Twitty Shares Lead: Howard Twitty, a 38-year-old native of Phoenix, worked with Tom Weiskopf and Jay Morrish on the design and construction of the Tournament Players Club golf course of Scottsdale, Ariz. This probably helped the 6-foot-5-inch Twitty shoot a six-under-par 65 yesterday on the new, 7,000-yard layout to share the second-round lead with Steve Jones in the 52d annual Phoenix Open. They were tied at 133 for 36 holes.

title: CAT FANCIERS ARE FLOCKING TO THE GARDEN
description: Ariel thrust a sleek white paw through the bars to swipe at her owner, while D'Artagnan, in a cage nearby, looking as though he had had a permanent, lay watching spectators do double takes at his white curled coat. But a few tables down the corridor, Gizmo, like a large brown caterpillar, in top hat and tuxedo, hunched on the roof of his cage, wary.

title: MONA SIMPSON, WRITING OF PERIPATETIC DREAMERS
description: During four years of writing, Mona Simpson thought of calling her first novel ''Lawns,'' as in yards, which a lot of people tend and read on all over the country, but no one seemed to go for it. ''A Place to Be From'' was another candidate; close, but it still wasn't quite right. Someone suggested ''American Dreams,'' but that had already been used and the author didn't think much of it anyway.

description: To the Editor:

title: African Meeting on Oil
description: Buoyed by higher prices, oil ministers from nine African countries will meet here Monday to formally begin a new forum aimed at improving cooperation and coordinating policy among African oil producers, the Nigerian oil minister's office said today. The African Petroleum Producers Association, organized by Nigeria, OPEC's largest African producer, combines four OPEC members, Nigeria, Libya, Algeria and Gabon, with five non-members, Angola, Benin, Cameroon, Congo and Egypt. The African oil group is seen as a forum for an exchange of views and coordination of policies. Nigeria says foreigners control the oil output of most African producers, and that the new oil organization aims to remedy this.

title: Willhite Matches Elway Step for Step
description: Where Elway goes, he goes.

title: G.E. Robotics
description: Cutbacks by the automotive industry have caused the General Electric Company to close its robotics plant in this central Florida community, putting 118 employees out of work. ''The market has been very poor in robotics,'' Jack Batty, a company spokesman, said.

title: Arms and Votes, East and West
description: In two very different and important nations, there's a discernible shift away from the long-held belief that voters are allergic to any increase in nonnuclear defense spending. Yesterday Japan agreed to end a decade-old policy of keeping military expenditures below 1 percent of gross national product. And in Britain, the opposition Labor Party finds it expedient to proclaim the need to strengthen NATO's conventional forces. It's a welcome shift, though the new Laborite gift horse comes with a mouthful of old teeth.

title: Congress; What Aspin Wrought
description: Representative Les Aspin shook the foundations of the Congressional seniority system two years ago when, as the seventh-ranking Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee, he engineered the overthrow of the incumbent chairman and won election in his place.

title: THE DANCE: A MODERN 'IN TRANSIT'
description: The 16th-century poet George Peele once sighed, ''O time too swift, O swiftness never ceasing!'' That sigh sums up ''In Transit,'' the program Michele Elliman and Ryn Hodes presented Wednesday night at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art (44 Walker Street). Their works concerned the passing of time, and both choreographers combined movement with texts to explore themes of longing and retrospection.

title: Honda Is Japan's No. 3
description: A sharp jump in output helped the Honda Motor Company leap past Mazda and Mitsubishi to become Japan's third-largest producer of vehicles last year, industry analysts said today. Honda produced 1.24 million units in 1986, far below Toyota's 3.66 million and Nissan's 2.24 million, but above Mazda's 1.20 million and Mitsubishi's 1.18 million, according to the car industry's official data compiler, the Japan Automobile Industry Association. Output for all Japan's vehicle manufacturers totaled 12.26 million in 1986, down one-tenth of 1 percent from the previous year, the association said.

title: Carthon's Leading Role Helps Make Morris a Star
description: He was a second-class citizen in the swamps of New Jersey, wearing stars on a red helmet in a football stadium built for a team that dresses in blue. In sadder times, when Giant fullbacks were often pushed backward, the blue team was known to allow talent to slip away. But when Maurice Carthon spent his springtimes in their home, playing for the New Jersey Generals and opening holes for Herschel Walker, the Giants were offered a glimpse of the future.

Lorimar Plans Income Charge
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, a leading entertainment concern, said it would take a $37 million charge against third-quarter pretax operating income. It blamed the weak financial condition of independent television stations. The charge, for the period ended Dec. 30, will go toward increasing Lorimar's bad debt reserves, which cover payments the company has not received from TV stations for its programs.

title: WALL ST. DAY: TORRID START, SUDDEN CHILL
description: At 1:30 yesterday afternoon, Mark Loehr, a stock trader, was feeding orders into a record-trampling surge in the market. Just 15 minutes later, he was scrambling to stay in control as prices suddenly were sucked into a free fall - and it dawned on him that he was in for a day unlike any other in his experience.

description: Americans buying big-ticket items to qualify for the sales-tax deduction pushed spending up 2 percent in December for the biggest rise in more than a decade. The prestigious show, now in its 12th year, which opens to the public tomorrow and continues until Feb. 1, was marked by a trio of stylish parties that were upper-class English in mood and theme.

title: Bavasi Leaves Indians
description: Peter Bavasi resigned as president of the Cleveland Indians in order to take over as president and chief executive officer of Telerate Sports, a newly formed sports- information service. The Indians said that Dan O'Brien, Joe Klein, Terry Barthelmas and Greg Olson would handle the direction and day-to-day activities of the club. Bavasi, 44, joined the Indians in November 1984. Last season the team had an 84-78 record, its best since 1968, and attendance of 1.47 million, its highest since 1959. Bavasi, the son of Buzzy Bavasi, the former baseball executive, was founding president the Toronto Blue Jays and former general manager of the San Diego Padres.

title: A MILLION SEEK 10,000 VISAS
description: In a huge outpouring, more than one million foreigners have applied for the 10,000 immigration visas the United States is offering without the usual tough entry requirements, a State Department official said today.

title: CONCERT: BATTLE SINGS WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: Before Erich Leinsdorf began conducting the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening he first turned to the audience, or what there was of it, and applauded. Only enough people to half fill Avery Fisher Hall had defied the snowstorm but, as it turned out, they were rewarded with what surely will rank as one of this season's premier musical events.

title: STOCK DROP HURTS BOND PRICES, TOO
description: Treasury bond prices slumped yesterday, with the longest maturities showing the largest losses, in trading that was heavily influenced by the turmoil in the stock market.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review yesterday of ''Sweet Country,'' by Michael Cacoyannis, misidentified a film by Costa-Gavras on the 1973 military coup in Chile that overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens. The Costa-Gavras film was titled ''Missing.''

title: Mets-Johnson Pact
description: Howard Johnson, who may be the Mets' regular third baseman this year, reached agreement with the club yesterday on a one-year contract for $297,500. Johnson was the second player to settle of the seven Mets who filed for salary arbitration. Wally Backman, the platooned second baseman, agreed to a three-year, $1.95 million contract, with salaries of $550,000, $650,000 and $750,000. Johnson had submitted a $320,000 salary for arbitration and the Mets were in at $265,000. It was the second consecutive year in which the switch-hitting infielder had filed for arbitration, then settled before the hearing on a salary closer to his arbitration number. A year ago, he sought $250,000, the Mets went in at $175,000, and they agreed on $227,500. Johnson's agreement reduced to 86 the players remaining in arbitration. The remaining Mets are Dwight Gooden, Ron Darling, Kevin McReynolds, Doug Sisk and Tim Teufel.

title: Denial From Septien
description: Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, denied charges yesterday that he sexually assaulted a 10-year-old girl. ''The truth is, I am not guilty,'' Septien said. ''When it all comes out, everybody will see it was a misunderstanding on everybody's part.'' He said members of the girl's family told him earlier this week that they intended to drop the charges. Septien said he was ''devastated'' when a Denton County, Tex., grand jury indicted him Thursday on a charge of aggravated sexual abuse of a child. Septien is free on a $10,000 bond. He and his lawyer, Jerry Banks, said they have been told by the court not to discuss the facts surrounding the case. Septien said he has known the family of the girl since about September last year. ''They are a good family,'' he said. ''They are good friends of mine. They are good neighbors.''I would like to clear my name. This is a very unfortunate incident that has hurt very, very much.''

title: INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vuckovich Invited
description: Among seven nonroster players who will report to the Milwaukee Brewers' spring-training camp in Chandler, Ariz., Feb. 23 will be Pete Vuckovich, a 34-year-old pitcher, and Jim Paciorek, a 26-year-old outfielder. Vuckovich won the American League Cy Young Award in 1982 with an 18-6 record, but then developed arm problems that sidelined him for most of the next two seasons. After posting a 6-10 record in 1985, he retired last spring but later pitched well in Triple A competition and in September had a 2-4 record after rejoining the Brewers. Paciorek, who batted .309 with Triple A Vancouver last season, is the brother of Tom Paciorek of the Texas Rangers. The other nonroster players are B. J. Surhoff, a catcher who batted .308 at Vancouver; Garrett Nago and John Beuerlein, backup minor league catchers, and Mark Ambrose and Don August, young pitching prospects.

BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Placed John Bagley, guard, on the injured list. COLLEGES ILLINOIS WESLEYAN - Named Norm Eash head football coach and athletic director. NICHOLLS STATE - Appointed Phil Greco head football coach. SYRACUSE - Named Paul Pasqualoni an assistant football coach. TULSA - Named Bob Brush defensive coordinator of the football team. VIRGINIA - Named Gary Tranquill an assistant football coach. HOCKEY DETROIT (NHL) - Recalled Mark Laforest, goalie, from Adirondack of the American Hockey League. ISLANDERS (NHL) - Recalled Gerald Diduck and Randy Boyd, defensemen, from Springfield of the American Hockey League. NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Announced that Terry Simpson, coach of the Islanders, and Mike Keenan, coach of the Philadelphia Flyers, had each received one-game suspensions as a result of a bench-clearing incident in the game on Jan. 18. The teams were fined $5,000 each.

title: TREASURER DISCUSSED PROSPECTS OF PARDON BEFORE ENDING LIFE
description: R. Budd Dwyer, the Pennsylvania State Treasurer, who publicly committed suicide after proclaiming he had been wrongly convicted of bribery, learned the day before his death that he could not immediately seek a Presidential pardon, an aide to Senator Arlen Specter said today.

title: A.T.& T. Job Cuts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would lay off about 300 employees at its Oklahoma City works facility effective next Friday as a result of a soft market for the plant's products. A.T.& T. said it would lay off mostly entry-level workers producing microprocessor computers and telecommunications switching systems, leaving the plant with 6,000 employees. Last month A.T.& T. announced a $3.2 billion charge against 1986 earnings and said it would slash 27,400 jobs.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERIBANC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $416,000 for the year and a loss of $179,000 for the quarter and a gain of $754,000 for the year from the cumulative effect of a pension settlement. c-Net loss

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,313,000 and $1,510,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $393,000 and $979,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Paradise Systems on Nov. 26, 1986, accounted for on a pooling of interests basis. The company said that in the latest first quarter, revenue for Paradise Systems was $6.7 million with a pretax loss of $300,000 which included a one-time acquisition expense of $600,000 and certain adjustments required to conform to Western Digital's accounting methods; in the second quarter, Paradise generated $8.5 million in revenue and $1.6 million in pretax earnings.

title: PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,079,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $3,114,000.

title: Why We're Forced To Be Slumlords
description: My wife and I are about to become slumlords.

title: High-Speed Trains Must Travel Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: MET OPERA: 'CLEMENZA,' BY MOZART, IS PRESENTED
description: In the last few months of his life, Mozart composed the Piano Concerto No. 27 in B-flat, the Clarinet Concerto, ''The Magic Flute,'' the unfinished Requiem and the two-minute motet ''Ave Verum Corpus'' - bar for bar, one of the most extraordinary canons of music in the repertory. Until recently, ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' a contemporaneous work in the opera seria manner, which Mozart began during a three-day stagecoach journey between Vienna and Prague and finished some two weeks later, was widely dismissed as the one potboiler in the series - work for hire, as it were, tossed off hurriedly in a style for which the composer had no particular empathy.

title: 160 Homes for 160 Babies: Now
description: Why can't homes be found for the ''boarder babies,'' the abandoned or abused infants who languish in city hospitals? New York City is dragging its feet on accepting Albany's help, charges Cesar Perales, the state Commissioner of Social Services. Albany promises much but is slow to deliver, responds Eric Brettschneider of the city department responsible for foster children.

title: INDIA PUTS MILITARY ON FULL ALERT, CITING A PAKISTANI TROOP BUILDUP
description: India put its army and air force on maximum alert tonight, citing a threat from what it described as a huge Pakistani military buildup on the border.

title: FIERCER FIGHT TO SELL BATTERIES
description: There's hardly anything drabber and more basic than a battery. But now that another competitor has entered the rapidly expanding market, battery makers are emphasizing gold and copper - as well as rebates, coupons and some new technology - to try to insure that their brand goes into the watches, toys, radios and other electronic gear that have made batteries a big business.

title:
PATENTS;
Electrical Instrument For Bloodless Surgery
description: LEAD: An electrical instrument intended for bloodless surgery has been invented by a Soviet citizen. Patent 4,637,390 was granted this week to Oleg A. Sorochenko, who assigned it to an institute in his home city of Kharkov.

description: b-Net income The company's 1986 net income reflects $12.9 million in tax credits, compared to $16.7 million in 1985, offsetting a $10.7 million pre-tax loss, against $11.3 million in 1985. The 1986 net also includes a $3.8 million after-tax gain from the sale of securities, compared to $1.1 million in 1985.

title: CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTOR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,845,000 and $6,134,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDER BRAWL: 2 COACHES BANNED
description: That bench-clearing brawl between the Islanders and the Flyers at the Spectrum last Sunday may not have contained actual fisticuffs, but it continues to produce casualties.

title: STALEY CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of investment tax credits recognized in the prior fiscal year amounting to $2.4 million, or 8 cents a share.

title: CENTRAL FIDELITY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SNOW CLEARED DESPITE DEPOT CLOSING
description: Despite the court-ordered closing of a key Sanitation Department depot serving northeastern Queens, the city was able to clear the snow from the area's larger thoroughfares and many of its side streets by midmorning yesterday, community officials said.

title: JUDGE PUTS GOODEN ON PROBATION
description: Dwight Gooden pleaded no contest yesterday to two felony charges of fighting with the Tampa police, and was placed on probation for three years with the understanding that the charges would be erased if he performed community service and had a clean record.

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 CAMP SHOWS LOOK AHEAD TO SUMMER
description: It's midwinter, and that means it's time to think about summer camps. Two camp shows are scheduled for Sunday, Feb. 1, where parents and children can meet directors and staff members of camps and summer programs, and find out what they offer and what it all costs.

title: Board Approves Cable Transfer
description: The Board of Estimate has ended a seven-month delay and voted to authorize the transfer of the two Manhattan cable television franchises to the American Television and Communications Corporation.

title: BLACK FOE OF PRETORIA DEFENDS VIOLENT RESISTANCE TO APARTHEID
description: The head of the African National Congress, Oliver R. Tambo, offering a stark defense of the use of violence by his followers, says the occasional killing of South African whites gives hope to blacks and will make white people ''used to bleeding.''

title: PROGRAM TRADING WIDENS THE SWINGS
description: The chaos that erupted on Wall Street yesterday was at least partly fed by feverish activity in Chicago's financial futures pits, where stock index futures are traded.

title: FOR SOVIET CIVILIANS, A 'NERVOUS' LIFE
description: In the last seven years, a small city of concrete apartment buildings and shops has risen on the outskirts of Kabul, not far from the airport.

title: LA JOLLA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a distribution of one Class B common share for each share of common stock outstanding, paid Jan. 16.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Beautiful Babies'
description: It is a sad fact that the nation's capital city, with one of the highest personal income levels in the country, also has the highest infant mortality rate, roughly twice the national figure.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a charge of $141,934,000 from the writeoff of a portion of the Wm. H. Zimmer generating station for both the quarter and year.

title: Nikolai Petrov
description: The pianist Nikolai Petrov will make his formal New York debut at Alice Tully Hall at 3 P.M. tomorrow. Mr. Petrov will play works by C. P. E. Bach, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Liszt. Admission is $10 to $17.50; information: 362-1911 or 874-6770.

title: CITY BALLET: A REVIVAL OF BALANCHINE'S 'PORTE'
description: Picture the following. A woman with a huge black cape that billows over an entire stage preens or advances toward a man, a desperate coiled shape at her feet. The theater is filled with sounds of creaking and breathing for 20 minutes. Suddenly the woman ''swallows'' up the man in her cape and disappears along with him.

title: UNITED BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES ASK TO ASSIST THE HOMELESS
description: Concern for the plight of the city's homeless people has been expressed repeatedly by contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 results include those of General Bancshares Corp. acquired in March 1986, and the 1985 figures have been restated to reflect this acquisition.

title: M.T.A. Approves Toll Increase On Five East River Crossings
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board approved yesterday an increase of 25 cents on automobile tolls on several East River bridges and tunnels. The increase, which raises the one-way toll to $2 from $1.75, will take effect Feb. 7.

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER IS KILLED IN SHOOTING AT HIS BRONX BUILDING
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was killed yesterday afternoon in an apparent robbery attempt in the lobby of his Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: NO-NAME PERFORMERS GO NATIONAL
description: This week, the Drawing Legion Theater company from Iowa City is working at Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions. The Vermont-based Bread and Puppet Theater company is performing at the Painted Bride Arts Center in Philadelphia. American Inroads in San Francisco is presenting collaborations by two New Yorkers - Perry Hoberman, a visual artist, and Bill Obrecht, a composer and saxophonist. And the California-based writer-actress-musician Jo Harvey Allen, who appeared in David Byrne's film ''True Stories,'' is appearing in Austin, Tex., at the Laguna Gloria Art Museum.

title: PRISON TERM IMPOSED IN INSIDER CASE
description: Ilan K. Reich, a 32-year-old former partner with one of the nation's top law firms, was sentenced yesterday in an emotional court session to a year and a day in prison for his role in the Wall Street insider trading scandal.

title: Your Money; Self-Employed And Tax Law
description: THOUSANDS of self-employed engineers, computer programmers and other technical service personnel breathed a sigh of relief this week, following the release of Internal Revenue Service guidelines clarifying their tax and employment status.

title: EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
O'CONNOR SAYS HE'LL DROP SOME FOSTER-CARE PACTS WITH CITY
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said in Washington Thursday night that he had decided to discontinue some of the foster care that his archdiocese provides to children in New York City, rather than comply with a recent court stipulation.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid last October.

title: A THREE-FRONT WAR ON DRUGS
description: LEAD: Americans often assume the United States is the only victim of the narcotics tragedy. Yet drugs afflict all the Americas: more Bolivians per capita are addicted to cocaine than are residents of the United States; although drug-related corruption is pervasive in the United States, in Latin America it is eating away at the fabric of fragile democracies.

title: GOLDEN POULTRY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
LOUISISANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: New Push for Contras The White House, seeking to regain the initiative on foreign policy, began a campaign for continued financing for the Nicaraguan rebels. Page 5.

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago periods' net includes an after-tax gain of $159,000 from the sale of Electro-Kinetic Systems Inc.

title: STAGE: PUERTO RICAN TROUPE OFFERS 'A LITTLE SOMETHING'
description: In ''A Little Something to Ease the Pain,'' two brothers, one a Cuban immigrant playwright in Toronto and the other a popular radio commentator in Santiago, Cuba, struggle to find where home really is in a world of exiles. That Carlos (Jorge Luis Ramos), who had gone to Canada after Fidel Castro came to power, cannot find it is obvious from the first scene, in which he returns to Santiago to discover the church of his childhood desolate, its last priest an abandoned invalid.

title: MEXICAN STUDENTS SEEK LARGER ROLE AT UNIVERSITY
description: About 100,000 students gathered in the city's central square one night this week in the latest protest against a series of changes at the National Autonomous University.

title: F.D.A. to Get Report On Drug for Baldness
description: An advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration will meet Monday to receive a report on a drug that the Upjohn Company is seeking to market as a cure for baldness.

title: JAILED MEXICAN OIL CHIEF DEMANDS PROOF IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: After spending nearly three and a half years in jail accused of defrauding Mexico of $34 million, the former head of the Mexican Government's oil monopoly is demanding that the Government either prove its case or release him.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press on Jan. 8 from New Bedford, Mass., about a court ruling in the death of a student undergoing treatment at a school for autistic teen-agers, described the ruling incorrectly. Matthew Israel, director of the Behavior Research Institute, was found negligent in having inadequately supervised the use of a helmet, not in the death itself.

title: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The share earnings reflect 100 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 21. The 1985 results restated for a change in the company's accounting method.

title: GATEWAY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Gateway Bank went public in August 1985.

title: MILTON ADLER
description: Milton Adler, for many years a criminal trial lawyer on the staff of the Legal Aid Society in Manhattan, collapsed and died Monday on a subway platform in lower Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMPUTER COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WEBSTER'S AILMENT CLOUDS HIS FUTURE
description: A day after Tom Webster suffered a relapse of his inner-ear condition, he acknowleged that there was a possibility that his illness would prevent him from flying and, as a result, from coaching the Rangers for the remainder of the season.

title: S.E.C. Looking At Volatility
description: After a Wall Street session in which stock prices fluctuated wildly, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency continued to be concerned about increasing volatility in the nation's securities markets, and was examining ways to dampen the volatility.

title: TOKYO MARKET IN RISE
description: The Tokyo stock average rose to a record high close today in volatile trading after Wall Street's biggest single-session advance and in anticipation of a cut in Japan's discount rate, brokers said.

title: PHILIPS INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OAKWOOD HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in October.

description: The Rangers, a team in flux, met the team of Gretzky tonight, and they were hardly soothed.

Correction
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about big bands gave an incorrect day and an incorrect ticket price for a concert with the Sauter-Finegan orchestra. The concert, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, is at 8 P.M. tomorrow, not today; tickets are $12 and $15.

title: SEEKING A NEW HOME, NBC NARROWS PICK TO 3
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it has narrowed its search for a new home to three sites, one in the New Jersey Meadowlands, one on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and the other in the same location it has occupied for more than 50 years, Rockefeller Center.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMEMT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAMPAIGN BONUSES ROIL G.O.P. LEADERS
description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., national chairman of the Republican Party, said today that members of the party's national committee were outraged by big bonuses paid staff members of some party campaign organizations and by commissions paid to some party fund-raisers.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,872,000 for the quarter and $8,616,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $1,026,000 for the quarter and $471,000 for the year. The bank converted to stock form in June 1986.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the AMR Corporation omitted an explanation for its sharp drop in net income. Profits in the fourth quarter fell mainly because of a one-time charge of $38.9 million, caused by provisions of the new tax law. Operating income rose substantially, to $86.9 million, from $36.5 million in the 1985 quarter.

title: Texas Bank Posts Deficit
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it was ''actively looking'' at a number of options meant to bolster the ailing bank holding company, including a possible merger with an out-of-state company. The long-rumored admission came as the company reported a $136.75 million loss during the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 and a loss of $401.96 million for all of 1986. The company earned $7.6 million for the three months in 1985 and $41.8 million for that whole year.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $113,000 from interest income from payoff of participating loans. c-Includes gains of $2,503,000 from interest income loan payoff and $178,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: CARMEN'S UNION REACHES ACCORD IN RAIL WALKOUT
description: The Long Island Rail Road reached agreement yesterday with another striking union, the carmen, but several others broke off talks.

title: YONKERS ORDERED TO CHOOSE EXPERT TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED HOUSING
description: A Federal judge today gave Yonkers two weeks to select a housing expert who would propose a long-term integration plan for the city.

title: Big Board Weathers The Storm
description: Yesterday's record stock market activity left brokers breathless - and eagerly hoping for more.

title: Convictions Reversed For 2 in Gambino Trial
description: A Federal appeals court has partially reversed the convictions of two men convicted last year in a Mafia trial involving Paul Castellano and the Gambino crime family.

title: JURY SELECTION IS A CHALLENGE IN GOETZ CASE
description: Of the 18 prospective jurors who entered the small back room of the State Supreme Court at 111 Centre Street yesterday, most had heard of Bernhard H. Goetz and knew why he was on trial.

title: WASHINGTON'S PASS IS NO GEM FOR NETS
description: Was it a smart play or a rookie mistake? Pearl Washington wanted to believe he had done the right thing tonight, that his lob pass to Orlando Woolridge should have resulted in a basket at a critical stage for the Nets. Instead, it resulted in a turnover and contributed to a 125-120 loss to the Seattle SuperSonics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: GENERAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PLAZA COMMERCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings adjusted for 5 percent stock dividends in August and December.

title: What's a Jersey Guy?
description: Just when everyone here thought nothing more could be said about that game tomorrow, more of nothing was said.

title: Giants, Led by Simms, Are Sharp in Final Practice
description: The Giants went through an impressive two-minute drill today in their final practice for Sunday's Super Bowl game against the Broncos.

title: Whither Perle?
description: Richard N. Perle, the hard-line Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, is said to be telling friends he is leaving the Pentagon.

title: Talking of Two Cities
description: He was my teacher at City College and I called him for lunch because I wanted some advice. He was the best teacher I ever had and the only black teacher. I had admired him for decades, for his historic work in desegregating the country's schools, for explaining the reality of the Harlem ghetto, for creating lives and careers for young people - Ken Clark, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark.

title: Tiger Gets New Chief
description: Tiger International Inc. has named Stephen M. Wolf as its chairman, president and chief executive. Mr. Wolf will remain chief executive of Flying Tiger Lines, the air cargo carrier and Tiger's chief subsidiary. Mr. Wolf succeeds Robert P. Jensen, who retired and stepped down from the boards of Flying Tiger and Tiger International.

title: Hear, Hear
description: Washington is a town that thrives on news leaks. Reporters love them, and in an environment in which information is power, those who have it usually want to use it. Thus it was that Senator James A. McClure of Idaho, the ranking Republican on the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, ruminated that he had attended a closed hearing at which senior intelligence officials briefed selected lawmakers. Not a word of it leaked. Suddenly Mr. McClure thought of the reason: ''In that hearing we didn't hear anything.''

title: TRI-STATE PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company noted that it became a publicly-owned company on June 3, 1985, at which time it succeeded to the business of Tri-Star Pictures, a joint venture, and that the results of operations of the joint venture through June 3, 1985 have been included in the results.

title: CONNECTICUT MOTHER BECOMES DETECTIVE TO VINDICATE SON 920:41,813>
description: Sandra Visnapuu could not believe it, but the police were certain.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Let no one believe that Congress, for all its wisdom and cool impartiality, has escaped the pervasive hoopla surrounding the Super Bowl.

title: NOV. 23: GIANTS 19, BRONCOS 16
description: Last Nov. 23 the Giants defeated Denver, 19-16, at Giants Stadium, with a 4 to 2 edge in turnovers and without the Giants' offense scoring a touchdown.

title: MAMET PLAY IN STAMFORD
description: DAVID MAMET'S laconic style can lure one into thinking there must be something more to his plays than reaches the ear.

title: ROSE BOWL SPRUCES UP FOR THE BIG SHOW
description: THE Rose Bowl sits in a dry river bed called the Arroyo Seco, its west bank at the foot of the Linda Vista Hills. In the distance, the San Gabriel Mountains offer a picture-postcard view, especially on these sometimes chilly winter southern California mornings when a brisk wind clears the clouds and thick, yellow smog.

title: Eat and Drink But Don't Smoke
description: WHILE many restaurants with bars in Massachusetts had nonsmoking sections, one in Newton became the first to go cold turkey.

title: Koch Sees a City Getting Well Again
description: Earlier this month, when he reported on the city's financial condition, Mayor Koch's rhetoric was fanned by a landward breeze. ''I can now say we sail in calmer waters,'' he said. Last week, commenting in his State of the City Address on the corruption scandals that had ''wounded us all,'' the Mayor modeled his ship of state after the hospital vessel Hope: ''The knife of corruption endangered the life of New York City. The scalpel of the law is making us well again.''

title: Mourning in Iran
description: On the arid flatlands south of this capital, a cemetery is growing quickly.

title: The Cat's Meow: Fake Furs
description: THESE days fake-fur fanciers have little to growl about. That's because of the preponderance of big-cat facsimiles, which are uncannily like the real thing. The coats are made of lightweight but warm synthetics printed with mirror images of the cats' markings. Among the most eye-catching are the Somali leopard fakes (top right), with small, ringlike spots, and the ocelot (bottom, second from right), with a distinctive dot-and-broken-line pattern. Also seen around town are the mock turtle leopard (near right), so-called for obvious reasons, and a new deep-piled French import that looks like jaguar (center).

title: BUILDING IN BRISTOL IS 3d LARGEST
description: LEAD: RISING 29 stories into the air, Bristol's newest building houses several elevators with nowhere to go. The Otis Research Tower, with 10 hoistways for testing high-rise, mid-rise and low-rise elevators, will be Connecticut's third-tallest building when it opens next Sunday.

title: EXPERTS SEE GIANT VICTORY
description: The Giants. In a low-scoring, close game.

title: A MOVING PICTURE IS WORTH 1,000 WORDS
description: SEVERAL years ago it occurred to William K. Grollman, an accountant, that instead of sending people to a business seminar, at large expense, one could take the seminar program to the people.

title: Why Sprinklers Stay on the Sidelines
description: IN A 1983 survey of its 8,200 members, the American Hotel and Motel Association found that, while more than 70 percent of respondents had smoke, fire or heat detectors in guest rooms, less than 10 percent had installed automatic sprinklers. The absence of sprinklers in guest rooms, fire protection experts said, is a glaring deficiency in hotel safety measures and could result in future fires and needless deaths.

title: TOY GUNS: A REAL AND GROWING PROBLEM FOR POLICE
description: Just after midnight over the school holidays last month, three San Francisco police officers responded to a silent alarm indicating that someone had entered a local high school. A few minutes later a 15-year-old high school student lay dying in a darkened hallway, shot by one of the officers, who had seen the youth pointing a gun at him.

title: BRITISH MINISTER TOURS NEW YORK AIDS CLINIC
description: Kneeling at the bedside of AIDS patients at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, Britain's Minister of Social Services, Norman Fowler, yesterday talked to the gaunt victims about their illness and the medical care they were receiving.

title: French Visas
description: To the Editor: The Dec. 7 Q & A column told your readers that a French visa must be obtained here if one plans to cross France by train. Not so.

title: Times Between Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: HEARTY STEWS CAN TAKE THE CHILL OFF
description: OLD-FASHIONED stews make perfect meals for cold winter evenings. Hearty and comforting, they are also immensely practical, because they can be made in one pot and cooked a day or two in advance - and they improve in flavor when left overnight.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
In Parsippany, A Man's Hotel Is His Castle
description: LEAD: BUILT to meet the needs of corporate travelers, business hotels that sprang up throughout New Jersey in the last two decades were designed to be simple and functional. They were stationed along major highways and, for the most part, were tall boxes of glass and steel.

title: Has Liu the Justice Been Silenced by Beijing?
description: zo the Editor:

title: Discovering China's Folk Art
description: For centuries, the elite of China dismissed as trivial the crafts made by villagers for their own use - the leather shadow puppets, paper cutouts, embroideries, batiks and woodblock prints. Today these handcut and stitched works are gaining recognition in China and in the West, a change that seems long overdue after viewing ''Chinese Folk Art: The Small Skills of Carving Insects,'' at the Yale University Art Gallery. The exhibition is the first of its kind in this country.

title: SO THE TEXAN WHO'S BROKE SAYS TO THE...
description: Once upon a time there were jokes about rich Texans.

title: INSURANCE: EXECUTIVES OFFER PLAN
description: LEAD: THE key to resolving New Jersey's liability-insurance crisis may lie in reforming the state's tort liability system, a group of business executives has reported after a yearlong study.

title:
INVESTING;
Technology Stocks Start Catching Up
description: LEAD: JANUARY'S stock market rally has sent many technology stocks into orbit. The Alliance Technology Fund, a $200 million mutual fund, for instance, has climbed 33 percent in value since the beginning of the year - a return that investors would be pleased to earn over several years.

title: FEELINGS OF AND AND IF, OF AND BUT
description: IN the second chapter of Joyce's ''Ulysses'' Stephen Dedalus is admonished by his employer, Mr. Deasy, ''We are a generous people, but we must also be just.'' ''I fear those big words,'' Stephen answers, ''which make us so unhappy.'' He does not specify the big ones: presumably they include ''generous,'' ''people,'' ''just'' and ''must,'' words that lodge an ethical or a nationalist claim.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BLACK HISTORY EVENTS

title: Building a Buffer for the 21st Century
description: SOCIAL Security has not been in the news much lately, and with good reason. In 1983, Congress ended the financial crises that had plagued the Social Security System since the 1970's. It did so principally by modifying benefits in several ways and by moving to 1988 some of the previously scheduled 1990 contribution rate increase. In 1987, Social Security may well be back in the news, not because there is a problem but because some people are urging Congress to cancel a key element of the 1983 solution.

title: Words About Minimalism
description: To the Editor:

title: The State of the President
description: What's new, coming up on the President's report to Congress, is not the State of the Union but the state of the President. Starting suddenly, on successive days last November, the Reagan Administration changed. Six years of genial invincibility have faded fast and that's why this address to Congress ranks in importance with his first one. It will show whether Ronald Reagan, whose resilience has been so often underestimated, can bounce back once again.

title: VIDEO CONCERN CREATES WIZARDRY FOR TELEVISION
description: LEAD: AT kickoff time today, more than 104,000 cheering fans will be packed into the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., for the Super Bowl. Many millions of viewers, meanwhile, will be comfortably settled in front of their televisions, watching the technical wizardry that makes many people prefer watching sporting events from their living rooms.

title: A Lackluster G.N.P. Caps a Dismal Year
description: The economy grew at a dull 1.7 percent rate in the fourth quarter, and just 2.5 percent for all of 1986, which had been heralded by many as a 4 or 5 percent growth year. The fourth-quarter gain was below what most Government and private economists had expected. Much of the blame goes to the trade deficit, which has remained stubbornly high despite the falling dollar, and lackluster performances in energy and business investment. But consumer expenditures were relatively strong - personal spending rose 2 percent in December in spite of a rise of just eight-tenths of 1 percent in personal income - and exports were up, which could herald a brighter outlook.

title: Sailing a Boat Can Be Heavenly
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Data Bank: January 25, 1987
A Cup Pursued
description: Come next month, Dennis Conner could be the first American yachtsman to retrieve the 136-year-old America's Cup from foreign hands.

title: SCHOOL TAKEOVER PLAN: TWO VIEWS
description: On Dec. 14 an Opinion article by Joan D. Abrams, Superintendant of Schools in Red Bank, appeared on this page. In it, the writer said she viewed ''as singularly unfortunate the opposition of the New Jersey School Boards Association to the plan of the state's Department of Education to take over certain school districts that have gone into educational bankruptcy.'' She went on to say why she supported the ''intervention'' plan. The article elicited the accompanying two responses. Is the attempt by the State's Department of Education to ''take over'' allegedly deficient school districts a necessary action to bring ''quality education'' to urban schoolchildren?

title: ALONG WITH POX, A DOSE OF ISOLATION
description: THIS is a true story. I write, hoping to evoke compassion, forgiveness and eventual reacceptance into society.

title: BOMBS IN THE BALANCE
description: THE PRICE OF PEACE Living With the Nuclear Dilemma. By Lawrence Freedman. 288 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: 6 Picked as Hall Finalists
description: Don Maynard, Len Dawson, Larry Csonka, Joe Greene, Jim Langer and Gene Upshaw were chosen today by the Pro Football Hall of Fame selection committee as the six finalists for 1987 induction.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: RESPONDING to an invitation from the New Jersey Library Association to ''call your library for anything,'' I did, calling the name on the flier: Margaret Jiuliano, the librarian and director of the Bernards Township Library in Somerset County.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: BREAKER BOYS. By Jan Kubicki. (Atlantic Monthly, $17.95.) If you come to this novel about a turn-of-the-century Pennsylvania mining town looking for a thoroughly researched social and historical document, you'll find it. Jan Kubicki knows well the details and texture of the bleak lives of his Polish and Welsh miners and their families before the existence of the United Mine Workers union.

title: 'Maximum Tolrenance' Is Put to the Test
description: LAST week's killing of 12 protesters by Government policemen substantially raised the already enormous pressure on President Corazon C. Aquino and appeared to set the limit on her policy of ''maximum tolerance.''

title: Doctors And the Humane Touch
description: It is hard not to be skeptical about the ''new approach to medical education'' described in Amy Wallace's article ''Teaching the Humane Touch'' (Dec. 21). In fact, the title itself is trendy enough to make one want to run to the nearest technocratic physician he can find.

title: Shelby Barber to Wed Jeffery Tranter in June
