description: Mrs. Arthur Barber Jr. of Alpine, N.J., and Blue Hill, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter Shelby Sprague Barber to Jeffery Michael Tranter, a son of Mrs. Sefton Tranter of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Tranter. A June wedding is planned.

title: Official Who Killed Himself Had Rejected a Plea Bargain
description: In the months before he committed suicide, R. Budd Dwyer, the Pennsylvania State Treasurer, vehemently rejected a plea bargain in his bribery-conspiracy case.

title: Woody Allen and Neil Simon Conjure a Compelling Era
description: On the boardwalk in the 1940's, dancers did the Lindy to music from a juke box in front of ''Meyer's Knishes.'' Nearby was the Takee-Cup stand where you bought chow mein served in a cup made out of noodles. You ate the chow mein, then you ate the cup. The bars featured a kind of juke box with a screen that played ''soundies,'' short subjects of big bands playing their hits, like Artie Shaw and his Orchestra doing ''Star Dust.'' The lamppost lights along the boardwalk were painted black on the side facing the ocean so as not to be a beacon for German submarines. If a German plane ever flew overhead you would have spotted it for sure with your intimate knowledge of enemy aircraft silhouettes. I could go on and on. I could fill this article with references to my childhood in the 1940's during the war, of Rockaway at that time, of the sounds, the textures.

title: When The Group Becomes The Star
description: On the surface, Richard Harris's ''Stepping Out'' and Israel Horovitz's ''North Shore Fish'' are totally dissimilar. The former, an English play with music, deals with Londoners from disparate backgrounds who are taking an evening class in tapdancing. The latter, a drama set in Gloucester, Mass., is concerned with a group of workers who are employed in a frozen-fish processing plant. At their core, however, ''Stepping Out'' and ''North Shore Fish'' belong to the same theatrical school. With different degrees of success, they are plays in which, through a shared activity, a cross-section of people reveal their problems and personalities and arrive at a dramatic conclusion.

title: GOOD FORTUNE DOGS WRITER OF 'OUTRAGEOUS FORTUNE'
description: LEAD: Leslie Dixon is a student of Preston Sturges comedies, has not a particle of snobbery about sitcoms, she adores the ''vulgar trashy tacky sleazy exciting glitz'' of Hollywood, worships at the feet of the French director Francis Veber (''Les Comperes'') and believes - popular wisdom notwithstanding - that a female screenwriter today is at a happy advantage.

title: ISLANDERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Ari Haanpaa scored at 2 minutes 28 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Islanders a 2-1 victory over the Quebec Nordiques.

title: THE LAST TWO YEARS OF THE 'REAGAN REVOLUTION'
description: CONSERVATIVES with a historical bent store among their nightmares the fading of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal after the Democrats' huge majorities in Congress were cut sharply in a Republican surge in 1938 and the President became preoccupied by foreign policy. As Ronald Reagan prepares for his State of the Union address this week, they have a similar worry about the ''Reagan Revolution.''

title: SALMON RENEWAL PLAN FACING THREAT
description: An Interior Department program to reintroduce the Atlantic salmon to the rivers of New England is facing a threat to its survival.

title: HELP FOR VICTIMS OF 'ORPHAN DISEASES'
description: LEAD: TO LOOK at her, you wouldn't know. An outgoing, green-eyed, blonde child, she looks and acts like any other 4-year-old, stealing potato chips from her brother and sister and jumping on her daddy's lap.

title: BAKER TO PICTURE DECLINE OF DOLLAR AS ECONOMIC BOON
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d is expected to tell President Reagan Monday that the two-year fall of the dollar that accelerated late last month has been good for the economy, an Administration aide said today.

title: DANCE: ANNABELLE GAMSON COMPANY
description: ANNABELLE GAMSON is to be thanked for her revivals of dances by Isadora Duncan and for the insights into great performing that she has provided over the past decade. Now we are even more in her debt - this time for bringing to life the work of Eleanor King, in a program presented Thursday at St. Mark's Church.

title: 2 Bombings in Italian Alps
description: Two bombs exploded a minute apart today near the homes of local politicians in Bolzano, the capital of Alto Adige, an Alpine region racked by tensions between ethnic Germans and Italians. The explosions blew out windows but caused no injuries. No immediate claim of responsibility was reported. The explosions occurred near the homes of a provincial assessor, Remo Ferretti, a Christian Democrat, and of Andrea and Piero Mitolo, who are local leaders of the Italian Social Movement, a neo-Fascist party.

title: GOING OVER THE GREAT DIVIDE
description: A CONFLICT OF VISIONS By Thomas Sowell. 273 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: SEARCH BY POLLICE IS DEBATED
description: LEAD: THE director of the Office of Inmate Advocacy of the state's Department of the Public Advocate said last week that he planned to sue the New Brunswick Police Department this week on behalf of four women who said they were strip-searched after being arrested at a demonstration protesting this city's treatment of the homeless.

title: Star Wars Stampede
description: If a new Democratic Congress were to make a difference in only one thing, it probably ought to be in President Reagan's plan for a ''Star Wars'' strategic defense. Now the Pentagon is talking of deploying elements of such a defense in the early 1990's - a dubious notion that Congress should dispel promptly and firmly.

title: ''SIDE BY SIDE': ELEGANT SONDHEIM
description: FOR Stephen Sondheim fans, the revue ''Side by Side by Sondheim,'' now at the New Studio Theater, offered by the Broadhollow Players, is a retrospective of musical numbers by one of Broadway's great composers. Out of this tuneful cornucopia spill songs from shows as diverse as ''Follies,'' ''Company,'' ''A Little Night Music,'' ''Pacific Overtures'' and ''Sweeney Todd.''

title: Selling Dollars Above Face Value
description: EVERYONE knows a dollar is no longer worth a dollar, but that didn't stop the Government last year from selling $1 and $2 bills for more than they were worth. Demand was good, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing said.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
GARDENING;
SLOWING THE SPREAD OF ELM DISEASE
description: LEAD: THE accidental introduction of Dutch elm disease to the United States on veneer logs from Holland some 60 years ago proved to be devastating to our native American elm. This grandest of all shade trees once provided shade for houses, created arch canopies over city boulevards and small-town streets and made parks pleasant places to while away hot summer afternoons.

title: SHANGHAI EMERGING FROM LONG ECONOMIC TORPOR
description: Despite the size of this sprawling city, its location and profusion of intellectual and technical expertise, Shanghai has stumbled almost blindly through the last three decades shackled by radical politics, neglect from the national Government and bureaucratic obstinacy.

title: POLL FINDS A NEGLECT OF MATH
description: AT a time when national studies rank American students among the lowest in the industrialized world in math skills, a survey released this month indicates that Connecticut elementary pupils are spending more than twice as much time in class studying English than mathematics.

title: THE BENEFITS OF BEING A HOST PARENT
description: ACQUAINTANCES and even somefriends were puzzled. This year, despite being the parents of three children and in spite of my teaching full-time during the day and part-time at night, we became American Field Service host parents. Keiko Ichimura, 17 years old, from Zama, Japan, is living with us. She is attending Somers schools with my children.

title: NEEDS OF THE ELDERLY SEEN SHARPLY INCREASING
description: THE number of elderly people in Connecticut is growing at a faster rate than the rest of the nation.

title: Topics: Winning in Winter; Expertise in the Chair
description: Congressional Republicans and Democrats made leadership choices of enormous importance last week, one good and one troubling.

title: Sam May Not Play It Again
description: You won't find a proposal to edit Humphrey Bogart's films on Congress's agenda right now. But if pending legislation to ban all cigarette advertisements is enacted, you may want to Betamax ''Casablanca'' before the Government gets to it.

title: A Violent Reprisal In South Africa
description: Leaders of the United Democratic Front, the big anti-apartheid coalition in South Africa, have long accused Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader, of cooperating with the white Government. Last week, the Front blamed the Chief's followers for an attack on the home of one of its prominent members in which seven children and five adults were killed.

title: WITNESS AT THE FREE-FOR-ALL
description: In 1951, 12 years before his death, Jean Cocteau began keeping a diary. Its existence was kept a secret until 1983, when the first of six volumes was published in Paris. The initial volume covers the years 1951 to 1953, when Cocteau, in his early 60's, was living partly in Paris, partly in relative solitude at his villa Santo Sospir at Cap-Ferrat in the South of France. His constant companions were Francine Weisweiller, his friend and patron, and the young actor Edouard Dermit (Doudou), his lover and adopted son. By this time, Cocteau had already built - through talent and self-promotion - an international reputation as a poet, novelist, critic, film maker, dramatist, artist and flamboyant public figure. The following excerpts are from ''Past Tense: Volume I, Diaries,'' translated by Richard Howard. On Keeping a Diary

title: ON THE SUPER BOWL, OR ANYTHING, AMERICA IS READY TO BET
description: BY the time the Giants and Denver Broncos finish butting heads in Super Bowl XXI today, about 130 million Americans, or more than one in two, will have watched at least part of the game on television. And to judge from the comments of bookmakers, police officers and gambling industry observers, a good number of those people will have made a wager on the outcome.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN HOTEL SAFETY
description: THE scene following the New Year's eve fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, was a familiar one: officials parading before the television cameras, calling for tougher fire prevention laws. Similar appeals were heard after fatal fires in 1980 at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., and at a Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Valerie E. Baecker to Wed Michael J. Murphy in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Baecker of Emerson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Ellen Baecker, to Michael J. Murphy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Murphy of Tequesta, Fla. The wedding is planned for May 16.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: ANCIENT ENEMIES. By Elizabeth North. (Academy Chicago, Paper, $6.95.) Petra, the heroine of Elizabeth North's new novel, is a 16-year-old English schoolgirl with many of the problems that affect teen-agers everywhere. Although she has the usual adolescent verbal ticks and shorthands (very nicely reproduced by Ms.

title: Fun-in-the-Sun Paraphernalia
description: In flipping through the Dec. 21 issue of The New York Times Magazine, I could not help noticing the tremendous difference between resort wear for men and women (''Winter Break,'' by Ruth La Ferla, Men's Style, and ''Fun in the Sun,'' Fashion). Men ''will wear what they feel comfortable in. They are not going to fill their suitcases with a lot of paraphernalia.'' To have ''fun in the sun,'' women, on the other hand, must adorn themselves with futuristic accessories such as pliable hats and exaggerated jewelry. CHENOWETH MOFFATT Cambridge, Mass.

title: ECONOMY IS KEY AS IRISH GO TO POLLS
description: ON the day after he called for the dissolution of Parliament last week, and scheduled a national election, Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, an economist by profession, said the election would be won and lost on economic issues. Did that not mean, asked a reporter, that Dr. FitzGerald would be running against his own record? He shook his head, as if in mild reproach of a student who hadn't grasped the subtleties of history.

title: INSPIRED BY DESPAIR
description: THE COLLECTED LETTERS OF JOSEPH CONRAD Volume Two: 1898-1902. Edited by Frederick R. Karl and Laurence Davies. Illustrated. 483 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $44.50.

title: BLIND SKIERS TAKING ON VERMONT COUNTRY TRAILS
description: When she is skiing across a windswept and dazzling field here, Debby Hoover says, the things she notices most are the sounds: snow that ''squeaks,'' ''crunches'' or ''hums, like a telephone line,'' the constant barking of a nearby dog, the shouts of other skiers.

title: RETURNING WITH THE TIDES TO BREHAT
description: LEAD: Growing up on the Atlantic coast of France, I was charmed when I came for the first time to Brittany. The sea could be a richer world, a mixture of mists and brilliant colors, of mysterious islands and black, half-submerged rocks, of deep blue inlets and castles towering over distant promontories.

title: Go Back to Old Colors On New York Plates
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Eckelberry Engaged to Marry Douglas Johnson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Evans Eckelberry of Muttontown, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Emily Stark Eckelberry to Douglas Scott Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Johnson of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I.

title: Reading Lips
description: MORE THAN any other item of makeup, red lipstick is capturing the imagination - and the dollars - of American women. For most of these women, coming to red after seasons of wearing more subtle lipstick is logical. Women today are putting extra effort into dressing up for evening, and sophisticated makeup seems to be a natural accompaniment. But unlike other current examples of opulent makeup - false eyelashes or plucked eyebrows, for instance - vivid red lipstick is simple and quick to apply.

title: Land Use On Stormy Shorelines
description: AFTER slashing away the sand that covered a steel seawall in front of Robert and Gail Saum's 38-year-old home in Beverly Shores, Ind., Lake Michigan storms are now working on the house. In anticipation of losing it to the lake, the Saums are packed and ready.

title: Being Alert to Fire Safety
description: Every so often a disaster serves to remind travelers that they cannot take their safety for granted. Such was the case with the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, P.R., as a result of which 96 people died. It reminded travelers everywhere of their vulnerability and of the need for precautions.

title: They Love a Parade
description: I address this to Mayor Koch: Dear Mayor:

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Recent Releases Og Video Cassettes
description: LEAD: THE STORY OF THE SYMPHONY VOLUME I: HAYDN AND MOZART Andre Previn and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra Home Vision. Stereo hi-fi. 90 minutes. $39.95.

title: A POLEMICIST WHO AIMS AT POLITICAL AND CORPORATE TARGETS
description: Hans Haacke, a diligent provocateur whose controversial art is aimed at political and corporate might, has not exactly had a high-profile career. His untrendy, hard-to-pigeonhole work is shunned by most American collectors, and - though he's had regular gallery shows - his current exhibition at the New Museum, 583 Broadway (through Feb. 15), is his first one-man museum exhibition in the United States.

title: I.R.S. AIDE HAS A WARNING
description: LEAD: THE Tax Reform Act of 1986 will neither deter cheating nor make it easier, says Thomas W. Greelish, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, but the chance of getting caught is greater.

title: Topics: Winning in Winter; Flowers On Ice
description: In Willa Cather's famous short story, ''Paul's Case,'' set in yesterday's New York, the hero takes a carriage ride down Fifth Avenue on a snowy night and marvels at ''stands with whole flower gardens blooming under glass cases, against the sides of which the snowflakes stuck and melted; roses, violets, carnations, lilies of the valley - somehow vastly more lovely and alluring that they blossomed thus unnaturally in the snow.''

title: MANDLIKOVA HOPES TO SHED A LABEL
description: Hana Mandlikova hopes she has finally buried the tag that has followed her throughout her tennis career.

title: WORLD VIEW
description: The lack of senior staff and operating managers with an international perspective is the major weakness of most companies doing business on the world market, contends Thomas Gross of Communications International, a management-consulting firm in White Plains that specializes in facilitating successful international business partnerships.

title: Doctors And the Humane Touch
description: The attempt to incorporate compassion and understanding into the medical student is a noble concept, but it is a self-selecting process that appeals to the very individuals who need it least. The overwhelming remaining majority will see this curriculum as the gesture that it is, an isolated course or two in the context of a highly competitive environment populated by compulsive overachievers. ROBERT G. STERN, M.D. Philadelphia

title: Iraqis Face Shells
description: Basra is besieged but not burning.

title: L.I.R.R. CONTINUES PACT TALKS
description: The Long Island Rail Road continued to hold talks yesterday with the union for the train engineers in an effort to end the strike that has shut the railroad since last Sunday. But the union's leader, Joseph A. Cassidy Jr., said a settlement was not likely this weekend.

title: Sherlock Holmes and His Maker
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE WELL-DRESSED BIRD ''I WOULD like you to make it very clear that I am not some type of crazy person,'' said Alba Ballard of Huntington Station. ''People, they say she dresses up birds, she must be very strange, but I love these birds,'' she said as she dressed Viking, her 6-year-old parrot, in his Willie Nelson outfit.

title: OPERA: 'THE CORONATION OF POPPEA'
description: Until this past fall, when the Music Center Opera mounted its first real season, Los Angeles had no top-line resident opera company. Perhaps this lack explains the enthusiasm that greeted the Long Beach Opera, an apparently spunky smaller outfit given to innovative productions.

title: Snakeskin
description: THE SKINS OF TWO RATTLESNAKES, TROPHIES OF A sort, were nailed to boards in my great-uncle's library. They were stiff, like old parchment documents, and flattened, as if run over, and crinkled, like discarded tinfoil.

title: Woods in Winter, Florida Fair
description: Exploring The Wilderness In Minnesota

title: G.E.'s Costly Locomotive Gamble
description: THE General Electric Company and the General Motors Corporation routinely racked up big profits from their locomotive divisions during the late 1970's. But G. E., which straggled with 25 percent of the domestic market, wanted more.

title: POWER EVENING
description: THE party is being held in the boiler room, where the big machines will be festooned with a red bow, and guests will nibble on steamed cocktail franks and sip (steaming) capuccino.

title: RUSSIANS FIND MISSING POLAR POST
description: Soviet scientists examining satellite photographs have found an Antarctic research station that disappeared last fall when a piece of ice shelf with the outpost broke away.

title: Allison Pines Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Pines of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Allison Pines, to Kenneth Klein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Klein of Chicago. Ms. Pines is a senior at Northwestern University. Her father is president of National Foods Inc. A division of that company, Hebrew National Kosher Foods, was founded by the late Isidore Pinckowitz, great-grandfather of the future bride. Mr. Klein is a second-year student at the Chicago Medical School. His father is a dentist.

title: SYRACUSE HOLDS OFF ST. JOHN'S
description: Syracuse, facing St. John's for the first time since a 1-point loss in the Big East championship game last season, remained unbeaten in the conference with a 64-63 victory today in another classic battle at the Carrier Dome.

title: POSTINGS: 122 Semidetached; Midway Positioning in Lawrenceville
description: Tiffany Woods, a new home development in Lawrenceville, N.J., is hoping to attract to its wooded 30-acre site buyers who will appreciate its placement eight miles from the halls of academe at Princeton and 58 miles from the glitter of New York City.

title: Harpist, Percussionist, Bassist and Pianist
description: Sylvia Kowalczuk

title: MATTINGLY'S BAT IS HOTTEST, EXCEPT WITH SALARY SWING
description: MAYBE today's football game will be super; maybe it won't.

title: HIGH SCHOOL CLASSES JOIN IN MOCK TRIAL
description: LEAD: FOR five consecutive mornings recently, Room 233 at New Rochelle High School bustled with activity. Student attorneys, court officals, witnesses, jurors and spectators gathered there to participate in and listen to ''The Trial of Jeffrey MacDonald,'' a mock proceeding conducted by a senior law-studies class - one of four offered at the school.

title: CRAFTS CRITICISM IS COMING INTO ITS OWN
description: CRAFT criticism, as a pursuit apart from art criticism, is coming into its own as a subject for discussion. Although scattered in place and time, more panel discussions and seminars are being devoted to the subject.

title: TOURS AND LECTURES TO TELL TALE OF 6 SHIPS
description: FROM whalers to fishing boats to submarines, the seagoing vessels of southeastern Connecticut have long been important in, and also beyond, local life. Starting Wednesday evening, a series of monthly tours and lectures in Groton, Mystic, New London and Stonington will focus on the role of six vessels in American history and in the contemporary maritime scene.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: RONALD REAGAN - HIS LIFE STORY IN PICTURES by Stanley P. Friedman. Dodd, Mead & Company. 159 pages. $12.95.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It might not be the right way to play the game, but it might be the only way.'' - Albert M. Wojnilower, First Boston economist, on Treasury Secretary Baker's strategy on the dollar.

title: A GIFT TO LAST A LIFETIME
description: WE had hoped for a white Christmas and got drizzle instead. It forced the young cast of ''The Living Creche'' to abandon its rustic lean-to on the church lawn and pose instead, rather self-consciously, before the altar inside. It was a lovely Christmas Eve, nonetheless.

title: HOSPITAL REFUNDS $1.1 MILLION IN FEES
description: THE first hospital in the state to lose a budgetary dispute with its regulatory agency is returning $1.1 million in fees charged its patients, but in many cases it costs more to process the check than the check is worth.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Appraisers;
Standardizing The Industry
description: LEAD: THE nation's 250,000 real-estate appraisers may be getting new uniform guidelines by 1988.

title: Dolby Circuit Plays Role in Copying CD's On Cassette
description: Ray Dolby, the British inventor who now maintains his laboratory in San Francisco, has been known mainly for his patented method of reducing tape hiss. These noise-reduction circuits were the spur for the transformation of the audio cassette - originally intended merely as a dictating device - into a medium suitable for music. And the use of this invention, now part of most cassette recorders, has been so widespread that the name of Dolby has become a household word throughout the world.

title: New Powers in Foreign Affairs
description: The House Democrats fiercely argued personalities; the Senate Republicans calmly debated precedence. In the end, both reversed earlier votes. The Democrats returned a chastened moderate, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, to the chairmanship of the House Armed Services Committee; the Republicans turned to a combative conservative, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, as ranking minority member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Elizabeth Kahn Plans To Be Married in May
description: Judge and Mrs. A. David Kahn of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hette Kahn, to William Ashby Jump 3d, the son of Mr. Jump Jr. of San Antonio and the late Dorothy Walsh Tenney of Port Washington, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: When Walls Sound an Early Alarm
description: ONE of the major problems in hotel fires is the lack of an early warning. Fires can fester in closets, walls or ventilation systems for several minutes and then suddenly burst forth with great force.

title: A CITY OF MUSICIANS AND AUDIENCES
description: An art museum may sound like a strange place to begin a musical tour, but for the visitor to Prague who is interested in Czech music, the Gallery of 19th-Century Czech Art is a striking introduction. The museum, part of the National Gallery, is imaginatively housed in the former Convent of the Blessed Agnes, a vast and magnificent 13th-century complex, the largest and oldest Gothic monument in the city, still being restored, rescued after centuries of neglect. Two wings are now open; in the intelligently installed collection you can see any number of big canvases reflecting the last century's nationalist passion for Czech history: the legendary Queen Libuse stands on Vysehrad Hill, prophesying the glory of Prague; and here is the Amazonlike Sarka, and Premysl, the farmer-king; and, closer to modern times, Jan Hus, the 15th-century religious martyr. All these characters inspired the operas and tone poems of Czech composers, from Smetana and Dvorak to the later Fibich and Janacek.

title: BEIRUT COLLEGE IS HIT BY FACTIONAL STRIFE FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: Beirut University College, where four faculty members were kidnapped by gunmen yesterday, is a small private co-educational institution founded in Moslem West Beirut by American missionaries 63 years ago and has continued to function despite civil war and chaos in Lebanon.

title: NICARAGUA VISITEED TO LEARN AND HELP
description: LEAD: UNIVERSITY students, the first to be included after 15 delegations in the two years of the New Haven/Leon Sister City Project, have returned from two weeks of working and learning in Nicaragua.

title: PRETORIA LEGISLATOR QUITS RULING PARTY, URGING MORE CHANGE
description: A member of Parliament has resigned from the ruling National Party, expressing dissatisfaction with what he called the slow pace of change and the lack of negotiation with leaders of other races.

title:
DINING OUT;
A VOID IS FILLED IN MORRISTOWN
description: LEAD: A FEW years ago, Morristown residents had to leave there to find a first-class restaurant. However, recent years have brought a vast improvement. There is now an excellent French/Continental restaurant in the town, an elegant hotel restaurant and several lesser but still interesting ones.

title: MENUS CATEGORIZED IN BYTE-SIZED PIECES
description: I WAS on the telephone when my neighbor stopped by for a cup of rice. Motioning to the cupboard, I expected her to grab the grain and run. Instead, she opened the cupboard door, paused and let out a loud guffaw. She had discovered my ''Batterie de Cuisine,'' a computerized list of my pots and pans by size and capacity.

title: Outdoors; Ducks Unlimited Is Proud of Its History
description: THE New York City Chapter of Ducks Unlimited will hold its annual fund-raising dinner Feb. 19 at the Waldorf-Astoria, according to the event's chairman, Julien (Lash) McCall Jr., who notes that it was the first of its kind in the nation. The organization was founded in 1937 by a small group of the city's sportsmen.

title: WHOLE THEATRE: A REVISED ''STEAL AWAY''
description: ''STEAL AWAY'' was a slight play when it was offered more than two years ago at New Brunswick's Crossroads Theatre.

title: IN AND OUT OF TOWN
description: Health for Africa Feb. 1 - While attending the 1985 United Nations Decade for Women conference in Kenya, Dr. Sorosh Roshan, an obstetrician and gynecologist practicing in Millburn, N.J., helped establish the International Health Network, in which volunteers - medical specialists and others - work with local authorities to bring medical treatment and education to African villages. Dr. Roshan invites those who are willing to pay their own way and work hard for two to six weeks to join the health expeditions. A less strenuous way to help is to attend a black-tie benefit the health group is holding at the Chanticler restaurant in Millburn, about a 40-minute drive from Manhattan. Cocktails at 6 P.M., followed by a dinner dance. Tickets, $125 or $75 for those under 21 years old, and directions from 201-467-9109 or 201-377-3300. Trans-Atlantic Dancing Feb. 4 - The Sadler's Wells Association in this country arranges exchange programs between British and American dance companies such as the visit last year of the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet to the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Starting in April and on into 1988, four American dance companies - Merce Cunningham, Twyla Tharp, Pilobolus and Trisha Brown - will perform as part of the Sadler's Wells American dance series in London. Princess Margaret is scheduled to attend the black-tie ''Gala Dansant'' benefit for the association at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street, beginning with cocktails at 7:30 P.M., followed by dinner at 9 P.M. and dancing. Tickets, $350, from 212-412-5896. Gourmets' Delight Feb. 5 - More than 25 Manhattan restaurants, including La Cote Basque, La Grenouille, Lutece and Primavera, will be offering some of their specialties at ''A Taste of Manhattan'' at the Roseland Ballroom on 52d Street near Broadway. The black-tie evening, starting with a 7 P.M. buffet followed by dancing, will benefit the Manhattan Society, a group of young professionals who raise money for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Tickets, $75, from 212-921-9199. For Young Hearts Feb. 6 - Over a year ago, Charlotte Poth, then 7 months old, underwent open-heart surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's Babies Hospital. The operation was a success, and in gratitude, the child's mother, Charity Poth, and her husband, Christopher, decided to create a charity for the hospital, which admitted 200 children last year for treatment of heart defects. The result was the Babies Heart Fund, which is holding its second Heart Beat Cabaret at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street. Starting at 7:30 P.M., the evening will include dinner, dancing, an open bar, a raffle and entertainment. Requested dress: black tie (with a touch of red). Tickets, $175 or $125 for those under 40, from 212-305-3155. In Washington Feb. 7 - For the seventh year, the Hospital Relief Fund of the Caribbean will hold its fund-raiser in Washington. Founded in 1979 to raise money for hospitals damaged in two hurricanes, the charity has continued and now supports hospital services in the region. A fund-raiser for the group, a black-tie dinner dance, will start with cocktails at 7 P.M. at the newly restored Willard Hotel on Pennsylvania Avenue. Tickets, $150, from 301-652-7822. Supporting Self-Help Feb. 12 - Founded in 1975 by the late Senator Jacob K. Javits, the Citizens Committee for New York City provides information and organizational and political guidance to the hundreds of organizations in the five boroughs that seek to improve or maintain the quality of life in their neighborhoods. At the group's annual New Yorker for New York Awards Celebration at the Waldorf-Astoria, Eugene Lang, Edward S. Finkelstein and John Brademas will be honored. The black-tie evening will start with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $350, from 212-997-0100. Theater Celebration Feb. 12 - The Pan Asian Repertory Theater will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a 10-course Chinese dinner at the Silver Palace Restaurant, 52 Bowery, near Canal Street. The benefit for the theater, which presents plays in English translation, will begin with cocktails at 6 P.M., with entertainment throughout the evening. Tickets, $50, from 212-505-5655.

title: CHINA PARTY OUSTS A TOP JOURNALIST
description: China's Communist Party has expelled a prominent journalist known for his scathing attacks on corruption in party ranks, it was disclosed today.

title: JAPAN FORMALLY DROPS MILITARY SPENDING CAP
description: Japan formally rid itself tonight of a policy that had put a specific cap on yearly increases in military spending. But it coupled the action with a promise to stay ''a peace-loving nation.''

title: PAVIN BIRDIES 16TH AND 17TH TO GAIN ONE-SHOT LEAD IN PHOENIX
description: Corey Pavin, winner of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by a shot last Sunday, birdied the 16th and 17th holes today to take a one-stroke lead over Paul Azinger through three rounds of the 52d annual Phoenix Open.

title: Conflicting Concerns In a Co-op
description: IF not carefully handled, the anticipated scramble for equity loans resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986 could bring co-op boards and shareholders into conflict.

title: File on Gooden
description: NOW that Dwight Gooden has pleaded no contest to two felony charges stemming from a fight with the police in Tampa, Fla., the prosecution's file on the case has been made public. According to the file, one of the officers involved in the scuffle with Gooden yelled ''break his arm'' during the altercation last Dec. 13.

title: Darling's Charges
description: HE isn't scheduled to appear in court in Houston until tomorrow, but Ron Darling, the Mets pitcher who was arrested along with the team's second baseman, Tim Teufel, after a scuffle with two off-duty police officers working as bouncers at a Houston nightclub last July, may have already achieved an important legal victory.

title: A LEVERAGED MACY'S WAITS FOR THE REWARDS
description: IN early 1985, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, the nation's fourth-largest department store chain, found himself increasingly preoccupied with two problems. Some of his most talented executives were restless; a few were leaving for better-paying jobs with more authority at other retailers. And Macy stock was moving up in a way that suggested the possibility that someone was planning to launch a hostile takeover.

title: Woman Indicted in Swindle
description: A woman who insists she is the sister of the late Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis has been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on forgery and other charges. The authorities said she was trying to swindle clothes, money and lodging from residents and businesses. The woman, identified by the police as Rowena Riggs Powell, a 59-year-old native of Virginia, was charged in the indictment Thursday.

title: CORNELL'S BAJUSZ HAS BUSY DOCKET
description: This semester, the second in which John Bajusz has enrolled in both Cornell's College of Enginering and Johnson Graduate School of Management, he takes seven courses that bring some five hours of classes each weekday. He is also in his fourth season as a starter on the basketball team.

title: Jerusalem
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your article on Jerusalem (Travel, Dec. 14) but find that, once again, you omitted my family's favorite restaurant in that wonderful city. Mama Mia in an old stone house on Hillel Street serves delicious, authentic, homemade Italian pastas, sauces, salads, desserts, etc. It is a kosher dairy restaurant. One of my fondest memories is of going there on our first night in Jerusalem and hearing the chef, who normally sings Italian opera while cooking in the kitchen, chant the blessings as the Hanukkah candles were lit in the small rustic dining room. Food and atmosphere are excellent. JANET SCHWARTZ Aberdeen, N.J.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: The Giants will win because, on behalf of their long-suffering loyalists, even masochism has its limits. ALAN C. MILLER New York

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Historically as a nation, Turkey has not always been on the friendliest of terms with its neighbors, but the Turkish Embassy in Washington has its own record for hospitality. The embassy supervised much of the guest list for a black-tie dinner at the National Gallery last week to celebrate the opening of an exhibit, ''The Age of Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent.''

title: Beaux-Arts Sketches: Grace Under Pressure
description: Among the ordeals that faced the young French painter who wanted to climb the official ladder in the 19th century none was either more daunting or more decisive than the historical composition contest that was held every year between 1816 and 1863 at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Success in that contest was the indespensible preliminary to all the other competitive stages that led in time to the Rome Prize. From the Rome Prize there could follow a lifetime of official commissions and prestigious appointments until, heavy with honors, the veteran workhorse was accorded a state funeral.

title: Signs of Life in Times Square
description: New York City's Board of Estimate couldn't decide last week whether to adopt new zoning intended to keep the heart of Broadway emblazoned with the big electric signs known around the world. On Feb. 4, it will try again. Though signs are not the whole answer, a zoning change to guarantee their presence deserves approval.

title: IN CENTRAL AMERICA, ILLS STILL RESIST SIMPLE CURES
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has repeatedly declared that Central America is one of the preoccupations of his Administration. In fact, Frank C. Carlucci, his new national security adviser, last week called the region ''one of the more challenging, if not the most challenging, issue that we will have to deal with in the next two years.''

title: HARTMAN OFFERS PLAY BY MANET
description: DAVID MAMET'S laconic style can lure one into thinking there must be something more to his plays than reaches the ear. Just as the pauses of Harold Pinter are rife with suggestiveness and tension, the clipped cadences and sentence fragments, the repetitions, sometimes even the grunts, of Mr. Mamet's characters have come to represent the poetic innuendos of the inarticulate.

title: COZY FRENCH FOR HEARTY APPETITES
description: AT least three restaurants are clustered along Torrington's Main Street, making it a small-scale Restaurant Row. Newest is Le Rochambeau, whose name telegraphs the French menu you find within.

title: FOR HOSPITALS, NEW VENTURES AND NEW PROFITS
description: Since 1894, Day Kimball Hospital, on the outskirts of the old mill town of Putnam, Conn., has provided most of the health care for the largely rural northeastern corner of the state.

title: NEW IRISH PARTY IS HOPING TO PLAY KINGMAKER
description: Geraldine Kennedy became so weary of covering Irish politics as a journalist that she decided to do what some of her former colleagues consider the next worst thing. She became a politician herself.

title: WHO PUT THE BOMP IN THE BOMP BA BOMP BA BOMP?
description: LEAD: THE TRIUMPH OF VULGARITY Rock Music in the Mirror of Romanticism. By Robert Pattison. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: LINE IS DRAWN: ELWAY VS FRONT 7
description: They have won their last 11 games. They have not lost in more than three months. On Sunday, when they play in the Super Bowl for the first time, the Giants indeed have a chance to become giants.

title: Bruce Hungerford Memorial
description: Ten years ago tomorrow, the pianist Bruce Hungerford died in an automobile accident in the Bronx at the age of 54. Since then all of his recordings have gone out of print, and one will search in vain for his name in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. Yet Hungerford has not been forgotten. Many aficionados consider him one of the most temperate, original, penetrating and deeply satisfying of his generation, and rank his incomplete survey of the Beethoven sonatas (he had recorded only two-thirds of the cycle at the time of his death) with the classic interpretations of artists such as Wilhelm Backhaus, Claudio Arrau and Yves Nat.

title: OLD-FASHIONED SWISS SKIING
description: With its very social and pricey ski resorts like St. Moritz and Gstaad, Switzerland is often avoided by skiers like me -old navy blue parka, lowish boots, longish skis and a hint of the Arlberg technique left over from my racing days. But during a week in the Bernese Oberland we found great skiing, modest prices and a small ski-town atmosphere reminiscent of New England.

title: On Rereading 'Native Son'
description: David Bradley amusingly underrates the ingenuity of bigots to fashion racist motivations in suggesting that Richard Wright's portrait of Bigger Thomas in ''Native Son'' was a needed peg for the stereotyping of black males as muggers (''On Rereading 'Native Son,' '' Dec. 7).

title: Office-Space Demand Strong in Hartford
description: NICHOLAS KAZONIS, senior project manager for corporate real-estate needs with the Amdahl Corporation of California, could not believe what was happening when he started negotiating a few months ago for a lease for 4,000 square feet of office space in downtown Hartford.

title: The Technicalities of Auto-Focusing
description: IT would be a hard job to halt the tide of auto-focusing, single-lens-reflex (SLR) cameras. Never mind that so-called point-and-shoot cameras do the job of making picture-taking easy for most Sunday snapshot photographers. The language being spoken by SLR camera makers these days is not ''quick and simple'' but ''versatile and complex.'' As a result, auto-focusing is getting to be a technical subject in its own right.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
What's In the Future
description: LEAD: A new form of coin holder is raising questions about the future course of numismatics. Holders that protect coins, enhance their appearance and provide a convenient means of storage, have always played an important role.

title: Free Lodging Awarded In Housing Bias Case
description: A Federal judge awarded a year's free lodging on Friday to a fair-housing official who had accused a landlord of refusing to rent a home to him because he was black, according to an attorney in the case.

title: Exploring the World of the Male Ballet Dancer
description: Peter Schaufuss, the Danish ballet star who now directs London Festival Ballet, suffered a severe back injury in 1976 while he was a member of the New York City Ballet. He was treated in London by his osteopath, Demetri Papoutsis, who claims that since then he has stretched Mr. Schaufuss's height by an inch and a quarter.

title: CABARET: JANIS SIEGEL, SOLO
description: WITHIN the Manhattan Transfer, the quartet that has increasingly devoted its energies to vocalization of jazz instrumentals, Janis Siegel has proven to be the most prolific arranger and adventurous singer. And as the group's musical interests have shifted from swing and rhythm-and-blues nostalgia to be-bop, her singing style has toughened and sharpened.

title: Jolie Lisa Busch Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Tobi Busch and Stuart Busch, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Jolie Lisa Busch to Darren Alexander Frank, a son of Rita Paleschuck of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Elliott S. Frank. Ms. Busch, a member of the class of '87 at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, graduated cum laude from Boston University. Her fiance, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton, is an advertisingsales representative of The New York Times.

title: BROADCASTING MUSEUM SEEKS TV'S SELF-HISTORY
description: THOUSANDS of people will videotape Super Bowl XXI today. But fans looking for a copy of the first Super Bowl broadcast - in which the Green Bay Packers trounced the Kansas City Chiefs 35-10 and Max McGee grabbed two touchdown passes - are out of luck.

title: LISTENING FOR VOICES THAT ARE MUTED
description: In visiting the world's cities, one becomes fairly attuned to the voice of a place, whether the sounds are heard in Leningrad or Fez, Kyoto or Rio. It didn't take long to hear that Prague was like an opera singer at rehearsal, singing merely at half-voice. And an alto at that.

title: DRAMATIC FOOD, DRAMATIC SETTING
description: IT was the lure of tapas that brought me to the Grand Cafe in Glen Cove. Those trendy Spanish appetizers had finally made it to Long Island. But tapas at the Grand Cafe included spanakopita, ratatouille, pasta salad and quiche -none Spanish, all lackluster. As a result, it was goodbye tapas and cavernous barroom, hello balcony dining room and sit-down dinner.

title: EVERY POLICE BULLET FIRED MUST PASS MANY LAYERS OF INQUIRY
description: A POLICE officer answers a call to a burglary in progress and spies a figure on a dark fire escape brandishing a gun. He calls ''Stop!'' but sees the weapon turned on him and fires. A 12-year-old boy is killed.

title: Dr. Carol Lee and Dr. Brian R. Apatoff Plan to Be Married in May Ceremony
description: Dr. Ben Bumsun Lee and Dr. Hyang Won Lee of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Carol Miyoung Lee, to Dr. Brian Richard Apatoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Apatoff of Chicago and Venice, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: Detectors That Talk to the Front Desk
description: RESEARCH on smoke detectors, as with most fire safety research, has focused on the issue of speeding up the warning time, giving guests a chance to get out and firefighters a chance to get in before dense smoke and toxic gases make approaching the fire hazardous or even impossible.

title: Doctors And the Humane Touch
description: We were disappointed and puzzled by Amy Wallace's article on medical education. Through an infuriating use of partial and out-of-context quotes, the article created the absurd impression that Johns Hopkins disdains the humanities and emphasizes only hard-line biomedical curriculums.

title: They Love a Parade
description: Regarding the question of whether or not the New Jersey Giants should receive a parade or not, I would like to say that I am not only amazed, but outraged that the Giants, their fans (in New York as well as New Jersey), or anybody else could suggest that the Giants are entitled to a ticker-tape parade down Broadway. The same Giants who deserted their loving fans almost 10 years ago. The same Giants who traveled from stadium to stadium, and city to city (from Yankee Stadium to Shea, then to Connecticut, and later finally to the Meadowlands), never giving a thought to their diehard followers, me among them. Have we forgotten so soon?

title: RESORTS PUTS BACK DATE OF 'TAJ MAHAL' OPENING
description: LEAD: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL, which had planned to open its second hotel-casino here - the Taj Mahal - in July, has moved the target date back to ''the late summer.''

title: Divided Verdict in Trooper's Death
description: It was clear that either Thomas W. Manning or Richard C. Williams, both of whom say violence is justified in shaping America to their vision, fired the shots that killed a New Jersey State Trooper, Philip J. Lamonaco, five years ago. During their two-month murder trial, Mr. Manning said he had done it, but prosecutors insisted that Mr. Williams had done it.

title: Easing an Ill of Gentrification
description: THE displacement of residents by the reclamation of inner-city property continues to give gentrification a bad name around the country. It has posed a policy quandary for social-welfare officials who must help the dislocated find new homes, and it has become an embarrassment for the developers and preservationists who make up the vanguard of the back-to-the-old-neighborhoods movement.

title: Doctors And the Humane Touch
description: It seems that once again the medical community has opted for the easy way out, by making a specific diagnosis and prescribing what it considers appropriate treatment.

title: HERETICS AND THE PRIESTHOOD
description: NOBEL DREAMS Power, Deceit, and the Ultimate Experiment. By Gary Taubes. 320 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: The Brookvilles
description: THE brooks that run through the Brookvilles cut across the wooded grounds of vast estates, skirt the well-kept fairways of the area's many golf courses and wind along tree-lined country roads. Years ago, these narrow waterways gave this Long Island community its name; today, they continue to add to its nonpareil beauty.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Austrian Pastry at Teatime
description: LEAD: ''Let's stop in at Zauner's and pick up a Gugelhupf and some Creme-schnitter for Jauza,'' said my Austrian hostess. I politely agreed, though at the time I hadn't the faintest idea what she was proposing. Not to keep you in suspense, a Jauza is the Austrian version of afternoon tea, but with coffee and pastries and, most likely, Schlagobers, of which more later.

title: MAMARONECK YARD PROUD OF ITS WINNER
description: WHEN the skipper announced he was coming to the boatyard in Mamaroneck to inspect his nearly completed 12-meter yacht, the boat builder had to act quickly. By the time Tom Blackaller, captain of the America's Cup contender, USA, arrived at the Robert E. Derecktor Yacht Building yard, the second boat was shrouded in curtains.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Looking Down, Up, Out Like a statue in a public park, the Jew in literature is exposed to the climate. In his latest novel, Philip Roth is a weatherman reading the signs, scanning the heavens. This is from ''The Counterlife'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).

title: CAPTIVES IN LEBANON: CITIZENS OF 8 NATIONS
description: A total of 19 foreign hostages were known to be held in Lebanon as of Friday, before the latest kidnappings. The number does not include two men who were reported to have been bundled into a car in Beirut on Friday but who have not been identified.

title: LYSA ANN GORDON TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by J. James Gordon of Greenwich, Conn., and Helen H. Gordon of Hartsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Lysa Ann Gordon to Joseph Walton, a research analyst at Colin A. Houston & Associates in Mamaroneck, N.Y. The bridegroom, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Latue Walton of Sunderland, England, graduated from the Imperial College of Science and Technology of the University of London. A June wedding is planned.

title: ROGUES' CONTINENT
description: THE FATAL SHORE By Robert Hughes. Illustrated. 688 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: CONCERT: APOLLO'S BANQUET
description: APOLLO'S BANQUET - an early-music ensemble consisting of Frederick Urrey, tenor; Peter Wolf, harpsichord; Sonya Monosoff, violin; Judith Davidoff, viola da gamba, and Stephen Berkelhammer, oboe and recorder - played a diverting program of chamber works by Bach and Telemann at the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night.

title: Alexia Larr Engaged To Richard W. Duker
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter Larr of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Alexia Aisha Larr to Richard Walker Duker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Duker Jr., also of Rye.

title: On Rereading 'Native Son'
description: I recently read ''Native Son,'' and I must say that any shortcomings in the writing style were not so apparent to me. Perhaps my not being a critic permitted me the freedom of approaching the book simply from the standpoint of its emotional impact. As far as I'm concerned, it did the job.

title: ZONING THE RESERVATION FOR ENTERPRISE
description: WITH its red rock canyons and cliffs, dirt roads, sagebrush, cactus, goats, sheep and rattlesnakes, the Navajo Indian Reservation hardly seems a likely place for a business renaissance. But that is what Peter MacDonald

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Shaw Island, Wash.; A Noisy Row Over a Retreat
description: AT less than eight square miles, Shaw Island is one of the smallest of the green-forested San Juan Islands in the far northwest corner of the lower 48 states. With 125 year-round residents, it is also one of the most tranquil.

title: Business Cycle
description: To the Editor: Peter Kilborn's characterization of the business cycle (''The Business Cycle Rolls Over and Plays Dead,'' Jan. 11) as ''a perpetual motion machine that propelled the nation through booms and busts'' disregards a large and important area of economic research. Pioneering work done by Milton Friedman and Anna J. Schwartz on the behavior of the economies of the United States and Britain over the past century shows that a consistent explanation of business cycle behavior is the prior behavior of the money stock.

title: AIRPORTS GET GRANTS
description: LEAD: NINE local and regional airports in New Jersey have been awarded state and Federal grants for airport and air-safety improvement.

title: A NIGHT IN A SHELTER: PESSIMISM AND HOPE
description: ''SOMEBODY tell me one good thing that happened today,'' one man said to 15 others sitting in a circle.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: The Giants will win the Super Bowl because the Mets won the World Series.

title: Equality in Ads
description: To the Editor: ''A Grueling Struggle for Equality'' (Nov. 9) did not have to make use of 1961 classified ads to illustrate the 1960 survey statement, ''Whatever their work skills, less attractive women were rejected - even in the classified ads.'' A review of the classifieds in the Nov. 9, 1986, edition of The New York Times showed that:

title: WHERE BIRDS NOT OF A FEATHER STILL FLOCK TOGETHER
description: THE wood ducks and mallards that live here year-round come out to feed more often now on the food left for them. The Canada geese have settled in for the winter. And not too long ago an unannounced guest, a peregrine falcon, swooped through for a visit.

title:
ART;
A SHOW WITH A BROAD RANGE OF PHOTOGRAPHY STYLES
description: LEAD: THIS year's juried photography exhibition at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's gallery at Mills Pond House in St. James attracted 90 entries, of which 52 were selected by Harvey Weber, Newsday's former director of photography.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: REAGAN TALK TO STRESS HIS DOMESTIC INITIATIVES
description: As President Reagan heads into the final two years of his term, he will try to re-invigorate his lagging Administration on Tuesday with a State of the Union Message that attempts to shift public attention away from the Iran arms scandal by announcing new initiatives in jobs, education and economic growth.

title: Slow Motion on Solar Planning
description: IN the six years since its passage, fewer than a third of the towns in Connecticut have complied with a state law requiring local subdivision ordinances to consider the passive solar potential of developments.

title: Let's Be Philosophical
description: I HAVE DECIDED TO read philosophy. I had always meant to, but kept putting it off. You know how it is: You mark Saturday night on the calendar and say, ''That's when I start reading Wittgenstein,'' then you wander into the video rental shop on Saturday afternoon and next thing you know you're walking out with ''Rose Marie,'' starring Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald.

title: WENDELL W. SCHAUS ENGAGED TO ROBERT O. BROWN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendell Walton Schaus to Robert Otis Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Brown of Providence, R.I.

title: M. D. Rhea Wed To Ms. Damerell
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Diane Edna Damerell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald G. Damerell of Bronxville, N.Y., was married to Michael D. Rhea, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. J. Rhea of Hinsdale, Ill. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony.

title: FURNITURE FINISHES THAT AREN'T JUST PAINT
description: DOROTHY DIAMOND'S studio in New Canaan has no easels, no brushes and no wet paint. Yet The Studio, as her year-old shop is aptly called, is home to the ''painted finish'' look that is increasingly popular in decor.

title: SUCCULENTS WILL THRIVE WHEN GIVEN MINIMAL CARE
description: LEAD: The mother-daughter team of Laura and Judy Becker barely notice the winter storm raging outside their snug greenhouses. The two self-confessed ''plantaholics'' are so busy raising and tending hundreds of varieties of plants in their family business in northwestern Connecticut that cold gray weather can sometimes slip by unnoticed.

title: HOW RADIATORS WORK, AND WHY THEY SOMETIMES DON'T
description: HOMES heated by steam or circulating hot water have radiators. For maximum economy and efficiency it is essential that the homeowner make certain that the radiators are operating properly.

title: SCANDAL IMPERILS MULRONEY'S HOLD
description: In the House of Commons this week, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, half-moon spectacles perched on his nose, spent several hours fending off attacks by opposition members aroused by a sense that his 28-month-old administration has suffered an irrecoverable blow.

title: OFFICIALS RAISE QUIERIES ON HIGH POLICE INCOMES
description: TO most police officers, the midnight tour of duty is by far the most undesirable.

title: Taylor Honored
description: NO matter how well he does in the Super Bowl today, Lawrence Taylor has strengthened his credentials as the top player of the 1986 National Football League. Besides many other honors, he has won the 1986-87 Gillette Most Valuable Player Award.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE idea of a Clean Ocean Authority, unveiled by Governor Kean in his State of the State Message, is more a topic of discussion than a specific legislative proposal.

title: OFFICERS INTERROGATE AMERICANS VISITING RESIDENTS IN ODESSA
description: American tourists visiting Soviet homes in Odessa have been questioned three times in the last three weeks by the police, Western diplomats said this week.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN ADDITION TO PORT CHESTER
description: LEAD: IN a residential neighborhood of Port Chester, almost on the Connecticut-New York line, beautifully renovated Pastore's makes a classy and comfortable place to have a meal. This Italian newcomer has already shown itself capable of producing some exceptionally fine dishes at prices that might be considered reasonable.

title: Television
description: Some newer movie entries and less frequently shown vintage fare stand out this week on cable and broadcast TV. Janet Maslin of The Times wrote that Jessica Lange's portrayal of country singer Patsy Cline hoisted ''Sweet Dreams'' (1985) -Cinemax on Sunday at 9 P.M., Tuesday at 4:30 P.M. and Saturday at 5 P.M. Vincent Canby lauded ''Smash Palace'' (1981), an unheralded surprise from New Zealand, as a piercing study of a shattered marriage -Tuesday at noon over USA. ''Bright Victory'' (1952) is a quiet drama about a blind veteran of World War II; the New York Film Critics voted Arthur Kennedy the year's best actor - Monday at 10:05 A.M. on WTBS. There's a hypnotic British thriller called ''Captain Kronos: Vampire Hunter'' (1974) - Saturday at 2 P.M. over USA.

title: Mary Hotchkiss to Wed E. A. Harvey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Winchester F. Hotchkiss of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Stuart Stevens Hotchkiss to Edward Ashton Harvey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashton Harvey of Skillman, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 6.

title: Finding's Losings
description: GERUNDS EVERYWHERE are proud that one of their clan has made it big in Washington: a finding, capitalized when used by the National Security Council staff, is the noun that enables a President secretly to suspend a law. (A gerund, called by stiffs a ''verbal substantive,'' is a term in grammar that is forgotten as soon as it is learned. It means ''a noun that is formed from a verb and ends in -ing''; in the sentence Ducking a question is easy, the gerund is ducking. In addition, when you hold a witness's head under water, you are giving him a good gerundy ducking; however, when the same word is used as an adjective, it is not a gerund but a participle: ''the bobbing, weaving, ducking adviser took the Fifth.'' Hold your breath; count to three; you have now forgotten what a gerund is.) ''I hereby find that the following operation . . . is important,'' goes the once-secret document signed by President Reagan back on Jan. 17, 1986, ''. . . and direct the Director of Central Intelligence to refrain from reporting this Finding to the Congress. . . .'' In that sentence, finding is a gerund (a wha'?), and that noun is dear to executives because it has since 1859 had a judicial connotation: ''The result of a judicial examination or inquiry; the verdict of a jury, the decision of a judge or arbitrator.'' In this case, the National Security Act of 1947 lets the President act as judge of when to obey a law.

title: Photography
description: A half century ago, modern war photography cut its teeth on the Spanish Civil War. Earlier photographers had captured the devastation and human toll of warfare, to be sure, but the combat between the Republicans and Franco's Nationalists was the first in which photographers joined the fray, showing the battlefields and combatants while bullets were flying. Emblematic of the new war photography is Robert Capa's famous (and recently controversial) photograph of a soldier falling in battle, purportedly at the moment he was fatally struck by enemy fire.

title: 'SQUARE ONE' FACTORS IN TV AS A PLUS
description: Anyone wondering what happens when music video meets number theory will get a first glimmering of an answer tomorrow in the opening minutes of ''Square One,'' public television's most ambitious attempt at educating younger viewers since ''Sesame Street'' began 18 years ago.

title: Suicide on Camera
description: ''By the time you receive this letter,'' R. Budd Dwyer wrote, ''the office of State Treasurer of Pennsylvania will be vacant. I stress to you that I did not resign but was State Treasurer of Pennsylvania to the end.''

title: DEVILS' VICTORY MARRED BY BRAWLS
description: In a game marred by brawling on the ice and in the stands, the Devils regained some respectability in the Patrick Division tonight with a 4-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: I am a firm believer in the saying that good things happen for those who wait. Well, I've waited for 23 years. I know it's time. The only question that should be asked is how many points will those Giants win by? JOHN FERREIRA Elmhurst

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE JOHNSTOWN FLOOD, by David McCullough. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) On the afternoon of May 31, 1889, an earthen dam burst in the mountains above Johnstown, Pa., and in the resulting flood the booming coal-and-steel town was devastated and more than 2,000 people died. David McCullough's re-creation of the catastrophe, its causes and its aftermath is ''a superb job, scholarly yet vivid, balanced yet incisive,'' Alden Whitman said in The Times in 1968. MR. NOON, by D. H. Lawrence. Edited by Lindeth Vasey. (Penguin, $7.95.) This novel's first section, originally published in 1934, is the story of an English schoolteacher named Gilbert Noon, a specialist in ''spooning'' who loses his job and is nearly forced into marriage when he gets a young woman pregnant.

title: SPURS HAND KNICKS A DEPRESSING LOSS
description: The swelling euphoria spawned by unexpected victories and steady improvement is gone. Patrick Ewing is tired, Bill Cartwright is slumping, Coach Bob Hill's fuse is short and the Knicks are losing once again.

title: Smoke Out
description: To the Editor: Scott Edward Stapf's reference to a nonsmoker's nicotine-equivalent exposure and to other red herrings is an exercise that contributes nothing to the social debate on passive smoking (''A Propaganda War Against Cigarettes,'' Forum, Jan. 4).

title: THE ASTRONAUTS AFTER CHALLENGER
description: BEFORE THE unthinkable happened on that bitterly cold January day in Florida, they were the elite's elite, operating in that strange, unforgiving stratosphere where only several hundred humans have ever been. They were trained to set aside their feelings, groomed to spout clipped, noncommittal responses in public. With space flight becoming virtually routine, they came to be seen as near-flawless human robots - those ''genetically perfect Texans,'' as a British commentator once put it.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
AMERICAN HOUSE SPIDER
description: LEAD: Achaearanea tepidariorum Size: Female, one-quarter inch; male, one-eighth to one-quarter inch.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT BIG SWINGS INS TOCK MARKET TO CONTINUE
description: The wild gyrations in Friday's stock market, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring first by 64 points, then plunging by 114 points and ending the day with a 44.15-point decline, have stunned the financial markets. And although few analysts said yesterday that they understood what happened or what it would mean for the nation's economy or the markets, they are predicting the wild swings will continue.

title: Words About Minimalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Cigarettes Or Your Job, Workers Are Told
description: Voicing a concern for its employees' health that went mostly unappreciated, a Chicago company announced last week that it would ban smoking - on the job and at home, too - conduct lung tests to make sure workers comply and dismiss those who do not.

title: Mayor Goode's Father Dies
description: Albert Goode, the grandson of a North Carolina slave who was the father of Philadelphia's first black Mayor, W. Wilson Goode, died Thursday of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 83 years old.

title: Gift of Life in China
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS WARNELL PLANS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Warnell of Lincoln, Del., have announced the engagement of his daughter RuthAnn Warnell to David Livingstone Kerr 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kerr of Essex Fells and Bay Head, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Stewart Family Lawyer Hails Counsel's Report
description: The attorney for Michael Stewart's family said yesterday he was pleased with a new report that indicated transit officers used excessive restraint in the 1983 arrest of Mr. Stewart, who lapsed into a coma and subsequently died.

title: Five Important Matchups to Watch
description: Once, matchups for Super Bowl games were obvious. The left tackle on offense always played against the right end on defense and this man played against that man, and the team that won most of those man-against-man battles generally won the game.

title: Alfred Thimm Jr. Engaged To Marry Andrea L. Bozzi
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Bozzi of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Longboat Key, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Louise Bozzi, to Alfred L. Thimm Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thimm of Burlington, Vt.

title: COMMUTER PARKING GROWS MORE SCARCE
description: LEAD: WHEN yearly parking permits for the Goldens Bridge railroad station went on sale last week at a school in Lewisboro, a handful of commuters began lining up in their cars the night before. Maria Buncick, a South Salem resident who commutes to New York, got there first at 8:30 P.M.

title: Yankees, Inc.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: A MODERN DAY YANKEE IN A CONNECTICUT COURT: And Other Essays on Science. By Alan Lightman. (Viking, $14.95.) The physicist Alan Lightman belongs to a profession that has shaken and humbled us through the centuries - knocking our earth from the center of the solar system, our solar system from the center of its galaxy and convincing us that we are unlikely to be the only intelligent life around.

title: Put a Permanent Lid on Payroll Taxes
description: MAJOR increases in Social Security payroll tax rates, scheduled for 1988 and 1990, will boost the total employer-employee tax rate to an astonishing 15.3 per cent. Besides imposing an untenable and unfair economic burden on American workers - particularly those with lower incomes - these increases will undermine America's competitiveness and destroy jobs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 25, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Telltale Holdup Note Leads to Quick Arrest
description: A man who wrote a holdup message on the back of his probation-parole card and then left it behind was arrested as he prepared to board a bus next to the police station, officials said Friday.

title: 9 FROM NBC PROVIDE AID TO NEEDIEST
description: Nine employees of NBC Enterprises at 30 Rockefeller Plaza gave $155 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''We are delighted to do what we can,'' said a note sent with their gift.

title: Who Created the Drug Trafficking Monster?
description: THE television series ''Miami Vice'' might appropriately symbolize the conflicting views of Americans and Colombians about narcotics traffic.

title: BUCKING PREDICTIONS, NUMBER OF PUPILS IS SURGING
description: THE playground at the Timothy Dwight School in Fairfield was filled one recent morning with children running around a large yellow metal object that looked at if it had just landed from space.

title:
GARDENING;
SLOWING THE SPREAD OF ELM DISEASE
description: LEAD: THE accidental introduction of Dutch elm disease to the United States on veneer logs from Holland some 60 years ago proved to be devastating to our native American elm. This grandest of all shade trees once provided shade for houses, created arch canopies over city boulevards and small-town streets and made parks pleasant places to while away hot summer afternoons.

title: PROVIDING A HOME AWAY FROM MOTEL
description: LEAD: PUZZLES, building blocks and paint sets are de rigueur at the St. Bernard's Center for Learning in White Plains, just as they are at most day-care and nursery-school programs in the county.

title: FLATTEN YOUR KARMA IN 30 DAYS
description: THIS MAGIC MOMENT A Love Story for People Who Want the World to Make Sense. By Gregg Easterbrook. 327 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/St. Martin's Press. $17.95.

title: SUNGLASSES MADE TO BE SEEN
description: Sunglasses aren't just for summer anymore. Nor are they always functional, as these eye-accessory eyefuls prove.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CELLIST AND PIANIST Fred Sherry, cellist, and Bernice Silk, pianist, will play a recital next Sunday for the New Jersey Chamber Music Society at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE official opening on Feb. 2 of The Armory, a nautical museum and restaurant on Raritan Bay in Perth Amboy, marks a step forward in the planned development of waterfront projects that begin at the mouth of the Raritan River and extend west along the river to New Brunswick.

title: Collaboration Is Still What Holds Pilobolus Together
description: ''Pilobolus's original uniqueness still exists, and what worked 16 years ago still works,'' Jonathan Wolken, one of the founders of Pilobolus Dance Theater, said recently. When the company opens a monthlong engagement on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, several of its earlier works will be revived and will reveal just how effectively the group has managed to retain this uniqueness. The program will also include four local premieres, choreographed and collaborated on by the troupe's original five artistic directors - Robby Barnett, Alison Chase, Moses Pendleton, Michael Tracy and Mr. Wolken (all met in the modern-dance class that Ms. Chase taught at Dartmouth College).

title: 2 Are Killed as Fire Sweeps Riverdale Apartment House
description: Two people were killed and another person was injured when a two-alarm fire swept through two ninth-floor apartments in a 23-story building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx last night. Several firefighters and two police officers were injured fighting the blaze.

title: RESERVE IS SPARK AS VILLANOVA WINS
description: A Villanova sophomore, Gary Massey, came off the bench to score a career-high 21 points tonight and lead the Wildcats to an 86-82 Big East Conference triumph over Seton Hall.

title: Diane Van Arsdale Weds
description: Diane Frances Van Arsdale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson J. Van Arsdale of Westbury, L.I., and Steven Neal Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Miller of Bellerose, Queens, were married yesterday at the Baptist Church-in-the-Garden in Garden City, L.I. . The Rev. Patrick Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Hofstra University, is a real-estate evaluator and consultant for John P. O'Rourke Associates in Garden City. Mr. Miller is a photographer.

title: PRAGUE QUARTET TO PLAY
description: LEAD: THE Prague String Quartet, which celebrated its 30th anniversary last year, will perform works by Beethoven and Shostakovich Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church, 1 East Passaic Avenue.

title: Education Dept. Loan Program Isn't Student Aid, but Bank Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE MAKE PUBLIC SKETCH OF MAN SEEN NEAR OFFICER SLAYING
description: Investigators hunting the killer of an off-duty police officer in the Bronx released a sketch and a description yesterday of a young man they said had been seen near the scene of the murder. They declined to call the man a suspect or a witness, but said he was wanted for questioning.

title: SIMMS'S ROUGH RIDE TO PASADENA
description: NOT long before the most significant game of his eight seasons with the Giants, during a week when quarterbacks of Super Bowl teams have been known to produce enough news to fill a forest worth of newsprint, Phil Simms inadvertently capsulized the rise of himself and his team without a word.

title:
WINE;
A SHIFT TO THE OFF-DRY AND SWEETER IS SEEN
description: LEAD: AFTER more than a decade of consumer preference for bone-dry white wines, a number of area restaurateurs and managers of local retail outlets report an increase in the sales of fruity, off-dry and sweet products. At the forefront of this trend are the pale roses, also known as blush wines, and two new market entries from Villa Banfi, the importers of Riunite.

title: A Cuomo Budget For Good Times
description: Governor Cuomo, portraying a state in a happy condition, proposed a budget last week that would increase spending and reduce tax rates. But Democrats and Republicans alike complained, insisting that greater prosperity called for greater tax cuts.

title: Stephanie Golan Plans Marriage to Alan Dean
description: Stephanie Golan, who sells institutional bonds for the Quadrex Securities Corporation in New York, and Alan Dean, a partner in the New York law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, plan to be married April 10. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Golan of Columbus, Ohio, who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernie P. Dean of Elmhurst, Queens.

title: RIGHTS CEDED FOR SOCIETY'S GOOD
description: INVOKING what one conceives to be his Constitutional rights has become a very popular activity. The tobacco companies do it when they feel that Congress might curtail their advertising, motorcyclists do it when they oppose helmet laws, some individuals do it whenever they don't like something, and now, a Connecticut group is doing it in attempt to see that the mandatory seat-belt law is repealed.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE MECHANIC MUSE. By Hugh Kenner. (Oxford, $13.95.) The author argues wittily, if unsurprisingly, that the literary modernists - Eliot, Pound, Joyce and Beckett - were modern. The muse of the title is modern technology, particularly modern machines. For Mr. Kenner, T. S. Eliot is the ''poet of the alarm clock,'' and ''The Waste Land'' is a ''telephone poem.

title: ALCOHOLISM TREATMENT PROGRAM HAILED FOR ITS RECOVERY RATE
description: STATE alcoholism officials and others who have referred troubled alcoholics and their families to the Gabrielsen Group, a private team of state-certified counselors here, say that the group's clients get better sooner and seem to maintain their sobriety.

title: WHITE PLAINS OPENS NEW TRAIN STATION TOMORROW
description: A THREE-YEAR nightmare for White Plains railroad commuters - climbing temporary wooden stairs to stand on narrow, windswept platforms - should end tomorrow morning with the opening of the city's new $2.57 million train station.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: A LANDMARK FALLS, BUT HOPES ARISE
description: LEAD: A WAVE of shock, dismay and remorse for neglected heritage went through Southold Oct. 29 when a landmark house dating to the mid-1600's disappeared in one day. But Christmas week brought at least partial redemption, thanks to the efforts of a group of public-spirited citizens, a Santa Claus in the form of an 81-year-old hooked-rug maker, a bank president and a real-estate developer with a sense of community responsibility.

title: DELEGATION IN ALBANY OUTLINES PRIORITIES
description: WESTCHESTER'S representatives in the State Legislature say that major priorities for the county this year would be creating affordable housing, providing permanent shelter for the homeless, acquiring funds for education and adequate solid-waste disposal, and cutting state taxes.

title: HOW ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS WORKS
description: EACH week in New Jersey, there are 1,500 meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous, a self-help fellowship established by alcoholics in 1935. It offers a 12-step program of treatment.

title: Recent Releases Og Video Cassettes
description: SMILES OF A SUMMER NIGHT Featuring Eva Dahlbeck, Ulla Jacobsson, Harriet Andersson, Gunnar Bjornstrand, Bjorn Bjelvenstam. Written and directed by Ingmar Bergman. In Swedish with English subtitles. 1955. Embassy Home Entertainment. 108 minutes. $29.95.

title: Q and A
description: Alpine Spring Question: I will be in France late in March and would like to know if the ski season typically extends into the first week of spring. Are there weeks in which resorts are likely to be overcrowded? - B. F., San Antonio Answer: Assuming average snowfall - and there has been a lot of snow already - the ski season in the French Alps will be in full swing at the end of March. The season generally extends well into April. Many of the hotels in ski resorts close after the Easter holidays, unless Easter falls early. Easter Sunday this year is April 19 and in France the Easter school vacation is from April 11 until May 4. The two weeks around Easter are generally the season's busiest. But even when the season has officially ended, good skiing can usually be had through mid-May at such resorts as Courchevel, Chamonix and Val d'Isere. In July and August, at Tignes, skiers make for the Glacier de la Grande Motte, which has snow the year round, and at La Plagne, farther south, there's skiing in summer on the Glacier de Bellecote. Wright House Question: I would like infomation on how to get to Frank Lloyd Wright's house in the Appalachian Mountains. - G. G., Philapdelphia Answer: The house Wright designed in the Appalachians is Fallingwater (Mill Run, Pa. 15464; 412-329-8501).
