Mill Run, east of Uniontown in the western part of the state, is about 45 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. The best way to reach it is from the Donegal exit of the Pennsylvania Turnpike; it's a 25-minute drive from there. The house is four miles south of Mill Run on State Route 381.

title:
ART;
THE ZIMMERLI'S NEW LESSON IN THE HISTORY OF PRINTMAKING
description: LEAD: STRANGE as it may seem, a couple of conflicts in the Far East almost a century ago were the catalysts for some spectacular advances in printmaking.

title: Bandwagons, Ho!
description: Nothing new is neglected these days. As soon as someone constructs a successful plan, everyone jumps to try it out.

title: Carol Buttenwieser Engaged
description: The engagement of Carol Helen Buttenwieser and John R. Sharp has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser of New York and North Salem, N.Y. Mr. Sharp is the son of Helen L. Sharp of Brookline, Mass., and Richard H. Rubin of Newton, Mass.

title: FEARS ON MENTAL CENTER PROPOSAL
description: NESTLED among affluent homes in the Dix Hills-Melville area are 500 acres of seemingly untouched, rolling woodlands.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HUMAN RIGHTS
description: LEAD: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights recently selected three books to be distributed to United Nations information centers worldwide. Dr. Peter Schwab, professor of political science at the State University of New York at Purchase since 1971 and a specialist in human rights, is the co-editor of one of the selected books, ''Human Rights, Cultural and Ideological Perspectives.

title: Gino Quilico as the Don At Philadelphia Opera
description: The Canadian-American baritone Gino Quilico will sing the title role in Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' with the Opera Company of Philadelphia tomorrow and Friday nights at the Academy of Music (Locust and Broad Streets). It will be the first American performance of the role for the 31-year-old singer, whose father is the baritone Louis Quilico.

title: HONORA BLISS AWAITS THE WRECKING CREW
description: THE PART OF FORTUNE By Laurel Goldman. 249 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: THEY'RE MINDING THE ARSENAL
description: REAGAN AND GORBACHEV By Michael Mandelbaum and Strobe Talbott. 190 pp. New York: A Council on Foreign Relations Book. Vintage Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: I LOVE THE GRAY, DEPRESSING (ACHOO) L.I. WINTERS
description: I KNOW that winter is probably not your favorite season. Once the holidays are past, all you have to look forward to is a succession of cold, gray days, slush-spattered windshields and heating bills that make your temperature rise, literally and figuratively.

title: NEW YORK TO CLOSE UNITS FOR DISABLED
description: The state will close two developmental centers for the mentally and physicially handicapped in New York City in the next few years as part of its effort to move the disabled out of large institutions.

title: NEWS THAT PARENTS DREAD
description: LEAD: MOTHER, I HAVE SOMETHING TO TELL YOU By Jo Brans. Research by Margaret Taylor Smith. 322 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: HAVERFORD PHOTO SHOW

title: A Pianist's Memorabilia
description: Steinway and Sons, 109 West 57th Street, is currently exhibiting a display of memorabilia pertaining to the life and work of the American pianist William Kapell, who lived from 1922 to 1953. Many of the same items are shown that were displayed at the International Piano Library in College Park, Md., last summer, including a wide variety of photographs (both personal and professional), letters from Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland, press notices, recording documentation, diaries and other effects. The exhibition is open to the public and will be on display through Saturday. Information: 246-1100.

title: SOVIET SEEKS RISE IN FARMS' OUTPUT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has rebuked farm officials for failing to reverse chronic agricultural problems, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 25, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. title: NATURAL SNOW OR NOT, SKIING IS POSSIBLE WITHIN THE STATE
description: LEAD: THANKS to snow machines, New Jersey skiers do not have to venture outside the state in pursuit of their favorite sport.

title: COMPROMISE SEEN IN U.S.-EUROPE TRADE FIGHT
description: The United States and the European Community appeared to be edging toward a compromise today in a conflict over feed-grain sales to Spain that has threatened to develop into an Atlantic trade war.

title: Headliners; A Critic Unleashed
description: The way things are going, Milovan Djilas may yet get to write a book that does not land him in jail. Considered the most prominent Yugoslavian dissident, Mr. Djilas fell into official disgrace in 1953 and has pretty much stayed there.

title: EX-FRAT MEN RECALL '47 DELAWARE CROSSING
description: LEAD: In an article on Dec. 21 about the annual re-enactment of George Washington's crossing of the Delaware during the American Revolution, it was reported that the first re-enactment took place in 1953. The article prompted letters from two men whose fraternity re-enacted the crossing six years before that, in 1947.

title: WILL INSTANT REPLAY TRIP THE REF?
description: WEEKS BEFORE this afternoon's kickoff of Super Bowl XXI, Tex Schramm, the president and general manager of the Dallas Cowboys, sat in his office in Irving, Tex., and worried. As chairman of the National Football League's Competition Committee, a group charged with refining the rules of the game to accommodate its changing nature, Schramm was envisioning a crisis during today's showcase event:

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE STRATEGIES OF ZEUS. By Gary Hart. (Morrow, $18.95.) Somehow, during his last term as a United States Senator from Colorado, Gary Hart found time to run for the Presidency and write a 360-page novel about the arms race. In Mr. Hart's second work of fiction (the first was co-written with Senator William S.

title: HARP: NICANOR ZABALETA
description: NICANOR ZABALETA resolves the enigmas of the harp as few others do, which may explain why almost half a houseful of listeners fought their way through Thursday's snowstorm to hear the 80-year old Spaniard play at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Disallowed in England
description: To the Editor:

title: W.H.O. INCREASING ANTI-SMOKING FUND
description: The World Health Organization, citing a sharp increase in smoking in the third world, has increased its budget for anti-smoking activities for the first time, an agency official said today.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHAT'S IN A NAME? TAKE THE NEW YORK GIANTS (AND JETS)
description: LEAD: AN ARTICLE in Newsweek magazine not too long ago offered some sadly amusing evidence thatbooks aren't the only things Johnny can't read these days.

title: 'Who Wickedly Is Wise, or Madly Brave'
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Strategy
description: 'I have been underestimated for decades. I've done very well that way.' - Helmut Kohl West German Chancellor, discussing today's national election, which the coalition he leads is favored to win.

title: The Yankee Way
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: It is not just a question of who makes it to the Super Bowl but rather how are the teams performing immediately before and during the playoffs.

title: 2 CHURCHES AGREE ON SALVATION ISSUE
description: A joint Anglican-Roman Catholic group says it has resolved one of the major doctrinal disputes that gave rise to the Protestant Reformation.

title: BILL SEEKS TO CURB POLLUTION OF BEACHES
description: LEAD: THE memory of New Jersey beach closings in the last two summers because of pollution is still fresh in the minds of lawmakers and state officials, who want to find the sources of the problem in time to keep it from happening again this year.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Emerson Quartet Turns to Romantics
description: LEAD: Although at the planning stage they toyed with the idea of calling themselves the Boss Tweed Quartet or the Nixon, it was the name of Ralph Waldo Emerson they chose to crystallize their thoroughly American identity, and in the decade since they initially appeared on the concert circuit the Emerson Quartet has proved itself in the first rank of string quartets in America as well as abroad.

title: POLL FINDS PREFERENCE FOR GIANTS
description: More Americans want the Giants to win the Super Bowl than prefer the Denver Broncos, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. But even more say they don't care or don't know who they want to win.

title: FROM ELIZABETHAN TO PRESENT, CONCERTS COVER THE SPECTRUM
description: MUSIC dating from the Middle Ages to music composed just last year will be heard in the state in the next two weeks.

title: New Orleans Put On the 1988 Map
description: In a Presidential campaign's early going, much of the news involves those hardy quadrennials of Des Moines, Manchester, Concord. The earliest voting is in Iowa and New Hampshire, and the Presidential hopefuls slog into their snows at least a year ahead of time.

title: Grading The State Of the Economy
description: WITH President Reagan gearing up to give his State of the Union Address this Tuesday, it seemed an appropriate time to discuss with some of the nation's most prominent private economists their assessment of the state of the union's economy. Judging from the results of this somewhat informal report card, the United States economy at the start of 1987 would not make anyone's honor roll.

title: Miss Evans to Marry Francis X. Queally Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Errol Kemp Reece of Greensboro, N.C., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Elder Evans, to Francis Xavier Queally Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Queally of Greenwich, Conn., and Jupiter, Fla. The wedding is planned for April 11. Miss Evans, an account executive at Liz Claiborne in New York, is the daughter of the late William James Evans, who was an engineer at the Western Electric Company in Burlington, N.C. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The future bride was presented at the 1981 North Carolina State Debutante Ball in Raleigh and is a provisional member of the Junior League of New York. Her mother, Janie Crumpton Reece, is an assistant professor of mathematics at Elon College. Her stepfather is a vice president of the Interstate Securities Corporation in Greensboro.

title: INSIDE
description: Early Clues to 1988 A New York Times/CBS News Poll finds Gary Hart and George Bush early leaders among their parties'

title: New York's Programs at Work at 'Allerton Coops'
description: ''IT was the biggest family I ever belonged to.'' ''It was a village.'' ''It was a complete community; we had everything a working family could need or want.''

title: Frances Barnard Weds Frank Fowlkes
description: The marriage of Frances Roderick Barnard, an artist, and Frank Vaughan Fowlkes, an editorial consultant and author, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church in Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Randolph C. Miller, the stepfather of the bridegroom, and the Rev. Stephen R. Davenport 3d.

title: A May Wedding For Miss Murphy
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Murphy of Buffalo of the engagement of their daughter Anne Marie Murphy to Robert Lewis Banner Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Banner of Richmond. A May wedding is planned. Miss Murphy, an export specialist for the International Trade Administration in Washington, graduated from Georgetown University. Her father is a urologic oncologist and a professor of urology at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: POLL GIVES HART AND BUSH CLEAR LEADS FOR NOMINATIONS
description: Former Senator Gary Hart is the clear early leader among Democrats in the race for the party's Presidential nomination, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But the survey also found that Governor Cuomo, who has not yet said if he will run, could pose a serious challenge.

title: 'THE ONLY TRUE TIGHT END'
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' tight end, has many admirers. One of them is Mike Ditka.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: MANSON IN HIS OWN WORDS. As told to Nuel Emmons. (Grove Press, $16.95.) This autobiographical account of the convicted murderer Charles Manson was extracted from interviews begun in 1979 by Nuel Emmons, a photojournalist. The news media often have tried to fathom Mr. Manson's character and the strange power he held over his ''family,'' a group made up mostly of attractive young women.

title: PROSPECTS
description: High-Tech Turmoil

title: BALTIMORE MAYOR ASCENDS TO STATE
description: Only days after taking office, Gov. William Donald Schaefer, the autocratic former Mayor of Baltimore, is already being called ''the Mayor of Maryland.''

title: ANNOUNCER FINDS HIS NICHE
description: WELL, it's Super Bowl Sunday, and when it ends, so, for all practical purposes, does the National Football League season. And what happens then to Bob Costas, the product of Hicksville and Commack who has spent the season presiding over ''NFL '86,'' the NBC pregame and halftime television show? After today, when he will be in Pasadena doing his show on NBC Radio - CBS has the television rights for this year's Super Bowl - will someone swathe the 34-year-old Mr. Costas in mothproof insulation and store him until it's time for ''NFL '87''? Hardly. In broadcasting, Mr. Costas is a hot property, and when the Giants and Broncos have finished Super Bowl XXI, he will still be on the go. He has a new syndicated radio show, ''Costas Coast to Coast,'' a two-hour Sunday night interview and conversation program that began in November and, he said, is carried by more than 150 stations around the country. Next Friday he'll fly down to Raleigh, N.C., and on Saturday he'll be handling the telecast of the Oklahoma-North Carolina State basketball game, a prelude to several more he'll cover for NBC during February.

title: REMAKING THE AMERICAN C.E.O.
description: THE turmoil in corporate America is forcing the nation's business leaders to undertake the most radical reassessment of their practices and beliefs since the end of World War II. But out of this soul-searching, a new set of management precepts is emerging, with profound impact on individual companies and the country as a whole.

title: EX-APPLE VENDOR WILLS $8 MILLION TO U.S.
description: A man who was penniless when he left Imperial Russia but died rich in the United States has left the bulk of his $8 million estate to the Federal Government, a bequest being contested by his stepchildren.

title: COUNTRY CLUB WORKERS ARE LUCKY TWICE
description: THE chief of the State Lottery, J. Blaine Lewis Jr., says he might as well become a member of the Shuttle Meadow Country Club in Berlin, since he has come to know so many of its employees.

title: LEARNING: SOONER IS BETTER
description: A BETTER START New Choices for Early Learning. Edited by Fred M. Hechinger. 172 pp. New York: Walker & Company. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: MEETING THE COMPOSER Whenever Irwin Swack, the composer from Bellmore, makes a ''Meet the Composer'' appearance - and he will this afternoon during the latest L'Amore di Musica chamber music concert in Garden City - invariably he's asked why he has ''written that particular piece,'' he said. ''Then they ask how.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 16 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 16 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Francine Newton To Be Wed May 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philippe W. Newton of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Francine Newton, to Robert Jacobs Shanfield, a son of Mrs. Frederick T. Shanfield of Natick, Mass., and the late Mr. Shanfield.

title: Dance
description: Yoshiko Chuma calls her company the School of Hard Knocks advisedly. It is often hard to believe that any of the dancers will survive an evening of her dance, so fast-paced and physically demanding is it. But exhilaration is in store for Ms. Chuma's audiences, for this is dance of an infectious physicality. In ''The Big Picture,'' for instance, Ms. Chuma uses fast-paced, aggressive rock music and paintings and drawings of windows on a world seen from the upper air to focus on flight as a metaphor for modern society. She isn't talking about swan dives, either, but about such things as airplanes and airports.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WINTER-SURVIVAL TACTICS An ice-fishing and winter-survival clinic that is, from 1 to 5 P.M. today at the Bolton Lake Boat Launch, deals with such topics as down clothing not offering as much protection from Connecticut winters as many people might think.

title: GROUP PROPOSES 3 PROGRAMS TO MEET INCREASE IN THE HOMELESS
description: Saying that increased private efforts are needed to arrest the growth of homelessness in New York City, a leading advocacy group yesterday proposed a series of programs to give real-estate developers a major role in building apartments for the homeless.

title: CABARET: OBBA BABATUNDE
description: OBBA BABATUNDE, the actor-singer-dancer-choreographer who originated the role of C. C. White in ''Dreamgirls'' and subsequently took over the lead role from Ben Vereen in the ill-fated musical ''Grind,'' is a graceful dancer with a mellow pop baritone, a pleasant personality and the good looks of a contemporary matinee idol. But he is not a human firecracker like Sammy Davis Jr., whom he impersonated briefly in his glitzy one-man show at the Latin Quarter on Wednesday night.

title: Music
description: ''Music Is An Open Sky,'' the annual mini-festival of new jazz at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South at Bleecker Street, begins its second week Sunday night with an appearance by the pianist Roger Kellaway, performing a new composition, ''Suite for Jerusalem,'' with strings. The keyboardist-arranger Gil Evans and his jazz-rock orchestra continue their longtime residency on Monday, but Tuesday brings the aggressive young trumpeter Frank Gordon and a promising quintet, including Bobby Watson on alto saxophone, James Williams on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Ralph Peterson on drums - a lineup that looks likely to play some vigorous hard-bop.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: Who will win the Super Bowl? Easy, Denver. Why? Easier. John Elway. LARRY COHEN New York

title: Repertory May Be Solution for U.S. Opera Companies
description: Is it permissible for one who is not a licensed seer to offer a few speculations about the future of opera in America? For some years it has seemed to me that in New York we have a laboratory in which certain volatile developments in the art form may be observed at close range. Under the microscope we see, side by side, a Metropolitan Opera committed to an international star system that no longer works with any consistency and a New York City Opera that, on a shoestring, has gone a long way toward building a repertory company of mostly American artists. In the past, both the international system and the repertory system have produced impressive artistic results. The City Opera, for instance, has demonstrated in recent seasons that people will support a largely native-born company that judiciously mixes standard and unusual repertory. And in periods when there were enough genuine supersingers to go around, the Metropolitan certainly has had its share of triumphs.

title: How Should We Celebrate the Constitution?
description: As we commemorate in 1987 the 200th anniversary of the Constitution, we will inevitably be pulled toward two seductive but ultimately inappropriate impulses. We will be tempted, first, to trivialize the event - to turn it into a glitzy collage of fireworks, essay contests and 30 second television moments. We will be tempted, second, to politicize the event - to turn it into a competition over who can most cleverly co-opt the language of the Founding Fathers in the service of a modern political agenda. If we are not to allow our commemoration to degenerate into so much nostalgic bicentennial goo, nor allow it to disintegrate into raw partisan contests, how then should we celebrate the achievement of these 200 years?

title: TUITION AID FOR CHILDREN IS SOUGHT IN ALBANY BILL
description: THE county's ''motel children'' should not have to travel miles every day from temporary motel quarters back to their home school districts, State Senator MaryB. Goodhue said in annoucing a bill she said she would introduce next week in the State Legislature.

title: Permutations on a Coup
description: Exactly half a millennium ago a man named John Morton became Archbishop of Canterbury. Within a few years he was Lord Chancellor of England and a Cardinal. For the supporters of Richard III, he is the villain who originated the Tudor and Shakespearean portraits of their hero. As Lord Chancellor he was the inventor of Morton's Fork: A system in lieu of taxes in which a free-spending merchant has proved by his spending that he can afford a ''gift'' to the king. A miserly one must have saved enough so that he can afford to be generous.

title: AH, THE LUXURY OF A ROARING FIRE
description: LAST Sunday, as I sat reading the paper in the meager light of a December afternoon, my next-door neighbor arrived with an armful of freshly split maple logs. He had just taken down a diseased tree, strewing his front lawn with more wood than he needed. My own woodpile, sorely depleted after five years of occasional and purely decorative fires, required replenishing; so at his invitation, I threw down the paper, drew on boots, hat, and gloves, and left the warmth of my living room to slog through the season's first snow in pursuit of a vanishing luxury.

title: THE PINELANDS HERITAGE COMES TO STATE MUSEUM
description: THOSE who should know say the New Jersey pinelands are unique on this planet: 1.1 million acres of ''outer coastal plain pinelands forest'' that are duplicated nowhere.

title: Judith E. Strong Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James K. Strong of Redondo Beach, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Judith Eleanor Strong, to Gregory Arnold Jorgensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Jorgensen of Salt Lake City. The wedding is planned for April 25.

title: CHARITIES BUREAU TO REVIEW ITS EVALUATION STANDARDS
description: Charities are developing new styles in fund-raising. And the National Charities Information Bureau is taking a fresh look at the standards it has used for decades to evaluate the leading charities.

title: The Talks, Says Shultz, Kept Going
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee at a closed session last week that United States officials met with the Iranians in London Dec. 6, even as President Reagan was saying that the effort to establish a relationship with ''moderates in Iran'' had been ''broken off.''

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday on the engagement of Angela Simeone to Ben Yagoda described her postgraduate education incorrectly. She received a Ph.D. degree in higher education from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Miss Tregellas to Wed Michael McManus Jr.
description: The engagement of Sandra Bond Tregellas and Michael A. McManus Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Robert B. Kyle Jr. and S. Staley Tregellas, both of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. McManus of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mary McManus. A May wedding is planned.

title: 6 Hostages Are Taken In Lebanon
description: The latest events in Lebanon demonstrate how easily terrorists can confound national policy and international diplomacy.

title: TONING UP AT THE SLEEKEST OF HEALTH SPAS
description: ''It is,'' said one obviously enchanted guest, ''like summer camp, except that you don't have to sew on name tapes.'' In fact you don't have to take much in the way of clothing, or cosmetics. And you certainly are expected to leave the traditional package of goodies -the chocolate chip cookies and Heath Bars -at home.

title: Joys and Trials Of Horse Country
description: TRAIL riding, fox hunting, horse shows - North Salem, N.Y., has all. Real-estate advertisements laud the town as ''horse country.'' But . . .

title: Official's Daughter Arrested
description: The daughter of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, has been charged with possession of a controlled substance after the police raided an apartment and found packets containing cocaine in her purse, the authorities said Friday. Dawn Rosten, 34 years old, was arrested with two other people Wednesday. She appeared in court Thursday and was freed on her own recognizance.

title: A LOT IS POSSILBE WITH ELWAY
description: SUPER Bowls used to match a team from the American Conference against a team from the National Conference.

title: THEATER: 'SQUARE ROOT OF 3'
description: THINGS are not tiptop in the Atlas household as ''The Square Root of Three'' begins. Elliot is a car salesman who hasn't sold a car since Japanese imports took over. Pretty soon a collection agency is going to take over his furniture. His wife, who believes he is carrying on the business mainly to carry on with his 19-year-old secretary, is getting ready to leave him. Their 26-year-old son spends his days and nights drinking beer and adding the empties to the thousands of cans and bottles he is sorting for recycling. ''I feel part of the great cycle of life,'' says Danny.

title: HONG KONG'S WORST SLUM SEEMS PLEASED TO FACE ITS DOOM
description: In the bowels of this city's worst slum, people walk about on paths that seem like tunnels. The buildings are so close together that the sky is just a thin crack in the blackness, 15 stories above a jumble of contorted alleys and dripping pipes.

title: POSTINGS: Southold Donation; Village Green
description: The Village of Southold, midway up the North Fork at the eastern end of Long Island, is about to acquire an empty parcel of land in the middle of the town that will forever be preserved as the village green, or public park.

title: Claudette Fisher To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Meredith Fisher of Boulder, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Claudette Marie Fisher to Ridgely Couper Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Dudley Johnson of New York and Edgartown, Mass. The wedding is planned for March 21.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A RAT'S TALE By Tor Seidler. Illustrated by Fred Marcellino. 186 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: Miss O'Hanrahan Planning to Marry Robert Benjamin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Brian A. O'Hanrahan of Dublin have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellenore O'Hanrahan to Robert Kellner Benjamin, the son of Mrs. Edward N. Benjamin of New York and the late Mr. Benjamin. A May wedding is planned.

title: Sherlock Holmes and His Maker
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAREWELL TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: THE NEWSPAPER BILLBOARD I sighted on my last drive to Johannesburg's Jan Smuts Airport bore the message ''Evicted U.S. Newsman Regarded as Hostile.'' I was, in fact, being expelled by a Government that no longer wished me to chronicle its country's internal struggle. But hostile? Had I been hostile to South Africa in my three years as chief of The Times's bureau in Johannesburg, then surely that last ride along the freeway would have been laden with relief. Instead, it was a journey shot through with sadness and questioning, as if some great epic had been torn from me midway in the reading, as if I had been robbed of the chance to grasp all its narrative strands - the harshness and the resilience of the characters, the myriad small tragedies, and the battle, on a grand scale, of a nation convulsed by an anguished history.

title: CLINICAL SOCIAL WORK: PROBLEMS IN SCHOOLING
description: Re ''Shortage of Social Workers?,'' Dec. 7: If there are difficulties attracting students interested in clinical social work, perhaps schools would do well to re-examine their internal structures and possible hidden agendas.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SONG AND DANCE

title: Serving time
description: Governor Cuomo has made increased prison capacity one of his highest priorities. During his first term, capacity in state prisons increased 27 percent. Last week, Mr. Cuomo proposed a $40.9 billion budget that calls for a 7 percent increase in state spending and the construction of two more prisons, bringing the total to 52. Since 1966, the state's prison population has more than doubled. Meanwhile, the population in the city's 11 prisons has risen 22 percent while capacity rose 31 percent. AVERAGE DAILY PRISON POPULATION

title: Getting TV Stereo Plus High Fidelity
description: With the spread of stereo television broadcasting, there has been growing interest in the sound quality of video presentations, and many videophiles cling to the notion that stereo means high-quality sound. This is simply not so; and with so many stereo TV sets now being sold, the distinction between stereo and fidelity should be clarified. The term stereo merely signifies that two separate sound channels are employed - one left and one right. It indicates nothing about the fidelity of the sound.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING IS A BASIC HUMAN RIGHT
description: The following is excerpted from a pastoral letter on housing issued recently by Bishop John R. McGann of the Diocese of Rockville Centre:

description: Answer: The Giants. Why: Lawrence Taylor. JEFF DORSEY Baltimore

description: The marriage of Virginia Deaver Thomson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Thomson of New York, to Jonathan Morgan Hamren, a son of Mrs. Henry Coles of Aptos, Calif., and the late Dr. John Hamren, took place yesterday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York. Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York performed the ceremony.

title: TOPICS
description: FVE days a week, a few minutes before 9 in the morning, and just at 3 in the afternoon, I walk outside school. In fact, every teacher in the school is outside to assure the safe arrival and departure of all students.

title: A Fugitive Caught
description: In the late 1960's, when revolution was a romantic notion that captured many a young mind for a semester or two, Silas Bissell took it seriously, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MAN WITH SOVIET MEAT SECRETS CAN EMIGRATE
description: Lev Blitshtein, the man who was said to know too much about meat storage in the Soviet Union, has learned that he can leave to join his family in the United States.

title: Degrading
description: To the Editor: Plastic is prominent in litter not only because it is non-biodegradable (''Plastic Falls to Pieces,'' Prospects Jan. 11) but because of its lightness. The wind carries plastic everywhere while metal and glass, which are also non-biodegradable, stay put. Similarly, metal and glass sink to the bottom of streams while plastic floats. Visible or not, all are there to clutter and clog.

title: Sports of The Times; As Big As It Is, It's Still a Game for the Fans
description: THE most staggering thought of the week was uttered by a colleague as we stood at the edge of yet another packed news conference staged by the logistics experts of the National Football League.

title: Congress Returns To Old Business
description: Hesitating only long enough to avoid forcing an unseemly veto confrontation before President Reagan goes to Capitol Hill to deliver his State of the Union message, the Senate last week sent him an eight-year extension of the Clean Water Act, a measure he rejected in November.

title: Rule Praised
description: RULES prohibiting football players from ''spearing'' - tackling opponents helmet first and ramrod straight - have dramatically cut the number of paralyzing injuries in the sport, according to Dr. Joseph Torg of the University of Pennsylvania Sports Medical Center.

title: THE WOUNDED GIANT REGAINS HIS DIGNITY
description: On a darkening afternoon seven or eight years ago, I sat with my small daughter in Giants Stadium watching Roger Staubach drive the Cowboys 60 or 70 yards for a winning field goal in the last few seconds. As Rafael Septien's kick went through the uprights, my daughter burst into tears. The next day, she saw a photo in The Times of Harry Carson sitting in dejection on the Giants' bench and told me she wanted to write to him. I remember the words of the letter because we worked on it together hoping to relieve both our broken hearts. Or rather, I simply helped out with some editorial advice, for the sentiments, which I endorsed, came directly from her. ''You mustn't be sad,'' she told the Giant linebacker. ''You're a great player and a wonderful man. We'll all be happy again. I love you. Priscilla Gilman, age 9.''

title: SUFFOLLK DEMOCRATS ASK NEW ELECTION
description: LEAD: UNWILLING to let Republicans seize the highest elected position in Suffolk County without a vote or at least a fight, Suffolk Democrats will move on two fronts tomorrow to force a special election for county executive.

title: CUTTING TAXES: TRY SOME COMPETITION
description: Re ''The Purcell Legacy: Steady Course in Nassau,'' Dec. 28:

title: Dorsett's Surgery
description: ARTHROSCOPIC knee surgery has become commonplace among athletes in recent years, and Tony Dorsett had it done twice on Friday. The Cowboys running back had surgery on both knees.

title: TOPICS
description: NOWHERE in the book about ''passages'' did they warn me that there would be such a time in my life. I have made my peace with the growing gray patches in my chin whiskers. I have begun to rest my folded hands gently upon my small but persistent paunch.

title: U.S. EXPERTS STILL PUZZLED ABOUT FUTURE OF GULF WAR
description: WITH carnage reminiscent of the trench warfare during World War I, the battle for the Iranian port city of Basra, at the head of the Persian Gulf, is about to go into its second month. Both Iraq and Iran made what seemed to be exaggerated reports of enemy casualties last week, with Baghdad citing 100,000 Iranian casualties and Teheran saying 30,000 Iraqis had been killed or wounded. United States Defense Intelligence Agency estimates were lower but still dramatic: 50,000 casualties for Iran and 10,000 to 20,000 for Iraq.

title: HOUSE FIRE LESSON: NO BATTERIES, NO BEEP
description: LEAD: A SMOKE DETECTOR hanging outside the bedroom of a Branford couple failed to warn them of a December fire that produced smoke so thick it drove them to the roof to await help.

title: Habib Confers With Chirac
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, has begun a tour of six Western European capitals by meeting with Prime Minister Jacques Chirac.

title: Pretty Soon, All You'll See Are Big Hits in Tiny Theaters
description: One of the gags in Richard Pryor's new comedy, ''Critical Condition,'' is about a plan to build a 32-screen, so-called multiplex theater with 18 seats per screen. Yet, even as audiences are laughing at this idea, a $10 million, 18-screen multiplex is under construction at Univeral City in California.

title: Resignation Over Affirmative Action
description: Joseph N. Cooper, one of the highest ranking black officials in the Reagan Administration until he resigned nine days ago, went public with his protest last week. ''Vocal dissenters'' among his colleagues not only give no more than ''lip service'' to affirmative action, he said, but also ''promote the idea that goals and timetables are quotas and that reverse discrimination is a reality.''

title: THE POLKA CONTINUES TO THRIVE ACROSS AMERICA
description: LEAD: To many contemporary listeners, polka music has become synonymous with all that is hopelessly square, the butt of lampoons such as John Candy and Eugene Levy's Schmenge Brothers routine on the ''SCTV'' television show. Yet the polka continues to thrive and develop in various Eastern and Central European ethnic enclaves across the United

title: A MOON THAT NEVER SETS
description: ''GOODNIGHT MOON,'' the classic bedtime book of the American nursery, will be 40 years old this year.

title: NO ACCORD YET IN DISPUTE ON LIBRARIES
description: LEAD: A TEMPORARY truce in a financial dispute between the White Plains Library and the Westchester Library System is almost one month old, but no progress has been made toward finding a permanent resolution, officials on both sides say.

title: Capasso Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion Charges
description: In a move that startled nearly everybody concerned, Carl A. Capasso pleaded guilty last week to Federal tax-evasion charges that technically could cost him up to 37 years in prison and $1.5 million in fines. In a statement issued later, the 41-year-old contractor said he regretted ''errors in judgment'' that resulted in his using funds from his company for his personal expenses.

title: PARCELLS PUTS OFF VISIT TO GAME SITE
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants called off today's scheduled team walk around the Rose Bowl, so the players who wanted to stretch their legs did so on their own.

title: NO. 1 IOWA UPSET BY OHIO STATE
description: Dennis Hopson scored 36 points as Ohio State upset Iowa, 80-76, in a Big Ten game today, handing the Hawkeyes their first defeat of the season.

title: GENE SAKS SERIOUS ABOUT LAUGHS
description: WHEN Gene Saks goes to his home in East Hampton these days, it's mainly to gain some respite from the acclaim, phone calls and scripts he has been receiving because of his recent triumph directing two current Neil Simon hits, ''Broadway Bound,'' now playing at the Broadhurst Theater, and the film ''Brighton Beach Memoirs.''

title: KOCH HOPES TO MEET JARUZELSKI IN POLISH TRIP
description: Mayor Koch began a five-day private visit to Poland this evening by ladling out moderate praise for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, calling the Polish leader ''one of the most interesting public figures in the world.''

title:
INVESTING;
Cheap, and for Good Reason
description: LEAD: With small investors flocking back to the stock market, any familiar name selling for less than $5 has a chance of attracting bargain hunters. But not all low-priced plays are undervalued, according to George Putnam 3d, editor of The Turnaround Letter, which tracks companies in bankruptcy or otherwise out of favor.

title: 'Scientific Morality' Meets Political Reality
description: FANG LIZHI was a symbol of the new China, a Princeton-trained astrophysicist who inspired students with calls for academic freedom and independent thinking. In early December, when Mr. Fang, a vice president of the University of Science and Technology in Hefei, supported student demands for greater participation in elections, he was lionized as ''China's Sakharov.'' But then came a wave of demonstrations by Chinese students. The Government reacted by blaming Mr. Fang, dismissing him from his post and last week expelling him from the Communist Party on charges of advocating ''bourgeois liberalization,'' the code words for Westernization.

title: JAZZ: BASSDRUMBONE TRIO
description: BASSDRUMBONE - the trio of Mark Helias on bass, Gerry Hemingway on drums and Ray Anderson on trombone - romps through its music, artfully pulling compositions in three directions at once. Like the trio Air and a very few other jazz ensembles, BassDrumBone's collective improvisations can be bluesy or ethereal, pensive or raucous in the space of a few seconds. In the early set Thursday at Sweet Basil, the compositions touched on free-bop, calypso, blues and a ballad, but they were volatile; the players would easily shift into double time, toss around cross-rhythms or fall into a hush as if on a single impulse.

title: NORWALK ADVISED TO ADD JOBS AT THE TOP
description: IF Norwalk adopts the new management plan it has been given - Mayor William A. Collins hopes the plan will be operating by this summer - Mr. Collins will have fewer people reporting to him directly and more time to take the long view.

title: GETTING THE SHORT SHRIFT FROM THE TALL
description: LEFT-HANDED people complain that the world was made for the right-handed. Older people think it was made for the young. I maintain that it was made for the tall. They keep putting things up while putting me down. Subway straps are short, stairs are steep, and a friend of mine has a bathtub with fixtures so high that I have to stand up to turn off the faucets.

title: A FIESTA OF WOMEN'S SELF-EXPRESSION
description: Several years ago, Jocely Carvalho, a Brazilian artist living in New York, and her colleague Sabra Moore, an American, started thinking about what was on women's minds - in particular, what was happening with other artists. As a transplanted Latin American who has been living in the United States for over 20 years, Ms. Carvalho also wondered what issues were important to women in the arts in Latin America.

title: CONCERT: MANDEL AND LYDON
description: DOES anybody remember Darlene and Jonathan Edwards - the deliberately inept, pseudonymous, country-pop artists whose whackily off-key recordings fooled a lot of people at parties and who actually were Jo Stafford and Paul Weston? Today, New York City has its own urban contemporary version of the Edwardses in the team of the pianist-singer-composer Ellen Mandel and the guitarist-writer-harmonica player-songwriter Michael Lydon, who perform original folk-pop songs and classical compositions.

title: WHERE THE FOUNDATION SPENDS ITS MONEY
description: Higher education is a principal concern of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

title: Q and A
description: Landlord-Access Rules Question: Does someone have the right to buy the apartment I rent in a co-op building even though I'm living there? Secondly, does the new owner have the right to enter my apartment whenever he wishes? This would seem an invasion of my privacy and would give the landlord access to my possessions. Should he not call and make an appointment first? . . . A. S. K., Manhattan Answer: Lanie Accles, a spokesman for the State Attorney General's office, says that not only may your apartment be sold while you are still a tenant, but that such changes in ownership of occupied cooperative apartments are common. Owners may not enter rented apartments whenever they wish, but tenants must allow them access at reasonable hours to make repairs or improvements required by law. This does not mean, however, that owners can inspect or rummage through a tenant's personal belongings or furnishings.

title: DIET CONCERNS TOUCH YOUNGER CHILDREN
description: LEAD: ''IF you break a diet, you feel guilty about it and vomit or you just stay on a diet for so long.''

title:
CABLE TV;
The America's Cup Sails Into Focus
description: LEAD: Everyone loves a loser - at least, one coming off a winning streak of 132 years. Or such are the hopes of ESPN, which this week will begin live coverage of the finalists' round of the America's Cup, the yachting contest whose silver trophy was snatched in 1983 by Australia, following an unbroken run of victories by boats flying the United

title: HEADING FOR MANHATTAN, DESPITE THE STRIKE
description: THE strike that began last week against the Long Island Rail Road underscored a number of factors about the Island, its geography and its economy.

title: MONDELLO'S DUAL ROLE: VOTER REACTION FEARED
description: SEVERAL Nassau County Republicans have acknowledged that Joseph N. Mondello, the new Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor and the Nassau Republican chairman, who engineered changes in the County Executive, Hempstead Presiding Supervisor and Supervisor positions, could be the focal point of voter reaction next November when Thomas S. Gulotta, the new County Executive; Gregory Peterson, the new Hempstead Supervisor, and Mr. Mondello face the voters for full terms.

title: Catherine Taylor To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. John A. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Shawhan Taylor to John Gordon Hawkins, a son of Patricia Hawkins of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and David Hawkins of Brookline, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN PRAGUE TODAY, TREASURES OF THE PAST
description: Great capitals are usually hard to ignore: as cultural, economic and political centers, they attract crowds of travelers year after year, and are, if anything, overexposed. Yet right in the center of Europe, one of the most attractive cities ever built, long the residence of the Holy Roman Emperors, is often overlooked - a fact all the more surprising because, unlike many of its neighbors, it largely escaped the ravages of the last world war.

title: EDUCATROS LEARNING TO BE LITERARY TUTORS
description: ONE HUNDRED employees of the state's Department of Education, including Dr. Saul Cooperman, the Commissioner of Education, are enrolled in a volunteer training project here to become tutors for illiterate Trenton adults.

title: They Love a Parade
description: There is no denying that New Yorkers love their hometown sports teams. I am writing this letter to point out the feelings of local pride and excitement we experienced as a result of the success of the Mets last fall, and now the Giants.

title:
FOOD;
A New Taste From China
description: LEAD: OF THE APPROXIMATELY HALF-DOZEN Chinese regional cuisines, the cooking of the Chiu Chow people from an area some 200 miles east of Canton is virtually unknown in the United States. A robust version of Cantonese food, a kind of soul food of southern China, Chiu Chow cuisine was a novelty even in the culinary mecca of Hong Kong 20 years ago.

title: Soviet Psychiatric Hospital Is Reported to Free Aviator
description: A Soviet airline navigator who was forcibly committed to a psychiatric hospital after applying to emigrate was discharged today after an appeal from Andrei D. Sakharov, the navigator's daughter said.

title: Bernadette Casey to Wed
description: The engagement of Bernadette Katherine Casey to R. Dorsey Gray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Gray Jr. of Atlanta, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Emmet Casey of Yonkers. Miss Casey is a senior at Georgia State University. Her fiance is a student at Mercer University and a sales representative for Heinrich Technology Inc. in Atlanta.

title: SCOUTING REPORTS: TEAM POWER VS. ELWAY'S SKILL
description: Last year's Super Bowl coaches, Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears and Raymond Berry of the New England Patriots, are the sources for the scouting reports on today's Super Bowl teams.

title: Elizabeth A. Peck, a Teacher, to Marry Mark P. Sperry, a Stockbroker, in June
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Alden Peck to Mark Porter Sperry has been announced by Philip F. W. Peck of West Hartford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., the father of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Corydon S. Sperry of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass., and the late Mr. Sperry. A June wedding is planned.

title: BID TO AVOID A MOSTLY BLACK JERSEY SCHOOL
description: Three Bergen County communities are embroiled in a legal battle over whether an affluent white community continues to send teen-agers a predominantly black high school in Englewood.

title: Surrogate Motherhood Binds Unequal Parties
description: To The Editor:

title: COACH'S TOUCH PUTS IOWA IN NO. 1 SPOT
description: AFTER suffering through a fourth straight disappointing season at Stanford last year, Tom Davis, the Cardinal's head coach, decided, somewhat regretfully, that he had had enough.

title: If Monty Had Taken Berlin
description: To the Editor:

title: DESIGNING A WINNING STRATEGY
description: If you were coaching one of this year's Super Bowl teams what would you stress in your game plan?

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: SOON after passage of the tax act last year, many tax specialists and employee benefit consultants were predicting that deferred compensation arrangements for top executives would go the way of the dinosaur. They reasoned that with a top tax bracket of 28 percent, executives would prefer to take their money now, rather than deferring payment and risking a tax rise later.

title: A WAY OUT OF REYKJAVIK
description: LEAD: EVENTS DURING THE AUTUMN of 1986 have produced greater confusion in American strategic policy than perhaps at any other time in the nuclear age. After unveiling its startling proposal at the Reykjavik summit meeting in October that the United States and the Soviet Union agree to ban all ballistic missiles within a decade - a proposal that was a major departure from NATO strategy that has kept peace in Europe for 40 years - the Reagan Administration has hesitantly begun to develop a rationale for that position.

title: MOVIE THEATER IS BACK IN MAINSTREAM
description: THE Clint Eastwood film ''Heartbreak Ridge'' and ''Song of the South'' were the offerings last week at the Webster Theater in Hartford, with a special matinee on Monday of the Walt Disney animated film. It was a school holiday, and the theater manager, Albert Reynaud, hoped for a large turnout.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today we have embarked on a journey, a journey that will take a lifetime to fulfill, the journey of worldwide brotherhood and understanding. Without this, Forsyth County, Georgia, and even our nation will fail. Without brotherhood in a community, violence and intimidation will exist.'' - Dean Carter, an organizer of the march yesterday in Forsyth County. [ 21:1. ]

title: David C. Cushing And Miss Spring, Buyer, Are Wed
description: Deborah Leigh Spring, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Polmer Spring of Boston, was married yesterday to David Charles Cushing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William Cushing of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Michael Boardmann performed the ceremony at the First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church in Brookline, Mass.

title: FROM YUPPIES TO THE HOLOCAUST, IN DANCE
description: LEAD: ''I WANT to send the audience through the gamut of emotions in one evening,'' Carolyn Dorfman said during an extensive interview last fall, and the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company's program in West Long Branch and Morristown Friday and Saturday should accomplish just that.

title: The Sea Of Darkness
description: When President Reagan says, ''It is in our interest to stand with those who would take arms against the sea of darkness,'' he is not misquoting Hamlet so much as confusing two romantic worlds: William Shakespeare's Renaissance and George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' (''By the Beautiful Sea,'' by William Safire, On Language, Dec. 28).

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SURROGATE MOTHER'S IRON WILL
description: A recently-released psychiatric profile of Mary Beth Whitehead, the mother of Baby M, called her a strong-willed woman who ''felt somewhat rushed and unready'' by her two previous pregnancies during her teen-age years in the mid-1970's.

title: STATE'S DIVISION OF MOTOR VEHICLES SEEKS NEW IMAGE
description: THE state has 5.2 million licensed drivers who must deal with the Division of Motor Vehicles at least twice a year, and recently the experience has been anything but pleasant.

title: PRESERVATION TAKES RARE MANUSCRIPTS FROM THE PUBLIC
description: ''My overriding duty is to preserve the manuscript. No one will be allowed to see it again,'' says Frederic Vergne, the curator at the Conde Museum housed in the moated Chateau of the Dukes of Aumale in this small town a few miles north of Paris.

title: HITLER IN A VERY SMALL TOWN
description: THE SPELL By Hermann Broch. Translated by H. F. Broch de Rothermann. 391 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: Mr. Baker's Subtle Strategy of Coercion
description: THERE is considerable unease in the American financial community about Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's apparent decision to pursue an aggressive devaluation strategy against West Germany and Japan. It is feared that a sharply lower dollar could reignite inflation and trigger a collapse in the bond market by discouraging foreign purchases of United States financial assets. But as risky as Mr. Baker's strategy may seem, it is, under current circumstances, somewhat analogous to Winston Churchill's description of democracy - all the known alternatives are worse.

title: 2 East Germans Flee to West
description: Two East German men fled unharmed Friday night across the fortified border to West Germany, the border authorities said today. Their escape brought to seven the number of East Germans who have fled to West Germany since Jan. 1.

title: Janice A. Racaniello Wed To David W. Henderson
description: Janice Ann Racaniello, a floor reporter for the New York Stock Exchange, and David Walsh Henderson, a vice president of the New York Stock Exchange specialist firm of Henderson Brothers, were married yesterday at Our Lady Mother of the Church in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The Rev. Edward Cooke performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Marion Sue Waskover To Wed Dr. D. A. Frank
description: The engagement of Marion Sue Waskover and Dr. David Alan Frank has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Waskover of New York and Miami, the parents of the future bride. Dr. Frank is a son of Mrs. Hilton Kimless of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Newton Frank of New York.

title: STATE SHOULD DEMONSTRATE ABILITY TO CORRECT DEFICIENCIES
description: GOVERNOR KEAN recently called for a state takeover of school districts that are not able to meet New Jersey's constitutional requirement that all students receive a ''thorough and efficient'' education.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: RECOLLECTIONS OF THINGS TO COME. By Elena Garro. Translated by Ruth L. C. Simms. (University of Texas, Paper, $10.95.) The narrator of Elena Garro's first novel, which originally appeared in 1963, establishes the tone of this dreamy, nonlinear story in the first paragraph. The reader must guess at the identity of the speaker by solving sphinx-like riddles: ''I am and I was in many eyes. I am only memory and the memory that one has of me.'' As the story of the Mexican village of Ixtepec unfolds, and an extraordinarily large cast of characters comes and goes, it becomes clear that the narrator is the voice of the town itself. Ixtepec is a small, desperate community in the post-Zapata Mexico of the 1920's. At the story's center is General Francisco Rosas, the execrable head of Ixtepec's Military Command who is obsessed with Julia Andrade, his wispy, sullen mistress. Though the book has the makings of a historical novel, the story's warping (and, at one point, complete stopping) of time keeps it from reading like a persuasive account of the Mexican Revolution. In fact, the lyric tone and fabulous plot solidly position the book in the tradition of Latin American magical realism. The old illusion-vs.-reality conflict is tackled with brio by Ms. Garro; one of her more likable characters stops the clock every night in an effort to live outside time. Her evocation of a town, its denizens and their collective memory (smoothly translated here) is luminous and affecting.

title: From O'Neill's Heroines To His Haunted Widow
description: LEAD: Colleen Dewhurst, two-time graduate of Smokenders, unleashes a haunted cigarette cough before lighting up again. She has a stiff neck, the result, she believes, of masking tension and terror at work. She is hardly eating. In rehearsal one day, giddy with anxiety, she actually fell off the stage, a first for a player who has adorned the theater with honor and glory and without an accident for more than 30 years.

title: S.R.O. BILL HAS ROOM FOR COMPLAINT
description: IN the alphabet soup of municipal government, the letters ''S.R.O.'' have taken on special meaning. New York City officials have wrestled for months over the fate of the city's remaining 52,000 rooms in S.R.O., or single-room-occupancy, hotels. They arrived at a solution last week, but it was not easy and it was not popular.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Posh Cunard Berth In Philadelphia

title: Marianne Bardach to Marry on May 31
description: The engagement of Marianne Bardach to Dr. Richard Allen Dornfeld has been announced by Peter H. Bardach of Providence, R.I., and Lesta Summerfield Stacom of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Carolyn Dornfeld of West Orange, N.J., and Norman Dornfeld of New York, Sag Harbor, L.I., and West Dover, Vt. A May 31 wedding is planned.

title: POSTINGS: $17 Million Surgery; Madison Facelift
description: The office building at 625 Madison Avenue, which occupies the entire blockfront between 58th and 59th Streets on the east side of the avenue, is going to get a facelift, and the surgeon will be one of the city's better-known architects, Der Scutt.

title: Jennifer R. Wingate to Marry John Edward Schott
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Wingate of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Reese Wingate, to John Edward Schott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Schott of New Canaan, Conn.

title:
FICTION: IN SHORT;
UP FROM SEGREGATION
description: LEAD: EYES ON THE PRIZE: AMERICA'S CIVIL RIGHTS YEARS, 1954-1965 (Viking, $24.95) is a companion volume to the six-part television series currently being broadcast on PBS. The Washington Post reporter Juan Williams, with the ''Eyes on the Prize'' production team, has created a fascinating, fast-moving overview.

title: KOHL'S COALITION FAVORED IN VOTE TODAY
description: West Germans are to vote Sunday in a parliamentary election that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition is strongly favored to win.

title: Custom Building
description: To the Editor: I found your article on ''Custom Building With an Architect'' on Dec. 21 informative, with the exception of the section on the Henry Noble home. Mr. Noble's cost-cutting efforts on a projected half-million-dollar home focused on employing out-of-state subcontractors and eliminating part of the contracting fees by employing his architect as a construction manager.

title: Jumping the Gun on 'Amerika'
description: Whatever else ''Amerika'' is - at 14 1/2 hours, it is, if nothing else, a very large piece of prime time - it is now the source of great controversy.

title: SUPERBOWL IS WASHING DENVER'S WOES AWAY
description: Suddenly, Denver is jubilant.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR many people, says Arnold Wexler, executive director of the Trenton-based Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, today's Super Bowl XXI clash between the Giants and Denver Broncos in Pasadena, Calif., ''is like waiting for the stock market to crash - it's just a waking nightmare.''

title: Paris Shapes
description: WHEN THE PARIS designers get onto something, they are certainly capable of putting it across. Buttressed by that city's formidable battery of talented background performers - seamstresses, tailors, embroiderers, fabric and accessory suppliers and the like - designers are free to let their individual imaginative talents fly. And with these top talents ranging in viewpoint from avant-garde to conservatism, the results usually vary widely.

title: U.S. Is Using The Dollar To Twist Some Arms
description: ON Friday, as the stock market roared upward by 64 points and then plunged by 115, one stockbroker said: ''It's berserk. It's total confusion. No one knows what the heck is going on.'' The apparent chaos on Wall Street was closely linked to financial events around the world. In foreign exchange markets last week, the weak dollar plunged and the mighty yen climbed. And the Japanese Finance Minister flew.

title: Doctors And the Humane Touch
description: I am not sure whether the expansion of scientific knowledge and technology to which Ms. Wallace alludes has made physicians less compassionate, but it has given them the ability to treat their patients effectively. It is for this, after all, that patients consult them, and it is a service the most compassionate of their predecessors were unable to provide. ALBERT S. BRAVERMAN, M.D. Brooklyn

title: HOLLANDER HOPEFUL ON STUDENT AID
description: ''PARENTS and students ought to apply for all the programs to which they think they're entitled and not assume that the proposals from the White House will be enacted.''

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Aids for the Disabled Of Benefit to Others Gadgets, implements and equipment designed for easier dressing, food preparation, dining, communicating, recreation and mobility after a stroke, automobile accident or hospitalization can often serve others without disability. Purchase is possible by catalogue, but Westchester Surgical Supply, formerly of New Rochelle, has an extensive retail showroom in

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: The Broncos and the Giants will both win the game. How can any team that has played so valiantly, physically and psychologically, possibly be a loser? Sure, one team will gain more points and drink more champagne, but no amount of numbers put down in black and white can tell the true story. So everyone is a winner. MINNIE WALKER New York

title: What I Really Think About South Africa
description: There is a place in South Africa, on the south coast, where the waves thrash and the whales come to mate, and from the shore you can see their humps and their tails slapping the waves. The rocks merge into forest, which thickens and turns and climbs into sturdy green hills. It is a beautiful place. This is what I said when I was asked, during my six months in South Africa, ''What do you think of our country?'' It was the first thing South Africans asked when they discovered they were talking to an American. ''It is a beautiful place,'' I answered, and they went away satisfied that they had met a sensible foreigner who understood their country.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: DON'T BET ON THE PRINCE: Contemporary Feminist Fairy Tales in North America and England. Edited by Jack Zipes. (Methuen, $18.95.) Once, long before Perrault and the Grimm brothers gave us their helpless Little Red Riding Hood, there was a tale about a clever little girl who duped the wolf disguised as granny and fled into the woods. Centuries passed and, as Jack Zipes has documented in many studies of folk and fairy tales, our best-loved storybook heroines came to reflect the paternalistic values of Western society. What's a kid to do? ''Don't Bet on the Prince'' offers an appealing antidote, 16 feminist retellings and departures from the classics. The stories for children teach lessons: if you're kind, resourceful and brave, you'll find happiness; sit pretty and wait for the prince, and you'll be sorry. Too often, these tales do not cloak their morals in the spirit of enchantment that made the classics so alluring. The exceptions are Angela Carter's ''Donkey Prince,'' and Jane Yolen's ''Moon Ribbon,'' in which ''plain but good-hearted'' Sylva accidentally leads her wicked stepmother and stepsisters down ''a silver-red stair'' to hell. The stories and poems for adults - wry subversions of stereotypes - are richer. Meghan B. Collins creates a good witch's bad love affair in ''The Green Woman,'' Tanith Lee a sympathetic female werewolf in ''Wolfland,'' and Anne Sexton a ''Briar Rose'' spiritually imprisoned by Daddy. The four solid but stale critical essays might have been left out, though. These wise new heroines can speak for themselves, as Cinderella does in Judith Viorst's brief poem: ''He's not nearly as attractive as he seemed the other night. / So I think I'll just pretend that this glass slipper feels too tight.'' Now there's a girl who could live happily ever after.

title: The In Crowd Is Watching Apple
description: I.B.M. watching, long a leading sport in Silicon Valley, consists in large measure of following Big Blue's every move with an eye toward making a few million dollars here or there by producing cloned or compatible products. The International Business Machines Corporation, meanwhile, zigzags through the marketplace trying to avoid giving the competition any clues concerning the destiny of computing.

title: A SAMPLER OF WORKS BY STAMP ARTISTS
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT artists have so often been tapped by the Postal Service to design commemorative stamps ''because of the stature of the artists who happen to reside there and their availability,'' according to the manager of stamp design for the service in Washington, D.C., Jack Williams.

title: The Defendant's Rights vs. Police Efficiency
description: ACCORDING to officials in the Justice Department, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d might soon ask the Supreme Court to overturn its 1966 Miranda decision, which requires the police to inform criminal suspects of their legal rights to silence and to counsel before questioning.

title: PIPELINE PROTESTS FLOOD U.S. AGENCY
description: SOME homeowners sent photographs of pristine landscapes.

title: TEACHING THE GIFTED: ANOTHER ASPECT
description: As a parent whose children went to the Long Island School for the Gifted and then to public schools, I read with interest the recent article ''School for Gifted: Where the S.A.T. Is Just Another Test'' and the letters to the editor that it drew.

title: Miss Chernuchin Weds D. J. Barsky, A Fellow Lawyer
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York last night Cindy Jo Chernuchin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Chernuchin of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Daniel Jonathan Barsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Barsky of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: Shelley Slade Plans to Marry
description: Shelley Rodes Slade, an associate at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Mark Dobson Betts, an associate in the Washington office of the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, plan to be married in April, the parents of the bride-to-be, Jarvis James Slade and Alice Patterson Slade, both of New York, have announced.

title: PRESIDENT OF PRINCETON IS LEAVING TO TAKE MELLON FOUNDATION POST
description: William G. Bowen, who led Princeton University into co-education and guided it through 15 years of academic expansion, announced today that he was stepping down as its president.

title: MAVERICKS STOP LAKERS' STREAK AT 6
description: Mark Aguirre scored 35 points and Brad Davis came off the bench to add a season-high 21 today, carrying the Dallas Mavericks to a 132-117 victory over Los Angeles that broke the Lakers' six-game winning streak.

title: U.S. AIDES LINK LATEST SEIZURES TO EXTRADITION
description: Administration officials said today that the abduction of four teachers in Beirut, three of them Americans, appeared to be linked to the capture by West Germany of a Lebanese hijacking suspect wanted in the United States.

title: Aqueduct Races Canceled
description: The stewards at Aqueduct canceled the racing program yesterday, citing the below-zero wind-chill factor early in the morning. Thursday's racing was also canceled by the weather and Friday's program was called off after one race.

title: Housing Boom Sweeping the Catskills
description: THE time-worn and gentle Catskill Mountains have been described as a sublime natural wonder that is best viewed from a cabin porch.

title: WAITING ROOM LITERARY CLUES
description: THE sniffle season being in full flow, it is small wonder that the winter is turning out to be another festival of medicine in many homes. I myself, like any used car, have been in regular attendance for oil change, odd noises in the transmission, creakiness in gear shift and suggestions for getting more mileage with less fuel intake.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
description: The Giants will win the Super Bowl because how else can Bill Parcells get his sweet revenge by dumping a bucket of Gatorade on Harry Carson's head? KATHERINE NEWELL SMITH New York

title: POSTINGS: 50,000 Sq. Ft. in Yonkers; Condos for Doctors
description: Samuel Davis, chief executive officer of Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City for 10 years until his resignation in 1984, now heads a Westchester County development team that plans to build a professional building for doctors and dentists in Yonkers.

title: SPORTS CAR SEASON OPENS WITH TOP TEST
description: The sports-car racing season opens next weekend with the running of the most challenging event on the schedule, the SunBank 24 at Daytona Beach, Fla. Outright speed doesn't win at Daytona. For cars that were designed for races that are no longer than six hours, Daytona and the 12-hour race in March at the Sebring, Fla., airport are ultramarathons.

description: LEAD: FAVORITE FOLKTALES FROM AROUND THE WORLD Edited by Jane Yolen. 498 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

description: HOME FIRES BURNING By Robert Inman. 392 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

description: LEAD: OF all the current and planned investigations of law enforcement in Suffolk County, none are likely to have greater impact than one by a state watchdog agency that will hold two public hearings this week.

title: Honors From the United Nations
description: On Friday, the United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of three commemorative stamps to honor Trygve Lie. Mr. Lie served as the first Secretary-General of the United Nations from Feb. 1, 1946, to April 10, 1953.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: REPLAY. By Ken Grimwood. (Arbor House, $17.95.) After the first death there is another, and another, and another - so learns Jeff Winston, the hero of Ken Grimwood's fourth novel. At 43, Winston dies, only to return as his 18-year-old self in 1963. He'll die again at 43 and come back again, but successive existences grow progressively shorter as he returns each time to a later point in his original life.

title: A Contract Is a Contract

That race was won by another Georgian, Jimmy Carter, but Mr. Carter's success is less on Mr. Nunn's mind than the defeat of one of his early mentors, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington.

HIS STEPFATHER'S GUN

description: To the Editor:

title: Acapulco
description: Acapulco, it seems, grows larger every year, and the city is paying a price for its growth. But the qualities that give the city its charm and attract so many visitors are still the same.

title: THOUSANDS IN CIVIL RIGHTS MARCH JEERED BY CROWD IN GEORGIA TOWN
description: This small town in Forsyth County was overwhelmed today by civil rights marchers, members of the Ku Klux Klan and their sympathizers and an army of National Guardsmen and law-enforcement officers who kept the opposing groups separated.

description: LEAD: OPEN-HEART surgery costs more in New Jersey than in surrounding areas, according to a recent report by the New Jersey Cardiac Services Task Force.

description: As the final seconds tick off the clock, all of the New York Giant fans and even the casual observers will be in a stupor. Their mighty titans will have succumbed to overconfidence, videotapes and the idea of the whole sporting world that they could never lose.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

ART;
REMEMBERING EICKEMEYER, AN ADVOCATE OF PICTORIALISM

But while Stieglitz went on to a secure place in the history of photography and modern art in general, Eickemeyer has been quite forgotten.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: In his Oct. 26 story on the Swiss hotel Haus Paradies, Israel Shenker says, ''Swiss Germans have quaint notions about spelling.'' There is nothing quaint about ''Paradies.'' It's the regular German spelling of ''paradise.''

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
New Surgery For the Bellevue
description: LEAD: THE grande dame of Broad Street, having barely survived Legionnaires' Disease a decade ago, is about to undergo major surgery in yet another attempt to save her life.

title:
GARDENING;
SLOWING THE SPREAD OF ELM DISEASE
description: LEAD: THE accidental introduction of Dutch elm disease to the United States on veneer logs from Holland some 60 years ago proved to be devastating to our native American elm. This grandest of all shade trees once provided shade for houses, created arch canopies over city boulevards and small-town streets and made parks pleasant places to while away hot summer afternoons.

title: A TENSE INDIA SEEKS TALKS WITH PAKISTAN AND SEES NO ATTACK
description: India pledged tonight not to attack Pakistan and said it wanted talks with its neighbor to reduce the tension caused by troop movements on both sides. Pakistan also is seeking talks, officials in Islamabad said.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Port Washington Project Offers Flexibility
description: LEAD: WHEN Seagull Associates bought an 8.9-acre site at the Seaview Office & Industrial Park in Port Washington in 1985, the low price of $1 million reflected the fact that only about five acres of the property was level.

title: WASHINGTON RAIDERS: Herbert and Robert Haft; The Dynasty Behind Dart's Expanding Empire
description: ''MY father always has to be building something,'' says Robert Haft.

title: IN THE BOOK WORLD, AMERICAN PUBLISHERS ARE BEST SELLERS
description: WHEN Ajai Singh Mehta leaves London in March to replace Robert A. Gottlieb at Alfred A. Knopf, he will be one of very few foreigners who have become editors in chief of an American book publisher. But if foreigners are rare in editorial sanctums, they have become increasingly familiar in the publishers' management suites.

title: Concert Artists Guild Broadens Its Services
description: ''I'm of many minds about competitions,'' says Ellen Highstein, executive director of Concert Artists Guild, a 36-year-old organization that has been running one such contest for the last 33 years. ''Their negative side is that, no matter how often you try to make it clear that one can't equate musical competitions with the Olympics, there are people who feel that if someone can run the fastest, then someone can play the Chopin Second Concerto the best. On the other hand, competitions are a very democratic, leveling situation. Contacts are very scarce these days, and a contest is one way a performer can find a place in the musical community without playing 'who do you know.' And I think that's particularly true of a competition like ours, where all instruments are welcome, and where there are no age limits or nationality requirements.''

title: TALKS PROGRESS, BU NOBODY IS WORKING ON THE RAILROAD
description: LONG Island Rail Road executives and the leaders of 15 unions have tried for more than two years to come to terms on new contracts for the line's 6,600 organized employees, with only partial success. Last week, because railroad unions traditionally honor one another's picket lines, 110,000 daily riders paid the price.

title: New Rules Mean Job-Hunters Need Proof of Identity
description: A 1982 proposal to catch illegal aliens by giving American workers ''counterfeit-proof'' identity cards was hooted off the boards as a threat to individual liberty. Under rules proposed last week by the Immigration and Naturalization Service for the administration of the landmark immigration law enacted last year, passports, driver's licenses, Social Security cards or birth certificates will have to serve instead.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article Jan. 4 listing tips for travel to Kenya incorrectly linked a disease to mosquitoes. Mosquitoes carry yellow fever and malaria, not cholera.

title: ARGENTINE OFFICER IS ARRESTED IN U.S.
description: A former Argentine general accused of taking part in the torture and killing of thousands of Argentine leftists in the 1970's was arrested in a San Francisco suburb today after a nationwide search, the United States Marshals Service said.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plan to meet Wednesday with Oliver Tambo, leader of the African National Congress, a militant anti-apartheid organization banned by South Africa, has stirred consternation among conservative Republicans.

title: Another Attack on Ecuador's Leader
description: Only days after Ecuador got its President back from renegade air force commandos, the National Congress tried last week to get rid of him. The majority of the legislators voted to ask Leon Febres Cordero to resign, arguing that his kidnapping would not have occurred if he had not blocked their amnesty of a rebellious general.

title: PREP-SCHOOL TALES COME TO TV SCREEN
description: LEAD: WHEN the young male actors, ages 15 to 23, arrived on location to shoot a comedy set at a prep school at the turn of the century for public television's ''American Playhouse,'' Jan Jaffe Kahn had misgivings. Just how would these young men, some sporting rock-concert T-shirts and carrying large portable radios, relate to her screenplay adapted - though not updated -from Owen Johnson's ''Lawrenceville

title: LAUNCH A PEGASUS, 13-1, WINS
description: Launch a Pegasus, making his first start since last May, scored a 1 1/2-length upset victory in the $104,050 Seminole Handicap today at Hialeah Park as the heavy favorites, Smile and John's Treasure, finished off the board.

title: OFFICIAL, IN FRAUD TRIAL, SAYS ASSEMBLY LACKS HIRING RULES
description: A top official of the State Assembly testified last week that formal rules governing hiring and supervisory practices in the Assembly are virtually non-existent.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IT'S the night before the party, the pots on the stove are simmering, the sweatsuit has a few new stains -some chicken stock here, a dab of mousse there - and finally, it's time to flop and relax with ''Wheel of Fortune'' or ''Moonlighting'' or ''L.A. Law.'' Well, in just a minute - a little snack first. All that cooking and preparation gives a person an appetite - maybe some cheese and crackers, dill pickles, a bit of vino, a Tuscan Pop or two. What bliss!

title: Linda M. Brody to Marry R.G. Blumenreich in May
description: Linda Marlene Brody, a lawyer for the Federal Trade Commission, and Richard Glenn Blumenreich, a lawyer in the office of the chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Service, both in Washington, plan a May wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Morton Brody of Potomac, Md., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Leatrice Blumenreich of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Ira Blumenreich.

title: TEN GIANT STEPS TO SUPERDOM
description: BEFORE the National Football League season began in early September, a Super Bowl crystal bowl contest was conducted among sportswriters. Select the teams that will get to Super Bowl XXI, and the score of the game. In a rare moment of clairvoyance, this entry read:

title: BE REASONABLE - UNLESS YOU'RE A WRITER
description: SHELLEY believed that poets - and by that he meant all imaginative writers -are good people. He writes in his essay ''A Defence of Poetry'' that ''cruelty, envy, revenge, avarice, and the passions purely evil, have never formed any portion of the popular imputations on the lives of the poets.'' Thank you, Mr. Shelley. However, he also thought that writers don't necessarily know what they're doing.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: THE KREMLIN AND THE WEST: A Realistic Approach. By Wolfgang Leonhard. (Norton, 7.95.)
