Wolfgang Leonhard would seem well qualified to deliver what he promises here - a ''new policy toward [ the ] USSR.'' Arriving in Moscow in l935 as a l4-year-old German, Mr. Leonhard spent the war years in the Soviet Union and at war's end was whisked off to Berlin as one of the original members of the ''Ulbricht group,'' charged with setting up a Communist state in what became East Germany. He defected in l948 and now teaches history at Yale University. Although he provides a useful account of how the Soviet system functions, his proposed ''realistic approach'' is disappointing - a combination of sensible but vague and not terribly new ideas. Mr. Leonhard's central argument is that a more sober Soviet foreign policy is inextricably tied to internal liberalization: moderation will come only with political strictures (whether formal or not) at home. The West should encourage liberalization by bolstering institutions like Radio Liberty; by firmly linking arms agreements and East-West trade to internal moderation; and by insisting that important trade deals, such as grain shipments and other dealings with the West be publicly acknowledged within the Soviet Union. He argues that the West must maintain relations not only with the Soviet Government, but with the Soviet people as well, and urges that the West vigorously support human rights groups within the Soviet bloc countries. Useful but familiar advice, and hardly the new course Mr. Leonhard promises between the ''primitive anti-Communism'' of the Cold War and the ''over-optimistic illusions'' that he believes accompanied detente.

title: FOR EX-GIANT, SUPER BOWL'S AT HOME
description: THE hoopla that has come to characterize Super Bowl week has never been in keeping with Andy Robustelli's style. And so today, when the New York Giants make their first appearance in the Super Bowl, Mr. Robustelli, one of the greatest players in Giants history, will watch the game as most Americans will - on television.

title: From Swords to Knives in Kyoto
description: Nishikikoji (familiarly referred to as just Nishiki), a narrow arcaded street in the heart of central Kyoto, is the market basket of Kyoto's food lovers. Extending several blocks west of the Teramachi arcade, both sides of the street are bursting with the best Kyoto has to offer. Fishmongers and butchers, greengrocers and noodle makers, the shops are stocked with the freshest of the season, and many offer regional specialties rarely seen in other parts of Japan. On the north side of the street just west of Gokomachi-dori, a block from Teramachi, Aritsugu may seem, at first, a bit intimidating when you peer in from Nishiki, warm with hurrying shoppers and grilling eel. One long wall is lined with glass cases containing enough knives, row upon gleaming row, to equip all of Japan's finest chefs. It is not only the shining blades, however, that give Aritsugu an imposing air but also the 18 generations of history behind the business.

title: Carol Kirkman Weds Richard Berman
description: Carol Kirkman and Richard K. Berman were married yesterday at their Manhattan apartment by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles D. Lippman. The couple's parents are the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Kirkman of Atlantis, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. David J. Berman of Port Washington, L.I.

title:
GARDENING;
SLOWING THE SPREAD OF ELM DISEASE
description: LEAD: THE accidental introduction of Dutch elm disease to the United States on veneer logs from Holland some 60 years ago proved to be devastating to our native American elm. This grandest of all shade trees once provided shade for houses, created arch canopies over city boulevards and small-town streets and made parks pleasant places to while away hot summer afternoons.

title: Topics: Winning in Winter; No-Armed Bandit
description: The Nevada Gambling Control Board has authorized a test of cashless no-armed-banditry, a plastic card that takes the place of coins in slot machines and enhances a casino's ability to hook customers.

title: ESPOSITO WILL FILL IN AGAIN FOR WEBSTER
description: Phil Esposito, the general manager with the best coaching record in the National Hockey League, will be behind the Rangers' bench at Madison Square Garden again tonight for a game against the Devils because Tom Webster's train from Toronto will not arrive in time.

title: A CRITICAL POINT FOR BRIDGE REPAIR PLAN 921:56,813>
description: The cables that support the Williamsburg Bridge are rapidly corroding and money for a daring operation to replace them is being held up in Congress, state transportation officials said.

title: Sinatra, Simms and Minelli
description: MOMENTS before the second half of Super Bowl XXI was about to start, the Denver Broncos were holding a 10-9 lead as the Giants hurried out of their locker-room tunnel. Over the public-address system, Frank Sinatra's voice was booming.

title: ANGER IS VOICED OVER AMERICANS STILL IN LEBANON
description: The kidnapping of three American teachers in Beirut led today to expressions of resentment against Americans who have remained in Lebanon despite unequivocal warnings from the State Department that they cannot be protected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is simply not fair in the interest of this country for them to stay there and place themselves in jeopardy. They aren't showing any special courage, but are simply offering themselves to be used as pawns against the interests of this country.'' - Representative

title: The Editorial Notebook; Roosevelt, Reagan and the Law
description: When Presidents misbehave, defenders look to history for precedent to demonstrate that all White House occupants cut corners or flout the wishes of Congress for brave or expedient reasons. A favorite illustration is Franklin Roosevelt's 1940 swap of 50 old destroyers for the lease of British bases in the West Indies. President Reagan's dealings with Iran, the argument runs, are not much different from that act of benign usurpation.

title: WORKERS MAINTAIN SHADOW OF A RAILROAD
description: From his office at the Long Island Rail Road's headquarters in Jamaica, Queens, Larry Baggerly surveyed what he said was one of the saddest scenes a railroad man could behold. On the tangle of tracks that pass through the line's central station, threads of silvery trains were parked, their running lights burning but their motors dead.

title: EDBERG REPELS CASH FOR TITLE
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden held off a comeback by Pat Cash of Australia to win his second straight Australian Open men's singles title today.

title: KNICKS FIND TROUBLE IN TEXAS
description: Just one week ago, the Knicks were brimming with the confidence borne of 8 victories in 12 games and were buoyed by their surprising defeat of the Celtics. Anything was possible. Even the playoffs. Patrick Ewing was playing the best basketball of his professional career. Bill Cartwright was a commanding complement at power forward, a position he was still learning. Others were filling in the gaps, with Gerald Henderson providing aggressive leadership and Gerald Wilkins adding a touch of flair.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A commuter guide that appeared last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday with an article on the Long Island Rail Road strike incorrectly described the parking fees at Shea Stadium. The price is $2 before 10 A.M. and $3 afterward. In addition, an article and a picture caption Wednesday about the effects of the strike incorrectly described the parking situation at Shea Stadium. While the main lot was filled almost to capacity, parking spaces were available at two other lots at the stadium.

title: JUDGE PREVENTS USE OF WITNESS'S TAPE IN PRE-SCHOOL SEX ABUSE CASE
description: The judge presiding over the case involving charges of child molestation at a pre-school chastised the prosecution Friday for surprising a witness, who is a former prosecutor in the case, with a tape recording without first notifying the defense.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said H. Weston Clarke Jr. is retiring as senior vice president of personnel on March 31 and will be succeeded by Harold W. Burlingame.

title: CORPORATE HEDGERS GETTING AGGRESSIVE
description: The dollar's sharp decline since the start of the year has come as a pleasant surprise to corporate treasurers, who have been accustomed to using the foreign exchange markets to finance international transactions and hedge against volatile movements in currency values. Now, if they are lucky, they can play the market for a profit.

title: Princeton to Increase Fees
description: Students at Princeton University will pay 5.9 percent more in fees to attend the Ivy League school next year, according to the Board of Trustees. Under the increase, announced after a board meeting Saturday, students will pay an average of $16,918 next year, a $938 increase, Princeton officials said. Officials said $12,550 will go toward undergraduate tuition and $4,368 toward room and board. Of the eight Ivy League schools, Princeton ranked fifth in overall costs this year.

title: SIMMS IS CLOSE TO A PERFECT DAY
description: After watching years of pain threaten his career before it really began, Phil Simms changed his luck today.

title: PICKENS ALL SET FOR NEW GAME
description: T. Boone Pickens is not saying much about it, but when the last remnants of his Mesa Petroleum Company are transferred in early February to its successor, Mesa Limited Partners, it will open a door for the Texas oilman to pursue corporate takeovers outside the energy business.

title: Bernhardt Hurwood Is Dead; Wrote on Variety of Subjects
description: Bernhardt J. Hurwood, the author of 64 books on a wide variety of subjects, died of cancer Friday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 UConn Players Declared Ineligible
description: Jim Calhoun, coach of the University of Connecticut's basketball team, said today that three players have been declared ineligible because of poor academic performance.

title: HALFTIME REVIVAL INVIGORATES DEFENSE
description: ''Must be 110 degrees in there,'' said Sean Landeta, as he made his way out of the narrow box that was the Giants' locker room today in the Rose Bowl.

title: SILENT SUFFERERS, AND OTHERS
description: At the first sign of a cold she takes to her bed and remains there till it subsides. He, on the other hand, goes to the office no matter how hacking the cough, how throbbing the head. She sprains her ankle but keeps her appointments; he throws his back out and cancels everything. He wants chicken soup and conversation during recuperation; she yearns only for isolation and silence.

title: BANK'S WORKERS HOLD PARTY TO AID THE NEEDIEST APPEAL
description: Employees of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, who for eight years have held fund-raising parties for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have sent $305 to the 75th annual appeal.

title: MINISTERS COMPLAIN MARCH LEFT UNFAIR IMAGE OF TOWN
description: A day after this all-white community was crowded with up to 25,000 marchers demanding racial tolerance, ministers here complained today that Cumming had been unfairly characterized as racist.

title: AUSCHWITZ CAMP IS VISITED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch, eyes watering with emotion and the bitter cold, today touched the wall at Auschwitz against which 20,000 people were shot by the Nazis.

title: TEST FOR AQUINO: WILL THE CENTER HOLD?
description: One year after her triumphant campaign for office, President Corazon C. Aquino is fighting to defend her presidency against powerful challenges on both the left and the right.

title: BLACK POVERTY SPREADS IN 50 BIGGEST U.S. CITIES
description: When the Rev. H. V. Savage established his Kitchen for the Poor in 1969, he envisioned the free food center in the heart of Toledo's black district as a temporary measure until economic gains took root from civil rights laws and Government antipoverty programs.

title: ABORTION FOES PONDER SETBACKS
description: The snow was so heavy Thursday that many protesters had difficulty finding the rally, wandering across the Ellipse until they finally saw, off on the white horizon, a small cluster of placards and banners.

title: OVETT'S VICTORIES UPHOLD A TRADITION
description: WHEN ''Chariots of Fire'' won a bagful of Oscars five years ago, the scriptwriter, Colin Welland, received his award with the hyperbolic boast that ''The Brits are coming.'' The British film industry may not be living up to that claim, but the subject of that particular movie, British track running, is going from strong to stronger.

title: A FAULTY OFFENSE HAMPERS REDMEN
description: It will be interesting to see how Coach Lou Carnesecca responds to his team's third Big East loss of the season. For the first time in three seasons, St. John's, which rallied from 17 points behind only to drop a 64-63 decision at Syracuse on Saturday, finds itself in something of a life-or-death situation.

title: FANS SAY TRIP WAS WORTH IT
description: It has been 30 years since the Giants last won a National Football League championship, and when they finally did it again today, the fans who followed them here to Super Bowl XXI celebrated in the way that only the long-suffering faithful can.

title: DIRECTOR'S REMARK BARRED IN TRIAL
description: The judge in the manslaughter trial stemming from the making of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' has barred prosecutors from introducing a statement by the film's director, John Landis, that he ''didn't care'' about the location of a helicopter on the movie set moments before the helicopter crashed and killed three people.

title: AT HIS BEST, ELWAY COULDN'T DO IT ALL
description: Rarely has a Super Bowl team relied on one man as the Denver Broncos did today. The funny thing was, for a half John Elway seemed to be leading them to an upset of the Giants.

title: GEORGETOWN HANDS DePAUL FIRST LOSS
description: Reggie Williams's 3-point field goal with 28 seconds remaining today highlighted a 13-1 run that gave Georgetown a 74-71 victory over previously unbeaten DePaul.

title: SANTUCCI DEFENDS LUNCH PRESENCE
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens yesterday denied that he erred in spending eight hours at a luncheon with a reputed organized-crime figure in 1983, saying he was unaware at the time of the man's criminal ties.

title: BAR GROUP TO DEBATE MOVE TO CURB STATE OFFICIALS WHO ARE LAWYERS
description: A move to prohibit state officials who are lawyers from representing clients before state agencies will be debated at the 110th annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, which opens tomorrow in Manhattan.

title: 4 NEWEST BEIRUT ABDUCTIONS ATTRIBUTED TO A SHIITE GROUP
description: Two anonymous callers reportedly asserted today that an underground Moslem group had carried out the kidnapping of three American teachers and an Indian professor at a university here Saturday.

title: Haves and Have-Nots
description: It is no secret that the thrift industry is fragmented into the highly profitable and the highly unprofitable. But the Federal Home Loan Bank Board recently released figures that starkly drive the point home.

title: 2 Unreported Incidents Cited by Air Controller
description: An air traffic controller said in an interview published Friday that two supervisors at southern California's main radar center failed to report two incidents in which passenger jets passed within a few miles of each other.

title: CHAIRMAN DISMISSED AT J.W. THOMPSON AFTER BUYOUT TALKS
description: Less than a month after becoming chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, Joseph W. O'Donnell has been discharged, apparently because of his involvement in discussions with an investment banker about taking the advertising agency's parent company private through a buyout.

title: McCONKEY: 'OUR PLACE'
description: HE came out waving the white flag that has become his trademark - not the white flag of surrender but the white flag of incitement.

title: TESTING TRIED IN CAPITAL
description: Last year, virtually all of the 20,000 defendants in criminal cases in Washington, D.C., underwent drug tests voluntarily, according to the head of the program, John A. Carver.

title: Man Shoots Family, Then Kills Himself
description: A Brooklyn man, angered by a dispute with his wife, shot her and their 14-year-old son before fatally shooting himself, the police said yesterday.

title: Dr. Judith Reichman Is Married to Director
description: Dr. Judith Reichman, an obstetrician and gynecologist in private practice in Beverly Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to Gilbert Cates, a film, theater and television director. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: As Gulf War Intensifies, Oil Price Worries Grow
description: Oil specialists in the United States are deeply concerned that the escalation of the Iran-Iraq war could ultimately cause a significant shift in world oil supplies. Such a shift, by its very abruptness, could cause unsettling movements in price.

title: A Cabby Is Stabbed; Police Seek Suspects
description: A cabdriver was stabbed and left critically injured by the side of the road here Saturday night, the police reported. They said they were searching for a man and a woman suspected of the assault.

title: A WOMAN IN THE RUNNING FOR ST. PATRICK'S MARSHAL
description: The question is beginning to seem as old as the St. Patrick's Day Parade itself: When will a woman be elected grand marshal?

title: AMAKER AND TOUGH DEFENSE ARE KEEPING DUKE NEAR TOP
description: LEAD: THE Duke basketball squad had just returned to campus following a loss to Louisville in the 1986 National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game. Tinged with spring green and the promise of seasons to come, the trees lining the main quadrangle glistened festively in the midday sun as each of four senior starters addressed the small sea of assembled well-wishers.

title: Advertising; More Ads To Reflect AIDS Peril
description: TIME Inc. and The New York Times are both going to accept condom advertising, largely because of the health threat of AIDS.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Super Day in Boston: Kevin McHale scored 30 points, including 14 in a third-period surge, as the Boston Celtics defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 111-96. With their 55th straight victory at Boston Garden over an Eastern Conference rival since a loss to Milwaukee during the 1985 playoffs, the Celtics reached the halfway mark of the season with a 30-11 record, seven games ahead of the 76ers in the Atlantic Division. With Larry Bird scoring 9 of his 17 points in the first period, the Celtics charged to a 27-17 lead. Philadelphia closed to 42-39, but Boston went on a 12-6 run for a 54-45 halftime lead. The Celtics, who won their fifth straight Super Bowl Sunday game, went ahead by 31 points early in the final period.(AP) Horse Racing Aqueduct Cancellation: Because of what it termed the ''deteriorating condition'' of the track, the New York Racing Association canceled yesterday's and today's racing programs at Aqueduct. The track will be closed tomorrow as usual, and racing is expected to resume Wednesday. Skiing Zurbriggen Wins Title: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won a World Cup men's downhill ski race yesterday at Kitzbuehel, Austria, to capture the combined title and establish himself as the favorite for the Alpine world championships this week. And in a slalom race, Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia, relying on his experience and skill, placed first, beating Mathias Berthold of Austria by only eight one-hundredths of a second. Zurbriggen mastered the Streif course, measuring 3,500 meters with a vertical drop of 860 meters and 24 gates, in 1 minute 58.06 seconds, 73 one-hundredths of a second ahead of Erwin Resch of Austria. Peter Mueller of Switzerland finished third in 1:58.83. Krizaj laid the groundwork for his slalom victory with the fastest first-heat time. A strong but careful second run was enough for Krizaj to win in 1:41.84. Berthold was timed in 1:41.92, with Armin Bittner of West Germany third, only four one-hundredths of a second behind. (AP) Ski Jumping Ulaga Is Victor: Primoz Ulaga of Yugoslavia produced the day's longest jump, 121.0 meters, en route to his second 90-meter World Cup ski jumping victory of the season. Ulaga soared 113.5 meters on his second jump and gained 231.8 points to 215.8 for the second-place finisher, Miran Tepes of Yugoslavia, who had jumps of 113.5 and 109.0 meters. The event was held at Ohkurayama Hill, site of the 1972 Sapporo Winter Olympics. Steinar Braaten of Norway placed third with 208.1 points after soaring 112.0 and 107.0 meters. (AP) Track Nehemiah First: Renaldo Nehemiah won his first race in the United States in five years and Earl Bell soared a personal best 19 feet 2 3/4 inches in the pole vault Saturday night at the Pacific Northwest Bell Indoor track and field meet in Portland, Ore. Nehemiah, the world-record holder making a comeback in the hurdles after four years in professional football, won the 55-meter hurdles in a hand-timed 6.9 seconds. Roger Kingdom, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the 110-meter hurdles, was second at 7.1 seconds. (AP) Luge East German Sweep: East Germany swept all three medals yesterday in the women's singles event in the world luge championship on the Olympic bobsled and luge chute at Innsbruck-Igls, Austria. The European champion, Cerstin Schmidt, won her first world title with an aggregate time for three runs of 2 minutes 5.876 seconds. Gabriele Kohlisch was second in 2:06.235 and Ute Oberhoffner was third in 2:06.248. Joerg Hoffmann and Jochen Pietzsch of East Germany won their third consecutive world championship in the men's doubles event. West German sleds finished second and third. (AP) Road Racing Chebor Is First: Solomon Chebor of Irvington, N.J., a former all-American at Fairleigh Dickinson, braved 10-degree cold yesterday to win the New York Road Runners Club's 20-kilometer run in 1 hour 5 minutes 35 seconds in Central Park. A field of 710 men and women competed in the 12.4 mile race. Chebor crossed the finish line 1,000 yards ahead of Tom Phillips of the Central Park Track Club with a time of 1:08.15. Luis Borja of the West Side Y.M.C.A. was next in 1:09.52. Angela Hearn led the Atalanta Track Club to a sweep of the top three women's places by winning in 1:18.10.

title: Reagan Nominates 7 For Council on Arts
description: President Reagan has nominated seven people active in the arts for the National Council on the Arts, the advisory body to the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: NEW IONA COACH DRAWS ON HIS PAST
description: It has been 13 years since the U.C.L.A. Bruins had their 88-game winning streak, the longest in college basketball history, snapped by Notre Dame.

title: CITY TO SELECT DEVELOPER OF CENTER ON THE HUDSON
description: New York City is poised to make a major decision on the future of the Hudson shoreline by choosing from among three distinct plans for a 25-acre site that extends into the river, behind the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: State Secret
description: The Chinese may have taken long strides toward modernization in recent years, but when it comes to the Super Bowl they're four months behind the times. China Central Television, the country's sole network, has bought the rights to show 10 of the National Football League's 1986 regular-season and playoff games on tape, and only yesterday began broadcasting one roughly every other week, in sequence.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 26, 1987: Monday American President Co Kennametal Inc Armstrong World Indus Kentucky Utilities Black & Decker Koppers Co Consol Freightways Lubrizol Corp Foster Wheeler NWA Inc Heck's Inc Stone Container Howell Corp Wells Fargo M & E Tr TUESDAY Ball Corp Interstate Pwr Becor Western Inc Interstate Securs Becton Dickinson & Co Johnson Controls Black Hills Corp NUI Corp Borden Inc Newmont Mining Corp CILCORP Inc Norwest Corp Crompton & Knowles Rollins Inc Eaton Corp Tambrands Inc Equifax Inc U G I Corp Fedders Corp USX Corp GLENFED Inc USLIFE Corp WEDNESDAY Chevron Corp Southland Corp Georgia-Pacific Standex Intl McGraw-Hill Inc Stewart-Warner Corp Natl Medical Enterprises Taft Broadcasting Newell Co Tokheim Corp Oneida Ltd Tracor Inc Panhandle Eastern Corp Union Carbide Russell Corp Veeco Instruments SCANA Corp West Point Pepperall Shaw Industries Westinghouse Elec SmithKline Beckman Wisconsin Elec Pwr THURSDAY Anadarko Petroleum Natl Distillers & Chem CRS SIRRINE Inc Niagara Share Corp Cameron Iron Works Quaker State Oil Refining Donnelley & Sons RLC Corp Entex Inc Sonat Inc Fairfield Communities Texas Amer Bancshares Mark Controls WICOR Inc Nalco Chemical FRIDAY Holly Sugar Corp Rollins Envirnmentl Servs Kysor Industrial SPS Technologies McDonnell Douglas Corp U S Leasing Intl Mobil Corp Vulcan Materials SUNDAY ouisiana-Pacific Corp

title: RECITAL: HYNNINEN AND DAVIS
description: THE soprano Osceola Davis and the baritone Jorma Hynninen joined forces yesterday afternoon for a distinctive and unusual program of spirituals at St. Peters Lutheran Church.

title: SCORES INJURED IN CLASHES IN BRITISH PRESS DISPUTE
description: More than 180 people, mostly police officers, were injured in a night of violence over the weekend in a year-old dispute over Rupert Murdoch's switch to modern printing equipment at his newspapers here and the resulting dismissal of 5,500 workers.

title: Trump Moving Castle Account
description: The Trump Organization has switched the advertising responsibility for Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK from McCann-Erickson.

title: Appeal Is Made for 10 Kidnapped in Somalia
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that it had asked several African nations to help find 10 French medical workers kidnapped Friday from a refugee camp in Somalia.

title: Youth Is Charged In Racial Attack
description: OZONE PARK (AP)

title: How to Pick a Candidate
description: Max Hugel, who has been a businessman, political activist and high Central Intelligence Agency official, is trying to develop a conservative consensus on a 1988 Republican Presidential candidate. He has summoned 50 people, including some veterans of Ronald Reagan's successful 1980 campaign, to a meeting in Waterville Valley, N.H., Feb. 13-15, including party politicians from 15 key primary and caucus states.

title: Weirton Chief Plans to Retire
description: Robert L. Loughhead, who led the Weirton Steel Corporation as it was acquired by its employees, said Friday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Loughhead, 57 years old, told the board at its meeting that he would step down as soon as a successor was named.

title: ART: 'THE AGE OF SULTAN SULEYMAN'
description: Inch for inch, ''The Age of Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent'' is one of the most spectacular exhibitions ever set before the American public. It is also in some ways one of the most demanding. Not only does it deal with folkways remote from our own, but it also asks us to empathize with a great warrior, statesman and administrator who authorized the execution of his sons and grandsons while overseeing the growth of an empire that stretched from Aden to Algiers, from Cairo to the Crimea, and Baghdad to the outskirts of Vienna.

title: THEORY IS OFFERED ON DEPTH OF EARTH'S VOLCANIC PLUMES
description: A concept that many earth scientists regard as a key to understanding the dynamics of this planet has been challenged at a conference here on volcanoes.

title: HOWARD BEACH CASE BELONGS IN FEDERAL COURT... ALSO IN QUEENS
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Gets Bally Ruling
description: The Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission have found no antitrust problem in the request by Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, to purchase additional shares of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, officials of the Federal agencies said. Mr. Trump is already Bally's major shareholder, owning 9.9 percent of Bally stock.

title: Foreign Competition Is Winning by Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Baseball's triple crown for hitters goes to the player who leads his league in batting average, home runs and runs batted in. But there's also an unofficial triple crown for pitchers that goes to the one who leads his league in victories, strikeouts and earned run average. Has any team ever had both triple crown winners in the same season?

title: Loss Is Painful for the Fans in Denver
description: The game was not even over, but Amanda Welch had seen enough.

title: A.M.C., Workers Continue Contract Talks
description: The American Motors Corporation said its union workers had agreed to continue talks tonight past their deadline for reaching an agreement on a new labor contract. The company says the contract is crucial to a $250 million plan to keep its only United States auto plant operating.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Diamond-Star Motors Corp., Bloomington, Ill., the company formed by a joint venture between Chrysler Corp. and Mitsubishi Corp., said Friday it had chosen Automotive Industries as the supplier of its interior trim parts. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ONCE LED GEOLOGICAL AGENCY
description: Dr. Vincent Ellis McKelvey, an earth scientist who spent 46 years with the United States Geological Survey, seven of them as its director, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal paralysis, Friday at his home in St. Cloud, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: '88 PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS GETTING READY TO SPEND '87 WITH THEIR HANDS OUT
description: Fund raising for the 1988 Presidential campaign will differ markedly from other recent elections because of the lack of an obvious favorite in either party and the increased number of early primaries, according to political strategists and campaign finance experts.

title: L.I.R.R. TALKS TO RESUME
description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and eight unions still without contracts were expected to resume talks today after a weekend of informal discussions that appeared to offer little hope for an immediate settlement to the strike, now in its second week.

title: CONTROL CENTER FOR SPACE SHUTTLE IS DROPPED FROM PENTAGON BUDGET
description: Buried deep inside a new Air Force complex at the edge of the Rockies here is a steel-encased room that the Pentagon once envisioned as its own version of Mission Control in Houston, a place for the military to command classified flights of the space shuttle.

title: MUSIC: SOPRANO AND VIOLIN
description: THE soprano Elisabeth Pehlivanian and the violinist George Pehlivanian - of Armenian descent, Lebanese birth and Long Beach, Calif., residence - presented an unusual and richly rewarding program Saturday night at Weill Recital Hall.

title: The Other Jersey Giants
description: The folks at Logo 7, an Indianapolis shirt-screening concern, had a lot riding on the Super Bowl. As the largest N.F.L. licensee, the company had its workers standing by last night ready to turn out T-shirts, jerseys and other garments proclaiming the winners as league champions just as soon as the outcome was clear. And although their N.F.L. contract put them in a no-lose situation, the company's executives - just like officials for 35 other league licensees - were cheering on the Giants, for a reason that was plain. The team has many more fans than Denver does, and more fans mean more Super Bowl shirt sales for the company - an estimated 10,000 dozen, compared with 3,000 dozen for a Bronco victory.

title: IVAN R. POWELL
description: Ivan R. Powell, a designer and illustrator who taught at the Parsons School of Design, died of cancer Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Market Place; Small Buyers' Timely Moves
description: WALL STREET savants are fond of saying that small investors usually come into a bull market too late, sell too late and generally exhibit poor timing. If this is so, most small investors should have missed the extraordinary rise in the market this year and then been whipsawed by last Friday's roller-coaster market performance.

title: U.S. Opposes Baker-Hughes Merger
description: The Justice Department today announced that it would sue to block the merger of the Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation, two of the world's largest oilfield service companies.

title: Realism In Africa
description: A quiet neighbor of South Africa, Botswana is in many ways a model of what the United States would like to see in Africa: a genuine democracy, non-racial, devoted to free enterprise. Its politics earn that prized American adjective, moderate.

title: CHICAGO DEMOCRATS' RACE TIGHT
description: Mayor Harold Washington and former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, his opponent in the Democratic mayoral primary Feb. 24, are running neck-and-neck, according to a new poll.

title: CANNON LOSES SOME LUSTER
description: The Cannon Group, once the hottest little film studio in Hollywood, has fallen on hard times. And Yuram Globus has this to say for himself and his cousin Menahem Golan, who run the company: 'Our only crime is that we love cinema. You don't see us at the Polo Lounge, on the tennis court or at parties. You see us at the office seven days a week.''

title: NEW ENVOY TO PUSH U.S. ROLE IN MEXICO DRUG FIGHT
description: The new American Ambassador to Mexico plans to substantially revamp United States participation in a program with the Mexican Government to combat narcotics production, according to his advisers.

title: REFLECTIONS UPON LEAVING THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Larry Speakes has been the main press voice of the White House since the press secretary, James S. Brady, was wounded in the assassination attempt on President Reagan in March 1981. Come Feb. 2, Mr. Speakes will leave the White House to become a vice president for communications at the investment concern Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: A SHIFT IN INDONESIA'S ATTITUDE
description: In theory, all of Indonesia should work like Abu Hasan.

title: Robinson Vargas Levy Fills Health-Care Niche
description: Robinson Vargas Levy is a new health-care specialty agency that has opened at 235 Park Avenue South serving Winthrop Pharmaceuticals as agency of record and doing projects for Pfizer Laboratories and J. B. Roerig, a unit of Pfizer Inc.

title: IRAQI HINTS AT HEAVY LOSS OF JETS
description: Iraq said today that it had repelled two Iranian attacks on the southern war front and asserted that the two-week-old Iranian offensive faced final defeat. An Iranian leader said victory for Teheran's troops was in sight.

title: The New Congress's No. 1 Priority
description: A reporter recently asked me what I considered to be the first priority of the new Congress.

title: AZINGER POSTS 67 TO EDGE SUTTON
description: Paul Azinger, a 27-year-old Floridian who has been threatening to win on the PGA Tour for many months, finally got his first tour victory today, capturing the 52d Phoenix Open. He was able to edge Hal Sutton by a single shot when Sutton, the 1986 Phoenix Open winner, missed a 5-foot putt for par on the last hole.

title: Ben-Zion, a Writer, Painter And Sculptor, Is Dead at 90
description: Ben-Zion, a poet, writer, painter and sculptor, died after a heart attack Friday in his home in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: A DOW-DOLLAR LINK IS SEEN BY EXPERTS
description: The surge in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year - not counting Friday's wild gyrations - has been accompanied by a decline in the value of the dollar. There is, many experts believe, a strong link between the two.

title: McConkey Returns Gun
description: Phil McConkey, the Giants' wide receiver, appeared briefly on television after the Super Bowl game today, handing a gun to a security officer. According to a spokesman for the police, McConkey was returning a policeman's pistol that had fallen.

title: New York Pops Honor Marvin Hamlisch
description: The New York Pops - the assembly of freelance players that Skitch Henderson presents each year at Carnegie Hall - opened its season Friday evening with a first half devoted to music for the stage and a second half devoted to one of the stage's most successful composers, Marvin Hamlisch. The first segment, purely orchestral, came from shows by Offenbach (''Orpheus in the Underworld''), Bizet (''Carmen'') and Weill (''The Threepenny Opera''). The audience gave every sign of enjoying the first two, but was nonplussed by the Weill; the music stopped, but nobody noticed the suite was over until, after a brief silence, Mr. Henderson said that that was all. There was more fun than polish in the orchestral playing and conducting.

title: AC&R Given Account By Johnston & Murphy
description: Johnston & Murphy, the Nashville-based shoe manufacturer, is taking its account to AC&R Advertising.

title: DITKA AND BERRY SIZE IT UP
description: Last year's Super Bowl coaches, Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears and Raymond Berry of the New England Patriots, saw two different games yesterday when the Giants beat the Denver Broncos, 39-20, in Super Bowl XXI.

title: The Surrogate's Baby Comes First
description: A little boy's truck is a toy, not a harbinger of a career in the trucking industry. A little girl's doll is not simply a doll but a symbol of the baby she's expected to have some day. Small wonder, therefore, that women are so often devastated when they find themselves infertile. Men may wish just as fervently to be fathers but women have been programmed for parenthood, socially as well as physiologically, almost since birth.

title: HEIMEL'S 'GIRL'S GUIDE' STUDIES MODERN ROMANCE
description: When Wynn Handman, the director of the American Place Theater, first called Cynthia Heimel, the author of a humorous book on modern social mores called ''Sex Tips for Girls,'' she didn't know who he was and had never even considered writing for the theater.

title: Grey's Karp Is Named Chief Creative Officer
description: Richard M. Karp, 57, executive vice president and co-creative director of Grey Advertising with Richard R. Kiernan since 1979, has been promoted to chief creative officer.

title: 2 BROTHERS HELD IN MURDER OF 2 LINKED TO DRUGS
description: Two brothers were charged yesterday with what the police called the drug-related killings of two men whose bound and gagged bodies were found in a Brooklyn marsh early Saturday.

title: COLOMBIA WAGES A COOLER PEACE EFFORT ON REBELS
description: Barely two years ago, while artists, poets and musicians lent their talents to promote the new cause, Colombians were enthusiastically embracing the idea that a ''peace process'' could end decades of political violence here.

title: Broncos Suffer Losses in Run on Banks
description: The only drawback with running from Lawrence Taylor, as the Denver Broncos learned today, was that it led them directly into the path of Carl Banks. The Broncos and the rest of the teams in the National Football League, will now have nearly six months to devise a method of avoiding both in the future. They will probably need all of it.

title: Howard Beach Case Belongs in Federal Court... Also in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE STUDENTS DEFEND OPEN LETTER
description: Yang Xiaokai's nightmares have returned. When the 36-year-old Chinese national awakens each morning, he often recalls a haunting dream of imprisonment.

title: BOLSHOI HEAD INVITES MAKAROVA AND 2 BALLET OFFICIALS TO SOVIET
description: Yuri Grigorovich, director of the Bolshoi Ballet, said yesterday that he had invited Natalia Makarova and two prominent American ballet directors to Moscow in addition to Mikhail Baryshnikov. He said he hoped that the four would participate in a round-table discussion on the arts and sciences there next month, but added that no official invitations had yet been sent by the Soviet Government.

title: Conner Flies New Sail
description: Dennis Conner unveiled a new spinnaker today for Stars & Stripes in a practice run for the America's Cup finals. The 12-Meter flew a giant white spinnaker with three rows of pockets along the upper half of the balloon sail. The use of pockets appears to increase the sail area of the spinnaker and give added lift to the sail. The America's Cup finals are scheduled to begin Saturday. Iain Murray, project director and skipper of the cup defenders, spent today doing speed trials between Kookaburra II and III. Murray won the right to defend the cup aboard Kookaburra III, but he has an option to substitute Kookaburra II. Murray and the Kookaburra syndicate must announce their decision by Monday night.

title: SHOW FOR SPORTSMAN
description: NEW YORK is going to have its first sportsman's show since the late Daily Mirror's Coliseum-based event closed for good more than a decade ago, and it may seem incongruous, given the city's tough gun control regulations, that the new event is slanted strongly toward the hunter.

title: Aaronson Shop Chosen
description: Aaronson, Bartolone, Pearlman Advertising, which resulted from the Jan. 1 merger of AMS Advertising and Shapiro, Bartolone & Budrow, has been selected by Fremarques Ltd. to handle the United States introduction of The Antiquary, a 12-year-old Scotch whisky from J&W Hardie, a subsidiary of the Guinness Beverage Group. The $1 million budget will be spent in 15 markets.

title: Monday Night Football
description: Maintaining Super Bowl suspense is also a matter for Japanese fans, several million of whom will stay home tonight to watch the game on delayed tape. Because the broadcast begins 10 hours after the final gun, the trick is to get through the day without learning the result. The Tokyo Broadcasting System could have gone live and, in fact, did provide a live closed-circuit hookup Monday morning, local time, at the Tokyo American Club and the Hilton Hotel, where a seat cost $50, breakfast included. But a telecast at that hour for a general audience would have been a commercial flop, says a network spokesman, Kazuo Date, who takes a philosophic approach. ''An exciting thing,'' he says, ''is exciting even if you know the score.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page article Saturday about a guilty plea by Mark W. Hoffman in two bombing deaths in Utah in 1985 misidentified the prosecutor. He was Robert Stott, not Robert Scott.

title: TRADERS PONDERING THE CROSSCURRENTS
description: Overshadowed by the gyrations of the equity market, Treasury notes and bonds traded listlessly last week with a trend toward lower prices and higher yields.

title: Trade Bank Chief Looks To Far East for Growth
description: World Trade Bank N.A. has named John F. King chairman and chief executive of the Los Angeles-based merchant and commercial banking organization. The bank is controlled by a group of investors that includes former Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, Roy Doumani, Larry B. Thrall and Gerald L. Parsky.

title: PARENTHOOD THEN AND NOW
description: With the average age of marriage increasing and growing numbers of women postponing childbearing to pursue careers, women age 35 and older gave birth to 224,000 babies in 1984, a 36 percent increase since 1980, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Yet, contrary to the widespread perception of late childbearing as a recent yuppie phenomenon, older parents were actually more common in earlier decades. In 1960, for example, 457,000 babies, or 10 percent of the nation's total, were born to women 35 and over, compared with about 6 percent in 1984.

title: REORGANIZED CHURCH OF LATTER DAY SAINTS BATTLES A NEW SPLIT
description: In secret councils that go on long into the night, leaders of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints are trying to resolve troubles that have erupted here, near a site hallowed in their beliefs.

title: Moving Commentary
description: The latest Washington bumper sticker reflecting, in a historical vein, the Iran-Nicaragua investigations reads: ''Release the Reagan Tapes.''

title: THE U.N. TODAY: JAN. 26, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Drafting Committee for Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Chip Maker Shows Profit
description: Texas Instruments Inc. returned to profitability in 1986. The Dallas-based company said it earned $29.1 million, or 71 cents a share, for the year in contrast to a loss of $118.7 million in 1985.

title: DANCE: PARIS TROUPE'S 'ROMEO' IN BRONX
description: NEW dance troupes seem to be sprouting up constantly in France nowadays, and inevitably, not all of them can be top-flight. Nor do they all have the same purpose.

title: China Says a College Student Spied for American Reporter
description: A Chinese university student was arrested today and charged with passing ''intelligence'' to an American journalist, according to the New China News Agency.

title: He'll Drink to That
description: For someone who has been following the Giants only two months, Dr. J. Robert Cade was pulling awfully hard for them to win last night. Cade isn't a New Yorker, has no nephew on the team and made no big bet. It's just that he's been getting special delight from the victory ritual in which Harry Carson sneaks up on Coach Bill Parcells and dumps a cooler of Gatorade on his head.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods OrdersDecember Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Merchandise Trade BalanceDecember Farm PricesJanuary

title: 'ALAMO: 13 DAYS TO GLORY,' ON NBC
description: SHOULD we fight the Battle of the Alamo again? John Wayne did it last in 1960; there were films before that, too. Davy Crockett, Jim Bowie and a handful of Texans met Santa Anna. Comes now ''The Alamo: 13 Days to Glory,'' a three-hour movie on NBC. Don't ignore it, however, just because you know how the battle turns out. The new ''Alamo,'' at 8 o'clock tonight, is a very decent production.

title: CANADIANS ANXIOUS TO PRESERVE U.S. AUTO PACT
description: A ready measure of Canada's thriving auto industry can be taken from the 270-mile section of Highway 401 that links Oshawa, east of Toronto, with the border at Detroit.

title: KOHL KEEPS POWER BY NARROWER EDGE IN WEST GERMANY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition won a parliamentary majority today that will permit it to govern West Germany for another four years.

title: British Telephone Engineers Call Strike Over Suspensions
description: About 117,000 engineers began a nationwide strike today that could halt repairs to most of Britain's telephone and data services, officials said.

title: Outlook for China Trade
description: Despite recent student demonstrations in China and the ouster of the party head, Hu Yaobang, both of which raise questions about future Government policy, American business remains optimistic about prospects for the continued growth of trade and investment in China.

title: Arab Currency Talks
description: The governor of Kuwait's central bank, Sheik Salem Abdul-Aziz al-Saud al-Sabah, said today that monetary officials of Persian Gulf states will meet in Abu Dhabi to discuss a common exchange rate. The meeting will bring together central bank governors and directors of monetary authorities in the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council. Member nations in the group are Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

title: INSIDE
description: L.I.R.R. Fights Rust A handful of trains continue to run on the Long Island Rail Road, keeping the tracks polished and checking safety systems. Page B3. Poverty of Blacks Spreads More blacks are living in poverty, a new study says, and they are becoming increasingly concentrated in the nation's largest cities. Page A27. Chinese Defend Letter Chinese students in the United States, defending an open letter of protest to Beijing, say their fears of persecution have been rekindled. Page A3.

title: PENTAGON CURBING PUBLIC DATA ON 'STAR WARS'
description: The Pentagon office in charge of ''Star Wars'' research is tightening the flow of information to the public, according to Government officials and experts outside the Government.

title: Cardinal Assesses Foster-Care Dispute
description: ''The door is always open'' to a settlement in the continuing dispute between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese and New York City over foster-care programs, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday. But he said the archdiocese would not compromise in its opposition to providing family-planning information to youngsters in the program.

title: KAISER WORKERS LOSE BENEFITS
description: Company-paid medical benefits for more than 5,000 retired and active workers of the Kaiser Steel Corporation have been canceled because the company cannot afford them, according to a letter sent to employees.

title: Washington Watch; S.E.C. Weighs 1 Share, 1 Vote
description: THE issue of one share, one vote is slowly making its way through the Securities and Exchange Commission and it appears that the agency regulating Wall Street will come up with a compromise before the end of March.

title: Joan Fishman Is the Bride Of Michael Elliot Salzman
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in New York yesterday Joan Renee Fishman and Michael Elliot Salzman, associates at the New York law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, were married by Rabbi Philip M. Weinberger.

title: DANCE: EVENING OF DUETS IN FESTIVAL
description: NEW YORKERS had their first glimpse of a fascinating ballet by George Balanchine on Saturday night when a duet from ''Mozart Violin Concerto'' received its New York premiere as part of ''Festival of Dance Stars 1987,'' a program of pas de deux at Brooklyn College. It was a real discovery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 26, 1987
description: International

title: TO LIVE UNNOTICED, 17-YEAR FUGITIVE SAYS, 'WEAR A RED HAT'
description: Silas Bissell, arrested here last week as a suspect in a 1970 attempt to bomb the University of Washington, said he would rather be in jail than live the life of a fugitive as he has for 17 years.

title: ON 5, AMERICAN P.O.W.'S
description: THE original black-and-white enemy footage in ''P.O.W. -Americans in Enemy Hands: World War II, Korea and Vietnam'' strongly resembles and confirms the wild battle scenes in the current movie ''Platoon.'' The voices of nine Americans who were prisoners of war are heard tonight at 8 o'clock on Channel 5.

title: PAUSE NOW IS EXPECTED FOR STOCKS
description: The illness that hit the stock market Friday and caused a stunning reversal of luck for many investors is likely to take at least a few days to get out of Wall Street's system, market experts believe.

title: People
description: * F. Christopher Labash has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director at Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: Pittsburgh at Syracuse (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7 P.M.); Michigan State at Northwestern (ESPN, 9 P.M.) HOCKEY DEVILS VS. RANGERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.)

title: BONN HAS YET TO DECIDE ON EXTRADITING SUSPECT
description: West Germany has yet to decide if it will extradite to the United States a suspected Lebanese hijacker whose detention may have triggered the latest kidnappings in Beirut.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about a contract for Navistar International to supply diesel engines to Ford Motor misstated its expiration date. The contract, which was to end in 1990, was extended for an unspecified time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 26, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Only Short-Term Issues This Week
description: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills, but government securities dealers are looking ahead to a heavy supply of notes and bonds next week.

title: HAIR PROFILES, BY COMPUTER
description: There was a time when only your hairdresser knew for sure. Not anymore. If you patronize any of the area's leading hair salons, an army of chemists, computer programmers and shrewd marketers may know more about your hair than you thought there was to know in the first place.

title: North Korea Offers an Arms-Control Opening
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Even for the Expert Player, Accidents in Bidding Occur
description: When an expert partnership sits down to play in a major event the players are likely to have hours, or days, of theoretical discussion in the bank. But accidents can happen when they have had little prior conversation about bidding methods.

title: PRESERVING UGLY SIDE OF HISTORY
description: The real estate would seem to be some of the most desirable in California: a 432-acre island, just 20 miles north of San Francisco, overlooking the San Pablo and San Francisco Bays.

title: 'Competitiveness,' Not Industrial Policy
description: LEAD: In the early 1980's, after a short, controversial life, ''industrial policy'' was declared politically dead and buried. Six years later, Lazarus-like, it is back, looking healthier than ever and sporting a brand new name: ''national competitiveness.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COASTING. By Jonathan Raban. Illustrated with map. 302 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IN his new book, ''Coasting,'' the English travel writer and novelist Jonathan Raban does just what his title will suggest if you connect it to the silhouette of a sailboat and the map of the British Isles that also appear on the front of the book's dust jacket. He buys a 40-foot ketch named the Gosfield Maid, has her overhauled and outfitted as a floating home, and sails her counterclockwise around England, Scotland and Wales.

title: White House Classifieds
description: The White House is in the market for two people who are conversant with economic policy. Alfred H. Kingon, the Cabinet secretary who is also Chief of Staff Donald T. Regan's No. 1 man on economic issues, is leaving to become ambassador to the European Community in Brussels once the Senate approves him for the post.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Nina Beilina Performs In a Varied Program
description: Nina Beilina's violin recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was - either by design or accident - rarely devoted to the beauty of the instrument or the virtues of virtuosity. Miss Beilina's program was largely somber, often dense with complexity, even grim.

title: Liberia's Sad Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Tool Orders Down 16% Last Year
description: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 2.6 percent in December from November, but orders for all of 1986 dropped 16 percent compared to 1985, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: RUSSIANS HOLD KEY TO POWER, BUT NOT TO AFGHANISTAN'S SOUL
description: The rug merchants speak Russian, but gladly accept personal checks for dollars that they deposit in New York bank accounts.

title: NEW YORK CITY PLANS VOLUNTARY DRUG TESTS IN FELONY ARRESTS
description: The Koch administration, in a move that has come under criticism from civil-liberties groups, is planning to begin asking people arrested on felony charges to undergo drug tests voluntarily before their first court appearance or arraignment.

title: MUSIC: 'FOCUS!' FESTIVAL AT JUILLIARD AND TULLY
description: THE Juilliard School has long presented public new-music concerts, primarily as part of its students' education but also as an admission-free offering to the New York audience. The concerts used to be rather randomly programmed, but since Joseph W. Polisi became Juilliard's president, and since Joel Sachs took over the concerts, there has been an annual attempt to focus them into a festival entitled ''Focus!,'' and to provide each installment with a theme.

title: How to Pick an Issue
description: A Presidential election offers a golden opportunity for issue-oriented special interest groups. Such a group can press candidates to take a position on its key issue in the nominating competition and in the general election. If both finalists endorse the group's position - say, more national parks or no compulsory drug testing - favorable publicity results, and something might actually happen in the next Administration. But how do such pressure groups, often relatively small, poor and politically inexperienced, inject themselves into the campaign?

title: Israeli Move Sparks Debate
description: The former head of the Tel Aviv stock exchange, criticized over a 1983 collapse of bank shares, was appointed Friday as the new chairman of Bank Leumi L'Yisrael, Israel's biggest commercial bank. But the appointment of Meir Heth, intended to restore confidence at the bank after the entire board resigned in protest over huge payoffs to its former chairman, Ernst Japhet, instead caused new controversy.

title: Karlis of Broncos Bears Brunt of Loss
description: Rich Karlis's eyes were red from tears. There were no answers in his eyes, only questions about why he had failed on two critical field-goal attempts in the first half of the Super Bowl.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MAKING BELIEVE A large exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center gets you close to the ingredients of spectacle, to the very real objects designed to make your mind accept imaginary settings. ''Art Behind the Scenes,'' in the main second-floor gallery of the library, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, displays 125 objects made by more than 60 artists for theater, movies and opera.

title: Subsidized Exploitation
description: To the Editor:

title: 41 VICTIMS: ROLL OF VIOLENCE
description: Forty-one people were slain here last year, according to the police. These are the victims and the dates they were attacked:

title: GIANTS ROUT BRONCOS IN THE SUPER BOWL
description: The Giants won the Super Bowl today, emphatically.

title: HOUSTON IN LEAD FOR DEMOCRATS IN '88
description: Houston has emerged as the leading candidate for host of the 1988 Democratic national convention, even though party leaders prefer New Orleans, according to Democrats close to the process.

title: Philadelphia Entree For Hungry Banker
description: Robert Van Buren, known as the Hungry Banker, is getting ready to swallow Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia and expand into Pennsylvania from New Jersey.

title: Deal Gives Philippines New Hope in Debt Talks
description: An agreement reached on Friday by what is known as the Paris Club to reschedule $870 million of Philippine debt is expected to help the Government of Corazon C. Aquino in other long-stalled debt negotiations, bankers and Government officials said last week.

title: TIME MELLOWS FRANCE: IS IT READY FOR HENRI VI?
description: If he had his way, the Count of Paris, whose full name is Henri Robert Ferdinand Marie Louis-Philippe d'Orleans, the head of the royal House of France and a direct descendant of such luminaries as Louis XIV, would reign in France as a modern constitutional monarch called Henri VI.

title: PAKISTAN APPEALS TO INDIA ON CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo called on India today to enter into immediate negotiations to defuse tensions rising from the massing of troops in each country on their mutual border. He declared that Pakistan had no aggressive intentions toward India.

title: Blue Monday
description: To many of the 130 million or so Americans who watched it, the Super Bowl was also the Super Bet. The game is by far the biggest betting event of the year, drawing more than $40 million legally in Nevada, Las Vegas, and hundreds of millions illegally in the 49 other states. ''People who bet $25 on a game during the season will be betting $100 on the Super Bowl, and $100 bettors will be betting $500,'' says Tony, an otherwise anonymous recovering compulsive gambler who helps man the hot line (689-7500) for Gamblers Anonymous in New York.

title: USX SEEN PLANNING SELL-OFFS
description: The USX Corporation is considering the sale of some, if not all, of the businesses that make up its diversified products group as the initial part of its long-awaited restructuring, Wall Street and industry sources believe.

title: IN BRIDGEPOPRT, A SHARP RISE IN MURDER RATE
description: A startling jump in murders here is being blamed on a burgeoning drug traffic that has become more profitable - and more violent -than ever.

title: LEFTIST CHIEF EASES CRITICISM
description: The confirmed death toll in last Thursday's clash between leftist demonstrators and security forces rose to 18 today. At the same time, a leader of a major leftist organization softened its criticism of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: A Human Rights Meeting in Moscow?
description: LEAD: Resumption this week of the Helsinki review conference in Vienna will again focus world attention on Mikhal S. Gorbachev's challenging ''new style'' in the human rights field. Since the emphasis of the meeting will now shift from review of how the Helsinki accords have been implemented to discussion of new ''proposals,'' the Soviet delegation is certain to press its proposal for a conference on human rights to be held in

title: 4 Mets to Appear In Court Today
description: Four Mets charged in July after an incident at a Houston nightclub are scheduled to appear in court Monday.

title: Alabama Family Dies in Fire
description: All five members of a family died in a fire Saturday that apparently was touched off by a wood-burning heater used since a snowstorm cut off electricity to their mobile home last week, the authorities said. The victims apparently died in their sleep.

title: 5-NATION PARLEY ON DOLLAR POLICY IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The United States and its biggest economic allies are negotiating arrangements for a meeting to discuss the dollar and the ways their economic policies affect it, European and Japanese officials said today.

title: How U.S. and Mexican Workers Lose Together
description: To the Editor:

title: OLDER PARENTS' CHILD: GROWING UP SPECIAL
description: ''When I realized my parents were older than other kids', I felt embarrassed and angry, that they weren't like the parents on TV,'' said Rich Simon, a Washington psychotherapist whose parents were in their 40's when he was born. ''Because they died fairly young, I became sort of an orphan at a relatively early age.''

title: SORTING OUT THE NEW YORKER PROTEST
description: More than a week after 154 contributors and staff members of The New Yorker wrote a letter to their newly appointed editor asking him to decline the job, their protest continues to preoccupy literary and journalistic circles.

title: Mingo-Jones to Become G.M. Minority Agency
description: Mingo-Jones Advertising, a black-owned agency that specializes in minority advertising, has been selected from a field of more than 12 similar shops to be the General Motors Corporation's first such agency.

title: ONLY GIANTS LIKED ENDING
description: SANDY GROSSMAN, CBS's director of Super Bowl XXI, was asked last week about what things could go wrong to make his job more difficult. Equipment could falter, he said, but that didn't really concern him because the technology has long been reliable. His real worry was a blowout.

title: WINNIE MANDELA QUESTIONED AND FREED
description: Winnie Mandela, one of South Africa's most outspoken black campaigners, was taken by the police for questioning tonight but later released, her lawyer said.

title: DAY BY DAY: BUILDING TO INTENSITY
description: Brad Benson, the Giants' offensive left tackle, is in his ninth year with the club, longer than all but two of his teammates. This was his best season individually. He was selected as the National Conference player of the week after his performance against Washington Dec. 7 - an uncommon honor for an offensive lineman - and soon afterward was named to his first Pro Bowl.

title: NO MORE WAITING FOR NO. 1; GIANTS' FANS ENJOY THE DAY
description: At the moment that Raul Allegre's toe touched the ball and the clock began ticking on Super Bowl XXI, Bruce Jagoda popped the cork on a bottle of champagne. ''It's over now,'' said the 39-year-old financial analyst.

title: A Matter of Pay
description: The Department of Defense and the White House's Office of Management and Budget seem at odds over raises for senior officers of the armed forces. Next month, unless Congress disapproves, Cabinet officers, sub-Cabinet officials, members of Congress and Federal judges will receive salary increases of up to 16 percent. An under secretary's pay, for example, will go up 8 percent, to $82,500.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The ''Your Money'' column in Business Day on Jan. 10, about Individual Retirement Accounts, misstated conditions for their tax deductibility.

title: A COLD, QUIET DAY
description: It was a day to stay home or venture out into an unfamiliar New York.

title: Gerry Mulligan's Band Regroups at Blue Note
description: Gerry Mulligan's Concert Jazz Band, which has existed sporadically since 1960, came together this past weekend for a tantalizing three-night appearance at the Blue Note.

title: Goodbye, Mr. Chips
description: As predicted here not one month ago with stunning prescience (I never forget the ones I get right), the hot new verb of the year is ''out-compete.'' In his State of the Union address, the President will hustle to get out front of the caravan of competitiveness (h'ray!) that has become the euphemism for the parade of protectionism (boo!).

title: DAZZLING GIANTS PULL OUT ALL THE STOPS
description: They were better than good and maybe even great. But they were more than that; they were also what every championship team aspires to be. They were resourceful. For it was not always the blowout it now seems because of the lopsided nature of the score. For more than two quarters, it was close, nail-biting close. The Giants had seen enough of John Elway, the magnificent Denver quarterback, to know what he might be capable of.

title: Ewa Demarcyzk Sings At Town Hall
description: Ewa Demarczyk, who is renowned in her homeland as ''The Black Angel of Polish Song,'' is one of the few international popular singers with the vocal resources, theatrical command and musical discrimination to transcend, at least partially, the language barrier that makes so many European performers inaccessible to American audiences.

title: Tame the High Tech Monster
description: In March 1983 an American company won an order to sell an advanced medical spectrometer to Eastern Europe but had to wait 910 days for an export license. The Pentagon feared, needlessly, that one computer chip and hard disk drive in the machine might be of military help to the Russians.

title: Washington Heights Copes With Change
description: IN four decades at what they are sure is Washington Heights's oldest business -Sachs Trimming Store, 4232 Broadway, founded 1911 - Charlotte and Bert Cohen have had to accommodate themselves to a number of changes.

title: THEATER: 'MURDERER,' ONE-ACT BY KOKOSCHKA
description: IN common with other artists, Oskar Kokoschka was drawn to the theater as a place in which to re-enact primal passions. In 1909, the young Kokoschka staged his own one-act Expressionist play, ''Murderer, Hope of Women,'' in the Kunstschau garden theater in Vienna, and, according to the painter, it provoked a storm of protest.

title: Democracy in the Military? Sort Of
description: On June 21, Gen. John A. Wickham Jr. must step down as Chief of Staff of the Army because the law allows him exactly four years in office, and not a day more. On June 30, Gen. P. X. Kelley will end his term as Commandant of the Marine Corps for the same reason.

title: IN A 'RANDOM WORLD,' HE COLLECTS PATTERNS
description: WITHOUT quite meaning to, Neil J. A. Sloane has become the world's clearinghouse for number sequences.

title: ANTIBODIES REDESIGNED AS POTENT NEW TOOLS
description: ANTIBODIES, the most familiar and longest known of the body's defenders against infectious disease, are being drafted into extraordinary roles new to medicine and biological research.

title: Bringing the Reality of Babies to the Classroom; Lives Gone Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $415,000 and $471,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pigskin Rams
description: Through the 1930's, Fordham basked in the glory of its football teams. Some five decades later, this season's Ram basketball team still seems haunted by reminders of football.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a special charge for both the quarter and year of $432.7 million, net of income taxes, representing a writedown in the book value of certain ocean-going tankers and a provision for marine transportation costs in excess of market rates.

title: Japan's Target Is 3.5% Growth
description: The Japanese Government adopted an economic growth target today of 3.5 percent for the fiscal year beginning April 1, up slightly from the 3 percent expected in the current year. Approval of the target came at a special Cabinet meeting.

title: 2 OTHERS REFINERS DROP
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, yesterday reported an 18 percent earnings drop in the fourth quarter despite firming prices and nearly $500 million of special gains.

title: REAGAN SAYS MEN SEIZED IN LEBANON IGNORED WARNINGS
description: Expressing frustration at his Administration's inability to prevent the seizure of Americans in Lebanon, President Reagan said today that the three men abducted Saturday had ignored official warnings and stayed in Beirut ''at their own risk and on their own responsibility.''

title: Merrill Net Up Sharply In Quarter
description: In a sign of the enormously profitable environment that most of Wall Street has been enjoying, Merrill Lynch & Company, the country's largest brokerage house, reported yesterday that its net earnings nearly tripled in the fourth quarter.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1.7 million for the quarter and for the year includes income from discontinued operations of $33.3 million plus an extraordinary credit of $18 million and a charge of $27.2 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $7.4 million and $25.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said its results for the fourth quarter and full year 1985 have been restated to reflect separately as discontinued operations the results of the former controls division, which was sold on June 30, 1986; the results of the former sewing and related products operations and furniture division, which have been combined into a separate, stand-alone company; and costs associated with the spun-off operations.

title: PITT ENDS 26-YEAR LOSS STREAK
description: Jerome Lane scored 26 points and dominated inside with 15 rebounds as Pittsburgh beat Syracuse, 84-70, in a Big East Conference game tonight, breaking a 26-year losing streak in the home of the Orangemen.

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Progressive Bar To Greenfield Plan
description: The Progressive Savings and Loan Association said the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had given it permission to withdraw its conditional approval of Greenfield Partners' application to take over the association. Progressive Savings, based in Alhambra, Calif., which has assets of $500 million and 10 branch offices in southern California, was put under the conservatorship of the bank board last summer. Greenfield Partners, a New York investment firm, is Progressive's largest shareholder.

title: Careers; Foreigners' Takeover Attempts
description: SMALL, prosperous companies that expect to keep doing well may find themselves the object of foreign takeover attempts. That is the gist of a recent survey by the Research Institute of America, a private organization. Most of its members are closely held companies with sales of $50 million or less.

title: WINNIE MANDELA SAYS POLICE TOOK A SHACKLED MAN INTO HER HOME
description: Winnie Mandela, the prominent opponent of apartheid, said today that the police brought an unidentified man in leg irons into her home while they searched the house before Mrs. Mandela and her daughter, Zinzi, were detained Sunday.

title: The Next Hijacking
description: Next week an airplane will be hijacked and the passengers, many of them American, will be taken hostage.

title: WITHHELD SHUTTLE DATA: A DEBATE OVER PRIVACY
description: NEWS organizations have intensified their efforts to gain access to unreleased information on the space shuttle Challenger disaster, prompting a debate on the limits of privacy and the public interest that seems likely to be decided in the Federal courts.

title: SECOND BIG STORM IN 5 DAYS STRIKES EASTERN SEABOARD
description: The second major storm in five days struck the East Coast and the New York metropolitan region yesterday. High winds and heavy snows reglazed the city, buried some suburbs in mountainous drifts and brought a reprise of winter doldrums.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,456,000 from costs associated with United First Federal's conversion to a state-chartered bank. The 1986 figures reflect the merger of United First Federal and Barnett, accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: STAGE: ACTORS COLLECTIVE IN 'TIME AND TIMBUKTU'
description: ''I THINK I am traveling through my own dreams and nightmares,'' says Stony Stevenson toward the end of the first act of Kurt Vonnegut Jr.'s ''Between Time and Timbuktu.'' That doesn't explain or excuse this ''space fantasy,'' but it offers an inkling of what was in Mr. Vonnegut's mind, which is helpful since the contents are tumbled incoherently onto the stage of the Courtyard Playhouse.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $123 million for the quarter and year from reversal of previously recorded income taxes. c-After an extraordinary gain of $29,440,000 from a change in accounting methods.

title: MCKESSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.6 million for the quarter and $4.4 million for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and $1.3 million for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months results are after a pre-tax gain of $23.1 million from the sale of two million shares of the company's PCS Inc. subsidiary in an initial public offering in November, less a $10 million contribution to the capital of the McKesson Foundation. The net effect of the special items was to increase after-tax income by $10.6 million, or 22 cents a share.

title: ARMY DISSIDENTS REPORTED FOILED IN MANILA RAIDS
description: Dissident soldiers were blocked in an attempt today to take over key military installations, broadcasting stations and public utilities, Government and military spokesmen said.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fewer Oil Rigs Active
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States has dropped to 837, down 49 from a week ago amid a traditional seasonal decline, the Hughes Tool Company said today. One year ago its rig count was 1,671.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARA: A GRAND OLD NAME AGAIN
description: In their frustration of other years, many Giants fans thought the co-owners didn't want to win and the quarterback didn't know how to win. But as the Super Bowl XXI champions, the Giants indeed are the giants of pro football now. And after three decades, again.

title: REAGAN'S REMARKS SEEM TO ILLUSTRATE HOW A GANG CAN FOIL A SUPERPOWER
description: The Reagan Administration, which has made fighting terrorism such a visible priority, now finds itself with no attractive options in the face of the kidnappings of three Americans in Beirut over the weekend.

title: DARLING, TEUFEL GET PROBATION
description: The Mets brought their busy legal season to a sudden and successful close today when charges of fighting police officers at a Houston nightclub last summer were reduced for two of their players and dismissed for two others.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 2, 1986.

title: CRANE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said prior year sales includes Unidynamics Corp. from its acquisition in February 1985.

title: WALKING UNDER MANHATTAN'S STREETS
description: Kyle York considers himself an ''urban submarine.'' ''I intend to find ways to get around New York without ever stepping outside,'' declares Mr. York, an advertising man, who darts through building lobbies when he cannot dive underground.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $41.6 million from writedown of an investment and $12.2 million pre-tax gain from sale of assets.

title: CONGRESS AT WORK ON CATASTROPHIC-ILLNESS PLAN
description: Congress today began work on legislation to establish an insurance program for catastrophic illness without waiting for President Reagan to submit proposals in his State of the Union Message.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: CITY BALLET IN BALANCHINE'S 'SWAN LAKE'
description: JOHN MEEHAN brought a touch of melancholic poetry to George Balanchine's ''Swan Lake,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. Mr. Meehan, a guest artist at City Ballet and former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has a romantic presence that brought added luster to this version of the ballet's second act, set to the familiar Tchaikovsky score.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a federal income tax research and development credit of $19 million. The company said a change in its accounting for employee pension plans effective Jan. 1, required by FASB 87, will result in a significant reduction of 1987 pension cost relative to the 1986 level of $215 million.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: SYNAGOGUE IS URGED NEAR AUSCHWITZ SITE OF CONVENT BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch today proposed to Franciszek Cardinal Macharski of Cracow that a synagogue be constructed near a recently opened Carmelite cloister at Auschwitz that has offended some Jewish groups.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RUSSIAN STUDIES. By Leonard Schapiro. Edited by Ellen Dahrendorf, with an introduction by Harry Willetts. 400 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.
