LEONARD SCHAPIRO, who died in 1983 at the age of 75, was a leading authority on 19th- and 20th-century Russian politics and ideas. Born in Glasgow, he was taken back to Russia and spent his childhood in Riga and St. Petersburg, but returned to Britain with his parents in 1920 and completed his education in London.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The front-page ''Sports of The Times'' column in some editions of SportsMonday yesterday, along with its headline, incorrectly described the recording of ''New York, New York'' that was played at the Super Bowl. It was sung by Liza Minelli.

title: NEW BATTLE OF AUTO INCENTIVES
description: The General Motors Corporation, which swore off sales incentives last year because of their high cost, has apparently touched off another war of incentives.

title: TRINOVA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,330,000 and a gain on sale of the company's glass business of $85 million. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,804,000 and $19,538,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said results for the latest quarter and year include a provision for restructuring charges amounting to $19.3 million pretax in the quarter and $52.6 million pretax for the full year.

title: Officer Is Suspended For Shooting at Cab
description: A New York City police officer has been suspended without pay after he fired four shots at the back of a taxicab whose driver had refused to give a ride to the officer and a friend, the police said.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,894,000 for the quarter and $16,740,000 for the year. The year also includes an extraordinary gain of $2,595,000 from renegotiation of executory contract. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,136,000. d-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $2,479,000 and a loss of $16,191,000 from cumulative effect on prior years of change in revenue recognition policy. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Robert Lee Henry, 80, Dies: Founded Hemophilia Charity
description: Robert Lee Henry, a tax lawyer and founder of the National Hemophilia Foundation, died Saturday of Alzheimer's disease at Wellington Regional Medical Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Wellington, Fla., and Locust Valley, L.I.

title: 3 MIDAIR CRASHES SPUR U.S. TO WEIGH NEW SAFETY RULES
description: Three midair collisions in two weeks, two involving small airliners, have spurred Government consideration of new safety measures to supplement programs already in the works.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 100-percent dividend paid in November 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Jan. 14 about the suspension of two Houston Rocket players for drug use misidentified the laboratory that conducted the tests. It was the Psychiatric Diagnostic Laboratories of America.

title: AFFILIATED BANK CORP OF WYOING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Viola Gets $837,000
description: Frank Viola, a Hempstead, L.I., native, who last season won 16 games for Minnesota, reached agreement with the Twins yesterday on a one-year contract for $837,000, a healthy raise from the $674,000 salary he won in salary arbitration last year.

title: More of the Same From Bonn?
description: The message of Sunday's West German election seems to be more of the same. Chancellor Helmut Kohl is back, if slightly chastened, for what promises to be another round of friendly oratory followed by cautious and even timid action. In other words, Bonn is unlikely to help much in making tough decisions about the international economy or East-West relations.

title: A Service for David Maysles
description: A memorial service for David Maysles, the documentary film maker, is to be held Thursday at 6:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. Mr. Maysles, who was noted for the cinema verite films he made with his brother Albert, died Jan. 3 at the age of 54. The service, which is open to the public, is to be followed by a reception.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (INDIANA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $647,000 for the quarter and $2,934,000 for the year. Earnings per share for 1985 have been restated to reflect the 10 percent dividend paid June 2, 1986.

title: IT'S THE WEEK OF THE YEAR OF THE RABBIT
description: ''Gung Hay Fat Choy!'' 400 pupils roared yesterday at the Edward Hart Elementary School in Flushing, Queens.

title: Firm Dollar Unaffected By Reports on Meeting
description: The dollar closed essentially unchanged against most major foreign currencies in light trading yesterday, despite reports that the Group of Five finance ministers planned to meet Feb. 7 to discuss foreign-exchange stabilization measures.

title: More Products in Stores
description: The December tally of new product introductions in supermarkets and drug chains came to 203, an increaase of 28 from December 1985, according to the DFS-Dorland New Product News. That brought the total for the year to 2,530, up from 2,206 in 1985.

title: ARGENTINE UNIONS IN 24-HOUR STRIKE
description: Labor unions shut down industry, transport and commerce across Argentina today in a 24-hour general strike against the economic policies of President Raul Alfonsin.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes after-tax benefits of $62 million representing the net effect of oil and gas asset sales and costs associated with the 1986 restructuring of Dallas-based oil and gas operations and a credit of $18 million from the adoption of new pension accounting. These credits were offset by an approximate $35 million after-tax reduction in investment tax credits (retroactive to Jan. 1, 1986), a $24 million after-tax charge associated with the writedown and sale of the company's agriculture-biotechnology businesses and $18 million after-tax charge for costs incurred in the restructuring of Arco Chemical Co. c-After a $164 million after-tax charge for a settlement of department of energy claims. d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $535 million.

title: Inflation Up in Belgium
description: Consumer prices have risen 0.55 percent in January, the Government said today. Belgium's annual inflation rate grew to 0.88 percent this month from 0.59 percent in December. Higher gas and medical costs were cited.

title: DANCE: LYONS TROUPE'S 'CINDERELLA'
description: BECAUSE Maguy Marin's production of ''Cinderella'' for the Lyons Opera Ballet is performed by dancers who wear masks and are meant to look like dolls, there would seem to be little range available to performers in individual roles.

title: ARC AMERICA TO BUY AGGREGATES CONCERN
description: The American Aggregates Corporation, a mining and concrete products company based in Greenville, Ohio, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Arc America Corporation for $30.63 a share, or $242 million.

description: b-Includes a loss equivalent to 9 cents a share from the sale of the company's seeds business and furane products, a subsidiary, for the quarter, and for the year includes charges totaling 45 cents a share for costs related to the settlement of litigation and for writeoffs associated with the company's seeds business. c-Includes a gain of 7 cents a share from divestiture of certain assets.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Detroit is tentatively offering $107 million of sewer disposal system refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 6.967 percent for bonds due in 2007 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: OPERA: ARGENTO WORK, 'CHRISTOPHER SLY'
description: THE idea on which Dominick Argento based ''Christopher Sly'' - his fourth opera, first heard in 1963 and revived Saturday by the Center for Contemporary Opera at the Henry Street Settlement - is not an unpromising one. Sly is the tinker in the ''Induction'' to ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' who awakes from a drunken stupor to find himself dressed as a lord and surrounded by courtiers - the butt of a nobleman's joke.

title: BUSINESS, AS USUAL
description: At the end of the lobby of the hotel where the Giants have spent most of the week of their lives, the big man sat near the main entrance and very, very slowly signed his name across the pebbled surface of an official Super Bowl ball: George B. Young. ''B?'' someone asked. ''B for Bozo,'' Young said.

title: RECORD NUMBER GIVEN HOUSING IN CITY SHELTERS
description: As temperatures dropped into the teens Sunday night, a record number of people sought emergency housing, causing overcrowding at eight city shelters for homeless individuals.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Fletcher Corp., Indianapolis, said its acquistion by Banc One Corp. had been completed.

title: TRADING RULES ARE WEIGHED
description: Regulators are studying only modest ways of protecting stock market investors from the kind of violent price swings that occurred in Friday's turbulent session.

title: BRITISH INQUIRY GIVES GO-AHEAD ON NUCLEAR POWER
description: A British inquiry begun four years ago decided today on the basis of 55 tons of evidence to go ahead with a new generation of nuclear power stations.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $4.6 million for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $14.3 million for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $69.3 million for the quarter and $71.1 million for the year.

title: MACARTHUR FUND GIVES HELP TO FAMILY-PLANNING GROUPS
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago has awarded $5.7 million in grants for population control activities, including one to promote soap operas carrying the family planning message to millions in third world countries.

title: BANK ASKS $1 BILLION IN NEW ISSUES
description: The BankAmerica Corporation filed today for permission to sell up to $1 billion of securities as part of its plan to restore its strength and stave off a takeover threat from First Interstate Bancorp.

title: PACKING PLANT STRIKE: ARDUOUS BATTLE TO SURVIVE
description: For almost 500 days now, Latina Sanchez has reported each morning to the picket line outside the Watsonville Canning and Frozen Food Company, the site of one of America's most bitter and persistent labor disputes.

title: Market Place; Bank Portfolios That Set Pace
description: MANAGERS of equity fund portfolios administered by banks used different strategies to achieve the best results among their peers last year. Even now, after the stock market's stunning rally in January, most of these managers are optimistic about prospects for 1987.

title: ONCE AGAIN SNOWSTORM HALTS U.S. GOVERNMENT
description: For the second time in a week, the nation's capital was virtually shut down today by a large snowstorm of the size that most big cities would take in stride.

title: INSIDE
description: L.I.R.R. Talks Advance The Long Island Rail Road reported settlements with three more unions, including the group that began the nine-day-old walkout. Page B1.

title: GENERAL CINEMA BUYS 8.3% OF CADBURY SCHWEPPES
description: The General Cinema Corporation, a leading theater chain owner and the nation's largest independent soft-drink bottler, said yesterday that it had acquired 46.5 million shares, or 8.3 percent, of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.

title: RALLY'S WIDER EFFECT DEBATED
description: Now retired in Florida, Stanley M. Burnham figures he is worth $300,000 - about double the value of his assets just a few years ago - thanks to the run-up in stock prices since 1982. But aside from the $12,000 Buick he bought in 1984, which Mr. Burnham said he would probably have purchased anyway, his market-induced spending has consisted mainly of a video camera-recorder and inexpensive personal computers for his grandchildren and a trip to Canada for himself.

title: AIDS RISE SPURS DEBATE ON TESTING OF VICTIM'S SEX PARTNERS
description: The epidemic spread of AIDS, now estimated to infect more than one million Americans, is raising a public policy debate on whether to embark on large-scale testing and tracing of sexual and drug contacts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. PHILADELPHIA 76ERS, at Madison Square Garden, 8 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. WTBS, 8:05 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. KINGS, at Sacramento, 10:30 P.M. Fordham at Army (Radio - WFAS 1230, 7:30 P.M. WFUV-FM 90.7, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. WINNIPEG JETS, at Nassau Coliseum, 8 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight)

title: Parcells and Simms Bask in the Glow
description: The triumphant few always seem to glow in the aftermath of winning a championship. You could see it in Bill Parcells's tired face this morning at his final news conference of Super Bowl XXI. You could see it in the little-boy face of Phil Simms, the most valuable quarterback who followed his coach to the podium.

title: RADAR IN GREENLAND BECOMES AN ISSUE IN DENMARK
description: A dispute among American arms-control experts over a new early warning radar in Greenland, which is Danish territory, has spilled over into Denmark, creating foreign policy problems for the United States.

title: AUTOMATED SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REEVES REFLECTS ON LOST CHANCES
description: Dan Reeves had run out of second-guesses. Maybe he could cheer himself up with a quip when he looked at a price list early this morning for Denver Broncos Super Bowl mementos.

title: Donald MacKinnon, Psychology Professor
description: Dr. Donald W. MacKinnon, a psychology professor who formulated controversial theories on creativity and helped select Secret Service agents in World War II, died last Tuesday in a hospital here. He was 84 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q.How do cats retract their claws? A.Cats retract and extend their claws by using two tendons, one above and one below the claw's center of rotation. The claw is retracted when tension is applied to the extensor tendon above the center of rotation. This moves the claw upward and backward. When tension is applied below the center of rotation through the flexor tendon, the claw is extended. The cat's ability to retract its claws prevents their becoming blunted by contact against the ground. To keep the front claws sharp, cats pull them against tree bark or other tough materials. The back claws are kept sharp through biting and normal use. Q.Where does nutmeg come from? A.Nutmeg, a delicately flavored spice, is ground from the seeds of the nutmeg fruit. Nutmeg fruit are golden-yellow and resemble apricots. They grow on a dark-leafed, tropical evergreen tree about 30 to 60 feet in height. When ripe, the fruit lose moisture and split to expose shiny brown seeds. The seeds are covered by a fibrous material which can be flattened, dried, and ground into the spice mace. The kernel inside the seed is nutmeg. It is often treated with lime to prevent damage by insects. Q.How does bleach remove stains? A.Home laundry bleaches contain agents such as chlorine or oxygen which whiten materials through oxidation, a chemical process that changes the coloring matter through reaction with oxygen. Bleach may also loosen soil compounds so that they are easily washed away. Liquid chlorine bleaches contain sodium hypochlorite which forms an oxidizing acid when added to water. Chlorine bleach can be used on cotton, linen, and most synthetic fibers, but it should not be used on fabrics with finishes that retain chloride, such as silk and wool. Oxygen bleaches contain sodium perborate or potassium monopersulfate and are safe for most washable fabrics.

title: Upjohn Delayed
description: Heavy snow in Washington has delayed a hearing by a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee reviewing an Upjohn Company drug that the company says can grow hair on balding scalps, Upjohn said. The committee had completed its review of the drug minoxidil, which would be sold under the name Rogaine, and was to present its findings, R. D. LaRue, an Upjohn spokesman, said. No new hearing immediately was scheduled. Upjohn asked the agency to approve minoxidil for sale as a treatment for the type of baldness men often experience as they age.

title: How to Turn a Merely Formidable Politician Into a Shoo-In A Family Celebration
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Message To Be Aired Tonight
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message will be broadcast live at 9 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast.

title: Let Airwaves Auction Help Public Broadcasting
description: To the Editor:

title: MOZAMBIQUE JET CRASH STILL A MYSTERY
description: Three months after a Soviet plane carrying Mozambique's President plunged into the South African highlands, the cause of the crash remains in dispute.

title: Bridge: Ruffing With Smallest Card Is Common Beginners' Error
description: An error made routinely by almost all beginners and intermediate players consists of ruffing in the closed hand with the smallest available spot card when it would have been safe and desirable to ruff with a slightly higher card.

title: NUN, 65, IS SLAIN IN THE BASEMENT IN BRONX SHELTER
description: A 65-year-old Roman Catholic nun was stabbed to death Sunday night in a Bronx shelter for homeless men where she worked and lived, the police said yesterday.

title: AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVES
description: * Betz Laboratories Inc., Trevose, Pa., named B.C. Moore president of Betz Industrial, a new division of the company.

title: Financial Fiddling With a Tinderbox
description: Leaders in Western Europe and Japan have a good idea of what must be done to right the yawning imbalances in world trade and money flows. Thanks to unsubtle signals from Treasury Secretary James Baker, they're also beginning to understand the dangerous consequences of continuing inaction. But this doesn't mean that the Group of Five, meeting early next month, can achieve an agreement with teeth. For in each country, teeth would bite into powerful economic interests. That's something none yet dare do.

title: U.S. Wheat Subsidy Set
description: The Reagan Administration today approved the subsidized sale of up to one million metric tons of wheat to China.

title: 10% OF DRINKERS DOWN HALF THE ALCOHOL
description: ABOUT two-thirds of adult Americans drink alcoholic beverages on a regular basis, but 10 percent of the drinkers down half the total alcohol consumed, according to a new study. In addition, the age at which young people begin to drink is falling: ''In 1984 more than 30 percent of surveyed high school seniors reported having tried alcohol by age 13,'' reports Margaret Mushinski in the Statistical Bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: DST SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,650,000 from the sale of partnership interests.

title: E.P.A. PERMITS USE OF A PESTICIDE AGAINST TERMITES, REJECTING A BAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has decided to allow the pesticide chlordane to remain on the market with some restrictions, rejecting calls that it be banned because it may cause cancer and other health problems.

title: NO U.S. PRESSURE, KUWAIT AIDE SAYS
description: Kuwait's Foreign Minister denied today that the United States had put pressure on the emirate to release 17 Shiite prisoners in an effort to gain the freedom of American hostages held in Lebanon.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: DESPITE temperatures in the teens, New York's night set was out in force all last week. The weather was unchanged at Nell's on West 14th Street: chilly outside and quite warm within. Patrons included Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, who came to hear Edwige, a smoky-voiced chanteuse who was stoking the club's midnight fires.

title: RAILWAYS TO RECOVERY
description: The black countries of southern Africa are stepping up efforts to reduce economic dependence on South Africa, which Pretoria uses to assert its ''regional superpower.''

title: A COMMON MAN FOR ALL SEASONS
description: Charles Keating, who portrays the Common Man in the Roundabout Theater's production of ''A Man for All Seasons,'' was standing center stage at a recent performance when a man at the rear of the theater suddenly shouted to him.

title: TEXAS DOMINO PLAYERS LOSING A COURTHOUSE MEETING PLACE
description: A group of elderly men who join in the basement of the Wise County Courthouse to play dominoes, smoke cigars and drink coffee have been told to vacate the premises by Tuesday.

title: HBM/Creamer Promotion
description: Mary E. Moore, a former advertising executive in New York, has been promoted to president of HBM/Creamer, the second-largest agency in Boston.

description: Year-ago per share results are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1986.

title: FIRST SOURCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

The gain in the latest period included previously announced sales of the corporate office building in New York and Reliance Electric operations, as well as several smaller sales and dispositions.

description: b-Net income includes an extraordinary credit of $889,000.

title: PATIENT ALLOWED TO END TREATMENT
description: A man who is paralyzed as the result of drug abuse went without nourishment for the fifth day today, exercising the right he won in court to starve to death, his lawyer said.

description: b-Net income. There are no year-ago quarterly per share earnings because preferred dividend requirements exceeded income.

title: The Giant Apple

Those were heady days for New York sports fans, when all roads to sports championships seemed to run through the Big Apple.

description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1.2 million on the sale of a subsidiary and an after-tax gain of $4.4 million on a royalty agreement advance settlement.

description: President Reagan, fighting to revive his Presidency with his sixth State of the Union Message tonight, will address a nation that is deeply skeptical that he can achieve his goals and doubtful that he is telling the truth about Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Arms and the Lobbyists
description: The past year or so has brought signs of increasing squabbling and rivalry in the capital's normally cohesive gun lobby. The latest indication is the appearance of a publication devoted to covering the split.

The program would give outstanding high school graduates a choice of becoming leaders, not in the military, but in the cause of peace and international understanding.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 27, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Drafting Convention Against Recruitment, Use, Financing and Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M.

title: Coach Reprimanded
description: The Mid-American Conference yesterday publicly reprimanded Vernon Payne, the men's head basketball coach at Western Michigan University, for public criticism of game officials after Western's 62-60 victory at Ball State Jan. 14.

title: LAVA LIES HEAVY ON HAWAIIAN LAND AND LIVES
description: Although lava from the Kilauea volcano is now flowing away from inhabited areas, its output of recent weeks, when it flowed to the coast, lies heavy on the landscape and the lives of those whose homes were in its path.

title: CHARTS AND WORKSHEETS
description: FOR all its dominance of the spreadsheet market, Lotus has never exactly garnered raves for the graphics capabilities of its 1-2-3 software package. Considering that Mitch Kapor, founder of the company, is reputed to have gained his start by developing a plotting package for VisiCalc, at the time the only spreadsheet available, this apparent indifference to graphics might seem surprising. Then again, perhaps Lotus felt that the essentials needed to manipulate a spreadsheet were enough, and that presentation graphics was not much in demand.

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Bid for Special Vote In Suffolk Is Rejected
description: By one vote, the Suffolk County Legislature rejected a measure yesterday to hold a special election for county executive on March 3.

title: A.M.C. Sets Price On Medallion Line
description: The American Motors Corporation has set the base price for its 1988 Renault Medallion, the car on which it has pinned its comeback hopes, at $9,965 for the four-door sedan, the auto maker. Base prices will be $10,693 for the four-door wagon and $10,497 for the LX version of the sedan.

title: EXCHANGE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from extraordinary credits of $1,110,000 for the quarter and $1,530,000 for the year. All per share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: Into Overtime
description: ''It'll be nice to have my husband back and the TV set off for a change,'' said Rhonda Palazzo at an annual ''football widows'' party held at the Old Homestead Restaurant in Manhattan on Sunday while husbands watched the Super Bowl telecast at another party elsewhere. Of the victory by the Giants, she predicted, however, that ''now he'll talk about nothing but football for the next two months.''

title: BEIJING EXPELS AMERICAN REPORTER FOR FRENCH NEWS AGENCY
description: An American reporter working for the French news service here was barred from China today for accepting what the Government called ''intelligence'' from a Chinese student.

title: Chess: Russian Grandmaster Wins Over 13 Players in Hungary
description: The second Szirak International Tournament, probably the strongest competition held in Hungary in the last 30 years, was won by Lev Psakhis of the Soviet Union. The 28-year-old Russian grandmaster scored 9-4 to top a field of 14 that included 12 grandmasters.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HOW POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 18 through 21 with 1,590 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Miller, Tabak Deal For Penn Traffic
description: The Penn Traffic Company said it had agreed to be acquired by Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company. Under the agreement, an affiliate of Miller, Tabak would begin a tender offer to acquire all of Penn Traffic's shares for $31.60 each. There are 4.2 million shares outstanding. After completing the offer, the affiliate would merge with Penn Traffic and the remaining shares would be converted into the right to receive $31.60 in cash.

title: Kidder to Advise U.S. on Loan Sale
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has been named financial adviser for the Department of Agriculture's proposed sale of rural housing loans.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN OFFICER'S KILLING
description: A 23-year-old Bronx man was arrested last night and charged with the murder on Friday of an off-duty police officer, Michael Reidy, in an apparent robbery attempt in the lobby of the officer's apartment building in the University Heights section of the Bronx.

title: POST PLANS TO START A SUNDAY ISSUE
description: The New York Post plans to start a Sunday issue this spring if the tabloid can win concessions from newspaper unions, a senior union official said yesterday.

title: SIX MODELS INTRODUCED BY I.B.M.
description: Just days after one of the worst earnings reports in its history, the International Business Machines Corporation made a bid to bolster its product line yesterday by introducing six new mainframe models, including the most powerful computer it has ever made.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net earnings for both the latest fourth quarter and year include a $105.2 million after-tax gain from the previously announced sale of Merrill's leasing subsidiary, as well as a $14.8 million after-tax loss from the early recall of certain medium-term debt issues to take advantage of currently lower interest rates.

title: REMEMBERING WHAT DAY IT IS
description: WHEN AT-class computers were introduced in August 1984, each came equipped with a battery-powered clock and calendar. Clock-calendars are a dandy thing for people who hate to type in the time and date each time they create or update a file. Besides, some of us rarely know what time or day it is. Even when the computer's power is switched off, the clock-calendar keeps track of the real time and date.

title: STAGE: SONDHEIM SONGS IN 'MARRY ME A LITTLE'
description: WHEN ''Marry Me a Little,'' the revue of Stephen Sondheim's trunk songs, was first produced in New York in October 1980, it triumphantly overcame the challenge of weaving such songs - some from unproduced shows, others cutouts from famous shows - into a dramatically coherent evening.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flames 6, Maple Leafs 5: Calgary spotted Toronto a 5-0 lead in the first period last night, then score five goals in the third period at Maple Leaf Gardens. The Flames won when Colin Patterson scored at 1 minute 30 seconds of overtime.

title: MUSIC: ORPHEUS ORCHESTRA PERFORMS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: ORPHEUS, the conductorless chamber orchestra, gave exquisite pleasure at the beginning of its Carnegie Hall concert Saturday night. Everything that followed was substantial and pleasing, but it was this symphony by Haydn (in C minor, No. 52) that balanced so many and opposing tensions with such poise.

title: Waiting for Regan
description: Although Donald T. Regan has been a more palpable presence of late, after all but disappearing from public view for a period, reporters still complain that the White House chief of staff is inaccessible.

title: THE SOUND OF HATE REVERBERATES IN NORTH GEORGIA
description: Beyond the sheer size of the civil rights march that filled this town Saturday, or the armed force necessary to guard the demonstrators, what stays in the memory of those who witnessed the events is the violence of feeling that awaited the march. It was the sound of hate that is so indelible.

title: KELLOGG COMPANY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a non-recurring loss of $11.5 million from the purchase of the company's 150 million 12 1/4 percent debentures due Feb. 15, 2015.

title: 'FRONTLINE' RESUMES WITH LOOK AT SHUTTLE
description: ''FRONTLINE'' begins its fifth season tonight with ''The Real Stuff,'' a somber but sometimes exhilarating examination of the space program. The somberness lies in the approach; space flight is dangerous. The exhilaration lies in the film; space missions look magnificent. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 P.M., marks tomorrow's anniversary of the Challenger disaster.

title: POSTGAME WORKOUT: A VICTORY PARTY
description: The morning after the Super Bowl Leonard Marshall wanted to see a newspaper to make sure it really happened. Carl Banks said if he were a drunk, he would be totally drunk. Phil McConkey said he was still stunned and didn't know when that would pass ''because I've never done this before.''

title: FIRST REPUBLIC BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RAU QUITS RACE FOR BRANDT'S POST
description: Johannes Rau, who was defeated Sunday as the Social Democrats' candidate for Chancellor, today renounced any claim to succeed Willy Brandt as party chairman next year.

title: Affirmative Action, Via Japan
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's attack on affirmative action remedies to eliminate employment discrimination, a Federal district court settlement this month proves that the concept is not only alive and well but can even create thousands of jobs for Americans, men as well as women.

title: HART CALLS FOR LONGER SCHOOL YEAR AND TESTS OF TEACHER COMPETENCY
description: Former Senator Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, outlined a sweeping education program today that calls for competency tests for all teachers, a national volunteer effort to combat illiteracy and a longer school year.

title: NUCLEAR MANAGER SUBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: Federal regulators have begun a formal investigation of alleged misstatements and ''potential wrongdoing'' by the Tennessee Valley Authority's top nuclear manager, according to Federal officials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WORLD SERIES Starting today, the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street, becomes the permanent home of the New York World Television Festival, which is intended to show us foreign programs that have won international awards but are not likely to be seen on our home screens.

title: Pondering The News From JWT
description: THE advertising community was aghast yesterday at what appeared to be a quelled palace coup at the JWT Group. The question now is: ''What's next?''

title: WEST GERMAN VOTE: VICTORY FOR A WEAKENED KOHL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl won an unsatisfying victory Sunday in parliamentary elections that many politicians say could make the next four years at the helm of a center-right coalition much more arduous than the last four.

title: AFGHAN GUERRILLAS IGNORE TRUCE, SAY WAR GOES ON
description: Eleven days after the Afghan Government declared a cease-fire, guerrilla leaders say that fighting persists throughout Afghanistan and that there has been no trace of a return by refugees to their homeland.

title: If Truman Had Dealt With the Contras
description: Any hope that revelation of its folly in Iran might induce the Administration to abandon its equally ill-conceived policy in Nicaragua has gone quickly aglimmering. Administration officials are again insisting that aiding the contras is our only hope. The President can be expected to join in tonight, in his State of the Union Message, doubtless again describing the contras as the only thing standing between us and the Communist hordes.

title: Children's Mental Health
description: One in eight children in the United States suffers from a mental health problem severe enough to require treatment, according to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment. Of these 7.5 million children, 70 to 80 percent are not getting appropriate mental health services, the office says.

title: WARRIORS' CARROLL VOTED TO ALL-STARS
description: After a recent 35-point, 12-rebound performance against the Sacramento Kings, Coach Phil Johnson said, ''J. B. is playing better this season than I've ever seen him play.''

title: FIRST NORTHERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1987
description: Companies

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1987
description: International

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year earnings were reduced by $2.1 million, or 15 cents a share, as a result of the loss of investment tax credits due to the new tax law.

title: Sharp Rise At Fireman's
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, helped by higher premiums and improved underwriting, said yesterday that operating earnings in the fourth quarter of 1986 had increased nearly fourfold on a 20 percent increase in revenues.

title: WOMAN DIES IN JUMP FROM ROOF
description: A South Bronx woman apparently jumped yesterday with her 17-month-old granddaughter from the roof of her five-story apartment building in what the police said they believe was a suicide attempt.

title: RUDOLF F. KALLIR
description: Rudolf F. Kallir, the former vice president of the American Mannex Corporation and a noted antiquarian specializing in musical manuscripts, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old. Mr. Kallir's career began in Vienna, where he studied law, and continued in the steel industry in Prague, London and New York.

title: Racial Attack Suspect Freed
description: A 19-year-old white man was released on $1,000 bail yesterday after he was arraigned on assault and other charges stemming from what the police said was a racial attack on two Hispanic youths in Ozone Park, Queens, last month. The man, Arthur Biazzo Jr., is charged with having pointed a gun at the victims and with threatening them, not with participating in the beatings. The incident occurred two hours before three black men were attacked in Howard Beach, Queens, on Dec. 20.

title: BEVERLY INVESTMENT PROPERIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are not available; the company completed its initial public offering on Dec. 30, 1985.

title: DIAMOND CRYSTAL SALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $373,000, or 15 cents a share and $1,126,000, or 44 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, resulting from the adoption of FASB No. 87.

title: PLAINTIFF TESTIFIES IN THE 'BELL JAR' TRIAL
description: A psychiatrist testified here today that she felt dismay and outrage reading Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar'' and seeing the 1979 film of it because, she said, she was recognizably the person on whom a key character was based.

title: REPORT RAISES FEARS FOR WAITE
description: Three men, including a Saudi national and two men believed to be foreigners, were abducted in West Beirut today, and there were reports that an anonymous telephone caller had threatened to kill one of two West German hostages ''at any hour.''

title: Rates Up in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury issues rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday, as government securities dealers began preparing for a heavy supply of new issues.

title: Bringing the Reality of Babies to the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMONWEALTH ENERGY SYSEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of about $5.1 million, or 55 cents a share, from the sale of interest in Algonquin Energy Inc. Revenue represents operating revenue.

title: Morales Pleads Guilty
description: George Morales, three-time winner of the Offshore Power Boat world championship, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to drug and tax evasion charges.

title: ALVARADO APPLIES FOR TOP POSITION IN SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former New York City Schools Chancellor, wants to run a Manhattan school district and has submitted a formal application for the job, he said yesterday.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Chairman of Baker In Fight on Hughes
description: Earnest Hubert Clark Jr. is scheduled to become chairman of a merged Baker International Corporation and Hughes Tool Company, but the Justice Department has thrown up a block to the proposed merger.

title: MURRAY PICKS KOOKABURRA III
description: Two days of speed testing has convinced Iain Murray that Kookaburra III is the boat he will sail to defend the America's Cup against Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes.

title: ALLEN PORTER
description: Allen Porter, for many years a member of the staff of the Museum of Modern Art, died last Wednesday at a nursing home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Barrytown, N.Y.

title: THIOKOL TELLS OF PROBLEM WITH BOOSTER TEST PLAN
description: The manufacturer of the space shuttle's solid-fuel rockets said today that under the space agency's current schedule, only half of the full-scale tests of a new rocket design would be completed by the time flight-ready boosters are delivered to Cape Kennedy for a resumption of shuttle missions.

title: NICARAGUA TO FREE AMERICAN HELD ON SPY CHARGES
description: Nicaragua will release an American held on espionage charges, the Nicaraguan Embassy announced tonight.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $85 million and $147 million from asset sales for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Business and the Law; U.S. Bounties In Fraud Cases
description: ABOUT three years ago, John Phillips, a co-director of the Center for Law in the Public Interest in Los Angeles, discovered an obscure law passed during Abraham Lincoln's Administration, after the public expressed outrage about Civil War contractors who mixed sawdust with gunpowder, or sold the Government the same horse twice.

title: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,161,000 and $1,263,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $217,000 and $355,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and 6-month also includes a gain of $487,000 from the sale in September 1985 of the distribution rights by A-S N. Foss Electric. The company said effective Dec. 31, 1986, it sold the assets of Swenson Spreader Co. for $960,000 after tax and sales have been restated to reflect this change.

title: UAL Loses $13.6 Million
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, reported a loss of $13.6 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to income of $20.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985. Operating revenue rose 23.8 percent, to $2.34 billion, from $1.89 billion a year earlier.

title: COMMERCIAL SECURITY BANORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: 'FOCUS!' OFFERS 'ASIAN BRIDGE'
description: A PROGRAM devoted to the developing connections between Asian and American music in this century might be expected to tell us something about the reasons behind that fascinating rapprochement. The concert last evening at the Juilliard Theater, one in a series going under the heavyweight title of ''Focus! Music in the Melting Pot: Immigration and Interaction,'' seemed at times to head in that promising direction. But what it added up to, finally, was a stultifying jumble, as if one were listening to an interesting speaker who had too much to say and not enough time to say it in.

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Yellow Ribbons for Beirut
description: Understandably, American responses to hostage-taking in Lebanon are hardening. Civil authority in that shattered country has long since vanished. Every Westerner still in Beirut surely knows the risks. The State Department keeps urging Americans to clear out, as it did only days before the weekend abduction of four teachers at Beirut University College. By staying on, they and others put themselves and their country at hazard.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $49.3 million related primarily to the company's undeveloped oil and gas leases. c-After a special charge of $88 million. d-Net income

title: Time for Giants And the Bulls
description: The Super Bowl stock theory, which has held true in 19 of the last 20 years, proposes that if the Super Bowl is won by a team that once belonged to the American Football League, the stock market will close lower at the end of the calendar year than it opened at the start.

title: Mesa Fulfills Plan
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had purchased 15.5 million Mesa Limited Partnership common units for $263.9 million, in accordance with its previously announced plan of liquidation. The plan was approved by shareholders in December 1985. The units will be distributed Feb. 2 to Mesa Petroleum shareholders of record Jan. 26. Each common share will receive just under 23 percent of one partnership common unit, it said. All of Mesa Petroleum's oil and gas operations were transferred to the limited partnership in Decmber 1985.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change for pension plans in the U.S. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $5.2 million related to asbestos-related personal injury claims. Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November 1986.

title: A Third Grand Jury To Hear Death Case
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they would present evidence to a third grand jury in the case of a sculptor, Carl Andre, whose wife died in 1985 in a fall from the couple's 34th floor Manhattan apartment.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from tax credits of $13,115,000 for the quarter and $45,974,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from a tax credit of $1,795,000. The per share latest year figure is pro forma, and there are no year-ago per share figures, because the bank converted from mutual to stock form in August 1986.

title: HOWARD SAVINGS BANK OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared Jan. 26.

title: ILLINOIS MARINE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $421,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Space Magazine Relies On MacNamara, Clapp
description: As new accounts go, it was a little one, billing about $300,000. But the name was good - the Smithsonian Institution. And since the advertising would be aimed at the decision makers at agencies and advertiser companies it would serve as a showcase for the agency's talents.

title: Soviet Seeks U.S. Talks On Afghanistan Issue
description: The ambassador-designate to Pakistan has rejected an approach from the Soviet Embassy here for direct talks on a solution to the conflict in Afghanistan, American officials said today.

title: Jury Seeks Espionage Money
description: The daughter, a former business partner and a former companion of John A. Walker Jr., convicted as a Soviet spy, appeared today before a Federal grand jury looking into what happened to $1 million Mr. Walker got from spying.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring transactions for the quarter, and the year includes a gain of $31,358,000, or 32 cents a share, of Continental Cablevision and a gain of 3 cents a share from the 1986 sale of other investments. c-After nonrecurring transactions for the quarter, and the year includes a net gain of 5 cents a share from sale of land.

title: FOR ONE FAMILY, CONTRIBUTING TO THE NEEDIEST IS A TRADITION
description: Continuing her mother's tradition of giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Myra Heller of Setauket, L.I., gave $25 to the 75th annual appeal. Mrs. Heller said as with her mother, Bertha Levine, who began contributing in 1925, she has given annually to the Neediest, first on behalf of her children and then her grandchildren.

title: Bringing the Reality of Babies to the Classroom; Blame Unemployment
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENCY TAKES STEPS FOR PARTLY BANNING ALL-TERRAIN VEHICALS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has taken a step toward possibly banning at least some all-terrain vehicles, according to a commission source.

title: KOCH REAFFIRMS PARADE INVITATION
description: Citing his ''regional pride,'' Mayor Koch yesterday urged the Giants to use today's celebration at Giants Stadium as a warm-up for a later ticker-tape parade in New York, an offer the Super Bowl champions did not seem the least bit interested in accepting.

title: DBA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Refuse Oil Cuts
description: A British official told the Saudi Arabian oil minister, Hisham Nazer, today that the Government would not curb oil production in the North Sea to help the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices, an Energy Department spokesman said. Mr. Nazer met the junior energy minister, Alick Buchanan-Smith, after arriving in Britain on a private visit. Mr. Nazer was to have met the British Energy Secretary, Peter Walker, but officials said Mr. Walker was ill.

title: Daniel Sargent Is Dead; A Biographer and Poet
description: Daniel Sargent, an educator, poet and author noted for his biography of Sir Thomas More, died Saturday at Leonard Morse Hospital here. He was 96 years old.

title: NEW POLITICAL WINDS MAY AFFECT RESPONSE TO PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE
description: When President Reagan mounts the rostrum of the House of Representatives Tuesday night to deliver his State of the Union Message, he will be facing a different Congress and a new set of political dynamics, according to political analysts.

title: MUSIC: 'BEAUTY OF FLUTE' AT THE ASIA SOCIETY
description: ALTHOUGH ''The Beauty of the Flute,'' a program presented Saturday at the Asia Society, was marred by a recalcitrant tape machine, and - somewhat more seriously - by underrehearsal, its best moments made the afternoon a worthy one.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS COEUR D'ALENE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split in April 1986 and a 10 percent dividend issued in November 1986.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,232,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Arts for the Parks
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel will join his predecessor, James Watt, next week in announcing a $100,000 nationwide Arts for the Parks competition to recognize artistic contributions to the national parks system. The competition is sponsored by two private organizations, the National Parks Foundation, of which Mr. Hodel is chairman, and the National Parks Academy of the Arts, led by Mr. Watt, who now lives in Jackson Hole, Wyo., where the announcement will be made Feb. 4.

title: Greyhound In Verex Talks
description: The Greyhound Corporation said it was negotiating with an unidentified party to sell its Verex Corporation mortgage insurance subsidiary, the nation's second-largest private mortgage insurer. John W. Teets, Greyhound's chairman and chief executive, said the company had discussed Verex with several parties.

title: Biggest Winners
description: The Giants, in rolling to a 39-20 triumph over the Broncos in Super Bowl XXI, amassed the largest cumulative scoring margin over three postseason opponents since the current playoff system was established for the 1969 season. The Giants defeated the 49ers, 49-3, and the Redskins, 17-0, for a total playoff margin of 105-23, an 82-point differential. The 10 other largest margins: Scored Allowed Margin 1985, Bears 91 10 81 1983, Raiders 106 33 73 1977, Cowboys 87 23 64 1984, 49ers 82 26 56 1978, Steelers 102 46 56 1973, Dolphins 85 33 52 1982, Redskins 79 31 48 1979, Steelers 92 46 46 1971, Cowboys 58 18 40 1974, Steelers 72 33 39

title: How to Turn a Merely Formidable Politician Into a Shoo-In
description: To the Editor:

title: US LEASING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1.7 million related to a $3.2 million increase in reserves to cover potential losses on the sale of equipment and disposal of some foreign holdings and a gain of $2.3 million from settlement of a tax dispute; results were also reduced by $500,000 by the new federal tax law's elimination of investment tax credits retroactive to Jan. 1. c-Reduced by $1.2-million convertible debt redemption costs. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,759,000.

title: USG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $228,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,254,000 and a loss on planned disposal of discontinued operations of $26,668,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,476,000 and $1,450,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: WHITE HOUSE PANEL ON IRAN HAS INTERVIEW WITH REAGAN
description: President Reagan answered questions today from a special White House panel about his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Loss Reported By Premark
description: Premark International Inc. said today that it lost $95.5 million in the fourth quarter, partly reflecting a previously announced $98 million write-down of two raw material plastic plants. A year ago, Premark said, it earned $24.4 million.

title: CONIFER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Speakes Plans a Book
description: When Larry Speakes departs Feb. 1 as the White House press spokesman to start his new job with Merrill Lynch & Company, the Wall Street investment house, he hopes to supplement his $150,000 salary with a book contract.

title: 7 PRO-PALESTINIANS HELD BY F.B.I. IN LOS ANGELES
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the arrest of seven supporters of a militant Palestinian group that has been under investigation in the United States.

title: TDK CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: The figures in U.S. dollars have been converted at the rate of U.S.$1.00 equals 163 yen, the rate on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Nov. 30, 1986. Share earnings for the annual period ended on November 30, 1985, have been adjusted to reflect free distribution of shares at a rate of 10 percent, made to existing shareholders as of May 31, 1985.

title: THRIFT BIDS BY CITICORP EXPECTED
description: Citicorp has requested applications from Federal regulators to acquire troubled thrift institutions in Texas, Arizona and Pennsylvania, banking sources said yesterday.

title: BellSouth Net Climbs 8.3%
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the regional telephone holding company that serves nine states in the Southeast, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 8.3 percent, to $361.1 million, or $1.14 a share, from $333.4 million, or $1.09 a share, a year ago.

title: CURTICE-BURNS FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results include Custom Technologies Corp. from its date of acquisition, June 21, 1985. Results for 1986 are after a pre-tax charge of $4 million for restructuring and closing of the company's electronic products division.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: THE AGED AND MEDICINE ARE FORMING AN ALLIANCE
description: THE medical procedures that Ronald Reagan went through earlier this month graphically illustrate a quiet revolution in medical care that has become part of growing old. It is a revolution people often forget until a prominent older individual's ailment makes the news or they face such procedures themselves.

title: Home Resales Set a Record
description: A rush to take advantage of expiring tax incentives helped push sales of existing homes to a monthly high in December, closing out the best year for home resales since 1979, a real estate trade group said today.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued title insurance operations of $187,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of $4,732,000 from discontinued title insurance operations. c-Includes a loss from discontinued title insurance operations of $1,085,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of $7,475,000 from discontinued title insurance operations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Beirut University College misidentified the body that chartered the college. It was the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, not the State University.

title: Soto Recovering
description: The Cincinnati Reds say Mario Soto, the key to the success of their starting rotation this year, should be fully recovered from shoulder surgery for this season.

title: RECITAL: NIKOLAI PETROV, PIANIST FROM MOSCOW
description: HECKLING by two supporters of Soviet Jewry greeted Nikolai Petrov on the stage of Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon, but it was more or less drowned out by an applauding audience seemingly more interested in music than politics.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $9.5 million after-tax charge from restructuring costs.

title: Federal Plan Threatens National Rain Forest in Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Maximum Yield 6.921% In M.A.C. Refunding
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation is tentatively offering $694 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6.921 percent for 6 7/8 percent bonds, due in 2006, at a price of 99 1/2.

title: FIREMAN'S FUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $39.3 million for the quarter and $72.9 million for the year. c-Includes a gain from realized investments of $600,000. d-Net loss includes a gain from realized investments of $1.2 million. There are no year-ago shares outstanding because the company went public in October 1985.

title: UNIVERSITY BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DOW RISES 5.76 IN CALMER TRADING
description: With an assist from Mother Nature and the cooperation of the stock index futures markets, Wall Street yesterday returned to a more normal trading volume and less volatility in stock prices.

title: LIFE IN SUN, UNCLOUDED BY APARTHEID'S TURMOIL
description: Joleen Lasker, a social worker, and her husband spent a year scouting the world for a new home. Like thousands of other white South Africans, the Laskers ended their quest in Australia, a country she found similar to her birthplace but devoid of its strife.

title: PREMARK INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss is after a charge of $115.1 million related to a $98 million asset writedown reflecting excess capacity at two plants producing raw materials for Tupperware's ultra-21 ovenware and Xydar, commercial plastic, and a $17.1 million provision for taxes resulting from expected foreign earnings repatriation and capital restructuring at foreign subsidiaries. The latest year is after an after-tax charge of $159.1 million from the writedown, the provision of $17.1 million, which were both mentioned above, and a $44 million third-quarter charge for inventory writedowns, plant consoldiations and restructuring. The share earnings for the year-ago periods are not available because the company was recently spun off from Dart & Kraft Inc.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,586,000 and $6,280,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $9,813,000 from cumulative effect on prior years of changes in accounting principles. The company said the latest periods' results are after the retroactive elimination of $3.2 million in investment tax credits that had been accrued through the first 9 months of the year.

title: London Gets Junior Market
description: The London Stock Exchange began operations today of its Third Market, a junior equity market designed for young growth companies.

title: In Sea of Prosperity, Outpost of Homeless
description: ON a quiet suburban street here sits a handsome white ranch house where the lucky homeless stay. It is a tiny shelter by New York City standards, with a capacity of just 15, but it is the biggest of five shelters in suburban Nassau County (population 1.5 million). Last weekend, the coldest of winter, 17 men, women and children squeezed in.

title: MID-STATE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company did not report 12 month earnings.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $50 million pre-tax charge for the formation of a copier and facsimile joint venture. The latest fourth quarter net increased about $22 million, or 19 cents a share, due to the change in the value of the dollar, and for the year, currency changes increased net income by $79 million, or 69 cents a share.

title: Prison Terms In ESM Case
description: Two co-founders of the defunct ESM Government Securities Inc. were sentenced today to prison terms for their role in the $315 million collapse of the securities dealer, which led to a thrift-unit crisis in Ohio.

title: ATALANTA/SOSNOFF CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After pre-tax charges of $4,591,000 for the quarter and $6,713,000 for the year. Earnings are on a pro-forma basis to account for the company's ''S'' Corporation status until the close of its initial public offering in June 1986.

title: BILL IN CONGRESS CALLS FOR AN END TO L.I. WALKOUT
description: The United States House of Representatives is expected to pass legislation today that would require striking employees of the Long Island Rail Road to return to work immediately, according to the bill's sponsor.

title: The Most Senior Skiers
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY MAYOR'S ACTION ON TAXES UNDER INQUIRY
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating tax assessments recommended by Mayor Thomas M. Whalen 3d for clients of his law firm, city officials said today.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE PARIS COUTURE OPENS ON AN PLAYFUL NOTE
description: Christian Lacroix, with his daffy but amusing clothes for Patou, and Karl Lagerfeld, with his irreverent approach to Chanel, have in recent seasons revived the couture here. Their exuberance has now spilled over to the other 21 couture houses.

title: Williams to Sell Agrico Chemical
description: The board of the Williams Companies has approved a tentative agreement to sell the company's Agrico Chemical Company fertilizer subsidiary to Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners Ltd. in New Orleans. Directors also said Williams's commercial real estate company, the Williams Realty Corporation, was for sale.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $4,100,000 for the phase-out of the company's printed circuit board manufacturing subsidiary. c-Net income

title: NEWORLD BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $694,000 for the quarter and $3,392,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $610,000 for the quarter and $1,614,000 for the year.

title: QUAINT TOWN NOW A COMMUTER'S NIGHTMARE
description: Usually, people here are pleased when visitors say their suburb looks like a little New England fishing village.

title: AMID THREATS AND WAR, ISLAM'S CHIEFS SEEK UNITY
description: The leaders of the Moslem world gathered here today for an Islamic organization ''unity'' meeting that was overshadowed by a war, virtually within earshot, between two of the organization's most powerful members.

title: ETHICS PANEL STUDIES LEGISLATOR'S ROLE
description: The Assembly Ethics and Guidance Committee has begun to review the conduct of Assemblywoman Gerdi Lipschutz, Democrat of Queens. Mrs. Lipschutz has admitted putting two ''no show'' secretaries on her payroll at the request of an influential Queens political figure.

title: ESPOSITO RETURNS AND RANGERS WIN
description: For people who follow the Rangers, there is one requirement. They should never, not for a moment, turn away, for if they do, they are likely to miss something.

title: ABUSED-CHILD DEATHS UP 29% IN REPORTS OF 24 STATES FOR '86
description: Reported deaths of abused and neglected children increased 29 percent last year in 24 states, according to a group that collects state statistics. The head of the group said today that state agencies were getting too overburdened to cope with the problem.

title: 3 MORE L.I.R.R. UNIONS AGREE TO TERMS, LEAVING 5 TO GO
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced settlements with three more striking unions yesterday, including the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, the group that began the walkout 10 days ago.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Henning, recently dismissed after four seasons as head coach of the Atlanta Falcons, reportedly will join the Washington Redskins' coaching staff as an offensive assistant. He was offensive coordinator of the Redskins in 1981 and 1982. . . . Denny Crum, the head basketball coach at Louisville, has been chosen coach of the United States team for this summer's Pan American Games. . . . The Cleveland Indians have signed a free-agent pitcher, Ed Vande Berg, to a major league contract. The left-hander played last season with the Los Angeles Dodgers, with whom he had a 1-5 mark, with no saves and a 3.41 earned run average in 60 relief appearances. . . . Derek Harper, a guard, has signed a nine-year contract extension to be with the Dallas Mavericks through the 1995-96 season, the team announced Monday.

title: New Stock Sale By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, a federally chartered shareholder-owned company active in the mortgage markets, yesterday announced plans to sell eight million shares of common stock in the United States and abroad. The association, known as

title: DANCE: 'BIG PICTURE,' BY YOSHKO CHUMA
description: EVER turn on your television set and find yourself bewitched by a movie that is absolutely incomprehensible - because you missed its beginning - and yet compelling? Yoshiko Chuma offered a dance like that Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. ''The Big Picture,'' performed by Yoshiko Chuma and the School of Hard Knocks, was simultaneously a musical, a dance extravaganza and a melodrama.

title: Dole Is Taking Everybody's Temperature on '88
description: It is late afternoon, and a heavy wind laced with snow shakes the windows in Bob Dole's office in the Capitol. The Senate minority leader and potential 1988 Presidential candidate looks up as he prepares to leave for Boston and New Hampshire.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3 million due to an accounting rule change necessitated by the new federal tax law.

title: Hill Samuel Is Making Key Executive Shifts
description: Richard Lloyd is to succeed Sir Robert Clark as chairman of Hill Samuel & Co. the merchant banking subsidiary of Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., a financial services organization. Sir Robert, 63, will remain chairman of the Hill Samuel Group.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHIRLPOOLS, hot tubs, saunas, steam rooms:

title: Advances in Tin Cans; Lasers Help In Welding Smooth Seam
description: SOME manufacturers contend that the seams on tin cans are unsightly and make labeling and decoration more difficult. They say technological advances in the welding process will make these seams less noticeable and, in turn, create more attractive cans.

title: Dow Chemical, Utility in Pact
description: The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company, as expected, announced a $600 million definitive agreement today to convert the idled Midland nuclear plant to burn natural gas.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary items of $24,526,000. c-Includes a gain of $96,160,000 on the sale, and income from continuing operations, of Colonial subsidiaries sold in 1985. All net income figures are before dividends on preferred stock of $2,151,000 for the quarter and year-ago quarter and $8,604,000 for the year and year-ago 12 months.

description: To the Editor:

description: b-Includes a charge of $57.1 million on the sale of independent television stations. c-Net income
