description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $6.7 million. Net income for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1986 include the net after-tax benefit of $7.7 million, or 38 cents a share, which is applicable to the first 3 quarters of the year due to the retroactive adoption of new accounting rules for pensions to Jan. 1, 1986.

title: IN LEGISLATURE, WOMEN MAKE QUIET STRIDES
description: If the designers of the State Capitol had intended there to be women in the Legislature, logic says, they would have built two bathrooms in the Assembly chamber. But they did not. So up until a few years ago, when the men's bathroom was divided in two, women who were legislators ran the risk of being locked out of the chamber during an important vote.

title: AT THE FRONT IN THE GULF WAR: THE IRANIANS SEEM CONFIDENT
description: About three miles behind the Iranian front lines, in what used to be an Iraqi stronghold, there was a traffic jam this morning.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nasdaq Short Interest Down by 12.4% in Month
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks was down 25.7 million shares, or 12.4 percent, in the month ended Jan. 15, to 181.6 million shares.

title: BORG-WARNER CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Teaspoon Parade
description: Senator Bob Dole, who scores well in the polls as a Republican Presidential possibility, wondered out loud the other day about his campaign:

title: MOZAMBICAN SEEKS U.S. INVESTMENT
description: The problem facing Mozambique's new President is hardly unfamiliar on a continent racked by insurgencies and instability. Put simply, it is that internal strife discourages foreign investment, but the lack of investment deepens the instability on which the insurgents feed.

title: EVERGREEN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHELL OIL COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $62 million from the sale of some of its Canadian interests to Shell Canada Ltd. c-Benefited from a $108 million gain from reorganization of certain natural gas contracts. Share earnings were not reported.

title: Elizabeth G. Holt, 81, Peripatetic Art Expert
description: Elizabeth Gilmore Holt, an art historian who wrote widely on the social context of art, died Monday at her home in Washington. She was 81 years old.

title: SAN DIEGO GENERAL & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an 8-cents-a-share charge related to the Public Utilities Commission decision disallowing part of its construction costs on San Onofre units 2 and 3.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on the Washington Talk page on Jan. 5, comparing the First Congress and the 100th Congress described the racial makeup of the 100th incorrectly. Two of the 100 Senators and 3 of the 435 Representatives are Asian-Americans.

title: Why We Shouldn't Go Metric McCarran-Walter Excludes Hundreds
description: To the Editor:

title: TYSON FOODS(0) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Strategist's Top Deal Is Rexnord Acquisition
description: Jeffrey Steiner, chairman and chief executive of Banner Industries, a diversified manufacturer in Cleveland, has taken the final steps to acquire Rexnord Inc. for about $525 million. The move is the biggest financial maneuver taken by Mr. Steiner, who is 50, since he came to Banner in 1984.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes LIFO inventory gains of $17 million and a benefit of $41 million from the adoption of the new pension accounting standard, and also reflects a $100 million provision for the accelerated amortization of exploration and producing assets. c-After a loss of $150 million on the sale of Container Corp., whose revenues are included in Mobil's through June 1986. d-Includes LIFO inventory gains of $64 million. e-Includes a provision of $508 million for the restructuring of Montgomery Ward, and also includes Jefferson Ward and catalog operations sold and discontinued in mid-1985.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN a classic New Yorker drawing, a glowering husband sitting behind a newspaper says to his equally glowering wife: ''What did I have for lunch? The same thing I have every day - a hot dog with sauerkraut and a magnum of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild.'' Plainly, he has discovered one of the secondary pleasures of wine: marrying it with food.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Friday about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the total contributions to the 75th annual appeal. The record amount received last year -$2,726,331.40 - was exceeded this Monday, not last Thursday.

title: Cleveland Fed Chief Moves to Bank One
description: Karen N. Horn, the first woman to become president of a Federal Reserve Bank, is going to try her hand at commercial banking.

title: Jacobs Suchard Drops Hero Bid
description: A bitter three-week-old takeover battle involving two leading Swiss food companies ended when Jacobs Suchard said it was abandoning its attempt to buy the preserved food manufacturer Hero. Jacobs Suchard, maker of Jacobs coffee and Suchard and Tobler chocolate, said it had agreed to sell back to Hero management a 30 percent stake in the company it bought from a Zurich bank on Jan. 5. It did not disclose the price. At the same time, Hero announced a modification of its statutes aimed at strengthening what it called its ''shark repellent'' against unfriendly takeovers. Hero shares fell sharply on the news, with the most-traded shares hitting a low of 3,500 francs, or $2,300, from Monday's closing 4,500 francs - $2,960. Jacobs Suchard shares were little changed.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sandstrom an All-Star
description: Tomas Sandstrom has been named to represent the Rangers and Kirk Muller will represent the Devils on the 27-man all-star team that will represent the National Hockey League in a two-game series against the Soviet Union in Quebec City on Feb. 11 and 13. Both forwards were added to the team yesterday - along with Wayne Gretzky - as the N.H.L. filled out its squad for the Rendez-Vouz '87 series. Gretzky, whose 48 goals for Edmonton this season are five more than the combined total of Sandstrom's 26 and Muller's 17, was beaten out at center by Mario Lemieux in the fan voting for the starting team. Five of Gretzky's Oiler teammates were added to the squad yesterday: Mark Messier, Glenn Anderson, Esa Tikkanen, Jari Kurri and the goaltender, Grant Fuhr. The only Islander representative is Mike Bossy, who was voted as the starting right wing but has a back injury that might force him to miss the games.

title: ALLISON DANZIG, 88, TIMES WRITER, DIES
description: Allison Danzig, a sportswriter for The New York Times for 45 years and an authority on tennis, football and rowing, died yesterday of a heart attack at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Ramsey, N.J.

title: Bryant Park Restaurant Plan Was Landmarks Board Business
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE YEAR OF THE RABBIT Today, you should know, is the eve of the Chinese New Year, a major annual occasion rooted in a distant past. Some of the most ancient artifacts of that past time are enshrined at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, at 82d Street and Fifth Avenue. Perhaps it was coincidence - in keeping with the arrival of the Year of the Rabbit, which is noted for being fortuitous -but the Met only last week put on display one of the finest collections of Chinese antiquities anywhere.

title: ROLLINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,434,000 from the sale of non-operating property.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: USX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes for both periods a pretax nonrecurring charge of $1.5 billion which principally reflects the write- down of asset values and recognition of employee and other costs associated with indefinitely idled facilities in steel, coal, agri-chemicals and oil service operations, as well as a reduction in the value of certain oil and gas assets; for the year includes after-tax effects of $300 million for the call of Marathon 12- 1/2 percent notes and $300 million for the inventory market valuation reserve resulting from the decline in oil prices. c-Net income The company said 1986 results were affected by tax expenses for loss of investment tax credits of $150 million and a $70 million provision for adjustments of prior years' taxes, as well as the five-month work stoppage in steel.

title: FOR THE L.I.R.R., FRIDAY IS TARGET FOR RESUMPTION
description: Even before Congress moved to end the Long Island Rail Road walkout, officials of the strikebound line were formulating a strategy to resuscitate it.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago 9 months figures have been restated to reflect the combined result of Logicon and Chase, Rosen and Wallace.

title: UGANDA, AT PEACE, IS FACING ECONOMIC BATTLES
description: A year after leading his guerrilla movement to power in Uganda, President Yoweri Museveni now finds himself mired in economic problems that could erode his popularity.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE PANEL WILL HOLD HEARINGS ON CONDUCT OF VETERANS AGENCY
description: The House Veterans Affairs Committee will hold hearings on conduct by the Veterans Administration that has prompted a Federal district judge in San Francisco to impose more than $134,000 in penalties against the agency.

title: 43.17 SURGE PUTS DOW AT 2,150.45
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply to a record level yesterday. In the process, it nearly offset all of Friday's big loss as Wall Street appeared to regain its magic touch.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ANTONE ATALLAH
description: Antone Atallah, a former Foreign Minister and a Member of Parliament, died today, his family said. He was 89 years old. Mr. Atallah was a member of Jordan's lower house of Parliament for the Jerusalem district and later as a member of the Senate, the upper house. Mr. Atallah, born in Jerusalem of a Greek Orthodox family, was Jordan's Foreign Minister in 1964-65 and in 1970.

title: PARABOLAS AND PEPLUMS
description: The upbeat mood of the spring and summer couture collections continued today as bright colors and fresh shapes gave a cheerful look to the showings of warm-weather clothes. While all this gaiety is welcome, sometimes it seems to get out of hand. Karl Lagerfeld tried so hard to express the new spirit at Chanel that he ended up making styles better suited to the theater than to real life.

title: REJECTING CALL FOR 'FIGHTING SPEECH,' REAGAN URGES UNITY AND DRAWS ON THEMES OF PAST
description: President Reagan delivered a State of the Union Message tonight that he could have delivered, with only modest changes, if his party had won the Senate elections last November and if the Iran-Nicaragua controversy had never developed.

title: FIRST SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIGH COURT ACCEPTS APPEAL OF 'MOMENT OF SILENCE' LAW
description: Returning to the contentious issue of school prayer, the Supreme Court agreed today to consider the constitutionality of a 1982 New Jersey law requiring that public schools permit students to observe one minute of silence daily ''for quiet and private contemplation and introspection.''

title: DANCE: FROM PILOBOLUS, THE OLD AND THE NEW
description: PILOBOLUS - that dance troupe specializing in mad scrambles of arms, legs and ideas - opened for a four-week season at the Joyce Theater Tuesday night with a gala benefit that spanned 12 of the 16 years the troupe has been in existence. The early and more overtly athletic days were represented by two relatively simple pure-movement pieces. And there was a new work, ''Land's Edge,'' that is in the company's latest, narrative style.

title: Kings Top Nets, 118-115
description: Mark Olberding, a reserve forward, hit two free throws in the final 50 seconds tonight to help thwart a New Jersey rally as the Sacramento Kings edged the Nets, 118-115.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 1, 1986.

title: JUSTICES OVERTURN 3 DECISIONS BACKING DEFENDANTS
description: The Supreme Court overturned three unrelated state court decisions favorable to criminal defendants today, taking a narrow view of its rules curbing police interrogations and upholding the procedures used in sentencing a California defendant to death.

title: FAMILY CELEBRATES YEAR OF THE RABBIT WITH FEASTING, SHANGHAI STYLE
description: THE week before celebrating the Lunar New Year, which begins tomorrow, San Yan Wong, his wife, Rosanna, and his mother-in-law, Kwai Wu Chui Fung, began searching the markets of Chinatown for the appropriate foods. For the start of the year 4685, the Year of the Rabbit, the Wongs had decided to celebrate as they had in Shanghai.

title: Chrysler Lowers Rate
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had lowered its loan rate on its buyer incentive programs to 3.7 percent, from 3.9 percent, and was expanding its selection of cars eligible for rebates, which range from $300 to $1,000. It said annual percentage rates range from 3.7 percent for 24 months to 9.9 percent for 60 months on selected 1986 and 1987 model cars.

title: EX-ADDICTS HELP MONITOR THE DRUG SCENE
description: Sitting amid drug dealers and buyers in a smoky coffee shop, Jake ticks off a numbered code on his Lotto form.

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $16.8 million for equipment writedowns, revaluation of television film rights and other assets. c-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1986.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BITOK, an easily put-together entree, is one of the most interesting distortions of an English word first ''borrowed'' by the French and further misappropriated by the Russians, who introduced the dish to France around 1920.

title: Schools Boycotted in Spain
description: Students in Spain's high schools boycotted classes today to protest police action during a student march last week in which 25 people were injured, officials said. Several thousand teen-agers rallied in Puerta del Sol Square here and poured red dye in fountains. The students demanded the resignation of Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo. Meanwhile, teachers started their own strike in the high schools. Hundreds of teachers gathered outside the Education Ministry here to protest plans to reform their professional status.

title: PUBLIC BLAMES NASA OFFICIALS
description: One year after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, the American people blame officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the disaster, rather than the scientists and engineers who developed the craft's technology, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: UNIVATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company noted that the latest- quarter results reflect the continuing transition of the company's business from microcomputer peripheral products to local area network products.

title: ARMS TO IRAN HALTED, SHULTZ SAYS, BUT INTEREST IN BETTER TIES REMAINS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz pledged today that there would be ''no more transfers of U.S.-origin military equipment to Iran, either directly or through any third party.''

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $1.9 million from the sale of surplus real estate for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a credit of $600,000 from adoption of FASB No. 87 relating to pensions. c-Net loss and includes a net charge of $4 million resulting from provisions for employee terminations and restructuring of operations, principally in France for both the quarter and year, and the year includes a net gain of $1.4 million from the sale of surplus real estate.

title: American Can Chairman Set
description: Gerald Tsai Jr. was named chairman of the American Can Company yesterday, succeeding William S. Woodside, who is retiring Jan. 31. Mr. Tsai, 57 years old, joined American Can in 1982 and has been vice chairman and chief executive. He will also become president on March 1, succeeding Francis J. Connor.

title: Soo Line Layoffs
description: The Soo Line Corporation said it had begun to cut its work force by 800 employees in the fourth quarter. These reductions will continue in 1987 and 1988, the company said.

title: Israel Extends Price Controls
description: Israel's Government, trade unions and industrialists agreed today to extend price controls on goods and services until March 1988 in an effort to avert labor unrest and a return to hyperinflation.

title: Taxed Tot
description: Children learn of life's cruelties at an early age. By kindergarten, most have seen the ice cream topple from the cone, the dime disappear through the grate, the balloon tangle itself in the treetop. But few have been disillusioned as brutally as Shannon Burns, age 10, of San Jose, Calif. The I.R.S. seized the $694 in her savings account.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1987
description: International

title: WHEN SIMMS SAW RED
description: Sometimes you can't even trust a good cliche. There is the belief, for example, that bulls get mad when they see red. There are those, however, who contend that this is false, that bulls don't get mad when they see red. They say cows get mad when they see red, but bulls get mad when people mistake them for cows.

title: OPERA: 'DON GIOVANNI,' BY PHILADELPHIA COMPANY
description: If you close your eyes - or keep them open but concentrate on characters' faces in the foreground - there is a good deal to enjoy about the Opera Company of Philadelphia's production of ''Don Giovanni'' at the Academy of Music, the second and final performance of which can be seen on Friday.

title: ALL 7 ELIGIBLE ELECTED TO PRO FOOTBALL HALL
description: All seven eligible players were elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame today, including Don Maynard, the wide receiver who became the second former member of the Jets to earn the honor.

title: Esposito Decision Due Today
description: Phil Esposito said yesterday that he was still agonizing over what to do about the Rangers' coaching situation. He said that a meeting would be held today to ''clarify everything.'' He even went so far as to say that his decision would be harder to reach than ever.

title: I.B.M. Upgrades Its PC Convertible
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, in a move intended to bolster its sagging share of the lightweight portable-computer market, announced several improvements to its PC Convertible computer. Although an I.B.M. executive said the company was ''very pleased'' with sales of the Convertible, which was introduced in April, machines from Toshiba, Zenith and others have dominated the market with technically superior features at comparable prices. The I.B.M. Convertible will keep a base price of $1,995.

title: DOW O. WALLING
description: Dow O. Walling, a retired cartoonist who created the comic strip ''Skeets,'' died Friday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Pelham Manor.

title: Radar Trap, and Opportunity
description: The United States is building missile warning radars at Thule in Greenland, a Danish territory, and Fylingdales in Britain. Soviet officials and some Americans assert these violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The issue is being debated this week in Denmark, too. American critics suggest halting construction if the Russians will stop building an almost certainly illegal missile-sensing radar at Krasnoyarsk in Siberia. The proposal is both a trap and an opportunity.

title: Bonn Drops Bribe Case Against an Ex-Official
description: A prosecutor today asked a court today to acquit Otto Lambsdorff, a former Economics Minister and a senior figure in the Free Democratic Party, of charges he accepted $50,000 between 1977 and 1980 from the Flick concern in return for granting lucrative tax waivers.

title: Accounts
description: * Chattem Inc. to Tracy-Locke, Dallas, for its Corn Silk cosmetics.

title: An Army Anniversary
description: Secretary of the Army John O. Marsh Jr. will reach his sixth anniversary in office on Friday, establishing a record for time in grade.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. Gets The Army Account
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM, the largest American ad agency, has won the Army's $100 million recruiting account, the Army announced yesterday.

title: FOR THE BUYER, PICKING TASTE OVER LOOKS
description: ORGANICALLY grown foods are usually labeled as such. Whether or not they actually are organic is another matter; consumers should ask to see verification.

title: Swiss Account Holders Challenge Iran Inquiry
description: At least eight parties linked to Swiss bank accounts in the American investigation of the Iran affair have appealed a Swiss decision to give legal assistance to the United States, Swiss authorities said today.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
SAVOR WITHOUT SALT
description: LEAD: SALT in small amounts is essential to the human body - to be precise, the sodium provided in a tenth of a teaspoon of salt a day. Yet most people consume, on average, two to four teaspoons of salt every day.

title: Aide Quits Iran Panel
description: The executive director of the House committee investigating the Iran-contra arms affair, John P. O'Hara, has resigned, just a few weeks after accepting the post. Mr. O'Hara was to have been in charge of hiring staff for the committee and scheduling hearings.

title: JAPAN KEEPS CAR-EXPORT CURB
description: Bowing to political reality, Japan announced today that it would continue its curbs on automobile exports to the United States for a seventh year. The decision is part of an effort to head off mounting American protectionist sentiment.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: New York Telephone is a Nynex company.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,364,000 and $3,891,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a provision of $5,937,000 for loss on disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the quarter and $65,000 for the year.

title: Go to Beirut at Your Own Risk, Not America's
description: LEAD: West Germany arrests a suspected hijacker of Trans World Airlines flight 847, and West German citizens are kidnapped in Beirut. The United Stated requests extradiction of the suspect, and Americans in Beirut disappear. France sells weapons to Iraq, and French citizens are kidnapped in Beirut. The United States bombs Libya with planes flying from British bases, and British citizens are kidnapped and murdered in

title: PLAINTIFF DENIES 'BELL JAR' FILM EVENTS
description: A 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar'' was shown on two television screens here today in Federal District Court, and a psychiatrist who contends she is the basis for one of its characters denied vehemently that certain scenes in the movie had ever taken place in real life.

title: People
description: * Patrick A. Hehir has been elected executive vice president and chief financial officer of McCaffrey & McCall.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NO-SHOW STRATEGY PAYS OFF
description: The two boats that will sail against each other in the America's Cup matches have something in common.

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RUTGERS AND STRIKING LOCALS REACH TENTATIVE AGREEMENT
description: A tentative contract agreement was reached late Tuesday between Rutgers University and representatives of 2,800 nonteaching employees, ending a nine-day strike, spokesmen for the two sides said.

title: Numbers Are Impressive
description: Jim Catalano, the basketball coach at New Jersey Tech in Newark, an engineering college with high academic standards, was explaining on Monday afternoon the new point-producing power that has made his Highlanders the nation's top-scoring college team.

title: CNB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $4.5 million pre-tax gain from the sale of consumer finance receivables for the quarter and year.

title: WEST BANK STUDENTS MARCH IN SUPPORT OF FATAH FIGHTERS
description: Hundreds of students at Al Najah University in Nablus, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, defied warnings from Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin and demonstrated today in support of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's guerrilla organization.

title: LESTER A. BURCHAM
description: Lester A. Burcham, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the F. W. Woolworth Company, died Saturday at the North Carolina Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 73 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Guerin B. Carmody, 76, Dies; Former Judge in Connecticut
description: Guerin Benedict Carmody, a former Chief Judge of the Connecticut Assembly of Trial Justices, died Monday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: London Coffee Climbs
description: Growing sales of coffee from Brazil have drawn processors back into the market, jolting prices out of a three-month slump, analysts said today. The March futures contract here rose more than $152 a ton in the last nine days, to $2,462 on Monday. The price dipped to $2,424 today, but dealers attributed this to market nervousness on the eve of a three-day meeting of coffee-producing countries here.

title: Economic Scene; Jumpy State Of the Public
description: HOW is the state of the union, economically speaking?

title: QUINONES ACTS TO TAKE OVER LOCAL PROGRAM
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor yesterday ordered Board of Education officials to take over a $712,000 after-school program, run by a Manhattan community school district, for homeless children whose families have been placed in hotels.

title: New Chairman Named At St. Martin's Press
description: Thomas J. McCormack has been named chairman of the board of St. Martin's Press, succeeding Alexander Macmillan, the book publishing company has announced.

title: Official Gets a Year and a Day In Pennsylvania Bribery Case
description: A former state Republican Party chairman was sentenced today to one year and a day in prison for his role in a bribery-conspiracy scandal that led to the suicide of another official, State Treasurer R. Budd Dwyer.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS VILLANOVA, 61 TO 58
description: St. John's is rapidly becoming basketball's version of the hitless wonders. The Redmen put together another tremendous defensive effort, with weak offensive support, and defeated Villanova, 61-58, at Alumni Hall last night.

title: Maryland County
description: Ann Arundel County, Md., is offering about $61 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6 1/4 percent for issues due in 2012 through 2014, through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago. The financing also includes yields ranging from 3 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 4.60 percent in 1992, 5.40 percent in 1997, 5.95 percent in 2002 and 6.15 percent in 2007. The bonds are rated double A by Moody's and S.& P.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the favorable effect of stronger foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar added 9 percentage points to the year-to-year sales growth.

title: Some Nerve in the Philippines
description: How Corazon Aquino must enrage her foes: she refuses to fight like a man. On the left, zealots thirst for martyrs and shootings, the stuff of revolution. So what does the President of the Philippines do? She opens her palace to fist-shaking demonstrators and orders her Cabinet ministers to greet them, for heaven's sake, in an arms-linked human chain of bureaucrats, businessmen, students and Roman Catholic nuns.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the distribution of Freeport-McMoran Gold Cos. common stock to its shareholders of $3,388,000 for the quarter and $17,395,000 for the year. c-Includes a gain of $94,068,000 from the initial public sale of units in Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P. and a writedown of $149,578,000 on its oil and gas assets. d-After a charge from relocation expenses of $1,830,000 for the quarter and including a gain from the sale of stock in a subsidiary of $31,061,000 for the year.

title: Emhart Divestiture
description: The Emhart Corporation said that it would sell its assets in South Africa as part of its worldwide restructuring program. Emhart's three operations in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, acquired in the company's 1976 purchase of the USM Corporation, have annual revenues of about $32 million and employ 900 people. Emhart said it expected to complete the divestiture by year-end.

title: EX-RESIDENT HELD IN NUN'S DEATH
description: A former resident of a long-term shelter for the homeless was arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal stabbing of a 65-year-old Roman Catholic nun who lived and worked at the Bronx shelter.

title: Marijuana Doesn't Mix With Rail Safety
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $4,325,000 from the termination of a salaried employee's pension plan and $3,033,000 from the sale of the company's holdings in Statex Petroleum Inc. for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $9,420,000 from the sale of a coal mine. description: Two Occidental Petroleum Corporation subsidiaries will reduce their exploration and production work force by 450 worldwide as a result of consolidation, company officials said. The terminations will affect the Occidental Oil and Gas Corporation operation in Bakersfield, Calif., and the Cities Service Oil and Gas Corporation activities in Denver, Jackson, Miss., and Midland, Tex.

title: SUMMATIONS BEGIN IN THE 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: Summations in the ''pizza connection'' trial began yesterday with a prosecutor accusing the defendants of operating an international Mafia ring that distributed tons of drugs.

description: 1.For Micromarathoners

title: SPLIT EMERGES IN KIDNAPPERS LINKED TO IRAN
description: A split has developed within Islamic Holy War, the clandestine pro-Iranian group holding at least two Americans hostage in Lebanon, and it may have had an effect on an Anglican envoy's effort to free the captives.

title: REAGAN CONFESSES A 'MAJOR REGRET': FAILURE ON IRAN
description: President Reagan, trying to rebound from the lowest point of his Presidency, told Congress and a national broadcast audience tonight that he had ''one major regret,'' the failure of the attempt to win the freedom of American hostages and establish contacts with Iran.

title: LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: The quarter and year ended Jan. 3, 1987, contain 14 weeks and 53 weeks respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks ended Dec. 28,1985. The 1986 results include those of American Furniture Co., acquired Oct. 31, 1986. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in January 1986 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September 1986.

title: Atonement for Racist Episodes Isn't Enough
description: Howard Beach, N.Y. Forsyth County, Ga. The Citadel in South Carolina. The University of Massachusetts at Amherst. These are new place names on the map of racial violence. As symbols, they remind us that the agenda of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is still unfinished, that race-conscious behavior continues to endanger our society.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,500,000 from reversal of the investment tax credit due to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: AGENCY REJECTS INDUSTRY ROLE
description: The top Federal land manager has rejected a staff recommendation to make his agency an advocate for the minerals industry, it was announced today.

title: FED PROPOSES TO ALTER HOW BANKS SET CAPITAL
description: The Federal Reserve Board is asking banks to comment on a significant accounting change that would force them to raise capital and could depress their stock prices.

title: SEATTLE GATHERING IDEAS FOR MAJOR PARK PROJECT TO RENOVATE THE LAKESHORE
description: Seattle's city government has begun a major park project aimed at renovating the south end of Lake Union, which lies between downtown and the waterway linking Lake Washington to salt water.

title: 25,000 HAIL THE GIANTS AT MEADOWLANDS RALLY
description: From the first flake of confetti to the final kazoo chorus of ''California, Here I Come'' it was a pep rally, it was a rock concert, it was a New Year's Eve blowout and it was a revival meeting. But it was not Koch country. The Giants celebrated their Super Bowl victory today in the Meadowlands stadium that, according to Coach Bill Parcells, the team calls ''our house.''

title: Complete Quarterbacks
description: Phil Simms, in leading the Giants to victory in Super Bowl XXI, connected on 22 of 25 pass attempts for an 88-percent completion ratio, the best in Super Bowl history. Simms, who set another Super Bowl record with 10 consecutive completions, easily surpassed Ken Anderson's previous percentage record, set five years ago. The top 10: Player, Team, Year Comp. Att. title: Victim of AIDS Is Rehired
description: The Navy has rehired a commisary worker who was dismissed last year after contracting AIDS, his lawyer said Monday. The lawyer, Katherine Franke, said the Navy rescinded its dismissal of 32-year-old Ed Horan, who took a medical leave from his job at the Navy Supply Center last August when he contracted pneumonia related to acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES A HOLDOUT JUROR IN MISTRIAL
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they were investigating whether a juror had acted improperly in holding out for the acquittal of an accused organized-crime figure during a trial last November. The judge in the case said the juror should be prosecuted if the inquiry indicated wrongdoing.

title: IN NEW JERSEY, TASTE OF BURNS'S SCOTLAND
description: LEAD: AT the Argyle Restaurant in Kearny, N.J., on a weekend night, Pipe Major Jock Nisbet is taking a turn around the room, regally kilted in the Nisbet Old Colors of bittersweet, green and white, a fur sporran hung from a chain round his hips and a dagger in his gartered hose. Mr. Nisbet, a United States pipe champion, is playing a dinnertime set on the great Highland bagpipes.

description: The surrogate mother seeking custody of Baby M, Mary Beth Whitehead, faces the threat of losing her home because she and her husband owe $12,000 in back payments on a mortgage granted by her older sister.

description: The extraordinary bidding shown in the diagram is an accurate record of a deal in the 1986 world team championships in Miami Beach. It might seem that North made a semipsychic opening bid, but in actuality he was the victim of a semipsychic - by the organizers.

Pope Bestows Title on Nun
description: Pope John Paul II has bestowed the title ''venerable'' on Mother Katharine Drexel, a step that could lead to the heiress nun's being declared a saint. Mother Drexel, a member of a prominent Philadelphia banking family, founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament in 1891 to work among blacks and American Indians.

description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's State of the Union Message, delivered to Congress last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

description: For nearly a decade the skeletons of unfinished apartment and office buildings haunted the San Juan skyline, symbols of an economy made sluggish by high energy costs and rising interest rates.

description: Mike Vreeswyk, a sophomore forward, scored 22 points as Temple defeated Rutgers, 76-56, in an Atlantic 10 Conference game tonight.

title: While the Boss Is Away . . .
description: One of the marvels of the computer age is the ''boss button.'' Instead of entering sales data, Mr. Smith is playing a game on the company computer - say ''Leather Goddesses of Phobos.'' Without warning, the boss rounds the corner. Mr. Smith hits the ''control'' and ''B'' (for Boss) keys, and an official-looking data base instantly fills the screen.

description: The company went public in September 1986.

description: ANYONE who has seen any of the Boise Cascade Corporation's financial papers lately surely must have seen the line: ''Boise Cascade is a different company than it was 10 years ago, five years ago or even last year at this time.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Bailor, the utility infielder traded by the Mets to the Dodgers three years ago in the deal for Sid Fernandez, has been hired by Toronto to manage the Blue Jays' Class A farm team in Dunedin, Fla. Bailor, 36 years old, was the first player selected by the Blue Jays in the 1976 expansion draft. . . . Curt Warner of the Seattle Seahawks, whose 1,481 yards rushing led the American Football Conference this season, has dropped out of Sunday's Pro Bowl in Honolulu with a severe case of the flu. . . . Dick Taylor, the assistant coach, has been elevated to head football coach at Hobart College, replacing Jack Daniels, now an assistant coach at The Citadel. . . . Another assistant coach, Dick Farley, defensive coordinator at Williams College, has been promoted to replace Bob Odell, who retired after 16 seasons. Farley is a former defensive back with the San Diego Chargers.

title: NEW PLUNGE PUTS DOLLAR AT 7-YEAR LOW VS. MARK
description: The dollar resumed its steep decline yesterday, falling to a seven-year low against the West German mark in New York and losing further ground against the Japanese yen.

title: Gala for the Giants: Kazoos and Beer
description: BEER in hand and implanted in a snowbank yesterday on the playing field of Giants Stadium, Jim Colangelo, happy fan, predicted optimistically that he would be back at work today.

title: TESTING THE TECHNICAL LIMITS OF TRADING
description: A LOT of investors are trying to forget their roller-coaster ride on the New York Stock Exchange last Friday, when prices soared and then collapsed as a record 302 million shares changed hands. But technology officials at the exchange are studying what happened in minute detail and expect to continue for some time to come.

description: Howard J. Lichtenstein, a specialist in labor-relations law and a partner of the Manhattan law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, died Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PRIDE STIRRED BY FIRST GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: First-time contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often include notes with their donations expressing their pride at joining the appeal, now in its 75th year.

description: Joseph W. Bellacosa's nomination to New York State's highest court was confirmed yesterday by the State Senate in a unanimous vote.

description: The Household Finance Corporation is offering $150 million of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.725, to yield 7.549 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: THE FRESH APPEAL OF FOODS GROWN ORGANICALLY
description: IF any one event focused public attention on the hazards of chemical contaminants in food, it was the poisoning in 1985 of thousands of watermelons with the pesticide aldicarb. ''It seemed to crystallize consumer and producer awareness, because there were so many people who got so acutely sick,'' said Mark Lipson, executive secretary of California Certified Organic Farmers.

title: One Way to Keep Smiling
description: When he was a running back at Auburn, Bo Jackson, the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner who became an outfielder for the Kansas City Royals, was occasionally criticized for letting minor injuries keep him on the sidelines. Now Jackson, who has been taking courses at Auburn during the offseason, has revealed how he keeps smiling and avoids being rankled by such sniping from sportswriters: ''The only thing I read in the paper is the comics. When they start mixing the sports with the comics, I'll stop getting my subscriptions.''

title: SCREENING URGED FOR ALL PREGNANT
description: The American Liver Foundation and four medical experts yesterday called for routine screening of all pregnant women for the hepatitis B virus, a major cause of cirrhosis and liver cancer.

title: ONE YEAR AGO: THE LAST MINUTES
description: Icicles hang from the gantry where Challenger stands ready for flight, venting propellant vapors into the wintry air. Its seven crew members are on board: Francis R. (Dick) Scobee, the spacecraft commander; Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy, the pilot; Dr. Judith A. Resnik, Dr. Ronald E. McNair and Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force, mission specialists; Gregory B. Jarvis, a payload specialist, and Christa McAuliffe, the first participant in the spage agency's teacher in space program. As the countdown progresses, the seven are strapped into their seats.

title: Our Sky Is Wide Open for Soviet Missiles
description: LEAD: The Administration's signals that it is now thinking of a ''phased deployment'' of the Strategic Defense Initiative to begin ''as quickly as possible'' reflect not a decision but rather one more refusal to make basic choices about how to deal with the Soviet missile force. In this field as in so many others, the

title: Fiat Profits Rise 12.5%
description: Fiat, Italy's leading industrial group, said today that its estimated operating profits rose 12.5 percent last year. Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, commenting on Fiat's performance in his annual letter to shareholders, said the operating profit rose to 2.55 trillion lire, or $1.75 billion, in 1986. He did not release estimates of 1986 group net profit. The company said revenues from its automobile division rose a provisional 14 percent, to 16.4 trillion lire, or $12 billion. It now has a 12.7 percent share of the European car market, up slightly from 12.3 percent at the end of 1985.

title: MANILA REBEL SOLDIERS HOLDING OUT AT TV STATION
description: Dissident soldiers continued to hold a private broadcasting station today despite a warning by President Corazon C. Aquino that she would no longer tolerate the military threats that have shaken her Government.

title: Jane Morrison, Film Maker, Is Dead of Malaria in Africa
description: Jane Morrison, an independent film maker, died of malaria Wednesday in Nairobi, Kenya, where she was attending a film festival. She was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chicago Magazine Names Publisher
description: Roger Tremblay, 38, the former associate publisher, advertising director and a vice president of Texas Monthly, will be moving the old bones to Chicago to take the publisher's chair at Chicago magazine.

title: DAUGHTER CITES BUMPUR'S STAY IN STATE HOSPITAL
description: A daughter of Eleanor Bumpurs lied 10 years ago when she told hospital authorities her mother was mentally disturbed and violent, another daughter told a Bronx jury yesterday.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A YEAR LATER, TWO ENGINEERS COPE WITH CHALLENGER HORROR
description: A year ago tonight they were two unknown rocket engineers, two urgent voices pleading against a launching. No one listened.

title: E.P.A. Accuses Orkin Of Misuse of Pesticide
description: A Federal agency today accused the Orkin Exterminating Company of incorrectly applying a pesticide that a woman has asserted caused the stillbirth of her child.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S TALK AT PARTY PARLEY
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today to the Communist Party's Central Committee, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Technical Workers Snarled by Tax Law
description: Scores of engineers, designers, computer programmers, systems analysts or other similarly skilled workers who make a living as independent consultants are planning to march on Washington tomorrow to protest a tax amendment that hurts them, confuses their employers and apparently puzzles the Government as well.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring fee of $530,000 from a loan prepayment. All year-ago figures are from Feb. 22, 1985, the inception of the real estate investment trust, to Dec. 31, 1985. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Baylor Honored Again
description: For the second straight season, Don Baylor has been voted baseball's top designated hitter by public relations directors of American League teams, broadcasters and sportswriters. Baylor earned the honor for 1985 as a member of the Yankees, who traded him to the Red Sox for Mike Easler before the 1986 season. . . . Four more players who filed for arbitration have reached agreements with their clubs, reducing the number of unresolved cases to 78. The four who agreed are Johnny Grubb and Pat Sheridan of the Tigers, Mark Gubicza of the Royals and Nick Esasky of the Reds.

title: Country Pie, City Pie
description: Mary Thomas of De Valls Bluff, Ark., bakes exceptional pies. Not unexpectedly, word got out. Jane and Michael Stern, authors of ''Roadfood and Goodfood,'' included Mrs. Thomas in their book. Newspapers profiled her and now customers come to her little roadside shop from Memphis, Tenn., 85 miles away.

title: State of the Audience
description: If audience trends go as expected, when viewer ratings for President Reagan's State of the Union address last night are computed in a week or so, it is likely he will have spoken directly to 20 million to 30 million fewer Americans than President Carter did in his last State of the Union address in 1980.

title: AIR FORCE LISTS EATON PROBLEMS
description: An Air Force inspection of the Long Island plant where electronics for the B-1B bomber are assembled found the Eaton Corporation was badly mismanaging the program, according to the inspector's report.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
FREEPORT-MCMORAN ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of oil and gas assets of $318,774,000. c-Net income. The period covered in year-ago 12 months revenue, net income and unit earnings is from April 26 to Dec. 31, 1985. The company went public April 2, 1985. Units represent depositary units.

title: DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CRISIS IN ECUADOR: DEMOCRACY IS LOSER
description: Ecuador's fragile democracy appears to have been seriously damaged by the weeklong crisis that began with the kidnapping of the President by air force commandos and ended last Thursday when he rejected a congressional call for his resignation.

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $42.8 million writeoff of goodwill c-Net loss d-Net income

title: GORBACHEV, CITING PARTY'S FAILURES, DEMANDS CHANGES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, charging his Communist Party with stagnation and systematic failures, called today for secret balloting and a choice of candidates in the party's elections of its officials.

title: Union Head to Lead St. Patrick's Parade
description: The president of the Transport Workers Union of America, John Lawe, was chosen last night to be the grand marshal of the 1987 St. Patrick's Day Parade, narrowly defeating a challenge by Dorothy Hayden Cudahy of Queens who campaigned to become the first woman to lead the 225-year-old parade.

title: CHEVRON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $316 million charge from the writeoff of oil and gas properties, a $167 million gain from the resolution of outstanding Venezuelan income tax claims and the reversal of certain U.S. taxes relating to selected foreign marketing operations for both the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter loss is also after a $25 million reversal of investment tax credits, a $12 million reduction of pension expense and foreign exchange gains of $58 million. c-Net income and includes foreign exchange gains of $21 milliion. The company said the latest fourth quarter results were decreased by $10 million from asset dispositions and by $84 million due to LIFO inventory drawdowns recognized during the fourth quarter as high-cost inventory acquired in prior years was used in current year operations. The company said the latest year results includes a $25 million fourth quarter reversal of investment tax credits. In addition, latest year results were reduced by $84 million as a result of LIFO inventory drawdowns recognized in the fourth quarter. The latest year results also included a net charge of $48 million relating to the company's manpower reduction program and foreign exchange gains of $123 million. The company said the 1985 results included foreign exchange gains of $5 million.

title: BEFORE BROILING A FOWL
description: ONE of the quickest midweek dinners busy working people can make is broiled chicken, perhaps with a fresh herb and mustard glaze or a coating of seasoned bread crumbs. The chicken will cook more evenly and have a uniformly crisp skin if you follow the technique here for splitting and pounding it beforehand. This simple preparation works equally well with squab, guinea hen, Cornish hen and other fowl.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Accordingly, the reversal of investment tax credits for the last half of fiscal 1986 and the first quarter of this year, amounting to $830,000, or 2 cents a share was reflected in the second quarter results. The company said the year-ago results are restated to give effect to the adoption of new pension standards in the fourth quarter of last year. This increased last year's previously published first quarter net income and share earnings by $800,000, or 2 cents a share and its second quarter net income and share earnings by $700,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: MOSELEY HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $174,000 for the quarter and $506,000 for the year. c-Net loss includes a pre-tax charge of $12 million related to certain ceased U.S. government securities trading activities.

title: KEYSTONE HERITAGE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend payable Feb. 10.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics: Lessons Learned; Educator in Exile
description: Unquestionably, Anthony Alvarado is a dynamic educator. Also unquestionably, he had to resign as School Chancellor in May 1984 because of personal financial difficulties. Should those same difficulties now bar him from consideration as head of a community school district in Manhattan? No. Society can be stern without also being vindictive.

title: STAGE: MUSICALS OF THE 50'S, AT THE Y
description: IF all the historical data and show-business lore that have been dispensed in the 92d Street Y's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series were crammed into a book, one would end up with a chatty, oversized encyclopedia of American commercial songwriting during the pre-rock era. On Sunday, the series opened its 17th season with the latest chapter in its informal survey of Broadway musicals since 1940. By examining shows in thematic groupings and combining nostalgia and education, the series has hit upon a delightful formula that could be spun out successfully for years to come. For the next two seasons, the subject at hand will be the 50's musical, which the series portrays as a ''golden age.''

title: CONCERT: DIVERSE 'FACES OF YIDDISH MUSIC'
description: NOT all Jewish composers turn to their ethnic idioms for inspiration, but those who do have the good fortune of being able to move easily between ''art music'' and popular or folk styles. ''Faces of Yiddish Music,'' an enjoyable and enthusiastically received program Sunday at Merkin Concert Hall, ran from sophisticated art songs to folk and theater songs without the least impression of incongruity. The closest parallel in the standard concert repertory is probably the Spanish music of Falla and Granados, with folk song always close to the surface.

title: Execution Stopped in Texas
description: A Federal judge today granted a stay of execution to John R. Thompson, who had been scheduled to die Wednesday for shooting to death a 70-year-old woman. The judge, Dorwin Suttle, granted the stay based on an appealed filed by Mr. Thompson's lawyer, Mark Stevens, who said the appeal included allegations that Bexar County prosecutors reneged on an offer of a life sentence if Mr. Thompson agreed to plead guilty. Mr. Thompson who turned 32 years old today, had faced lethal injection in the death of Mary Kneupper at a storage warehouse where she worked.

title: Greyhound Pact Progress
description: Union leaders representing more than 6,000 employees of Greyhound Lines Inc. have voted overwhelmingly to recommend acceptance of an agreement with the Dallas-based investment group that plans to buy the bus company.

title: LAWRENCE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in May 1986. The per share earnings for 1986 assume the shares were outstanding for the full periods.

title: BURRITT INTERFINANCIAL BANORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $181,600 from a pre-payment penalty on a Federal Home Loan Bank advance. c-After a tax credit of $76,300.

title: CRUMPET INGREDIENT: WILD ABANDON
description: Kristin Beattie asks only two questions of job applicants at her Seattle bakery, London Maid Crumpets: ''Can they lift a 100-pound sack of flour and can they whip batter?'' At London Maid, the notion of a handmade product is literal, and whipping batter means getting an arm into the action, right up to the elbow.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Westchester Fills Top Correction Post
description: The warden of Westchester County's correctional institutions for 14 years, Norwood E. Jackson, was named yesterday by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to be Commissioner of Corrections. Mr. Jackson, who is black, becomes the first member of a minority group to hold cabinet-level rank in the Westchester government.

title: Forks Pitched; Spoons, Too
description: For over a decade, the House and Senate dining rooms have used flatware made in Japan, Korea and Taiwan.

title: NYNEX AND PACTEL GAIN; SOUTHWESTERN BELL DOWN
description: The Nynex Corporation and the Pacific Telesis Group yesterday reported higher fourth-quarter profits, while earnings fell at the Southwestern Bell Corporation.

title: College Basketball Notebook; PAPER-TIGER LABEL DISTURBS CLEMSON
description: Cliff Ellis, Clemson's coach, probably is wondering what it will take to convince cynics that the basketball team isn't a paper Tiger this season. Despite his team's best start ever, the Tigers have been criticized for fattening up on a cupcake schedule.

title: Injured Employees Still at a Disadvantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Warning By Vatican
description: The industrial world has a duty to help developing countries with their debt, but radical, unilateral action by debtor nations could destabilize the world financial system, according to a Vatican document released today.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1986.

Aren't There Any Real Republicans Around?
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICANS EATING THEIR VEGETABLES
description: Americans are eating more vegetables than ever before, particularly the fresh kinds found in produce markets, according to a Department of Agriculture analyst. But canned and frozen vegetables are popular, too, says Shannon Reid Hamm of the department's Economic Research Service. Potatoes, excluded in the overall vegetable count, have recovered from earlier slippage.

title: SIERRA PACIFIC RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lloyd Plans Cutback
description: Chris Evert Lloyd says she expects this will be her final year of full participation on the women's tennis tour. She will continue, however, to play selected tournaments, including Wimbledon and the French, United States and Australian opens. ''I would be very, very surprised if I play past this year,'' Lloyd said yesterday. ''The work is very hard now. It takes me longer to get warmed up, longer to recover from a tough match. It is tougher, but I still enjoy the commitment that I make to tennis.'' The 32-year-old Lloyd, who has won at least one Grand Slam singles title every year since 1974, has won 148 titles and 1,143 matches in her career, the most of any player, male or female, since tennis's open era began in 1968.

title: CHRYSLER PULLS ADS FROM 'AMERIKA'
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the largest sponsor of the ABC mini-series ''Amerika,'' has pulled its commercials from the program, stating that the car maker's patriotic advertisements would be inappropriate in the 14 1/2-hour film about a Soviet takeover of the United States.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: ON weekends I read a small daily newspaper in a rural area of Pennsylvania, and there are always advertisements in the Special Notices section of the classifieds that go something like this: ADOPTION

description: Is Patrick Ewing, who is averaging 19.8 points and 8.7 rebounds a game for the Knicks, the fourth best center in the Eastern Conference?

description: What happens to the money when two friends decide to go to the movies?

description: The Mobil Corporation, the country's second-largest oil concern after the Exxon Corporation, said that its earnings plunged 52.7 percent in the fourth quarter.

FINAL ARGUMENTS ARE OFFERED IN QUEENS NO-SHOW JOB TRIAL
description: The prosecution in the Federal trial of Richard L. Rubin, an influential Queens political figure, summed up yesterday by depicting the defendant as a man who used his power to steal and to corrupt the system because he was ''greedy'' and ''arrogant.''

Year-ago fourth quarter net adjusted for non-recurring net income.

title: Procter Net Is Up 15%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, benefiting from improved gross margins, reported a 15.2 percent increase in earnings for its second quarter.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER ELDERLY A CATASTROPHIC-ILLNESS PLAN
description: President Reagan said tonight that he would soon send Congress a legislative proposal to insure elderly people against the costs of catastrophic illness.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net sales and income for the latest quarter includes the operations of businesses acquired from Dayco Corp. Oct. 24, 1986. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 87, employers' accounting for pensions.

title: 'BROKEN VOWS' ON CBS
description: FATHER McMAHON is having a crisis of faith - sleepless nights spent staring at the ceiling. Clearly, he is ripe for a trauma. In ''Broken Vows,'' a two-hour movie on CBS at 9 tonight, he finds one: murder, nastiness and sex. It's not an entirely persuasive television movie, but it is more interesting than most.

title: Why We Shouldn't Go Metric McCarran-Walter Excludes Hundreds
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Taste of Spring Is it too soon to think spring? Not when shad and shad roe have arrived in town. The shad fillets and pairs of shad roe are available at some of the fish markets that command higher prices. (At wholesale, the fish are selling for around $4 a pound, a price that may drop as the season progresses.) Citarella, 2135 Broadway (75th Street) has shad fillets for $6.95 a pound and the roes for $6.95 a pair. At Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), shad fillets are $6.99 a pound, roes $6.50 a pair. On the Upper East Side at Rosedale, 1129 Lexington Avenue (78th Street), fillets are $7.50 a pound; roes are $6 to $7.50 a pair depending on their size. At Leonard's, 1241 Third Avenue (71st Street), fillets are $9.50 a pound, roes $9 a pair. With some asparagus on the side, it might as well be spring. Calcium and Girls

title: Long, Haymes Gets CSX Corporate Account
description: Long, Haymes & Carr Advertising, Winston-Salem, N.C., has been selected to do corporate advertising for the CSX Corporation of Richmond. The budget has been set at $3.9 million.

title: BARKLEY STOPS KNICKS
description: On the day he learned he was an all-star selection for the first time in his career, Charles Barkley celebrated at the expense of the Knicks.

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I took a risk with regard to our action in Iran. It did not work, and for that I assume full responsibility.'' - President Reagan.

title: Computer Crime Is 'Big Business'
description: In computers, at least, crime appears to pay. August Bequai, a Washington lawyer writing in ''Techno-Crimes'' (Lexington Books), estimates that the annual take of computer criminals could reach $5 billion a year. The greatest potential for high-technology thievery with minimal risk is in electronic fund transfering, Mr. Bequai says, where the average theft is measured in tens of thousands of dollars - dispelling the image of the computer criminal as a socially retarded teen-ager creating mischief from a suburban bedroom.

title: REAGAN'S ADDRESS PROVOKES A HIGHLY PARTISAN REACTION
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message tonight provoked a Congressional response that was more sharply partisan than veteran members of either party could remember.

title: CASEY REPORTED MAKING PROGRESS FOLLOWING BRAIN TUMOR SURGERY
description: Even as the Reagan Administration sounds out potential successors, allies of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, say he is making progress in his recovery from cancer surgery.

title: FAMILIES SAY QUEST IS INCOMPLETE
description: Following are excerpts from a ''Letter to America,'' written by family members of the seven Challenger astronauts and made public today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration:

title: MOLESTATION CASE RECEIVED BY JURY
description: The jury began deliberations today in the case of a former president of a state college in western Massachusetts charged with sexually assaulting a male undergraduate.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time pretax gain of $3,422,000 from a real estate transaction.

title: INSIDE
description: No Chrysler 'Amerika' Ads The Chrysler Corporation, citing the content of the film, has pulled its commercials from the ABC mini-series 'Amerika' Page C26. Court Test on Silent Minute The Supreme Court will consider the constitutionality of a 1982 New Jersey law requiring schools to permit a minute of silence daily. Page B7.

title: HORNSBY'S 'WAY IT IS' CLIMBS THE ROCK CHARTS
description: ''A SONG about racism with jazz piano soloing is certainly not your obvious hit,'' the pianist-songwriter-singer Bruce Hornsby said a few days ago. ''I don't think it's commercial at all.'' But that song, ''The Way It Is,'' moved steadily up the pop charts to No. 1 after its release last September, and it has made Bruce Hornsby and the Range one of the leading new bands to emerge in 1986, selling more than 1.7 million copies of their first album, also titled ''The Way It Is'' (RCA). Bruce Hornsby and the Range will perform Monday and Tuesday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues.

title: ACTOR AND 71 OTHER PROTESTERS ARRESTED AT NUCLEAR TEST SITE
description: The actor Martin Sheen and 71 other antinuclear protesters were arrested at the Nevada Test Site on Tuesday in a demonstration marking the 36th anniversary of the first nuclear test there.

title: Stone to Purchase Southwest Forest
description: The Stone Container Corporation, one of the nation's largest producers of corrugated container and paperboard products, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Southwest Forest Industries for $32.25 a share, or $441.8 million.

title: USX LOSES $1.41 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The USX Corporation today announced a $1.41 billion loss for the fourth quarter, giving it a $1.83 billion loss for all of 1986.

title: Saluting Simms
description: Morehead State University in Kentucky never has retired a football player's jersey and number, but the performance by Phil Simms of the Giants in the Super Bowl could end that. ''I definitely think it should be done,'' said the Eagles' coach, Bill Baldridge, who is leading the campaign to preserve No. 12. Baldridge said Simms had done a lot for the university. ''How many times did they mention Phil's name on television Sunday and that he was from little Morehead State?'' the coach asked. He said the quarterback ''never has forgotten us'' and ''I hope we never forget him.'' Baldridge also noted that Simms conducts a football camp at Morehead and is one of the program's strongest supporters. Gov. Martha Layne Collins already has announced plans for a statewide celebration. ''We plan to have a Phil Simms Day as soon as all the details can be worked out,'' the governor said. ''We're very proud of him.''

title: Good Investor Demand On Mortgage Securities
description: About $650 million of collateralized mortgage obligations were offered yesterday, as underwriters took advantage of good investor demand for the mortgage securities offering yields substantially higher than Treasury issues.

description: b-Net income

title: Paine Webber Profit Up 23.2%
description: The Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that its net earnings in the most recent quarter rose 23.2 percent, to $17.5 million, from $14.2 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: A FIRST NOVEL'S WINDFALL IN FILM AND CLUB RIGHTS
description: Three months before its scheduled publication date, a first novel acquired for a modest $5,000 advance has already earned its author an additional $2.5 million in motion picture and book-club rights. ''It's like winning a lottery, except that you're winning it for something you've written,'' said Georges Borchardt, the author's literary agent.

title: REVAMPING GREAT LAWN IS WEIGHED 821:69,813>
description: A plan to expand Belvedere Lake and shrink the Great Lawn of Central Lawn was presented publicly last night and immediately ran into an unexpected obstacle: the 19 species of dragonfly and damselfly that are said to use the north shore of that small pond as their ''rendezvous.''

title: First Chicago in Acquisition
description: The First Chicago Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire First United Financial Services Inc. for $20.83 a share, or $175.6 million. The acquisition would establish First Chicago's presence in the western and northwestern Chicago suburbs.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE VOTE COOLING-OFF IN L.I.R.R. WALKOUT
description: Congress approved legislation today to end the 10-day Long Island Rail Road strike by imposing a 60-day cooling-off period.

title: SPECIAL COUNSEL TO EMPANEL IRAN ARMS JURY TODAY
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra arms affair will empanel a grand jury Wednesday, according to Federal law enforcement officials.

title: Key Rates
U.S. Budget Deficit Down
description: The Federal Government ran a $12.08 billion budget deficit last month, down 18 percent from the $14.66 billion deficit a year ago, the Treasury Department said today.

title: 200 OFFICERS STORM PRISON IN PITTSBURGH TO END RIOT
description: About 200 law-enforcement officers stormed a maximum security prison here early today to put down rioting that broke out after a fire forced officials to release several hundred inmates from their cells.

description: b-Net income

title: NASA FACES YEAR OF CRUCIAL DECISIONS
description: One traumatic year after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, the American space program is facing a momentous 12 months that will decide not only whether the redesigned shuttle is fit to fly again soon, but also whether the space program has any larger purpose beyond getting the stricken shuttle fleet back into the air.

title: PROFESSOR SEEN TO HEAD STATE ENVIROMENT UNIT
description: Governor Cuomo has chosen Thomas C. Jorling, a professor at Williams College, to head the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, people familiar with the decision said today.

title: SMITH SAVES TIE FOR ISLANDERS
description: Like it or not, and they don't, domination is no longer the name of the Islanders' game. They have had to turn their attention to less flamboyant tactics, emphasizing a stingy defense meant to offset an anemic offense.

title: SANTA FE ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the wider loss to drastically reduced oil and gas prices and a resulting $91.3 million third quarter writedown of proved oil and gas properties; that writedown, or impairment, while having no direct effect on available cash or on partners' taxable income or loss, reduced depreciation, depletion and amortization in the fourth quarter.

title: Only 122.6 Million Viewers
description: If Lawrence Taylor had, say, taken to wearing a fright wig, or if Phil Simms, perhaps, had spit in Pete Rozelle's eye, it might have been different. But according to preliminary estimates, Sunday's Super Bowl clash between the Giants and the Denver Broncos did not have the national appeal of the 1986 showdown between the Chicago Bears and the New England Patriots.

description: The United States and Mongolia established diplomatic relations today.

title: PEROT BACKS MUSEUM'S PLAN
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive who offered $70 million to relocate the Museum of the American Indian from New York to Dallas, has retracted his offer and stated his support for the museum's effort to relocate in the United States Custom House, an 80-year-old, seven-story Beaux Arts building in lower Manhattan.

title: KOCH, REFUSING TO SWITCH PLANS, MEETS WALESA
description: Despite apparent efforts by the Polish Government to lure him away, Mayor Koch traveled to this Baltic seaport today to embrace Lech Walesa, calling the Nobel Prize-winning Solidarity trade union leader ''a monumental force for good.''

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $14.5 million. c-Net income

title: Norfolk Considers Acquiring Piedmont
description: In a disclosure that many analysts found puzzling, the Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it was considering the acquisition of Piedmont Airlines. Such a merger, if it occurred, would be the first between a railroad and an airline in the United States.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK OF CALIF reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect 3-for- 2 stock splits declared in August 1985 and June 1986.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Parallels: U-2, Bay of Pigs, Iran
description: Michael R. Beschloss, adjunct historian of American politics and diplomacy at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, has worked as a consultant on a number of projects involving the Presidency, like the 1984 celebration of the Truman centennial. He has also written two well-received books, ''Mayday: Eisenhower, Khrushchev and the U-2 Affair'' and ''Kennedy and Roosevelt: The Uneasy Alliance.'' And he plans to begin work soon on a comprehensive history of the Cold War in the Kennedy years.

title: WAGE INCREASES FELL TO 3.5% IN 1986, LABOR DEPT. REPORTS
description: Wage and salary increases last year averaged 3.5 percent, down from 4.4 percent in 1985, as more employers issued year-end bonuses to their workers rather than larger raises, the Government reported today.

title: MUTTERING ABOUT SUHARTO, BUT IT'S NEVER IN PUBLIC
description: When President Suharto announced last fall that he would seek a fifth term in office in 1988, he focused attention on a question that cannot be publicly debated here: How long can - or should - he stay in power?

title: Beatification Cleared For Nun, Born a Jew
description: The Vatican took the last official step today toward the beatification of a German Jew who became a Roman Catholic nun and was killed in the Auschwitz death camp. Beatification is a first step toward possible sainthood.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GALO PLAZA, EX-ECUADOR LEADER
description: Galo Plaza Lasso, a former President of Ecuador who later served as Secretary General of the Organization of American States, died yesterday in Quito. He was 80 years old.

title: Glen Tetley Joining Canada's National Ballet
description: Glen Tetley, the internationally known choreographer and former director of the Stuttgart Ballet, will join the National Ballet of Canada as artistic associate, the company has announced.

title: Prison for Sanctuary Worker
description: A Federal district judge has ordered a woman who helped aliens flee political upheaval in Central America to report to prison to begin serving a six-month term. The woman, Stacy Lynn Merkt, was sentenced in March 1985 after being convicted of conspiracy to transport illegal aliens. The judge, Filemon Vela, denied her motion to reconsider the sentence on Jan. 13 and ordered her to surrender last Thursday. Ms. Merkt was once a worker at the Casa Oscar Romero in San Benito, Tex., a refuge house for aliens.

title: Books; U.S. and Arms
description: TO ARM A NATION: Rebuilding America's Endangered Defenses. By Richard Halloran. Macmillan. 396 pages. $21.95. AMONG the more unexpected developments of the last few years has been the growth of widespread public interest and debate about the state of the armed forces. This debate goes well beyond the tired arguments about who should serve or whether more or less money is required for national defense. It now embraces such questions as the organization, composition, command and control of the armed forces, their doctrine and training and the entire weapons development and procurement process.

title: 'BUILDING FACADES': A NEW MANUAL
description: IN 1980, nine months after a pedestrian was struck and killed by a piece of masonry that had fallen from a building, Mayor Koch signed Local Law 10, which requires periodic inspection and maintenance of exterior walls on private property.

description: The Allied-Signal Corporation has sold its 15.6 percent stake in the Henley Group back to that company for $465 million, severing its most important ties with the concern that Allied spun off just last year.

description: The White House indicated today that President Reagan would make few, if any, public statements about the details of the Iran affair until the Congressional and Federal investigations were completed.

description: The Reagan Administration today proposed a five-year delay in opening the nation's first burial site for highly radioactive nuclear waste. It said that a decision on where to place a second repository need not be made before the mid-1990's.

description: A coalition of consumer groups and their supporters in Congress have started a campaign to freeze the $2 service charge imposed on millions of telephone subscribers each month for access to their local telephone company.

title: THE DANCE: SUKANYA
description: ALTHOUGH much Indian dance is religious in nature, it is not necessarily also unremittingly solemn. That was made clear on Tuesday night at the Minor Latham Playhouse of Barnard College, where Sukanya offered a program of solos in the classical Indian styles known as Kuchipudi, Bharata Natyam and Orissi.

title: JAZZ: SAUTER-FINEGAN GROUP
description: ''FROM the time the late Eddie Sauter and I started this band, everything went wrong but the music,'' Bill Finegan remarked at Town Hall on Sunday evening early in the concert by a reconstituted Sauter-Finegan Orchestra. The music certainly was splendid. And perhaps today's audiences, as well as the musicians involved, are ready for the uniquely evocative, gleefully eccentric sounds of an early 1950's dance band that thought nothing of accompanying a sentimental ballad in several different keys at once or voicing a swinging riff for orchestra bells, harp and tuba.

description: Dissident soldiers agreed this morning to end their two-day occupation of a broadcast station, but hours later armed troopers, standing on rooftops, said they were refusing to leave.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: WHEN the Museum of Modern Art opened its exhibition of Mario Botta's architecture last November, the Swiss architect's first work in the United States was being completed in Long Island City, Queens. People who saw his monumental brick houses and schools displayed in the show could simply take the subway to the International Design Center, New York and see firsthand the surprising furniture showroom he designed for International Contract Furnishings. The architect had virtually created an in-house Stonehenge - an orderly landscape of monumental circular brick walls, with a sense of great permanence and purpose.
