title: Washburn in Clinic
description: Chris Washburn, the Golden State Warriors' rookie center who was the third player picked in the college draft last spring, entered a drug-treatment clinic yesterday after voluntarily seeking help. The team said that Washburn, who was placed on the injured list Tuesday for a kidney problem, was expected to remain at the Adult Substance Abuse Program Drug Rehabilitation Center in Van Nuys, Calif., for a minimum of four weeks. The Warriors did not disclose what drug was involved. Dan Finnane, the team president, said, ''He has the support of all of us in the Warriors' organization.'' One of the players drafted ahead of Washburn, Len Bias, died of cocaine intoxication two days after being picked by the Boston Celtics. Washburn played in 27 games for the Warriors, averaging 10 minutes and 3.5 points. George Karl, the Warriors' coach, said, ''My failure with Chris Washburn was I started him too early in the season and played him a lot. He had made a big impression in training camp. I should have brought him along more slowly.'' Under the agreement between the National Basketball Association and its union, a player who seeks drug treatment is given three opportunities for rehabilitation. The first time, he remains on the payroll, the second time he is removed from the payroll, and the third time he is banned with the possibility of reinstatement after two years. A player who tests positive for drugs without first volunteering for treatment is automatically banned. On Jan. 13, Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins of the Houston Rockets were banned after testing positive for cocaine.

Simple and beautifully designed, it carried no excess baggage in the form of weird headgear or accessories. It was his best collection since his ''rich peasant'' clothes 10 years ago, though the emphasis has shifted. Instead of fantasy, the focus is now on reality. This is not costume-party dressing - these are clothes women can wear.

title: Rodgers Guilty In Assault Case
description: Johnny Rodgers, the 1972 Heisman Trophy winner as a Nebraska halfback, was convicted today of assault with a deadly weapon and being a former felon in possession of a firearm.

description: The Government may push back the release of key trade and economic reports by as much as two weeks because of concern about their accuracy, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 'Political Is Personal'
description: Artworks by 90 women will be shown in ''The Political Is Personal,'' at the Ceres Gallery, 91 Franklin Street, from Feb. 3 through 21. Sponsored in part by the New York State Council on the Arts, the show is the third annual exhibition for the New York Feminist Art Institute and Women's Center for Learning. The artists in the exhibition include Isabel Bishop, Louise Bourgeois, Judy Chicago, Barbara Kruger, Elizabeth Murray, Suzanne Resnik, Faith Ringgold, Miriam Schapiro, Carolee Schneemann, Nancy Spero, Leonore Tawney and Hannah Wilke. Gallery hours are Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 6 P.M. For information, call 219-9590.

title: Talking Deals; Ted Turner Accepts a Veto
description: MANY private financing deals are struck with investors who become minority shareholders. Even though they do not get to call the shots, those investors often find ways to protect their interests.

title: DEBATE OF THE UNION
description: The state of ''The State of the Union'' is in flux. Before our very eyes, but while we were not looking, a fundamental change has taken place in the tradition known as the State of the Union Message.

title: Third World Subsidy
description: The European Community foreign ministers have agreed to give four underdeveloped countries a special subsidy already available to 66 states in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, community officials said today. Ministers agreed Tuesday that the subsidy program, under which the community compensates certain countries for losses in export earnings, be extended to Bangladesh, Haiti, Laos and Nepal.

title: CARDIOPULMONARY TECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CARRIAGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
WALL MASKS WITH DRAMA
description: FOR the past five years, on her annual summer trips to Venice, the interior designer Altina Pierro Vergata, left, has collected modern papier mache and leather masks, and brass-topped wood walking sticks. Most of the masks and sticks are handmade and depict classic characters from the 16th-century commedia dell'arte theater. Recently she started offering these items for sale. ''Collectors use the masks for wall decorations,'' she said. The Capitano Barba mask, bottom center, is red papier mache with a white beard, and is $55. The white Medico Delle Peste papier mache mask, top center, with its exceptionally long nose, was worn by doctors during epidemics. ''They filled the long nose cavity with herbs and spices to keep the insects away,'' said Mrs. Vergata. It is $55. The Baccho papier mache mask, above, has purple grapes and green leaves and is $90. The Giullare or jester mask, top left, costs $750. Walking sticks, which Mrs Vergata holds, left, are also topped with commedia dell'arte characters. Sticks are natural or black-painted walnut, and are $35 each. Mrs. Vergata can be reached at 212-688-6439, by appointment.

description: The Government has begun a large-scale campaign to teach the country that AIDS is spreading in Britain and that it is a fatal disease with no known cure.

title: Data General View
description: The Data General Corporation's orders are flat and the company sees no evidence of improvement in overall market demand, the company's chairman, Edson D. de Castro, told shareholders. Data General has seen modest improvement in its European order rate, Mr. de Castro said, but ''the rest of our business is weak.'' He added that the company's MV/15000 computer, announced last month, had received ''solid early acceptance, mostly from existing accounts.'' The company's stock closed today at $33.625, down 75 cents.

title: Spinoff to Settle Avondale Dispute
description: The battle for control of Avondale Industries has ended with the announcement that the company will sell six subsidiaries to a new concern being formed by William F. Connell. Mr. Connell, Avondale's chairman, is expected to leave the corporation when the sale is made final in late March. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Selected School Group To See a Tape on AIDS
description: The New York City Board of Education plans to show a 20-minute videotape about AIDS to students next month without changes requested by senior officials, a spokesman for the Schools Chancellor said yesterday.

title: U.S. Woman Arrested On Thai-Burmese Line
description: A New Jersey woman who has been campaigning on behalf of the rebellious Shan people in Burma was arrested today as she crossed the Thai border. She was later reported to have been released, fined about $40 and ordered deported.

title: Septien Case
description: A 10-year-old girl who accused Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, of sexually assaulting her would like to drop the charges, according to the girl's mother. But Jerry Cobb, Denton County (Tex.) District Attorney, said that the case had already gone through the grand jury and that his office would continue to pursue the matter. Septien, 33 years old, was indicted last week on a charge of aggravated sexual assault of a child. ''She's just a kid,'' the mother said. ''She is able to forgive and forget easily. She says we can still be friends with him, but it is hard for me, too. I don't want to be friends anymore.'' Septien said he was not guilty of the charge and called the accusation a misunderstanding. At a news conference last week, he said he had met with the parents and thought they had agreed not to pursue the case.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the killing of a nun at a halfway house in the Bronx misidentified the men shown. The police officer was Andrew Pecorino and the man leaving the house was Robert Martinez.

title: STRUGGLING TO KEEP SPANISH PURE
description: To many Hispanic New Yorkers, ''vacunar la carpeta'' means to vacuum the carpet. The phrase would baffle their Latin American counterparts, however, since by most dictionaries it translates into ''to vaccinate the portfolio.''

title: Ex-Prosecutor Denies Knowledge of a Tape
description: A former prosecutor of the molestation case at the McMartin preschool institution testified today he had not known that a tape recording depicting the mental condition of a key witness was made more than two years ago.

title: JAZZ: BUDDY DeFRANCO
description: BOTH Buddy DeFranco and Terry Gibbs made the transition from their swing-era roots to be-bop during the 1940's, but there is still a bit of both styles in their playing. For the last seven years they have made short annual tours together - Mr. DeFranco playing clarinet, Mr. Gibbs on vibes - and they are leading a quintet at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, through Sunday.

title: FRENCH COURT ORDERS A TRIAL FOR LEBANESE TERROR SUSPECT
description: A Paris appeals court ruled today that George Ibrahim Abdallah, the presumed leader of a major Lebanese terrorist group, would go on trial in Paris for complicity in the slayings of an American and an Israeli diplomat.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday incorrectly described the Petrina olive oil being sold locally. It comes in 12.7-ounce bottles.

title: IRANIAN DEFENDS BEIRUT ABDUCTIONS
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament today defended the seizure of Western hostages in Beirut and other terrorist actions by Lebanese groups, saying the Lebanese had no other way to defend themselves.

title: MUSIC: EMERSON QUARTET STARTS BEETHOVEN CYCLE
description: UNTIL about a decade ago, it was easily possible for a chamber-music enthusiast to go through a lifetime of concertgoing without hearing a complete performance of Beethoven's 16 string quartets. Nowadays, owing to an explosion of performing talent and a developing audience interest in these cornerstone works, such traversals have become almost commonplace. Even the youngest quartets feel the need to embrace the entire Beethoven cycle, which has become a Good Housekeeping warranty of excellence in the chamber-music world.

title: We Can Help
description: As South Africa hardens in its determination to maintain white supremacy, what can the United States do? Has it any useful role to play in this region? The questions are urgent. For it is ever clearer that apartheid threatens the peace of the whole area, with potentially dangerous consequences for the West as well.

title: Sunny Thoughts
description: He was among those in Pasadena on Sunday, but the way things turned out, the young man figures he might as well have stayed at home. ''It's like we were never even there,'' said John Elway, who suggested that, for a while at least, the 39-20 Super Bowl loss has made him a quarterback without a team. ''It's like the Giants are the only team there is.'' Despite his despondency over the Denver Broncos' loss, Elway, who is in Honolulu for the Pro Bowl game, indicated he had managed to find a ray of hope following the Giants' victory on Sunday: ''I was happy to see the sun still came up Monday morning.''

title: EATING FRESH FRUIT CAN REDUCE RISK OF STROKE, RESEARCHERS REPORT
description: Eating an extra helping of fresh fruit or vegetables each day could cut the risk of stroke nearly in half by increasing the body's supply of potassium, researchers have concluded.

title: SETTING THE RIGHT TONE FOR 'NEW' CARNEGIE HALL
description: ANYBODY who has spent time in Carnegie Hall since it reopened last month knows that - despite the painstaking care during its restoration and the oceans of public reassurance afterward - the acoustics of this magnificent space are not the same. The changes, if not dramatic, are at least significant, and I think all the parties concerned - the people who run Carnegie Hall, the people who play there and the listeners who buy tickets - are going to have to come out from behind the wall of public relations and talk about it openly. What follows is one man's view, and at the moment it could well be a minority view.

title: SOME OF THE BEST STAYED ON SIDELINES
description: A frequent caller to local newspapers and radio shows is someone who identifies himself as Steve, the Buck man.

title: WILLIAM G. RABE
description: William G. Rabe, a former director of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died Jan. 17 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

description: With Tom Webster still grounded, Phil Esposito made the decision yesterday that he wanted to avoid. For the sake of stability, Esposito said, he named himself as coach of the Rangers for the rest of the season.

title: Russian Revolution
description: Now Mikhail Gorbachev has turned his reformist zeal on the ultimate redoubt against change in the Soviet Union, the Communist Party. Yes, overcoming systemic inefficiency and cynicism still looks almost impossible. Yes, the West should understand that Mr. Gorbachev's call for democratization and an open society do not mean to him what they meant to Thomas Jefferson. Yet the Soviet leader's bold course makes a remarkable drama.

title: THE THEATER: 'WE SHALL,' RIGHTS ERA
description: KARMYN LOTT'S ''We Shall'' is a celebration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil-rights movement of the 1960's, and its funnier episodes and rousing musical numbers certainly leave one in a surprisingly festive spirit. It is surprising because Miss Lott's story, about a Howard University student who returns to his hometown in Texas in 1968 to spark a civil-rights drive, has its serious purposes. But, fortunately, she has indulged her infectious humor in scenes that exploit generational and social conflicts during church services, conversations in a very proper home and a hilarious meeting called to organize a protest march.

title: LYNCH SISTERS SEEK SAME BLUE RIBBON
description: One of the runners has set national records and the other, sprinting like a shadow on the heels of the first, would like to accomplish similar feats. Theirs is the very essence of a rivalry: they are sisters, a couple of smooth-gaited, well-spoken city girls with two years and nothing much else to separate them. They share the same parents, the same home, the same school and, ever since the younger sister decided five years ago that nothing but running would do as an emblem of her individuality, they share the same track.

title: COMPUTER SHAKEOUT AWAITED
description: For a little more than two years, computers for scientific and technical users have been the hottest sector in the industry, sending manufacturers scrambling to keep up with demand. Though sales are still soaring, the manufacturers' ranks have so swelled that industry leaders and analysts alike say a shakeout is inevitable.

title: Head of G.M. Sees End To Perot Controversy
description: The General Motors Corporation is recovering after a year of bad news, the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith, told a group of pension fund managers at an unusual meeting yesterday, the group's leaders said.

Shirley becomes one of six pitchers who will compete for the left-handed relief job behind Dave Righetti.

title: Chain-Collision in Fog Kills 4
description: Four people died and five others were critically injured today as 33 vehicles collided in dense fog on Interstate 10, about 15 miles west of New Orleans, the state police said. Officers said the collisions began about noon when three tractor-trailers collided. Four people died when the small car in which they were riding was crushed beneath a tractor-trailer that burst into flames, the police said.

title: Playing for Time For the '88 Campaign
description: Governor Cuomo's closest advisers insist he is still making up his mind about running for President. They say that if he does run, he will be a late starter - no earlier than next April, and more likely the summer or early fall.

title: HOMELESSNESS INSPIRES A GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: Elizabeth Quinn of Glen Ridge, N.J., is one of many contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who have asked that their donations be used to aid the homeless.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Andy McGaffigan, a pitcher, settled his salary arbitration case with the Montreal Expos, reducing to 77 the number of major-league players remaining in arbitration. . . . Bill Giles, president of the Philadelphia Phillies, met in Los Angeles with Tom Reich, agent for Lance Parrish, the free-agent catcher. ''It was a very cordial meeting and we'll meet again,'' Reich said. . . . Billy Olson, the American indoor record-holder in the pole vault, has withdrawn from the Millrose Games tomorrow night. Howard Schmertz, the meet director, said that Olson did not have any physical problems but that Olson was despondent about failing to clear a height in two meets this season. . . . The Islanders have recalled Roydon Gunn, a goalie, from Erie of the Atlantic Coast Hockey League.

title: Santa Fe Seeks I.C.C. Approval
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it had reached an agreement with the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad in hopes of securing Interstate Commerce Commission approval to merge two of its rail units. The I.C.C. last July denied a petition by Santa Fe Southern Pacific to merge two of its units, the Santa Fe Railway and the Southern Pacific Transportation Company. The I.C.C. cited a potentially adverse effect on rail competition.

title: Bridge: A Delicate Bidding Decision Paid Off in a Florida Game
description: Some very difficult bidding decisions arise when there is a weakness for no-trump purposes but no convenient trump fit. An example is the diagramed deal, played recently in Hobe Sound, Fla. There was no eight-card fit in a major suit, no nine-card fit in a minor suit and three no-trump was headed for heart trouble.

title: GAF Chemicals Picks a President
description: For Heinn F. Tomfohrde 2d, formerly the president of specialty and service businesses for the ailing Union Carbide Corporation, the world has taken a peculiar turn. Yesterday, the 51-year-old chemical engineer was named president of the GAF Chemicals Corporation, a unit of the same company that last year mounted a ferocious attempt to acquire Carbide.

description: In this city steeped in history and crammed with Buddhist temples, Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor, is leading a quiet life, studying the ancient practice of Zen meditation and writing a book on his word processor.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: Q.Behind the wood-burning stove in our home we have a wall of brown fieldstone. We would like to put a clear coating over this stone to bring out the color. Can you suggest anything that will not be affected by the heat from the stove? A.It depends how far away the stove is from the wall. Codes in many communities require that there be at least three feet between the stove and the nearest flammable materials. I know of no clear sealer or coating that is completely nonflammable. There are a number of clear sealers sold for use on masonry that will brighten the color. But if the stove is very close the heat could darken - or scorch - any sealer left on the surface of the stone (even though most of it will soak in). Q.My house has horizontal lap siding on the outside. The boards are about nine inches wide and three-quarters of an thick on the lower edge. They taper to about one-eighth-inch thick at the top. The boards were poorly installed; certain ones barely overlap. When certain boards shrink there is no overlap in places. Even though the nails seem to be the right kind (coated or screw nails), some have backed out and loosened -mainly because they were not driven into the studs, only into the black building board underneath. A.Where nails are improperly located, merely drive in new nails that will hit the studs. You can then pull the old nails out and fill the holes with putty. However, where the boards do not overlap properly, there is no easy repair. Those boards will have to be ripped off and nailed properly, even if this means taking off a few more boards than seem necessary at first glance. Q.We put in a cedar deck last spring and applied a sealer to protect the wood. When the wood is dry it is pale gray, but when it is wet it has a reddish color that looks more like cedar. We don't want to paint the wood, but we wanted something to bring out more of the reddish color. My husband read about using linseed oil for this, so he tried this over the sealer in one section. That section is now dark gray and is spotty looking. A.There are decking stains and pigmented wood sealers that can be used on wood decks to restore the original color - or close to it -and maintain that color. As you have discovered, linseed oil is not a good choice for a clear sealer because it usually oxidizes and turns black in time. Although the oil will eventually wear off, this may take years and the deck will still look spotty.

description: Top officials of the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday that they would retry one of two avowed revolutionairies accused of killing a New Jersey state trooper in 1981.

title: The Stage of the Union
description: Like an old trouper, President Reagan belted out all the old favorites. Old oratory like ''You and I stand on the shoulders of giants'' . . . Old proposals like ''a line-item veto so we can carve out the boondoggles and pork'' . . . Even familiar jokes about his own age. It was as though endless evocations of the old would serve as incantations to the political spirits; as though preserving the illusion of strength would preserve the real thing.

title: WHEN WORKING IS GOOD FOR YOUR HEALTH
description: LEAD: FILLED with daylight, clean air and trees, the new national headquarters of the Evironmental Defense Fund brings the outdoors inside. Completed this month, it is the result of a yearlong collaboration among architects and environmentalists who wanted, literally and symbolically, to provide a breath of fresh air in a midtown office building.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JOYCE IN PARIS The Gotham Book Mart and Gallery, 41 West 47th Street (719-4476), has had a relationship with James Joyce for more than a half-century, since ''Ulysses,'' which was classified as an immoral, unimportable work by the Federal Government, was sold under the counter at the store. The society of James Joyce admirers still meets at the Gotham and his books are sold over the counter in this most venerable of quality New York bookstores.

Tarkenton Heads List
description: Fran Tarkenton, 10 other former players and three former coaches have been named to the National Football Foundation's College Hall of Fame. Before Tarkenton embarked on an 18-year career with the Minnesota Vikings and the Giants, he played quarterback at Georgia. The other players chosen were Johnny Majors, tailback from Tennessee; Carroll Dale, wide receiver from Virginia Tech; Ted Hendricks, linebacker from Miami; Don Heinrich, quarterback from Washington; Mike Reid, tackle from Penn State; Dick Scott, center from Navy; Jim Ray Smith, tackle from Baylor; Joe Steffy, guard from Army; George Webster, roverback from Michigan State, and Ron Yary, tackle from Southern Cal. The three coaches were Bob Blackman, who coached 33 years, at Denver, Dartmouth, Illinois and Cornell; Dave Nelson, 17 years, at Hillsdale (Mich.), Maine and Delaware, and Thad Vann, 20 years at Southern Mississippi.

description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $15.4 million ($10.7 million after tax, or 39 cents a share) and $6.4 million ($4.6 million after tax, or 17 cents a share) for the quarter and year, respectively, from the sale of certain timberlands; the quarter also includes a pre-tax gain of $15.5 million ($11 million after tax, or 40 cents a share) from the sale of the company's headquarters complex; an after-tax gain of $2.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of packaging operations; a pre-tax loss of $10.8 million ($6.5 million after tax) to provide for the writeoff of certain non-strategic operations; a pre-tax loss of $31.1 million ($16.8 million after tax) for severance benefits and other expenses related to corporate overhead reductions; and higher tax expense of $4.6 million related to reversal of ITC benefits previously recorded. Also included is an extraordinary pre-tax loss of $19.4 million ($10.5 million after tax) from debt redemptions. c-Includes pre-tax gains of $69.3 million ($47.9 million after tax, or $1.76 a share) from the sale of 17 percent of American Capital Management & Research Inc. to the public, and the non- recurring impact of a labor strike in the packaging business, which reduced pre-tax income by $21.4 ($13.6 million after tax, or 50 cents a share). Also included is a pre-tax extraordinary loss of $22.8 million ($13.2 million after tax) from debt redemptions. d-Includes pre-tax gains of $5.4 million ($3.9 million after tax, or 16 cents a share) and $11.8 million ($8.5 million after tax, or 34 cents a share) from the sale of certain timberlands for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes the following non-recurring items: a pre-tax gain of $33.3 million ($17.5 million after tax, or 72 cents a share) from the sale of an equity interest in James River Corporation, and a pre-tax loss of $40 million ($28.8 million) from the writedown of a preferred stock investment in New TC Holding Corporation.

title: Land for the Landless Will Help Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: He Came to Stay
description: The rookie from towns in southwest Texas like Denver City and Colorado City and El Paso -places where his father had worked as a ''cotton-ginner'' - showed up in 1958 in the training camp of the New York Giants. He was tall and skinny and wore unfashionably long sideburns and not-yet-fashionable cowboys boots. He had had a foot locker carted in and, as he recalls it, carried ''a bag in my right hand and a bag in my left hand.''

title: SOUTH JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $145,000 and $178,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and for the year also includes an extraordinary credit of $1,503,000 from an accounting change. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $653,000 and $616,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: An Electoral Gap
description: Analysis of exit poll data from last fall's Senate elections suggests that the political difference between how men and women vote is alive and well. A breakdown compiled by CBS News indicates that women voted significantly more Democratic than men. Of 23 races analyzed, in only one did the Republican candidate appeal more to women than to men. That was in Oregon, where the incumbent, Bob Packwood, a defender of abortion rights, won with 61 percent of the vote, polling 60 percent among men and 62 percent among women. Interestingly, the broadest gap appeared to be in Maryland, where both candidates were women. Forty-four percent of the men who voted cast ballots for the Republican, Lydia Chavez; only 34 percent of the women supported her. The Democrat, Barbara Mikulski, who won the race, got 62 percent of the female vote and 54 percent of the male.

title: U.S. Presses Airbus Fight
description: The United States is ready to file charges of unfair-trade practices against Airbus Industrie, the European airplane-building consortium, if it builds A330 and A340 jetliners to compete against the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's new MD-11, officials here said today.

title: Marketing Is Added To Charity Food Fair
description: An especially popular fund-raising event that aids Harlem youngsters is about to become a marketing tool.

title: 'Platoon' and 'Critical' Lead Box-Office Sales
description: The Vietnam War film ''Platoon'' nearly equaled Richard Pryor's ''Critical Condition'' at the box office last weekend, even though it played in about one-sixth as many theaters.

W.R. GRACE IS CHARGED WITH LYING ABOUT WASTE
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted W. R. Grace & Company on charges that it lied to the United States Enviromental Protection Agency about the use of chemicals and waste disposal techniques at its industrial plant in Woburn, Mass.

title: DOLLAR UP IN RELATION TO THE YEN
description: In global currency trading roiled by rumors, the Japanese yen finally lost ground against the dollar yesterday. There were unconfirmed reports of heavy intervention by Japan's central bank to prevent the yen from gaining further strength to the detriment of vital Japanese exports.

title: RECTAL: STALLMAN, A FLUTIST
description: ROBERT STALLMAN, a flutist who performs and teaches in both the New York and Boston areas, gave a musically rewarding if rather overbright and insistently performed recital Tuesday night in Weill Recital Hall. These qualities may reflect Mr. Stallman's association with Jean-Pierre Rampal, who has a similar approach, or the acoustics of Weill Hall. Most likely this is just his own personal style, which places a premium on forceful attacks, rhythmic propulsion and a narrow range of tonal colors.

title: THEATER: 'SELF-DEFENSE,' A COURTHOUSE DRAMA
description: As it took a New Haven jury to deliver verdicts in the New York municipal scandals, so it apparently falls to a New Haven theater to examine the New York system of ''negotiated'' criminal justice. ''Self Defense,'' the new play at the Long Wharf, is a plunge into the bleak morass of due process as practiced by public defenders and district attorneys in the Bronx of 1986. It's not a spectacle to inspire a nation's civics classes. In the view of the author, a first-time playwright named Joe Cacaci, such concepts as guilt and innocence, let alone such niceties as civil rights, are rendered irrelevant on an urban legal battlefield buffeted by plea bargaining, City Hall politics and pretrial publicity in The New York Post.

title: IPALCO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $48,684,000 from the sale of the assets of Indianapolis Cablevision Inc.

title: JEROME H. TEITELBAUM
description: Jerome H. Teitelbaum, a New York real-estate executive, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Whitney Houston Wins Five Music Awards
description: Whitney Houston's two-year-old album has brought her five American Music Awards, while Lionel Richie, whose album was not even nominated, won four awards for songs and videos from his ''Dancing on the Ceiling'' album.

description: Yields on money market accounts, certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds showed a general softening for the second consecutive week ended yesterday.

description: Two Sikhs were sentenced to life in jail today for plotting to blow up a plane.

title: Westvaco to Continue Family's Leadership
description: The Lukes have run the Westvaco Corporation since it was founded in 1888. Yesterday, one Luke announced his intention to relinquish the chief executive post next year - but to his younger brother.

title: Rep. Burton Will Not Seek Re-election to House in '88
description: Representative Sala Burton, who has been unable to attend a session of Congress this year because of treatment for cancer, said today she would not run for re-election in 1988.

title: ENGINEER WHO OPPOSED LAUNCHING CHALLENGER SUES THIOKOL FOR $1 BILLION
description: A Morton Thiokol engineer, whose anguished pleas to delay the launching of the space shuttle Challenger were ignored a year ago, filed a $1 billion personal injury and damage suit against the company today and accused it of ''criminal homicide'' in the death of the seven crew members.

title: JEFFERIES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fundamental Awards
description: Fundamentalists Anonymous, an 18-month-old group based in New York, has chosen the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who is an unnanounced contender for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, for a ''Hall of Infamy'' award.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Fraud and Garbage in Science
description: An elaborate case of scientific fraud, first discovered at the Harvard Medical School in 1981, has turned out to have another, more surprising dimension. Besides fraud, according to an analysis in Nature magazine, the papers of Dr. John Darsee and his co-authors were studded with obvious errors and inconsistencies. Yet even these failed to alert the peer committees, editors and referees who vet the quality of medical research.

title: Dow Rises by 12.94 To Another Record
description: Profit takers robbed Wall Street of much of its energy yesterday, but in the end, the stock market was able to gather enough strength to move once again to record levels.

title: McDonald's Up 9.8%
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that it earned $113.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1986, up 9.8 percent from $103.5 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 10.5 percent, to $3.17 billion, from $2.87 billion. For the year, McDonald's said it earned $479.7 million, or $3.73 a share, a 10.8 percent gain from the $433 million, or $3.32 a share, of 1985. Annual sales increased 13 percent, to $12.43 billion, from $11 billion. The company's sales have doubled in the last six years, Fred L. Turner, the chairman, said. About 500 restaurants will be added worldwide this year, he said.

title: BATTLE ON IMPORT CURBS LOOMS
description: A conflict is looming between the White House and Congress over Presidential discretion in import curbs.

title: A BIG LOSS AT CARBIDE IN QUARTER
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported a substantial quarterly loss but a profit for 1986 as a whole. Another chemical giant, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, was down 11.1 percent in the quarter but up 38 percent for the full year.

title: Books; Faith in Freedom
description: OF PRISONS AND IDEAS. By Milovan Djilas. Translated from the Serbo-Croatian by Michael Boro Petrovich. 166 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95. MILOVAN DJILAS is one of the last of the high-ranking ex-Partisans who fought in the mountains of Yugoslavia against the Germans. The political power of members of resistance groups, who harassed the Nazi Occupation forces in all the countries along the Mediterranean littoral, faded long ago. Disappointment in the rigidities of promised revolutionary change, after the relative independence of life in combat, led to the dismemberment of wartime dreams.

title: Truck in Newark Kills Stowaway Fleeing Ship
description: Nine stowaways on a cargo vessel from Ecuador jumped ship yesterday in Port Newark, and one was killed and one was seriously injured minutes later when they were hit by a truck, a Port Authority spokesman said.

title: ALL THIS AND FRUIT, TOO: ASIAN PEAR, HARDY KIWI
description: THE produce manager of my grocery store calls them ''yuppie fruit.'' Imported from Japan and individually protected from damage by little jackets of plastic foam netting, they cost $1.29 each. He also calls them pear-apples and says that they're a cross between a pear and an apple, just as nectarines are a cross between a plum and a peach. They are round, like apples, but my greengrocer is wrong. Nectarines are peaches, period, but smooth-skinned ones. What are sold in my grocery store are pears, but Asian ones.

title: The White House Link To Iran Investigations: David M. Abshire
description: David M. Abshire knows something about dealing with Capitol Hill. He was an Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations in the early 1970's, when the Nixon Administration was trying to suppress information about military incursions into Laos and Cambodia.

title: Market Place; Global Funds For Bonds
description: GLOBAL mutual funds that invest mainly in bonds of foreign governments are becoming popular. These funds offer American investors a potential play on the declining value of the dollar against overseas currencies.

title: MOSTLY MISERY FOR KNICKS
description: There appears to be little to brag about for the Knicks at the halfway point of the season. They have a record of 13-29 - two games worse than at this point last season - a four-game losing streak, and diminishing hopes of qualifying for the playoffs.

title: DU PONT DE NEMOURS, E I & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company reported lower net for the latest fourth quarter, said the net effect on 1986 earnings of gains from sales of businesses, losses on restructuring of investments, the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and various non- recurring items was a net benefit of 11 cents a share, and earnings for 1985 included a net charge of 58 cents a share for non-recurring items. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter reflects a tax benefit resulting from adjustment of a prior- year tax provision of $40 million and related interest of $45 million. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year include gains of $46 million on the sale of the ''Reemay'' and U.S. ''Typar'' businesses and $43 million on the sale of its 50-percent interest in Condea Chemie GMBH, a German affiliate. The latest fourth quarter also includes a charge of $138 million associated with the dismantlement of ''Kel- Chlor,''Chlorocarbons and Chloralkali facilities. The company said that in 1985 it accrued a loss of $194 million from its withdrawal from an investment in Syngas Co. and the shutdown of an associated methanol plant, and the shutdown of an ethylene production unit. In addition, a loss of $32 million was recognized when Du Pont Canada Inc., a majority-owned Canadian subsidiary, agreed to dispose of its 20-percent interest in Petrosar Ltd. The company said the 1985 results also include a $200 million expense related to an incentive offered to substantially all domestic employees for early retirement.

title: KEY CONTRA LEADER IS SAID TO PLAN TO RESIGN
description: A key civilian leader of the Nicaraguan rebel movement has told State Department officials and his political associates that he intends to resign, sources close to him said today.

DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S ART PATRONS
description: Paul Schnell said that two years ago he didn't know very much about the contemporary art scene but yearned to know more. Though his mother was a painter and his grandfather an art dealer, Mr. Schnell's everyday world revolves around corporate mergers and acquisitions -far from the heart of New York's art world.

description: To the Editor:

title: BEST HOPE FOR NETS: '87 LOTTERY
description: The season only seems to grow longer for the Nets. At their present pace, they are likely to finish the season with their worst record in a decade and without a spot in the playoffs. They have endured a succession of injuries, smallish crowds in their own arena and the indignity of losing at home with frightening regularity.

title: ARCHITECTURE: IN WRIGHT'S SHADOW
description: THE work of the architect Lloyd Wright, the eldest son of Frank Lloyd Wright, has been all but ignored beside that of his more famous father. So overwhelming is the presence of the elder Wright in the American architectural consciousness that there is barely room for any other Wrights. With a father like Frank Lloyd Wright, how could any architect-son make his presence felt?

title: U.A.W. REACHES A TENTATIVE PACT WITH DEERE
description: A tentative agreement between Deere & Company and members of the United Automobile Workers was reached late Tuesday, ending a 168-day work stoppage at 14 plants in Iowa and Illinois, the longest in the company's history.

title: Genesco in Canada
description: Genesco Inc. has signed an agreement to allow a group of investors to buy the company's operations in Canada, the company said. The producer of footwear and men's apparel will sell three plants and 330 retail stores to a corporation controlled by Michael K. Graye and a group of Canadian investors, including the Royal Bank of Canada, a Genesco spokesman, John Pennington, said. The sale price was not disclosed.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN snow piles up on the roof in freezing weather, ice dams can form at the edges of the roof, particularly above the eaves. Water may be trapped by these dams and eventually back up under the shingles, dripping into the attic and damaging insulation, plaster, gypsum board, paint or wallpaper.

title: HEAT WHERE IT'S NEEDED
description: WITH the advent of central heating in the mid-19th century, cast iron registers and grilles were used as a way to distribute heat in a home. Installed in walls, ceilings and floors, the grilles enabled hot air, created by the basement furnace, to circulate from room to room. Now these registers and grilles are being revived, largely by those using wood stoves.

title: MOLESTATION JURY CLEARS EX-OFFICIAL
description: A jury today found the former president of a western Massachusetts college not guilty of sexually molesting a student.

title: Indiana Utility Improves
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana said today that it will report a much smaller loss for 1986 than it had in 1985. The company also said its board had approved the payment of preferred dividends for the first quarter, and for other quarters. Such payouts were suspended last year. The Indiana utility did not specify what its total loss will be. It said it would have operating earnings of $1.68 a share for 1986, but noted that those operating earnings would be wiped out by, among other things, losses on the canceled Marble Hill nuclear power plant.

description: Given the mystery surrounding the Reagan Administration's secret effort to keep the Nicaraguan rebels supplied with arms, perhaps it was inevitable there would be talk about a movie.

title: Armco to Sell Units
description: Armco Inc. said it would sell several of its steel-tubing operations in Europe to the London-based TI Group for about $41 million. The agreement includes Armco's small-diameter tubing business in Europe, consisting of a steel-strip coating operation in Liege, Belgium, and 10 facilities in Sweden, Denmark, Italy, Belgium and Spain. TI Group will also buy Armco's steel merchandising and welding equipment businesses in Italy. Armco said in a statement that the sale should be completed by the end of February.

Keeton to discuss a settlement in the trial.
