The company said currency adjustment losses totaled 9 cents a share in 1986 compared with 25 cents in 1985.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes benefits of $48 million in non-operating gains from the sale of selected assets and surplus properties and from the settlement of an outstanding issue with the Iranian government; a $36 million operating gain arising from clarification of the arrangements with a foreign producing country; a $21 million operating profit attributable to the recognition of a receivable for prior periods' gas production in the United Kingdom; a $24 million gain due to a change in pension accounting policies and a $20 million charge for employee severance programs. c-Includes foreign currency translation gains amounting to $130 million, compared with gains of $28 million a year ago. d-Includes a gain of $31 million from the reversion of overfunded pension assets in excess of the receivable recognized in the merger of Getty Oil Co., and a charge of $54 million relating to writeoffs of idle and surplus assets and adjustments to previously established reserve provisions. e-Includes LIFO inventory drawdown benefits totaling $63 million, of which $22 million was recorded in the fourth quarter. The company said there were no LIFO drawdown effects in 1986 and that under LIFO inventory accounting, the sharp rise in spot market prices since mid-December 1986 increased the cost of crude oil lifted in November and December under netback arrangements and penalized fourth-quarter net earnings by about $60 million.

title: THE DANCE: LYONS OPERA BALLET IN NEW INTERNATIONAL WORKS
description: THE hit mentality is basically alien to ballet but a hit production is very much what the Lyons Opera Ballet came up with last week in Maguy Marin's ''Cinderella.'' Faced with a hard act to follow in its final week, the French company - eager to show off its dancers in a wider repertory - is now presenting a very different program. There are four works by five choreographers.

title: Each Administration Builds White House Anew; Panel of Wise Men
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT WARREN
description: Robert Warren, a song writer and music arranger, died of pancreatic cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the results for the latest fourth quarter and year-ago period include loan loss provisions of $6,300,000 and $1,500,000, respectively. The company said the latest year results include an after-tax gain of $1,771,964 from the sale of securities.

title: STAGE: 'WHISPERS,' SOVIET OUTCASTS
description: IN Crispin Larangeira's ''Whispers,'' Joan MacIntosh plays a Soviet poet who has survived years of Stalinist repression. An exile within her own country, she has endured the death of her husband and child. In isolation in Siberia, she continues to write verse - while working as a schoolteacher. Privately, she transcribes her thoughts, putting the poems in jars, which she hides in various places in her cabin. Forty-one jars are testimony to her indomitability.

title: HEAVY BURDEN OF COLLEGE DEBT RAISES ANXIETY FOR YOUNG FAMILIES' FUTURE
description: In May, Mark Kaplan, a senior at the University of Michigan, will graduate with a bachelor's degree in English, $18,000 in student loans hanging over him and no idea how he will pay the money back.

title: DATAFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GUILTY PLEA BY BOESKY EMPLOYEE
description: Michael Davidoff, formerly the head trader at a securities company controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, pleaded guilty yesterday to having engaged in bogus stock transactions with a British broker to evade Federal laws requiring brokers to maintain minimum amounts of capital.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Die in Ozone Park Fire Three children and their baby sitter died when a smoky fire swept a two-story house in Queens. A fourth child was critically injured. Page B3. Nuclear Waste Site Delay A five-year delay in opening the nation's first burial site for radioactive nuclear waste was proposed by the Reagan Administration. Page A19.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: STUDENTS IN SPAIN WIN SOME DEMANDS
description: The Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, confronted by student strikes and some of the worst youth violence in Spain in a decade, offered today to increase university scholarships and student participation in the schools.

title: MANUFACTURER NOW SAYS SMOKING WON'T MEAN AUTOMATIC DISMISSAL
description: Employees of the USG Acoustical Products Corporation will not necessarily be dismissed if they violate a widely publicized smoking ban and some will not be affected at all, a company spokesman said Tuesday.

title: KEMP FAULTS THREE G.O.P. RIVALS AS HE PRAISES SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN
description: In the first open skirmish over ideas in the 1988 Presidential campaign, Representative Jack F. Kemp today criticized three other Republican Presidential hopefuls for their positions on Social Security. He vigorously defended the existing system, which he said must remain ''the bedrock of retirement security.''

title: EX-QUEENS PARTY DEPUTY CONVICTED IN 'NO SHOW' JOB CASE
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday convicted Richard L. Rubin, an influential Queens political figure, of fraudulently arranging to have two former secretaries in his law firm paid with state funds.

title: 9 ALIENS' ARRESTS LAID TO POLITICS
description: American and civil liberties groups today condemned as ''politically motivated'' the arrest of nine people this week in Los Angeles who were said to be supporters of a militant Palestinian group.

title: Commerce Chief Says He Will Resign
description: Ronald Moss, New York State's Commerce Commissioner since May 1985, announced yesterday that he was resigning.

title: IN CHINA, FROM MARCHES TO A LEADERSHIP CRISIS
description: When 3,000 students marched through the streets of Hefei, in Anhui Province, last month in support of democracy, it seemed inconceivable that in little more than six weeks China would be wrenched by its most serious political crisis in more than a decade.

title: Economic Woes Laid To Society's Failings
description: Behind the theme of ''competitiveness'' that President Reagan struck in his State of the Union Message Tuesday lies new political attention to failings in the American economy that have troubled industrial analysts for years.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUGHTON-MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $3.9 million, or 27 cents a share, on the sale of real estate. The company said the latest share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 20, 1986. The year-ago share figures have been restated for comparative reporting requirements.

title: Fannie Mae Issue For Home Savings
description: Home Savings of America is offering $454 million of Federal National Mortgage Association securities backed by adjustable-rate mortgages, with the First Boston Corporation as underwriter.

title: EMERGENCY-ROOM RULES STIFFENED
description: The Emergency Medical Services said yesterday that the 43 hospitals in New York City's emergency ambulance system would soon be required to have fully trained attending physicians and more nurses and lifesaving equipment in their emergency rooms 24 hours a day.

title: ROCKING CHAIRS: FOLKLORE AND FACT
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the motion of a crib supported on curved runners had for centuries lulled infants to sleep, it took a while longer for the idea to be carried over into other types of furniture. The rocking chair came into its own in the mid-18th century. Although it is part of folklore that the rocking chair was invented by Benjamin Franklin, it has not been proved.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Tentative Approval For USAir-P.S.A.
description: The Transportation Department has tentatively approved USAir Group's proposed $400 million acquisition of Pacific Southwest Airlines. The agency, which has final authority over airline mergers, said it had concluded that the transaction would not harm competition and would be consistent with the public interest.

title: ENGINEER DENIES USE OF DRUG IN COLLISION THAT TOOK 16 LIVES
description: The Conrail engineer whose locomotive traveled into the path of an Amtrak train Jan. 4, resulting in a collision that claimed 16 lives, denies smoking marijuana in the cab the day of the crash and says he has been plagued with guilt for surviving.

title: NEEDIEST GIFT IS AN HONOR TO A MEMORY
description: Among the contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is New York State Senator Roy M. Goodman, who gave $12,500 through the Goodman Family Foundation in memory of his parents, Dr. and Mrs. B. A. Goodman.

title: ECONOMIC REPORT PRODS ALLIES
description: Amid new signs of an impending five-nation meeting to try to stabilize the dollar, President Reagan urged other major countries today to help reduce the American trade deficit, a key reason for the dollar's decline.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Sports Pages on Jan. 23 about a Devils game attended by only 334 spectators because of a snowstorm, omitted the name of the team that the Devils defeated, 7-4. It was the Calgary Flames.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOW AIR FARES OFFERED, WITH A TWIST
description: Continental and Eastern Airlines said yesterday that they would cut their lowest fares by as much as 40 percent on nearly all domestic flights beginning Sunday. Passengers must buy the tickets when they reserve seats, and no refunds, exchanges or transfers to other people will be allowed.

title: 'BELL JAR' CASE ENDS IN ACCORD
description: The trial centering on ''The Bell Jar,'' a 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel, ended here today in Federal District Court when both sides agreed to a judgment that Dr. Jane V. Anderson, a 55-year-old psychiatrist, was unintentionally defamed by the movie.

title: GATT MEMBERS AGREE ON NEW TRADE ROUND
description: Representatives of nearly 100 industrial and developing nations finally agreed today to start important trade-freeing negotiations next month. Their accord came after the United States and France reached an ambiguous compromise on what priority agriculture should have in the talks.

title: Hannah's Distant Cousins
description: The setting was in Maputo, Mozambique. It is summer and the flame trees were in gaudy blossom along the broad, grass-verged avenues where well-to-do Portuguese lived when this was a colonial capital called Lourenco Marques.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 30, 1987
description: International

title: Rocking the Boat
description: A mutiny led by four American oarsmen threatens to swamp Oxford's chances of beating Cambridge in the famous Thames match race March 28.

title: Phillips Income Falls Steeply
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported substantial declines yesterday in profits for the fourth quarter and all of 1986.

title: Clarke Show Delayed
description: Martha Clarke's ''Hunger Artist'' will begin previews next Thursday at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. The production was originally scheduled to begin previews this Tuesday, but it needed more preparation time, according to Pete Sanders, press spokesman for the show. Information: 265-4375.

title: ART: 50 YEARS OF TWORKOV ON PAPER
description: THE current 50-year retrospective of works on paper by Jack Tworkov at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery, 429 West Broadway, at Prince Street, is an exhibition that reveals itself slowly and gently. But it turns out in the end to have more strength, and more variety, than many a show that tries to knock us out before we even get inside the door.

title: Contradictions Emerge
description: To the Editor:

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After losses of $876,000 from discontinued operations and $4,898,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $395,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $819,000 from discontinued operations. The company did not report on quarterly share earnings.

title: Israelis Wound an Arab Youth Trying to Flee Arrest in Gaza
description: Israeli forces shot and seriously wounded a Palestinian youth today as he tried to escape from arrest after taking part in an anti-Israeli demonstration in the occupied Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said.

title: COGHLAN REGAINS FORM AND CONFIDENCE
description: Eamonn Coghlan has known the bad days. Now, he says, he is enjoying the good.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ''I WANTED a bowl for the dining-room table,'' Jill R. Fine said, recalling how she and her husband, M. Austin Fine, began their 25-year pursuit of Americana. Most of the couple's collection - 338 ceramics, paintings, pieces of furniture, quilts and weathervanes -is to be auctioned today at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, in a sale the auction house estimates will total between $755,000 and $1 million.

title: NORTHWEST TELEPRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October.

title: What Arms Control Is All About
description: On Jan. 15, arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union resumed in Geneva. That event was greeted with satisfaction in most quarters around the world. The outstanding exception is here in the United States, where a significant body of opinion on the right views arms control as a snare and a delusion.

title: INSIDE
description: Impellitteri Dies at 86 Vincent R. Impellitteri, Mayor of New York from 1950 to 1953, died in a Bridgeport, Conn., hospital. He was 86 years old. Page B8. 2 Airlines Slash Fares Continental and Eastern said they would cut discount domestic fares as much as 40 percent but would make the tickets nonrefundable. Page A16.

title: BRIDGEPORT PLAN PROMISES JOBS TO GRADUATES
description: Business leaders here today promised 75 jobs to students graduating from local public high schools this year. Eventually, they intend to guarantee a job for virtually every graduate.

title: Tunnel Loan Weighed
description: The European Community is considering granting a $:1 billion, or about $1.54 billion, loan to help finance the planned tunnel under the English channel to link Britain with mainland Europe, a community official said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 378 money market mutual funds decreased $554.6 million, to $233.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $294.7 million, to $65.28 billion. Assets of the 195 general purpose funds were down $449.4 million, to $61.96 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds fell $299.9 million, to $106.63 billion.

title: GOVERNOR PICKS PANEL OF ADVISERS 821:76,813>
description: Governor Cuomo - in the strongest hint to date that he might run for President - named a panel of experts yesterday to advise him on policies for dealing with the national trade deficit and other problems in the United States economy.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes restructuring charges of $139.9 million for the quarter and $162.2 million for the year, and quarter also includes one-time charges of $69 million primarily associated with workforce reductions and facility closings. c-Includes restructuring charges of $121 million and $274.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: G.M. Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 3,000 hourly workers Monday, bringing to 30,000 the number of employees on indefinite leave from the car maker's American plants. A spokesman said the layoffs reflect previously announced cuts at assembly and component factories. G.M. employs 380,000 hourly workers in the United States.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yanks' Scurry Arrested
description: Rod Scurry, the Yankee relief pitcher who has undergone drug rehabilitation, was arrested Wednesday for drunken driving and reckless operation of a vehicle, according to police in Reno. Officers said Scurry, 30 years old, was released on $770 bail six hours later. Since Scurry refused to submit to a chemical test, his driver's license was revoked under Nevada law, the police said. Scurry, who recently signed for another season with the Yankees, was among the players whom Commissioner Peter Ueberroth required to take part in drug testing before the start of last season. He testified in 1985 before a Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh investigating drug use in major-league baseball.

title: CHINA PREMIER VOWS TO LIMIT CAMPAIGN AGAINST DISSENT
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, in what amounted to an address to the nation, said today that the campaign against intellectual freedom and political dissent would be curtailed and that China's policy of economic change would continue.

title: Cadbury Cool To Stock Buyer
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the soft-drink and chocolate concern, told the General Cinema Corporation yesterday that further purchases of Cadbury stock by General Cinema ''would not be welcome.'' Earlier this week, General

title: REAGAN CLASHES WITH DEMOCRATS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan and the Democratic leaders of Congress clashed sharply today at a White House meeting on the Federal budget and other domestic policy matters.

title: CALIFORNIA MICRO DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $217,000 for the 6 months.

title: WHO'S AFRAID OF THE NEW BRITISH READING ROOM?
description: As long as there's an England, there will probably be a reading room at the British Museum.

title: WILD TALES OF THE SOUTHERN SNOW BELT
description: The capital has had a tough week.

title: Transcontinental Sets Debentures
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation is offering $150 million of 9 1/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99.44 to yield 9.18 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title:
TV SPORTS;
AT LONG LAST, A MAJOR EVENT FOR ESPN
description: LEAD: Finally, there is something special on ESPN.

title: Wesleyan Unit Urges Six Be Disciplined
description: The Student Judical Board at Wesleyan University has recommended that three students be given written warnings and three others put on disciplinary probation for interrupting campus tours for prospective freshmen and their families.

title:
Economic Scene;
U.S. Prospects For Growth
description: LEAD: ONE of the questions perplexing economists these days is whether the stunning rise in the stock market this month presages a similar surge in the nation's economy - as it has so many times in the past.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A SPECIAL GAIN HELPS T.W.A. NET
description: Trans World Airlines yesterday reported both an operating and a net profit for the fourth quarter, which in the past has been its weakest quarter and one usually with heavy losses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 30, 1987
description: The Economy

title: A WORRY FOR LABOR
description: The sudden end of the Long Island Rail Road strike, a relief to 110,000 commuters, has left union leaders pondering whether they lost not only this particular strike but also the strike as a weapon in future labor disputes. Labor experts fear that

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6 million for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $171 million for the quarter and $178 million for the year. The company said the latest year net includes a $148 million gain from restructuring of its retirement plan and a $144 million gain from the sale of assets. The year also includes a $62 million charge related to the company's employees separation program, a $53 million writeoff of suspended wells and a $59 million writedown of oil and gas reserves. The prior year net includes a gain of $147 million from asset sales.

title: US TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects the adoption of FASB 87, which reduced pension costs by $1.3 million, or 1 cents a share, for the quarter and by $5.1 million, or 4 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes a capital gain of $3.3 million from the sale of broadcasting operations for the quarter, and the year includes a pre-tax provision of $3.3 million for plant closing. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 31, 1986.

title: L.I.R.R. RETURNS TO LIFE AMID THE ICE AND SNOW
description: Seven hundred miles of track and 375 miles of third rail must be cleared of snow and ice; 1,450 switches must be inspected.

title: AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a restatement in the third quarter from a change in accounting rules for recognition of investment tax credits. The company said net income for 1986 was lower than 1985 due to rate competition, which adversely affected 1986 first half results, and an effective tax-rate increase to 57 percent in 1986 from 25 percent in 1985.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIRST NORTHERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which retroactively eliminated the investment tax credit, negatively affected net income by about 10 cents a share in the fourth quarter.

title: CONDOMINIUM ACTIVITY IN EAST HARLEM
description: ''Please don't write about me,'' implored Ji Soo Lee, wrapped up in scarves and layers of flannel in her chilly model apartment this week. ''Write about my building.'' But to understand the building - a former school in East Harlem that she has converted into loft condominiums - it is necessary to learn a few things about Miss Lee.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $35 million and $115 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $14 million for the quarter and $81 million for the year.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (AT&T)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a restructuring charge of $1,095,000,000. For the year, the restructuring charges reduced net by $1.12 billion. The latest quarter and year includes a $409 million charge from the reduction of the value of certain inventory and other assets. A change in accounting for pensions increased net for the latest quarter by $50 million, or 5 cents a share, and increased net for the year by $416 million, or 39 cents a share. The company said that in 1986 it changed from group to unit depreciation accounting for certain factory and laboratory equipment. It was also said that the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in depreciation method reduced net income by $175 million in the latest year. The company said the latest year results included previously announced pre-tax charges of $3.2 billion, which reduced net earnings by $1.59 a share. The latest year net earnings reduction consisted of a 38 cents a share charge for reducing the value of assets and inventory, which resulted in an earnings base of about $1.434 billion, or $1.26 a share. The company said the remaining reduction, $1.21 a share, consisted of special charges for business restructuring and an accounting change that increased depreciation reserves.

title: PITTSTON COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,857,000 for the latest quarter and $6,683,000 for the year-ago period.

title: TRADE PACT IS SET WITH EUROPEANS
description: The United States and the European Community reached an accord today resolving a major trade conflict over American grain exports to Spain.

title: SENATE REJECTS RAISES, BUT THEY SEEM INEVITABLE
description: The Senate voted tonight to block the pay increases President Reagan proposed for members of Congress, Federal judges and high-level officials in the executive branch. But because the House of Representatives does not plan to vote on the question, the raises are virtually certain to take effect at 12:01 A.M. next Wednesday.

title: The Right Reagan Script
description: The President had two scripts for his State of the Union Message Tuesday night - and delivered the wrong one. The speech he delivered in person billowed with stale wind. His written message crackles with energy, spelling out how to rebuild America's competitive pre-eminence.

title: PACER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $225,000 and $397,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $90,000. The company said it has nearly $5 million of tax credits remaining that are available to offset future income tax liabilities and that under the new federal tax code, it will be able to continue benefiting from these tax credits.

title: Diplomat Dole, Candidate Dole
description: Politicians are entitled to a certain quota of cynicism. Senator Bob Dole exceeded his by denouncing Secretary of State George Shultz's meeting with Oliver Tambo, the head of the African National Congress. Mr. Dole, a probable candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, was perhaps less concerned with terrorism, as he claimed, than with currying favor with his party's right wing.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $23,000 for the quarter and $158,000 for the year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about tighter standards for hospital emergency rooms in New York City erroneously described staffing at some emergency rooms and the status of residency programs in emergency medicine. The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation says that every municipal hospital, not just Bellevue, has an attending physician in the emergency room 24 hours a day. Among others with such staffing are New York Infirmary-Downtown Hospital, Beth Israel Medical Center, St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center. Among those besides Bronx Municipal Hospital with the residency program are Lincoln and Metropolitan Hospitals and Long Island Jewish.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was, for once, acceptable to stay home for an evening or two this week, as New York's supersonic party schedule slowed to a crawl in the days between the Super Bowl and Chinese New Year. As Anne Slater put it, ''This is one of the all-time dumb weeks.'' But, with reflection, she changed her mind. ''Actually there is joy in a week with no tickets to anything, no obligations,'' she said. ''You can stay home and read a book or make pepper jelly.''

title: Special Summer Camps
description: For parents who want to get a jump on summer-camp possibilities for youngsters with special needs, the third Special Camp Fair will be held on Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street. Representatives from 100 summer camps will be on hand to provide information about sleep-away and day camps that specialize in programs for children with physical or learning disabilities. A cartoon show will entertain youngsters as parents talk with camp personnel; there will also be Spanish translators and an interpreter for the deaf. The fair, which is free, is sponsored by Resources for Children With Special Needs. Information: 677-4650.

title: KOOKABURRA CREW TAKES THE EARLY LEAD IN GAMEMANSHIP
description: Part of winning an America's Cup race is learning to beat your opponent both on the water and off. Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes team and Iain Murray's Kookaburra III crew have shown they are experts in both places.

title: DISCLOSURE CASE
description: Congressional supporters of Michael E. Pillsbury, who was dismissed last year from his Defense Department job on the ground that he gave secret information to a newspaper, say they are heartened by developments in his case and hope to see him reinstated soon to his old post.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from an asset writedown of $229,070,000 and including a gain of $26,371,000 from the settlement of a claim against a foreign government. c-Net income.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly described regulatory action concerning the Progressive Savings and Loan Association of Alhambra, Calif. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board may withdraw its conditional approval for Greenfield Partners to take over the thrift institution, which is operating under a supervisory agreement with the bank board, but the agency has not yet done so.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL HOLDNG reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Walt Disney to Sell Assets of Arvida
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had agreed to sell the real estate assets of its Arvida community development subsidiary for $400 million in cash and notes.

title: ALLTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a non-recurring writeoff of $16.5 million from the company's investment in the Argo Group Inc. and a $7 million non-recurring writedown of the company's investment in Telecom Plus International Inc. for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $7 million for the quarter and $83.1 million for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary loss of $4,700,000. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $6.3 million and $24.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the June 1986 merger with Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., and that merger was accounted for as a pooling-of-interest, as a result, the company noted that the fourth-quarter comparison was aided by Key having reported a net loss of $9.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: KMW SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago net income and share earnings have been restated to reflect adoption of FASB Rule 86. Prior year shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid Sept. 21, 1986.

title: Canadian-British Talks
description: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, met today with the Canadian External Affairs Minister, Joe Clark, for talks on trade and transatlantic air service, East-West relations, arms control, international cooperation against terrorism and developments in South Africa, a spokesman for the Foreign Office said. Mr. Clark is to leave Britain Friday for Bangladesh and India.

title: Market Place; Xerox May Be 'Nifty' Again
description: MANY people regard the copier machine as synonymous with the Xerox Corporation, one of Wall Street's favorite ''Nifty Fifty'' stocks in the early 1970's.

title: THE RESISTANCE TO GORBACHEV
description: After 22 months in which his campaign for ''reconstruction'' appears to have gained considerable support, Mikhail S. Gorbachev this week started a fresh drive to overcome inertia in the Communist Party itself. But in promising to shake up the party, the repository of real power, he moved into an area that has frustrated reform-minded leaders in the past.

title: MOSLEM PARLEY ENDS WITHOUT RESOLVING DISPUTES
description: The leaders of the Moslem world wound up talks here today without resolving the issues dividing them, notably the Iran-Iraq war.

title: REAGAN'S CUTS IN ANTI-DRUG EFFORT BRING OUTBURST AT SENATE HEARING
description: In an unusual display of frustration an abandonment of decorum, two Senators shouted down a Reagan Administration spokesman today at a hearing and attacked proposed cuts in anti-narcotics programs with such phrases as nonsense, drivel and totally dishonest.

title: THIRD SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN FIRE THAT KILLED 96 IN SAN JUAN HOTEL
description: A third worker at the Dupont Plaza Hotel was arrested today on charges of murder and arson in the New Year's Eve fire there in which 96 people died.

title: Shamrock Ruling
description: A Federal judge rejected a request by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation to block a $300 million stock tender offer by a group headed by T. Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman. Federal District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer said he would not grant a preliminary injunction because the Pickens group had not violated Federal securities laws. The group's offer is for nearly 23 percent of the company's shares.

title: GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC OF THE YORUBA IN 2 CONCERTS
description: THE Yoruba orisha Oya can summon whirlwinds; Yemanja, another orisha, controls all the energy and riches of the ocean. Like the other orishas - deities who symbolize forces of nature and human attributes in the Yoruba cosmogony - they also have their own rhythms, chants and dances. Those rhythms, which were brought to the New World by slaves from West Africa, supply a heartbeat and a dance beat for all sorts of African-American and Latin American music.

title: SALINGER BIOGRAPHY IS BLOCKED
description: A biography of J. D. Salinger was blocked yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan that said the book unfairly used Mr. Salinger's unpublished letters.

title: INQUIRY INTO L.I. POLICE IS ASSAILED BY OFFICIALS
description: The State Commission of Investigation, in the second day of a public inquiry into the Suffolk County Police Department, today questioned department procedures and drew angry reactions from police officials and a roomful of detectives.

title: IRISH POLITICIAN TRIES FOR 3D COMEBACK
description: Charles J. Haughey, the frayed but durable ''Boss'' of Irish politics who descends on precincts in his bright green helicopter, today began his campaign to become Prime Minister a third time.

title: JOHN HURT STARS IN 'THE STORYTELLER'
description: WHAT makes ''Hans My Hedgehog'' such a treat is the writing. Not that there's anything the matter with the pictures in this tale from ''The Storyteller,'' the NBC ''Family Special'' that graces Channel 4 at 8:30 tomorrow night - but we've come to expect visual virtuosity on television, and when a show arrives under the auspices of Jim Henson, we can be pretty sure we won't be disappointed.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $10,909,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 15, 1987, in which one Class B common share was issued for each Class A common share outstanding. The 1985 share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 split paid March 1985.

title: Wind and Thunder
description: The group Wind and Thunder, featuring Bill Cole on non-Western reed instruments and Julius Hemphill on saxophones, will perform ''Yoruba Proverbs'' Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Says Kiev Is Safe For Visits by Tourists
description: The United States said today that it was safe for Americans to visit Kiev, a city close to the site of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster last April.

title: NEWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it had no cash earnings for all of 1986 because of an accounting rule, used only for utilities, which allows utilities to treat plant construction costs as income on the premise costs will be recouped through rate increases. Without this accounting technique, the company said they would have reported a net loss for 1986.

title: MODULAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BAKER POSTPONES AND PONDERS ON HIS CANDIDACY
description: From his law office in the Willard, one of the city's most prestigious addresses, just two blocks from the White House, Howard H. Baker Jr. has a splendid view of Pennsylvania Avenue, the route of Presidential inaugural parades. Mr. Baker is still trying to decide whether he would rather be leading that parade in 1988 or watching it from his eighth-floor window.

title: Refunds for Tickets Are to Be Prorated
description: Long Island Rail Road commuters holding weekly or monthly tickets will receive refunds or credit on a prorated basis for the days they could not travel during the strike, a railroad spokesman said yesterday.

title: DR. OTTO NATHAN, AN ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Otto Nathan, an economist who served as executor and co-trustee of the estate of Albert Einstein, died of heart failure Tuesday at Van Etten Hospital in the Bronx. He was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A SWIRL OF CELEBRATIONS SWEEPS INTO CHINATOWN
description: FOR the rest of New York, winter, with snowy white trimmings, is still the order of the day, but in Chinatown, resplendent in rich reds and golds, it is the first weekend of the Spring Festival. Yesterday, the festival - which is the name for this celebratory season of the Chinese New Year - reached a climax with the customary frenzied Chinatown greeting of the first day of the year, but that is not the end of this joyous event.

title: Concert: Kurt Masur With Gutierrez at Piano
description: IT would be difficult to name two composers more dissimilar in temperament and taste than Hindemith and Chopin, who found themselves oddly coupled on last evening's New York Philharmonic program. Kurt Masur, the guest conductor, began with Hindemith's Concert Music for Strings and Brass, one of those works that reflect with startling accuracy the German composer's personality. Anyone who knew him or saw him perform would recognize him clearly in this 1930 piece, a ruddy, vigorous and technically admirable but rather mechanical showpiece. Mr. Masur and the Philharmonic made the most of this lustily sonorous score's good points and made the others tolerable.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BILL PLANNED FOR HOSPITAL STAYS FOR OLD, BUT NOT NURSING HOME CARE
description: Key members of the House of Representatives said today that the 100th Congress would probably establish a new Federal program to help elderly people pay for unusually long hospital stays but not for care in nursing homes.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dr. Joseph R. Wilder, director of surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, is among four former players who will be inducted into the Lacrosse Hall of Fame in Baltimore tonight. Dr. Wilder, a star at Dartmouth from 1940-42, will be enshrined with Major Peter B. Cramblet, a former star at West Point; Joseph Corcoran, formerly of Ithaca, and Tom Postel, formerly of C. W. Post. . . . The Los Angeles Clippers have traded Kurt Nimphius, a forward-center, to the Detroit Pistons in exchange for selections in the first and second rounds in this year's National Basketball Association draft.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SEURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets at Dec. 31, 1986.

title: A Bullish Start
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, who is leading the National Basketball Association in scoring with 36.9 points a game so far this season, has tallied 4,233 points for an average of 30.0 during 141 games in his first two and a half seasons as a pro. He was limited to 18 games last season because of a broken bone in his foot. Until now, only three players who eventually totaled at least 400 games and 10,000 points in their N.B.A. careers completed their first three seasons with a higher average. The N.B.A.'s top 10 in career average and their averages after three seasons:

title: AQUINO ANNOUNCES THE MUTINEERS WILL BE 'HELD TO FULLEST ACCOUNT'
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the two-day occupation of a television station by dissident soldiers had been part of an attempt to overthrow the Government and that those involved would be ''held to the fullest account.''

title: Archives Sets a Date To Open Nixon Files
description: The National Archives will give notice Friday that it intends to open for public viewing the most sensitive of all the papers seized from President Nixon when he resigned office.

title: HORIZON FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss is after a loss of $221,530 from the sale of unconsolidated subsidiaries. c-After a loss of $678,524 from the sale of unconsolidated subsidiaries. The company did not give share data because they went public in November 1986; at Dec. 31, 1986 the company had 1,610,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

title: LABARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $123,620 and an extraordinary gain from the exchange of debentures of $2,016,904 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,450,697 for the quarter and $3,517,309 for the 6 months.

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 30, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Population Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Rates Close Little Changed
description: Interest rates ended little changed yesterday in a quiet but nervous bond market that continued to take its cue from trends in the currency market and prospects for America's trade balance.

title: ITT Names a President For Its Automotive Unit
description: The ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it had named Ralph E. Reins president and chief executive of ITT Automotive Inc., under which it is consolidating all of its automotive products units worldwide.

title: Maine Utility
description: The Central Maine Power Company said it would write off $17.2 million of its investment in the Millstone Three nuclear power plant in Connecticut. The company said that after taxes the write-off would amount to $11 million, or 48 cents a share on 1986 earnings. Last July, Central Maine and state regulators in Maine agreed to a rate order that did not permit recovery of 15 percent of the company's total Millstone Three investment of $114.9 million, the company said.

title: SHULTZ ASSERTS IRANIANS HAD 'STRONG TIES' TO KIDNAPPERS ELAINE SCIOLINO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Iran had ''very strong ties'' to a group that has taken responsibility for kidnapping three American teachers in Beirut last week.

title: DUKE LOSES, 75-66, TO GEORGIA TECH
description: Bruce Dalrymple scored 25 points, including eight free throws in the final 1 minute 7 seconds, as Georgia Tech beat Duke, 75-66, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: BIRTHDAY CELEBRATIONS HONOR FRANZ SCHUBERT
description: One hardly needs an excuse to celebrate Franz Schubert, but since the composer would have been 190 years old tomorrow, this seems as good a time as any for a party. And that's just what's in store tomorrow at the Symphony Space, which will commemorate the birthday with a 12-hour free concert entitled ''Wall-to-Wall Schubert,'' scheduled to last from 11 in the morning until 11 at night.

title: Youth, 15, Sentenced In Shooting of Officer
description: Shavod Jones, 15 years old, convicted of shooting Officer Steven McDonald in Central Park last July 12, was sentenced yesterday to three and one-third to ten years in prison.

title: WHEATON TO ADMIT MEN IN '88
description: Wheaton College, one fo the nation's earliest schools for women, announced today that it would start admitting men as undergraduates in the fall of 1988.

title: New York's Tax Burdens May Drive People Out
description: LEAD: Have you ever thought of leaving New York for Connecticut or New Jersey? With the new Federal tax, more and more people may be thinking the same thing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Caldwell Takes One-Shot Lead: Rex Caldwell, who qualified on a sponsor's exemption, shot a 5-under-par 67 and took one-shot lead yesterday after the first round of the $600,000 A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. At 68, four under par, were a former British Open champion, Sandy Lyle of Scotland; Lanny Wadkins, Tom Byrum and John Adams. Caldwell, who lost his place on the all-exempt PGA Tour when he finished 149th on the 1986 money-winning list, kept his card clear of bogeys with a couple of 10-foot par-saving putts on the 16th and 17th holes at Pebble Beach, one of three Monterey Peninsula courses used for the first three rounds of the tournament. Tom Watson, twice a winner of the event, had a 69 in the chilly, breezy weather at Cypress Point.(AP) Alcott Leads by a Stroke: Amy Alcott, putting the final touches on a five-under-par 67, birdied the last two holes at Boca Raton, Fla., to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $200,000 Mazda Classic on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour. Alcott, who has earned more than $1.8 million during her career, sank putts of 20 feet on the eighth and ninth holes to finish the opening day of the tour's 38th season with seven birdies and two bogeys. Becky Pearson, an eighth-year pro who more than doubled any of her previous year's earnings in 1986 when she won $155,244, shot a 68. Betsy King and Lauri Peterson trailed Alcott by three shots.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 102, Hawks 91: Craig Ehlo scored a career-high 26 points and Ron Harper also had 26 last night as Cleveland, playing at home, used a 29-11 third-quarter surge to beat Atlanta. Cleveland, which has won just 3 of its last 11 games, held Atlanta scoreless for the first five minutes of the third quarter to expand a 52-45 halftime lead to 60-45 with 6 minutes 10 seconds left in the period. After two baskets, Atlanta was shut out for four minutes as Cleveland went up by 81-54 late in the period. (AP) Pistons 112, Bullets 101: At Pontiac, Mich., Adrian Dantley, hitting his first 7 shots, scored 15 of his 25 points in the first quarter to lead Detroit. Dantley, finding success with the set shot, hit from 5 feet, 19 feet and twice from 17 feet during his first-quarter surge, which gave the Pistons a 31-26 lead they never relinqished. The victory snapped a three-game losing streak for Detroit. (AP) N.H.L. Whalers 6, Bruins 3: Sylvain Turgeon and Stuart Gavin each scored two goals, including one each in the third period last night, in Boston. The victory put the Whalers in first place in the Adams Division of the National Hockey League, a point ahead of the idle Montreal Canadiens. The loss snapped a Bruins' six-game winning streak. Hartford led, 3-2, entering the third period when Boston's Jay Miller tied the score with his first goal of the season at 4:03. Turgeon scored the game winner with four minutes left when he tapped in a rebound of Gavin's slap shot past the Boston goalie, Bill Ranford.(AP) Flyers 5, Penguins 3: Murray Craven had two goals and an assist in the final period to lift the Flyers to a victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in Philadelphia. Dave Poulin scored the winning goal from inside the left circle at the 11-minute mark of the third period on a pass from Craven and gave the Flyers a 4-3 lead. Their final goal came with 21 seconds left by Rick Tocchet into an open net after the Penguins pulled the goalie, Steve Guenette, who was making his first N.H.L. start.(AP) Horse Racing Long Shot Clicks at Aqueduct: Gallic War was up in the final stride to beat favored Rolling By by a neck in the $27,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. It was another head to Switch in Time. Gallic War, an outsider in the field of seven, carried 117 pounds under Ruben Hernandez six furlongs in 1:10 3/5 on the fast track to record his third victory in 17 career starts. Gallic War returned $41.40 for $2 to win.

title: MINNTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $138,000 for the quarter and $210,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $126,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: AFTER YEARS OF COSTLY EFFORTS, THE RACE IS FINALLY ON
description: The 1987 America's Cup series will finally begin here Saturday afternoon with the first race of the four-of-seven-race match between Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes and Iain Murray's Kookaburra III.

title: Advertising; A Smiling Sheraton Campaign
description: ALTHOUGH a couple of TV commercials for Sheraton hotels from the first pool created by Della Femina, Travisano & Partners have begun to trickle onto the networks, the real outpouring will not start until Sunday, Feb. 8, during the National Basketball Association All-Star game on CBS-TV.

title: ESPOSITO ADDING STABILITY
description: When he used to appear behind the bench, it was as Uncle Phil, laughing, grabbing his players by their necks, cheering them on. He would win and then he would disappear for a while. ''When Phil Esposito is around,'' said Pierre Larouche recently, ''everything is light and happy.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A NEW OPERA Over the centuries, the twists and turns of love have been a favorite subject of opera singers. This weekend will be no exception when ''All's Well That Ends Well'' is performed as a two-act opera at the Marymount Manhattan Theater under the auspices of Dell'Arte Inc., an arts organization. The world premiere of the English-language opera, based on Shakespeare's play and with music by David Winkler, was conceived and directed by David Pfeiffer. It will be performed by a 25-member cast and 27-member orchestra under the baton of Constantine Kitsopoulos. The singers include the soprano Leira Satlof, the baritone Don Richardson and the tenor Thomas Tomasiewicz. Performances at the theater, at 221 East 71st Street, are tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday night at 7. Tickets are $10. Information: 279-4200. ELECTRONIC TAP

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK NY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $6,193,000 and $21,711,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,047,000 for quarter and $5,013,000 for year. The company said there are no 1985 share earnings because the bank converted to stock form in November 1985.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said that it had signed a contract with China to supply about $100 million worth of aircraft engines. The order for 16 PW-4000 engines to be used in commercial Boeing 767's is part of a continuing program with China, which the company said was one of its biggest customers.

title: PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,375,000.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Morgana King, the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Morgana King's humming coloratura and highly ornamental style of pop-jazz embellishment have changed little over three decades. Her pitch, rhythmic precision and near-supersonic upper register remain as secure as ever, and her highly stylized delivery of pop standards suggests someone confiding an obsessive romantic daydream. In her current Blue Note engagement, Ms. Morgan is appearing on a double feature with the Buddy DeFranco-Terry Gibbs Quintet. Mr. DeFranco, a clarinetist, and Mr. Gibbs, a vibraphonist, smoothly bridge swing and be-bop. Show times are 9 and 11:30, tonight through Sunday. At tables there is a $15 music charge and a $5 minimum, and there is a $7.50 music charge at the bar.

title: Khashoggi Company Seeks Court's Shelter
description: The Triad America Corporation, the cornerstone of Adnan M. Khashoggi's business empire in this country, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: AIDS MAY DWARF THE PLAGUE
description: A worldwide AIDS epidemic will become so serious that it will dwarf such earlier medical disasters as the Black Plague, smallpox and typhoid, the nation's top health official said today.

title: FILM: WOODY ALLEN'S FOND REMEMBRANCES OF 'RADIO DAYS'
description: RADIOS once came in two basic models of wooden cabinets. The table-top, sheathed in oak or mahogany veneer, looked like a small, peak-roofed sentry box, with Romanesque or Gothic arches in front of the sometimes gold-flecked fabric masking the speaker.

title: FRANCIS BELLO
description: Francis Bello, a retired associate editor of Scientific American magazine, died of leukemia Tuesday at the Stanford Medical Center in Stanford, Calif. He was 69 years old and lived in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: The Met's Extra Room
description: Somewhere in New York City there lives someone who has never longed for an extra room. This person has never wanted to house a guest; or store the butterfly chair and amoeba-shaped coffee table until they come back in style; or have a place for a sewing machine, or a miniature railroad. This person, then, will not be able to see the Metropolitan Museum's new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for what it really is: the quintessential extra room.

title: Gregg Smith Singers
description: The Gregg Smith Singers and the Ensemble Josquin Des Pres will present a program of French and American music for chorus and wind ensemble at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street, tomorrow night at 8:30. The program includes ''An Acadian Mass'' by Charles Reynolds, and works by Dan Locklair, Ralph Swickard and Mr. Smith. Tickets are $12; information: 874-2990.

title: EXECUTIVE AT INTEL PROMOTED TO CHIEF
description: The Intel Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer chips, announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Andrew S. Grove, will become chief executive at the next shareholders meeting in April. Dr. Grove, a Hungarian immigrant and author of a popular book on management, will inherit the mantle from Gordon E. Moore, a co-founder of the company and chief executive since 1975.

title: Depleted Islanders
description: The Islanders traveled to Washington for tonight's game against the Capitals with neither their best scorer, Mike Bossy, nor half of their goaltending team, Kelly Hrudey. Bossy, who will miss his sixth and seventh consecutive games this weekend because of a strained back, may return next week when the team travels to western Canada for three games. Various tests and doctors have found no damage to his back, which has bothered him since September, and Islander management has left it up to Bossy to decide when he feels fit enough to contribute. Hrudey injured his leg in a collision with a Detroit player last Wednesday, and because the swelling and soreness has persisted, he was X-rayed yesterday afternoon to rule out the possibility of a stress fracture. The test results were not immediately known. Hrudey has been replaced by Roydon Gunn, who will serve indefinitely as backup to Billy Smith.

title: Garland and Minnelli Share Screen at Filmfest
description: Judy Garland and Liza Minnelli will share the silver screen during a five-week retrospective beginning Sunday at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street. A double bill of ''The Wizard of Oz'' and ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' will get the series under way Sunday, with screenings beginning at noon. Other Garland films to be shown during the festival include ''Thoroughbreds Don't Cry,'' ''Love Finds Andy Hardy,'' ''The Harvey Girls,'' ''Judgment at Nuremberg,'' ''Babes on Broadway,'' ''For Me and My Gal,'' ''Strike Up the Band'' and ''A Star Is Born.''

title: Charles F. Wolcott, 80, Disney Film Composer
description: Charles Fredrick Wolcott, a music composer and arranger who worked with Walt Disney Studios and is credited with bringing rock-and-roll to the screen, died Wednesday. He was 80 years old.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and year results include a $1,223,000 writeoff of its unsuccessful effort to convert to a limited partnership.

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $140,000 for the quarter and $107,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $3,266,000 attributable to the receipt of life insurance proceeds on Paul A.Johnston, who died Sept.18, 1985, net of provision for retirement and related settlements and applicable income tax benefits.

title: Tax-Exempt Offering For a Utility in Illinois
description: A $150 million tax-exempt financing by the Illinois Development Finance Authority on behalf of the Illinois Power Company was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: SENATORS SEEK TO MAKE ARMS TREATY BINDING
description: Four Senators introduced legislation today that would compel the United States to stay within the limits of the strategic arms treaty of 1979.

title: KEY SECTIONS FROM SENATE SELECT PANEL ON IRAN ARMS AFFAIR
description: Following are key sections of a report on the Iran-contra case made public today by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. Report on Preliminary Inquiry

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: Net Income Percent Oct.-Dec. Change 1986 From '85 American Tel. & Tel. $ (1,170,000,000) - Bell Atlantic Corp. 271,900,000 +0.8 Consolidated Rail Corp. 119,000,000 +6.3 Control Data Corp. (226,200,000) - Dow Chemical Co. 168,000,000 *- Phillips Petroleum Co. 11,000,000 -88.4 Trans World Airlines Inc. 85,000,000 *- Xerox Corp. 87,000,000 -44.2 See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Diner's Journal
description: THE early bird catches the worm - and a free bottle of champagne, too - at Prunelle, the graceful French restaurant at 18 East 54th Street. Guests who dine between 5:30 and 7 P.M. can choose from a half-dozen champagnes in the $40 range, including Laurent-Perrier, Mumm Extra Dry and Piper-Heidsieck, or, if desired, a bottle of wine costing up to $30. Jacky Ruette, one of the owners, says the promotion will last indefinitely.

title: NACCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,160,000 for the quarter and year.

title: FILM: MIDLER AND LONG IN 'OUTRAGEIOUS FORTUNE'
description: IF Redford and Newman were chasing their man and had tracked him to a little shack somewhere, would they stop to check their makeup before breaking down the door? Probably not - and certainly not with the delicious aplomb shown by Shelley Long and Bette Midler in ''Outrageous Fortune,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters. Since ''Outrageous Fortune'' is a buddy film starring two women, and since it is sure to be a hit, it will undoubtedly prompt speculation that two-women buddy films are now the genre to beat. Maybe so - but that's not why this one works. It works because Miss Midler and Miss Long are hilarious, both separately and together.

title: IN 'FREO,' CAMELS BUT NO WORRIES
description: G'day, mate. Bet you haven't heard the camel story. Not the kangaroo or the koala story, but the camel story. About the four visitors to the America's Cup races who went camel-riding in the desert north of here. If you stop to rest, they were told by the camels' owner, the camels will lay down, but just say ''Y'up'' and the camels will get up. When they stopped, sure enough, the camels lay down. As the visitors were chatting a few minutes later, one happened to mention the America's ''Cup.'' And the camels got up. Apparently even the camels out here in ''Freo'' in Western Australia on the Indian Ocean are up for the America's Cup final between Stars & Stripes, the American challenger skippered by Dennis Conner, and Kookaburra III, the Australian defender. The four-of-seven-race series starts tomorrow. Or tonight, New York time. Or is it yesterday?

title: CONSUMER SPURT LIFTS DURABLE GOODS
description: Civilian orders for durable goods rose 6.9 percent in December, although orders for all durable goods, including military projects, rose only nine-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATE VOTES $50 MILLION IN AID FOR THE HOMELESS
description: The Senate tonight approved $50 million in emergency aid to the homeless. The vote was 77 to 6.

title: Masco Industries
description: Masco Industries, a manufacturer of oilfield and industrial products, is offering $175 million of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 at a price of 100. The offering is being made through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $36 a share; the stock closed yesterday at $28 in over-the-counter trading. Underwriters said the debentures, which are noncallable for two years, are rated Ba-1 by Moody's and BB- by S.& P.

title: USX Price Rise
description: The USX Corporation said that it would increase prices of certain carbon and high-strength, low-alloy plate steel. USX said customers with special needs involving quantity or dimensions would face increases of $10 to $15 a ton, beginning April 5. USX said its base price for such steel remains unchanged at $380 a ton.

title: Maj. Gen. Hugh M. Milton 2d, Army Aide Under Eisenhower
description: Maj. Gen. Hugh M. Milton 2d, a former Under Secretary of the Army,died Tuesday at William Beaumont Army Medical Center in El Paso, Tex. He was 89 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the conviction of Richard L. Rubin, the former executive secretary of the Queens Democratic organization, misstated the sentence he could face.

title: Strawberry Faces Suit
description: The wife of Darryl Strawberry filed a petition for a legal separation yesterday in Los Angeles Superior Court, accusing the Mets' outfielder of violent behavior last month and breaking her nose after a playoff game last October. Lisa Strawberry also obtained a court order forbidding her husband from coming within 100 yards of her mother's home in Altadena, a suburb of Los Angeles, where she is staying. In her petition filed by Marvin Mitchelson, an attorney, Mrs. Strawberry cites irreconcilable differences as the reason for the separation after two years of marriage, and seeks sole legal and physical custody of their 19-month-old son, who lives with her. She also seeks child and spousal support. Jay Horwitz, the Mets' public relations director, said the club was aware of the suit and had spoken to Strawberry, who was reported to be ''sad and distraught.'' Strawberry said he would have no comment at this time and denied the allegations in the suit.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Control Data Reports Loss
description: The Control Data Corporation, a worldwide supplier of computer services and products, today reported losses of $226.2 million for the fourth quarter and $264.5 million for all of 1986 because of operating losses and restructuring charges.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year results include a pre-tax gain of $200.4 million on the sale of Technical Publishing Co. and a pre- tax expense of $251.1 million for other restructuring actions.

title: FILM: 'MALANDRO,' ON RIO
description: ''Opera do Malandro'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival under the title ''Malandro.'' Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 27, 1986. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: SUCCESSOR FOR SPEAKES
description: With the appointment of Marlin Fitzwater as the next chief White House spokesman, a search is under way for a successor to Mr. Fitzwater in his old post as Vice President Bush's press secretary. Tom C. Griscom, who served as press secretary to Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Senate Republican leader, was sounded out for the Bush job but did not express any interest.

title: FILM: EUSTACHE'S 'PETITES AMOUREUSES'
description: IN many ways ''Mes Petites Amoureuses,'' Jean Eustache's 1974 French film opening today at the Public, looks as if it had been meant to answer anyone who'd been less than enchanted by the director's ''Mother and the Whore,'' one of the more antagonizing films presented at the 1973 New York Film Festival.

title: SAMUEL G. FUQUA
description: Samuel G. Fuqua, who received in the Medal of Honor for heroism at Pearl Harbor and whose story of that day helped build the U.S.S. Arizona Memorial there, died Tuesday. He was 87 years old. Mr. Fuqua, who retired from the Navy in 1953, was a lieutenant commander aboard the battleship Arizona when Japan's planes attacked on Dec. 7, 1941. He was knocked unconscious in the bombardment but recovered and directed rescue operations.

Seat-Belt Defense Wins Case
description: A motorist who argued he was not guilty of negligent homicide in the deaths of two crash victims because they were not wearing seat belts was acquitted Wednesday. The two people who died in the collision had not been wearing seat belts, in violation of Michigan law, said Jim Fisher, lawyer for the motorist, Jeffrey Smith. ''There's no question he caused the accident,'' Mr. Fisher said. ''Our argument is that death would not have resulted had they been following the law.''

description: President Reagan will appoint Gary L. Bauer, a political conservative who is now Under Secretary of Education, as his chief adviser on domestic policy, Administration officials said today.

title: Too Much Pain Even for a Hero
description: Billy Olson, the pole-vaulter whose last-minute withdrawal from tonight's Wanamaker Millrose Games had been blamed on ''despondency'' over his failure to clear the bar in his first two meets this year, was being portrayed yesterday not as an emotional weakling. He was being portrayed as a hero who had been competing and setting world records while silently suffering from a chronic and debilitating sinus infection that has finally forced him to the sideline.

description: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont today asked three of the five justices on the state's highest court to step down until a complaint of judicial misconduct against them was settled.

title: What's What in the America's Cup
description: Those who follow the early-morning telecasts on ESPN of the America's Cup races will have to listen to a new vocabulary of sailing terms while fighting off sleepiness. Here is a glossary of some of the terms likely to be used. Aft: Toward the back of the boat. Beat: To sail upwind. Bow: The front of the boat. Clear Air: Unobstructed wind; a boat having clear air is not covered by its opponent. Cover: To block your opponent's wind and slow him down. Downwind: To sail with the wind coming from behind. Forward: Toward the front of the boat. Genoa: A large overlapping headsail. Halyard: A rope or wire used to raise a sail. Jibe: To turn so that the wind passes behind the boat. Keel: A heavy, usually lead-filled fin under the boat that provides stability. Leeward: Away from the wind. Luff: Turning into the wind to slow or stop the boat. Mainsail: The large sail aft of the mast. Mark: A buoy used as a turning point on the course. Port: Left. Reach: To sail with the winds coming over the side of the boat. Run: To sail downwind. Sheet: The rope or wire used to pull in or let out a sail. Spinnaker: Large, parachute-like sail set ahead of the mast on a run or a reach. Starboard: Right. Stern: The back of the boat. Tack: To turn so that the wind passes in front of the boat. Upwind: Sailing into the wind. Windward: Toward the wind.

title: FROM NUTS TO SOUP, FOR CHINESE NEW YEAR
description: THE usual animated pace of Chinatown intensifies to a dizzying pace this weekend as the new year is welcomed with spirited toasts and staggering feasts. Some Chinatown restaurants offer special prix-fixe banquets during the holidays; others feature traditional dishes ripe with symbolism: chicken brings good fortune, egg rolls portend the arrival of spring, egg dumplings signify golden ingots, round meatballs connote family togetherness. The most providential food during the Chinese New Year is the rice cake, whose name in Chinese suggests ''going higher and higher'' in health, wealth, happiness and wisdom.

title: The Contras Need Us
description: LEAD: Congress belatedly recognized the strategic and moral importance of aiding the Nicaraguan contras against the Communist Sandinistas last July. The strategic case for aid is that the Sandinista regime is a beachhead for Soviet expansionism on the mainland of the Western Hemisphere and therefore a serious threat to the United States' national security.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Quake in San Francisco Area
description: A mild earthquake struck the San Francisco Bay area today, but no injuries or damages were reported. Preliminary reports measured the earthquake at 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion. Don Finley, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey in the District of Columbia, said the temblor was centered about 12 miles southeast of Oakland and occurred at 5:35 P.M. The earthquake was felt throughout the Bay area, said Clement Randall of the State Office of Emergency Services.

title: Costly Call at Aqueduct
description: Because he had failed to provide workers' compensation insurance for his employees, Gaspar Moschera, a trainer with 41 thoroughbreds racing at Aqueduct, was suspended on Jan. 1 for 30 days by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. The recommendation for suspension had come from the stewards. Moschera was denied access to the premises of any New York state race track, although his horses - owned mainly by Barbara and Albert Davis - continued to race at Aqueduct. But the trainer evidently did not take the terms of his suspension literally and reports filtered back to Aqueduct officials that he had been seen on the grounds. The other day, he answered the telephone at his barn and found himself talking to John P. Joyce, one of the three stewards. Yesterday, 15 additional days were added to Moschera's suspension.

title: Dismember Items
description: What does a cheese museum in upstate New York have in common with a harness racing hall of fame and a double-Dutch jumproping contest? They are among the pet projects of Albany lawmakers that were funded last year out of a shameless legislative extravagance called the ''member items'' budget. Member items are ways of using tax money to buy favors for incumbents. The idea offends responsibility; it warrants abolition in the new Legislature.

title: EPSCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133). If anyone can use the vast, reverberant space within the cathedral to improve their music, it might be the improvising duo of Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos. Mr. Cherry made groundbreaking records in the 1960's as the puckish trumpeter in Ornette Coleman's jazz quartets. Since then, he has delved into world music, listening to Latin, Caribbean, Arabian and African music and adding keyboards and doussn'gouni (African hunter's harp) to his collection of instruments. Mr. Vasconcelos, a Brazilian percussionist, can play anything that shakes, rattles, rings or taps; he and Mr. Cherry are longtime collaborators who bring out each other's humor and willingness to take risks. For this duo, the cathedral's echo should just be one more plaything. Tonight at 8; tickets are $10. Sam Rivers and the Rivbea Orchestra, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). The saxophonist-flutist-pianist-composer Sam Rivers has been an iconoclastic force in new jazz for nearly three decades, working in every style from free-form trio improvisation to short, snappy tunes that are as concise as pop songs. He gets the chance to convene a big band only once every few years, but when he does he attracts some of the city's best players. With reed, brass and rhythm sections at his disposal, Mr. Rivers has written dense, knotty compositions as well as pieces that sound like slightly warped mainstream big-band music. This time, he is likely to have new approaches as well. Tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: PLEA MADE TO KOCH BY JEWS IN HUNGARY FOR HELP FROM U.S.
description: Hungarian Jewish leaders appealed through Mayor Koch today for financial help from American Jews to maintain Jewish life in this country.

title: A.T.&T. REPORTS IT LOST $1.17 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it lost $1.17 billion in the fourth quarter because of a $3.2 billion charge taken to reduce its work force and consolidate operations.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESTORS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Wooing Parcells
description: The Atlanta Falcons, still searching for a coach after the dismissal of Dan Henning and rejections from Dick Vermeil and Terry Donahue, have sought permission to talk with Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants, according to today's editions of The Atlanta Constitution and The Boston Globe. The Giants denied Atlanta permission, though the Falcons have been in contact with Parcells's attorney, one report said. The Falcons are willing to offer Parcells $900,000 a year to become coach and general manager, another report said, and the Falcons are ready to offer Parcells a five-year contract. Parcells, contacted by The Constitution, said there was no truth to the reports.

title: MEN VS. WOMEN AT THE OFFICE
description: An executive, a woman, entertains a male business client from out of town, taking him to dinner and a show. Although it's a successful night out, his host is certainly not one of the boys, and he realizes that he feels awkward at times about how he should behave during the evening.

title: Mets Invite 6 To Spring Camp
description: The Mets issued the surest sign of seasonal cheer yesterday when they invited six of their farmhands to spring training, which opens when pitchers and catchers report to St. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 20.

title: GIVENCHY IS OPULENT FOR BOTH DAY AND NIGHT
description: After the histrionics of the last few days, the spring and summer couture collections ended on a calming note today. Before an audience that included many American clients who find his traditional approach to fashion soothing, Hubert de Givenchy showed a reassuring collection with two flattering themes. His daytime styles have jackets with nipped waists guaranteed to emphasize curves, and his evening dresses have an opulent festive look.

title: Bowery Breaks With Chargit
description: The Bowery Savings Bank said yesterday that it was severing its relationship with Chargit Inc., the processor of Mastercard and Visa transactions that filed for protection last month under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.

title: STAGE: COLLEEN DEWHURST IN 'MY GENE'
description: LEAD: IN a bare, oppressive room at St. Luke's Hospital in New York in 1968, Carlotta Monterey relives her marriage to Eugene O'Neill. Uncertain whether she is sane or crazy, she addresses an imaginary psychiatrist and her battered toy monkey, Esteban, a gift from her husband a long time ago. Esteban is ''our own little 'Hairy Ape,' '' she says, the ''only child'' she and O'Neill ever had together.

Sam is the acronym for Screen Activated Machines, customer-operated electronic ticket dispensers, nine of which have been installed at Hialeah Park.

title: West German Trade Surplus
description: West Germany's trade surplus grew about 50 percent in 1986, to a record 112 billion marks, equivalent to $62.9 billion, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The total included an unexpectedly large jump in December, to a record $6.46 billion, from November's $5.7 billion.

title: NEWARK BISHOP SEEKING TO BLESS UNWED COUPLES
description: The Episcopal Bishop of Newark, bolstered by a diocesan report, called on the church yesterday to ''open its eyes to reality'' by recognizing and blessing nonmarital relationships, including those between homosexuals.

Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company were awarded a $100 million issue of 8 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2017, which were reoffered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.774 percent, or 1.18 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016.

ART: DUTCH SHOWS AT MORGAN AND MET
description: THE Netherlands is now getting special attention by way of two related museum exhibitions. The one at the Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, is a selection of 16th-century drawings, most of which are making their first appearance in the United States, and it comes with a plump catalogue. A joint effort by the library and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, where it first materialized, the show musters about 120 works, including eight by Pieter Bruegel the Elder (about 1525 to 1569). As it happens, two of the Bruegel works are present in the second display, albeit reversed as engravings. That second exhibition is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and it consists exclusively of the prints that Bruegel habitually made his drawings for. All 65 of them come from the museum's collection, which is billed as the largest in the country.

title: HOLIDAY CORP.
description: The Holiday Corporation said it had received commitments from three banks for $1.23 billion in financing for its previously announced recapitaliztion plan. The company also said it had set Feb. 27 as the date for the special meeting at which stockholders will vote on the plan. Under the plan, Holiday shareholders will receive a $65-a-share dividend and retain ownership of about 90 percent of the company's stock to be outstanding.

description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit slipped 2.3 percent because of the higher costs of producing and developing two lines of airplanes and a higher effective tax rate.
