title: The Martini War, Averted
description: The United States and Europe almost went to war this weekend, a trade war over U.S. grain exports. Now, narrowly, open combat has been avoided - to the immense relief of consumers and exporters on both sides. But to be truthful about it, this was more like one battle; war danger endures.

Enron's oil and gas exploration and production segment has suffered from reduced prices.

Results for the full year include investment tax credits, available under the transition rules of the act, of about $494,000, or 3 cents a share in 1986, compared with about $2,200,000, or 14 cents a share in 1985.

title: Phillip J. DiNatale, 67, Dies; Led Boston Strangler Inquiry
description: Phillip J. DiNatale, the chief investigator in the Boston Strangler case, died Sunday at the home of a daughter here. He was 67 years old. Mr. DiNatale was a Boston detective in 1963 when he was assigned to head the investigation of the killings of 13 women in the Boston area from 1962 to 1964.

description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa announced in Cape Town today that new elections to the white house of Parliament would be held in May. He set the tone for his campaign with a call for unity ''against the spirit of revolution incited against us from abroad.''

description: A remote-controlled bomb blew up a military bus in the northern city of Zaragoza today, killing 2 people and wounding 41 others, the police said.

title: Gunman Held After Standoff
description: State police officers forced their way into a house where a man armed with a shotgun barricaded himself for more than five hours, subduing the man without injury, the authorities said. The standoff began at around 5 A.M. after the suspect, Andrew Marcaurel, 31 years old, of Plainfield, had a fight with a woman described as his girlfriend, the state police said.

2 Bidding Theories Govern The Use of the Jump Raise
description: There are two schools of thought about the jump raise of partner's major opening. Modern tournament players favor the limit treatment, showing the equivalent of about 11 high-card points and inviting game. This leaves them with a problem with slightly stronger hands and it usually is solved by giving two no-trump or three no-trump a conventional meaning.

title: Devils Beat Canucks, 4-3
description: The Devils built a three-goal lead on scores by Peter McNab, Doug Sulliman and John McLean, then needed a goal by Claude Loiselle five minutes into the third period to hold off Vancouver and defeat the Canucks, 4-3, tonight.

description: The ''I Love New York'' campaign began when many were not in the mood.

title: CHRYSLER WILL PAY $295,000 FINE FOR VIOLATIONS ON INJURY RECORDS
description: In the largest penalty ever imposed for violations of job safety rules, the Chrysler Corporation has agreed to pay a $295,000 fine for failing to keep accurate records about employee injuries, the Labor Department announced today.

title: TWO AILING SOPRANOS ADD UP TO ONE IN PERFORMANCE OF 'LEMENZA DI TITO'
description: Last night the Metropolitan Opera decided that misery loves company. When both the lead soprano for ''La Clemenza di Tito'' and her standby cover singer said they could not perform, the Met thought it over, determined that their agonies were different but complementary, and put the two on stage together.

There was the same parade of modernist pieces (six, in this case) performed by talented student forces ranging from soloists to a conducted octet.

description: In a reversal of startling magnitude, the nation's foreign-trade deficit plunged 44 percent in December, to $10.6 billion, the lowest level since March 1985.

The 1.5-million-square-foot plant builds a variety of car parts, such as foam arm rests, door trim panels and instrument panels. Holiday Corp.

title: Herbert Menzel Dies at 66; N.Y.U. Sociology Professor
description: Herbert Menzel, a sociology professor at New York University, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

Mark Peskanov is to be the violin soloist in Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 378) for violin and piano. Tickets are $8; $5 for students and the elderly. Information and directions: 548-8200.

title: Rally for a Soviet Jew
description: Jewish leaders from around the country will convene in Washington Thursday to increase pressure for the release of the imprisoned Soviet Jew Iosif Begun. Mr. Begun, a leader of the Jewish emigration movement, has been refused permission to leave the Soviet Union since his first application in 1971, and the ''refusenik'' is now imprisoned for the third time.

title: A WAR OF WORDS (LIKE 'MACHISMO')
description: Hidden in the service apartment of a friend's large mansion near here, awaiting his moment to burst back onto the political scene, the rebel air force general spoke bitterly of President Leon Febres Cordero as a ''tyrant'' and ''dictator'' who should resign to forestall ''a civil war'' here.

title: COGHLAN SETS MARK BY TAKING 7TH WANAMAKER MILE
description: Forget the shinbones that kept getting fractured, and forget the dog that bit him five times and helped break his left hand, and forget the diet that almost ruined him. Forget all the bad things that sidelined him so often. Eamonn Coghlan is back. Last night, the 34-year-old Irishman won the most glamorous race of indoor track, the Wanamaker Mile, in the most glamorous of indoor meets, the 80th annual Wanamaker Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden. He won the way he had won so often in the past, with a driving, blasting finish that had the screaming capacity crowd of 18,122 on its feet. Coghlan's time of 3 minutes 55.91 was nothing special for him, but a victory by the most popular miler of this era is always special. Surpassing Cunningham

title: Father Files Claim in Death Of Son Aboard Space Shuttle
description: The father of Gregory Jarvis, a member of the Challenger crew, filed a $5 million claim today against the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the death of his son.

title: O'CONNOR EULOGIZES NUN SLAIN AT SHELTER IN BRONX
description: As snow fell yesterday outside St. Pius V Roman Catholic Church in the South Bronx, the nave was lighted with candles and filled with voices in prayer at a funeral mass for a 65-year-old nun stabbed last Monday.

title: RIVER DISPUTE DIVIDES TICONDEROGA
description: Like many one-company towns, Ticonderoga is not a place where corporate decisions are often debated. When the major employer here, International Paper, sent clouds of acrid smoke drifting from its old mill, residents used to sniff the air unperturbed and proclaim it ''the sweet smell of prosperity.'' For decades, the saying here has been, ''What's good for I.P. must be good for Ticonderoga.''

title: NORTEK-REXHAM
description: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7.8 percent stake in the Rexham Corporation and said it might seek control of the Charlotte, N.C., packaging products concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nortek said it had bought the Rexham shares ''with a view to acquiring a significant equity interest'' in the company, but added that any possible acquisition of the company was ''subject to future developments.'' Between Nov. 26 and Jan. 28, the diversified manufacturer, based in Providence, R.I., bought 172,450 Rexham shares for prices ranging from $31.50 to $34 a share.

title: Bravely, Let Federal Pay Increase
description: Members of Congress will face issues of greater obvious importance this session but probably none requiring such political courage as whether to pay higher salaries to themselves and 2,500 other top Federal officials. These raises are in everyone's best interest.

title: LICENSING PLANNED FOR NEW AIDS DRUG
description: Federal officials say the Government intends to grant an exclusive manufacturing license for an experimental drug to treat AIDS victims to Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. of Nutley, N.J.

description: The hospitalization of Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo chief in Lyons, is not expected to further delay his long-awaited trial, French judicial officials said today.

title: CITES BUDGET GAP
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill aimed at cleaning up the nation's water at a cost of up to $20 billion, but he acknowledged that Congress would override his veto and enact the measure into law next week.

title: HOTEL UNION LEADER ARRESTED AFTER GUN IS FOUND IN LUGGAGE
description: Edward T. Hanley, the general president of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, has been arrested for carrying a stolen gun in his carry-on luggage that was discovered when he tried to board an airplane, the police say.

title: UNITED TO CUT A THIRD OF ITS CORPORATE STAFF
description: United Airlines said today that it would lay off 1,016 employees, or nearly one-third of its corporate staff, beginning next week.

In the third quarter the company recorded $8.5 million (pretax) in costs attributable to the proposed divestiture of the steel and non-residential construction divisions which was turned down by shareholders in August.

description: Several of the works that Pilobolus presented Thursday night at the Joyce Theater were fine examples of the goofy acrobatics for which this company is known.

description: At rush hour Thursday night, in his neighborhood in the South Bronx, Felix Rodriguez boarded the No. 6 train on the Lexington Avenue line and rode to work.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DOWN 1.7%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products in January dropped an average of 1.7 percent, beginning the new year 4 percent below January 1986, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: Esther Greenberg, the wife of former State Senator Samuel L. Greenberg, died Wednesday at Florida Medical Center in Lauderdale Lakes. She was 87 years old and lived in Tamarac, Fla.

title: HARVARD PROFESSOR OF EDUCATION REPORTED MISSING SINCE JAN. 17
description: Lawrence Kohlberg, a professor of education at Harvard whose book on moral development is used by teachers around the world to promote moral reasoning, has been missing since Jan. 17. According to the police in nearby Winthrop, there were fears he may have drowned.

New developments have unfolded at the Bronx Zoo, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, for this latest bloc of Bronxites: eight slender-tailed meerkats.

description: Concerned over a cascade of unauthorized disclosures from closed hearings, the Senate Intelligence Committee recently adopted a rule that no Senator could take his notes from the hearing room. description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett and Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, in a move to play down their differences on AIDS education, today released a joint statement asserting that young people should be taught that sexual ''abstinence is safest.''

TAKEOVER BY SUCHARD
description: The Swiss food company Jacobs Suchard has won a takeover battle with its Swiss rival, Nestle S.A., for control of Belgium's leading chocolate maker, Cote d'Or. The Belgian company's board announced after a long meeting Thursday that it had accepted a takeover bid from Jacobs Suchard in preference to a later offer from Nestle. The Suchard offer values Cote d'Or at about $124 million, well above the $84 million that the public stock price implies. Only about 15 percent of the company's stock is publicly held, with much of the rest controlled by two families that run the company.

Patent 4,639,367 describes the foam as stable and as having a consistency of whipped cream.

title: RIVER AGENCY TRIES TO STOP WATER LEAKS
description: The Delaware River commission said yesterday that it would seek to require all water providers to repair leaks because more than a fourth of the water drawn from the Delaware River for use by consumers in four states is lost through seepage.

title: A'S ACQUIRE CEY
description: The Oakland A's traded Luis Quinones, an infielder, to the Chicago Cubs for the right-handed-hitting Ron Cey, who they said would share the designated hitter's duties with Reggie Jackson, who bats left-handed. Cey played third base the last four seasons for the Cubs after spending 10 years with the Los Angeles Dodgers. He has 312 career home runs and 1,128 runs batted in.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alleghany Corp. has been given approval by the Federal Trade Commission to buy a Los Angeles-based title insurance company from Safeco Corp.

title: Moose in Experiment Dies of an Infection
description: Moose No. 1, who wore a radio collar for a wildlife study, died on Wednesday of a bacterial infection, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation reported today.

title: BEAU GESTE I
description: Alex English of the Denver Nuggets, who was named this week by National Basketball Association coaches to participate in his sixth All-Star Game, has offered to relinquish his place to his teammate Lafayette (Fat) Lever, for the game next Sunday in Seattle. Lever, a 6-foot-3-inch guard, has had nine triple-double games (double figures in scoring, rebounding and assists) this season but was not named by either the fans, who selected the starting West team, or the coaches, who completed the 12-man roster.

QUINN CAN'T COACH UNTIL '90-91 SEASON
description: John Zeigler, the president of the National Hockey League, has banned Pat Quinn, the former Los Angeles Kings coach, from coaching in the N.H.L. until the 1990-91 season, the league said today. Ziegler also fined the Vancouver Canucks and the Kings a total of $440,000, and barred Quinn from all league activities until after the annual N.H.L. meetings in June.

title: Guilt and Mr. Meese
description: Last February the Justice Department's Office of Legal Policy sent a 128-page report to Attorney General Edwin Meese urging him to ask the Supreme Court to overturn its 1966 Miranda v. Arizona decision. That's the famous decision that made confessions inadmissible as evidence unless an accused person has been warned by police of the right to silence and to a lawyer, and waived it.

title: A NUCLEAR TAINT IN MILK SETS OFF GERMAN DISPUTE
description: West German officials were locked in a struggle today over what to do with about 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk, apparently a legacy of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

SEOUL STUDENT'S TORTURE DEATH CHANGES POLITICAL LANDSCAPE
description: In life, all 21 years of it, Park Jong Chul barely had time to make his mark. Death made him a political force. Mr. Park, a linguistics student at Seoul National University, died two weeks ago while being questioned by policemen about the whereabouts of a campus radical leader.

title: Fitting Setting for Fitting Choice
description: The weather at Aqueduct yesterday was reportedly vintage Ozone Park in January: cold, rainy and dreary as the mist crept in from Jamaica Bay. Amid the inclement surroundings, Lady's Secret was named the Horse of the Year for 1986. The verdict was no surprise. It had been widely expected and was ringingly confirmed as the gray daughter of Secretariat received 172 of the 228 votes from racing officials and journalists. Manila was the runner-up with 41 votes, followed by Turkoman with 8, Snow Chief with 4 and Flatterer, the grand old steeplechaser, who got 3 whimsical votes.

title: HONDA PURCHASES A CRAY COMPUTER
description: The Honda Motor Company has bought a supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. for $7 million, the seventh Japanese company to do so. These high-speed computers, capable of extraordinarily complex calculations, have been the focus of trade talks this week between the United States and Japan. Because they are so expensive, even a few sales may help trim Japan's trade surplus with the United States.

description: A woman pleaded not guilty today in connection with the 1965 death of her 3-year-old adopted son, a death that has remained unresolved for more than 21 years. The boy's natural mother persuaded the authorities to reopen the case last year.

description: An altercation over a parking space in the Bronx last night left an accused assailant dead at the scene and an off-duty Transit Authority Police sergeant being treated in the hospital for head wounds, the police reported.

title: Japanese Buy Bond Boats
description: Alan Bond, the Australian business tycoon, announced today that he had sold both of his America's Cup yachts and other syndicate gear to a Japanese group that plans to launch a cup challenge in 1990.

title: LTV POSTS BIG DEFICIT IN QUARTER
description: The LTV Corporation, despite rising profits from its steel operations, said yesterday that it lost $453.4 million in the fourth quarter because of a newly reported $600 million charge related to anticipated creditor lawsuits.

title: DON KING'S ROLE CITED
description: Trevor Berbick, the former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, received at most $700,000 of his $2.1 million purse to fight Mike Tyson, with $1 million of the money going to the promoter Don King and his son, Carl, Nevada boxing regulators say. Half of the $1 million went to pay advances improperly made to Berbick by King, and the other $500,000 went to Carl King as Berbick's manager, members of the Nevada State Athletic Commission said. The other $400,000 was attached by the Internal Revenue Service for back taxes. Berbick was knocked out in the second round of the November fight, losing his title to Tyson.

title: END OF FEDERAL REVENUE SHARING CREATING FINANCIAL CRISES IN MANY CITIES
description: The end of a Federal aid program that provided more than half the money for some municipal budgets has caused a severe financial crisis in small and medium-size cities around the country and is forcing larger cities to make hard choices between cutting services and raising taxes.

title: Wardair-Airbus
description: Wardair International, the Canadian airline, signed a contract worth more than $670 million for 12 European Airbus A310-300 aircraft and spare parts, Airbus Industrie announced. It was the first Canadian order for new aircraft in the Airbus range. Wardair currently operates three second-hand Airbus A300's. Wardair will take delivery of the new aircraft between November 1987 and December 1988. They will be powered by General Electric CF6-80C2 engines.

description: The Kokasai Motor Company, Japan's largest taxicab and livery service, has agreed to acquire the Hyatt Regency Maui hotel for $320 million, a record price for a hotel property, according to the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation, the mortgage banker in the transaction. Sanwa Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, Japan's fifth-largest bank, provided financing. The seller was a partnership sponsored by VMS Realty Partners Inc. of Chicago. The deal is expected to close this spring.

title: HANDLE WITH CARE
description: These are the salad days, and that means the horizontal lunch. It generally comes in a white bag that has to be held carefully, in both hands, so that the salad prepared at one of the city's hundreds of new salad bars won't spill from its plastic container before it gets back to the office. The vertical lunch, well, it's still around town but out of fashion, and it usually comes in a brown bag that can be held almost any which way except upside down.

RESTORING ANGKOR WAT, A VAST, SIX-YEAR JOB
description: Armed with chemical cleaners, preservatives and experience, a team of Indian archeologists has begun restoring Angkor Wat, the vast and ancient capital of Cambodia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Hess Clinches Two Golds: In Crans-Montana, Switzerland, yesterday, Erika Hess of Switzerland clinched her third consecutive gold medal in the combined and record fifth gold over all with a controlled but swift downhill run at the world Alpine championships. The 24-year-old Hess, competing in her fourth world championship, finished third in the downhill and, with her third place in Thursday's slalom portion, retained the title. Sylvia Eder of Austria took the combined silver medal, and Tamara McKinney of the United States won the bronze medal. (AP) Golf Morse Leads by Two Shots: Cathy Morse shot a career-best 66 and came from five strokes off the lead yesterday to take a two-shot advantage over Rosie Jones and Becky Pearson after two rounds of the Mazda Classic. Morse birdied the last three holes on the Stonebridge Golf and Country Club course in Boca Raton, Fla., to finish at six under par in the Ladies Professional Golf Association event. Morse, who equaled a year-old course record, posted a 36-hole total of 138. (AP) Horse Racing Clever Allemont All the Way: Clever Allemont never trailed as Richard Migliore rode him to a 1 3/4-length victory in the $40,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Cutlass Reality closed fast in the middle of the track to be runner-up, four lengths ahead of the winner's entrymate, Sovereign Don. Clever Allemont, who is owned by Eugene V. Klein, went six furlongs on the sloppy track in 1:11 4/5 to earn $24,000 and returned $16.60 for $2 to win. N.B.A. 76ers 121, Bulls 112: In Philadelphia, Charles Barkley scored 40 points and grabbed 21 rebounds as the 76ers won last night despite 49 points by Michael Jordan. The 76ers, in winning their third straight and 11th of the last 15, led by 86-82 after three quarters and pulled away from the Bulls by outscoring them, 10-2, at the start of the final quarter. (AP) Mavericks 133, Bucks 117: Mark Aguirre and Derek Harper each scored 28 points to lead Dallas at home in an record-setting game for 3-point baskets. Dallas made nine 3-point shots and Milwaukee had seven, with the total of 16 surpassing the previous mark of 11 set by Dallas and Portland on Jan. 13, 1985. Harper made five 3-point shots and Craig Hodges of the Bucks had four. Aguirre and John Lucas of the Bucks had two each. (AP) Celtics 100, Pacers 94: Kevin McHale scored 9 of his 31 points in a key third-quarter spurt as Boston rallied from a 14-point deficit to beat Indiana for its sixth consecutive victory. The loss, in Indianapolis, was the Pacers' fifth straight. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres 3, Nordiques 1: In Buffalo last night, Christian Ruuttu, a rookie, scored what proved to be the winning goal and added an assist. Quebec, with 45 points, is 9 points ahead of Buffalo in the race for the fourth and last playoff spot in the Adams Division. Adam Creighton and Mike Ramsey were the other Buffalo goal scorers while Tom Barrasso looked sharp in stopping 35 shots, including 24 in the second period. (AP) College Basketball Yale 81, Penn 80: Paul Maley scored 26 points, including a layup with three seconds left, to give Yale the Ivy League victory last night in Philadelphia. Penn took an 80-79 lead with 12 seconds left on a pair of free throws by Perry Bromwell, but Maley, who made 12 of 13 field-goal attempts, took the ball on the inbounds pass and drove the length of the court to score the game-winner. Penn, 4-9 over all and 1-2 in Ivy League, jumped ahead early in the game and led by as many as 20 points with 1 minute 53 seconds left in the half. Yale (9-7, 3-2) went ahead, 77-74, with 4:08 to play on a 3-point field goal by Peter White. Tyrone Pitts was the leading scorer for Penn with 22 points. (AP) Princeton 93, Brown 77: Joe Scott scored 23 points and Alan Williams added 21 to lead Princeton in a game marred by 53 fouls. Princeton, which extended its home-court winning streak over Brown to 37 games, led by 38-25 at halftime and by as many as 28 points in the second half. Brown committed 29 fouls and Princeton 24. Princeton improved to 9-5 and 2-1 in the league while Brown, the defending Ivy League champion, fell to 7-11 and 2-3. (AP)

title: PRIVATE AMBULANCES: WHEN TO USE THEM
description: They come screeching through the streets, sirens wailing and lights flashing, grim symbols of life-or-death emergencies. New York's best-known ambulances are those operated by the city's Emergency Medical Services, which respond to emergencies and can be summoned by telephoning 911. The city's approximately 125 ambulances answer about 720,000 emergency calls a year.

title: Detroit Crime Rate Declines
description: Detroit's overall crime rated declined 6.4 percent in 1986 from that of 1985, the second consecutive year the rate has declined, police officials said Thursday. Detroit reported 9,540 fewer major crimes last year than in 1985, according to statistics released at a Board of Police Commissioners meeting. Major crime in 1985 decreased by 7.2 percent from that of 1984. Despite the decline, Detroit still has the highest per-capita crime rate for cities above 100,000 population, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An AIDS education that accepts children's sexual activity as inevitable and focuses only on 'safe sex' will be at best ineffectual, at worse itself a cause of serious harm.'' - Secretary of Education William J. Bennett and Surgeon General C. Everett Koop. [ 6:2. ]

title: FILM: 'QUATERMAIN,' STARRING CHAMBERLAIN
description: The credits for ''Allan Quartermain and the Lost City of Gold,'' from the never-bashful Cannon Films, tell us that the film is ''based on H. Rider Haggard's best-selling classic novel.'' That's sweet, but it isn't entirely accurate, since the new film is really based on Steven Spielberg's Indiana Jones sagas. Even the music is as similar as is legally possible. And while this second Quartermain film, in what is rather wishfully intended as a series, hasn't got much to recommend it, it's of minor academic interest. Those who take the Spielberg special effects for granted are sure to learn a lot by watching these same tricks done badly.
